title: SUMMER SEATING
description: The drought makes hailing this summer's weather a shade feckless, yet the days have seldom been crisper or the nights coolor than they have been for the last three months. If there has ever been a summer to walk around New York City, this has been it.

title: Jarvik-7 as An Interim Heart
description: Ever since doctors implanted the first permanent artificial heart into Dr. Barney B. Clark in 1982, medical scientists have been debating the long-term effectiveness of the device. Many critics have said that, because of blood clotting, strokes and other serious complications suffered by patients who received the implants, artificial hearts should be used only on a temporary basis.

title: THE SPIES WHO CAME FROM NEXT DOOR
description: IT is one of the quiet, persistent anxieties of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that its most important European member is also the most penetrated by spies from the Warsaw Pact. Lying on Europe's ideological fault line, the Federal Republic of Germany faces not only the massed divisions of the Soviet Union and its allies; in the midst of its open, pluralist society lurk the agents of a formidable espionage establishment run by Germans who happen to be Communists.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, the review in today's Book Review of Janet Dailey's novel ''The Glory Game'' is incomplete. The review should begin: ''The game of the title is polo, which people do not play for money or great fame but for its own sake. This parallels the attitude of our heroine, the wealthy Luz Kincaid Thomas, for whom her own polo-playing family and children are enough.''

title: TIPS ON MESHING A DIVERSE STAFF
description: 'Power and Influence: Beyond Formal Authority, by John P. Kotter. Free Press, N.Y. 218 pages, $19.95. IN today's typical corporation, most top jobs are closely intertwined with other departments.

title: MARK SWANK ENGAGED TO CYNTHIA WHITMAN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Cutler Whitman 3d of Katonah, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Graham Whitman, to Mark Frederick Swank, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bruce Swank of Rye, N.Y. The wedding is planned for Oct. 5. Miss Whitman, a saleswoman for Kneedler Fauchere, a home furnishings concern in Denver, graduated from the Rippowam Cisqua School, Dana Hall and the University of Vermont.

title: HIGHWAY PATROLS INCREASED
description: STATE police in Connecticut are joining their counterparts in other New England states this holiday weekend in a program to try to curb the number of accidents on interstate highways.

title: JOHN R. MARX IS BETROTHED TO ELIZABETH ANNE MAHER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Maher of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Anne Maher to John R. Marx, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Burt Marx of Highland Park, Ill. An Oct. 13 wedding is planned.

title: TYPHOON KILLS 10 IN SOUTHERN JAPAN
description: A typhoon swept through southwestern Japan with winds of up to 124 m.p.h., leaving 10 people dead and 16 missing, injuring 156 people and sinking a cargo ship and fishing boats, officials said today.

title: GROUPS ANNOUNCE PROGRAMS FOR FALL
description: THE early subscriber gets not only the better seats (usually at discounted prices), but avoids the frustration of looking wistfully at the ''sold out'' sign for those concerts he most wanted to hear. As the new season begins, now is the time to look ahead to some of the series.

title:
ART;

LIVELY EAST END SHOWS
description: Summer is winding down for most people, but for East Hampton art galleries this is the liveliest of times.

title: JAMIE OSMAN PLANS TO WED
description: The engagement of Jamie Lynn Osman to H. Edward Abelson has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Osman of Stamford, Conn., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Abelson of Philadelphia and Lumberville, Pa.

title: PHILADELPHIA STRIKE PUT OFF
description: Nine unions representing more than 4,000 workers at the city's two daily newspapers said they would extend their strike deadline past midnight today, citing progress in talks to replace contracts with The Inquirer and The Daily News that were to expire at midnight. The unions have rejected a pay increase of $18 a week in each of the next three years.

title: ELISABETH WELLACOTT IS WED TO CHRISTIAN ROESCH
description: Elisabeth Ann Wellacott, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Howe Baber Wellacott of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to Christian Legare Roesch, the son of Alberta Legare Roesch and the late Kurt Ferdinand Roesch of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Douglass Ray, associate rector of St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Coyne.

title: PROVIDENCE BILL TO AID HOMOSEXUALS IN DOUBT
description: A battle has broken out here over rights for homosexuals, pitting the Governor of Rhode Island and the Mayor and City Council of Providence against the Roman Catholic Church.

title: CLEANUP IS BEGUN IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Seven beaches in Westchester County were closed to swimmers and hundreds of trees were down yesterday in the aftermath of storms that sped through the metropolitan area Friday afternoon, authorities said.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;

AN ARCHITECT IN LANDSCAPE
description: Benjamin Henry Latrobe (1764-1820) was one of America's first architects and engineers. The Capitol in Washington, the Bank of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia and the Roman Catholic Cathedral in Baltimore are testaments to his lasting influence.

title: NEW CONDUCTOR IN DEBUT
description: TO audience and critical responses that ranged from cautiously enthusiastic to an unqualified rave, Hugh Wolff, the newly appointed 31-year-old conductor of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, made his official debut Wednesday night at the Garden State Arts Center here.

title: A BRIEF WORD ABOUT BIKINIS
description: I WAS AN ADOLESCENT visiting a country club in Connecticut in the 1950's the first time I saw an actual, living girl in a bikini. In fact there were two girls, sticking fairly close together. They must have come there on a dare - ''I'll do it if you will'' - after a vacation somewhere extremely bizarre and foreign, because bikinis were not yet even for sale in America (they probably still aren't for sale in Connecticut).

title: LYDIA FOX BECOMES BRIDE
description: The marriage of Lydia Kilborne Fox, the daughter of Nancy Kilborne Fox of Ridgefield, Conn., and G. Sidney Fox of Roxbury, Conn., to David Arthur Humphreys took place yesterday at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Ridgefield.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

AUCTIONS AND SALES
description: An important auction of United States and foreign coins, currency, tokens, medals and other numismatic material will take place Sept. 9-11 in New York under the auspices of Auctions by Bowers and Merena Inc. of Wolfeboro, N.H. The sale will encompass more than 4,000 lots and will be conducted in five sessions at the St. Moritz Hotel at 50 Central Park South.

title: SUDAN BEGINS TO SEND FAMINE REFUGEES HOME
description: Ten months ago, in desperation, Sheik Ibrahim Ismail Adam gathered the 65 members of his clan and told them they were to walk north to Khartoum. After several successive seasons of drought, the sheik had become convinced that to remain at home was to risk death.

title: JANET LOUGHLIN IS ENGAGED TO MARRY DANIEL RUBIN
description: Janet Gunning Loughlin and Daniel Edward Rubin plan to be married Sept. 22. The future bride is a daughter of Mrs. Charles Thomas Loughlin of Remsenburg, L.I., who has announced her engagement, and the late Lieutenant Colonel Loughlin, U.S.A.F. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Rubin of Tucson, Ariz.

title: BROADCAST TV
description: ''A Walk Through the 20th Century With Bill Moyers'' may be the best television series on American history that you are likely to see. It is substantial.

title: WOODWARD IS WON BY TRACK BARRON
description: Track Barron scored the most important and impressive victory of his career yesterday when he strteched an early lead into a four-length romp over Vanlandingham and Chief's Crown in the $334,000 Woodward Stakes at Belmont Park. The victory stamped him the best older horse in the East and a contender for the horse-of-the-year title.

title: STORY OF A YIDDISH STORYTELLER
description: WHEN Dvorah Menashe informed her employer that she was enrolling in a course of study in the Yiddish language, he was somewhat skeptical about the whole enterprise and asked in broken English, ''What for do you need with Yiddish?''

title: Typhoon Halts Golf
description: The third round of the $177,000 K.B.C. Augusta Golf Tournament was canceled today because of a typhoon. The final round will be held Sunday, shortening the four-round tournament to three rounds. Hajime Meshiai of Japan leads with a nine-under-par 135 total, followed by Fuzzy Zoeller of the United States, one stroke back.

title: 230-MILE BIKE RACE TO PROMOTE HEALTH
description: MORE than 100 cyclists will set off Thursday on a three-day, 230-mile ''Bicycle Race for Health'' for $5,500 in prizes and ''to draw attention to the health activities that are going on in the state.''

title: BALANCHINE'S CHOREOGRAPHIC INFLUENCE: PLUSES AND MINUSES
description: Choreographically, we live in the age of Balanchine. Through his works, the late George Balanchine significantly changed our ideas of ballet, and his influence continues to be felt by other choreographers.

title: NOV. 2 WEDDING FOR NINI CUSHING
description: Howard G. Cushing Jr. of New York and Newport, R.I., and Mrs. John P. Jennings of Mill Neck, L.I., and Hamilton, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nini Cochrane Cushing to Robert Keith Marceca, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Marceca of Chatham, Mass. The wedding is planned for Nov. 2.

title: Weinberger Cans a Weapon
description: Caspar W. Weinberger's critics frequently complain that he has never met an expensive weapon that he did not like. But last week the Secretary of Defense mounted a surprise attack on the Army's Sergeant York antiaircraft gun. The project was to be killed, he announced, because in recent tests the gun ''didn't work well enough.''

title: GROWING UP WITH THE ARTS OF INDIA
description: When the nationwide celebration that is the Festival of India arrives in the city Sept. 10, it will provide New Yorkers with a wider and more intense exposure to India's cultural history than any but the most privileged Indians could hope for in a lifetime.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: STRAW HAT AT FALMOUTH Most summer theaters strike their sets and put the costumes in mothballs after Labor Day, but the Falmouth Playhouse on Cape Cod will continue its season through the end of September.

title: U.S. Loses Medals
description: Paige Zemina of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., a member of two United States swimming relay teams was disqualified from the World University Games in Kobe, Japan, yesterday because she was too young to compete, and the move cost the United States a pair of gold medals.

title: DROUGHT TRANSFORMING LIVES FROM MAINE TO THE CAROLINAS
description: The Northwest River, which supplies drinking water to Chesapeake, Va., contains so much salt from ocean tides that city officials have warned residents with high blood pressure that the water might be hazardous.

title: Trade Talks Stall
description: Officials of the Boston Celtics and the Los Angeles Clippers ran into snags yesterday during negotiations to trade the Clipper center, Bill Walton, for the forward, Cedric Maxwell, according to a Celtics official.

title: The Competition With Japan
description: The Japanese are moving ahead of us industrially because of the vast resources that we waste on the arms race. Because the Japanese have virtually no resources committed to weapons technology, they can focus their efforts on civilian production. The argument runs deeper, but it is correct to say that our military spending has put us at an extreme disadvantage with respect to the industrial production of competitor nations not so engaged. HENRY F. ARNOLD Princeton, N.J.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Supplies and Lessons For Worldwide Crafts During 19 years in Croton-on-Hudson, The Niddy Noddy has developed a worldwide reputation for supplying the needs and wants of the textile crafts of spinning, dyeing, weaving and knitting. The yarn colors are in all gradations and provide a feast for the eyes of a newcomer, even to offering inspiration to a casual knitter, who then may get caught up in the commercial possibilities of the craft.

title: DEMANDS OF PARENTS CREATING NEW ISSUES IN SUBURBAN SCHOOLS
description: More than one million suburban public school students in the New York metropolitan area resume classes this week, with school officials confident that they have reached the end of a long drop in enrollment but unsure about how to handle a number of new issues.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SETTING THE EAST ABLAZE: Lenin's Dream of an Empire in Asia. By Peter Hopkirk. (Norton, $17.95.) At the end of 1917, V. I. Lenin called upon Asia's peoples to overthrow their oppressors.

title: NIGERIA ORDERS RELEASE OF 87 FROM JAIL
description: Nigeria's new military Government today began freeing scores of people detained by the country's former rulers.

title: Aftershocks in The Oraflex Case
description: The Justice Department's case against Eli Lilly & Company for failing to report the dangers of the arthritis drug Oraflex ended on Aug. 21 when the company pleaded guilty to misdemeanor charges.

title: SCHOOL REPRIEVE
description: THE little red schoolhouse of Valhalla, one of the county's last one-room schoolhouses, where nine grades were taught by a single teacher, got a reprieve recently after being threatened with demolition. The school, which dates at least to 1907 and possibly to 1901, is an old clapboard building that has been covered with asphalt shingles. It has a wide porch and a cupola, but the school bell is gone. The school is on a Stevens Avenue site that a developer, Lucca Cappelli, wants to use for a two-level parking lot for his large new office building.

title: SANDRA L. MILLER TO BECOME BRIDE
description: Mrs. Edward M. Miller of Fort Lee, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter Sandra Lynn Miller to John Richard Firestone, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Firestone of Houston.

title: A CRIME VICTIM IS FINALLY ABLE TO REQUEST AID
description: After the Brink's armored-car robbery on Oct. 20, 1981, that left two police officers and a security guard dead, Lori Ann Priest lost sleep and had some nightmares.

title: TRIPODS HAVE COME A LONG WAY
description: THE tripod has been the ugly duckling of equipment since photography began. Many photo directories have stopped listing the tripod, but one measure of a good photographer is the ability to handle one.

title: DR. ROSENBLOOM PLANS TO BE MARRIED NOV. 16
description: Drs. Mindy Sharon Rosenbloom and Stuart T. Schwartz, both graduates of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey-Rutgers Medical School, plan to be married Nov. 16. Dr. and Mrs. Donald T. Rosenbloom of Paramus, N.J., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Schwartz of Union, N.J.

title: MYKONOS WARMTH IS MORE THAN SUN
description: Mykonos, a tiny speck of an island in the central Aegean, is known for brilliant sunlight, turquoise sea, blue-trimmed, whitewashed cubic houses and windmills on the cliff. Danish, German, Dutch, French and English are heard more than Greek in the summer months. Jet setters mingle with backpackers off the ferries and day visitors from tourist ships that anchor just outside the harbor.

title: MAURA NAYLOR IS MARRIED
description: Maura Elizabeth Naylor, the new design coordinator for Steuben Glass, a division of the Corning (N.Y.) Glass Works, was married yesterday to G. Lauriston Walsh Jr. of Corning, a real-estate developer.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: BOOK BARGAINS More than 50,000 used books and thousands of new ones will go on sale next Sunday in West Orange with the opening of the annual Brandeis Book Sale.

title: COLLECTING HONORS FOR THE DEFENSE
description: The recent Summer Nationals in Las Vegas fulflled predictions and became the biggest tournament ever played anywhere in the world. The total number of tables played, in a 10-day period with a little overflow at each end, was 19,827. This broke the old record, set in the same location six years earlier, by 1,310.

title: COALITION SEEKS HIGH COURT SUPPORT ON ABORTION
description: Offering the vivid memories of women who had illegal abortions, a coalition of abortion-rights groups has filed a brief asking the Supreme Court to reaffirm its 1973 decision legalizing abortion.

title: LAWRENCE M. LOMARDO
description: Lawrence M. Lombard, a former partner in the law firm of Hemenway & Barnes and a former director of Dow Jones & Company, died Tuesday at his home in Dedham, Mass.

title: ANALYSTS SAY CUTS IN AID HURT YOUNG
description: Four years after the Reagan Administration began reducing spending for social services, a group of analysts for the Urban Institute has concluded that the retrenchment has generally spared the elderly but has seriously hurt programs for children, young adults and the long-term unemployed.

title: CONNECTICUT OPINION
description: AS a young man growing up in the 50's, standing around with the guys, looking over girls and under automobile hoods, I was more attracted to the girls. So whenever I stared into the oily cleavage of the piston engine, I was fond of saying, ''The voltage regulator is out of synch with the generator.'' Then I would shift my mind into neutral and just idle while others absorbed my little sophistry.

title: EDWARD HENRY TO WED PAMELA ANNE KANNER
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Kanner of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Wellfleet, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter Pamela Anne Kanner to Edward John Henry, a son of Grace G. Henry of Chicago and Daniel Henry of Sarasota, Fla. The wedding is planned for Oct. 26.

title: The Hispanic Underclass
description: Two new studies show that Hispanic New Yorkers are poorer, less educated and have more serious health and social problems than any other segment of the state's population, it was reported last week. ''Affirmative action programs to date have done little, if anything, to change our poverty status,'' wrote the authors of one of the reports, the Association of Puerto Rican Executive Directors in New York City.

title: HODEL TO RE-EVALUATE COAST OFFSHORELEASING PACT
description: Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel, ending a 12-day information-gathering tour of California, held a public hearing here Friday on a ''preliminary agreement'' that would ban nearly all oil and gas exploration off the coast of California for the rest of the century.

title: EFFORTS TO AID VETERANS OF VIETNAM STIR DEBATE
description: THE answering machine at Jobtrac for Veterans responds with the opening chords of Bruce Springsteen's anthem for Vietnam Veterans, ''Born in the U.S.A,'' a song that addresses the frustration and disillusionment many veterans have faced trying to find employment.

title: A MISTAKE TOO BEAUTIFUL TO BE JUNKED
description: THE antiques shop is at the intersection of two well-traveled streets in Eastchester.

title: RELIGIOUS TEST FOR BOY SCOUTS VIOLATES FEDERAL CHARTER
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION
description: LABOR DAY, and summer has slipped through my fingers. Wasn't it just yesterday, or surely no longer than a week ago, that I stored away my space heater and packed away my snow boots? Like a movie sequence in which leaves of a calendar float swiftly away, something has stolen my summer.

title: U.S. IS FOUGHT ON KILLING FOX TO SAVE GOOSE
description: Federal wildlife officials trying to save the rare Aleutian Canada goose say they need to kill its chief predator, the arctic fox. Their plans worry environmentalists who once enthusiastically supported the goose recovery program.

title: THE DANGERS OF LABELING CHILDREN
description: LINUS, the ''Peanuts'' character, announced after his first day at school that he had the worst thing a kid could have - potential.

title: RELIGION ART UNDER A TENT
description: FROM the outside, the ''Tent of Meeting'' looks only like 1,100 square feet of black canvas.

title: ITALY'S UNSCRUPULOS PATRIOT
description: CAVOUR By Denis Mack Smith. 294 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: ELLEN GRACE KELLY PLANS TO BE WED TO J. T. BRADY JR.
description: Mr. and Mrs. William E. Kelly of Spring Lake, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Grace Kelly, to John Thomas Brady Jr., the son of Mr. Brady of New York and Jean Brady of Summit, N.J. A November wedding is planned.

title: MEETING THE RUSSIANS AT THE SUMMIT
description: IN the age of nuclear parity, summit meetings between the leaders of the United States and the Soviet Union have become essential if peace is to be preserved.

title: AMERICANS THRONG TO VACATION POINTS
description: Despite concern over air safety, Americans took to the skies in record numbers this summer, thronging European and domestic tourist destinations at a rate of more than a million passengers a day.

title: Summer People And Their Baggage
description: I have but one comment to make regarding Ruth Jernick's recent article, ''What Summer People Do'' [Opinion Page] : Henceforth she shall be known as Saint Ruth - patron saint of native (and year-round) Long Islanders!

title: HELP GROWS FOR MS VICTIMS
description: WHEN Dorothy Moses began to limp 17 years ago, her doctor handed her a cane and told her to use it till she got better. Fourteen years and many doctors later, the Teaneck resident learned that she had multiple sclerosis.

title:
AS THE MAYORAL PRIMARY ROUNDS THE FINAL TURN;

ROGER STONE ON BELLAMY: BOLD, BUT COSTLY RISKS
description: IN February, when City Council President Carol Bellamy and Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr. announced that they would challenge Mayor Koch, who is seeking re-election to a third term, The Week in Review asked three Republican political strategists to outline what tactics they would use if they were managing the campaigns. Last week, with campaign for the Sept. 10 Democratic primary entering its final days, Alan Finder, an editor of The Review, asked the same three consultants to review the race. Roger J. Stone Jr. is a political consultant who was in charge of New York and 13 other Northeastern states for the Reagan-Bush campaign in 1980 and 1984; among his clients this year is Governor Kean of New Jersey, who is running for re-election. Richard J. Behn is president of Numbercrunchers Inc., a political consulting company, and was communications director for Lewis E. Lehrman's 1982 New York gubernatorial campaign. Robert Price, the president of Price Communications Corporation, was Deputy Mayor under John V. Lindsay. Excerpts follow. From the beginning Carol Bellamy has needed a two-person race. There were two possibilities to provide that. One was if she could get Ed Koch into a runoff. That has now been eliminated as a possibility by the courts. The other was to see if Denny Farrell could be eliminated from the ballot. In my view attempting to eliminate him was a reasonable political risk to take, and I think she was bold and correct in taking it.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

T.BEAR'S MESSAGE
description: ''I promise to spread T.Bear's message that handwashing prevents infection,'' states the T.Bear pledge. As part of a nationwide infection-control program, children in the pediatric unit at Mount Vernon Hospital will take this oath, promising to wash their hands and to remind others, who take care of them, to do the same. As an incentive, the children will receive a copy of the pledge and their own T.Bear, a furry brown stuffed animal sporting a red heart on its chest and a plaid ribbon around its neck.

title: CROTON NURSERY
description: To the Editor:

title: RELAXED WILANDER DEFEATS ANNACONE
description: His tennis philosophy, Mats Wilander said, is based on a personality he calls typically Swedish. What this means is that aspiring to be No. 1 in the world is not the magnificent obsession it is for Americans, driving such players as John McEnroe and Jimmy Connors to be better than they ever imagined they could be. For Wilander, it is enough to have played well and to treat his victories like after-dinner mints.

title:
DINING OUT;

SOUTH AMERICAN CUISINE ARRIVES
description: A DISTINCTIVE new entry in the list of ethnic restaurants in the county, Carrizos does a first-rate, bang-up job of bringing to Westchester the refined cuisine from a number of South American countries. The elegant representation includes mellow as well as spicy dishes, wholesome, delectable and carefully prepared and served with grace and charm. Every item on the short menu is worth trying, and considering the high quality of ingredients, the prices are a bargain.

title: LOUISIANIANS GROUSE OVER 2d FALSE ALARM
description: Louisiana residents who evacuated their homes to escape Hurricane Elena and instead got a day of sunshine are irritated.

title: CITY OPERA: LEHAR'S 'MERRY WIDOW'
description: ''THE MERRY WIDOW'' is one of the New York City Opera's more visually attractive productions. The eye rests gratefully on the Helen Pond/Herbert Senn sets: they are unassertive, apt and gentle. And the cast that revived the show Friday night reflected those qualities to a greater degree than has sometimes been the case; the staging has mellowed.

title: EXPLORING THE ETRUSCAN MYSTERY
description: Who the Etruscans were, where they came from and what became of them are questions that have fascinated archeologists and historians as much as they have romantics and mystics. All were drawn to these attractive people, who inhabited Tuscany and other parts of central Italy for a good deal more than half a millenium and then disappeared from history's pages.

title: MARINO JOINS TEAM
description: The Miami Dolphins' quarterback, Dan Marino, ended his 38-day holdout today, saying that he wanted to return to the team before the start of the regular season ''to be fair to myself and to a lot of other people.''

title: JANE E. MACCALLUM TO BECOME A BRIDE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Clark MacCallum Jr. of Wyckoff, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jane Elizabeth MacCallum to Benard Vincent Preziosi Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Preziosi of Brooklyn. The wedding is planned for Nov. 17.

title: Randall Jarrell's Tennis
description: To the Editor:

title: BLACKS GAIN POSTS ON 10 STATES HIGH COURTS
description: Ernest Finney, a 54-year-old former state legislator, has become the first black to sit on South Carolina's Supreme Court since Reconstruction.

title: LIEUT. BONNIE ANN HAGEMEISTER IS WED
description: Lieut. Bonnie Ann Hagemeister, U.S.N., the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Hagemeister of Sparta, N.J., was married at the First Presbyterian Church there yesterday to Lieut.

title: PAST GLORIES OF AN AILING BUS LINE
description: 'Hounds of the Road: A History of the Greyhound Bus Company, by Carlton Jackson. Published jointly by Bowling Green University Popular Press, Bowling Green, Ohio, and Kendall/Hunt Publishing Company, Dubuque, Iowa. 214 pages. $24.95 (hardcover), $12.95 (paper). SEVERELY damaged by competition from the airlines, especially the no-frills airlines with rock-bottom prices, the Greyhound Corporation recently announced major cutbacks in its bus operation. And it also said that it might sell the bus line unless it achieves a 15 percent return on equity within three years.

title: LOUDSPEAKERS MEET THE CHALLENGE OF THE DIGITAL ERA
description: Judging by the results, loudspeaker engineers must have put in lots of overtime in the last year.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THREE FARMERS ON THEIR WAY TO A DANCE. By Richard Powers. (Morrow/Beech Tree, $17.95.) This first novel is an extended meditation provoked by a May 1914 picture taken by the photographer August Sander of three young German men on their way to a dance. Mr. Powers's nameless narrator becomes fascinated by the photograph and creates the World War I experiences of the young men.

title: CHUCK NORRIS -- STRONG, SILENT AND POPULAR
description: Chuck Norris, the movie star, former karate champion and superpatriot on the order of his idol, John Wayne, was sitting in a Manhattan office the other day doing two things he doesn't do very much of in his movies: smiling and talking.

title: ELEANOR M. UFFORD PLANS TO BECOME BRIDE OCT. 19
description: Eleanor Morris Ufford and Albert Leger plan to be married Oct. 19, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Ufford Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and South Bristol, Me., have announced. Mr. Leger is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Leger of Caraquet, New Brunswick.

title: BUILDING PLANS SPARK MIODWEST FEUD
description: In many ways it is a classic fight between the older city and the upstart suburb, but the outcome of a battle now being waged here could have economic repercussions throughout Minnesota.

title: WORLD WAR II WORDS
description: To the Editor:

title: The Competition With Japan
description: Theodore White's images are disturbingly reminiscent of the ''yellow peril'' alarmism of the early decades of this century in his characterization of Japan-United States trade competition as a continuation by ''commerical offensives'' of the 1941-45 Pacific war, with Japan ''on the move again,'' this time to make ''the whole world its Greater Co-Prosperity Sphere.''

title: GENTLEMAN IN THE HOUSE ON CORBETT ROAD
description: PERIODICALLY, we get phone calls from a certain boxing historian. He called the other day. ''Do you know,'' he asked, ''that Sunday, Sept. 1, is the 119th anniversary of the birth of Gentleman Jim Corbett?'' We said it was unlikely that we would remember even so notable an event; we have great difficulty remembering the birthday of the Marquis of Queensberry. The caller said it was a shame, because he had remembered and had gone out to Bayside, Queens, to stand at Corbett's shrine. He said he had returned to Manhattan all larded over with awe.

title: TWO STORES NAMED DUNHILL FIND A SOLUTION TO CONFUSION
description: FOR years, the identical Dunhill names created customer confusion, dismay and sheepish grins.

title: POWER TO HURT
description: THE NEWS AT ANY COST How Journalists Compromise Their Ethics to Shape the News. By Tom Goldstein. 301 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: NATIONAL ENDOWMENT FOR THE ARTS IS HONORED AS 20TH BIRTHDAY NEARS
description: In hindsight, everyone agrees the American Ballet Theater's brush with extinction could not have come at a better time.

title: THE MEANING OF ROSE
description: PETER EDWARD ROSE has averaged a little better than three hits every 10 times at bat over his 23-year career. He has maintained nearly that pace for much of this season. At the age of 44, an antique in baseball terms, he remains as consistent as a grandfather clock.

title: CHANGES IN CACTUS GROWING MAY BENEFIT ENDANGERED SPECIES
description: While other rare plants are bulldozed into extinction by indifferent developers, many cactuses are gradually being loved to death by collectors. For a century the pattern has been the same: Shortly after a rare species is described in a publication, its habitat is invaded by well-to-do hobbyists who simply must have a specimen and by opportunistic dealers who may bag thousands of plants to sell through nurseries and catalogues. Within months, certain species have become extinct.

title: DENG IS GIVEN A SHARP TALK BY MOYNIHAN
description: A decade after he lectured America's foes from the podium at the United Nations, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan brought some of the same style into a meeting this week with China's pre-eminent leader, Deng Xiaoping.

title: U.S. Orders Inspection of Jet Engines
description: United States officials decided not to wait for the final report on what caused an engine of a Boeing 737 to explode during take-off in Manchester, England, two and a half weeks ago. The Federal Aviation Administration last week ordered the inspection of Pratt & Whitney JT8D-15 engines, the type involved.

title: TAX EXAMINER ACCUSED IN NEW ORLEANS SCHEME
description: An Internal Revenue Service employee has been accused of tampering with taxpayers' addresses and collecting $175,000 in unauthorized tax refunds that were delivered to a friend.

title: VERPLANK IS DEFEATED AT U.S. AMATEUR
description: Scott Verplank, who is expected to be a star on the PGA Tour when he turns pro next year, was upset in the quarterfinals of the 85th United States amateur championship today when he played and lost one hole.

title: FAIR-HOUSING LAW MAKING INROADS
description: OVER the last four years, discrimination in housing has cost the real-estate industry in the metropolitan New York area almost $2 million in legal awards and in negotiated settlements, according to the Open Housing Center of New York.

title: CRATE LABELS THAT HAVE LEFT AN IMPRINT
description: Those bold, bright labels that once emblazoned crates of fresh fruit shipped from California to the East are once again taking an easterly direction, this time in the form of collectible art. Crate art, with highly stylized depictions ranging from strutting roosters to high-riding broncobusters, has been popular for some time in California, but only recently has it been finding its way beyond the Golden State's borders.

title: AT 88, THE DOYEN OF STAMFORD TENNIS
description: THE combined ages of his partner and their two opponents does not come close to equaling his own, but the dimunitive man with the blue baseball cap was more than holding his own in a mixed-doubles tennis match one recent sunny morning at Scalzi Park in Stamford.

title: PITT PREVAILS, 31-30, AS 2-POINT TRY FAILS
description: Jim Everett passed incomplete on a potential game-winning, 2-point conversion play with 49 seconds remaining as Pitt withstood a 398-yard performance by the Purdue senior to win, 31-30, in the first night game in the 60-year-old Pitt Stadium.

title: MANY AMERICAN WORKERS CONCEDE THAT THE JAPANESE DO BETTER WORK
description: Few American workers may have visited Japan. Fewer still may know any Japanese workers. And even fewer may know what it is like to work in a Japanese factory.

title: Battling 'Hoppers'
description: NOT since 1933 had grasshoppers swarmed in such great numbers in the Middle West and West, devastating range grass and some crops in parts of 13 states.

title: IN THE NORTHWEST, STURGEON IS KING
description: Three times a year in Seattle a question circulates in the city's restaurants and fish markets. ''Is there any fresh sturgeon yet?'' Seattle residents await sturgeon season the way most people await Christmas. Once in season, huge, whole sturgeon are on display at fish stands in the Pike Place Market and fresh sturgeon appears simultaneously on the menu of nearly every restaurant in the city that offers fish.

title:
INVESTING;

JOLTING A $27 BILLION PENSION FUND
description: BY any measure it is an extraordinary amount of money. In fact, the $27 billion in assets of the California Public Employees Retirement System ranks behind only two other pension funds in the nation: the New York State Common Retirement Fund and the General Motors Pension Fund.

title: DEBATE CONTINUES OVER LEAD SHOT
description: NEARLY a decade has passed since the Federal Government launched its program to require the use of shotgun shells loaded with shot made of steel - rather than lead - for waterfowling in certain areas of the country, and from the beginning, there has been intense reaction both for and against the concept.

title: BOYS' CLUB HELPING 150 TO FURTHER EDUCATION
description: The Boys' Club of New York, with a record budget of $4 million and 5,400 members, started a new summer camp school for fifth- and sixth-graders this year and has helped get 150 boys into top preparatory schools and colleges this fall.

title: SOLIDARITY LOUDSPEAKER STARTLES POLISH POLICE
description: As a crowd of 7,000 people here left a church service tonight commemorating the fifth anniversary of the founding of Solidarity, they were greeted by the amplified voices of the labor union movement's underground leaders.

title: THE ALPS BY CARRIAGE, COUNTRY FAIR NEAR ROCHESTER
description: To Italy By Coach And Four To the rhythm of horses' hooves drawing a 19th-century carriage across Alpine landscapes into northern Italy, a journey in the style of the past is in prospect for next year.

title: The Poetry of a Precinct
description: When Phillip Mahony graduated from college, he wanted to be a poet. He lived what he now calls ''the noble-poverty scene,'' working part-time jobs here and there, eating spaghetti often and writing verse after verse that never made it into print.

title: OFFICER CHARGED WITH MURDER
description: A 26-year-old probationary police officer was charged with murder and manslaughter yesterday in the fatal shooting of a woman companion in a car in Queens while he was off duty Thursday night, the police said.

title: CLINTON GREENBAUM WED TO ELISA FISHBEIN ON L.I.
description: Elisa Fishbein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eli Fishbein of Lawrence, L.I., was married there yesterday to Clinton Greenbaum, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Greenbaum of Mission Hills, Kan.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Fiesta as Cosmic Experiment In ''The Labyrinth of Solitude'' (Grove), Octavio Paz says that ''the solitary Mexican loves fiestas,'' which represent ''the advent of the unusual.'' He even sees the fiesta as a sort of costume ball of social upheaval.

title: DEBRA AMENT AND RICHARD FIELDHOUSE ARE WED
description: The Rye Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Debra Ann Ament, a daughter of Sally H. Ament and Charles E. Ament, both of Rye, N.Y., to Richard George Fieldhouse, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Fieldhouse of Ventnor City, N.J. The Rev. Donald W. Poole performed the ceremony.

title:
GARDENING;

PERENNIALS CAN BENEFIT FROM REPLANTING
description: THE nurseryman's slogan, ''Fall is for planting,'' is especially appropriate when applied to herbaceous perennials. When planted in the fall, they have an opportunity to become well established before winter.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE IN THE DESERT
description: THE NYE COUNTY BROTHEL WARS A Tale of the New West. By Jeanie Kasindorf. 302 pp. New York: The Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: CIVILIAN POLICE EMPLOYEE ACCUSED OF BEATING PRISONER WITH A WHIP
description: A civilian police employee was charged yesterday with beating a prisoner with a metal whip in a holding cell at Police Headquarters in lower Manhattan, authorities said.

title: WILLIAMS STAGES RALLY FOR KNOCKOUT IN 10TH
description: Carl (The Truth) Williams recovered from a pair of knockdowns to stop Jesse (Thunder) Ferguson of Philadelphia with a 10th-round knockout in a scheduled 10-round heavyweight bout today.

title: U.S. SAW KOREAN JET STRAY, SUIT SAYS
description: Evidence introduced in lawsuits filed in connection with the Soviet downing of Korean Air Lines Flight 007 suggests that American radar operators knew hours beforehand that the jetliner was off course and heading into Soviet airspace.

title: SOUTH AFRICA MINERS SEE THREAT OF STRIKE 'WARFARE'
description: South Africa's biggest black labor group, the National Union of Mine Workers, accused employers today of preparing ''for total warfare'' in a strike of 62,000 of its members, due to begin Sunday. The union also renewed threats of a wider stoppage if management tried to break the strike.

title: WINFIELD: TRIPLE THREAT
description: WHEN Dave Winfield is on a roll, he is more of a physical menace to opposing pitchers than they are to him. The way he stands away from the plate, sweeping his long arms into the strike zone, produces some of the most awful screamers that ever gave a pitcher nightmares, but Winfield has been hit by pitches only 16 times in his 13 major league season.

title: Shaffer at Quarterback
description: John Shaffer, a junior from Cincinnati, will be Penn State's starting quarterback this season, Coach Joe Paterno announced yesterday. Shaffer beat out another junior, Matt Knizner of Youngwood, Pa.

title: A British Plot, a Texas Payoff
description: Karleen Koen lived in 18th-century England for five years while she wrote her first novel, but she was very much back home in Texas last week when she learned that Random House would pay her $350,000 for her 1,300-page manuscript. Mrs. Koen said she lost herself in the age of Defoe, Pope, Swift and Addison after giving up her job as editor of a Houston magazine to attend to her husband and two children. After one literary agent and a publisher rejected her work, Mrs. Koen was taken on by Jean Naggar, another agent.

title: U.S., PROTESTING ARRESTS, BARS MEETING WITH POLE
description: Political arrests in Poland have increased, and the Reagan Administration has decided to respond by refusing to hold any meetings with Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, when he comes to New York next month, State Department officials said today.

title: SONGS AND MEMORIES OF LABOR WARS
description: Obviously, it is time to consider the union movement. Labor Day is at hand. As a rule, television does not pay much attention to unions, other than when they go on strike or when political candidates look for their endorsements. Meanwhile, the popular culture gives the labor movement mixed reviews, with the reviews from the past more positive than the ones from the present. Artists and writers were sympathetic to the labor movement during the Great Depression; unions were the hope of the common man. In the 60's, however, the counterculture saw unions differently. George Meany, the president of the merged labor federation, supported the Vietnam War, while individual unions, particularly those in the building trades, were accused of excluding minorities. The romance with labor fled.

title: Robbery Suspects With a Cause
description: Two years ago, the Macheteros, a Puerto Rican nationalist group, claimed responsibility for the armed robbery of more than $7 million from a Wells Fargo depot in West Hartford, Conn. On Friday, the Justice Department said that the case had been broken and that the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which quietly slipped 100 agents into Puerto Rico, had arrested 13 people for planning or participating in the robbery.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM GARBO TO POOH CORNER
description: Puccini's 'Manon Lescaut' A Royal Opera production filmed at Covent Garden, featuring Kiri Te Kanawa, Placido Domingo and Thomas Allen; conducted by Giuseppe Sinopoli Thorn EMI Video 130 minutes. $79.95 ''Manon Lescaut'' may not be everybody's cup of operatic tea, but those devoted to it should find this video cassette a special treat.

title: MIRIAM, TIRED OF BEING STRONG
description: THE SWIMMING POOL SEASON By Rose Tremain. 274 pp. New York: Summit Books. $16.95.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

FORM AND MOTION
description: Dance may well be the art of movement but when Jeff McMahon premiere's his new work, ''More Moving Pictures,'' Saturday at the State University of New York at Purchase, at least two of the performers will remain motionless during the entire 40-minute presentation.

title: Marcos Prevails On Two Fronts
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos probably won't be calling early presidential elections after all. According to aides of the Philippine leader, Government-controlled opinion surveys showed ''overwhelming rejection of the proposal,'' which Mr. Marcos had said was under serious consideration.

title: KEY ISSUE IN LIMBO AS SCHOOL BEGINS
description: A NUMBER of educational changes that Governor Kean set in motion two years ago are finally coming to fruition this year and, as the 1985-86 school year begins, other states are watching to see if New Jersey's ideas work.

title: ROBERT TOBITT MARRIED TO SUZANNE K. GERBER
description: Suzanne Kathryn Gerber, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Gerber of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert William Tobitt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Tobitt of Essex, England. The Venerable John A. Greco, Episcopal Archdeacon of Nassau County, performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Rosyln, L.I.

title: NEW PRESIDENTS AT 3 UNIVERSITIES
description: ADELPHI UNIVERSITY A COLLEAGUE once told Peter Diamondopoulos that ''you don't look or act like a college president.''

title: FITTING IN IN SEASON
description: YOU know you've finally become part of a New England village when the farmer down the road calls to tell you she's about to pick her first crop of corn and asks, ''Do you need any?''

title: HOMER BATES CHASE IS DEAD: ACTIVE IN COMMUNIST PARTY
description: Homer Bates Chase, an American Communist Party activist who could trace his lineage to the days of the Mayflower, died Thursday in his sleep at a home in Hingham, Mass., where he had been staying. He was 68 years old.

title: REAGAN THREATENS TO VETO ANY MOVE TO LIMIT IMPORTS
description: President Reagan, facing growing Congressional pressure to counter the nation's deepening international trade problems, today reiterated his free-trade position and threatened to veto protectionist legislation.

title: WE NEED A BRAIN-DEATH LAW
description: ''WE knew he was dead,'' a mother recalls.

title: IN EASTERN STATES, THE WATER SUPPLY IS TOPIC A
description: THE Northeast, experts told the eight governors at last week's meeting of the Coalition of Northeastern Governors, is sitting on almost enough water to float away, but the resource of water in the ground is being thoughtlessly squandered. ''Scattered below the nation's surface are an estimated 8 million storage tanks containing literally billions of gallons of petroleum products, hazardous wastes and industrial process chemicals,'' said Michael R. Deland, regional administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. ''It is estimated that 25 percent of these tanks will leak their toxic contents into the ground water in the next five years,''

title: CODSWALLOP, POPPYCOCK AND HORSEFEATHERS
description: FACED WITH A charge by Sir Fred Hoyle, astronomer, and Chandra Wickramasinghe, an astrophysicist, that the fossil known as Archaeopteryx - whose reptilian bones adorned with beautifully preserved feathers suggest a link between reptiles and birds - is a fake, Alan J. Charig of the British Museum of Natural History, in London, told New Scientist magazine: ''We think the suggestion that it's a fake is a load of codswallop.'' (That is a classic lead sentence. They're just not writing leads like that anymore. Savor it; as the eulogists say, we shall not soon see its like again.) The clipping on the Archaeopteryx (say ''arky opterix'' - the name means ''ancient wing'') controversy was sent to me by John Noble Wilford, a science correspondent of The New York Times and possessor of the classiest name in journalism today. My colleague asked: '' 'A load of codswallop.' I have a clear enough picture of the meaning intended, but Merriam-Webster's Third Unabridged does not acknowledge the existence of such a colorful expression. Can you? Or is it not 'fit to print'?''

title: 70,000 AT FUNERAL IN BALCK TOWNSHIP
description: A crowd of 70,000 people converged on this small, battered black township near the Indian Ocean today to bury 18 victims of recent violence here. The dead included a 16-month-old baby.

title: NETWORK OF SPIES
description: Which TV network will win top ratings this fall? Answer:

title: TROUBLES CONTINUE FOR BALLET TROUPE
description: ATTEMPTS to reorganize the Connecticut Ballet in time for the 1985-86 season have failed.

title: NEW HOUSING FOR ELDERLY URGED
description: A SURVEY taken earlier this year in Scarsdale revealed that residents want to remain in the village when they get older, either in their own homes or something smaller. But the organization that conducted the survey, the two-year-old Scarsdale Citizens for Senior Housing, points out that in the village - where the average house sells for $300,000 - there is a scarcity of smaller houses, apartments and town houses.

title:
FOR EDUCATION, BEST AND WORST OF TIMES;

TAX FEARS FOR PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: LONG ISLAND school officials are keeping a watchful eye on Washington as they prepare to open the doors of the local public schools this fall.

title: LESLIE JOHNSTON, ACTRESS, IS WED
description: Leslie Suzanne Johnston, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Ray Johnston of Wayne, N.J., was married there yesterday to Paul Joseph Durgin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. Durgin of Milton, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Fred M. Buker, a Baptist minister, and the Rev. Michael Lombardo, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Packanack Community Church.

title: MELLENCAMP AIMS AT THE HEARTLAND
description: What's gotten into John Cougar Mellencamp? Just a few years ago, before he reclaimed his last name, John Cougar acted like a standard-issue rock hellion - a scruffy, guitar-twanging, girl-chasing wise guy. Now, on his new album, ''Scarecrow,'' Mr. Mellencamp is writing about failing farms and disillusioned steelworkers and he's calling songs ''Justice and Independence '85'' and ''The Face of a Nation.''

title: The Winning Pitcher Misnomer
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: WHAT GOOD ARE BAR EXAMS ANYWAY?
description: To the Editor:

title: A DIG FOR ARTIFACTS FROM THE DAYS OF OLD BREUKELEN
description: Archeologists have been digging in Brooklyn - in downtown Brooklyn, to be precise, on the edge of Brooklyn Heights, several feet beneath what was a broad, boring parking lot.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HOLIDAY TREATS It's one thing to put away the barbecue and declare summer is over, but another to do it without experiencing one more time some of the things that make the season so much fun. Like outdoor music festivals. For example, there's still time to take in Nasaau County's celebration of the Arts, from noon to 6 P.M., today and Monday at the Fine Arts Center, Northern Boulevard, in Roslyn Harbor. Besides exhibits and visual arts demonstrations, among the highlights left today are the pianist Morton Estrin offering ''An Afternoon of Chopin'' at 1 P.M.,; the Orchestra de Chiesa performing ''Baroque Favorites'' at noon; Susan Wagner singing musical theater favorites in ''A Taste of Nostalgia'' at 3 P.M., and the Long Island Original Music Ensemble performing original music at 5 P.M. Tomorrow, there is traditional folk music from Orion's Belt at noon, classical music from the Connoisseur Chamber Ensemble at 2 P.M. and Squeaky Clean's rockabilly music at 3 P.M. Everything is free.

title:
ANTIQUES;

TRANQUILITY AND COLLECTIBILITY
description: THE setting of the annual Tinicum Park Antiques Show - in a 126-acre oasis of tranquility on the shores of the Delaware in Bucks County - is as attractive to dealers as to those who go there to picnic, play or camp.

title: A NEED FOR UNIFORM LAWS, FASTER TRIALS
description: TRADITIONALLY, product liability has been a matter left to state law, but today the morass of product liability law is a problem of national concern that requires Congressional action. The system of compensating people injured by defective or dangerous products is costly, slow, inefficient, confusing and unpredictable. It hurts business and consumers as well as our competitive position in world markets.

title: The Founding Flavors?
description: Coolly easing back into one of the capital's routine hungers, the American Institute of Architects Foundation plans an ice cream fund-raising fete in memory of the Madisons, Dolley and James, offering brown bread ice cream, Parmesan cheese ice cream and other founding flavors to be tested by invited palates. It will be held Sept. 8 at Octagon House, a Revolutionary era town house near the White House that the institute operates as a museum. The building provided handsome refuge for the Madisons after the British burned the White House in 1814, and Dolley gave parties there to cheer up neighborhood and nation.

title: Using the Ga Bolga
description: To the Editor:

title: EILEEN CONDON PLANS TO MARRY OCT. 19
description: Eileen Philomena Condon, a marketing associate with the Big Apple Circus in New York, and Carter Sterling Wiseman, a senior editor and the architecture critic at New York magazine, plan to be married Oct. 19. The future bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael A. Condon of Washington, Conn., who have announced her engagement to the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Mark Huntington Wiseman of New York and Westport, Conn.

title: CORRECTION
description: An incorrect photograph accompanied an interview with Jack Matthews, the author of ''Crazy Women,'' in the Aug. 18 Book Review. It showed Jack E. Matthews, the chairman of the board of trustees of Lester B. Pearson College of the Pacific in Victoria, British Columbia.

title: THE BARON'S STORY
description: THERE HAS ALWAYS been keen competition among the Rothschilds when it comes to wine -keen but discreet. But when it comes to Rothschild wine promotion, there is no competition whatsoever. Philippe de Rothschild, the chatelain of Mouton-Rothschild, in Bordeaux, has no peers - inside the family or out. Whether by instinct or calculation, he discovered long ago that by promoting himself he promotes his wines. He has promoted both brilliantly. The man and his product are known throughout the world.

title: REPUBLICANS BUCK THE PRESIDENT ON A BOTING RIGHTS COURT CASE
description: IT is a happy time for public officials, especially those aspiring to higher office, when they see a political issue and a ''good government'' issue coincide. Some key Republicans have long seen such a conjunction in legislative districting practices in Democratic Southern states, which they feel discriminate against both blacks and the G.O.P. Last week, Republican members of Congress and the party's national committee joined with Democrats in filing briefs opposing the Reagan Administration in the first major legal test of the recently amended Voting Rights Act. In saying the Administration had misstated the intent of the act, the legislators, who included Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, heightened the conflict between the White House's states rights philosophy and the Republican Party's desire to bolster its strength at the local level and broaden its appeal to minority voters.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;

HAND ACROSS THE SEA
description: ON Friday, June 14, two items were featured prominently on the front page of The News Letter of Northern Ireland. One was a confidential telephone number that readers could call to report terrorist threats. The other was an announcement that Peter Sklar, a talent scout from the United States, would be in Belfast auditioning youngsters, offering two of them an expense-paid trip to his country and a free week in late summer at a performing arts camp in upstate New York.

title: Emergency Kicker
description: Have you heard the one about how Billy Ray Smith of the Chargers discarded his shoe and booted a 17-yard field goal with no time left to lift San Diego past the New Orleans Saints, 21-20, in a National Football League preseason game Friday night? The kicker to the story is that the kicker is a linebacker. The 6-foot-3-inch, 231-pound Smith was forced to take over the place-kicking duties because of groin injuries to Ralf Mojsiejenko and Rolf Benirschke, the Chargers' regulars.

title: LOSING THE LOSING-THINGS BLUES
description: WHEN I was 5 my mother bought me a pair of white buck shoes with silk laces. She said I had to save them for our big trip but when we unpacked, my new shoes had vanished. We searched everywhere - gonzo. I still mourn those beautiful shoes.

title: ISRAELI BROADCAST 'DOCTOR' IS A RADIO BRIDGE TO ARABS
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 31 - Ilana Basri is not a household name in Israel. In fact, few Israelis have heard of her.

title: Books From The Times
description: TOWARD A SAFE AND SANE HALLOWEEN AND OTHER TALES OF SUBURBIA.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Weeks This Last on Week Fiction Week List 1 LUCKY, by Jackie Collins. (Simon 4 2 & Schuster, $17.95.) The heiress of a crime lord takes on the heiress of a shipping tycoon in fashionable spots all over the world. 2 SKELETON CREW, by Stephen King. 1 11 (Putnam, $18.95.) Twenty-two tales of horror set in contemporary America. 3 THE FOURTH DEADLY SIN, by Lawrence Sanders. 2 7 (Putnam, $17.95.) Which of six suspects murdered a saintly New York psychiatrist? 4 THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom Clancy. 3 24 (Naval Institute Press, $14.95.) A Lithuanian submarine driver defects to the United States with the Soviet Union's most advanced nuclear secrets. 5 THE TWO MRS. GRENVILLES, by Dominick Dunne. 5 3 (Crown, $14.95.) Romance, scandal and murder in New York's high society. 6 THE CIDER HOUSE RULES, by John Irving. 6 15 (Morrow, $18.95.) Life in a Maine orphanage earlier in this century. 7 LAKE WOBEGON DAYS, by Garrison Keillor. 1 (Viking, $17.95.) Recollections of a small American town. 8 LONESOME DOVE, by Larry McMurtry. 8 10 (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The Old West seen larger than life. 9 JUBAL SACKETT, by Louis L'Amour. 7 15 (Bantam, $16.95.) In this forerunner to the 17-volume Sackett saga, a restless explorer scouts the 17th-century American wilderness. 10 HOLD THE DREAM, by Barbara Taylor 10 16 Bradford. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Continuing the family saga begun in ''A Woman of Substance.'' 11 IF TOMORROW COMES, by Sidney Sheldon. 9 32 (Morrow, $17.95.) A young woman destroys the crime lords who got her an undeserved prison term. 12 TOO MUCH, TOO SOON, by Jacqueline 13 2 Briskin. (Putnam, $17.95.) Three sisters find their destinies bound by an obsession with the same man. 13 THE LOVER, by Marguerite Duras. 11 7 (Pantheon, $11.95.) The sexual initiation of an adolescent girl by a rich Chinese in Saigon in the 30's. 14 INSIDE, OUTSIDE, by Herman Wouk. 15 24 (Little, Brown, $19.95.) A traditionalist Jew's quest for identity in glittery contemporary America. 15 FALL FROM GRACE, by Larry Collins. 12 7 (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Machinations by spies, double agents and a beautiful woman on the eve of D-Day. Nonfiction 1 YEAGER: An Autobiography, by Chuck Yeager 1 8 and Leo Janos. (Bantam, $17.95.) The story of the first man to fly faster than sound. 2 IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee 2 44 Iacocca with William Novak. (Bantam, $19.95.) The rise of an immigrants' son to top jobs at Ford and Chrysler. 3 SMART WOMEN, FOOLISH CHOICES, 4 22 by Connell Cowan and Melvyn Kinder. (Clarkson N. Potter, $13.95.) Two clinical psychologists analyze modern women's efforts to find acceptable men. 4 A PASSION FOR EXCELLENCE, 3 17 by Tom Peters and Nancy Austin. (Random House, $19.95.) Ways to achieve distinction in management. 5 THE MICK, by Mickey Mantle with Herb Gluck. 5 6 (Doubleday, $15.95.) The autobiography of the New York Yankee baseball star. 6 THE AMATEURS, by David Halberstam. 9 3 (Morrow, $14.95.) Four American men seek the 1984 Olympic gold medal for single sculling. 7 MARTINA, by Martina Navratilova 7 7 with George Vecsey. (Knopf, $16.95.) The autobiography of the Czechoslovak-born tennis champion. 8 CONFESSIONS OF A HOOKER, by Bob Hope 16 16 with Dwayne Netland. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Memories of more than 50 years of golfing, by the comedian. 9 NUTCRACKER, by Shana Alexander. 8 9 (Doubleday, $17.95.) Treachery, mystery and high society in the 1978 murder of a Mormon multimillionaire. 10 HAMMER OF THE GODS: The Led Zeppelin 10 4 Saga, by Stephen Davis. (Morrow, $15.95.) The British heavy metal group's boisterous tours of the 1970's. 11 FUNNY MONEY, by Mark Singer. 11 5 (Knopf, $15.95.) The scandal surrounding the 1982 collapse of the Penn Square Bank in Oklahoma City. 12 LOVING EACH OTHER, by Leo Buscaglia. 52 (Slack/Holt, $13.95.) Suggestions for ''setting our priorities right in order to enjoy life to the fullest.'' 13 THE GRASSHOPPER TRAP, by Patrick 12 3 F. McManus. (Holt, $13.95.) Amusing pieces about pursuing pleasures in the great outdoors. 14 THE BRIDGE ACROSS FOREVER, by Richard Bach. 16 52 (Morrow, $16.95.) How the author of ''Jonathan Livingston Seagull'' sought a true love. 15 THE DANGEROUS SUMMER, by Ernest Hemingway. 13 7 (Scribners, $17.95.) A chronicle of the Spanish bullfight season of 1959. 16 A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel 141 Silverstein. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) Light verse and drawings by the author. Advice and Self-Help 1 DR. BERGER'S IMMUNE POWER DIET, by Stuart 1 12 M. Berger. (NAL Books, $14.95.) A regimen designed to produce weight loss while improving health and increasing energy. 2 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. 43 (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard work updated in 1983. 3 WOMEN WHO LOVE TOO MUCH, by Robin 2 3 Norwood. (Tarcher/St. Martin's, $14.95.) How to find the right man and maintain a happy relationship with him. 4 THE FRUGAL GOURMET, by Jeff Smith. 3 22 (Morrow, $14.95.) Recipes for delicious dishes prepared at moderate cost. 5 FIT FOR LIFE, by Harvey 2 Diamond and Marilyn Diamond. (Warner, $16.50.) A diet for weight loss and physical fitness.

title: CAN JAPAN CREATE A NATION OF CONSUMERS?
description: FORTY years ago tomorrow, Gen.

title: A CAMP THAT LETS PATIENTS BE CHILDREN l>By GARY GATELY
description: THE first time Eric Jones went water-skiing, he lost his balance and fell. He gritted his teeth, grabbed the side of the speedboat and tried again.

title: STALKING KILLER DISEASES TAKES THE CAMERA TO EXOTIC LOCALES
description: ''Marie Curie once said that a scientist must be interested in things, not people. Well, I just didn't have what it takes,'' says June Goodfield, the English scientist-turned-writer who inspired the five-part television series ''Quest for the Killers'' that begins a week from this Tuesday evening at 10 on Channel 13.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: TROUBLED WATERS MOST Long Island families finish up the swimming season on the Labor Day weekend. The Kanofsky family of Melville hopes to start its season today.

title: 'YEAR OF DRAGON' CALLED LIBEL
description: A coalition of Chinese groups has filed a $100 million libel suit charging that MGM/UA studios falsely depicts Chinese as murderous drug traffickers in the movie ''Year of the Dragon.''

title: ANASAZI TIMES IN OLD AMERICA
description: Their ruins are scattered throughout the brushy, sandstone canyons of the Southwest, built on boulders and cliffs and tucked into crevices, the remains of one of the most advanced civilizations of prehistoric America.

title: Reagan Rejects Quotas on Shoes
description: In rejecting a Federal panel's recommendation to protect the ailing domestic shoe industry against the imports that have captured 76 percent of the American market, President Reagan last week put his free-trade principles ahead of Republican political concerns.

title: NEW YORK STAT'S REDUCTION IN VEHICLE FEES BEGINS TODAY
description: A $100 million annual reduction in motor-vehicle registration fees going into effect Sunday will reduce the average motorist's $36 registration cost by a third, Governor Cuomo said.

title: TWO NEW SERIES
description: Two popular stamp series will be continued later this month. One is the topical series of the United States Postal Service and the other is the flag sheets of the United Nations Postal Administration. Both of them follow the tradition of similar issues that received strong collector support in annual ''most popular stamp contests'' published by various stamp publications. These new series will no doubt garner many votes in 1985 tabulations.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Aug. 18 about Bath, England, gave the incorrect price of a double room at the Royal Crescent Hotel. The rate is about $100 ($150 deluxe) for two.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing Nascar Southern 500, Darlington, S.C. A victory by Bill Elliott, who is on the pole position, would be worth a $1 million bonus to him. (Television - ESPN, 1 P.M.) Baseball Yankees vs.

title:
DINING OUT;

BY THE SEA AT BALLY'S PARK PLACE
description: TRUE to the formula of Atlantic City casino dining, Bally's Park Place has a restaurant for everyone from high rollers to day trippers. The coffee shop and cafeterias attract the bus brigades, Prime Place is for steak lovers and By the Sea is the hotel's starched and formal dining room with a Continental menu and higher prices targeted for big spenders.

title: GERHARDT W. HYATT, 69, DIES: EX-CHIEF OF ARMY CHAPLAINS
description: The Rev. Gerhardt W. Hyatt, second vice president of the 2.7-million-member Lutheran Church Missouri Synod who was a former Army Chief of Chaplains, died Friday. He was 69 years old.

title: 450,000 SQ. FT.
description: Within the next five years, Sterling Drug Inc., a worldwide manufacturer and distributor of pharmaceutical and personal-care products, will be leaving the 320,000 square feet it leases on Park Avenue at 40th Street for the new facility it plans to build on a 103-acre country club and golf course in River Vale, N.J.

title: The Competition With Japan
description: It is not my desire or role to defend Japan. I served in Japan in the 1930's and dealt with the Japanese Army in North China and Manchuria, and was its prisoner in 1941 and 1942. Thus I have no romantic illusions (''The Danger From Japan,'' by Theodore H. White, July 28). However, I do have great respect for what Japan has accomplished since Aug. 15, 1945, and fundamentally believe that peace in the Pacific, and accordingly, in the world, depends on how the two of us manage our relations.

title: COUNTY MOVES TO COMPLY WITH VOTE ON APARTHEID
description: THE Westchester County Legislature made its own move against apartheid last week, calling on the county government ''not to do business'' with banking institutions that make loans to the Pretoria Government or to banks that make new loans to private banks in South Africa.

title: Longo, Piasecki Win World Cycling Titles
description: Jeannie Longo of France and Lech Piasecki of Poland won the world open road championships today.

title: PREPARE GIRLS TO ACHIEVE IN MATHEMATICS
description: IF your daughter is able and fails to study at least four years of mathemetics in high school, her personal academic development, her career possibilities and her earnings potential all will be severely limited.

title: MINERS STRIKE IN BOLIVIA OVER ECONOMIC PLAN
description: Bolivia's miners began a 48-hour strike today as labor unrest grew over measures to fight inflation.

title: U.S. Seeks Summit Results
description: A gesture by Washington toward Moscow last week seemed more a case of diplomatic expediency than of letting bygones be bygones. President Reagan and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev are scheduled to meet for the first time on Nov. 19, but prospects are as dim as ever for breakthroughs on major issues like arms control or regional conflicts.

title: Bank Penalized $2.25 Million
description: Ever since Congress began questioning why Federal banking auditors had taken so long to catch on to some big banks' failure to report large cash transactions to Washington, the regulators at the Treasury have been talking tough. Last week, they acted tougher still, imposing civil penalties of $2.25 million on Crocker National Bank of San Francisco, the country's 11th largest, for violating reporting requirements under the Bank Secrecy Act of 1980.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A WOMAN OF GENIUS. By Mary Austin. (Feminist Press, Paper, $8.95.) At last. A turn-of-the-century novel about an independent woman which ends in neither madness nor death.

title: WARNING IS ISSUED ON SEWAGE PLANTS
description: FOR state and local officials, the closing of beaches in Monmouth and Cape May Counties because of bacterial pollution late last month was a dramatic reminder of how the environmental consequences of inadequate sewage treatment have been long ignored.

title: YANKEES TROUNCE ANGELS
description: The sight of Dave Righetti entering the game in the fifth inning was startling, even to Righetti. The sight of Doug Corbett entering the game in the fifth inning turned out to be delightful, for the Yankees.

title: NORTH AMERICAN KALEIDOSCOPE BY RAIL
description: Although passenger rail service in the United States is only a glimmer of what it was half a century ago, many travelers are discovering that today's long-distance trains offer an exceptional opportunity to absorb the American scene.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM GARBO TO POOH CORNER
description: Grand Hotel Starring Greta Garbo, John and Lionel Barrymore, Joan Crawford, Wallace Beery; directed by Edmund Goulding, 1932 MGM/UA Home Video 112 minutes. $39.95 These long-ago Hollywood personalities -some are legend - light up the screen.

title: HECKLER ASSERTS MEDICARE WILL SAVE $1.8 BILLION
description: Margaret M. Heckler, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, says the freeze on Medicare hospital reimbursement rates for 1986 will save more than $1.8 billion without reducing the quality of care for the nation's elderly.

title: MORE DOCTORS JOIN LIMITED-FEE PLAN
description: A STUDY recently completed by the county's Office for the Aging and the Gray Panthers of Westchester shows a 14-percent increase in the number of county physicians accepting ''assignment'' from Medicare patients. This means that these physicians will charge their elderly patients only what Medicare determines to be a reasonable fee for services.

title: DON'T DEBASE A 200-YEAR-OLD TRADITION
description: A RECENT New Yorker cartoon characterizes for me the sentiment of those who would drastically change the historic way we legally compensate victims of dangerous and defective products.

title: STORM SHOWS WICKED SERVE
description: Reporters called it ''Curren's Revenge'' and ''Hurricane Kevin.'' Kevin Curren, the fifth-seeded men's player, had expressed his displeasure with New York City and the National Tennis Center after losing a first-round match to Guy Forget of France in the United States Open. Curren suggested that an A-bomb be dropped on the facility. Well, it wasn't a bomb, but Friday's violent thunderstorm caused quite a bit of damage on the grounds, nonetheless.

title: Saving Newspaper In Greenbelt, Md.
description: GREENBELT, Md., was one of America's first planned communities when it was built in the 1930's, about 10 miles northeast of the District of Columbia. Some volunteers decided the town needed a newsletter, and The News Review was born Nov. 24, 1937.

title: ELISABETH GREENOUGH WEDS ALDEN D. BOOTH
description: Elisabeth Bates Greenough, a daughter of Dr. William Bates Greenough 3d of Providence, R.I., and Baltimore and the late Jane Woodruff Greenough, was married yesterday to Alden David Booth, a son of the Rev. Dr. Newell Snow Booth Jr. and Mary Louise Booth, both of Oxford, Ohio. The bridegroom's father, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Barrington, R.I.

title: PUTTING OFF UNTIL TOMORROW WHAT HAD TO BE DONE YESTEDAY
description: PATRICE MUNSEL sounded as if she had been waiting for the phone to ring or, for that matter, for any other distraction. She was off to Europe that afternoon, she said, and she was packing - but not to worry.

title: QUEENS SCHOOL UNIT REJECTS CITY'S POLICY ON AIDS SCREENING
description: The president of a Queens community school board that voted to bar any student with AIDS from attending regular classes said yesterday that a new citywide policy on school-age children with AIDS did not resolve the issue.

title: CARDS LOSE THIRD STRAIGHT
description: Jose Cruz doubled home the tiebreaking run in the eighth inning and Bob Knepper pitched a five-hitter tonight as the Houston Astros beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 3-1.

title: HEARING SET ON DRUG-TEST PLAN
description: The following article is based on reporting by Jacqueline M. Pisatowski and Michael W. Robinson.

title: HOW TO BEAT THOSE PRE-TAG-SALE BLUES
description: ADAM and Eve were lucky. They made a quick departure. They had no blenders, no television tables, no chipped coffee cups, no schlefera or aloe or philodendron, no outgrown baby clothes, no collections of National Geographic magazine. They had, fortunate progenitors, no need for tag sales. They could take their leaves and run - and there was nothing to be driven to the dump or to store until the next Girl Scout fund-raiser.

title: FOLLOWING THE TRAIL OF HISTORY
description: ERNEST SHAW seems an unlikely time traveler. A tall man in dark trousers, starched white shirt and striped tie, he appears to be an ordinary tour guide. But, as he recounts the story of the day when Benedict Arnold ordered the city of New London burned to the ground, his voice deepens with excitement and the centuries appear to melt away.

title: SOME WILL MISS LEADED GASOLINE
description: I have been driving a peculiar car of late. It is a lovely white coupe, a '63 Buick Special that belongs to my son and was born one year before he was.

title: In Hempstead, Rock Rights Won
description: FREEDOM of speech is not often associated with a seven-foot-high rock, but the twain do meet in downtown Hempstead, L.I.

title: TWO CEREMONIES REFLECT A DIVISION ON WOMEN'S ISSUES
description: FOR the first time in the 13 years that Women's Equality Day has been celebrated in the county, separate ceremonies were held two hours apart last week, re-opening old divisions between County Executive Andrew O'Rourke and some feminist organizations.

title: CHILD CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: THE UNHOLY GRAIL OF GRANVILLE SWIFT
description: DWARF RAPES NUN; FLEES IN UFO By Arnold Sawislak. 212 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $12.95.

title: ALMAGRO STILL LIVES IN THE REENAISSANCE
description: The town of Almagro, in the heart of the Mancha region of Spain south of Madrid, is an anachronism: a flourishing Renaissance community in the 20th century. Almagro's past is marked not by crumbling walls, decaying ruins or tattered traces of former glory. Its vitality stems instead from its urban design, its 16th-century functional architecture and its Corral de Comedias, a theater predating Shakespeare and the dramatists of the Siglo de Oro (Golden Age).

title: BABE RUTH: FAT AND 43 AND NEVER TO PLAY BALL AGAIN
description: LET'S go back in time for a baseball story that comes as a deep, dark secret. I give you Babe Ruth, fat and 43, and suddenly back in the game in 1938 as a first-base coach for the Brooklyn Dodgers, of all teams. After a few months, he asks one small favor. He wants to be activated, to play again. Incredibly, the Dodgers, who are going nowhere, say no. They take the bat out of his hands. You don't believe it? It happened.

title: HARTSDALE
description: TO many people who live there, Hartsdale is a bit of mythical Brigadoon.

title: Connecticut's Bus Problem
description: Just months after New York City transit officials ordered 851 Grumman Flxible buses off the streets because of repeated breakdowns and a fire, Connecticut officials also began an early retirement program for one-third of the state's fleet of Flxibles, The New York Times reported last week.

title: Ivan Klima in Michigan
description: To the Editor:

title: East German Women Win 4 Rowing Events
description: The United States women's national rowing team challenged but never seriously threatened East European and Soviet dominance of the world rowing championships today. The Americans gained two silver and two bronze medals in the nine finals, but the Soviet, Rumanian and East German women captured all six gold medals in the unlimited weight categories.

title: IS POVERTY A CONDITION OR IS IT A DEFINITION?
description: When the Census Bureau last week reported a sharp decline in poverty for 1984, some skeptics, automatically suspicious of anything the Administration says about the status of the poor, asked whether the statistics included the value of noncash benefits such as food stamps, Medicaid and housing subsidies.

title: SWEDEN'S NASTY, SEXIST, RACIST GENIUS
description: STRINDBERG By Michael Meyer. Illustrated. 651 pp. New York: Random House. $24.95.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;

SURVIVING A BATTLE FOR SPRINGSTEEN'S TICKETS
description: ''END up like a dog that's been kicked too much.'' So goes Bruce Springsteen's hit, ''Born in the USA,'' which describes the fate of a returning Vietnam veteran. It might also be an appropriate verse for those who survived the wait and got tickets for his six sold-out concerts this month. For when I finally got the tickets I felt like I had survived a war.

title: PROTEST AT U.S. MISSILE BASE
description: Anti-nuclear demonstrators blocked access to a United States Army Pershing-2 missile base today to mark the 46th anniversary Sunday of the German attack on Poland that began World War II. At least 150 people sat in the road, but there were no violent incidents, and the police took no action, a police spokesman said.

title: SIMEON IS BEST
description: A 185-pound Saint Bernard, Ch. Elba's Simeon Von Mallen, owned by 15-year-old Brandon Baker, a high school sophomore, was named best in a field of 1,174 at the New Brunswick Kennel Club Show in Thompson Park on Friday.

title: CORN OFF THE COB
description: FOR ANYONE WITH CHANCY DENTAL work, corn on the cob poses a problem. But no one need suffer undue humiliation, for the glory of American corn is not the kernel but the creamy liquid inside. Corn kernels, after all, are nothing but biodegradable packaging for what used to be called corn milk.

title: WHEN LADIES CARRIED PARASOLS ON THEIR WAY TO CHURCH
description: ''DIG those crazy costumes'' might be the typical young person's reaction to the parasols and long dresses in the accompanying photo.

title: ALICE O. WHEELER TO MARRY OCT. 19
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard Warren Wheeler of Bronxville, N.Y., and Concord, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter Alice Owens Wheeler to Peter John Morris, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Robert Morris of Sydney, Australia. The wedding is planned for Oct. 19.

title: IN THE THREATENED AREA, 5 MAJOR HURRICANES IN 20 YEARS
description: Over the last 20 years five major hurricanes have struck the area threatened by Hurricane Elena, from Florida to Texas.

title: A TREK FOR VOLUNTARISM LINKS CAMPUS PROJECTS
description: Early last year, when Wayne Meisel told his father about his plan to go on a 1,500-mile trek through 13 Eastern states to interest college students in volunteering for public service projects, his father grimaced.

title: 3 PRIESTS KILLED IN BLAZE AT A RECTORY IN INDIANA
description: Three Roman Catholic priests died today when a fire roared through a rectory and chased back firefighters who tried to rescue the victims.

title: POLITICALLY, SUMMER IS OVER
description: THE Assembly was pulled back from its summer vacation and into the fall election campaign last week by Governor Kean.

title: MOST AMERICANS IN CBS POLL KNOW LITTLE ABOUT APARTHEID
description: Most Americans polled by CBS News said they did not know enough about South African issues to have formed opinions, the network said yesterday.

title:
GARDENING;

PERENNIALS CAN BENEFIT FROM REPLANTING
