description: THE nurseryman's slogan, ''Fall is for planting,'' is especially appropriate when applied to herbaceous perennials. When planted in the fall, they have an opportunity to become well established before winter.

title: FOR FLIGHT SCHOOLS, POPULARLITY GROWS
description: FLYING is growing in popularity for both pleasure and business, and people of all ages, backgrounds and occupations are taking lessons to qualify for licenses, according to flight instructors.

title: BUSINESSMAN IS CREDITED WITH REVIVING MARYLAND'S HORSE RACING INDUSTRY
description: Two years ago, most business executives and politicians in Maryland would have said, ''Frank De Francis who?''

title: 'CROSSOVER DREAMS': A SHOESTRING SUCCESS
description: If the box-office response to the ebullient comedy ''Crossover Dreams'' approximates the enthusiasm of the reviewers, this could turn out to be the year of crossover film makers.

title: FREDERIC JAY GROSS WED TO LAURA A. GERINGER
description: Laura Ann Geringer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Geringer of Merrick and Sag Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Fredric Jay Gross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Gross of Plantation, Fla. Rabbi David Barbalatt performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in South Merrick, L.I.

title: GRETA HESSE IS BRIDE OF DAVID L. BOWDEN
description: The marriage of Greta Anne Hesse, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce E. Hesse of Plymouth, Minn., to David Lloyd Bowden, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Bowden Jr. of Villanova, Pa., and Mantoloking, N.J., took place yesterday at St. Philip the Deacon Lutheran Church in Plymouth. The Rev. David Hoffman performed the ceremony.

title: In Pennsylvania, A Visiting Laborer
description: DON RITTER punched in Tuesday at the Sure Fit Products Company in Bethlehem, Pa., and went to work slicing five-inch fabric rolls for sofa, drapery and bedspread ruffles. Later he helped roll the fabric into tight bundles and load it onto a cart.

title: China and World War II
description: Amid all the World War II battle and victory anniversaries being observed, the Chinese Embassy will hold a cocktail party Sept. 10 to commemorate ''victory in the war of resistance against Japan.'' A spokesman said the event would focus on improved relations since then. Two films are to be shown: one on the rehabilitation of Japanese prisoners of war in China and the other ''The Go Masters,'' a joint postwar undertaking by film makers of both countries that is about the chess-like, noncombative board game, go.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM GARBO TO POOH CORNER
description: Welcome to Pooh Corner, Vol. III Walt Disney Home Video 111 minutes. $49.95 A number of television programs for children have been repackaged and released on video cassettes.

title: PARTY HEADS CLASH ON EFFECT OF G.O.P. TRIAL
description: THE chairmen of the Nassau County Republican and Democratic Committees differed sharply last week over how the kickback trial of Republicans would affect county political races this fall.

title: STRUMMING A LAMENT FOR THAI LOSERS
description: The little girl in the tattered dress with half a sash, a new possession tucked firmly under a tiny arm, marched down the busy sidewalk with the stride of a child on an important errand. Her destination was a windowless lean-to at the edge of a lumberyard where her family sat on cast-off bricks and boards. There, on the dirt floor, she unpacked her incongruous, shrink-wrapped treasure: a pink plastic dollhouse sofa and chair, a table and a lamp.

title: KOHDE-KILSCH AIMS FOR RECOGNITION
description: According to computer rankings released just before the start of the United States Open tennis championships last week, only four women in the world are playing better tennis than Claudia Kohde-Kilsch. But when the company that pays her to wear their tennis outfits hosted an autograph party for her at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadow on Friday afternoon, nobody came.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN NEWPORT
description: Newport, founded in 1639, was already a summer resort of note when a Georgia planter, George Noble Jones, abandoned the city's hotel colony in 1839 to build the first summer ''cottage'' on Bellevue Avenue. He was followed by generations of robber barons, yachtsmen and society figures who made Newport one of the world's premier summer addresses.

title: OFFICIAL AT AMERICAN U. GUILITY IN WIFE'S DEATH
description: William Evans-Smith, administrator of American University, has been found guilty of second-degree murder in the strangling of his wife, and the Loudoun County jury has recommended a five-year prison sentence. Judge Carlton Penn of Circuit Court could hand down a shorter term. Mr. Evans-Smith, 65 years old. was a retired Army colonel and head of the foreign studies program at the Washington university.

title: MOWATT SIDELINED FOR ENTIRE SEASON
description: Before the Giants could celebrate their first perfect preseason record in a dozen years, they received the bad news today: They have lost Zeke Mowatt, one of the National Football League's premier tight ends, for the season.

title: THE TIGHT NEW RULES ON LOANS
description: WHEN the Federal National Mortgage Association announced last month that it was tightening income requirements for anyone buying a home with less than a 10 percent down payment, the move seemed, at first glance, to deal a particularly cruel blow to lower-income buyers and their dreams of home ownership.

title: Bed and Breakfast And L.I. Hospitality
description: The article ''Bed-and-Breakfasts Challenged'' [July 21] brought to mind several stories about the growth of this movement in Britain. Reader response pieces have, I've observed, been highly favorable.

title: ACID ESCAPES AT PLANT SCHEDULED FOR CLOSING
description: About 2,000 gallons of sulfuric acid escaped today from a collapsed tank at a chemical plant, just a few hours after its owner announced that it was closing the operation.

title: THE PARK 'DROON': SPINE-TINGLER TURNED INTO RIB-TICKLER
description: Vladimir Nabokov venerated Charles Dickens for his ability to make the reader shiver with excitement. As he said, in reference to matters Dickensian, ''Let us worship the spine and its tingle.'' By that he meant not only the cliffhanging quality of the prose, but its ''esthetic vibrancy.'' The musical version of Dickens's last and incomplete novel, ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood,'' which has been entertaining audiences at Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival in Central Park, has many virtues, beginning with its exemplary cast of actor-singers, but those virtues do not include anything that could be described as spine-tingling. More accurately, one might call the show rib-tickling.

title: A RAIDER TAKES COMMAND AT AMF
description: IRWIN JACOBS'S ten-year ascendency on the takeover ladder is filled with tales of triumph, miscues and setbacks. But one incident sticks out firmly in his mind.

title: CARRIED AWAY
description: The Price of Junkets Was it really necessary for the Air Force to fly Representative Bill Alexander of Oklahoma to Brazil in a C-9 transport - at a cost of $56,364 - so he could study alcohol fuel production? Whatever the merits of the dispute between the Congressman and the Defense Department over how the embarrassing trip was arranged, the need to curb Congressional junketing seems clearer than ever.

title: THE DREAM FULFILLED
description: A CERTAIN PEOPLE American Jews and Their Lives Today. By Charles E. Silberman. 458 pp. New York: Summit Books. $19.95.

title: WITH EXCEPTIONS, DRINKING AGE IS 21
description: A TWO-TIERED legal drinking age in effect as of today is already causing confusion among retailers and officials and anger among some 20-year-olds.

title: LOON WOMAN IN THE LONG AGO
description: THE MYTHOLOGY OF NORTH AMERICA By John Bierhorst. Illustrated. 259 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $13.

title: TIPS AT ATOM PLANT: KEEP INSPECTORS IN DARK
description: Workers at a nuclear power plant whose owner had just been indicted for falsifying information were advised by a consulting concern in 1983 that certain Federal rules were best handled by giving information to Federal regulators only at the last minute.

title: Remember Flight 007
description: Excerpt from an article by Thomas Maertens, a State Department officer who specializes in Soviet affairs, published in the September issue of the Foreign Service Journal, a magazine for professional Foreign Service officers:

title: VIDEO DISKS CATCH ON AT THE OFFICE
description: THE MOST ubiquitous purveyor of information today is the video screen. While its most common form is the television, its influence extends far beyond entertainment and the evening news. Screens seem to be everywhere, displaying information above airline counters, in railroad and bus terminals and in hotels. Certainly, no one considers a television threatening.

title: NOTTINGHAM BOWS, 3-1, TO MANCHESTER UNITED
description: Manchester United scored a 3-1 victory at Nottingham Forest today to stay unbeaten in the English soccer season and remain atop the standing.

title: CHRONICLERS OF THE STATE'S 'FIRSTS'
description: THE State of Connecticut is in many ways a dwarf.

title: INMANY SOCIET SCHOOLS, MONEY TALKS
description: According to an account he swears is true, a young part-time comedian prepared thoroughly in the traditional manner for his recent entrance exam at a local institute: he had a friend slip the examiner an appropriate bribe. But something went terribly wrong. When he winked and told the examiner, ''I'm Abulbegov,'' the examiner answered coldly, ''So what? I'm Professor Petrov.'' Back he went to his friend, the young man said, and ''prepared'' even more thoroughly the second time around. He passed; indeed, this time it was the esteemed professor who winked and told him, ''Welcome to our institute.''

title: PRO-ARAFAT PALESTINIAN SLAIN IN SOUTHERN LEBANON
description: A masked man with a silencer-equipped pistol assassinated a Palestinian guerrilla leader loyal to Yasir Arafat on Friday night, the police in the southern port city of Sidon said today.

title: IRAN SEALS SOME BORDER AREAS TO COMBAT DRUG SMUGGLING
description: Iran said today that it had sealed off some border areas to stem the flow of narcotics into the country.

title: BUSES
description: To the Editor: Buses used to a be a great means of long-distance transportation within the United States, but they aren't anymore.

title:
ANTIQUES;

COUNTRY ITEMS BEING SHOWN AT SALISBURY
description: IF you live in an early Connecticut house and would like a true 18th-century candle stand to light the parlor or kitchen, you might want to consult with Larry Foster and his partner, Jack Lanergan, at the Salisbury Flea Market on Saturday.

title: WINNER OF $1 MILLION IS ACCUSED OF LARCENY
description: A Bronx man who won more than $1 million in the state lottery three years ago has been charged with stealing from a convenience store owned by his sister and brother-in-law, authorities said.

title: A CHURCH IN SEARCH OF ITSELF
description: IT IS INDEED A STRANGE FELLOWSHIP OF BELIEVERS THAT CAN, IF NOT BOAST OF, AT LEAST TOLERATE:

title:
THEATER REVIEW;

STAGE: ''FIFTH OF JULY''
description: LANFORD WILSON'S ''Fifth of July'' is one in what is currently a trilogy of plays about the Talley family of Lebanon, Mo. Mr. Wilson, a year-round resident of Sag Harbor, won the Pulitzer Prize for ''Talley's Folly,'' and he says there are at least two more plays in his mind about the Talleys.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HERE BE DRAGONS. By Sharon Kay Penman. (Holt, $19.95.) Branded by sobriquets such as John Lackland and John Softsword, remembered as the ruler who signed the Magna Carta under extreme duress, King John of England has never been one of history's favorite sons.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: STRIKEMAKERS & STRIKEBREAKERS By Sidney Lens. Illustrated. 170 pp. New York: Lodestar/E. P. Dutton. $14.95. (Ages 12 and up) SCHOOL textbooks so often convey a sense that American labor history is just one strike after another. But violent strikes and strikebreaking are the vehicles, not the essence, of the labor movement, and listing them is generally a poor way to teach labor's story. It is Sidney Lens's achievement in this study that he successfully presents a notion of the theory and justice of unionism in a democratic society.

title: THE LONG BATTLE FOR APPROVAL OF CITY CENTER TOWER
description: ITS creator calls the 72-story City Center Tower - the political, financial and cultural package emerging in concrete in midtown Manhattan - the most complicated building transaction in the history of New York real estate. And he may just be right.

title: LISA S. ROGOVIN WEDS IN CAPITAL
description: Lisa Shea Rogovin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell Rogovin of Washington, was married there yesterday to Timothy J. Lindon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elick Lindon of Wilmette, Ill. Rabbi Harold White performed the ceremony at the Cosmos Club.

title: PERU JOINS ATTACK ON COCAINE TRADE
description: After years in which Peruvian authorities chose to ignore the fast-expanding cocaine business, the country's new President, Alan Garcia Perez, has ordered a frontal attack on the problem.

title: ON THE FARM, WHAT COUNTS IS SEEING COSTS COMING
description: By 7:30 each morning, Jim and Elizabeth Krenzer have been at work for two hours milking their 60 cows. With a pail of fresh milk in hand, they head toward their white frame farmhouse for breakfast with their two teen-age children.

title: BERTRAND RECALLS YACHTING VICTORY
description: John Bertrand may have won the America's Cup for Australia. But when it comes time for sailing with his family, his renown as a skipper does not get him much time at the tiller.

title: PHYSICIAN TO WED AILEEN O'ROURKE, REGISTERED NURSE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Andrew P. O'Rourke of Yonkers and Jupiter, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Aileen Bernadette O'Rourke to Dr. Eugene Caracciolo, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Camillo Caracciolo of New Rochelle, N.Y. The wedding is planned for Oct. 13.

title: THE ENDURING OBSESSION: DON SHULA'S NEED TO WIN
description: HEAT AND HUMIDITY grip Miami every day of a long summer that stretches past September to the last weeks of October. In July and August, the discomfort index is as high as the new downtown skyline. The heat is even more oppressive in the northern reaches of the city, in a decaying suburb-turned-ghetto called Opa-Locka, a forgotten 1920's oasis of ersatz Moorish architecture and littered streets with whimsical names like Ali Baba Boulevard. In this setting, the Miami Dolphins, the 1984 American Football Conference champions, prepare for another season on the athletic fields of St. Thomas University, a Roman Catholic campus of low, concrete-block buildings and scrub pine.

title: PATCHING CRACKS BEFORE PAINTING
description: PATCHING cracks, nail holes and other defects in walls and ceilings before they are painted or papered is essential for a smooth, blemish-free surface.

title: BONN NAMES NATO ENVOY
description: West Germany's Ambassador to Israel, Niels Hansen, has been appointed envoy to NATO in a shakeup caused by the West German spy scandal, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: 3 BIG COMPANIES PLAN TO RESTRUCTURE
description: A wave of restructurings hit the corporate world as big companies tried to respond more quickly to market conditions. Union Carbide, facing severe financial problems because of a series of chemical leaks and trying to cope with overtures by GAF, said it would take about a $1 billion charge against earnings as it cuts its white-collar work force by 15 percent, shuts unprofitable plants and takes other write-offs. Carbide is consolidating 12 chemical divisions into 7, and reassigned some top executives.

title: SUB-SAHARAN BALANCE SHEET
description: AFRICA The People and Politics of an Emerging Continent. By Sanford J. Ungar. 527 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: ELISE HALLARMAN TO MARRY OCT. 6
description: Dr. and Mrs. Edwin Hallarman of Roslyn, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elise Hope Hallarman, to Robert Charles Greenberg, a son of Sali Greenberg of Westport, Conn., and Frank Greenberg of Great Neck, L.I. The wedding is planned for Oct. 6. Miss Hallarman, an assistant buyer of men's outerwear for J. C. Penney & Company in New York, graduated from Emory University and received an M.B.A. degree from New York University.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: THE Rev. Frederick La Garde of Paterson remembers the last New Jersey appearance of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. well.

title: FILIPINO RIGHTS LAWYERS MENACED, BAR TEAM SAYS
description: An international team of lawyers has expressed ''grave concern'' about the treatment of human rights lawyers in the Philippines, saying they have been arrested, detained and sometimes killed in recent months.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HIGH ADVENTURE. By Donald E. Westlake. (Mysterious Press, $15.95.) Donald Westlake is a veteran yarn-spinner, and once again he spins true to form, though here the yarn is perhaps too thin.

title: POETS WITTY AND ELEGIAC
description: LATE SETTINGS By James Merrill. 87 pp. New York: Atheneum. Cloth, $12.95. Paper, $6.95. NEW SELECTED POEMS By Howard Moss. 296 pp. New York: Atheneum. Cloth, $20. Paper, $10.95. NO HEAVEN By David St. John. 54 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. Cloth, $13.95. Paper, $5.95. OF all living poets, British or American, none is more like W. H. Auden than James Merrill.

title:
AS THE MAYORAL PRIMARY ROUNDS THE FINAL TURN;

ROBERT PRICE OF KOCH: ABOVE THE FRAY
description: IN February, when City Council President Carol Bellamy and Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr. announced that they would challenge Mayor Koch, who is seeking re-election to a third term, The Week in Review asked three Republican political strategists to outline what tactics they would use if they were managing the campaigns. Last week, with campaign for the Sept. 10 Democratic primary entering its final days, Alan Finder, an editor of The Review, asked the same three consultants to review the race. Roger J. Stone Jr. is a political consultant who was in charge of New York and 13 other Northeastern states for the Reagan-Bush campaign in 1980 and 1984; among his clients this year is Governor Kean of New Jersey, who is running for re-election. Richard J. Behn is president of Numbercrunchers Inc., a political consulting company, and was communications director for Lewis E. Lehrman's 1982 New York gubernatorial campaign. Robert Price, the president of Price Communications Corporation, was Deputy Mayor under John V. Lindsay. Excerpts follow.

title: LISA MELCHER PLANS TO WED
description: An Oct. 5 wedding is planned by Elizabeth Hale Melcher and Bernard Joseph Clarke Jr., her mother, Eleanor Dowling Melcher of Shaker Heights, Ohio, has announced.

title: TEACHING TALL BUILDINGS TO KEEP THEIR BALANCE
description: The skyscraper model swayed precariously as a seven-and-a-half-ton table pitched and shook beneath it in a laboratory simulation of an earthquake. The tremors ceased, and then a researcher prepared to repeat the experiment. But this time he ''turned on'' the model, activating a network of computerized sensors. The building stood steady as a rock as the table shook.

title: FLIGHT ATTENDANTS VOTE TO ACCEPT FAN AM PACT
description: Flight attendants of Pan American World Airways have avoided a strike by narrowly voting to accept a contract with drastically reduced benefits, the International Union of Flight Attendants announced today.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE MARCH TO THE SEA AND BEYOND: Sherman's Troops in the Savannah and Carolinas Campaigns. By Joseph T. Glatthaar. (New York University, $27.95.) Lessons abound for 20th-century warriors in this instructive study of the personal and military conduct of the enlisted men in the Union Army in the middle of the 19th century. Joseph T. Glatthaar, who teaches history at the Command and General Staff College's Combat Studies Institute in Fort Leavenworth, Kan., assembles the story of Gen. William T. Sherman's troops in their own words as they drove through Georgia and South Carolina and destroyed the Confederacy. Some of the main lessons are from Sherman himself: war is total and death-defying, an enemy's industry and property should not be spared, forget chivalrous conduct toward civilians. But the major lesson to be gained from the book concerns what integrates a soldier into a fighting unit. According to the quotations here from diaries and letters, the answer is not saluting but experience, mutual respect and camaraderie with officers. ''At first glance,'' the author writes, ''the men looked more like a mob than an army. They were an unkempt, boisterous, seemingly unruly lot, in no way resembling the stereotypical professional army. But Sherman's men took pride in their ability to endure all hardships and still achieve in battle.'' Officers and soldiers fraternized; generals were called by their first names. Mr. Glatthaar also covers whites' attitudes toward blacks in Union blue (they were generally admired but there were pockets of prejudice); the wartime election (the soldiers were overwhelmingly for President Lincoln); the destruction in the South (unsparing).

title: NEW LIFE ON CD FOR THE MUSIC OF DELIUS
description: Like other brilliantly orchestrated works of the late 19th and early 20th centuries, those of Frederick Delius are served particularly well by compact disks. Till the present, the composer has been represented only by some of his shorter orchestral pieces on part of one such release. A second recording devoted only to his music has now appeared. It is doubly welcome because it returns to the recorded repertory, ''The Song of the High Hills,'' a work not available recently, and adds the first orchestral recordings of nine songs (Unicorn Kanchana DKP (CD) 9029). To those who respond to Delius's music, it is a superb disk.

title: TOWNS REDISCOVERING THEIR TRAIN STATIONS
description: BUILT to reflect the power, wealth and aspirations of their communities, train stations were the Industrial Age equivalents of medieval cathedrals. Through the first half of this century, they were the busiest and most imposing structures in many towns across the state.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in today's New York Times Magazine on the Episcopal church contains an incorrect reference to the ordination of women as priests. They are not ordained by bishops in 18 of the 98 continental United States dioceses.

title: BALLET PARTNERS: WHY THE MAGIC FADED
description: ''Choreography, like love,'' the choreographer Maurice Bejart once mused, ''is done in pairs.'' The bravura of a solo, the uniformity of a corps de ballet, each has its place, but it is in the pas de deux, or dance for two, that the heart of the ballet lies.

title: The Competition With Japan
description: Whether couched in the glorious prose of Theodore White or the ugly curses of unemployed steel workers, the message is still the same - we won the war, why are they winning the peace?

title: I.R.A. SAYS IT KILLED CATHOLIC POLICE INSPECTOR
description: Two Irish Republican Army gunmen shot and killed a police inspector in an ambush outside his home in Northern Ireland early today, the police said.

title: MAN HELD IN COAST DEATHS AFTER CAPTURE BY CITIZENS
description: Angry residents of this city's east side today ran down and caught a man whom the police later identified as their suspect in the ''night stalker'' killings of at least 16 people in California since February.

title: ON MIRANDA
description: 'I think the idea that the police cannot ask questions of the person that knows most about the crime is an infamous decision.

title: A LIVING DEMONSTRATION OF LIVE AID
description: ENTERING a hospital for surgery is never an easy matter. Even though my 16-year-old son's leg operation was not considered serious, it was a necessary procedure if Todd were to have full use and control of his body.

title: 65% IN POLL APPROVE REAGAN'S PERFORMANCE
description: The latest Gallup Poll shows that 65 percent of the American people approve of President Reagan's job performance.

title: MARTIN CRITICIZES SYSTEM
description: Billy Martin, who has had an ostensibly amicable relationship with George Steinbrenner since he returned as manager earlier this season, took his first verbal swipe at the Yankee owner yesterday. Martin's comments concerned what he saw as a need for minor league reinforcements for the stretch run.

title:
ART;

DOMESTIC ITEMS THAT TELL OF OUR HERITAGE
description: INCREASINGLY, entire wings of museums are being devoted to American art, as Americans have more of a desire to understand their heritage. The Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford opened three floors consisting of 17 rooms devoted to American art last summer. The first anniversary of that opening is a good time to make a quick survey of what the American Galleries contain.

title: THE VCR POSES A THREAT
description: ''MY kids saw 'Return of the Nerds' eight times last week,'' my co-worker Annie confided the other day. Annie and many of my other friends have VCR's that record programs they might have missed during the day while working or that they use to watch an incredible array of films from those specially geared to children to outright ''adult porn.''

title: OPERA: 'MAGIC FLUTE'
description: Despite its perennial popularity throughout the world and despite its having been recorded dozens of times and transformed into a film by Ingmar Bergman, Mozart's ''Magic Flute'' remains something of an enigma to most audiences. The opera contains some of the composer's most immediate and seraphic music with a libretto that seems, at first, incomprehensible twaddle. What are we to make of this menagerie of characters - these feathered birdcatchers, vengeful queens, cackling old crones and spitting serpents?

title: FARM ECONOMIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Croly and The New Republic
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILD CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: 7 CHILEAN POLICEMEN ORDERED HELD IN 3 SLAYINGS
description: Seven paramilitary policemen, including two colonels, have been arrested in connection with the slayings of three Communist Party opponents of the Government, the police said today.

title: A NEW MOTIVEIN WEST SIDE COUPLE'S SLAYING
description: It had become the nightly custom of 67-year-old William Pardenilla to meet his wife at 44th Street and Ninth Avenue as she returned by taxi from her job as a cleaning woman.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE GLORY GAME. By Janet Dailey. (Poseidon, $16.95.) The game of the title is polo, which people do not play for money or great fame but for its own sake.

title: THE NEW YORK IRREGULARS: ANGLING IN ON ODD SITES
description: WHEN the Egyptians raised pyramids and obelisks in the desert, they created the basic rules of geometry for builders. Today, those ancient rules are being tested and contorted as never before as New York developers and architects plot construction on small or oddly shaped sites in an ever more crowded urban landscape.

title: Union Carbide Plans Cutbacks And Closings
description: Well before the stunning run of accidents at Union Carbide Corporation facilities in India and West Virginia, many financial analysts were warning that the company, beset by stiff competition and rumors that it had become a prime takeover target, was overdue for a drastic steamlining. Last week, the company belatedly announced a far-reaching plan for cutting costs.

title: ROCKLAND TO ELECT FIRST COUNTY CHIEF
description: This fall Rockland County voters will choose their first county executive, and an important step in the process will take place Sept. 10 as Democrats, the majority party in the county, select their candidate in a primary.

title: CONFESSIONS OF A PAGE-STAYER, STALLER, STOPPER
description: WHILE some reviewers use the expression ''page-turner'' to recommend a book, I think the word has just the opposite connotation. An eagerness to turn the page suggests that there is nothing on it to hold you. Yet the more I like a book, the more reluctant I am to turn the page. Lovers, even book lovers, tend to cling. No one-night stands or ''reads'' for them.

title: A FIRE UNIT CONFRONTS TOXIC PERIL
description: As fire and smoke filled Grand Central Terminal Wednesday morning, a major concern among fire officials was the potential for PCB contamination from burning electrical transformers.

title: New Pact for Anderson
description: The Detroit Tigers have extended the contract of Manager Sparky Anderson by two years, through the 1988 season. Anderson, 51, joined the Tigers in June 1979, signing a contract that ran through 1986.

title: JAZZ
description: The annual Village Jazz Festival saves its major extravaganza for Labor Day on Monday, giving fans of new jazz a chance to spend the holiday afternon and evening sampling select groups. From 2 P.M. to about 1 A.M. at Sweet Basil (88 Seventh Avenue South, 242-1785), five groups rarely heard in clubs will perform; the lineup is promising, mixing representatives from the 1960's and 1980's avant-garde.

title: The Heat Is On In South Lebanon
description: By its own special standards, Beirut was relatively calm last week, with only periodic shelling and occasional kidnappings to mar the latest Syrian-sponsored cease-fire. But in southern Lebanon there was an upsurge of military activity.

title: ON THE SCENT OF TREASON
description: THE RED FOX By Anthony Hyde. 321 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95. THE valuable core of Anthony Hyde's first novel, ''The Red Fox,'' is its meditation on idealistic Westerners who spy for totalitarian governments. The author unhesitantly defines such idealism as treason - not pure and simple, perhaps, but shameful all the same. To read that lesson in ''The Red Fox'' is a refreshing experience, given the proliferation of books and films - for example, Robert Littell's novel ''The Amateur'' or ''The Jigsaw Man,'' starring Laurence Olivier and Michael Caine - where the fact is in various ways obfuscated. Stripped to its essentials, the argument of such works goes that some British lord or American intellectual was disappointed with democracy (or even with some Government agency), saw the light from Moscow and acted for the enemy in good faith - therefore he can and should be exonerated.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM GARBO TO POOH CORNER
description: The Sleeping Beauty With the Kirov Ballet, featuring Irina Kolpakova, Sergei Berezhnoi, Lubov Kunakova and Vladimir Lopukhov Thorn EMI/HBO 135 minutes. $59.93 This Kirov Ballet production of ''The Sleeping Beauty,'' one of the masterworks of 19th-century ballet, was filmed in 1983 and so offers a contemporary performance by dancers on whom tradition sits lightly but strongly.

title: ANNE MCHUGH BRIDE OF JAMES KEEGAN WALL
description: At St. Luke's Roman Catholic Church in Westport, Conn., yesterday Anne Elizabeth McHugh, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James L. McHugh of Westport, was married to James Keegan Wall, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Wall of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas J. Driscoll performed the ceremony.

title: PICTURE STIRS COMET WATCHERS
description: AN amateur astronomer from Stamford is apparently the first person in Connecticut to photograph Halley's comet since 1910.

title: BILL BROCK BECOMES THE ODD MAN IN
description: It was intended to help mend the Administration's frayed ties with the civil rights community, Labor Department officials insist. In June, at the convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Bill Brock told delegates that ''this country is going to have to have some form of affirmative action for the foreseeable future'' to overcome the ''remarkable disadvantage'' to which blacks were once subjected.

title: Delaware: Pigs Eat a Building
description: THE University of Delaware needs $40,000 from the state because pigs are eating its swine research and demonstration building.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE administrator of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency's Region II office, Christopher J. Daggett, has objected to part of an item in the July 28 Environment column, saying it would ''only serve to undermine the cooperation between E.P.A. and the affected public that is essential to cleaning up [hazardous-waste] sites quickly, safely and to the satisfaction of all concerned.''

title: Fish Story
description: BY popular vote, the humuhumu-nukunuku-a-pua'a became Hawaii's state fish last fall, and doubtless you've asked yourself what effect this has had on the state.

title: ART
description: At a time of the year when most of the dealers' galleries give way to inanition, Serge Sabarsky has carried on as usual with his exhibition of paintings by Egon Schiele, which can be seen through Sept. 14. The short and tumultous life of Egon Schiele (1890-1918) coincided with the decline, the downfall and the subsequent dismantling of the unified central Europe that had constituted - sometimes willingly, sometimes not - the Hungarian Empire.

title:
GARDENING;

PERENNIALS CAN BENEFIT FROM REPLANTING
description: THE nurseryman's slogan, ''Fall is for planting,'' is especially appropriate when applied to herbaceous perennials. When planted in the fall, they have an opportunity to become well established before winter.

title: Federal Judge Indicted
description: The way Judge Walter L. Nixon Jr. tells it, his investment in oil wells was just a business deal. But to the special grand jury investigating public corruption in Mississippi, the wells paid off so handsomely for the Federal district judge before he ever put up any cash that there must have been more to it.

title: SEPT. 28 WEDDING FOR MISS TEMKIN
description: Cindy Temkin and Frederic Jay Leonard plan to be married Sept. 28. The future bride is the daughter of Victor Temkin of New York and Susan Baer of Scarsdale, N.Y., who have announed her engagement to the son of Stephen Leonard of Albertson, L.I., and Eleanor Leonard of New York and Amagansett, L.I.

title: The Competition With Japan
description: Theodore White's article is a brilliant and swashbuckling indictment of the economic policies of Japan and the world trading system created by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). He gives Clausewitz a new dimension by treating business as an extension of war by other means.

title: CABLE TV
description: Bravo has an interesting trio of 1984 movies as cable premieres this week, starting with Sergei Leone's four-hour ''Once Upon a Time in America.'' This is the director's homage to the American gangster movie -a richly textured saga of Brooklyn Jewish youths who become legendary mobsters.

title: Recent Sales
description: Fanwood $129,700 *2* 93 Chetwood Terrace *2* 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 48-year-old Cape; *2* fieldstone facade, built-in bookcases, fenced yard; *2* taxes $2,450. Florham Park $160,000 *2* 28 Orchard Road *2* 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 33-year-old split-level; *2* 2-zone heat, recreation room; *2* taxes $1,658. Irvington $72,000 *2* 60 Lindsley Avenue *2* 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, older two-family rowhouse; *2* basement family room and workshop; *2* taxes $1,850. Millburn $135,500 *2* 750 Ridgewood Road *2* 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; *2* brick front, 1-car attached garage, attic; *2* taxes $2,529. Ringwood $127,500 *2* 232 Skyland Road *2* 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 55-year-old log cabin; *2* living room with fireplace, den, 2-car garage; *2* taxes $3,497. Short Hills $165,000 *2* 58 Elmwood Place *2* 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; *2* den, fireplace; *2* taxes $2,999. OTHER AREAS Easton, Conn. $181,000 *2* 86 Bayberry Lane *2* 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old ranch; *2* in-ground swimming pool, overlooking watershed land, 3.1 acres; *2* taxes $3,350. Mount Vernon, N.Y. $220,000 *2* 40 Carwall Avenue *2* 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 55-year-old stone/ stucco Tudor/Norman; *2* eat-in kitchen, den, second-floor sitting room, *2* flagstone patio, 58- by 100-foot lot; *2* taxes $2,580. Bay Shore, L.I. $60,000 *2* 1465 Fifth Avenue *2* 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 100-year-old colonial; dining room, *2* eat-in-kitchen, Florida room, 2-car garage; *2* taxes $2,700.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest: COME AWAY. By Myra Cohn Livingston. Illustrated by Irene Haas. Atheneum/Aladdin. Paper, $4.95. (Ages 3 and up) Late one afternoon two little children slip away from the city streets and into a park where they have a small-scale, slightly magical, adventure before the sun sets.

title: THE TV COMMERCIAL TRIES ON SOME DISGUISES
description: MARK'S TV routine is winding down. After a series of one-liners, the young comedian describes what it's like being a kid and riding in the family car. Finally, he segues from the car radio - they played it so low ''it was like they were playing it for the engine'' - to coffee:

title: L.I.R.R. SEEKING TO REPLACE TRESTLES
description: IF a Long Island Rail Road plan goes through, Long Beach passengers will no longer have to cross Reynolds Channel on trains that rattle and sway along a wooden trestle for a quarter of a mile or that crawl at a snail's pace over a swing bridge.

title: GIACOMETTI: PORTRAIT OF A HAUNTED, ELOQUENT SCULPTOR
description: Alberto Giacometti remains in many ways a legendary figure. He was an articulate, self-confident and well-informed artist whose sculptures and paintings are ravaged by uncertainty and doubt. His intelligence, independence and generosity fascinated artists and writers like Andre Breton, Jean Genet, Pablo Picasso and Jean-Paul Sartre. His familiar but exceptionally elusive work has left a mark on painters and sculptors as different as David Smith, Louise Bourgeois, Barnett Newman, Susan Rothenberg, Mark di Suvero and Bryan Hunt.

title:
PERSONAL FINANCE;

GETTING A TOEHOLD IN THE HOUSING MARKET
description: JEFFREY KATZ, a 30-year-old attorney, was renting a large house overlooking Lake Michigan in Beverly Shores, Ind., when the owner suddenly offered him a chance to buy. ''It was a great deal,'' Mr. Katz recalled, but there was one little hitch. He could not come up with $55,000 in cash for the down payment and closing costs, nor could he handle the $2,300 a month in mortgage payments, taxes and insurance for the $250,000 home.

title:
AS THE MAYORAL PRIMARY ROUNDS THE FINAL TURN;

RICHARD BEHN ON FARELL: SEARCHING FOR A THEME
description: IN February, when City Council President Carol Bellamy and Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr. announced that they would challenge Mayor Koch, who is seeking re-election to a third term, The Week in Review asked three Republican political strategists to outline what tactics they would use if they were managing the campaigns. Last week, with campaign for the Sept. 10 Democratic primary entering its final days, Alan Finder, an editor of The Review, asked the same three consultants to review the race. Roger J. Stone Jr. is a political consultant who was in charge of New York and 13 other Northeastern states for the Reagan-Bush campaign in 1980 and 1984; among his clients this year is Governor Kean of New Jersey, who is running for re-election. Richard J. Behn is president of Numbercrunchers Inc., a political consulting company, and was communications director for Lewis E. Lehrman's 1982 New York gubernatorial campaign. Robert Price, the president of Price Communications Corporation, was Deputy Mayor under John V. Lindsay. Excerpts follow.

title: George Sand's Children
description: To the Editor:

title: SITUATION COMEDIES TACKLE NEWSCASTS
description: One approach to building an empire, it seems, relies on ''total nonsense - comedy written strictly for entertainment, and not with any redeeming value.''

title: Libraries Proposed As Cultural Centers
description: The Aug. 4 letter from Milli Janz urging that every community have a cultural center struck a resonant note because for years I have advocated designating public libraries - a uniquely American institution - as community cultural centers.

title: LANGER AND BRAND TIED
description: Bernhard Langer of West Germany sank a 5-foot birdie putt at the 18th hole today to move into a tie for the lead with Britain's Gordon Brand Jr. after three rounds of the $280,000 European Open.

title: PROVIDENCE LOSING A BRIDGE TO GAIN A RIVERBANK
description: Two rivers will be moved and the world's widest bridge will be torn down as part of $145 million in government projects already beginning to transform the heart of this city.

title: STREETWISE IN LONDON
description: Mincing Lane. Old Jewry.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SEEDS OF THE SEVENTIES: Values, Work, and Commitment in Post-Vietnam America. By Arthur Stein. (University of Rhode Island/University Press of New England, Cloth, $18.

title: Money, Money, Money
description: Hard-core Republicans have done double takes lately upon receiving solicitations for Senate campaign donations playfully disguised as dunning notices announcing that they have ''lapsed'' as contributors in good standing. Actually the cheeky ''invoice'' approach is a measure of the confidence that managers of the National Republican Senatorial Committee have in their perennial contributors who are being asked to duplicate their previous contributions as an ''amount due.''

title: RED SOX DELVE INTO CAUSES OF THEIR MANY 1984 PROBLEMS
description: WHEN the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox began the first of two consecutive weekend series Aug. 9, only three games separated them in the standing. As the teams entered play yesterday, only three weeks later, the Red Sox languished 14 games behind the Yankees. And instead of figuring out how to overcome the division-leading Toronto Blue Jays, the Red Sox brass spent the past week trying to figure out how to come back from this season next season.

title: CUOMO SEEKS CURB ON LILCO'S CHARGES FOR SHOREHAM TESTS
description: Governor Cuomo moved yesterday to prevent the Long Island Lighting Company from charging its electric customers $150 million for the extra costs of low-power testing if the Shoreham nuclear plant is ultimately abandoned.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: With the season for picking cranberries approaching, bog owners in the southern part of the state are worried that their crops may be contaminated by toxic and cancer-causing substances as a result of dumping near their grounds. In addition, some of them learned last week that the Federal Environmental Protection Agency has refused to release more than $750,000 in Superfund money to help combat the threat.

title:
GARDENING;

PERENNIALS CAN BENEFIT FROM REPLANTING
description: THE nurseryman's slogan, ''Fall is for planting,'' is especially appropriate when applied to herbaceous perennials. When planted in the fall, they have an opportunity to become well established before winter.

title: ANTHONY JAMES SIMPSON, EXECUTIVE, MARRIED TO WENDY ANN WOLSTONCROFT
description: The marriage of Wendy Ann Wolstoncroft, an account executive with Doyle Dane Bernbach, the advertising agency in New York, and Anthony James Simpson, a vice president of Salomon Brothers in New York, took place yesterday at the Lotos Club in New York. Algernon D. Black, leader emeritus of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, performed the ceremony.

title: A Correction
description: Two picture captions in early editions of The Week in Review last Sunday identifying publishers who commented on the Moscow Book Fair were transposed. The photograph at the bottom of the page was of Robert Bernstein, chairman of Random House, and the photograph near the top of the page was of Brooks Thomas, the president of Harper & Row.

title: HOUSES IN THE SUN
description: THE CARIBBEAN, THE PLACE IMMEDIATELY brings to mind specific colors, arranged in a specific way. Blue above, blue below. White for the beach, green for the coconut palms. Dominating all, the gold of the sun.

title: THE NEXT NEW YORK - AND THE NEXT
description: The brightness of New York's economic future and the quality of life for all its residents depends on the ability of its youth to fill the service-oriented, white-collar jobs the next decade will bring. That, in turn, depends on education, and the candidates in the Sept. 10 primary can be judged, most importantly, by how they propose to train the children of 1985 to become the adults of the 1990's.

title: A WIDE OPEN ECONOMY HAS DRAWBACKS FOR THE WEST
description: THE West, with its vast spaces, abundance of natural resources and wizards of high technology has long been the envy of many officials in older parts of the country who had to cope with urban decay, and declining basic industries. But when governors from eight Western states met just a few steps from the white sand of Waikiki Beach last week, it was not to celebrate the riches of their region. It was to consider its problems.

title: WORLD WAR II WORDS
description: To the Editor:

title: THOUSANDS FLEE AS STORM WHIPS COAST OF FLORIDA
description: Hurricane Elena lashed central Florida with rains, high winds and eight-foot tides today, causing widespread flooding and chasing hundreds of thousands of people out of a 280-mile-long ribbon of the Gulf Coast from Sarasota to Apalachicola.

title: A PRIMER FOR THE ETHICAL BUSINESSMAN
description: 'It's Good Business, by Robert C. Solomon and Kristine Hanson. Atheneum Publishers, N.Y. 282 pages, $17.95. IN a particularly memorable phrase, Peter Drucker described business ethics as ''being able to look at your face in the mirror in the morning.'' That may be an apt rule-of-thumb for the majority of business executives, but - as E. F. Hutton's recent guilty plea to 2,000 counts of fraud makes clear - some have a stronger stomach than others. Thus, there is a need for ethical guidelines that allow less leeway for personal choice.

title: A PEACEMAKER IS THRUST INTO BANKING'S BATTLEGROUND
description: BASKING in the sun on the widow's walk of his summer home overlooking Nantucket harbor, L. William Seidman, the Reagan Administration's nominee for chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, reminisces about the last time he worked in Washington - as President Gerald R. Ford's assistant for economic affairs.

title: NEWARK MUSEUM: NAVAJO TEXTILES
description: AN exhibition entitled ''Navajo Textiles: A Century of Change'' has been installed in the permanent Native American Gallery upstairs in the Newark Museum.

title: MARIA M. RAGO PLANS TO MARRY
description: The engagement of Maria Martha Rago and Howard I. Bernstein has been announced by the future bride's mother, Juliet Rago McNamara of Evanston, Ill. Her fiance is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Abraham S. Bernstein of New Britain, Conn.

title: LIVERPOOL OFFICIALS CATCH BEATLE FEVER AT LAST
description: After more than 20 years, Beatlemania has begun to catch on with municipal authorities here.

title: NEW LIFE FOR A GLEN COVE ESTATE
description: A 16-acre estate in Glen Cove, L.I., built for financier Francis Lyman Hine in the early 1900's, is being turned into a condominium community that will include the transformation of its Georgian-style mansion into six apartments and the construction of 10 new town house units.

title: THE BIDDING TO MAKE POISON GAS
description: WHEN the Army solicited companies to manufacture components for the first battlefield nerve gases to be produced by the military in 16 years, the Vertac Chemical Corporation of Memphis, a company with $60 million in sales and a small niche in custom herbicides and fertilizers, had no qualms about bidding for the job. ''We don't have to worry about housewives not buying our Saran Wrap because we're involved in a weapons project,'' said David Simmons, Vertac's public affairs counsel. ''We don't have exposure in the commercial range.''

title: AT THE O'NEILL CENTER, FLEDGLING OPERAS GET A START
description: The O'Neill Center is an idyllic spot, a clutch of old Yankee barns and houses on a large estate a few miles west of New London, Conn. It stretches to the Long Island Sound, and is neighbor to the carnival that Eugene O'Neill - for whom the center was named - evoked in ''Ah, Wilderness.''

title: EMERGENCY SHELTERS ARE CROWDED AS EVACUEES WAIT OUT THE STORM
description: Jim Demas, like thousands of Floridians today, waited first at home and then at emergency shelters as Hurricane Elena aimed its 100-mile-an-hour winds at Florida's Gulf Coast.

title:
FOR EDUCATION, BEST AND WORST OF TIMES;

COLLEGE TUITION UP, ROLLS OFF
description: STUDENTS at Long Island's colleges and universities will return to classes this week to both good news and bad news.

title: NEW ZEALAND TRIAL MAY EMBARRASS PARIS
description: France last week was in the grip of one of those affaires that start small and then, fed on a rich diet of hints and disclosures, become an issue of state. It was summed up in the question: Who sank the Greenpeace environmentalists' ship, the Rainbow Warrier? The official French answer last week was ''not us.'' The disclaimer met with widespread public skepticism, leaving the Rainbow Warrior affair as a major embarrassment for the Government of President Francois Mitterrand.

title: GOODEN'S STEAK HALTED BY GIANTS
description: As it must to all men, defeat finally came to Dwight Gooden today, three months and 14 victories after his last one on May 25.

title: MARIJUANA FOUND AT AIR BASE
description: A field of more than 1,700 marijuana plants has been discovered and destroyed near one of Eglin Air Force Base's landing sites, according to a base spokesman. The field was the fifth discovered over the past months on the base's 728-mile reservation, the base spokesman said Thursday.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The Beatles showed that any kid playing a guitar could make it.'' -George Downey, managing director of Cavern Entertainments, which includes Liverpool's rebuilt Cavern Club, where the Beatles' fame began. [12:4.]

title: A MULTIPLE BIRTHPLACE FOR THE HUMAN SPECIES
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMACHO, 39 OTHERS PENALIZED
description: Forty profesional boxers, including Hector (Macho) Camacho, the World Boxing Council lightweight champion, have been suspended by the New Jersey Athletic Commission for failing mandatory drug tests.

title: RESHAPING LABOR TO WOO THE YOUNG
description: LIKE many workers in the fast-growing health care, high-tech and government sectors here, Paula McLain Mixson was solidly anti-union when she moved to this Texas boomtown. During her childhood in East Texas, her father often told her not to take a job ''where some union goes around telling you what to do.''

title: G.O.P. FEARFUL REAGAN POLICIES WILL HURT IN '86
description: Already troubled by their prospects in the 1986 Senate and Congressional elections, some Republicans are expressing concern that the White House may be losing political control of the major issues on which next year's campaign battles are likely to be fought.

title: ANNIE CLARK MARRIED TO EDGAR STEWART
description: The Wardsboro (Vt.) Methodist Church was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Annie Atkins Clark, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elias Clark of New Haven, to Edgar Eginton Stewart, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Fyfe Stewart of Brandon, Vt.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:I plan to take a cruise by myself. Do cruise ships have single cabins? Or will I have to share a room with someone else? Or pay for double occupancy? - J. D. D., Huntington, N.Y. Answer:The answer can be any of the above. Some cruise ships have single cabins, but they are in the minority, and they tend to be booked quickly. Single passengers who prefer their own one-bed cabin must plan well in advance. More commonly, singles can share a cabin with one, two or three other people, depending on the cabins available, and pay the appropriate per person fare. Single travelers can also reserve a double cabin for themselves by paying a supplement to the regular fare. The supplement ranges from an additional 10 to 100 percent, but generally it is 50 percent.

title: JERSEY PROGRAM HELPS TROUBLED TEEN-AGERS
description: When she entered the seventh grade, Andrea M. was well behaved and had a close relationship with her family.

title: WARNING ON DRUGS
description: Dr. Rlbert J. Slater,, director of medical programs at the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, cautions MS patients against seeking treatment with drugs still being tested.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Supplies and Lessons For Worldwide Crafts During 19 years in Croton-on-Hudson, The Niddy Noddy has developed a worldwide reputation for supplying the needs and wants of the textile crafts of spinning, dyeing, weaving and knitting. The yarn colors are in all gradations and provide a feast for the eyes of a newcomer, even to offering inspiration to a casual knitter, who then may get caught up in the commercial possibilities of the craft.

title: JAPANESE SCHOOLS
description: To the Editor:

title: DIANNE M. LEWIS MARRIES LIEUT. JAMES CATALANO JR.
description: The marriage of Dianne Marie Lewis, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George P. Lewis Jr. of Middletown, R.I., to Lieut.

title: Chievous Leads U.S. In Basketball Victory
description: Derrick Chievous of New York City and the University of Missouri scored 27 points and Chuck Person of Auburn had 21 to lead the United States to a 123-68 basketball victory today over Japan and a berth in the semifinals of the World University Games.

title: A PRINCETON SUMMER COURSE HANDS POWER TO THE STUDENTS
description: For many of the students, the classes in the public policy course at Princeton University this summer were something they had not experienced before.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: THE DAY OF TRINITY, by Lansing Lamont. (Atheneum, $11.95.) ''The Day of Trinity'' recounts the work of scientists at the Government's laboratories in Los Alamos, N.M., which culminated in the explosion in the desert of the first atomic bomb on July 16, 1945. In 1965 our reviewer, William L. Laurence, who witnessed the blast, termed this book ''a remarkable achievement . . . authentic history providing facts, never told before.'' And he added, ''The author fills in the background that gives the occasion its meaning and significance.'' Two new chapters describe the scientists' subsequent lives and the state of nuclear science today. THE OLD BUNCH, by Meyer Levin. (Citadel, $14.95.) A 964-page composite story of 19 Chicago youths - 11 boys and 8 girls - from the same neighborhood. ''The Old Bunch'' follows them from their high school graduation in 1921 to the mid-1930's. In 1937 in these pages Harold Strauss called the book ''a landmark in the development of the realistic novel'' that ''brilliantly succeeds in taking the reader on a memorable tour of the world in which the old bunch lived.'' Levin later became well known for his novel ''Compulsion.'' THE ECONOMICS AND POLITICS OF RACE: An International Perspective, by Thomas Sowell. (Quill, $6.95.) Thomas Sowell tries to answer the question ''Why have some American minorities climbed the ladder of economic success more readily than others?'' To do so he takes a comparative historical look at the fate of racial and ethnic minorities in societies throughout the world.

title: CAST IN MT. LAUREL CASES, STABLE SINCE '71, MAY SOON CHANGE
description: THE roster of participants in Mount Laurel I and II cases could change when Governor Kean appoints the nine-member Council on Affordable Housing called for in the Fair Housing Act he signed on July 3.

title: AN AD MAN GOES FOR THE HEART
description: ''I'M the quarterback, or maybe the manager,'' said Benjamin Colarossi of Huntington, summing up his job.

title: JAYS WIN ON 4-RUN RALLY
description: Lloyd Moseby snapped a 2-2 tie with a triple and Rance Mulliniks followed with a home run today as the Toronto Blue Jays scored four runs in the eighth inning to beat the Chicago White Sox, 6-2.

title: TOP MATCHES FOR TODAY
description: Stadium Noon Yannick Noah (7) v. Vitas Gerulitis Second Match - Sandra Cecchini v. Martina Navratilova (2) followed by Thierry Tulasne v. Jimmy Connors (4) 7:30 P.M.

title: JETS TRIUMPH, 30-20, WITH STRONG RUSH
description: The Jets flashed a brilliant opening 30 minutes of preseason play tonight, but whether this will be the New York Jets of the regular season still is uncertain.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ENGLAND, FIRST & LAST. By Anthony Bailey. (Elisabeth Sifton/Viking, $15.95.) In ''America, Lost & Found,'' Anthony Bailey told a charming story of four amiable years spent in Dayton, Ohio, during World War II.

title: SONDHEIM'S 'FOLLIES' REVISITED
description: Even amid the Stephen Sondheim canon, ''Follies'' stands apart as a show of huge dimensions - in ambition, in execution, in reaction. The original Broadway production in 1971 united the three contemporary titans of American musical theater, Mr. Sondheim, Harold Prince and Michael Bennett. The show boasted a cast of 50, costumes by the score and the staggering sets of Boris Aronson. And ''Follies'' aspired to nothing less than an examination of American disillusionment after World War II, adopting as its metaphor the reunion of song-and-dance girls in an abandoned theater.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Carbide has been like a cartoon character with a black cloud over its head - it is constantly plagued with problems.''

title: PROSPECTS
description: Retailing Report Card The back-to-school selling season, in full swing at the nation's stores, is showing some promise, according to initial reports, and even raising hopes for brisk Christmas sales.

title: HELPFUL ADVICE
description: To the Editor:

title: A YANK AT DRAMA SCHOOL
description: It is nearly three months since I completed a year at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art. Since I was interested in performing in and writing for the theater, I wanted to study not in New York or at Yale, but in the city where Shakespeare had worked, a city that is so devoted to the theater and the people working in it.

title: A Brief Time To Oppose Zia
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, the military ruler of Pakistan, allowed one of his most prominent opponents only eight days of freedom before confining her to home under armed guard last week.

title: EVERY DOG HAS HIS DAY
description: WHEN you have toured the world as Jose Greco's dance partner, traveled with your own band of gypsy dancers, studied bullfighting in Spain, been photographed by Avedon, performed on the Ed Sullivan show and appeared with Johnny Carson, what do you do when you settle down?

title: DEATHS IN FRENCH TRAIN WRECH RISE TO 49
description: The death toll rose to 49 today in a train derailment and collision in central France. Nearly 100 people were reported injured, 10 of them critically, when a passenger train derailed and was struck by a mail train.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM GARBO TO POOH CORNER
description: Chick Corea and Gary Burton: Live In Tokyo Pacific Arts 60 minutes. $24.95 As a duo, the pianist Chick Corea and the vibraphonist Gary Burton make the most of their instruments' capacity to plink and twinkle and shimmer.

title: NICARAGUA CALLS REBELS A THREAT IN HBONDURAS
description: Nicaragua's Embassy in Honduras has requested protection from the Honduran Foreign Ministry after threats from right-wing Nicaraguan rebels.

title: HIDDEN FACTS
description: FIFTY YEARS AGO men wore hats, but now they wear mustaches. You can confirm it by looking at photographs of baseball crowds in the 1930's.

title: ELEGANT LODGINGS IN REDWOOD COUNTRY
description: As it rambles through the high country near the northern coast of California, U.S. 101 is also called the Redwood Highway. It is the spine of a region with attractions that include the wine-growing counties of Napa, Sonoma and Mendocino, a rugged, rocky coastline and, as a traveler approaches the Oregon state line, small fishing towns.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN ECONOMY: ACHILLES' HEEL OF APARTHEID
description: South Africa's Government, which has withstood riots, an arms embargo and condemnations from other countries, this week faces a major challenge from an unlikely corner: international bankers.

title: WOMEN WHO DO KNOW BETTER
description: RETURN TRIPS By Alice Adams. 195 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $14.95. NOBODY writes better about falling in love than Alice Adams. The protagonists of her stories, almost always women, often professional women - lawyers, art historians, illustrators, journalists - with a number of years and a good deal of experience behind them, know exactly what is about to happen: no nitwits, never victims or too gaga, they have been there before. They fall with eyes open, knowing full well that the man in question might be inappropriate - married or too self-involved ever to commit totally. Such women think they should know better. They do know better. That is the glory of an Adams heroine, she is that smart and still goes on. ''Ah,'' she says to herself, sighing, ''this again: love.'' And plunges in.

title: MELISSA MATTEO BRIDE IN CAPITAL
description: Melissa Ann Matteo, the daughter of Drs. Richard S. Matteo and Demaris B. Matteo of Teaneck, N.J., was married yesterday to Arnold Cale Johnson Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Johnson of Chevy Chase, Md.

title: ONE STOP IN AFRICA OMITTED BY THE POPE
description: To the Editor:

title: RACHEL COOKE IS A BRIDE
description: Rachel Hamilton Cooke, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Kinsman Cooke of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, was married yesterday to Robert William Heil, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Harold Heil of Akron, Ohio. The Rev. Joseph P. Russell performed the ceremony at St. Alban's Episcopal Church in Cleveland Heights. Mrs. Heil is an investment broker for the ABD Securities Corporation in New York. Mr. Heil is an operatic tenor. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: THE CONTRADICTIONS PERSIST
description: Ferruccio Busoni was a musician of many skills. During the second half of the 19th century and the early years of the 20th, Busoni was one of the most talented - and controversial - of piano virtuosos. He probed deeply into music's intellectual content, becoming an author and theorist whose avant-garde ideas were of incalculable importance for the growth of 20th-century music. And the creative spark burned brightly in Busoni as well; though his own compositions have never been as well known as his transcriptions, they reveal much about the peculiar state of affairs in turn-of-the-century German musical life.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CRAMPTON HODNET. By Barbara Pym. (Dutton, $14.95.) The self-deluding, smug clergyman. The intelligent woman pondering spinsterhood. The imperious grande dame. The high-minded student and her married suitor, well into his midlife crisis. These and other characters familiar from Barbara Pym's later books assemble for the first time in this early work (1939-40), now published posthumously. As is ever the case in a Pym novel, the scope of the action is constricted but made compelling by understatement, an underlying sense of compassion and a precision of language through which mundane vocabulary is elevated into art. Crampton Hodnet is the name of a parish invented by the clergyman as an unnecessary alibi for an innocent walk in the woods, and it comes to signify all the imaginary excuses and rationalizations by which the book's inhabitants live. They watch themselves and each other closely, alert for any lapse of North Oxford decorum, and together preserve a world of interchangeable parts where no one is indispensable and equilibrium is maintained above all else. The novel is framed with three flirtations - two improbable, one predictable and all ultimately transitory. ''Falling in love is never ordinary to the people who indulge in it,'' a woman says, settling into her unmarried state. But passion implies a risk of uncertainty and is unstable; no character is capable of extricating him or herself sufficiently from past comforts or habits to indulge in passion for long. In pre-World War II academic Britannia, convention rules.

title: PROVOCATIVE DRAWINGS BY THE MASTERS
description: One of the curious things about the fall season in New York is that, whereas the big stores would almost pay to get us inside their doors as of tomorrow, our museums and galleries hang back. ''Nobody's in town,'' they say, as if they were characters in an Edith Wharton novel, and they take their time about sending an invitation for the third week in September.

title: MADLOCK SENT TO DODGERS
description: Bill Madlock, a four-time National League batting champion, was sent by the Pittsburgh Pirates to the Los Angeles Dodgers today for the outfielder R. J. Reynolds, the first baseman Sid Bream and the outfielder Cecil Espy.

title: A QUALITY OF ABSENCE
description: BORDERLINE By Janette Turner Hospital. 287 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $15.95.

title: NEW BOOK CITES LOCAL FIRMS
description: IN ''The Challenge of Hidden Profits, Reducing Corporate Bureaucracy and Waste,'' published last month by William Morrow ($19.95), John S. Berry of Larchmont and his co-author, Mark Green of New York City, have coined a new word: ''corpocracy.'' It describes the corporate bureaucracy they believe prevails in corporate America.

title: The Competition With Japan
description: The danger is not from Japan but from the future and our unwillingness to make the changes and sacrifices necessary to compete.

title: September 1, 1985
description: Fiction 1 THINNER, by Stephen King writing as Richard Bachman. (NAL/Signet, $4.50.) The case of a lawyer whose body is mysteriously wasting away. 2 FIRST AMONG EQUALS, by Jeffrey Archer. (Pocket, $4.50.) Three young men vie to be chosen Prime Minister of Britain. 3 BRAINCHILD, by John Saul. (Bantam, $3.95.) A young boy miraculously saved by an operation becomes an instrument of revenge. 4* ''. . . AND LADIES OF THE CLUB,'' by Helen Hooven Santmyer. (Berkley, $5.95.) Chronicle of an Ohio hamlet from 1868 to 1932. 5* FULL CIRCLE, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.50.) The relationship of a mother and daughter is altered by the changing values of the past 40 years. 6 CRESCENT CITY, by Belva Plain. (Dell, $4.50.) A Jewish woman in 19th-century New Orleans. 7 THE MIKO, by Eric Van Lustbader. (Fawcett, $4.50.) An American businessman struggles with a vengeful Japanese sorceress in a high-stakes battle. 8 THE PASSION OF MOLLY T., by Lawrence Sanders. (Berkley, $4.50.) The loves and hatreds of a feminist activist all but consume her. 9 JULIE, by Catherine Marshall. (Avon, $4.50.) The fortunes of a young woman and her family during the Depression, based on the author's experiences. 10 SUPERIOR WOMEN, by Alice Adams. (Fawcett, $3.95.) Five friends at 1940's Radcliffe and after. 11 THE OUTSIDER, by Howard Fast. (Dell, $3.95.) Life as seen by a young rabbi and his family. 12 OTHER WOMEN, by Lisa Alther. (NAL/Signet, $4.50.) The relationship of two women as they progress through life's vicissitudes. 13 THE HAJ, by Leon Uris. (Bantam, $4.95.) One man's experience in the wars of the Holy Land. 14 THE WITCHES OF EASTWICK, by John Updike. (Fawcett, $4.50.) Three witches wreak havoc in a contemporary Rhode Island town. 15 TWIN OF FIRE, by Jude Deveraux. (Pocket, $3.95.) A hot-bloodedwoman of the old west wins her man. Nonfiction General 1 IACOCCA, by David Abodaher. (Zebra, $3.95.) His life, by a former employee of Chrysler's ad agency. 2 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (S&S/Touchstone, $8.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 3 IN SEARCH OF EXCELLENCE, by Thomas J. Peters and Robert H. Waterman Jr. (Warner, $8.95.) Lessons from well-run corporations. 4 THE KENNEDYS: An American Drama, by Peter Collier and David Horowitz. (Warner, $4.95.) Four generations of a prominent family. Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 RAND MCNALLY ROAD ATLAS: United States, Canada, Mexico. (Rand McNally, $5.95.) For 1985. 2 PENGUIN DREAMS AND STRANGER THINGS, by Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $6.95.) Cartoons. 3 DIETS DON'T WORK, by Bob Schwartz. (Breakthru Publishing, $9.95.) How to lose weight without dieting. 4 VALLEY OF THE FAR SIDE, by Gary Larson. (Andrews, McMeel & Parker, $5.95.) Cartoons. 5* THE ONE MINUTE MANAGER, by Kenneth Blanchard and Spencer Johnson. (Berkley, $6.95.) How to increase your productivity. 6* EAT TO WIN, by Robert Hass. (NAL/Signet, $4.50.) A regimen for sports and fitness activities. 7* SNIGLETS, by Rich Hall and Friends. (Collier/ Macmillan, $5.95.) Newly minted words. 8* GROWING UP CATHOLIC, by Mary Jane Frances Cavolina Meara, Jeffrey Allen Joseph Stone, Maureen Anne Teresa Kelly and Richard Glen Michael Davis. (Doubleday/Dolphin, $4.95.) Humor. 9 BRIDE OF THE FAR SIDE, by Gary Larson. (Andrews, McMeel & Parker, $5.95.) Cartoons. 10 THE SILVER PALATE GOOD TIMES COOKBOOK, by Julee Rosso and Sheila Lukins with Sarah Leah Chase. (Workman, $11.95.) Recipes. 11 WHAT COLOR IS YOUR PARACHUTE? by Richard Nelson Bolles. (Ten Speed Press, $8.95.) Job and career advice; 1985 edition.

title: HEALTH CODE VIOLATORS CITED BY NEW YORK CITY
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 21 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Comparable Buttons
description: President Reagan opposes the notion of ''comparable worth,'' which seeks to establish equal pay levels for jobs of same value although of different duties, and some of the women who work for him in the White House are expressing their support for their boss by wearing green and white buttons that say: ''My worth is INcomparable.''

title: MULTI-USE PROJECT
description: For more than a century the lower Manhattan neighborhood now known as TriBeCa was an industrial district. But in the past few years its identity has been changing, as loft-style residences, offices and chic food shops and restaurants have opened.

title: MASKED BANDITS IN FURS
description: THE burglar never came back, and that's fine with us, as I'm reasonably sure it's fine with him. In his line of work, getting caught must be as bad for the nerves as it is for business. When he was surprised in the front foyer, he ran like a thief.

title: A FORK IN THE ROAD FOR U.S. LABOR
description: THE lackluster economy and intensifying foreign competition are forcing American management and labor to choose between two paths. The first would yield a cheap, unskilled work force engaged in routinized tasks, generally angry and disaffected, with no continuing commitment to the enterprise. The second path depends on a highly trained work force that's vitally committed. That's the choice. The first path would involve cutting labor costs. For managers this path means undertaking (or threatening) massive layoffs; using bankruptcy to annul costly wage contracts; moving (or threatening to move) to lower-wage states and countries; sending work out to lower-cost subcontractors; and automating to reduce skill levels. For workers it means defending existing jobs and pay scales; grudgingly conceding lower wages, benefits and cost-of-living allowances; shifting burdens by accepting lower pay scales for junior workers; and occasionally striking.

title: COUNTRY BISTRO IN WEST CORNWALL
description: IT may be a while before new restaurants can catch up with the real-estate boom taking place in northwest Connecticut. A start in the right direction is Freshfields, a brand-new ''country bistro,'' as it calls itself, near the historic covered bridge in West Cornwall.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: RIDGWAY'S PARATROOPERS: The American Airborne in World War II. By Clay Blair. (Dial Press/Doubleday, $19.95.) This study of Gen. Matthew Bunker Ridgway's long and illustrious career offers not only an exhaustive account of his role in World War II, but also a comprehensive history of American airborne operations in Europe.

title: L.I. A STAGE FOR ABORTION FIGHT
description: EVERY Saturday for the last few months, anti-abortion activists have picketed the Hempstead Professional Building, which houses an abortion clinic and a counseling service, the Bill Baird Institute, associated with it. Mr. Baird, who in 1965 opened the country's first abortion clinic on Long Island, is an outspoken advocate of the right of women to undergo the procedure.

title: WHERE THE OTHER HALF LIVES, SIR
description: Barbara Kelley has no need for an alarm clock.

title: PRODUCERS MAKE DEBUT WITH SOLID HIT
description: A COUPLE of years ago in California, a pair of madcap magicians - Penn Jillette and Teller (who says he cannot remember his first name) - were discovered by a trio of successful Westchester real-estate developers. With their own sleight-of-hand, the owners of Ivy Properties in White Plains switched hats and became part-time producers of an Off-Broadway hit: ''Penn & Teller'' at the Westside Arts Theater.

title: JILL A. SANCIBRIAN, A MODEL, BECOMES BRIDE OF CARL PRESTON WALKER, ARTIST
description: Jill Audrey Sancibrian, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Philip Sancibrian of Trumbull, Conn., was married yesterday to Carl Preston Walker, a son of Emilie Jones Walker of Greenwich, Conn., and Hilton Head, S.C., and Richard Henry Walker of Norwalk, Conn. Msgr. Martin J. McDermott, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Craig W. Casey, an Episcopal priest, officiated at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Aug. 18 on inheriting rent-regulated apartments incorrectly described New York State law regarding a tenant's right to buy an apartment in a conversion. Conversion sponsors must offer apartments at the preferential insider's price to all tenants in residency at the time the Attorney General accepts the conversion plan for filing unless, before the plan has been accepted, a court has determined that a tenant breached a lease.

title: COTTAGE'S DETAILS RECALL ITS HISTORY
description: Officially, Sunshine Cottage, which opened in August 1931 on the grounds of what was then Grasslands Hospital in Valhalla, was a preventorium, intended, as a 1931 newspaper article said, to put ''Westchester County in the vanguard of the modern crusade against tuberculosis in childhood.'' The two story Neo-Georgian Revival-style structure, built by the County's Department of Public Welfare for $617, 179, combined modern technology with the most current therapeutic techniques.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 1, 1985 International Peru is joining the cocaine war under the leadership of its new President, Alan Garcia Perez. His Government provided police assistance in recent raids financed by the United States, on cocaine processors near the Colombian border. [Page 1, Column 5.] Evidence presented in lawsuits filed in Washington in connection with the Soviet downing of Korean Air Lines flight 007 suggests that American radar operators knew for hours that the plane was off course and headed for Soviet air space. The United States position has been that no one knew the plane was veering off course and therefore no warning could have been considered. [3:1.] South African miners accused employers of preparing ''for total warfare'' in a strike due to begin today by 62,000 members of the country's biggest black labor group, the National Union of Mineworkers. [17:1.] National Hurricane Elena hit central Florida with 100-mile-an-hour winds and eight-foot tides, causing widespread flooding. Hundreds of thousands of residents fled from a 280-mile strip of the Gulf Coast from Sarasota to Apalachicola, and Gov. Bob Graham ordered the mandatory evacuation of parts of 10 coastal counties. [1:6.] Vetoing of protectionist trade bills pending in Congress was threatened by President Reagan in his weekly radio speech. White House officials said his comments should be taken as a threat of a veto against protectionist measures that are designed to stem the record $150 billion trade deficit expected this year.

title: STALE WINDS FOR THE SHIP OF STATE
description: One day soon, proponents of a balanced-budget amendment may announce to the House and Senate that the required 34 states have petitioned Congress for a convention to propose that amendment and that Congress must therefore create one. If they're right, the nation will then face at least a constitutional mess, perhaps even a crisis. Fortunately, the danger can be avoided, now, if Congress will spell out procedures for handling the convention campaign.

title: A.I.D. SUPPORTS FAMILY-PLANNING CHOICES
description: To the Editor:

title: Buses
description: To the Editor: With great delight I read Jim Lehrer's ''To Buses, With Love'' (Travel, Aug. 4).

title:
ART;

NOT SO INNOCENT 'PAPER DOLLS'
description: Remember what fun it was to play with paper dolls, to imagine favorite characters dressed up in various outfits, assuing different roles? The very term paper dolls evokes the kind of harmless make-believe that represents an idealized view of childhood, with its innocent games and two-dimensional realities.

title: WORKERS IN FICTION: LOCKED OUT
description: MANY politicians will appear at Labor Day gatherings tomorrow mouthing platitudes about industrial workers being the backbone of the United States, but few of these speakers will believe what they say. For many Americans in this age of high technology, industrial workers are at best an anachronism, at worst an embarrassment.

title: JOAN B. MUNVES PLANS TO WED NEXT MONTH
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Munves Jr. of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Joan Barbara Munves to Philip George Boening, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence P. Boening of Valley Stream, L.I. The wedding is planned for next month.

title: NANCY SCAPPATICCI, A LAWYER, TO MARRY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Mario L. Scappaticci of Harrison, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Jean Scappaticci to Paul Boyton Brickfield, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. Brickfield of Brooklyn.

title: A COMPUTER HUNT FOR FINGERPRINTS OF CRIME
description: In a cubicle at the National Bureau of Standards, a British police officer is developing a fingerprint coding system for computers that American experts say could make it dramatically easier to identify lawbreakers.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL) - Recalled the pitchers Reggie Patterson and Johnny Abrego, from Iowa.

title: 2 NEW MUSICALS SEEK FUTURE RUNS
description: AFTER the most musically mediocre theater season in memory, it is no wonder that producers are scouting the state's theaters to see what is new and promising.

title: Stagecoach
description: To the Editor: As the daughter of the late author Ernest Haycox, I read with interest Arnold Benson's article, ''The Taming of the Old Wild West'' (Travel, July 14).

title: AN ELECTRONIC BYPASS IS PERFORMED IN SPACE WALK
description: Two space-walking astronauts plucked a disabled 15,000-pound satellite out of orbit today and, working with the agility of tree surgeons and the skill of electricians, performed an electronic bypass operation in an ingenious attempt to bring the satellite back to life.

title: ELLEN SALOMON PAVIA
description: Ellen Salomon Pavia, a psychiatric social worker, died suddenly yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: CONTRASTS IN DRAMA AT DREW
description: THE New Jersey Shakespeare Festival's scheduling of Robert Bolt's highly honored 1960 play, ''A Man for All Seasons,'' being performed in tandem with Shakespeare's ''Henry VIII'' at Drew University, is a timely, perhaps timeless, study in contrasts.

title: Q AND A
