description: 421a Rent Increase Question: I am renewing my lease for two years with a 6 1/2 percent increase on the rent and another 6 1/2 percent increase for the real-estate tax we pay because the tax exemption our building receives under the 421a program is decreasing. Is this second rent increase proper? . . . M. M. G., Floral Park, N. Y. Answer: The owner of a building receiving a diminishing tax exemption under the 421a program is entitled to a 2.2 percent annual increase above the regular guideline increase, which effective Oct. 1 is 6 1/2 percent for two-year renewals, according to Gary Gutterman, deputy director of the tax-incentive program for the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development.

title: A Union in the House?
description: Although Congress over the years has allowed American workers to organize into unions, it has withheld that right from most of its own employees. Now, however, the Architect of the Capitol, George M. White, has agreed to allow a secret ballot in which employees of the restaurants run by the House of Representatives will state whether they want to join a union.

title: FRESH FIGS FIND PLACE IN MANY COURSES
description: MANY years ago as a student, I went camping with friends along the French Riviera. One night we spread our bedrolls under a tree in what appeared to be a public beachside garden. It was a clear but moonless night but before dawn we felt ourselves being pelted from above with some kind of soft, dark projectiles, hardly pleasant.

title: IN 3D YEAR AT ALABAMA, PERKINS FACES A PIVOTAL SEASON
description: RAY PERKINS is happy. He says that, like most everything he says, with authority in his voice and a fixed stare in his steely blue eyes. He even adds a laugh, believable even if seemingly self-assuring, when he says it.

title: IT'S RACE WEEKEND AT LIME ROCK
description: FOR Louis C. Rettenmeier, a 27-year-old Danbury mechanic, motor vehicles are an 80-hour-a-week business.

title: DOCTOR IN ARTIFICIAL-HEART CASE HAS JUST A FEW WEEKS TO MSAKE A SWITCH
description: As an artificial heart pumped blood through Michael Drummond today, his surgeon, Dr. Jack G. Copeland, was facing a narrow window of time to replace the device with a human heart.

title: SCHOOLS TO SCREEN JERSEY AIDS PUPILS
description: Most schoolchildren who have AIDS should be allowed to attend regular classes, according to New Jersey health and education officials, but they said the initial decision should be left up to the local school district.

title: WOMAN IN CAR IS SHOT BYMAN AT W. 95TH ST.
description: A 30-year-old New Jersey woman was shot in the chin yesterday by a man who demanded entry to her car near Central Park, the police said.

title: BEACHES YOU'LL NEVER FORGET l>By EUGENIA GARVEY; Eugenia Garvey, who now lives in New Rochelle, N.Y., has a summer house in Point Lookout.
description: ARE there any beaches in the world quite like ours on Long Island? Perhaps so, but I doubt it. I haven't lain in chic languor on the Riviera, nor any Asian watering place, but I suspect that seeing and being seen there takes precedence over the sheer pristine pleasure of white sand and clear, salty water.

title: WORLD'S TOP GRAPE-CATCHER
description: Paul Tavilla, a produce dealer, won a place in the Guinness Book of World Records by catching a grape, dropped from the top of a 38-story building, in his mouth. The 51-year-old Mr. Tavilla caught a large seeded red grape dropped 520 feet, 5 inches from the Shawmut Bank here July 7. An editor for the book's United States edition said the feat, in a new category, grape-catching, would be included in the 1986 volume.

title: PLAYING AIR GUITAR
description: WHEN I hear a song on the radio that I really like, or that used to be a favorite, I sometimes dance around a little bit and pretend to play guitar. I play air guitar. It probably looks dumb to an outsider, but to the man who plays, it is quite serious - a primal and private dance. Men identify with the great rock guitarists the way they do with sports legends, and we mimic their gestures and attitudes in an instinctive quest for grace.

title: ELASTICITY OF ESTIMATES
description: To the Editor:

title: GREEK FARE WITH REFINEMENT
description: THERE is a certain elegance about Athena, a Greek restaurant that opened this season in Southampton and expects to remain in business year round. Not only does the subdued decor - walls covered in creamy beige and pastel and adorned with handsome architectural renderings - strike an extremely gracious note, but also the presentation of the food is equally attractive.

title: METROPOLITAN LIFE FUND TO AID SOCIAL PROGRAMS
description: The Metropolitan Life Foundation, set up by the insurance company in 1976, has created a $25 million loan program to encourage business ventures that meet ''significant social needs,'' according to foundation officials.

title: HISTORICAL OPERA ELUDES SEARCHERS
description: IN 1983, after a successful production of ''The Frogs of Windham,'' two members of the Windham Theater Guild decided that ''The Charter Oak,'' another opera by the father-son musical team of Nason and Burton Leavitt, would be a fitting production for Connecticut's 350th anniversary.

title: Domed Stadium for Football
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: OPTION INCOME
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;

THE POWER OF POSTER DESIGNS
description: IF we were supposed to heed the almost 200 messages and slogans in ''The 20th Century Poster: Design of the Avant-Garde,'' currently at the Neuberger Museum at the State University of New York at Purchase, we would feel trapped in a nightmare peculiar to this media-crazed century.

title: CHILEAN CHURCH IN THE FOREFRONT OF POLITICS
description: When President Augusto Pinochet lifted the state of siege two months ago, the opposition magazines immediately resumed publication. Their covers, however, did not feature outlawed political leaders, but people who figure prominently in General Pinochet's most consistent opposition force, the Roman Catholic Church.

title: IN BOTH AFRICAS, INSTABILITY UNDERMINES A RICH POTENTIAL
description: ON both sides of its racial divide, Africa reaped a harvest of uncertainty and discontent last week. In Nigeria, the sixth military coup since independence replaced one set of generals with another and provided ammunition for those in South Africa who justify continued white domination by referring to the tyrannies of black rule.

title: SCHOLARS FIND AMAJOR SHIFT FAVORING G.O.P.
description: Republican gains of recent years, especially in the South, constitute a major reshaping of political forces in the nation, leading American political scientists agree.

title: 1889 DEPOT
description: Though the former railroad station off Route 9 in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., had long been a graffiti-scarred eyesore, the building's terra cotta-framed windows and sloped roof had always appealed to Mal Brett Schwartz and Janine Snow, a husband-and-wife team who own Graphic Harmony, an advertising agency in nearby Buchanan.

title: Judge Tightens Rules on Housing The Homeless
description: When New York City provides a place for a homeless family to sleep, it has to be on beds in a hotel or shelter, not on table tops or plastic chairs in a welfare office, a State Supreme Court judge ruled last week. The decision by Justice Helen E. Freedman applies only to families with children. It was the first time a court had stated explicitly that the city, under a directive from the State Social Services Commissioner, is obliged to be the provider of last resort for all homeless families.

title: ELENA BORN AS STORM HOVERS
description: Charyl Brimage was supposed to have given birth Monday, but her child waited until Friday, just about the time that Hurricane Elena was hovering in the Gulf of Mexico, threatening the Mississippi coast. ''The baby waited on the hurricane, so I just had to name her Elena,'' Mrs. Brimage said. Mother and daughter were doing fine a spokesman for Biloxi Regional Medical Center said.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: MUSIC ALFRESCO The Wallingford Symphony Orchestra opens its 10th season with a free concert on the grounds of Wallace International Silversmiths Inc., Barnes Industrial Park, from 7 to 9 P.M. Friday. It will be an opportunity to bring a picnic and enjoy the music alfresco.

title: Racial Politics
description: WHEN Mark Stebbins lost his City Council seat in Stockton, Calif., in a recall election in December, it was generally agreed that the major issue was, for the second time, race.

title: IPANEMA BEACH IS CLOSED
description: Ipanema beach here was closed by sewage pollution today after an underwater duct broke 1.7 miles offshore. A sewage department spokesman said water contamination on the beach used daily by thousands of foreign tourists was above the permitted level, though ''not alarming.'' He said Ipanema would be closed for at least two or three days.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: JOHN JAY CHESS As a change of pace from the usual Labor Day parades, backyard barbecues, speeches and square dances, the John Jay Homestead in Katonah is again scheduling its traditional chess tournament from 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Monday, co-sponsored by the Max Pavey Chess Club of Mount Kisco. Registration begins at 9 A.M.

title: MONTANA HAS ITS REASONS TO FEAR REAGAN TAX PLAN
description: In many of the old mountain towns of Montana there is a boom in historic preservation, the result of a fragile economy's turning from mining and lumber to recreation and tourism. Old downtowns, railroad stations, hotels and Victorian houses are being restored to preserve the flavor of remote Western places as they existed a century ago.

title: AT 90, JUDAIC SCHOLARSHIP IS STILL FINKELSTEIN'S PASSION
description: When Dr. Louis Finkelstein reached his 90th birthday in June, hundreds of letters of tribute arrived at the Jewish Theological Seminary, the school where Dr. Finkelstein has spent the last 74 years as a student, teacher, president, chancellor and chancellor emeritus.

title: INDIA'S LOW-PAID POLICE SEEM EASILY TEMPTED
description: Few officials in India had more protection from physical attack than Harchand Singh Longowal, the moderate Sikh leader who in July signed an accord with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi to end the turmoil in Punjab.

title: U.S. ATTORNEY RALLYING TROOPS IN WAR ON DRUGS
description: When most public officials think of Kennedy International Airport or the Port of New York, they think of travel and trade and how these can be stimulated.

title: CAMBODIAN REBEL SAYS TIME IS GROWING SHORT
description: The leader of the larger of two non-Communist factions fighting to dislodge the Vietnamese from Cambodia said today that he had given his guerrilla army a two-year deadline to provoke and support a popular uprising in the country.

title: FARMERS FACE COURT ON WORKERS UNION
description: TWO vegetable farmers are to return to Superior Court this week to face Judge Edward S. Miller on the issue of whether they will obey his order to recognize and bargain with New Jersey's first farm-worker union or risk jail for contempt.

title: MEASLES VACCINATION URGED AT 9 MONTH OUTSIDE THE U.S.
description: Around 9 months is the best age to give measles vaccine to babies in places where the disease is still a major killer, a new study recommends.

title: THE VENERABLE RUY IS STILL POTENT
description: There must be a lot going for an opening where good moves come as easily as trouble for the opponent. That's the Ruy Lopez. Its object is not a quick knockout -the gambits are much better adapted to that - but it avoids deadening simplification and does an admirable job of maintaining tension over a long period of moves.

title: WINDSOR SWIMMER CONQUERS CHANNEL
description: HE had to wait 18 days to try, but last week Martin V. McMahon of Windsor did something no other Connecticut resident has done. He swam the English Channel. ''It feels fantastic,'' he said. Mr. McMahon, a 22-year-old former lifeguard, made the 21-mile crossing from Dover, England, to Cape Gris Nez, France, Monday in 11 hours 14 minutes 21 seconds, according to a spokesman for the British Coast Guard.

title: ECUADOR TROOPS TRAP KIDNAPPERS OF BANKER
description: Special police and army units engaged left-wing guerrillas in a brief gunfight today and then surrounded the house near Guayaquil where the rebels are holding a kidnapped banker, Nahim Isaias, the governor of the state of Guayas said.

title: DEBORAH BURNS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edmund J. Burns of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Deborah Ann Burns to Bjorn Eric Nielsen the son of Mr. and Mrs. Egon Nielsen of Leatherhead, Surrey, England.

title: KIRKLAND SEES A RESURGENCE FOR TROUBLED LABOR UNIONS
description: Organized labor has suffered serious setbacks and faces sizable problems but will overcome them all, Lane Kirkland, president of the nation's largest labor federation, said in a Labor Day statement issued today.

title: STATE ADDING 9,248 ACRES TO UPSTATE PRESERVE
description: New York State is acquiring 9,248 acres to be added to the Adirondack Forest Preserve as part of an effort to consolidate and expand its holdings in the region.

title: Dragor
description: To the Editor: The merest mention of the seaside village of Dragor in Denmark (Travel, June 16) brings back Holocaust memories. During my first encounter with that town, there was little time to admire and enjoy its charms.

title: NEARING LAST WEEK OF PRIMARY RACE KOCH'S MAIN RIVALS ADMIT HE LEADS
description: New York's Democratic mayoral primary campaign moves into its final week with both of Mayor Koch's principal rivals acknowledging that he is the front-runner and that he is still far outspending them at a critical point in the race.

title: Gomez Plans to Retire
description: The three-time champion Wilfredo Gomez says he will retire after his upcoming mandatory defense of the World Boxing Association junior-lightweight title against Alfredo Layne, sell all his property in Puerto Rico and move to Venezuela. His decision came in the midst of a bitter dispute that contributed to the cancellation of International Boxing Federation junior middleweight champion Carlos Santos's defense against Davey Moore in San Juan last night.

title: UNITY OVER DRUGS GROWS AT MEETING
description: Participants in a United Nations conference on crime say the spread of drug abuse in the third world seems to have brought the industrialized nations and the poorer, drug-producing countries a little closer together.

title: WHAT MAKES A PERFORMANCE GREAT?
description: Any music-lover who regularly attends concerts and operas occasionally encounters great performances; one says ''occasionally'' because if he never encounters greatness he's a curmudgeon and if he promiscuously encounters it, he's just overexcitable. I myself heard a great performance just a few weeks ago at Tanglewood, when Leonard Bernstein led the Boston Symphony in Brahms's First Symphony. But what is a great performance? The question, I hope, is not quite so naive as it sounds.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;

MARATHON MAN MEETS BEETHOVEN
description: IN the highly competitive world of music festivals, there are gimmicks designed to keep the turnstiles turning.

title: BLACK: AN ELEGANT TRANSITION TO FALL
description: SEVENTY-FIVE years ago this summer, officials at the Royal Ascot in England decreed that those attending the horse races that season must wear black, because the mourning period for Edward VII was still in effect. The subsequent parade of women in black on the emerald lawns of the famous racecourse was such a startlingly elegant sight that all black garb became a symbol of sophistication.

title: Salvador Holds 3 Suspects in Death of Marines
description: He refused to say when, where or how they had been arrested, but President Jose Napoleon Duarte insisted there was no doubt about who the Salvadoran Government had in its custody last week. Appearing with members of the military high command at the executive mansion, Mr. Duarte announced the capture of three leftist guerrillas suspected of taking part in an attack on a cafe in which four off-duty United States marines were killed.

title: Lakeside Summers
description: The About Westchester column on Aug. 11 about Pine Lake (Shangri-La) brought back beautiful memories of the best three summers of my life. You conveyed a feeling that I've carried within me since September 1959, when my family and I drove away from Pine Lake for the last time.

title: SUSAN SARANDON SHAPES A SLEUTH IN A MURDER MOVIE
description: In ''Compromising Positions''

title: EX-SOCCER STAR
description: Colin Fowles, a former defender with the Fort Lauderdale Strikers and a former soccer star at Long Island University, has been identified as one of two people killed by gunfire at a north Dade County park.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S NEW FEAR
description: Helen Suzman, a longtime campaigner against apartheid, was musing the other day on the call by some in the United States for disinvestment in South Africa - a course of action she opposes.

title: CATHERINE CONN BRIDE OF JOHN M. YOUNGDAHL
description: At the Unitarian Church in Summit, N.J., yesterday Catherine Roberta Conn, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jason Conn of Watchung, N.J., was married to John Mason Youngdahl, a son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Richard Youngdahl of Tequesta, Fla. The Rev. Allen Wells performed the ceremony.

title: NEW YORK CITY OFFICER SEIZED ON AN UPSTATE ARSON CHARGE
description: A New York City police officer was arrested in Lake George, N.Y., Friday night and charged with arson and reckless endangerment after he was accused of setting fire to a poster on the wall of a restaurant where he had been refused service at the bar.

title: The Competition With Japan
description: It is not only nonsense to argue that Japan is capable of damaging the United States to the extent implied by Mr. White, it is dangerous in that it provides an easy excuse for Americans to explain away problems that are of our own making, notably, continued large budget deficits.

title: TANGLEWOOD, ENDING SEASON, LOOKS AHEAD TO '86
description: THIS afternoon's concert at Tanglewood, the summer home of the Boston Symphony, marks the end of the longest-ever season at this picture-book Berkshires concert facility three hours north of New York City.

title: WARNER CUTS A DIFFICULT PATH BACK
description: ''AS soon as he did it, you knew something was wrong. You could hear a pin drop in the stadium.''

title: The Bloom May Be Over For 'Garden of Eden'
description: His lively eyes shaded by a purple baseball hat, Adam Purple surveyed a realm he calls the Garden of Eden. Butterflies flitted about. The breeze stirring the bright flowers beneath the maples, walnuts and fruit trees seemed fresher than the exhaust-laden air of nearby Houston Street. Other gardeners stopped by to work and chat.

title: Marriott Marquis Delays Opening
description: The $450 million Marriott Marquis Hotel off Times Square was unable to open as planned yesterday because the city's Buildings Department had not yet issued it a temporary certificate of occupancy, the hotel's marketing director said.

title: RISING VALUE OF PLATINUM
description: UNREST in South Africa has grabbed front-page headlines, and many commodity market traders, reading between the lines, have been acting out fears or hopes.

title: Laura Bachman Becomes Bride of William Raynolds
description: Laura Adams Bachman, an assistant treasurer at the National Westminister Bank USA in New York, and William Sinclair Raynolds, an assistant vice president at the bank, were married yesterday at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Roger A. Bachman, in Portland, Ore.

title: METS TOP GIANTS ON 3 IN 9TH
description: Until someone writes a better scenario, this one will have to do:

title: A Prescription for Our Ailing Unions
description: In the early 1930's organized labor was in serious shape; today its condition is equally poor. Its image is tattered. Its organizing machinery is running poorly. Only 19 percent of American workers are union members, compared with a peak of 33 percent in 1953. And management is resorting to increasingly aggressive tactics to weaken collective bargaining. What can be done? Stricter enforcement of existing labor laws would help. But this alone is not enough. There are several steps the leadership of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. can take to help unions improve their operations and, in so doing, improve their chances of becoming a vibrant force in the 21st century.

title: NEWSPAPER PACT SEEN IN DETROIT
description: When the Gannett Company becomes the owner of The Detroit News, it will not only mark the first time that Gannett and Knight-Ridder Newspapers will own competing papers in the same market, but it could become the first time they cooperate in a joint operating agreement.

title: HEAD OF GROUP W GIRDS FOR BREAKUP
description: As chairman and chief executive of Westinghouse Broadcasting and Cable Inc., Daniel L. Ritchie has helped build the company, known as Group W, into the nation's third-largest cable system, with 2.1 million subscribers from Manhattan to Beverly Hills.

title: Pace of Fires Slowing In Northwest Forests
description: A fire that has burned more than 31,000 acres of timber and range land in national forests in Idaho and Montana was slowed yesterday by increased humidity and decreased wind.

title: UNION'S DETERMINED LEADER: CYRIL RAMPHOSA
description: Cyril Ramaphosa, the leader of black mine workers who began a strike today, recalled a time when he was a young boy walking to school and a soldier in uniform and big boots kicked him into a ditch without provocation. He said he did not cry. He stared at the soldier, picked up his small briefcase and continued on to class.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Sept. 2, 1985: *2*MONDAY *2*None Reported *2*TUESDAY Albertson's Inc Foxboro Co Allegheny Intl *2*WEDNESDAY Allen Group Inc Pennwalt Corp Beatrice Cos Premier Industrial First United RE RCA Corp Louisville Gas & Elec Signal Cos Midcon Corp USF&G Corp Northwest Indus *2*THURSDAY Allegheny Pwr Sys Engelhard Corp American Standard General Host Anderson Clayton Handleman Co Atlantic City Elec Co Lucky Stores Inc Brown Group Inc SPS Technologies Disney Productions *2*FRIDAY Chubb Corp Witco Chemical Hazleton Labs

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 2, 1985
description: International

title: BUJONES CANCELED AT MET
description: American Ballet Theater has announced that, because of a contract dispute, Fernando Bujones will not appear at his scheduled performances during the company's two-week engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House. Tomorrow night, at the company's opening performance, Leslie Browne and Robert La Fosse will replace Marianna Tcherkassky and Mr. Bujones in Sir Kenneth MacMillan's ''Romeo and Juliet.''

title: BAVARIAN CONFERS WITH EAST GERMAN
description: The East German leader, Erich Honecker, met for an hour here today with Franz Josef Strauss, the conservative Bavarian Premier.

title: Abuse of the Elderly Is Not the Whole Picture
description: To the Editor:

title: PHILIP PEARLSTEIN THURS TO VIDEOS TO TEACH ART
description: The teaching of art - how to draw a figure, a still life or a landscape -has traditionally been a matter of instruction between the master painter and his students, usually in studio classes, sometimes in books.

title: Reviving Labor
description: Labor Day can be so quiet in the capital that it seems little more than an occasion for cynics to mark as an empty measure of the dimming of old labor's fire in an age of material complacency. Not so, says Ed Rosney, president of the National Capital Labor History Society, who notes some street displays are being introduced today in preparation for the planned revival next year of the booming downtown parade that once marked Labor Day.

title: FOUNDER'S SON EXPLAINS BID FOR FREEDOM CHAIN
description: Harry H. Hoiles, whose $900 million bid for Freedom Newspapers Inc. was rejected by the newspaper and television chain's board of directors late last week, said that philosophical and personal differences in the family had led him to seek control of the company founded by his father, Raymond Cyril Hoiles, in 1927.

title: STEPSON OF SAKHAROV BEGINS A HUNGER STRIKE
description: The stepson of Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist and human rights advocate, has begun a hunger strike to protest what he says has been Reagan Administration inaction in winning freedom for his father.

title: Dairy Group In Chapter 11
description: The financially troubled Northeast Dairy Cooperative Federation has filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: TURKEY EXCAVATION TO CLEAR WAY FOR A DAM YIELDS LAYERS OF CIVILIZATIONS
description: In a mound 180 feet high, surmounted by the jagged ruin of a citadel that Arab invaders built seven centuries ago in this town on the Euphrates, lie, layer upon layer, artifacts of at least six millenniums of history.

title: THE ALLURE OF BASEBALL AND BREWS
description: Beware of Indianapolis!

title: Kim Feuer Weds on L.I.
description: The marriage of Kim Feuer, a student at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business, to Charles Antony Ruys de Perez, an associate with the New York law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton, took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence H. Feuer, in Brookville, L.I. Village Justice Martin I. Kaminsky of Muttontown, L.I., performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Alfred D. C. Ruys de Perez of Toronto and the late Stephanie Ruys de Perez.

title: ISRAELIS DETAIN 14 MORE ARABS IN NEW WEST BANK CRACKDOWN
description: Israel detained 14 more Arabs in the occupied West Bank today and ordered them held without trial.

title: Dueling Conductors
description: Until now, the only scores that Alvin Robertson had to worry about were those that determined the success or failure of the San Antonio Spurs, with whom he will be entering his second season this fall. But in recent weeks the 23-year-old guard has set aside the X's and O's in favor of a cram course of musical notes prepared for him by James Sedaris, the associate conductor of the San Antonio Symphony.

title: Topics;   Socialist Sociology; East Wing
description: Remember the convergence theory? It was once fashionable to believe that the Soviet bloc, after exposure to Western entrepreneurs peddling blue jeans and double cheeseburgers, would absorb the values of John Locke and Adam Smith. Diners Club International is working on its own version of the theory.

title: Sindelar Wins
description: Joey Sindelar knocked in a hole-in-one on the 14th hole today, breaking a three-way tie for the lead en route to the title of the B. C. Open.

title: O'CONNOR SAYS HE MAY UPHOLD HOSPITAL ACCORD
description: John Cardinal O'Connor said yesterday that he was prepared to break with New York City's private hospitals to reach a final labor agreement with the hospital workers union that struck last year.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Associated Dry Goods Corp. has appointed Herbert A. Abbott Jr. to the new position of vice chairman of its L. S. Ayres & Co. division, which operates department stores in the Cincinnati area throughout Indiana.

title: RECOVERING HEART PATIENT HEARS 'CLUNKING' SOUND
description: Michael Drummond continued his dramatic recovery after an artifical heart implant four days ago, but was apparently surprised by the noise coming from the mechanical pump, hospital officials said.

title: ARMY IS MARCHING IN RIGHT DIRECTION
description: The air was rushing out of the Army football program. The Cadets had not had a winning season in seven years and their record against Division I-A opponents over the previous five seasons was a feeble 4-33-1.

title: Fountain of Happiness
description: Washington remains a place to avoid in the summer when the boxy office buildings take on an adobe glare and there is a dog-pant pace that recalls the harsh judgment of Trollope: ''As melancholy and miserable a town as the mind of man can conceive.''

title: RAMS HOPE BROCK IS MORE THAN A PASSING FANCY
description: You should see Dieter Brock's arms. His biceps and triceps bulge like those of a weightlifter. His forearms look as if they were chiseled in marble. ''They're Popeye arms,'' said Jack Faulkner, the Los Angeles Rams' administrator of football relations.

title: Flexible System
description: His football players averaged more points a game than some college basketball teams last season, and Archie Cooley suddenly found himself in charge of a football phenomenon. When Mississippi Valley State produced 60.9 points and 496.8 yards a game, and the wide receiver Jerry Rice became a first-round selection in the National Football League draft, Cooley was in demand.

title: Nan Borowitz Weds Andrew Langer
description: At the Community Synagogue in Sands Point, L.I., yesterday Nan Safran Borowitz and Andrew Michael Langer were married by Rabbi Eugene B. Borowitz, the bride's father, assisted by Cantor Jacob Yaron. The bride also is a daughter of Dr. Estelle Borowitz of Port Washington, L.I. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Langer of West Newton, Mass.

title: Cabinet Is Revived In Burkina Faso
description: Sept. 1 (Reuters) - Burkina Faso's President, Thomas Sankara, today reappointed most members of the Cabinet he dissolved on Aug. 12.

title: ELLIOT'S EVEN PACE WINS SOUTHERN 500
description: Bill Elliott, driving a conservative race, watched three of his top competitors go up in smoke on his way to winning both the Southern 500 Grand National stock car race today and a $1 million bonus.

title: U.S., INDUSTRY AND PHYSICIANS ATTACK MEDICAL MALPRACTICE
description: After decades of little action, the Federal Government, industry and organized medicine have begun a new attack on the problem of medical malpractice and incompetence.

title: Power on L.I. Curbed 2 Days After a Storm
description: More than 1,400 families on Long Island remained without power for most of today, two days after a violent thunderstorm swept through the metropolitan area on the eve of the Labor Day weekend. But by 10 P.M. all but 20 homes had their power restored.

title: China Reminds Tibet Of Takeover in 1965
description: China today marked the 20th anniversary of Tibet's designation as an autonomous Chinese region by reiterating Peking's sovereignty and promising prosperity for Tibetans.

title: FACULTY STRIKES HOFSTRA AS TALKS ARE BROKEN OFF
description: Faculty members struck Hofstra University yesterday morning, two days before the scheduled start of classes, after all-night negotiations failed to yield a contract agreement, union officials said.

title: Why CBS Rejects Birth-Control Message
description: To the Editor:

title: Catching Up
description: Steve Rogers, the 35-year-old right-hander whose 158 victories established a club record at Montreal, is still trying to make it back to the major leagues, but the sledding continues to be rough. Released by the Expos in May, Rogers signed on with the California Angels' farm at Edmonton, where he lost two of three decisions before being dropped again early in July.

title: TEAM IS DEFENDING 6 IN STEWART CASE
description: Frank Lopez raised his hand in a hold-your-horses gesture to Barry Agulnick.

title: MOULTON'S STUDIES CONTINUE ON COURT
description: There are some athletes who enter college hoping to obtain a degree they can fall back on in case they falter in their sport. Alycia Moulton did it the other way around. She went to Stanford, earned her diploma in political science and planned a career in law, only to discover, she said, that ''there are too many lawyers, especially in California.''

title: GOLD HELD UNLIKELY TO RISE RAPIDLY
description: Gold prices are not likely to rise rapidly soon, in the opinion of bullion traders and analysts, despite the specter of racial violence and labor unrest in the South African gold mines, where more than 60 percent of the non-Communist world's gold is produced.

title: Legionnaires' Illness in West
description: The bacterium that causes legionnaires' disease has been found in an air-conditioning unit on the roof of the city's Public Safety Building, The Spokesman-Review reported today. It said one case of the disease had been confirmed and a second suspected among Spokane County maintenance employees who worked on a roofing project near the unit.

title: The Most Vulnerable
description: To the Editor:

title: Pakistani Bonds Sell Heavily
description: Pakistan said today that it had raised at least $868 million by selling a special Government bond aimed at attracting money hidden by the business classes to avoid taxes. Finance Minister Mahbubul Haq said the strong response to the bond offer demonstrated that the private sector had confidence in the Government.

title: 3 NEW GROUP PRESIDENTS AT CONTINENTAL GRAIN
description: The Continental Grain Company, the world's largest commodity trading concern, has named three new group presidents, completing a realignment of its major businesses.

title: WHEELING WORKERS TO GET AID
description: Officials who administer the Ohio unemployment compensation fund have ruled that striking workers at the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation are entitled to jobless benefits because they are the victims of a company lockout.

title: GORBACHEV INVOKES DIETY
description: To Western ears, the invocation of the deity by the head of an atheist nation may seem somewhat akin to a citation of Lenin by an American President.

title: CITY STILL NEEDS 600 TEACHERS, QUINONES SAYS
description: With schools scheduled to open a week from today, New York City has yet to hire 600 teachers, Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones said yesterday. But he predicted that the teachers would be hired by opening day.

title: Lights, Camera, Kickoff
description: SPORTS movies used to be simple in the old meat-and-potato days, with Gary Cooper saying ''yup'' and ''nope'' as Lou Gehrig, Elizabeth Taylor jumping up and down at the finish line in ''National Velvet'' and that marvelous character actor - I wonder what he's portraying lately - asking Pat O'Brien to ''Win one for the Gipper.''

title: Markets Closed
description: All stock and commodity markets in the United States are closed today in observance of Labor Day. Government offices, banks and many businesses also are closed.

title: SPACEWALKING ASTRONAUTS REPAIR SATELLITE AND SPIN IT OFF ON MISSION
description: Leaning forward from the end of the space shuttle's mechanical arm, like the figurehead on the prow of an old sailing ship, Dr. James D. van Hoften today gave the rewired Leasat 3 satellite a vigorous shove and sent it spinning away with a new chance at a useful life in higher orbit.

title: TEXTILE CURB PRESSURE BUILDS
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN's rejection of shoe industry pleas for protection against imports has strengthened the hand of textile lobbyists pressing for legislated curbs, and a showdown with the Administration could come within a few weeks.

title: Chicago and Philadelphia Facing Teacher Strikes
description: The Chicago Teachers Union broke off negotiations early yesterday and prepared for a strike vote, while Philadelphia teachers who were threatening a walkout resumed talks with the school board.

title: DUTCH CYCLIST EDGES LEMOND
description: Greg LeMond is a professional cycling superstar, and at no time was that more evident today than on the 18th and last lap of the men's professional world cycling championship, a 165-mile bicycle road race on a twisting, hilly circuit through the wine region of Veneto.

title: MOTHERS WHO LOST CUSTODY
description: Eight years ago Cathy Knapt's husband told her that he had filed for divorce and that he wanted custody of their two sons, Russell, 10 years old, and Marty, 8.

title: EATING DISORDERS: NEW TREATMENTS
description: ''I've wanted to be normal for a long time,'' said Susan Losek. ''I had anorexia for a year 12 years ago and I've been bulimic for 12 years. I've wanted to be well. I've wanted it so badly.''

title: Topics;   Socialist Sociology; Unhappy Families
description: ''Happy families are all alike; every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way,'' goes the famous opening line of ''Anna Karenina.'' Yet today's young Russian family turns out to be miserable in some commonly predictable ways, too.

title: 50 Cuban Prisoners Force Fed in Atlanta
description: Fifty Cuban prisoners at the Federal penitentiary here have been on a hunger strike for a week and are being force fed under a doctor's care, according to a prison spokesman.

title: For Prestige's Sake
description: The ways of connoting prestige in the capital seem as varied and relentless as the separate egos that keep the city in motion. Some strivers who work in assorted inner sanctums - Congress, the White House - play the game by leaving their photo credentials casually dangling on display after hours, like vain monks showing their scapulars of status in the inner sanctum.

title: New York Policemen March With the I.R.A.
description: Members of a New York City police band ignored appeals by the Government and Irish police and marched Saturday in a parade with I.R.A. supporters.

title: Barbara A. Lent Weds Geoffrey D. Roberts Jr.
description: Barbara Anne Lent, a daughter of Representative Norman F. Lent of East Rockaway, L.I., and Washington, and Nancy B. Lent of Cape Coral, Fla., was married yesterday to Geoffrey Dorning Roberts Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roberts of Boxborough, Mass., and Punta Gorda, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Frederick Hummel performed the Methodist ceremony at the Church by the Sea in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: The Grip of History
description: The diverse regions of this huge country were first united in 221 B.C. when Qin Shihuangdi conquered other states and proclaimed himself emperor. The name Qin, pronounced Chin in English, gave us the word China. Qin Shihuangdi also left one of the most extraordinary memorials on earth: the terra-cotta army.

title: Old School Ties
description: Before halftime of this century, the best college football teams were often led by coaches who had long since gained vast experience in how to wear the school colors well. In fact, beginning in 1936, when The Associated Press became the first news agency to conduct a football poll, and continuing for 14 years thereafter, alumni coached all but two teams that ended a season with the A.P.'s No. 1 ranking.

title: BAINE'S HOMER HELPS BEAT JAYS
description: Harold Baines hit a two-run home run and Ron Kittle added a bases-empty homer today to lead the Chicago White Sox to a 4-1 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays. Baines's homer was his 15th this year and sixth in 11 days.

title: STRIKE AT 7 MINES
description: MBlack workers at seven mines tonight began a strike over pay that is expected to involve 60,000 of the country's 550,000 black mine employees.

title: CURB ON CURRENCY
description: The South African Government tonight announced a four-month freeze on repayments of principal on the country's foreign debt. Payments of interest on the loans will be permitted. At the same time, the Government said it was reintroducing exchange controls to stem the flow of foreign currency out of the country.

title: STONEHENGE AGAIN
description: A MAGGOT. By John Fowles. 455 pages. Little, Brown. $19.95. Several years after writing ''The Collector,'' ''The French Lieutenant's Woman'' and other novels, John Fowles provided the text for a fine book of photographs by Barry Brukoff called ''The Enigma of Stonehenge.'' In it he described his fascination since boyhood with those mysterious boulders standing in solitude on the Salisbury Plain. Recounting the theories about the ancient monument as a religious temple or astronomical calendar or both, his hand was sure. Now, by a leap of the imagination, Stonehenge plays a significant part in his new novel, ''A Maggot.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 2, 1985
description: International

title: OUTDOORS: LABOR DAY DEPARTURES
description: LABOR DAY has come, a time when resident anglers in seacoast resort communities know that they will soon have the fishing to themselves, miles of dunes and wide, summer-formed beaches beautifully bare of all save dunnage planks, wheeling gulls and terns, shorebirds stilting the wash of the waves and a handfull of familiar four-wheel-drive vehicles.

title: CONCERT: OPERA STARS STAGE BENEFIT FOR AIDS
description: Robert Jacobson, the editor of Opera News, stood at the lectern in the East Hampton High School Auditorium on Saturday night and announced that history was being made: ''everybody listed on your program is here and waiting to sing.'' The roster was indeed a starry one - ''A Gala Night for Singing,'' it was called, without hyperbole - but the historic import lay in the fact that the operatic community was rallying its forces for the first time in support of AIDS research.

title: Driver Is Killed In Race Accident
description: Stefan Bellof, a West German Formula One racer, died today of injuries suffered in a car crash during the 1,000 Kilometers of Spa endurance race, officials said.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: FROM 'HAVE NOT' CAMBODIA
description: Prak Sarinn had nothing to do with a Government decision to invite a group of foreign journalists to this poverty-racked country recently. But when a few of them turned up at Orphanage No. 1, which he runs, he took the opportunity to mention a few things that were on his own agenda.

title: KEY U.S. ROLE SEEN IN FURTHERING TRADE
description: Protectionism in world trade has gathered so much momentum that American and foreign officials who met here in recent days say that only the United States has the power to reverse it, possibly by orchestrating a shock to the world economy.

title: The Day When
description: Labor Day started out, and remains, a celebration of the labor movement. What it would become as well was surely undreamt of by its architects, the Knights of Labor, when they paraded in New York City on the first Monday of September 1882.

title: Chicago Board Deal
description: The Chicago Board of Trade will gain exclusive rights to develop and list a futures contract based on the Montreal Exchange's Canadian Market Portfolio index under an agreement signed Friday. The Canadian index consists of stocks from 25 of Canada's largest public companies, representing about 40 percent of the total value of all listed Canadian stocks.

title: Kansas Defeats Hawaii by 33-27
description: Mike Rogers, who started after two backs ahead of him became academically ineligible, rushed for two touchdowns, and Mike Norseth threw for 318 yards Saturday night to lead Kansas to a 33-27 victory over Hawaii in the opener for both teams.

title: SATANIC SYMBOLISM REPORTED IN HOMES OF 'STALKER' VICTIMS
description: Symbols of devil worship were found in the homes of some of the 16 people slain in the ''night stalker'' case, according to news reports.

title: TAX PLAN SLOWS SALES OF RESORT PROPERTY
description: Uncertainties over President Reagan's proposed overhaul of the tax code are depressing prices and causing a slump in the sale of resort property over much of the nation this summer.

title: Pacific Republic of Palau Getting New President
description: Senator Lazarus Salii defeated acting President Alfonso Oiterong in a special presidential election in this tiny Pacific republic, according to uncertified results announced today.

title: NICARAGUA REBELS OPEN A NEW FRONT
description: Anti-Government rebels appear to have opened a new battlefront in the central part of Nicaragua, where eight months ago the war was something local residents only read about in newspapers.

title: ELLEN SALOMON PAVIA
description: Ellen Salomon Pavia, a psychiatric social worker, died Saturday of a cerebral hemorrhage at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: CARDINALS' TUDOR POSTS 7TH SHUTOUT
description: Willie McGee had three hits, including a bases-empty home run, and John Tudor pitched his seventh shutout today to pace the St. Louis Cardinals to a 5-0 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: Solidarity Calls for Boycott
description: Underground Solidarity members called on Poles today to boycott October parliamentary elections to protest the outlawing of the union under martial law and the violation of the 1980 accord that led to union's formation. Pope John Paul II, from his summer residence in Castel Gandolfo, Italy, also urged the Communist authorities to respect the accords that granted Poles the right to strike and form independent trade unions.

title: MATTINGLY PROPELS YANKEES
description: Don Mattingly and Don Baylor have been hitting in opposite directions this season, but yesterday they converged at the intersection of Mike Witt and Al Holland and wheeled the Yankees one game closer to first place.

title: ASSAULT IN CELL WAS WITNESSED, OFFICIALS REPORT
description: Law-enforcement officials said yesterday that investigators had several witnesses to the reported beating of a handcuffed prisoner by a civilian police employee in a holding cell at Police Headquarters last Thursday.

title: Profit at British Aerospace Up
description: British Aerospace says its pretax earnings in the first half of 1985 climbed 21 percent, to $:68.3 million, or $95.6 million at present exchange rates, from $:56.3 million a year earlier.

title: NEW SMALL-COLLEGE LEAGUE EXPECTED TO SPARK INTEREST
description: Formation of a league with six of the metropolitan area's solid Division III teams should increase local interest in small-college football even though two of the best small-college teams in the area - Hofstra and Wagner -were barred from the Liberty Football Conference.

title: The Road to Industrial Rebirth
description: As everyone knows, foreign competition and technology are fundamentally changing the American economy. As an instrument of progress, change is welcome. But change becomes a problem when it occurs as a series of shocks, causing massive dislocation. It is this form of change we have experienced in America's steel industry and in the broad basic manufacturing sector of the economy.

title: TRAINING TENNIS PARENTS
description: IN tennis circles, stories of parents engaging in shouting matches and even fisticuffs with other parents in the stands while their children are playing a match are commonplace.

title: BANKERS SAY CREDIT RATING WILL SUFFER
description: South Africa's freeze on repayments of foreign debt was a necessary move but will harm the country's credit rating and discourage new lending there in the future, bankers said yesterday.

title: Sir Muhammad Z. Khan, 92; Pakistan Ex-Foreign Minister
description: Sir Muhammad Zafrulla Khan, Pakistan's first Foreign Minister, died today after a long illness at the age of 92, the official press agency reported.

title: Suspect Is Jailed In Trooper's Death
description: A Westville man charged with killing a state police detective during a drug raid has been moved from a hospital to the Gloucester County Jail, where he was being held today in lieu of $1 million cash bail, officials said.

title: 11 TO BE EXTRADITED IN $7 MILLION THEFT
description: A Federal magistrate today ordered 11 suspects in a $7 million Wells Fargo robbery in 1983 extradited to Connecticut.

title: CAMBODIAN WAR BY RADIO
description: Journalists, usually denied the opportunity for first-hand reporting from inside Cambodia - or Kampuchea, as it is known in Southeast Asia - rely for information at least in part on the radio broadcasts of two opposing sides in the Cambodian civil war.

title: RANDOLPH WINS U.S. AMATEUR, 1 UP
description: A chiropractor worked on Sam Randolph's painful back twice today during the 36-hole final match of the United States Amateur golf championship. Claiming the treatment made him feel better, Randolph, a 21-year-old senior at Southern California, went on to beat Peter Persons, a University of Georgia senior, 1 up, to win the title he almost won last year.

title: OLD COLLEAGUES VIE IN COUNCIL RACE
description: Miriam Friedlander, seeking her fourth term in the City Council, was at the podium of a voter forum on Mott Street in Chinatown the other day, reminding her audience that she had appointed the first Asian-American to the local planning board.

title: Why CBS Rejects Birth-Control Message
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. STUDIES POLICY ON MIDEAST TALKS
description: The Reagan Administration will undertake a policy review in the coming weeks on whether to offer an American initiative to keep alive a Jordanian plan for Middle East peace talks, senior Administration officials say.

title: The Care That Goes Into Making a Theater a Landmark
description: To the Editor:

title: JOSIANE HAYAT IS BRIDE OF DR. PETER GOTTESFELD
description: Josiane Hayat, a daughter of Rosette Hayat of Rego Park, Queens, and the late David Edouard Hayat of Alexandria, Egypt, was married yesterday to Dr. Peter Michael Gottesfeld, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Gottesfeld of Teaneck, N.J., and Stockbridge, Mass. Rabbi Barry Schaeffer performed the ceremony at the Tammybrook Country Club in Cresskill, N.J.

title: NOAH AND CONNORS REACH ROUND OF 16
description: Some people come to New York City seeking fame and fortune. There are composers who have earned a living writing about them. But for Yannick Noah, New York's appeal was its promise of anonymity. In 1983, he won the French Open and was driven from Paris by his adoring countrymen. In New York, New York, he found a refuge and a new identity as just another face in the crowd.

title: CAN PITCHING SURVIVE PENNANT DRIVE?
description: IN each of the past two seasons, the team the Yankees finished the season with won the American League's Eastern Division championship - the Baltimore Orioles in 1983 and the Detroit Tigers last season. This season they finish with the Toronto Blue Jays, the team in first place, four games ahead of the Yankees. Will recent history repeat, or will the Yankees reverse the outcome and win the division championship themselves?

title: WHITEFISH PRODUCT BAN STANDS
description: Health officials have extended a ban on sales of kapchonka, a Russian preparation for whitefish, by its two metropolitan area processors until the processors change their methods, according to the City Health Department.

title: HURRICANE GROWS AS WIND AND TIDES HIT FLORIDA COAST
description: Hurricane Elena intensified dangerously today, unpredictably doubling back and once again bearing down on the Gulf Coast east of New Orleans with winds up to 125 miles an hour.

title: CITY OPERA: 'MERRY WIDOW' CHANGES
description: The New York City Opera seems to be functioning not merely as an ad hoc collection of players but as a genuine ensemble in its current production of Lehar's ''Merry Widow.'' As such, Saturday night's performance, the third so far this season, was a modest triumph.

title: Man Held in Miami Assaults
description: Michael Richard Gersley, 30 years old, has been charged with five counts of sexual battery of women in their homes, the police say. The attacker gained entry by saying he was to check the air conditioner. Sgt. David Simmons of the Metro-Dade Police rape squad said Mr. Gersley was arrested Thursday when he ran naked through a Dade County apartment complex. He was also charged with five armed burglaries and two armed robberies.

title: Costa Rica Ties Canada in Soccer
description: Canada and Costa Rica tied 0-0 today in the race for a spot in the 1986 World Cup tournament in Mexico City.

title: HAMPTON JITNEY'S PATH IS PAVED BY SAVVY OWNER
description: WHEN the weekend rush between New York and the Hamptons ends today, no one will be sorrier than James Davidson.

title: Demolition Is Claiming A Famed Funeral Chapel
description: ''Time after time during the afternoon, a dozen mounted policemen were forced to charge into the crowd, while women shrieked and yelled in terror and tried to scramble away from the horses' hoofs.''

title: MUSIC: R.E.M. AT RADIO CITY
description: R.E.M., the critically admired rock quartet from Athens, Ga., makes droning, astringently textured music that combines a backwoods American twang with the militant austerity of contemporary new wave music. Building on the minimalist esthetics of punk rock, the group, which played a sold-out concert at Radio City Music Hall on Saturday, modernizes the sounds of 60's folk rock - especially the Byrds - by adding carefully planted guitar dissonances.

title: A War on Malnutrition
description: To the Editor:

title: Steel Imports Fell in July
description: Steel imports in July totaled 1.6 million net tons, a 41 percent drop from a year ago and 33 percent below June 1985 imports, the American Institute for Imported Steel said Friday.

title: Reagan Vacation Over; Missouri Trip Planned
description: President Reagan got in the final day of horseback riding and ranch work of his three-week vacation today. He and his wife, Nancy, plan to return to Washington on Labor Day by way of Independence, Mo.

title: Topics;   Socialist Sociology; Red Rock
description: With a loud harrumph, a moralist indicts rock groups in this way: ''They preach sex, fun and a life which is devoid of social meaning but filled with a thirst for fancy material goods, money, and for unbounded anarchy, license, cruelty and indifference to people.''

title: MEXICO BID FOR LOAN REVISIONS
description: Mexico announced today that it would demand new negotiations with its foreign creditors in an effort to improve the terms of payment on its $96 billion foreign debt.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Seattle Mariners, at Yankee Stadium, 1:05 P.M. Ron Guidry pitches for the Yankees in the first of a three-game series.

title: The New Generals in Nigeria
description: Military coups are not the ideal mechanism for changing political leadership, but to judge from the first signs, the latest change in Nigeria may be for the better. The military government of Gen. Ibrahim Babangida has quickly eased the repressive policies of the prior military government, releasing political prisoners and easing up on the country's traditionally outspoken press.

title: China's Grain Exports
description: Despite floods, China for the first time will export more grain than it imports this year, the Government said Friday. Stored grain from record harvests in past years will permit the net export.

title: Valerie W. Moss Weds Edward McKee Fields
description: At the Chapel in the Woods of St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y., yesterday Valerie Winter Moss and Edward McKee Fields, graduates of the University of Denver, were married by the Rev. Arthur W. Hargate and Rabbi Roy Rosenberg.

title: 1,000 PROTEST KAHANE'S VIEWS IN ISRAELI ARAB CITY
description: About 1,000 Jews and Arabs marched through the narrow streets of this Arab city over the weekend to protest Rabbi Meir Kahane's extreme anti-Arab views and discrimination against Israeli Arabs.

title: Hospital Union Chief Elected to Labor Post
description: Doris Turner, president of the 102,000-member New York City-based hospital workers union, has become the first black woman to be elected to the state's A.F.L.-C.I.O. executive council, a spokesman announced today.

title: PLAY AND WORK HEED A CASUAL SCRIPT
description: To the delight of White House officials, President Reagan's working vacation in the West has gone off without a hitch. With Mr. Reagan heading back to official Washington Monday, there have been no serious deviations from aides' script for his 23-day stay at his ranch in the Santa Ynez mountains.

title: PROFESSORS ASSESS REAGAN AS LEADER
description: The Reagan Presidency received mixed reviews from a panel of scholars at the annual meeting of the American Political Science Association.

title: IN UNION'S 80TH YEAR, 22 WOBBLIES KEEP RADICAL FIRES BURNING
description: The convention got under way an hour late. The masking tape broke loose and a banner fell off the wall. The report of the general executive board could not be presented. It was said to be in the mail. A temporary chairman had to be elected to replace the temporary chairman, who also was on the luncheon committee and had to go out for food.

title: RULES TO ENFORCE VOTING RIGHTS DUE
description: The Reagan Administration has developed new rules for enforcing the Voting Rights Act that would make it more difficult for black and Hispanic people and other minority groups to challenge state and local election laws as discriminatory.

title: FOR THE WORKER: CHANGING TIMES, NEW CHALLENGES
description: He was a radio operator during World War II, and afterward Raymond Liebgott decided there was a future in all those tubes and wires. By the late 1940's, he was working on black-and-white televisions. By the 1980's, he was peering at circuitry so tiny he sometimes needed a microscope.

title: Monogamy's Helpers
description: To the Editor:

title: MEXICO THREATENED BY OIL PRICE CUTS
description: Mexico, which depends on the sale of crude oil to generate 75 percent of its export income and half of its government's revenues, is increasingly finding its economic back to the wall as the price of oil falls on the international market.

title: PASTOR SCOLDS PARISH FOR REJECTING AN AIDS SHELTER
description: The pastor of a West Side Roman Catholic church told his parishioners yesterday that he was ''saddened'' by their opposition to the establishment of a shelter for AIDS patients because ''the weakest of our community need help, and we were unable to offer that help.''

title: EDUCATION: KOCH CALLS SCHOOLS IMPROVED, BUT HIS MAIN OPPONENTS DISAGREE
description: None of the major candidates for mayor in the Sept. 10 Democratic primary election express satisfaction with the school system, but what separates Mayor Koch from his two opponents is that he says the schools are getting better and they do not.

title: RUSSIANS DOMINATE ROWING FINALS
description: The men's finals of the World Rowing Championships concluded on a somewhat disappointing note for the United States team. The United States had entries in four of the eight men's heavyweight championships contested today, and captured a silver medal in the single sculls and a bronze medal in the glamour race of the regatta, the eight-oared championship, which was won by the Soviet Union.

title: Pursued
description: Unaccustomed as he is to private speaking, Howard H. Baker Jr., busy citizen, has just hired a press secretary, David L. Spear. Mr. Baker is the former Senate majority leader from Tennessee, and since retirement to a law firm everything he does is usually construed as a sign of his lingering resolve to run for President.

title: Witnesses Named For Drug Trial
description: Keith Hernandez, Enos Cabell and Dave Parker are among the current and former major league baseball players who may testify for the Government in the Federal drug trafficking trial of a Philadelphia caterer that is scheduled to begin Tuesday.

title: VANCOUVER EXCHANGE STRUGGLES TO REPAIR ITS TATTERED IMAGE
description: Last Oct. 19 is still remembered as Black Friday on the Vancouver Stock Exchange - Canada's penny stock market. The bottom fell out of the market, investors suffered more than $30 million in losses and the exchange's already shaky reputation teetered a bit more.

title: FOREIGN BANKS EAGER FOR DEBT TALKS WITH PERU
description: Western banks seem eager to start debt talks with Peru's new Government despite its decision to turn its back on the International Monetary Fund and limit debt payments over the next year to just 10 percent of export earnings.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We believe that to travel all the way to Geneva just to get acquainted, just to look at the beauties of Lake Geneva, the beauty of Swiss mountains, that is not adequate to the leaders of two such great nations.

title: JAZZ: MORGANA KING
description: Some 30 years since she began preforming in clubs, Morgana King remains in formidable command of the vocal techniques she has long used to communicate a mood of mystically enraptured eroticism. Working in a high soprano register that seems untouched by the years, Miss King spins out short vocal improvisations, embellishes phrases with delicate fluttery melismas, and bends notes, all in a voice that is barely larger than a hum.

title: A BLEAK SUMMER FOR MOVIE MAKERS
description: The summer of Hollywood's discontent ended this weekend. Ticket sales were 17 percent lower than last summer. Only three movies - ''Rambo,'' ''Back to the Future'' and ''Cocoon'' - kept their momentum month after month.

title: Venezuela Debt Pact
description: President Jaime Lusinchi of Venezuela said neither he nor his Government would bow to pressures against signing a $21.2 billion foreign debt rescheduling agreement.

title: Pamela Blum Marries
description: Pamela Brenda Blum, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Blum of Stamford, Conn., and Robert Blattner 2d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lionel Blattner, also of Stamford, were married yesterday. Rabbi Joseph Ehrenkranz performed the ceremony at Congregation Agudath Sholom in Stamford. The bride is a manager in the management consulting services department of Price Waterhouse in Los Angeles. Mr. Blattner is president of RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video in Burbank, Calif.

title: WALKER INJURY PUTS JETS IN BIND
description: Just when it appeared that, finally, the Jets' glass was half-full and not half-empty, it cracked.

title: Young Bridge Climbers Swallowed by Twilight
description: Something mysterious hangs over Inwood Hill Park at times, perhaps never so much as when a dark autumnal cloud cover skirts the treetops in that near wilderness at Manhattan's tip.

title: Wife Charged in Fatal Fire
description: A 31-year-old woman whose husband died earlier in the day in a fire that swept through their apartment here was arrested today and charged with homicide and arson in connection with the death, authorities said. The woman, Julia Alston, bought gasoline today and there was a strong gas odor when firefighters arrived at the couple's Hawthorne Avenue apartment, said the city's Fire Director, John Caufield. The body of the woman's husband, Michael, 33, was found there.

title: Susan Rich Is Married To Mitchell Mailman
description: Susan Mary Rich, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank D. Rich Jr. of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Mitchell E. Mailman, the son of Sybil J. Mailman of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Harry Mailman. Rabbi Gerald Skolnik, assisted by Cantor Erno Grosz, officiated at the Rich home.

title: Old, Young and The Labor of Love
description: Though Labor Day has long been greeted with groans by people who dread returning to work or school, there are a growing number who cheer its arrival - old people and young people who, having not seen each other since June, will again be reunited in programs of mutual aid and companionship.

title: ECONOMIC CALENDAR
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: 'Arms and the Man' Closes
description: ''Arms and the Man,'' George Bernard Shaw's 1894 comedy starring Kevin Klein, Raul Julia and Glenne Headly, closed yesterday at Circle in the Square. The play, directed by John Malkovich, ran for 109 performances and 23 previews.

title: State to Give Housing Aid
description: Governor Cuomo today announced $24.6 million in loans or grants to rehabilitate housing and to convert vacant, non-residential property into housing. Under the Governor's plan, the state's Low-Income Housing Trust Fund will provide up to $40,000 a unit to nonprofit organizations, municipalities or low-income individuals. Applications must be received by the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal by Oct. 21.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MUSIC IN THE SKY ''Music is an Open Sky,'' a 12-hour mini-festival of experimental jazz, closes the Dewar's Village Jazz Festival today at Sweet Basil (88 Seventh Avenue South at Bleecker and Grove Streets). Produced by Horst Liepolt, a co-owner of the club, the festival begins at 2 P.M. and features five ensembles. Each will play an hour-and-a-half set with a 45-minute break. Opening the show is the Steve Turre/ John Blake Quintet followed by Khan Jamal's quartet at 4 o'clock, and Sam Rivers's ten-piece Rivbea Orchestra at 6. Keshavan (with Charles and Charnet Moffett) will appear at 8, and Beaver Harris's 360 Degree Music Experience will play at 11.

title: TAYLOR CALDWELL, PROLIFIC AUTHOR, DIES
description: Taylor Caldwell, one of the world's most prolific best-selling authors, died of pulmonary failure on Friday at her home in Greenwich, Conn. She was 84 years old and suffered from lung cancer.

title: GORBACHEV SAYS U.S. TIES GROW WORSE
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in his first interview with an American publication since becoming Soviet leader, has accused the Reagan Administration of intensifying its anti-Soviet statements despite the approach of the Geneva summit meeting.

title: Jokes, Tears And Honors
description: The Baltimore Orioles retired the No. 22 jersey of Jim Palmer today, but the 268-game winner hinted he may yet make a comeback.

title: Morgenthau for District Attorney
description: After 10 years as District Attorney for Manhattan, Robert Morgenthau faces his first serious opponent. C. Vernon Mason, a lawyer in private practice, seems unlikely to unseat the incumbent in the Sept. 10 Democratic primary. But the challenge inspires healthy discussion of this powerful office and the way Mr. Morgenthau has filled it. While not beyond criticism, his handling of the job well-qualifies him for another four-year term.

title: No Headline
description: When the Japanese delegation arrived by boat for the 9 A.M. ceremony aboard the battleship Missouri 40 years ago today, chattering spectators jammed every space on the forward decks and in the ship's superstructure.

title: Sir MacFarlane Burnet, 85; Nobel Laureate in Medicine
description: Sir MacFarlane Burnet, who won the Nobel Prize in Medicine in 1960, died Saturday of cancer, his family said today. He was 85 years old.

title: FOR JAPANESE, A TIME TO REMEMBER: NOT WAR'S CONSEQUENCE, BUT NATUIRE'S
description: In a sturdy stone building across the street from the Imperial Palace moat, one must ride up five stories and then walk down a long corridor to find the office from which Gen. Douglas MacArthur once presided over Japan.

title: Israeli Policy Bolsters Meir Kahane's Appeal
description: To the Editor:

title: TOUGHEST SEASON
description: IN his black-sleeved sweatshirt, Chuck Tanner sat behind his manager's desk in the Pirates' clubhouse in Riverfront Stadium and scanned the sports section yesterday morning. He did not look at the standings. ''I don't have to,'' he said, ''I know how far out of first place we are. Thirty-five games, isn't it?'' The Pirates were deep in last place, 37 games, in fact, behind the Cardinals.

title: 1,877 JOBS GO FROM SHREVEPOPRT, LA. TO SINGAPORE
description: Sandra Grilliette has spent the last five years of her life testing and fixing the circuit boards that go into telephones, the little Trimlines, the avocado-green Touchtones, the big black business sets.

title: Springsteen Gives Funds to 2 Groups
description: The rock singer Bruce Springsteen gave $15,000 to each of two public-interest groups Saturday night during the intermission of his concert at Giants Stadium at the New Jersey Meadowlands.

title: HOPING FOR HITTING REVIVAL
description: WITH just five weeks to go, the Mets are entering the homestretch of a pennant race they were supposed to win, struggling, second and speculating on what they must do to overtake the dashing St. Louis Cardinals.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Are the Niekro brothers closing in on the career pitching victory total achieved by the Perry brothers?

title: PUPILS WITH AIDS A RISK, KOCH, SAYS
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that in his opinion, no child suffering from AIDS should attend New York City public schools, and he predicted that a panel charged with assessing each case would agree with him.

title: Amy E. Herfort Becomes a Bride
description: Amy Ellen Herfort, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alan Herfort of White Plains and Stockbridge, Mass., and Andrew Richard Gelman were married yesterday. The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Sidney S. Gelman of Chicago and the late Mr. Gelman.

title: TV: SERIES ON FILM MAKERS
description: ''The Moviemakers'' is a new half-hour, 25-week series on Channel 13, looking at the men and women who direct, produce, write, act in, and even criticize movies. Judged by its first episode, at 7 o'clock tonight, the series is modest and without much nonsense, or at least without very much. Movie fans will like it.

title: MEMORIES AND CATCHING UP IN PLAINS
description: The man wearing blue jeans and a big smile rode up to the railroad depot on a bicycle and said, ''Four years ago I was on Air Force One, and now. . . .''

title: RESTRUCTURING THE OIL INDUSTRY
description: T. Boone Pickens, the controversial chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company of Amarillo, Tex., has long warned oil company chiefs to find ways to get the best return for their shareholders.

title: Olga Hirshhorn Is Married To Robert Whittier Dudley
description: Olga Hirshhorn of Naples, Fla., widow of Joseph H. Hirshhorn, whose American art collection forms the Smithsonian Institution's Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington, was married yesterday to Robert Whittier Dudley of Washington and Sharon, Vt., chairman and president of the Consumers Gas Utility Company in Huntington, W.Va. The Rev. Betty Edson, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home in Sharon.

title: Deal Stirs Warm Memory Years After It Was Played
description: Most experts have a favorite deal that gives them a warm glow when it comes to mind in later years. One such, for Nick Zampino of New Rochelle, N.Y., is in essence the one shown in the diagram.

title: CHRISTOPHER E. CHANG WEDS GENEVIEVE MARIE CHU
description: Genevieve Marie Chu, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Y. Chu of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday to Christopher E. Chang, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Emmanuel Chang of Forest Hills, Queens. Msgr. George Bardes performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: The Care That Goes Into Making a Theater a Landmark
description: To the Editor:

title: Therapeutic Riding
description: The public riding stable in Rock Creek Park often sets a good example for the rest of the capital, most notably in being the base for the National Center for Therapeutic Riding, a program in which retarded and handicapped children learn to ride horses. The stable is now gathering and selling horse manure to local gardeners under the label D.C. Doo, with proceeds helping to subsidize the stables. The possibilities seem promising in this waste-rich town, starting with yesterday's position papers becoming tomorrow's mulch.

title: LIBYAN ARMY REPORTEDLY THWARTS TROOP REBELLION AGAINST QADDAFI
description: A state-controlled Egyptian newspaper reported today that units of the Libyan Army and Air Force mutinied Saturday after receiving orders to invade Tunisia, and that they tried unsuccessfully to overthrow the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: JAZZ: AT TOWN HALL, CHARLIE PARKER TRIBUTE
description: Charlie Parker would have been 65 years old Thursday, and the effects of his revolutionary music, be-bop, can be heard just about every time a jazz musician picks up a horn. On Saturday, a concert at Town Hall called ''Bird Lives'' paid tribute to Parker and be-bop music with a heartfelt but oddly slanted program.

title: SCOTTISH FINANCIERS STAY WARY OF FADS
description: Scotland's capital has long been a provincial financial center with a twist. As the home of major banks, huge insurance companies and, according to local estimates, more investment funds than any European city outside of London and Zurich, Edinburgh has inevitably been more caught up in international financial developments than regional British centers such as Manchester.

title: U.S. ACTION AGAINST BIAS SEEN AS ALREADY WEAK
description: While the Reagan Administration is moving toward relaxed requirements on affirmative action for Federal contractors, the Labor Department has quietly made deep cutbacks in its enforcement efforts, according to civil rights groups, economists and even some officials of the department.

title: Top Matches For Today
description: STADIUM Noon John McEnroe vs. Tomas Smid Second Match - Carling Bassett vs.

title: ZABAR'S CO-OWNER SAY 4 BIDDERS HAVE SURFACED
description: More than seven months after the founder of David's Cookies set the New York culinary world abuzz with his attempt to buy Zabar's, the venerable Upper West Side food and cookwares store remains unsold. But other bidders have emerged, according to one of Zabar's owners.

title: Fort Worth Museum Adds 10 Motherwells
description: The Fort Worth Art Museum has acquired 10 related works by the American painter Robert Motherwell, and the artist himself is participating in the selection.

title: Acid Escapes at Plant Scheduled for Closing
description: About 2,000 gallons of sulfuric acid escaped Saturday from a collapsed tank at a chemical plant, just a few hours after its owner announced that it was closing the operation.

title: CATSKILLS RESIDENTS MARK THE BIRTH OF THE ASHOKEN RESERVOIR
description: They gathered today, as they have every Labor Day since 1914, to commemorate the completion of the Ashokan Reservoir.

title: Bridge: Rules for the Opening Lead Have Important Exceptions
description: Old wives' tales have remarkable longevity, in bridge as in other areas. At the beginning of the century somebody, whether an old wife, an old husband or simply an old person is not clear, announced that one should ''always lead the highest card of partner's suit.''

title: Rodent Hangovers
description: Ever since human beings discovered how to intoxicate themselves, experimenters of one kind or another have been looking for reliable ways to sober up quickly. Neither black coffee nor cold showers work, but scientists at the University of Southern California may have hit on something that does - for rats, at least.

title: KANSAS CITY ART SCHOOL LOOKS AHEAD
description: A sense of excitement seems pervasive as students return to the Kansas City Art Institute.

title: KHMER REBELS SAY POL POT IS RETIRING
description: The Khmer Rouge rebel movement in Cambodia announced today that its leader, Pol Pot, was retiring from command of the organization.

title: COMPANY MEETINGS NOT WHAT THEY USED TO BE
description: When 400 managers of M&M/Mars gathered for a three-day meeting last April at a luxury hotel, the climate inside was scarcely what they had expected on Florida's balmy west coast.

title: Chairman Is Expanding Fidelcor Cautiously
description: Nobody knows more about the perils a company faces when it strays too far afield than Harold W. Pote, chairman and chief executive of Fidelcor Inc., Philadelphia's third-largest bank holding company and parent of the Fidelity Bank.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 3, 1985
description: The Economy

title: THATCHER, HER PARTY IN A SLUMP, SHAKES UP CABINET
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher announced a sweeping realignment of her Cabinet this evening in a what appeared to be a bold attempt to reverse a recent sharp decline in her political fortunes.

title: 24-Year Texas Blue Law Ends; Rule on Seat Belts In Force
description: Laws mandating the use of seat belts and repealing the 24-year-old Texas blue law went into effect Sunday, three months after the 1985 legislative session that approved the measures.

title: Sir MacFarlane Burnet, 85; Nobel Laureate in Medicine
description: Sir MacFarlane Burnet, who won the Nobel Prize in Medicine in 1960, died Saturday of cancer, his family said Sunday. He was 85 years old.

title: Man Is Found Shot to Death In Hotel Close to La Guardia
description: A man in his 30's, believed to be from out of town, was found shot to death in his Queens hotel room yesterday afternoon, the police reported.

title: Wilson Sidelined
description: Willie Wilson, the Kansas City Royals' center fielder, underwent surgery yesterday for pain and swelling in his buttocks and could be sidelined up to three weeks. Wilson, the Royals' leadoff batter, is hitting .285 with 40 runs batted in.

title: WIND 'WAS REALLY RIPPING' ON ISLAND
description: Hurricane Elena is the latest storm to pound this fragile strip of sand southwest of Mobile Bay. The storm's winds stripped away the entire west beach front, wiping out 50 homes and several businesses that had been rebuilt since Hurricane Frederic in 1979.

title: Residents Fighting Over Reward in Killings
description: As many as six residents of the neighborhood where a crowd captured the prime suspect in 16 ''night stalker'' slayings claim credit for the capture and are thus at odds over who deserves the $70,000 reward.

title: Feeding the Animals
description: There is the popular notion of the politician feeding at the public trough. That may or may not be an accurate depiction, but at least some Washington residents do eat well at public expense: the denizens of the National Zoo uptown and the lesser known National Aquarium downtown.

title: HENRY B. ROTHBLATT, WATERGATE BURGLARS' ATTORNEY
description: Henry B. Rothblatt, a defense lawyer whose clients included four of the Watergate burglars, died of a brain tumor Sunday at the Broward General Medical Center in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 69 years old and lived in Fort Lauderdale.

title: SOVIET ACTOR DEFECTS
description: A Soviet matinee idol, who has been described as a Russian Robert Redford, arrived in America's movie capital over the weekend after defecting from his homeland.

title: AN ASSEMBLY-LINE REVOLUTION
description: When Henry Ford perfected the continuously moving assembly line around the turn of the century, he made mass production and a consumer society possible at the price of forcing factory workers to keep pace with machines. Now -compelled by increasing competition from abroad and concerned about outcries over American quality -major manufacturers are beginning to abandon this cornerstone of the industrial economy.

title: British Publisher Ready To Fight Takeover Bid
description: Lord Matthews, the 65-year-old chairman of Fleet Holdings P.L.C., publisher of The Daily Express, Star, and Sunday Express in Britain, is digging in for the long siege. On Wednesday, United Newspapers P.L.C., a publisher of provincial newspapers and Punch Magazine, made a long-anticipated offer of $320 million for the 80 percent of Fleet it does not already own.

title: Some Room for Beauty
description: This year, the signs in Central Park turned from green to brown before the trees did.

title: ARTS GROUPS OPPOSE PLAN FOR CLINTON
description: The leaders of three major Manhattan arts groups are opposing an urban renewal plan for the Clinton neighborhood because it would give the city the right to raze their building. The proposal is expected to come before the city Planning Commission on Sept. 9.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. ROLE TARGET OF INQUIRY
