description: The Justice Department halted scrutiny of financial affairs at the military shipyard in Newport News, Va., in 1983 over the objections of its frontline investigators, according to a new Congressional study.

title: KARPOV AND KASPAROV GIRD FOR BIG CHESS MATCH
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov made no pretense of camaraderie this time around as they faced off today at the ceremonial opening of the second round of their stormy struggle for the world chess championship.

title: LONDON MARKETS VIEW PRETORIA MOVES CAUTIOUSLY
description: South Africa's freeze on loan repayments was greeted cautiously today in the City of London.

title: TV FILM 'LOVE' ALTERED AFTER THREAT OF LAWSUIT
description: Television presents so many films inspired by true stories that the networks' legal staffs are constantly scrutinizing scripts to guard against possible charges of libel or invasion of privacy. In the case of ''Love on the Run,'' a forthcoming NBC movie about an attorney (Stephanie Zimbalist) who helps her convict-client (Alec Baldwin) to escape from prison, the threat of a lawsuit was one of the factors that encouraged the network to change the story from a docudrama to a fictitious melodrama.

title: ECUADOREAN BANKER IS SLAIN WITH ABDUCTORS
description: Policemen and army commandos stormed a house today in an effort to rescue a banker from four guerrilla kidnappers, but he was killed during the raid along with his abductors.

title: AIDS Found in Indonesia
description: Doctors have diagnosed the first five cases of AIDS in Indonesia, Health Minister Suwardjono Suryaningrat said today. Mr. Suwardjono declined to give details but said the patients included at least one non-Indonesian.

title: Conservative Path to Success
description: The Golden West Financial Corporation, of Oakland, Calif., earned $81 million in 1984, the second highest profit total, after the Great Western Financial Corporation, of any company in the problem-plagued thrift industry. Its second-quarter profits, at $36.1 million, were nearly double last year's.

title: RESORT LINES FOCUS ON SIMPLICITY
description: For America's top designers, the resort collection is a pleasant interlude, free from the pressures of the major fashion show that is regarded as essential for the fall and spring openings. Resort clothes are designed in the summer and geared for warm-weather wear a few months later. It is the only collection of the year when the weather during the design period matches that of the time the clothes will be worn.

title: Pentagon;   Reflections on 46 Years of Army Service
description: On the eve of retiring after 46 years of Army service, the past three as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. John W. Vessey Jr. is in a reflective mood these days.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Letter: On Sales Taxes;   End the Levy on Books
description: To the Editor:

title: Climate and Crime
description: Violent crimes such as homicide, rape and robbery are more common on warm, sunny days than on cool or rainy ones, according to a study reported at the American Psychological Association's meeting last week in Los Angeles. This seems to account for the higher rates for those crimes in southern states than in northern ones.

title: CONCERN OVER AIDS MOBILIZES LOS ANGELES EFFORTS
description: Each day a platoon of city buses rolls out into Los Angeles carrying an advertisment featuring what appears to be a doting mother cautioning a homosexual son: ''Play safely. L.A. cares.''

title: King Cards 67-205 And Wins by 2
description: Betsy King birdied five holes on the back nine, including two of the last three, to score a two-stroke victory over Janet Anderson today in the Rail Charity Classic.

title: The Isle of Nynex
description: To judge a borough by its book cover, the 12 1/2-mile-long island between the Hudson River and the East and Harlem Rivers is now known as Nynex.

title: Record Crop
description: Chalk up another one for the Yankee farm system:

title: In Reverse
description: It only seemed that way:

title: HOFSTRA SCHEDULES CLASSES TODAY DESPITE A WALKOUT BY ITS FACULTY
description: With faculty members on strike and no new talks scheduled, Hofstra University yesterday prepared for today's opening of its school year.

title: OF CRIME, SUBWAYS AND THE NO. 5 TRAIN
description: Junior Beeson was shot on a budding day this summer on a subway ride they used to call the ''Zoo Train.'' The car was crowded, an argument developed and someone pulled a gun. The detective on the case said the incident was ''spontaneous'' and that crime on New York's subways knows no particular zone or time of day.

title: Boy, 11, Dies in Fall at Mine
description: An 11-year-old boy fell 500 feet to his death when he leaned from his motorized three-wheel cycle to peer into an abandoned mine shaft, the authorities said. Mountain climbers rappelled into the shaft late Sunday and recovered the body of the boy, Kris Marchant, who fell around 11 A.M., said Box Elder County Police Sgt. Curtis Larsen. The boy had been riding with his father, brother and two friends.

title: Ground Worker Union Accepts American Pact
description: A union representing 12,000 ground workers has voted to accept a new contract with American Airlines, three months after rejecting one, officials said Saturday.

title: America's Plunge Into the Debt Abyss
description: What does a Monday morning economic quarterback say about the indebtedness of third world countries? They should have seen that they were borrowing more than they could repay and should have taken actions to prevent themselves from sinking ever deeper into debt.

title: REMEMBERING THE SUMMER AT A PLACE WHERE IT ENDS
description: In 1921, Robert Moses, exploring alone in a small motorboat, came upon a stretch of unspoiled beach 25 miles southeast of Manhattan and envisioned a magnificent public park, offering miles of oceanfront and dunes of white sand.

title: PRUITT AND ZORN ARE AMONG FINAL CUTS
description: Mike Pruitt, Cleveland's veteran fullback; Jim Zorn, the Seattle quarterback; Ron Springs, the Dallas running back, and Bob Thomas, the Chicago Bears' place-kicker were among the most notable players cut yesterday as National Football League teams trimmed their rosters to the mandatory 45-player limit.

title: Barbara Salberg Marries
description: Barbara Beth Salberg, the daughter of Melvin Salberg of New York and the late Rita Salberg, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Alan Zuck, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Zuck of Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Awaiting Walton Word
description: The Los Angeles Clippers expect to have an announcement today on the planned trade of Bill Walton to Boston for Cedric Maxwell.

title: Pitcher's Pick
description: Who will be on top at the end, the Yankees or the Blue Jays?

title: THE ACTIVIST JUDGES PRESIDENT REAGAN WANTS
description: To the Editor:

title: GLUT OF POTATOES LEAVES FARMERS' HOPES DASHED
description: Potato growers nationwide planted more acres this year, and they have enjoyed adequate rainfall, and no major blights, floods or frosts. In other words, the outlook is bleak.

title: NON-BANK POSTS FOR ECONOMISTS
description: WHERE will economists go?

title: TAX ISSUE STIRS INTEREST, BUT MAINLY IN CONGRESS
description: Members of Congress's tax-writing committees, returning from summer recess, report that they found lackluster support among constituents for fundamental tax revision. But they said they would nevertheless support sweeping tax-overhaul legislation in the remaining weeks of the Congressional session.

title: Inspire 85
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary who was severely wounded in the 1981 assassination attempt on President Reagan and who has been helped by the therapy provided by horseback riding, will show off some of his riding skills soon on the Mall as part of Inspire 85, a five-day event focusing on leisure, sports and the arts for the disabled.

title: Spain to Join Project
description: Spain announced today that it would join the European venture to build a fighter aircraft for the 21st century, with or without French participation. Spain had previously said it would join if France did. The project was originally conceived by Britain, Italy, West Germany, France and Spain.

title: Family Circle Change
description: Family Circle said it would begin a new policy in January that would guarantee a circulation size for each issue in which an ad appears, rather than making a guarantee based on average circulation over a given period. The magazine, which is owned by The New York Times Company, said it would offer rebates in cash or credit to advertised brands when circulation in a given issue falls short of the guaranteed rate base.

title: Eye on the Ball
description: After his Twins were battered Sunday, 10-3, by Boston, Manager Ray Miller faulted the Minnesota players' pre-game preparation.

title: ALLURE OF DIAMONDS LEADS SCIENTISTS INTO NEW EFFORTS TO MATCH NATURE
description: DIAMONDS, whose glitter can kindle the worst and best of human passions and whose unrivaled hardness is indispensable to the tools of industry, have never been taken for granted.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Recalled Bill Swaggerty, pitcher, from Rochester of the International League. Purchased the contracts of Lenn Sakata, Kelly Paris and Tom O'Malley, infielders, Brad Havens, pitcher, and Leo Hernandez, outfielder, from Rochester.

title: Revival Signs Upset Traders
description: Bond investors and traders have remained calm in the face of torrid growth in the nation's money supply, but signs that the economy is reviving are enough to give them the jitters and bring on a quick drop in prices and rising interest rates.

title: ARMY REPORTS SUCCESS IN COMBATING STRESS
description: TYPE A behavior is practically an endemic ''disease'' among the officer-students who attend the United States Army War College. Men and women training for sensitive and demanding leadership positions as commanders and top staff officers, not surprisingly, tend to be aggressive, hard-driving and ambitious, characteristics typical of people said to exhibit coronary-prone Type A behavior.

title: Markets Closed
description: All stock and commodity markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Labor Day.

title: Stradivarius Is Bait; Violinist Is the Catch
description: Colleges always promote their assets to attract desirable students, but Princeton University cried foul after Stanford University used a precious perquisite to lure a violinist.

title: C.I.A. OFFICERS TESTIFY AT HAWAII FRAUD TRIAL
description: A retired officer of the Central Intelligence Agency's clandestine service has told, in tears, how he persuaded his 86-year-old mother, who was blind and disabled, to invest most of her savings in the business ventures of Ronald R. Rewald.

title: GUARDING AGAINST UNCERTAIN RISKS
description: A READER who uses a color television set as a computer monitor is worried because her son sits for hours at a time staring point-blank into the screen. Her worry is justified. Many eye doctors warn that intensive close-up work can lead to nearsightedness in children.

title: Belgian Parliament Is Dissolved Over Budget
description: King Baudouin dissolved Parliament today after a new rift developed in the Government over the sharing of the education budget.

title: Chemicals Of Neem Tree Deter Pests
description: SCIENTISTS with the United States Department of Agriculture have derived a new, ''natural'' insecticide from a tree that grows prolifically in tropical regions.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Three for Borough President
description: The presidents of New York City's five boroughs serve the whole city. Besides appointing community boards and conveying the demands of local groups to City Hall, they cast crucial votes on the Board of Estimate. Thus the three Democratic primary contests on Sept. 10 are important to the whole city. There are no contests for Republican or Liberal party nominations.

title: MUSIC: ELLINGTON'S SACRED CONCERTS
description: DUKE ELLINGTON'S Sacred Concerts are not a project to be undertaken lightly.

title: People
description: Thomas Mabley has been named executive vice president and creative director-U.S. at Henderson Friedlich Graf & Doyle.

title: LASER PUTS PRINTING PLANT IN HOME
description: THE headlong rush of technology seems to know no bounds. Perhaps even more startling than its rapid evolution, however, is the impact on society of its new personal trend.

title: The New Plague, in Perspective
description: Should schools admit children with AIDS? Need the Pentagon test recruits for exposure to AIDS virus? These are just the latest of the social problems raised by the deadly new disease.

title: Babble in the Sky Can Be Very Reassuring
description: To the Editor:

title: Working Profile: Andrew H. Oerke;   A Poet Whose Muse Is a World Traveler
description: ''Hunger's grip is cold stone,'' Andrew H. Oerke scribbled in his notebook on a recent trip to the drought-plagued sub-Saharan region of Africa. ''It does not forgive good intentions and tonic by the pool.''

title: Jill Abramson Is Wed To a Medical Student
description: Jill Lynne Abramson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Abramson of Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday to Stuart Wasser, a son of Mr.and Mrs. Melvin Wasser of Bayside, Queens, at Congregation Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi Gilbert Klaperman, assisted by Cantor Marcus Ehrlich, performed the ceremony.

title: DECISION IS DUE ON EPIC UNIT
description: A Federal District Court judge in Virginia is scheduled to decide on Tuesday whether to appoint a receiver for the mortgage-banking unit of the EPIC group of companies, which is in default on more than $1 billion in mortgage securities.

title: An Audubon Set Too Precious to Break Up
description: To the Editor:

title: PERU GETS A LIFT FROM NEW LEADER
description: After barely one month in office, Peru's new President, Alan Garcia Perez, has shaken this country out of a prolonged mood of pessimism with a burst of reformist zeal unseen here in years.

title: KLEVER IS USEFUL ALL OVER THE FIELD
description: Rocky Klever, who has a grand total of three career catches, survived another roster cut yesterday, and who can blame the Jets for keeping him?

title: TOP MODERN JAZZ DRUMMER
description: Philly Joe Jones, a leading modern-jazz drummer, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 62 years old.

title: China Financial Data
description: China today published full balance of payments figures for the first time since 1949 in what foreign bankers said was another step in Peking's opening to the outside world.

title: The Activist Judges President Reagan Wants
description: To the Editor:

title: Hernandez Likely to Testify
description: The first trial arising from the Pittsburgh drug investigation is set to begin today, and Keith Hernandez, Lonnie Smith, Dave Parker and Enos Cabell are among the baseball players expected to testify that they purchased cocaine from the defendant, Curtis Strong.

title: Thousands of Workers Hold March in Bolivia
description: At least 10,000 workers marched in La Paz today and strikes spread through Bolivia to protest severe economic measures the Government imposed to combat an inflation rate of 14,000 percent.

title: Dr. Steiner Is Married To Pediatrics Resident
description: Dr. Jeanne Laura Steiner, an assistant clinical professor of psychiatry at the University of California Medical School at San Francisco, and Dr. William Rosenblatt, a resident in pediatrics at the Stanford University Medical Center, were married yesterday at her parents' home in Watchung, N.J. Rabbi Bruce Charnov officiated.

title: 6 Die in Arson Fire In Apartment Building
description: A three-alarm fire swept a northeast Kansas City apartment building early today, killing six people and injuring six others. ''The fire was deliberately set,'' said Harold Knabe, a Fire Department spokesman.

title: Dollar, Gold Both Strengthen
description: The dollar gained vigorously against all of Europe's major currencies today, following a renewal of optimism in the United States economy. Gold prices also rose slightly.

title: WINNING THE WAR WITH CAPTAIN MARVEL
description: Forty years ago yesterday, the Japanese formally surrendered. But we couldn't have lost that war. Not with Lt. Comdr. Don Winslow, Col. Flip Corkin, Pfc. Joe Palooka, Spy Smasher and Terry and the Pirates on our side.

title: CALIFORNIA FINDS ITSELF TRYING TO ENTICE MORE VACATIONERS
description: After decades of coasting on its reputation as a sun-drenched vacation land, California is belatedly joining many other states in advertising its own attractions for tourists.

title: Bill Sale Dominates Treasury Action
description: Treasury financing this week is confined to the bill market, where the regular Monday auction was delayed until today because of Labor Day. No auctions of Treasury notes or bonds are expected until the two-year note sale on Sept. 18, followed the next week by auctions of issues due in 4 years, 7 years and 20 years.

title: REAGAN RENEWS DRIVE TO REVISE THE TAX SYSTEM
description: President Reagan, saying ''I'm back and rarin' to go,'' began his drive for an income tax overhaul today with a blunt attack on the curpent system as ''unfair, unworkable and unproductive.''

title: INDUSTRIAL ROW TURNED BY BLAZE TO JAGGED RUINS
description: Inside of six hours this Labor Day, the old factories burned, one after another. By nightfall the industrial row was nothing more than a jagged seven-story hunk of wall here, a four-story chunk there and a three-story burning piece off in the distance.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We came on it early this morning. It was just bang, there it was right on top of it.

title: 18 HITS PROPEL METS
description: The Mets came crashing out of their swoon tonight with 18 hits that buried the San Diego Padres, 12-4, and moved them within one game of the first-place St. Louis Cardinals.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: NOW that September is here, we really have to think about fall clothes, whether we like it or not. Of course, women in the fashion business are always a season or two ahead of the calendar, so they did their thinking about fall many months ago. On the theory that they might have some ideas to inspire the rest of us, a few were asked what they were planning to buy.

title: WRECKAGE OF TITANIC REPORTED DISCOVERED 12,000 FEET DOWN
description: A team of American and French researchers was reported yesterday to have found the hulk of the luxury liner Titanic south of Newfoundland.

title: A REUNION MARKS MEMORIES OF THE ORPHAN TRAINS
description: In the darkened Grundy County Museum, a hushed audience fixed its attention on a home movie screen set up at the front of the room.

title: CONFUSION AND FLAWS PLAGUE RULES ON DISCIPLINING DOCTORS
description: Health-care officials trying to control the problem of medical incompetence say many of their efforts are confounded by a disjointed, unuieldy and lomphole-ridden system of medical peer review.

title: Arthur B. Flick Dies; Wrote on Fly Fishing
description: Arthur B. Flick, who played a major role in charting the course of fly fishing in the United States, died last Friday at the Benedictine Hospital. He was 81 years old.

title: ONE YEAR LATER IN SOUTH AFRICA, STREET VIOLENCE HAS WON THE UPPER HAND
description: In the year since unrest took root in the nation's black townships, South African academics and other specialists assert, a shift of mood has overtaken many black communities, propelling them toward radicalism and harsh tactics.

title: The Store, Then the Scent, and Now the Movie
description: FOR a while there, Manhattan's hopelessly trendy Upper West Side smelled more exotic than usual. That was because the resident Yuppie pacesetters had been to Bloomingdale's and were dousing themselves with something called Camp Beverly Hills. Jeff Stein wasn't really very surprised.

title: AS EXCHANGES REOPEN, RAND SURGES
description: The rand rose sharply today, with strong support from the central bank.

title: Marketing Linked to Charity
description: THIS evening, the American Express Travel Related Services Company will begin an advertising campaign intended to raise money for a new group of charities. Called Project Hometown America, the effort links a donation by the company to consumer use of American Express products and services, and it is expected to raise about $3 million by the end of this year to help local groups ''tackle human problems at the grass-roots level,'' the company says.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Reuters dispatch from Tel Aviv yesterday reporting that 14 Arabs were detained by Israel in the West Bank on Sunday was incorrect. Military officials said there had been no new arrests since Friday, when 14 Arabs were ordered held on suspicion of involvement in subversive activities. The detentions brought to 32 the number of Arabs arrested in the West Bank since Wednesday.

title: A Feline Cinephile
description: ''The Leopard'' was on the screen, but a street cat named Lulu stole the spotlight at the Carnegie Hall Cinema.

title: A Volunteer Van: Opinions on Wheels
description: L. Robert McClean was strolling through a street fair when he noticed an electric-blue van parked on West 42d Street. In front of it, publications of opposing political views stood side by side in democratic harmony.

title: A Troubleshooter At Fairchild Unit
description: John W. Sandford is no stranger to companies that are having problems introducing high-technology products.

title: CARDINALS BEATEN BY REDS, 4-1
description: Dave Parker hit a two-run homer, and Tom Browning won his 15th game tonight as the Cincinnati Reds beat the Cardinals, 4-1.

title: PURCHASERS SEE SLUMP PERSISTING
description: The economy weakened further in August, with no sign of improvement for the rest of the year, according to a report being released today by a national group of purchasing managers.

title: Chinese Monkeys for Minnesota Zoo
description: Several rare golden monkeys from China will visit the Minnesota Zoo next summer as a gesture of cooperation between the United States and Chinese Governments.

title: North Sea Oil Peak Forecast
description: Britain's North Sea oil will run out in 10 years if production continues at the present rate, a top economist said today.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN'S LABOR DAY SPEECH ON TAXES IN INDEPENDENCE
description: Following are excerpts from the text of President Reagan's speech on taxes as prepared for delivery here today:

title: LINDQVIST A TOUGH TEST FOR NAVRATILOVA
description: If women's tennis were a game of musical chairs, the only players would be Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert Lloyd. And they would be scurrying around a single seat - the throne for No. 1 - waiting for the music to stop.

title: SANDINISTA PORTRAIT: POET, MILITANT, BIBLE DEVOTEE
description: Tomas Borge, the Nicaraguan Interior Minister, is a man of many public identities. Sometimes he appears in battle fatigues. Other times, he is dressed as a policeman. At a recent fire in Managua, he turned up in a fireman's suit, complete with rubber overcoat.

title: JETS' FINAL TRIMS MAY BE TEMPORARY
description: Needing to arrive at the final 45-player roster, the Jets cut five players today. But some of those players may return to the team soon as the Jets prepare to move some of their wounded to the injured-reserve list.

title: COMPUTER IS NEW TOOL IN PSYCHIATRIC WARD
description: BY the time Joey was 12 years old and Theresa had turned 13, most of their teachers did not think either child could sit still in a classroom long enough to absorb lessons or to let others around them learn.

title: BONN SPY CASE: 'HOPELESS PERSONAL SITUATION'
description: A note apparently written by Hans Joachim Tiedge, a West German counterespionage officer, says he defected to East Germany because he was in ''a hopeless personal situation,'' a well-informed Bonn official said today.

title: NO BIG SURPRISES IN FINAL GIANT TRIM
description: The players arrived in the morning in a slight drizzle and they taped up silently. Some watched the tennis match on television. Others clustered in small groups in the dressing room. It was a quiet morning at Giant Stadium but filled with all sorts of rumblings.

title: Cross-Pollination
description: It started one day in June 1983, when the Los Angeles Dodgers were paying a visit to the Braves. The hot sports news down in Atlanta was that the Hawks had just hired Mike Fratello, of late an assistant with the Knicks, to succeed Kevin Loughery as head coach.

title: Iraq Reports New Raid On Iranian Oil Terminal
description: Iraq said its air force attacked Iran's Kharg Island oil terminal today.

title: Poison Gas Is Good For Killing Civilians
description: To the Editor:

title: DIET DEFICIENCY OF VITAMIN A IS REVEALED AS A MAJOR KILLER
description: DIETARY deficiencies of vitamin A, long implicated as a cause of blindness, have now been linked to hundreds of thousands of deaths of children each year in Africa, Asia and Latin America.

title: Mutual Funds' Present Focus
description: AT a time when direct participation in the stock market by individuals appears to be slackening, sales of mutual funds are booming. Growing numbers of people, according to Laszlo Birinyi Jr., an equity market analyst for Salomon Brothers, are using mutual funds as their investment vehicle.

title: PARADE CELEBRATES LABOR AND POLITICS
description: In a colorful celebration of politics and labor solidarity, union members marched, sang and danced up Fifth Avenue yesterday, accompanied by bands and campaign placards.

title: WIDE DAMAGE SEEN AS HURRICANE HITS MISSISSIPI'S COAST
description: Hurricane Elena stormed ashore along Mississippi's Gulf Coast today, peeling the roofs from buildings and toppling trees and power lines but, in one sense, ending an ordeal for millions of residents from Sarasota, Fla., to New Orleans.

title: CBS EXAMINES IMMIGRATION ISSUES
description: ''WHOSE AMERICA IS IT?'' recognizes complexity. The ''CBS Reports'' program, on Channel 2 at 8 o'clock tonight, looks at new immigrants, legal and illegal, and says they create problems. At the same time, it assigns no blame. Immigration policy is bedeviled by too many competing factors.

title: One Union at Maine Shipyard Accepts Pact, With Proviso
description: Members of the union representing 408 ship designers at the Bath Iron Works voted Saturday to approve a new contract, but a union lawyer said all economic provisions of the pact were subject to what the striking shipbuilders' union negotiated.

title: HEART PATIENT'S DOCTORS LEARN FROM TREATMENT
description: One lesson that Michael Drummond's doctors have learned from his first five days on an artificial heart is that a cardinal rule of medicine applies even in an age of high-technology medicine: the best guide to therapy is careful observation of the patient.

title: Free Reign
description: The baseball fan who approaches George Brett with that old opening line, ''What's your sign?'' may be disappointed by the answer. Says the Kansas City Royals' all-star third baseman: ''I don't even know the signs of the ball club.

title: Aron Chilewich Is Dead at 84; Philanthropist and Importer
description: Aron Chilewich, a philanthropist and an international trader in hides, leather and other commodities, died of cancer yesterday at his Manhattan apartment. He was 84 years old and also had a home in Jerusalem.

title: MAN WHO SHIELDED CROOKED PAST KEEPS COLLEAGUES' RESPECT
description: Many friends and colleagues have rallied around Robert L. Gipson since the 67-year-old locksmith's decision to run for the school board led to exposure of his past life as a confidence man, felon and fugitive.

title: Addendum
description: Scientific American said that, effective with its January 1986 issue, it would increase its national advertising rates by 4.9 percent.

title: AN INSIDE LOOK AT HIGH SCHOOLS
description: ''WE have inadvertently designed a system in which being good at what you do as a teacher is not formally rewarded, while being poor at what you do is seldom corrected nor penalized.''

title: MORE EXECUTIVES HITTING THE BOOKS
description: At 8 A.M. in one of Northwestern University's dining halls, a group of students are doing what students often do before class: cramming. Between spoonfuls of cereal, the students use yellow markers to furiously highlight lecture notes, making occasional wisecracks about professors.

title: PUZZLING ECONOMY AWAITS TRADERS
description: Like schoolchildren coming back from summer vacation, Wall Street investors are expected to show renewed excitement over stock trading in the post-Labor Day period. But analysts believe that the reality of an uncertain economy as well as questions about the Federal budget deficit and tax reform will soon spoil their fun.

title: TENNESSEE BATTLES WITH U.S. ON NUCLEAR WASTE PROGRAM
description: Tennessee's central location, a factor in General Motors' decision to build a $3.5 billion automobile plant here, has also attracted a less welcome proposal. The Federal Government plans to build a $1 billion plant in Tennessee to repackage and consolidate radioactive nuclear waste for final disposal.

title: SCORES HOMELESS AS FIRE IN PASSAIC ENGULFS 4 BLOCKS
description: A roaring fire engulfed a four-block industrial complex and spread to several blocks of homes and apartment buildings in Passaic, N.J., yesterday, forcing the evacuation of hundreds of people and leaving scores of families homeless.

title: Syracuse's Moseley Out
description: Walter Moseley, expected to be Syracuse's starting tailback after Harold Gayden was declared ineligible last week for this college football season, will be sidelined for two to four weeks with a sprained knee. Moseley, a junior, hurt the knee in Saturday afternoon's practice. Syracuse opens its season Sept. 14 at Mississippi State.

title: Beer Still Flows at Brewery
description: Free beer for employees of the Miller Brewing Company will continue to be served on breaks, officials said. Members of Local 9 of the Brewery Workers voted overwhelmingly Saturday to reject a bid by the brewer to reopen the contract so there could be discussions of the century-old practice.

title: ST. BART'S TO TRY AGAIN TO BUILD TOWER
description: St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, rebuffed twice in the last two years, today will again ask the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission for permission to build an office tower on its landmark Park Avenue site, according to the rector of the church.

title: Whither Danzansky?
description: Conservative Republicans are mounting a campaign to ward off the appointment of Stephen I. Danzansky, a Washington lawyer, to the National Security Council. Mr. Danzansky is an old school friend of the national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane, and was reported last week to be Mr. McFarlane's choice to become the council's international trade coordinator.

title: The Bottle Collectors
description: To the Editor:

title: Progress in Afghan Talks Is Reported by Pakistan
description: A Pakistani official said today that United Nations-sponsored talks in Geneva have made progress toward a settlement of the Afghan war, including proposals on withdrawing Soviet troops.

title: Top Matches For Today
description: STADIUM Morning 11:30 A.M. - Yannick Noah vs. Jay Berger Second Match - Chris Evert Lloyd vs.

title: John S. Walton Dead; An Expert on Antiques
description: John S. Walton, a major influence in the collecting of Early American antiques for more than 45 years, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Jewett City, Conn. He was 77 years old.

title: Tourism Is Our Top Consumer Item for Japan
description: To the Editor:

title: SYRIA MEETS LEBANESE GROUPS ON WAYS TO END THE FIGHTING
description: Syria is consulting Lebanon's warring factions in an effort to begin discussions on how to end a decade of fighting here.

title: Girl Fatally Stabbed In Barbecue Accident
description: A 6-year-old girl from Uniondale, L.I., was accidentally killed yesterday evening when she ran into a steak knife carried by her grandfather at a family barbecue in West Hempstead, the Nassau County police reported.

title: 3-1 CREME FRAICHE WINS JEROME MILE
description: Creme Fraiche, who three months ago became the first gelding to win the Belmont Stakes, showed his versatility and class with a handy victory over Pancho Villa, El Basco and Ziggy's Boy yesterday in the $182,100 Jerome Handicap for 3-year-olds at Belmont Park.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 3, 1985
description: International

title: DIRECT SELLING LEAVES HOME
description: When Terry Mazur began selling Avon products door-to-door in Central Islip, L.I., six years ago she usually found housewives at home. Nowadays, Mrs. Mazur sells at office complexes, schools, and nurseries because that is where, she says, ''it's easier to pick up new customers.''

title: IN SYRACUSE, MAYORAL BIDS PROVE LIVELY
description: When Lee Alexander announced in mid-July that he would retire after 16 years as Mayor, politicians expected a lively campaign to succeed the man who for a generation had dominated the politics of New York's fifth-largest city.

title: Drug-Testing Backlog
description: A big backlog of samples to be tested was the reason for a lengthy time gap between the failing of drug tests by 40 pro boxers and their announced suspensions by the New Jersey State Athletic Commission last week, according to the acting commission chairman, Robert W. Lee. For example, Hector Camacho has fought twice, outside New Jersey, and won the World Boxing Council lightweight championship since he last fought in New Jersey, when he stopped Louie Burke in the fifth round on Jan. 19.

title: S.M.U. Aide Dismissed
description: Southern Methodist officials have refused to disclose why an assistant football coach was dismissed other than to say he was involved in unspecified ''violations of university policies.'' P. J. (Bootsie) Larsen, who coached linebackers, ''has been relieved of his coaching duties, effective immediately,'' Athletic Director Bob Hitch said Sunday in a three-paragraph statement. Hitch did not say whether the action was related to S.M.U.'s football program being placed on probation Aug. 16 by the N.C.A.A. for recruiting violations. Bob Weber, former coach at Louisville, was hired to replace Larsen.

title: Canadian Bank to Be Closed
description: The Canadian Government has announced plans to liquidate the Canadian Commercial Bank only five months after arranging a $186 million bailout of the institution.

title: Feeding More Than One Hunger
description: The schoolchildren who donated their pennies, the rock stars who gave their talents, the people who wrote checks to relief agencies - all can take pride in the news from Ethiopia.

title: Babble in the Sky Can Be Very Reassuring
description: To the Editor:

title: CENSUS, COUNTING ROBOTS, FINDS 5,535 ADDED IN 1984
description: American industry produced 5,535 robots last year, the Census Bureau said after its first survey of such machines.

title: AFTER REPAIRING LEASAT, ASTRONAUTS HEAD HOME
description: As the crew of the space shuttle Discovery prepared to come home to earth, ground controllers activated systems of the repaired Leasat 3 satellite today and found it in apparently excellent health.

title: BLACK UNION BLAMES INTIMIDATION
description: A strike by black mine workers faltered today, and union leaders blamed intimidation by employers.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: JAZZ BENEFIT The jazz saxophonist David (Fathead) Newman recently had his instruments stolen from his car. A benefit has been organized at the Lone Star Cafe (Fifth Avenue and 13th Street) tonight to raise money to replace them. Many well-known blues and jazz musicians in the New York area will be performing. They include Wilbur Bascomb, Hank Crawford, Bob Cunningham, Lou Donaldson, Cornell Dupree, Charles Eubanks, Sonny Fortune, Dr. John, Jack McDuff, Jimmy McGriff, Bernard Purdie, Little Jimmy Scott, Dakota Staton, Cedar Walton, and Richard Tee, among others. A number of surprise guests are also likely to appear. The concert will start around 9:15 P.M. Admission is $15. Information and reservations: 242-1664.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Seattle Mariners, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. Phil Niekro, trying for his 298th career victory, will pitch for the Yankees.

title: Frito-Lay Inc. Splits With Young & Rubicam
description: Frito-Lay Inc. has ended a 22-year relationship with Young & Rubicam. According to a memo distributed to Y.&R. employees last week, the Pepsico Inc. division pulled from the agency an estimated $15 million in billings for three of its snack food brands: Ruffles potato chips, Rold Gold pretzels and Chee-Tos cheese puffs.

title: Police Seeking a Queens Man In Shooting Death of His Wife
description: The police yesterday sought a Queens man who they said killed his estranged wife Sunday night when they met to talk about the custody of their three children.

title: New Shekel For Israel
description: Israel's Parliament today unanimously approved introduction of a new shekel valued at 1,000 existing shekels, in a currency change aimed at keeping pace with inflation.

title: CITY WEIGHS USE OF WATER METERS IN DROUGHT FIGHT
description: The city's Department of Environmental Protection is studying whether to compel the owners of all of New York's 600,000 residential buildings to inqtall water meters as a conservation measure, according to the city's top watep official.

title: THE SUDDENLY HOMELESS STRAGGLE INTO SHELTER
description: They stood expressionless and silent on street corners in the Dundee section of Passaic last night, people with heaps of possessions at their feet and eyes fixed on a night sky that glowed in unnatural shades of red and peach and lavender.

title: WELLS FARGO SUSPECTS ARRIVE
description: Federal authorities today were holding 11 suspected Puerto Rican terrorists, indicted in a $7 million Wells Fargo robbery, at an undisclosed site after transporting them to the mainland by military plane.

title: Strength And Grace
description: When it comes to the folly of judging all packages by the wrapping, there may be no finer example than that of Mike Ruth, Boston College's nose guard.

title: Righetti and Fisher Save the Yankees
description: The bullpen, Ron Guidry said, is as good as the Yankees have had in his time with them. Dave Righetti hasn't been with the Yankees as long as Guidry, but he thinks he knows a good bunch of relievers when he sees them.

title: Herbert Sussan Dead; Longtime TV Producer
description: Herbert Sussan, a longtime television producer and the chronicler in film of the effects of the American bombing on Japan, died of pneumonia and kidney failure yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in New York.

title: A Rodent's Report
description: He is known as the White Rat. ''No,'' said Whitey Herzog, manager of the Cardinals, ''I don't mind the nickname. I even have a white rat about this big'' - he spread his hands a few feet apart - ''on my front lawn at home.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Crossland Industries, which has mining and oil and gas interests, has appointed Richard G. Naylor president and chief executive officer.

title: Indian Opposition Party To Boycott Punjab Vote
description: A second political faction in Punjab State announced today that it would boycott state elections scheduled for Sept. 25.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ROBERT FULTON. A Biography. By Cynthia Owen Philip. 371 pages. Illustrated. Franklin Watts. $18.95. IN 1816 the main crosstown thoroughfare linking the two riverboat terminals in Manhattan was named Fulton Street, in honor of Robert Fulton, who had died the previous year. Since then Fulton's role in the development of steam navigation has been commemorated on countless other occasions; his place in the history books is secure. But the achievements are better known than the man himself, and Cynthia Owen Philip's admirable new biography reveals a much stranger and in many ways more troubling figure than you are likely to anticipate if you come to it expecting to read the story of an exemplary, smooth-flowing scientific career.

title: LETTERS
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: BECKER LOSES TO NYSTROM IN 4 SETS
description: During the final desperate games of his match against Joakim Nystrom on the stadium court, Boris Becker was on his hands and knees, trying to unearth a victory from the rubble of the first two sets. He bloodied his knee, pounded his racket in frustration and tossed his body around like a rag doll, stripped of all pretense and the red cape he had worn since leaving Wimbledon - the 17-year-old boy wonder and future No. 1 in all the world.

title: AIDE SAYS KOHL WANTS TO AVOID BONN DEBATE ON 'STAR WARS' ROLE
description: A senior security adviser to Chancellor Helmut Kohl says the Government has adopted a low-key, somewhat skeptical approach to the Reagan Administration's space weapons research program in an effort to prevent the issue from moving to the center of political debate here.

title: ALABAMA RALLIES IN FINAL SECONDS
description: They stood still in the middle of the madness of Sanford Stadium, victims of a shocking comeback that seemed certain to become part of Georgia football lore.

title: A Disintegrating Story
description: On the second anniversary of the shooting down of Korean Air Lines Flight 007 on Sept. 1, 1983, it seemed clearer than ever that the truth of this terrible event, in which 269 lives were lost, has not been told. Facts keep turning up that won't fit the generally accepted version or that raise serious and unanswered questions about it.

title: EX-GOVERNOR BROWN OF KENTUCKY PLANS TO RUN AGAIN IN '87
description: John Y. Brown Jr., who was Governor of Kentucky from 1979 to 1983, says he plans to be a candidate again in 1987.

title: HOUSE PLANTS FILTER OUT AIR POLLUTION, SAYS RESEARCHER
description: The ordinary house plant may be a solution to the problem of how to combat some forms of indoor air pollution, a space agency scientist has suggested.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Seattle Mariners, at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. Bob Shirley is on the mound for the Yankees in the finale of the three-game series.

title: Registration
description: Students in shorts and sunglasses looked ready for the beach rather than the ivy-covered halls.

title: Higher Bid Made For Broad Street
description: The First Jersey National Corporation said yesterday that it had raised its offer for all the shares of Broad Street National Bank to $66 a share, from $57 a share.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL DETROIT (AL) - Called up Doug Baker, infielder, and Bob Melvin, catcher, from Nashville of American Association; purchased Bob Stoddard, pitcher, from Nashville.

title: Lonnie Smith to Testify
description: Lonnie Smith of the Kansas City Royals was expected to be the first witness called by the prosecution Wednesday in the cocaine-trafficking trial of Curtis Strong, a Philadelphia caterer accused of selling the drug to major league baseball players.

title: CARTER HITS 3 HOMERS AS METS WIN
description: The San Diego Padres finally got Keith Hernandez out tonight, but they had the very devil of a time with Gary Carter, who hit three home runs, knocked in six runs and led the Mets to an 8-3 victory on a night filled with seven home runs.

title: Sikh Gunmen Said to Kill 3 Hindus in the Punjab
description: Sikh gunmen fired on Hindus in two places in the Punjab tonight, killing three people and wounding nine, the police said.

title: Fading Urban Know-How
description: Only three months living in another place, and already I am losing survival habits developed during 10 years as a New Yorker. During a brief visit last week, for example, I caught myself at 46th and Lexington looking up at the beauty of the Chrysler Building in a pastel twilight.

title: JACKSON AND FALWELL ON 'NIGHTLINE'
description: After two weeks of public sparring over United States policies in South Africa, the Rev. Jerry Falwell and the Rev. Jesse Jackson have agreed to face each other tonight for an hour on ABC's ''Nightline'' program.

title: 'BLIND ALLEYS,' DRAMA ON METROMEDIA PLAYHOUSE
description: GO ahead and watch ''Blind Alleys.'' It won't hurt, and it's always good to see someone attempt serious drama on television. Moreover, ''Blind Alleys'' is a modest attempt, no huge production, and this is a good thing, too. It's healthy when television gets down to basics. Western art may not be at stake, but it's encouraging when a television drama depends mostly on actors and words and not on spectacular sets. ''Blind Alleys'' doesn't even have a car chase. It will be seen on Channel 5 at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: 3 IN HAWAII ARREST TIED TO JAPANESE CRIME GROUP
description: Drug-enforcement officers here and in Hong Kong have arrested eight men described as major Japanese crime figures, and seized heroin and other drugs with a street value put at $56 million, Federal officials announced today.

title: U.S. in Yachting Series
description: An international competition between C-Class catamarans, the most technologically advanced of four world catamaran classes, is scheduled to begin today on Long Island Sound near Norwalk, Conn.

title: EX-HEAD OF CITY HOSPITALS INDICTED IN THEFT OF $250,000 FROM CLIENT
description: John J. McLaughlin, who resigned last month as president of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, was indicted yesterday on charges that included stealing more than $250,000 from a woman whom he had represented as an attorney and financial trustee.

title: U.S. CALLS HANOI TALKS 'MOST POSITIVE' IN 12 YEARS
description: The Reagan Administration said today that talks last week with Vietnamese officials in Hanoi were ''the most positive'' to date in the 12-year effort to resolve the problem of Americans unaccounted for in the Vietnam War.

title: GETTING SET FOR SCHOOL DAYS
description: SCHOOL is starting, so this is a time for new clothes, book bags, lunch boxes.

title: PEP BOYS-MANNY, MOE & JACK reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid July 15.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Arvin Industries, Columbus, Ind., which makes automotive, consumer and industrial products, has elected to its board Joseph P. Allen, executive vice president of Space Industries and a former astronaut with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Hawaii Volcano Active Again
description: A fountain of lava roared 1,000 feet into the night sky as another major phase of eruptive activity broke a three-week period of quiet at Kilauea Volcano, scientists said. The 36th phase of activity in the eruption that began on Jan. 3, 1983, started Monday afternoon when a 100-foot fountain of lava erupted 12 miles east of Kilauea's summit and gained strength as night approached, the United States Geological Survey's Hawaiian Volcano Observatory said. The eruption ended at 11:35 P.M.

title: On 'Faded Glory'
description: The libraries of Washington are overflowing with books about Presidents in office and how they got there, but there is remarkably little about the lives of these men after they left the White House spotlight. Into this breach has stepped James C. Clark, a former Washington correspondent for United Press International, with ''Faded Glory,'' a book from Praeger Publishers recounting the later lives of the 30 men out of 38 who did not die in office.

title: ARSON IS SUSPECTED IN FIRE AT PASSAIC
description: Authorities said today that they believed that arsonists set the devastating fire that raged through a 40-acre industrial complex on Labor Day, destroying 18 aged brick factories, leaving 400 people homeless and causing an estimated $400 million in damage.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SING ALONG WITH ASTI Beginning tonight, Asti, the restaurant that has been a landmark in Greenwich Village since 1925, is celebrating its 60th year with an opening program that features ''a tuneful musical feast served with Northern Italian cuisine.''

title: Even Baseball Players Can Have Civil Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Addendum
description: * Modern Maturity magazine, with its February/March 1986 issue, will increase its rate base 30 percent, to 13 million, and its advertising rates by the same percentage.

title: Title Bout to Go On
description: Nevada boxing officials said Bernard Benton would be allowed to keep his Sept. 21 ring date in Las Vegas with the World Boxing Council cruiserweight champion, Alfonso Ratliff, even though Benton has just been given a 90-day suspension by New Jersey authorities for failing a postbout drug test last February. Sig Rogich, the chairman of the Nevada Athletic Commission, said there was not be enough time to hold a hearing on the matter before the bout. . . . In another title bout on the featured Larry Holmes-Michael Spinks card, Julio Cesar Chavez, the World Boxing Council superfeatherweight champion, will defend against Dwight Prachett.

title: More Spanish Ads For Primary Race
description: Additional Spanish-language advertisements will be published about next Tuesday's Democratic primary for Bronx borough president and additional Spanish-speaking poll workers will be hired under an agreement announced yesterday by the city's Board of Elections.

title: Time to Talk With Black South Africa
description: All but the white right in South Africa seem to recognize that political power-sharing, if not outright majority rule, is inevitable. What is not inevitable is an American policy of diplomatic segregation that puts the United States in the unenviable position of being on both the wrong side, and the losing side, of South Africa's incipient civil war.

title: MASTERS MERCHANDISE MART reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including nonrecurring income of $478,000 on the sale of real estate and a loss from discontinued operations of $225,000. c-Net loss after a loss of $253,000 from discontinued operations.

title: HOWARD L. STEINBERG
description: Howard L. Steinberg, a civil engineer and a land developer in central and southern New Jersey, died of complications from diabetes Saturday at New England Deaconess Hospital in Boston. He was 66 years old and lived in Roseland, N.J.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: New Toyota Plant
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation plans to build a $300 million auto plant somewhere in Canada that will be completed in 1988, according to the office of the Industry Minister, Sinclair Stevens.

title: A Chair Moves On
description: While Dr. William C. Freund didn't have a seat on the New York Stock Exchange, he had a chair.

title: A Famous Case
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Houston Offering Sewer Bond Issue
description: A $270 million issue of Houston sewer revenue refunding bonds was tentatively offered yesterday with a maximum yield of 9.42 percent for bonds due in 2014. Underwriters are led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: 3 CHANGES IN TAX BILL ARE PROPOSED BY TREASURY
description: The Treasury Department today announced three modest refinements in President Reagan's tax revision plan to meet Congressional demands that the package generate more revenue than the proposals the Administration submitted to Congress last May.

title: SCM BID IS RAISED BY HANSON
description: Hanson Trust P.L.C. sharply raised its bid for the SCM Corporation yesterday to $72 a share, or a total of $878 million, in cash.

title: Fires in West Reported Near Containment
description: Firefighters began what they hoped would be their final assaults yesterday on an outbreak of wildfires that charred more than 70,000 acres in the West, mostly in national forests, and destroyed nearly 30 homes and other buildings.

title: PENTAGON BACKING PROPOSAL TO DROP A FAIRCHILD PLANE
description: The Defense Department has proposed canceling a new Air Force training plane that is the mainstay of the Fairchild Republic Company's aircraft plant on Long Island, Pentagon and industry sources said today.

title: CBS OFFERING 2,000 EARLY RETIREMENT
description: CBS Inc., looking for ways to pay for its costly takeover fight earlier this summer with Ted Turner, announced yesterday that it would offer early retirement to 2,000 employees, or about 7 percent of its work force.

title: Takeover Sought For Maine Utility
description: The Central Maine Power Company said that it remained willing to negotiate an acquistion of the Maine Public Service Company, even though Maine Public said that it had broken off negotiations. ''The door is wide open, from our point of view,'' said Peter G. Thompson, a spokesman for Central Maine Power.

title: WEST BANK STABBING KILLS ISRAEL SOLDIER
description: An Israeli soldier was stabbed to death and another seriously wounded today as they stood guard at an apartment in the West Bank, the Israeli Army spokesman announced.

title: MARRIOTT MARQUIS OPENS ITS DOORS
description: The $450 million Marriott Marquis Hotel near Times Square opened its doors yesterday at 6:10 P.M. after getting 11th-hour city approval of the hotel's main floor in time for the arrival of guests.

title: RECEIVERS FOR JETS AN UNTESTED GROUP
description: The wide receiver position was one area the Jets had counted on strengthening before this season, but when they open Sunday in Los Angeles against the Raiders, their wide receiving corps will comprise players who have not started in the National Football League.

title: People
description: * Carol A. Good and Thomas A. Hedrick Jr. have been appointed senior vice presidents at Ted Bates Advertising/New York.

title: TIPPERARY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $9,000 from discontinued operations for the latest quarter and $43,000 for the latest nine months. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $227,000 and an an extraordinary credit of $6,000 for the year-ago quarter and a loss of $795,000 and a credit of $6,000 for the year-ago nine months.

title: ON NOT BITING INTO THE GREEN APPLES OF SOUTH AFRICA
description: To the Editor:

title: Watching Out for the Public's Investment in New York Transit
description: To the Editor:

title: Minnesota State Police Join Search for Killer of 2 Brothers
description: State investigators and local officers are searching for the killer of two elderly bachelor brothers who were rumored to have kept large amounts of cash hidden at their farmhouse.

title: BUYER MAY BE FOUND FOR EPIC UNIT
description: A major real estate company has agreed to buy the troubled Equity Programs Investment Corporation if the private mortgage insurers backing Equity Programs' securities contribute $100 million to such a bailout, investment banking sources said yesterday.

title: Hotel Attack in Athens Wounds 18 Britons
description: An attacker threw two hand grenades into a Greek hotel today, wounding 18 British tourists.

title: 3 Tamil Moderates Found Slain in Sri Lanka
description: Four leaders of a moderate Tamil party were kidnapped in Sri Lanka Monday and the bodies of three were found today, Government and party spokesmen said.

title: NUMBER OF CASUALTIES IS DISPUTED
description: A car packed with explosives blew up in southern Lebanon today. The driver was killed, but there were conflicting reports about other casualties.

title: Advertising;   Intermarco's Sales Pitch
description: ARLENE HOFFMAN breeds butterflies in her office up above the chicly situated Paris Theater. Soon, blue-jade chrysalises will make their magical metamorphosis into Monarch butterflies, which will then be set free to embellish the existing beauties of Grand Army Plaza.

title: Bridge: Strong Showing in Spingold Bodes Well for Mike Kamil
description: Those who watched the performances in the recent Spingold Knockout Teams in Las Vegas, Nev., prophesied a bright future for Mike Kamil of Bergenfield, N.J.

title: A BALLERINA AND A ROLE TO REUNITE
description: Alessandra Ferri has been in New York only three weeks and already she has seen ''42d Street'' and ''The Rocky Horror Picture Show,'' browsed and bought in Bloomingdale's, suffered the travails of Manhattan apartment hunting and studied the collection of Renaissance paintings at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: COMPOSED HIT SONG, 'RUDOLPH' IN 1949
description: Johnny Marks, the composer of ''Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer,'' died of complications from diabetes yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Real Estate;   Stamford's Waterfront Renewal
description: BY the time autumn starts to show its colors early next month, a new 600-foot boardwalk is to be completed on the waterfront in Stamford, Conn., opening up that section of the water's edge to the public for the first time this century. The boardwalk is part of a new commercial development called Stamford Landing, another in a growing number of projects that are transforming the city's wasted industrial south end into a revitalized neighborhood of shops, restaurants and offices.

title: FOR BERGER, NO. 733, IT WAS A FINE TIME
description: There are ballboys at the National Tennis Center who have a better chance of making an appearance on the stadium court than the 733d-ranked player in the world. But at 11:30 A.M. yesterday, Jay Berger, the 17-year-old wild-card entry from Clemson University, walked on the court where the stars play.

title: SBE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CHINESE CONDUCTOR REVISITS HOME
description: When Tsung Yeh arrived in New York on a piano scholarship five summers ago he headed for a corner store only to discover that he had forgotten the English word for rice.

title: Market Place;   Colonial Penn Takeover Talk
description: THE Colonial Penn Group, an insurance holding company, has been identified for the past year as a possible takeover target. So when the stock traded Friday at 30 1/4 - its highest price since last summer - the question arose as to whether any deal was imminent.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: West Indian Fare Amid the gong of steel drums and the blare of trumpets, the infectiously driving rhythms of calypso and soca (soul-calypso), dancing feathery headdresses, glittering body suits and elaborate gold and silver costumes, Brooklyn's Eastern Parkway was transformed into a razzle-dazzle Caribbean thoroughfare for last Monday's West Indian American Day parade. The event marked the climax of the carnival celebrated each year over Labor Day weekend by the city's sizable West Indian population.

title: Observatory Toll Call Gives Help on Comet
description: The return of Halley's comet is generating much attention, but its appearance may be less exciting than many hope and the inexperienced are likely to need help in sighting it.

title: NIGERIA COUP TIED TO LACK OF POWER-SHARING
description: The roots of the latest coup in Nigeria may lie in the refusal of the former leaders to share decision-making powers with others in the Government, according to several experts on Africa's largest nation.

title: KASPAROV HOLDS EDGE AS CHESS TITLE PLAY BEGINS
description: Gary Kasparov seized the initiative today early in the first game of his restarted world chess championship play against the champion, Anatoly Karpov, and by the time the game was adjourned he was poised for an opening victory.

title: BLACK MINE UNION CALLS OFF STRIKE IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: The nation's principal black mine workers' union announced today that it had suspended a strike against selected mines after less than three days.

title: HALMI, ROBERT INC reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: The company recently changed its fiscal year-end from March 31 to May 31. Year-ago results are for the year ended March 31.

title: COMPUTRAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
WELDED TUBE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: MAYORAL CANDIDATES URGE RESHAPING OF SCHOOL BOARD
description: Mayor Koch and his two major challengers for the Democratic mayoral nomination agreed yesterday that the city's Board of Education should be reorganized but disagreed on how to do it.

title: SOUTH AFRICA BANK CHIEF SEES U.S. BANKERS ON MORATORIUM
description: The head of South Africa's central bank met yesterday with leading bankers in New York to begin what the bankers predicted would be arduous negotiations over how that nation's foreign debt should be rescheduled.

title: CULP INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
HOFSTRA FACULTY'S STRIKE MARS SEMESTER OPENING
description: Russell King embarked on his college career today, and it was somewhat anticlimactic. ''I'm pretty anxious to get going,'' the 18-year-old freshman at Hofstra University said. ''And now I'm on hold.''

title: U.S. CENTER KEEPS EYE ON STORMS
description: In this season, work never stops at the National Hurricane Center.

title: 11 WELLS FARGO ROBBERY SUSPECTS APPEAR IN HARTFORD COURT
description: Security was tight today for the first court appearance here of 11 suspected Puerto Rican terrorists charged in the $7 million robbery of a Wells Fargo depot in 1983.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Aug. 19 about barbecue grills incorrectly described the part the Ford Motor Company played in the origins of charcoal as a consumer product. Half a century ago, wood was more common as an auto component, so scrap for charcoal was obtainable in several ways, not simply from station wagon trim. And while Ford Motor did require its auto dealers to sell its briquettes, it did not require that they accept a carload for each carload of autos shipped.

title: Gliding in the Park
description: John Pendry glided gracefully down a gentle slope on the East Lawn of Central Park yesterday, tantalizing the small crowd of onlookers. He flew on a fragile-looking, 30-foot-wide, yellow-and-white wing, from which he hung suspended by a harness.

title: Mazzei to Head Club
description: Julio Mazzei, who coached the Cosmos twice, was named director of soccer operations for Corsairs Soccer Club of Mount Vernon, one of the nine teams in the Super Division of the Southern New York State Soccer Association. He said among the players he had already signed were Barry Nix and Gerry Reardon, former all-Americans at Columbia and Adelphi, respectively.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: REAGAN WANTS TO VOICE VIEWS ON RUSSIAN TV
description: The White House, responding to remarks by Mikail S. Gorbachev, said today that President Reagan was willing to meet the Soviet Union ''halfway in an effort to solve problems.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Business Day on Saturday with an article on the Canadian gold industry omitted the standard of measurement in comparing sales of Canadian Maple Leaf coins and South African Krugerrands. Sales were in millions of troy ounces.

title: On Scientists as Lobbyists
description: Forty years ago the Federation of American Scientists, then called the Federation of Atomic Scientists, was founded by veterans of the World War II atomic bomb project to serve as the ''conscience'' of the scientific community in promoting world peace.

title: ALABAMA'S SHULA PASSES TEST
description: His education began long before college, and even before high school. Mike Shula was learning about the family business even before he knew he wanted to play quarterback. When he worked for his father, as the assistant equipment manager of the Miami Dolphins, he gathered laundry and chased footballs, and watched. Mike Shula was always paying attention.

title: BROWN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $810,000 for the quarter and $804,000 for the 9 months. c-After a loss of $10,957 from discontinued operations.

title: Court Case Resumes On Child Molestation
description: The preliminary hearing in a wide-ranging case charging molestation in a nursery school resumed today with prosecutors arguing that five purported victims should be allowed to testify over closed-circuit television.

title: MARRIED PRIESTS TILT BRAVELY AT UNYIELDING VATICAN
description: The meeting was small, but with a large name and a passionate cause.

title: Bad Reactions
description: With the Yankees down in Texas for a series about a month ago, Billy Martin's back started acting up again. Spasms were the villain, but not to worry. The Rangers' team physician, Dr. B. J. Mycoskie, was on hand to administer an injection that would bring relief. Problem was, the needle went where it shouldn't have gone, and the Yankee manager was left with a punctured lung and an unexpected vacation.

title: PARSLEY, SAGE, ROSEMARY AND MRS. STREET
description: AN urgent telephone call roused the folks at Apple Pie Farm one recent morning. A Boston hotel needed 400 freshly cut nasturtiums, six times the standard order, for a dinner party of chefs that evening.

title: GUNTHARDT DEFEATS LECONTE IN 5 SETS
description: He applauded his opponent several times during the afternoon, tapping the strings of his racket with his right hand. And when the entertaining, well-played five-set match was over, Henri Leconte fought back the disappointment and smiled, meeting Heinz Gunthardt at the net for the ceremonial handshake and ''well done.''

title: CITY OPERA COSTUMES LOST IN FIRE
description: The warehouse that stored the costumes for most of the New York City Opera's productions was destroyed in the fire that engulfed an industrial complex in Passaic, N.J., on Monday, City Opera officials reported yesterday.

title: IN SODA RIVALRY, CHOCOLATE IS IN
description: In Chicago, it was called the ''chocolate phos,'' for phosphate. To New Yorkers, it was a chocolate soda.

title: TEACHERS FROM SPAIN TAKE NEW YORK 101
description: Thirty-five teachers newly recruited from Madrid to help ease the city's teacher shortage reported to the Board of Education's headquarters in Brooklyn yesterday for a daylong orientation session that started with the basics.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: FOR Wendy, the painful tingling in the fingers of her right hand began 12 years ago during her first pregnancy. Despite the doctor's assurance that her symptoms, which he described as carpal tunnel syndrome, would disappear after she gave birth, they persisted. She had to give up needlework, knitting and reading in bed - her favorite ways to relax - because her hand hurt so when she applied any tension to it. As a teacher, she was distressed by her inability to write on a blackboard and her difficulty writing even on paper. But the worst discomfort came every morning when she woke to find her hand oddly twisted, apparently in an unconscious attempt to relieve the symptoms that flared in the night.

title: ROYALE AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $309,000 from the sale of two aircraft.

title: Scott Buys Back Brascan's Stake
description: The Scott Paper Company said yesterday that it had purchased the 24.9 percent of its common stock that Brascan Ltd. had accumulated. A Scott spokesman valued the deal at $578 million to $590 million.

title: ASTRO-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
SWEDE'S STROKE RAISES CONCERN FOR HEART RECIPIENT IN ARIZONA
description: A report that Sweden's artificial heart patient had suffered a stroke raised concern here today as Michael Drummond, the latest American recipient, continued what doctors described as ''a dramatic'' recovery.

title: STOCK PRICES DECLINE BROADLY
description: Wall Street stock prices fell broadly yesterday, but trading volume remained in a slump as investors, just back from the long Labor Day weekend, found nothing in the latest economic reports to lure them back into the market.

title: Richardson Signs With Nets
description: Micheal Ray Richardson, the Nets playmaker who is coming off his finest season, has signed a four-year contract that, with bonuses, could be worth more than $3 million.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 4, 1985
description: Companies

title: CARDINALS DEFEAT REDS, 6-4
description: Brian Harper pinch-hit a two-run, two-out double to snap a seventh-inning tie tonight and lead the Cardinals past the Cincinnati Reds, 6-4.

title: The Primary Threat to Chile's Rule of Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Koch for a Third Term
description: In ''Winter's Tale,'' Mark Helprin's soaring novel about a fantastical New York City, mayors are labeled by metaphors to characterize their eras. There's an Ermine Mayor, for instance, for a period of unusual cold and a Gold Mayor for a time of shining promise. What would be an appropriate metaphor for Edward Irving Koch?

title: MICROSOFT HAS IT ALL - ALMOST
description: Something is gnawing at Microsoft.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mary Slaney and Said Aouita of Morocco, who have dominated the first international track and field Grand Prix season, could earn $35,000 each on Saturday by winning their events at the series final in Rome. Victories by Mrs. Slaney in the 3,000 meters and Aouita at 5,000 meters would assure them the grand prizes. . . . The Boston Celtics traded the guard Quinn Buckner to the Indiana Pacers for a second-round draft choice. The Celtics may select any second-round choice before 1990.

title: Mortgage Delinquencies
description: In July, 1.85 percent of Americans with home loans from a savings and loan institution had missed at least two payments, the U.S. League of Savings Institutions said today. The rate is up slightly from the June report but is still down significantly from the beginning of the year.

title: SPY CASE EVIDENCE IS CALLED COMPLEX
description: Federal law-enforcement officials said today that the case against Jerry A. Whitworth, one of four Navy men accused of participating in a Soviet spy ring, was based largely on circumstantial evidence and will be the most complicated to explain to a jury.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   The Titanic Lesson
description: The wreck of the Titanic has been been found, 560 miles off the coast of Newfoundland and in 13,000 feet of water. Its French and American discoverers report the wreck is in ''museum piece'' condition. Fascination with the great disaster of April 15, 1912, hasn't lost its freshness either.

title: Yount Back in Spring
description: Robin Yount, the Brewer slugger, underwent shoulder surgery in Milwaukee, and afterward club officials said the operation to remove bone spurs and calcium deposits had been a success and that Yount should be ready to play in time for spring training. . . . Jim Clancy, the Toronto pitcher who has been on the disabled list with a shoulder injury since July 27, was reactivated and assigned to start the Blue Jays' game against the Minnesota Twins on Sunday. . . . The Pittsburgh Pirates pitcher Rick Reuschel, a 36-year-old right-hander whose sore shoulder almost ended his career last winter, has signed a three-year contract with the team. Reuschel, a 14-year veteran, is 10-7 with a 2.52 earned-run average in 23 appearances this season for the Pirates, who have baseball's worst record. . . . Mike Heath, the Oakland catcher who pleaded a sore foot after failing to run out a ground ball in the A's 14-3 loss to the Detroit Tigers on Sunday, was fined $1,000. The manager, Jackie Moore, explained: 'If you can run 55 feet on a sore foot, you can go all the way to first.''

title: Glen A. Wilkinson, a Lawyer; Firm Aided American Indians
description: Glen A. Wilkinson, chairman of George Washington University's board of trustees and a partner in the law firm of Wilkinson, Barker, Knauer & Quinn, died of cancer Thursday. He was 74 years old.

title: CONSTRUCTION SPENDING INCREASED 1.2% IN JULY
description: Construction spending climbed by a moderate 1.2 percent in July, led by sizable gains in new office buildings, Government projects and some housing, the Commerce Department reported today. The July increase brought construction spending to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $349.5 billion.

title: PASTORA BELEAGUERED AS AID DRIES UP
description: At a time when other rebel groups are receiving renewed financing from the United States, the best-known Nicaraguan exile rebel commander, Eden Pastora Gomez, appears to have stumbled to the lowest point yet in his three-year fight against the Nicaraguan Government he once served.

title: Accounts
description: * Commonwealth National Bank, Harrisburg, Pa., to Mel Richman Inc. of Bala-Cynwyd, Pa.

title: COACH WAS ALWAYS THERE
description: Bruce Gehrke was a high-school coach of such epic measure that he could be in two places at once. It was not unusual for him to be at home in one town, yet at the same time be patrolling the streets of Mineola, L.I., where he was the football and basketball coach.

title: GORBACHEV HINTS HE'LL BE FLEXIBLE
description: A delegation of United States Senators met for three and a half hours today with Mikhail S. Gorbachev and said afterward that the Soviet leader had indicated the possibility of flexibility by his side at the Geneva arms talks.

title: Bank of Boston Lifts RIHT Bid
description: The Bank of Boston Corporation said yesterday that it had raised its bid to acquire the RIHT Financial Corporation from $59 a share, to $73 a share, or a total of about $150 million.

title: Director Guides South Africa Group
description: John H. Chettle has been in Washington as director of the South Africa Foundation since 1975. During those years, he has seen his country go through difficult times. But nothing matches the current turmoil.

title: Trial Opens in Killing Of a Fashion Student
description: The lawyer for a man accused of killing a Norwegian fashion student said today that the death stemmed from a sex game, disputing prosecution claims that it was a cold-blooded murder.

title: NATIONAL LUMBER & SUPPLY reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company changed its fiscal year-end to Jan. 31. Year-ago results are for the quarter and 6 months ended June 30, 1984.

title: Automobile Recalls Set By G.M. and Volkswagen
description: The General Motors Corporation will recall 454,000 Chevrolet and Pontiac subcompact cars from the 1981 model year to repair corroding pollution control equipment, the Environmental Protection Agency announced today.

title: Sally Looms Large In Plans of Giants
description: Uncomfortable as the center of attention, Jerome Sally covered his eyes when it was suggested to him that he had proved he could be a starter with the Giants. ''The coach says I played a good game,'' he said. ''He has a better view than I do.'' This is not a case of modesty, false or otherwise, but rather one example of how some football players still look at themselves as an instrument in somebody else's master plan. Sally, a nose tackle, does not see himself as an independent agent, but rather as simply part of a defensive line.

title: Jetliner With 190 Aboard In Emergency Landing
description: An American Airlines DC-10 carrying 190 people today made an emergency landing when a warning light showed an engine was on fire, a company spokesman said.

title: POLAND SAYS U.S. HAS BAD MANNERS
description: The Polish Government accused the State Department today of ''bad manners'' for having announced that the Reagan Administration would refuse to hold any meetings with Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski when he arrives in New York later this month.

title: HULK OF TITANTIC REPORTED INTACT
description: The Titanic is intact with a hull ''like a museum piece,'' the first person to view the wreckage by television said today, but he added that any salvage attempts would desecrate the gravesite of the more than 1,500 people who died when the ship sank.

title: A Quiet Crisis in the Work Place
description: The dramatic growth of corporate mergers and takeovers in the last few years is having a disturbing effect on the nature of job commitment in the United States. Perhaps unwittingly, and certainly without much public notice, these corporate maneuverers are undermining the elusive pursuit of job satisfaction in America. Unless we address this condition, the nation will find that it is restructuring its economic resources on quicksand. For years, sociologists have noted an undercurrent of worker discontent in this country. In 1973, a special Presidential task force on ''Work in America'' concluded that ''significant numbers of Americans are dissatisfied with their working lives.'' Later, Studs Terkel's best seller ''Working'' reached the same conclusions through hundreds of interviews with people in all walks of life.

title: NEW YORK URGEGES HIGH COURT TO AFFIRM ABORTION DECISION
description: Robert Abrams, New York State's Attorney General, has filed a brief urging the Supreme Court to reaffirm its 1973 decision legalizing abortion and to reject the Reagan Administration's arguments for overruling that precedent.

title: CHEVRON PROPERTIES ON BLOCK
description: The Chevron Corporation is soliciting bids on its Philadelphia refinery and its chain of 4,800 East Coast gasoline stations, as well as on its refinery and 275 stations in Puerto Rico, the San Francisco-based oil company confirmed today.

title: CIRCUS CIRCUS ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ON NOT BITING INTO THE GREEN APPLES OF SOUTH AFRICA
description: To the Editor:

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DURING the recent lottery madness, Larry Diamond of Manhattan decided to buy one more ticket. He'd already used birthday, anniversary, address and phone number combinations. This time he decided to read the newspaper food advertisements and select the first six prices between 1 and 48. If I win, he thought, what a story that will make. Eagerly, he began his quest. Chicken legs, 79 cents. Chicken wings and seedless grapes, both 69 cents. Back to school filler paper, 59 cents. Getting closer.

title: A Worker Gets Ahead
description: Shirley L. Klein's daughter laughed at her when she sat down to apply for a job at the Buildings Department.

title: KOCH WON'T PUT AIDS PATIENTS IN QUEENS SITE
description: Mayor Koch yesterday reversed his policy and announced that he was dropping a sharply disputed plan to move some homeless AIDS patients into a Queens nursing home.

title: Mozambican Plans U.S. Trip
description: President Reagan and President Samora M. Machel of Mozambique will confer in Washington on Sept. 19, the White House announced today.

title: Freddie Mac President Will Head Imperial
description: The Imperial Corporation of America yesterday named the president of the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, Kenneth J. Thygerson, to be president and chief executive officer of the San Diego-based savings and loan holding company.

title: LITTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
NATO General Renews Call For New Chemical Weapons
description: NATO's Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, Gen. Bernard W. Rogers, renewed his call today for the United States to produce modern chemical weapons and said he wanted better political guidance on their use.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: IN COUNTRY. By Bobbie Ann Mason. 245 pages. Harper & Row. $15.95.

title: Waiting for Steve
