description: By the end of the week, Steve Young will be a quarterback for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. Or he won't be.

title: FOR PRECISE AMOUNTS
description: MOST kitchen scales are designed to weigh meat, fish and vegetables.

title: Sore Feet Unable To Slow Aouita
description: During a summer in which Said Aouita has set world records in the 1,500 and the 5,000 and has turned in the second-fastest time ever in the mile, he has obviously had no problem with meters or, by implication, yards. But the 24-year-old Moroccan does have difficulty with feet, which as a consequence may slow his pursuit of his announced goal: eventually setting all the major records from 1,500 through 10,000 meters.

title: SUSPECT IN COAST DEATHS CHARGED IN 1 MURDER
description: Charges of one count of murder and seven counts of burglary, robbery and sexual assault were filed today against Richard Ramirez, whom the police are investigating for possible connection to a series of murders that terrorized many Californians for weeks.

title: APPLIED CIRCUIT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss including tax credits of $532,000 for the quarter and $199,000 for the nine months.

title: On Things Free
description: Even in these days of declining inflation, it is worth noting when the cost of something actually goes down instead of up. For most of the 60 years that the Library of Congress has been offering chamber music concerts, tickets cost a 25-cent service charge after a wait in line at a downtown music store. With the season that opens Sept. 21, tickets will become free, reservable by telephone, at (202) 287-5502, with a limit of two tickets per call.

title: AMERICAN SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
The Presidency;   A Baedeker, of Sorts, On Travels With the Chief
description: The 1988 Presidential election is already a subject of considerable discussion among White House staff members, Secret Service agents, reporters and others who make a living out of following Presidents around. Not the election's politics but its geography.

title: Ex-E.P.A. Aide to Be Freed
description: Rita M. Lavelle, former head of the Environmental Protection Agency's program to clean up toxic waste dumps, is to be released from prison Wednesday after serving four and a half months of a six-month sentence for lying to Congress.

title: GUATEMALAN PROTESTS BROKEN UP
description: The police fired tear gas to disperse hundreds of students, workers and housewives today as demonstrators rampaged through the Guatemalan capital, stoning shops and vehicles.

title: US DESIGN CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ELDER BEERMAN STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 4
description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in January 1985.

title: FILM: FOUR DOCUMENTSTARIES ON PHOTOGRAPHERS
description: THE four short documentary films about still photography that are currently having their premieres at the Film Forum all suffer from the same fault, which seems to be inherent in the genre: motion pictures must move, whereas still photographs do not. The film maker has to make the still photograph move, panning across it, coming in for a close-up, cutting rapidly from one image to another. He can never let the whole photograph sit still on the screen long enough for the viewer to take it in. Or else he has to concentrate on the photographer, which is what the makers of these four films tend to do.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHEN I was chef at Le Pavillon, which has since closed, I was fascinated to read repeatedly that it was considered the finest French restaurant in the United States. To tell the truth, in those days we had little competition in New York, and because of the restaurant's reputation, we had our choice of the finest professional chefs in the country. Our reputation, in turn, attracted a noteworthy clientele.

title: Ohio State's Byars Out
description: Keith Byars, the Ohio State tailback whose stunning 1984 performance made him a strong preseason candidate for the 1985 Heisman Trophy, broke a bone in his right foot during a Buckeye practice on Monday and will miss at least one game and as many as three, the university announced yesterday. Dr. Robert Murphy, the Buckeye team physician, described the fracture as a ''clean break'' of the bone leading to Byar's little toe and said the 235-pound running back would have to wear a cast for 10 to 14 days before rehabilitation could begin. According to Coach Earle Bruce, Byars was running a sweep when he suddenly went down without being hit.

title: BOLIVIANS MULL GENERAL STRIKE
description: Strikes spread across Bolivia today as labor leaders prepared to study calls for an indefinite general strike to protest tough economic measures against 14,000 percent inflation.

title: Forgiveness and Amends
description: Tax evaders, who may be slothful about filing tax returns, have been eager beavers in applying for amnesty.

title: OFFICIALS SAY F.B.I. INSISTED PRESSER PAY 'GHOST WORKERS'
description: After authorizing Jackie Presser to put people who did no work on the teamsters' union payroll, agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation several times rejected his requests for permission to dismiss them, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Mandlikova Finds Improved Game
description: If she's on.

title: 'ALASKA TURKEY' AND OTHER SAYINGS
description: There are Tennesseans who refer to snoring as ''calling the hogs,'' Virginians and North Carolinians who call firecrackers ''baby-wakers'' and some New Jerseyans who suffer ''buckwheat itch'' supposedly from eating pancakes in summer.

title: The Primary Threat to Chile's Rule of Law
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transcription error, an article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about the mayoral race in Syracuse misidentified one of the two candidates for the Republican nomination. He is Bernard Mahoney, chairman of the Syracuse Common Council, the Right to Life Party's mayoral candidate.

title: NIEKRO GAINS HIS 298TH VICTORY
description: Phil Niekro and his brother, Joe, gained the 500th victory of their major league careers last night. Joe, of course, had his brother to thank. They could both thank Mike Pagliarulo, Dan Pasqua, Bobby Meacham and Dave Winfield.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The important thing is to get to this meeting, to have the two men look each other over, size each other up, lay out their views on these various topics and then be able to set an agenda to deal with these in the future.'' - Larry Speakes, on the meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [A6:1.]

title: Canadian Bank Action Seen
description: The Government will increase its powers to scrutinize financial institutions in the wake of the collapse of the Canadian Commercial Bank of Edmonton, Alberta, Barbara McDougall, Minister of State for Finance, said today.

title: China Bars Import of Blood In an Effort to Prevent AIDS
description: In an attempt to prevent the deadly disease AIDS from spreading to China, the Ministry of Public Health and customs officials have banned the import of blood products, the official New China News Agency reported today.

title: On Not Biting Into the Green Apples of South Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: WINE TALK
description: EXPLAINING the college experience to someone who has never attended but wishes he had is trying. One eventually gives up. People believe what they want to believe. They don't want to hear that 50 percent of college life is just wheel-spinning, that courses can be dull and the curriculum irrelevant.

title: JAZZ: SAM RIVERS AT VILLAGE FESTIVAL
description: THE heady free jazz of the 1960's is still with us, in recognizable but radically changed shape. At Monday's all-day ''Music Is an Open Sky'' concert, finishing the Village Jazz Festival, the final seven hours of music recast the full-tilt, wide-open music of the 1960's in forms fit for the 1980's.

title: Icahn's T.W.A. Stake Up to 52.5%
description: The New York investor Carl C. Icahn bought an additional $17 million, or 776,900 shares, of Trans World Airlines Inc. common stock at the end of last week, reinforcing his control of the New York-based airline. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Icahn disclosed that he now controls 52.5 percent of T.W.A.'s shares outstanding, up from 50.3 percent.

title: ENTERTAINMENT MARKETING INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Warrnts Introduced For Currency Units
description: The growing use of European Currency Units by borrowers and lenders in the capital markets led Phibro-Salomon yesterday to issue the first put and call warrants for these units.

title: JUDGE IN NASSAU TRIAL MIXES ADVICE WITH HUMOR
description: In preparing their summations for the jury, the lawyers in the class-action suit by Nassau County employees were warned by Judge Jacob Mishler not to put the jurors to sleep.

title: G.M.-Hughes Delay Seen
description: The General Motors Corporation's acquisition of the Hughes Aircraft Company has been delayed several weeks because the Securities and Exchange Commission has questioned some of G.M.'s accounting procedures in the $5 billion merger, sources close to the negotiations said today.

title: HUTTON TO PUNISH 'A DOZEN'
description: About ''a dozen'' employees of E. F. Hutton & Company will face disciplinary action by the firm for engaging in excessive bank overdrafting activities, its chairman, Robert M. Fomon, told Hutton employees in a 30-minute talk today.

title: Novelist Gets High Post In British Tory Party
description: The best-selling novelist Jeffrey Archer was named deputy chairman of the Conservative Party by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allnet Communication Services Inc., Chicago, an interstate, long-distance telephone company, said it had been told by its lender, Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co., that it intended to take no action to collect on a short-term $10 million credit facility that expired Aug. 30.

title: Chicago Yields Range to 10%
description: Chicago is offering $216 million of general obligation bonds, tentatively priced with a maximum yield of 10 percent for bonds due in 2013, through underwriters led by the First National Bank of Chicago.

title: SOVIET BARS THREE FROM BOOK FAIR
description: The Soviet Government has denied visas to three Americans who planned to participate in the Fifth Moscow International Book Fair, which opens next Tuesday.

title: CHINA SCHOOL LEADS FOOD RENAISSANCE
description: THE signs of recovery from the Cultural Revolution are everywhere in China. But they seem even more exciting in this city, which many say took the brunt of the intellectual and cultural purges from 1966 to 1976. Even the culinary field seems to be enjoying a renaissance, as evidenced in a recent visit by American food professionals to the Shanghai Food and Drink Service Institute, otherwise known as the Shanghai Culinary Institute.

title: The Long Road
description: More news from the Kansas City medical front:

title: HIGH-FAT FISH: HEALTHFUL AND TASTY
description: ALL fish are not equal in nutritional merits or consumer appeal, and until very recently, fatty fish seemed to be considerably less equal than others. Most health professionals, believing that the high level of fat in the standard American diet was leading to a high incidence of heart attacks, were rating fish according to their fat and calorie content: the greater the amount of fat, the less desirable the fish.

title: RTC TRANSPORTATION CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
NCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 4, 1985
description: International

title: Treasury Yields Off Modestly
description: Interest rates on short- and long-term Treasury issues declined modestly yesterday.

title: DIRE STRAITS IRONY STIRS A DISPUTE
description: ''BROTHERS IN ARMS'' (Warner Brothers), the fourth studio album in seven years by the British rock group Dire Straits, may be the finest mainstream rock record of 1985. The album, which soared to No. 1 on Billboard's pop album chart two weeks ago, has already sold nearly two million copies and has spawned one of the year's most controversial hits in ''Money for Nothing'' (No. 6 on Billboard's singles chart and climbing rapidly).

title: MAYORAL CANDIDATES DEBATE SCHOOLS, HOUSING AND SUBWAYS
description: Following are excerpts from a debate held yesterday by Mayor Koch, who is seeking his third term, and his major challengers in the Sept. 10 Democratic primary, City Council President Carol Bellamy and Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr.:

title: Benjamin Lazrus Dies; Founder of Benrus Co.
description: Benjamin Lazrus, founder and former chairman of the Benrus Watch Company, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91 years old.

title: CHARLES GIBSON
description: Charles Gibson, retired professor of Latin American history at the University of Michigan, died Aug. 22 at the Champlain Valley Physicians Hospital in Plattsburg, N.Y. He was 65 years old and lived in Keeseville, N.Y.

title: On Celebrating Ourselves
description: As the National Endowment for the Arts prepares for a flag-flying 20th anniversary celebration, its sister organization, the National Endowment for the Humanities, is keeping a low profile, which is perhaps fitting for an organization that usually takes the long view, measuring many things in millenniums.

title: BHUTTO ARREST STIRS DOUBTS ON ZIA'S PLAN
description: The recent arrest of Benazir Bhutto, a prominent leader of the opposition to President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, has raised new doubts among politicians about General Zia's promise to restore a civilian government to Pakistan.

title: L.P. Media Bid Off
description: L. P. Media Inc. said that it had ended its tender offer for shares of the Evening News Association, which last week agreed to a higher offer from the Gannett Company. L. P. Media said that it would return all shares tendered to it.

title: SHARPEVILLE: SYMBOLISM BURNS ANEW
description: The idea, according to black students who live in this austere emblem of resistance outside Johannesburg, was to protest peacefully.

title: TELECREDIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Year-ago results include a nonrecurring gain equal to 7 cents a share from the sale of Telecredit's equity position in DMC Systems Inc. in June 1984.

title: AS SERVICE STANDARDS DECLINE, A FEW RESTAURANTS STILL EXCEL
description: ON the subject of restaurant service, virtually every diner has a full menu of common complaints: waiters and waitresses who are indifferent or rude, those who have little knowledge about the food and wine they serve, endless waits for dishes, awkward presentation, uncleared plates, dirty ashtrays. There are also the ''Who gets the chicken?'' school of service and the overly familiar ''Hi, I'm Bruce'' types.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE LANDS SAFELY AFTER 'NEAR PERFECT-MISSION'
description: Riding the first thin rays of dawn, the space shuttle Discovery glided safely to earth today to complete what one space agency official called ''a near-perfect mission.''

title: Corestates Unit To Buy Talcott
description: The Corestates Financial Corporation said that its subsidiary, the Congress Financial Corporation, had agreed to acquire James Talcott Inc., a factoring and commercial finance concern, from Lloyds Bank P.L.C. Terms were not disclosed, but Gary Brooten, a spokesman for Corestates said the price was slightly more than Talcott's book value of $35 million.

title: Reagan Back to Work At 'Full Steam Ahead'
description: President Reagan plunged ''full steam ahead'' into his regular White House schedule today, the chief White House spokesman said, and plans to follow a health checkup regimen in the aftermath of his surgery for colon cancer.

title: SAUDIS, IN POLICY SHIFT, MAY SET PRICE DISCOUNT
description: Saudi Arabia may be putting into effect a new policy that could result in its first discounts from the official OPEC price, analysts said yesterday.

title: NEW YORK CITY STARTING A POLICE CADET CORPS
description: Mayor Koch yesterday announced the establishment of a Police Cadet Corps in which college students will receive scholarships and training in police work in exchange for a promise to join the Police Department after graduation.

title: NEBRASKAN IS TRYING TO START AN ORDER OF MONKS
description: Deep in the rolling hills near this northeast Nebraska hamlet a priest is starting what he hopes will become a new order of Roman Catholic monks, re-creating the ''life of silence and solitude'' of an abbey long in ruins.

title: Pope Meets General Walters
description: Pope John Paul II met today with Lieut. Gen. Vernon A. Walters, the American representative at the United Nations, the Vatican announced. No details of the private audience, at the Pope's summer palace south of Rome, were made public.

title: Counting Crime vs. Measuring Crime
description: The Brooklyn woman on her way to the bus stop wasn't aware of the four young men. When one suddenly stepped in her path, she saw the flash of a knife, felt the strap of her handbag give way. They threw her to the ground and dashed off.

title: RULES UNDER QUESTION ON JETLINER EVACUATION
description: Amid criticism that Government-required evacuation tests for jetliners often bear little resemblance to the problems faced in a crash, the Federal Aviation Administration is considering an overhaul of its rules.

title: ORDER ENDS AN ERA FOR BOSTON
description: A Federal district judge relinquished control over this city's public schools today, more than a decade after he ordered busing to desegregate the school system.

title: AS SUMMER DIES, THE CITY IS REBORN
description: For Charlotte Glasser, a schoolteacher, it always happens in August, regardless of the temperature or the color of the leaves, that nearly imperceptible moment that signals the coming of fall.

title: Economic Scene;   The Explosion Of Private Debt
description: THE rapid growth of the Federal Government's debt has been the focus of a great deal of public concern in recent years. But much less attention has been paid than is due to the even greater explosion of private debt.

title: Memorial for Taylor Caldwell
description: A memorial mass for the author Taylor Caldwell will be said on Monday at 11 A.M. at St. Patrick's Cathedral, Fifth Avenue and 50th Street. Miss Caldwell died last Friday at the age of 84.

title: Supreme Court Stays Execution in Florida
description: Willie Darden, who has been on Florida's death row since 1974, won a stay of execution late tonight from the United States Supreme Court, seven hours before he was scheduled to die in the electric chair.

title: Burson-Marsteller In a China Venture
description: Almost a year after Hill & Knowlton became the first American public relations firm with an office in China, Burson-Marsteller, the world's largest such company, has announced it is going into business over there with a subsidiary of the New China News Agency.

title: S.M.U. Staff Change
description: Bob Weber, who was replaced by Howard Schnellenberger as head football coach at the University of Louisville after last season, has been tapped to replace P. J. (Bootsie) Larsen as linebacker coach at Southern Methodist. Larsen was dismissed on Sunday for unspecified violations of school policies, and yesterday The Dallas Times Herald said it had learned that Larsen's transgression had been to pay a vacation visit to a summer home belonging to John Appleton, one of nine Mustang boosters who had been declared off limits to S.M.U. staff and players. The ban on contacts with the boosters had been imposed in the wake of the National Collegiate Athletic Association investigation into illegal recruiting practices that led to stiff sanctions against S.M.U. Both Larsen and Appleton declined to comment.

title: TROOPS PATROL IN MISSISSIPPI AFTER STORM
description: National Guard troops remained on patrol today along Mississippi's Gulf Coast, where Hurricane Elena stormed ashore Monday, causing untold millions of dollars of damage and leaving 60,000 people without electricity and hundreds more homeless.

title: Maryland Thrift Unit Loss Listed
description: Depositor losses at Old Court Savings and Loan, which in May experienced runs that touched off a still-unresolved thrift crisis in Maryland, could reach $200 million, but the state's newly formed insurance company should cover the bulk of the losses, representatives for the conservator of the thrift institution said today.

title: CONGRESS, NEARING END OF VACATION, FACES SERIES OF DIVISIVE ISSUES
description: As Congress returns from a summer recess, it faces a series of major issues that will pit the House against the Senate and both houses against President Reagan.

title: A Grand Ol' Surprise?
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp of New York has done nothing to discourage speculation that he will seek the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination from a conservative base, but there are already indications that he is a considerable underdog and may even face strong competition within his own ideological sector of the party.

title: JAPANESE-AMERICANS REMAIN TROUBLED AFTER 40 YEARS
description: For many of the 800,000 Japanese-Americans, the heavy attention in recent weeks to the 40th anniversary of the dropping of the atomic bombs on Japan and the end of World War II has stirred unhappy memories and unsettling thoughts about the present.

title: 21 Invited to Marlboro
description: Mom's Command, the 3-year-old who swept the New York filly triple crown series this year, is expected to take on the nation's top older males in the Marlboro Cup at Belmont Sept. 14. She is one of 21 thoroughbreds, including the top older horses Track Barron and Greinton, who were invited yesterday to run in the mile-and-a-quarter handicap race.

title: Addabbo Undergoes Surgery In Capital for Kidney Ailment
description: Representative Joseph P. Addabbo, Democrat of Queens and the senior member of New York City's Congressional delegation, is recovering from surgery in Walter Reed Hospital here, an aide to the Congressman said tonight.

title: FABRI-CENTERS OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: b-Net income.

title: Murder Suspect Linked By Prints to '84 Killing
description: The suspect in a series of killings that terrorized Los Angeles for months has been linked by fingerprints to the slaying of a 79-year-old woman in 1984, Police Chief Daryl Gates said today.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Oakland A's, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. This is a makeup game of a rainout June 5, the last time the A's were in town.

title: STRIKE IN AUSTIN, MINN., DISRUPTS THE 'GOOD LIFE'
description: Signs of the pleasing time of summer's end and the start of fall are everywhere in this community. Children returned to school Thursday. The water tower is being painted. The fields and trees are already touched with yellow and red. The high school football team is practicing.

title: MUSIC: REAL FIREWORKS FOR 'ROYAL FIREWORKS'
description: TUESDAY evening's free Handel 300th birthday concert at the Damrosch Park Bandshell was a nice idea, and it provided some stirring moments. But the whole enterprise had been frought with troubles from the outset, and was undermined by one major miscalculation.

title: The Presidency;   Mr. Popularity Prepares to Hit the Road
description: ''He didn't get to 65 points with a song and a dance and a nice smile.''

title: SUN ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss including a $75,000 tax credit in the year-ago quarter. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $456,000.

title: TREASURY CALLS FOR NEW FORMULAS ON AID TO STATES
description: The Reagan Administration says Congress should establish new formulas for distributing Federal aid to the states because the current ones are ''seriously flawed'' and do not accurately reflect the states' ability to raise revenue.

title: 2 LOCAL BOARDS CALL FOR A DELAY ON AIDS PUPILS
description: Officials of two community school boards in Queens called yesterday for a ''moratorium'' on efforts to have children with AIDS attend regular schools.

title: Joseph C. Zavatt, 84, Ex-Chief Federal Judge
description: Joseph C. Zavatt, a former chief judge of Federal District Court in Brooklyn, died last Saturday at Winthrop-University Hospital in Mineola, L.I. He was 84 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.

title: Treasury Rates Off Slightly
description: Interest rates declined modestly yesterday for short- and long-term Treasury securities, as demand for government debt was increased by reports that the Farm Credit System is seeking Federal Government assistance.

title: 2 MORE DEATHS LINKED TO SULFITE IN FOOD ARE UNDER SCRUTINY
description: Federal agencies are investigating two more deaths linked to food containing sulfite preservatives, one involving a California woman who ate commercially prepared potatoes and the other a Texas man who drank some white wine. In both cases, death was caused by extreme asthmatic reaction.

title: MAN CONVICTED OF ARSON IS FREED
description: A Federal judge today granted a convicted arsonist's request to be freed from jail, ruling that prosecutors had failed to present exculpatory evidence to the grand jury that indicted him.

title: Boesky Stakes In 2 Companies
description: The New York investor Ivan F. Boesky said today that he had purchased stakes in two companies that have received unsolicited tender offers, the SCM Corporation and the Transway International Corporation.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Great Lakes Shipping
description: A slump in Great Lakes shipping has continued all summer, the Lake Carriers Association said today. July shipments of 13.1 million tons were 30 percent less than a year earlier.

title: JUDGE REQUIRES THAT BONANNO GIVES TESTIMONY
description: A Federal judge from New York ruled here today that Joseph Bonanno must testify about his part in creating a ''commission'' governing organized crime.

title: Conoco-Tenneco Plant Being Built
description: The E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company's Conoco Inc. subsidiary said that it and the Tenneco Oil Company were proceeding with construction of a previously proposed natural gas processing plant at a cost of $60 million.

title: American League;   Indian Homer in 9th Beats Blue Jays, 5-4
description: Light-hitting Otis Nixon slammed a tie-breaking two-run homer in the ninth inning tonight to lead the Cleveland Indians to a 5-4 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays. Toronto's lead in the American League East was reduced to two and a half games over the Yankees.

title: 5 SEIZED IN CLASH INSIDE CAPE TOWN
description: Police officers brandishing whips clashed with demonstrators in the center of Cape Town today.

title: SAFECARD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DOUGLAS AMARON
description: Douglas Amaron, a retired general superintendant of The Canadian Press, died Tuesday in a Toronto hospital, where he had been admitted with a heart ailment. He was 70 years old.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Amana Refrigeration Inc., Amana, Iowa, a subsidiary of Raytheon Co., has named Laura J. Hahn to the new position of assistant general counsel.

title: Deak-Perera: A New Chief
description: R. Leslie Deak resigned yesterday as chief executive officer of Deak-Perera U.S. as part of a previously announced agreement to sell it.

title: Japan Is Exporting Its Unemployment to Us
description: To the Editor:

title: HERS
description: LAST year I was invited to participate on a panel in honor of Women's History Month.

title: Offshore Oil Is Worth the Risk
description: From time to time someone accuses the Interior Department of selling out to special interests; but this time around, the charges are especially intriguing. The ''special interests'' now are environmental groups, and the cries of sellout come from the energy industry, angered by Secretary Donald Hodel's tentative decision to close most of California's offshore waters to oil exploration for the rest of the century.

title: WATER FOR SALE, BUT NEW YORKERS CAN'T BUY IT
description: In the midst of the city's drought, Irving Berkowitz thought he had the perfect product to sell - 210,000 gallons of water a day.

title: 3 DRUG COMPANIES GET LICENSE TO SELL VALIUM EQUIVALENTS
description: The Food and Drug Administration today gave three drug companies approval to market their own versions of the tranquilizer Valium, setting off an immediate scramble to get bargain-priced versions into drugstores.

title: Reagan to Meet With Aides On U.S. South Africa Policy
description: President Reagan will meet with his top foreign policy advisers on Thursday to review the crisis in South Africa and American policy toward the Pretoria Government, a White House official said tonight.

title: GENOVESE DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 16
description: b-Including a gain of $2,445,000 for the quarter and 6 months on the sale of nine stores, less the cost of the closing of one store.

title: PREFERRED SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Reflects a reserve of $746,000 for the quarter and year for a possible loss on a deposit with Financial Institutions Assurance Corp. c-Net income.

title: No Rest for This Envoy
description: Samuel W. Lewis, who was the United States Ambassador to Israel for eight years until last June, has retired from Government service but will be keeping in close touch with Israel.

title: KASPAROV WINS CHESS TITLE OPENER
description: The challenge of Gary Kasparov for the world chess championship got off to a roaring start as he won the first game against the titleholder, Anatoly Karpov, in Moscow's Tchaikovsky Concert Hall yesterday.

title: NATIONAL HARDGOODS DISTRIBUTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
New G.M. Shop
description: Officials at the General Motors Corporation have announced plans to spend $240 million for a new auto painting and finishing shop here. The decision to build the facility next to an existing plant, where Oldsmobiles and Chevrolets are assembled, protects some 4,000 jobs and creates more than 1,000 construction jobs, officials said. The investment and improvements at the Framingham G.M. plant, the only auto factory in New England, are designed to bring G.M.'s painting operations into compliance with Federal air-quality standards.

title: A Gandhi Party Figure Is Slain in New Delhi
description: A prominent local politician and member of the governing Congress Party was shot and killed along with his bodyguard here this morning by three gunmen who escaped on a motor scooter.

title: FARM CREDIT AGENCY MAY REQUEST FEDERAL AID AS BAD LOANS PILE UP
description: The Farm Credit Administration, overseer of the nation's farmer-owned banking system, is considering asking the Reagan Administration for a rescue from a pile-up of bad loans, officials of the agency reported today.

title: MCENROE IS SHARP IN BEATING NYSTROM
description: When John McEnroe is at his best, it really doesn't matter who is standing across the net. On the nights when his serve is accurate and he hits his volleys with a surgeon's touch, then the fans who anticipated a tennis match have to settle for a one-man exhibition instead. On nights like these, the only player who can beat McEnroe is himself.

title: NIXON RETURNS TO CHINA: IT SEEMS LIKE OLD TIMES
description: When Richard M. Nixon visited a Chinese college campus today it was reminiscent of his best moments on the presidential campaign trail, with people mobbing him with requests for autographs or a touch of the hand.

title: Property-Standards Change Affects Fire Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Dull? Someone Say Dull?
description: The summer lull in breathtaking news in the capital seems to have impelled a New Jersey publicist to seek attention for himself by announcing that he will be the Boring Party candidate for President in 1988. He has handouts and bumper stickers and he contends that the voters quickly forget the names of candidates who bore them.

title: Transactions
description: COLLEGES IDAHO - Named Dave Nielsen head track coach.

title: VORNADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
U.S. Oil Reserves Up In First Gain Since '70
description: The United States last year increased its oil reserves for the first time since the Arab oil embargo more than a decade ago, the Government said today.

title: Australian Yacht Wins
description: Victoria 150, the Australian challenger for the International Catamaran trophy, soundly defeated Patient Lady VI, the American defender, by 3 minutes 47 seconds today to take a 1-0 lead in the four-of-seven series, also called the Little America's Cup. The Australian yacht, skippered by Chris Cairns, won in a shifty southwesterly breeze of 6 to 16 knots on Long Island Sound off Roton Point. The ships are C-class catamarans, light, twin-hull craft with complex solid sails called wings.

title: Changes in Boston
description: The Boston Marathon will have an official sponsor, will pay competitors for the first time in its 89-year history and will have a new finish line.

title: United Energy To Take a Charge
description: United Energy Resources Inc. said it would take a charge of $131.6 million against third-quarter results to provide for the disposition of litigation now pending against its largest subsidiary, the United Gas Pipeline Company. United Energy said that the charge would cause it to report a substantial full-year loss.

title: China Says Wages Rise
description: Average wages for China's 121 million urban workers will rise 19 percent this year to the equivalent of $394 a year, from $331, the Government said today.

title: FRAUNCES TAVERN NEEDS COLLECTIBLES
description: Eighteenth-century objects including medicine spoons, nursing bottles, tortoise shell tweezers and forceps used for removing bullets are just a few of the items being sought by the Fraunces Tavern Museum for its Touch Collection. This is a program designed by the museum's education department that, by allowing children and adults to handle historic objects, helps them understand and identify with the exhibitions.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: COMEDY IN THE PARK ''The Ritual Project,'' a new music-theater work by the playwright Nancy Beckett and the composer Kim Sherman, will be presented in Central Park this evening at 7 o'clock, with the performance taking place on a triangular plot less than 200 feet northwest of the Delacorte Theater. The 33-minute performance includes eight actors and the composer, and is free to the public.

title: Ex-E.P.A. Aide Ends Federal Perjury Term
description: Rita Lavelle, former head of the Environmental Protection Agency's toxic waste clean-up fund, was released from Federal prison today after serving most of a six-month sentence for perjury before Congress.

title: Lear Stock Falls
description: Wall Street analysts slashed fiscal 1986 earnings forecasts for Lear Siegler Inc. after the company warned that the analysts' estimates were ''substantially overstated.''

title: Leading Edge
description: Looking for every edge Tuesday night en route to a 6-4 victory over Cincinnati, Manager Whitey Herzog of the front-running St. Louis Cardinals used five pitchers in the seventh inning. That ties a National League record for most hurlers by one team in an inning - a mark previously reached more than a score of times -and is one short of the major league record, set on Sept. 3, 1983, when Steve Boros pulled out all the stops for Oakland in the ninth inning of a game against the Indians.

title: Hodel Seeks Oil Pact Change
description: Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel said today that he would try to persuade Congress to revise an agreement with California on offshore oil leasing that appeared to contain ''the wrong 150 tracts.''

title: NU-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Indiana Toll Unit's $256 Million Sale
description: The Indiana Toll Finance Authority is offering $256 million of refunding revenue bonds with a maximum yield tentatively set at 9.55 percent for 9 percent bonds due in 2014 through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: Embassy Row;   An Old American Hand
description: Ambassador Han Xu still recalls those days of his youth when, as a guerrilla fighter, he belonged to an army unit that rescued American flyers downed by Japanese while on air raids over the mountains of north central China.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: A Close Look At the Airlines
description: LAST Friday afternoon, just as investors and their brokers were savoring prospects of the long Labor Day weekend, Merrill Lynch sharply downgraded its opinion on airline stocks -a group that showed price gains averaging nearly 35 percent in the first half of 1985.

title: U.S., JAPAN AND PANAMA PLAN STUDY OF CANAL
description: The United States, Japan and Panama have agreed to study the feasibility of widening the Panama Canal or perhaps replacing it with a new sea-level waterway to connect the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.

title: New Analysis Method Pinpoints Heart Illness
description: A new, computerized method of analyzing the results of treadmill exercise tests can accurately pinpoint heart disease in people who are suffering no symptoms, a medical study shows.

title: DELTAUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $214,000 for the quarter and $401,000 for the 6 months and a provision of $8,823,000 for the quarter and 6 months for loss on the disposal of net assets to be sold. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,102,000 for the quarter and $2,044,000 for the 6 months.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If the United States holds tests of anti-satellite weapons against a target in outer space, the Soviet Union will consider itself free of its unilateral commitment not to place anti-satellite systems in space.

title: The Real Latin Threat
description: THE United States should be concentrating its attention on the Latin American debt crisis, not on the arming of contras against Nicaragua. The price riots in the Dominican Republic, the invasion of supermarkets in Rio de Janeiro, and the waves of strikes everywhere in Latin America pose a far greater threat to United States security than do the politics of three million Nicaraguans.

title: Not Retiring
description: Mary Lou Retton has said that she expects to compete in the 1988 Olympics, but since winning her third straight American Cup title last winter, the 17-year-old gymnast has been concentrating more on commercial than Olympic gold.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 5, 1985
description: The Economy

title: WESTERN HEALTH PLANS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Blast at Arms Depot Kills 9 Near Havana
description: Nine workers died today in an explosion, apparently caused by a fire, at an arms storage installation about 15 miles outside Havana, civil defense officials said.

title: JOHN H. McDOWELL
description: John Herbert McDowell, who composed more than 150 works for ballet, film, television and theatrical productions, died Tuesday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 58 years old.

title: GRAF STUNS SHRIVER IN OPEN
description: When Pam Shriver was upset last year in the quarterfinals of the United States Open by 32-year-old Wendy Turnbull of Australia, she was not a gracious loser. She said her defeat was ''bad for women's tennis,'' insinuating that her conqueror was not able to give Martina Navratilova, whom Miss Turnbull met in the next round, as much competition as she would have.

title: TRC COS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: AOUITA DEFEATS MAREE IN ITALY
description: Said Aouita of Morocco, who has broken the world records for the 1,500 and 5,000 meters in the last six weeks, won another race tonight, but he may have lost the war. In the annual track meet in this industrial town 50 miles northwest of Rome, Aouita won an exciting 2,000-meter race in 4 minutes 54.02 seconds.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Hitachi Will Cut Capital Spending
description: Hitachi Ltd. will cut its capital spending in its semiconductor sector for the year ending March 31, 1986, to about $262 million, from the earlier planned $375 million. The company will also cut group capital spending to about $379 million, from an estimated $433 million, a company spokesman said.

title: FCP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $3,000 for the quarter from the reversal of a tax credit and a tax credit of $104,000 for the 9 months.

title: SKY EXPRESS INC reports earnings for Year to May 31
WRITER SUES TO MAKE 'AMOS 'N' ANDY' A MUSICAL
description: Few Americans have heard anything from Amos and Andy, Sapphire and the Kingfish since they left the airwaves nearly 20 years ago. But ''Amos 'n' Andy,'' the most popular and durable program in the history of broadcasting, is once again the subject of bitter controversy - this time in a New York courtroom.

title: U.S. AIDE'S TIES TO CONTRAS CHALLENGED
description: The chairman of the House intelligence committee said today that the involvement of a ranking member of the National Security Council with the rebels fighting to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government may have violated the law.

title: Birthdays
description: Balloons flew, horns blew and water spouts spewed as two of New York's more venerable institutions, the United Nations and the Circle Line, wished each other a mutual happy 40th birthday.

title: DARK DAYS FOR FAIRCHILD UNIT
description: The military contracting business is typically boom or bust, and of late, it has mostly been boom. But the Defense Department's new efforts to rein in spending a bit may be puncturing the boom for some companies.

title: HEAVY SMOKING FOUND TO CURB CANCER OF THE UTERUS LINING
description: Heavy cigarette smoking by women reduces their risk of developing cancer of the lining of the uterus, the endometrium, but this benefit is vastly outweighed by other health hazards of smoking, according to a new report.

title: Scalped
description: It may be that on Capitol Hill no man, or woman, is a hero to his or her hairdresser.

title: PONDEROSA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 15
DAVID ROCKEFELLER DONATION TO LIBRARY HONORS BROOKE ASTOR
description: ''I think it's the nicest thing that ever happened to me,'' Brooke Astor said yesterday. She was referring to the announcement that David Rockefeller had given $2.5 million to the New York Public Library in her honor.

title: How Voltaire Made a Killing in the Lottery
description: To the Editor:

title: GRACE R. CONANT
description: Grace Richards Conant, the widow of James Bryant Conant, president of Harvard University from 1933 until 1953, died Saturday in Newtown, Pa., after a stroke. She was 87 years old. Dr. Conant died in 1978. Surviving are a son, Theodore R. Conant of New York, and five grandchildren.

title: Grateful Dead Are Off-Limits
description: A judge ruled Tuesday that a teen-ager who took LSD at a Grateful Dead concert could not go to any more of his favorite group's concerts for five years. State District Judge Woody Densen sentenced the defendant, Sean Foley, 17 years old, to five years' probation and fined him $500. The youth, from McLean, Va., said he had planned to follow the group around the country for two years after his high school graduation next year.

title: General Dynamics
description: The General Dynamics Corporation has received two Navy contracts totaling $460.8 million, the Navy said. The company's Pomona, Calif., division received both contracts, one of them for $248.1 million for guidance control work on the Navy's SM-2 antiaircraft missile. The other, $212.7 million contract is for work on the MK-16 rapid-fire antiaircraft gun.

title: Jurors Are Selected For Baseball Trial
description: After two days of trying, the prosecution and the defense selected a jury today for the trial of Curtis Strong, a Philadephia man accused of selling cocaine to baseball players.

title: FARRELL IS BUOYED BY A CAMPAIGN STOP IN HARLEM
description: Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., the least known of the three major candidates for the Democratic mayoral nomination, basked in constituent recognition at the Polo Grounds subway station in Harlem yesterday morning as he shook hands and asked for votes in his home district.

title: National League;   Cards Down Reds With 2 in 9th, 4-3
description: The St. Louis Cardinals rallied for two runs in the ninth inning tonight on a double by Andy Van Slyke, a two-base error by the shortstop Dave Concepcion and a game-winning single by Mike Jorgensen to beat the Cincinnati Reds, 4-3.

title: WORLD AIRWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago figures were restated.

title: Mr. Murdoch, American
description: Along with 185 other aliens, he raised his right hand and recited the oath of allegiance in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday. Moments later, they and Rupert Murdoch were citizens of the United States of America.

title: RYKOFF-SEXTON INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
Insurance Costs to Decline
description: Health insurance premiums paid by most Federal employees will decline about 6 percent next year, the director of the Office of Personnel Management, Constance Horner, said Tuesday.

title: NEW PROGRAMS AID LATCHKEY CHILDREN
description: WHEN 9-year-old Jay Wilson comes home from school in Riverdale, Md., at 3 P.M. he is alone until 5:30, when his mother returns from her job as a legal secretary. The first thing he does is to call the Care Line, a telephone hot line and check-in service sponsored by the Mental Health Association of Prince Georges County. It is one of the many new services now being offered by nonprofit organizations to children whose parents are not at home when they return from school.

title: YANKS GAIN SWEEP AND TRAIL BY 2 1/2 87 >
description: The Yankees moved closer last night to the Toronto Blue Jays than they have been all season as they completed a three-game sweep of the Seattle Mariners at the Stadium.

title: CARBIDE RULES OUT 'GREENMAIL'
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, the subject of hostile takeover rumors, yesterday ruled out any form of ''greenmail,'' including attempts by a large stockholder to exchange shares for one or more of Carbide's best businesses.

title: BELLAMY ISSUES PROPOSAL ON HEALTH
description: Emphasizing that preventive health services would be one of the top priorities of her administration if she becomes mayor, City Council President Carol Bellamy outlined her views yesterday on human services and health programs.

title: Notes by Safeco
description: The Safeco Corporation is offering $200 million of 10 3/4 percent notes due in 1995 at a price of 99.60 to yield 10.861 percent through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The notes, rated A-2 by Moody's and AA by S.&P., will be used to buy nearly 3.5 million shares of its stock from the Lincoln National Life Insurance Company.

title: Grandmet Deal
description: Grandmet USA Inc., a unit British Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., said that it had received about four million shares, or about 34.5 percent, of Pearle Health Services Inc. in response to its $33-a-share tender offer. buy G.D. Searle & Company's 40 percent stake in Pearle, said that its offer had expired Tuesday, and it has started buying Pearle shares.

title: SCIENTIFIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
14 ON A JURY PANEL QUIT CASE OF A DEFENDANT WITH AIDS
description: A murder suspect diagnosed as having AIDS was escorted into Superior Court today by sheriff's deputies wearing rubber gloves. Fourteen prospective jurors promptly asked to be dismissed from the case.

title: CONGRESS CHIEFS WARN OF ACTION TO CURB TRADE
description: Congressional leaders from both parties warned today that rising public alarm over jobs lost to imports could cause Congress to defy President Reagan's veto threat and adopt restrictive trade legislation this fall.

title: Baseball;   Dodgers the Difference in the West
description: Report from California:

title: Seahawks Drop Gill
description: Owen Gill, the rookie running back from Tilden High School in Brooklyn who starred at Iowa, was waived yesterday by the Seattle Seahawks. ''We would have been overstocked at running back,'' Coach Chuck Knox said of the decision. ''I'm sure he'll play for someone in the N.F.L.'' The Seahawks drafted Gill in the second round. . . . The Houston Oilers placed Oliver Luck, backup quarterback, on injured reserve and re-signed Brian Ransom to replace Luck, who suffered a broken bone in his lower left leg in the 20-10 loss to the Dallas Cowboys last Saturday. . . . The Los Angeles Rams said they are willing to take out a $1 million disability policy for the running back Eric Dickerson, who has been boycotting camp to try to get guarantees against a possible career-ending injury.

title: Across the River
description: The Wayfarer III, which until Labor Day transported weekenders to Fire Island, backed out of her slip yesterday at the Fulton Ferry Landing Pier in Brooklyn and slowly nosed her bow toward the East River's rushing tide.

title: JUDGE ORDERS HALT TO WORK ON CARTER LIBRARY ROAD
description: In what could be a crippling blow to Atlanta's Presidential Parkway, a Superior Court judge today ordered a halt to all parkway construction. He ruled that the city could not hand over parkland that lay in the path of the road leading to the Jimmy Carter Presidential Library.

title: COUNCIL PRESIDENT CANDIDATES DEBATE TRANSIT AND LAW-ENFORCEMENT ISSUES
description: Following are excerpts from a debate held yesterday by the major candidates in next Tuesday's Democratic primary for City Council President: Assemblyman Angelo DelToro,Joseph R. Erazo, Kenneth Lipper, State Senator Israel Ruiz Jr. and Borough President Andrew J. Stein:

title: CHINA HAILS CAMBODIA REPORT
description: China today officially welcomed the announced resignation of Pol Pot, the head of the Communist Cambodian rebel group known as the Khmer Rouge.

title: Marvin Warner To Testify
description: Lawyers for the Cincinnati financier Marvin Warner, former owner of the Home State Savings Bank, said today that Mr. Warner planned to testify before the special grand jury investigating the fall of the Cincinnati thrift unit.

title: Orders Up in Germany
description: The West German economy is growing briskly, despite nagging unemployment, the Government said today. Orders to the nation's factories rose 4.5 percent in July from June. The unemployment rate dipped to 8.9 percent in August from 9 percent in July.

title: U.S.-PRETORIA BANK TALKS: POLITICS HELD AVOIDED
description: The governor of South Africa's central bank said yesterday that American banks had not pressed for political changes by Pretoria in talks over the last week but had focused on technical issues.

title: 30 Wounded in Ulster As I.R.A. Attacks Police
description: Guerrillas fired 18 mortar rounds across a river into a police station and training center today, wounding 30 people, none of them seriously.

title: SCIENTISTS PLANS TO STUDY TITANIC BY SUBMARINE
description: The chief scientist of the team that found the steamship Titanic says he plans to return to the site, possibly next summer, to inspect the wreckage close up in a small submarine, according to a telephone conversation made public today.

title: THE NEW SUMMITRY
description: In the new summitry, the media are the sherpas. Having foolishly begged for a get-acquainted meeting with the new Soviet leader, Mr. Reagan has been rocked back on his heels by the Gorbachevian response: a beautifully orchestrated barrage of publicity aimed at raising hopes for a dramatic American concession.

title: ALL ARE RESCUED
description: A fire that started in an air compressor yesterday evening cut off power to a water tunnel under construction in upper Manhattan, trapping scores of workers for almost two hours in the darkened complex hundreds of feet below the streets.

title: ROYAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Royal Bank of Canada is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: SYSTEMS ASSURANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Tandon Wins Trade Round
description: The Tandon Corporation, one of the largest domestic producers of floppy disk drives, said today that the International Trade Commission had approved a temporary exclusion order against double-sided floppy disk drives imported by the Mitsubishi Electric Company and its domestic subsidiary.

title: EPIC UNIT TOLD TO OPEN ITS BOOKS TO TWO BANKS
description: A Federal District judge today ordered EPIC Mortgage Inc., the troubled mortgage-banking company based in Falls Church, Va., to give a full accounting of its finances and to set aside in escrow any mortgage payments it receives until further determination by the court.

title: PRODUCER AND LEAGUE MEND A RIFT
description: Emanuel Azenberg, the most successful independent producer on Broadway in recent seasons, rejoined the League of American Theaters and Producers yesterday, ending his two-year rift with the organization.

title: Tunisia Calls All Workers Home From Libya
description: Tunisia is calling all its emigrant workers home from Libya and cutting off all trade relations with Tripoli, Prime Minister Mohammed Mzali announced today.

title: JO JONES, 73, A JAZZ DRUMMER INFLUENTIAL IN SWING ERA, DIES
description: Jo Jones, a jazz drummer who was a major innovator in the swing era, died of pneumonia Tuesday at New York Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about the Vancouver Stock Exchange in Business Day on Monday misstated the status of a $15.5 million lawsuit against the exchange and others. The suit was settled out of court earlier this summer, with the exchange paying $275,000 as its part of the settlement.

title: Gibson to Deny Klan Permit To Demonstrate in Newark
description: An application to hold a Ku Klux Klan rally in front of City Hall will be denied, a spokesman for Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson said today.

title: 'INDAY,' NEW STEP IN TV SYNDICATION
description: ''This,'' said Henry Siegel, pointing to a laminated plastic loose-leaf book, ''is the closest to a fourth network anyone has come.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 5, 1985
description: International

title: ENI Lira Role Cited by Italy
description: Italy's Treasury Minister, Giovanni Goria, raised the possibility today that the lira's sudden collapse last July might have been the result of deliberate currency speculation by the state oil company, Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi, which is more familiarly known by its initials, ENI.

title: WILLFUL SHORTSIGHTEDNESS ON POVERTY
description: THE White House euphoria over the drop in the poverty rate to 14.4 percent in 1984 is deeply disturbing. In celebrating a statistical ''triumph,'' President Reagan and his staff have obscured a larger injustice.

title: A MACHINE-TOOL DYNASTY
description: In this small rural town in central Japan lies the plant of one of the largest machine-tool manufacturers in the world, Okuma Machinery Works Ltd. The company started up 87 years ago when its founder invented a simple lathe, and its rise tells a great deal about how Japan grew to dominate this industry.

title: HOW TO ESTIMATE SHELVING NEEDS AND SOURCES FOR MODULAR UNITS
description: FOR most book lovers, the ideal is to have a library that is an integral part of a room's decoration, one that is neatly organized so that quick retrieval is possible.

title: MICROS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: Stores Acting to Curb Illegal Sales of Alcohol
description: The National Association of Convenience Stores today announced a new program designed to prevent the illegal sale of alcohol to minors and people who are intoxicated.

title: OLD-STYLE MAILBOXES AND PERIOD LETTER SLOT
description: AN old-fashioned mailbox or letter slot can add character to a period home. Urban Archaeology carries about 30 different varieties. Some are old but have never been used; others have been salvaged from demolished buildings.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of change in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

title: SHIITES AND PALESTINIANS BATTLE IN BEIRUT
description: Heavy fighting broke out today for a second consecutive day between Shiite Moslem militiamen and Palestinian guerrillas in and around the largest Palestinian quarter here. The police said 10 people had been killed and 20 wounded.

title: LONG SHOTS BRING LONG FACES
description: Nobody picked six at Belmont Park yesterday, not surprising considering the parade of long shots that ended up in the winner's circle, but that was little consolation to the four partners from Bayside, Queens.

title: 'LOVE IT OR LEAVE IT'
description: Many tennis players have come to regard it as a House of Horrors like those found in amusement parks where ghoulish figures pop up out of the dark and the air is filled with bloodcurdling screams. That is an exaggeration, perhaps, but the National Tennis Center is in New York and remember, some people don't think the city is even a nice place to visit.

title: United's Share Of Denver Airport
description: United Airlines, a unit of UAL Inc., said it expected to spend up to $350 million to help Denver build a new airport north of the current Stapleton International Airport. Airlines have put a cost cap of $1.1 billion on their share of costs, and United's split, based on its current use rate at Stapleton, would be about $350 million, a spokesman said.

title: FOTOMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 4
Broken Up
description: When North Carolina State opens its season at home against East Carolina Saturday night, its two wide receivers will have casts on their hands, thanks to the quarterback, Eric Kramer. Nasrallah Worthen and Danny Peebles suffered broken hands on passes from Kramer during the last two weeks of practice.

title: New Promotional Tools Aimed at Health Care
description: To the uninitiated, the health care industry might appear to be too solemn for frivolous promotion gimmicks. Never.

title: JAPANESE HELD IN HAWAII IN CRIME CRACKDOWN
description: Drug-enforcement officers here and in Hong Kong have arrested eight men described as major Japanese crime figures and seized a large amount of heroin and other drugs, Federal officials announced Tuesday.

title: HELPING RECOGNIZE FORGOTTEN TRIBES
description: Frank W. Porter 3d travels across the country from Indian group to Indian group, helping lay claims to full rights for previously unrecognized tribes.

title: NOW IS THE TIME TO PLAN FOR NEXT SPRING
description: THE air is about to cool, making it pleasant to work outside, a time to plant for spring. Just about everything can go into the ground. Pay special attention to azaleas, rhododendrons, yews, junipers, pines and other evergreens.

title: People
description: Robert Starr has joined Backer & Spielvogel as a senior vice presient, associate creative director.

title: President Leaves Post At Warner Cosmetics
description: George Friedman, a co-founder of Warner Cosmetics, which makes Gloria Vanderbilt, Chaps and Polo fragrances, has resigned as president of the company and as executive vice president of Cosmair Inc., which bought Warner last year.

title: 'PARANOIA' OVER HERPES SEEMS TO SUBSIDE
description: As public concern has shifted to the serious consequences of AIDS, doctors, public-health officials, psychologists and others say the exaggerated fear of herpes - once described as the ''leprosy of the 80's'' - has eased.

title: PRESIDENT IS URGED TO SUPPORT WAIVER OF OVERTIME PAY RULE
description: One of President Reagan's Cabinet Councils recommended today that he endorse legislation reversing a Supreme Court decision that required state and local governments to pay public employees overtime wages, according to sources in the Senate and organized labor.

title: 'ONE MAN'S WAR' RECALLS THE OCCUPATIONAL YEARS
description: ''ONE MAN'S WAR'' is not a documentary; its director says it is ''a documentary fiction.'' Actually, it defies nomenclature, and it is as much history lesson as anything else. Any characterization, however, is inconsequential. ''One Man's War,'' on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight, is riveting. It resonates, and the resonance lingers.

title: Steiger Tractor Lures Ex-Harvester Official
description: Steiger Tractor Inc. yesterday named Irvin E. Aal, a former head of the International Harvester Company's agricultural equipment group, as president and chief executive of the company, which has been hurt by the weak market for farm machinery.

title: Steel Import Relief Seen
description: While problems remain with the Reagan Administration's program to curtail foreign steel shipments, new figures show the plan is on the way toward giving the United States industry adequate relief from imports, trade officials said today.

title: CARTER WALLOPS 2 MORE AS METS TROUNCE PADRES
description: One night after he hit three home runs in a game, Gary Carter hit two more tonight and muscled his way into several lines in the baseball records as the Mets completed a three-game sweep over the San Diego Padres.

title: MANDELA: MAN, LEGEND AND SYMBOL OF RESISTANCE
description: Percy Qoboza remembers the days fondly. One of them goes like this: In the early 1960's the man was on the run from the police, and Mr. Qoboza, a young black reporter, was following the story.

title: In Appalachia, the Quality of Life Has Improved
description: To the Editor:

title: Simmons Options To Buy Aircraft
description: Simmons Airlines Inc. has taken options on four French-Italian Avions de Transport Regional-42 planes and six ATR-72 short- and medium-range passenger planes, a spokesman for the manufacturers said.

title: Bridge: Epson Tournament in Tokyo Drew a Cosmopolitan Field
description: The world's most cosmopolitan tournament, as distinct from international occasions, was played last week in Tokyo. It was the third annual Inter-City contest sponsored by the Epson Computer Corporation, and the field of 32 teams included entries from Budapest, Sydney, Melbourne, New York and Panama.

title: BRIEFS
description: BMW of North America Inc., Montvale, N.J., said it was increasing the prices for its 500-series-model cars by $415.

title: VENICE FESTIVAL PROTESTS YIELD TO MICKEY MOUSE
description: Film festivals, in a haphazard sort of way, often offer useful signs of the times: hints of how societies look at themselves, of where the political winds are blowing, of what problems are obsessing people.

title: IMMUNEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Market Off Again; Dow Drops 2.47
description: Stock prices moved lower for the third consecutive session yesterday with trading volume remaining in a rut below the 100-million-share level.

title: Automated I.D. Trade Gets New Bimonthly
description: After Douglas C. Edgell, 33, and his wife, Gabriele, had learned a thing or two about magazines - the two had spent time at Ziff-Davis, where they met, and he had also worked at Conde Nast - they decided to join the world of the business press. For Mr. Edgell, this was familiar territory since he is the son of Robert L. Edgell, vice chairman of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich and president of the American Business Press, the major trade organization.

title: Improvement Seen In A.M.C.'s 2d Half
description: The American Motors Corporation, which lost $99 million in the first half of the year, will break even in the second half, its president, Jose Dedeurwaerder, said today.

title: McNab Seeking Carpenter Again
description: Max McNab describes Bobby Carpenter as a hard-core Washington Capital - the team's ''tattoo is on his rear end,'' the Devils' general manager says - and so he has serious doubts that any other club will be able to lure Carpenter away. But this has not necessarily dulled McNab's interest in signing the 22-year-old center, for what would be the second time.

title: Gross Out
description: Greg Gross, the Philadelphia Phillies' outfielder, will miss the rest of the season because of a broken little finger on his left hand. . . . Phil Regan, the Seattle Mariners' pitching coach, appealed his two-game suspension to Bobby Brown, the league president who imposed the penalty last month after a bench-clearing incident in Seattle on Aug. 12. Regan became enraged when Rod Carew of the Angels was not ejected for charging the pitcher Ed Vande Berg, who had thrown close to Carew.

title: AIR FORCE PLANS TO PROCEED WITH ANTI-SATELLITE TEST
description: The Air Force announced today that it planned to go ahead with its test of a new anti-satellite weapon this month, despite the Soviet Union's threat to follow suit.

title: 5 Plead in Mortgage Inquiry
description: The former chief of the state's housing mortgage finance agency, a former speaker of Rhode Island House and three others pleaded not guilty today to felony charges stemming from a sweeping investigation of the scandal-ridden agency. It provides low-interest mortgages to low- and middle-income Rhode Islanders.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in July.

title: HEART RECIPIENT STEPS UP THERAPY
description: Michael Drummond, the latest artificial heart patient, ate three meals today and stepped up his exercise and physical therapy in preparation for receiving a human heart, hospital officials said.

title: ONE INGENIOUS SOLUTION
description: SOMETIMES books are only a part of an even larger storage problem. Especially for those who live and work in the same place. Beyond bookshelves, the solution often requires built-in desks, cabinets and partitions.

title: BENIHANA NATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to July 21
HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: SOME new tools, lighting appliances and other products that should be of interest have been introduced recently.

title: For the City Council
description: Two candidates for president of the New York City Council are spending millions on the crudest, least enlightening citywide campaign in memory. Meanwhile, three unknown candidates have been unable to make themselves heard above the hubbub. Voters can, and probably should, ignore the overheated campaign and judge the candidates on past performance.

title: 'Shoah' Premiere Set
description: ''Shoah,'' the epic film about the Holocaust by the French journalist and film maker Claude Lanzmann, will have its American premiere on Oct. 23 at the Cinema Studio, Broadway and 66th Street.

title: Role Players
description: It is separated from New York by an entire continent, to say nothing of an entire N.B.A. championship. But for today, at least, the Forum in Los Angeles is being asked to play the role of Madison Square Garden.

title: Management Shifts Set at First Jersey
description: First Jersey Securities, the ambitious independent broker-dealer, announced a number of management changes yesterday that it said would help further the firm's expansion.

title: Technology;   IMPROVING ARTIFICIAL TURF
description: WITH the National Football League season beginning on Sunday, team owners, trainers and fans will again prize player health as critical for success. And whether players avoid injury depends in part on artificial turf, which has undergone many technological improvements to make it safer.

title: Shearson Lehman Sets New Floating-Rate Note
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers yesterday introduced a new kind of floating-rate note, which it expects to underwrite soon for the American Express Credit Corporation. The American Express unit filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exhange Commission for up to $200 million of the notes.

title: SOVIET LIFTS BAN ON 1 U.S. DELEGATE
description: The Soviet Union, reversing an earlier decision, granted a visa yesterday to Bernard Levinson, president of the Association of Jewish Book Publishers, to attend the Fifth Moscow International Book Fair, which begins Tuesday.

title: Bank Yields Unchanged
description: Rates on certificates of deposit, money market deposit accounts and money market mutual funds were largely unchanged in the week ended yesterday.

title: Many Chiefs See Softness
description: UNLIKE many of his peers, Robert E. Jacoby, president of Ted Bates Worldwide, is extremely optimistic about the outcome of 1985.

title: WORKERS AT L.I. PLANT STILL HOPEFUL
description: Employees of the Fairchild Republic Company are taking in stride news that the Pentagon has proposed the cancellation of the $3.5 billion T-46A program, according to several workers interviewed during their lunch break at the company's plant here today.

title: GLAMIS GOLD LTD reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars. Year-ago results are for the 11 months ended June 30, 1984.Revenue figures represent revenues from gold production.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: POOLS AS A HAVEN
description: It will never be known with certainty how many thousands, even millions, of people were forced to flee in the four days that Hurricane Elena stalked the Gulf Coast before it pushed ashore Monday in Mississippi.

title: SOVIET MAY DEPLOY SATELLITE WEAPON IF U.S. HOLDS TEST
description: The Soviet Union served notice today that if the United States went ahead with a planned test of an anti-satellite weapon, Moscow would no longer consider itself bound by its two-year-old commitment not to deploy such weapons.

title: SEXISM IN OPERA, DON'T BLAME CRITIC
description: TO some recent comments on a singer's work, a reader has raised an objection that ought to be answered, since it touches on a controversial area for anyone who writes about drama (operatic, in this case). I had heard the exciting young soprano Aprile Millo in an aria from ''Andrea Chenier,'' and wrote that her voice and style were ''fiery, metallic, yet still vulnerably feminine.''

title: BACKSTAGE AT A HOUSE IN THE MAKING
description: ''WHEN the details get finer and finer and aren't designed,'' says Jim Locke, a carpenter and builder in Apple Valley, Mass., ''that's where the people who build a home make the decisions.'' When the story of a house is told, he says, the people who laid the joists properly so the floor wouldn't squeak are usually overlooked.

title: Wells, Rich Greene Gets Enquirer Account
description: Wells, Rich, Greene has become agency for The National Enquirer, the weekly tabloid that is especially visible at supermarket checkouts.

title: France Tells Greenpeace Not to Dictate Policy
description: Prime Minister Laurent Fabius warned tonight that France would not allow the environmental group Greenpeace to ''dictate a defense policy to France.''

title: 2 ROBBERS HUNTED IN MIDWEST
description: The Federal authorities searched Wisconsin and Illinois today for two fugitives accused of abducting a bank vice president and his family at gunpoint and using them virtually to clean out his suburban bank.

title: 21 ARE INJURED BY LEAKING GAS AT ATOMIC SITE
description: Twenty-one workers at a nuclear plant being built in Salem County were felled today by an accidental release of carbon dioxide from an automatic fire-suppressant system, officials said.

title: AT HOME IN TOWER OF LONDON: COZY, DESPITE THE STONE DUST
description: THE Tower of London, the ancient fortress on the Thames that consists of not one but 20 towers, is home to 54 families who live in a close-knit community within the confines of the moat, today covered with grass. The families of the 39 yeoman warders, popularly called beefeaters, and of the support staff are housed either in 13th-century casemates, brick barracks built to serve both as living quarters and fortifications, or in the towers.

title: Letter: On Superfund;   How to Get On With the Cleanup Job
description: To the Editor:

title: THOUSANDS JOIN IN PROTESTS IN CHILE'S CAPITAL
description: Thousands of Chileans joined the biggest day of anti-Government protests here in nearly a year today.

title: JAZZ: HENDRICKS AND ROSS
description: FOR jazz nostalgists, the reunion of Jon Hendricks and Annie Ross, the surviving members of the seminal jazz vocal trio Lambert, Hendricks and Ross, at the Blue Note (131 West Third Street) on Tuesday for a six-night stand was an occasion for misty-eyed remembrance. But for those hoping that after 23 years apart, Mr. Hendricks and Miss Ross might recapture the vocal chemistry they enjoyed in the late 1950's, their opening set came as a painful disappointment.

title: Revenue Bonds Offered by Texas
description: The Texas Building Authority is offering $143.9 million of revenue bonds tentatively priced with a maximum yield of 9 3/8 percent for bonds due in 2012 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: CRAM COURSE: LIVING WITH TOO MANY BOOKS
description: It is a fact that people who collect books tend to have them in quantity. In some cases, astounding quanities. Dr. Barbara Kirshenblatt-Gimblett, for example, has amassed some 11,500 books in the living, dining and bedroom areas of her 4,500-square-foot loft on the Bowery. An anthropologist and the chairman of the department of performance studies at New York University's Tisch School of the Arts, she and her husband, Max Gimblett, an artist, live amid crammed floor-to-ceiling shelves that occupy 78 linear feet of wall space; the look is closely akin to the basement of the Strand Book Store.

title: A New Prime Minister Is Appointed in Egypt
description: The Government of Prime Minister Kamal Hassan Ali resigned today, and President Hosni Mubarak named a leading economist to form a new one, indicating he wants action on economic problems.

title: More Oil Goal Of Gorbachev
description: Mikail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, called today for more oil production during a visit to western Siberia.

title: A BED FOR WORKING
description: DESIGNED by Ubald Klug, the WOGG 3 bed is for those who like to work in bed. The bed has an adjustable headboard and swingaway pivoting tables that can hold a television set, word processor or telephone. Available through designers at Cumberland, a division of I. M. Rosen & Company, 40 East 49th Street, the bed shown here is $6,880, list price.

title: HONDURAS REPORTED TO RAID REFUGEES
description: Eighty Honduran Army soldiers entered a United Nations camp for Salvadoran refugees here last week and killed two refugees, wounded 13 and beat 25 others with rifle butts and kicks, according to international relief officials from four relief organizations that work in the camp.

title: NASSAU G.O.P. MADE EMPLOYEES DONATE MONEY, JURY FINDS
description: A Federal jury found today that from 1973 to 1976 the Nassau County Republican Committee required government workers to contribute 1 percent of their salaries to the party to get promotions and wage increases.

title: BACTERIUM TESTED ON GYPSY MOTHS
description: A biological agent used against a major gypsy moth infestation here is being hailed as an unexpected success by scientists and state agriculture officials, on the basis of preliminary results.

title: TEACHERS' STRIKE IN CHICAGO ENDED
description: With the mediation efforts of Gov. James R. Thompson, Chicago teachers and school board officials reached agreement this afternoon to end a strike that had closed the nation's third-largest school system for the third September in a row.

title: AIDING A NEIGHBOR, BOY IS KILLED IN FALL DOWN AN AIR SHAFT
description: A 12-year-old boy who was helping a neighbor who had been locked out of her East Village apartment plunged to his death as he was being lowered by a clothesline from the roof, the police said yesterday.

title: Concern Over Pryor
description: He's an undefeated boxing champion who hasn't fought in six months and that has prompted concern among his friends that Aaron Pryor has a drug problem he can't shake. According to The Miami Herald, Bob Arum, the promoter, said Pryor needs ''a radical transformation of his life style,'' and Ferdie Pacheco, the fight doctor, has urged him to seek treatment. But Pryor, undefeated in 36 bouts and the International Boxing Federation junior welterweight champ, while acknowledging he has used cocaine, denied he was hooked and told the paper he had ''ignored'' Pacheco's advice.

title: Gastineau to Miss Jet Opener
description: The irrepressible Mark Gastineau, who had been nursing a broken thumb with three pins holding it in place, has aggravated the injury by weight-lifting on his own rehabilitation program, and will be lost to the Jets for the season opener against the Raiders in Los Angeles Sunday.

title: AMERICAN EDUCATIONAL COMUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $74,000.

title: HOUSE APPROVES REGIONAL AID
description: The House, ignoring the threat of a veto, voted today to continue two programs that provide economic aid to distressed areas.

title: A Classic
description: Significant firsts are hard to find around Washington, and truly classic events are even rarer. But the Potomac Polo Club, out in suburban Poolesville, Md., says that on its main field Saturday afternoon there will be an event that is a not only a first but a classic, too, therefore qualifying as something of an oxymoron.

title: HIGH COURT HALTS FLORIDA EXECUTION
description: The Supreme Court, in a rare reversal, has indefinitely postponed the execution of Willie Jasper Darden and granted a full review of his conviction for killing a businessman in a holdup that netted him $15.

title: GUATEMALA, TO CONTROL VIOLENCE, RELENTS ON PRICES
description: After a week of intensifying street violence, the Government agreed today to freeze prices of basic goods and to rescind an unpopular increase in bus fares.

title: DANCE: BALLET THEATER DOES 'ROMES AND JULIET'
description: THE American Ballet Theater led off its new two-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House with ''Romeo and Juliet'' Tuesday night - and certainly, on many levels, it is already an eventful season.

title: 2 BOYS ACCUSED OF STARTING HUGE PASSAIC FIRE
description: Two boys, 12 and 13 years old, have been arrested and charged with starting the raging, multimillion-dollar fire on Labor Day that ravaged 18 factories here and destroyed or damaged 23 nearby houses.

title: DELTA NAMES F.A.A. IN CRASH LAWSUIT
description: Negligence by air traffic controllers helped cause a crash of a Delta Air Lines jumbo jet last month at Dallas-Fort Worth Airport that killed 135 people, the airline said in court papers filed Aug. 29.

title: Federal Feathers
description: There are few smiles and scant ironies in the pages of the Federal Register, the daily, small-print list of Government hearings, rules and regulations. People who read it must endure sentences like ''These regulations have been determined to be major under Executive Order 12291 and they have a significant economic impact on substantial numbers of small entities under the Regulatory Flexibility Act.''

title: LIBERALS SPLIT AS HOMOSEXUAL SEEKS COUNCIL SEAT IN MANHATTAN
