description: At 7:55 on a bright morning, David Rothenberg stands at the top of stairs to the Sheridan Square subway station, dipping into a Gimbels shopping bag for campaign leaflets and pressing them into the hands of riders.

title: SAUDIS TO LET U.S. USE BASES IN CRISIS
description: Saudi Arabia has told the United States that it will allow American military forces to use its bases in case of Soviet ''aggression'' or if it is unable to handle a Persian Gulf crisis on its own, according to a confidential Reagan Administration report.

title: U.S. COURT UPSETS PAY EQUITY RULING FOR WOMEN
description: The nation's first statewide court ruling requiring comparable pay for jobs of comparable worth was overturned today by a Federal appeals court. The appellate court said the State of Washington did not have to offer women equal pay for such jobs.

title: 48-HOUR STRIKE AGAINST AUSTERITY PARALYZES THE BOLIVIAN ECONOMY
description: Government and commercial activity was paralyzed today as workers began a 48-hour general strike to protest Government economic measures aimed at controlling the highest inflation rate in the world.

title: BOWNE & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including a capital gain of $1,175,000 on the sale of securities. c-Including a capital gain of $490,000 on the sale of securities.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: DANTE'S INFERNO. Translated and illustrated by Tom Phillips. 311 pages.

title: Pets Mourned
description: Surveying the Rock Cornish hens and shards of glass, the dripping water and smoke, Anthony Beshara could only think of four things: Snowball, Tommy, Baby and a stray cat he had never named but adored nonetheless.

title: CASEY'S GENERAL STORES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Deputy Killed by Partner
description: An off-duty deputy sheriff was killed by her partner Sunday night, the police said Monday. Deputy Sheriff Gretchen Costello of Philadelphia, 35 years old, died of a bullet wound in the head after she was shot by her partner, Deputy Sheriff Juan Saez, also 35, the police said.

title: GRAND AUTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
Indiana Hospital Says AIDS Boy Is Improving
description: The condition of a 13-year-old boy barred from school because he has AIDS improved today, two days after he was admitted to a hospital, according to officials, who did not disclose his symptoms.

title: COUNCIL PRESIDENT DEBATE TAKES PERSONAL TONE
description: Personality conflicts and questions about candidates' character and integrity, rather than differences on issues, dominated a 90-minute debate yesterday by five Democratic candidates for City Council president.

title: GARDENERS COPING WITH THE DROUGHT
description: THE current restrictions on water use have forced city gardeners to look for alternative methods to see their greenery through the crisis.

title: How Tall Is Tall
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan was traveling in upstate New York yesterday using a town meeting format to try to find out what his constituents were thinking, particularly about President Reagan's tax revision plans.

title: EDELMAN IN BID FOR DATAPOINT
description: The Datapoint Corporation, the financially troubled computer company, said yesterday that it had received a leveraged-buyout offer of $6 a share, or $100 million, from a management group led by Asher B. Edelman, the New York financier who gained control of Datapoint in March.

title: REHEARING SOUGHT OVER JUSTICE AIDE
description: Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum called today for a new hearing on the nomination of Richard K. Willard to head the Justice Department's civil division after disclosure of the department's decision not to prosecute three officers of Eli Lilly & Company.

title: The Bomb That Shook The World's Conscience
description: To the Editor:

title: PRIME MOTOR INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CALENDAR: A WORKSHOP FOR DISABLED ATHLETES
description: F.D.R. Day Festivities, Roosevelt Island, F.D.R. Day Committee, 212-750-6735.

title: THE XIAMEN EXAMPLE
description: Yves Binet is a boat-builder who could have stepped out of a French film: 28 years old, with a luxuriant mustache and a large straw hat. He used to build boats in Taiwan. Now he makes luxury yachts in the People's Republic of China, 48-foot fiberglass sloops and ketches that sell in the United States for $135,000.

title: SUMMIT SAVINGS ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Comings and Goings
description: Louis E. Wolfson, whose Florida stable, Harbor View Farm, owns the 1978 Triple Crown winner, Affirmed, has offered $46.2 million, or $120 a share, to buy Churchill Downs, the home of the Kentucky Derby, in Louisville. . . . Booker Russell, a running back for the Raiders in 1978 and 1979, was charged in Houston with the shooting death of his estranged common-law wife, Merline Ruth Dixon.

title: SCOPE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NORTHROP-DYNAMICS FIGHTER TEST SET
description: The Pentagon has ordered the Air Force to arrange a one-time competition between Northrop's F-20 Tigershark and the General Dynamics F-16 Falcon for a role in defending the United States against bomber attack, Pentagon officials said today.

title: COURT TOLD OF SOVIET ACCESS TO SEVERAL F.B.I. DOCUMENTS
description: A former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation not only admitted passing a classified document to a Soviet intelligence agent but told bureau interrogators that they ''could assume'' Soviet agents had seen other F.B.I. documents in his home, the bureau's top polygraph expert testified today in Federal District Court.

title: Some High-Flying Lobbying
description: Earlier this summer the Air Transport Association, a lobbying group for passenger airlines, heard that the Federal Aviation Administration might tighten restrictions on baggage that passengers carry on airplanes.

title: A SLOW START FOR AN UPSCALE PENNEY'S
description: Penney's, after some disappointments, is trying again.

title: BENNETT FILLS IN AS A TEACHER AND IS PETITIONED ON SCHOOLS
description: After working today as a substitute teacher at a Roman Catholic school and a public school, Education Secretary William J. Bennett was petitioned to enforce the separation of church and state.

title: BERKSHIRE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Test Cases In Bevill Claims
description: A Federal judge said today that he would select several test cases in an attempt to iron out the complicated collapse of a New Jersey-based government securities brokerage. United States District Judge Dickinson R. Debevoise said that on Oct. 15 he would select certain creditors of Bevill, Bresler & Schulman Inc. of Livingston, N.J., and its affiliates for the proceedings.

title: EX-POLICEMEN ACQUITTED OF KILLING BLACK IN 1960
description: Two white former policemen were acquitted by an all-white jury today of charges that they beat a black jail inmate to death 25 years ago.

title: Move in Japan On Imports
description: A Government panel today instructed Japanese ministries to prepare measures by the end of the month to stimulate demand for foreign goods in an effort to reduce trade surpluses, an official said.

title: Computerized Prints
description: To the Editor:

title: Now Just a Coach
description: Craig Ramsay, the 34-yer-old Buffalo Sabres' defenseman, has retired as a player after a 14-year career but will continue as an assistant coach. Ramsay scored 252 goals with 420 assists in 1,070 regular-season games and set one National Hockey League record, most consecutive games (776) with one team. . . . Peter and Anton Stastny of the Quebec Nordiques will not play in an exhibition series against their former Czechoslovak teammates this weekend despite a request by the president of the International Olympic Committee.

title: Japan Is Exporting Its Unemployment to Us
description: To the Editor:

title: TOROTEL INC() reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income. The company changed its fiscal year ending from March 31 to April 30. Year-ago results are for the quarter ended June 30, 1984.

title: KOCH KEEPS BUSY SCHEDULE, SEEKING TO BUILD A 'MANDATE'
description: Beneath the shady maples and oaks outside Bohemian Hall in Astoria, Queens, a cheering throng of elderly New Yorkers took the Edward I. Koch pledge yesterday.

title: RETAILERS' SALES ROSE IN AUGUST
description: The nation's largest retailers said yesterday that their sales in August were higher than in August 1984, but the figures did not appear to represent a major turnaround from the sluggish pattern of recent months.

title: SPY SUSPECT SEEKS NAMES OF MILITARY SOURCES
description: A naval intelligence analyst accused of espionage filed a motion yesterday seeking to force the Federal Government to identify officials who might have disclosed to the press part of the information he was later charged with illegally disclosing.

title: 2 Newspaper Sales By Capital Cities
description: Capital Cities Communications has agreed to sell The Daily Register of Red Bank, N.J., a 28,000-circulation newspaper serving Monmouth County, and the 100,000-circulation semi-weekly Ocean County Reporter of Toms River, N.J., to Price Communications for $7.5 million.

title: Perot, Computer Executive, To Receive Churchill Award
description: H. Ross Perot, the computer entrepreneur who organized a 1979 rescue mission to free two of his employees imprisoned in Iran and once underwrote a plan to liberate American captives in Vietnam, will receive the Winston Churchill Award, it was announced yesterday.

title: 94 Degrees Yesterday Broke a 1961 Record
description: New Yorkers wilted and demand for electricity hit a record yesterday as the temperature reached 94 degrees, equaling the high for the year and setting a record for a Sept. 5. In addition, the year's highest ragweed pollen count made it an uncomfortable day for hay-fever sufferers.

title: ATTENTION SHIFTS TO GRAF
description: Two years ago, Martina Navratilova, just starting to emerge as the hottest player in tennis, managed to set aside her racquet long enough to write a letter to a shy but talented 14-year-old West German who had been forced to withdraw from the Australian Open tennis tournament after tearing the tendons in her thumb. The message was a simple one: Take your time. Stay in school. Don't rush into a game that had already crumbled the growing, fragile bodies of other young women who had struggled too soon for the golden ring.

title: LET THEM EAT RERUNS
description: The Marie Antoinette Let-Them-Eat-Cake Award (I know, I know, she probably didn't say it that way) goes to anybody who raves too openly about pennant-race games on the tube. There is a guillotine awaiting the first person to blurt, ''Did you see Griffey's catch yesterday?'' or ''Did you see Carter's home runs last night?'' because friends don't do that to friends, not until all households are wired equally.

title: SHOPS SEEK EXEMPTION FROM STREET-STALLS BAN
description: Invoking New York City's tradition of sidewalk selling, more than 40 shop owners from the Lower East Side and three other districts asked the city yesterday to exempt their blocks from a year-old law banning stands and stalls on more than 250 streets.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: WHEN Ellis Larkins, McCoy Tyner and Mac (Dr. John) Rebennack sit down at a piano, they all face the same 88 keys and three pedals. From the music they make, however, they might almost be playing three different instruments.

title: 800 REFUGEES AT REUNION RECALL LIFE IN THE GHETTO OF SHANGHAI
description: Sonya Wiesenfeld and Erika Schlesinger were once playmates in Shanghai. So were Susie Goldfarb and Susie Bergman.

title: CANOE RACE TO FOLLOW TRAPPERS' ROUTE
description: A challenging, 90-mile paddle through a magnificent wilderness area awaits those who take part in the Adirondack Canoe Classic Sept. 13-15.

title: GUATEMALA TROOPS LEAVE UNIVERSITY
description: Soldiers who occupied Guatemala's principal university Tuesday night withdrew today and returned the campus to civilian control.

title: MUSICIANS PLAN ANTI-APARTHEID DISK
description: More than three dozen leading pop, rock and jazz musicians, including Bruce Springsteen and Miles Davis, have joined as Artists United Against Apartheid to record a song with an anti-apartheid message.

title: NICHOLS, S E INC reports earnings for Qtr to August 3
AT THE MOVIES
description: Except for a single documentary on Jack Kerouac at the Bleecker Street Cinema, there's nothing new at the movies this week - not one Hollywood or foreign film opening in New York today. This is the week when Hollywood changes clothes, when it stores away the white tank tops of summer and airs out the prim and conservative tartan plaid skirts of fall. Or, as one studio executive put it, ''Now come Jessica Lange, Sally Field, Sissy Spacek and Meryl Streep in their Oscar-nominated performances.''

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday MAKING WAVES ON A FERRY Staten Island Ferry riders were stunned last year when leaping forms and tapping toes greeted them on their evening commute. Local dance companies were using the boat's decks and railings as a stage. They will be doing it again this weekend, to open the second Staten Island Council on the Arts Making Waves festival. Appropriately, Yoshiko Chuma and the School of Hard Knocks, a troupe noted for pieces celebrating urban transportation, will be among the companies performing on the two upper decks, on crossings from 5:30 to 7:40 P.M. tonight and 2 to 3:30 Saturday. Also pirouetting above the waves will be the American Ballroom Theater Company, NYC Tapworks, Marta Renzi and the Project Company and the Clive Thompson Dance Company. Admission is simply the 25-cent round-trip ferry fare. The number for information and detailed schedules: (718) 447-4485.

title: William Thinnes, 55; U.S. Bankruptcy Judge
description: Judge William Thinnes of the Federal Bankruptcy Court died of a heart attack today three months after he collapsed while he was working 15 hours a day, seven days a week. He was 55 years old.

title: Music on the Square
description: The renovation of Union Square Park will be celebrated from noon to 2 P.M. today with a concert sponsored by the 14th Street-Union Square Local Development Corporation in cooperation with the Department of Parks and Recreation. The event, called ''Sky Music,'' was conceived by the Broadway director Tom O'Horgan.

title: MCFARLANE BACKS AIDE ON CONTRA ROLE
description: President Reagan's national security adviser told the leaders of the Senate intelligence committee today that no one on the National Security Council had violated the law by assisting anti-Government rebels in Nicaragua.

title: TITANIC PHOTOS MAY HOLD CLUES TO FINAL HOURS
description: Researchers who found the wreckage of the Titanic headed home to Massachusetts yesterday with more than 12,000 color photographs of the ship that scientists said might provide clues about the Titanic's agonizing final hours before she slipped below the icy North Atlantic waters 73 years ago.

title: 'Much Ado' for Free
description: Free performances of Shakespeare's ''Much Ado About Nothing'' continue this weekend at the bandshell in Brooklyn's Prospect Park, Ninth Street and Prospect Park West.

title: EXCERPTS FROM GRIFFIN BELL'S REPORT ON HUTTON
description: Following are excerpts from the report of former Attorney General Griffin B. Bell on his investigation into the overdrafting practices of E. F. Hutton Inc.:

title: Aouita to Run Despite Injury
description: The battle lines are drawn, sort of. Sydney Maree of the United States and Said Aouita of Morocco, the year's most successful distance runners, will run different races here Saturday night in the International Amateur Athletic Federation Mobil Grand Prix final, the year's most important track meet.

title: LIFETIME COMMUNITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $123,289 for the quarter and $174,000 for the 9 months. c-Including the provision of an $800,000 valuation reserve for a condominium project. d-Net income.

title: Datapoint Auditor
description: The Datapoint Corporation said Peat Marwick had resigned as the company's independent auditor. Datapoint said it was inappropriate for Peat Marwick to continue as auditor because of a class-action suit charging Datapoint had overstated or misrepresented financial results from August 1980 through May 1982. Datapoint has agreed to pay a $22.5 million settlement but Peat Marwick remains a defendant.

title: NOEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
A CELEBRATION OF YIDDISH CULTURE
description: There is a tendency, and often with reason, to look at things Yiddish as relics - quaint, curious, fascinating but, ultimately, dated. They occasion retrospection and a wan sense of loss.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell $563.9 million, to $208.72 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 70 institutional funds increased $81 million, to $52.75 billion. The 188 general purpose funds were up $4.6 million, to $61.81 billion.

title: JAMES BUCKLEY ON LIST FOR U.S. APPEALS COURT
description: James L. Buckley, a former Republican Senator from New York, said today that he was under consideration for appointment as a judge of the United States Court of Appeals in New York.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a Chicago dispatch yesterday on an agreement that ended a teachers' strike in that city incorrectly named the parent group of the Chicago Teachers Union. The union is affiliated with the American Federation of Teachers, not the National Education Association.

title: AMERICAN TECHNICAL CERAMCS reports earnings for Year to June 30
ART: SHOW FOCUSES ON DAVID PARK
description: ALTHOUGH David Park's work is widely known among painters, it has received little attention from New York City museums, and is little known to the art public. Yet he was a key figure in the development of San Francisco Bay Area painting. He loved paint, he loved the natural world, and he was the first Bay Area painter who passed through Abstract Expressionism to return to the human figure. Park's style was clearly expressionist, but his monuments to gesture and color are also inhabited by silence.

title: GUILTY PLEA IN EXPORTS TO SOVIET
description: A Spanish company pleaded guilty in Federal court here today to providing Cuba and the Soviet Union with almost $2.5 million in valuable American manufacturing equipment. Prosecutors said the equipment was probably being used to make semiconductors for weapons systems.

title: Murray Signs
description: Eddie Murray, the Baltimore first baseman, has signed a five-year contract extension that will reportedly bring him $13 million and make him the highest-paid Oriole and among the highest-paid players ever. ''This is the largest contract ever given to one of our players,'' said Hank Peters, the general manager, who announced the signing Wednesday but declined to discuss financial terms.

title: The Final Word?
description: In the two years since Korean Air Lines Flight 007 was shot down over Sakhalin Island on Sept. 1, 1983, with the loss of all 269 persons aboard, the Reagan Administration has steadfastly maintained that no one in the U.S. Government knew that the airliner was in danger until after it had been destroyed by a Soviet fighter plane. Therefore, officials insist, they could not have warned Flight 007 that it was off course and headed for sensitive Soviet territory.

title: Elders Seeks Allied-Lyons
description: The Australian company, Elders IXL, said today that it was heading a consortium to bid for Allied-Lyons P.L.C., the food and drinks group, in what could turn out to be Britain's biggest takeover battle.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Oakland A's, at Yankee Stadium. 8 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Dodgers, at Los Angeles, 10:35 P.M. This will be the fifth meeting between Dwight Gooden and Fernando Valenzuela over the last two years. Gooden, who is 20-4 this season, has a lifetime record of 3-1 against Valenzuela. (Television - SportsChannel, 10:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 10:30 P.M.) Cardinals vs. Atlanta Braves, at St. Louis, 8:35 P.M. John Tudor, who has won 15 of his last 16 decisions, will be on the mound for the Cardinals. (Television - WTBS, 8:35 P.M.) Tennis United States Open, at National Tennis Center, Flushing Meadows, Queens. The women's semifinals will feature the top three seeded players and one surprise. Top-seeded Chris Evert will play third-seeded Hana Mandlikova, and Martina Navratilova, No. 2, will face Steffi Graf, No. 11, who upset fourth-seeded Pam Shriver on Wednesday. The men's doubles final will also be played. (Television - Channel 2, 11 A.M. to noon, then returning at 12:30 P.M.; highlights at 11:30 P.M.) Other Events BOXING: Azumah Nelson vs. Juvenal Ordenez, 12 rounds featherweights, at Miami, for Nelson's World Boxing Council title. Nelson, who lives in Ghana, is 20-1; Ordenez, from Chile, is 34-1. On the undercard, the former W.B.C. heavyweight champion, Tim Witherspoon, meets Larry Belfus. GOLF: Bank of Boston Classic, Pleasant Valley Country Club, Sutton, Mass. Second round of play. Portland Ping Championship, at Portland, Ore.

title: Nonaligned Foreign Ministers Express Support for Mandela
description: Foreign ministers of the group of countries espousing nonalignment approved a message of support today for Nelson Mandela, the imprisoned South African black nationalist leader.

title: DAUGHTER SEEKS HANK WILLIAMS'S SONGS AND NAME
description: When the country singer Hank Williams died in the back seat of his green Cadillac convertible in the dark early hours of New Years Day 1953, on his way to perform in Canton, Ohio, the rural South and country people around the nation went into mourning.

title: 3 Units Are Sold By Penn Central
description: The Penn Central Corporation said it had sold its Hydrotherm-North America, Flexible Technologies and Harris Tube units for about $52 million to investors headed by McBain Rose Partners and managements of the units sold.

title: Brazil Trade Surplus
description: Brazil's trade surplus in August narrowed to $1.08 billion, from $1.39 billion a year ago, the Government said today. Exports were $2.13 billion, down 16 percent from $2.54 billion a year earlier. Imports were $1.06 billion, off 7.8 percent from $1.14 billion.

title: U.N. LEADER APPEALS FOR NEW SPRINT OF UNITY
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar called today on members of the United Nations to set aside their own narrow interests and dedicate themselves to building ''the international system of the future.''

title: Double-Barreled Jazz
description: The guitarist Jean-Paul Bourelly and the singer E. L. James each will lead a quartet in jazz double-bills tonight at 8 and 10 at Greenwich Music House, 27 Barrow Street (645-2330). Mr. Bourelly's group includes Henry Threadgill on saxophones, Kevin Harris on bass and Andrew Cyrille on drums; Mr. James will be backed up by Geri Allen on piano, Tommie McKenzie on bass and Rocky Bryant on drums. The alto saxophonist Marion Brown will also perform. Tickets for each concert are $10.

title: VOTE FRAUD TRIAL ENDS IN HUMG JURY
description: A Federal district judge has declared a mistrial in the trial of the Mayor of the tiny town of Union on a charge of voting fraud after one juror held out for a verdict of not guilty through eight hours of deliberations.

title: FARM LOAN AID PLAN IS ASKED
description: Saying that the nation's system of more than 800 cooperative farm banks faces ''the most severe crisis since the Depression days,'' the system's top regulator today asked Congress and the Reagan Administration to begin laying plans for a Federal rescue that he said could run to ''multibillions of dollars.''

title: 16 Turks Die in Bus Plunge
description: Sixteen Turks were killed today when the minibus they were traveling in plunged 300 feet down a cliff near the southern town of Adana, the Anatolian News Agency reported. One passenger survived.

title: Iraq Tells of New Raid On Kharg Island
description: Iraqi warplanes dropped more than four tons of explosives in a raid on Kharg Island today and shot down an Iranian jet in a dogfight over Iran's main oil terminal, the Baghdad command said.

title: NOTED RABBI TAKES A POST ON WEST SIDE
description: A rabbi internationally known for his opposition to Argentine military regimes has been named to lead one of New York's oldest congregations, B'nai Jeshurun on the Upper West Side.

title: AS AUTUMN LEAVES START TO FALL, STREET FAIRS ARE ON RISE
description: THE beginning of September is the starting gun for New York's fall street festival season. This weekend there will be festivals all over town, drawing large crowds with their popular blend of ethnic foods, free entertainment, crafts sales and civic-minded spirit that manages to turn the big city into a network of small neighborhoods.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 6, 1985
description: International

title: MARYLAND TO CONTROL THRIFT UNIT
description: In an unexpected development last night, the State of Maryland took control of the Community Savings and Loan Association of Bethesda. While the move is aimed at protecting depositors, it will probably complicate efforts to rescue the thrift institution's troubled nationwide real estate subsidiary, the Equity Programs Investment Corporation.

title: At the Freer Gallery
description: When Manchurian warriors captured Peking and overthrew the 276-year Ming Dynasty in 1644, many artists, including some of royal blood, took refuge in Buddhist monasteries and engaged in poetry, calligraphy and painting there. Among them were Shih-tao, a Ming prince who developed the use of wet ink in landscapes in the late 16th Century, and Chu Ta, who became a famous painter of flowers, birds and fish despite the fact he felt compelled to feign madness as a monk to help preserve his personal safety.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: GAMES THE MALL PEOPLE PLAY
description: When the workday is done, some would-be athletes in Washington plop down in front of a television set to watch sports. The more adventurous organize a local game of their own. But the truly daring head out for international competition on the Mall and its surrounding parks.

title: Thousands of Strikers March in Bolivia
description: Thousands of workers marched through La Paz today to protest harsh economic measures imposed last week, and labor leaders said a general strike that was to have lasted 48 hours would be extended through Monday.

title: Caddie's Smooth Follow-Through
description: It is not the most significant event on the men's golf tour, and it never will be. But you should hear the way some people talk about the B.C. Open.

title: RECIPIENT OF ARTIFICIAL HEART IS STRICKEN, SPURRING SEARCH FOR HUMAN HEART
description: Several small strokes were suffered today by the first recipient of an artificial heart approved by the Government for temporary use, forcing his doctors to begin a search for a human heart under emergency conditions.

title: RACIST GETS 20-YEAR SENTENCE ON RACKET AND ARMS COUNTS
description: The leader of the Covenant, the Sword and the Arm of the Lord, a militant white supremacist group based in north Arkansas, was sentenced Wednesday to 20 years in prison on Federal racketeering and weapon charges.

title: Scott & Fetzer, Kelso Deal Off
description: The Scott & Fetzer Company said yesterday that it had ended an agreement with Kelso & Company, the New York investment firm that had unsuccessfully tried to organize a $440 million leveraged buyout.

title: Saturn's Pay Pattern
description: White-collar workers in the General Motors Corporation's Saturn subsidiary will receive smaller salaries but more incentive pay than elsewhere in G.M., a company spokesman said today. The new car is to be built in Tennessee.

title: VIOLENCE SPREADS INTO WHITE AREA IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: Crowds of mixed-race youths hurled rocks and gasoline bombs at homes in a white suburb outside Cape Town over night and whites responded with gunfire, the police said today.

title: SERVICE CORP INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ALAIA SHOW AT PALLADIUM MIXES FASHION AND FLASH
description: The invitations for Azzedine Alaia's fashion show Wednesday night at the Palladium requested that guests wear black. Mr. Alaia is known for his provocative fashions. His show was calculated to enhance that sexy image.

title: PEERLESS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
3 Arrested in Slaying On Upper West Side
description: Three men were arrested yesterday and charged with the ''contract'' murder of a building superintendent who tried to keep drug pushers away from her building on the Upper West Side, the police said.

title: Mobil Withdrawal
description: The Mobil Corporation, citing ''intense competitive pressure,'' has announced that it has withdrawn from selling gasoline and diesel fuel in New Mexico, Oklahoma, most of Arkansas, western Texas and the southern part of Nevada. Mobil said it would continue to market aviation fuel and lubricants in all the areas affected. It also said it would continue other business interests in those areas.

title: CARTER IS ENJOYING HIS BEST STREAK
description: When it was over, Gary Carter had five home runs in two games and eight in six games, and he said: ''In my 11 years, I never had a streak like this, a feeling like this. I wish I could bottle it.''

title: EAST SIDE CONDOMINIUM COMBINES TWO HISTORIES
description: At the corner of Third Avenue and 70th Street in Manhattan, there is a new building with two histories. One is written in its architecture, which is tied to the romantic spirit of Old New York, and the opulent late 19th-century era of the Fricks, Astors and Carnegies. The other history - more recent and considerably less romantic - is written in the dry language of city zoning law, and in the Upper East Side's traditions of community activism and control.

title: Another Executive Resigns at Wang
description: Jon F. Kropper, an executive vice president and one of four top officials at Wang Laboratories Inc., resigned yesterday, less than two months after John F. Cunningham resigned as president of the troubled computer maker.

title: Two Banks Plan Merger
description: Union Bancorp of Los Angeles has agreed to buy United Bancorp of Arizona for $33 a share, or a total of about $335 million, the companies said yesterday.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: SHE had gone shopping for earrings, Barbara Franzheim said, but decided instead on a silver armchair. Having done that, Mrs. Franzheim thought it only fitting to give a party for her new acquisition to show it off to friends settling back in a still-stifling town. On Tuesday evening then, two dozen or so of them oohed, aahed and hmmed at the gleaming object in Mrs. Franzheim's Upper East Side apartment while sipping champagne and munching on Cuban hors d'oeuvres from Victor's Cafe 52. Mrs. Franzheim, who does historic restorations, insisted she couldn't remember how much she paid for the Victorian piece. ''All I can say is, it's a good thing I wasn't shopping for a necklace.''

title: SYNTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
AVON TO SELL MALLINCKRODT UNIT
description: Avon Products Inc., the company that built the world's biggest beauty business by ringing doorbells, said yesterday that it was putting its large Mallinckrodt chemical and hospital products division on the block. It said it would use most of the money it collected to buy back 25 percent of its stock.

title: TRIAL SEPARATION AS A THERAPY TECHNIQUE
description: Early this summer Carol and Joseph Rothenstein took a vacation in England. It was a happy time, a sharp contrast to their experience several years earlier in the Caribbean after which they had decided they could no longer live together. ''There had been nothing but tension and rows,'' said Mrs. Rothenstein, a psychotherapist in the Boston area. ''We had reached an impasse.'' They attribute the change to a 10-month period of ''creative separation'' - a technique a growing number of marital therapists are using to try to temper the precipitous manner in which many couples now rush headlong into divorce.

title: A Welcome New Will in Peru
description: Immediately after taking office, Peru's reform-minded new President, Alan Garcia Perez, took bold steps to stabilize his country's reeling economy. He temporarily limited repayments to foreign creditors, froze prices and cut back arms purchases.

title: 6 CHILEANS REPORTED KILLED IN WIDE PROTESTS
description: Six Chileans were reported killed in a day of anti-Government demonstrations on Wednesday protesting the military regime of President Augusto Pinochet. More than three dozen people were wounded, including six who were in serious condition.

title: PENN TRAFFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to August 3
ENERGY RESOURCES OF NORTH DAKOTA INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
COURT TOLD OF AGENT'S SPY ADMISSION
description: A woman who said she had an intimate relationship with Richard W. Miller, a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation on trial for spying, testified today that only hours before his arrest he told her he had ''only passed one'' classified document to a Soviet intelligence agent.

title: JLG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a writedown of $3,500,000 resulting from the discontinuance of hydrostatic drive industrial cranes and truck cranes.

title: H.H. Velde, Ex-Chief Of Inquiry on Radicals
description: Harold H. Velde, a former Republican Congressman from Illinois who headed the House Un-American Activities Committee in the 1950's, died Sunday. He was 75 years old.

title: Injured List
description: John Hannah, the New England Patriots' all-pro guard who missed the last two exhibition games with a torn calf muscle, reinjured the leg in practice on Wednesday and may miss the season opener against Green Bay Sunday. . . . David Huffman, an offensive lineman who jumped to the Memphis Showboats of the United States Football League two years ago after five seasons with the Minnesota Vikings, has rejoined the Vikings under an arrangement that will give him two weeks of training before the club decides whether to add him to the roster or waive him. ''It's my own personal training camp,'' he said.

title: WOMEN VOW TO PUSH PAY EQUITY FIGHT AFTER LOSING COURT RULING
description: Labor unions and women's groups said today that they would continue their campaign to achieve equal pay for men and women holding different jobs of comparable worth, even though a Federal appeals court has rejected their arguments in a major test case.

title: 'No-Losers' Tax Reform
description: Amid all the controversy over President Reagan's tax reform plan, his proposal to nearly double the personal exemption has gone virtually unchallenged. Yet the exemption would help taxpayers of moderate and low incomes less than it would others. A tax credit would help a lot more, and at much less cost to the Government.

title: Pact on Right to Die Cited in Court Case
description: The wife of a comatose firefighter has cited a new ''right to die'' policy approved by the Massachusetts Medical Society to support the family's request for the man to be separated from an artificial feeding system.

title: ADVANCED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
THE BALLET: ALESSANDRA FERRI'S JULLIET
description: ALESSANDRA FERRI, the exciting young Italian star from Britain's Royal Ballet who has just joined American Ballet Theater, is a hothouse flower - her qualities are special and may require special care and feeding.

title: Peabody Holding
description: The Miami investor Victor Posner said he intends to increase his stake in the Peabody International Corporation from 34.3 percent to more than 50 percent of the company's shares outstanding.

title: DR. EVELINE BURNS, WHO HELPED SHAPE SOCIAL SECURITY, DIES
description: Dr. Eveline M. Burns, a longtime Columbia University economist and one of the architects of the Social Security Act, died Monday at St. Mary's Hospital in Newton, Pa. She was 85 years old.

title: Three for Civil Court
description: As long as New York clings to the fiction that citizens know as much about their courts as they do about their legislatures and City Hall, there will be elections for the bench. Judges should be picked in other ways, like merit selection, but reform will not come soon.

title: LITCHFIELD: TIME STANS HAPPILY STILL
description: ISOLATED by thick forests and corrugated hills, Litchfield County held out as the last corner of Connecticut to be settled in the 18th century. Bypassed in the 20th century by four-lane highways and economic development, this charming backwater is often one of the last areas of Connecticut to be discovered by visitors.

title: NAVY SPY SUSPECT LOSES A BAIL PLEA
description: A Federal district judge today refused to set bail for Jerry A. Whitworth, one of four Navy men accused of participating in a Soviet spy ring.

title: BROADWAY
description: RIGHT from the beginning, which was almost a year ago, Nancy Walker insisted that she didn't want to do a one-woman show. She wanted, she said in no uncertain terms, a terrific leading man and a top musical banana to appear with her in her return to Broadway after 25 years.

title: CUOMO TO OFFER BROAD PLAN FOR ECONOMIC GROWTH
description: The Cuomo administration, in its most comprehensive initiative to date, is about to propose an economic development plan that will include special help for the state's poorest areas and government loans for manufacturers, exporters and emerging businesses.

title: Bridge: The Safer Bid Means Failure As Game Goes Topsy-Turvy
description: ''Fivepence farthing for one, twopence for two,'' said the Sheep, surprising Alice, who doubted that two eggs could be cheaper than one. The topsy-turviness of the Looking-Glass world is sometimes mirrored at the bridge table. There are some strange deals in which a game succeeds easily but a safe-looking part-score, played correctly, fails.

title: Silk Tapestry Returned For West Point Chapel
description: A silk ark curtain that was commissioned for the United States Military Academy at West Point, but that was stolen last month from the Long Point Gallery in Provincetown, Mass., has been returned, according to officials.

title: Topics;   Literary Frustrations Writer's Crimp
description: Edward R. Grant 3d, a New Orleans man, has a problem familiar to many writers. He discovered that the public couldn't care less about his novel, ''Saints in the Shadows.''

title: Affordable Legends Invoked
description: THE advertising line ''Introducing the same old idea'' hardly seems the best way to sell a product, except perhaps when that old idea was an affordable legend,such as the Ford Model T and the Volkswagen Beetle.

title: MUSEUM MERGER STALLED
description: The executive committee of the Museum of the American Indian has recommended that the museum reject a plan to merge with the American Museum of Natural History, according to Roland Force, the director of the Indian museum.

title: Florida Issue
description: The Hillsborough County, Fla., school district is offering $96.8 million of 8 7/8 percent general obligation bonds with yields ranging from 5.20 percent in 1986 to 7.20 percent in 1990, 8.25 percent in 1995, 9 percent in 2000 and 9.20 percent in 2005 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The bonds are rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by Standard & Poor's.

title: Topics;   Literary Frustrations Windows on the World
description: Banned Books Week '85, which begins Saturday, will memorialize the noble and the ignoble, the sublime and the ridiculous. All that the books banned over the last 500 years have in common, in fact, is that somebody found them dangerous.

title: Rumor, Reality At Southdown
description: WALL STREET apparently likes rumors more than facts. Take as a case in point Southdown Inc., a Houston-based cement supplier that also has oil and natural gas holdings.

title: ROHR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ORSON WELLES: A Biography. By Barbara Leaming. 562 pages. Illustrated.

title: Air Force Major to Take Part In a Secret Shuttle Mission
description: An Air Force major from New Jersey will join the astronauts next month on the military flight of the newest space shuttle, the Atlantis, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today. The agency is keeping the primary purpose of the mission secret.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Allegheny Power System Inc., an electric utility holding company, said the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission had authorized rate increases for the company's West Penn Power Co. unit intended to produce additional revenue of $28.3 million annually.

title: VORNADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
description: b-Including tax credits of $2,018,000 for the quarter and $3,978,000, or $1.17 a share, for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $3,808,000 for the quarter, or $1.03 a share, for the quarter and $1,265,000 for the 6 months.

title: New Richardson
description: A clutch of scribes made their way to a New Jersey restaurant yesterday, there to meet with Micheal Ray Richardson, fresh from his re-signing with the Nets. The man who showed up was not the Micheal Ray known for his excitability, for his gift of causing his coaches no little exasperation, even for some troubled brushes with cocaine.

title: MCINTOSH APPLES READY FOR PICKING
description: First the good news: The McIntosh apple crop is ready for pick-it-yourselfers a week earlier than usual. Now the not-so-good news: This year's crop is smaller.

title: The Unscrutable Mideast
description: The Washington office of the U.S.-Arab Chamber of Commerce has an unlisted telephone number.

title: CANADIAN IMPERIAL BANK OF COMMERCE reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: LANCASTER COLONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REAGAN SEES JOBS IN TAX RATE CUTS
description: President Reagan, seeking to spark grass-roots support for his proposed overhaul of the Federal income tax, said today that another round of across-the-board rate cuts could help create up to 10 million new jobs in the next four years.

title: MUSIC: 'ALI ON THE BEACH'
description: WE walked from the West Side Highway onto the synthetic beach to the accompaniment of the old ''Andy Griffith Show'' theme song. Out by the Hudson River, some 20 musicians blew raucously into a collection of brass and woodwind instruments, while two men shoveled sand into the wind.

title: KOCH SAYS CITY PLANS HOME CARE FOR AIDS VICTIMS
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that the city would soon ask for proposals from groups willing to provide home care for people with AIDS.

title: Campaign News
description: Looking like a defunct monthly of almost the same name, something called The New West Side News is being handed out in Manhattan's 4th Council District.

title: SCREEN: 'KEROUAC,' A DOCUMENTARY
description: THE wittiest thing about John Antonelli's ''Kerouac, The Movie'' is its title, which effectively separates this particular work from Jack Kerouac (1922-69), the author who named the Beat Generation; Jack Kerouac, the public personality, and Jack Kerouac, the hero of John Byrum's ''Heart Beat'' (1980), based on Carolyn Cassady's memoir and certainly one of the funniest films ever made about a life in literature.

title: Advanced Micro Realigns Units
description: Advanced Micro Devices, a semiconductor company, said it had realigned its operating units, except the advanced-technology division, into three major business groups -the memory group, the general logic group and the special logic group.

title: NEW-CAR SALES SOARED 70.9% IN LATE AUGUST
description: Aggressive consumer incentive programs pushed new-car sales to record levels in August. The major American automobile manufacturers reported today that sales soared 70.9 percent in the last 10 days, compared with the period in 1984, and were up 23.4 percent for the entire month. The auto makers sold more than 1 million new vehicles in August.

title: Street Awards
description: More than 100 performers will vie for the Street Entertainer of the Year title in ''Homage to Street Entertainers,'' to be sponsored by The Village Voice on Sunday from noon to 9 P.M. at Lafayette Street and Astor Place.

title: CAMBODIAN REFUGEES ARE MOVED INTO HARM'S WAY
description: Last December the people of Site 7, a Cambodian refugee camp in Thailand also known as Bang Poo, had begun to build new lives.

title: BONANNO JAILED AFTER REFUSING TO BE WITNESS
description: Joseph Bonanno, a major figure in the history of organized crime, went to jail here today after refusing to testify about a ''commission'' governing the Mafia.

title: A.T.&T. Chip
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it had begun producing a million-bit computer chip that can store four times as much data as the most advanced chip now available. A.T.&T. said it is the first United States company to produce the mega-bit, random-access memory chip for customer inspection and testing. The company, which announced development of the chip six months ago, said the chip eventually could ''shrink desktop computers to briefcase size.''

title: Dining Out Guide: Restaurants on the Rise
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. DEVON HOUSE LTD., #1316 Madison Avenue, at 93d Street (860-8294) -

title: SEAGRAM CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Mary Kay Gets Its Financing
description: Mary Kay Cosmetics Inc. said yesterday that it had received the $141 million in financing it needs to go private in a leveraged buyout by a group headed by the company's founder, Mary Kay Ash, and her son Richard R. Rogers, chief executive.

title: SCM Stake Raised
description: The New York investor Ivan F. Boesky has purchased an additional 332,100 shares of the SCM Corporation, raising his stake to 12.1 percent, from 8.7 percent.

title: CITY HALL STEPS: A POLITICAL BATTLEFIELD
description: The best way to City Hall is by the steps. At least, that's the premise a lot of groups seemed to be working on yesterday.

title: Australians Win Again
description: Victoria 150, the Australian challenger for the International Catamaran trophy, also called the Little America's Cup, today won its second race in two days against the United States defender, Patient Lady VI. Victoria 150, which won by 37 seconds today, leads the four-of-seven-race series, 2-0.

title: CHESS TITLE GAME ADJOURNED
description: The second game of the world chess championship match between Anatoly Karpov, the reigning champion, and Gary Kasparov was adjourned on the 41st move today in what grandmasters called an exciting battle.

title: Who's in Charge Here?
description: For years now, the National Security Council in the White House and the State Department over in Foggy Bottom have tugged and hauled over control of the nation's foreign policy, each maintaining at various times that it was really in charge. The latest manifestation of this rivalry is mostly confined to bragging rights, but its resolution could have some long-range effect on the delicate balance of power.

title: No Frills for 4 Lanes
description: Motorists on the Triborough Bridge will discover today that there are four lanes at the toll plaza where they cannot get change or a receipt, where they cannot buy tokens or a newspaper.

title: SURPRISE AND CONCERN IN CAIRO AT RESIGNATION OF THE PREMIER
description: Egyptian officials and diplomats here expressed surprise and some concern today at the resignation Wednesday of Prime Minister Kamal Hassan Ali, a close confidant of President Hosni Mubarak.

title: VISITORS GIVEN LESSON IN INNER CITY SURVIVAL
description: Not long ago Melissa Izor, 17 years old, put on a plaid skirt, white blouse and pearls, left her parents' split-level home in a suburb of Little Rock, Ark., flew to New Orleans and caught a ride to the St. Thomas public housing project. What she saw surprised her. Three-story brick apartment buildings sprawled toward the Mississippi River in a monotonous march of building-courtyard-building. Torn screens drooped. Sidewalks crumbled. Broken glass glittered. In the street, clusters of men sat on parked cars, some drinking beer from cans in paper bags.

title: IN A POLICY SHIFT, CITY WILL ALLOW SELLING OF WATER
description: The city agency that enforces water restrictions in the current drought reversed its policy yesterday and said it had no authority to prevent private suppliers from bringing water into the city and selling it for industrial purposes.

title: STAGE: 'FABIOLA,' TALE OF FAMILY AND CASTRO
description: ANY play that reduces the Cuban revolution to a tale of squabbling in-laws and homosexual incest must have something going for it - even if that something is mainly bad taste. In ''Fabiola,'' a new potboiler at the Theater for the New City, the writer Eduardo Machado fiddles madly and at times divertingly while Havana burns. ''Fabiola'' purports to deal with such matters as the rise of Castro, the collapse of the Bay of Pigs invasion and the horrors of totalitarianism. The evening is at its liveliest, however, when we watch two brothers make out feverishly in their bedroom while others fight the revolution (or counter-revolution) off stage.

title: ART: 'ANXIOUS INTERIORS,' IN THE BRONX
description: HOME being where the heart is, it is also headquarters for anxiety, dread, dissension and a whole bunch of neuroses. Or so goes the collective message of the photographs and sculptures comprising ''Anxious Interiors.'' On view at the Bronx Museum of the Arts, this is an import from the Laguna Beach Museum of Art in California, where it was organized by the curator of special exhibitions, Elaine K. Dines, and it gives scholarly sanction to an idea that's been in the air for some time. To wit: not only is it now O.K. for art to be anecdotal without being ironic, but also a fondness for camp is no longer the prerequisite for its appreciation (how time flies!).

title: HERNANDEZ, ANDUJAR CITED AT TRIAL
description: Lonnie Smith, the first baseball player to testify in the Federal trial of an accused drug dealer, today named Joaquin Andujar, Keith Hernandez and Gary Matthews as players who were involved in cocaine use with him when he was with the Philadelphia Phillies and the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: A CATHOLIC-ANGLICAN PANEL TAKES A KEY STEP TOWARD RECONCILIATION
description: In an important step toward a reconciliation between the Anglican and Roman Catholic Churches, a high-level commission of theologians said today that they were close to an agreement on the spiritual means of attaining salvation. The issue is among those that have divided the churches since the Reformation in the 16th century.

title: May Petroleum
description: May Petroleum Inc. said it had agreed to be acquired by a company controlled by Craig Hall, the Dallas investor, for $6 a share, or $51 million. May also said it had agreed to sell to Mr. Hall 3 million new shares at $4.75 each, or $14.25 million, with the proceeds being used to pay down bank debt. About $11.6 million worth of the new shares will be bought by Sept. 24, with the remainder purchased after regulatory approval.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''My doctors instructed me not to testify to protect my life.

title: FOR HUTTON'S CHIEF, PAINFUL EXONERATION
description: Griffin B. Bell's long-awaited report on E. F. Hutton's illegal cash management practices concluded, as Hutton chairman and chief executive Robert Fomon has said all along, that neither Mr. Fomon nor any other of the brokerage firm's top management had masterminded the scheme.

title: Article 242684 -- No Title
description: Governor Kean yesterday released $1 million in state funds to help the hundreds of people who lost their homes and jobs in a devastating fire in a 40-acre industrial complex in Passaic on Labor Day.

title: Radzinsky's 'Lunin'
description: The Jean Cocteau Repertory troupe will open its 15th anniversary season tonight at 8 with the American premiere of the Russian playwright Edvard Radzinsky's ''Lunin: Theater of Death.''

title: What We Know From Biomedical Research With Animals
description: To the Editor:

title: Poindexter at Tramps
description: Buster Poindexter, alias David Johansen, will sing selected rock and pop songs tonight and tomorrow at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077). Sets begin at about 9:30 and midnight; there is a $9 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: Cavaliers Quiet
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers weren't talking, but the club is believed to have protected its rights to John (Hot Rod) Williams, the former Tulane star, by offering him a minimum National Basketball Association contract in time for yesterday's deadline. If the club had not made such an offer, it would have lost its draft rights to Williams, a second-round choice whose N.B.A. prospects have been under a cloud because of charges of sports bribery that had been lodged against him in connection with the Tulane point-shaving scandal.

title: 15 HUTTON EMPLOYEES ARE CITED
description: The report on an internal investigation by former Attorney General Griffin B. Bell cited 15 employees of the New York brokerage firm of E. F. Hutton & Company for their part either in the bank overdrafting scheme or their lack of proper management that would have stopped the practices. The individuals, a description of their activities and the actions recommended by Mr. Bell and approved by Hutton are these: Thomas P. Lynch, vice chairman, chief financial officer and corporate secretary, will relinquish all corporate titles and responsibilities. He will remain as a director of Hutton's board. Mr. Lynch was cited in the Bell report for failing to impose adequate financial controls. Thomas W. Rae, general counsel, was cited because his department failed to fully comply with the Justice Department's subpoena of Hutton documents. But he was ''not involved in the activities that gave rise to the plea,'' the Bell report said. The legal department will be reorganized within 90 days. Mr. Rae plans to retire by the end of the year. Thomas Morley, senior vice president and money manager, has resigned from Hutton. A key player in coordinating Hutton's overdrafting activities, he was not criminally implicated but was cited for irresponsible management of Hutton's money operations. Norman M. Epstein, executive vice president, was responsible for internal auditing controls, which, Mr. Bell asserts, were lacking in regard to Hutton overdrafting practices.

title: The Case of Judge Kozinski
description: A coalition of public interest lawyers and political activists is planning a news conference on Capitol Hill this morning to urge that the Senate Judiciary Committee reopen hearings on the nomination of Chief Judge Alex Kozinski of the United States Claims Court to a vacancy on the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Ordinarily, Presidential appointments to the circuit courts arouse little Congressional opposition, particularly when they involve a sitting Federal judge, but Judge Kozinski is emerging as a special case.

title: Amax to Cut 1,500 By End of the Year
description: Amax Inc., which has been tightening its belt amid bad times for the mining industry, said yesterday that it will lay off 1,500 employees from its work force of 12,400 by the end of the year.

title: A Simple Tax Plan For Bankruptcy
description: To the Editor:

title: TWO TOP OFFICIALS OF HUTTON RESIGN IN BANKING SCHEME
description: Two high-level executives at the E. F. Hutton Group resigned today after the release of a report by Griffin B. Bell, the former Attorney General, on his investigation of a bank overdrafting scheme by the company's brokerage firm.

title: DYR and Wunderman Team Up for Westin
description: The Los Angeles offices of DYR and of Wunderman, Ricotta & Kline, a direct marketing agency, will both be working on the $8 million account of Westin Hotels, a Seattle-based subsidiary of United Airlines. It has about 80 hotels in this country and Asia, not the least of which is our own Plaza.

title: SALVADOR SAYS IT HOLDS KEY REBEL
description: A guerrilla leader who is second in command in the Salvadoran Communist Party has been arrested and is being held for trial by a military court, a spokesman for the army said today.

title: EIL INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 6, 1985
description: Companies

title: Tougher Sanctions
description: Otto Jelinek, Canada's Minister of Sports, announced a program of stepped-up drug tests for athletes and stiff sanctions for those caught using banned drugs.

title: Fortune Quartet
description: The alto saxophonist Sonny Fortune is leading a quartet tonight and tomorrow at the Angry Squire, 216 Seventh Avenue below 23d Street (242-9066). Sets begin at 10 and 11:15 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $6 cover and a two-drink minumum.

title: German Study Of 'Star Wars'
description: A delegation of West German Government officials, business executives and scientists began a 10-day study of the American space weapons market today with briefings at the Pentagon.

title: A GLIMPSE OF THE FUTURE ON AVANT-GARDE STAGES
description: EACH fall, New York's performing arts season is like a giant engine whose motors rev up slowly but steadily toward the overdrive of mid-October. But in the world of experimental performance, the fall season has already begun in half a dozen of the important seeding grounds for fresh talent and new ideas. Given the post-Labor Day doldrums of New York's uptown culture, this weekend is an ideal time for esthetic adventurers to take a peek at what's happening in the avant-garde. In doing so, they may get a glimpse of the future.

title: New York State Cars Are Testing Air Bags
description: To the Editor:

title: E.P.A. PROPOSES ADDITION OF 38 TOXIC WASTE SITES TO CLEANUP LIST
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today proposed to add 38 more toxic waste sites to its ''national priority list'' requiring expedited cleanup because of the dangers they posed to public health and the environment.

title: SAGE LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bombeck Is Parade Chief
description: The humorist Erma Bombeck has been named grand marshal of the 1986 Rose Parade.

title: 2 RANDOLPH HOMERS POWER YANKS
description: With 10 seasons of major league baseball behind him, Willie Randolph has been around long enough to know that one good game - especially as a Yankee - is hardly cause for a celebration.

title: Giants' Offense a New Threat
description: It had been the Giants' cult image: the team with the esteemed defense that pushes wearily along, always encumbered by that offense. For fans there was almost something romantic about the notion, that their team was sturdy, not fancy, and opponents saw the Giants as a menacing underdog. But there always was that offense. Life with the Giants would have been perfect if they didn't need an offense.

title: ARROW AUTOMOTIVE INDUSRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
Pacific Telesis Offering
description: Pacific Telesis Group said it planned to issue up to six million common shares in a public offering. It expects to file a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission next week. The company has 101 million shares outstanding.

title: MODEST TESTIMONIAL FOR CREME DE LA FETE
description: John Henry, who was retired last month with 39 victories and $6.5 million in earnings, was honored last week with a black-tie dinner for 600 at the Kentucky Horse Park in Lexington, his new home. Creme de la Fete, who is being retired with 40 victories but less than 10 percent as high a bankroll, will be honored at Belmont Park Saturday before heading to the state penitentiary at Walkill.

title: TEST FOR SOUTH AFRICAN BLACK LABOR
description: Minutes before members of the National Union of Mine Workers went on strike against three mining companies last Sunday, the union's general secretary said he expected employers to flex the almost absolute power they wield over the workers and quickly cripple the work stoppage.

title: Carbide Names Lawyer To New Safety Position
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, in an apparent attempt to bolster public confidence in the wake of its recent safety troubles, said yesterday that it had created the new post of vice president in charge of community and employee health, safety and environment and had named a senior company lawyer to fill it.

title: Dole Issues Trade Warning
description: The Senate Majority Leader, Bob Dole, said today that the United States can no longer be ''the world's only free trader, any more than we can unilaterally disarm.''

title: HAPPY RETURN FOR EAST RIVER FERRY SERVICE
description: On board were 20 refugees from the subways, most of whom said this was one trip they wished had lasted just a little longer.

title: CANDIDATES TRADE BARBS AT LAST MAYORAL DEBATE
description: Mayor Koch, alternately lecturing and quipping, defended himself yesterday against charges that he had divided the city, and asserted that he ''appealed to every single person.''

title: ALEXANDER 2-HITTER GIVES JAYS VICTORY
description: Doyle Alexander pitched a two-hitter, and Lloyd Moseby hit a home run and drove in three runs tonight to lead the Toronto Blue Jays to a 7-0 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

title: GUIDELINES FOR DONATED BLOOD TIGHTENED AS AN AIDS GUARD
description: In revised guidelines intended to eliminate from the blood supply the virus that causes AIDS, Federal health officials recommended today that any man who has had sexual relations with another man even once in the last eight years refrain from donating blood.

title: What We Know From Biomedical Research With Animals
description: To the Editor:

title: George O'Brien, 86, Is Dead; Hollywood Western Film Star
description: George O'Brien, who acted in 75 films, including the westerns ''Fort Apache'' and John Ford's ''Iron Horse,'' died in a convalescent home Wednesday. He was 86 years old.

title: BONANNO LED CRIME GROUP
description: Until Joseph Bonanno fled to Canada in 1957, he had led one of New York City's five major organized-crime groups.

title: EFFECT OF NASSAU VERDICT IS DEBATED BY POLITICIANS
description: A day after a Federal jury found that the Nassau County Republican Party illegally forced government workers to contribute to the party to get promotions and raises, politicians in both parties disagreed on how much the verdict would harm Republicans.

title: Lloyd's Cites Record Loss
description: The Lloyd's insurance market said today that its underwriters suffered their worst loss in nearly three centuries in 1982 and warned that it might have to withdraw from the American insurance market unless there was a reform of United States liability law.

title: Three Mile Island Study Finds No Cancer Rise
description: A survey of residents living near Three Mile Island found no evidence of increased cancer as a result of the nuclear plant's 1979 accident, the state Health Department said today.

title: Herr Talks on Testing
description: Tommy Herr, the player representative of the St. Louis Cardinals, said yesterday that many major league baseball players are ''tired of protecting drug users'' and may eventually consent to drug testing.

title: Floor Plan
description: With new coaches come new ideas, but not frequently redecoration.

title: Top Yield of 9.197% Set On California Offering
description: A $248 million issue of California Department of Veterans Affairs home purchase revenue bonds was offered yesterday through underwriters led by L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin with a maximum yield of 9.197 percent for 9 1/8 percent bonds due in 2011 at a price of 99 1/4.

title: STUARTS DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug. 3
ARGONAUT ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REAGAN AND AIDES REVIEW POLICY ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: President Reagan met with his top advisers today to discuss how the United States could use its influence to end the violence in South Africa and bring about talks between the Government and prominent black leaders, Administration officials said.

title: HOFSTRA STRIKE ENDS AS UNION APPROVES PACT
description: Hofstra University and its striking faculty members agreed on a new contract yesterday, ending a five-day walkout that disrupted the start of classes for 11,500 students.

title: 'Small Wonder' a Sitcom About a Robot-Child
description: Chilling as the thought may be, it seems conceivable that if Carlo Collodi were alive today, he would create not the immortal ''Pinocchio'' but the sort of assembly-line sitcom series that makes its debut tomorrow from 6:30 P.M. to 7 P.M. on Channel 5.

title: AMERICAN STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to August 3
BEST PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to August 3
description: Results for the latest periods reflect a change in the company's method of accounting for certain vendor allowances.

title: Designer Films
description: The Queens Museum has scheduled a series of seven films on 20th-century design and architecture for this month.

title: DEBT AID PLEDGED BY SOUTH AFRICA
description: Acting to defuse a financial crisis that threatened its ability to engage in world trade, South Africa said yesterday that it would stand behind the international debts of all of its banks.

title: A Simple Burglary'
description: A former Police Commissioner's apartment was broken into. The police arrested a suspect and recovered most of the stolen property.

title: BANNER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $300,000 for the quarter and the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $200,000 for the quarter and the year and pretax losses of $90,099 for the quarter and $482,125 for the year on an equity investment in an affiliate.

title: Police in Mexico Break Up Demonstration by Students
description: The police used tear gas to disperse demonstrators outside the Autonomous University of Chihuahua, where the office of the rector remained occupied today by about 3,000 students demanding his resignation.

title: CLUES ARE FOUND IN JAPAN AIR CRASH
description: Investigators looking into the crash of a Japan Air Lines Boeing 747 last month have found evidence of improper rear-cabin repairs that could have led to the disaster, according to authorities involved in the inquiry.

title: Preventing Debt Disaster
description: THE huge expansion of private debt of recent years poses a threat to the financial health of major sectors of the American economy.

title: Indian Artistry
description: In celebration of the Festival of India, the Asia Society's performing arts department is offering a series of workshops on five forms of traditional Indian dance this season.

title: 4 COMPANIES BOMBED IN PARIS
description: Four bombs exploded here early today, wounding three people slightly and causing extensive damage at four companies with business interests in South Africa.

title: CARDIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $406,200, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and $940,500 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $117,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $430,600 for the 9 months.

title: You Call That a Recovery?
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNORS AND LENDL GAIN SEMIFINALS
description: It appears that order has been restored and men's tennis is back on serve. After a Wimbledon marked by upsets and dominated by the emergence of the child star Boris Becker, the four top seeded players have advanced to the semifinals of the United States Open. That means Jimmy Connors is still around and that seems only right too.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: PETITIONS ASK VOTE ON S.I. NAVY BASE
description: Opponents of a proposed Navy base on Staten Island presented the City Clerk yesterday with enough petition signatures to place a referendum about the issue on the citywide ballot in November.

title: NOW CHIEF DESCRIBES PLANS TO FIGHT 'FASCISTS AND BIGOTS'
description: Eleanor Smeal, president of the National Organization for Women, outlined plans today for a militant new campaign on such issues as abortion, equal pay and the proposed Federal equal rights amendment.

title: Lever Traded
description: Don Lever, a 32-year-old forward who scored 10 goals and had 8 assists in 67 games with the Devils last season, was traded to the Buffalo Sabres for future considerations.

title: Taiwan Rejects Appeals Of Journalist's Killers
description: The Supreme Court today rejected the appeals of two reputed gangsters sentenced to life imprisonment after being convicted of killing a Chinese-American journalist in California last year.

title: Stocks Off; Volume Improves
description: The stock market retreated for the fourth consecutive session yesterday, but the selloff was less severe than in recent sessions and trading volume improved.

title: Required Reading;   On Domestic Terrorism
description: Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana, chairman of the House intelligence committee, writing in his Aug. 14 newsletter to constitutents:

title: Times Mirror Unit Is Selling 6 Mills
description: The Times Mirror Company said that the Publishers Paper Company, its newsprint and forest-products subsidiary, is seeking a buyer for four sawmills and two particleboard mills in Oregon. The company, which broke off discussions with the Boise Cascade Corporation for the sale of its newsprint and forest-products facilities in March, is also considering the sale of its 272,000 acres of timberland in Washington and Oregon.

title: AMBRIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
AUCTIONS
description: WHEN Christie's auctioned the contents of the Duke of Buckingham's home at Stowe in 1848, the sale lasted 40 days and caused a flurry of activity described by The Times of London as ''a cavalcade which was daily making its way to the magnificent Palladian facade.''

title: All the President's Cookies
description: President Reagan got his cookies a little confused in North Carolina yesterday. He was exploring with a North Carolina State University audience in Raleigh one of his favorite themes: the romance of growing rich through entrepreneurial enterprise.

title: Ohlmeyer Gets Another Entertainment Account
description: Ohlmeyer Advertising seems to be on a roll as far as winning accounts with entertainment orientations.

title: POP: TEXAS TRIO AT THE BALLROOM
description: MONTGOMERY, PLANT & STRITCH, a versatile harmony trio from Houston, bring a cool and assured vocal technique to an unusually wide-ranging pop repertory. The group, which is appearing at the Ballroom Theater (253 West 28th Street), Wednesdays through Saturdays, has refined an impeccably smooth vocal blend that suggests a much less adventurous echo of the Manhattan Transfer.

title: Fifth Ave. Gas Wars
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress;   Handling the Hot Potato of Reagan's Popularity
description: As President Reagan and members of Congress returned to the capital this week from their summer holidays, they offered strikingly different views of the months ahead.

title: Still Fighting Voting Rights
description: President Reagan, who won by a landslide in 1980 and 1984, lost another kind of voting battle by another kind of landslide in 1982. That's when Congress, despite his opposition, voted overwhelmingly to strengthen the Voting Rights Act. The votes, 389 to 24 in the House and 85 to 8 in the Senate, so buried the opposition that Mr. Reagan reluctantly signed the bill rather than have his veto overridden. Now the Administration seeks to win in the Supreme Court what it lost in Congress. In a case from North Carolina, it has asked the justices to interpret the law in precisely the ways Congress rejected so resoundingly.

title: Taking Up Space
description: Sam Wyche, coach of the Cincinnati Bengals, has accused Chuck Knox, coach of the Seattle Seahawks, of sending a spy to the Bengals' final exhibition game to steal the sideline signals the Bengals use to communicate with their quarterbacks. ''I've never heard of anybody doing that,'' said Wyche, who acknowledged that teams try to figure out each other's signals during a game.

title: ISRAELI IS STABBED IN GAZE, HEIGHTENING CONFLICT IN OCCUPIED AREAS
description: The conflict between Arabs and Israelis in the occupied territories intensified today with the stabbing and serious wounding of another Israeli, this time in the Gaza Strip.

title: New York Broadsides
description: ''To the Publick: New York in Broadside,'' an exhibition of 18th- and 19th-century public notices, opens today at the New-York Historical Society.

title: DOG SHOW IN JERSEY
description: That hot sultry part of the summmer called the dog days, when Sirius, the Dog Star, rises with the sun, is over. But the real dog days will be here this weekend. On Sunday, 2,807 canine stars will be seen at Lyndhurst, the national landmark on a promontory overlooking the Hudson, on Route 9, in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: HOMOSEXUAL RIGHTS REJECTED
description: The Providence City Council, after days of community debate that deeply divided religious leaders, refused tonight to ban discrimination against homosexuals .

title: DEFUNCT SATELLITE IS IDENTIFIED AS TARGET FOR WEAPON TEST
description: The Air Force has apparently settled on a six-year-old military research satellite called Solwind as the first target for a new American anti-satellite weapon, according to a private analyst.

title: UNIVERSAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DEBT REPAYMENT PLAN FILED BY CONTINENTAL AIR
description: Continental Airlines filed a reorganization plan today with the United States Bankruptcy Court here under which it will repay $897.1 million in debt to about 20 creditor groups.

title: Hurricane Caused Loss For 25,000 Families
description: Food, shelter and water remained scarce today on the Gulf Coast, with the authorities estimating that more than 25,000 families in Mississippi, Florida and Alabama suffered property losses from Hurricane Elena.

title: BBC Lifts Ban on Film On Northern Ireland
description: A banned television documentary on Northern Ireland has been revised and will be shown next month, the British Broadcasting Corporation announced today.

title: Stop Kahane Now
description: For all his notoriety, Rabbi Meir Kahane does not represent a threat to Israeli democracy. Nor is there any prospect of his ever coming to power. Nonetheless, Rabbi Kahane's movement - dedicated to the expulsion of Israel's Arabs and the imposition of religious fundamentalism - is a disturbing force that feeds off the anxieties of a beleaguered people. Israel has awakened, however belatedly, to the danger of Kahanism. The United States, and particularly American Jewry, also have an important stake in seeing this militant fanaticism halted.

title: U.S. Steel to Buy Its Pollution Bonds
description: The United States Steel Corporation plans to purchase more than $200 million of face amount tax-exempt pollution-control revenue bonds issued on its behalf by the Allegheny County Industrial Development Authority between 1973 and 1979. It will make the purchase from investors, it announced earlier this week.

title: Military Injustice In the Dreyfus Affair
description: To the Editor:

title: Fuel Projects' Aid Delayed
description: The embattled Synthetic Fuels Corporation has agreed to delay $774 million in Federal subsidies to three synthetic fuels projects until President Reagan decides whether he wants the agency abolished, Administration sources said today.

title: DECLINE AND FALL OF MUSSOLINI DEPICTED ON HBO
description: TELEVISION has had its spate of Hitler docudramas, including ''The Bunker,'' with Anthony Hopkins as Nazi Germany's Fuhrer. Now attention seems to be drifting toward Italy's Mussolini, who is the subject of a three-and-a-half-hour drama beginning on Home Box Office this Sunday at 8 P.M. and concluding on Monday. The pay-cable channel's ''Mussolini: The Decline and Fall of Il Duce'' stars Bob Hoskins in the title role, Susan Sarandon as Mussolini's independent-minded daughter Edda, and the peripatetic Mr. Hopkins as her husband, Count Galeazzo Ciano.

title: Hazards for Soviet Personnel in the U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Nixon and Chinese Meet
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon met today with Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang and with the Communist Party General Secretary, Hu Yaobang, during a private visit.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Angeles Corp., Los Angeles, an investment management company, has named S. Ross Gentry 3d first vice president and director of the commercial properties division of Angeles Real Estate Management Co., a subsidiary.

title: Stores in 14 States Urged To End Sale of Tainted Fish
description: Food stores in 14 states have been asked to take a salted fish product, kapchunka, off their shelves after it was implicated in the botulism deaths of a New York couple.

title: Trade, Japan And the Year 2000
description: There are no short-run solutions to the economic problems that are affecting the relations between Japan and the United States. Both countries seem to agree that two-thirds of the enormous American trade deficit is caused by the overvalued dollar. But the remainder of the deficit still represents $15 billion, and this chronic imbalance is likely to grow larger in the future.

title: Landmark Sold
description: Landmarks have been razed, gutted and altered beyond recognition. But rarely before, if ever, have they been sold by a city employee and simply carted away.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Tap on 34th Street
description: A chorus line, possibly the longest ever, will tap its way along 34th Street, from Seventh Avenue to Broadway, to the tunes of ''You're a Grand Old Flag'' and ''Give My Regards to Broadway,'' in Macy's ''Tap-O-Mania'' on Sunday, beginning at noon. Last year's lineup, which included 3,450 amateurs and professionals, will be noted in the 1986 Guinness Book of World Records.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: JUST how far Italian cuisine has come in this country in recent years is evident from the menu at Trastevere, a Roman-style sliver of a restaurant on the Upper East Side that received plaudits four years ago as a leader in its field. It is owned by the energetic Lattanzi family, which has since expanded its domain to include another restaurant a block away, Trastevere 84, as well as Erminia's on East 83d Street and Lattanzi on West 46th Street. Dining at the original Trastevere is like watching the late show on television - there is nothing new or surprising on the schedule, but some of the oldies are as enjoyable as ever.
