title: CHECK TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: BEETHOVEN FESTIVAL UNDER THE TREES
description: Beethoven will flower this weekend among the trees and shrubs of the Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay, L.I., where more than 100 instrumentalists will offer concertos, sonatas, lectures and a master class as part of the sixth annual Friends of the Arts Beethoven Festival.

title: Interest Rates Rise Modestly
description: Short- and long-term interest rates rose modestly yesterday, with traders concerned that a spate of stronger economic statistics, combined with weak investor demand for notes and bonds, could point toward higher interest rates in the future.

title: Diner's Journal
description: AMSTERDAM'S Bar and Rotisserie, the hip Upper West Side dining and drinking spot that has elevated grilled chicken to near-cult status, has opened a branch at 454 Broadway, between Grand and Howard Streets. The new, larger establishment has a clean, almost stark design with a high black-painted ceiling, whitewashed brick walls, a bar as long as a bowling lane, a raised dining room in the back and an exposed kitchen containing two huge vertical rotisseries.

title: Panel Delays Tax Meetings
description: The House Ways and Means Committee has decided to delay for a week the start of meetings to draft tax legislation so it can hold a hearing on trade issues Sept. 17, a committee spokesman said today. The tax meetings are now scheduled to begin the week of Sept. 23, he said, and will probably last three or four weeks.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL YANKEES (AL) - Recalled Mike Armstrong and Jim Deshaies, pitchers, from Columbus of the International League.

title: ROBERT McCORMICK
description: Robert McCormick, an NBC news reporter and analyst for 34 years, died of a heart attack Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 74 years old and lived in Tarpon Springs, Fla.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S TRADE EXPECTED TO FACE OBSTACLES
description: South Africa's ability to trade with other nations may be hampered by concern among international bankers about the country's prospects, bankers and economists said yesterday.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alltel Corp., Hudson, Ohio, said a unit, Alltel Mobile Communications of Ohio Inc., had agreed to acquire MCI Communications Corp.'s MCI Airsignal Inc., a northern Ohio radio paging system. Terms were not disclosed.

title: PEKING APPOINTS 5 YOUNGER MINISTERS
description: China replaced its heads of police and state security today in a Government shuffle that brought younger people to five ministries.

title:
PATENTS;

SELF-CONTAINED RADIO FITS INTO EAR CANAL
description: A self-contained radio that fits entirely in the ear canal was patented this week for the American Technology Corporation, Salt Lake City.

title: CANADIAN PANEL URGES FREER TRADE WITH U.S.
description: Canada's Conservative Government, already leaning toward a sweeping accord for free trade with the United States, has been given one last push as the time nears for a crucial decision on the issue.

title: LASERS FOR MEDICINE reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: Year-ago results include the period from the company's inception on June 20, 1983 until May 31, 1984.

title: VISIONTECH reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
STRAIN ON BUDGET SEEN IN NAVY PLAN
description: The Navy's ambition to have a 600-ship fighting fleet is on a collision course with the Pentagon's latest budget plans, according to testimony today before a House subcommittee.

title: Muncie Is Suspended
description: Chuck Muncie, the Minnesota Viking running back who was reinstated in July after a one-year suspension for drug problems, has been suspended for the season opener against the San Francisco 49ers because he missed two therapy sessions, according to Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League. . . . Another Viking with a drug-related difficulty is Tim Newton, a rookie nose tackle. He was ticketed on a petty-misdemeanor charge of marijuana possession Thursday night in Minneapolis. Newton had been expected to start tomorrow in the team's opener against the San Francisco 49ers, but now his status is unclear.

title: Justice John Hill, 96, Believer in Discipline
description: Justice John Warren Hill, the presiding justice of the New York Domestic Relations Court from 1934 to 1959, died Thursday at the Noble Horizons extended-care facility in Salisbury, Conn. He was 96 years old.

title: HEART PATIENT RECOVERS FROM EFFECTS OF STROKES f813>
description: Most of the effects of the strokes that the latest artificial heart patient suffered Thursday ''disappeared'' today, according to his doctors, who continued their urgent search for a human heart.

title: WESTERN HEALTH PLANS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,206,000 for the latest 4th quarter and $1,055,000 for the year-ago.

title: MARINA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ENGINEERED SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
COMMISSIONER IS SILENT
description: Baseball Commissioner Peter Ueberroth is ''monitoring'' the Pittsburgh trial of a man accused of selling cocaine to major league players, his office said yesterday, but will not comment on whether any actions will be taken against the players involved.

title: Rostenkowski Meets Executives on Taxes
description: A group of the nation's elite corporate leaders, including the heads of I.B.M., General Motors and R. J. Reynolds, flew to the Chicago area today to meet with Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, to discuss the status of tax revision and to convey their views.

title: Back in the Picture
description: Back in June, Ken Norton Jr., the son of the former heavyweight boxing champion and a reserve linebacker at U.C.L.A., posed with his father and other family members for a department store Father's Day advertisement.

title: INDIA ARRESTS 400 SIKHS IN PRE-ELECTION MOVE
description: The police have arrested at least 400 Sikhs in an effort to avert a threatened disruption of elections set for Sept. 25 in Punjab State, officials said today.

title:
SCOUTING;

Painful
description: When Russ Francis of the San Francisco 49ers pleaded an upset stomach in explaining why he missed Thursday's practice, Coach Bill Walsh found an apt reason for not disclosing whether Francis would be fined: ''It's an internal matter.''

title: MANDLIKOVA BEATS LLOYD IN U.S.. OPEN UPSET
description: When the United States Open began 11 days ago, it was a almost a foregone conclusion that Chris Evert Lloyd and Martina Navratilova - the top-seeded players - would meet in the final, renewing a fierce rivalry.

title: CHILDREN, POOR AND GETTING POORER
description: Children, Poor and Getting Poorer Good news is good news, and the Census Bureau report that poverty decreased last year prompted Reagan Administration spokesmen to hail a great triumph. It's true that poverty is down, primarily because of the economic recovery over which Mr. Reagan has presided. But that's not the only news here. A longer look at the census report produces three conclusions, none triumphant:

title: 2 BOYS AT PASSAIC BLAZE ORDERED TO STAND TRIAL
description: The multimillion-dollar factory fire in Passaic on Labor Day started in a stockpile of naphthalene, and the two boys charged with arson have blamed each other for starting the blaze, two detectives testified today.

title: Odds Against Jimmy Connors
description: Can Jimmy Connors really beat Ivan Lendl today and advance to the final at the United States Open? His New York idolaters may cry yes, but his past performance responds with a loud no.

title: LEGAL ISSUES ARE RAISED BY TITANIC
description: The discovery of the dusky hulk of the steamship Titanic 13,000 feet deep in the north Atlantic has put a glitter in the eyes of assorted adventurers and at least one insurance company. It has also raised a host of thorny legal issues and disputes about both the technological feasibility of recovering objects from the hulk and the morality of trying to do so.

title: First Mutual Bid By Pierce Group
description: The First Mutual Savings Association of Florida said it had entered into an agreement to be acquired by Pierce Group Inc. of Knoxville, Tenn., for $38.50 a share, or about $41.5 million.

title: HEAD OF PLANT THAT LEAKED GASES SAYS CARBIDE IS TRANSFERRING HIM
description: The manager of the Union Carbide Corporation plant in Institute, W.Va., that leaked a mixture of poison gases Aug. 11, sending 135 people to area hospitals, said today that he was being transferred.

title: CLABIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: MONTREAL CITY & DISTRICT SAVNGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
2 MORE TO TIE
description: Four thousand one hundred eighty-eight . . . four thousand one hundred eighty-nine . . . Two steps closer. Three to go. Pete Rose slugged two hits this afternoon at Wrigley Field to come within two of tying and three of breaking Ty Cobb's record of 4,191 base hits. Rose went 2 for 5, striking out twice and grounding out to third.

title: Could Have Been
description: In case you were wondering:

title: U S MINERALS EXPLORATION COMPANY reports earnings for Year to May 31
SATELLITE SET TO CROSS COMET'S TAIL WEDNESDAY
description: After seven years as a lonely scientific sentinel in space, an American spacecraft, redirected from another mission, is fast approaching a small comet and is to fly through its luminous tail next week for the first probe of one of these mysterious wanderers of the solar system.

title: WELLCO ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Year to June 29
description: b-Including a tax credit of $540,000. c-Net loss after a pretax charge of $1,703,000 for the divestiture of certain operations.

title: Emhart Tool Deal
description: The Emhart Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to buy Allegheny International Inc.'s True Temper line of non-powered lawn and garden products, striking tools and gold club shafts.

title: PAYMENT IN JAPAN CRASH
description: Japan Air Lines said today that it had reached the first compensation settlement in the world's worst single-aircraft accident, agreeing to pay an undisclosed sum to the family of an Indian couple who were among the 520 people killed. Aviation and insurance industry experts have said compensation is likely to be about $400,000 per passenger.

title: YANKEE COS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a credit of $298,000. Year-ago results include the operations of Yankee Bank for Finance & Savings FSB for June 1984.

title: Royals Win Pair, Move Into First
description: The Kansas City Royals moved into first place in the American League West tonight after defeating the Milwaukee Brewers in a doubleheader, 4-3 and 7-1.

title: MORE BLIMPS GO TO MARKETING
description: As Goodyear's giant blue and silver blimp drifts serenely and confidently above Manhattan, a red and silver challenger, sporting McDonald's ubiquitous golden arches, suddenly darts into sight and playfully dogs its tail.

title: NAKASONE IS DEALT SETBACK ON ARMS SPENDING
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone suffered a major political defeat today when he failed to convince his governing party that Japan should abandon a self-imposed restriction on military spending.

title: ISRAELIS RATE 'SECURITY ZONE' IN LEBANON A SUCCESS
description: When Israel established its ''security zone'' in southern Lebanon three months ago, many Israeli policy makers were dubious about how long it could be maintained.

title: CONRAIL'S UNCERTAIN FUTURE
description: An argument increasingly heard these days is that the Consolidated Rail Corporation, because it is now making money, should be publicly owned. The outlook for the Government-operated railroad, regrettably, is not rosy. According to some analyses, Conrail's ability to be self-sustaining in the private sector is questionable.

title: MR. REAGAN REGRETS
description: For confessing political error, no one has improved on New York's former Mayor La Guardia: ''When I make a mistake, it's a beaut.'' In the same spirit, if less colorfully, President Reagan says he's sorry he carelessly gave the impression that South Africa had eliminated racial segregation. He explains that he was not ill informed and meant only to say in a radio interview that ''great improvements'' have been made by the white regime.

title: MCA Stock Up on Rumors
description: Stock in MCA Inc., the entertainment company that owns Universal Pictures, soared $6.75 a share yesterday, to $70.50, on rumors of a pending deal with the RCA Corporation.

title: Cuts at Timken
description: The Timken Company said nearly 70 percent of the 340 salaried workers who were offered early retirement as part of a budget-cutting move had accepted the offer. Timken has said it wants to reduce the number of salaried positions by 500.

title: Gastineau, With Cast, Will Play
description: Mark Gastineau's voice was trembling with determination today after he checked himself out of the hospital with his reinjured broken thumb, worked out briefly and announced that he would see spot duty against the Raiders in the Jets' season opener Sunday in Los Angeles.

title: JEWELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $26,000 for the quarter and $281,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $204,000 for the quarter and $857,000 for the 6 months.

title: CERTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: BOND PRICES SLUMP ON JOBLESS DATA MICHAEL QUINT
description: Treasury bond yields rose by nearly a quarter of a percentage point yesterday as a batch of strong economic statistics and reports that Japanese institutions might reduce their bond purchases led to a wave of selling by traders and investors.

title: NO EFFORT TOMAKE SGT. YORK TESTS LOOK GOOD
description: To the Editor:

title: SHULTZ SAYS ARMS SALE TO JORDANIANS IS NEEDED
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that there was ''a definite need'' for the sale of advanced American arms to Jordan even though his aides said such a deal would lead to a confrontation with Congress.

title: 3 CHILDREN DIE IN NEWARK FIRE
description: Three children were killed and four adults were injured, three of them critically, in a fire early today at a three-story frame building here, fire officials said.

title: HERMANN WEIGAND, A PROFESSOR AT YALE IN GERMANIC STUDIES
description: Hermann J. Weigand, an internationally renowned scholar and critic of German literature, died Tuesday at the Branford Hills Convalescent Center in Branford, Conn. He was 92 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: 'Sky Music'
description: With a red flag rather than a baton giving the downbeat, Tom O'Horgan's ''Sky Music'' whirred into action in Union Square yesterday played by five musical groups -some on the roofs of surrounding buildings.

title: WHY INUIT SHOULD NOT BNE CALLED ESKIMO
description: To the Editor:

title: I.R.S.'s Rules On Retirement
description: THE new Internal Revenue Service regulations on the Retirement Equity Act include a couple of major surprises that will affect workers both before and after retirement.

title: THE RUSSIANS ARE COMING
description: In Moscow a group of visiting officials is called a ''delegatsiya'' and is accorded V.I.P. treatment, as was the case when the Speaker of the United States House of Representatives, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., led a group of lawmakers to the Soviet capital last spring.

title: Wang Labs Fills Post
description: Wang Laboratories said yesterday that J. Carl Masi had been named executive vice president, worldwide sales and marketing. Mr. Masi, who is 44 years old, had been senior vice president at Wang.

title: O-T-C Broker Is Suspended
description: Blinder, Robinson & Company, the largest over-the-counter penny stock brokerage in the Middle West, was suspended today from participating in any underwritings for two years for violating securities laws.

title: FAY'S DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Rutgers Hires Coach
description: Craig Littlepage, University of Pennsylvania basketball coach, was named the new Rutgers coach yesterday.

title: Dolphins Sign Clayton
description: Mark Clayton, the Miami Dolphins' wide receiver, signed a new contract that will reportedly bring him $1.4 million over four years. Clayton, who caught 73 passes last season for 1,389 yards and a record 18 touchdowns, had been promised a re-negotiated contract during the offseason. Negotiations lagged, however, until Dan Marino, the Dolphin quarterback, ended his holdout.

title:
PATENTS;

AUTOMATED TUTORING BY PHONE
description: A TUTORING system to be operated by telephone and automated equipment was patented this week. It was designed as a study tool for professionals continuing their education.

title: MATTINGLY HOMER PROPELS YANKEES
description: The Yankees, who seemed lately to find a new way to win every time out, benefited from a tried and true formula last night: Don Mattingly's bat.

title: FATHERS AND SONS
description: MIDAIR. By Frank Conroy. 149 pages. E.P. Dutton. $15.95. Published in 1967 when he was 31, Frank Conroy's ''Stop-Time'' remains one of the finest contemporary memoirs of boyhood and adolescence - a memoir so shapely and piercing in its candor that it reads more like a novel than a work of reminiscence.

title: GIVE A PREMARITAL BLOOD TEST FOR CHOLESTEROL
description: To the Editor:

title: FLORIDA CONGRESSMAN TO MAKE SHUTTLE FLIGHT
description: Representative Bill Nelson, a Florida Democrat who is chairman of a House subcommittee on space science, was invited by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration today to be the next Congressional passenger on the space shuttle.

title: SCHEIB, EARL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I may have been careless in my language in that one thing, but I was talking about improvements that actually do exist there and have been made.

title: Walton Is Traded
description: The long-awaited trade of the center Bill Walton from the Los Angeles Clippers to the Boston Celtics for Cedric Maxwell became a reality yesterday.

title: SHOREHAM SHUT DOWN BY AN INCORRECT SIGNAL
description: The Shoreham nuclear power plant shut down automatically yesterday when a warning signal incorrectly reported that the reactor's water levels had dropped, a spokesman for the Long Island Lighting Company said.

title: RATING REAGAN ON LAW AND ORDER
description: Like most others involved in law enforcement, Mark A. Cunniff cheered the election of Ronald Reagan. Mr. Reagan's law-and-order oratory gave heart to those whose law-enforcement budgets had been steadily eroded.

title: ALBANY G.O.P. FIGURE URGES ANTI-APARTHEID STAND
description: President Reagan should support anti-apartheid legislation both to protest a ''reprehensible'' system and to head off pressure on local governments to dabble in foreign policy, the New York State Comptroller said yesterday.

title: WITNESS TO HONDURAN RAID REBUTS ACCOUNT OF OFFICIALS
description: An international relief worker who says she was the only outside witness to a Honduran Army raid on a Salvadoran refugee camp last week has given an account of the incident that contradicts that offered by the Honduran Government and by the United States Embassy here.

title: 3 MAYORAL RIVALS BEGIN A FINAL WEEKEND DRIVE
description: A heavy front of mayoral politics moved through New York City yesterday: Mayor Koch lectured Manhattan high school students; Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr. spoke to a group of elderly people in Queens; City Council President Carol Bellamy wooed subway riders and Hispanic voters.

title: Mets Careful Not to Judge
description: The Mets' front office did not offer a judgment on Keith Hernandez's admission of cocaine use today, but the first baseman received support in his team's clubhouse.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. 1. The Gulfport, Miss., Holiday Inn had some unusual guests among those forced to flee the coast as a result of Hurricane Elena. Who were they? 2. In response to a recent announcement, Prince Sihanouk said they ''are my allies, so in my official capacity I must believe them,'' adding, ''But, if you ask me for my personal opinion, I would say that it is better not to believe what they say.'' To what was he referring? 3. The Reagan Administration has developed new rules for enforcing the Voting Rights Act. What is their major thrust? 4. A fire in Passaic, N.J., that left 400 people homeless and destroyed a 40-acre industrial complex also proved devastating to a New York City institution. What happened? 5. An eagerly awaited match at the United States Open tennis tournament never took place because of the exploits of Joakim Nystrom. What did he do? 6. French and American scientists have located the wreckage of the Titanic. After further studies by submarine, what do they propose be done with it? 7. As a result of Griffin B. Bell's investigation of E. F. Hutton's bank overdrafting scheme, two top officials have resigned and one will take early retirement. How many other executives were cited in the report? Was the brokerage concern's chairman, Robert Foman, among them? 8. Hughes Aircraft has received an $8.5 million bill from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: De Havilland Talks
description: Officials of the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation confirmed that their respective companies were discussing the possible acquisition of the ailing De Havilland Aircraft of Canada Ltd. De Havilland officials were said to be unavailable for comment. But Paul Marshall, president and chief executive of the Canada Development Investment Corporation, the Government agency that owns De Havilland, has said that talks with a number of companies were in early stages.

title: GIVE OIL PRODUCERS A BREAK
description: The domestic oil and gas business is the industry Americans love to hate. In the public imagination, the oil business is the quintessential special interest, its ''depletion allowance'' the ultimate loophole. As Congress takes up the Treasury Department's tax reform proposal in earnest, it will be all too tempting to abolish what is left of these tax incentives in favor of more populist concessions. Such temptations must be resisted.

title: Head Start
description: Coach Joe Gibbs of the Washington Redskins announces that John Riggins, and not George Rogers, will start at running back Monday night against Dallas: ''It's no big deal. They will both play enough to have their tongues hanging out. But John's tongue will be hanging out first.''

title: DR. KONSTANTIN D. FRANK, 86, NEW YORK STATE WINEMAKER
description: Dr. Konstantin D. Frank, a New York State winemaker who proved to skeptical colleagues that Europe's finest vinifera grapes could thrive in the rigorous Northeast climate, died yesterday at the Ira Davenport Hospital in Bath, N.Y., at the age of 86. He had suffered a stroke a week ago.

title:
PATENTS;

CHAIR FOR HANDICAPPED AIDS SITTING AND RISING
description: Nat Levenberg, a Brooklyn business executive, was granted a patent this week on a chair for handicapped persons, for which he was honored at the 1984 Worldwide Inventors Exposition held in New York.

title: IN CALIFORNIA, MONEY TALKS - AND IT SAYS GOODBYE
description: National economic problems and tense international situations motivate Californians in unusual ways. Their latest motto is ''When the going gets tough, the tough go shopping.''

title: REAGAN APOLOGIZES FOR ASSERTING THAT PRETORIA SEGREGATION IS OVER
description: President Reagan said today he was sorry that he ''carelessly gave the impression'' last month that racial segregation had been eliminated in public places in South Africa.

title: OPTIMISM ON FREEZE
description: To the Editor:

title: A.T.&T. Disputes Atari Tie Report
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it was not likely to sell the Atari Corporation's new ST personal computer, although it had looked at the machine.

title: OFFICER SWORE POLICE DID NOT ABUSE STEWART
description: John Kostick, the transit police officer who arrested Michael Stewart for writing graffiti in a Manhattan subway station in September 1983, told a grand jury in 1984 that neither he nor his fellow officers had abused Mr. Stewart physically.

title: DARPOV HOLDS ON TO GAIN DRAW IN 2d GAME
description: Dogged defense by Anatoly Karpov enabled him to hold a draw in the second game of the world chess championship against his challenger, Gary Kasparov, in Moscow's Tchaikovsky Concert Hall yesterday.

title: SECURITIES FIRMS IN DEAL FOR BROKER
description: Salomon Brothers announced yesterday that it was leading a group of securities dealers in a joint venture to buy PGB Securities, a small broker of Treasury securities, for undisclosed terms.

title: Draft Resister to Be Freed
description: A convicted draft resister is to be released on parole Sept. 20 from the Federal prison in Lompoc, Calif. The man, Benjamin Sasway, who is 24 years old, has served four months of a 30-month sentence. He was convicted three years ago and became the first man to serve prison time for failure to sign up under the current mandatory registration law.

title: GENERAL CINEMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including a net gain of $2,316,000 for the quarter and the 9 months resulting from the sale of a radio station and the sale of stock which were partially offset by a provision to reflect losses on certain leases and losses from discontinued operations of $553,000 for the quarter and $550,000 for the 9 months.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT DROPS TO 6.9%, A 5-YEAR LOW
description: The nation's unemployment rate fell three-tenths of a percentage point in August, to 6.9 percent, the lowest level since President Reagan took office, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Britain to Sell Cable Concern
description: The Government says it will sell its remaining 23 percent stake in Cable and Wireless, the communications and telephone giant.

title: CLASSIC WORK CLOTHERS: ENDANGERED SPECIES
description: Classic American work clothes such as chambray shirts, chinos, overalls and surplus military uniforms were once worn primarily by working men. Ever since the days of Pop and protest, however, they have become fashion statements for both men and women.

title: CONNECTICUT MAY BAR HUTTON
description: The Connecticut Attorney General said yesterday that the evidence in the report by Griffin B. Bell on the E. F. Hutton Group Inc.'s illegal check overdrafting scheme had convinced him that the brokerage company ought to have its registration in the state either suspended or revoked - a harsher penalty than had been considered previously.

title: Uruguay Debt Extension
description: A committee of international banks has agreed in principle to reschedule $2 billion of Uruguay's foreign debt that matures for the rest of the decade, Citibank said yesterday.

title: Top Matches For Today
description: STADIUM Noon - John McEnroe vs.

title: BURNDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,458,000 for the quarter and $3,307,000 for the year and a writedown of $3,147,000 for the quarter and the year related to Latin American investments. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $437,000 for the quarter and $980,000 for the year. d-Net income.

title: SPLICING OLD WITH NEW, CONNECTICUT SAILMAKERS ENJOY A BOOM
description: With thousands of sails dotting the waters of Long Island Sound on weekends, Connecticut has emerged as the nation's third largest sailmaking state, after Florida and California.

title: Mexico Bars Chrysler Plan
description: The Mexican Government has turned down the Chrysler Corporation's proposal to set up a joint venture for building heavy-duty trucks. The decision, announced Thursday, was a setback to efforts by American companies to expand their investments in Mexico, where the Government tightly controls such projects.

title: Ailing Franklin's New Computer
description: The Franklin Computer Corporation, which filed for reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws last year, introduced a new personal computer that is compatible with Apple Computer Inc.'s machines. Until now, no company has been able to make a computer compatible with Apple's software, Morton E. David, Franklin's chairman and chief executive, said.

title: RUSS TOGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to August 3
3 TYPES OF SANCTIONS PROVIDED IN MEASURE
description: The sanctions legislation the Senate is expected to consider next week is a compromise measure approved by a House-Senate conference committee on July 31. The House agreed to the conference report on Aug. 1.

title: CHASE TO BUY THRIFT UNIT
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation has signed a letter of ntent to buy one troubled Maryland savings and loan association, and another money center bank is interested in purchasing a second thrift institution, Gov. Harry R. Hughes said today.

title: BLAST AT HOME OF EX-WAR CRIMES SUSPECT INJURES ONE
description: A bystander who saw a Long Island house on fire and ran up to alert its occupants was seriously injured yesterday by a bomb apparently intended for the homeowner, a former Latvian policeman once accused of Nazi war crimes.

title: CYBERMEDIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
INDIAN MUSEUM REJECTS PLAN
description: The board of trustees of the Museum of the American Indian voted yesterday to reject a plan to merge with the American Museum of Natural History, according to Roland Force, the director of the Indian Museum.

title: WRITER'S CUPBOARDS AREN'T BARE
description: People who write about food for a living have to contend with strange public perceptions of how they cook and eat at home. More than one acquaintance has taken a sidelong glance in my kitchen cupboard to see if I have stashed away any of the processed foods of which I speak so disparagingly: marshmallows, potato chips, canned soup, maybe even SpaghettiOs. From time to time people come up to me in the supermarket and examine the contents of my shopping cart, looking for similar items that would betray me.

title: Amax Officials Will Retire
description: Three executives of Amax Inc., including two of the company's top four officers, announced today that they will retire on Oct. 1.

title: EPISCOPALIANS TO CHOOSE NEW LEADER
description: The Episcopal Church opens its General Convention today across a broad parking lot from Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif., and the setting, although entirely coincidental, still reflects the more relaxed mood of the church after weathering the conflicts of the past two decades.

title: Study of Sunset Park Finds It Isn't Sinking
description: City consultants, hired after residents in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn complained that buildings in a 20-block area were sinking, said yesterday that there was no evidence of a widespread problem there.

title: BASE TEN SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: CHAPTER 11 FOR EQUITY PROGRAMS
description: The Equity Programs Investment Corporation of Arlington, Va., already delinquent on payment on more than $1 billion in mortgage loans, said today that it had filed bankruptcy petitions on behalf of its 341 limited partnerships.

title: BURLINGTON COAT FACTORY WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to August 3
description: b-Net income.

title: 'Professional Spectators'
description: Tennis, everyone?

title: Long Road North
description: Well, if college basketball can have a Great Alaska Shootout, why can't the professional game have an Alaska-N.B.A. Pro Classic?

title: NEWS ABOUT WOMEN OR JUST PLAIN NEWS?
description: To the Editor:

title: DELTAUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $214,000 for the quarter and $401,000 for the 6 months and a provision of $8,823,000 for the quarter and 6 months fr loss on the disposal of net assets to be sold. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,102,000 for the quar- ter and $2,044,000 for the six months.

title: SERIES OF DEADLY CRASHES
description: There have been four other major crashes this summer. These included the crash of an Air-India Boeing 747 in the Atlantic in which sabotage is strongly suspected; the crash of a Delta Air Lines Lockheed L-1011 in Dallas, apparently because of violent wind shifts; the destruction of a Japan Air Lines Boeing 747 after its tail ripped off in flight; and the destruction of a British Airtours Boeing 737 whose engine caught fire as the plane was attempting a takeoff from Manchester, England. The toll of 520 dead in the Japanese crash was the largest ever in a single-plane accident.

title: PHILADELPHIS NEWSPAPERS STRUCK BY UNIONS
description: Union employees went on strike early today against The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Daily News early today in a dispute over wages, benefits and working conditions.

title: U.S. RULES OUT USE OF A HERBICIDE IN RESUMPTION OF MARIJUANA PLAN
description: The Reagan Administration announced today that it had ruled out use of the herbicide paraquat to eradicate marijuana this year but would resume use of other chemical herbicides in its campaign to end production of the plants on Federal lands.

title: GOING TO WORK ON THE WATER
description: Brooklyn's Old Fulton Landing and Manhattan's Pier 17 are a long way from Fire Island, where the Wayfarer III usually ferries passengers. But once the boat starts across the East River, the feeling is similar: gulls flock, the breeze blows and the morning sun shines down on the passenger deck. It's the first ferry to link Brooklyn and Manhattan in 61 years.

title: TRAK AUTO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
454 SCHOOLS SHUT FOR MIXED RACES IN CAPE TOWN AREA
description: The authorities here announced today that they were closing 454 schools and colleges for students of mixed race after days of violence in Cape Town's mixed-race areas. A Cabinet official said the Government could no longer guarantee the students' safety.

title: No Currency Action by U.S.
description: The United States did not intervene on currency markets in May, June or July, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in a quarterly report.

title: ESKEY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: UNITED STOCKYARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Year-ago figures are pro forma because the company was spun off from Canal-Randolph Corp., on June 1, 1985.

title: PAUL P. EWALD, A PIONEER IN CRYSTAL ANALYSIS
description: Paul P. Ewald, who played a key role in development of the X-ray analysis of crystal structure now widely used in chemistry and physics, died at his home in Ithaca, N.Y., on Aug. 22 after a long illness. He was 97 years old.

title: HERNANDEZ OF THE METS TELLS JURY OF HIS EXPERIENCES WITH COCAINE
description: Keith Hernandez of the Mets, admitting for the first time publicly that he has used cocaine, told a United States District Court today how the drug was ''a demon in me'' and how it is ''the devil on this earth.''

title: Financial Payout
description: The Financial Corporation of America said it will again omit a common stock dividend in the current quarter, but will consider a cash dividend next quarter. The troubled thrift company last paid a common stock dividend in January 1985.

title: SICK CHILDREN LEARN SELF-HYPNOTISM TO FIGHT PAIN
description: For much of Stephanie Henry's young life, every time she suffered an attack of severe pain typical of her sickle-cell anemia she had to be treated with narcotics that made her, in her mother's words, ''spaced out.'' From time to time the pain would be so unbearable that she had to be rushed to the hospital and admitted for several days.

title: VISITOR FROM POLAND BRINGS ACADEMIC TRAINING IN GAME
description: There is one university, and probably only one, at which it is possible to major in bridge teaching. It is the University of Gdansk in Poland, and one such graduate is now in New York City. He is Antony Zdzienicki, and he will eventually return to his native city of Lodz armed with much information about teaching methods in the United States.

title: CARSON PIRIE'S SPECIAL LURE
description: The suit and shirt departments are opposite each other. Straight ahead is a stockbroker and insurance salesman. And farther on, before reaching the ticket broker and restaurant, are a dry cleaner, postal booth, men's hair salon, shoeshine stand.

title: NEW DEFECT REPORTED FOUND IN BLOOD OF AIDS SUFFERERS
description: Researchers say they have discovered a previously unknown defect in the blood serum of AIDS patients that may make them more susceptible to fatal infections.

title: FINDING HELP WITH ALZHEIMER'S
description: NEW YORK CITY has opened an information and referral service for the families of people who have Alzheimer's disease, an incurable mental deterioration that robs its victims of their memories and reasoning abilities.

title: Rumors Spur Vicks Trading
description: The stock of Richardson-Vicks Inc. jumped $3.50 a share yesterday, to $40, in active New York Stock Exchange trading amid fresh takeover rumors.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14. 1. Twenty-one dolphins evacuated from an aquarium were placed into the pools of three local hotels. 2. The announcement from the Khmer Rouge that Pol Pot would retire from command of the Cambodian rebel movement. 3. They would make it more difficult to challenge state and local election laws as discriminatory. 4. The costumes for 69 of the New York City Opera's productions stored in a Passaic warehouse were destroyed. 5. Nystrom defeated Boris Becker, the Wimbledon champion, ending the possibility that Becker would meet John McEnroe, defending champion of the Open. 6. Calling attempts to salvage the ship ridiculous, they propose making it a marine memorial to the more than 1,500 people who died. 7. 13. No. 8. For the added costs of repairs on the stricken satellite Leasat 3, performed by crew members of the space shuttle Discovery. 9. A polyunsaturated fatty acid found in some seafood. 10. 70.9 percent. 11. Saudi Arabia. 12. Zeke Mowatt, tight end for the Giants, is out for the season with a torn ligament in his knee. Wesley Walker, wide receiver for the Jets, will miss at least the opening game with a sprained knee. 13. From 1973 to 1976. 14. Alan Garcia Perez of Peru. 15. The Industrial Workers of the World, or Wobblies. 16. John J. McLaughlin, who resigned recently as president of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation. 17. Singapore. 18. ''Rambo,'' ''Back to the Future,'' ''Cocoon,'' ''Goonies,'' and ''View to a Kill.'' 19. Reversed. 20.

title: AFGHAN REBELS REPORTS A PARTIAL SOVIET RETREAT
description: Afghan guerrillas said today that their counteroffensive against a Soviet thrust near the Pakistan border had forced Soviet troops to retreat in at least one sector.

title: UNIVERSAL COMMUNICATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CMX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $26,000 for the quarter and $52,000 for the 6 months related to terminated employment contracts and nonrecurring charges of $250,000 for the quarter for inventory valuation and about $200,000 for the quarter associated with the move of the company.

title: APARTHEID FOE SAYS PROTEST IN WHITE AREAS IS INEVITABLE
description: The head of the African National Congress says the spread of black protests into white areas of South Africa is an inevitable step in the fight against apartheid.

title: STATEX PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $170,000. c-Net loss. There are no share earnings for the latest 9 months because preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: PENTAGON WHISTLE-BLOWER REBUTS CHIEF AT CONGRESSIONAL HEARING ON WEAPON COSTS
description: The Pentagon's most celebrated whistle-blower testified at a Congressional hearing today that he doubted the Defense Department was able to control the bureaucracy of uniformed military personnel who buy billions of dollars worth of weapons annually.

title: ASSIGNMENT NICARAGUA
description: Robert Werner Duemling, who has been a Foreign Service officer for 28 years, has been chosen by President Reagan to administer the flow of United States Government humanitarian aid to the insurgent forces trying to overthrow the government of Nicaragua.

title: WAXMAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $238,000 for the quarter and the year from expenses incurred in connection with the amendment of a revolving credit agreement and early repayment of longterm debt and a pretax gain of $286,000 for the year made in the first quarter from the termination of a capitalized lease.

title:
PATENTS;

IMAGING SYSTEM DETECTS AGRICULTURAL CONTRABAND
description: For the Department of Agriculture, a radiant energy - a form of X-ray -imaging system has been devised to detect agricultural contraband in baggage or parcels.

title: Merrill Drops Bid For SCM, for Now
description: The SCM Corporation and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. said late yesterday that they had agreed to break off merger talks, but would continue exploring ''all possible alternatives.''

title: BONANNO IS SENT TO A U.S. CENTER FOR ILL PRISONERS
description: Joseph Bonanno, a top Mafia leader for many years, was sent to a prison hospital today following his refusal Thursday to testify about the ruling ''commission'' of organized crime.

title: Farmers Sue Bank
description: Nine southwestern Iowa farm families today sued their local bank for $100 million, saying they were being wrongfully forced off their land.

title: From Collar to Beard
description: The triumph of Republican conservatism has produced remarkable cultural changes. Who, for example, is the man everyone now loves to hiss? Fidel Castro, of course.

title: GEORGE MACRAE OF HARVARD DIES
description: George W. MacRae, S.J., acting dean of the Harvard Divinity School, died this morning at St. Elizabeth's Hospital in Brighton, Mass., apparently of a heart attack, according to Michael West, a spokesman for the Divinity School.

title: MARGARET KENNEDY, A LEADER IN WOMEN'S FINANCIAL ADVICE
description: Margaret E. Kennedy, one of the first women to achieve prominence on Wall Street and a leading financial adviser to women, died Monday at St.Vincent's Hospital of complications from a heart attack in July. She was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: MARSHALL ASSAILS DEATH PENALTY PLEA PROCESS
description: Justice Thurgood Marshall of the Supreme Court said today that the rights of inmates on death row to challenge their sentences were being denied by ''fundamentally unfair'' procedures and inadequate legal representation.

title: WIELBOLDT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
TRANSCRIPT OF REAGAN NEWS SESSION
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network:

title: JOBLESS DROP SENDS STOCKS UP SHARPLY
description: Helped by upbeat employment statistics, the stock market yesterday turned in its best showing in three weeks as prices rose sharply although volume picked up only slightly.

title: GENEVA'S LAKE
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $2,684,000, or 69 cents a share, for the quarter and $3,350,000, or 80 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $1,150,000 for the quarter and $1,293,000 for the 6 months and an extraordinary charge of $8,000 for the quarter.

title: SCIENTIST DESCRIBES HARROWING MOMENT IN SEARCH FOR TITANIC
description: In a frightening moment aboard the research ship Knorr, the scientists realized that the robot vehicle Argo had struck one of the Titanic's smokestacks on the bottom of the North Atlantic.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Alejandro Pena, Los Angeles pitcher sidelined all season after shoulder surgery, has been activated. . . . Owen Gill, who set rushing records at Iowa, was claimed by the Indianapolis Colts after being waived by the Seattle Seahawks.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MUSIC VIDEO SHOW It is less than a year and a half since the rebuilt, modernized Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, opened to the public in May 1984. The overcrowding of those first few months has disappeared, but the museum is still thronged and it would be easy to miss a new exhibition devoted to one of the most modern of the arts, the music video.

title: GIVE A PREMARITAL BLOOD TEST FOR CHOLESTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: DEMOCRATS IN 20 DISTRICTS WAGING CONTESTS FOR THE CITY COUNCIL
description: Mention ''City Council district'' and an image comes to mind of a small neighborhood with shared concerns. But in reality, each of New York's 35 Council districts is anything but that, taking in 200,000 people, twice as many as an Assembly district.

title: OF HEAT AND FEVER
description: Congress is gearing up again, President Reagan is back in town ''raring to go,'' and there is much ferment about tax revision, South Africa and the forthcoming Reagan-Gorbachev summit meeting. But what everyone is talking about minute by minute, what leads the big news, is the weather.

title: HOUSE OF FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: COST OF HURRICANE ELENA IS PUT AT $543.3 MILLION
description: The four Gulf Coast states hit by Hurricane Elena reported an estimated total insured private property loss of $543.3 million, insurance officials said today.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Oakland A's, at the Stadium, 8 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Dodgers, at Los Angeles, 3:20 P.M. (Television - Channel 4, 3:15 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 3:15 P.M.) Cardinals vs. Atlanta Braves, at St. Louis. 8:05 P.M. (Television - WTBS, 11:15 P.M. tape-delay.) Royals vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Kansas City. 8:35 P.M. (Radio - WCBS 880, 8:20 P.M.) Football College Games: Boston College vs. Temple, at Chestnut Hill, Mass., noon (Television - Channel 11, noon). Penn State vs. Maryland, at College Park, Md., noon (Television - MSG, USA, noon). Southwestern Louisiana vs. Auburn, at Auburn, Ala., 12:30 P.M. (Television -WTBS, 12:30 P.M.) Florida State vs. Nebraska, at Lincoln, Neb., 3 P.M. (Television - Channel 7, 3 P.M.) U.C.L.A. vs. Brigham Young, at Provo, Utah, 7:30 P.M. (Television - ESPN, 7:30 P.M.) North Carolina vs. Navy, at Annapolis, Md., 7:30 P.M. (Television - MSG, 7:30 P.M.) Oklahoma State vs. Washington, at Seattle, 8 P.M. (Television - WTBS, 8 P.M.) Soccer Brazil vs. Spain, final of the World Youth Championship, at Lenin Stadium, Moscow, 11 A.M. The tournament is held every four years for national teams of players under 20 years old. (Television - Channel 41, 10:45 A.M.) Tennis United States Open, at National Tennis Center, Flushing Meadows, Queens. Women's final and men's semifinals, in which top-seeded John McEnroe will play Mats Wilander, who is seeded third, and second-seeded Ivan Lendl will play Jimmy Connors, who is seeded fourth.

title: COUNT RODOLFO CRESPI, FIGURE IN FASHION CIRCLES, DIES AT 61
description: Count Rodolfo Crespi, an international magazine executive and a figure in international fashion and society circles, died of cardiac arrest yesterday morning at New York Hospital. He was 61 years old and had homes in Manhattan, Rome and Sao Paulo, Brazil.

title: ARENO-SERONO INTERNAIONAL HOLDING S A reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SALVADOR GETS 12 U.S. GUNSHIPS TO BATTLE REBELS
description: A spokesman for the United States Embassy in El Salvador said today that the United States was sending 12 helicopter gunships to the Salvadoran Air Force.

title: SENATORS SAY RUSSIANS ARE FLEXIBLE ON ARMS
description: A delegation of United States Senators returned today from a visit to Moscow and reported ''movement'' in the Soviet position on arms reduction, which they attributed to the ''flexibility'' of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: CHYRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Aug. 20, 1984 and a 10 percent stock split paid Aug. 15, 1985. Results for the latest year include on a purchase accounting basis the operations of CMX Corp. since Jan. 1 and Digital Services Corp. since Feb. 1.

title: A SEPTUPLET GOING HOME AT 15 WEEKS
description: The firstborn of the Frustaci septuplets left the Orange County Children's Hospital today amid pink balloons, a crowd of well-wishers and a sea of reporters and cameramen.

title: SHAER SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Mack Discussions
description: Officials of Mack Trucks Inc. and the United Automobile Workers are discussing the possibility of the truck maker using outside suppliers for some parts made at its Hagerstown plant, a move that could cost many workers here their jobs. A final decision has not been made on whether Mack will begin ''outsourcing,'' which involves buying parts or services from outside suppliers, Bill McCullough, spokesman at Mack's Allentown, Pa., headquarters, said.

title: COLLEGE GAMES AT A GLANCE
description: Home teams are listed first. Season records are in parentheses.

title: FINDING SMALL COMET IN CROWDED NIGHT SKY
description: Although the International Cometary Explorer satellite will not intercept the comet Giacobini-Zinner until next week, the comet is now visible in the sky from 1 A.M. to dawn.

title: INSTINET CHIEF TO ADD TITLE
description: The Instinet Corporation said yesterday that William A. Lupien, the chairman and chief executive, will assume the additional title of president on Nov. 1.

title: 23 MORE ARE DEAD IN BEIRUT FIGHTING
description: Palestinian gunmen and Shiite militiamen fought with mortars and rockets today for a fourth straight day in southern Beirut.

title: BRIDLE HELPS AIRCRAFT RECOVER FROM SPINS
description: A means of helping aircraft recover from spinning caused in test flights when the pilots lose control was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: DYCOM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
IRANIANS SAID TO SEIZE ITALIAN SHIP BRIEFLY
description: A small group of helicopter-borne Iranian commandos seized an Italian cargo ship off Saudi Arabia today, the ship's captain reported.

title: Berkey's Holders Back Sale of Unit
description: Berkey Photo Inc. said shareholders had approved the sale of its film processing group to the Colorcraft Corporation, a unit of Fuqua Industries, for $40 million.

title: AMERICAN FUEL TECHNOLOIES reports earnings for Year to May 31
TUTU SEES 'NO LIGHT AT END OT TUNNEL'
description: Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, the 1984 winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, said today that he saw ''no light at the end of the tunnel'' in South Africa, with more and more blacks concluding that violence is the only way to bring about change.

title: BLOCKING A DISEASE
description: Sometime this morning, John and Marianne Maarleveld of Rutherford, N.J., will park their motor home near Byrd Stadium on the campus of the University of Maryland, and their movable feast will begin.

title: CROWN BOOKS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
FARM BANK PLEA GETS COOL REPLY
description: The White House took a dim view today of extending Federal aid to the Farm Credit System, the nation's biggest lender to farmers. At the same time, two prominent officials of the system said that its regulator, the Farm Credit Administration, had exaggerated the severity of the lenders' mounting losses.

title: JAPAN AIR LINES AGREES TO PAY FAMILIES OF 2 CRASH VICTIMS
description: Japan Air Lines said today that it had reached the first compensation settlement in the world's worst single-aircraft accident, agreeing to pay an undisclosed sum to the family of an Indian couple who were among the 520 people killed.

title: STATE DEPARTMENT NOMINEE
description: President Reagan intends to nominate Alan L. Keyes, the American representative at the United Nations Economic and Social Council since 1983, to be Assistant Secretary of State for International Affairs, the White House announced today. Mr. Keyes, 35 years old, would succeed Gregory J. Newell in the State Department post.

title: WHY INUIT SHOULD NOT BE CALLED ESKIMO
description: To the Editor:

title: LENDL BATTLES THE OPEN CROWD
description: He may never be known as the Connecticut Yankee of tennis although Ivan Lendl is a resident of Greenwich and has lived in this country long enough to have an appreciation for winning the United States Open that many of his fellow European players lack.

title: FELONY MURDER RULE HOLDS CRIMINALS RESPONSIBLE FOR CRIMES
description: To the Editor:

title: METS DEFEAT DODGERS IN 13TH ON STRAWBERRY'S 2-OUT DOUBLE
description: The attraction tonight was Dwight Gooden and Fernando Valenzuela, but their work was finished by the time the game was decided. Darryl Strawberry sliced a double just inside the left-field line, scoring two runs in the 13th inning to give the Mets a 2-0 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: 'A Little Bit of Help'
description: In another corner of the National Tennis Center at Flushing Meadows, Beverly Sills and Itzhak Perlman turned up in support of handicapped people in the performing arts and in tennis.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: GERMAN SOCIALISTS' GODSEND: 'BROTHER JOHANNES'
description: It is a measure of a new volatility in West German politics that the hopes of the opposition Social Democratic Party for winning the 1987 general elections ride on the shoulders of one man.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1985
description: The Economy

title: 'Do Your Homework'
description: Offering T-shirts, dictionaries and dignitaries, the Board of Education held a raucous pep rally for students at Louis D. Brandeis High School yesterday to kick off a $10 million citywide program to reduce the dropout rate.

title: DUMPER OF ASHES FINED
description: A judge has fined a Santa Clara man $7,000 for dumping the ashes of as many as 5,600 people on his property. The defendant, Bill Elkin, 57 years old, who was fined Thursday, had been hired by mortuaries since 1976 to use a plane to scatter the ashes over the Sierra or in the ocean. Mr. Elkin is also the defendant in a lawsuit in which about 1,200 people are seeking damages.

title: FEDERAL AGENTS SEEK EX-JERSEY LEGISLATOR MISSING IN BAHAMAS
description: A former New Jersey State Senator who was convicted of extortion and is now a Government informer has disappeared while scuba diving in the Bahamas, and the F.B.I. is investigating.

title: CITY AUGUST UNEMPLOYMENT RATE ROSE AS MORE YOUTHS SOUGHT JOBS
description: Unemployment in New York City rose by almost a percentage point last month, surpassing the national average, because of an increase in the number of youths seeking jobs, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: DOLLAR CLIMBS SHARPLY ON HOPES FOR ECONOMY
description: The dollar rose sharply against other currencies yesterday, continuing to pull out of its late summer slump as traders upgraded their expectations of economic growth this fall.

title: WILLIAMS-SONOMA INC reports earnings for Qtr to August 4
description: b-Net loss.

title: 2 HURT IN FRENCH DERAILMENT
description: A commuter train derailed in eastern France today after the engineer apparently failed to observe speed limits, and two people were hurt, the state-owned railway company said. A company spokesman said the locomotive and three cars had left the rails near the town of Noveant with more than 50 people aboard.

title: MILWAUKEE CRASH KILLS ALL 31 ON JET
description: A twin-engine DC-9 veered to the right moments after takeoff here this afternoon, nosed into a nearby woods and exploded in an orange fireball, killing all 31 people on board.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1985
description: International

title: TCA Purchase
description: TCA Cable TV Inc. said it had tentatively agreed to acquire Texas Community Antennas Inc. for about $50 million in stock.

title: TRANSIT CHIEF IS FINDING A SURPLUS OF ADVICE
description: He stops just short of pleading the Fifth Amendment.

title: PRIMARY IRRESPONSIBILITY
description: It's deplorable enough that most of the New Yorkers registered to vote in Tuesday's primary election won't bother. The traditional indifference to primaries, however, is compounded in New York by the city's creaky electoral system. The need for an overhaul, by state as well as city authorities, is ever more urgent.

title: PRESIDENT TO ASK CONGRESS TO HELP WITH A TRADE PLAN
description: President Reagan, who has threatened to veto protectionist legislation, said today that he would ask Congress soon to work with him to devise a ''freer and fairer trading system,'' but he declined to go into detail.

title: BOMB GOES OFF IN JERUSALEM
description: A bomb exploded on a Jerusalem street at midday today, wounding one person. Nearly 20 suspects were detained, a police spokesman said. The spokesman, Rafi Levy, refused to say whether the wounded man was the bomber himself, but he denied a news report that the bomber was killed in the explosion.

title: GREEN FIELDS FOR WARHORSE
description: Two years ago, Kelso, Forego and John Henry led the post parade for the Jockey Club Gold Cup at Belmont Park, and just about everyone got the willies seeing the three greatest geldings of the last 50 years on the same track on the same day. Kelso and Forego were shipped in for the event from their lush retirement homes, Kelso from Mrs. Allaire du Pont's Chespaeake City, Md., farm, Forego from the Kentucky Horse Park in Lexington, Ky., the equine showcase where John Henry went to enjoy his pension last week.

title: VENICE FESTIVAL AWARDS TOP PRIZE TO VARDA FILM
description: The 42d Venice Film Festival awarded its Golden Lion prize today to ''Sans Toit ni Loi'' (''Without Roof or Law''), Agnes Varda's picaresque tale of a vagabond's journeys across southern France.

title: WOMEN'S GROUPS CITE CBS AND ABC IN COMPLAINT
description: Recent decisions by ABC and CBS not to run public service announcements about birth control have provoked the anger of women's rights activists.

title: SIZZLING SEPTEMBER WILTS NEW YORKERS READY FOR AUTUMN
description: By 2:30 P.M., with the temperature soaring to a record-breaking 92 degrees, Kerry Fristoe, a waitress stationed outdoors at the Riviera Cafe in Greenwich Village, was hot, discouraged and tipless. She had served only two customers, the others wisely choosing the air-conditioned indoors.

title: HOFMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
description: b-Net income.

title: GUATEMALAN CALLS FOR CHIEF TO RESIGN
description: A delegation from the Constituent Assembly met today with the chief of state, Gen. Oscar Mejia Victores, to urge him to take emergency measures to stem popular protest.

title: IN SEARCH OF THE MODERN MATURE WOMAN
description: I NEVER would have imagined that my older years would be spent living alone. After divorcing in my 50's, I was assured by friends and relatives that the world out there was populated with women just waiting for me - an educated man, in a position of responsibility, pleasant-enough looking, a sense of humor, a culture lover.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S TROUBLES SPREAD
description: IT has been a year since a confrontation in the sprawling township of Sharpeville claimed 29 lives and began South Africa's latest cycle of racial conflict. The bleak anniversary was marked in typically tragic fashion last week as the death toll from the year of strife passed 670 and mixed-race youths hurled rocks and firebombs at suburban homes owned by whites, the first time turmoil has spread into white neighborhoods.

title: THE FAMILY FARM
description: TWO YEARS AGO, MY SIS-ter and I sold our family farm, 100 acres in western Massachusetts. It was a glorious piece of land, with rolling meadows leading to sweeping views of the Berkshire hills, a brook that glistened through a hemlock forest and a rambling 19th-century farmhouse with slanting floors and hand-hewn rafters. My wife and friends told me I was crazy to want to get rid of the place. I kept four acres, not because of their remarks but for another reason that, I have only recently come to understand, is closely related to a mother's influence over a son.

title: OPERA IN ABUNDANCE AND THE MODERNS, TOO
description: This past classical-music season was dominated by milestone anniversaries of great composers - Bach, Handel, Schutz, Berg, Jerome Kern. And in previous years there have been institutional anniversaries, most dramatically the 100th birthday of the Metropolitan Opera. The 1985-86 season shapes up rather more normally. But that hardly means prosaically, given New York's unchallenged place as the showplace of the nation's and the world's music.

title: Doing Something About Road Tie-Ups
description: When I first became involved in government over 16 years ago, one of the reasons that motivated me was hearing from people who, when confronted with a problem, never tried to solve it, but rather said, ''Unfortunately, it's just one of those things.'' If something needs to be improved, I don't believe in just living with the problem.

title: DISABLED SCOUTS ENJOY A CAMP OF THEIR OWN
description: This has been a summer of firsts for the Boys Scouts at the 135-acre Harold J. Kalikow Memorial Camp on Staten Island.

title: MISS ISHAM HAS WEDDING
description: Elizabeth Isham, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jonathan Trumbull Isham of Newport, R.I., was married there yesterday to Foster Nichols Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nichols of Brookville, L.I. The ceremony was performed at the St. George's School Chapel by the Rev. John S. Rogers, the school's Episcopal chaplain.

title: WENDY FRANCES LAWRENCE MARRIED TO MARK POWDEN
description: Wendy Frances Lawrence, the director of the Capitol Hill Squash Club in Washington, was married yesterday to Mark Powden, the staff director of the House Committee on Education and Labor.

title: Philippine Mayor Slain At a Beauty Pageant
description: A gunman shot the mayor of a northern Philippine town, in the back before hundreds of people watching a beauty pageant in the plaza, the Philippine News Agency reported today.

title: Two of Social Security's Forgotten Heroes
description: To the Editor:

title: KAREN TREADWELL WED TO ALAN HAHN EUGLEY
description: The marriage of Karen Ann Treadwell, an assistant vice president of Banque Paribas in New York, to Alan Hahn Eugley, senior vice president and director of corporate development for the Marine Midland Banks in New York, took place yesterday in the Versailles Room at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel in Manhattan. The Rev. Nadine Hundertmark, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: DETERMINING VALUE A 2-SIDED QUESTION
description: Perhaps it is baseball's version of the ancient argument over the chicken and the egg: Which type of player is more valuable to a team, the one who serves as the catalyst by getting on base and starting something or the one who drives in that player?

title: STALKING GRAVEYARDS FOR HISTORY AND ART
description: WHILE workers continue to sort through the debris left from the fire that destroyed Town Hall in Salisbury early last month, one volunteer has been spending many hours in the adjacent cemetery.

title: PHOTOJOURNALISM MAKES A COMEBACK
description: Photojournalism - photography's most visible claim to fame as recently as 25 years ago - is back. Galleries and museums, whose ostensible interest in the medium is as a form of art, are turning their attention this fall to images made primarily for the sake of reportage, not personal expression. On the agenda are major retrospectives of the legendary careers of Robert Capa and W. Eugene Smith (each accompanied by a biography), a historical survey of war photography from the Crimea to Nicaragua, and new insights into the work of Henri Cartier-Bresson, Andre Kertesz and William Klein, each of whom has influenced today's photojournalistic style.

title: BUILDINGS AND BUSES
description: The article ''Building Boom in Long Beach'' [Aug. 18] was, by and large, quite well written and a fair assessment of the building renaissance that the City of Long Beach is currently experiencing.

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing and a caption in the Arts and Leisure section today misstate the title of Lily Tomlin's one-woman show that is scheduled to open Sept. 26 at the Plymouth Theater. It is ''The Search for Signs of Intelligent Life in the Universe.''

title: SUMMERFARE TO RETAIN HUNT
description: SIX weeks after the conclusion of the sixth Pepsico Summerfare, officials involved in the performing arts festival agree that attendance this year was ''disappointing,'' but say that Christopher Hunt will continue in his role as the festival's director.

title: NEW DESIGN CENTER ABOUT TO OPEN
description: THREE years after the city first proposed that a design center for the wholesale furnishings and interior decorating industry be carved out of a string of former industrial structures in Long Island City, Queens, its first tenants are preparing to move in.

title: ANNA MCDONNELL IS MARRIED
description: The marriage of Anna McDonnell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. Murray McDonnell of Peapack, N.J., and Samuel Huntting Harper, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul C. Harper of New York and Old Lyme, Conn., took place yesterday. The Rev. Michael Alliegro officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Brigid in Peapack.

title: WHITE SOCKS, WIDE EYES AND A DREAM
description: BUNNY The Real Story of Playboy. By Russell Miller. Illustrated. 371 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $16.95.

title: Oil Storage Tank Fire Kills Man in Alabama
description: A fire ignited by a cigarette lighter killed one person and raged out of control at an oil storage tank for 15 hours today, forcing the evacuation of 500 people and threatening this town in southwestern Alabama until firefighters brought it under control. Gilbertown is about 90 miles north of Mobile and 10 miles from the Mississippi line.

title: 12 FLOK ARTISTS RECEIVE AWARDS
description: Their stories, backgrounds and skills are diverse, like pieces of American patchwork.

title: FRENCH ELEGANCE GOES ITALIAN
description: LA COTE D'OR, the splendidly elegant restaurant in the Garden City Hotel, has shifted gears completely. Originally a serious French restaurant with ambitious, impeccably served food, it has now become Continental and northern Italian. Prices are on a somewhat less lofty scale than before.

title: A SELECTION OF FALL EVENTS AROUND THE U.S.
description: OHIO, KENTUCKY; An operating farm and a colonial settlement Louis Bromfield, a conservationist and author who won the Pulitzer Prize in 1929 for his novel ''Early Autumn,'' lived on a 914-acre dairy farm between Columbus and Cleveland. The farm, Malabar, has been turned into a state park, but Bromfield's ideas about agriculture have not been forgotten. The farm is still in operation and 50 head of cattle graze its pastures, but there are also nature trails and a restaurant, the Malabar Inn, which closes for the season at the end of October.

title: ELEMENTS OF GOOD TAILORING
description: A well turned-out loook is the sum of many details -- the cut of a jacket, the length of a sleeve, the cuff of a trouser. Dressing well means making the right decisions about those details, both in selecting garment and inhaving it tailored. Here is guidance on the subject from experts in the men's-wear field, including Eric Paynter, a taylor and stylist; Chris Ryan, a senior manager at Barney's in New York; John Fresco, vice president, divisional merchandise manager for men's apparel at Saks Fifth Avenue; A. Marc Zolio, vice president and general merchandise manager for clothing of Brooks Brohers, and Robert St. Clair, a tailor. How Would You Define Good Tailoring? Paynter: Good tailoring immediately suggests good fabric, well designed, well constructed. You don't get that without paying for it. You don't always get what you pay for, but you never get more.

title: DR. DIANE DRUGGE WEDS STEVEN HOBBS IN DARIEN
description: Dr. Elizabeth Diane Drugge, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henning Everett Drugge of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to Steven Andrew Hobbs, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Hobbs of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. William T. Donovan performed the ceremony at St. John's Roman Catholic Church.

title: HOW TO GET HOLD OF THE BIG PICTURE
description: ONE of the amazing things in photography is that most photographers never see their pictures larger than 3 1/2 by 4 1/2 inches - the way they come back from the processing lab.

title: W.G. CLARK 4th WEDS ELIZABETH GARRETT ROSS
description: Elizabeth Garrett Ross, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Lewis Ross of Enfield, N.C., was married there yesterday to Watson Gerould Clark 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clark 3d of Tenafly, N.J. The Rev. Richard Smith, assisted by the Rev. Frederick W. Paschall, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Advent.

title: DATA ON TOXICS AT PASSAIC FIRE WERE SKIMPY
description: HEATED to high temperatures, polychlorinated biphenyls (PCB's) can produce highly poisonous dioxins, and chlorine compounds can give off hydrochloric acid or, rarely, deadly phosgene gas.

title: BLUE JAYS AND STIEB DEFEATED BY TWINS
description: Kent Hrbek belted a two-run homer and Tom Bruanansky added a bases-empty homer today to back Mike Smithson's six-hitter and send the Minnesota Twins to a 6-3 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: A SELECTION OF FALL EVENTS AROUND THE U.S.
description: HAWAII: A time for hiking trails around volcanic peaks Even though seasons mean less in Hawaii than anywhere else in the United States, autumn has become a time for hiking on the mountain trails through the wilderness areas around the volcanic peaks that dominate each island. Examples are the trails that wind through tropical forest to the hidden beaches on Kauai's west coast or the path from the crater of Maui's Haleakala volcano down to remote Hana on the east side of the island.

title: Land of Opportunity
description: The Australian-born publisher Rupert Murdoch became Citizen Murdoch last week. Mr. Murdoch, whose journalism empire stretches from Australia to Britain to the United States, became an American citizen after reciting the oath of allegiance in Federal District Court in Manhattan. In response to questions, the publisher said he wanted to be an American citizen ''because I wanted to be, and I'm very happy and very gratified.'' Mr. Murdoch, whose holdings include The New York Post, The Times of London, New York Magazine and half of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, had said that he would seek United States citizenship because of a Federal rule limiting an alien's share in the ownership of an American broadcast license. Mr. Murdoch is in the process of buying seven television stations from Metromedia Inc.

title: Japan Limits Arms Spending
description: Japan's many critics in Congress have made clear their unhappiness with the tight lid on Japanese defense spending, which they translate as a limit on American weapons sales and thus a burden on the trade deficit. The Senate voted 88 to 7 in June for a resolution accusing Japan of failing to honor its military commitments.

title: PERUGIA
description: To the Editor: It's too bad that the Burts gave up on Perugia after one night (Letters to the Editor, Travel, Aug. 18). We spent two weeks in an Elderhostel program in Perugia in the Della Posta Hotel, which faced right on the Corso Vannucci where the daily passeggiata occurs. After the second night we didn't even hear the noise. No, not noise, but the sound of life in an Italian hill town. What a joy is Perugia.

title: CHANCELLOR IS UNDER PRESSURE TO MAKE HIS MARK
description: Nathan Quinones begins his second full academic year as New York City Schools Chancellor tomorrow with more money than ever to spend, but under increased pressure to deliver improvements that parents, politicians and community groups have been demanding.

title: BELL WORKERS WAIT FOR LAYOFF DETAILS
description: THE 12,000 New Jersey employees of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Information Systems unit are waiting to learn whether they are among the 24,000 workers in the nation whose jobs will be eliminated in the next 18 months.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN DENTISTRY;

AN ANTI-CAVITY VACCINE BY THE 1990'S
description: EVERY mother's admonition to ''Brush your teeth before you go to bed,'' may in a decade or two include the semiannual demand, ''And don't forget to take your anti-cavity pill!''

title: NINE OR ELEVEN?
description: Most of the new residential development now under way in Yorkville is taking shape in the form of large high-rise projects. Among them are the Astor, a 291-unit condominium on 93d Street between Second and Third Avenues, and the Barclay, the first of two 37-story rental buildings being built on York Avenue between 90th and 92d Streets.

title: HOLD YOU TONGUE
description: The memorable lines in Presidential speeches have not always been recognized as such by the men for whom they were written. In an interview for a forthcoming ABC News television program, Gerald R. Ford recalled his personal farewell in 1974 to Richard M. Nixon, who had just resigned and was leaving the White House by heliocopter.

title: TIMBERLANDS IN THE SOUTH ARE BEING RAVAGED BY INFESTATION OF PINE BEETLES
description: An infestation of southern pine beetles that forestry experts say is the worst on record is sweeping the rich pine forests of the South.

title: A SELECTION OF FALL EVENTS AROUND THE U.S.
description: MINNESOTA: Little Wabasha welcomes a riverboat On Sept. 21 the Mississippi Queen makes a stop in Wabasha, Minnesota, en route from St. Louis to St. Paul, setting off a celebration in this small town 80 miles south of the Twin Cities.

title: COLUMBIA'S PRESIDENT TAKES A BOW, AND SOME QUESTIONS
description: TOMORROW night the friends and colleagues of Michael I. Sovern will gather at the New York State Theater to mark his fifth anniversary as president of Columbia University. There is much to celebrate, they say. Applications are up at Columbia. A fund-raising drive has produced $375 million so far, surpassing expectations. The faculty has gotten salary increases. Moreover, the most volatile topic on campus may soon be defused. On Aug. 28, a panel of university trustees recommended that Columbia divest itself of $39 million of stock in companies doing business with South Africa. In an interview last week with Gene I. Maeroff, a New York Times education reporter, Dr. Sovern talked about himself and the university.

title: OKLAHOMA ST. A 31-17 WINNER
description: The tailback Thurman Thomas ran for 237 yards and one touchdown and threw for a second score tonight to rally Oklahoma State to a 31-17 victory over Washington.

title: AT 13, HE BECOMES A NATIONAL MASTER
description: Thirteen-year-old Ilya Gurevich of Worcester, Mass., has won the World Under 14 Championship held in Lomas de Zamora, Argentina. In a Swiss-system field of 38 players from 26 countries, he scored 7 1/2-1 1/2.

title: GUARDING 'THE GATES OF PARDISE'
description: WE WHITES IN SOUTH AFRICA present an updated version of the tale of the emperor's clothes; we are not aware of our nakedness - ethical, moral, and fatal - clothed as we are in our own skin. This morning on the radio the news of the withdrawal of more foreign diplomats from South Africa, and the continuing threat of the withdrawal by foreign banks, was followed by a burst of pop-music defiance by the state-owned South African Broadcasting Corporation, on behalf of Afrikaners and English-speaking whites. ''Allies,'' yelled a disco idol, ''We're allies, with our backs against the w-a-ll. . . .''

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 8, 1985
description: International

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In the city where the average age of Jews is 78, a Jewish boy has come to manhood and I have lived to see it.'' - Roza Jakubowicz of Cracow, Poland. [19:1.]

title: INSPIRATION FROM INDIA
description: ''AMERICANS have for centuries felt spiritual kinship with India,'' begins Staurt Cary Welch of the Fogg Art Museum in his introduction to ''A Second Paradise: Indian Courtly Life 1590-1947,'' to be published by Doubleday this week.

title: BY TRAIN FROM PARIS, ON FOOT IN GREECE
description: French Rail's New First Class For passengers traveling by rail between Paris and Strasbourg, Sept. 29 will bring something new in service aboard two new trains, the Jean Lamour and the Gustave Dore, which will run at speeds up to 125 miles an hour. Known as the new first class, the service includes three types of car. One is the basic passenger car, which has 28 nonsmoking seats and 20 smoking seats, that can be divided into partly partitioned salons. The car is equipped with swivel chairs, to enable 2 to 10 people to sit together.

title: U.S. SPYING HELD UNHURT BY WEST GERMAN BREACH
description: Reagan Administration officials have concluded that recent disclosures of West Germans spying for East Germany are very costly to West German intelligence operations but will not seriously hurt American intelligence activities.

title: The Accidental Tourist
description: IN Anne Tyler's fiction, family is destiny, and (nowadays, at least) destiny clamps down on one in Baltimore. For an archeologist of manners with Miss Tyler's skills, the city is a veritable Troy, and she has been patiently excavating since the early 1970's, when she skipped off the lawn of Southern fiction and first sank her spade in the soil which has nourished such varied talents as Poe, Mencken, Billie Holiday and John Waters, the director of the films ''Pink Flamingos'' and ''Polyester.''

title: MANNES COLLEGE JOINS THE WEST SIDEMUSIC SCENE
description: Outside the Mannes College of Music, the sounds of pianos and flutes blend with the din of buses and trucks on nearby Amsterdam Avenue, creating a dissonant tutti.

title: SAVING MANATEES
description: SUNRISE and Savannah, two of only a handful of manatees born in captivity and the first scheduled for release to the wild, were moved to a river pen in Homosassa Springs, Fla., in August 1984, with the expectation that if all went well, they would be freed in a year.

title: WHEN HOME WAS MORE THAN HOME
description: IN my family, home was more than home - it was The Old Homestead. This was our affectionate name for the place in Great Neck where the four of us grew up and, as adults, returned for comfort, escape and refueling.

title: EVEN WANDS CAN'T CREATE MAGIC AT THE BOX OFFICE
description: It's not been a great summer at the box office.
