According to reports from Hollywood early this week, there have been only two unmistakable blockbusters, Sylvester Stallone's ''Rambo,'' which has brought in $146 million in ticket sales so far, and Robert Zemeckis's ''Back to the Future'' ($128 million), trailed by ''Cocoon'' ($69 million), ''Goonies'' ($61 million) and the latest James Bond adventure, ''A View to a Kill'' ($50 million).

title: SNARL OF ISSUES LED TO STRIKE BY 9 UNIONS
description: The strike of all nine unions at The Philadelphia Inquirer and Philadelphia Daily News that began at 12:01 Saturday morning was prompted by what both management and union spokesmen describe as a tangle of issues that both sides say may be difficult to unravel.

title: EQUAL RIGHTS FOR DEFENDERS
description: PASS-INTERFERENCE penalties will decrease, more players will be injured, games will be shorter. These are the likely effects, intended or otherwise, of the major changes for the National Football League's 66th season, which begins today.

title: ALONG WITH THE FAMILIAR, CABLE SEEKS DISTINCTIVE FARE
description: In many ways, cable remains the medium of the future that cannot unshackle itself from the past. To a growing degree, cable services are finding themselves having to push harder to snag and sustain viewership, and the primary way they are doing this is by providing programming - either through original productions or acquisitions - that cannot be seen elsewhere.

title: STUDYING EINSTEIN'S BRAIN
description: Walter Reich suggests that it is somehow not ''decent'' to perform anatomical studies on post-mortem specimens (''The Stuff of Genius,'' July 28). During his lifetime, Einstein himself showed a certain fascination with the character of his brain.

title: Nassau G.O.P. Loses 1 Percent Kickback Case
description: Local government workers in Nassau County were required to make contributions to the county Republican Party during the mid-1970's, a jury concluded last week. After a month-long trial in Federal District Court in Uniondale, L.I., the jury found that the Nassau Republican Committee and government officials had put pressure on municipal workers to pay 1 percent of their annual salaries to the party in return for promotions and wage increases.

title: PAPER MAKING: STATE OF THE ART
description: A MULTIFACETED view of handmade paper art is being presented in a show of more than passing interest at the Historical Society of Rockland County here.

title: FROM HERNANDEZ, APOLOGY TO FANS
description: Keith Hernandez said today that the period in his life in which he used cocaine was both ''stupid'' and ''difficult,'' and he offered an apology to Met fans.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: In Sportive Footwear, Discounts Up to 50% Since February, Athletic Action has been the name for the former Sneaker Circus on Mamaroneck Avenue, a White Plains franchise that moved across town four years ago to The Mall on Hamilton Avenue. Sport footwear and running clothing is always discounted by 15 percent from suggested retail prices, and selected models can be 40 or 50 percent off during special promotions. All merchandise is first quality, there are no seconds. Footwear sizes are infant to 14 men's and to 10 for women.

title: FOR GEGULARS, A BELLYFUL OF 'CHEERS'
description: THE regular at the Bull and Finch Pub in Boston, who seldom set foot in the Beacon Hill establishment between Memorial Day and Labor Day, were positioned once again on their customary stools and drinking to the old days. Back then, they were saying th eother night, you could always get a seat at the bar and a view of the Red Sox game unobstructed by the backs of heads of people from Cincinnati and such. You could play darts until a few years ago, when the dart board was taken down to make room for these same people.

title: ILL ADOLESCENTS TURN TO PEERS FOR HELP
description: ADOLESCENTS with newly diagnosed chronic and debilitating illnesses often require more than medical expertise and the emotional support of their families. Successful growth to adulthood, according to experts in psychology, requires that adolescents reach for independence - a feat frequently hampered by the measures taken to control the illness.

title: MISS BRIGGS WED TO D.F. HUDSON
description: Betsy Laura Briggs and Derek Fernando Hudson were married yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church in Millbrook, N.Y. The Rev. Richardson Schell performed the ceremony.

title: CLIFFORD GRODD: PRESIDENT, PAUL STUART
description: Clifford Grodd wants you to think of Paul Stuart as if it were a comfortable and mildly eccentric grocery shop in London, not big or famous but well regarded by a close circle of patrons.

title: A MYSTERY TALE WELL TOLD
description: IT'S somewhat comforting to believe that if the world suffers a cataclysm and all written material disintegrates, there will still be master storytellers who will travel around, preserving great tales of literature for future generations.

title: TRYOUTS FOR ZORN
description: He won't be playing, but as the National Football League opens its first season since 1976 without him, Jim Zorn, the quarterback cut by the Seattle Seahawks last week, will be passing his heart out anyway.

title: THE SEA AND SOUP
description: IT IS LIKELY THAT SOUP OFFERS MORE DIVERSITY THAN any other category of food. It can range from the simplicity of bouillon or double consomme to the complexity of a Mediterranean bouillabaisse. It can be as basic as chicken broth or packed with all the vegetables of a summer garden, not to mention all manner of meats and fish.

title: A HEROIC DECISION ON THE TITANIC
description: The discovery of the wreck of the Titanic, more than 73 years after its tragic sinking, brings to mind one touching story that seems to have been overlooked, and I want, after all these years, to pay tribute to a heroic and exceptionally kind and considerate woman who went down with the ship. She was Ida Blum Straus, Mrs. Isidor Straus, and the story was told to me many years ago by her daughter Sara Hess.

title: DALLAS TO BEGIN 143-MILE RAIL TRANSIT SYSTEM
description: For 30 years the North Central Expressway that connects northern neighborhoods with downtown Dallas has strained the tempers of Dallas drivers.

title: WIDER HORIZONS IN SCOUTING
description: WHILE many another 22-year-old was preparing during the last days of August to return to college or graduate school, Lesliann Helmus of Garden City was packing for a trip to Indonesia. She will return to school later this month, when she begins studies toward a master's degree in preventive medicine at Ohio State University.

title: Alabama to Get Disaster Aid
description: President Reagan today declared the Alabama coastline a major disaster area in the wake of Hurricane Elena, which caused an estimated $100 million in damage to private property there. The declaration allows the use of Federal funds in relief and recovery efforts.

title: REAGAN ORDERS MOVES AGAINST TRADE PARTNERS
description: President Reagan, seeking to thwart protectionist legislation in Congress, announced plans today to move against Japan, South Korea, Brazil and the European Economic Community for ''unfair trading practices.''

title: CHILD CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: SANDRA EARLEY MARRIES P.S. HAWKINS
description: The marriage of Sandra Lea Earley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Earley of Greer, S.C., to Phelps Stokes Hawkins, the son of Elizabeth Phelps Stokes Hawkins of Boulder, Colo., and the late Robert Bradshaw Hawkins, took place yesterday. The Rev. Richard G. Laurens, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Capt. Richard Flanders House in Chilmark, Mass.

title: MUSIC: FRANK SINATRA BEGINS 9-CONCERT SERIES
description: FRANK SINATRA'S post-retirement concerts have a singular atmosphere. His star power draws adoring fans - they quickly sold out the nine-show Carnegie Hall engagement Mr. Sinatra began on Thursday - but Mr. Sinatra takes it for granted, even shrugs it off. Once the opening act is out of the way and Mr. Sinatra has walked onstage, minus fanfare, the hall becomes hushed and devotional; together, line by line, singer and orchestra and audience will worship the well-made pop song.

title: CO-OP CONCEPT SPREADS TO MORRIS COUNTY
description: OUTSIDE of the Fort Lee area, where a legion of cooperative apartment houses tower over the Palisades, there are few co-ops in New Jersey. For although the co-op form of ownership is widely used in New York, it never took root west of the Hudson River except where a large number of New Yorkers familiar with the concept might be expected to buy.

title: CHARIOTS OF THE GODDESSES, OR WHAT?
description: A MAGGOT By John Fowles. 455 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $19.95.

title: JACKSON SCORES 4, GAINS 290
description: Bo Jackson raced to four touchdowns and piled up 290 yards rushing on 23 carries today as Auburn unveiled its new I-formation with a 49-7 pounding of Southwestern Louisiana (0-2).

title: A Paradise For Book Lovers
description: I must take exception to a statement made in the Long Island Journal on July 28, under the heading ''The Last Chapter,'' which noted the closing of the Book Case in Sayville. The article stated the bookstore was ''the only store of its kind for miles around.''

title: OPENING ATHLETICS TO DEAF PLAYERS
description: WHEN he arrived on the Hofstra University campus last year, Andrew Metz was not the average freshman football recruit. Although his high school statistics (4,077 yards rushing, 56 touchdowns) earned him a 1983 prep player of the year award, Hofstra was the only college that paid any great interest to his athletic talents.

title: MELANIE E.L. BARRETT BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Melanie Elizabeth Lee Barrett, a daughter of Judith Barrett of New York and Robert Barrett of Cold Spring, N.Y., was married yesterday to Christopher Vernon Freitag, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Werner Freitag of New York and Silkeborg, Denmark. The Rev. John Evans Scott performed the ceremony at Christ and St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in New York, assisted by the Rev. Joseph M. Zorawick.

title: Spanish Chief Gets Apology After Iran Diverts His Plane
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain said today that Iran's Prime Minister has sent him a message of deep regret after Iran diverted his plane and made him late for a visit to China.

title: Blaze at 3 Mile Island Plant Damages Electrical Switches
description: A fire broke out in an electrical relay room in Unit 1 of the Three Mile Island nuclear plant today, damaging switches but presenting no danger to plant workers, according to Doug Bedell, a spokesman for the General Public Utilities Nuclear Corporation, which operates the plant.

title: No Headline
description: We Risk Killing an Entire Generation of Europe

title: WHAT'S NEW IN DENTISTRY
description: AMERICANS' dental health is improving all the time, but many of the nation's dental practices are ailing.

title: BEST SELLERS: Sept. 8, 1985
description: Weeks This Last on Week Fiction Week List 1 LUCKY, by Jackie Collins. 1 3 (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The heiress of a crime lord takes on the heiress of a shipping tycoon in fashionable spots all over the world. 2 LAKE WOBEGON DAYS, by Garrison Keillor. 7 2 (Viking, $17.95.) Recollections of a small American town. 3 SKELETON CREW, by Stephen King. 2 12 (Putnam, $18.95.) Twenty-two tales of horror set in contemporary America. 4 THE FOURTH DEADLY SIN, by Lawrence Sanders. 3 8 (Putnam, $17.95.) Which of six suspects murdered a saintly New York psychiatrist? 5 THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom Clancy. 4 25 (Naval Institute Press, $14.95.) A Lithuanian submarine driver defects to the United States with the Soviet Union's most advanced nuclear secrets. 6 THE TWO MRS. GRENVILLES, by Dominick Dunne. 5 4 (Crown, $14.95.) Romance, scandal and murder in New York's high society. 7 THE CIDER HOUSE RULES, by John Irving. 6 16 (Morrow, $18.95.) Life in a Maine orphanage earlier in this century. 8 LONESOME DOVE, by Larry McMurtry. 8 11 (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The Old West seen larger than life. 9 TOO MUCH, TOO SOON, by Jacqueline Briskin. 12 3 (Putnam, $17.95.) Three sisters find their destinies bound by an obsession with the same man. 10 IF TOMORROW COMES, by Sidney Sheldon. 11 33 (Morrow, $17.95.) A young woman destroys the crime lords who got her an undeserved prison term. 11 THE LOVER, by Marguerite Duras. 13 8 (Pantheon, $11.95.) The sexual initiation of an adolescent girl by a rich Chinese in Saigon in the 30's. 12 JIAN, by Eric Van Lustbader. 1 (Villard, $17.95.) Martial arts, spies and counterspies, and an intrigue to control all Asia. 13 JUBAL SACKETT, by Louis L'Amour. 9 16 (Bantam, $16.95.) In this forerunner to the 17-volume Sackett saga, a restless explorer scouts the 17th-century American wilderness. 14 HOLD THE DREAM, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. 10 17 (Doubleday, $17.95.) Continuing the family saga begun in ''A Woman of Substance.'' 15 FALL FROM GRACE, by Larry Collins. 15 8 (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Machinations by spies, double Bagents and a beautiful woman on the eve of D-Day. Nonfiction 1 YEAGER: An Autobiography, by Chuck Yeager and Leo Janos. (Bantam, $17.95.) From West Virginia hillbilly to World War II fighter pilot to the first man to fly faster than sound. 2 IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee Iacocca 2 45 with William Novak. (Bantam, $19.95.) The rise of an immigrants' son to top jobs at Ford and Chrysler. 3 A PASSION FOR EXCELLENCE, by Tom Peters 4 18 and Nancy Austin. (Random House, $19.95.) Ways to achieve distinction in management. 4 SMART WOMEN, FOOLISH CHOICES, by Connell 3 23 Cowan and Melvyn Kinder. (Clarkson N. Potter, $13.95.) Two clinical psychologists analyze the successes and failures of modern women in looking for acceptable men. 5 LOVING EACH OTHER, by Leo Buscaglia. 12 53 (Slack/Holt, $13.95.) Suggestions for ''setting our priorities right in order to enjoy life to the fullest.'' 6 THE MICK, by Mickey Mantle with Herb Gluck. 5 7 (Doubleday, $15.95.) The autobiography of the Oklahoma farm boy who became a New York Yankee baseball star. 7 THE AMATEURS, by David Halberstam. 6 4 (Morrow, $14.95.) Four American men seek the 1984 Olympic gold medal for single sculling. 8 HAMMER OF THE GODS: The Led Zeppelin Saga, 10 5 by Stephen Davis. (Morrow, $15.95.) The British heavy metal group's boisterous tours of the 1970's. 9 FUNNY MONEY, by Mark Singer. 11 6 (Knopf, $15.95.) The scandal surrounding the 1982 collapse ofthe Penn Square Bank in Oklahoma City. 10 CONFESSIONS OF A HOOKER, by Bob Hope 8 17 with Dwayne Netland. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Memories of more than 50 years of golfing, by the comedian. 11* NUTCRACKER, by Shana Alexander. 9 10 (Doubleday, $17.95.) Treachery, mystery and high society in the 1978 murder of a Mormon multimillionaire. 12 FINAL CUT, by Steven Bach. 1 (Morrow, $19.95.) How the making of the film ''Heaven's Gate'' proved the unmaking of United Artists. 13 THE GRASSHOPPER TRAP, by Patrick F. McManus. 13 3 (Holt, $13.95.) Amusing pieces about pursuing pleasures in the great outdoors. 14 MARTINA, by Martina Navratilova with 7 8 George Vecsey. (Knopf, $16.95.) The autobiography of the Czechoslovak-born tennis champion. 15 THE BRIDGE ACROSS FOREVER, by Richard Bach. 14 53 (Morrow, $16.95.) How the author of ''Jonathan Livingston Seagull'' sought a true love.

title: ARE CRIMINALS MADE OR BORN?
description: Subjecting Einstein's brain (or any other) to scientific scrutiny is macabre, an exercise in futility.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;

QUESTIONS IT WILL TAKE A SESASON TO ANSWER
description: FOR the National Football League player, every new season means a new commitment to the game, to the team and to the self. It is a time for personal growth and, for the veteran, a challenge to be mature enough to benefit from experience. It is an attempt to out-work, out-condition, out-think and, finally, on Sunday, to out-hit and out-hustle each opponent.

title: AFTER THE BOMBS DROPPED
description: THE CRAZY IRIS And Other Stories of the Atomic Aftermath. Edited and with an introduction by Kenzaburo Oe. 204 pp. New York: Grove Press. Cloth, $22.50. Paper, $6.95. BLACK RAIN By Masuji Ibuse. Translated by John Bester. 300 pp. New York: Bantam Books. Paper, $3.95.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CHIN MUSIC. By James McManus. (Crown, $14.95.) In his second novel James McManus plays dark games with a sports metaphor. ''Chin Music'' involves the last hours of Chicago and Gamma Ray Zajak, a pitcher for the Chicago White Sox, who wakes up in the hospital with amnesia and a monstrous headache, with the nuclear holocaust close at hand. Known for throwing at batters' heads - playing ''chin music,'' as it were -Gamma Ray has himself been laid up by a lethal fast ball to the cranium. Gradually he learns who he is and the novel follows him home through streets where murder, suicide, ground zero interviews for television and all manner of doomsday madness is transpiring. At one point Gamma Ray stumbles into a nightclub where sex and death abound and a handcuffed cheerleader is being punished for the patrons' enjoyment. Mr. McManus toys with images meant to shock - splattered brains, a dismembered body, eroticized suicide -shows some obliquely, shuffles others as though in a deck of cards and then flips them at the reader. He is clearly a talented writer, but his experiment seems naked and calls too much attention to itself. It may be ''that a syntactical series can swoop and leap like a mother and still retain deep intact structure,'' as he writes. But swooping to what end? ''Out of the Blue,'' Mr. McManus's first novel, about kidnappers who steal the wrong child, was more conventional. Composed of spare, snapshotlike segments, it was occasionally like trying to watch a banquet through a keyhole, but a vital tension kept it coherent.

title: A SELECTION OF FALL EVENTS AROUND THE U.S.
description: ALASKA: The glow of Indian summer heralds winter In late September and October the fast slide into deep winter frequently is interrupted in interior Alaska by an Indian summer of profound beauty when, almost overnight, thousands of acres of aspen and birch forest take on a golden glow of autumn colors.

title: THE BIG MARKET IN LITTLE READERS
description: CURIOUS GEORGE, a monkey who made his first mischievous appearance in 1941, caught Jake Ames's eye at a recent booksellers' convention in New York. ''I like him,'' the four-year-old boy told his father. ''He's very silly.''

title: Princeton Defends Action in Protest
description: It is misleading for Jamie Sayen to say, without elaboration, that he was ''literally dragged off the steps of Nassau Hall at Princeton while protesting the university's continued refusal to divest stocks in corporations which do business in South Africa.'' [The quotation from Mr. Sayen, author of a new book on Albert Einstein's years in Princeton, appeared in the About Books column of Aug.24.

title: IRAQ REPORTS RAIDING KHARG ISLAND AND 'LARGE NAVAL TARGET'
description: Iraq said today that its warplanes raided the Iranian oil terminal at Kharg Island twice in the last 24 hours and hit a ''large naval target'' in the Persian Gulf. Iraq generally uses the term to refer to an oil tanker or merchant ship.

title: HOW WILL COLLEGE SPORTS REFORMS LOOK IN 1990?
description: IN 1990 the observers of intercollegiate sports will report on one of two possible results from the 1985 effort at reform:

title: AFTER 20 YEARS, CRACOW MARKS A BAR MITZVAH
description: As the elderly remnants of Cracow's ancient and once-flourishing Jewish population murmured half-remembered prayers, Eric Strom, a 13-year-old from Stamford, Conn., read from the Torah and became the first youth to mark his bar mitzvah here in more than 20 years.

title: COMMUNITY AND EQUALITY IN CONFLICT
description: One dusky evening not so long ago, I sat at the beer-stained bar of a tavern in Charlestown, a predominantly Irish-Catholic Boston neighborhood, known as the site of the Battle of Bunker Hill and other more recent struggles. Above the click of billiard balls and the clink of ice, I overheard two regulars in conversation:

title: A SELECTION OF FALL EVENTS AROUND THE U.S.
description: NEW ENGLAND: From highland games to a harvest festival Just like modern man, the ancient inhabitants of North America moved to the beach for the summer and returned to their regular lodgings when autumn chilled the air. In what is now Maine, the Red Paint Indians of 3000 to 5000 B.C. maintained such a settlement on the banks of the Pushaw stream, now the site of an archeological dig by the University of Maine.

title: ON THE HEELS OF ELIZA
description: UNCLE TOM'S CABIN AND AMERICAN CULTURE By Thomas F. Gossett. Illustrated. 484 pp. Dallas: Southern Methodist University Press. $29.95.

title: SEASON OF MISTS IN FORESTS OF SOLOGNE
description: Autumn is the Sologne's shining season. Throughout the year nature and man have been collaborating, nurturing the dense forests of oak, birch and chestnut, the flat fields of wheat and millet, even the wild blackberries, to assure the survival of the plenitude of game that roam this solitary land.

title: CITY PLANS NO APPEAL ON HOMOSEXUAL BIAS
description: The city has decided not to appeal a court decision declaring that Mayor Koch did not have the power to ban discrimination against homosexuals by anyone holding a city contract, officials said yesterday.

title: WHERE TO BUY UNUSUAL GIFTS ON CAPE COD
description: It is no secret to my friends that I love to shop when I am on vacation. But large department stores do not interest me so much as small specialty shops, especially those that promote craftsmanship or carry unusual products.

title: Sweet Sounds Of Yesterday
description: How does it feel to view Long Island after returning from a trip out West? I must respond to Nancy Schrager Hochman's article, ''Seeing City Streets Through Long Island Eyes'' [Opinion Page, July 28] .

title: THE RULES ON MAKING CHANGES
description: AMONG the joys of owning a suburban home is the opportunity to alter the structure as needs and tastes change. No wonder buyers of condominiums and houses in planned developments bristle when this right is curtailed and architectural standards are rigidly upheld.

title: PEGGY GREENOUGH WED TOJOEL JOHNSON
description: Margaret Randolph Greenough, a daughter of Sarah Eden Greenough of Beverly, Mass., and Malcolm Whelen Greenough Jr. of Prides Crossing, Mass., was married yesterday to Joel Frederick Johnson, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Hastings Johnson Jr. of Columbus, Ga. The Rev. Susan B. Curtis performed the ceremony at Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Manchester, Mass.

title: NAYLA RIZK WED TOJAMES MCCALL
description: Nayla Rizk, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Rizk of New York, Cannes, France, and Beirut, Lebanon, was married yesterday to James Wilson McCall, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Livingston McCall of Norman, Okla. The Rev. Charles Henderson performed the ceremony at the Central Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Hard Times Down At the Bank
description: After years of falling land values, declining income and heavy borrowing, many farmers are deep in debt. So, it turned out last week, is the Farm Credit Administration, which oversees the nation's farmer-owned banking system and for the first time in 40 years expects to lose more money on bad loans than it will earn in interest.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest: THE VISITORS WHO CAME TO STAY. By Annalena McAfee. Illustrated by Anthony Browne. Viking Kestrel. $11.95. (Ages 5 to 10).

title: Fire Routs Guests at Hotel
description: More than 120 guests at a downtown hotel were evacuated early today after a clothes dryer overheated and caught fire in a basement laundry room, sending smoke through the building and setting off alarms.

title: F.B.I. AND JACKIE PRESSER: WHO USED WHOM FOR WHAT?
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation often uses informers to help build cases against suspected criminals, but sometimes the informers end up building cases against the agency.

title: F.B.I. AIDE TESTIFIES TO ESPIONAGE CONFESSION
description: Less than an hour after his arrest last fall on espionage charges, Richard W. Miller confessed passing a secret document to a Soviet intelligence agent, the head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation office in Los Angeles testified Friday in Federal District Court here.

title: JET PARTS FOUND NEAR CRASH
description: Federal investigators, who are looking into the cause of jetliner crash here that killed all 31 people aboard, have found pieces of an engine on the runway used by the plane, a Federal official said tonight.

title: CAST IN IRON
description: New York's Dutchess County is growing economically and and one node of its growth is Poughkeepsie, a former manufacturing center that is experiencing a commercial revitalization. To encourage further growth there, two adjoining cast-iron buildings erected in the 1870's will soon be renovated into a 20,000-square-foot building with both office and retail space.

title: GREEN TOOTH
description: Twenty-two hundred years ago, a stocky middle-aged man was buried in a mass grave in the Negev. Given the condition of his mouth, death may have come as a relief.

title: OCEAN CITY SEEKS VOTE ON BLUE LAWS
description: BUSINESS gains have been substantial among restaurants, amusements and stores, and boardwalk and beach crowds here have been larger for the last nine Sundays as a result of the lifting of a selective blue law.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

THE RIGHTS OF STUDENTS AND ADULTS
description: ROSEMARY was almost 13 years old and a good student in the seventh grade. Her family was intact, she had friends and she was well thought of by her teachers. Rosemary, however, was about 10 pounds overweight and considered herself to be obese and repulsive. The school rules mandated that gym suits were to be worn for the twice-weekly physical education classes. Rosemary could not tolerate being looked at in this outfit by her peers, and began to refuse to dress for gym.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: Sept. 8, 1985
description: Fiction

title: DON'T REWARD INEFFECTIVE RELIEF
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Fire Breaks Out on British Jet But Is Extinguished Quickly
description: A fire broke out on a British Airtours jet as it was about to take off at Gatwick Airport today, but the blaze was extinguished automatically, the airline said.

title: PENN STATE RALLIES TO GAKE 21st STRAIGHT FROM MARYLAND
description: The Maryland football team, considered the school's best in three decades, today suffered the fate of so many of its predecessors: It lost to Penn State.

title: WESTPORT THEATER SETS A FALL SEASON
description: WHILE Tuesday night's opening of '' 'night, Mother'' will be the last in the summer season at the Westport Country Playhouse, it also will be the start of a short autumn season and will signal a new philosophy for the playhouse.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A TRAVELLER'S ROOM. By Elspeth Davie. (Hamish Hamilton/David & Charles, $15.95.) ''Where does it come from?'' demands a character in one of the 19 stories in this collection, ''the idea of order - this unknown, perfect state of things that makes us feel askew. Can you get some sense of it?'' In studiously measured prose, the Scottish writer Elspeth Davie conveys a sense of the repressive power of that idea of order. Almost all of her plots turn on the characters' feelings of ambivalence about their circumspect lives. In the title story a girl imagines that a mysterious traveler is an exotic explorer, only to meet the drab man and discover ''how all adventures can be flattened at one blow, how heroes are simply tired men.'' Several stories suggest that women are particularly likely to be trapped in flat, stiff lives; yet in the end Miss Davie often liberates them. ''It would do you good to let the whole house go crooked for a change,'' one woman is advised and, goaded by thoughts of her gallivanting suitor, she abandons her orderly ways. In ''The Return'' a wife with odd, emerald-green streaks in her hair also deserts a cramped life; she disappears back to her home in the sea. Green hair grows in one other overtly fantastic story, ''Green Head,'' in which a young man sprouts flowers from his scalp. Here the idea of order, gleaned from the known, imperfect state of nature, is robust rather than repressive: ''He was lucky, he realized, to have a rooted season of steady flowering and steady withering.''

title: GLIMPSING THE FUTURE BEFORE IT'S SET IN STONE
description: Rare is the building that looks the same in an architect's drawing as it does on a city street.

title: EASTON PLAYERS BRING SOME GOOD-TIME MUSIC
description: THE best thing about being a member of the Easton Banjo Society, its members say, is that ''banjo music is happy music.''

title: No-Smoking Areas In Restaurants
description: I read Fred G. Sampson's article, ''A Smoking Ban is Bad Business'' [Opinion Page, Aug. 18] , with great interest. For one thing, his logic is wrong.

title: A GAUGE OF PRESSURE
description: Two university professors who conducted a two-year study of the pressure on college athletes have analyzed their findings and come up with some not-quite startling conclusions: Male basketball players on Division I teams are under more pressure from their coaches to sacrifice academics for athletics than their counterparts in Divisions II and III and under far more such pressure than female basketball players, especially Division III women. The study, based on a survey of 644 basketball players from 47 schools and 37 athletic conferences, was conducted in 1983 and 1984 by Allen L. Sack, chairman of the Department of Sociology at the University of New Haven, and Robert Theil, a statistician from Southern Connecticut State. Among other things, they found that 55 percent of the Division I men said their coaches made demands on their time and energy that lowered their academic achievements, but only 7 percent of the Division III women said they were hampered by such demands.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN MILFORD
description: IN 1639, a group of Puritans seeking land on which to settle purchased the site of present-day Milford, Conn., from the Ansantawae Indians for 6 coats, 10 blankets, a kettle, 12 hatchets, 12 hoes, two dozen knives and a dozen small mirrors. Today condominium developers are the principal seekers of land in Milford and they are paying premium prices for it, especially along the 17-mile Long Island Sound coast.

title:
GARDENING;

A ROSE'S JOURNEY TO A TITLE
description: THE competitive urge that prevails in this country has led us to seek out the best in most every field of endeavor and to award them with the title ''all American'' - from all-America football players to the ''all-American beauty,'' Miss America. Some might say that all this is largely frivolous, but there is one all-American title that has proven itself without doubt over the 45 years it has been in existence - the All-America Rose Selection winners.

title: WATT POLICY UPSET BY FEDERAL JUDGE
description: A Federal district judge has ruled that an Interior Department program allowing private ranchers to manage public lands is illegal.

title: APARTMENT DEVELOPMENT IN THE BOROUGHS GETS A LIFT
description: DURING the last session, when the Legislature was agonizing over New York City's Section 421a tax-abatement program for new multifamily housing, the focus of public attention was on one narrow issue: Would rents in buildings already produced under the program be permitted to rise to market levels immediately when the tax abatements ended, or would they remain stabilized?

title: REVILLUSIONARY PUNORAMA
description: AMALGAMEMNON By Christine Brooke-Rose. 144 pp. New York: Carcanet Press. $14.95.

title: Dashing Deputy
description: Politics has often powered the imagination of Jeffrey Archer, the best-selling British writer. His most recent novel, ''First Among Equals,'' details the conflicting fortunes of three Englishmen, each of whom believes himself destined to become Prime Minister.

title: Provincialism Exists Here
description: I was uncomfortable reading the article ''On Leaving Connecticut for the Middle West.'' The attitude of the author reveals a provincialism I frequently find in New England, even among sophisticated, savvy people.

title: LESSONS FOR YOUTHFUL HOBBYISTS
description: Virtually every subject imaginable has been reproduced on stamps: famous people, important events, native customs, geographic features, industrial achievements and historic sites. The store of knowledge offered has earned for stamp collecting its description as ''the educational hobby.''

title: MAYORAL CAMPAIGNS STEAM AHEAD IN PURSUIT OF THE UNWOOED VOTER
description: The three major candidates in Tuesday's Democratic mayoral primary swept through the boroughs yesterday in pursuit of what seemed a rapidly diminishing species - the unwooed voter with unshaken hand.

title: ROAMING WHALE ENLIVENS SOUND
description: MARGE NAVARETTE of Stamford is an ardent fisherman who can usually count on catching an ample batch of blues the late-August Bluefish Tournament that is part of the annual Long Island Sound America Festival. But this year, Mrs. Navarette, fishing off Todds' Point in Greenwich with her husband, Oscar, came up empty.

title: PERI FROST BRIDE OF DAVID CLARK JR.
description: At St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., yesterday Peri Mara Frost, the daughter of Albert Frost of New York and the late Sandra Ruth Frost, was married to David Crawford Clark Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clark of Oyster Bay, L.I. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN DENTISTRY;

COSMETIC DENTISTRY, A GROWTH INDUSTRY
description: ACCORDING to widely-accepted industry estimates, cosmetic procedures will account for 65 percent of restorative dental treatment in 1985, up from 30 percent in 1983 and 14 percent in 1980. Apparently, people who never could stand going to the dentist before are being lured by the promise of a flawless smile attained with minimal discomfort.

title: CYNTHIA BRANCH WEDS REAL ESTATE BROKER
description: Cynthia Branch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Callcote Branch of Bedford, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Paul John Mas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Mas of East Hanover, N.J. The Rev. Dr. William E. Foley performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church.

title: THE NETWORKS SHOOT FOR THE STARS
description: This season will see the networks responding to their audiences' newly acquired power to take a walk in the growing video supermarket. A decade ago, CBS, ABC and NBC only had to wrestle each other for the 91 percent of all television viewers who primarily watched commercial television, but as of last season, the A. C. Nielsen Company reported that about 77 percent of viewing time was spent with the networks. The missing viewers had begun moving to what Paul Klein, a television consultant, recently called ''AOT'' -All Other Television: independent stations, cable and a video-cassette market going through spore-like growth.

title: SUSAN DRAPER WHITE WED
description: Susan Draper White, a daughter of Chareline Tozier of Sioux City, Iowa, and Lyman D. White of Elkhart, Ind., and Harbert, Mich., was married yesterday to Christopher Jon Marentis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Cosmos Marentis of Franklin Square, L.I., and West Palm Beach, Fla. Mrs. Marentis is an advertising sales manager for American Health magazine in New York. Mr. Marentis is an account executive for Backer & Spielvogel, an advertising agency in New York.

title: DR. JOHN J. THEOBALD, EX-SCHOOLS HEAD, DIES AT 80
description: Dr. John J. Theobald, a former Superintendent of New York City's public schools and a Deputy Mayor under Mayor Robert F. Wagner, died Friday at his home in Sands Point, L.I., apparently of a heart attack. He would have been 81 years old today.

title: DECORATED BY HISTORY
description: Though not a soul is to be glimpsed in the 100 interiors in THE ENGLISH ROOM (Harmony Books/Crown, $19.95), it is the servants who seem to have just stepped discreetly aside after polishing the muzzles of the heraldic beasts on the newel posts or straightening the stadium-size Oriental rugs. Derry Moore, who took the evocative photographs, and Michael Pick, who emphasizes English history, designers and architects in his witty text, include two cozy country cottages, a swatch of town houses and a London flat in this visual essay on Englishness at home. But the dramatics, and the fantasy, are left to estates with names like Kedleston Hall (the Derby house of Viscount Scarsdale), about whose massy interior marble pillars Dr. Johnson complained: ''They take up too much room.'' Many of these dwellings, like enormous old oaks, are rooted in England's past, and there is often a melancholy about them that no amount of polishing can remove. Glass cases of curiosities - the collectibles of the outer world brought home by its ''civilizers'' - line the brocade walls of some rooms. In others, ranks of mounted heads stare toward extinction in a decorative fashion that to Evelyn Waugh owed ''more to the taxidermist than the sculptor or painter.'' Mr. Pick parses English style into individuality, eccentricity, love of light and craving for warmth. At Clouds Hill, T. E. Lawrence's Dorset retreat, the bedroom walls are lined in foil (for warmth or coolness) and the high wood bunk bed has a Shaker severity.

title: SHAPIRO SEEKS WAY TO CLOSE GAP
description: WITH public opinion polls giving Governor Kean an early lead of 40 to 50 points over his Democratic opponent, Essex County Executive Peter Shapiro, in the race for Governor this year, the size of the challenger's task is apparent. But there is disagreement over what to do about it. Not only is the gubernatorial race on the ballot, but all 80 seats in the State Assembly will also be contested. The Democratic candidates are eager to see Mr. Shapiro close the gap on Mr. Kean to prevent Republicans riding the Governor's coattails from sweeping them out of office.

title: LEONARD'S RETURN
description: It was the ninth inning of a 7-1 rout, hardly the time to call in a 20-game winner. But Dick Howser, the Kansas City manager, decided to do just that Friday night as the Royals prepared to complete a sweep of a doubleheader against the Milwaukee Brewers in Kansas City.

title: JETS BUMBLE TOWARD THE SEASON
description: LOOKED at coolly, dispassionately, and without open-mouthed astonishment, the Jets are not yet the disaster they seem to be courting. But they could be.

title: NEBRASKA TEAM TRIES TO COPE
description: IN the Nebraska football team's locker room, the cubicle with Number 94 on the door rests undisturbed. It is filled with football shoes, a helmet, shoulder pads, hip pads, knee pads, all the gear that would have been worn this season by Brian Hiemer. He was to have been one of the starting tight ends. He died Aug. 14, a day after shooting himself in the head with a .22-caliber rifle on his parents' farm.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ONE night last month, at the Clinton Inn in Tenafly, 250 winetasters tried something completely different: beer. Members and guests of the Northern Valley Chapter, New Jersey Les Amis du Vin - an international wine-tasting society - educated their palettes to beers from Germany, Belgium, Peru, the Netherlands and the United States, including a sampling from Vernon Valley Brewery, which recently began operating at Action Park.

title: A HUMAN-RIGHTS PANEL FOR EVERY OCCASION
description: IT once seemed so simple to defend human rights in Nicaragua. A group of priests and lay people came together in 1977 and organized a human rights commission to document and shed light on the abuses of the Somoza Government. There was widespread sympathy for their undertaking and acceptance of their legitimacy. Today, that band of human rights advocates has split in various political directions, and there are three human rights commissions run by Nicaraguans.

title: Dance
description: Aside from offering experimentalist dance and performance art of unusual variety, P. S. 122 is one of the most charmingly idiosyncratic dance spaces around, as well as one of the most impudent and adventurous of dance producers. Typically, P. S. 122 calls its showcase program ''New Stuff.'' Sunday night's choreographers are Mark Anderson, Mark Dendy, the Kinematic company, Ralph Lemon and Nina Martin, and the work ranges from ''an aroboreal dance of myth and mystery'' to dance dealing with ''crisis management,'' as P. S. 122 describes it.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: The Go-Go's: Wild at the Greek Music

title: SOUTH AFTICAN STUDENTS: NEW WAVE OF RESISTANCE
description: The children lined up against the wall of the small courtroom to await processing for possible prosecution, so many youthful symbols of resistance. They were among about 800 students rounded up by police and army units at the behest of officials who view as an intolerable challenge to their power the school boycotts that have flared across this racially-divided nation for more than a year.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Washington Talk page Aug. 25 about Chevy Chase, Md., incorrectly named the place that, until 1948, had a covenant that prevented Jews and blacks from owning land. The covenant applied to the Chevy Chase section of the District of Columbia, not to Chevy Chase, Md.

title: CORDELIA REARDON BECOMES A BRIDE ON LONG ISLAND
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Westhampton Beach, L.I., yesterday Cordelia Reardon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy L. Reardon of New York and Westhampton Beach, was married to William Laverack Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Laverack of Andover, Mass., and Sorrento, Me. The Rev. Joseph Murray performed the ceremony.

title: TEDDY KOLLEK'S JERUSALEM
description: The tribute to Teddy Kollek's Jerusalem is truly deserved. While so many cities around the world have deteriorated, Jerusalem has been turned into a beautiful city.

title: WHERE SCRAPPLE MEETS MESQUITE
description: ''Drink Buttermilk and Live Forever'' proclaims the sign above Spataro's buttermilk and sandwich bar in Philadelphia's Reading Terminal Market. Heavy, hinged steel lids, set into the octagonal tiles, indicate where the dairy cans of buttermilk used to be kept on ice, the buttermilk dipped out with a cup. ''Years ago we got it direct from the farmer - now it's all cultured and comes packaged,'' said Mr. Spataro, who's been serving sandwiches and buttermilk in the market since 1947. On the wood shelves behind the counter, white cardboard cartons are stacked for the cottage cheese he still gets in bulk from a farm.

title: RICHARD P. HAMILTON: CHAIRMAN AND EXECUTIVE CHIEF OFFICER , HARTMARX
description: Richard P. Hamilton started cultivating a sure sense for suits at age 13, as he waited on men shopping for a nice wing tip in a 9D or a brown loafer in a 12EEE.

title: HANA PROVES HER PROPHECY
description: WITH the quickness of a cheetah, Hana Mandlikova of Czechoslovakia has been considered the best athlete on the women's tennis tour for some time, the best prospect to be the next great champion sooner or later. And now she's on the way. In the women's final at the United States Open yesterday, she dethroned Martina Navratilova, 7-6, 1-6, 7-6, after having eliminated Chris Evert Lloyd in Friday's semifinals.

title: M'LIZ FLANAGAN BRIDE OF RICKY PAUL PARADIS
description: At St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J., yesterday Mary Elizabeth Flanagan. a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Flanagan Jr. of Summit, N.J., was married to Ricky Paul Paradis, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Paradis of Hubbardsville, N.Y. Msgr. Harold Murray performed the ceremony.

title: Our Way of Life Isn't Perfect, Either
description: Regarding Susan H. Greenberg's article, there is always a view from the other side of the street. I recently moved from a Mid-Atlantic state to western Connecticut and have found things just as frustrating at the other end of the scale here as Ms. Greenberg found in Kansas City.

title: CBS Cuts More Than Corners
description: CBS Inc. disclosed last week how it would try to offset part of the high price it had to pay in turning back Ted Turner's takeover offensive this summer: about 2,000 people, 7 percent of the company's workforce, will be given incentives to retire early. Under the plan, all employees who are at least 55 years old and have 10 years' pension credit will qualify for ''significantly increased'' pension benefits, CBS said.

title: ARE CRIMINALS MADE OR BORN?
description: Dissecting Einstein's brain for the purpose of counting glial cells and relating their number to brain activity and stimulation is hardly cause to assume a conspiracy to minimize genius and further separate the rest of us from it. On the contrary, learning how to stimulate brain growth is far more useful than worrying, as Dr. Reich seems to, that because genius may be ''a very complex thing,'' such research is doomed. DR.MELANIE G. BROWN Fairfield, Iowa

title: JUDGE VOIDS JERSEY RULE ON HOUSEHOLD DATA
description: It was unconstitutional for New Jersey to require that more than 100,000 residents give a water company the name of every individual living in their homes, a Federal judge has ruled.

title: NEW WAYS TO FIX AND SERVE EGGPLANT
description: MANY of the great dishes of France, Italy and the Middle East are created with eggplant. Ratatouille, eggplant Parmigiana and Moussaka are certainly the best known of these. But there are many other ways of cooking this vegetable.

title: MUSIC: 3 PIANO CONCERTI OPEN BEETHOVEN FESTIVAL
description: Combining Beethoven's first three piano concerti on a single program would be a wretched idea for any but an extraordinary pianist. Even with Russell Sherman, who is one, it could seem hard work for a hot summer evening at the Friends of the Arts Beethoven Festival here. But the concert offered rewards commensurate with the effort of concentration; the pianist, and the orchestra of St. Luke's under Raymond Leppard, had much to offer in this music.

title: Detective in Boston Suspended Over Arrest
description: Police Detective Francis G. Kelly Jr. was suspended for one year without pay Friday on each of two department charges of using too much force and filing a false report in the arrest of a Chinese immigrant.

title: PLAYERS' TESTIMONY ADDS DRAMA TO DRUG TRIAL
description: Before the Federal grand jury investigating cocaine distribution in Pittsburgh reached the indictment stage, Commissioner Peter Ueberroth said that he didn't ''expect Pittsburgh to be such a major incident as some others do.'' When the grand jury handed up indictments last May, people in baseball generally stopped holding their collective breath, greatly relieved that no players were indicted. Baseball, the feeling seemed to be, was in the clear.

title: Ethnocentricity Is Everywhere
description: We cannot speak for all Midwesterners, but as native North Dakotans living in Connecticut, we would like to respond to Susan Greenberg's article on her move from Connecticut to Kansas City.

title: STATE'S PLAN FOR PARKWAY STIRS OPPOSITION IN HASTINGS
description: AS part of a program to rehabilitate Westchester parkways, the State Department of Transportation is planning to eliminate most of the traffic-signal intersections on the Saw Mill River Parkway - a plan it says will make the parkway safer and reduce delays to traffic. But the plan has run into heavy resistance in the village of Hastings-on-Hudson, which wants the state to abandon the idea.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

CANADIAN ANNIVERSARY
description: Canada began issuing silver dollars in 1935, the same year the United States stopped and this year marks the golden anniversary of the Canadian series. For perhaps a decade or more, silver dollars dominated the United States coin market, but American collectors and investors have shown no similar interest in the silver dollars of Canada.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: THE South Jersey Gas Company has filed petitions with the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities for permission to offer rate incentives to customers whose activities further the area's economic development.

title: VICTORIA BAKER WEDS WILLIAM H. MASTERS
description: Victoria Maxwell Baker and William Howell Masters 3d, both producer-directors for the ABC television program ''Good Morning America,'' were married yesterday at St. Andrew's Dune Episcopal Church in Southampton, L.I. The Rev. Malcolm Foster performed the ceremony Mrs. Masters, a graduate of Miss Porter's School, is a daughter of Mrs. Henri Ziegler Lake of Southampton and the late John Hamilton Baker, who was a vice president of the Todd Shipyards in New York.

title: TUNNEL VISION
description: NOT long after unearthing an old railway tunnel in Brooklyn in 1980, Robert Diamond dreamed of converting the site, which he called the world's first subway, into a railway museum. A year ago the 25-year-old Brooklyn engineering student set out to make his dream come true.

title: IN THE COUNTRY: 3 INNS CELEBRATE GILDED ELEGANCE
description: No more than 15 years ago the term country inn conjured up bathrooms down the hall, muslin sheets and plain though hearty food, often served at a communal table. The concept of the country inn has changed dramatically in recent years, however, and the category has been enlarged to include everything from restored taverns to refurbished mansions.

title: QUICKNESS RENEWS THE GIANTS
description: THEY sat with their shoulders and heads forward, towels slung around their necks. One held a pencil and drew arrows and the other three nodded. They were together, hunched over a yellow legal pad, scribbling and scratching, taking the pencil from one another. Then, as though they had figured out the map to a treasure, one said out loud, ''That's it. That's what we have to do every time.''

title: HELPING HER MOTHER DIE
description: LAST WISH By Betty Rollin. 236 pp. New York: Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: Revising Children's Classics
description: To the Editor:

title: ROSE, 0-4, STAYS 2 BEHIND COBB
description: Ty Cobb got a reprieve this afternoon. Pete Rose went 0 for 4 and walked once in five times at bat as the Chicago Cubs beat his Reds, 9-7, at Wrigley Field.

title: ANN MEREDITH DICKINSON IS MARRIED TO SIMON COWIE
description: Ann Meredith Dickinson, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Meredith Moore Dickinson of Gardiner, Me., was married there yesterday to Simon Cowie, the son of Gwendolyn Oland Cowie of London and the late David Cowie.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

BETTER BIRDHOUSE
description: They are only 6 inches high, 6 inches wide, and 10 inches deep. But to Beresford Proctor the redwood structures he carefully constructs in his Mamaroneck home are the bluebird boxes of happiness and they bring him large satisfaction.

title: FASSBINDER'S MASTERWORK
description: Rainer Werner Fassbinder, the German film maker, was found dead, apparently from drug and alcohol abuse, on June 10, 1982, 10 days after his 37th birthday. As director, writer and sometimes actor, he had made 43 films in a career that spanned a mere 13 years. He had won international acclaim with productions such as ''The Marriage of Maria Braun,'' ''Despair'' and ''Veronika Voss.'' What is likely to survive as his masterwork, the one most monumentally encompassing his peculiar methods and fierce obsessions, is ''Berlin Alexanderplatz.'' Like much of Fassbinder's work since the early 1970's, this 15 1/2-hour epic was made for television, providing still another convincing example that the medium needn't confine itself exclusively to harmless entertainments and carefully ''balanced'' documentaries. It can provoke and indeed infuriate. It can be exasperating but naggingly memorable. ''Berlin Alexanderplatz'' refuses to pass quietly into some massive graveyard for forgettable television diversions.

title: Protests Resume Against Pinochet
description: Protests against continued military rule in Chile seem to come in waves as President Augusto Pinochet alternately tightens and loosens his dictatorship. Last week the demonstrators were in the streets again, and so were General Pinochet's police.

title: LIVING WITH A GARDEN OF COMPAROMISES
description: Mine is a garden of compromises.

title:
ART;

CAPTURING CREATURES IN STONE AND CANVAS
description: FOR the fifth year, the Elaine Benson Gallery in Bridgehampton is closing out the summer season with a show on the theme of ''Creatures Large and Small.'' Fauna of all varieties, both real and imaginary, grace the gallery's walls, cavort across its floors and ramble around its courtyard.

title: MISS GRAY, TRAVEL AGENCY EXECUTIVE, IS THE BRIDE OF CHRISTOPHER W. CAREY
description: Lucinda H. Gray, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Gray of Dover and South Dartmouth, Mass., was married yesterday to Christopher W. Carey, a son of Mrs. John P. Carey Jr. of Oyster Bay Cove, L.I., and the late Mr. Carey. The Rev. J. Brooke Mosley performed the ceremony at St. Aidan's Episcopal Chapel in South Dartmouth.

title: ARE CRIMINALS MADE OR BORN?
description: Can't our detached theorists of ''criminal behavior'' entertain for one moment the possibility that the young men who commit ''serious street crime'' are responding with logic to a society that keeps them in perpetual poverty, exhaustion and humiliation? And why is it that no criminologist will devote years of patient labor ''to unravel the complex and subtle ways in which intelligence, temperament, hormonal levels and other traits combine with family circumstances and later experiences in school and elsewhere to produce'' the men who poison Bhopal and kite checks for E.F. Hutton? LARRY GOLDSMITH Cambridge, Mass.

title: REMOVING RAMPS IN PHILADELPHIA
description: IN June a conductor for Philadelphia's Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority, leaning out of a moving train to check on a rock-throwing incident behind his car, died after hitting his head against a newly installed ramp.

title: EIGHT FOOD OUTLETS CITED BY NEW YORK FOR VIOLATING CODE
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of eight food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: 80 TEACHERS TAKE ALTERNATE ROUTE
description: MORE than 80 men and women are teaching in New Jersey under the new provisional teacher program, among them a chemical engineer, a microbiologist, a university research assistant and a dentist.

title: CHILD CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIGHAM YOUN STREAK ENDS
description: U.C.L.A. ended Brigham Young's 25-game winning streak tonight with a 27-24 victory. It was the longest active streak and had begun in the 1983 season.

title: A BELUGA WHALE ROAMS THE SOUND
description: MARGE NAVARETTE is an ardent fisherman who can usually count on catching an ample batch of blues the late-August Bluefish Tournament that is part of the annual Long Island Sound America Festival. But this year, Mrs. Navarette, fishing off Todds' Point in Greenwich with her husband, Oscar, came up empty.

title: REALITY AND THE GAMES
description: IN four days we shall arrive at Baseball Thursday, the moment of truth when both New York teams shall meet their nearest competitors, only a few hours and 90 cents apart, change at Grand Central Station from the No. 7 to the No. 4 subway.

title: THE WORLD ON A COUCH
description: FREUD FOR HISTORIANS By Peter Gay. 252 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $17.95.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: NEW SCULPTURE TERRACE The Stamford Museum and Nature Center celebrates the opening today of its art gallery and sculpture terrace. Admission charges will be waived from 1 P.M. to 5 P.M.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: AT FREDDIE'S. By Penelope Fitzgerald. (Godine, $14.95.) What's to be said about a well-meaning book like this? We approach with respect the British novelist Penelope Fitzgerald's first work to appear in America; she won the prestigious Booker Prize for an earlier novel, ''Offshore.''

title: WHY PEOPLE GO TO THE BAD
description: CRIME AND HUMAN NATURE By James Q. Wilson and Richard J. Herrnstein. Illustrated. 639 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title: INDIA BOLSTERING PUNJAB FORCES AS VOTE NEARS
description: The Indian Government moved this week to strengthen its paramilitary forces in the Punjab amid rising fears of further bombings and killings by Sikh extremists before the state elections later this month.

title: A SELECTION OF FALL EVENTS AROUND THE U.S.
description: THE SOUTH: A walk on the wild side and folklore in Miami Just about every Tarheel from Nags Head to Asheville will turn up in Raleigh for the North Carolina State Fair, and others will enjoy it too. The event, running from Oct. 18 to 26, has all the old-fashioned state fair offerings: The homemade and homegrown face fierce competition for ribbons in cooking, horticulture and livestock, with cows and sows and goats. There is a horse show, a demolition derby, a tractor pull, a rodeo and a flower show. There are 100 midway rides and more than 100 craftsmen demonstrating their skills. There are cloggers, mandolin players, banjo pickers and folk dancers competing for prize money. Every night at 7, free entertainment is offered in the Dorton Marina. Hours are 9 A.M. to midnight, Sunday, noon to midnight. Admission is $3, $1 for ages 6 to 12.

title:
GARDENING;

A ROSE'S JOURNEY TO A TITLE
description: THE competitive urge that prevails in this country has led us to seek out the best in most every field of endeavor and to award them with the title ''all American'' - from all-America football players to the ''all-American beauty,'' Miss America. Some might say that all this is largely frivolous, but there is one all-American title that has proven itself without doubt over the 45 years it has been in existence - the All-America Rose Selection winners.

title: FOOD IRRADIATION GETS A GO-AHEAD
description: FOR years, American astronauts traveling in space have consumed foods preserved by nuclear radiation. But the process remained unapproved for widespread use by American consumers here on earth.

title: VICTORIA LEONARD WED IN MARYLAND
description: Victoria Clayton Leonard, the daughter of James G. Leonard of New York and Madison, Conn., and the late Georgine F. Leonard, was married yesterday to Thomas Edward Hambleton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. T. Edward Hambleton of New York and Timonium, Md. The Rev. Kingsley Smith performed the ceremony at the Trinity Episcopal Church in Towson, Md.

title: A NAZI AT RUTGERS, REVISITED
description: Between March and August 1935, Rutgers University conducted an extraordinary proceeding. A special committee of the board of trustees heard public testimony in a case that pitted Lienhard Bergel, an instructor of German and an outspoken anti-Nazi, against his department chairman, Frederick J. Hauptmann, an ardent Nazi sympathizer. When the hearings ended, the committee found in favor of Mr. Hauptmann, upholding his dismissal of Mr. Bergel for incompetence and rejecting arguments that differences over German politics were the real reason.

title: Academic Protege Or Meal Ticket?
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Push For Arms Sales In Middle East
description: Ever since Egypt turned to Moscow for weapons in the 1950's, when Washington refused its demands, the United States has kept the arms pipelines open to its Middle Eastern friends. Pursuing that policy last week, the Reagan Administration said Saudi Arabia, Jordan and Israel needed advanced weapons to promote peace and serve American security interests. A confidential memorandum obtained by The New York Times said American weapons are vital to the three countries' self-confidence and trust in Washington.

title: RODNEY R. PORTER, BIOCHEMIST
description: Prof. Rodney Robert Porter of Oxford University, a biochemist and expert in antibodies who won the Nobel Prize for Medicine in 1972, was killed yesterday in a four-car automobile accident in the cathedral town of Winchester, 60 miles southwest of London, the British police said. He was 67 years old and was to have retired in October.

title: A BASEBALL WRITER'S SHOESTRING CATCH
description: GOOD ENOUGH TO DREAM By Roger Kahn. 351 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $16.95.

title: VICTORIA LEWIS IS WED TO TIMOTHY P. NOLAN
description: At the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn., yesterday Victoria Ann Lewis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Thomas Lewis of Riverside, Conn., and Sarasota, Fla., was married to Timothy Patrick Nolan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Nolan of Elkhart, Ind. The Rev. Dr. Thomas Lowell Stiers and the Rev. Vincent Joseph O'Connor, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: RECITAL: EUGENE FLEMM
description: EUGENE FLEMM, who made his New York debut Thursday night at the newly reopened Carnegie Recital Hall, is a better musician than pianist. Throughout the evening, one could admire his lively, intelligent conceptions of works by Haydn, Beethoven, Chopin, Brahms and Scott Huston, but the resultant performances, while by no means without merit, were rarely as polished or assured as one might have wished.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Puccini's 'Fanciulla del West' A Royal Opera production, featuring Carol Neblett, Placido Domingo and Silvano Carroli; conducted by Nello Santi Thorn EMI/HBO Video 135 minutes. $39.95 Inspired by a David Belasco play, Puccini musicalized America's 19th-century gold rush in ''La Fanciulla del West'' (''The Girl of the Golden West'').

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ROBERT FULTON. By Cynthia Owen Philip. (Franklin Watts, $18.95.) In England, France and the young United States, the last two decades of the 18th century were a time for tinkerers, and no one was better at it than Robert Fulton (1765-1815).

title: HILARY C. DOWNE BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Hilary Campbell Downe, the daughter of Susan Campbell Downe and Edward R. Downe Jr., both of New York, was married yesterday to Richard Carey Hayes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hayes of Shepperton, England. The Rev. Gary Fertig performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York.

title: TEDDY KOLLEK'S JERUSALEM
description: Thomas L. Friedman's encomium of Teddy Kollek conveniently fails to mention the two most salient aspects of the transformation of Jerusalem since 1967: 1.) The systematic eviction of Christian and Moslem Arabs by expropriating their land, razing their homes and closing their community facilities in order to settle Jews in the territories annexed by Israel. 2.)

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HECKSCHER'S BIG SPLASH To celebrate its 65th birthday, the Heckscher Art Museum is throwing itself a party today based on the theme of its new exhibition, ''Waterworks: The Long Island Legacy.'' From 1 to 5 P.M. the Huntington museum on Prime Avenue will be a veritable oasis of artsy fun and games. These include carp-kite making, sidewalk chalk drawing of ''water scenes'' and a concert at 3 P.M. by the local Community Band. Outside, on the Heckscher Park pond, the U.S. Naval Sea Cadet Corps/U.S. Navy League Cadet Corps Nautical Festival will be held from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Said to be the ''world's largest radio-controlled model boat show and contest,'' the festival this year uses the Hawaiian Islands, volcanoes and all, as its decorative thrust, floating them through the pond. Oh, yes, inside the museum there will be paintings - 33 major works by such prominent Long Island artists as Arthur Dove, Balcomb Greene, Fairfield Porter, John Marin and Jane Freilicher, which celebrate the waters that surround us. The day's activities are free. ''Waterworks'' can be seen until Oct. 27 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesdays through Fridays and from 1 to 5 P.M. weekends.

title: GROUP POLISHES PUBLIC WORKS' IMAGE
description: The Holland Tunnel, the New York City subway system, Newark International Airport - cursed at and crowded, they seem unlikely to land on most lists of cherished artistic achievements.

title: JURY HEARS TAPE ON GANG WARS IN BOSTON TRIAL
description: Gennaro J. Angiulo, in the sanctuary of his headquarters in Boston's North End, was reminiscing about gang wars in the 1960's.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;

SURGEON MAKES HIS MARK AS AN ARTIST
description: FORTUNATELY for Joe Wilder, he doesn't have to choose among his several worlds.

title: WASHINGTON'S 'OPTHER' AIRPORT AIMS TO TRIUMPH OVER ITS INCONVENIENCE
description: When Dulles Airport was built on an empty 10,500-acre site in northern Virginia in the early 1960's, it was the first airport in the nation designed for jumbo aircraft.

title: WHEN THE SOIL IS DRY...
description: The widespread drought emergency over most parts of the Northeast comes at a time when gardeners should be busy outdoors --planting new lawns, repairing old one, dividing overgrown perennials, setting out new perennials and evergreens and placing all those hardy bulbs for next spring's flower show.

title: BUILDINGS WITHOUT SOULS
description: NOTHING SHOWS UP MORE DEFINI-tively in a building than a lack of love, unless it is the love of money. Both are in abundant evidence today as, more and more, America's building programs have degenerated to little more than houses and condominiums of exorbitant cost, corporate office buildings and, the icing on the cake, one museum after another.

title: Ralph Lauren THREE PURVEYORS OF EXECUTIVE STYLE
description: The chairman of the board wore a work shirt, old jeans with holes in them and scuffed-up cowboy boots as he talked about what today's American business executive should be wearing. ''Poetic license,'' explained Ralph Lauren, who heads the international Polo/ Ralph Lauren fashion empire.

title: GRAB YOU BIKINI
description: The week's nominee for International Pushover Assignment of 1985 is Mayor Jacques Medecin of Nice, who is to appear at the National Press Club Monday morning to open a five-city tour aimed at persuading American business to locate some of its investment on the French Riviera. He arrives in a capital that has grunted and sweated for a week under the year's most punishing heat and humidity, a time when any non-comatose Washingtonian would sign up for the Riviera in a flash without benefit of color film, bilingual speech or recitation of economic advantage.

title: A SELECTION OF FALL EVENTS AROUND THE U.S.
description: THE SOUTHWEST: Texas prison opens gates for its 54th rodeo Texas traditions might seem a bit odd to outsiders, but few can beat the Texas Prison Rodeo. Every October since 1931, the gates of the prison in Huntsville swing open and tens of thousands of visitors stream in to watch the state's convicts buck broncos, milk wild cows and ride bulls. There's also some big name country entertainment, headed this year by Willie Nelson.

title: CATHERINE DERVICHIAN WEDS
description: At Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Rumson, N.J., yesterday Catherine F. Dervichian, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Dervichian of Brussels, was married to Richard Story Riker, a son of Richard J. Riker of New York and Mrs. James M. Weil Jr. of Rumson. The Rev. Thomas R. Rittenhouse performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is an administrator for Swift, an international banking organization in Brussels.

title: DR. SCHJNEIDER MARRIED TO HENRY B. MCNULTY
description: Dr. Anne Margaret Schneider, an obstetrician and gynecologist in Waterbury, Conn., and Henry Bryant McNulty, an associate editor of The Hartford Courant, were married yesterday at Immanuel Congregational Church in Hartford. The Rev. Richard B. Griffis performed the ceremony.

title: NATIONAL GALLERY ASSEMBLES A 20th-CENTURY SHOW
description: With a smile of satisfaction, Jack Cowart surveyed the new exhibition of 20th century painting and sculpture at the National Gallery of Art. ''The general feeling is that it is beginning to look like a collection, for the first time,'' said Mr. Cowart, the gallery's curator for 20th century art.

title: ROUTE 206 LEAVING ITS RURAL PAST BEHIND
description: IT was not so long ago that the prettiest drive in New Jersey was U.S. Route 206. Starting near Montague, on the banks of the Delaware, the friendly two-laner ambled gently through Newton farmland, breezed by stately homes in Pluckemin and whisked along the outskirts of Princeton before slowing to a crawl in downtown Trenton.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

SCHOOLS NEED AN ENVIRONMENT FREE OF DRUGS
description: THE latest action in the Becton Regional High School Drug Prevention Program is a blow to a safe environment for teen-agers. On a motion by the American Civil Liberties Union, a court has ordered the school board not to start mandatory urine and blood testing for drugs as a requirement for admission to high school each year, pending full hearing in court. [Last Tuesday, both sides agreed to a temporary restraining order issued by Judge Peter Ciolino in Superior Court. Trial was scheduled for Nov. 12. Meanwhile, the drug tests will not be conducted.] The issue revolves around confusion about the nature of teen-age drug abuse.

title: VILLAGE TO LIMIT DOCTORS?
description: THE village trustees of Lawrence are considering a proposal that will prevent doctors and dentists from starting practices in their homes.

title:
SAMPLER OF AUTUMN EXCURSIONS;

A SELECTION OF FALL EVENTS AROUND THE U.S.
description: THE WEST: A time for bald eagles and Yellowstone elk Mid-November in Glacier National Park brings a gathering of eagles.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: LAWS restricting pornography can demean women as much as the material itself, says Katherine Ellis, a professor of English at Rutgers University in New Brunswick.

title: M. CAROLE TERRY IS WED TO STEPHEN JOHN BRADY
description: The marriage of M. Carole Terry, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Hart Terry of Syracuse, N.Y., to Stephen John Brady, took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Rosary in Syracuse. Msgr. Robert F. Lavin performed the ceremony.

title: BUTTLE DESERVES BEST OF LUCK
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: EMISSIONS TEST DEFIES LOGIC
description: WHILE some state legislators continue to question the worthiness of the Connecticut Motor Vehicle Emissions Inspection, citizens apparently have settled into accepting it as simply another bureaucratic thorn in their sides.

title: F.A.S.B.
description: To the Editor:

title: RACIAL ISSUE RAISED IN HARTFORD PRIMARY
description: RACE became an issue last week in Hartford's Democratic primary, with battlelines drawn between the city's predominently black North End and the predominently white South End.

title: PUTTING BOING IN A CLASS BY ITSELF
description: WHEN T. A. Wilson became chief executive of the Boeing Company in 1969, it was on the brink of collapse. Commercial airplane orders had dried up, Government aerospace business was being cut back and Boeing was reeling under the development costs of the 747 jumbo jet.

title:
GARDENING;

A ROSE'S JOURNEY TO A TITLE
description: THE competitive urge that prevails in this country has led us to seek out the best in most every field of endeavor and to award them with the title ''all American'' - from all-America football players to the ''all-American beauty,'' Miss America. Some might say that all this is largely frivolous, but there is one all-American title that has proven itself without doubt over the 45 years it has been in existence - the All-America Rose Selection winners.

title: ONE GOOD SUMMIT REQUIRES ANOTHER
description: President Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev are traveling unnecessarily devious paths toward the Geneva summit. With only 10 weeks left to prepare, they have yet to rise above the thickets of suspicion and seem more concerned with blaming each other for failure than averting it. They apparently neglected to decide how best to spend their few hours together and what mood they want to impart to their bureaucracies. That risks leaving the bureaucracies to carry on in deplorable confusion.

title: DEMAND MAY EXCEED THE CD SUPPLY
description: In audio, the prospect before us is like a clear sky with a dark cloud in the middle. Thanks to the phenomenal success of compact disks, the audio industry has been buoyed both economically and in terms of its inventive vitality. Basic design principles for all types of components are being critically reexamined and revised. We are in the midst of a period of intense creative effort by audio engineers, with the results evident everywhere as the shops fill up for fall.

title: FOREIGHN-BORN PRIESTS FIGHT FOR ACCEPTANCE
description: THE Rev. Antonio S. Pascual, who came to Elmont from the Phiippines in 1975 to serve the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre, sometimes tells a joke to describe the plight of foreign-born priests on Long Island.

title: DODGING THE GRAFT
description: Politicians are making money as never before, and that is wrong.

title: SUIT BY PRISONER SEEKS COLLEGE AID
description: Oral argument begins Tuesday in New Hampshire Supreme Court in a case that lawyers for the state say could require the Government to finance the college education of any qualified prison inmate.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: AWAAAAAY THEY GO PETER CRESCENTI of Huntington and Robert Columbe of Bay Shore are finding it hard to eat lunch these days. They are the co-presidents of RALPH, the Royal Association for the Longevity and Preservation of ''The Honeymooners,'' a fan club for the old Jackie Gleason television show. They have been trying to fit their ''career hobby'' into their lunch hours and vacations, but the schedule is getting a little crowded.

title: City to Seek Police Cadets
description: Hoping to increase the number of college graduates working as New York police officers, city officials announced last week that they would offer summer jobs and scholarships to sophomores at local colleges. Under the program, students who live and attend school in New York could be granted $1,500 during each of their last two years of college and work each summer alongside community patrol officers.

title: MADRID
description: A cultural and spiritual renaissance has taken hold in Spain since the death of Francisco Franco 10 years ago, and nowhere is it more evident than in the capital, Madrid.

title: CATHERINE FIELD BECOMES BRIDE OF CARL GERCKE
description: Catherine Field, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Warner Field of New Haven and Fenwick, Conn., was married yesterday to Carl Givens Gercke, a son of Mrs. Guy G. Gardiner of Crowley, La., and the late George J. Gercke. The Rev. Francis Cheney performed the ceremony at St. Mary's-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Old Saybrook, Conn.

title:
GARDENING;

A ROSE'S JOURNEY TO A TITLE
description: THE competitive urge that prevails in this country has led us to seek out the best in most every field of endeavor and to award them with the title ''all American'' - from all-America football players to the ''all-American beauty,'' Miss America. Some might say that all this is largely frivolous, but there is one all-American title that has proven itself without doubt over the 45 years it has been in existence - the All-America Rose Selection winners.

title: 'CAUTIOUS' ESTIMATE ON STATE REVENUES
description: AS they closed the books on a robust year that brought Connecticut a record budget surplus, state officials lowered their sights a bit last week on expectations for the current fiscal year.

title: F.B.I. DISCERNS BIG GAIN ON PUERTO RICO TERRORISTS
description: With the arrests of 17 men and women, the Federal Bureau of Investigation may be near to breaking a major terrorist organization operating here and on the United States mainland, a bureau agent here says.

title: EDMEE SCHAEFER BECOMES A BRIDE IN RYE CEREMONY
description: Edmee Moran Schaefer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Jay Schaefer 3d of Stonington, Conn., was married yesterday to Charles Justin Zahringer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George John Zahringer Jr. of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Joseph P. Bishop performed the ceremony at the Rye Presbyterian Church, assisted by Msgr. Donald J. Pryor, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: YOUNG SPACE ENTHUSIASTS CROWD ALABAMA CAMP
description: Television monitors flicker in the darkness inside Mission Control, where teen-agers wearing radio headsets crouched at consoles, pretending to guide the space shuttle Challenger to a landing at Cape Canaveral.

title: It's Batter Up In a Federal Court
description: Curtis Strong, a Philadelphia caterer, sat at the defense table in a Federal courtroom in Pittsburgh last week, but to many minds, major league baseball was on trial with him. Mr. Strong was accused of selling cocaine to a string of big leaguers, and several of them - perhaps emboldened by immunity from prosecution - stepped to the witness box to testify. They dropped enough names to make an all-star team.

title: PRESERVE THE TAX DEDUCTIONS
description: LONG ISLAND'S high cost of living and lack of affordable housing are driving our young people away - at a rate of seven each day.

title: HEPATITIS AT 2 CONNECTICUT SITES
description: Connecticut health officials are investigating several cases of infectious hepatitis that have broken out in the last two and a half weeks at a hotel in Danbury and a factory in Wilton.

title: 3 HURT IN BOAT EXPLOSION
description: A fisherman and two Coast Guardsmen suffered burns Friday when an 80-foot trawler sailing from New Jersey to Massachusetts caught fire and exploded into flames that engulfed a Coast Guard utility boat, the authorities said. The three victims were taken by a Coast Guard helicopter to a medical station on Block Island, where they were treated for second-degree burns. Investigators have not yet determined what caused the explosion.

title: MCENROE, LENDL REACH FINAL
description: Ivan Lendl has already had more opportunities than most players get. Now he will have yet another. Late this afternoon he will make his fourth consecutive appearance in the final of the United States Open - a Grand Slam of sorts - but this time he would like to win the championship he says he covets the most.

title: LOW INFLATION REINS IN REALTY-TAX RISES
description: LOW inflation has helped check the rise in real estate taxes in the New York metropolitan area, and this year, once again, most homeowners saw their tax bills increasing by only moderate amounts. Some even had their tax bills decline.

title: CAPE COD BIDS ADIEU
description: YEAR-ROUND residents of Cape Cod celebrated last week what they are calling ''Over the Bridge'' days, the time when the temporary summer dwellers and tourists cross the Bourne and Sagamore Bridges over the Cape Cod Canal and head for home.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: FORTY: The Age and the Symbol. By Stanley Brandes. (University of Tennessee, $12.95.) When Tom Seaver won his 300th baseball game recently, the sportscasters questioned him at length about the symbolic (in baseball) meaning of the number 300, but little fuss was made over his age - 40. Stanley Brandes, a professor of anthropology at the University of California, Berkeley, believes we are so in thrall of the number 40 that we expect and often create a crisis at this time of life. Assuming the so-called midlife crisis to be a fact, Mr. Brandes goes on to explain why it exists and to examine its legitimate and illegitimate foundations in biology, history and mythology.
