He discusses and dismisses most of the biological evidence for midlife crises, cites interesting and contradictory historical evidence from Dante to Montaigne to Erik Erikson, and catalogues at length the symbolic uses of the number from the 40 days of the Flood to the 40 days Jesus spent in the desert to ''Ali Baba and the Forty Thieves.'' The examples, whose meanings often seem at odds with one another, indicate that 40 has been and is seen as a turning point. But in some examples, 40 is the age when wisdom begins or when rebirth takes place; in others, it is the age when one's usefulness ends or when death takes hold. Mr. Brandes concludes that a life transition at 40 is a ''collective fantasy'' that is the ''combined product of . . . cultural, social, and economic circumstances.''

title: WHAT DO FARMERS WANT?
description: OF approximately 4,000 farms in Connecticut, 1,000 are commercial farms that produce more than half the family income. The remaining 3,000 farmers are part-timers. Less than 5 percent of the farms are owned by corporations, principally family corporations formed to help transfer farms from generation to generation.

title: JAPAN PROTECTS ITS ARTISTIC HERITAGE
description: There are laws to keep the best of Japan's ancient art in Japan. And beyond the laws there are the Japanese themselves.

title: A MARTYR TO SEX AND LITERATURE
description: OUR THREE SELVES The Life of Radclyffe Hall. By Michael Baker. Illustrated. 386 pp. New York: William Morrow. $17.95. UNA TROUBRIDGE The Friend of Radclyffe Hall. By Richard Ormrod. Illustrated. 340 pp. New York: Carroll & Graf. $18.95.

title: ART IS WHAT YOU CALL IT
description: WHY DUCHAMP An Essay on Aesthetic Impact. By Gianfranco Baruchello and Henry Martin. Illustrated. 158 pp. New Paltz, N.Y.: Documentext/McPherson & Company. Cloth, $20. Paper, $10. GIANFRANCO BARUCHELLO, an Italian artist whose real gift may be for conversation, has talked another book into print. Like ''How to Imagine,'' a book by Mr. Baruchello published last year - a stream of ideas, verbal images and mental fireworks on dozens of loosely related subjects, from sugar beets to death and the soul - ''Why Duchamp'' has been distilled and edited by Mr. Baruchello's friend Henry Martin from many hours of taped Baruchello monologues. ''Why Duchamp,'' however, has only one subject - how to make use of the life and works of Marcel Duchamp.

title: WESTPORT SETS FALL SEASON
description: WHILE Tuesday night's opening of '' 'night, Mother'' will be the last in the summer season at the Westport Country Playhouse in nearby Connecticut, it also will be the start of a short autumn season and will signal a new philosophy for the playhouse.

title: MINOR CANDIDATES SEEKING ATTENTION
description: Left out of most debates and rarely noticed by the public in New York, three candidates for the Democratic nomination for mayor argue that, if their support is slight, their ideas are worth attention.

title: MUSIC: THE CHOIR OF KINGS COLLEGE
description: THE night was sweltering, the midtown air all but poisonous with pollen and pollution, but a capacity audience found its way to St. Thomas Church Friday evening for a beautiful program by the Choir of Kings College, Cambridge.

title: HELPING THE REBELS
description: 'It seems to me that the National Security Council is involved in intelligence activities, and I don't see how they can escape the Congressional prohibition against assistance to the rebels fighting the Government of Nicaragua.' rrRepresentative Lee H. Hamilton rrchairman of the Select Committee on Intelligence.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: OUT OF ORDER: Affirmative Action and the Crisis of Doctrinaire Liberalism. By Nicholas Capaldi. (Prometheus Books, $17.95.) With the Reagan Administration committed to ending affirmative action programs, the intellectual case underlying opposition to them is a timely topic.

title: TRIBUTE TO KERN IN CHESTER
description: TODAY in Chester, the Norma Terris Theater will resound with the music of Jerome Kern, the American composer of such musicals as ''Show Boat'' and songs such as ''Look for the Silver Lining.'' Joining the tribute to Mr. Kern, who was born 100 years ago, will be Miss Terris herself, the former star of musicals for whom the theater was named.

title: Performance Art
description: ''Thomas Cole: a Waking Dream'' is being billed as ''an unsung cantata'' - a collaboration by the composer and saxophonist Henry Threadgill, the writer-director Donald Sanders and the set and costume designer Vanessa James. Although it takes place Wednesday through next Sunday to open the season of New Jazz at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, the 90-minute work is not exactly a jazz concert or a conventional theatrical work or, indeed, a ballet; the idea is to meld visual and musical elements as absolute equals.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN DENTISTRY
description: TEN years ago, Terry McDonald, an orthodontist in Salem, Ore., had a waiting list for his services. Now that list has evaporated, a casualty, Dr. McDonald says, of a declining teen-age population and a sluggish local economy. So Dr. McDonald and Salem's seven other othodontists have done something they never thought they would do: advertise in the local paper, with such slogans as ''When you dress for success, don't forget your smile.''

title:
INVESTING;

A STOCK FUND BETS ON 'THE NEXT JAPAN'
description: ON Wall Street, some analysts are promoting South Korea as the next Japan. A few even go so far as to say that the Koreans are more entrepreneurial and hard-working than the Japanese. ''It is a thriving capitalist society, in many ways even more so than Japan,'' said P. Maureen White, an analyst with New York's First Boston Corporation. ''The Government is in the business of creating profitable companies.''

title: Trial Ruled Necessary In Trump Housing Case
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan has ruled that the question of whether the developer Donald Trump has been harassing tenants to get them out of a building he owns must be decided in a trial.

title: REAGAN PLANNING KRUGERRAND BAN IF GATT APPROVES
description: President Reagan is expected to announce on Monday that the United States will ban the sale of South African gold krugerrands in this country if permission to do so is granted by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, Administration officials said today.

title: REMOVING THE RUST BEFORE IT BECOMES TOO LATE
description: ALTHOUGH metal kitchen cabinets, dishwashers, clothes washers, dryers and other home appliances usually have tough, baked-on enamel finishes, in time these will start to chip or flake off and rust will begin to eat its way into the metal. This is especially true of dishwashers and clothes washers because of their constant exposure to hot water and strong detergent and bleach.

title: THE MICHENER PHENOMENON
description: The elderly gentleman sitting quietly in an Austin, Tex., restaurant, hands folded before him, tends to stare straight ahead into space. It is impossible for someone who has just met him to know whether this signals shyness, boredom, the self-absorption of an obsessive writer or the natural distraction of a 78-year-old, tired and hungry at the end of a long day. But it is the most surprising of James A. Michener's many unexpected traits - this author, renowned for his curiosity, does not seem curious about other people; he rarely meets your eyes.

title: IN POP MUSIC, THE OUTLOOK IS DEFINITELY BULLISH
description: The bell has rung and the class of '86 is filing in from recess. Here come a crew of record executives, talking bullishly of the coming pop-music season while they total up the profits from what's been a very good year. Straggling in after them, singly or in small groups, come some long-time truants, clutching new works that signify their intentions to go ahead and shoot for the moon. Stevie Wonder's got ''In Square Circle'' (Motown), his long-awaited new album, in the stores this week. Hall and Oates and a couple of old friends, the ex-Temptations Eddie Kendricks and David Ruffin, are clutching their joint class project, a soulful album recorded ''Live at the Apollo,'' for release later this month on RCA.

title: SINGER WON FAMRE AS 'G.I.'S SINATRA
description: Johnny Desmond, the singer and actor who rose to fame as a vocalist with Glenn Miller's swing band, died of cancer on Friday night at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 65 years old. The singer had performed in New York as recently as last April, at the Rainbow Room.

title: An American Asserts Greeks Seized Him Without Charges
description: A 74-year-old Albanian-American traveling through Greece says he was arrested by the airport police at the Athens airport and held for two days in late August without being informed of any charges against him, and without being allowed to get in touch with the American Embassy.

title: CHILD CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: MERCHANT MARINE WINS
description: The fullback Chris Fiore had three touchdowns and the quarterback Skip Azzarita passed for two scores today as Merchant Marine Academy defeated St. John's, 35-14, in the first game of the Liberty Football Conference. The other members of the league are Fordham, Post, Pace and Iona.

title: DAY-CARE CENTER OPENS AT PACE
description: REFLECTING a growing national trend of providing child-care services on campuses for the increasing numbers of older college students, Pace University opened a new day-care program last week for the children of its students.

title: IN QUOTES
description: Americans ''don't like the attitude of the President of the United States.

title: A SELECTION OF FALL EVENTS AROUND THE U.S.
description: AROUND D.C.: Cheers for the Blue; Mr. Jefferson's legacy Not too many towns in the United States are prettier or more historic than Annapolis, the capital of Maryland. It is also the home of the United States Naval Academy, an attraction in itself. There are football games, with the return of the running back Napoleon McCallum promising lots of scoring. The remaining home games are against the Air Force Academy on Oct. 12, Lafayette College on Oct. 19, Pittsburgh University on Oct. 26 and Syracuse University on Nov. 9. Tickets can be obtained easily and reserved seats cost $12.

title: WINDOWS INTO THEIR WORK: ARCHITECTS AS WRITERS
description: ''ARCHITECTURE is built with bricks and stones, not with words,'' Philip Johnson argued in 1975. Yet 20 years earlier he had conceded that ''artists who write . . . have a great advantage, especially if they have a broad theoretical bent. Le Corbusier, Wright, Neutra and Mendelsohn are good architects, but their reputations are surely enhanced by their voluminous publications.'' A century before that, the American architect Andrew Jackson Downing had been less sanguine about the literary talent of his colleagues but no less certain about the role of the architect in shaping society's views of the art. ''While a general ignorance on the subject of architecture among us must be admitted,'' he said, ''this very innocence is mainly owing to the dry and barren manner in which architects have usually written on the real meaning or philosophy of their art. It would seem that men who work our beautiful thoughts in ponderous stone seldom wield so slight an implement as a pen with grace and power.''

title: 40 YEARS LATER, 'NOBLE ACT' IS RECALLED
description: NEARLY four years ago, Jean Berger, 72, of Yonkers, lay on the floor of a Manhattan subway car, deliberately tripped by a young girl who, she said, ''wanted to have a laugh.'' Although Mrs. Berger cried out, no one would help her, and, as the car went through a series of stops, she said she thought she was ''going to be killed.'' Finally, at one station, a man got in, saw Mrs. Berger's plight, and came to her aid. He stayed with her for hours, making sure she received the proper medical attention. Much to her regret, Mrs. Berger said, she never learned his name.

title: AFGHAN REBELS SAID TO DOWN AIRLINER, KILLING 52
description: The official Afghan radio said today that rebels had shot down an Afghan airliner with a United States-made ground-to-air missile as it took off from the Kandahar airport in southern Afghanistan, killing all 52 people aboard. [Afghan guerrilla groups based in Pakistan said they did not know about the report, The Associated Press reported. ''We know nothing of this,'' said one senior guerrilla official. ''We will have to check.''] The radio, monitored in Islamabad, said the plane of the domestic Bakhtar Afghan Airlines was shot down Wednesday during a flight from the capital, Kabul, to the western province of Farah, bordering Iran.

title: SHOREHAM IS ISSUE IN SUFFOLK RACES
description: The future of the Shoreham nuclear power station has become a central issue in many of the races this fall for seats in Suffolk's County Legislature, which has consistently voted against the opening of the plant.

title: Hurricane Takes Course Away From Hawaii
description: Hurricane Pauline turned north today and moved away from the Hawaii Islands, but a potentially stronger, second hurricane could still threaten the islands, the National Weather Service said.

title: FIRST VARSITY GAME
description: Sean Mahoney passed for two touchdowns today as Worcester State College opened its first varsity season after 17 years of playing on the club level with a 14-0 victory over Western New England.

title: THE WEAVERS OF WEEKEND TWEEDS
description: Tweed began humbly, as the homespun, black and white checked blanket, or ''plaid,'' favored by Scottish shepherds. Wrapped around the body, the heavy woolen cloth served as protection from rain and cold, or even to warm lambs and lassies.

title: NANCY WEINSTOCK WED TO DR. R.N. KOLESNICK
description: Nancy Jane Weinstock, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Weinstock of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Dr. Richard Neal Kolesnick, the son of Seymour Kolesnick and Louise Kolesnick, both of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Martin Cohen performed the ceremony at Hampshire House in Manhattan.

title: IN 300TH YEAR, CHURCH CELEBRATES AND PRESERVES
description: SUNDAY mornings in the 1680's, tenant farmers and their families came on foot and on horseback to worship in the new Dutch Reform Church of Sleepy Hollow, built of native fieldstone by their patroon, Vredryck Flypse (Anglicized later to Philipse). They came from all parts of Philipsburg Manor, the vast land holdings of the patroon that stretched from the Bronx to Croton on both sides of the Albany Post Road.

title: THE EXECUTIVE STYLE
description: Although successful men routinely take risks in many aspects of their professional lives, today they generally opt for a conservative approach to their wardrobes. A man's desire to look as if he has ''arrived'' - indeed, long ago -translates into a seriousness of attitude toward his attire.

title: DARE IS HERE
description: WHAT YOU MEAN sometimes depends on where you are.

title: LESLIE MILLS WED IN RHODE ISLAND
description: Leslie Augusta Mills, the daughter of Mrs. Douglas R. Riggs of Newport, R.I., and the late Richard Alsager of Wilson, N.C., was married yesterday to Thomas Alan Greene Jr., the son of Mrs. Richard Wilde of Lake Forest, Ill., and Mr. Greene of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. D. Lorne Coyle performed the ceremony at the Trinity Episcopal Church in Newport.

title: ARIZONA MAN GETS NEW HUMAN HEART
description: A 25-year-old Arizona man was given a new human heart early today after a medical team raced to and from Tyler, Tex., to obtain an organ to replace the artificial heart implanted as a desperate measure nine days ago.

title: MUSEUMS SET THE TONE IN ARCHITECTURE
description: This season in architecture will belong, more than any in years, to the museum. Three museum buildings of national importance will open in the first few weeks of autumn: the National Building Museum - housed in one of Washington's greatest works of 19th-century architecture, the Pension Building -will open its doors Sept. 20; the Hood Museum of Art at Dartmouth College, by the distinguished architect Charles Moore, will make its debut with a weeklong series of events at the end of September, and the Sackler Wing, a major addition to Harvard's Fogg Art Museum and the first museum in the United States by the great British architect James Stirling, will open in October.

title: MANDLIKOVA WINS OPEN BY UPSETTING NAVRATILOVA
description: For the last five years, women's tennis has waited for the day when Hana Mandlikova would realize her full potential. Yesterday, at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadow, that day finally arrived.

title: BAY STATE LANDMARK, ON E.P.A. LIST, IS OFF LIMITS
description: For almost 75 years, the townspeople here paid little attention to the Baird & McGuire plant on a rise of the Cochato River wetlands.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: FOOTFALL by Larry Niven and Jerry Pournelle (Del Rey/Ballantine, $17.95) tries to serve two masters, and gets away with it. I'm not referring to the collaborators, both of whom are science fiction writers whose previous books have attracted a substantial readership. Their latest novel is a structural hybrid that shouldn't work but does. On the one hand, it is a big, fat ''crossover'' novel clearly aimed at an audience more familiar with the formulas of mass-market fiction, such as pop psychology and boudoir athleticism, than the conventions of science fiction. On the other hand, its science fiction elements are handled with a skill found only in the best of the genre.

title: SUSAN MARTENS MARRIES
description: The marriage of Susan Maria Martens, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Martens of Mount Pocono, Pa., to John Samuel Cooper, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Cooper of Swiftwater, Pa., took place yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Mount Pocono. Msgr.

title: BLUNDERING INTO AN UNBEATABLE CONTRACT
description: If one were looking for the weirdest hand of 1984, or indeed of any year, the diagramed deal would be a good candidate. It occurred at the Summer Nationals in Washington, D.C., about a year ago and was played in several events there and in some four-hundred clubs throughout North America competing in the International Fund Game.

title: ORADELL RESERVOIR FISHING: GOOD, BUT NOT WHAT IT USED TO BE
description: STANLEY ALEXANDER'S gold-plated spinner hit the water 40 feet from shore and, reeling in, he felt a nibble.

title: ON BROADWAY, THE ACCENT WILL BE DECIDEDLY BRITISH
description: Surveying the theater season used to be a simpler thing.

title: Water-Flow Devices
description: To the Editor:

title: A LOT LESS ORDER IN CLEVELAND COURT
description: Until a few weeks ago, Cleveland's Federal Courthouse was often called ''Fortress Battisti.'' It is a forbidding building, matching, Cleveland residents said, the power of Frank J. Battisti, for 16 years chief judge of the United States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio. But there has been a palace revolt at the courthouse, and hardly anyone is calling it ''Fortress Battisti'' anymore. On Wednesday, the Judicial Council of the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals, which is charged with disciplining judges and mediating court disputes, will hold a hearing on Judge Battisti's feud with the 11 other Federal judges here over how much power he should have.

title: An Understanding On Salvation
description: Is faith alone enough to attain salvation? Or does it also depend, as Roman Catholics assert, upon a believer's good works? A disagreement on that sensitive issue of Christian faith has divided Protestants and Catholics since the Reformation in the 16th century.

title: ONE-MAN SHOWS WILL ENRICH THE SEASON
description: The 1985-86 art season is notable for the unusually large number of promising exhibitions. The season is particularly strong in sculpture and in unexpected glimpses of the ancient and medieval worlds. There is no pattern to this season's shows, however, and there is no exhibition with the across-the-board appeal of last season's ''Van Gogh in Arles'' and '' 'Primitivism' in 20th-Century Art.''

title: TEACHERS DIVIDED ON AIDS
description: THE first case of pediatrics AIDS in the nation was discovered in New Jersey in 1981, but it was not until last month that the state Health Department developed a policy on AIDS-afflicted children in public schools.

title: SCHOOLS IN NEW YORK WILL ADMIT AN AIDS PUPIL BUT NOT 3 OTHERS
description: On the first day of school last week, a teacher stopped his car in downtown Miami and picked up three little girls, Diana, Deana, and Juliana, who giggled and smiled and showed no striking signs of disease.

title: Helping the Aged With Drug Misuse
description: Thank you for bringing the little-known problem of rising drug abuse and misuse to the attention of your readers [''Misuse of Drugs by Elderly on the Rise,'' Aug. 4] .

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CANNED GOODS AS CAVIAR: American Film Comedy of the 1930s. By Gerald Weales. (University of Chicago, Cloth, $35. Paper, $12.95.) In this excellent (if cumbersomely titled) book, Gerald Weales scrutinizes 12 films, including such classics as ''City Lights,'' ''Duck Soup,'' ''Bringing Up Baby'' and ''My Man Godfrey.''

title: KIMBERLY PERKINS WEDS J.B. WESTCOTT
description: Kimberly A. Perkins, a daughter of Mrs. William F. Prehn of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and Jamestown, R.I., and the late Richard A. Perkins, was married yesterday to Jeffrey B. Westcott, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Westcott of Springfield, Ohio. The Rev. James Bocchino performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Jamestown.

title: MEMOIRS OF A WOULD-BE CATHOLIC GIRLHOOD
description: A HIDDEN CHILDHOOD #1942-1945. By Frida Scheps Weinstein. Translated by Barbara Loeb Kennedy. 151 pp. New York: Hill & Wang/Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $13.95.

title: THE TICK OF TIME
description: A clock and weather vane that were covered in a 1960's modernization project were recently rediscovered during the initial stages of restoration of a 19th century building in downtown Troy, N.Y.

title: ANNE BAVIER DARIEN BRIDE
description: Anne Bavier, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Bavier Jr. of Darien, Conn., and Seabrook Island, S.C., was married in Darien yesterday to Alan Mark DeSantis, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene M. DeSantis of Pound Ridge, N.Y. The Rev. Lawrence MacColl Horton performed the ceremony at the Noroton Presbyterian Church.

title: A FEW INVENTIONS THAT NEED INVENTING
description: EVERY Feb. 11, the birthday of Thomas A. Edison, the National Inventors Hall of Fame inducts a handful of worthy men (no women so far, but that is not the issue here) into its ranks. Among the 1985 honorees was Dr. Willem Kolff, whose invention is described as a ''soft-shell, mushroom-shaped artificial heart.'' Kudos, Dr. Kolff! No one can dispute the impact of your creation on medicine and mankind, nor your deservedness of the highest honor.

title: MIRANDA JOHNSON WEDS MARK HADDAD
description: The marriage of Miranda Stuart Johnson, a candidate for a doctorate in Renaissance studies at Yale University, to Mark Edmonde Haddad, a law clerk to Federal Judge Louis Pollak in Philadelphia, took place yesterday at Cunningham House in Rochester. Associate Justice Elizabeth Pine of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court, Fourth Department, performed the ceremony.

title: ATHLETES INELIGIBLE
description: Charles Shackleford, a top basketball recruit, and three football players have been ruled ineligible for sports for their freshman year at North Carolina State, The Greensboro (N.C.) News & Record reported yesterday. The decision by the school's chancellor, Bruce Poulton, was based on the fact that the athletes failed to meet certain academic requirements, the newspaper said.

title: JENNIFER A. KUDE PLANS TO BE WED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard Otis Duke of Sylvania, Ohio, of the engagement of Mr. Duke's daughter Jennifer Anne Duke to Alexander Whelan Rutherfurd, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Guy Gerard Rutherfurd of New York and Allamuchy, N.J. The wedding is planned for Nov. 2.

title: STATE AIDS SEE NO BAR TO WAGE-EQUITY EFFORT
description: New York's multimillion-dollar program to increase wages in some state jobs dominated by women and members of minority groups will not be slowed by a court decision in the State of Washington on comparable worth, officials said.

title: REALITY WITH WITCHES
description: DREAMTIME Concerning the Boundary Between Wilderness and Civilization. By Hans Peter Duerr. Translated by Felicitas Goodman. Illustrated. 462 pp. New York: Basil Blackwell. $24.95.

title: NEW YORK'S SHORTAGE OF ORGAN DONORS GROWS ACUTE
description: New York's seatbelt law has saved more than 100 lives since it took effect on the first of the year, according to state officials. But in a way that no one anticipated and almost no one wants to talk about, the new law has also made saving lives more difficult. The reduction in the carnage on the highways has led to a dramatic decline in the number of human organs available for transplant.

title: Bell Speaks, Hutton Listens
description: The Justice Department came in for considerable criticism on Capitol Hill for being soft on corporate crime when it decided not to prosecute executives of E.F. Hutton & Company after the brokerage house pleaded guilty to 2,000 felony counts of mail and wire fraud in a scheme to overdraw bank accounts. But the department won plaudits of sorts last week from an expert, former Attorney General Griffin B. Bell, as he reported on a three-month investigation of the case that he conducted at the request of the company chairman, Robert Forman. The Justice Department inquiry, Mr. Bell said, had been thorough; like Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, he said he found no criminal culpability among the highest Hutton executives.

title: LOST IN THE WILDS OF WESTCHESTER
description: THE Long Islander had been told that to get to Yorktown Heights you took the Taconic Parkway to Underhill Road, and there you were. But he had not been told, nor had he asked, how to get to the Taconic. He remembered something about the Hawthorne Circle and the Saw Mill River Parkway, but that would involve the Bronx and all those baffling signs at the George Washington Bridge.

title: KATHLEEN CULLEN MARRIES DEAN HARWOOD IN BUFFALO
description: Kathleen Mary Cullen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Sinnott Cullen 2d of Buffalo, was married there yesterday to Dean Brook Harwood, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Harwood of Short Hills, N.J. Msgr.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Oakland A's, at Yankee Stadium. 2 P.M. (Television -Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 2 P.M.) Mets vs.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: HARVEST IN BROOKLYN All summer children have been cultivating their own plots of soil at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Next Saturday they will be showing off the fruits - and vegetables - of their labors at the Children's Garden Harvest Fair.

title: L.I. SCHOOL'S SEX EDUCATIONS
description: IT was one of the most popular courses ever offered at Long Island's Lindenhurst High School. According to Lee McLaughlin, health education coordinator for the school district, the sex education course called ''Family Life'' had an average sign-up rate of about 94 percent of the 11th grade.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

WOMEN AT THE TOP
description: While women have made breakthroughs as superintendents and assistant superintendents of school districts in the county, no increase has been made in the number of female principals here since 1978. Also, some districts, such as Croton and Peekskill, employ no female administrators.

title: CHILE ARRESTS 64 IN AFTERMATH OF DEMONSTRATIONS
description: The Chilean Government arrested 64 people today, including middle-level political and union leaders, according to the police.

title: SURROGATE CONTEST HIGHLIGHTS PRIMARIES
description: TUESDAY'S primary elections on Long Island will be marked by several unusual and significant contests. They are multiparty primaries for the nomination for Suffolk County surrogate, and Democratic contests over the renomination of the Suffolk County Legislature's minority leader and the Long Beach Supervisor, two of the few major local offices held by Long Island women and Democrats.

title: THE FORGOTTEN SUMMIT
description: President Reagan and the leaders of Congress have come back from vacation proclaiming that they're ''rarin' to go.'' The problem is that they're going in opposite directions.

title: A QUIET ACQUISITOR IS CAUGHT IN A CROSS FIRE
description: AS Mohamed al-Fayed talks of his family's prized possessions, such as Harrods, this city's legendary department store, or the Ritz Hotel in Paris, he is an effusive and joyous man. But when a visitor to his elegant Mayfair penthouse residence overlooking Hyde Park turns the discussion to his friends, his family background and the scope of the family fortune, affability fades from the face of the 53-year-old Egyptian patriarch. He rustles impatiently in the deep cushions of his chair and, although the politeness is unfailing, he becomes tense. Such questions have become the bane of Mr. al-Fayed's existence.

title: MUSIC: VIOLINIST PAYS TRIBUTE TO FRITZ KREISLER
description: SANDOR BALINT has been a first violinist with the Metropolitan Opera orchestra for 29 years and, however worthy, might as such seem a prime candidate for orchestral anonymity. But Mr. Balint managed to win a form of public attention a few years ago as chairman of the Met orchestra committee during the bitter labor dispute of 1980. More artistically, he has pursued a solo career on the side, partly as a duo with his wife, Joyce Rasmussen Balint, who is a violinist and a mandolinist with the Met orchestra.

title: FOR A SEMINARY, NEW MISSIONS IN A NEW AGE
description: IN THE 1920's, when it became apparent that St. John's Seminary in Brooklyn could no longer train all the Roman Catholic priests needed for parishes in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, Brooklyn and Queens, Bishop Thomas E. Malloy decided that a new seminary should be built.

title: THE VANISHING ACT
description: THEY USED TO BE CALLED vanishing creams. Women everywhere embraced them in the hope of wiping away wrinkles, those all-too-telling signs of aging. In a way, they were a sort of joke, a cartoonist's dream, a pretend plunge into the fountain of youth. Hope in a jar. The creams and lotions all had one thing in common: They promised youth to those who used them daily. Whether they worked or not was another matter.

title: A SELECTION OF FALL EVENTS AROUND THE U.S.
description: ILLINOIS: Spoon River Valley has anthology of fairs This is the 18th year of the Spoon River Valley Scenic Drive and Fall Festival, which attracts thousands of people from within Illinois, as well as from Iowa and Wisconsin. Maps are provided to visitors who want to make the 65-mile drive through 12 towns, stretching from Farmington in the north to Waterford in the south.

title: FLORIDA ST. UPSETS NEBRASKA BY 17-13
description: Danny McManus, a sophomore in his second start this season, threw for 172 yards and one touchdown today to lead Florida State to a 17-13 upset of Nebraska. McManus completed 15 of 27 passes as Florida State (2-0) dealt Nebraska its first defeat in a home opener since the 19-10 loss to Washington State in 1977.

title: TEDDY KOLLEK'S JERUSALEM
description: In reading Thomas L. Friedman's article ''Teddy Kollek's Jerusalem'' (Aug. 4), one is, of course, struck by the concern of Jerusalem's Mayor for all the people of the city that he governs.

title: ARE CRIMINALS MADE OR BORN?
description: It is no accident that those nations which maintain low rates of unemployment and provide social support to cushion the effects of unemployment, such as the Scandinavian countries and Japan, also experience low rates of violent crime (''Are Criminals Made or Born,'' by Richard J. Herrnstein and James Q. Wilson, Aug. 4).

title:
SAMPLER OF AUTUMN EXCURSIONS;

A SELECTION OF FALL EVENTS AROUND THE U.S.
description: PENNSYLVANIA: As the foliage turns, the cultural calendar fills Pennsylvania's fall foliage season crosses the state with a dazzling array of maples, oaks, lindens and elms turning scarlet, yellow, orange and vivid browns. From about Oct. 10 through Oct. 31, the viewing is best in the state's southern zone from the eastern slope of Laurel Hill Mountain west of Somerset, in western Pennsylvania, to Stroudsburg on the Delaware River. The best viewing time in the central portion of Pennsylvania is generally from Oct. 12 to 26 and in the northern zone from Oct. 1 to 14.

title: LIFE IS A FOREIGN COUNTRY
description: THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST By Anne Tyler. 355 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: Reagan Responds To Congress On Trade
description: President Reagan took to the offense yesterday with his defense against Congress's full-court press for protectionism. While reiterating his oposition to legislation ''that would raise prices and destroy the jobs and prosperity trade bring to all,'' he announced in his weekly radio address plans to push some of the nation's bigger trading partners to open their doors wider to United States products.

title: Laura Santirocco Weds Lawrence J. Davidson Jr.
description: Laura A. Santirocco, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Raymond A. Santirocco of Rochester, was married there yesterday to Lawrence J. Davidson Jr., a son of Alice Herrmann of Avon, Conn., and Mr. Davidson of New Britain, Conn. Justice Joseph G. Fritsch, the administrative justice of the Seventh Judicial District in Rochester of the New York Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Top of the Plaza restaurant.

title: No Room for AIDS Victims
description: Victims of AIDS have run into increasing hostility from people who do not want to be around them. After protests from residents of Rockaway Beach, Queens, the city canceled last week plans to provide shelter in a nursing home for 10 homeless AIDS patients. And two Queens school boards called for a moratorium on efforts to place students who have AIDS in public schools because, they said, evidence about the transmission of the disease, Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome, was ''inconclusive'' and ''constantly changing.'' And at a Superior Court trial in Stamford, Conn., 14 prospective jurors asked to be excused when they learned that the defendant, who was accused of murder, suffered from AIDS-related complex, an early stage of the disease.

title: PREACHERS FIND PULPIT ON STREETS
description: Every weekday at noon, Brenda Allen appears at a corner of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue. She sets up a microphone, a small table and a plastic crate and hangs up a blue and white sign that says ''Jesus Is the Way, Truth and Life.''

title: THE PUZZLE OF POL POT'S 'RETIREMENT'
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk called it a farce. Others made jokes about gold watches. Such was the reaction to last week's guerrilla radio announcement that the Khmer Rouge had instituted a retirement policy, and that the first person to be pensioned off at the age of 60 was none other than Pol Pot.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE GOOD SOLDIER SVEJK: And His Fortunes in the World War, by Jaroslav Hasek. (Penguin, $6.95.) A soldier in the World War I Austrian Army, Josef Svejk is cheerful, unshaved and rumpled; a little guy who usually outwits the powerful establishment. Critics have described him as one of the great characters of 20th-century literature. Jaroslav Hasek died in 1923, leaving the novel unfinished, but it is considered a classic. Cecil Parrott translated this 1974 edition from the Czech. #20TH CENTURY JOURNEY: A Memoir of a Life and the Times. The Start: 1904-1930, by William L. Shirer. (Bantam, $12.95.) William L. Shirer arrived in Paris in 1925 and began a celebrated journalistic career in Europe.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HORSE'S NECK. By Pete Townshend. (Houghton Mifflin, $12.95.) Pete Townshend, songwriter-guitarist of the Who and one of rock's authentic masterminds, has assembled this collection of poems, anecdotes and metaphysical vignettes.

title: ANDUJAR, CARDS FALL TO BRAVES
description: Ken Oberkfell had two hits and drove in the winning run to give Steve Bedrosian and the Atlanta Braves to a 3-1 victory tonight over Joaquiin Andujar and the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: What's a Spy Between Friends?
description: So beneficial do the two Germanys find their improved relations, it seemed after high-level talks last week, that they will not allow even a major spy scandal to interfere.

title: WEEKEND COWBOYS GO EAST FOR RODEO THRILLS
description: On weekdays, Dennis Sciabica works as an aide to a state senator. In his free time he is a professional cowboy, wrestling steers and riding bulls.

title: AT HOME AND ABROAD, COTEMPLATION OF WAR AND REMEMBRANCE
description: Like an array of sprinters ready for a mad dash toward Christmas with visions of dollars signs, critical acclaim and Academy Awards seething inside, a new season of movies is poised to begin.

title: HOFSTRA FOOTBALL: NATIONAL GOAL
description: WHEN Hofstra University's football team takes the field Friday at home for its first game of the season, against Iona College, it will be surrounded by questions as well as cheering fans.

title: A NEW WAVE DORECTOR GOES TO WORK ON 'RIGALOTTO'
description: Late of a recent evening, as I sat weak and weary before my television set, desultorily shuffling worthless lottery tickets, I must have drifted off into the awful half-waking state that can bring on twitching seizures accompanied by episodic visions. I was able to seize one of these fleeting phantasmas for a moment, only to have it recede maddeningly as usual before I could pin down the details. It seems, however, that a major opera house had engaged me, a celebrated director of the legitimate theater, to work up a new staging concept for an opera of my choice, preferably something by Verdi. I had heard the name - Pavarotti spoke well of him on a TV talk show - so naturally I accepted.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: COMING-AND-GOING MEN By Paul Fleischman. Illustrated by Randy Gaul. 147 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $11.50. (Ages 11 and up) THE car, the radio and the television set have gradually opened up the valleys of Vermont.

title: BOEING SAYS REPAIRS ON JAPANESE 747 WERE FAULTY
description: The Boeing Company acknowledged Friday that it had made faulty rear-cabin repairs in 1978 on a Japan Air Lines Boeing 747 that crashed in Japan last month, killing 520 of the 524 people on board.

title: TEDDY KOLLEK'S JERUSALEM
description: The article on Teddy Kollek deserves a footnote of interest to Americans and others fascinated by Jerusalem. Mayor Kollek has created something unusual in the international sphere as well: the Jerusalem Committee.

title: SUMMER PROGRAM PRAISED
description: THE 78 Yonkers seventh and eighth graders who received promotions at the end of the Yonkers Youth Connection Summer School learned, in addition to their academic lessons, that failure is not inevitable.

title: NICARAGUA'S AMERICAN LAWYERS PREPARE CASE
description: Relying heavily on American lawyers and witnesses, the Government of Nicaragua will try to prove in proceedings opening at the World Court next week that the United States controls and directs Nicaraguan rebels in violation of international law.

title: Mozambique Reports It Smashed Rebel Base
description: Mozambican and Zimbabwean warplanes and paratroopers smashed the mountain headquarters of the Mozambique National Resistance and killed hundreds of rebels, the semi-official Mozambique News Agency reported today.

title: STORES LENDING TAPES ON SAFETY
description: TWO video tapes on child-safety topics were distributed to Stop and Shop supermarkets throughout Connecticut last week as part of a free lending library that the Massachusetts-based store chain plans to assemble.

title:
DINING OUT;

RUSTIC FARE IN RANDOLPH
description: THE barnlike structure in Randolph that houses an eight-month-old restaurant called Old Timbers has been the home of a variety of eating places over the last 50 years. But, according to informants in the area, during the last decade or two, most had the reputation of being little more than ''dives.''

title: BEIRUT MOSLEMS TO ASK FOR SYRIAN TROOPS
description: Lebanon's top Moslem officials decided today to ask Syria to send troops here to check the worsening security situation as new violence broke out, this time across the line that divides Beirut into Moslem and Christian sectors.

title: Adjustment Takes Time
description: Culture shock. That's what I said to myself after reading ''On Leaving Connecticut for the Middle West,'' disparaging Kansas City. The Connecticut Yankee in Kansas City, Mo., has all the symptoms of dislocation shock. I know, because I had a mirror-image case of it when I came to Connecticut from Kansas.

title: THE HIDDEN HAZARDS OF THE MODERN OFFICE
description: TRADITIONALLY, public discussion of work-related health dangers has been limited to the blue-collar environment (and efforts to eliminate exposure to substances such as asbestos, vinyl chloride, benzene and an array of carcinogens and radiation). While this concern is warranted, it has also diverted attention from what we may someday regard as the greatest occupational hazard of all: the modern office building.

title: A SELECTION OF FALL EVENTS AROUND THE U.S.
description: THE SOUTH: A walk on the wild side and folklore in Miami It's not quite on the order of the Mardi Gras in New Orleans, but the annual Fantasy Fest in Key West is a four-day party whose fame is spreading beyond Florida. Billed as ''the premier adult Halloween party in America,'' the event this year actually takes place on Oct. 24 to 27, the weekend preceding the holiday, and has little to do with witches and hobgoblins.

title: THE SPLASHY RETURNS IN SECTOR FUNDS
description: THE recent showy performance of some sector funds has caught the attention of many individual investors. Sector funds, also known as specialty funds, limit their portfolios to specific market groups ranging from utilities and financial services to health care and high tech.

title: NEWPORT OFFERS A LOOK AT YACHTING'S 'GOLDEN AGE'
description: Nearly six years ago, a small group of yachtsmen gathered here regularly for lunch in the winter months. Their boats were tucked safely away under heavy canvas and it was the time of year for making plans. Inevitably, their conversation would turn to classic boats and the need for some kind of museum to record the history of yachting in the United States.

title: LOUISE LEFFERTS MARRIES
description: The marriage of Louise Buckley Lefferts, a student at the Parsons School of Design, to Cary Jay Marcus, an account executive with Italia Imports in New York, took place yesterday at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof in New York. Justice Theodore R. Kupferman of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court performed the ceremony. The bride is the daughter of Leffert Lefferts of Washington and the late Anne Dale. The bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Irving Marcus of Manhasset Hills, L.I.

title: NFL '85: A STRONG U.S.F.L. LOOK, BUT AUSTERITY SIDELINES SOE STARS
description: As it turns out, the United States Football League was not exactly the pariah the National Football League thought it was. Oh, sure, the U.S.F.L.'s $1.3 billion antitrust suit is on a court docket somewhere, and the younger league still intends to return in the fall of 1986, as direct competition for the older league.

title: PAMELA STEHLI IS BRIDE OF PAUL HEARNE
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in New York yesterday, Pamela Hays Stehli, a daughter of Peter Henry Stehli of Westport, Conn., and Joan Thompson Gilmour of Alexandria, Va., was married to Paul Gregory Hearne, the son of Patricia H. Hearne of Floral Park, L.I., and the late Peter R. Hearne. The Rev. James O'Keefe performed the ceremony.

title: MISS WALKER HAS WEDDING
description: At Most Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in East Hampton, L.I., yesterday Christina Tilghman Walker, a daughter of Mrs. Bayard Walker of New York, East Hampton and Hobe Sound, Fla., and the late Mr. Walker, was married to Richard Paxton Burks, the son of Mary Paxton Burks of Chicago and Dr. James L. Burks of Kansas City, Mo. Msgr. Christopher Huntington performed the ceremony.

title: Karpov Takes First Timeout In Championship Chess Play
description: The world chess champion, Anatoly Karpov, took the first timeout today in the his title rematch against the challenger, Gary Kasparov.

title: A TOUR OF THE COUNTY'S STONE MENAGERIE
description: ANIMALS, both mythic and realistic, adorn buildings around Westchester, surprising our vision as we move about the county. These decorative details give character to buildings and places, evoking a sense of history.

title: HUDSON CRUISE VESSELS DRAW GROWING CROWDS
description: Five years ago, Gerard Henne took over the fishing vessel Marion T. Budd, converted it into an excursion boat and set out on the Hudson River, hoping to make a few extra dollars.

title: BREAKING AWAY -- IN A WAY
description: BREAKING Away, Part I:

title: A SELECTION OF FALL EVENTS AROUND THE U.S.
description: THE HEARTLAND: Kansas City art, River City roundup Two events in the Kansas City area may well be worth some effort getting to.

title: POLICIES TELL WHEN TO SEARCH
description: ALONG with the usual schedules, forms, and assignment sheets that accompany the start of a new school year, students in Milford last week received copies of the new policy under which they may be searched if they are suspected of having drugs, weapons or other contraband.

title: Second to the Nobel Prize
description: To the Editor:

title: DESCENDING INTO NAPLES
description: The entrance to the underworld, legends said, was somewhere between Mount Vesuvius and the Neapolitan coast. Ancient Romans, who were not intimidated by the smoking volcano, hot springs and bubbling black lakes, built their vacation villas in its vicinity. And now, even though tourists rush from Rome to Pompeii and Herculaneum for the afternoon to see the consequences, the reputation of Italy's urban netherworld - Naples - still scares otherwise brave travelers.

title: HAVE YOU NOTICED?
description: WE STAND AT the outermost frontier. Human enlightenment is far advanced. We can now say ''chairperson'' without feeling absurd. Technological progress is miraculous. We have the digital wristwatch.

title: A 'Father's' Honor
description: The Hippocratic oath and the ''code of silence'' conjoined last week for Joseph Bonanno, the 80-year-old organized-crime leader who is living in retirement in Tucson, Ariz. Contending that his doctors had instructed him not to testify, Mr. Bonanno refused to cooperate with a Federal inquiry into organized crime.

title: DR. GRAZIANO CARLON WEDS DR. ANNE TERESA CORSA
description: Dr. Anne Teresa Corsa, a resident in obstetrics and gynecology at New York Hospital, was married yesterday to Dr. Graziano Carlo Carlon, clinical chief and associate attending anesthesiologist in the department of critical care at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. The Rev. R. DeWitt Mallary performed the ceremony at the All Saints Episcopal Church.

title: IN STONINGTON, THE FLEET'S IN AND THRIVING
description: SINCE 1979 more than $500,000 has been spent to improve the fishing facilities at Stonington Harbor, in order to reverse a decades-long decline in the size of the commercial fishing fleet there.

title: GREAT LAKES GNAW AWAY AT SHORELINE'S DEFENSES
description: While the Northeast is plagued by drought and the Southeast is tormented by hurricanes, the Middle West has its own, more subtle, problem - record high-water levels in the Great Lakes. They have caused flooding in parts of Illinois, Michigan and Indiana and have heightened the effects of erosion. Cellars have been flooded, bulkheads have been broken and some bluffs along the water have been so eaten away that they they are in danger of collapsing.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;

ETCHED FOR LIFE
description: A PARROT, a unicorn, dragons Chinese (five-toed) and Japanese (claws of an eagle). Jesus wearing a crown of thorns, a hot rod with a flaming engine, bluebirds nesting in flowers, tigers poised for attack. A mermaid gazing into a mirror, a pinup girl perched in a martini glass, a creation labeled ''Sailors' Dream'' that features a woman, a bottle and playing cards. A skull with a top hat, a skull with fangs, a skull sprouting wings, the Grim Reaper on a motorcycle, the Grim Reaper wielding his scythe, and oh, yes - a heart bearing the inscription ''Mother.''

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE TWO MRS. GRENVILLES. By Dominick Dunne. (Crown, $14.95.) This lifestyles-of-the-rich-and-famous story, a loose retelling of the famous Woodward murder case of 1955, must have made a more compelling news account than it does a novel.

title: RADIO MARTI SAYS CUBA SANK HIJACKED BOAT IN '80
description: In a sharp departure from its earlier programming, Radio Marti, the United States' broadcast service to Cuba, has been running a long ''special report'' on what it describes as a previously undisclosed sinking by Cuban authorities of a crowded excursion boat that had been hijacked by at least two soldiers trying to flee the island.

title: NEGOTIATING DEBATES
description: WHEN County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke last ran for office, in 1983, he and his Democratic opponent, Ogden R. Reid, met in debate more than three dozen times. That busy schedule probably will not be matched this year, as Mr. O'Rourke, the Republican incumbent, faces another challenger, Arthur H. Goodman, in what appears to be a much less active campaign.

title: Buses Resume Service In Guatemala City
description: Buses resumed service today, and the capital was calmer than it has been since anti-Government protests broke out 10 days ago.

title: SHOWS THAT STRESS THE EXOTIC Rita Rief
description: Collectors with a taste for the esoteric in everything old, from ancient works through Art Deco objects, have much to explore this season in museum and gallery exhibitions and antiques fairs. Among the more exotic and offbeat genres covered are barbarian jewelry, Anglo-Indian furniture, Chinese silver made for the export market, period drawings of decorative arts, early radios and 20th-century Finnish glass.

title: C.S. SADLER WED TOMISS JOHNSON
description: The First Presbyterian Church in New York was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Meredith Bevis Johnson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey B. Johnson of Smithfield, Me., to Christy Scharff Sadler, the son of Harry M. Sadler and Sheila Emerson Sadler, both of New York. The Rev. John Mellin performed the ceremony.

title: CIVIL WAR ECHO
description: AFTER an anchor was recovered in 1983 from the Monitor, the ironclad that sank during the Civil War, specialists put the 1,450 pounds of metal in a tank of water in Greenville, N.C., and considered how to remove more than 120 years of rust and crust.

title: RUSSIANS NAME GEM FOR SAMANTHA SMITH
description: A diamond found in a small settlement in Siberia has been named after Samantha Smith, the 13-year-old unofficial peace envoy who was killed in a plane crash in Maine on Aug. 25, the official news agency Tass said today.

title: TAYLOR A THREAT TO EAGLES
description: Through the years, the Giants have always had to make due on offense, but for their opener against the Eagles today, they were ready to make adjustments in what is still the team's cornerstone - the defense.

title: ARE CRIMINALS MADE OR BORN?
description: It is important to remember that where one stands on the nature-nurture question has historically been a function of one's politics, and a hereditarian theory of I.Q. and criminality is primarily a statement of ideology. In this context, it is not surprising to note that James Wilson is a professor of government. It seems clear to me that the real purpose of this sort of article is to take the heat off of our social and governmental institutions for the inequities of our society and place them back at the feet of the victimized. ERIC MART Cincinnati

title: GRIT AND WIT MADE RUTH GORDON A STAR
description: The Ruth Gordon that America cherished for almost three-quarters of a century began in 1911 at the Colonial Theater in Boston. Miss Gordon was fond of telling the story, and, along with so many of her stories, it could serve as an inspiration to all aspiring young actresses. Hazel Dawn was playing in ''The Pink Lady,'' and sitting in the Colonial balcony was Ruth Gordon Jones from Quincy, Mass. She saw Miss Dawn - and she loved her - and she also heard ''my voices.'' As Miss Gordon recalled, about those voices, ''Joan heard hers at Domremy, mine came through at the corner of Boylston and Tremont, Boston, Mass. My voices said go on stage, Ruth, go on stage! Be an actress!''

title: Teachers Take To Picket Lines
description: School strikes have joined football as a harbinger of fall. In Chicago, Seattle, Pittsburgh, Flint, Mich., and Pawtucket and Newport, R.I., as well as a host of other cities and towns, teachers were on the picket lines last week.

title: BLACK FUNERAL NEAR CAPE TOWN ENDS IN VIOLENCE
description: Policemen and troops in armored trucks opened fire with tear gas, rubber bullets and shotguns in black townships near Cape Town late today after a funeral for 11 victims of recent racial violence, including a 2-month-old girl.

title: CHANGES TO HELP RETARDED
description: A MAJOR reorganization of the Connecticut Department of Mental Retardation will consolidate 12 regions into 6, with more attention on community-based services for the retarded and their families.

title: A CHANGED BOSTON REGAINS CONTROL OF ITS SCHOOL SYSTEM
description: When lawyers for black pupils filed suit against the city of Boston and its educational system 13 years ago, their target was segregated public schools. But when the case finally ended last week, more than the schools had been integrated. ''I think the political climate has changed,'' Mayor Raymond L. Flynn said recently. He cited ''the overall more positive feeling there is in the city of Boston, the responsible feeling of good will in the city.''

title: Expulsion at Stanford
description: To the Editor:

title: WILLIAM GEORGE, MEREDITH MALLORY EXCHANGE VOWS
description: Meredith Brooks Mallory and William Whitney George were married yesterday at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Tuxedo Park, N.Y., by the Rev. Edwin H. Cromey. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Downs Mallory of Tuxedo Park and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: MUSIC: LUTHER VANDROSS OFFERS POP-SOUL VOCALS
description: THROUGH four solo albums, each of which has sold more than a million copies, Luther Vandross, the New York-based pop-soul idol, has fostered a thriving vocal subgenre that treats the pop ballad as a vehicle for virtuosic vocal display. Mr. Vandross and followers such as Freddie Jackson stretch conventional pop songs into elongated tonal showpieces that allow a singer to insert anything that he feels like saying. This open-ended format could theoretically stretch a single song into a whole evening of flowery embellishments.

title: ARE CRIMINALS MADE OR BORN?
description: It is of interest to know if some persons are born more prone to crime than others, but it is a matter of overwhelming political importance to understand, for example, why United States crime rates are so much higher than those of most other industrialized nations. The work of Richard Herrnstein and James Wilson, though valuable, should not deflect us from our most urgent tasks. LOUIS MARANO Washington

title: Broadcast TV
description: The Chicago Lyric Opera opened its 30th-anniversary season last fall with Tchaikovsky's ''Eugene Onegin'' in a rapturously received production that will be aired Wednesday at 9 P.M. on Channel 13. I didn't see it, but when I arrived in Chicago a few months later for another opera, ''Onegin'' was still on everyone's lips.

title: RESEARCHERS GAIN ON MULTLIPLE SLCEROSIS
description: SCIENTISTS at the New Jersey Medical School here are making promising headway in their search for the causes of multiple sclerosis and therapies to stop its devastating course to the central nervous system.

title: Revising Children's Classics
description: To the Editor:

title: A.C.L.U. and Japanese-Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: A FATHER'S FEARS OF RAISING A PRINCESS
description: I NEVER call my daughter Princess for fear she will grow up to be one. This is much easier said than done, for she is 4 years old and I adore her. I want her to understand that beauty comes from within, that a person who depends on good looks alone courts disappointment.

title: A TEACHER RETURNS RENEWED
description: IMAGINE the mists rising magically in the moonlight from the ink-black waters of Walden Pond. Imagine 15 high school teachers from New York, New Jersey, Hawaii, Oklahoma, Nebraska, Oregon, Georgia, Maryland, Michigan, Connecticut and Maine wading gently into the water, at Thoreau's Cove, beneath his cabin site. Imagine this as the culmination of six weeks of study as National Endowment for the Humanities fellows, and you will be witnessing the reality of 15 professionals returning to the classroom, enthusiasm and excellence renewed.

title: Chad Reports Rebels Battle Libyan Allies
description: Chad said today that anti-Government troops rebelled against their Libyan allies controlling the northern town of Faya-Largeau and hundreds were killed or wounded in the fighting. The rebels denied the report.

title: THERE'LL BE MUCH DANCE FROM ABROAD
description: What's ahead in dance? There will be a great diversity of attractions, with the city's major companies featuring their quota of premieres and major revivals. The new dance year brings a celebration of Bronislava Nijinska, and a Martha Graham anniversary. A number of companies and performers will return to New York after long absences. And, perhaps most notably, the year brings an extremely wide variety of dance from abroad.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE KNOWLEDGE EXECUTIVE: Leadership in an Information Society. By Harlan Cleveland. (Truman Talley/ Dutton, $18.95.) Does successful leadership today require different qualities from leadership in the past? The management guru Harlan Cleveland, the dean of the University of Minnesota's Hubert H. Humphrey Institute of Public Affairs and the author of ''The Future Executive: A Guide for Tomorrow's Managers'' (1972) and other books, believes it does, and he devotes ''The Knowledge Executive'' to explaining why.

title: A Close-up Look At the Titanic's Resting Place
description: When the Titanic, the ''unsinkable'' ship with the double steel hull, struck an iceberg and sank in 1912, some of the era's faith in progress and technology went to the bottom with her.

title: A CHIC TIMEPIECE IS OF THE ESSENCE
description: WHEN it comes to timely accessories, the watch has few equals. Its usefulness, first of all, is not arguable, at least not in a city of workaholics, traincatchers, movie-, play- and concertgoers and other assorted clockwatchers.

title: VIBRANT BRAZILIAN SPIRIT ENLIVENS 46TH STREET
description: It was all there: glittering carnival costumes from Rio, saucy samba and bossa nova music, tasty feijoada and vatapa (black bean stew and shrimp with peanut sauce) and the boisterous joy that makes Brazil's tropical culture special.

title: RULING BACKS HOSPITAL LEAGUE
description: The National Labor Relations Board has ruled that the League of Voluntary Hospitals acted properly in not putting into effect the agreement that ended the 47-day strike by hospital workers in the city last year.

title:
SCHOOL YEAR STARTS, AND SO DO CONFLICTS;

DISTRICTS RESTRICT NONRESIDENTS
description: AN increasing number of Connecticut students are crossing town lines, both legally and illegally, to attend public schools in other communities, school officials in several suburban towns report.

title: MISSMOORE WED TO JAMES L. FIELD
description: The marriage of Jennifer Dongan Moore, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dongan Reynolds Moore of Westport, Conn., and Quechee, Vt., to James Lowell Field, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Parton Field of Englewood, Fla., took place yesterday. The Rev. Thomas Driscoll performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Luke in Westport.

title: HIGH-FIDELITY STEREO VCR'S JOIN AN ALREADY CROWDED FIELD
description: This fall, the field of video resembles an overly fertile garden patch. Lots of good things are in season, but they all seem to to be competing with one another.

title: HIGH-RISE PLAN ALARMS LOW-RISE SECTION
description: AFTER decades as a quiet, working-class neighborhood on the southwest corner of Prospect Park, Windsor Terrace has begun to attract developers.

title: THE PUNJAB: TORN BY TERROR
description: LATE IN THE AFTERNOON ON TUESDAY, AUG. 20, HAR-chand Singh Longowal walked into a Sikh temple near Sangrur, his home village in the heart of the Punjab, to offer prayers for peace. Longowal, president of the Sikhs' major political party, the Akali Dal, had spent the earlier part of the day in the state capital of Chandigarh, where he conferred with party colleagues on how to contest state and parliamentary elections that Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi had ordered for late September.

title: APPEALS COURT RULES A JUDGE USED 'COERCION' TO SETTLE SUIT
description: An appeals court has ruled that Judge Robert W. Sweet of Federal District Court in Manhattan used ''coercion'' and ''excessive zeal'' in trying to get a pretrial settlement of a medical malpractice suit.

title: FOR NEW ENGLANDERS, A SUMMER OF CLOUDS
description: A Labor Day weekend storm that dampened holiday hopes contributed to what appears to be the cloudiest New England summer on record.

title: KOCH PRACTICALLY HAS IT IN WRITING
description: FEW politicians could pull off the Edward I. Koch pledge. Standing in front of a crowd on a sidewalk or in a hall, the Mayor has been asking people to raise their right hands and repeat after him: ''I solemnly pledge that on Sept. 10, I shall rush to the polls and vote for Ed Koch for Mayor.'' The brief ceremony ends with the Mayor waving his finger like a conductor's baton and emphasizing each of the final words, ''So help me God.''

title: BRIDGE GALLERY EXHIBITS WORK OF 6 LOCAL PHOTOGRAPHERS
description: AN exhibition space sponsored by the county and located in its White Plains headquarters at 148 Martine Avenue, the Bridge Gallery naturally specializes in shows of local interest. Accordingly, the six photographers featured in its current display are all from Westchester.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: A SPECIAL State Assembly investigative committee is expected to announce soon its first hearing on hazardous-waste dumping at the Lakehurst Naval Air Engineering Center, according to Marlene Lynch Ford, a Democrat whose 10th District includes parts of Ocean County.

title: Dutch Jews in World War II
description: To the Editor:

title: DIRECTING ASPIRING DIRECTORS
description: THEY were told that their contributions would often be underestimated, that their craft was almost impossible to define and that even if they could create a definition for it, chances were they might never actually work at it.

title: Lots to Like In Missouri
description: This is in answer to the article ''On Leaving Connecticut for the Middle West'' [Opinion page, Aug. 18] by Susan H. Greenberg, who has moved from Connecticut to Kansas City, Mo.

title: SUSAN M. TIMARES IS WED TO REAL-ESTATE EXECUTIVE
description: Susan M. Timares, director of the Employee Assistance Program Consortium and the Employee Development Center, both at the Cornell University Medical College in New York, was married yesterday to John T. Livingston, a vice president of acquisitions for VMS Realty in New York. Rabbi Joy Levitt officiated at the Plaza.

title: TOPICS
description: IN suburbia as in life, it's the little things that count.

title: TRIMMING THE DEFENSE BUDGET COULD COST LONG ISLAND JOBS
description: LONG Island, with an economy fueled by the aerospace industry, learned last week that a major new Air Force plane may be grounded before its first takeoff. The aircraft, a training plane called the T-46A, is being developed by the Fairchild Republic Company in Farmingdale.

title: CANADA DECLINES TO JOIN U.S. SPACE-ARMS EFFORT
description: Canada will not formally take part in the research phase of President Reagan's space-based missile defense plan, but does not oppose it, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said today.

title: Article 247661 -- No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: Proof of Primary Residence
description: Question: The owner of my rent-stabilized apartment recently asked me to prove that my apartment is my principal residence. Specifically, he asked that I submit photocopies of my voter registration card; New York State driver's license, 1984 state tax return (with figures blacked out) and a statement that I dwell in my unit at least 183 days a year. Am I required to provide this information? . . . J. K., Manhattan Answer: There is no requirement in the law or rent stabilization code that a tenant has to provide an owner with any kind of additional information once he is a tenant in possession, says Martin A. Shlufman, deputy counsel for rent administration for the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. Who Pays Transition Bills? Question: My apartment building is being converted into a co-op and I intend to purchase. I have had a problem with my terrace railing cracking, which I have discussed with the managing agent and the tenant lawyer, but no repairs have been made. Is it possible that if it is not repaired before the closing that I would be held responsible for repairing it? . . . S. H., Brooklyn Answer: In most cases, a shareholder in a co-op would not be responsible for repairs to a terrace, Redinger says David Clurman, an attorney who represents tenants and sponsors. But you should read the proprietary lease carefully to see if there is any particular reference to the responsibility for repairing terraces once the co-op plan becomes effective.

title: BEVERLY RUKEYSER WED TO ANTHONY J. BELLISIO
description: Beverly Jane Rukeyser and Anthony J. Bellisio were married yesterday at the Greenwich, Conn., home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Louis R. Rukeyser. Probate Judge Paul D. Shapero officiated.

title: MEXICO CITY GETS TOO BIG A MILLION TIMES A YEAR
description: When the movie ''Soylent Green,'' depicting the nightmare of urban overpopulation, came here its Spanish title was ''When Our Destiny Catches Up With Us.'' Many residents and urban planners believe the nightmare has arrived. With an estimated 18 million residents and a million more arriving each year, Mexico's capital is well along to becoming the world's largest city; by some counts it is already there.

title: BOSTON
description: To the Editor: We must not allow the author of ''Brahmin Boston Preserved'' (Travel, July 14) to spread a rumor that the Cabots so demeaned themselves as to speak to Lowells. As John Bossidy tells us:

title: SLANEY TAKES 3,000 IN ROME
description: Mary Decker Slaney and Judi Brown-King broke American records tonight, and Mrs. Slaney and Doug Padilla won $35,000 prize money each. Those were the highlights of the year's most significant track and field meet, the International Amateur Athletic Federation Mobil Grand Prix final.

title: VALIUM, BY ANY OTHER NAME
description: The 22-year-old patent on Valium has finally run out. That's bad for Hoffman-La Roche, the company that held it; Valium is an immensely popular prescription drug.

title: Offshore Lease Sale Proposed
description: The Interior Department on Friday announced the proposed mid-January sale of offshore oil and gas leases on a 5.6 million-acre tract of Alaska's North Aleutian Basin.

title: IN PRAISE OF THE TOPCOAT
description: There is a new cloakroom attendant at my club in New York, and when I went to pick up my topcoat after lunch there one day last spring, he came around from behind the counter to hold the coat for me. He is usually too busy to do that, but we were alone that day, and he spoke to me for the first time.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: A Face in the Crowd Starring Andy Griffith, Patricia Neal, Walter Matthau; directed by Elia Kazan, 1957 Warner Home Video 126 minutes. $59.95 Though nearly 30 years have passed since this film was made, it carries one of those messages that history suggests cannot be stated too often: beware megalomaniacal demagogues.

title: GRAB YOU TOAD
description: Over the ages, the toad (Bufo americanus and others) has been a tailless amphibian maligned in many cultures. But in the central highlands of the Chiapas region of Mexico, Maya communities felt the toad was important and even called the warty creature ''the musician of the rain.''

title: ZACHARY SOLOMON MARRIED TO SUSAN PHILLIPS BARNETT
description: Susan Phillips Barnett, marketing manager for fragrance and new treatment ventures with the Lancome division of Cosmair Inc. of New York, was married last evening to Zachary Solomon, chief executive officer of Perry Ellis Inc. and senior vice president of Manhattan Industries, the parent company.

title: NO-SMOKING AREAS IN RESTAURANTS
description: It is unfortunate that Fred G. Sampson is so frightened of driving business away that he fails to see the pressing need for no-smoking sections in restaurants. Simply improving ventilating systems is not sufficient, especially when restaurant owners can opt to turn them off, as I have experienced on more than one occasion.

title: RESTORING THE GREAT WALL OF CHINA
description: Most travelers to outposts of the old world know what it is to feel time receding. On the steps of the Senate in Rome, toward dusk when the crowds have fled the Forum, the visitor has only to filter out the traffic noise to imagine how it was in Julius Caesar's time. In Leningrad, before the Hermitage museum on a snowy winter's night, the last days of the Romanovs in their winter palace can suddenly spring to life.

title: Pinelands Approvals Draw Disapproval
description: I was appalled to read in the Aug. 18 Environment column of the amount of development approved in the pinelands since January 1981.

title: IGNORANCE BREEDS ANTI-SEMITISM
description: ON Oct. 17, 1984, Joseph Busalacchi, 18 years old; Keith LaRocca, 19, and Timothy McLane, 18, started a bulldozer on the grounds of the newly dedicated Temple Beth Shalom in Manalapan. Mr. Busalacchi drove it into the wall of the temple, causing extensive damage.

title: INVITE NEW EGYPTIAN-ISRAELI TALKS
description: All the huddling about the Middle East peace process in recent weeks has focused on one issue: How to get the Jordanians and Palestinians into the negotiations. The meetings between King Hussein of Jordan and Yassir Arafat of the Palestine Liberation Organization and the frantic comings and goings of various envoys have been aimed at devising a formula that would permit the Palestinians to join the Jordanians in a joint delegation to the negotiations.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:My husband and I are interested in taking a golf vacation in England and Ireland. Can you tell me what companies arrange this type of trip, including reservations on the better courses? - C. Z., Hartford Answer:Among companies that specialize in arranging golfing vacations in Britain and Ireland is Exclusive Sports Holidays (5151 San Felipe Street, Suite 222, Houston, Tex. 77056; 713-960-9060 or 800-824-5389). Exclusive represents Maj. Neil Ramsay Golf Holidays and Castle Tours, which is based in Scotland. It offers tours for small groups and tailors vacations for individuals, arranging hotel accommodations, chauffeur-driven or rental cars and starting times at leading courses. A spokesman for Exclusive said the cost of a seven-day trip started at $795 a person for the land arrangements, including breakfasts.

title: 'UPON A MATTRESS': TUNES WITH MAGIC
description: ALTHOUGH it may pop up in high school auditoriums, a musical comedy devotee does not get to see ''Once Upon a Mattress'' as often as he ought to.

title: Cable TV
description: Cable has some nice movie surprises this week, like a singing Laurence Olivier. As the dashing rogue-hero of ''The Beggar's Opera'' (1952), the great actor does quite pleasantly by several ballads echoing London's early 18th-century underworld. This stylish, raffish adventure can be seen on Sunday at 5 P.M. on Bravo.

title: COLLEEN MULLIN MARRIES
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in Darien, Conn., yesterday Colleen M. Mullin and Matthew W. Lake, graduates of Keene State College in New Hampshire, were married by the Rev. Edward Howley. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Mullin of Darien and the bridegroom a son of John F. Lake of Barnstead, N.H., and the late Marlyne W. Lake.

title: A ROUND TRIP ON THE CAROUSEL OF LIFE
description: The carousel is always crowded. The horses are so highly varnished that they glow in the sunlight and their laquer reflects the brilliance of the raindrops.

title: WISCONSIN DEMOCRATS PUSH FOR OPEN PRIMARY RULE
description: Wisconsin Democrats are pressing a national party rules panel to permit their state to resume allowing people who are not Democrats to vote in the party's Presidential primary. They contend that this would help expand the party's base among independent voters.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET SET HIGH-LEVEL TALKS ON THE FAR EAST
description: The Soviet Union has agreed for the first time to hold high-level talks with the United States on their differences over Indochina, Korea and other areas of potential trouble in the Far East, State Department officials said today.

title: FOOD FOR THINKERS AT HARVARD
description: THINGS usually change slowly when they change at all at the Harvard Faculty Club in Cambridge, Mass. But on Monday, when the venerable eating club reopens after a summer break, not only will a group of outsiders, Creative Gourmets, be supplying the meals, but several of the club's senior employees will no longer have jobs.

title: MOSCOW SAID TO URGE PALESTINIANS TO REJECT TALKS
description: The Soviet Union has begun a new campaign to increase its influence among Palestinians and encourage them to reject American-sponsored efforts to revive Arab-Israeli peace talks, according to senior Palestinian leaders who have recently returned from Moscow.

title: VOTERS FOUND DOUBTFUL OF '86 DEFICIT DECLINE
description: The American public does not agree with the Reagan Administration's prediction that the Federal budget deficit will decline next year, according to the Gallup Poll.

title:
ANTIQUES;

DECORATIVE ITEMS IN OLD WETHERSFIELD
description: THERE is nothing tangible left to mark the beginning of the Connecticut colony 350 years ago - the small ''fortress houses'' at Windsor and Wethersfield or the cave-like rooms dug out of the river bank at Hartford all disappeared years ago. Pride and a sense of community history, however, have helped preserve many other late 17th- through mid-19th-century homes throughout the state. This has been especially true in Old Wethersfield, the village described by one early writer as the ''most Auncient Towne in Connecticut.''

title: ARE CRIMINALS MADE OR BORN?
description: Professors Herrnstein and Wilson have come up with so many thought-provoking observations on the role of biology in street crime that they should expand their studies and apply their hypotheses to office criminality. Could biology also help to explain the large amount of law-breaking behavior among politicians, bankers, corporation executives, union officials and other national leaders? HERBERT J. GANS New York City

title: AMERICANS PICKING JAPANESE BRAINS
description: AFTER decades of pooh-poohing Japanese scientific research, American business executives no longer patronize the Japanese as ''imitators'' and ''copiers'' of American technology. Quite the contrary. In the wake of Japan's drive for technological supremacy, they are scrambling to keep up with the new scientific research in Japan.

title: AH, SEMIWILDERNESS
description: Like a providential life preserver, a wide ring of semiwilderness surrounds the metropolitan Washington area, providing some of the best, cheapest and handiest getaways in the nation.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: THE YORKTOWN FAIR It's the season for country fairs, and one of the longest running, locally, is the 62-year-old Yorktown Grange Fair. It will be in full swing from 10 A.M. to 7 P.M. today on 15 acres of the Rochambeau Park Fairgrounds off Moseman Avenue, Yorktown Heights. For an admission price of $2.50 for adults, $1 for children, and free parking, a full range of bucolic diversions are available.

title: TENSIONS MANIFEST FARGO TRIAL
description: POLICE sharpshooters perched on nearby rooftops.

title: THE PUZZLE OF HIS RISE
description: THE REVOLUTIONARY CAREER OF MAXIMILIEN ROBESPIERRE By David P. Jordan. Illustrated. 308 pp. New York: The Free Press. $22.95. MORE than Danton, Saint-Just or Marat, Robespierre was the Jacobin revolution, for contemporaries and for writers ever since. Except for Napoleon, Robes-pierre is the most written-about figure of the revolutionary era. Yet an air of mystery has always surrounded the man known as the Incorruptible.

title: THINGS WE DON'T TALK ABOUT
description: WISDOM, MADNESS AND FOLLY The Making of a Psychiatrist. By R. D. Laing. Illustrated. 147 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Company. $14.95.

title: ARTS COUNCIL'S DANCE AWARDS
description: WITH a substantial rise in its budget for fiscal 1986, the State Council on the Arts has awarded a record $517,000 in dance grants - an increase of $143,000 over last year.

title: L.I. Bomb Victim Stable
description: A 23-year-old passer-by, Robert Seifried Jr., who was injured early Friday when a bomb went off outside the Long Island house of a former Latvian policeman once accused of Nazi war crimes was reported in stable condition yesterday at University Hospital in Stony Brook. Members of the F.B.I.-New York City Police Joint Terrorist Task Force and the Suffolk County arson squad searched for clues, at the scene, the house of Elmars Sprogis in Brentwood, L.I.

title: GORBACHEV, A PR COMMISSAR'S DREAM
description: IN a few deft strokes last week, Mikhail S. Gorbachev showed that President Reagan is not likely to be the only ''great communicator'' at the summit in November.

title: RACE IS CLOSE AS NORWAY STARTS VOTING TODAY
description: Norwegians are to vote Sunday and Monday on who will lead them for the next four years, and polls indicate the Conservative-led coalition Government of Kaare Willoch and the Socialist coalition dominated by the Labor Party are in a close race.

title: SOUTHERN LEADERS CAST EYES ABROAD
description: Southern governors will be focusing their attention on doing business with foreign countries at their annual meeting, which begins here Sunday.

title: STATE INTENSIFIES ITS CHECKING OF TRUCKS
description: NOT every trucker would react the way the driver of the battered steel box on wheels did when State Trooper Thomas Fitzgerald handed him a summons for eight safety defects recently. The driver looked at the pink form listing the defects, nodded and said:

title: KITTY KEAN BECOMES A BRIDE
