description: The marriage of Katharine Jessup Kean to David William Czarnecki took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. John Kean, father and stepmother of the bride, in Bedminster, N.J. The Rev. Irvin Pusey, senior minister of the Red Lion Evangelical Church in Bear, Del., and uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony. The bride, known as Kitty, is a daughter also of Mrs. Morris Riley Eddy 2d of Chicago and Hobe Sound, Fla. Mr. Czarnecki is the son of Mrs. William J. Czarnecki of Wilmington, Del., and the late Mr. Czarnecki.

title: WESTCHESTER WEIGHS NEW ASSAULT ON GRAFFITI
description: Westchester County Legislators are expected to vote Monday on a county-wide ban on the sale of spray paint to minors in an effort to curb the increase in graffiti.

title: MAHAFFEY RALLIES TO TIE AT BOSTON GOLF CLASSIC
description: John Mahaffey posted a five-under par 66 on one of his favorite courses and pulled into a tie with George Burns for the 54-hole lead today in the $400,000 Bank of Boston Golf Classic.

title: TOPICS
description: DURING an early walk one Sunday morning, I passed a sad sight. Lying on the sidewalk were a bunch of slightly wilted flowers, an unopened pound box of drugstore chocolates and a blue and red heart-shaped balloon. Obviously somebody - and probably two somebodies - had not been, as my mother calls it, lucky in love that Saturday night.

title: YANKEES CUT GAP TO 1 1/2
description: The Yankees, continuing their relentless pursuit of Toronto, pulled within a game and a half of the Blue Jays last night, coming from behind for the second game in a row to beat the Oakland A's, this time by 3-2.

title: PROSPECTS
description: The P.P.I. Stays Put On Friday, the Government's report on the Producer Price Index - which measures changes in the prices of finished goods as they leave the factory -will show a rise of two-tenths of 1 percent for August, says John D. Paulus, chief economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. That is a slightly lower rate increase than the three-tenths of 1 percent for July, when there was a burst in food prices.

title: SWISS TEAM CAPTURES 4th LEG OF CYCLING RACE
description: The Vie Claire team won the fourth leg of the Tour of the Future cycling race today, and a Vie Claire rider, Benno Wiss of Switzerland, gained the individual lead.

title: STATES TEST THEIR LUCK AT LOTTERY
description: Susan Dunn stood at the counter of the Sweepstakes Commission office, carrying her 6-month old daughter as her 2 1/2-year-old daughter clutched her leg. In Mrs. Dunn's free hand was $2, for two chances at winning the lottery.

title: HOLD YOU BREATH
description: There are important assignments over at the State Department that even an assiduous reader of foreign news may never have heard of. Take United States Representative to and Chairman of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization Senior Consultative Group, the official who has the significant duty of coordinating the arms control activities of all the NATO allies.

title: 2 COUNCIL PRIMARIES IN G.O.P.
description: Even though there are no Republicans on the City Council, there are two contests for Republican nominations in districts that offer some possibility of a political reversal.

title: New Child Care Services Set in San Francisco
description: Mayor Dianne Feinstein signed an ordinance Friday requiring some office developers to provide child care services in new or renovated buildings.

title: A CHASTISED HUTTON TAKES ITS MEDICINE
description: Two Hutton officials resigned their top posts and 13 others were cited in a report by former Attorney General Griffin B. Bell that strongly chastised Hutton's middle-management for failing to exercise control and thus allowing a check-kiting scheme to proliferate. Hutton's board agreed to all of Mr. Bell's suggestions, including fines or reprimands for most of those cited and changes in management structure. While exonerating the highest Hutton officials, the report probably will reduce the control of Hutton's chairman, Robert Fomon. Mr. Bell said he did not see the need for criminal penaties against individuals, since the company has already pleaded guilty to felonies. A House panel and some state agencies are continuing their own investigations.

title: U.S. DELAYS ARE SLOWING L.I. PROJECTS
description: FEDERAL delays in distributing millions of dollars in community development grants last year and this year have led several Suffolk County municipalities to postpone projects and reassess their spending plans.

title: Recent Sales
description: Allendale $127,000 *2* 1 Delta Court *2* 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 27-year-old Cape Cod; *2* fenced yard, full basement with office; *2* taxes $2,361. Denville $117,000 *2* 15 Hinchman Avenue *2* 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; *2* natural woodwork, new furnace and water heater; *2* taxes $1,800. Manalapan $134,000 *2* 4 Little John Road *2* 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 26-year-old bilevel; *2* brick fireplace, patio, .5 acre; *2* taxes $2,466. Pine Brook $95,500 *2* 12 Adamary Place *2* 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 26-year-old Cape Cod; *2* fenced yard, new well pump, maintenance-free siding; *2* taxes $1,425. West Orange $315,000 *2* 460 Prospect Avenue *2* 4-bedroom, 3-bath, older colonial; *2* stone front, fireplace, zoned for commercial conversion; *2* taxes $4,175. Westfield $175,000 *2* 615 Coleman Place *2* 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 70-year-old colonial; *2* 2-car, detached garage, screened side porch, den; *2* taxes $2,565. OTHER AREAS Yorktown Heights, N.Y. $128,000 *2* 2670 Colonial Street *2* 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old frame ranch; *2* basement workshop, family room; *2* taxes $2,782. Farmington, Conn. $131,500 *2* 7 Red Coat Lane *2* 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 16-year-old Cape Cod; *2* expanded living area, 0.5 acre; *2* taxes $1,266. Mineola, L.I. $215,000 *2* 403 Jackson Avenue *2* 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath new high ranch; *2* dining room, eat-in-kitchen, *2* den, 1-car garage; taxes $2,400.

title: U.S. JEWS INVITE PALESTINIANS' VIEWS
description: With an eye toward breaking down stereotypes and exploring new views, a small group of rabbis and American Jewish organizations are inviting Palestinians to be guest speakers in synagogues.

title: TONS OF TRAVAIL
description: When Westchester County developer Martin Ginsburg first saw the mammoth rocks scattered along a rise on the 42-acre site where he is putting up 146 town houses in Scarsdale, there was no doubt in his mind that he should call the project Boulder Ridge.

title: MERGER OF BUSINESS AND SCIENCE LURES RETIREE
description: WHEN Richard Laster of Chappaqua decided on early retirement after a 38-year career at the General Foods Company, he expected to devote his time to leisure activities. But that plan turned out to be short-lived, for he soon found himself pursuing a new career in the plant technology field.

title: ELILEEN IGLESIAS IS WED
description: Eileen Iglesias Is Wed Eileen Marie Iglesias, a daughter of Edwin Iglesias of Huntington, L.I., and Mrs. Lawrence C. Rasmussen of Washington, was married yesterday to Robert Thomas Musachio, a son of Mildred Musachio of Brooklyn and Anthony Musachio. The Rev. Stan Moseley performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: WHAT PRICE COLLISION COVERAGE?
description: Auto renters, pay heed. The price of the collision-damage waiver has increased again. Meanwhile, a major debate is developing in the travel and insurance industries over whether the rental companies should offer it at all and over whether the public is being abused.

title: POPULAR NEWCOMERS IN WESTPORT
description: WESTPORT may well hold the state record for restaurants opened within the last eight years. Alas, few survive.

title: MASKETTE IS WON BY LADY'S SECRET
description: A 3-year-old filly who was winning her sixth straight stakes race and a 9-year-old gelding who is going home after 151 starts shared the cheers at Belmont Park yesterday when Lady's Secret won the Maskette Stakes and Creme de la Fete made a farewell appearance at the track.

title: RUGGED RIVALS FOR JETS
description: The finger-pointing and the shouting has begun, and next comes the hitting on Sunday when the Jets face the Raiders in the season's opener.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report Aug. 25 about the marriage of Elizabeth A. Tucker and Robert D. English incorrectly identified the department at Princeton University where the bride's father, Prof. Robert C. Tucker, taught. He is professor emeritus of politics.

title: A NEW PLACE IN WHITE PLAINS
description: WE remember reading about the ground-breaking ceremonies for Livanos in l982. The location, across from Westchester's County Center, was perfect. Passing the building site from time to time, we, no doubt like other critics and diners, patiently watched as the angular roofs rose and the glass skylights were installed. Finally the restaurant of palacial proportions opened three months ago, and it seems to have a lot more than location going for it.

title: WHALERS SIGN FOUR
description: Mike Zuke, a 31-year-old center who was used as a penalty killer by the Whalers last season, signed a one-year contract with Hartford, according to Emile Francis, the club president, who said the team had signed two-year pacts with three other players. They are Mark Paterson, a 21-year-old defenseman who spent most of last season with the Binghamton (N.Y.) farm club; Ray Ferraro, a 21-year-old center, who was also a Binghamton starter, and Peter Sidorkiewicz, a 22-year-old goaltender who joined the Whalers from Washington last March.

title: THE DANGERS OF TINKERING WITH BENEFITS
description: AT A TIME when more than 8 million Americans are officially jobless, there is a curious lack of public attention to serious efforts to get them back to work. Although the current jobless rate is high by historical standards, it is significantly lower than the worst point of the 1982 recession. As a result, the public is lulled into accepting a 7 percent unemployment rate as the norm.

title: CLASSIC OVERTONES TO A PITCHING DUEL
description: By the 12th inning, Dwight Gooden and Fernando Valenzuela were simply spectators in a scoreless game. Their work - each a masterpiece full of brilliant strokes - had been reduced to two lines in the box score. But they had already delivered a virtuoso performance: a pitching duel in which every other player was a helpless victim.

title: A NEW DIRECTOR FOR HARTFORD
description: THERE is going to be a new figure on the music scene this season, as Michael Lankester assumes the music directorship of the Hartford Symphony.

title: FOUND LUGGAGE
description: To the Editor: As a regular reader of The New York Times Travel section, I am naturally most concerned about the myriad difficulties being reported in foreign travel. I would like to take this opportunity to apprise you of a most reassuring and pleasant experience my wife and I had during our recent trip to Italy and Greece.

title: PRESIDENT IS ATTEMPTING TO DISMANTLE BARRIERS BUILT UP OVER YEARS
description: President Reagan, in pressing complaints of unfair trade today, is seeking to dismantle barriers that many foreign countries have built up over the years to protect their domestic industries.

title: TITANIC WRECK WAS SURRISE YIELD OF UNDERWATER TESTS FOR MILITARY
description: The discovery of the steamship Titanic last week was almost as surprising as the sinking of the luxury liner 73 years ago.

title: SUNDAY CLOSINGS: CHANGES
description: ALTHOUGH a poll conducted by Rutgers University's Eagleton Institute of Politics in 1979 found that 69 percent of New Jerseyans agreed that stores should be allowed to operate on Sundays, part of Cape May County and Bergen and Hudson Counties still observe Sunday closing laws.

title: EXECUTIVE SEARCH
description: To the Editor:

title: POINTS OF CONTENTION
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN and Congress returned last week from their summer break remarkably divided over the political agenda for the rest of the year. Mr. Reagan was determined to mount what his assistants call ''the fall offensive'' for his tax revision plan, the centerpiece of his second-term legislative program. Senators and representatives reported, however, that they had found little enthusiasm at home for the tax program. They said they were more eager to deal with trade policy, deficit reduction, sanctions against South Africa and farm price supports, issues on which they are seriously at odds with the President.

title: JAZZ DISPLAYS A UNIFIED SPIRIT
description: Jazz, the musical tradition, has taken care of itself through the years - persevering and evolving according to its own virtuoso disciplines. But outside the music itself, the jazz community has always verged on anarchy. For all its art and intelligence, jazz has been caught between the pop-music business, where it rarely makes large profits, and the highbrow music world, where it has never been accorded the prestige of European classical music. Lately, the jazz community - that web of musicians and fans and institutions and entrepreneurs, who don't often speak one another's language - has begun to see itself as one embattled entity rather than a slew of competing factions. And 1985 may just turn out to be the year the anarchy gets organized.

title: TRADING SKILLS ACROSS THE AMERICAS
description: Erasmo Suazo Aleman, as the sole metal caster in his central Honduras town of Comayagua, had a problem. He could not fire up his kiln to the high temperature required to melt certain metals.

title: CURREN SHOULD STAY AWAY
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MISSPELLED, SOMETIMES INSPIRED
description: LETTERS TO BAB Sherwood Anderson to Marietta D. Finley 1916-33. Edited by William A. Sutton. With a foreword by Walter B. Rideout. 352 pp. Urbana: University of Illinois Press. $24.95.

title: MISSING AT SEA
description: Last fiscal year the Pentagon reported losing items valued at $1,021,876,000. They weren't necessarily stolen. Most just vanished in the chaotic traffic among the Pentagon's far-flung supply depots.

title: CONVENTION OF BLACKS TO FOCUS ON POLITICAL REPRESENTATION
description: A COALITION of black leaders is scheduled to gather this week for its third annual meeting, a four-day event focusing on a drive for increased black representation in the state government.

title: WHEN COMPUTERS NEED TO CHAT
description: PERSONAL computing is one of those activities that simply does not allow you to rest on your accomplishments. After mastering the operation of the machine, you find there is the business of a program to be dealt with. Be it word processing, a spreadsheet, a data base manager or one of the more esoteric software packages, conquering the intricacies of input commands, data manipulation and formatting for printing can take considerable time.

title: THE IMPACT OF FITNESS ON THE CUT OF CLOTHES
description: At 8 o'clock on a Monday morning, Ed Bradley, the ''60 Minutes'' newsman, sits on the floor of the plain gray basement gym at the Sports Training Institute on East 49th Street, pumping iron to the beat of Michael Jackson's ''Thriller.'' He's breathing hard, his forehead creased, teeth clenched, mouth grimacing. Several years ago, a doctor gave Bradley the choice of losing a damaged knee or exercising it regularly. Since then he has made physical fitness a regular part of his life.

title: IVES CENTER HOPEFUL OF SUPPORT
description: THE first full summer season of the Charles Ives Center for the Arts in Danbury ended last weekend with a blend of jazz, folk and classical music performances that its directors hope will become a staple of the center's programming in years to come.

title: A KENNEDY CANDIDACY?
description: Joseph P. Kennedy 2d is said to be considering running for Lieutenant Governor of Massachusetts in 1986, but he says he is not a candidate now. ''At this time, my answer is no,'' Mr. Kennedy, a son of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, told The Boston Herald Thursday, but said he was ''not foreclosing doing it, by any stretch of the imagination.'' The newspaper reported that it had been told that Mr. Kennedy, 32 years old, was ''strongly leaning'' toward the candidacy and had discussed it with his family.

title: BARGES CLOCK SEINE IN FIGHT OVER PRICES
description: The owner of the famous Seine River passenger boats chained himself Friday to one of about 100 freight barges that have been blocking the river in the center of the city for the last week.

title: 1 Hurt and 25 Boats Ruined As Blaze Hits an L.I. Marina
description: A fire today at a boating marina here destroyed 25 boats, severely injured one man and caused $3 million in damage, fire officials said.

title: TEMPLE FALLS, 28-25, TO BECOME COLLEGE
description: Shawn Halloran passed for touchdowns on Boston College's first two second-half drives and the Eagles survived two Temple touchdowns in the last four minutes for a 28-25 victory today. Boston College (1-1) overcame an early 7-0 deficit. Temple, which trailed by 9-7 at halftime, is 0-1.

title: CLASSICAL LABELS PLAY FAVORITES
description: Back to the future seems to be the byword for most of the major classical record labels: Tried and true repertory, for the most part, appears to be on the menu for the coming months, with tried and true stars doing the performing, along with a clutch of younger or less-well-known artists on whom the companies are pinning their hopes for the future. To be sure, there are a number of more adventurous entries as well, and, as usual, many smaller labels will offer some spice, including most of the contemporary-music listings.

title: BALTIMOREANS AWAITING N.A.A.C.P. AS NEIGHBOR
description: Officials of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People plan to move the organization's headquarters from Brooklyn to what was once a retreat house for nuns in northwest Baltimore.

title: JAMES BROOKE WEDS ELIZABETH A. HEILMAN
description: Elizabeth Ann Heilman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard J. Heilman of Chicago, was married yesterday to James Bettner Brooke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. B. Brooke of Lenox, Mass. The Rev. Duncan R. McQueen performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Lenox.

title: EXPANSION OF PARKLAND URGED
description: IF the County Board of Legislators gives its expected approval to the $4.2 million purchase of the 180-acre Lasdon Estate on Route 35 in Somers for recreational use, the action could signal the start of an effort to increase Westchester's parkland over the next few years.

title: DODGERS DEFEAT METS, 7-6
description: The brawl was nothing more than a few profanities hurled from one player to another and some innocent shoving that loosely resembled a rugby scrum. It was over as quickly, as suddenly, as it had begun. But Ed Lynch, who was at the core of a benches-clearing skirmish today with the Dodger rookie Mariano Duncan, may have felt lasting results.

title: LITCHFIELD'S HAMBURGR TRADITION
description: PEOPLE have been known to wait, dressed in formal attire on their way to gala events, behind others in mud-covered work boots. Rolls-Royces park next to pickup trucks. Children perch on the old wooden counter while their parents, who did the same once, chat with the woman behind the grill, who rarely forgets a face.

title:
ART;

PRINCETON: 19TH-CENTURY ACQUISITIONS
description: BACK-TO-BACK in the Art Museum at Princeton University are two relatively modest exhibitions that form a neat, rather subtle pair: 19th-century photographs by Europeans and 19th-century American landscape paintings.

title: BOOK DEALER COMES EAST, THE BETTER TO FIND BOOKS
description: Somewhere in the middle of nowhere (runs the dream of a certain fanatical type of bookbuyer) in a crumbling Southern mansion, say, or a dull city's sleaziest back alley, or in a cornfield, stands a miraculous bookstore, filled to the rafters with old first editions.

title: THE KILLING CATCHES UP TO REFUGEES IN HONDURAS
description: HONDURAN soldiers entered a Salvadoran refugee camp 10 days ago with the apparent intention of arresting what they thought were leftist guerrillas. Ten refugees were seized for questioning, but the raid exacted a high toll. By the time the shooting was over, two refugees had been killed and 13 wounded.

title: A SELECTION OF FALL EVENTS AROUND THE U.S.
description: PACIFIC COAST: For the copious bounty of sea and of vineyard About this time of year, Washington State residents start thinking about the Dungeness crab season, even though it doesn't start until Dec. 1. Frozen Dungeness crab can be found on the menus of some restaurants and at some supermarkets all year, but it is sweetest, flakiest and juiciest when it is eaten fresh in late fall.

title: PAY THE UNEMPLOYED TO CREATENEW JOBS
description: FOR AN unemployed steelworker who suspects his old job has permanently disappeared, the United States unemployment insurance system offers a peculiar choice. He can accept support (at 40 percent of his former wages for half a year) while looking for a job that may not exist. Or he can enroll in a retraining program, move to a new state or try to start his own small business - and most likely lose unemployment benefits.

title: Phone Companies Hold Back Technology
description: To the Editor:

title: Robin Sue Gutner Marries W.C. Calman in Purchase
description: Robin Sue Gutner and W. Charles Calman were married yesterday at the Old Oaks Country Club in Purchase, N.Y., by Rabbi Irving Koslowe.

title: MEN ONLY A THIRD OF U.S. IMMIGRANTS
description: A new Labor Department study says that women and children account for two-thirds of all legal immigration to the United States, contrary to conventional wisdom.

title: VETO SEEN FOR CURBS ON TEXTILES
description: Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States trade representative, said today that President Reagan ''almost assuredly'' will veto legislation on textile import quotas that is likely to be the first of some 300 protectionist bills to reach the White House in the current trade ferment.

title: Coalition in Jersey Is to Monitor Klan
description: A statewide organization has been established in New Jersey to monitor the activities of the Ku Klux Klan and develop strategy to oppose the white supremacist group, officials said today.

title: Pact Reported For Iran Plant
description: Technipetrol of Italy and Kinetics Technology International, a Dutch company, have jointly contracted to build part of a new petrochemical plant in central Iran, industry sources said today.

title: A Supporting Role
description: On the waterfront, a fort was once turned into an aquarium, an elevated highway into an pedestrian promenade and an aircraft carrier into a museum.

title: Pakistan Bill on Martial Law
description: The military Government introduced in Parliament today a bill that would prohibit courts from investigating eight years of martial law after the Government fulfills its promise to lift martial law by the end of the year. The new bill is designed to insure that courts do not question any orders issued by the country's military ruler, Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, since he came to power as the result of a coup in 1977.

title: Article 248924 -- No Title
description: A fire that broke out here when a man lit a cigarette lighter to search for a friend who had fallen into an oil storage tank burned for 14 hours Saturday and caused $500,000 in damage, an official said today. Rescue workers could not find the body of C. J. Turner, 22 years old, the man who had fallen in, and officials said it apparently burned up in the blaze.

title: George Polya of Stanford, 97; Mathematician and Educator
description: George Polya, a prominent figure in the world of mathematics, an educator and an author, died Saturday after a long illness. He was 97 years old.

title: PATIENT AND FAMILY EXPRESS THANKS FOR REAL HEART
description: His face glowing with restored health, Michael Drummond, the 25-year-old Arizonan who has had three hearts in 10 days, took a few steps to the window of his hospital room today and expressed his gratitude for a renewed lease on life.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 9, 1985
description: The Economy

title: Hunger Is Growing, But Relief Isn't
description: The key to the budget debate is knowing where to cut and where to invest in the battle for future savings. One fundamental lesson I've learned is that cutbacks in certain programs, such as those that feed the hungry, save no money at all. Hunger is so fundamental a problem, and has such a far-reaching effect on health and spirit, that even small investments today to combat it are likely to produce substantial long-term savings.

title: A Benefit - For and of the Theater
description: The standing ovation segued into a seated celebration after the triumphant performance of Stephen Sondheim's ''Follies'' at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night. A gathering of theater people and theater lovers alike, the dinner that followed the show drew a dazzling array of talent from just about every walk of life.

title: Betsy Frank Is the Bride Of Alan Mark Leinwand
description: Betsy Jane Frank, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Jay Frank of Cranbury, N.J., was married yesterday to Alan Mark Leinwand, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney B. Leinwand of Woodmere, L.I. Rabbis Saul Teplitz and Lazar Wax performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: BRAVES' RALLY IN 8TH HELPS BEAT CARDS
description: Bob Horner's pinch-triple with the bases loaded in the seventh inning and a three-run rally in the eighth powered the Atlanta Braves to a 7-3 victory today over the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Italian Grand Prix Is Taken by Prost
description: Alain Prost of France captured the Italian Grand Prix today and made a strong bid for his first world title by fighting off a strong comeback by Nelson Piquet of Brazil.

title: Accounts
description: Berkley Publishing Group to AC&R Advertising for its paperback books.

title: ONLY ON LOWER EAST SIDE: REUNION WITH STRANGERS
description: It was quite a distance to travel for cannoli and espresso, all the way from Thousand Oaks, Calif., to the Lower East Side. But for Anthony Palazzo it was a chance to be reunited with the neighborhood that was his boyhood home.

title: MORE GIRLS JOINING BOYS AS SPORTS TEAMMATES
description: Hundreds of high school girls in New York City and its suburbs, eager for athletic competition, are playing regularly on boys' sports teams.

title: FOR KILEY, JOB HAS BEEN AN EDUCATION IN POLITICS
description: As he approaches his second anniversary as chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Robert R. Kiley says he has learned a thing or two about running the world's largest mass transit system.

title: STEIN'S OPPONENTS VOW TO BAR SOME DONATIONS
description: Five of the six Democratic candidates for City Council president pledged yesterday that once they took office they would not accept campaign contributions from companies and individuals doing business before the Board of Estimate.

title: U.S. SMALL BUSINESS IS DRAWN TO CHINA
description: A little more than 20 months ago, Michael A. Andreottola was out of a job, his position as an engineer and designer with Applicon Inc. eliminated when a French company, Schlumberger, took over the American concern and transferred part of its operations to France.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Have any pitchers led their teams in victories as well as saves over the course of a season?

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 9, 1985
description: International

title: ROZIER LEADS OILERS TO UPSET OF DOLPHINS
description: Mike Rozier scored his second touchdown of the game on a 1-yard run with 25 seconds left today, giving the Houston Oilers a 26-23 upset of the Miami Dolphins, last year's Super Bowl finalists, in the season opener.

title: Connecticut Elections Feature Mayoral Bids
description: Voters in two of Connecticut's largest cities go to the polls Tuesday to nominate candidates for mayor in primary elections.

title: Jane Frazee, Movie Actress Appeared in Musicals in 40's
description: Jane Frazee, an actress who appeared in a series of light movie musicals in the 1940's, died of pneumonia Friday. She was 67 years old.

title: COUP ATTEMPT SPARKS FIGHTING IN THAI CAPITAL
description: A military faction this morning seized Thailand's armed forces headquarters and announced on Radio Thailand that it had overthrown the Government.

title: CLUES TO ANCIENT GEOLOGY SOUGHT IN AFRICA'S RIFT VALLEY
description: Peter Maguire, his hands poised over the detonation switch, began the countdown: ''Ten, nine, eight . . . '' Nearby a herd of wildebeests grazed. Masai children, armed with their traditional short clubs and cattle-herding staffs, looked on with increasing curiosity.

title: PRIMARIES AND THE CANDIDATES
description: Following are the candidates in the contested races in tomorrow's primary elections in New York City. Incumbents are marked with an asterisk.

title: PANEL AND TREASURY CONFER ON TAX PLAN
description: After a private weekend retreat in the Virginia countryside, Treasury Department officials and leaders of the House Ways and Means Committee said today they were optimistic they could work together to write legislation restructuring the Federal income tax system.

title: Park Ave. Viaduct To Reopen Today
description: The Park Avenue tunnel and viaduct, portions of which have been closed since last April, will be fully reopened to traffic today at 2 P.M., City Transportation Department officials said yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Tegucigalpa, Honduras, Saturday on the delivery of 12 American helicopter gunships to the Salvadoran Air Force misstated the size of their guns. The helicopters are equipped with 7.62-millimeter machine guns.

title: Gun Seizures Rise At Canada Border
description: Canadian customs officials said today that the number of weapons seized from Americans at border crossings in western New York has increased since Erie County eased its gun-control laws in June.

title: PARENTS WHO STILL CONTROL
description: PARENTING, by many accounts, can be a never-ending battle for truth, justice and a way to tell a 36-year-old son - the lawyer - that he needs a haircut and a 28-year-old daughter - the doctor - that she should bundle up when the weather turns cold.

title: Court Detente
description: Tennis, anyone? Why nyet? That, more or less, is the way Alan Boltin, a California pro, got permission from Soviet sports authorities for a group of tennis-playing tourists from the United States to take on some native amateurs in a series of friendship matches during a two-week visit to the Soviet Union later this month. ''It will be the first time that ordinary American and Soviet players have played each other in the Soviet Union,'' Boltin said the other day, expressing hope that the tour would help promote understanding.

title: Labeling Origin of Orange Juice
description: The nation's orange juice processors have lost a battle with the Government over labeling. The Customs Service has ordered packagers of frozen orange juice and orange juice made from concentrate to mark the country of origin on the label of the package starting Jan. 1.

title: Prices Jump 4.4% in Mexico
description: Consumer prices surged 4.4 percent in August, the sharpest monthly rise since January, the Government announced last week. For the first eight months of the year, prices climbed 35.8 percent, or slightly less than the 38.5 percent for the comparable period in 1984.

title: NAVRATILOVA IS 'DEVASTATED'
description: Barely two hours after Hana Mandlikova of Czechslovakia had completed her thrilling upset of Martina Navratilova to win her first United States Open tennis championship Saturday, she teamed with Wendy Turnbull of Australia in the semifinals of the women's doubles competition. Their team lost, but that did not spoil Miss Mandlikova's day.

title: THE DEER WHO DINE ON HEDGES
description: With summer ending and the nights beginning to cool, the thoughts of many homeowners along the Front Range of the Rockies turn to the prospect of wildlife emerging from the chilly mountains, looking for something to eat.

title: Award for Celeste Holm
description: The actress Celeste Holm will receive Town Hall's ''Friend of the Arts'' award in a special ceremony on Oct. 20 at the hall, 123 West 43d Street.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Tell Patterson I'm gonna buy him a steak dinner.'' - Pete Rose after tying Ty Cobb's record for base hits. [A1:3.]

title: In a Word - or More
description: Fearful that his syndicated television panel show, ''The McLaughlin Group,'' might be getting out of balance, John McLaughlin, the moderator, ordered a word-count of a typical Saturday broadcast late last month. The results, which would have surprised few viewers of the contentious program, were: Karen Elliot House of The Wall Street Journal, 505 words; Jack W. Germond, co-author of a syndicated political column, 577; Morton M. Kondracke, Washington bureau chief of Newsweek, 604; and Robert Novak, also a syndicated columnist, 1,007.

title: NBC REPORTER KILLED
description: The NBC bureau chief in Bangkok, Neil Davis, was killed when he and an NBC sound technician were recording the fighting around a radio station in the center of the city near Government House at 10 A.M. Bangkok time, an NBC News spokesman in New York said early this morning.

title: Judith Lynn Lehman Wed To D. J. Weiniger in Jersey
description: Judith Lynn Lehman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Charles Lehman of West Orange, N.J., was married yesterday to David Jay Weiniger, the son of Wallace Weiniger of Maplewood, N.J., and Mrs. Gerald Freedman of Washington and Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbis Barry Hewitt Greene and Eli Pilchick performed the ceremony at the Mountain Ridge Country Club in West Caldwell, N.J.

title: RURAL UNITS SEEK NEW FUNDS AS U.S. HOUSING EFFORT SLOWS
description: The people of Clay County live in a variety of houses along the creeks and rivers deep inside the Daniel Boone National Forest. Some live in sleek ranch-style houses; others in mobile homes or the ancient, sagging shacks that have served generations of mountain families.

title: POWER PLANS BY CONGRESS
description: For the first time in Ronald Reagan's Presidency, Congress has abruptly seized the initiative on foreign policy matters and has placed the White House on the defensive on several key, politically charged issues, White House and Congressional officials say.

title: FARM LOAN BAILOUT QUESTIONED
description: Of the major groups of the population that can claim injury from the failings of the nation's economy, farmers would rank high.

title: NEW HOPE FOR TRADE WITH EAST
description: Four years ago Bernd Brunner of Cleveland took $3,000 and started importing kits for trucks and forklifts from East Germany. Now he runs a $10 million business.

title: PRESSURE MOUNTING, PRESS CORPS GROWS
description: THE JOURNEY has been a long one, lasting nearly 23 years, and Pete Rose, now on the last leg, has appeared a little pooped. But to paraphrase the poet, Rose still has more to go before he sleeps. Or, at least, a little more to go before he sleeps the peace of the totally contented.

title: TIMING EQUITY PROGRAMS' FILING IS DISCLOSED
description: The move last week by Community Savings and Loan Association's key real estate subsidiary that placed most of its operations outside state control came only hours after Community Savings said it would not object to a takeover by the state of Maryland, state officials said yesterday.

title: No More Talk of Inferior Beginning Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Rings Around Reagan
description: President Reagan's plaintive plea that he be given television time to appeal to the Soviet people suggests that he's all too well aware of the sad truth - Mikhail S. Gorbachev has been running rings around him in pre-summit propaganda.

title: Exhibit on Black Role In the American West
description: An exhibition highlighting the presence of black explorers, cowboys, cavalrymen, homesteaders and entrepreneurs in the American West will open at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture next Monday.

title: 'CAN'T BUT THAT THRILL'
description: IN the Giants' locker room about two hours before yesterday's season opener, Phil McConkey turned to Phil Simms.

title: THE BOOT CAMP FOR TOP M.B.A.'S
description: ''YOU just walk into the trading room and it hits you between the eyes,'' said Christopher Charron. ''This is great, this is where it happens.'' Mr. Charron, Harvard '85, is one of 127 trainees in corporate finance, sales and trading who started at Salomon Brothers this summer and, if he sounds more like a religious convert than an investment banker, there are 126 others just like him.

title: Iran Says It Recaptured Vital Mountain Post
description: Iran said today that its soldiers recaptured a key mountain post and eight border villages from Iraqi forces in the northern sector of the border battlefront.

title: A CHALLENGE TO PINOCHET
description: The occasion of the largest anti-Government protests in a year, organized by a fragile alliance of usually fractious opposition parties, has given Chilean political leaders renewed hope for the return of civilian democracy.

title: INVESTIGATORS STUDY MORE CLUES IN MILWAUKEE CRASH THAT KILLED 31
description: Federal investigators found more engine parts today on the runway that Midwest Express Airlines Flight 105 traveled on its way to a fiery crash that left no survivors Friday.

title: SINGER ON TV AND BROADWAY
description: Johnny Desmond, the singer and actor who rose to fame as a vocalist with Glenn Miller's swing band, died of cancer on Friday night at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 65 years old. The singer had performed in New York City as recently as last April, at the Rainbow Room.

title: STP Is Recalling Containers Of Heavy-Duty Brake Fluid
description: The STP Corporation on Friday announced a recall of mislabeled plastic containers of STP Heavy Duty Brake fluid that contain power steering fluid instead.

title: THATCHER SEEKS U.S. CONTRACT
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain has personally appealed to President Reagan to award a multibillion-dollar military contract to a British company rather than its French rival, asserting that Britain is a more reliable ally of the United States than France, British officials confirmed today.

title: Mixing Old With New At Carnegie Hall
description: What color is Carnegie Hall? No one color at all.

title: DAUGHTER'S STORY: AIDING MOTHER'S SUICIDE
description: Betty Rollin says she regards her controversial new book, ''Last Wish,'' as a ''love story'' about her relationship with her mother. In it, she tells how she and her husband helped her mother, terminally ill with cancer, to commit suicide.

title: Spill in Derailment Forces Evacuation
description: Ten cars of a freight train, including two cars containing a highly flammable liquid chemical, derailed yesterday in Mechanicville, N.Y., forcing the brief evacuation of 150 homes and injuring two firefighters.

title: BEHIND NADER, A GENERATION AT THE READY
description: Ralph Nader has been at it 20 years now, criticizing business and government whenever he perceives a failure to consider the consumer. But his most enduring mark may come not from his attack, say, on a car he called unsafe at any speed, but instead from the legion of young people he inspired.

title: Brinks Robbed of $1 Million
description: Two men wearing masks handcuffed and bound a security guard at a Brinks armored car building here Saturday and stole more than $1 million from the vault, the police said today. One of the thieves was inside the building and surprised the guard, the police said.

title: FOOD-MOOD LINK IS REPORTED
description: Researchers at the University of Chicago have established a definite link between food and moodiness, including irritability, anxiety and depresssion. But it is too early to pinpoint particular foods as the source of certain moods, Dr. John Crayton, an associate professor of psychiatry who directed the study, said.

title: How Business Can Chip at Apartheid
description: This year at Texaco, fat envelopes came thumping into our chrome in-boxes. They were the proxy statements and with them the usual dilemma: How do we shareholders vote on the church group sponsored South Africa resolution?

title: LOPEZ WINS IN PLAYOFF
description: Nancy Lopez sank a 5-foot birdie putt on the third hole of a sudden-death playoff today to win the $175,000 Portland Ping Golf Championship.

title: The F.D.A. Keeps the Drug Companies Honest
description: To the Editor:

title: Protesting the Protest
description: When a compromise restricting offshore oil drilling on the California coast was announced in July by Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel, environmentalists cheered and business interests protested. Among the critics was the American Land Alliance, a coalition of private property-rights advocates, which circulated a statement by its president, Joseph M. Gughemetti, attacking the agreement as inviting economic disaster for the nation and spurning the will of Congress.

title: COMPLETE 'CIVIL WARS' TO BE STAGED IN TEXAS
description: Robert Wilson's epic music-drama ''The Civil Wars: A Tree Is Best Measured When It Is Down'' has been scheduled for its first complete performances, in Austin, Tex., next September.

title: 30 Hurt in Fireworks Mishap
description: Fireworks for a display here exploded apparently by accident Saturday night and sprayed a crowd of 2,000 people with debris. More than 30 people were burned or injured as the crowd fled through a dense cloud of smoke, the police said. The authorities said they thought the blast had been caused by a hot fragment that touched off about 70 mortar fireworks at the closing event of the three-day Reamstown Days festival.

title: WOODS HOLE AWAITS LATEST GLEANING FROM THE OCEANS
description: When the research vessel Knorr arrives this afternoon at the wharves of Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution bearing thousands of photographs, hundreds of feet of videotape and other data from the Titanic's final resting place in the North Atlantic, she will bring home another major accomplishment to a research center known throughout the world of marine science.

title: HELEN HAYES IS HELPING EUGENE O'NEILL'S HOME
description: Fourteen years after her last stage role, that of Mary Tyrone in Eugene O'Neill's ''Long Day's Journey Into Night,'' Helen Hayes today visited the secluded house where O'Neill wrote what came to be known as his finest plays.

title: CHILD ABUSE CASE MARKED BY DELAYS
description: In suburban Manhattan Beach, where, 18 months ago, prosecutors uncovered what they said was the largest child sex abuse scandal in the nation, some parents posted a sign on a telephone pole last week.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;

M.V.P. Trivia
description: Speaking of the Blue Jays and the World Series:

title: Union Bancorp Officer Busy Closing Bank Deal
description: John F. Harrigan, chairman and president of Union Bancorp and an avowed bird watcher, has not had much time lately to watch the two peregrine falcons nesting on his bank's roof. The head of California's sixth-largest bank holding company has been too busy buying a bank.

title: NEW YORK TO EXPAND SUBSIDY FOR A SHELTER FOR VICTIMS OF AIDS
description: New York City has been helping a private group shelter 21 AIDS victims in Manhattan apartments for several months and is now negotiating to give the group two city-owned buildings so that it can shelter 40 to 60 more victims, officials said yesterday.

title: TEXAS NURSING HOME DEATHS COMING TO TRIAL AFTER 6 YEARS
description: Six years after a young prosecutor ran across a neglected file of reports alleging that elderly nursing home patients had died of abuse and neglect, a convalescent home chain and several employees are going on trial Monday.

title: What Police Cadets Promise
description: For the moment it seems a modest step - New York City will spend $1 million a year to recruit 200 police officers from city colleges. Yet the Police Cadet Corps just launched by Mayor Koch and Police Commissioner Ward could also begin a historic transformation of police departments in the city and state, possibly even around the country. All depends on City Hall's commitment.

title: DANCE: FASCIST HORROR IN 'CHILDRENZ MUZEUM'
description: THE title made it sound childish. But ''Childrenz Muzeum'' was decidely for adults.

title: Two for One
description: The Corcoran Gallery of Art's decision to impose admission charges for the first time for four special exhibitions this season is not going to have as abrupt an impact as it appeared. Visitors to ''L'amour fou,'' an exhibit, opening Saturday, of surrealist photography between the two World Wars, will have to pay $1.50 for adults or 50 cents for students and senior citizens, it's true.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE WAY WE LIVE The ninth Margaret Mead Film Festival, named for the anthropologist, opens today at the American Museum of Natural History, 77th Street and Central Park West, where 44 recent films portraying 30 different cultures will be shown through Thursday.

title: Retractable Blade For Disposable Razor
description: If you consider a retractable blade on a disposable razor a meaningful consumer benefit, then you will be overjoyed to learn that the Wilkinson Sword unit of Allegheny International has just that sort of a product and will be spending $23.5 million over the next two years to promote it.

title: VIKINGS SURPRISE FUMBLING 49ERS, 28-21
description: Ted Brown's 10-yard touchdown run with 1 minute 49 seconds to play today powered the Minnesota Vikings to a 28-21 upset over the defending National Football League champion San Francisco 49ers and made Vikings Coach Bud Grant's return a triumphant one.

title: McEnroe Calm After Loss
description: John McEnroe is known for his fiery, competitive spirit. But last night, after his loss in the United States Open final to Ivan Lendl, he did not appear overly distraught.

title: Bridge: Defensive Bidding Can Give Opponents Too Much Help
description: Almost any bid can be considered a two-edged sword: It gives information to partner, in the hope of finding the best contract, but it also gives information to the opposition. This is particularly significant when bids are primarily defensive, aimed at a sacrifice.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption with a picture accompanying an article Saturday about the heat wave incorrectly described Friday's high temperature in New York. The record is 97 degrees.

title: JAYS' 4 HOMERS DEFEAT TWINS
description: Lloyd Moseby hit a pair of two-run homers, Jesse Barfield hit a three-run homer and Damaso Garcia added a two-run homer today to power the Toronto Blue Jays to a 10-9 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

title: OKLA. STATE UPSET PACED BY TAILBACK
description: Oklahoma State's coach, Pat Jones, was so delighted with the performance of his sophomore tailback, Thurman Thomas, in the Cowboys' 31-17 upset of Washington Saturday night that he said, ''If you don't put Thurman on your Heisman Trophy ballots, you're missing the boat.''

title: BOTHA SCORNS PLAN FOR TALKS WITH REBELS
description: President P. W. Botha today strongly criticized reported plans by a group of leading South African business executives to meet with the outlawed and exiled African National Congress, saying such actions were ''disloyal.''

title: Dori Bernstein Weds Daniel Allen Nathan
description: Dori Kay Bernstein and Daniel Allen Nathan, both graduates of the New York University School of Law, were married yesterday at Temple Beth Israel in West Hartford, Conn. Rabbi Jody Cohen and Rabbi Harry Zwelling co-officiated.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch from Cracow, Poland, yesterday about the bar mitzvah of Eric Strom of Stamford, Conn., was edited to incorporate an erroneous report from a Times article on Aug. 28. The visit was planned and financed by private individuals, not by the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies in New York.

title: JAZZ: BOURELLY, GUITARIST
description: TWO young jazz musicians who usually perform in other people's bands, and a better-known soloist, had a showcase concert Friday at Greenwich Music House, 27 Barrow Street.

title: No More Talk of Inferior Beginning Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: 'It Should Be So'
description: We were walking on the Bund, the Shanghai waterfront's famous esplanade, when a young man came up and asked, in English, ''Where are you from?'' Massachusetts. ''Ah,'' he said, ''the Bay State.''

title: P.O.W. Status in Ulster Said to Be Ending
description: A London newspaper reported today that Britain plans to stop granting the more prestigious status of prisoner-of-war to Northern Ireland inmates convicted of political terrorism.

title: RCA and MCA Met on Friday
description: Top executives of the RCA Corporation and MCA Inc. met Friday to continue discussions about a possible merger between the new companies, according to sources close to the situation. These talks followed talks last spring between top management of both entertainment conglomerates.

title: Bus Atrocity Reported In Sri Lanka
description: A guerrilla spokesman said today that 34 Tamils were burned alive in a bus in Sri Lanka by a group of Sinhalese.

title: HOW REAGAN ALWAYS GETS THE BEST LINES
description: ''I am paying for this microphone,'' Ronald Reagan told his rivals in the 1980 Presidential primary debate in New Hampshire.

title: COMPANY EXPENSES FOR RETIREES SOAR
description: Businesses that began to pay medical costs for retirees nearly 20 years ago are seeing their commitments soar to hundreds of millions of dollars, far beyond what most had envisioned.

title: 5,200 Workers Strike At a Ford Plant in Ohio
description: Some 5,200 employees of the Ford Motor Company assembly plant here went on strike this morning, protesting unsettled health and safety grievances.

title: CITY OFFERS REASSURANCES ON AIDS PUPIL
description: New York City's Schools Chancellor, Mayor Koch and other public officials yesterday sought to allay fears over the admission of a child with AIDS to regular classes today, warning against panic and insisting that there were no dangers to other children.

title: 11 IN NEO-NAZI 'ORDER' ON TRIAL TODAY
description: The trial of members of a neo-Nazi group called the Order, charged with counterfeiting, arson, armed robbery and murder in a plot to overthrow the United States Government, begins under heavy security here Monday, with the number of original defendants sharply reduced.

title: Air Express Chief Planning to Resign
description: The Air Express International Corporation, an air freight carrier that has been experiencing financial difficulties, said that Lawrence J. Rodberg, its chairman and chief executive officer, intended to resign by the end of the month.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: HOMELESS IN PASSAIC TAKE STOCK
description: Some wept openly, others wiped aside a stray tear, a few maintained an air of calm resignation.

title: BREAKING A COMPUTER BARRIER Three Ways to Speed Up Computers
description: For two decades, computer scientists have periodically wrestled with a seemingly obvious technique for greatly speeding up computers: Rather than funnel a vast amount of data through a single processor, design a machine in which a host of processors attack a problem at once. The result, they knew, would be like installing a bank of toll booths across an interstate highway, instead of forcing hundreds of cars into a single lane.

title: People
description: William A. Overlock has been named executive vice president, administration/finance, of SSC&B effective Sept. 30.

title: SANDINISTAS RETAIN THE UPPER HAND
description: Although rebel forces have widened their area of operation in Nicaragua and have won some battlefield successes, the Government still has a strong upper hand in the conflict, diplomats and Western military officers here say.

title: Hall Group Head Plans Expansion
description: At the tender age of 18, Craig T. Hall made his first real estate deal. He has not stopped since. ''I took all the money I had saved since I was 12, about $4,000,'' Mr. Hall, who is now 35, said in a telephone interview, ''and used it as a down payment on a rooming house in Ann Arbor, Mich. I paid $27,250 for the building. Two years later, I sold it for $49,000.''

title: IN ARIZONA MINING TOWN, IT'S YUPPIES VS. HIPPIES
description: Sleepy old Bisbee seems an odd place to find a triple-decker culture clash, but it's here.

title: At Hall of Fame, Much Remains to Be Done
description: To the Editor:

title: 'DIANA,' A SERIES BASED ON A DELDERFIELD NOVEL
description: IF you are partial to ''Masterpiece Theater'' serials, it is no longer necessary to keep your dial tuned to public television. Among the other outlets now offering the kind of British yarns long associated with Mobil Oil and Alistair Cooke is cable's Arts & Entertainment channel. And a fine example of that channel's competition is ''Diana,'' a 10-episode production currently being shown on Mondays at 9 P.M. The star is a quite formidable young actress named Jenny Seagrove.

title: 299TH FOR NIEKRO: METS WIN IN 14 WILSON STARS
description: Their seasons have been full of bumps and twists and occasional dead-end streets, but Doug Sisk and Mookie Wilson came back today. An afternoon that stretched into the early evening was suddenly in their hands, and the two missing Mets responded admirably.

title: Catching Up
description: What ever happened to Bob Sykes, the veteran pitcher the Yankees acquired from St. Louis four years ago when they unloaded Willie McGee, then a 22-year-old minor leaguer but now comfortably on his way to the National League batting championship? Simply this: a demotion the following spring to the Class AAA club at Columbus, a subsequent demotion to the Class AA club at Nashville, arm problems that required two operations that season and retirement from baseball that fall. Sykes is now 30 and is learning the oil business in Carmi, Ill., where he is employed by a company that is owned by a friend's father.

title: KENNEDY IS STILL DOMINATING CITY FOOTBALL PICTURE
description: Football in the Public School Athletic League took a major step forward last season. John F. Kennedy, completing the best season in its history, became the first public school team to win the Metro Bowl, the annual contest between the public school and Catholic school champions that determines the city champion.

title: Patterson Smothers Eagles' Receivers
description: Shortly after the shutout over Philadelphia today, someone asked Elvis Patterson, the Giants' left cornerback, the nature of his downfield conversations with the Eagles' wide receivers.

title: Man Finishes His Term For Killing a Professor
description: Theodore Streleski, who bludgeoned a Stanford professor to death for belittling his 19 years of trying to earn a doctorate, was freed after seven years in prison today, and he insisted he felt no remorse for his crime.

title: Sanctions for Nicaragua, but Not South Africa?
description: To the Editor:

title: 'RAIN,' A NEAR-FAILURE, HAS VIGOROUS RECOVERY
description: Late on July 2, ''Singin' in the Rain'' stood ready to enter Broadway history - as one of the most expensive one-night flops ever. After a year of preparation at a cost of $4.1 million, the show opened that night to damaging notices. Variety later tallied 12 unfavorable reviews, five mixed ones and but four positive nods: for most shows, an obituary.

title: Special Interest Politics
description: ''Dear Patient,'' begins the form letter from Dr. Alan Goldstein, a West Side dentist.

title: The Big Chill
description: A World Series game has not been postponed because of the cold since Oct. 9, 1903, in Pittsburgh, during the very first Series. But with the Toronto Blue Jays mounting a serious threat 82 years later, the question arises whether the fall classic can stand up to some classically Canadian fall weather.

title: AN URGENT QUEST IN LEISURELY GENEVA
description: Harald Muller is one of the busiest men in Geneva these days. He can be found almost anytime at the Palais des Nations here, where delegates from 90 countries are spending a month at a conference reviewing the treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons, defending or attacking the 15-year-old accord.

title: One by One
description: Michael K. Deaver, the former deputy chief of staff at the White House, is building his Washington public relations business by plucking seasoned staff members, one at a time, from the Reagan Administration. The latest to join his 4-month-old firm as an associate is Doral Cooper, a former assistant United States trade representative who had also worked for the Council of Economic Advisers and the Federal Reserve Board.

title: FANFARE AND THE FANS
description: THE POPULAR notion these days is that the United States Open attracts a crowd that, given a choice between talking commodities over brie and claret or attending any other sporting event, would go for the cheese without hesitation. To fans of other games, the Open finals seem like sports' equivalent of opening night at the opera, an occasion as likely to draw socialites and stuffed shirts as well as true-blue fans.

title: Leak at Chemical Plant Sends Five to Hospitals
description: Five people were sent to hospitals today after a poisonous chemical leaked at a plant here, the authorities said.

title: Market Place;   Growth Seen for Job Service
description: THE stock market got a needed boost Friday from the announcement that the nation's unemployment rate was down. But things have been going well for some time for several companies with a special link to the employment situation: publicly owned concerns that supply temporary workers to the job market.

title: Hillary Bakst, Teacher, Wed to Peter Rathjens
description: Hillary Dana Bakst, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Bakst of Great Neck, L.I., and Peter Laurence Rathjens, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Rathjens of West Newton, Mass., were married yesterday. Rabbi Morton Rosenthal performed the ceremony at Morven, which formerly served as home in Princeton for New Jersey governors.

title: 299TH FOR NIEKRO; METS WIN IN 14 A'S LOSE, 9-6
description: Phil Niekro, now on the brink of gaining career victory No. 300, made a startling admission yesterday. ''I'm just not as young as I used to be,'' he said after recording victory No. 299.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Brewers, at Milwaukee, 8:35 P.M. The Yankees go on the road for three games with the Brewers before coming back to the Stadium on Thursday for a four-game series with Toronto.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Adam Purple's Garden
description: These are not good days for Adam Purple's garden. Drought has baked the soil and the roses are looking spindly. But the herbs are flourishing, so are some purple blooms and recently somebody saw a yellow warbler and a hummingbird. That's a big thing, because Mr. Purple's garden is on Eldridge Street, a monument to decay on Manhattan's Lower East Side.

title: GIANTS TRIUMPH; JETS FALL, 31-0 RAIDERS ROLL
description: Not even in immobile Joe Namath's last, scrambling days in New York had a Jet quarterback been faced with the assault that greeted Ken O'Brien today.

title: Honored
description: Pamela Harriman, the Democratic activist and wife of W. Averell Harriman, will be honored by the National Mental Health Association for her contributions to the cause with a dinner at the Sheraton Washington Hotel Thursday evening. The organization gives such a citation only every two or three years; past recipients have been Rosalyn Carter, Walter Cronkite and Mr. Harriman. The 93-year-old diplomat is scheduled to attend, his health reportedly having improved over a restful summer.

title: SOUTH AFRICA JOB CODE IS FRUIT OF ONE MAN'S BATTLE AGAINST BIAS
description: While the Rev. Leon Sullivan was leaving South Africa after an overnight visit 10 years ago, security officials manhandled him, held him in a small room, forced him to undress for a search and tore through his luggage.

title: 'NEW WAVE' VIEW OF PROTECTIONISM
description: Although almost all economists remain aloof from the swelling political movement to curb imports, there are some who cite the results of complicated new research to contend that protectionism may at times be justified.

title: Three Mile Island Fire Delay
description: A smoldering electrical fire that damaged control switches at Three Mile Island's Unit 1 nuclear reactor over the weekend has crippled the unit for at least several days, the utility said today, and it could delay the planned restarting of the plant, which has been blocked by legal proceedings since May.

title: Japan Denial of Capital Curb
description: The Japanese Finance Ministry and the Bank of Japan today denied a press report that Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone has told them to study ways of curbing capital outflows from Japan.

title: Truck and Bus Deregulation
description: THE Senate today begins its part of the final required annual Congressional assessment of reduced regulation of the motor carrier industry. A parade of witnesses is scheduled to testify before the Subcommittee on Surface Transportation of the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation.

title: A Possible Departure
description: David Markey, one of the Administration's telecommunications policymakers, may soon be leaving his post as Assistant Secretary of Commerce and head of the National Telecommunications Information Administration. He is the latest official to be heavily courted by the new telephone lobby and he says he is actively engaged in discussions.

title: Jackson on Pretoria Boycott
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson urged consumers Saturday to boycott I.B.M. products to protest the company's business dealings with the South African Government. ''I.B.M. has got to choose dignity over dollars,'' Mr. Jackson said at a rally, telling the demonstrators that I.B.M. computer equipment is used by the South African military.

title: Gauge Interrupts Shoreham Testing
description: A faulty gauge interrupted low-power testing at the Shoreham nuclear plant for more than an hour today, a spokesman for the electric utility that operates the installation said.

title: New-Account News Signals Summer's End
description: From all over the country last week there came a fluttering of new-account announcements - summer was over. After the dog days of August it was business as usual.

title: DIRECTION OF RATES IS UNCLEAR
description: When bond prices fell two points on Friday, economists and traders were quick to blame the stronger-than-expected employment data, which suggested that the economy is rebounding from the meager 1 percent growth rate of the first half.

title: OUTDOORS: SEPTEMBER TRANSITIONS
description: IT is a five-minute walk from the scratched-out place on the side of the road to the path that follows the riverbank. Plenty of time for the sportsman to learn first hand what the calendar says much less eloquently: that the most dramatic, breathtaking and, ultimately, melancholy change of seasons is at hand.

title: Roberta Lindenberg Thumin Wed to Ivan Berger
description: Roberta Lindenberg Thumin, the owner of Roberta Thumin Communications, a public-relations firm in New York, was married yesterday to Ivan Berger, the technical editor of Audio magazine. Rabbi Joan Friedman performed the ceremony at the office of Video magazine in New York.

title: STAGE: CONCERT VERSION OF 'FOLLIES' IS A REUNION
description: IN the 1971 Stephen Sondheim-James Goldman musical, ''Follies,'' a troupe of retired show girls gathers for a ''first and last reunion'' 30 years after the Follies vanished into history. Their all-night party, held on the stage of their crumbling old vaudeville palace, is not a happy one. As the aging performers drift through the rubble of their glamorous past and dredge up old memories, they keep bumping into the ghosts of their younger selves and stumbling on the unsalvageable wreckage of their youthful, innocent dreams.

title: CODE FOR U.S. BUSINESSES
description: Following are the original principles written by the Rev. Leon Sullivan for American companies doing business in South Africa:

title: GIANTS TRIUMPH; JETS FALL, 31-0 BLANK EAGLES
description: The good fortunes befitting a 5-0 team in the exhibition season continued today for the Giants. They opened the National Football League regular season with a resounding 21-0 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles, a triumph that was marked by an exceptional defensive performance by the Giants and an unusually intense rainstorm during most of the first half of play.

title: AUTO EXECUTIVES DISPUTE CAR SAFETY RATINGS
description: Each year an arm of the insurance industry ranks the cars sold in this country on the basis of injury claims and repair costs resulting from accidents.

title: What Kennedy Said
description: To the Editor:

title: No More Talk of Inferior Beginning Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Little Urgency on F.C.C. Post
description: Look for the Federal Communications Commission vacancy being created this month by the departure of Henry Rivera to remain unfilled for a long time. There appears to be no urgency on the part of the White House to move and no pressure from Mark S. Fowler, the commission's chairman, to do so.

title: No New Talks Set in Strike Of Philadelphia Newspapers
description: Workers picketed in the rain today outside The Philadelphia Inquirer and Daily News, and a company spokesman said there was ''no cause for any optimism'' in the strike that has halted publication of the city's two daily newspapers.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Arthur D. Little Inc., the consulting company based in Cambridge, Mass., has elected William F. O'Neil senior vice president and chief financial officer.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Teamwork In a Proper Setting
description: EARLY Friday morning, an hour before McCann-Erickson would make its presentation for more than $15 million of Union Carbide billings, Jay McNamara, its chairman for North America, was already in his office and as cool as one would expect a former Marine Corps officer to be.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: CARACOLE. By Edmund White. 342 pages. Dutton. $17.95.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption in early editions yesterday accompanying photographs of minor candidates for the Democratic Mayoral nomination misidentified two candidates. Gilbert DiLucia was seen talking with a voter. The picture above him was of Dr. Frederick E. Newman.

title: DOLE SEEKS DELAY IN SENATE'S VOTE ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, said today that he would seek to postpone voting on a bill to impose economic sanctions against South Africa because President Reagan was expected to agree to put most of them into effect administratively. The vote has been scheduled for this week.

title: Abby Goodman Weds D. A. Rosenfeld
description: At Summerset House in Siasconset, Mass., yesterday Abby Rae Goodman, an artist and landscape architect, was married to Donald Alan Rosenfeld, president of the New England News and Photo Company, a legal photography concern in Brookline, Mass. Rabbi Herman Blumberg performed the ceremony.

title: Sanctions for Nicaragua, but Not South Africa?
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 IN MAYORAL RACE MAKING FINAL PUSH FOR CITY'S PRIMARY
description: From air-conditioned television studios to sweltering city streets, Democratic candidates yesterday tried to pump as many hands and win over as many voters as possible in the final hours of campaigning before tomorrow's primary.

title: Futures/Options;   Swiss Moving To Futures
description: THE Swiss banking community has decided to set up its own financial and stock index futures markets as well as to strengthen its presence in the Chicago, London, Philadelphia, New York and other financial and index futures and options markets.

title: POP: GREEN ON RED, ROCK AS AMERICAN FOLK
description: ''EVERY day I drive the same old car, every night I play a different bar,'' sings Dan Stuart of Green on Red, the Los Angeles-based rock-and-roll band that was at Irving Plaza Friday night. Like Bruce Springsteen, Green on Red spends long periods on the road, playing in town after town and writing songs about America and Americans. But Green on Red lives closer to the bone, staying in cheap motels, playing in the small college towns as well as the big cities. Mr. Sprngsteen must have to make an effort to break out of the star's customary isolation and relate to the working-class America that shaped him; Green on Red is thoroughly immersed in the America behind the billboards.

title: SHIITES SHELLING PALESTINIANS IN BEIRUT
description: Shiite Moslem militiamen trying to gain control of a Palestinian refugee area here bombarded positions inside the district today with mortar shells and heavy machine-gun fire.

title: CONSERVATIVES TOOK '84 LEAD IN INDEPENDENT POLITICAL AID
description: Political action committees and individuals spent nearly $23 million on the 1984 election, much of it disbursed by conservative groups backing President Reagan's re-election.

title: Magazine Network Focuses on Rich Men
description: CBS Magazines, which had a four-publication network before it acquired the consumer magazines of Ziff-Davis, has added seven of them to create an 11-magazine network of male-oriented enthusiast magazines with more than five million in circulation and a total readership of almost 20 million.

title: AFGHAN REBELS DENY KABUL REPORT THAT THEY DOWNED CIVIL AIRLINES
description: Afghan exiles today challenged Afghanistan's assertion that guerrillas shot down one of its airliners with an American-made missile. They said that the plane might have crashed or that it was a military transport.

title: U.S. ENVOYS MEET IN PANAMA TODAY TO DISCUSS LATIN PEACE EFFORTS
description: Elliott Abrams, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, said today that he would meet with American ambassadors to Central America on Monday to explore ways to give new impetus to the search for peace in the region and support elections in Guatemala and Honduras.

title: U.S. FINANCING FOCUSES ON BILL SALE
description: Treasury financing this week is confined to the bill market, where the Government has scheduled a regular weekly sale today of three- and six-month issues totaling $14.4 billion. About midweek, the Treasury is expected to announce plans for a two-year note auction on Sept. 18.

title: TINY LIECHTENSTEIN BASKS IN POPE'S BIG SPOTLIGHT
description: This tiny Alpine country, which thrives on anonymity and has reason to believe that small is beautiful, briefly loomed large today because of a visit by Pope John Paul II.

title: EPISCOPAL LEADER ASSAILS ADMINISTRATION POLICIES
description: The presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church has accused President Reagan of misunderstanding the causes of human suffering and enforcing policies that lead to a ''chain reaction'' of oppression, despair and death.

title: Dr. Faye Warren Wed To Dr. Joshua Berger
description: Dr. Faye Lydia Warren, chief resident in ophthalmology at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park, L.I., and Queens Hospital Center in Jamaica, Queens, was married yesterday to Dr. Joshua S. Berger, a dermatologist in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. Maj. Marc A. Abramowitz, U.S.A. Chaplain Corps, the Jewish chaplain at the United States Military Academy, performed the ceremony at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: REPORT FINDS CIGARETTE TAX COULD HELP TO CURB SMOKING
description: Hundreds of thousands of low-income Americans might quit smoking and hundreds of thousands of teen-agers might never take up the habit if Congress were to raise the tax on cigarettes next month, according to a Harvard University study.

title: ISRAELI PRESIDENT ASSAILS KAHANE
description: President Chaim Herzog of Israel said today that ''it is a disgrace'' that a man like Rabbi Meir Kahane could be accepted in Israeli society.

title: ALISON ADAMS MARRIED TO PETER COLLERY
description: Alison Elizabeth Adams, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Adams of New York and Old Field, L.I., was married Saturday to Peter Mitchell Collery, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Collery of New York and New Milford, Conn. The ceremony was performed at the Old Field home of the bride's parents by Associate Justice Lawrence J. Bracken of the Supreme Court of the State of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department.

title: VICTIMS OF PLANE CRASH LISTED
description: Following are the names and hometowns of victims of the crash Friday of Midwest Express Airlines Flight 105, as reported by the airline:

title: ABC PLANS '45/85,' A VIDEO HISTORY
description: With a live appearance by Ronald Reagan, tales told by the three living former Presidents and scores of other ''witnesses,'' rare color film of great moments in history, artifacts such as the ''Star Wars'' robot R2-D2 and an old Wurlitzer juke box, and never-before-broadcast audio tapes of Nikita S. Khrushchev and Dwight D. Eisenhower, ABC News will try to persuade millions of Americans to sit for three hours in prime time on Sept. 18 and watch a video history of the last 40 years.

title: CALIFORNIA DEBATING UNITARY TAX SHIFTS
description: Lobbyists supporting a measure to revise California's use of the worldwide unitary method of taxation face a final struggle to push the bill through a legislative maze that may stall any change for the seventh consecutive year.

title: MAJOR CANDIDATES FOR MAYOR ON KEY ISSUES
description: Carol Bellamy 43 years old. Elected to first of two terms as City Council President in 1977. Former state senator from Brooklyn.

title: LENDL TROUNCES MCENROE, WINS HIS FIRST TITLE
description: Ivan Lendl understood that he would never be able to silence his critics with words. No one ever sweet-talked his way to the United States Open championship. No, Lendl would have to prove his mettle on a tennis court, in the heat of a big match against the best player in the world. Only when he was confronted with still one more opportunity to crack -and survive - would Lendl be considered a champion, too.

title: GOOD REVIEWS IN TRACK
description: Track and field's first international Grand Prix series has ended, and the reviews are generally good.

title: The Roots of Cambodia's Misery
description: If the heavens could weep over a people's suffering, Cambodia would never know drought. The 15-year toll has been terrible enough: murderous aerial bombing followed by brutal revolution, famine and civil war, claiming the lives of perhaps a third of Cambodia's seven million people. Compounding the injury is the annual charade by which rival Communist warlords try to cleanse their record and feign moderation.

title: ROSE HITS NOS. 4,190 AND 4,191, TYING COBB'S 57-YEAR-OLD RECORD
description: On a day in which Pete Rose was not supposed to be in the lineup, on a day in which he, as player-manager of the Cincinnati Reds, did not even know he was going to play until two hours before game time, Pete Rose tied Ty Cobb's major league career record for base hits, 4,191.

title: Voting in Norway Is Described as Heavy
description: Voting in Norway's national elections got off to a strong start today, thanks to mild weather.

title: Bruiser Kinard Is Dead at 70; Headed Mississippi Sports
description: Frank M. (Bruiser) Kinard, former assistant football coach and athletic director at the University of Mississippi, died Saturday night at age 70.

title: NEW YORK CITY SCHOOLS OPEN WITH DUAL GOAL
description: The New York City public school system opens for another year of classes today with higher enrollment, a record budget and a variety of new programs intended to cut the dropout rate and raise academic performance.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Sept. 9, 1985: *2*MONDAY Bristol-Myers INTERCO Inc Dayco Corp M/A Com *2*TUESDAY Alaska Air Group Inc Fluor Corp Brunswick Corp Intl Flavors&Fragrnces Cummins Engine Jamesway Corp Fleetwood Entpr Lowenstein (M) Corp *2*WEDNESDAY Abbott Laboratories NICOR Inc Cox Communications Quaker Oats Federal Co So New England Tel Heinz (HJ) Co Transco Energy Co *2*THURSDAY Apache Corp Phillips-Van Heusen Bay State Gas Service Corp Intl Colgate-Palmolive Sierra Pacific Hallwood Group Inc Tidewater Inc Leaseway Transp Trinity Industries Petroleum & Res Universal Foods *2*FRIDAY Bank of Virginia Co Dennison Mfg Big Three Industries Intl Multifoods *2*SATURDAY Helmerich & Payne

title: AIRHORNS BLARE AS TITANIC RESEARCHERS SAIL IN
description: The triumphant researchers who found the luxury liner Titanic were greeted at their home port here today by cheering crowds, balloons and the blare of airhorns.

title: ABC'S 'NO GREATER GIFT,' ABOUT ORGAN DONORSHIP
description: WHEN a group called Action for Children's Television began complaining loudly about cartoon gluts and violence overdoses in programming for young audiences, ABC moved with remarkable speed to create a series called ''Afterschool Special.'' Offered on a more or less monthly basis, the hour-long dramas deal with everything from a death in the family to teen-age alcoholism.

title: DISPUTE EMERGING OVER TOP TAX RATE
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, suggested today that President Reagan's tax revision plan would be too generous to upper-income taxpayers and that his committee might vote for a higher maximum tax rate than the 35 percent the President has proposed.

title:
10 WAYS TO MAKE NEW YORK CITY A BETTER PLACE TO LIVE;

Listen an Ear To City Workers
description: All New Yorkers know about the 871 Flxible buses taken off the streets for being unsafe despite the millions they cost. Less than a handful know that before they were bought, city employees in the Transit Authority's engineering department filed reports predicting the breakdowns.

title: Statue in Search Of a Resting Place
description: While scientists probe the ruins of the Titanic, one of her heroes is homeless in New York.

title: SOUTHERN LEADERS CONFER ON TRADE
description: The Governors of 12 Southern states gathered here today at what was billed as a conference on doing business with foreign countries, but much of the talk centered on imports as a growing threat to Southern industries.

title: 4,191 DOWN AND 1 MORE TO GO
description: Two bellhops in Cincinnati were discussing the Ohio gubernatorial race after one of the candidates had checked into their hotel.

title: U.S. REFUSES TO FORBID TRUCKING ATOMIC WASTE THROUGH NEW YORK
description: Federal regulators refused today to block the trucking of spent nuclear fuel through New York City.

title: LITTLE IMPACT ON U.S. COMPANIES EXPECTED FROM CUT IN EXPORT AID
description: President Reagan's announcement that he will cut off export assistance to certain companies operating in South Africa appears likely to have little impact, because few companies are affected and they generally have not received export assistance.

title: Quotation of the Day
