description: ''Our influence over South African society is limited. But we do have some influence, and the question is, how to use it.''

title: MCI President and Chief To Take Up a New Post
description: V. Orville Wright, president and chief operating officer at the MCI Communications Corporation since 1975, will give up his current positions and assume the new post of vice chairman on Oct. 1, the company said yesterday.

title: NORWAY'S GOVERNMENT IS RE-ELECTED
description: The coalition Government led by the Conservative Party of Prime Minister Kaare Willoch was narrowly re-elected this morning to a second four-year term, although it lost the popular vote.

title: Asbestos Bill Stirs Dispute
description: Corporate officials clashed today with groups representing victims of asbestos-related health problems over a Congressional proposal to establish a Government-financed benefit trust fund.

title:
10 WAYS TO MAKE NEW YORK CITY A BETTER PLACE TO LIVE;

Let's Put First Things First
description: We need to get our priorities straight. Why should the opening of a discotheque command more attention than the opening of an art exhibition or an art gallery? Why should we occupy ourselves with the problems of a singing star who is trying to find a place to live, with all that New York has to offer, and to solve?

title: Rouse-Cigna Deal
description: The Rouse Company said it had completed the purchase of the Cigna Corporation's 80 percent interest in the Howard Research and Development Corporation for $120 million in cash.

title: BRIGHT COLORS, STYLISH CUTS IN WINTER COATS
description: This will be the winter of the good cloth coat.

title: BISHOPS SEEKING LARGER ROLE FOR BLACK CATHOLICS
description: The black American bishops of the Roman Catholic Church called yesterday for increased black influence and representation in the church hierarchy.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Ron Darling will face Danny Cox in the opener of this crucial three-game series. Darling has given up just four earned runs in 31 innings in winning his last four starts.

title: HAROLD GOMBERG, OBOIST, 68
description: Harold Gomberg, the principal oboist of the New York Philharmonic from 1943 to 1977, died of a heart attack Saturday in Capri, where he had lived since his retirement. He was 68 years old.

title: 7 Die in Nicaragua In Dance-Floor Attack
description: An unidentified attacker threw a hand grenade onto a crowded dance floor at a students' party in the northern town of Ocotal, the police said today. Seven people were killed and 35 wounded, a witness said.

title: Screening AIDS Facts, and Fears
description: New York City school officials are caught in a cruel dilemma that is arising increasingly around the country: Should children with AIDS be allowed to attend school?

title: BFI COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: CULTURAL RICHES OF INDIA AT THE MET
description: A staggering variety of exotic riches will open to the public at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Saturday in an exhibition called simply ''India!''

title: TREASURY YIELDS STABILIZE
description: Short- and long-term interest rates on Treasury issues stabilized yesterday, after having risen nearly a quarter of a percentage point for some maturities on Friday.

title: Bridge: AN INTERNATIONAL PARTNERSHIP SUCCEEDS AT TOKYO TOURNEY
description: World championships, in bridge as in other fields, tend to emphasize national loyalties. There has been much support for a suggestion that once in four years partnerships and teams should be allowed to cross national boundaries and so minimize the flag-waving element.

title: China Assays 5-Year Plan
description: China today declared its current five-year economic plan to be a success, setting the scene for the introduction of the next five-year plan sometime over the next two weeks.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MAN WITH A BRUSH Strange are the ways of success; sometimes an achievement is so popular that it almost blots out the rest of the achiever's lifetime work. No idle musing this, because it introduces Edward Lear, artist, illustrator and - as listed in some compendiums first of all - ''humorist.'' This last designation, by which he is perhaps best remembered, arises from his art, his illustrated limericks for his famous ''A Book of Nonsense.''

title: Newmont, Phillips
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation said that its Newmont Oil subsidiary had agreed to buy the Aminoil (Netherlands) Petroleum Company from the Phillips Petroleum Company for $165 million.

title: SATELLITE ON TARGET TO MEET A COMET
description: EARLY tomorrow, as the climax of an extraordinarily audacious and complex series of space acrobatics, a small spacecraft will plunge through the tail of the comet Giacobini-Zinner. The mission, by the International Cometary Explorer, will be the first to a comet and will provide a dress rehearsal for the multiple fly-bys of Halley's comet next March.

title: A BANNER YEAR FOR AUTO SALES
description: Even though car and truck sales will hit record levels for the 1985 model year, the chairman of General Motors Corporation warned today that the American auto industry, and others as well, would have to move swiftly to computerize their operations to meet threats from abroad.

title: An Exhibit to Bring the House Down
description: Tucked away behind the display rooms of the National Gallery of Art is a high-ceilinged office filled with architectural drawings, small-scale models, samples of paint and swatches of fabric and wallpaper.

title: Of Pornography and U.S. Subsidies
description: To the vexing question of what constitutes pornography has been added another: Should Federal funds be used to support poetry that some say is pornographic?

title: MASSEY-FERGUSON LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a provision for unusual costs of $7.6 million for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income. All figures are in U.S. funds.

title: Primary Election Choices
description: New York City's voters go to the polls from 6 A.M. until 9 P.M. today. This primary election will determine the Democratic nominations for, and hence the winners of, important offices in this predominantly Democratic city - mayor, City Council president, comptroller, three borough presidencies and district attorney of Manhattan.

title: FOES AND FRIENDS OF PRETORIA CRITICIZE REAGAN'S SANCTIONS
description: Leaders of the American movement protesting South African policies said today that President Reagan's sanctions were riddled with loopholes and had been crafted to spare him a rebuke in Congress rather than help black Africans.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tom Schneider, whose Lehigh team won the East Coast Conference basketball championship last season, is the new Penn coach. He succeeds Craig Littlepage, who was named the Rutgers coach last Friday. . . . The Pittsburgh Pirates disclosed the names of the final two players they obtained from the Dodgers Aug. 31 for Bill Madlock.

title: A FIRST FOR THE CATHEDRAL
description: THE sign posted just inside the Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine is inescapable. ''We are a community as well as a cathedral: Caring for the hungry, homeless and jobless; Educating the young, supporting the elderly.'' And that's not all.

title: HONDURAS BOLSTERS REPORT OF RAID
description: A Government informant today supported the official version of what happened when the Honduran Army raided a Salvadoran refugee camp 11 days ago.

title: Transactions
description: COLLEGES HOFSTRA - Named Joseph Dunleavy assistant basketball coach.

title: On Ice
description: Hockey in May raised eyebrows. So did pro football in the spring. But how about ski jumping in September?

title: Legal Prostitution Makes the State a Superpimp
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSH SAYS GORBACHEV TRIES TO SPLIT WEST
description: Vice President Bush said today that the Soviet Union, in preparation for the meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev in November, was trying to divide Western opinion rather than engage in serious talks.

title: Next Campus Voice On Drawing Board
description: The 13-30 Corporation, which is run by the same people who publish Esquire magazine, has its publishing roots in the campuses of America.

title: EPISCOPAL BISHOPS QUESTION PAPAL ROLE IF CHURCHES UNITE
description: The bishops of the Episcopal Church expressed strong reservations today about whether a pope should play the traditional role in any union between the Anglican and Roman Catholic churches, but they encouraged further conversations between the two churches on the complex question of church authority.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: SOMETHING a little different in boutiques is scheduled to open next week on Madison Avenue. It will carry accessories only, and everything will be designed by Isabel Canovas. The boutique will be a duplicate of her Paris shop, which carries accessories to adorn just about every inch of the body except the feet. Miss Canovas designs hats, belts, jewelry, hair ornaments, bags, muffs, shawls, capes, sweaters, gloves and even umbrellas. Everything is handmade in France.

title: Visitors From Denmark
description: The Prime Minister of Denmark, Poul Schluter, and his wife, Lisbeth, will begin a two-day visit to Washington today.

title: A Plan to Help Deposit Fund
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it was considering establishing a quasi-govermental unit to help the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation by buying and managing its nonproductive assets.

title: LEBANESE SHIITES SEE SYRIAN LEADERS
description: Syria's official press agency said today that President Hafez al-Assad had conferred in Damascus with four senior leaders of Lebanon's Shiite fundamentalist group, the Party of God. The report came amid speculation here that the Syrian leader was engaged in new efforts to obtain the release of seven Americans, four Frenchmen and a Briton kidnapped in Moslem West Beirut over the last year and a half.

title: YANKS WIN IN 10 ON 5-RUN RALLY
description: The Yankees extended their winning streak to 10 games tonight, but if they are to make it 11 and 12, they'll have to do it without the services of Dave Righetti and Brian Fisher.

title: UNION ELECTION ORDERED AT FARM IN SOUTH JERSEY
description: A South Jersey vegetable grower, who had been jailed briefly for refusing a judge's order to recognize a farmworkers' union, today agreed to permit an election on union representation.

title: Oomph
description: Those who patrol the streets are the Finest. Those who put out the fires are the Bravest. And those who collect the trash have styled themselves - with good reason - the Strongest.

title: TWO CZECH PLAYERS ON PARALLEL PATHS
description: They share more than a common heritage. For most of their professional tennis careers, Ivan Lendl and Hana Mandlikova have been labeled players who fell short of the ultimate victory. Lendl was ''semi-tough,'' but nearly always lost in a Grand Slam final. Miss Mandlikova was a talented but erratic player whose match results mirrored her game - a stroke of brilliance followed by a forehand into the bottom of the net.

title: CHARLES W. LEWIS
description: Charles W. Lewis, a retired senior partner of the New York law firm of Thacher, Proffitt & Wood, died last Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital.

title: KILLED IN THAI COUP ATTEMPT
description: Neil Davis, a correspondent and cameraman for NBC News, was fatally wounded yesterday by tank fire during an attempted coup in Bangkok. His sound man, William Latch, was killed at the same time.

title: Arco Alaska Cuts
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company, citing falling oil prices, said it would cut its Alaska exploration staff to 35, from 200, and centralize exploration operations in Dallas. Many of those in Alaska have been offered transfers to Dallas and other locations. In all, the company said, fewer than 50 people will be laid off.

title: EXPLORER OF THE SEA: ROBERT BALLARD
description: As a youth, Robert Ballard's eyes were constantly drawn skyward. His earliest memories, says the man who has spent more time on the bottom of the sea than any other, are of jets pushing ever higher at the Federal aircraft testing ground in California's Mohave Desert, where his father was a flight engineer. It was later, as a teen-ager in San Diego, that he ''fell for the sea'' while fishing from the long pier at the Scripps Oceanographic Institute. His father had been appointed naval representative to the institute.

title: DALE BERRA ADMITS TO USE OF COCAINE
description: Dale Berra of the Yankees told a Federal court here today that he had used cocaine on and off from January 1979 to last October and that he had sought help for his ''problem'' with the drug.

title: Marshall Puts Eagles in Bind
description: Apparently, Harry Carson had seen and heard enough.

title: RMJ Securities to Be Sold
description: The Bank of New York Company and management of the RMJ Securities Corporation, one of the two largest brokers in the Treasury securities market, said yesterday that they planned to buy RMJ for an undisclosed price from the Security Pacific Corporation.

title: BOTHA DECLARES SANCTIONS WILL RETARD RACIAL CHANGE
description: President P. W. Botha of South Africa tonight condemned the Reagan Administration's announcement of limited economic sanctions, and said ''outside attempts to interfere'' in his country's affairs could only retard racial change.

title: Federal Judge Sets Car-Ring Trial
description: Paul Castellano, who is charged with being head of an organized-crime faction in New York City, will go on trial Sept. 30 in a case involving a stolen-car ring, according to a Federal judge's decision yesterday.

title: DRAWBACKS IN OIL AND GAS PROGRAMS
description: WHEN T. Boone Pickens, chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, announced plans last month to reorganize Mesa into a limited partnership, he turned the spotlight anew on an increasingly popular form of oil and gas investment.

title: 4th Fatal Prison Stabbing Prompts Action in Texas
description: An inmate was stabbed to death today, the fourth fatal stabbing in state prisons in two days, prompting officials to impose an emergency lockdown at 13 units to quell violence among rival gangs.

title: Chinese Start Tour
description: The reorganized Chinese national soccer team, with Nian Weisi as its new coach, left for Papua, New Guinea, and its first international competition since the team was disbanded last May 19, following the worst soccer riot in China since Communist rule began in 1949. The riot began after a 2-1 loss to Hong Kong that eliminated China from World Cup play. One Hong Kong player was cut, cars of foreign spectators were damaged and several policemen were injured during the glass-smashing melee after the game.

title: Kodak Job Cuts
description: The Eastman Kodak Company is eliminating 300 jobs at its Clinical Products division as of Oct. 31, a spokesman, Henry J. Kaska, said. Mr. Kaska said the company hoped to find jobs in other divisions for about half of those workers, and would offer voluntary retirement to as many others as were eligible. The cuts are ''part of a cost-effectiveness program aimed at redundant and non-critical functions,'' he said, adding that they are not related to the profitability of the division, whose products include the Ektachem line of blood analyzers.

title: Canada Group Faults Latin Policy of the U.S.
description: A delegation of prominent Canadians said today that conditions in Central America were deteriorating and blamed United States policy for the lack of peace in the region.

title: Business and the Law;   Hutton-Type Investigations
description: TAKING the law into one's own hands has not been acceptable for decades. Yet many corporations these days are conducting investigations and playing both judge and jury in trying to root out evil from within their own systems.

title: POWER OF INDIAN DANCE
description: Indian dance can often seem rich and intricate - so intricate, in fact, that Westerners occasionally feel overawed by it. Not only are the dance steps unusual, but they also derive from myths that may be unfamiliar outside India. Nevertheless, Malavika Sarukkai, a prominent young Indian dancer, believes, ''Even though you don't know the intricacies, you need not feel lost at an Indian dance concert.''

title: Missouri Bonds For Student Loans
description: The Missouri Higher Education Loan Authority is offering $77.8 million of student loan revenue bonds through underwriters led by the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

title: COOPERVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SOCIAL PROMOTION IN QUESTION
description: SHARP disagreement has developed between school reformers and academic researchers over the emotional issue of whether to end ''social promotion'' in public schools.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bacardi Capital Ltd., the financial subsidiary of Bacardi International Ltd. and Bacardi & Co., has acquired 60 percent of the Financial Options Group Inc. of Philadelphia. Terms were not disclosed.

title: ANGELS CLOSE GAP BY BEATING ROYALS
description: John Candelaria combined with Doug Corbett on a two-hitter, and Ruppert Jones and Daryl Sconiers hit home runs tonight as the California Angels beat the Kansas City Royals, 7-1.

title: A $3 LOVE LETTER, PART OF THE ART OF MEXICAN SCRIBE
description: Hipolito Ortiz Acuna regards himself as having the heart of a poet, the acumen of a lawyer and the sensitivity of a psychologist.

title: BUREAUCRATS FEEL YEVTUSHENKO JAB
description: Apparently jumping on the Gorbachev bandwagon, the poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko published a poem today assailing timid bureaucrats who oppose innovation.

title: COLLINS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income. c-Including a tax credit of $350,000.

title:
10 WAYS TO MAKE NEW YORK CITY A BETTER PLACE TO LIVE;

STOP BEHAVING LIKE WOLVES
description: Any improvement in the form and content of New York presupposes an elevation of the generally low opinion of the place. It would need to be seen as a city instead of a wilderness.

title: ACCORD REACHED TO LIFT BALDWIN ANNUITY RETURNS
description: In a move that would help enhance the returns of investors of Baldwin-United annuities, 22 Wall Street securities firms and 49 states reached a tentative agreement under which the brokerage houses would pay a total of $157 million to investors who purchased the annuities through the brokerages from the bankrupt corporation.

title: Advocate on the Spot
description: Having waged countless rent battles on behalf of others, the Metropolitan Council on Housing now faces the same issue in its own home.

title: To Give Sanctuary Is in Accord With Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Careers;   Welding Engineers In Demand
description: THOMAS EDISON did a lot of welding in his New Jersey laboratory, a fact that partly explains a new association called the Edison Welding Institute, formed a year ago. Its home is in Columbus, Ohio, at a new research park adjacent to Ohio State University, which this fall is introducing a doctoral program in welding engineering.

title: Salute to Archie Moore
description: Several boxing greats, including Larry Holmes, Sugar Ray Robinson, Henry Armstrong and Sugar Ray Leonard, are expected to attend a testimonial dinner on Oct. 11 in San Diego for Archie Moore, a former light-heavyweight champion whose career spanned four decades. Proceeds will go to the Archie Moore Foundation, which benefits young fighters. The 71-year-old Moore, who held the world title from 1952 until 1962, compiled a 199-16-8 record that included 145 knockouts.

title: Tree Rings and Drought
description: Tree rings have long afforded scientists an index of historic fluctuations in the climate of arid regions: the wider a ring, the better the growing conditions during the year the ring formed. The system has not worked so well, however, in the moist parts of eastern North America, where the size of most tree rings is relatively little affected by floods and droughts.

title: URANIUM MINING NEAR GRAND CANYON POISED FOR A BOOM, UNDER AN OLD LAW
description: A disconcerting scene in any setting, it was particularly so in front of the Visitors Center in Grand Canyon National Park. Three figures in white radiation suits, masks over their faces, walked stiffly about, passing out leaflets and warning park visitors of the hazards of radiation.

title: VCR Makers Lift Sales
description: Manufacturers sold 798,402 video cassette recorders in August, the Electronic Industries Association said today. Sales so far this year totaled 6.2 million, up 59 percent from 1984.

title: To Give Sanctuary Is in Accord With Law
description: To the Editor:

title: A ROUND OF PARTIES OPENS FESTIVAL OF INDIA
description: A series of glittering social events this week opens the Festival of India, which will bring to New York City a multitude of concerts and artistic exhibitions in the coming months. The events will be attended by high-ranking Indian government officials as well as cultural, business and social leaders of Manhattan.

title: British Open O-T-C Shop
description: Britain's first over-the-counter stock-selling shop opened today, wedged between the toy and furniture departments in Debenham's Department Store on Oxford Street, the city's busiest shopping center.

title: ARMS AND THE HOLY DAYS
description: The Reagan Administration has decided that there will be no announcement of new arms sales to Arab nations until after the Jewish holy days are over later this month.

title: ESPEY MANUFACTURING & ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago results include a net gain of $255,218 recovered against a claim for adjustment of a 1977 contract.

title: RCA ADOPTS POISON PILL AS MCA TALKS FOUNDER
description: Top executives at the RCA Corporation and MCA Inc. failed to reach an agreement about a possible merger this weekend, and no further talks are scheduled, according to a source close to the negotiations.

title: WESTERN WASTE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss. c-After an extraordinary charge of $961,000 for the quarter and year.

title: $600 Million for Games
description: The Seoul Olympic Organizing Committee will ask $600 million for exclusive United States television rights to the 1988 Summer Games when negotiations take place this week in Switzerland, a committee source said. That figure is twice what the three American networks have said is a reasonable sum for the rights.

title: Eighth Raid Reported Against Kharg Island
description: Iraq said today that it had mounted another air attack on Iran's Kharg Island oil terminal.

title: IN SEARCH OF THE THINKING MACHINE-STILL
description: BREATHES there a computer user so unflappable that he or she has never, at least mentally, slammed a fist onto the desk with the exclamation, ''You dumb machine!''? Emotions aside, all computers are dumb. In fact, they are more than dumb, since even that pejorative implies some degree of intelligence, and these machines are truly mindless.

title: HADCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
description: b-Net income The company said the losses in the latest quarter and 9 months include a nonrecurring charge of $527,000 from the writeoff of goodwill related to the acquisition of Circuit Image Industries.

title: Auditions at Music Hall
description: It is just past Labor Day, but Radio City Music Hall is already thinking ahead.

title: Dept. of Bedfellows
description: If you hear it once, you hear it said 500 times a week in the capital:

title: 50 BUILDINGS ABLAZE
description: Gangs of youths rioted in this industrial city Monday night, setting fires that destroyed more than 50 buildings and then attacking firefighters trying to extinguish the blazes, a police spokesman said early today.

title: Jaworski Sacked
description: One day after being sacked eight times by the Giants, the Philadelphia Eagles quarterback Ron Jaworski was sacked as a starter by Coach Marion Campbell. Jaworski, the team's starter for eight seasons, will be replaced by the rookie Randall Cunningham in the home opener against the Los Angeles Rams Sunday.

title: NEW ROCKEFELLER CENTER OFFER
description: Rockefeller Center Properties Inc. said yesterday that it planned to increase the size of its public offering of shares in the Rockefeller Center real estate complex to $1.3 billion, from $1.1 billion, because of strong investor demand.

title: CITY'S RETAIL SALES UP 3.9%
description: New York City retail sales rose 3.9 percent in August from a year earlier, and sales in the metropolitan area were up 7 percent, according to a spot-check of seven large retailers.

title: AN OLD STORY FOR THAILAND
description: Four days ago, the Thai Foreign Ministry brought together a group of local reporters and foreign correspondents at a pleasant seaside resort on the Gulf of Siam to talk about the country's image.

title: Saudi Output Rise Reported
description: Saudi Arabian oil output, which dropped to a 20-year low last month, rose appreciably in early September, oil industry sources in the Persian Gulf said today.

title: Australians Win Catamaran Title
description: Victoria 150 of Australia today ended 11 years of American ownership of the International Catamaran Trophy, called the Little America's Cup.

title: RADICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Carcinoma Diagnoses Of Two Presidents
description: To the Editor:

title: WITNESSES SAY THEY SAW WOMAN INJECT BELUSHI IN HIS FINAL DAYS
description: Two friends of John Belushi testified today that they watched as Cathy Evelyn Smith injected the comedian with heroin and cocaine in the days before he was found dead of a drug overdose.

title: Rose vs. Cobb: Hit of Error?
description: One hit. After 4,191 hits, Pete Rose needed one more to break Ty Cobb's record. And during the countdown, the Reds' 44-year-old manager and first baseman was asked what type of hit the record-breaker is most likely to be. Over his 23 seasons, what has been his signature hit - a line single to left, or a double in the gap in right-center, maybe a bouncer up the middle?

title: BUFFALO'S NEW SUBWAY: NEAT AND SAFE
description: Imagine a New York subway system that has had one mugging and five graffiti scrawls and has its riders buy tickets on the honor system.

title: Canadian Pacific Deal
description: Canadian Pacific Ltd., the big transportation concern, said it plans a $1.01 billion merger with Canadian Pacific Enterprises Ltd., a holding company in which it already holds a 69.7 percent stake.

title: COKE'S STOCK FALLS ON EARNINGS REPORT
description: The Coca-Cola Company's stock price dropped yesterday after the company released 1985 earnings estimates that were lower than many analysts had expected.

title: CHILD WORLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
DEMOCRATS PLAN BROADER SCRUTINY OF REAGAN'S JUDICIAL CANDIDATES
description: Democrats on the Senate Committee on the Judiciary have announced plans to broaden their investigations of Reagan Administration nominees for more than 100 vacancies in the Federal judiciary.

title: PARADYNE AND S.E.C. SETTLEMENT
description: The Paradyne Corporation and the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that they had reached a settlement that avoids trial of a civil complaint charging that Paradyne had violated Federal securities laws to obtain a $100 million computer contract from the Government.

title: SUN BELT STATES TO LEAD RISE IN POPULATION, PLANNERS SAY
description: Five Sun Belt states will account for more than half of the population growth in the United States through the year 2000, but Middle Western states that had been expecting declines may not lose people after all, a private research group said today.

title: MARS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: No Talks Set in Strike At Philadelphia Papers
description: Negotiators for the union representing reporters at Philadelphia's two daily newspapers said today that they were prepared to move on several contract issues, but no talks were scheduled in the third day of the newspaper strike.

title: MBI BUSINESS CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
REAGAN TO PRESS MOSCOW ON JEWS
description: President Reagan told a Jewish delegation today that he planned to raise the issue of the plight of Soviet Jews at his meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: FEUD THREATENS THE TONY AWARDS
description: A rift has opened between the two organizations that sponsor and present the Tony Awards, raising the possibility that they will stage competing theater awards in 1987.

title: Beauty of New York's New Subway Cars Is Only Skin Deep
description: To the Editor:

title: KOCH AND RIVALS CAMPAIGN DOWN TO THE WIRE
description: Mayor Koch and his two major rivals sought votes on the streets and in the subways yesterday in a final spurt of campaigning before today's Democratic primary.

title: Agency Financing In Massachusetts
description: The Massachusetts Port Authority is offering $75.1 million of refunding revenue bonds that are tentatively priced with a maximum yield of 9 3/8 percent for bonds due in 2015 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: A Belfast Couple Are Slain as Informers
description: I.R.A. gunmen kidnapped a young Roman Catholic couple accused of being paid police informers, ''convicted'' them and put them to death, authorities said toaay.

title: H J HEINZ COMPANY OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Israel Plans to Release Last Detainees Today
description: Israel said today that the last of the 1,200 prisoners seized in southern Lebanon are to be freed Tuesday.

title: Better Outlook Seen by Apple
description: Apple Computer Inc. expects Christmas sales to be strong this year and has increased its advertising budget somewhat, the company said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 10, 1985
description: International

title: White House;   Perching For the President
description: An undeclared war of the aluminum ladders may have escalated to its limit among White House news photographers committed to jostling ever upward for better perches.

title: TEXAS AIR DEAL WITH ICAHN SEEN
description: The Texas Air Corporation has agreed to withdraw from its merger pact with Trans World Airlines, sources close to the two airlines said yesterday. The agreement, if signed, would pave the way for Carl C. Icahn, the New York financier who has acquired 52 percent of T.W.A.'s shares, to officially take control of the nation's fourth-largest airline.

title: Pilots Need Data on Air-Speed Loss Fast
description: To the Editor:

title: MIDWEST OFFICIALS FEAR EFFECT OF REAGAN TAX PLAN
description: The Reagan Administration's tax overhaul plan, particularly its proposed suspension of deductions for state and local taxes and its strict limits on investment incentives, could hurt the Middle West's chances for an economic comeback, state and local officials say.

title: PATTERNS OF LOVE CHARTED IN STUDIES
description: RESEARCHERS charting the course of love are beginning to put some order into an area that has long been regarded as chaotic and undefinable.

title: Advertising;   Reader's Digest Cuts Rate Base
description: CAUGHT in a long-playing industry trend of declining newsstand sales, the Reader's Digest, the country's largest-circulation magazine, will be cutting its circulation rate base by 1.5 million, to 16.25 million, with the January issue.

title: EXECUTION FOR JUVENILES: NEW FOCUS ON OLD ISSUE
description: Texas plans to execute a man Wednesday for a murder he committed at 17 years of age, focusing new attention on an potentially emotional issue: Should juveniles be subject to capital punishment?

title: KASLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income Share earnings have been adjusted to give retroactive effect to stock dividends issued Feb. 15, 1984 and Feb. 15, 1985.

title: Having It All
description: Call it sour grapes, but call it truthful, too - Lori Garbacz's complaint after Nany Lopez defeated her on the third hole of sudden death to win the $175,000 Portland Ping Golf Championship Sunday. Said Miss Garbacz of Miss Lopez: ''She's got too much money, she's got a great-looking husband and a beautiful child. I mean, come on, let somebody else have some,''

title:
10 WAYS TO MAKE NEW YORK CITY A BETTER PLACE TO LIVE;

Restore Toilets In Subways
description: Life in New York City could become vastly more decent by retrieving one commonplace of the past: subway toilets.

title: SENATORS FIGHTING FOR TOUGHER MOVE
description: The Senate Republican leadership won an initial vote today in an effort to postpone consideration of the Senate's South African sanctions bill. The vote came after President Reagan issued an executive order imposing trade and financial measures similar to those sought by Congress.

title: General Foods Shares Soar
description: Shares of the General Foods Corporation rose $7.125 yesterday, to $87.50, on the New York Stock Exchange as rumors arose again that the company was a target of Philip Morris Inc., the tobacco and consumer products concern. The same speculation surfaced several months ago, sending General Foods stock up more than $10 in one session.

title: JOHN F. ENDERS, VIROLOGY PIONEER WHO WON NOBEL PRIZE, DIES AT 88
description: Dr. John F. Enders, a Nobel Prize-winning virologist whose discoveries paved the way for vaccines against polio, measles, German measles and mumps as well as to major advances in the fight against cancer and in genetics, died Sunday night at his summer home in Waterford, Conn. He was 88 years old.

title: COWBOYS TROUNCE REDSKINS
description: Dallas's determined defense intercepted Joe Theismann passes five times tonight and the Cowboy quarterback, Danny White, and the place-kicker, Rafael Septien, made Washington pay for its mistakes with a 44-14 victory over the Redskins.

title: Hearings Are Proposed In Pentagon 'Windfall'
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato has called for Senate hearings on a Congressional agency's contention that the Defense Department had received a $36.8 billion ''windfall'' since 1981 because inflation in weapon prices was overestimated.

title: A.T.&T. Plans Computer Unit
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it would establish a new business unit to sell computer systems that could respond to limited spoken requests and dispense information with an electronic voice.

title: STOP & SHOP COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 17
description: b-Net income.

title: BEIRUT CHRISTIAN GOES TO DAMASCUS
description: The commander of Lebanon's Christian militia traveled to Syria today for talks with Government officials there about Lebanon's continuing political crisis.

title: Old College Try
description: The Ivy League and WNET-Channel 13 have jointly announced that 30 public public television stations from Boston to New Orleans to San Francisco will broadcast the second year of the league's football series, beginning Sept. 21 with the Cornell-Pennsylvania game. And in a move to spark interest in the 10-game series, Channel 13 has signed Marty Glickman, the one-time broadcaster for the Giants and the Knicks, to join the former Princeton coach, Bob Casciola, in the announcing booth. Last year, ratings for the Ivy games were reported by the A. C. Nielsen Company to be so low that they could not be accurately measured.

title: SHOPWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
description: b-Net losses.

title: THAI COUP CRUSHED BY LOYALISTS IN A 10-HOUR BATTLE WITH REBELS
description: An attempted coup led by former Thai Army officers was thwarted today after Government troops forced the rebels to surrender after less than 10 hours of fighting.

title: Israeli Aide in New York
description: The Israeli Foreign Ministry announced today that its new consul general in New York City, Moshe Yegar, would assume his post Tuesday. He will replace Naphtali Lavie, who is leaving the Foreign Ministry. Mr. Yegar, 55 years old, was formerly the Foreign Ministry's Assistant Director General for Information. He served two previous tours in the United States, as consul in Los Angeles and consul general in Philadelphia.

title: CITICORP, MCGRAW IN A VENTURE
description: Citicorp and McGraw-Hill are expected to announce today the formation of a joint-venture company, Gemco, which will make markets for buyers and sellers of crude oil.

title: Surprises Are in Store For Unwary
description: INFOWORLD, a weekly newspaper covering the microcomputer industry, recently sent computer experts to 24 stores across the country, including five in New York City, to pose as first-time buyers looking for a complete hardware and software system that could handle list management, financial analysis, word processing and communications. Stores were rated on several factors, including the suitability and pricing of the system, knowledge and attitude of the sales staff and availability of service and support. The results were intriguing.

title: NAPCO SECURITY SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The share earnings reflect two 50 percent stock splits paid in the year just ended.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Classes at C. W. Post Canceled by a Strike
description: Opening-day classes at Long Island University's C. W. Post campus were canceled today because of a strike by 375 full-time faculty members, a university spokesman, William Spiegler, said.

title: HIGHLAND SUPERSTORES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
MOVE CAUSES SPLIT IN SENATE;   AN EXECUTIVE ACT
description: President Reagan, in a major reversal of the Administration's opposition to economic sanctions against South Africa, announced today that he was adopting most of the trade and financial steps against apartheid sought by Congress.

title: Dow Up 3.58, to 1,339.27; Takeover Stocks Surge
description: Takeover speculation stole investors' attention yesterday on Wall Street, where the market scored only a minor gain despite some impressive increases in the shares of potential buyout candidates.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN'S REMARKS AND QUESTION SESSION WITH REPORTERS
description: Following are excerpts from the opening statement and questions and answers at President Reagan's news conference today:

title: Article 250106 -- No Title
description: New York City officials announced plans yesterday to sell $350 million of general obligation bonds next week through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: CUBS DROP CARDS INTO TIE FOR FIRST
description: Ryne Sandberg and Keith Moreland drove home first-inning runs, and Shawon Dunston singled home another in the second, leading the Chicago Cubs to a 3-1 triumph tonight over the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: MANDELA KIN REPORTED TO WIN EXTRA PRISON VISIT
description: A prison spokesman said today that the wife and two daughters of Nelson Mandela would be allowed to pay a ''special additional visit'' to the jailed nationalist leader, who was taken to a hospital last week and examined by a urologist.

title: Mr. Reagan Slaps at Apartheid
description: To fend off something stronger, President Reagan has finally embraced the tactic of his critics and ordered mild sanctions against South Africa to express repugnance for its racist political structure. ''The American people are impatient,'' he said. ''We all feel strongly about the changes needed.'' Those public words are overdue, particularly since only a few days ago the President was still pleading for patience and praising the modest ''reforms'' of Pretoria's white regime. Mr. Reagan had obviously clung too long to the view that a supportive collaboration with the South African Government, rather than condemnation of it, could speed the dismantling of apartheid. When that failed to happen, it left him sounding like the regime's apologist, just as the protest of black South Africans began to swell.

title: WHEREHOUSE ENTERTAINMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MAKING 'A LOT OF WORDS' TELL A STORY
description: WHEN a 2-year-old says ''Sit chair,'' he shows that he already knows much about the meaning of words. He does not know about prepositions, but in time he will pick them up. Yet when that child enters school the teacher is likely to use drill sheets and workbooks to make him memorize all the elements of speech as separate skills. It is the first step toward turning him off.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 10, 1985
description: International

title: Howitzers to Pakistan, Copters to Seoul
description: The Defense Department said today that it had approved more than $100 million in arms sales to Pakistan, and a $178 million sale of combat helicopters to South Korea.

title: BIG OPENERS A HABIT FOR LIPPS
description: As a rookie a year ago, Louis Lipps was a backup receiver for the Pittsburgh Steelers until Calvin Sweeney got hurt early in the opening game. Lipps replaced him and had what would be one of his best days of the season, catching 6 passes for 183 yards and 2 touchdowns.

title: THE RISKY BUSINESS OF ASSESSING RISKS
description: South Africa's problems may be creating difficulties for a host of companies doing business with that country. But for one business, political risk assessment, it could prove something of a boon, serving as a reminder of the relevance of political intelligence, particularly to companies operating abroad.

title: STAGE: GENE NYE PLAY, 'THE FLATBUSH FAITHFUL'
description: Just as it often was with the old always-striving Brooklyn Dodgers, from which ''The Flatbush Faithful'' draws inspiration, the Lion Theater Company's new production at the Judith Anderson Theater, written and directed by Gene Nye, looks promising as it comes to bat but goes down hitless at the end of three acts.

title: IN A DRY TOWN UPSTATE, SOME RESIDENTS SEE GAIN IN ABANDONING TRADITION
description: For a brief time, this drowsy town with one main thoroughfare and 36 square miles of green pasture sported several bars. Few of the longtime residents remember their names or precisely where, in the late-1930's, they stood.

title: FOUR ARAB YOUTHS ARE WOUNDED BY ISRAELI SOLDIERS IN WEST BANK
description: Israeli soldiers shot and wounded three Arab youths in Hebron today after they started to run away from an army patrol approaching to check their identification, the Israeli Army spokesman announced.

title: Public Radio Plans Weekend News Report
description: National Public Radio announced plans today for a Saturday morning news program, ''Weekend Edition,'' modeled after its successful ''Morning Edition'' and ''All Things Considered'' news magazines.

title: JOHN WILLIAMS CREATES THEMES FOR NBC NEWS
description: Tom Brokaw does not look much like E. T., but when he sat down to read the ''NBC Nightly News'' last night, the percussive buildup and gliding violins introducing him somehow recalled the long-necked reptilian in Steven Spielberg's movie. Somehow, the program put one in mind of - boys on flying bicycles. Spacemen. Sharks. Superman.

title: CARDS VS. METS: BATTLE FOR FIRST
description: With a roll of drums and a flourish of earned run averages, in the week when the pro football season began and Pete Rose caught Ty Cobb, the Mets and the Yankees will fill the New York sports stage starting tonight with six clamorous, crucial and even historic days of pennant-race baseball.

title: MEESE ADVOCATES NEW ALIENS CODE
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d urged Congress today to overhaul the nation's immigration laws, but strongly objected to key features of a bill proposed by Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., chairman of the Judiciary Committee.

title: Papercraft Accepts Revised Buyout
description: The Papercraft Corporation said its board had approved revised terms for the company's previously announced leveraged buyout.

title:
10 WAYS TO MAKE NEW YORK CITY A BETTER PLACE TO LIVE;

Demystify The Ballot
description: Perhaps those who are winners in today's primary can, in the weeks ahead before the general election, do something to remedy one of the most irritating flaws in the city's political process - the unintelligible way in which crucial amendments are presented on the ballot.

title: DANCE: ONE-ACT WORKS BY THE BALLET
description: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER offered one-act works Sunday afternoon and evening at the Metropolitan Opera House. The ballets were presumably chosen to suggest the diversity of the company's large repertory. But misfortune forced a change in programming.

title: TALKS OPEN ON E.E.C. REVAMPING
description: European foreign ministers opened talks today on proposals for a major reform of the European Economic Community.

title:
10 WAYS TO MAKE NEW YORK CITY A BETTER PLACE TO LIVE;

Give Drivers Better Signs
description: My doubts about Westway rest in part on my concern that I would not be able to find it.

title: SOVIET BOYS CASE MAY BECOME MOOT
description: Lawyers from the Justice Department and the American Civil Liberties Union argued today over whether Walter Polovchak's parents still had the right to ''coerce'' the teen-ager to return to the Soviet Union.

title: Rangers Sign Draftee
description: The Rangers added some size to their lineup and the Islanders traded some away yesterday. The Islanders sent Mats Hallin, the 6-foot-2-inch, 200-pound Swedish forward, to the Minnesota North Stars for cash or a late-round draft choice in 1986 while the Rangers signed 19-year-old Terry Carkner, a 6-3, 200-pound defenseman who was their first-round draft choice and the 14th over all in 1984.

title: Sybron Board To Study Bid
description: Directors of the Sybron Corporation are to meet today to consider a leveraged buyout offer from an investor group that includes top executives of the Rochester-based maker of medical and dental equipment.

title: MINIMUM TEACHER PAY SET AT $18,500 IN JERSEY
description: The State Senate gave final legislative approval today to a bill setting an $18,500 minimum salary for public school teachers. Governor Kean almost immediately signed it into law, making New Jersey's mandated minimum the highest in the country.

title: Tax Bill Gains In California
description: The state's Senate Revenue and Taxation Committee approved a bill today that would change California's use of the worldwide unitary tax method.

title: MUSIC: JENS NYGARD
description: IT is probably unfair to judge outdoor concerts too strictly. The programs are usually free, informal gatherings and attract a sizable group of people who might not ordinarily have the opportunity to attend.

title: Man Charged in Slaying Puts Off Making a Plea
description: A man accused of one of 14 slayings that the police believe are linked delayed entering a plea today, and his attorney said intense publicity would make a fair trial difficult in Los Angeles.

title: ULTRASYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including a net gain of $832,000 for the quarter and 6 months from the sale of a partial equity interest in an unconsolidated affilate company.

title: The Underrated
description: The compulsion to make up lists is at least as rampant in Washington as elsewhere in the nation. So, Alan Ehrenhalt, the editor of the 1986 edition of the Congressional Quarterly's political guidebook, ''Politics in America,'' has worked up a list of ''The Twelve Most Underrated Members of Congress.''

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in the Sports section on Sunday about the Federal trial of Curtis Strong in Pittsburgh on cocaine-trafficking charges incorrectly described the baseball commissioner's means of monitoring the proceedings. A representative of Harry Gibbs, the commissioner's director of security, is attending.

title: NEW STAMP WILL HONOR FIRST HEAD OF YESHIVA U.
description: Family, friends and former students of Yeshiva University's first president, Dr. Bernard Revel, gathered yesterday at the school's campus for a celebration to unveil a commemorative postage stamp in his honor.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE BUREAUCRATIZATION OF THE WORLD. By Bruno Rizzi. Translated and with an introduction by Adam Westoby. 111 pages. The Free Press. $16.95.

title: A JOKE HELPS JETS TO FORGET
description: Win or lose on Sundays, for the Jets there is always the Monday Club. And that is where they gathered today - except for Marvin Powell, who said he felt badly for the guys, but stayed at home.

title: Appeal to the Public Spirit
description: Last spring, when visiting public high schools, I was shocked by the debris in the halls and classrooms. Students casually dropped paper cups, crumpled papers and cigarette boxes on the floor, yet no adult told them to clean up after themselves.

title: Mets Back With Momentum
description: Their memories are not all the best, not when they recall the slide from first place to fourth, from a cozy lead to an unsettling deficit in the heat of summer. But so much has happened to the Mets since late June.

title: Too Hot to Trot
description: How oppressive was the Washington weather last weekend?

title: HOLE FOUND IN FAILED JET ENGINE
description: Federal investigators today found a hole in the right engine casing of a Midwest Express DC-9 that crashed here Friday but the investigators said that the path of debris from that hole would not have permitted it to strike the aircraft's fuselage, causing even further damage.

title:
10 WAYS TO MAKE NEW YORK CITY A BETTER PLACE TO LIVE;

Give Drugs To Junkies
description: Ring Lardner said, ''Prohibition is better than no booze at all.'' Who'd laugh if we substituted ''heroin'' in that line? Yet hard drugs are as available today as whisky was to Stage Door Johnny.

title: Medieval Festival Is Set For Sept. 29 at Cloisters
description: The Medieval Festival Guild of New York will present its annual Medieval Festival at the Cloisters on Sept. 29. The afternoon-long event combines jousting, parades, jugglers and booths displaying medieval crafts and offering various foods of the Middle Ages with mime, puppet shows, acrobatics and song.

title: Inco Stock Plan
description: Inco Ltd. said it was seeking to buy half of its $182.5 million (United States) issue of floating-rate preferred shares, series A, by having holders submit competitive tenders. The company said it expects to complete the purchase by the end of the month. It said the purchase was a further step to reduce after-tax financing costs.

title: Massey Debt Talks
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd. said it remains actively engaged in discussions with lenders on a restructured capitalization of the company, but it did not disclose details of the talks. Earlier today, it reported a second-quarter loss of $5.9 million, in contrast to a profit of $7.9 million, or 3 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: 'MAKING ALL POSSIBLE SPEED...'
description: On April 15, 1912, a sketchy report laden with the ingredients of enormous tragedy reached newspaper readers in New York. On the following day it became clear that these were the last words from the ocean liner Titanic.

title: INTERIOR SECRETARY TOO SEKK NEW ACCORD ON OFFSHORE DRILLING
description: Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel said today that he would ask California's Congressional delegation Tuesday to ''reshape'' a preliminary agreement on offshore drilling operations so that more gas and oil could be produced.

title: Puma Switches Ad Agency
description: Although it was wooed by some out-of-state heavyweights, Puma USA of Framingham, Mass., has remained loyal to its Bay State roots and has replaced Hill Holliday Connors Cosmopulos of Boston with Mullen Advertising of Beverly Farms, Mass. Billings, the agency said, could be between $5 million and $6 million.

title: Military Contract
description: The Wasatch division of Morton Thiokol Inc. is being awarded a $93 million Air Force contract in connection with production of the flight termination ordnance system and Stage 1 of the MX missile, the Defense Department said. The work is expected to be completed in April 1988.

title: 17 Hurt in Texas Collision
description: A Greyhound bus traveling from Chicago to the Texas-Mexico border struck the back of a moving tractor-trailer rig loaded with pipe today, injuring 17 people, the authorities said.

title: GISH BIOMEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
$200 Million Offering By State Mortgage Unit
description: The New York State Mortgage Agency is offering $200 million of revenue bonds to finance low-interest mortgages for single-family housing in the state. The interest rate on the mortgages is expected to be just under 10 percent.

title: GROWTH HORMONE'S FUTURE IN DOUBT
description: A FOURTH death has been found in a series of mysterious fatal infections among people who had been treated for years with natural human growth hormone to prevent severe dwarfism. These deaths, three in the United States and one in England within the past 10 months, make up one of the most bizarre, puzzling and ominous episodes in modern public health.

title: New Sears Card Set for San Diego
description: Officials of Sears, Roebuck & Company said they would introduce the company's Discover Credit Card in San Diego on Thursday, the second major market for the new card.

title: MOVE CAUSES SPLIT IN SENATE;   NEW POLICY ON PRETORIA
description: President Reagan made his decision to impose some limited sanctions against South Africa to avoid foreign policy disarray abroad and political humiliation at home, Administration officials said today.

title: The U.N. Today: Sept. 10, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee to Review International Development Strategy - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: ASHTON-TATE reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
11,000 BOYCOTT START OF CLASSES IN AIDS PROTEST
description: Classes for New York City's 946,000 public school students began yesterday amid scattered protests against the city's decision to allow a second-grade pupil with AIDS to attend regular classes.

title: U.S. May Mint Coin For Investors in Gold
description: In proposing to embargo imports of South African gold Krugerrands, pending the assent of other countries, President Reagan ordered the Treasury to study the possibility of minting American gold coins that would meet the desires of investors.

title: INSTEAD OF LEAVING, MORGAN BANK TO BUY A TOWER ON WALL ST.
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Com-pany, after considering and rejecting a move to Delaware, announced yesterday that it would occupy a new 50-story corporate headquarters ''for the 21st century'' on Wall Street.

title: UNILEVER BID VETOED BY VICKS
description: Richardson-Vicks Inc., one of the nation's leading consumer products companies, said yesterday that it had rejected an offer by Unilever N.V. of the Netherlands to buy the company for $1.24 billion in cash.

title: To Give Sanctuary Is in Accord With Law
description: To the Editor:

title: SATOR OF RANGERS: THE COACH AS CHEF
description: Ted Sator was married July 20, one month and one day after he began his new job as the coach of the Rangers. He and his bride, Susanne, left for their honeymoon in Sweden. There was just one complication. He had not arranged for any time off.

title: U.S. Jury Indicts 3 In Cuban's Slaying
description: Three men were indicted yesterday on Federal charges of taking part in the 1980 murder of a Cuban official in New York City and in other crimes attributed to an anti-Castro exile group called Omega 7.

title: EPIC UNIT REVENUES SOUGHT
description: The State of Maryland asked the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Alexandria, Va., today to give it effective control over revenues of approximately $8 million a month that flow to an affiliated company of the troubled Equity Programs Investment Corporation.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allegheny Beverage Corp., Cheverly, Md., has named John E. Baker senior vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Putting Hits In Perspective
description: When Pete Rose finally caught up to Ty Cobb's career-hit total on Sunday in Chicago, he made it clear that he still considers the Georgia Peach the best hitter ever.

title: Gruntal's Herzfeld Tie Unites Venerable Firms
description: The Gruntal Financial Corporation's agreement, announced yesterday, to buy the brokerage business of Herzfeld & Stern Inc. from Josephson International brings together two of Wall Street's oldest firms, which have been competitors since they were both founded in 1880.

title: BIRTH DEFECTS FROM ALCOHOL PERSISTING
description: TWELVE years ago, scientists first reported that heavy drinking of alcohol during pregnancy could cause birth defects, a cluster of abnormalities that have become known as fetal alcohol syndrome. In a 1973 article, researchers described 11 American children, their mothers chronic alcoholics, who were born with the syndrome. The victims were all severely underweight and suffered such facial deformities as odd noses and upper lips, misshapen ears and narrow, squinty eyes. Most suffered heart murmurs, ear disorders and various skeletal problems.

title: MALCOLM PERRINE MCNAIR, 90, RETAILING EXPERT AT HARVARD
description: Malcolm Perrine McNair, a former professor at the Harvard Business School who developed a retail inventory method now in wide use, died yesterday at the Memorial Hospital in North Conway, N.H. He was 90 years old and lived in Madison, N.H.

title: President Named At Home Loan Unit
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank of New York said yesterday that Brian D. Dittenhafer had been named president and chief operating officer, an appointment that was confirmed by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board in Washington.

title:
10 WAYS TO MAKE NEW YORK CITY A BETTER PLACE TO LIVE;

HOUSE HUMANS, NOT CORPORATIONS
description: One of the little noted blessings of New York City is that, despite the fame of our skyscrapers, the average height of buildings here is less than that of London or Paris.

title: SCULPTOR ACCUSED OF PUSHING WIFE OUT WINDOW TO DEATH
description: A 35-year-old sculptor fell to her death from her 34th-floor Greenwich Village apartment on Sunday, and her husband - a sculptor with an international reputation - has been arrested and charged with pushing her out the window.

title: Two Sue Globetrotters
description: Lawyers for Hubert E. (Geese) Ausbie and Frederic D. (Curley) Neal have filed suit in Federal District Court in Little Rock, Ark., seeking damages and explanations from Metromedia Inc., owners of the Harlem Globetrotters.

title: PSYCHOLOGICAL EFFECTS SEEN FOR CURBS
description: By themselves, the sanctions that President Reagan adopted today will have a negligible impact on the economy of South Africa and on the American companies doing business with the country, according to trade experts.

title:
10 WAYS TO MAKE NEW YORK CITY A BETTER PLACE TO LIVE;

Keep Trucks Off Fifth Avenue
description: A hundred signs for a hundred blocks on Fifth Avenue read ''No Commercial Traffic.'' The signs are posted on just about every corner, sometimes two to a block, from Harlem to Greenwich Village.

title: Career Change
description: Jeff Gossett may be a living example of the adage, ''When in doubt, punt.''

title: Reservoirs Still Low Despite Catskill Rain
description: One to three inches of rain have fallen over the Catskill Mountains this week, giving some sections a long-awaited ''boost in flow,'' experts said today.

title: C. Phillip Miller Is Dead at 91; An Expert on Bacteriology
description: Dr. C. Phillip Miller Jr., an authority on bacteriology and the immunology of infectious diseases who was professor emeritus of medicine at the University of Chicago, died Sept. 4 at his home in Chicago. He was 91 years old.

title: Protectionism And U.S. Jobs
description: IN the din of protectionist special pleading by such battered industries as shoes, steel and apparel, many people have come to believe that the nation's economic policies have caused a wholesale loss of American jobs.

title: The Site Project
description: Out at Zbigniew Brzezinski's home in McLean, Va., Sunday, nine Washington area sculptors are going to be installing examples of their work for an outdoor exhibition, ''The Spring Hill Site Project,'' that officially opens the next Saturday.

title: Converting A Police Station
description: FOR two generations its cells held Wall Street's bomb throwers, stock swindlers and confidence men as well as the sweepings of the nearby piers along Water and South Streets.

title: DINKINS IS VICTORIOUS, SETTING STAGE TO RETURN A BLACK TO ESTIMATE BOARD
description: City Clerk David N. Dinkins last night won the Democratic nomination for Manhattan borough president -setting the stage for the return of a member of a minority group to the Board of Estimate for the first time in eight years.

title: SENATE REJECTS BILL ON SCHOOL PRAYER
description: After a brief debate, the Senate today voted overwhelmingly to kill a bill designed to prevent Federal court challenges to organized prayer in the public schools.

title: STEWART & STEVENSON SERVCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: THAI POLICE PANEL IS CHOSEN TO INVESTIGATE COUP ATTEMPT
description: The Thai Government appointed a committee of police officers today to investigate an attempted military coup that was put down here Monday. The announcement came amid growing speculation that the attempted overthrow may have involved more officers than have so far been named.

title: Bonaro W. Overstreet, Author, Is Dead at 82
description: Bonaro Wilkinson Overstreet, an author, poet and psychologist, died of a stroke Tuesday at a nursing home in Arlington, Va. She was 82 years old.

title: In Defense of Protection
description: To understand the rise of protectionist sentiment in Congress and the country, most folks turn to the business pages, with their gloomy statistics on the budget deficit, the trade deficit and the brain deficit in Washington.

title: ART, MUSIC AND FOOD SALUTE INDIA
description: THE men in their white suits and colorful turbans and the women in their jeweled saris or patterned silk tunics worn over pants captivated the guests at the party Monday night celebrating the ''India!'' exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The exhibition, in the museum's special exhibition galleries, opens to the public Saturday.

title: HOW TO EVALUATE A SCHOOL OR INDIVIDUAL TEACHER
description: UNLIKE people in many other job categories, cooking teachers are not licensed in most parts of the country, including New York City. Anyone who wants to can hang out a shingle and offer cooking classes. While it is true that many of the finest cooking teachers started out by doing exactly that, it is also true that many less-than-qualified people have, too.

title: BUSH SAYS HE WAS RIGHT TO BACK PENSION FREEZE
description: Vice President Bush said today that he was right to support a freeze on Social Security benefits as part of an effort to reduce the Federal deficit.

title: PAYLESS CASHWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 24
BRITISH DIFFER ON THE CAUSE OF THE LATEST VIOLENCE
description: Opposition politicians and some local officials blamed youth unemployment and alienation for the rioting that broke out Monday night and again today in Birmingham.

title: REAGAN SWITCH ON TRADE IS FORECAST
description: Republican leaders on Capitol Hill said today that the Reagan Administration was willing to respond to the political pressures building in Congress by considering additional measures to correct the nation's soaring trade imbalance.

title: Revlon Files Debt Comment
description: Revlon Inc. may not be able to pay its debts if a ''poison-pill'' provision the company has adopted is triggered, the beauty and health-care concern said in an amendment filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: A Silver Lining In the Economy
description: There are grounds for greater optimism about the economy's prospects than the prevailing gloomy consensus would suggest.

title: LURIA, L & SON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
Afghan Rebels Reported To Repulse Soviet Drive
description: Western diplomats said today that Afghan guerrillas had repulsed a Soviet-led offensive in eastern Afghanistan.

title: OFFICIAL ATTACKED
description: Rioting youths threw bottles and bricks at Britain's Home Secretary today as violence erupted in this industrial city for a second straight day.

title: O-T-C Stocks On Exchanges
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission voted unanimously today to allow certain stock exchanges to trade for the first time in over-the-counter stocks.

title: Bid for Sybron
description: The board of the Sybron Corporation has directed a committee of eight outside members to evaluate a $253 million leveraged-buyout offer. The offer comes from top executives of the Rochester-based maker of medical and dental equipment, as well as Shearson Lehman Brothers and Hillside Capital Inc., a New York-based investor group. A company spokesman said no deadline had been set for the evaluation.

title: ISRAEL YIELDS LAST DETAINEES TO LEBANON
description: The last group of 119 Lebanese and Palestinian detainees held by Israel were freed today. They were given a heroes' welcome when they were driven into this port town.

title: Vintage Goal
description: Never underestimate the enthusiasm of Italian soccer fans. Preben Elkjaer, a star player for Verona of the Italian first division, won 700 bottles of premium Abruzzi wine on Sunday, merely for being the man who scored the first goal of the new soccer season.

title: CHASE CONTINUES: ROSE GOES HITLESS
description: Not tonight. Pete Rose went hitless in four times at bat against the San Diego Padres and delayed, for at least another day, the hit that would leave Ty Cobb as the the second most prolific hitter in baseball history.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Bruised Apples In Michigan, where apples are one of the most important food crops, the harvest began late in July with green Lodis and is now proceeding through early Jersey Macs. One of the biggest problems the apple industry faces, according to Bernie Tennes, professor of agricultural engineering at Michigan State University (and, incidentally, the husband of an apple grower), is the damage caused by bruising. ''It is a severe problem,'' Professor Tennes said, estimating that as much as 20 percent of the crop may be damaged.

title: Bucs Sign Steve Young
description: Steve Young, the former Brigham Young quarterback who spent two highly paid years with the Los Angeles Express, bought out the last two years of his United States Football League contract yesterday and signed a series of six one-year contracts with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. Leeman Bennett, the Tampa Bay coach, said he expected Young to become ''an outstanding star'' in the National Football League, but not right away.

title: Rod Funseth, 52, Pro Golfer Earned More Than $600,000
description: Rod Funseth, who won more than $600,000 during his career on the PGA Tour and continued to play professional golf on the senior circuit after discovering he had terminal cancer, is dead at the age of 52.

title: VETO RISK SEEN
description: The House Agriculture Committee, after months of sparring over new farm legislation, today approved a bill after adding a program to let some farmers vote on what kind of system they want to support their income.

title: Disney Pursues Buyback Plan
description: Walt Disney Productions said today that it had purchased 250,000 common shares of its stock from Shamrock Holdings Inc., which is owned by the Roy E. Disney family. The company also said it had bought 50,000 common shares from the estate of Edna F. Disney, wife of the late Disney Productions co-founder, Roy O. Disney.

title: NANKIN EXPRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ALEXANDRIA'S PLIGHT: POLLUTION POISONS CHIC SEASON
description: Alexandria and its environs are to Egypt what the Hamptons are to New York. Each year, wealthy and middle-class Cairenes flock to escape Cairo's burning desert heat for the cooler, humid breezes of the Mediterranean.

title: New Pillsbury Chairman
description: John M. Stafford, president and chief executive of the Pillsbury Company, has been named to the additional post of chairman, succeeding William H. Spoor, who retired. Mr. Spoor, 62 years old, will remain a director of the Minneapolis-based food and restaurant company. Mr. Stafford, 48, joined Pillsbury in 1979.

title: BONN SOCIAL DEMOCRAT WARMLY RECEIVED IN SOVIET
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev gave a pointedly warm reception today to Johannes Rau, the fast-rising star in West Germany's opposition Social Democratic Party.

title: Texas Steps Up Pace Of Tax-Exempt Issues
description: Local governments in Texas are accounting for an unusually large portion of the record amount of new tax-exempt bonds being issued by local governments across the country.

title: WESTERN STEER-MOM 'N POPS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 9
PRATT-READ CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: DANCE: 'CROSS COUNTRY'
description: ANGELIA LEUNG, a Los Angeles dancer, and Ann L. Rodiger, a New York dancer, like to choreograph by long distance. They mail notation symbols to each other, devise sequences in isolation and then meet to assemble their dances.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Company News column of Business Day on Friday about the Peabody International Corporation incorrectly described a merger. The company is to be acquired by the Pullman Company in an exchange of stock. The report also characterized Pullman incorrectly. The company, which formerly made railroad cars and was based in Chicago, now makes truck trailers and aircraft seating, and is based in Princeton, N.J.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Justice Burger Upholds Ruling on Cable Signals
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger has refused to force cable television operators to continue carrying all local television signals on their systems.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Ashton-Tate Co., Culver City, Calif., has introduced an integrated software package called Framework II.

title: Commodore, Banks Weigh Debt Plan
description: Commodore International Ltd., racing to market its new Amiga computer and reeling from an expected $80 million loss in its fiscal fourth quarter, said yesterday that it was in technical default of some bank loans.

title: DEMOCRATS PUSH PRETORIA SANCTIONS
description: Senate Democrats made it clear today that they would continue to push for a confrontation with the White House over their efforts to impose tougher economic sanctions on South Africa.

title: Florida Cane Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Arkansas Power Rate Increase
description: The Arkansas Power and Light Company has won an $81.3 million , or 10.2 percent, rate increase in a decision by the Arkansas Public Service Commission, a spokesman for the utility said. The utility, a subsidiary of Middle South Utilities Inc., reached a settlement with state regulators after earlier requesting an increase more than three times as large.

title: MAN GETS 83-YEAR SENTENCE IN KILLING OF 10 IN BROOKLYN
description: Calling him the ''most brutal killer'' he had ever met, a judge yesterday sentenced a Bronx man to from 83Y to 250 years in prison for killing eight children and two women in a house in Brooklyn last year.

title: DYNATEC INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Racing Is Halted
description: Racing was halted today at Finger Lakes Race Track after the second race when jockeys protested that three consecutive days of rain had made the track dangerous.

title: BUGS BUNNY AT THE MODERN - IS THAT ALL FOLKS?
description: He'd been applauded for singing Wagner in ''What's Opera, Doc?,'' took lessons with the Ballet Russe, and conducted symphony orchestras, but last night Bugs Bunny got a standing ovation at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: DOCTORS CONSIDER FEARS FOCUSED ON AIDS PUPIL
description: A decision by school and health authorities in New York City to permit a child with AIDS to attend regular classes has created a furor among some parents worried that the health of their children could be endangered.

title: STRONG LIBERAL AT EPISCOPAL CHURCH HELM: EDMOND LEE BROWNING
description: Edmond Lee Browning of Hawaii, the new Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church, is described by friends and colleagues as a relaxed man who nonetheless can be expected to be a very strong liberal presence on issues that affect church and society.

title: 'EUGENE ONEGIN' ON PBS
description: ''EUGENE ONEGIN'' has long been Tchaikovsky's most popular opera, and for good reason. Based on Pushkin's gloomy poem of the same name, ''Onegin'' contains some of the composer's most potent melodies, fills the stage with love, dancing and death - three time-tested theatrical elements - and offers irresistibly challenging roles for soprano, mezzo-soprano, contralto, tenor, baritone, and bass.

title: DANCE: GALA FESTIVAL OF INDIA CONCERT
description: THE first gala event for New York in the nationwide Festival of India's performing arts category took the form of a dazzling dance and music concert last night at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Politics;   Look Who Is Yelling On Trade
description: Who can recall the political beating Walter F. Mondale took last year for proposing protectionist measures against foreign imports and not marvel at how this issue suddenly has become political catnip on Capitol Hill?

title: GENERAL HOST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 11
description: b-Net losses including income from discontinued operations of $1,442,000 for the quarter and $3,268,000 for the 6 months.

title: GENERAL FOODS UP ON RUMORS
description: The stock of the General Foods Corporation rose sharply for the second consecutive day yesterday as rumors spread that the First Boston Corporation, one of Wall Street's premier investment banking firms, had placed the issue on its restricted list.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: MILLIONS of American women seem to have overcome the notion that sweat-inducing exercise is unfeminine and unattractive. They have discovered instead that exercise is one of the best ways to become and remain attractive long after sedentary women have lost their trim, tight bodies and the flush of youth. Some also realize that regular vigorous exercise can help protect them against the ravages of heart disease, high blood pressure, diabetes, varicose veins and osteoporosis as well as obesity.

title: Dow Off 5.82, but Volume Improves
description: A selling binge late in the day yesterday set the stock market back for the first time in three sessions, but trading volume increased sharply, in large part because of a continuation of various takeover rumors.

title: Ferraro and Zaccaro In New U.S. Inquiry
description: Former Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro and her husband, John A. Zaccaro, will be interviewed soon by Justice Department lawyers who are investigating financial-disclosure statements filed by Mrs. Ferraro while in Congress, one of the family's lawyers said today.

title:
MARKET PLACE;

Closed-Ends: Mixed Views
description: CLOSED-END mutual funds, most of which traditionally sell at a discount to the value of their portfolios of stocks or bonds, are becoming less of a bargain lately because of the surge in mutual fund sales. Nonetheless, investors continue to snap them up on the theory that as long as the market's tempo is upbeat, they stand to gain in two ways - from an increase in the value of the price of the fund and from a rise in its portfolio.

title: D.C.'s Team
description: Considering that the Redskins have sold out all 55,636 seats in Robert F. Kennedy Stadium for 141 straight home games dating back to 1966, it isn't surprising that a football fan club in Washington has attracted about 500 people.

title: PUBLIC BROADCASTING IS AIRING ITS LINEN
description: Ever since the Nixon Administration, some people have worried that political pressure might be applied against the Corporation for Public Broadcasting in an attempt to undermine its independence from the Government and to influence the way it funnels money to public radio and television.

title: MUSIC: RAIJA ROIVAINEN
description: RAIJA ROIVAINEN, a young Finnish mezzo-soprano who made her New York debut in 1982, returned to Carnegie Recital Hall Monday night. She is a singer with something to offer, though her performance left a certain doubt over the extent to which she has identified her own strengths.

title: FINDER OF TITANTIC AIMS TO CAPITALIZE
description: The scientist who pioneered the advanced Navy technology that found and photographed the steamship Titanic is also president of a company that is drawing up plans to sell versions of the underwater system to the Federal Government, foreign governments and private industry ''The top price might be $10 million to $15 million for a full-blown system with every bell and whistle,'' said a company spokesman. ''It's hard to come up with a firm price. It depends on what the customer wants.''

title: Belgium May Seek Cut In Its NATO Tasks
description: Belgium's Defense Minister said today that his country might seek a further reduction in its defense tasks within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: THRIFT HEARINGS TO FACE A FLURRY OF PROPOSALS
description: With pressure mounting to find ways to shore up the beleaguered Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation and provide assistance to a growing number of troubled thrift institutions, the House Banking Committee today begins two days of hearings on the industry's problems.

title: NOEL BUSCH, AUTHOR AND CORRESPONDENT FOR LIFE MAGAZINE
description: Noel Fairchild Busch, an author and Life magazine correspondent who reported extensively on World War II and its aftermath, died of pulmonary fibrosis Saturday at his home in Millbrook, N.Y. He was 78 years old.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE KINGDOM OF THE WICKED. By Anthony Burgess. 377 pages. Arbor House. $17.95.

title: WINE TALK
description: To a visitor from the city, it's still summer in the Champagne region. The gardens are ablaze with brilliant dahlias and every window box is brimming over with geraniums and vivid petunias.

title: CHICAGO SCHOOL TO DISMANTLE ITS NEW CANOPY AS UN-MIES-LIKE
description: The Illinois Institute of Technology, which is to rededicate its renovated library on Friday, is planning to tear down part of the renovations before the ceremony.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PORT SALUTE In a celebration today that promises to be as tumultuous as the waterfront was in its heyday, the South Street Seaport pulls out all stops to mark the completion of its complex.

title: PC QUOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Angels Get Sutton
description: The California Angels, moving to strengthen their pitching staff for a stretch drive, yesterday acquired Don Sutton from the Oakland, A's. Mickey Morabito, the A's public relations director, said Sutton had been traded to the Angels for two minor leaguers to be named later.

title: NAMATH: A 'HECKUVA' DEBUT
