description: Fifteen years ago, in the first Monday night regular-season game played, the Jets lost to the Cleveland Browns, 31-21. Joe Namath completed 18 passes for 298 yards for the Jets, but he also threw three passes for interceptions, including one that was returned for a touchdown in the final quarter when his team trailed, 24-21.

title: TEEN-AGER'S SUDDEN DEATH BEWILDERS FORENSIC EXPERTS
description: Last May, Jason Findley, a high school honors student who planned to attend West Point this fall, went into a bedroom of his grandmother's house in Scotch Plains to call a girlfriend.

title: Motherhood Magazine
description: Meredith Publishing Services, part of the same corporation that does Better Homes & Gardens magazine, is producing a quarterly magazine called Motherhood in behalf of Motherhood Maternity Shops, which will then distribute 200,000 copies of each issue through its 320 stores in 41 states. Outside advertisers will be welcome, and they will be approached by Fox Associates, an advertising rep firm. A four-color page will be going for $7,500 and a black and white for $5,250.

title: Fewer Pupils Absent In Protest Over AIDS
description: Fewer children stayed home from classes yesterday in two Queens school districts where parents have organized boycotts to protest a city decision to allow a second-grade pupil with AIDS to attend regular classes.

title: Transactions
description: Monday BASEBALLL MINNESOTA (AL) - Activated Tom Klawitter, pitcher, from disabled list.

title: Rise Requested In Debt Limit
description: The Reagan Administration asked Congress today to raise the national debt limit above $2 trillion and predicted that without new borrowing authority, the Treasury would run out of cash by Oct. 15.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S 'COLOREDS': A GROUP TORN BETWEEN BLACK AND WHITE WORLDS
description: The boy of fair skin - but not what is called white in South Africa - came home from school the other day and told his mother, who is dark of skin, that blacks smelled bad.

title: VATICAN CONDEMNS A PAPAL 'COLUMN'
description: The Vatican press office yesterday issued a strong condemnation of a new newspaper column based on the writings of Pope John Paul II. The column has been sold to over 200 newspapers worldwide by news syndicates owned by the publisher Rupert Murdoch.

title: CLARK CONSOLIDATED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Coca-Cola Rejects Order on Formula
description: The Coca-Cola Company has refused to obey a Federal judge's order to turn over its cola formulas, saying that revealing the ingredients even under a protective order could lead to public disclosure. District Judge Murray M. Schwartz had ordered the formulas turned over in a lawsuit brought by 40 bottling companies against Coca-Cola.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: CHARCOAL grilling out of doors is one of the great pleasures at this time of year. Yet few people go beyond the usual fare of poultry and beef, with an occasional shish kebab of lamb or a whole fish thrown in. They are missing delightful and easy-to-make dishes such as grilled pork.

title: Navy Yard Incinerator Endangers Public Health of Brooklyn
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN ENVOY BACK IN RETORIA
description: The United States Ambassador, Herman W. Nickel, returned to his post in South Africa tonight, carrying a personal message from President Reagan to President P. W. Botha.

title: STEIN AND DINKINS ALSO WIN BACKING OF CITY DEMOCRATS
description: Mayor Koch, showing overwhelming strength in every section of the city, won renomination in the Democratic primary yesterday.

title: WHITE WINES, RED AREAS, VICE VERSA
description: LIKE white eggplant and purple cauliflower, there are wines that are intriguing because they are unexpected. A white wine labeled Haut-Brion, usually the best red from the Graves district of Bordeaux, or a bottle of red Sancerre, which is better known as a delightful white wine from the Loire Valley, are two examples.

title: South Africa I
description: President Reagan's imposition of limited sanctions on South Africa involved more complications than a reversal of White House policy toward that country. His decision to ban the importation of the gold Krugerrand coins required a new interpretation of international trade regulations that has produced serious legal questions for the State and Commerce Departments and raised, although perhaps remotely, the possibility of economic retaliation by South Africa.

title: POWELL, MCELROY AGREE TO JETS PACT
description: The Jets took a major step yesterday to try to insure that the indignities they suffered in a 31-0 season-opening loss last Sunday won't happen again soon. After six months of haggling, the Jets and Marvin Powell reached agreement on a revised contract that will return the tackle to the offensive line, where he is sorely missed, and they agreed on a new contract with their other holdout tackle, Reggie McElroy.

title: GLOSSER BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
description: b-After pretax charges of $25,000 for the quarter and $150,000 for the 6 months. c-After a pretax charge of $420,000.

title: Nabisco Brands
description: Shareholders of Nabisco Brands Inc. approved the proposed $4.9 billion merger with R. J. Reynolds Industries, officials said. Under terms of the agreement, Nabisco Brands Inc. becomes an operating company of R. J. Reynolds. R. J. Reynolds had previously acquired approximately 50.2 percent of the voting stock of Nabisco Brands in a tender offer that expired July 2.

title: THE BRUISING ART OF STALKING SNAPPERS IN JERSEY'S WILDS
description: Thomas Brown pointed to a bruise on his leg the shape of a four-inch diamond.

title: U.S. AFFIRMS PLAN ON JORDAN ARMS
description: A high-ranking State Department official told a closed-door meeting of a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee today that the Reagan Administration would go ahead with planned sales of advanced aircraft and other equipment to Jordan even if it meant provoking a major clash with Congress, participants in the session said.

title: SOUTHERN LEADERS SET ELECTION GOAL
description: Democratic and Republican governors from the South said today that they would join an effort by state lawmakers to have all the region's 1988 Presidential primaries and caucuses held on the same day.

title: House Arrest Ordered For Draft Resister
description: A former Yale University philosophy student who refused to register for the draft was sentenced today to six months of house arrest.

title: Calvino Has Surgery After Suffering Stroke
description: Italo Calvino, the Italian novelist whose allegorial works have been critically acclaimed, suffered a stroke last Friday while at his summer home in Castiglione della Pescaia on the Tuscan coast. He underwent surgery Friday at a hospital in Siena for a blood clot in the cranal cavity.

title: IONESCO AND NISBET HONORED
description: The playwright Eugene Ionesco and the social historian Robert Nisbet have been named winners of the 1985 Ingersoll Prizes, awarded by the Ingersoll Foundation.

title: Ex-Official of Belize Sentenced in Drug Plot
description: A former Minister of Energy and Communications of the Central American nation of Belize has been sentenced to seven years in prison and fined $50,000 for conspiring to smuggle more than 1,000 pounds of marijuana and cocaine into the United States.

title: O'JAYS MAKE TRANSITION TO THE 80'S
description: THE trouble with making records that define a style or exemplify the mood of the times is what to do when times change. The O'Jays, a vocal group with roots in 1950's street-corner singing, made the definitive soul records of the early and middle 1970's, with the help of their resourceful producers, the Philadelphia International label's Kenny Gamble and Leon Huff. ''Back Stabbers,'' ''Love Train,'' ''Put Your Hands Together,'' ''I Love Music'' and other O'Jays, Gamble and Huff hits defined the sound and mood of the 1970's the way Motown and the Memphis soul scene defined the 1960's. But this is the 1980's, and the Philadelphia sound the O'Jays epitomized is no longer the coin of the realm.

title: A Stake Through the Apartheid Dracula's Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: Hurricane in North Pacific
description: Hurricane Rick, one of the strongest and best developed on record in the eastern North Pacific, was approaching the Hawaiian Islands today with winds gusting to 145 miles an hour, the National Weather Service said.

title: Switching Arenas
description: Tom McMillen, the 33-year-old center for the Washington Bullets, who has been weighing a political career, said he had decided to seek the Democratic nomination from Maryland's Fourth Congressional District next year but would remain with the Bullets in coming season. . . . Chuck Nevitt, the 7-foot-5-inch reserve center billed as the tallest player in the N.B.A., signed a one-year contract with the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: COOPER LASERSONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $40,000. c-Net loss. d-Including tax credits of $351,000 for the quarter and $29,000 for the 9 months.

title: DELTAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: KILEY REACHES TRANSIT TRUCE WITH D'AMATO
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Robert R. Kiley, held a peacemaking session here today with Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, who had been criticizing New York's transit system and the people running it.

title: Japanese Dancer Dies After a Six-Story Fall
description: A rope holding a member of an avant-garde Japanese dance troupe snapped today during a performance of a ''dance of birth and death,'' dropping the performer six stories to his death before hundreds of spectators.

title: Real Men Don't Need More Guns Every Year
description: To the Editor:

title: Cox Appointment
description: Cox Enterprises of Atlanta announced late yesterday that David R. Van Valkenburg, president of its Cox Cable Communications affiliate, had resigned and been replaced by James O. Robbins, vice president of operations. Mr. Van Valkenburg, reached by telephone at his Atlanta home, said he wanted to seek other opportunities. In his two years as president, he said, he worked to turn each cable-television unit into a profit center. He said both he and Mr. Robbins are 43 years old and Harvard Business School graduates. Mr. Robbins, who was unavailable for comment, was general manager of Viacom Cablevision, on Long Island, from 1979 until 1983, when he joined Cox.

title: EX-P.O.W. ENDS 40 YEARS OF HIDING
description: After 40 years in hiding in the United States, a World War II German soldier who escaped from a prisoner-of-war camp is to surrender to the Immigration and Naturalization Service today in California, according to officials of the agency.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Atico Financial Corp., a Miami-based holding company, has named Lawrence O. Turner Jr. chairman, replacing Nathaniel B. Elkins, who resigned to become chairman of the Pan American Mortgage Corp.

title: OIL-TRADER COMPUTER SERVICE SET
description: Citicorp and McGraw-Hill Inc. announced yesterday, as expected, that they were forming a joint venture allowing commodity traders to buy and sell goods as well as arrange shipping and insurance, all by computer.

title: GRANT IS ROCKLAND VICTOR
description: Rockland County Democrats yesterday chose a County Legislator, John T. Grant, as their candidate for Rockland County executive when the first election for that office is held in the fall.

title: 20-MINUTE MEALS: CONVENIENCE COUNTDOWN
description: TEN years ago a good buy at the grocery store was at the top of most shopping lists. Today it seems to have taken a back seat to convenience. More and more these days people are simply unable or unwilling to devote hours to the daily preparation of food.

title: NEUTROGENA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
NURSE SAYS STEWART WAS BRUISED WHEN HE ARRIVED AT THE HOSPITAL
description: A registered nurse at Bellevue Hospital Center testified yesterday that Michael Stewart was bruised and not breathing when he was wheeled into the emergency room in the early hours of Sept. 15, 1983.

title: KEY FIGURE IN MAYAN STUDIES
description: Tatiana Proskouriakoff, whose deciphering of Mayan glyphs helped lay the foundations of modern Mayan historical studies, died Aug. 30 in Cambridge, Mass., the Peabody Museum of Harvard University said yesterday. She was 76 years old and was long associated with the museum.

title: South Africa II
description: The Democratic National Club sponsored a golf and tennis tournament Monday at the Indian Springs Country Club in Maryland, honoring the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., and featuring competition among Democratic House members.

title: A Baldwin Plan To Aid Customers
description: An estimated 165,000 holders of Baldwin-United Corporation annuities would receive a higher rate of return on their policies than originally authorized by the courts under a plan announced by insurance regulators and the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, administrator of the plan.

title: Royals Top Angels, 6-0
description: Charlie Leibrandt pitched a three-hitter tonight as the Kansas City Royals defeated California, 6-0, to extend their lead over the Angels in the American League West to 1 1/2 games. The teams have split the first two games of a three-game series.

title: Since Phrixus and Phrontis, There Have Been Unisex Names
description: To the Editor:

title: CHI-CHI'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Rangers Sign Two
description: Raimo Helminen, a high-scoring center from Finland who was the Rangers' second-round draft choice last year, has signed a new contract, the club said yesterday as it also announced the signing of its sixth-round 1984 draft choice, Kjell Samuelson, a defenseman who played the last two seasons in Sweden. Helminen, a member of Finland's 1984 Olympic team, played in Finland last season after appearing in one exhibition game for the Rangers. . . . Dave Simpson, a 23-year-old Islander center, was traded to the Pittsburgh Penguins for future considerations.

title: Patent Filings in China
description: China published its first group of patent applications today, the New China News Agency said. Most of the 150 applications came from Chinese inventors, but foreigners were also represented. Since China's patent law went into effect last April 1, the patent office has had almost 9,000 applications, including more than 3,000 from abroad, the agency said.

title: DEMOCRATS CALM THREAT TO MILITARY PROGRAMS BILL
description: House Democrats today apparently calmed a liberal uprising that threatened to scuttle a military programs bill costing up to $302.5 billion approved by a House-Senate conference in July, according to Congressional aides.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Wendy Sly, the British runner who won a silver medal in the Olympic 3,000 meters last year, has entered the Fifth Avenue Mile Sept. 28. . . . Hector (Macho) Camacho, the World Boxing Council lightweight champion who was recently given an eight-month suspension by New Jersey boxing authorities for using illegal drugs in a bout last January, got a bit of support from the W.B.C. In a statement issued in Mexico City, the council questioned the validity of tests that supposedly found traces of drugs in Camacho's system after the bout. . . . Jim Nelford, a member of the PGA Tour, suffered mutliple fractures of his right arm last Sunday in a water-skiing accident near his home in Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: MEDITATION SET FOR TOXIC WASTE
description: Governor Cuomo and a group of state business leaders said today that they would test a program of mediation for deciding who pays to clean up abandoned hazardous-waste dumps. Now, cleanups can be delayed by years of litigation.

title: SHOREHAM FOE WINS EASILY
description: A Suffolk County Legislator opposed to the opening of the Shoreham nuclear power plant won a decisive victory tonight in a Democratic primary that pitted her against an advocate of the opening of the $4.5 billion plant.

title: Dispute in Finland
description: A high Finnish official said she would try to stop Keke Rosberg, a former Formula One champion, from using a Finnish license in competing in the South African Grand Prix at Kyalami next month, but Finnish racing officials said the effort would not keep Rosberg out of the race. ''I want to make sure the Finnish national anthem may not be played in a country which supports apartheid,'' said Kaarina Suonio, the Finnish Minister of Education, who oversees state financial aid to Finnish sports. Antti Syvaelahti, the association's secretary-general, said there was no way the association could keep a professional driver such as Rosberg from honoring his contractual commitments.

title: 12 Years of Night in Chile
description: What will opposition forces in Chile do today, the 12th anniversary of the coup that brought Gen. Augusto Pinochet to power? I found no clear answers to that question during a visit last month. But I saw water cannons waiting to quell demonstrators. I saw, too, deep frustration among the 11.8 million people, who are humiliated by the torture, murders, harassment and the exiling of citizens who are heirs to one of the richest democratic traditions in Latin America.

title: KIT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $112,000 for the quarter and year.

title: TICOR OFFERS EPIC 'WORK OUT'
description: The Ticor Mortgage Insurance Company, which is under serious financial strain because of the problems of the EPIC group of real estate and mortgage companies, today sent to numerous parties involved in the case the first concrete proposal to solve EPIC's problems.

title: AT COOKING CLASSES, A NEW SERIOUSNESS AS BOOM DAYS END
description: THE enormous wave of interest in cooking lessons that surged in the late 1970's and early 80's seems to have crested, according to a number of New York City's cooking teachers. Though no official statistics are kept, many smaller schools, which often consist of an individual teacher operating out of his or her own kitchen, have fallen by the wayside, a prey to a combination of rising costs and dropping enrollments.

title: Faberge Picks President With Sales Background
description: Faberge Inc., the perfume and hair care company, has named Steven Manenti, a former sales representative for the company's products, to the posts of president and chief operating officer. His appointment was effective Monday.

title: Saudi Pricing Pact Seen
description: A Kuwaiti newspaper, al-Watan, said today that Saudi Arabia had reached a preliminary agreement with six oil companies to undercut OPEC's official pricing structure by selling its crude oil at market-related prices beginning in October. The companies are the Exxon Corporation, the Mobil Corporation, Texaco Inc., the Chevron Corporation, the Royal Dutch/ Shell Group and the Mitsubishi Oil Company.

title: ANOTHER PRIMARY DAY AT 'AUNT BEA'S BAKERY'
description: ''The turnout is light . . . the turnout is light.''

title: Pennsylvania's Student Bonds
description: The Pennsylvania Higher Education Assistance Agency is offering $202 million of adjustable-rate student loan revenue bonds, due in 2000, through underwriters led by L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin.

title: UNIT OF GTE ADMITS PLOT TO GET DATA
description: The Justice Department today accused the GTE Government Systems Corporation of conspiring to illegally obtain internal Pentagon planning documents, and the company said it would plead guilty.

title: CHEEZEM DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Deciphering Diplomatic Decampments
description: President Reagan's decision, announced today, to send Ambassador Herman Nickel back to South Africa points out the way that travels by ambassadors are often used to send signals about the state of relations between two governments.

title: Canada Acts to Buttress Claims in the Arctic
description: The Canadian Government, stung by domestic criticism of a United States icebreaker's voyage through the Northwest Passage last month, announced new measures today to strengthen its claim to sovereignty over the Arctic waters.

title: Arthur Tatham, Co-founder Of an Ad Agency in Midwest
description: Arthur E. Tatham, co-founder of Tatham-Laird & Kudner, a Chicago-based advertising agency, died last Thursday at Evanston Hospital, Evanston, Ill. He was 77 years old and lived in Wilmette, Ill.

title: Since Phrixus and Phrontis, There Have Been Unisex Names
description: To the Editor:

title: CARROLL O'CONNOR IN 'BRASS'
description: WHERE does a talented actor go on television after singular success in a long-running situation comedy? There are possibilities. Buddy Ebsen went from ''The Beverly Hillbillies'' to ''Barnaby Jones.'' Jack Klugman found ''Quincy'' after ''The Odd Couple.'' And Mary Tyler Moore will be giving television another whirl this season after logging some impressive stage and film credits. But it is not easy, as Carroll O'Connor has been finding out.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: CLOSE VOTE PUTS NORWAY'S COALITION IN DOUBT
description: Kaare Willoch was something less than jubilant on learning early today that he had been re-elected Prime Minister of Norway.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. On Friday, it was Dwight Gooden vs. Fernando Valenzuela.

title: Real Estate Consultant To Assist With EPIC
description: Seeking outside help for advice on how to cope with problems at the troubled Equity Programs Investment Corporation, the State of Maryland Deposit Insurance Fund Corporation said that it had retained James O. Boisi, a real estate expert, as a special consultant.

title: KARPOV AND KASPAROV DRAW 3D GAME IN 20 MOVES
description: The world chess champion, Anatoly Karpov, and his challenger, Gary Kasparov, agreed to a draw today in the third game of the world chess championship match.

title: MAN EXECUTED IN KILLING COMMITTED AS TEEN-AGER
description: Charles Rumbaugh, 28 years old, who was convicted as a teen-ager of robbing and killing an Amarillo jeweler, was executed by lethal injection early today in the Texas death chamber. The execution was the first in more than two decades for a crime committed by someone under the age of 18.

title: The Master
description: ''Let's be frank about this. I know more about 'Ulysses' than anyone else in the world, and I'm going to teach it all to you.''

title: LIBERAL BISHOP TO LEAD THE EPISCOPAL CHURCH
description: Bishop Edmond L. Browning of Hawaii, a liberal churchman with strong international experience, was elected today as the Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church.

title: No Headline
description: Interest rates were mixed and little changed in lethargic trading yesterday as traders and investors waited for more clues to the future direction of interest rates.

title: Scotland Ties Wales in Soccer
description: A late penalty shot by a substitute, Davie Cooper, enabled Scotland to salvage a 1-1 tie with Wales today and keep alive the Scots' chances of gaining a berth in the World Cup soccer tournament in Mexico. Cooper's kick in the 81st minute maintained the Scots' lead in its group.

title: HEPATITIS AFFLICTS 27 AT DANBURY HILTON
description: Hepatitis has stricken 27 employees at the Hilton Hotel in Danbury, and the toll is expected to climb, the Danbury health director said today.

title: EQUALITY REMAINS AN ELUSIVE GOAL FOR U.N. WOMEN
description: ''During the Inquisition in Spain people were forbidden to talk so that there wouldn't be conflicts,'' said Mercedes Pulido de Briceno. ''And I have realized that when it comes to women, it's like the Inquisition here at the U.N.''

title: BOROUGH CHIEF DEFEATS LIPPER BY 2-TO-1 EDGE
description: Andrew J. Stein overwhelmingly defeated five other candidates yesterday to win the Democratic nomination for City Council president.

title: The Line-Item President
description: President Reagan says his executive order on sanctions for South Africa ''wouldn't have been necessary if I had what a President should have, which is a line-item veto. I could have signed the bill and line-item vetoed out'' disagreeable sections.

title: YANKS OUTSLUG BREWERS FOR 11TH IN ROW
description: Yogi Berra doesn't manage the Yankees anymore, but the pitchers Billy Martin inherited from him have given new meaning to Berra's wisdom about the game not being over until it's over. No matter how many runs the Yankee hitters produce - and they produce prolifically - their pitchers make sure the opposition has a chance to win before the game is over.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Your generation is subject to more information than any generation in history.

title: GAMBLE PAYING OFF AT CONTINENTAL AIR
description: When Frank Lorenzo, chairman of Continental Airlines, put the carrier under the protection of Chapter 11 two years ago, he repudiated all the union contracts and slashed wages in half. He was gambling both that the sharply lower labor costs would make the airline more competitive in the cutthroat era of deregulation, and that the bitterness the procedure generated among employees would die down.

title: REAGAN STARTS TAKING AIM AT SOVIET PUBLICITY
description: President Reagan, responding to what aides characterized as a ''media blitz'' by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, said today that ''the preservation of our freedom and independence will not be secured by wishful thinking and public relations campaigns.''

title: MEHTA IN SALUTE TO INDIA
description: In years gone by, when a major New York musical organization began a new season, it hadn't been heard from in months. Now, in the days of the 52-week union contract, one encounters an ensemble like the New York Philharmonic pretty much year round. Last month were the orchestra's free concerts in the city's parks, and just last weekend there were the two gala concert performances of Stephen Sondheim's ''Follies.''

title: KOCH'S OPPORTUNITY
description: Now that the primary voters have overwhelmingly validated what the pollsters and prognosticators knew all along, Edward I. Koch is likely to be given soon an opportunity afforded only two other mayors in the modern history of New York City: A third chance to get it just right.

title: A U.S. REBUTTAL IN K.A.L. CASE
description: The Justice Department denied today that American air-traffic controllers knew that Korean Air Lines Flight 007 was off course and that they discussed warning the pilot before the plane was shot down by a Soviet fighter.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Lake Louise and the Museum Monkeys
description: For city dwellers, summer is the time to look for beauty outside picture frames and far from the solids and voids of architecture. But what can a fugitive from city streets find to say about a landscape not created by a painter? What is there to point out in a real mountain?

title: New Evidence Reported In Klaus Barbie Case
description: The court that will try Klaus Barbie, the former Nazi chief in Lyons, for crimes against humanity indicated today that it had obtained new evidence allowing for more detailed charges in the case.

title: REAGAN NAMES PANEL TO STANDARDIZE SENTENCING
description: President Reagan today appointed a seven-member commission that will make sweeping changes in the way Federal justices set criminal sentences.

title: As in Oxygen Deficit?
description: When 500 runners, including senators, representatives, Administration executives and journalists, line up tomorrow morning for the fifth annual three-mile Nike Capital Challenge through East Potomac Park, each participant will have available a handy ''pace chart.''

title: Margin Seen Declining In Air Traffic Safety
description: The safety margin of the nation's system for controlling air traffic is diminishing because of staffing shortages, employee fatigue and an unseasoned work force, a Congressional report concluded today.

title: 'Invisible' Campaign For Bank
description: HOMER & DURHAM ADVERTISING has called on an invisible man to remind people how they frequently feel when doing business with modern New York area banks.

title: Ballroom in Jeopardy
description: Poignant in its shabby silence, the abandoned Audubon Ballroom in Washington Heights still summons memories.

title: Probing Soviet Plans
description: Moscow has now made clear the outline of the trade that Mikhail Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, is seeking with President Reagan. It is for important reductions in heavy strategic missiles in return for banning development and deployment of strategic defense weapons - ''Star Wars.''

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: U.S. IN POLICY SHIFT ON FARM SANITATION RULES
description: Labor Secretary Bill Brock plans to give the states 18 months to set toilet and water standards for migrant workers and to impose Federal standards if they do not act, according to department officials and Congressional sources.

title: NEWPORT PHARMACEUTICALS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: GRACE INVESTMENT IN HUTZLER'S SEEN
description: W. R. Grace & Company is expected to announce this week that it will invest in the Hutzler Brothers department stores of Baltimore, enabling Hutzler's to become the retail operator of the seven-store B. Altman & Company.

title: FOR METS' JOHNSON, THE PRESSURE HELPS
description: The situation begged for Gary Carter to step up to the plate last night, not Howard Johnson. It was an opportunity - bases loaded, two outs, tie game - for a hitter with an imposing bat. For Carter or Darryl Strawberry. Perhaps even Keith Hernandez or George Foster. But it belonged to Howard Johnson.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 11, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee to Review International Development Strategy - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: DIRECT ACTION MARKETING reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BUFFALO MAYOR LOSES TO DEMOCRAT BUT WINS TWO OTHER PARTY LINES
description: Buffalo's ebulliently combative Mayor, James D. Griffin, lost the Democratic primary yesterday, but won two other party lines.

title: SOVIET BOOK FAIR OPENS, WITH U.S.
description: The biennial Moscow Book Fair opened today, marked by the return of a combined exhibition of American publications after an absence of six years.

title: Navy Yard Incinerator Endangers Public Health of Brooklyn
description: To the Editor:

title: SHUBERTS WIN BATTLE FOR THE MUSICAL 'CHESS'
description: The Shubert Organization yesterday won the battle among Broadway producers for the right to stage ''Chess,'' the Tim Rice-Benny Andersson-Bjorn Ulvaeus musical about political and romantic intrigue amid a world chess championship.

title: The Hot Teams Suffer Big Losses
description: Sometimes when you win, you also lose.

title: MERCER AWARD TO DEARIE
description: Blossom Dearie, the 59-year-old singer, pianist and composer, was named the first recipient of the annual Mabel Mercer Foundation Award at a benefit gala held on the St. Regis Roof on Monday evening.

title: French Rail Chief Quits After Series of Crashes
description: The president of France's railroads resigned today, taking full responsibility for a recent series of accidents in which 83 people have been killed.

title: Requiem at Sardi's
description: Together they stood - the actor, the singer, the textile maker and dozens of others at Sardi's restaurant on Monday night.

title: SPI-SUSPENSION & PARTS INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The results include the cost of nonrecurring expenses incurred by the relocation of the company's plant to Carmiel, from Haifa Bay, Israel.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 11, 1985
description: International

title: Control Data Sells 2 Separate Issues
description: The Control Data Corporation began offering $300 million of securities yesterday in two separate offerings through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: A.B.T.'s Cast Change
description: Because of a foot injury, Cynthia Gregory will not dance tonight or Saturday night with the American Ballet Theater. Cynthia Harvey and Ross Stretton will dance ''Giselle'' at the Metropolitan Opera House tonight.

title: Operating Officer Resigns at Lorimar
description: Russell Goldsmith has resigned as chief operating officer and a director of Lorimar Inc. to head a new investment group that he said plans to start or invest in entertainment companies.

title: SO DRINKS DON'T LOSE THEIR COOL
description: WHILE Labor Day may officially signal an end to the summer entertaining season, the weather usually remains hospitable for at least another month. September and October can be ideal times for outdoor entertaining.

title: How Not to Milk the Poor
description: There are 11 billion pounds of surplus butter, cheese and milk stuffing Government warehouses, and the dairy lobby knows that as long as it all stays there, the public will howl at giving still more farm subsidies to produce still more surplus butter, cheese and milk. So the dairy interests have come up with a convoluted plan, sponsored by Representative Tony Coelho, Democrat of California, to reduce both surpluses and direct taxpayer subsidies.

title: WHY VICKS IS SUCH A HOT PROPERTY
description: Richardson-Vicks Inc. may not be on the leading edge of technology or the keeper of vast undervalued assets, but in the corporate takeover market its basic business - catering to the whims of the consumer market - is what is hot these days.

title: JWT Direct Network To Share Specialties
description: Independent ad agencies and public relations firms situated in different cities frequently affiliate in order that each may profit from being able to offer clients greater reach. No shared equity.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: G.M. Hughes Accounting
description: The General Motors Corporation, at the insistence of the Securities and Exchange Commission, will report two earnings figures for its new G.M. Hughes subsidiary, company officials said today.

title: Confinement Continues At Texas Prisons
description: Some 17,000 Texas inmates were locked in their cells for a second day today in an effort to quell a rash of inmate killings linked to warfare between two prison gangs.

title: Lebanese Shiites Meet With Palestinan Team
description: Lebanese Shiite and Palestinian leaders met here today in a new effort to end a week of bitter clashes around a Palestinian quarter in southern Beirut.

title: Wrong Message for the Klan
description: Mayor Kenneth Gibson of Newark has rejected a request for a rally permit by a man who purports to lead the New Jersey chapter of the Ku Klux Klan. The Klan is a terrorist organization intent only on sowing hatred, Mr. Gibson said, and it will never be allowed in Newark as long as he is Mayor.

title: SUIT IS FILED IN CAPITAL TO HALT SPACE-WEAPON TEST FRIDAY
description: Four House members and an group of scientists asked a Federal court today to block the United States' anti-satellite weapon test, on the ground that President Reagan had falsely certified to Congress that he was trying in good faith to negotiate curbs on such arms.

title: 'ONLY BAROMETER' FOR HERNANDEZ
description: First there were flowers, and then there was a 30-second standing ovation that made Keith Hernandez unable to focus on the first pitch. But nothing could shake his professionalism, even in the middle of a bench-clearing fight when he played peacemaker.

title: Ratings Reviewed For ATT Entities
description: Debt and preferred stock ratings of ATT Technologies Inc. and the ATT Credit Corporation are under review for possible downgrading, Moody's Investors Service said yesterday.

title: Mets, Yanks Vie on Farm
description: A subway series may still be a month away in New York City but down on the farm it's already going strong.

title: MOYNIHAN SAYS U.S. KILLED HIS ANTI-SPY MEASURE
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, charged today that the Central Intelligence Agency and the State Department had persuaded Congress to kill a measure he had introduced aimed at protecting American citizens from having their telephone conversations intercepted by foreign agents in this country.

title: BLUE JAYS DEFEAT TIGERS TO RETAIN LEAD
description: Damaso Garcia singled in the winning run in the seventh inning tonight to snap a 1-1 tie and Doyle Alexander outpitched Jack Morris as the Toronto Blue Jays defeated the Detroit Tigers, 2-1.

title: SHIFTS SEEN FOR OFFICERS OF CITICORP
description: After a year as Citicorp's chief executive officer, John S. Reed is getting ready to place his own stamp on the world's biggest banking organization with a series of top-level management changes.

title: EUROPEAN NATIONS ORDER SANCTIONS ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: Eleven West European nations agreed here today to impose trade, cultural and military sanctions against South Africa.

title: STARGELL AND MADLOCK ACCUSED BY BERRA
description: Dale Berra of the Yankees told a United States District Court today that Willie Stargell and Bill Madlock regularly dispensed amphetamine pills to their teammates when all three played for the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: THE SCREEN: 'BASTILLE,' BY RUDOLF VAN DEN BERG
description: THE Dutch film ''Bastille,'' which opens today at the Film Forum 1, has the compelling idea that a child of Holocaust victims might be obsessed with changing history. It concerns an Amsterdam schoolteacher named Paul de Wit, played with quiet gravity by Derek de Lint, who has made every conscious effort to eradicate his past. He has effectively renounced his Jewishness, marrying a pretty Christian blonde who seems not entirely to understand him. He has also taken a feverish interest in a book he hopes to write: a work of fiction about the 1791 flight to Varennes by Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette. History records that their efforts failed and that the king and queen were beheaded, but Paul plans to invent a happier version of the episode.

title: BELUSHI USED DRUGS HEAVILY IN HIS FINAL DAYS, AIDE SAYS
description: The defense in the criminal case resulting from John Belushi's death portrayed the comedian's friends and business associates at a hearing today as unable or unwilling to help stop his use of drugs.

title: New Product Ads Up
description: New product introductions in August were once again well ahead of the same month last year, with 168 compared with 145, according to the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News. That means that, with the exception of June, every month of the year has topped 1984 monthly totals. For the eight months, the figure was 1,415, compared with 1,292.

title: DR. WALTER DUSHNYCK
description: Dr. Walter Dushnyck, a specialist in Eastern European affairs and editor of the Ukraine Quarterly, died last Thursday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 76 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: EATON VANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Bridge: Game in Commercial League Includes a Challenging Deal
description: Those who like play-or-defend challenges should study the diagramed deal. If South plays six hearts would you choose to play or defend?

title: BREAST CANCER ANALYSIS STIRS A DEBATE AT PARLEY
description: A provocative new analysis of more than 100 clinical trials involving 36,000 women around the world has concluded that relatively mild hormonal therapy is more effective than toxic drugs in preventing recurrence of fatal breast cancer in women over the age of 50, the age group that incurs most breast cancer.

title: People
description: Henry W. Marks has joined M. Shanken Communications as a senior vice president.

title: Senior Surprise
description: Bob Lutz and Stan Smith, who dominated men's doubles tennis play from the mid-1960's until 1980, are still winning championships together, but in a special category. They teamed last week to win the United States Open men's 35-and-over title, defeating Marty Riessen and Sherwood Stewart, 6-1, 6-7, 6-1 in the final on Sunday.

title: METS EDGE CARDS, 5-4, AS JOHNSON HITS GRAND SLAM
description: The battle for first place opened before a sellout crowd of 50,195 in Shea Stadium last night, and it was a beauty: The Mets scored five runs in the first inning, four crossing on a grand slam by Howard Johnson, and then withstood several late threats to edge the St. Louis Cardinals, 5-4, and dislodge them from the top of the National League's East.

title: August Imports Fell in Japan
description: Japan posted a $3.53 billion trade surplus in August, as its exports continued to increase and its imports kept declining, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 11, 1985
description: Companies

title: A Setback for Women In Construction Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: Gates Learjet Names Chief Operating Officer
description: The Gates Learjet Corporation said yesterday that Max E. Bleck, former president and chief executive of the Piper Aircraft Company, had been named to the new post of chief operating officer.

title: Win 1, Lose 1
description: People with a fondness for balanced ledgers have a lot to root for in the Chicago White Sox, who have become a quintessentially .500 ball club.

title: MUSIC: SHANKAR AND PHILHARMONIC
description: FOR nearly three decades, ever since his first tour of the United States and Europe in the 1956-57 season, Ravi Shankar has served as India's unofficial ambassador for music. He and his sitar - that lovely fretted instrument that looks rather like an archlute's fingerboard with a large gourd attached to either end - have done their best to induct Western concert audiences into the mysteries of India's ancient and intricate classical music, with greater success in some quarters than in others. It was flower-powered youth that really seized on Mr. Shankar as a hero in the 1960's, you will remember. His popularity went clear off the pop charts after the Woodstock Festival in 1969, when he and the eminent Beatle, George Harrison, shared the stage for a memorable set.

title: Yields Rise in Quiet Trading
description: Interest rates rose slightly in quiet trading yesterday, as many traders and investors continue to worry about higher rates in the future but are not sure enough to make the large-scale trades that could raise interest rates sharply.

title: COUNTY WORKERS HIT RECORD HIGH
description: More people worked for county governments last year than ever before, and payrolls also reached an all-time high, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: HANOVER COS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $998,000, or 37 cents a share.

title: Advertising;   Generic Drugs and Agencies
description: NOW we have all heard about the plight faced by the makers of highly profitable prescription drugs as their patents run out and the makers of generic brands prepare to leap in and challenge their lock on the market.

title: Required Reading;   Not 'Uncle Sucker'
description: Excerpts of remarks by Representative Buddy Roemer, Democrat of Louisiana, in the House of Representatives, Sept. 4:

title: Public Art
description: Tall and exotic, they stand proudly in the courtyard of Hunter College, their public display the culmination of their public creation.

title: ALL SEASONS RESORTS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: PIER 17 OPENS AT SEAPORT WITH FANFARE OF TRUMPETS AND FIREWORKS
description: Trumpets, dancers and thousands of green, pink and purple balloons yesterday greeted the completion of Pier 17, a three-story complex at the South Street Seaport.

title: FORMER GERMAN P.O.W. GIVES UP AFTER 40 YEARS
description: A former German soldier who said he lived in fear of capture for 40 years after fleeing a United States prisoner-of-war camp in World War II surrendered today to the Federal authorities, saying he was relieved the ordeal was over.

title: HEARING ORDERED ON UKRANIAN BOY
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit today upheld a ruling that the Government had denied Anna and Michael Polovchak their rights in preventing them from taking their son Walter back to the Soviet Union in 1982.

title: STERLING EXTRUDER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Slayer Gets Six Life Terms
description: A former nursing home employee was sentenced Tuesday to six consecutive life terms for the rape and slayings of six women.

title: FIX-UP HOME SHOW
description: THE fourth annual Big Apple Fix-Up, a home improvement festival of three days of exhibits, lectures and workshops, opens tomorrow at the New York Coliseum.

title: A WORLD OF ANTIQUES AT A LONDON FAIR
description: The Burlington House Fair, which was opened today by the Prince and Princess of Wales, has transformed the interiors of the Royal Academy of Arts in Burlington House with the antique treasures exhibited by 78 art and antiques dealers.

title: BASEBALL'S BOUTONNIERE
description: With a line single in the first inning last night, baseball pinned a Rose named Pete on its lapel just when it needed something to celebrate.

title: Bridge: A REPLAY AS GOOD AS THE PLAY THE MARK OF HIGH STANDARDS
description: When an expert plays a difficult hand well in team play and achieves a maximum result, it is no surprise. But when the play follows an identical course in the replay, it is evidence of a high standard of play.

title: D&D BUILDING: MECCA OF DESIGNERS WHO DO INTERIORS
description: IT sits rather unassumingly on Third Avenue, its riches hidden behind its gray facade like an heiress behind a limousine window. The initial impression of the Decoration and Design Building, ''the D & D'' as it is known in the design world, is as workaday as it is glamorous. The travertine lobby is undergoing renovation, the display windows eschew a Bloomingdale's sense of chic and designers are as likely to be talking about the immediate space -the elevators and how slow they are - as the latest Italian import.

title: NBC BROKE RULES IN MEESE INTERVIEW
description: An accommodation made by ABC News to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d several weeks ago in connection with his appearance on ''This Week with David Brinkley'' violated the network's news guidelines and has prompted an amendment to those guidelines, David Burke, vice president and assistant to the president of ABC News said yesterday.

title: MCI Seeks Court Costs
description: The MCI Communications Corporation is asking a Federal court to order the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to pay $27.6 million in fees and costs incurred by MCI in its long-running antitrust lawsuit against the communications giant.

title: DEPOSIT INSURANCE PLAN QUESTIONED BY VOLCKER
description: The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Paul A. Volcker, expressed reservations to Congress today about a possible merger of the Government's two biggest deposit-insurance funds.

title: DEMOCRACY IN TURKEY: SOME PROGRESS IS MADE, BUT BARRIERS REMAIN
description: Five years after a military coup, the Turkish Government has reinstated important aspects of parliamentary democracy, but serious restrictions on civil rights continue to make the country lag behind its Western allies.

title: ENGINEERING MEASUREMENTS COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations and disposal of discontinued operations of $4,910. c-After loss from discontinued operations and disposal of discontinued operations of $37,243.

title: FIREMAN'S FUND OFFERING SET
description: The American Express Company, proceeding with its previously announced plan for a partial divestiture of its troubled Fireman's Fund insurance subsidiary, said yesterday that it would sell off 49 percent of Fireman's Fund's property-casualty business in a public stock offering.

title: Smokeless Cigarette
description: Favor, a smokeless cigarette made by Advanced Tobacco Products, will be sold intially in Austin and should be on the market by the end of the week, company officials said. The smoking device contains a nicotine solution and looks like a cigarette but does not burn. Favor is not restricted from advertising on television as conventional cigarettes have been since 1971.

title: Technology;   Fluorescents' Use Expanding
description: THE incandescent light bulb, invented by Thomas Edison in 1879, was such a good idea that it has since become a symbol of inspiration, hovering over heads at the moment of discovery. In the century since Mr. Edison's invention, the incandescent bulb has been overtaken in many offices and businesses by the more energy-efficient fluorescent bulb. But for use in ordinary household fixtures, consumers have found no acceptable alternative to the pear-shaped incandescent, whose virtues include low cost, small size and a pleasing light complimentary to skin tones.

title: MUSIC: BABTUNDE OLATUNJI
description: THIRTY years ago, the Nigerian drummer-singer Babatunde Olatunji released his album ''Drums of Passion,'' probably the first album of African and African-style music made in a modern, stereo recording studio. He marked the occasion with a concert Tuesday at the Ritz - a jubilant, 90-minute set of drumming, dancing and singing.

title: Laughs, From Denmark
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz led the laughter yesterday over lunch at the Danish Embassy after Prime Minister Poul Schluter told a soccer story. Mr. Schluter, ending a two-day official visit to Washington, said that in its last match with the Soviet team, the Danish national soccer team had scored an upset victory, 4-2, in Copenhagen. He added that players from teams of the officially pro-Soviet Eastern European nations who attended the game were rooting for the Danes. He indicated he did not expect this to recur when the teams meet again later this month, in Moscow.

title: Traffic Warning
description: Blue Jays will be in the Bronx today. Cardinals will be in Queens.

title: Prince Charles to Give Prize to Perot in U.S.
description: Prince Charles will present the Winston Churchill Award to H. Ross Perot at a dinner in Dallas in February, it was announced yesterday.

title: U.S. REBUFFS SOVIET ON CHEMICAL ARMS
description: The Reagan Administration today dismissed Mikhail S. Gorbachev's endorsement of a proposal for the creation of a zone in central Europe free of all chemical weapons.

title: NEWMARK & LEWIS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
$200.5 Million Offering From Mississippi Unit
description: The Mississippi Housing Finance Corporation is offering $200.5 million of tax-exempt, single-family mortgage revenue bonds through underwriters led by E. F. Hutton & Company.

title: KARPOV'S PRECISION PLAY STAVES OFF KASPOROV
description: Gary Kasparov probed for a tactical piercing of Anatoly Karpov's formation in the third game of their world chess title match in Moscow's Tchaikovsky Concert Hall on Tuesday, but precision play by the 34-year-old champion broke the effort. The 22-year-old challenger accepted a draw after 20 moves.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Archive Corp., Costa Mesa, Calif., which designs cartridge tape drives for computers, said J. Peter Wilson had been elected president and chief operating officer, succeeding D. Howard Lewis, who continues as chairman and chief executive.

title: The Missing Seven
description: Israel has now freed the last Lebanese and Palestinians whose release was demanded in June by hijackers of a T.W.A. airliner. They freed the last 39 American passengers on a tacit understanding that Israel would hold to its previous promise to liberate 766 captives taken from Lebanon.

title: E.D.S. Contract
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, said it had been awarded a contract valued at more than $200 million to carry out an office automation priject for the Agriculture Department.

title: MERRILL UNIT APPEARS TO WIN SCM
description: Merrill Lynch Capital Markets appeared yesterday to have made the winning bid to buy the SCM Corporation, but may yet have a major battle on its hands for the giant typewriter, food and chemical company.

title: EXCERPTS FROM RULING BY FEDERAL APPEALS COURT ON THE WESTWAY PROJECT
description: Following are excerpts from opinions by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit on the appeal to grant a landfill permit for Westway. Judge Richard J. Cardamone wrote the decision, with Judge George C. Pratt concurring. Judge Walter R. Mansfield issued an opinion partly dissenting, partly concurring.

title: MCGOVERN, FOR A FEE, DISARMS ITALIAN COMMUNISTS
description: George S. McGovern addressed the Italian Communist Party Tuesday night, and he said he had no apologies for doing so.

title: Escape Plot Laid To Brink's Convict
description: A woman convicted in the 1981 robbery of a Brink's armored truck conspired to escape from prison and has been ordered confined to an isolated prison cell for two years, officials said today.

title: PARKER ADMITS TO COCAINE USE
description: Dave Parker of the Cincinnati Reds testified in United States District Court today that when he was a member of the Pittsburgh Pirates he arranged cocaine transactions between a Pittsburgh man and players on the Pirates, the Houston Astros and the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Bunker Ramo
description: Bunker Ramo, a subsidiary of the Allied Corporation, introduced a new information network that it described as ''an aggressive repositioning for the company.'' The new network, called Supernet, provides an array of financial information on either special terminals or conventional personal computers. Bunker Ramo, which supplies information to investors, said the new system was being tested and would be operating in five brokerages by the end of the year.

title: 10 FORMER CHOATE STUDENTS PLEAD GUILTY TO FINANCING COCAINE-BUYING TRIP
description: Ten former students at the Choate-Rosemary Hall preparatory school pleaded guilty today to Federal charges of financing a cocaine-buying trip to Venezuela by two other students.

title: Take a Memo
description: President Reagan has chosen a new head for the bureaucratic agency that is charged with improving bureaucratic agencies. He is a New York lawyer, Marshall Jordan Breger, and his new job is to be chairman of the Administrative Conference of the United States.

title: IT'S TIME TO SELECT TULIPS AND DAFFODILS
description: CATALOGUES are showing elegant pictures of tulips and daffodils, and bins at garden centers are starting to fill up. Paying careful attention to the differences in the flowers of these hardy bulbs and in when they bloom can make spring's display longer and more varied.

title: Mexico Appoints Ex-Official As Its New Delegate to U.N.
description: The Government named a new chief delegate to the United Nations today, replacing a diplomat allegedly involved in a window-smashing incident earlier this year.

title: Is This Censorship Or Obeying the Law?
description: To the Editor:

title: COUSIN BRUCIE'S UP FOR THE COUNTDOWN
description: He is 48 years old now, on his second marriage and living in Manhattan, in Greenwich Village no less, for the first time in his life. The skin around his eyes wrinkles when he laughs. But he is still someone who laughs a lot, someone who scans the blackened redfish and blanquette de veau on the menu of a midtown restaurant, then settles on a cheeseburger and shrugs, ''What can I say. I'll always be from Brooklyn.'' Bruce Morrow, in other words, will always be Cousin Brucie. And now, after a seven year absence from the New York radio scene he once dominated as few others have, Cousin Brucie is back on the air. Five weeks ago he inaugurated a Saturday night program on WCBS-FM - opening it, by personal tradition, with Chuck Berry's ''Maybelline'' - and last night he brought back the show that made him most famous, the hit song countown.''

title: SCREEN: 'L'ADDITION,' FROM FRANCE
description: ''L'ADDITION,'' which usually translates as ''the bill,'' is the French title of ''The Patsy,'' a new French film with a most particular, cautionary message to deliver to the world:

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: EVERY do-it-yourselfer is sooner or later faced with a job that involves carrying a heavy carton, sheet of paneling or other bulky object. In the commercial and industrial world where this kind of heavy moving takes place daily, employees use labor-saving machines and equipment. But all too often the do-it-yourselfer has to depend on muscle power alone. As a result, amateurs incur thousands of back injuries and strained or pulled muscles each year.

title: Market Place;   Foreign Stocks Draw Attention
description: INSTITUTIONAL investors own an estimated $15.7 billion worth of foreign stocks, compared with $3 billion just five years ago. And investments overseas, according to money managers, promise to grow as pension funds and other institutions diversify their portfolios.

title: Amendment on Veto Approved for Ballot
description: A state appeals court ruled today that a proposed constitutional amendment that would allow the Legislature to void regulations drafted by the Governor or state agencies can appear on the November ballot.

title: Letter: On Transit;   To Keep Express Buses Express
description: To the Editor:

title: American Bombing Victim
description: A New Jersey businessman who was seriously injured two days ago in the explosion of a car bomb detonated by Basque separatists died today, officials of the Red Cross Hospital said. Eugene Ken Brown, 40, an inventory specialist with Johnson and Johnson, the pharmaceutical company, who lived near New Brunswick, was hit in the chest and neck by shrapnel Monday while jogging in the area of the explosion.

title: DEBRIS SHOWS TITANIC LOST HER STERN END
description: Identification of debris scattered on the sea floor a half mile from where the Titanic lies shows that the entire stern end of the giant ocean liner broke off and disintegrated in its sinking, according to Dr. Robert D. Ballard, leader of the expedition that found the ship.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: COMMON GROUND. A Turbulent Decade in the Lives of Three American Families. By J. Anthony Lukas. 659 pages. Knopf. $19.95. THE author's note with which J. Anthony Lukas begins ''Common Ground'' - his fourth book, and his first since ''Nightmare: The Underside of the Nixon Years'' appeared in 1978 -looks perfunctory. ''This is a work of non-fiction,'' the note begins. ''All its characters are real, as are their names, the places where they live, the details of their personal lives. Nothing has been disguised or embellished.''

title: NEW AFFIRMATIVE ACTION DRAFT ON WAY, BROCK SAYS
description: Labor Secretary Bill Brock said today that Administration officials were near agreement on an executive order to end requirements that Federal contractors set numerical hiring goals to remedy the effects of past discrimination against women and members of minority groups.

title: A CELEBRATION CON BRIO OF ITALIAN CREATIVITY
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago Bloomingdale's held its first promotion to showcase Italian wares. Now, Ecco L'Italia, a seven-week event that opens to the public today, is a storewide show celebrating Italy that will not only appeal to confirmed Italophiles but also should garner additional devotees. The energy, bravura and good taste of Italy's classic and modern wares are represented in everything from fashion to food to home furnishings.

title: STANFORD AND HOOVER INSTITUTE AT ODDS AGAIN
description: Antagonism between Stanford University and the Hoover Institution for the Study of War, Revolution and Peace. has boiled over again. This time the dispute involves charges by a Vietnam War hero that a course he planned to teach at Stanford had been canceled because of his ties to Hoover.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Toronto Blue Jays, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. (Television -Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio, WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. (Television -SportsChannel, 1:30 P.M. Radio -WHN, 1050; 1:30 P.M.) Braves vs.

title: U.S. AIDE SAYS G.T.E. CASE IS PART OF CRACKDOWN
description: A senior Justice Department official said today that the prosecution of a major defense contractor on charges of illegally conspiring to obtain internal Pentagon documents is part of the Reagan Administration's broader, continuing effort to restrict unauthorized use of secret information.

title: CITIZENSHIP PLAN OFFERED BY BOTHA
description: President P. W. Botha said today that the Government was prepared to discuss steps to restore the citizenship rights of nearly 10 million blacks.

title: BID TO TOUGHEN PRETORIA CURBS FAIL IN SENATE
description: The Senate Republican leadership blocked a Democratic effort today to force the Senate to vote on the Congressional version of economic sanctions against the Government of South Africa.

title: FROM FRUGAL TO FANCY, SOAP DISHES OF ALL SORTS
description: UNUSUAL handmade soap dishes in many finishes, including brass, gold, chrome, pewter and nickel, can be found at P. E. Guerin. Prices vary according to the finish; for instance, a scallop-shaped soap dish with a gold finish costs $195.

title: ATTACKS BY WHITES ON MINORITIES CAUSING CONCERN IN BRITISH CITIES
description: In the vast expanses of deteriorating public housing and small shops of London's East End and in other British cities, alarm has been growing over attacks by whites on Asians and other minorities.

title: Educational Campaign On Tobacco Chewing
description: Facing the threat of mandatory health warnings on its products, the Smokeless Tobacco Council has started an educational program aimed at preventing kids from chewing the stuff.

title: 'THE BIKO INQUEST' ON SHOWTIME
description: WHILE South Africa's apartheid society continues to erupt in violence, the nation's past also refuses to lie still. Steve Biko, a 30-year-old black activist leader, died in 1977 while in the custody of the South African security police. His was the 45th known death connected with detention by the security police since 1963. But the case of Mr. Biko was different. He was a rising star in the anti-apartheid movement, described by white and black supporters alike as ''a moral force.'' The official reason for his death was ''brain injury.'' But reports of cover-ups and medical neglect triggered so much international outrage that the Government ordered an inquest to prove that there had been ''no act of omission'' involving any person in authority.

title: Basques, From Boise
description: Just about every ethnic group eventually comes to Washington, but relatively little is seen or heard from the Basque people of northern Spain.

title: Back Up, At Last
description: After an absence of 14 months, Tim Leary, the onetime Met phenom, is back in the major leagues, one of seven players called up by Milwaukee yesterday. He has not appeared in a big-league game since July 6, 1984, when he got a no-decision in an outing for New York against Cincinnati. Five days later he was shipped to Tidewater, and six months after that he was traded to the Brewers, for whom his Triple A numbers this season were 10-7 and 4.00.

title: VIDEO-ERA ROCK CROWDS ARE PASSIVE
description: TOMORROW, the cable channel MTV will pat itself on the back with its second Video Music Awards - a show that takes for granted a transformation of the rock-concert audience.

title: MITTERRAND GOING TO PACIFIC ATOLL
description: The Government has announced that President Francois Mitterrand will leave Thursday for the Pacific nuclear testing site of Mururoa.

title: For Whom Bell Toils
description: Did someone high up at E.F. Hutton know about the company's check-kiting crimes and go scot-free?

title: Manville Meeting Petition Denied
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge blocked an effort to force Manville Corporation to hold a shareholders meeting.

title: Tax Plan Is a Step Toward Industrial Stagnation
description: To the Editor:

title: KETCHUM & CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After tax credits of $102,000 for the latest quarter and $67,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Saudi Denial On Yamani
description: A rumor that Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the Saudi Arabian oil minister, had been assassinated or died of an illness is unfounded, Saudi officials said today.

title: VICTORIOUS KOCH STARTS CAMPAIGN LIKELY TO COST LESS THAN PRIMARY
description: Hours after his sweeping victory in Tuesday's Democratic primary, Mayor Koch was back shaking hands with subway riders at an East Side IRT station yesterday, beginning what is likely to be a less hotly contested and considerably less expensive general-election campaign.

title: SENATE AIDE CALLS BASE SECURITY LAX
description: American military bases in the Philippines are poorly protected and are extremely vulnerable to terrorist attack, according to a Senate report sent to Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger this week.

title: HERS
description: TOLSTOY'S departure from home was certainly a flurried one. If a man of means, who is also a genius, who is also in his 80's, cannot leave in broad daylight then we know we are in a dangerous predicament. Leaving home is always a mess, regardless of whether it be husband, wife, lover, friend, child or cleaner. Whether it is done precipitously or with what is laughingly called ''deliberation,'' the moment is never right and the person who is left is rarely able to stomach the need for flight. Not that he, or she, who happens to be leaving understands it either, and there I think is the crux of the matter. We do not quite utterly want to leave, we want to leave for the most part, but there is one small tug that keeps us behind. It is not love, it is not even decency, it is either terror or that nice dull daily balm known as habit.

title: INTERGROUP, LEUCADIA IN ACCORD
description: National Intergroup Inc., pulling a thorn out of its corporate side, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Leucadia National Corporation to buy 75 percent of the National Intergroup stock held by Leucadia.

title: 9.45% Note Issue From Sperry Unit
description: The Sperry Lease Finance Corporation is offering $145.8 million of 9.45 percent lease-backed notes with final maturity in 1991 and an estimated average life of 2.4 years through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Yields Steady on C.D.'s, Bank Money Accounts
description: Rates on certificates of deposit, money market mutual funds and money market accounts continued to hold firm for the week ended yesterday.

title: SECOND LOVER'S TESTIMONY APPEARS CRUCIAL IN F.B.I. SPY CASE
description: At first it seemed like overkill when when prosecutors called to the witness stand a second lover of Richard W. Miller, who is on trial here accused of passing classified documents to the Soviet Union by way of his Russian lover.

title: Let's Raise the Level of All, Not Just Some, of Our Police Officers
description: To the Editor:

title: RISE IN WESTCHESTER RENTS VOTED
description: The Westchester Rent Guidelines Board voted 5 to 3 tonight to allow rent increases of 6 percent for one-year leases and 10 percent for two-year leases, ending a two-year rent freeze in the county.

title: SCHWARTZ BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After tax credits of $45,594, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and $104,147, or 13 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $32,140, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $51,140, or 6 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: SENATORS HEAR PHONE INDUSTRY PLEAS
description: It is too soon to deregulate the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's long-distance rates, and too late to change the basic rules for conversion to a competitive long-distance telephone industry, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, Mark S. Fowler, told a Senate panel today.

title: FILM: 'JOYCE'S WOMEN,' WITH FIONNULA FLANAGAN
description: AS ''James Joyce's Women'' -those who influenced his life and those who appeared in his writings - the Irish actress Fionnula Flanagan has an opportunity to recite some of Mr. Joyce's most famous passages, and to recreate some of her own earlier roles. Miss Flanagan played Gerty MacDowell in Joseph Strick's film of ''Ulysses,'' and Molly Bloom in the 1973 Broadway production of ''Ulysses in Nighttown.''

title: NEW EVIDENCE, OLD DEBATE
description: By learning the exact position of the sunken steamship Titanic, scientists have essentially corroborated historical testimony that the ocean liner Californian could easily have gone to the stricken ship's assistance.

title: ROSE GETS A SINGLE TO BREAK COBB'S CAREER MARK FOR HITS
description: Ten miles from the sandlots where he began playing baseball as a boy, Pete Rose, now 44 years old and in his 23d season in the major leagues, stepped to the plate tonight in the first inning at Riverfront Stadium. He came to bat on this warm, gentle evening with the chance to make baseball history.

title: A DIVORCED FATHER, A CHILD, AND A SUMMER VISIT TOGETHER
description: AFTER speeding from his home in Vermont to the Boston airport, Jeffrey Aronson could not reach the gate to meet his 15-year-old daughter, Blake, who was flying in from New Orleans for her annual visit. Held back in the crowd, he eventually spotted her.

title: Canadian Province Bans 7 American Wines
description: Three wines from the state of Washington and four from Oregon have been taken off the shelves of British Columbia liquor stores because they contain levels of the pesticide Mesurol that ''slightly'' exceed Canadian standards of acceptability, according to a Canadian health official.

title: A Bank Form To Cite Fraud
description: Seeking to encourage the banking industry to improve reporting of fraud and money laundering, the Government has approved a standardized form for disclosing these and other suspected crimes.

title: LOTUS IS FACING A CRITICAL TIME
description: The personal computer on Alexander Crosett's desk at the Lotus Development Corporation let out a piercing shriek this morning and Mr. Crosett, one of the company's marketing managers, rushed over and found that Lotus's stock price had just set a new low for the year. The decline was only the latest round in a selling spree fueled by reports that the industry's troubles have finally caught up with the seemingly invincible leader of personal computer software.

title: GLAZED CHINTZES STAR
description: MARIO BUATTA's glazed chintzes for Fabriyaz and John Saladino's furniture for Baker are the stars in Lord & Taylor's new model rooms.

title: BOBBIE BROOKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
THAILAND SUDDENLY ORDERS A SHIFT OF TROOPS
description: The Thai Government suddenly moved tanks and troops into the compound surrounding the country's military headquarters here today, two days after the collapse of an attempted coup in which four people were killed and about 60 wounded.

title: McDonnell Order
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation is being awarded four Navy contracts totaling $498.3 million, the Defense Department said.

title: MARCADE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
description: b-Includes $824,000 income from discontinued operations.

title: SQUIRMING CHILDREN HARD TO FINGERPRINT
description: Fingerprinting is an important tool in searching for missing children, but the authorities across Vermont say a state law passed this year requiring perfect prints is ''next to impossible'' to obey.

title: DR. JAMES D. HARDY: PHYSIOLOGIST STUDIED BODY TEMPERATURES
description: Dr. James D. Hardy, a physiologist and leading researcher on body temperature and the measurement of pain, died last Friday at his home in Woodbridge, Conn. He was 81 years old.

title: EX-CUOMO AIDE URGES SHOREHAM SAFETY TEST
description: Governor Cuomo's former Transportation Commissioner called today for an ''independent third party'' to observe and assess a test of emergency preparedness for the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: PULLMAN CHIEF TELLS OF POSNER CASH OFFER
description: Victor Posner, the Miami-based financier, personally offered the chief executive of the Pullman Company an extraordinary $10 million payment in August to abandon a merger agreement with the Peabody International Corporation and persuade Peabody instead to merge with a Posner company, according to a sworn statement by the executive filed in Federal District Court in New Haven.

title: HOUSE VOTES BY BIG MARGIN TO BAR FUNDS FOR WESTWAY
description: The House of Representatives voted today to block funds for the Westway project.

title: BLUE JAYS AND YANKEES: CAN PITCHERS STOP HITTERS?
description: They do not have a dominant player like a Don Mattingly or a Rickey Henderson anywhere in their lineup. Nor do they have any players who have become household names, at least not in this country. Very likely, there are even places in Canada where the names Bell, Moseby and Barfield or Upshaw, Garcia, Fernandez, Mulliniks, Iorg and Whitt don't mean anything. Yet the Toronto Blue Jays are in first place in the American League East and they have been in first place since May 13.

title: 2 APPOINTMENTS URGED FOR THE PORT AUTHORITY
description: Governor Cuomo met yesterday with Port Authority commissioners and asked them to pick a new top command - Steven Berger as executive director and Philip D. Kaltenbacher as chairman.

title: SOUTH AFRICA ORDERS OUSTER OF U.S. MAGAZINE REPORTER
description: A correspondent for Newsweek magazine was ordered deported from South Africa tonight for what the Government said were ''distortions'' and ''unfair reportage.''

title: China Currency Scheme
description: A group of ''entrepreneurs'' in central China made a fortune by buying $480,000 at the official rate and then selling the currency on the black market for nearly a 100 percent profit, a newspaper said. The official Hubei provincial daily said the four participants had set up a front company and obtained approval to import machinery valued at $480,000. They were thus permitted to buy the currency at official rates.

title: RALSTONE R. IRVINE, A LAWYER, 87
description: Ralstone R. Irvine, a founding partner of the New York City law firm of Donovan Leisure Newton & Irvine, died yesterday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 87 years old.

title: CALENDAR: A FLOCK OF HARVEST EVENTS
description: By Harvest Festival, the Horticultural Society of New York, 128 West 58th Street, 212-757-0915.

title: Hockey Rookies Report
description: A total of 77 rookies and free agents reported to the Rangers and Devils yesterday, passed their physical examinations and will start skating this morning. Forty-four players showed up at the Ranger training facility in Rye, N.Y., and 33 reported to the Devils in Totowa, N.J.

title: BROOKLYN BOTANIC PLANS ANNIVERSARY LECTURES
description: TO celebrate its 75th anniversary, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden is holding a symposium entitled ''Growing in America - New Horizons in Horticulture'' on Sept. 27 and 28. In it, eight panelists will discuss gardening techniques, landscape design and tree maintenance.

title: UNLUCKY STEP FOR STAR RUNNER
description: Some people are calling it the modern Heisman Trophy jinx. Others just say that's football. Whatever it is, Keith Byars of Ohio State is the latest victim of an early-season injury to a leading candidate for that most coveted of college football's individual awards.

title: U.S. Sets Auction Of 2-Year Notes
description: The Treasury Department announced plans yesterday to sell $9.25 billion of new two-year notes next Wednesday. Although Treasury officials are seeking an increase in the Federal debt limit, they estimate that there is enough unused debt capacity to hold the regular monthly auction of two-year notes.

title: IDENTITY OD SALVADORAN KIDNAPPERS UNKNOWN
description: Salvadoran officials said today that the kidnappers of the daughter of President Jose Napoleon Duarte had not made contact with the Government and that their identity was unknown.

title: DEFENSE IMPUGNS NURSE'S CLAIMS IN STEWART CASE
description: Defense attorneys in the trial of six transit police officers charged in the death of Michael Stewart called into question yesterday the objectivity of a prosecution witness who previously had retained the Stewart family attorney.

title: OFFICIAL DEFENDS SPACE-WEAPON TEST
description: A senior Government official, defending a decision to proceed with a test of an anti-satellite weapon, insisted today that the Reagan Administration had complied with a Congressional order that it delay any testing until it had made a ''good faith'' effort to negotiate limitations on the weapons.

title: Fighting Said to Spread In Northern Chad
description: Fighting between anti-Government rebels and their Libyan allies has spread to another town in northern Chad, the Government-controlled Ndjamena radio said today.

title: The U.N. Today: Sept. 12, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee to Review International Development Strategy - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: S.E.C. Rebukes Merrill Lynch
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said that it had censured Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. for failing to adequately supervise a broker at its San Francisco branch.

title: NICARAGUAN REBEL TELLS OF KILLINGS AS DEVICE FOR FORCED RECRUITMENT
description: A former Nicaraguan rebel says in a court affidavit that the rebels routinely forcibly recruited new guerrillas by publicly killing Government officials and their sympathizers in small Nicaraguan towns.

title: TEXAN PUT TO DEATH FOR A MURDER COMMITTED AT 17
description: Charles Rumbaugh, convicted of a murder he committed in a robbery at the age of 17, was put to death today in an execution a human rights group charged violated international agreements.

title: Businesses' Concerns
description: The main concerns of small business owners looking to 1986 are high taxes and interest rates, according to a national survey by Southwest State University's Small Business Development Center. The questionnaire was sent to 5,000 small businesses, with a 62 percent return, according to Al Hattis, director of the Small Business Development Center. Respondents listed Government regulations and red tape as the second-biggest concern, followed by low sales, competition from large business, and the quality and cost of available labor.

title: Detroit Mayor Is Victor In Primary by 2 to 1
description: Mayor Coleman A. Young, seeking a fourth term, crushed his nearest opponent by more than a 2-to-1 margin Tuesday in Detroit's nonpartisan primary.

title: 29 Miners Killed in China
description: A gas explosion in a coal mine last month killed 29 miners and seriously injured 14, the official English-language China Daily reported today. It was the second fatal accident in two months at Xinzhuangzi coal mine in the city of Huainan in Anhui Province.

title: The Next Mayor Koch
description: After winning a second-term primary by a disappointing margin, Edward Koch can now look confidently to becoming New York's third three-term Mayor.
