In Tuesday's Democratic primary, still lamentably the decisive vote in this one-party town, Mr. Koch certainly solved his political problems. He drew two of every three votes, won all but four of the 60 Assembly districts and got as many black votes as the candidate of an uncoalesced minority coalition. That triumph should inspire a most creative third term, but there's no guarantee that it will.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are not going to sacrifice 946,000 children to have 1 in a classroom.'' - Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones. [B11:3.]

title: WHITE HOUSE MAPS BILL TO STEM TIDE OF PROTECTIONISM
description: The White House assured Republican Congressional leaders today that it was drafting new proposals for trade legislation in an effort to head off protectionist measures pending on Capitol Hill.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, 1985
description: International

title: FOR SISK, DARKNESS IS BEGINNING TO LIFT
description: Following a trip that held the first professional rewards he had experienced in a long time, Doug Sisk returned to the Met clubhouse at Shea Stadium Tuesday night. He had pitched two perfect innings at Los Angeles Sunday afternoon. He had been responsible for five ground balls from the six hitters he retired. He had earned a victory over the Dodgers in a 14-inning game that held all the tension of postseason play.

title: THE ZESTFUL CURATOR OF 'INDIA'
description: One day, while traveling to gather works of art for ''India!'', the exhibition that opens Saturday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Stuart Cary Welch, the show's curator, found himself in a crowded bazaar in a village in East India.

title: Mets, From Washington
description: Many sports fans in the Washington area are in the slough of despond these days. The Washington Redskins lost to the hated Dallas Cowboys in their first game.

title: A Correction
description: An editorial about the voting rights act last Friday incorrectly stated that Senator Orrin Hatch of Utah led the eight Senators who opposed a key 1982 amendment. Senator Hatch voted against the amendment in the Subcommittee on Constitutional Rights, which he leads, and again, in dissent, in the full Judiciary Committee.

title: IMMIGRATION BILL WEIGHED IN SENATE
description: For the third time in four years the Senate today began debating a comprehensive bill designed to curtail illegal immigration.

title: CORRECTION
description: A television review on Tuesday of ''No Greater Gift,'' on ABC, misidentified the actor who played the father of a boy with a brain tumor. He was Reni Santoni.

title: Muncie Retires
description: Chuck Muncie, the running back who had been trying to make a comeback with the Minnesota Vikings after serving a one-year suspension for involvement with drugs, said yesterday that he had decided to retire.

title: Connecticut Colleges Face Tuition Increase
description: Tuition at Connecticut's public colleges and universities would rise an average of 10 percent under the proposed 1986-87 budget approved by the Board of Governors for Higher Education.

title: METS LOSE IN 10 AS TUDOR TOSSES HIS NINTH SHUTOUT
description: On a night when Dwight Gooden pitched nine scoreless innings of five-hit ball, the Mets lost a classic game as well as undisputed possession of first place because John Tudor pitched 10 scoreless innings of three-hit ball and his third straight shutout for the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: What Lester Cole Really Wrote About Resistance
description: To the Editor:

title: COCAINE RISK SEEN IN PREGNANCY
description: Cocaine use may be dangerous for pregnant women and their babies, causing spontaneous abortions, developmental disorders and life-threatening complications during birth, doctors reported today.

title: CORN HARVEST OUTLOOK
description: This fall's record corn harvest will be even larger than had been expected, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: QUINONES SETS A POLICY ON AIDS, CITING ILLNESS AMONG 8 EMPLOYEES
description: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones announced procedures yesterday for dealing with New York City public school students and staff members suffering from AIDS.

title: Bailout Plan for EPIC Gets Mixed Reactions
description: The reactions yesterday to the Ticor Mortgage Insurance Company's bailout plan for the ailing EPIC group of real estate and mortgage companies were mixed. While saying the plan made a good start, some of the participants, who asked not to be named, said that any ''work out'' will require more cash payments by Ticor and the other private mortgage insurers involved with EPIC's $1.4 billion in mortgages.

title: Get Much Tougher With South Africa
description: President Reagan's executive order imposing limited sanctions against the white regime in South Africa has been criticized as weak, tardy and probably ineffective. The sanctions fell short of what Congress wanted and failed to include a Congressional plea for automatic further sanctions in 12 months should South Africa fail to make significant reforms. But what the order also revealed was that the Administration's analysis of the depth and causes of the crisis in South Africa remains grievously flawed.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Autistic Man Missing On Adirondack Trek
description: An autistic man from Ohio has been lost five days in the Adirondacks.

title: Ross Roy Adds Griswold of Cleveland
description: Ross Roy of Detroit, with current billings of $290 million, and Griswold Inc. of Cleveland, with $38 million, have agreed to merge, after which the smaller shop will continue to operate, for a while at least, under its current name.

title: Submit Nicaragua Policy to Public Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: CENTENNIAL FESTIVAL HONORS WILDERNESS
description: This weekend's New York State Forest Preserve Centennial Festival at Lake Placid is part of a yearlong celebration of the creation a century ago of a forever-inviolate wilderness area - the largest one east of the Mississippi.

title: A JEWISH GROUP IS AIRLIFTING AID TO MOZAMBIQUE
description: A Jewish relief group founded in May to provide aid to developing nations without regard to religion began its efforts yesterday with an airlift of $750,000 in medical supplies to Mozambique.

title: CEDENO A HIT WITH CARDINALS
description: Jesse Orosco did not speak last night, except to quietly acknowledge the pitch he threw to Cesar Cedeno, the pitch that cost the Mets an important game at Shea Stadium. And when he had done that, he turned back to his game of cards with Rusty Staub, where he tried to lose himself and forget the events that had transpired just moments earlier.

title: ITALIAN EX-AGENT ORDERED EXTRADITED FROM U.S.
description: A former Italian intelligence official, in jail in New York since March, was ordered extradited to Italy yesterday to face financial fraud charges growing out of the 1981 bankruptcy of the Italian Banco Ambrosiano.

title: Arthel Watson Wins North Carolina Prize
description: Arthel (Doc) Watson, a guitarist and singer, has been chosen to receive this year's North Carolina Prize for outstanding work in the performing arts, according to John R. Harrison, president of The New York Times Company's regional newspaper group.

title: Semiconductor Shipments Up
description: Semiconductor shipments increased slightly during August, while there was a small drop in orders, the Semiconductor Industry Association said yesterday.

title: Foreign Veterans Share U.S. Award
description: A Federal judge decided yesterday that Australian and New Zealand veterans of the Vietnam War could share in a fund set up to help American victims of the herbicide Agent Orange.

title: FINAL HOUSE TAX ACTION BY OCT. 31 A POSSIBILITY
description: The House Ways and Means Committee today announced a legislative schedule that could lead to House passage of a tax bill by the end of October.

title: AMERICAN CENTURY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After reversals of prior tax credits of $394,000 for the latest quarter and $340,000 for the year-earlier period. c-After a gain of $236,000 on stock dividends from the Federal Home Loan Bank. d-After a tax credit of $5,467,000.

title: PAUL J. FLORY, NOBEL LAUREATE IN CHEMISTRY, DIES ON COAST
description: Paul J. Flory, a Nobel laureate in chemistry who used his prize in a passionate battle for human rights, died of a heart attack Monday. He was 75 years old.

title: Federal Inspections Ordered At Carbide Plant in Institute
description: Labor Secretary Bill Brock has ordered the inspection of all equipment at the Union Carbide Corporation's plant here, where a leak last month sent 135 people to the hospital.

title: GROWING CONCERNS ABOUT AIR SAFETY: QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS ABOUT RECORD TOLL OF DEATHS
description: This summer's run of airline disasters and the record-breaking toll of deaths so far this year have raised questions about the safety of air travel.

title: Charge Dropped For Goetz Victim
description: A state judge has dismissed an armed-robbery charge against a young man left paralyzed when he was shot by Bernhard H. Goetz.

title: Iraq Reports New Raid On Iranian Oil Depot
description: Iraq said its jets carried out a ''devastating raid'' on the Iranian oil terminal at Kharg island today, but Iran said it thwarted the attempt and a surface-to-air missile downed one of two Iraqi warplanes that violated Iranian airspace.

title: Textron Unit Sold To Ingersoll-Rand
description: Textron Inc. said that it had sold its Fafnir Bearing division to the Ingersoll-Rand Company for an undisclosed price.

title: MANDELA ADVISED TO HAVE SURGERY
description: Doctors have advised Nelson Mandela, the jailed black leader, to have an operation to remove an enlarged prostate gland, his daughter said today. She said Mr. Mandela also has cysts on his liver and right kidney.

title: SIR ELLIS WATERHOUSE, AUTHOR AND HISTORIAN OF BRITISH ART
description: Sir Ellis Waterhouse, the acknowledged dean of British art historians, a teacher and former director of the National Galleries of Scotland and the Barber Institute, died of a heart attack at his home in Oxford, England, on Saturday. He was 80 years old.

title: ALEXA KENIN
description: Alexa Kenin, an actress on stage and television and in motion pictures, died at her apartment in Manhattan on Tuesday. She was 23 years old, and the cause of death was not immediately known.

title: AN ERA ENDS AT SCHLUMBERGER
description: Jean Riboud, the dynamic chairman and chief executive of Schlumberger Ltd., who once told an interviewer that leaving the giant oilfield services company ''would be like trying to shake an oyster off a rock,'' stepped down yesterday, ending a 20-year era of leadership.

title: 'Let Me See My Parents'
description: He sits each day from about 8 A.M. to 6 P.M. on a busy corner at K and 16th Streets, the sun beating down, the traffic rushing by as he sips his water and smokes his cigarettes. The placard beside him reads: ''I am on hunger-strike. Soviets, let me see my parents. Free Sakharovs.''

title: POLL FINDS MANY AIDS FEARS THAT THE EXPERTS SAY ARE GROUNDLESS
description: About half the American people believe AIDS can be transmitted through casual contact despite what Federal scientists say is overwhelming evidence to the contrary, according to The New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Hagler Denied
description: Marvin Hagler, the World Boxing Association middleweight champion, has lost a round in his effort to fight John Mugabi without jeopardizing his W.B.A. title.

title: CONSOLIDATED STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $200,000 for the quarter and $500,000 for the 6 months from the sale of auto parts stores.

title: Air New Zealand
description: The International Lease Finance Corporation said it had agreed to buy six Boeing 737-200 aircraft and two McDonnell-Douglas DC-10-30 aircraft from Air New Zealand for more than $90 million.

title: Early Retirement For Bank Official
description: Lloyd J. Sugaski, the executive vice president in charge of loan policy at the troubled Bank of America, announced yesterday that he would take early retirement. Mr. Sugaski is 62 years old and the normal retirement age is 65.

title: CITY OPERA IN DRIVE FOR NEW COSTUMES
description: The New York City Opera has established a Fire Emergency Fund campaign to raise $5 million to replace its costumes lost in a fire Sept. 2 in Passaic, N.J.

title: Quake Hits Chicago Suburbs, Bringing Reports of Damage
description: An earthquake that a police officer said sounded ''like a deep tunnel explosion'' shook Chicago's suburbs Monday.

title: Jersey Delays Murder Trial
description: The trial of two men charged with murdering a state trooper has been postponed until after the suspects are tried in New York on bombing charges, state law-enforcement officials said today. The suspects, Thomas W. Manning and Richard C. Williams, will probably not be tried in New Jersey until next year, said Col. Clinton L. Pagano, the Superintendent of the state police. The trooper, Philip Lamonaco, was shot to death along Route 80 in Warren County on Dec. 21, 1981.

title: Accounts
description: * Bear, Stearns & Co., to Korey, Kay & Partners for its municipal unit investment trust advertising.

title: Good Reason
description: Coach Leeman Bennett of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, asked to cite one reason why the signing of Steve Young was worth two months of agonizing negotiations, comes up with three: ''Mind, feet and arm.''

title: Resorts Increases Pan Am Holding
description: Resorts International Inc. has increased its stake in the Pan Am Corporation to 12 million shares, or 9 percent of the shares outstanding.

title: SUICIDE CAR BOMB IN SOUTH LEBANON
description: A suicide car bomber crashed her vehicle into a checkpoint just outside the so-called Israeli security zone today. Estimates of casualties differed.

title: DOW SLIDES 14.01 POINTS, TO 1,319.44
description: A complex technical trading maneuver by major institutional investors, together with concern about the economy and interest rates, caused the stock market yesterday to suffer its biggest single-day loss in nearly five weeks.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Lee MacPhail, who has had a memorable career in organized baseball, has been assured that he would be remembered long after his career is over. Bobby Brown, who succeeded MacPhail as president of the American League, announced that the trophy honoring the most valuable player in the league championship playoffs would be known as ''the Leland S. MacPhail Jr. Award.'' . . . Billy Paultz, the former St. John's star who spent 15 seasons as a professional, will not be invited back to the Utah Jazz training camp because the club says it was looking for younger players. . . . At 37 years old, Mike Boit, the Kenyan middle distance runner, plans to retire and devote his time to coaching.

title: TAX PLAN IS A STEP TOWARD INDUSTRIAL STAGNATION
description: To the Editor:

title: DECORATOR OR INTERIOR DESIGNER
description: THE rule is clear - only professionals are allowed to make purchases in the to-the-trade home-furnishings showrooms. But the question remains - exactly what is a professional interior designer or decorator?

title: Keeble Wins Trump
description: Keeble Cavaco & Duka, one of the 1985 crop of new agencies, which is already serving Bergdorf Goodman and the designer Bill Robinson, has now been assigned the $1.5 million Trump Tower Atrium account. The former agency was Chillingworth, Radding.

title: R2 CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
North Little Rock Revenue Bonds
description: North Little Rock, Ark., is offering $139.1 million of electric system revenue bonds for the Murray Lock and Dam Hydroelectric Project, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: ARMY WINS CASE ON RECRUITMENT
description: In a case watched closely by military officials, educators and advocates of homosexual rights, a Federal judge held today that rules barring homosexuals from the armed forces took precedence over conflicting local antidiscrimination laws.

title: SCIENTISTS MAP OUT COMMON COLD BUG
description: Scientists reported today that they had determined the three-dimensional structure of a common cold virus in exquisitely small detail, measured in atoms, thus opening the way for a new line of attack on one of the most widespread and elusive disease-causing viruses known.

title: FREQUENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, 1985
description: The Economy

title: 15 Are Chosen for Jury In Trial of Racist Group
description: Nine women and six men were selected today to hear the Federal racketeering trial of 11 white supremacists accused of plotting against minority groups and the Government.

title: RESDEL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Population Institute Sets Multimedia Drive
description: The Washington-based Population Institute will begin what it considers to be an educational multimedia campaign in New York on Sept. 23 that will then be spread, state by state, until it has run in 16 states.

title: Theater Wing Meets With Tony Producer
description: The Board of Directors of the American Theater Wing met last night with Alexander H. Cohen, the producer of the Tony Award telecast for almost two decades. The Wing postponed a decision on renewing its contract with the League of American Theater Producers and will meet with League representatives Oct. 10.

title: SEAMAN FURNITURE reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
GRAHAM-MCCORMICK OIL & GAS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago period results include only the five months ended June 30 because Graham-McCormick became a partnership on Jan. 31, 1984.

title: U.S. APPEALS COURT UPHOLDS DECISION TO HALT WESTWAY
description: A Federal appeals court dealt a serious setback to the Westway project yesterday by substantially affirming a lower-court order that barred the project's construction.

title: BUSINESS SCALE BACK SPENDING PLANS FOR 1985
description: American businesses have scaled back even more on their projected spending for expansion and modernization this year, the Government said today.

title: Appeal Extended
description: Prosecutors in New Orleans have been given an extra week to seek reinstatement of charges against John (Hot Rod) Williams, the former Tulane basketball star who had been accused of sports bribery in a point-shaving scheme. Judge Alvin V. Oser, who dismissed the charges after declaring a mistrial because of misconduct by the prosecutors, had originally set yesterday as a deadline for an appeal of the ruling. He extended the deadline to Sept. 18.

title: GERIATRIC & MEDICAL CENTERS INC reports earnings for Year to May 31
Russian on World Court Resigns in Poor Health
description: Platon D. Morozov of the Soviet Union, one of the two Eastern-bloc judges at the World Court, has resigned because of ''a serious deterioration in his health,'' a spokesman for the court said. Judge Morozov is 79 years old.

title: Florida Official Blocks Clemency for Wife-Killer
description: A Florida Cabinet member refused today to drop his opposition to clemency for a 76-year-old man who said he killed his wife to end her suffering.

title: 2 Escapees Free 33 Hostages
description: Two escaped prisoners facing murder charges overpowered their guards Wednesday and ran into a downtown hospital, where they held at least 33 people hostage for seven hours before surrendering early this morning, the authorities said.

title: MEMBERS ONLY: INSIDE NEW YORK'S WORLD OF DESIGN
description: THE interior design industry in New York is a closed world and eager to stay that way. That, at least, is the opinion of Susan Freedman who is vice president of Clarence House, a wholesale decorative fabric company. She is the first to admit that she might be called a snob.

title: Some Issues Settled in Strike Against Philadelphia Papers
description: The largest of nine unions striking The Philadelphia Inquirer and Daily News settled noneconomic issues today as talks also resumed with other unions.

title: OFFICERS IN COURT IN ARGENTINE TRIAL
description: The nine military officers who governed Argentina during six violent years stood together for the first time today in a civilian courtroom accused as criminals. They are charged with murder, torture and kidnapping in the disappearances of more than 9,000 Argentines.

title: PATHOLOGIST SAYS TESTS ON BELUSHI SHOWED DRUGS
description: The pathologist who performed the autopsy on John Belushi testified today that while the comedian died of acute heroin and cocaine poisoning he could not say if the fatal dose had been administered by the woman charged with murdering him.

title: BLUE JAYS WIN, 3-2
description: Lloyd Moseby singled in Tony Fernandez from second base with one out in the seventh inning tonight to break a 2-2 tie and give the Toronto Blue Jays a 3-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

title: RIOTING DIES OUT IN CITY IN ENGLAND
description: Calm returned to the broken streets of Handsworth today as workers cleared debris and families who fled during two nights of rioting returned home.

title: More Than Just a Pump
description: Michael Drummond, the latest recipient of an artificial heart, is reported by his father to be glowing with restored health. But that's after receiving a transplanted human heart to replace the mechanical one that in his case was used just as a stopgap. Maybe that's the best use for artificial hearts, at least in their present stage of evolution.

title: Hepatitis A Found Near Alfred U.
description: Twelve cases of hepatitis A have been confirmed in the Wellsville area, and the disease has spread to Alfred, 12 miles away, Allegany County health officials said.

title: TERA CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
SANKAI JUKU ENDS TOUR
description: The Japanese avant-garde dance troupe Sankai Juku has canceled the rest of its 10-city United States tour following the death of one of its dancers during the company's opening performance in Seattle on Tuesday.

title: U.S. SPACECRAFT FLIES SAFELY THROUGH TAIL OF DISTANT COMET
description: A hardy little spacecraft, the International Cometary Explorer, flew unscathed through the tail of a distant comet today in mankind's first close encounter with one of these dazzling, enigmatic wanderers of the solar system.

title: Systems for Merrill
description: The Rich Inc. unit of Reuters Holdings P.L.C. said it had sold about 1,200 computerized work stations to Merrill Lynch & Company for $18 million. The work stations are to be installed in Merrill Lynch's main trading center in its new headquarters in the World Financial Center.

title: NEW EPISCOPAL HEAD SEES MORE ACTIVE ROLE ON SOCIAL ISSUES
description: The newly elected Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church says he believes Episcopalians now want the church to play a more vigorous role in combating hunger, unemployment, racism and the arms race.

title: TRITON GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-The company said it had no sales because it did not have any operating companies in 1984 after emerging from Chapter 11, but subsequently acquired the Simplicity Pattern Co. and Republic Corp. c-After tax credits of $1,509,000 for the quarter and $4,278,000 for the 6 months. d-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $7 million.

title: EDWARD R. DOWNING
description: Edward R. Downing, a former trial attorney for the United States Justice Department's admiralty and shipping section in New York City, died Saturday at a nursing home in Miami.

title: Harrison Williams To Leave Prison
description: Harrison A. Williams Jr., the former United States Senator from New Jersey, will be released from prison Jan. 31 after serving a little more than two years for his Abscam bribery and conspiracy conviction, a prison spokesman said today.

title: South African Reality
description: Events in South Africa have brought one old argument to a sudden end. Is the South African economy vulnerable to outside pressure? It is. For years the white minority Government has been telling the world that pressure was useless because it would not be felt. All that talk was blown away when the refusal of some American banks to renew loans started a panic and the Government froze repayment of foreign debts until Jan. 1. It is an extremely vulnerable economy.

title: Jock Stein, 62, Was Manager Of Scotland's Soccer Team
description: Jock Stein, manager of the Scottish national soccer team, collapsed on the sideline and died of a heart attack in the dressing room while his team played Wales in a World Cup qualifying game Tuesday night in Cardiff. He was 62 years old.

title: Ratelle Skates Into Hall of Fame
description: At age 44, four and a half years after skating into retirement, Jean Ratelle comes skating out for a bit of overtime tonight up in Toronto. The occasion is his induction into the Hockey Hall of Fame, and there will be more than a hint of the old days, because, although Rod Gilbert can't make it, Vic Hadfield will be on Ratelle's wing, offering applause this time instead of a set-up for an opportune score.

title: BREWERS HALT YANKS' STREAK
description: Fair or foul, the play was a foul way to end their winning streak at 11 games and drop them another game behind the Toronto Blue Jays, the Yankees thought tonight.

title: WALLACE COMPUTER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Rubbermaid-Gott
description: Rubbermaid Inc. said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the Gott Corporation in an exchange of stock valued at $23 a share, or a total of about $66 million. Both are rubber and plastic products companies. Gott employs 1,500, and Rubbermaid, which is based in Wooster, Ohio, employs 3,800.

title: Hunger Strike Ends
description: One of them was taken to a hospital.

title: INDIAN TREATY STIRS HUNTING DISPUTE
description: There is a bumper sticker on sale for $1 in taverns around here bearing the legend ''The 'Right' is Wrong!'' On the left is a representation of a parchment treaty with the dates 1837 and 1842; on the right is a many-tined fish spear.

title: Football Caucus
description: An update from the world of litigation and legislation:

title: PARACHUTIST DIES WITH COCAINE SACK
description: A parachuting smuggler wearing combat fatigues and carrying pistols and knives plunged to his death today in a backyard when his parachute failed to open, the police said today. At his side was 79 pounds of cocaine.

title: Yankees Drop Bid for Seaver
description: The Yankees' efforts to acquire a veteran starting pitcher have intensified proportionately with the rise in their starters' earned run averages, and today, in their latest bid, they failed to get Tom Seaver from the Chicago White Sox.

title: People
description: * Bert Rosenberg has joined Smith/ Greenland as executive vice president.

title: BUSH URGES RESISTANCE TO PROTECTIONISM
description: Vice President Bush asserted today that legislators trying to enact protectionist trade bills were seeking ''narrow and immediate political gain at a cost of untold economic pain.''

title: New York Fed Hires Financial Consultant
description: In another twist in his varied career, Edwin H. Yeo 3d yesterday left Morgan Stanley & Company, where he was a managing director, to become a consultant to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and a counselor to E. Gerald Corrigan, its president.

title: UNION HIRES AN AGENT FOR U.P.I. SALE NEGOTIATIONS
description: The union representing the dwindling number of reporters and editors at United Press International has hired a prominent adviser to represent their interests in negotiations to sell the financially troubled news agency.

title: Impressions of M. Gorbachev
description: In advance of the Soviet-American summit meeting scheduled for November, some of this country's most experienced politicians have sized up Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, as a seasoned pro with a surprising feel for the idiom and style of American politics.

title: BEAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
description: The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid July 25.

title: HUBBARD REAL ESTATE INVESTENTS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes gains on the sale of real estate of $28,101 for the quarter and $82,932 for the 9 months. c-Includes gains on the sale of real estate of $416,230 for the quarter and $1,653,611 for the 9 months.

title: Charleston, Ill., Strike Halts School for 3,100
description: Teachers in Charleston, Ill., demanding higher pay, went on strike yesterday as walkouts continued in six other states, disrupting classes for more than 110,000 students nationwide.

title: Gulfstream Orders
description: The Chrysler Corporation's Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation said it had received more than 80 orders for its new Gulfstream IV jet, for an order backlog of $1.3 billion. The Gulfstream IV was rolled out of the factory today, 30 days ahead of schedule, the company said. The 19-passenger jet is intended for high-speed, high-altitude and long-range capabilities, suitable for business travel.

title: OFFICIAL SAYS HE BARRED MORE PROSECUTIONS AT LILLY
description: The Deputy Attorney General of the United States acknowledged today that he had overruled staff lawyers who wanted to prosecute three officials of Eli Lilly & Company for failing to disclose deaths and ailments associated with the arthritis drug Oraflex.

title: A Jazzman's Birthday
description: Even Bradley Cunningham had trouble maneuvering through the crowd of musicians and friends at his namesake club. Every few feet, earnest handshakes and affectionate hugs headed off Mr. Cunningham, the soft-spoken owner of Bradley's, at University Place and 11th Street, that has become one of New York's jazz institutions.

title: ST. GERMAIN DEFENDS FINANCES
description: Representative Fernand J. St Germain criticized The Wall Street Journal today for reporting that he has received investment aid from people and institutions that have benefited from his actions as chairman of the House Banking Committee.

title: THE ESSENCE IS TIME ON ITALIAN FILM
description: Filming of the movie ''Il Pentito'' (''The Repenter'') was to have begun at 9 o'clock yesterday in the grand ballroom of the Westbury Hotel. At 9:30, a seamstress was looking for the star, Tony Musante.

title: DANCE: 'GISELLE' FROM BALLET THEATER
description: ''GISELLE'' once again proved to be one of ballet's great love stories when American Ballet Theater presented it for the first time this season on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: LEVEL OF USE OF ILLEGAL DRUGS WILL STAY HIGH, MEESE SAYS
description: The use and availability of cocaine and other dangerous drugs will remain high in 1985, but marijuana and heroin use will decline slightly, Attorney General Edwin Meese told a Senate committee today.

title: LOS ANGELES SEEN AS U.S. CAPITAL OF ILLEGAL PRESCRIPTION DRUG TRADE
description: Federal and state law-enforcement officials say Los Angeles may now be the national capital for illegal trafficking in several of the most commonly abused prescription drugs.

title: TOON, NO. 1 CHOICE, SIGNS JETS CONTRACT
description: As midnight approached Tuesday, the Jets signed Al Toon, the acclaimed receiver from Wisconsin, and that completed a whirlwind signing of their three holdouts barely 48 hours after the club suffered one of its most decisive defeats.

title: FIRST 2 HYDRANTS AT SITE OF PASSAIC FIRE WERE DRY
description: The first two hydrants that firefighters tried to use to put out the multimillion-dollar industrial blaze here on Labor Day produced no water, according to the Passaic Fire Department.

title: Israelis Wound Arab Youth
description: An Arab youth was shot today in the West Bank town of Ramallah by Israeli soldiers who said he had tried to run away when ordered to halt for a search. Officers said a group of four Arab youths aroused the suspicion of soldiers patrolling the town at midday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SELF-PROPELLED Rockefeller Center, the city within a city, includes 19 buildings on 22 acres of midtown Manhattan and it is surely one of the most walked-through pieces of real estate in New York. There is a difference, however, between just walking and walking while observing, as one does in a guided tour. The group guided tours of Rockefeller Center were discontinued this year, but the center has come up with a free self-guided tour that directs the visitor's eyes and feet.

title: CONGRESS PONDERS EXTENT OF FARM DEBT CRISIS
description: More than 20 lawmakers trooped before a House hearing today to warn that further damage to the nation's farm lending system would harm their agricultural areas and the rest of the American economy.

title: Forced Resignation
description: Bob Patterson, the former Memphis State athletic director who cited concern for his health when he submitted his resignation in September 1982, had apparently been forced to resign for making improper payments to athletes, according to university documents made public this week. The documents include a letter from the university president, Thomas Carpenter, to the National Collegiate Athletic Association, reporting two incidents in which university officials found that Carpenter had given money to unidentified Memphis State athletes.

title: Let's Raise the Level of All, Not Just Some, of Our Police Officers
description: To the Editor:

title: Lutherans Drop Plan To Bar Disabled Clergy
description: Responding to a flood of complaints, the American Lutheran Church has dropped plans to bar severely disabled people from entering the ministry.

title: A FESTIVE NIGHT FOR 6 FASHION DESIGNERS
description: THERE may have been a primary election going on, but politics intruded on Saks Fifth Avenue's annual SFA/ USA fashion show and dinner-dance Tuesday night only because Geoffrey Beene, one of Saks' six designer superstars, was absent. Mr. Beene was having dinner at the White House with the Reagans and the Prime Minister of Denmark.

title: Cadillac Predicts Only Nominal Gain
description: Cadillac will be unable to take advantage of the rising fortunes of the luxury car market in the 1986 model year and is predicting only a nominal increase in sales, company officials said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Corp., Morris Township, N.J., said it is seeking a buyer for its automotive unit's Prestolite Motor and Ignition division.

title: CHOCK FULL O' NUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $127,000 for the quarter and $202,000 for the year. c-Includes income of $615,000, or 13 cents a share, attributable to settlement of litigation. d-Includes income from discontinued operations of $354,000, or 7 cents a share.

title: Brock to Delay Action On Farm Health Plan
description: Labor Secretary Bill Brock announced today that he was suspending action for the next 18 months on a proposed Federal field sanitation standard for farm workers.

title: PESTICIDE INDUSTRY REACHES AGREEMENT TO TIGHTEN LAW
description: The chemical industry and a coalition of environmental, labor and consumer groups today announced agreement on broad changes to strengthen the law regulating pesticides.

title: How to Cope With Alzheimer's
description: Roswell Gilbert's rejection of community health-care and social-service assistance, and self-reliance to the point of murdering his wife because she suffered from Alzheimer's disease, demands examination. Whatever the outcome of legal appeals, the case and public response to it raise questions about how we view the quality of long-term care for the elderly and how adequate that care is for Alzheimer's patients.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CALIFORNIA (AL) - Acquired Don Sutton, pitcher, from the Oakland A's for two minor league players to be named later.

title: UNIT RECOMMENDS NEW THERAPY FOR BREAST CANCER
description: A National Institutes of Health panel recommended today that thousands of older women with breast cancer be treated with hormone therapy to prevent recurrence, saying death rates among such patients could drop by 20 percent because of the change.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Still a Free Lunch for Manhattan Developers
description: To the Editor:

title: Murdoch Talks On Fox Cited
description: The publisher Rupert Murdoch is negotiating with Marvin Davis to buy Mr. Davis's 50 percent interest in the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, according to sources familiar with the talks.

title: THE FUTURE OF WESTWAY
description: The road to Westway has now been narrowed to this:

title: Chemical New York Selects an Outsider
description: The Chemical New York Corporation, the nation's sixth-largest bank holding company, announced yesterday that Richard S. Simmons, deputy presiding partner at the New York law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, had been named vice chairman and a director. The appointment is effective Oct. 15.

title: SCORECARDS MIGHT BE NEEDED FOR GERRYMANDERING CASE
description: The first major case to be argued when the Supreme Court starts its new term next month presents some of the strangest alliances the Court has seen in some time.

title: 'AFTER HOURS' FROM MARTIN SCORSESE
description: MARTIN SCORSESE'S ''After Hours'' is not an easy comedy to get the hang of, that is, until you realize that it's as much about emotional disorientation as it is disorienting in itself. The perfect orderliness of the music under the opening credits - Mozart's Sympthony in D major - provides the comic contrast to almost everything that comes after, in which nothing is balanced or predictable or entirely coherent.

title: NORDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 4
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2,082,000.

title: Travel Is a Beneficial Culture Shock
description: To the Editor:

title: TOON MAKES A BIG IMPRESSION
description: ''Go out and catch a couple,'' a former No. 1 draft pick shouted to the newest No. 1 today at the Jets' practice.

title: The Liaison Watch
description: President Reagan has decided to name Max Green, a staff official of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, as his special assistant for liaison with Jewish groups.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL METS (NL) - Recalled Calvin Schiraldi, pitcher, from Tidewater of the International League.

title: DODGERS LOSE, 11-6
description: Brad Komminsk capped a six-run third inning with a three-run homer and Atlanta went on to a 11-6 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers, salvaging the final game of a five-game series.

title: American's Appeal Denied
description: A provincial appeals court today turned down the appeal of an American businessman convicted of criminal negligence in a Harbin hotel fire that killed 10 people, the New China News Agency said. The Higher People's Court of Heilongjiang Province confirmed the 18-month prison sentence given the businessman, Richard S. Ondrik, and ordered him to pay the equivalent of $50,800 in compensation, the press agency said.

title: CABARET: STEVE ROSS
description: STEVE ROSS, who is performing nightly at the Cafe Carlyle (Carlyle Hotel, Madison Avenue at 76th Street) for the next five weeks, until Bobby Short returns to the room, is very much an acolyte of Mr. Short's sensibility and high-toned style. ''I am a musical archeologist,'' the singer-pianist announced at his Wednesday night show, and to prove it he performed a program that ranged from vintage Eddie Cantor to Melissa Manchester and Carole Bayer Sager.

title: PHILIP McCORD MORSE, PHYSICIST
description: Philip McCord Morse, a physicist and educator who served as founding director of Brookhaven National Laboratory, died Sept. 5 at Emerson Hospital in Concord, Mass. He was 82 years old.

title: HOFFMAN IN 'DEATH OF A SALESMAN'
description: SUNDAY night's presentation of ''Death of a Salesman,'' from 8 to 11, is being described by CBS as an ''event.'' It is one of those rare and welcome occasions when commercial television is not exaggerating.

title: Architecture Lecture
description: A lecture on the architecture of New York and Chicago from 1916 to 1985 will be given on Sunday at 2 P.M. at the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, at 76th Street.

title: Ex-Chief's Son Named At American Express
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that Howard L. Clark, Jr., son of the company's former chairman and chief executive, had been named chief financial officer.

title: UNITED MERCHANTS & MANUFACTURINGS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income. The latest year includes a nonrecurring charge of $23,586,000 which primarily represents current and estimated future expenses related to the termination and/or relocation of certain of the company's domestic apparel textile operations. The results of Jonathan Logan Inc. which was acquired in fiscal 1985 have been included in the consolidated financial statements effective Sept. 1, 1984.

title: 'Guernica' Returns, In Another Medium
description: When the Spanish Government reclaimed Pablo Picasso's anti-war painting ''Guernica'' from the Museum of Modern Art in 1981, New York art lovers were dismayed.

title: Ogilvy & Mather Adds Polaroid Business
description: The Polaroid Corporation, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., has appointed Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide as the agency for its instant photographic products in Europe and the Middle East.

title: F.T.C. IS URGED TO DROP RULE ON STOCKS FOR FOOD RETAILERS
description: The Federal Trade Commission said today that its staff had recommended that the agency drop a requirement that food retailers have reasonable stocks of special sale items and keep records to prove it if challenged.

title: HEILEMAN'S MAVERICK TOUCH
description: When the G. Heileman Brewing Company announced last month that it would build a new brewery in Milwaukee, a lot of people were surprised.

title: Mitterrand's Pacific Trip Is Protested by Australia
description: The Governments of Australia and New Zealand today condemned as untimely and ''provocative'' a planned visit by President Francois Mitterrand to the French nuclear test site at Mururoa Atoll.

title: Coleco Plans New Doll Line
description: Coleco Industries said yesterday that it would issue a new line of licensed dolls designed by Xavier Roberts, the creator of its Cabbage Patch Kids.

title: What's Good About the Contract for the New Toyota-G.M. Plant
description: To the Editor:

title: VOLT INFORMATION SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-After gains of $260,000 for the quarter and $1,510,000 for the 9 months on the sale of securities. c-Net income

title: LASER DESTROYS MISSILE TARGET IN TEST BY U.S.
description: Gen. James A. Abrahamson, the director of antimissile research, said today that a large ''weapon grade'' laser destroyed its target, a section of a large, stationary missile, in a test last week.

title: Missouri Moves to Keep Rape Law on the Books
description: The Missouri Supreme Court, acting quickly in response to an urgent request from the Attorney General, agreed to hear an appeal Friday aimed at keeping in force the state's law against rape.

title: ENGINEERS DESTROY EUROPEAN ROCKET 10 MINUTES AFTER LAUNCHING
description: Engineers destroyed an Ariane rocket tonight, along with two satellites it carried, minutes after a launching by the European Space Agency that was watched by President Francois Mitterrand of France.

title: BALLET THEATER: HARVEY IN 'GISELLE'
description: ONE of two major points of interest in maintaining the 19th-century ballet classics in the international repertory is the opportunity for dancers to perform and interpret time-honored roles. On this count, Cynthia Harvey, Ross Stretton, Michael Owen and Nora Kimball, a new soloist in American Ballet Theater, offered some excellent and dramatic moments in ''Giselle'' on Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds decreased $520.6 million, to $208.68 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: TITLE GAME ADJOURNED
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov adjourned the fourth game of the world chess championship today, with Karpov sealing his 41st move.

title: Massachusetts Housing Offer
description: The Massachusetts Housing Finance Agency is offering $120.3 million of single-family mortgage revenue bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: BASEBALL THURSDAY IN NEW YORK
description: It wasn't the Subway Series, but Baseball Thursday certainly clogged the Triborough Bridge around 6 P.M. yesterday as jubilant Met fans mingled with expectant Yankee fans in a major league traffic jam.

title: Stocks Fall Again; Dow Declines 7.05
description: Wall Street stock prices fell moderately yesterday, with the market battered for the third consecutive day by a wave of technical selling related to index options contracts. The closely watched Dow Jones industrial index slipped to its lowest level in almost three months.

title: Circle Line
description: A swim around Manhattan has become almost as common in recent years as a jog in Central Park, and so little wonder that Benson Huggard felt he needed a new wrinkle to draw public interest to his own stunt. Here it is: Huggard, in an attempt to focus attention on the plight of New York's hungry, will try to swim a daily lap of 28.5 miles around the island for eight straight days - with his legs tied.

title: BEAR, STEARNS SECRETS ARE OUT
description: Among Wall Street's privately owned brokerage partnerships, profitability has always been a jealously guarded secret. But Bear, Stearns & Company disclosed all yesterday in announcing the terms of its plans for an initial public offering of stock - and at the same time confirmed its reputation as a savvy trader able to reap profits even in bad times.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Toronto Blue Jays, at Yankee Stadium. Phil Niekro tries to become the second pitcher this year to win his 300th game and the second to do it in Yankee Stadium. Tom Seaver of the White Sox did it Aug. 4. This is also the second game of the crucial series between the top two teams in the American League East. The 46-year-old Niekro (15-9) has won eight of his last nine starts and has not lost since Aug 1. Jim Clancy is on the mound for the red-hot Blue Jays. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Expos, at Montreal. twilight-night doubleheader. Rick Aguilera (2-3) and Terry Leach (7-5) are scheduled to pitch for the Mets in the doubleheader that completes the makeup of the two games missed during the players strike in August. The Mets hold a 6-5 edge in the season series. Bryn Smith (15-5) and Dan Schatzeder (2-4) are on the mound for Montreal. (Television - SportsChannel, 5:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 5:30 P.M.). Golf Greater Milwaukee Open, at Franklin, Wis., second round. Mark O'Meara won this event last season, his only victory. L.P.G.A. Safeco Classic, at Seattle, second round. Kathy Whitworth is the defending champion. Other Events COLLEGE FOOTBALL: William Paterson vs. Pace, at Wayne, N.J., 8 P.M. This is the second game for both teams. Pace lost to Trenton State last week while Paterson lost to Wagner.

title: Condition of Heart Recipient In Arizona Upgraded to Fair
description: The condition of Michael Drummond, the youngest man ever kept alive with a Jarvik-7 artificial heart, was upgraded to fair today by his physicians.

title: Human Error Blamed In Portugal Train Wreck
description: Railway officials blamed human error today for a train crash in northern Portugal in which at least 49 people died.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Atlas Corp., Princeton, N.J., a natural resources, services and manufacturing company, has named Richard R. Weaver executive vice president.

title: Saving Reagan From Reagan
description: President Reagan has been forced by Congress and events to become an active, if reluctant, ally of the South African majority in its struggle for fair participation in South African life. To push Mr. Reagan further, as Democrats in Congress now are trying to do, risks reversing this important development and offers no real gain for anyone.

title: Vietnam Reports Clashes
description: Vietnam said today that its armed forces killed or wounded 50 Chinese soldiers in repelling attacks along its northern border this week. A Vietnamese radio broadcast monitored in Bangkok said Chinese troops fired nearly 20,000 artillery rounds into Vi Xuyen district of Ha Tuyen province Monday and Tuesday.

title: AUCTIONS
description: THE Festival of India has arrived, and timed to coincide with the celebration, Sotheby's is staging what it describes as the largest auction of medieval Indian and Southeast Asian sculpture ever held in New York.

title: FEVER RISES: METS FIRST, YANKS GAINING
description: It never looked like it would come to this: There were the Mets, a six-run lead vanished, clinging in one half of the ninth and then scratching their way to victory in the bottom half.

title: Ryder Cup Play to Start
description: The 1985 Ryder Cup Match, a golf competition between teams of American and European professionals that begins here Friday, is a major golf event in Britain because, for the first time in 16 years, the Europeans are given a good chance to win.

title: COMMUNION-CUP FEAR ADDRESSED
description: The Episcopal Bishop of California issued a pastoral letter this week in response to fears among parishioners in the San Francisco area that drinking communion wine from a common cup could transmit AIDS.

title: Fiat, Ford Unit Cooperation Seen
description: Umberto Agnelli, chairman of the Italian car maker Fiat, said he expected talks with Ford's European subsidiary to produce a definite agreement on cooperation between the two concerns.

title: Oh, Say
description: When he wrote ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' 171 years ago this weekend, Francis Scott Key lived in Georgetown, but subsequent construction of the Potomac River bridge named after the lawyer-poet covered the land originally occupied by his home. So the Francis Scott Key Park Foundation plans to locate its proposed memorial park on a piece of Government-owned property as near to the bridge abutment as possible.

title: CORSARO AND SENDAK STAGE 'ORANGES'
description: Prokofiev's ''Love for Three Oranges'' contains the composer's most famous bit of music - the incisive, tangy little march from Act Two that was used as the theme to a radio program called ''The F.B.I. in Peace and War'' and as a piano encore by Arthur Rubinstein, among others. But there is a lot more to the Prokofiev opera than the march, as New Yorkers will discover tonight at 8 when a new production of ''Love for Three Oranges'' enters the repertory of the New York City Opera.

title: Bank Failure Sets Record
description: Moncor Bank of Roswell today became the 80th American bank to fail this year, eclipsing the record 79 bank failures in 1984, a Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation official said.

title: Put Wollman Ice Rink Into Private Hands
description: To the Editor:

title: DIVESTMENT PLAN APPROVED BY EPISCOPAL CHURCH GROUP
description: One of the two legislative houses of the Episcopal Church voted today to have the church divest itself of its holdings in companies doing business in South Africa.

title: Latin Street Fair
description: A street fair tomorrow with Latin music, dance and food will celebrate the completion of an art project on the walls of buildings facing La Plaza Cultural, Ninth Street and Avenue C. More than 30 artists have worked for nearly two months on the murals, which depict political and urban themes; the project was sponsored by several arts groups. Hours are noon to 5 P.M. Information: 966-0007.

title: WILLIAM ALWYN
description: The composer William Alwyn died last night in a hospital near his home in Blythburgh, on the Suffolk coast of eastern England, his family said today.

title: TORO COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Rush-Hour Fire Slows IRT Service
description: A fire in a cable room disrupted evening rush-hour service yesterday on the IRT Broadway line from Brooklyn to upper Manhattan, inconveniencing tens of thousands of passengers.

title: ANIXTER BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $77,000 for the quarter and $1,634,000 for the year.

title: CONNECTICUT CHARITY FOR CHILDREN IS SUED ON ITS USE OF MONEY
description: Connecticut's Attorney General is trying to shut down a charity for dying children that he says used most of its proceeds to pay excessive salaries and provide loans to its officers.

title: Economic Scene;   Banks' Impact On Apartheid
description: PRESIDENT P.W. BOTHA of South Africa has proposed to restore citizenship to millions of blacks who lost it when the Government set up its ''homelands'' policy, which was intended to make South Africa ultimately a white state. The pass laws controlling the movement of black labor appear likely to go next. If, as it now seems, apartheid is crumbling, what cracked it at last is the threat of economic collapse, brought on not by political pressures or sanctions but by the actions of bankers and business executives - and by the economic blunders of the South African Government.

title: A FESTIVAL IN MORNINGSIDE HEIGHTS
description: Seventeen years after protests forced Columbia University to abandoning its plans to build a gymnasium in Morningside Park, this long-neglected sliver of rocky woods and greenery between West Harlem and Morningside Heights is finally on the road to revitalization.

title: Travel Is a Beneficial Culture Shock
description: To the Editor:

title: SCREEN: 'AGNES,' BY JEWISON
description: ''AGNES OF GOD'' and ''A Soldier's Story'' have nothing in common except Norman Jewison, who has given them a similar ponderousness on the screen. And Mr. Jewison's ''Agnes of God,'' which opens today at the Guild and the Baronet, is, if anything, the slower and more self-evident of the two. The director's strength again lies in his casting, with Anne Bancroft, Jane Fonda and Meg Tilly sharing what is essentially a three-character melodrama; in unison or in any combination, these actresses cannot help but generate interest. But the material itself, thoroughly unsurprising on the stage, is if anything even more so on the screen.

title: SCREEN: 'WAR AND LOVE'
description: ''WAR AND LOVE'' is based on the true story of its producer, Jack P. Eisner, who, as a young man, survived the Warsaw ghetto and a Nazi concentration camp and went on to write a book about those experiences, ''The Survivor.'' Taking this into consideration, as well as the talents of Abby Mann, who wrote the screenplay, and Moshe Mizrahi, the director (''Madame Rosa''), the film is shockingly inept. It opens today at the Festival Theater.

title: SCREEN: 'RAZORBACK'
description: ''RAZORBACK,'' which opens a two-day run at the Thalia today, on a bill with George Miller's ''Mad Max,'' is an Australian horror movie about a wild hog described as being ''as big as a rhino.'' The movie isn't as funny as that American camp classic, ''Alligator,'' but it's far more esoteric looking, possibly because its director, Russell Mulcahy, seems to have gotten his film-making experience doing music videos for Duran Duran and Fleetwood Mac.

title: FOR FRESHMEN, SOME KEYS TO THE CITY
description: The 770 members of the class of 1989 at Columbia College arrived uptown on Aug. 28. Sixty-seven percent of them are from outside New York State. At New York University, 2,200 new students checked in 11 days later. About a third of them come from out of town. Passers-by on University Place seemed oblivious to their arrival. The freshmen, mostly 17 and 18 years old, were less blase about their first days in New York City.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Gilles Meloche, a goaltender for the Edmonton Oilers, has been traded to the Pittsburgh Penguins in exchange for Marty McSorley, a defenseman, and Tim Hrynewich, a left wing. Meloche. 35, spent the last seven seasons with Minnesota before being acquired by the Oilers during the summer. . . . Bob Thomas, who spent 10 years as the Chicago Bears' place-kicker, will fill that role for San Diego for at least the next four weeks. The Chargers have signed the 33-year-old Thomas to replace Rolf Benirschke, who was put on injured reserve with a severe groin injury. '' . . . Reggie McKenzie, a former offensive guard who was released by the Seattle Seahawks last month, has been named assistant director of marketing for the team.

title: END OF PASS LAWS FOR SOUTH AFRICA URGED BY PANEL
description: A Government-sponsored panel today recommended the abolition of the pass laws, which restrict blacks' right to move to the townships set aside for them in urban areas.

title: JETRONIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid July 17.

title: Greek Captain Sentenced In Stowaway Incident
description: A Greek sea captain was sentenced today to 10 years and 10 months in prison for forcing 11 African stowaways to jump overboard into the Indian Ocean off Somalia on March 17, 1984. It is not known whether they survived.

title: Toyota Gesture
description: Toyota, Japan's largest car maker, said it planned to bring more foreign parts and materials into Japan this year at the Government's request. The company's vice president, Hiroyasu Ono, said Toyota planned to import $246 million worth of goods in 1985, compared with $193 million last year. The move is a gesture toward helping reduce the country's big trade surplus.

title: PRETORIA BANS ISSUE OF NEWSWEEK WHILE EXPELLING ITS CORRESPONDENT
description: The authorities today banned the distribution of the current issue of Newsweek magazine, saying it was ''undesirable.'' The issue features a cover article on the situation in South Africa.

title: Ex-Cell-O Acquisition
description: The Ex-Cell-O Corporation said today that it would buy Babco Industries, a maker of precision jet engine components, for an unspecified amount. Babco, a closely held company based in Danvers, Mass., has annual sales of about $20 million and employs 200 people, Ex-Cell-O said.

title: MANY FARM CHILDREN ARE PREPARING FOR CAREERS OFF THEIR FAMILIES' LAND
description: Like many farm children, Jay Oltjen once dreamed of a career on the land his family farms near Hiawatha, in northeastern Kansas not far from the Nebraska border.

title: New Tack For British Airways
description: BRITISH AIRWAYS, which won numerous awards for its futuristic commercial showing the island of Manhattan landing at a London airport, has shifted tactics from such image-building and is about to begin a more pragmatic campaign aimed at the business traveler.

title: AEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Leftists Cause Blackout In Much of Chile
description: A bomb for which leftist guerrillas took responsibility plunged much of Chile into darkness Wednesday night. It was the 12th anniversary of the military coup in which President Augusto Pinochet took power, and church sources said nine people were hurt in anti-Government protests.

title: United Press Dropping Bid to Cancel Contract
description: United Press International is dropping plans to ask a Federal bankruptcy judge to cancel the news agency's contract with the Wire Service Guild, a company spokesman said today.

title: ART: THE SERIOUS WORK OF A NO-NONSENSE LEAR
description: ANYONE mildly good at ''Trivial Pursuit'' knows - if very little else about the man -that Edward Lear wrote ''The Owl and the Pussy-Cat,'' among many other deathless bits of English ephemera. Yet it was mainly as a painter - of flora, fauna and landscapes - that Lear made a reputation during his lifetime (1812-1888), and it was as a painter that he wanted to be remembered. When he died, this versatile workaholic managed to leave more than 300 oils, thousands of watercolors, two books of natural history illustrations, and more than 100 lithographs of birds - all this besides published travel and ''Nonsense'' books, manuscripts, songs, diaries and a wealth of amusingly illustrated letters to friends.

title: JUDGE WON'T BAR TEST FIRING AT SATELLITE, EXPECTED TODAY
description: A Federal judge today denied a request by four members of Congress and an organization of scientists to forbid a test of the United States anti-satellite weapon, which is expected to take place on Friday.

title: Red-Hot Tempers
description: Pete Rose's 4,192d career hit may have sent spirits soaring at Riverfront Stadium in Cincinnati Wednesday night, but before the game was over some tempers were flaring as well, at least in the San Diego dugout. Eric Show, the Padre pitcher who threw the ball that Rose knocked into baseball history in the first inning, was later involved in an altercation with Carmelo Martinez, the Padre left fielder.

title: Health Fair
description: Health issues, from nutrition to stress management, will be discussed during a free fair this weekend at the Wholistic Health Center, 50 Maple Avenue, Manhasset, L.I. The center offers programs emphasizing health care through prevention and a minimum of medications. The fair goes on tomorrow and Sunday from noon to 5 P.M. Information: (516) 627-0048.

title: 'Tempest' in the Park
description: Central Park's Belvedere Castle will be the setting Sunday for a free production of Shakespeare's ''Tempest.''

title: AILEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
Westway at the Brink
description: The opponents the Westway project in New York City, and also the faulty procedures of some of its supporters, have now forced the issue to an excruciating decision. A Federal appeals court has preserved an opportunity to proceed with this huge development of the Hudson shore, but not on a schedule that also preserves the fail-safe option of exchanging the approved Federal subsidy for much lesser aid to transit. The deadline for such a ''trade-in'' is Sept. 30, which leaves only days to choose between an all-or-nothing commitment to Westway and abandoning it for perhaps a third of its cash value.

title: Whitney President
description: The Whitney Communications Corporation yesterday named Bernard W. Kiernan president and William M. O'Shea to the additional post of secretary. Mr. Kiernan, who is 54 years old, had been senior vice president, while Mr. O'Shea, 42, continues as treasurer. Charles H. G. Rees, who had been president and secretary, resigned last month to pursue other interests. Whitney, which owns 30 newspapers in Maryland and Delaware, 6 magazines and cable television systems in Maine and New Hampshire, recently became a partial owner of WTNH-TV in New Haven.

title: PANEL URGES NEW THERAPY FOR BREAST CANCER
description: A National Institutes of Health panel recommended Wednesday that thousands of older women with breast cancer be treated with hormone therapy to prevent recurrence, saying death rates among such patients could drop by 20 percent because of the change.

title: Seminars Promote A Mannerly City
description: A man in a gorilla suit handed out balloons. The smiling faces of famous New Yorkers (Lena Horne, Dick Cavett, Mikhail Baryshnikov) beamed from posters declaring ''New York Loves You.''

title: PACKERS' DICKEY IS WARY OF GIANTS
description: Understandably filled with anxiety, Lynn Dickey considered each member of the Giants' defensive line and said: ''No, I don't think there's an opening there. No, that's not going to be easy either. No, that's not a help for me.''

title: Why Fordham Moved
description: ''I almost fainted when Bob Moses said, 'How many acres do you want?' I'd never heard anyone speaking of New York streets as acres.''

title: FOLK CITY AT 25: THE TIMES THEY ARE A-CHANGIN'
description: TOMORROW evening, the 60's will meet the 80's when two generations of folk musicians gather at Pier 84 to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the Greenwich Village club Folk City. Performers like Arlo Guthrie, Joan Baez, Tom Rush, and Odetta, who spearheaded the 60's folk music boom, will share the stage with talented acoustic-oriented artists like Suzanne Vega, the Roches, and David Massengill.

title: People
description: * Timothy Corrigan has been appointed senior vice president at Ted Bates Advertising/New York, a division of Ted Bates Worldwide.

title: AID OFFERS FLOW TO L.I. BOMB VICTIM
description: An outpouring of calls and letters, pledges of $60,000 in cash and offers of aid from artificial-limb makers and the state's Crime Victims Board have deluged a young Long Island man who may lose a leg because of an act of heroism last week.

title: BROADWAY
description: THERE are various kinds of musicals, said Marvin Hamlisch, the composer of ''A Chorus Line.'' There are spectacle musicals, nostalgic musicals and avant-garde musicals, and what he's doing for his next show is none of them.

title: Wilkins Will Wait
description: Dominique Wilkins, the Atlanta Hawks' leading scorer for the last three seasons, said he was seeking a renegotiation of his contract and was prepared to sit out the entire season if the Hawks don't accommdoate him. ''I do love to play and it would be hard for me to do something like that,'' he said, then added: ''I'll do what I have to do, and the Hawks will do what they have to do.''

title: 7 BLACKS KILLED IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: At least seven blacks were reported killed today in unrest around the country, and a white teacher and 10 black students were wounded by police gunfire at a high school in this black township near Johannesburg.

title: EX-CAROLINA GOVERNOR TO SHUN 1986 SENATE RACE
description: Former Gov. James B. Hunt of North Carolina has decided not to run for the United States Senate in 1986, dampening Democratic hopes of picking up a seat that figures in the party's strategy for taking control of the Senate.

title: OF A NEWSLESS SOCIETY
description: When the Rev. Richard C. Halverson raised the specter of a newsless society in his opening prayer in the Senate this week, Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming was momentarily intrigued.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: DOWNTOWN: A CHOICE OF FESTIVITIES
description: FROM the tip of Manhattan to Greenwich Village, from the South Street Seaport to the Battery, downtown is celebrating this weekend. Whether it is a party for something new, like the newly finished dock at the seaport, or something old, like the Feast of San Gennaro, there will be songs, food and fun.

title: No Offense
description: Art Schlichter has lost his assignment as the Indianapolis Colts' starting quarterback, but only for a while, and more because of a bum knee than for his bum performance in the Colts' 45-3 loss to the Pittsburgh Steelers. Schlichter, who hurt his left knee in the game, completed only 12 of 24 passes for 107 yards, but still has the confidence of Coach Ron Dowhower, who named Mike Pagel to start Sunday against the Miami Dolphins.

title: It Was Pure Cabbage
description: If Washington is not the national capital of the word industry, it is certainly a major East Coast distribution center. As a result, a certain number of stories that are interesting and reasonable on their face but actually baseless do get into print.

title: Diner's Journal
description: ONE of the more delightful lunch spots in Fifth Avenue's shopping district is a little-known restaurant perched on the fifth floor of the Trump Tower at 56th Street. Called Terrace Five, this charming bistro-like place offers engaging salads and entrees as well as a superior little wine list with many selections available by the glass. On clement days, you can sit on a tiny outdoor terrace that affords a striking view down the avenue; even from the indoor seats, the view through the wraparound windows is inspiring.

title: COLTS ARE HOPING MARINO IS STILL RUSTY
description: The Indianapolis Colts suffered the worst loss of any National Football League team on opening day, falling to the Pittsburgh Steelers by 45-3. It was the worst defeat for the Colts since Nov. 11, 1973, when they lost, 44-0.

title: 3-TERM HARLEM COUNCILMAN
description: Frederick E. Samuel, a three-term City Councilman from Harlem's Fifth District, died of a heart attack yesterday at Presbyterian Hospital. He was 61 years old.

title: $3.6 Million Is Seized; Cocaine Link Suspected
description: Federal agents seized $3.6 million in suspected cocaine profits from a car and a residence, United States Customs officials announced today.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 13, 1985
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 3:15 P.M. on situation in occupied Arab territories.

title: SENATE TO STUDY HANDLING BY U.S. OF PROSECUTIONS OF CORPORATIONS
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee announced today that it would investigate the Justice Department's handling of a series of prosecutions against large corporations.

title: Whither Dobrynin?
description: If Anatoly F. Dobrynin is returning to the Soviet Union after 23 years as Ambassador to the United States, he is not talking about it.

title: Price Corporation
description: The Price Communication Corporation is offering a total of $145 million of speculative-grade debt securities in two parts through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. A $125 million issue of 14 5/8 percent subordinated debentures due 2000 was offered at a price of 98 1/4, to yield 14.92 percent.

title: COMPANY OFFERS TO RUN TENNESSEE'S PRISONS
description: The Corrections Corporation of America today offered to pay $250 million for a 99-year lease of the entire Tennessee state prison system.

title: MUSIC: 2 INDIAN WORKS HAVE WORLD PREMIERE
description: WHEN the New York Philharmonic is in a saluting mood, it salutes anything that moves. Last night's program, the second of the season and the first of the subscription schedule, not only continued with the ''Festival of India'' theme of opening night but paid homage to Aaron Copland as well. The orchestra and its music director, Zubin Mehta, began a season-long retrospective of the composer's career by performing three of his works. Mr. Copland, who will be 85 in November, was represented by the 1969 ''Inaugural Fanfare,'' the 1925 ''Cortege Macabre'' and a suite from the 1938 ballet ''Billy the Kid.''

title: Nihilator Resting
description: Nihilator, the 3-year-old pacing sensation who has won almost $1 million this year while skipping several important races, will be held out of the Little Brown Jug, the final leg of pacing's triple crown, next Thursday because his owners believe he needs a rest after six races in six weeks. ''I feel bad, but we have a lot of respect for the horse,'' said Lou Guida, Nihilator's principal owner, who said the decision had been made in consultation with the driver, Billy O'Donnell.

title: RIVER OAKS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: STING, who has made nine feature and television films in eight years (and who appears with Meryl Streep in ''Plen-ty,'' which opens next Thursday), doesn't think it wise for rock stars to expect to be leading men overnight, especially in view of the apprehensiveness with which other actors may regard them. ''The acting establishment doesn't really appreciate this immigration,'' he said of the increasing eagerness of many pop singers to make the transition to the screen. ''I think they find it rather frightening.

title: MORTGAGE GROWTH INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes nonrecurring gains and contingent interest from the sale of real estate investments of $380,000, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and $816,000, or 17 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Includes similar gains and interest of $243,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and $913,000, or 22 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: WHERE KRISHNA FROLICKED, JOY MARKS HIS BIRTHDAY
description: The first shadows of dusk seem to bring this sacred old city to life with prayer. From countless corners in its narrow, winding streets comes an eery tinkling of cymbals, the buzz of chanting and the peal of bells.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: 'INDIA!' FESTIVAL OF FABLED ART AT THE MET
description: INNUMERABLE Indias will be on display, this year and next, all over the United States as part of the Festival of India. The performing arts of India have been seen and heard at Lincoln Center all this week, and many of New York's institutions - among them, the Asia Society, the Museum of Modern Art, the Brooklyn Museum, the Pierpont Morgan Library, the New York City Opera and the American Museum of Natural History - will contribute to the festival, in one way or another, well into the spring of 1986.

title: Former Cowboy Is Convicted
description: A jury convicted Ron Springs, the former Dallas Cowboy running back, of resisting arrest during a scuffle with police officers in a nightclub in January.

title: 'Beverly Hills Cop' To Be a Video Cassette
description: Paramount Home Video will release the blockbuster movie ''Beverly Hills Cop,'' starring Eddie Murphy, on video cassette October 30. The price will be $29.95.

title: FEARS ON AIDS TERMED LARGELY WITHOUT CAUSES
description: Fear and misinformation about AIDS are pervasive in the nation and, in recent days, have been particularly evident in New York City, where there has been intense debate over whether children with the disease should be allowed into the classroom.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American General Corp., an insurance company based in Syracuse, said it had completed the previously announced sale of its British subsidiary, including Albany Life Assurance Co., to Metropolitian Life Insurance Co.

title: SALVADOR POLICE RAID HOUSES, LOOKING FOR DUARTE DAUGHTER
description: Salvadoran police and army units raided 12 houses in the capital Wednesday night and this morning in a continuing search for the kidnapped daughter of President Jose Napoleon Duarte, according to a senior army official.

title: Remington Arms
description: The Remington Arms Company plans to lay off at least 400 workers at its Herkimer County plant by the end of the month, and the number could go higher, a plant official said. The company, which has been buffeted by a slowdown in the retail gun sales market, also plans to go to a four-day workweek.

title: THE M.T.A. PRESENTS: MUSIC TO SOOTHE THE SUBWAY RIDER
description: The place was Track 3 of the 42d Street shuttle at Grand Central. The music was ''Rondeau'' by Jean Joseph Mouret - the theme from ''Masterpiece Theater'' - played by a brass quintet. The subway was momentarily ennobled, the passing commuters both pleased and befuddled.

title: Tribute to Longhair
description: The New Orleans pianists Mac (Dr. John) Rebennack and Allen Toussaint will play dance concerts, with a band, in tribute to the pianist Professor Longhair tonight and tomorrow at 10 P.M. and midnight at the Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets (475-5120). Tickets are $13.50, and there is a two-drink minimum.

title: MUSEUM FOCUSES ON THE DEATH OF THE TITANIC
description: Two blocks east of Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell, tucked away in a ground-floor gallery of the Philadelphia Maritime Museum, there is a lesser known but equally riveting pilgrimage point for a few of the millions drawn to this city by the history it embodies and displays.

title: CORRECTION
description: The headline on a television-page article in some editions yesterday about a violation of network news procedure in the recent appearance of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d on ''This Week With David Brinkley'' misidentified the network involved. It was ABC, not NBC.

title: WESTCHESTER IN YEAR 2000: GROWTH TO BRING PROBLEMS
description: Westchester County's economy will grow through the end of the century but, unless corrective steps are taken, the county will also continue to face an inadequate supply of housing and growing traffic congestion, according to a new study.

title: HEARING BEGINS ON AIDS CHILD IN PUBLIC SCHOOL
description: A state judge began hearing testimony yesterday in a suit by a Queens school board seeking to bar a second-grade pupil with AIDS from attending regular classes until the child's identity was disclosed.

title: Article 260328 -- No Title
description: The House approved legislation today to continue financing mass transit systems, air service to small communities and the operation of Amtrak, the national passenger railroad.

title: WORLD COURT HEARING NICARAGUA'S CASE AGAINST U.S.
description: With the row of seats reserved for the United States conspicuously empty, the World Court began today to hear a Nicaraguan complaint that United States support for anti-Government rebels in Nicaragua represents ''state terrorism'' and violates international law.

title: Antique Show
description: Antiques and decorative arts from the United States, Europe and Asia will be on display this weekend at the Park Avenue Antique Show at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 67th Street.

title: STUDY SAYS FAMINE COULD KILL 4 BILLION AFTER A NUCLEAR WAR
description: Billions of people who survived the explosions of a nuclear war would face drawn-out deaths by starvation, an international scientific group said today in a new study supporting the theory of a global ''nuclear winter'' that would ruin agriculture.

title: DAIRY MART CONVENIENCE STORES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CONNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 18
description: b-After a tax credit of $450,000, or 40 cents a share.

title: NEW CANADA TALKS ON PLANE MAKERS
description: Justus Dornier, a West German industrialist, announced yesterday that he was holding discussions with the Canadian Development Investment Corporation to acquire de Havilland Aircraft of Canada Ltd. and Canadair Ltd., the two major airplane manufacturers of Canada.

title: Hospices, Not Hospitals, for AIDS Patients
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Revenue Service Agent Guilty of Fraud in Tax Case
description: An agent of the Internal Revenue Service was convicted today of mail fraud and 48 counts of filing false tax returns seeking $115,000 in refunds.

title: 3 Proposals Made To Develop Pier 84
description: Three private developers submitted proposals yesterday to transform Pier 84, at West 44th Street in Manhattan, into a shopping and entertainment complex.

title: A NEW TOP COMMAND FOR THE PORT AUTHORITY: PHILIP DAVID KALTENBACKER
description: Philip D. Kaltenbacher, the new chairman of the Port Authority, is a man with a healthy set of priorities.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Sports People column yesterday inaccurately described circumstances surrounding the resignation of Bob Patterson as athletic director at Memphis State University in 1982. It also erred in describing a letter that the school's president, Thomas Carpenter, had written on the subject. Dr. Carpenter wrote that the resignation was accepted after the university learned that Mr. Patterson (not Dr. Carpenter) had improperly used his own funds to pay fees owed by student athletes.
