title: WASTE DISPOSAL IS FOCUS OF BILLS PASSED IN JERSEY
description: The State Legislature today approved a package of 10 bills to deal with the state's increasing sewage and garbage disposal problems.

title: Agency Orders T.V.A. To Confer on A-Plants
description: The Tennessee Valley Authority, which last month voluntarily shut down its entire trouble-plagued nuclear generating system, will not be permitted to restart any of its reactors before its directors meet with the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, the commission said today.

title: HASSEY SPARKS 6-RUN RALLY IN 7TH AS YANKEES WIN
description: The Toronto Blue Jays, who have held first place firmly in their grasp since May 13, cracked for just an instant last night, and when the crack became a gaping hole, it wasn't Don Mattingly or Dave Winfield who drove the Yankees through it.

title: TEST OF TAX PLAN FINDS GAIN OVER '84 RETURNS
description: With the help of a national accounting firm, two members of Congressional tax-writing committees have examined how President Reagan's tax-revision plan would affect the taxes paid by their constituents and have concluded that if the plan were enacted intact, a large majority would wind up with lower tax bills.

title: SOVIET GAIN SEEN IN PUBLIC POSTURE
description: American arms negotiators in Geneva have expressed concern about what they perceive to be a Soviet public relations advantage gained in recent months at American expense, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: CLINTON PROJECT GOING UP IN THE PRESERVATION ZONE
description: The fear within the Clinton community of Manhattan in the 1970's was that development pressures from a proposed convention center in the West 50's would sooner or later bear down upon the many tenement buildings west of Eighth Avenue, threatening displacement of thousands of tenants with low and moderate incomes. The City Planning Commission agreed and adopted one of Manhattan's most restrictive special zoning districts.

title: RUSS TOGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
High Anxiety Over South Africa
description: Every so often an issue comes along that galvanizes Congress, setting tempers on edge and igniting political confrontations that may determine the course of future elections.

title: ANTI-IMPORT BILLS RETAIN MOMENTUM
description: Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said today that the Administration's plan to draft new trade legislation with Republican Congressional leaders would not stop his panel from writing bills to curb textile imports and impose a 25 percent tariff surcharge on all imports from four countries.

title: Incomplete Grade
description: After completing two of his first three passes in a 47-27 loss to Kansas City last Sunday, Dave Wilson of the New Orleans Saints finished up with 19 straight incompletions.

title: ART: BLUE-COLLAR LANIGAN-SCHMIDT
description: THE Holly Solomon Gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue, at 56th Street, opens its 10th season with a show by Thomas Lanigan-Schmidt - fittingly so, since the reputations of each have more or less grown up together. In fact, the artist's talent first came to light in the SoHo ''alternative'' space that Mrs. Solomon previously ran where, in 1973, he installed an altarpiece. Likened by Grace Glueck to the throne the naive artist James Hampton spent 15 years assembling in a Washington garage, the work was accompanied by requiem music.

title: SCREEN: 'SUDDEN DEATH'
description: YOU could not behave the way the heroine of ''Sudden Death'' does and have a very long career as a female vigilante. After Valarie Wells, a glamorous executive, is raped and brutally beaten on her way to a meeting with her distinguished-looking fiance, she decides to get even. Valarie buys a gun, and she even uses her computer skills to monitor police records and find out where rapists can be found. After this, she begins frequenting dive after dive, in a concerted effort to get herself attacked all over again.

title: MUSIC: RAVI SHANKAR AND THE PHILHARMONIC
description: FOR nearly three decades, ever since his first tour of the United States and Europe in the 1956-57 season, Ravi Shankar has served as India's unofficial ambassador for music. He and his sitar - that lovely fretted instrument that looks rather like an archlute's fingerboard with a large gourd attached to either end - have done their best to induct Western concert audiences into the mysteries of India's ancient and intricate classical music, with greater success in some quarters than in others. It was flower-powered youth that really seized on Mr. Shankar as a hero in the 1960's, you will remember. His popularity went clear off the pop charts after the Woodstock Festival in 1969, when he and the eminent Beatle, George Harrison, shared the stage for a memorable set.

title: Birdsongs Rock
description: Birdsongs of the Mesozoic, a progressive-rock band from Boston, will perform early Sunday morning at the Peppermint Lounge, 100 Fifth Avenue, near 15th Street (989-9505). The show begins at about 1 A.M.; tickets are $11.

title: Agency Cites Tongue Ailment As an Early Indicator of AIDS
description: Federal officials have concluded that a tongue sore first identified in San Francisco at the beginning of the AIDS epidemic four years ago is an early indicator of the lethal infection.

title: ART: PORTER PAINTINGS ON DISPLAY
description: FOR artists who believe there is life outside the artistic mainstream, Fairfield Porter remains a tremendously influential figure. He was a modernist in his sense of painting as an immediate, visual fact and in his belief that paint could turn perception into revelation. But also, Porter never stopped emulating the Old Masters, and he loved painting not as an end in itself but as a medium through which he and the world were joined. ''Painting is a way of making the connection between yourself and everything,'' he said.

title: Hutzler-Altman Deal Confirmed
description: The Hutzler Brothers Company, the Baltimore department store chain, confirmed that it had agreed to acquire the retail business of B. Altman & Company from a group of New York real estate investors and to sell a 30 percent interest in Hutzler to those investors and W. R. Grace & Company.

title: Thai Trials Sought In Journalists' Deaths
description: An official of the National Broadcasting Company demanded today that Thailand identify and put on trial the crew of a rebel tank that killed two NBC News journalists as they filmed fighting during an attempted coup here Monday.

title: Budget Deficits Are the Key to Trade
description: To ward off Congress's attack on imports, President Reagan has been reacting to the politics of the protest but ignoring the economic fundamentals. He is straining now to produce a trade policy that can stem the tide of dangerous protectionism; but he still refuses to make the connection between the huge Federal budget deficits and the loss of America's competitiveness.

title: COCAINE SALE IS PUT IN PIRATE CLUBHOUSE
description: John Milner, a former member of the Pittsburgh Pirates, said in United States District Court today that he had purchased cocaine in the Pirates' clubhouse at Three Rivers Stadium during a game in 1980.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 13, 1985
description: International

title: A NOVEL HORSE EVENT, WITH CARRIAGE TEAMS
description: Horses have long been the sport of royalty, kingdoms have been lost for the lack of them and countless millions have pursued racing techniques with a vigor dictated only by the size of a purse. This weekend, however, the sport takes on a different dimension when the Chrysler-Gladstone Driving Event presents equestrian carriage driving with both national and international teams competing at Gladstone, N.J.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE city awoke from the social doldrums of summer this week, donned its collective black tie and plunged into a whirl of dinners, parties and dances. One of the more elegant on many calendars was at the New York State Theater Promenade, where 600 friends and colleagues of Michael I. Sovern marked the fifth anniversary of his presidency at Columbia University.

title: Stopgap Money Bill Gains
description: The House Appropriations Committee approved stopgap legislation today to keep the Government solvent for 45 days after the new fiscal year starts Oct. 1. The bill is needed because Congress has not passed any of the 13 annual bills necessary to provide money for Federal operations and programs.

title: PUEBLO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 10
SENATE KILLS PLAN ON ALEN WORKERS
description: The Senate today narrowly rejected a proposal to admit thousands of aliens to the United States as temporary farm laborers.

title: Job Security Sought By U.A.W. at Chrysler
description: The United Automobile Workers will seek job security provisions from the Chrysler Corporation similar to those the union obtained from the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, union leaders say.

title: Dining Out Guide: Gramercy Park Area
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CAFE DU PARC, #106 East 19th Street (777-7840) -

title: HAROLD VOORHIS, 89, EX-N.Y.U. SECRETARY AND VICE PRESIDENT
description: Harold Oliver Voorhis, former senior vice president and secretary of New York University, died of cancer Aug. 31 at Northside Convalescent Center in Atlanta, where he had lived in recent years. He was 89 years old.

title: EXTENSION FOR SCM ON BAR TO HANSON
description: A Federal judge in New York granted the SCM Corporation a brief extension late yesterday of a temporary restraining order that prevented Hanson Trust P.L.C. from buying more shares in SCM.

title: Bridge: The Right Elements Permit Game in an Unusual Setting
description: One could travel for a lifetime without seeing a bridge game in progress in an airport. The necessary combination of four players, cards, table, time and desire are hardly ever available. But all the elements were present last week in Bermuda's airport, where two New York couples were waiting for the flight home.

title: PAPAL 'COLUMN' WILL CONTINUE, WITH CHANGES
description: A new newspaper column fashioned from the writings and speeches of Pope John Paul II that was strongly criticized by Vatican officials on Tuesday will proceed with Vatican cooperation, an official of the syndicates distributing the column said yesterday.

title: ANTI-SANDINISTA DENIES CHARGES
description: The military commander of the largest Nicaraguan rebel group said today that he knew of ''no evidence'' to support accusations that the rebels frightened young Nicaraguan men into joining them by killing Government officials and their sympathizers in towns and villages.

title: Baseball's Pride, Baseball's Shame
description: The rockets and roars of appreciation that greeted Pete Rose's 4,192d major-league hit screamed America's love of personal achievement and heroes. A gutsy athlete playing his utmost had crashed one of baseball's great barriers, the immortal Ty Cobb's 57-year-old record. That done, he embraced his 15-year-old son, Petey Rose, and told him that the record would be there for him to break someday.

title: Ortho Project
description: The Ortho Pharmaceutical Corporation, a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson, said it was withdrawing from a joint research project with the the McDonnell Douglas Corporation. The project involved testing new pharmaceuticals in laboratories in space, and Ortho said advances in genetic engineering had made its research possible where gravity existed.

title: S.E.C. CITES 3 BANKERS IN TEXAS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that the three top officials of a major Texas bank holding company illegally propped up reported earnings by failing to make sufficient provision for bad loans.

title: For a 'Star Wars' Trade-Off
description: American strategy for the Reagan-Gorbachev summit meeting, only 10 weeks off, hinges on a crucial decision about space weapons that faces the President.

title: FEVER RISES: METS FIRST, YANKS GAINING
description: It's sad. Beth Durso lost her husband, Al, two weeks ago when he succumbed to pennant fever. She said she was a baseball widow now, with Al watching both a Mets game and a Yankees game at home almost every evening and going out to the stadiums on weekends.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HONORABLE MEN. By Louis Auchincloss. 278 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $15.95. BLOOD FOR BLOOD. By Julian Gloag. 302 pages. Holt, Rinehart and Winston. $15.95.

title: Frito-Lay To Needham
description: Frito-Lay Inc., which recently ended its 22-year relationship with Young & Rubicam, has selected Needham Harper Worldwide, Chicago, as its new agency.

title: JOHN Y. DATER 3d
description: John Y. Dater 3d, former publisher of The Ramsey (N.J.) Journal, died of cardiopulmonary arrest Tuesday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y. He was 88 years old and a lifetime resident of Ramsey.

title: SHULTZ PROMOTES ARMS TO JORDAN
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has told a group of Jews in Congress that the Administration is determined to go ahead with a sale of advanced arms to Jordan despite legal roadblocks raised in the latest foreign aid bill, participants in the meeting said today.

title: Why They'd Cut Social Security
description: In the budget debate, we're obsessively told that reductions in the Social Security cost-of-living adjustments hold the key. But COLA cutters - especially advocates of ''generational equity'' - don't tell us they want to protect the rich at everyone else's expense.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in some copies of The Home Section yesterday, with an article about a promotion of Italian products, misidentified the man talking with John T. Sargent and Lily Auchincloss. He was Rinaldo Petrignani, Italian Ambassador to the United States.

title: AMID THE BIG ISSUES OF THE DAY, TOLLS ON VERRAZANO
description: Congress has momentous issues before it this fall.

title: APPLIED SOLAR ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
description: b-Net income after tax credits of $151,000 for the quarter and $891,000 for the 9 months. c-After a charge of $133,000 in connection with Stauffer Chemical Co.'s purchase of 1,576,000 common shares of Applied Solar in the first quarter.

title: K.G.B. DEFECTS AND BRITISH ORDER 25 RUSSIANS HOME
description: A key Soviet intelligence agent in Britain has defected and exposed a major espionage network, prompting an order for the ouster of 25 Russians, the Government announced today.

title: REAGAN ASSAILS CUOMO'S OBJECTIONS TO TAX PLAN
description: President Reagan today assailed Governor Cuomo's criticism of the Administration's tax-overhaul proposals as ''balderdash'' and said they would save New York State taxpayers $588 million a year.

title: ROPER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: Drug Is Linked to Risk Of Contracting AIDS
description: Researchers have confirmed suspicions that isobutyl nitrite, a recreational drug widely used as an aphrodisiac by homosexuals, increases the risk of contracting acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS.

title: BOY'S STRANGE PITCH DANCES NEAR 300TH
description: The years have passed quickly, but Phil Niekro can still remember the warm summer afternoons in Bridgeport, Ohio, when a boy learned to throw a strange pitch that danced in the air during sandlot games with his chums.

title: Rockefeller Center Inc.
description: Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., a real estate investment trust, began a worldwide offering yesterday of three separate securities issues totaling $1.3 billion, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: FOR JAYS' FERNANDEZ A NIGHT TO FORGET
description: Tony Fernandez secluded himself in the trainer's room last night, perhaps to sort out his thoughts and use an instant replay in his mind of the fateful seventh inning. When he returned to his dressing stall and saw a group of reporters close in, he waved them away and shook his head.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption Wednesday on a picture from The Associated Press with an article about offshore oil and gas development misidentified a California Representative. He was William E. Dannemeyer, not Mel Levine.

title: U.S. Investigators Clear Dr. Gross
description: A Federal investigation of Dr. Elliot M. Gross, the Chief Medical Examiner of New York City, ended yesterday when the Justice Department announced there was no evidence that he had violated any Federal laws.

title: MORALITY AS A PARTY GAME
description: You have a serious long-distance romance. To relieve loneliness, you start a romantic friendship locally. Do you mention your commitment? In the supermarket, you send a dozen packages tumbling into the aisle. No one sees you. Do you walk away?

title: Infant Is Crushed in Stroller When Car Mounts Sidewalk
description: A 6-month old girl was killed yesterday by an out-of-control automobile that mounted the sidewalk at Madison Street and Jefferson Streets on the Lower East Side and crushed her in her stroller, the police said.

title: G.O.P. AGAIN BLOCKS SENATE ACTION ON SANCTIONS
description: The Republican leadership in the Senate barred the Democrats today from pressing ahead with legislation that would impose economic sanctions against the Government of South Africa.

title: KIRKPATRICK RECEIVES AWARD FOR EFFORTS ON BEHALF OF ISRAEL
description: Dr. Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, former chief United States delegate to the United Nations, was named yesterday as a co-recipient of the 1985 Jabotinsky Prize-Defender of Jerusalem Award for her ''valiant support of Israel and the Jewish people during her tenure at the United Nations.''

title: From Broad St. To New York
description: The New York Slapshots, a first-year franchise in the Atlantic Coast Hockey League, plan to announce today that their general manager and coach will be Dave Schultz. Remember him? Mike Rogers does. ''The thing I remember,'' says Rogers, the Ranger center who played against Schultz during a previous tenure with the New England Whalers, ''was that I stayed away from him.''

title: IT'S PETE ROSE DAY ON PETE ROSE WAY
description: Saying that ''he's ours, we love him,'' Mayor Charles J. Luken of Cincinnati climbed a ladder at a brief ceremony today to unveil the first of the signs renaming Second Street as Pete Rose Way.

title: Horse Racing;   SWOLLEN ANKLE SIDELINES SPEND A BUCK
description: Swelling in Spend a Buck's right front ankle will keep him out of the Pennsylvania Derby Sunday. It also could prompt his early retirement because his career appeared to be heading nowhere after that race.

title: Put Wollman Ice Rink Into Private Hands
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. DROPS DRAFT REGISTRATION CHECKS BY COLLEGES
description: The Education Department has dropped a disputed rule requiring colleges to verify that male students receiving Federal aid have registered for the draft, officials confirmed today.

title: Grand Ol' Private Dancer
description: When was the last time a Republican Congressman persuaded Tina Turner, the rock singer, to star in a fund-raising event? It may not be unprecedented, but the latest instance involves Rep-resentative Manuel Lujan Jr. of New Mexico and his Endowment of Excellence in Education, which awards $500 scholarships to one senior in each of the 21 high schools in his district. Proceeds of Miss Turner's Oct. 20 appearance at the State Fairgrounds in Albuquerque are expected to move the endowment from its current $200,000 in assets much closer to its goal of $500,000.

title: To Protect World Trade
description: Attempts to stem the mounting pressure for trade protectionism are breaking down. President Reagan's recent complaints against the Common Market, Japan, South Korea and Brazil were pinpricks, intended to divert Congress from launching a barrage against imports. They aren't likely to defuse the fury on capitol hill, but they probably will increase foreign demands for retaliation.

title: No 'Normal' Plutonium
description: To the Editor:

title: Money Supply Up $1.4 Billion
description: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday, as improvement in the economy and continued rapid money supply growth continues to discourage purchases of notes and bonds by investors and speculators.

title: 'STAR WARS' FOES PRESS FOR BOYCOTT
description: A recently formed group of scientists and engineers is trying to get colleagues across the country to sign an unusual pledge of refusal to participate in research for the Reagan Administration's plan to create a space-based shield against nuclear attack.

title: 'Barbara Walters Special' Marks 10th Anniversary
description: ''The Barbara Walters Special'' isn't any old special; it's Miss Walters's 10th anniversary special and, all things considered, it's pretty good. Miss Walters gives us Princess Caroline of Monaco, Barbra Streisand, Priscilla Presley and, of course, herself.

title: Competitive Businesses
description: Millions of dollars had nothing to do with the latest real-estate battle in Manhattan.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is certainly true that all of us who use and work in the subway, from time to time, have bordered on becoming savage beasts.

title: Wallace Might Run Again
description: Gov. George C. Wallace said today that the intense pain caused by his paralysis was gone, thanks to spinal surgery, and he was considering running for a fifth four-year term. Mr. Wallace underwent surgery July 24 in Englewood, Colo., to deaden a 2-inch section of his spinal cord that was damaged in a 1972 assassination attempt.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 13, 1985
description: The Economy

title: Market Place;   Finding Stocks Nobody Wants
description: AFTER investors, brokerage-house analysts and the financial community have become disenchanted with a stock, Roderick MacIver is apt to take notice. His Toronto-based firm uses what he calls ''investigative research techniques'' to uncover investment ideas for institutional clients in the United States.

title: CHIEFS TOP RAIDERS
description: Nick Lowery tied a club record with five field goals and Bill Kenney threw two touchdown passes tonight, leading the Kansas City Chiefs to a 36-20 victory over the Los Angeles Raiders.

title: Israel's High Court Upholds Ouster of 11 From West Bank
description: Israel's Supreme Court today upheld military orders to expel 11 Palestinians from the occupied West Bank, a military spokesman said.

title: Reorganization Plan by Lionel
description: The Lionel Corporation said yesterday that the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York had approved a new reorganization plan.

title: VOLCKER REVIVES BANK FEARS
description: Banking-industry groups and bank analysts warned yesterday that many of the nation's smaller commercial banks could be hurt by a proposal endorsed by the Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, to increase the capital requirements of banks.

title: TAKE THE R TRAIN TO A BALKAN CELEBRATION
description: FOR 12 hours tomorrow, the crossroads of Serbia, Greece, Armenia, Italy and the Soviet Union will be a tree-shaded beer garden in Queens. The occasion is the 10th Annual Queens Ethnic Music and Dance Festival, put on at Bohemian Hall and Park in Astoria by the Ethnic Folk Arts Center - an annual blowout at which lambs roast on spits, musicians hold forth, families dine and dance and New York English is just one local dialect. Is it a concert? A dance? A picnic?

title: EX-LEGISLATOR WINS REVERSAL OF CONVICTION
description: Joseph R. Pisani, a former State Senator from New Rochelle, won a court decision yesterday reversing most of his 1984 conviction on fraud and tax charges.

title: Sale of Lance Bank Dropped
description: The First Railroad and Banking Company today abandoned plans to acquire Calhoun First National Bank, citing ''pending controversies'' involving the bank and its chairman, Bert Lance.

title: AMERICARE HEALTH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the year-ago quarter figures include a downward adjustment of $608,000 in the carrying value of short-term fixed income investments to reflect a decrease in the value of such investments to below cost. The company did not report share earnings for the 1984 year and converted from a nonprofit to profit corporate status on Feb. 3, 1984, and accordingly income taxes have been provided only since that date.

title: SALVADOR RIGHTS VIOLATIONS CHARGED
description: A private human rights group today condemned both the United States-backed Salvadoran Government and the leftist guerrillas fighting it for violating the ''laws of war'' in attacks on civilians this year.

title: Quilters' Exhibition
description: Members of the Manhattan Quilters Guild are exhibiting their handiwork at the Donnell Library Center of the New York Public Library, 20 West 53d Street. Fifteen quilts in contemporary and traditional designs will be on view through Sept. 30. Hours are 9:30 A.M. to 6 P.M. today, 9:30 A.M. to 5:30 tomorrow and 1 to 5 Sunday.

title: COLLINS & AIKMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
GULL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $117,000.

title: WHITE HOUSE OFFERS NEW PACKAGE TO END TRUCKING REGULATION
description: The Reagan Administration, in a legislative package submitted to Congress today, urged that the remaining economic restrictions on the interstate trucking industry be eliminated.

title: A NEW TOP COMMAND FOR THE PORT AUTHORITY: STEPHEN BERGER
description: ''I've had a series of terrific careers,'' Stephen Berger said yesterday between telephone calls at the investment firm where he has been working for three years, ''and each one was useful preparing for the next one.''

title: U.S. CONCERNED ON ATOM PERIL IN SUBCONTINENT
description: The Reagan Administration is sending two high-level officials to India and Pakistan to express concern about the possible development of a nuclear weapon by Pakistan and about overall tensions in the region, officials said today.

title: WESTINGHOUSE RADAR PAYMENTS HALT
description: The Air Force has withheld more than $155 million in contract payments from the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the Boeing Company because of defects in advanced new radar systems Westinghouse makes for F-16 fighter jets and B-1B bombers, Air Force officials said today.

title: Unitary Tax Bill Advances
description: The State Senate has approved a bill that would alter California's unitary method of taxing multinational corporations. It now goes for a final vote to the Assembly, which is to adjourn at midnight Friday.

title: LANDAU, 5 TO 5, RETAINS PUBLIC BROADCAST POST
description: Sonia Landau today kept her job as chairman of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting in a 5-to-5 vote by members of the board.

title: STEPHEN R. ELLSWORTH
description: Stephen R. Ellsworth, a featured actor in more than 100 teleplays and five movies, died of heart failure Tuesday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Paterson, N.J. He was 77 years old and lived in the Actors' Fund Home in Englewood, N.J.

title: BLUESKY OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
RESTAURANTS
description: THE OYSTER BAR and Restaurant in Grand Central Station is pushing 70. But happily for seafood aficionados, it is blithely ignoring mandatory retirement laws. The grand vaulted ceiling with its rim of twinkling lights is as impressive today as it was back when trains were clean and rail schedules were more than ballpark estimates. Unlike the commuter trains that thunder beneath the dining room, the Oyster Bar has upheld its quality over the years, so that it is still one of the best spots in town for uncompromisingly fresh seafood.

title: Relative of Sakharov Ends a Hunger Strike
description: The stepson of Andrei D. Sakharov ended a two-week hunger strike today after saying that the State Department had pledged to try to obtain the physicist's freedom before the November meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: The Editor Watch
description: As part of the continuing revamping of the editorial structure at U.S. News & World Report, Henry L. Trewhitt is taking over as deputy managing editor for international affairs.

title: COAST TRIAL BEGINS FOR NEO-NAZIS WHO SOUGHT RACIAL WAR IN U.S.
description: A neo-Nazi group held prayer meetings before taking up machine guns for robberies that were to finance a racial war resulting in the overthrow of the United States Government, prosecutors said today at the trial of 11 of the group's members.

title: MISTRIAL IS REJECTED IN STEWART CASE
description: Defense attorneys in the Michael Stewart case called yesterday for a mistrial, contending that the prosecution had departed from its original case by introducing new accusations.

title: SCREEN: 'NATURE CALLS'
description: ''WHEN NATURE CALLS'' is a movie comedy and a comedy about movies. Sometimes you can laugh heartily at this ambitious put-on and at other times you may find its preciosity more off-putting than on-putting. It opens today at the Criterion and other theaters.

title: Thrift Inquiry In Maryland
description: A Federal grand jury here began hearing testimony this week in an investigation into Maryland's savings and loan crisis, state sources said today.

title: Transway Urges Nortek Rejection
description: The Transway International Corporation said that it was urging shareholders to reject a $45-a-share takeover offer from Nortek Inc. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Transway's board said that it would seek other transactions that ''would provide stockholders with more value for their shares than the Nortek offer.''

title: Rhode Island Teachers Ordered Back to Work
description: Striking teachers in Rhode Island were ordered back to work yesterday, but teachers in five other states walked the picket lines, keeping more than 100,000 students out of the classoom.

title: JACLYN INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The year-ago share earnings was restated to reflect the 4 percent stock dividend paid in June 1985.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday HOME FIX-UP TIPS Your closet is too small to hold another shoe? Your kitchen could only be comfortably utilized by its resident cockroaches? If you've got a bad case of the New York City Apartment-Dweller Blues, the Big Apple Fix-Up might be a good way to start making your living quarters more livable. A three-day home improvement show starting today at the New York Coliseum, the Big Apple Fix-Up will feature exhibits, seminars, workshops, lectures and demonstrations on a wide variety of topics. You can bring a picture of a decorating or structural problem and get on-the-spot advice from Parsons School of Design experts at a home-improvement clinic; observe techniques like marbleizing and trompe l'oeil, or learn about subjects that range from water conservation methods to home security. The fix-up, which is sponsored by the City of New York as a nonprofit public service, runs from noon to 10 P.M. today, from 11 A.M. to 10 P.M. on Saturday and from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. on Sunday at the Coliseum, Columbus Circle at 60th Street. Admission is $5, but if you bring an apple (don't eat it; it has to be a whole one), you get a $1 discount; the apples will be donated to charity. Information: 765-0350.

title: CREATIONIST INFLUENCE STIRRING STATE REACTIONS
description: In rejecting about 30 seventh and eighth grade science textbooks with the argument that publishers are weakening lessons on evolution to avoid controversy, the California Board of Education yesterday was in effect reacting to the strong influence that backers of the creationist doctrine have had in the nation's classrooms in recent years.

title: JUDGE BARS DEATH SENTENCE IN NAVY SPY TRIAL ON COAST
description: Federal District Judge John P. Vukasin Jr. ruled today that the death penalty did not apply in the espionage case of Jerry A. Whitworth, one of four Navy men accused of spying for the Soviet Union.

title: NO PLAYERS ARE CALLED
description: For the first time in seven days, the prosecution did not call baseball players to testify in the cocaine-trafficking trial of Curtis Strong. Instead, the Government turned today to a presentation of physical evidence designed to show that the Philadelphia caterer was involved in cocaine deals in Pittsburgh.

title: MEN VS. WOMEN
description: STANLEY AND THE WOMEN. By Kingsley Amis. 256 pages. Summit Books. $14.95. Kingsley Amis's male characters have never had a particularly easy time of it with women - nor do they hold particularly enlightened views about the opposite sex. Half of his heroes are obsessed with finding ways of getting one pretty girl or another into bed; the other half are preoccupied with finding ways of avoiding the wrath of their irascible mates. ''I don't even like them much,'' says one fellow, adding, and ''I despise them intellectually.''

title: We Must Rethink Our Sugar Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: ALAGAE DESTROY EASTERN L.I.'S SCALLOP HARVEST
description: Algae covering Peconic Bay throughout the summer have destroyed the commercially valuable scallop crop here on eastern Long Island, scientists and baymen said this week as scallopers prepared to begin their annual harvest.

title: THE PERILS OF INCREASING OFFSHORE OUTPUT
description: To the Editor:

title: MARCUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 22
EX.-C.I.A. AIDE TESTIFIES IN HAGUE
description: A former C.I.A. insurgency specialist testified to the World Court today that the agency had drafted a plan to send 1,500 armed rebels into Nicaragua and had won President Reagan's approval of it.

title: THE BANK KEPT FROM A RUN
description: Repair of an unsound tax bill and creative transfer of development rights from a landmark encouraged the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company to keep its headquarters securely in New York. Morgan considered moving substantial parts of its growing operations out of the state altogether in order to escape an imprudent bank tax, but it has now committed itself to occupying a new building on Wall Street.

title: DANGER POINT
description: George Rogers, whose fumble last Monday night at Dallas marked a turning point in the 44-14 thrashing administered by the Cowboys, has promised the Washington Redskins that there won't be a recurrence. ''It's a blood oath,'' says the Redskins' backfield coach, Don Breaux. ''If he fumbles again, I get his blood.''

title: WORLD BANK RISK AGENCY SET
description: The World Bank, seeking to counter a decline in private capital flows to the third world, outlined plans today to insure the political risks of corporations that make investments in poor countries.

title: BLACK POLITICDAL LEADERS' DIVISIONS APPEAR AGAIN AFTER NEW YORK PRIMARY
description: Black politicians in New York City, after submerging some of their differences during the Democratic primary campaign, say sharp divisions are reappearing despite the nomination and almost-certain election of a black as Manhattan borough president.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Dan Reeves, the coach of the Denver Broncos since 1981, has signed a contract extension that will keep him with the club through 1989. . . . Ron Springs, the former Dallas Cowboys running back who was convicted of resisting arrest when two officers tried to remove him from a topless bar in January, was placed on 45 days probation and fined $2,000 yesterday. . . . Ray Pinney, a Pittsburgh Steelers starting offensive tackle for three years until jumping in 1983 to the United States Football League, where he played with the Michigan Panthers and Oakland Invaders, signed a multi-year contract yesterday with the N.F.L. team. . . . Pedro Guerrero, the Los Angeles Dodgers outfielder, will be out of action for three to five days with a sprained wrist, the club announced yesterday. . . . Frank Shorter, the 1972 gold medalist in the Olympic marathon, has entered the New York City Marathon Oct. 27. . . . Bob Weinhauer, the former basketball coach at Arizona State, is in line to take over the Detroit Spirits of the Continental Basketball Association, according to The Phoenix Gazette.

title: PANTRY PRIDE CUTS REVLON BID
description: Pantry Pride Inc. said yesterday that it was lowering its offer for Revlon Inc. in a move intended, in part, to put pressure on the board of the big cosmetics company. Its new bid, $42 a share, is $5.50 lower than an offer made last month and rejected by Revlon.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL CLEVELAND (AL) - Named Jack Aker pitching coach; Doc Edwards, bullpen coach, and Fred Koenig, third-base coach.

title: WARRANT SEEKS EX-JERSEY SENATOR WHO VANISHED BEFORE SENTENCING
description: An arrest warrant has been issued for former State Senator David J. Friedland, a convicted felon scheduled to be sentenced Sept. 23, who purportedly disappeared last week while scuba diving in the Bahamas, authorities said today.

title: SERVO CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Tighter Security
description: The marshal of the United States Supreme Court, Alfred Wong, has notified the Justices and other employees that tighter security begins at the Court building next Monday. At all entrances, metal detectors will screen visitors and X-ray machines will screen their bags and purses. The nine Justices and all employees with Court identification cards will be exempt.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Aug. 5 about the developer and publisher Mortimer B. Zuckerman misstated the amount he had sought in a fee disagreement with a former employer, the Boston real estate firm of Cabot, Cabot & Forbes. He had expected to receive $4 million - an amount, plus interest, that he was eventually awarded in court - not $2 million, the amount offered by the firm. The article also misstated the price paid by Mr. Zuckerman the site of the New York Coliseum - it was $455.1 million - and the amount he paid for U.S. News & World Report, which was $163.2 million.

title: ARTHRITIS AT THE JUSTICE DEPARTMENT
description: Oraflex is an arthritis drug that may have caused 26 deaths and 200 serious side effects in America. All that might have been prevented if earlier side effects in Britain had been promptly reported to the Food and Drug Administration. The Justice Department charges that Eli Lilly, the drug's maker, failed to do so. Yet last month it let a single Lilly official plead no contest, and merely to a misdemeanor. Why?

title: RECITAL: CLIVE SWANSBOURNE, PIANIST
description: The English pianist Clive Swansbourne's program Thursday night at Carnegie Recital Hall consisted of concentric circles. The outer ring, at the beginning and end, was formed by two excerpts from Messiaen's ''Vingt Regards sur l'Enfant Jesus'' - ''Le Baiser de l'Enfant Jesus'' and ''Regard de l'Esprit de Joie.'' After the first Messiaen and before the last came two Beethoven sonatas, (Op. 109 and Op. 31, No. 1). The inner circle (with the intermission at the center) was made up of late-Romantic Slavic music composed in the first two decades of the 20th century: Karol Szymanowski's ''Masques'' (Op. 16) and three Rachmaninoff Preludes (Op. 32, No. 1; Op. 23, No. 7, and Op. 23, No. 4).

title: PRATT-READ CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: NEW CHINA-VIETNAM CLASHES
description: China said today that Vietnamese troops mounted 22 attacks against Yunnan Province this week, killing ''large numbers'' of Chinese civilians. Peking said the attacks began Sunday and continued through Thursday.

title: 4 ROBBERY SUSPECTS SEIZED AFTER STOP BY HIGHWAY UNIT
description: Four gunmen robbed three armed guards of $100,000 in Queens yesterday but were arrested a mile away after they ran a red light in their getaway car, the police said.

title: FROM NBC, TWO NEW SATURDAY NIGHTS SITCOMS
description: Determined to make Saturday night comedy night, NBC is supplementing two of its established series - ''Gimme a Break'' at 8 o'clock and ''The Facts of Life'' at 8:30 - with two new situation comedies: ''The Golden Girls'' at 9 and ''227'' at 9:30. The network no doubt remembers the period in the early 1970's when CBS held a hammerlock on first place in the ratings with its Saturday comedy lineup, which at one point consisted of ''All in the Family,'' ''M*A*S*H,'' ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show,'' ''The Bob Newhart Show'' and ''The Carol Burnett Comedy Hour.'' There was no better ticket for laughs anywhere.

title: UNGAR PUBLISHING IS BOUGHT BY CONTINUUM
description: The Frederick Ungar Publishing Company, an independent house started in New York 45 years ago by a refugee from Nazism, has been sold for an undisclosed sum to the Continuum Publishing Corporation. The 87-year-old Mr. Ungar, who started his first publishing house in Vienna in 1922, will continue as publisher.

title: METS GAIN A SPLIT AND CLING TO LEAD
description: Far from the clamor and the crowds of Baseball Thursday in New York, the Mets suffered a bit of a lapse tonight when they split a doubleheader with the Montreal Expos and lost half of their one-game lead in the National League East.

title: PROLER INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Shelter Planned at Barracks
description: The Federal Government has agreed to spend $600,000 to rehabilitate three rundown barracks at Fort Meade to house up to 60 homeless men, women and children, officials of Anne Arundel County announced today. The barracks will become the nation's third and largest shelter at a military base. The shelters were established under a program ordered by Congress, a spokesman for the base said.

title: INTEREST RATES SHOW DECLINES
description: Long- and short-term interest rates fell across the board yesterday in response to economic indicators that some analysts believe may portend a less-than-robust rebound.

title: ON RECIPES AND LOBSTERS
description: The volume of mail from readers often bears little relationship to the importance of a story. Articles on the national deficit may elicit fewer responses than a recipe in which an ingredient is missing.

title: Jail in Ohio Emptied For Lack of Money
description: A judge released the last five prisoners in the Jackson County jail today after the sheriff told him there was no money to keep the jail open.

title: GTE UNIT'S ESCROW BID HALTED U.S. DEBARMENT
description: In an undisclosed part of the arrangement under which it pleaded guilty to illegally obtaining Pentagon documents, the GTE Government Systems Corporation offered to put $3 million in escrow to cover possible penalties for overcharging on Defense Department contracts, Government officials said today.

title: REFRACTORIES CO.
description: The General Refractories Company said Belmont Industries, owned by Raymond G. Perelman, had succeeded in electing nine directors to the 11-member Refractories board. It said Mr. Perelman had been elected chairman and chief executive officer, succeeding Robert W. Smith, who remains president. Refractories also said all litigation between the parties would be ended and Refractories would end its offer to exchange a new preferred stock for outstanding common stock.

title: CESSNA, DYNAMICS IN MERGER
description: The last four years have been a time almost all manufacturers of small aircraft would like to forget. Demand for the commercial and private planes plummeted as competition from foreign producers and product-development costs both soared. Losses and plant consolidations became the hallmark of the battered industry. Recently, two companies -Gulfstream Aerospace and Bangor Punta, owner of Piper Aircraft -merged with bigger companies that had greater financial resources.

title: CITY OPERA: SOME CAST CHANGES IN 'MANON'
description: Massenet's ''Manon,'' which is entering its second century with a boost from the New York City Opera, was given its fourth performance of the season by that company at the State Theater on Wednesday. Faith Esham, the soprano who has been filling the title role with notable vivacity, was again on hand as the dazzler accustomed to having life revolve about her, but there were wholesale cast changes otherwise.

title: METROCARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
REAGAN TAX PLAN TO BE TOPIC IN SHCOOLS
description: At the request of New York State's top education officials, New York City and 14 other school districts will conduct social-studies classes in the next few weeks on President Reagan's plan for reshaping the Federal income-tax system.

title: AUTOS SPUR RETAIL SALES GAIN
description: Retail sales, powered by a huge jump in auto sales, rose 1.9 percent in August, the best showing in four months, the Government reported today.

title: TRUCK KILLS BROOKLYN GIRL, 2
description: A 2-year-old girl was struck and killed by a private sanitation truck yesterday as her grandmother was wheeling her across a Brooklyn intersection in her baby carriage. The girl, Christina Carpenter of 3851 Flatlands Avenue in Brooklyn, was killed at Hendrickson Street and Flatlands Avenue, the police said. The truck driver was not charged.

title: BANK IN ROCKLAND SHUT BY THE U.S. AS INSOLVENT
description: The Federal Government closed the People's National Bank of Rockland County in the town of Ramapo, N.Y., today, declaring it insolvent.

title: COCHRANE FURNITURE CO reports earnings for Year to June 1
DEALING WITH RACKETEERS IN EXECUTIVE SUITESChange the Law
description: The United States Supreme Court last July issued a ruling that is bound to spawn unbridled use of the triple-damage provisions of a Federal antiracketeering law. Over strongly worded dissenting opinions, the Court, in a 5-4 decision, refused to restrict the scope of the statute.

title: CONTROL DATA
description: The Control Data Corporation said today that it was committed to paying dividends on its preferred and common stock. The company issued its statement after predicting in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it would sustain a ''sizable operating loss'' for its computer business this year, which it said has already lost $32.7 million before taxes through June 30.

title: Iraq Is Buying 45 U.S.-Made Copters
description: A White House spokesman confirmed today that Iraq was buying 45 American-made 20-seat helicopters once destined for Iran and said the purchase has been designated a commercial transaction.

title: TCA CABLE TV INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
...BUT APPRECITATED IN GOTHAM
description: ''In a perfect world, there'd be no need for the Women Business Owners of New York,'' Governor Cuomo, back in New York, told 600 people gathered yesterday at the annual conference of the organization at the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: OPERA: NEW PRODUCTION OF 'LOVE FOR 3 ORANGES'
description: The New York City Opera has a new star: a lady of formidable stature and irresistible charm who stole the show last night at the opening of Prokofiev's ''Love for Three Oranges.'' A 30-foot-high prima donna created by Maurice Sendak, the production's designer, this hugely appealing creature played the fat role of the Cook with relish, scoring one of the season's truly gargantuan hits.

title: OLYMPICS GROUP HALTS TALKS ON TELEVISION RIGHTS IN SEOUL
description: The International Olympic Committee suspended negotiations with the three major United States television networks today over the rights to broadcast the 1988 Games in Seoul, South Korea, and gave the networks 10 days to submit higher offers.

title: TRAIN RIDERSHIP ON N.J. TRANSIT RISES 8 PERCENT
description: Average daily ridership on N.J. Transit's rail system, after falling steadily in recent years, has risen by 8 percent this year, to the levels of the late 1970's, officials of N.J. Transit said today. Ridership on commuter trains has increased by 5,600 passengers, bringing the daily average to 70,900, up from 65,300 a year ago. Officials said the increase had helped to maintain fares at current levels and preclude requests for increased state transit subsidies.

title: ECONOMIC REPORTS SEND STOCKS LOWER
description: The stock market turned in its fourth consecutive decline yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average closed out its worst weekly performance in six months. Traders cited the latest economic figures coming out of Washington, which many experts said indicated that the economy might not rebound so much as expected in the second half.

title: 'NEW YORK BANKS ARE CRAZY'
description: I always knew banks were reluctant to give you their money. But now New York banks won't give you your own. Sometimes they won't even take your money.

title: INDIA IS SAID TO DROP PROSECUTION OF A.P. REPORTER IN PUNJAB CASE
description: The Government has dropped legal procceedings against a reporter for The Associated Press, Brahma Chellaney, who was accused of inflammatory reporting about army operations in the Punjab last year, a senior official says.

title: CRACKER BARREL OLD COUNRY STORE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Hamilton Jordan, CArter Aide, Is Hospitalized With Cancer
description: Hamilton Jordan, who was President Carter's chief of staff, has been hospitalized here with cancer of the lymph system, the authorities said tonight.

title: TEAMSTERS IN PACT ON HAULING CARS
description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters announced today the narrow approval of a three-year contract with the automobile-hauling industry.

title: DATA SOUGHT ON SMITHKLINE INQUIRY
description: Senate and House investigators studying the Justice Department's handling of corporate crime said today that they would request documents on the department's prosecution of a drug company that failed to disclose lethal effects of a blood-pressure drug.

title: KARPOV WINS 4TH GAME TO TIE CHESS MARCH, 2-2
description: Anatoly Karpov evened his world chess title defense match by sharply defeating Gary Kasparov in the fourth game yesterday in Moscow's Tchaikovsky Concert Hall. The score stands at 2-2.

title: CANADA TOUGHENS VIEW ON PRETORIA
description: Canada warned South Africa today that it would impose stringent sanctions against that nation unless there were changes in the policy of apartheid.

title: COALITION BACKS 'STAR WARS'
description: An alliance of members of Congress and private groups today announced the creation of a Coalition for the Strategic Defense Initiative to promote President Reagan's research plan to develop a defense against nuclear attack.

title: CANADA INFLATION RISES
description: Vegetable and meat prices fell sharply last month but it was not enough to prevent an increase in Canada's annual inflation rate, which edged back up to 4 percent from 3.8 percent in July, the Government's Statistics Canada agency said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 14, 1985

title: BRAZIL'S BATTERED WOMEN FIND HAVEN FROM ABUSE
description: Twisting a handkerchief nervously in her hand, one woman recounted how a younger sister had been shot four times in the back by her husband. When asked to arrest the man, she said, a police official remarked indifferently that the victim must have committed adultery.

title: Buckley Enters Hospital
description: William F. Buckley Jr., the author and columnist, was admitted at a Detroit hospital today after complaining of chest and stomach pains, an aide said. Mr. Buckley, 59 years old, who was scheduled to address the State Bar of Michigan at its 50th anniversary convention, was first taken to Detroit Receiving Hospital, then admitted to the coronary care unit at Harper Hospital, said his secretary, Francis Bronson. '' There is no diagnosis,'' Miss Bronson said. ''He's in stable condition.''

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 28.

title: SATORI ENTERTAINMENT CORP reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Net loss.

title:
PATENTS;

RAISING IMAGES ON PERSONAL COPIERS
description: Ezekiel J. Jacob of Brooklyn received a patent this week on a toner for producing raised images on personal copiers.

title: COMPACT VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
'Cop' Video Cassette Goes on Sale in October
description: Paramount Home Video will release the blockbuster movie ''Beverly Hills Cop,'' starring Eddie Murphy, on video cassette Oct. 30. The price will be $29.95.

title: For Uniform Living-Will Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: PAWNBORKING: A DYING TRADE
description: Three gold balls, medieval symbols of the pawnbroker, have dangled over the entrance of the S.&.G. Gross Company since 1901, and for almost as long a sepia-toned photo of the hundreds of members of the Pawnbrokers' Association of New York has hung on a wall inside.

title: REPORT ON CAPITAL GAINS DETAILS RATE CUTS' EFFECT
description: The Treasury Department reported today that cuts in capital gains tax rates in 1978 and again in 1981 had helped the national economy without significantly reducing Federal revenue.

title: AMERICAN BUILDING MAINTENANCE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
MAN CONVICTED OF DECEPTION OVER RESORT CONDOMINIUMS
description: A man who promoted time shares of condominium units has received a two-year jail sentence for violating a court order that forbade him to engage in deceptive practices in selling the shares, the Federal Trade Commission said today.

title: CARDS' CEDENO HELPS DEFEAT CUBS, 9-3
description: Cesar Cedeno had a pair of run-scoring singles, including one in a three-run first inning, and Willie McGee scored three runs today as the St. Louis Cardinals rolled to a 9-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

title: JUMBO JET ABORTS LANDING
description: A British Airways jetliner with 412 people on board was forced to abort its takeoff from O'Hare International Airport Thursday when one of its engines backfired, the authorities said today. No injuries were reported in the incident, which occurred on Flight 296, a Boeing 747 jumbo jet bound for London.

title: REAGAN URGES GORBACHEV TO GIVE CONCRETE PROPOSALS IN ARMS TALKS
description: President Reagan today called on Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, to translate his publicly stated readiness for sharp cuts in nuclear forces into ''concrete proposals'' at the Geneva arms talks, which resume next week.

title: DEALING WITH RACKETEERS IN EXECUTIVE SUITES Triple Damages
description: A large-scale corporate lobbying campaign is about to hit Congress. Its goal - to repeal or severely cripple the Federal anti-racketeering law, the Racketeering Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act. Its motive - to relieve corporations engaged in fraudulent activities from the threat of triple-damage lawsuits.

title: SISTER OF HENRY LUCE DIES
description: Emmavail Luce Severinghaus, the sister of the founder of Time magazine, has died at the age of 85.

title: SOBERING YEAR FOR MAGAZINES
description: At Newsweek, advertising pages have fallen 9 percent from last year. At Business week, they have slipped 12 percent. And at Sports Illustrated, 13 percent.

title: DIVERSIFIED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $403,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,402,000 for the quarter and $1,526,000 for the 9 months; a gain of $10,651,000 from the settlement of litigation for quarter and 9 months, and after tax credits of $8,267,000 and $8,401,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. d-After a gain from discontinued operations of $1,620,000, or 28 cents a share, and a tax credit of $2,367,000.

title: METRO AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CORRECTION
description: A review of the American Ballet Theater yesterday misidentified the dancer who will perform the title role of ''Giselle'' tomorrow in a matinee at the Metropolitan Opera House. She is Cynthia Harvey, not Leslie Browne.

title: INJURY STOPS LAUDA
description: Niki Lauda of Austria, the defending world champion Formula One driver, was knocked out of the Belgian Grand Prix yesterday after the accelerator of his Maclaren-TAG-Porsche became stuck during a practice run for tomorrow's race. The car crashed into a guard rail at more than 100 miles an hour and left Lauda with a severely sprained wrist. Lauda's departure left his teammate, Alain Prost of France, with the provisional post position.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES TO DOUBLE AIDS RESEARCH FUNDS
description: A House Appropriations subcommittee has voted to double the budget for research on AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome, and to increase funds for other education and public health programs on the fatal disease, Representative Edward R. Roybal, Democrat of California, said today.

title: PROSECUTORS IN AQUINO CASE SPURN NEW DATA FROM U.S.
description: Prosecutors in the trial of 26 people accused in the assassination in 1983 of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. today rejected evidence supplied by the United States that described what appeared to be unusual activity by the Philippine Air Force on the day the opposition leader was slain.

title: MUTUAL FUND RULE ON COSTS
description: THE Securities and Exchange Commission has come up with a proposal that it believes will help mutual fund investors make a more valid comparison of the annual yields that funds offer.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS AND TOP REBELS MEET IN ZAMBIA
description: White South African businessmen and newspaper editors held talks in Zambia today with leaders of the main rebel group opposed to white minority rule in South Africa.

title: WHITNEY PRESIDENT
description: The Whitney Communications Corporation has named Bernard W. Kiernan president and William M. O'Shea to the additional post of secretary. Mr. Kiernan, 54 years old, had been senior vice president, while Mr. O'Shea, 42, continues as treasurer.

title: Alienated by Censors
description: To the Editor:

title: Crash of a Private Plane In Alabama Kills Six
description: A twin-engine plane that reported engine trouble crashed and burned today in a soybean field in northern Alabama, killing six people, the authorities said.

title: SYRIANS AND ISRAELIS FORTIFY POSITIONS ON GOLAN HEIGHTS
description: Syria and Israel have fortified their military positions on the Golan Heights in recent days, a development that has raised tensions in the area.

title: O'BRIEN PATH CLEARS QUICKLY
description: After months of practice and film study at the Jets' training facility, after hours and hours spent digesting The System, Ken O'Brien suddenly became a better quarterback this week.

title: TIRED OF THE IVY
description: David Del Tredici, who won the Pulitzer Prize for music in 1980, has become a professor at City College. ''It's wonderful at last to work in the city I want to live in,'' Professor Del Tredici said.

title: SATELLITE'S FLIGHT SUGGESTS COMET HAS CORE OF ICE
description: Data from the first spacecraft to fly through the tail of a comet appeared to confirm the theory characterizing comets as ''large dirty snowballs,'' mission scientists reported today.

title: K.G.B. DEFECTOR IS CALLED A BRITISH DOUBLE AGENT
description: A Soviet intelligence operative whose defection led Thursday to an order for the expulsion of 25 Russians from Britain had been working for Britain as a double agent for nearly 20 years, Western intelligence sources said today.

title: MTV SALE PACT
description: The American Express Company has given its consent to an accelerated sale of MTV Networks Inc. to Viacom International. MTV Networks is partly owned by Warner Amex Cable Communications, a joint venture of American Express and Warner Communications.

title: DICKERSON IS RETURNING
description: Eric Dickerson, satisfied that the Los Angeles Rams will begin negotiations for a contract extension, agreed today to rejoin the team and end his 47-day holdout. But the running back will not play Sunday against the Eagles in Philadelphia, his attorney said.

title: EWING IS CLOSER TO A BIG PACT
description: The Knicks' training camp opens at Hofstra University two weeks from today, and, since the success of their immediate future rests largely on his shoulders, the club would be glad to hear Patrick Ewing answer the roll call. Little surprise, then, that in recent days the talks to get the 7-foot center under contract have intensified. Three meetings were held this week between David Falk, Ewing's agent, and representatives of the Knick hierarchy, and word is that the two sides are moving - or inching -ever closer to an accord.

title: U.S. SAYS NICARAGUANS AID SALVADOREAN REBELS
description: In an effort to counter Nicaraguan Government arguments before the World Court, the State Department issued a long position paper today asserting that the Nicaraguan Government has continued to supply weapons, training and advice to the guerrillas in El Salvador.

title: 500 Years Later, Richard III is Still an Issue
description: Just over 500 years ago, the battle of Bosworth was fought and King Richard III was killed. Five centuries later, there are Richard III Societies in New York and London to keep his memory green. They would like to think that Richard was not a criminal and not guilty of murdering his nephews, the Princes in the Tower. But Ricardians are not historians, and do not know, or face, the facts.

title: CITIZEN MAYS
description: zillie Mays denies involvement in the goings-on being bared at the Pittsburgh drug trial, and adds: ''If you're going to bring me into this, that's un-American.''

title: 3 STATES VETO BALDWIN PLAN
description: Ohio, New York and Georgia insurance commissioners have rejected the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's takeover plan that would enhance the interest paid to holders of annuities sold by the Baldwin-United Corporation insurance companies.

title: MORTGAGE RATES AREMIXED
description: Interest rates on fixed-rate home mortgages rose for the first time since April, while the average rates for adjustable mortgage loans continued to decline between early July and early August, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday.

title: COUNTRYWIDE CREDIT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CAMPANELLI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $29,165 for the quarter and $87,655 for the 6 months. c-After extraordinary credits of $28,919 for the quarter and $93,076 for the 6 months.

title: U.S. LEADS EUROPE IN RYDER CUP GOLF
description: Europe's team of professional golfers lived up to the hopes of its supporters today by rallying in the afternoon segment of the first day of the Ryder Cup Match against the United States. The day ended with the favored Americans leading by only one point, 4 1/2 to 3 1/2.

title: Mr. Ambassador
description: Our man in Paris, France, is now Joe M. Rodgers, of Nashville, Tenn., a wealthy building contractor who was finance chairman of the Reagan-Bush campaign last year. Mr. Rodgers expects President Francois Mitterrand to accept his credentials soon, making his ambassadorship official. Meanwhile, he is trying to drum up money from corporate America to refurbish the Ambassador's residence on the Rue Faubourg St.-Honore in downtown Paris.

title: U.S.C. AIDE RESIGNS
description: An assistant football coach at the University of Southern California has resigned following an investigation by the school and the Pacific-10 Conference that revealed National Collegiate Athletic Association recruiting violations, it was announced yesterday. Russ Purnell, an assistant coach in charge of tight ends and special teams, resigned.

title: S.E.C. STUDIES HANSON BUYING
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has opened a formal investigation of a series of rapid-fire purchases of SCM Corporation stock by Hanson Trust P.L.C. of London shortly after the British conglomerate dropped out of a bidding war for the company, court sources said yesterday.

title: ASTROS DISMISS ROSEN
description: He had almost five years to build a playoff team, but yesterday with the Houston Astros in fourth place and well out of contention in the National League West, time ran out for the club's general manager, Al Rosen. He was dismissed by the Astros' owner, John McMullen, and replaced by Dick Wagner, the former general manager of the Cincinnati Reds, who has been a consultant since his dismissal by the Reds in 1983.

title: JAYS STOP NIEKRO'S BID FOR NO. 300
description: If 38-year-old Al Oliver had any respect for his elders, Phil Niekro might have gained career victory No. 300 last night. Instead of respect, though, Oliver registered two hits that drove in three runs and carried the Toronto Blue Jays to a 3-2 victory over the Yankees.

title: CHURCH RETAINS HOMOSEXUAL BAR
description: One house of the Episcopal Church's legislature tried to take a strong step today toward opening the process of ordination to homosexuals, but the other house narrowly resisted any change.

title: Portugal Train Toll At 54 Dead, 64 Missing
description: The official death toll in a train collision rose to 54 today, but the authorities said at least 64 people were still missing, their bodies believed buried in the charred wreckage.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Toronto, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. (Television -SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio -WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Expos, at Montreal. (Television - Channel 4, 3:15 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 3:15 P.M.) Cubs vs. St. Louis, at Chicago. (Radio - WCBS, 880; 3:07 P.M.) College Football Maryland at Boston College. (Television - Channel 11 and USA, noon.) Georgia Tech at North Carolina State. (Television - MSG, noon.) Baylor at Georgia. (Television -WTBS, noon.) C. W. Post vs. Salisbury State, at Greenvale, L.I., 1 P.M. (Radio -WCWP-FM, 88.1; 1 P.M.) Notre Dame at Michigan. (Television - Channel 2, 1:30 P.M.) Western Michigan at Army, West Point, N.Y., 2 P.M. U.C.L.A. at Tennessee. (Television - Channel 7, 3 P.M.) Rutgers at Florida, 4 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Sunday, tape.) Syracuse at Mississippi State. (Radio - WNYE-FM, 91.5; 7:30 P.M.) Texas A&M vs. Alabama, at Brimingham. (Television - ESPN 7:30 P.M.) Pitt at Ohio State. (Television -WTBS, 8 P.M.) Soccer Canada vs. Honduras, at St. John's, Newfoundland, World Cup qualifying game. Canada has a victory and 2 ties for 4 points in the group. Honduras is 1-1-1 for 3 points, so Canada can advance to its first World Cup championship round next year in Mexico with a victory or a tie.

title: GREENPEACE AFFAIR: FRANCE IS COMBATIVE
description: A revealing moment in what has come to be called the Rainbow Warrior affair - the sabotage of the flagship of the Greenpeace environmental group in New Zealand in July - came here the other day when Prime Minister Laurent Fabius, appearing in a 90-minute television interview, answered questions from the French television audience.

title: MEETING PLANNED IN LOS ANGELES BY BLACK MUSLIM STIRS A DEBATE
description: A meeting planned for Saturday by Louis Farrakhan, the black religious leader, has drawn sharp attacks from leaders of Jewish groups here, who have demanded that blacks prominent in politics and civil rights publicly repudiate him.

title: TEKTRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 24
description: The company said expenses in the latest first quarter related to its decision to reorient its workstation efforts reduced earnings by $3,835,000, or 18 cents a share.

title: PHILADELPHIA MAKES DO WITH NO NEWSPAPERS
description: Last Sunday morning, on the second day of a strike that has shut down Philadelphia's two major newspapers for nearly a week now, a crowd in search of out-of-town papers at the Bryn Mawr News Agency was so unruly that the doors had to be locked.

title: Public Will Benefit From the Sale of New York City's Audubon
description: To the Editor:

title: CARPENTER TO SIT OUT AGAIN
description: Not so long ago, this bit of news might have caused a stir on the Giants. But when Coach Bill Parcells said today that Rob Carpenter had not rejoined practice and would not play for the second consecutive Sunday, it was just another item apparently with no great urgency attached.

title: PATIENT DEFENDS ARTIFICIAL HEART USE
description: Michael Drummond, the Arizona man whose life was supported for nine days on an artificial heart until he received a human heart transplant, tonight took issue with critics who urge a moratorium on further use of mechanical hearts until the problem of strokes has been solved.

title: JEFFREY MARTIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
PRODUCTION UP SLIGHTLY IN AUGUST
description: The Government today reported a large gain in retail sales and higher industrial production for August. But the sales gain was inflated by cut-rate automobile financing programs and the increase in output was considerably less than many analysts expected.

title: G.E. BAN IS LIFTED
description: The Air Force said it had lifted a suspension on awarding contracts to the General Electric Company's missile re-entry systems operation. The Air Force said the ban had been lifted because of G.E.'s cooperation with the Government on weeding out and reporting past violations of Government procurement regulations. G.E. was suspended from doing business with the Government in March after a Federal grand jury in Philadelphia indicted the company on charges of defrauding the Government. The suspension was narrowed to the re-entry division in July.

title: ICOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: b-Net loss.

title:
PATENTS;

A CALENDAR ISSUES DATE REMINDERS
description: TWO psychologists and an electrical engineer have invented an electronic calendar display that is designed to help people organize their time better. The calendar comes in a weekly, monthly or yearly model and can be updated.

title: BORMAN'S INC reports earnings for 12wks to Aug 10
description: b-After extraordinary tax benefits for book loss carryforwards of $220,000, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and $530,000, or 19 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: TIDEWATER WINS CHAMPIONSHIP
description: The Tidewater Tides, the Mets' top farm team, relied on strong pitching tonight to beat the Columbus Clippers, the Yankees' top farm team, 2-0, and win the International League championship.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: JAZZ POTPOURRI Mikell's, 760 Columbus Avenue, at 97th Street (864-8832), is by now one of the city's senior jazz houses, an establishment situated on the Upper West Side and not in either of the traditional jazz strongholds of New York, Harlem or Greenwich Village. But talent will out here, too, as the aggregation making music this weekend in the club attests.

title: TEXAS AIR HALTS PACT WITH T.W.A.
description: The Texas Air Corporation agreed yesterday to revoke its merger pact with Trans World Airlines. The move cleared the way for Carl C. Icahn, the New York financier who has already acquired 52 percent of T.W.A.'s shares, to buy the remaining shares of the nation's fourth-largest airline.

title: SYSTEM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
PORT AGENCY HEAD VOWS OPEN POLICY
description: Stephen Berger, the new executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said yesterday that he would try to maintain an ''open dialogue'' when differences arose between the two states and avoid the ''dissonance'' that had existed at times in the past.

title: FEWER EPIC HOUSES FOUND
description: The Federal bankruptcy court judge presiding over the case of the ailing EPIC group of mortgage and real estate companies was told yesterday that there were 7,000 fewer houses in the company's bankrupt partnerships than had been previously believed. The court was also told that an EPIC affiliate paid a special $2 million dividend to its three owners just one month before EPIC halted all payments on its outstanding mortgages.

title: NEO-NAZI DESCRIBES ASSASSINATION PLANS
description: A member of a Neo-nazi group testified today that the group included an ''assassination unit'' with a contingency plan to murder former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and the the heads of the nation's three major television networks.

title:
PATENTS;

DETERMINING OUTPUT OF HEAT FROM COAL
description: A method of determining the heat-producing capabilities of coal was patented this week for the Department of Energy under a contract with the University of California.

title: NOT-TOO-FAMILIAR VISITOR AT THE CAPITOL...
description: In Washington, building passes and security credentials are worn like jewelry, usually on a metal chain dangling from the neck.

title: SELIGMAN & LATZ INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: What Affirmative Action Is and What It Is Not
description: To the Editor:

title: HONDURAS SAYS IT HIT A COPTER FROM NICARAGUA
description: The Honduran Air Force shot down a Nicaraguan helicopter and attacked Nicaraguan positions inside Nicaragua today in the most serious border confrontation yet between the two countries, according to Honduran Government and American diplomatic officials in the Honduran capital.

title: REAGAN TO MEET WITH ARABS
description: President Reagan has invited President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and King Hussein of Jordan to meet with him separately this month, and Mr. Mubarak has accepted an invitation for Sept. 23 and King Hussein for Sept. 30, Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, announced today. The Arab leaders will be in the country to attend the United Nations General Assembly meeting in New York.

title: CONCERT: 'THE RITUAL PROJECT'
description: Around and around a miniature track jogged Our Girl (Kate Fuglei), monologuing about God, working, romance, petty sins, getting what she wanted and not getting what she wanted. Three women and four men - clad, like Our Girl, in harlequin checks and stripes - hopped, did quasi-magic tricks and posed in commedia dell'arte attitudes; now and then, the women ululated or sang quasi-medieval harmonies.

title: Lmits on 500 at U.N. Take Effect Tomorrow
description: The United States, citing reports of spying by United Nations personnel, will restrict the movements of about 500 United Nations employees from the Soviet Union and five other nations.

title: MICRODYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The 1984 results for the quarter and 9 months have been restated for an elimination of certain inter-company transactions.

title: UNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income. c-After a tax credit of $151,000.

title: AROUND THE WORLD Peru Orders Inquiry On Atrocity Report
description: The Peruvian Government has ordered an inquiry into a purported massacre of 69 villagers by troops fighting Maoist guerrillas in the Andes.

title: Locked-In Positions
description: To the Editor:

title: BANKAMERICA HEADQUARTERS
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its headquarters complex here for $660 million, a price it said was probably the highest ever paid for a single building complex. The buyer is Walter H. Shorenstein, a leading San Francisco commercial developer, who is already the largest holder of real estate in the city's financial district.

title: SOFTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: JOHN KERANS, BRITISH SKIPPER WHO LED '49 YANGTZE EXCAPE
description: Comdr. John S. Kerans, the British naval officer who was hailed as a hero after he stealthily guided the frigate Amethyst down the Yangtze River out of a Chinese blockade in 1949, died Wednesday, his family said.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It seems to me that saying sulfates do not cause acid rain is the same as saying that smoking does not cause lung cancer.'' - Drew Lewis, President Reagan's special representative on the acid rain problem. [1:1.]

title: The Court's Role as a Guardian of Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday about a proposed Federal Trade Commission regulation involving food stocks misstated the F.T.C.'s position. There is no requirement that food stores keep inventory records of special sale merchandise, but merchants say they believe they would need such records if accused by the F.T.C. of having insufficient stocks.

title: Citibank Office and U.S. Cars Damaged by Athens Bombs
description: A bomb exploded at 1:42 A.M. today in the branch office of Citibank, causing minor damage, and another bomb exploded nearby five minutes later, damaging two cars belonging to United States military personnel, the authorities said.

title: SALVATORE T. CHIANTIA
description: Salvatore T. Chiantia, chairman of the National Music Publishers Association, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Port Washington, L.I. He was 67 years old.

title: THE CALL OF RETIREMENT
description: It took less than an hour for the word to spread through the stable area of every race track in the country Thursday morning: Spend a Buck, the Kentucky Derby winner, had come up with a swollen ankle and would miss his scheduled start in the Pennsylvania Derby tomorrow.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 13. 1. The bar mitzvah of Eric Strom, a 13-year-old boy from Stamford, Conn., was the first such ceremony in Cracow, Poland, in more than 20 years. The boy went at the invitation of Mrs. Jakubowicz, a Jewish leader in Cracow, who had asked American Jews to send a bar mitzvah to the city, where only 600 Jews, with an average age of 78, remain from the pre-World War II Jewish population of 60,000. 2. Medical costs for retirees. 3. Could have. 4. In Manhattan, a Federal appeals court upheld a decision that barred construction of Westway, and in Washington, the House of Representatives voted to block Federal funds for the project. 5. The RCA Corporation. 6. President Botha proposed the restoration to nearly 10 million blacks of the citizenship rights they lost when their tribal homelands became nominally independent. The Government panel recommended the abolition of the pass laws, which restrict blacks' rights to move to the townships set aside for them in urban areas. 7. John Williams, the composer of soundtrack music for ''Star Wars,'' ''Superman'' and ''E.T.,'' wrote a series of themes for the network's news programs. 8. Prosecutions of large corporations, including E. F. Hutton, Eli Lilly & Company and numerous military contrtactors. 9. True. 10. An American spacecraft flew unscathed through the tail of the comet Giacobini-Zinner, the first time such a feat had been achieved. 11.

title: COUPONS DISPENSED AT MARKETS
description: ACCORDING to the A.C. Nielsen Company, 79 percent of all United States households clip coupons, saving $2 billion on grocery bills each year. For every coupon redeemed, however, there is a pile a shopper forgets to take to the store.

title: IT MAY TAKE A LONG TIME TO FIND THE BEST CONTRACT
description: With a free run in the auction, good players can expect to reach the best contract, or something close to the best contract, on more than 90 percent of all deals.

title: OLD CHAPLIN FILMS MAY BE BURIED IN A DUMP
description: A nine-month search by a film historian for a missing movie library ended two hours too late, and as many as 300 films, from Charlie Chaplin to Chinese movies, were apparently sent to a landfill and buried under 3,000 tons of garbage.
