title: PRODUCER PRICES DOWN 0.3%
description: Producer prices fell three-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Government reported today, lending credence to some analysts' predictions that inflation at the producer level this year could be the lowest in two decades.

title: KODAK INFRINGED ON POLAROID PATENTS
description: The Polaroid Corporation yesterday won the first stage of a nine-year-old suit against the Eastman Kodak Company that charged Kodak with infringing upon key patents for instant photography.

title: FIRST TO SIGN
description: Spotting an apparently lucrative opening in the edgy game of waiting for Patrick Ewing to set the pattern for rookie salaries, Xavier McDaniel, a former Wichita State star, left his fellow high-draft choices at the line yesterday as he broke for the bank with a four-year contract from the Seattle SuperSonics. No financial terms were disclosed, but McDaniel, the fourth player taken in the National Basketball Association draft -and the first of the top 12 to come to contract terms - may have had assurance that his salary will be in line with the one Ewing is negotiating with the Knicks.

title: SEPT. 1-10 AUTO SALES SET RECORD
description: Buoyed by incentive programs, sales of new American-made cars soared 56.8 percent in the first 10 days of September, compared with the similar period last year, the manufacturers said today.

title: IN PRINCETON, TRADITION AND CHANGE ON CAMPUS AND OFF
description: A tall man with gray hair and an easy gait made his way along Nassau Street this week. In his khaki trousers and blue button-down shirt, he looked for all the world like a lifelong Princetonian.

title: F.A.A. ORDERS CABLE CHANGE ON BOEING 737 ESCAPE SLIDES
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has ordered all United States airlines to lengthen cables on emergency escape slides on the doors of Boeing 737's after investigators of an accident last month in Manchester, England, found that a slides momentarily inteferred with the opening of a door.

title: WINIFRED CECIL IS DEAD AT 78
description: The soprano and vocal coach Winifred Cecil of Manhattan died Friday at Roosevelt Hospital of cardiopulmonary complications. She was 78 years old.

title: JERSEY MOB DEFENDANT ENTERS NOT-GUILTY PLEA
description: The man who prosecutors say runs the Luchese organized-crime group's illegal activities in New Jersey from his home in Florida pleaded not guilty to Federal racketeering and conspiracy charges today.

title: No Headline
description: President Reagan's special representative on acid rain told the governors of six New England states today that he believes the problem is caused by sulfur emissions from industry and that he will recommend a cleanup program.

title: TORONTO FILM FESTIVAL: BIG AND GETTING BIGGER
description: In its 10 years of existence, Toronto's film festival has grown to become the largest in North America, organizers say.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: THE POST PRIMARY LULL
description: Calm has come to City Hall, bringing with it a gentleness that always seems appropriate to the old building's fine marble corridors but rarely is achieved.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CITY OPERA: 'NEW MIKAKO'
description: The New York City Opera's current production of Gilbert and Sullivan's ''Mikado'' has greatly improved since its first performances this year, and, by Thursday night, it had developed into a diverting evening of music theater. Most important, one now feels that the characters on stage inhabit the same universe; there was a genuine sense of give and take.

title: A SPRING THAT YONKERS CAN'T CUT OFF
description: Along the Saw Mill River Parkway here is a spring that refuses to go away.

title: 2 EXPERTS TESTIFY THEY OPPOSE ALLOWING AIDS CHILD IN SCHOOL
description: A physician and a scientist who have studied AIDS in children told a Queens court yesterday that they disagreed with a decision to permit a second-grade girl with the disease to attend regular classes in one of the city's 620 elementary schools.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Audi of America Inc., Troy, Mich., said increases on its 1986 models average three-tenths of 1 percent, or $45, from comparably equipped 1985 models.

title: Ballet Theater Dancers Hear of Longer Layoff
description: American Ballet Theater's management has informed the company's dancers that its projected layoff period after the current season, which ends tomorrow at the Metropolitan Opera House, will be extended by two weeks because of financial difficulties.

title: YET ANOTHER ROSENBERG CHAPTER
description: It is a case that will not go away.

title: ON THE GO: TRIM LOOK
description: It's that in-between-seasons time, not quite summer and not quite fall, and the question is, what to wear? A number of New York women have answered simply but elegantly -pairing a classic long-sleeved silk blouse with a slim dark skirt that is knee-length or slightly shorter.

title:
PATENTS;

SENDING LIGHTWAVES OVERLONGER DISTANCES
description: An A.T.&T.; scientist has invented a fiber-optic receiver that allows lightwave transmission over longer distances, does not overload from high-power signals and is inexpensive. Patent No. 4,540,952 was granted this week to Gareth F. Williams and assigned to A.T.&T.; Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J. He is a member of the Lightwave Systems Research Department in Holmdel, N.J.

title: CITADEL HOLDING
description: The Citadel Holding Corporation said it had canceled its proposed $109 million takeover by the Great Western Financial Corporation, parent of the nation's third-largest thrift institution, the Great Western Savings and Loan Association. The takeover was agreed to May 20, but a Citadel shareholder group headed by an investor, Alfred Roven, soon opposed it. Mr. Roven emerged the victor in a board room struggle, and Citadel let the takeover plan languish.

title: ALL EYES AND EARS
description: Max Albert says he is ''a prisoner on Sundays,'' but no prisoner was ever happier in the role.

title: Rating the Lobbyists
description: There is constant discussion in Washington about which lobbyists have the most influence on the Government. Adding some grist to the talk will be the results of a survey to be published next week by the National Journal.

title: Philadelphia Inquirer Cancels Sunday Issue
description: Publication of the Sunday issue of The Philadelphia Inquirer was canceled today after newspaper executives concluded that they could not settle a strike by nine unions in time, a company spokesman, William Broom, said.

title: GENERAL CERAMICS reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in August 1985.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 14, 1985

title: ENNIS BUSINESS FORMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in June 1985.

title: BACK FROM CRACOW, YOUTH FEELS 'SPECIAL'
description: The first Jew in more than 20 years to celebrate a bar mitzvah in Cracow, Poland, returned to the United States yesterday, saying the event made him feel ''really special.''

title: AIR FORCE MISSILE STRIKES SATELLITE IN FIRST U.S. TEST
description: An Air Force missile destroyed an orbiting derelict satellite 290 miles above the Pacific Ocean today in the first such test of an anti-satellite weapon.

title: WHY CUT THE PRICE OF SMOKING?
description: Cigarette smokers pay a high price for their habit. Nine of ten lung cancers, for instance, are attributed to cigarettes; so are a third of all heart-disease deaths and the vast majority f deaths from emphysema and chronic bronchitis.

title: 5 Killed, 16 Hurt in Crash Of Church Bus in Ozarks
description: A bus carrying about 40 church members went off an embankment and overturned in the Ozark Mountains today, killing five people and injuring at least 16 others, the authorities said.

title: SENATE BACKS STATUS CHECKS ON ALIENS SEEKING BENEFITS
description: The Senate approved a proposal today that would require states to check the legal status of aliens applying for welfare, food stamps, Medicaid and other benefits.

title: Thai Labor Leaders Questioned on Coup Bid
description: The Thai police questioned a group of labor leaders today about their activities during the coup attempt Monday, according to Bangkok press reports.

title: Buchanan's New Desk
description: Patrick J. Buchanan, the White House communications director, lately has been showing off a newly acquired mahogany desk-bookcase in his office.

title: DOLE HAS MINOR SURGERY
description: Doctors at Walter Reed Army Hospital removed a bone spur Thursday from the right elbow of the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, in what they termed ''minor'' surgery. The Senator was abled to resume work later in the day, according to an aide, Walt Riker. Mr. Riker said the bone spur had been pressing on a nerve and causing the Senator pain. The aide said the bone spur was a result of Mr. Dole's having his arm and shoulder shattered by gunfire in fighting in Italy in World War II.

title: Blame the Computer?
description: If there is one thing Congressional aides understand with some sympathy it is that anyone can make a mistake in a mailing. A recent letter to the key assistants of members of Congress soliciting subscriptions for The Washington Times was written in the form of a memorandum from the newspaper's editor, Arnaud de Borchgrave, marked ''From the desk of the editor in chief.''

title: SWEDES FORESEE A CLOSE ELECTION TOMORROW
description: Undecided voters could be the pivotal factor in national elections here Sunday, in which a non-Socialist coalition is challenging the Social Democratic Party of Prime Minister Olof Palme.

title: NIEKRO TAKES LOSS IN STRIDE
description: After the top of the ninth inning last night at Yankee Stadium, the ovation accompanied Phil Niekro to the dugout. Although the Yankees were losing to the Toronto Blue Jays, 3-2, which turned out to be the final score, the 46-year-old knuckleball pitcher was being heralded as if he had registered his 300th victory instead of being about to be pinned with his 248th loss.

title: A HOTEL'S NEW LIFE
description: For decades, the American Hotel in Hoboken, N.J., was a cornerstone of the port city's commercial district. The hotel closed in 1982, but now the ornate, turn-of-the-century building that housed it is being converted into a commercial building with 50,000 square feet of office and retail space.

title: ATOM-WASTE RULING APPLAUDED BY STATE
description: THE ruling last week by a Federal agency refusing to block the shipments of spent nuclear fuel through New York City has both short- and long- range implications for Connecticut, according to state officials.

title: MILITARY SUPPLIERS DRAW FIRE AGAIN
description: The Government is cracking down again on military contractors. A GTE unit's guilty plea to conspiring to illegally obtain secret documents was the latest salvo. GTE said it is common industry practice to use internal budget documents to better plan a bid, but the Government wants to stop the practice and invoked espionage statutes in the GTE case. In addition, GTE has put $3 million aside to cover possible penalties for overcharging at one of its plants. Meanwhile, the Air Force has held up more than $155 million in payments to Westinghouse and Boeing over two years because of defective parts in two Westinghouse radar systems. And the Senate wants to examine prosecution of big companies to see if the Government is doing enough about white-collar crime.

title: Fond Memories Of Ty Cobb From the '22 Season
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: REAGAN WARNS SOUTH AFRICA, BUT CONGRESS MAY WANT MORE
description: IT is one of the tenets of Ronald Reagan's Presidency that the path to success often leads through compromise. His change of mind last week on South Africa was a case in point.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: AUTO SHOW AND PICNIC About 30 Rolls-Royces and Bentleys will park on the lawn at Lyndhurst from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. today for the annual Concours d'Elegance of the regional chapter of the Rolls-Royce Club of America. The event is open to the public for an admission charge of $4, or $3 for the elderly and $2 for children over the age of 6. A 45-minute guided tour of the former Jay Gould mansion on the National Landmark estate is included.

title: JACQUELINE R. SOMECK IS WED TO PHILIP WARE
description: The marriage of Jacqueline Renee Someck, the daughter of Michael S. Someck of Tokyo and Martha Belva Someck of Largo, Fla., to Philip Charles Ware, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Ware of West Hartford, Conn., took place yesterday. The Rev. John F. Ware, uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in West Hartford.

title: 52 YEARS ON THE L.I.R.R.: A $23,800 TICKET
description: AFTER nearly 52 years of riding the Long Island Rail Road, I have bought my last commutation ticket. I am retiring.

title: LAWRENCE GENDRON MARRIES CLAIRE BAILEY BREENE
description: Claire Bailey Breene, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Kibbe Breene Jr. of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Warren, Conn., was married yesterday to Lawrence Remi Gendron, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Remi Gendron of Claremont, N.H. The Rev. Richard Curci performed the ceremony at St. Bridget's Roman Catholic Church in Cornwall Bridge, Conn.

title: MUBARAK HAS TALKS WITH HUSSEIN TO AID STALLED PEACE DRIVE
description: King Hussein of Jordan and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt met here today to discuss ways of injecting new life into the stalled peace process, senior officials said.

title: IN THE U.S.FEWER WOMEN'S BANKS
description: Banks for women, most of which sprang up to enable women to obtain banking services without relying on their husbands' co-signatures, are declining in the United States. Some have fallen victim to a general consolidation throughout the banking industry. But the main reaon for the decline, bankers say, is that such legislation as the Equal Credit Opportunity Act of 1976 has alleviated most official discrimination against women.

title: MISS HIGGINS HAS WEDDING
description: Kathleen Tryphon Higgins, a daughter of Ann Higgins of Falmouth, Mass., and Fort Myers, Fla., and the late Herbert N. Higgins, was married yesterday to Andrew Denison Ebbott, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph D. Ebbott of White Bear Lake, Minn. The Rev. Diane Root, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Grace Memorial Chapel in East Falmouth, Mass.

title: HOW ONE GROUP REDUCED PREMIUMS
description: FOR doctors in most high-risk specialties, malpractice premiums have climbed sharply, but for the 400 anesthesiologists insured by the Medical Inter-Insurance Exchange of Lawrenceville, rates this year dropped 10 percent, to $18,000.

title: PARLEY TO RECLAIM GLORY OF VERSAILLES
description: A week of scholarship and spectacle - bringing together academics, artists, socialites and politicians - opens on Sept. 29 in the palace of Versailles, once the center of cultural and political power in Western Europe. The visitors are expected to include Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: MISS PRECHT IS THE BRIDE OF JOHN ONG
description: The marriage of Katherine Anna Precht, an assistant editor at Doubleday & Company, to John Francis Harlan Ong, a lending officer with the Middle East division of the Bankers Trust Company, took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany in New York. The Rev. Martin T. Seeley performed the ceremony.

title: RESTORING A METHODIST CHURCH
description: Services at the so-called Mother Church of American Methodism are not punctuated by drips on rainy days, now that the roof is patched. But the pastor of the church, Lovely Lane United Methodist, says $6 million is still needed to complete an $8.5 million restoration project that began here five years ago.

title: SAVING BURN VICTIMS
description: MORTIMER KEANE remembers seeing the world turn red. A few bright sparks from his acetylene torch sprayed into what was thought to be an empty 50-gallon chemical drum. The resulting explosion ignited his clothing and knocked him from a ladder to the floor of a United Feather and Down factory in Brooklyn, where he had been employed for just six months as a maintenance worker. The fire was quickly extinguished, but just as quickly he had lost 40 percent of the skin from his neck, chest, abdomen and parts of his back and face. Keane never lost consciousness. He felt no pain. His strongest sensations were a terrible thirst and a suspicion that, at the age of 20, he was going to die. As he waited for the ambulance, he drank two big glasses of water and thought about his family.

title: STUDY FAULTS TOXIC WASTE CLEANUP PROGRAM
description: A national environmental group has concluded that the Environmental Protection Agency is doing a slipshod job of cleaning up toxic waste sites.

title: THE BROWNSTONE PROJECT INHARLEM RAISES HOPES AND FEARS
description: Will the Harlem of Malcolm X and Duke Ellington become a Yuppie community of ice cream boutiques and trendy Cajun cafes? The fear of some Harlemites that they will be priced out of their community is probably exaggerated. But there is no doubt that the value of Harlem real estate is going up as the tide of Manhattan prices begins to sweep north of 110th Street.

title: CALIFORNIA REJECTS SCIENCE TEXTBOOKS
description: At a hearing of the California Board of Education last week, religious fundamentalists complained about passages on evolution in textbooks. But when the board unanimously rejected all the science books offered for the seventh and eighth grades, the backers of creationism were hardly pleased.

title: NUCLEAR WASTE GETS GREEN LIGHT
description: Federal officials last week refused to allow New York City to bar trucks carrying nuclear fuel. It was the latest in a series of rulings that allows the Government to disregard local regulations prohibiting the transport of hazardous materials.

title: DEALING WITH A TRAGEDY, TRAGICALLY
description: ONE of the nicest aspects of Michael Brady's play ''To Gillian on Her 37th Birthday,'' now playing at the Studio Theater in Lindenhurst, is that it is filled with sympathetic characters.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: THE man behind the place in Trenton where Democrat meets Republican is now doing his best to have East meet West.

title: BOOK-HUNGRY CROWDS THRONG MOSCOW FAIR
description: The old man sat hunched over a large volume in Hebrew, painstakingly copying the text into a notebook.

title: THE GARDEN SPOT OF KINGS
description: In any season few people are in the vast park of Versailles after the chateau closes at 5 P.M. There may be some groups of four or five tourists - those who arrived too late to visit the chateau but have decided to see what can still be seen. Sometimes a mother or an au pair girl with stroller and the paraphernalia of the sandbox heads home from a day in the part of the gardens that serves the local community as a playground.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Toronto Blue Jays, at Yankee Stadium, 2 P.M. Doyle Alexander (15-8) has lost only 1 of 14 decisions in September and October in the last three years, and that includes consecutive complete-game victories this month. Alexander is 0-2 against the Yankees this year and only 3-10 in his career against them. Ed Whitson is the Yankees' scheduled starter. (Television - Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Expos, at Montreal. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.) Football Jets vs. Buffalo Bills, at Giants Stadium, 1 P.M. Home opener for the Jets. (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M. Radio - WMCA 570, 1 P.M.) Giants vs. Packers, at Green Bay, Wis. (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130, 4 P.M.) College: Rutgers at Florida. (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. tape from yesterday.) Tennis World Couples Championships, at Hilton Head Island, S.C., finals (Television - ESPN 1 P.M., live). Super Seniors, age 60 and over, and 65 and over, Eastern Clay Court Championships at Old Field Tennis Club, Greenlawn, L.I., 2 P.M. semifinals and finals. Other Events AUTO RACING: Formula One Belgian Grand Prix. (Television - ESPN, 9:30 A.M., same-day tape). BASKETBALL: N.B.A. Veterans vs. N.B.A. Rookies, PUSH for Excellence Classic, at Chicago Stadium. John Thompson of Georgetown will coach one of the teams and among the pros scheduled to participate are Earvin (Magic) Johnson, Isiah Thomas, Dominique Wilkins and Michael Jordan. GOLF: Greater Milwaukee Open, at Franklin, Wis., final round.

title: EUROPEANS MOVE AHEAD IN RYDER CUP
description: The confidence and encouragement they acquired in the Ryder Cup Match of 1983 paid off today as Europe's team of professional golfers passed their American opponents. On the second day of the 1985 Ryder Cup competition, the Europeans won five matches, lost two and tied one.

title: YANKEES SYMPATHETIC TO GOODEN'S LACK OF SUPPORT
description: Pitching two consecutive shutouts isn't rare, but how often does a pitcher shut out the opposition for nine innings in two consecutive games and not have his team score a run for him in those 18 innings? None of the Yankees' pitchers has experienced that frustration, but they certainly could feel sorry for Dwight Gooden, who ''shut out'' Los Angeles and St. Louis in his last two starts but who has no victories to show for those 18 scoreless innings. ''It stinks,'' Dave Righetti said. ''That's what you call a hang-with-'em,'' Ron Guidry added at the next locker. ''That means you'll be real confused the next time out. That means you're doing the job and you get no help.

title: SOUND OF MUSIC SILENCED
description: THE surprising thing is not that they stole the radio, but that it took them so long to get around to it. When you park in New York every day, it is merely a matter of time.

title: ANN TAYLOR FINDS THE PERFECT FIT
description: ABOUT five years ago, a shopper at a recently opened Ann Taylor store in Woodland Hills, Calif., was approached by an executive of the apparel retailing chain. ''What do you think of our new store?'' asked Sally J. Frame, who was then director of stores for the company's 32 outlets.

title: CHECKERED CAREERS OF THE TITANIC'S SIBLINGS
description: To the Editor:

title: CUOMO IS URGED TO GIVE UP WESTWAY ALTERNATIVE
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that he was under growing pressure from some labor leaders to support Westway unequivocally and to give up on the possible alternative of trading in Federal funds for the project in exchange for mass-transit financing.

title: A HISTORIC INN IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: Behind ornamental irongates, the Cameron Estate Inn, in Lancaster County, Pennsylvania, sits high on a knoll in a park of great natural beauty.

title: GOSSIP AND ITS USES
description: To the Editor:

title: A REMINDER OF COUNTY'S AGRARIAN ROOTS
description: THE story is all too familiar.

title: CATHY WHITLOCK BECOMES A BRIDE
description: The Brick Presbyterian Church in New York was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Cathy Dawn Whitlock and Peter de Lancey Harrison. The Rev. Dr. Herbert W. Anderson performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Gerald Porter, an Episcopal priest.

title: MILITARY COLLEGES GETTING BACK TO BASICS
description: Sometime within a few months, the next generation of generals and admirals will sit down at their computer terminals hundreds of miles apart and ''fight a war'' on the northern plains of Europe.

title: OLGA KING WEDS ANTHONY D. DUKE JR.
description: Olga Cabrer King and Anthony Drexel Duke Jr. were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Oyster Bay, L.I. The Rev. Robert T. Hollett performed the ceremony. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Augustin Cabrer of Humacao, Puerto Rico, and Mr. Duke of Glen Cove, L.I., and the late Alice Rutgers Dodge.

title: GROUP SEEKS RIGHTS FOR ORDINARY PEOPLE
description: ''WE COME from different backgrounds, speak different languages, have different religions,'' Salvio Raspanti said, ''but we have one aim in common: To do the best we can to alleviate human-rights violations.''

title: TV'S CUSTOM-TAILORED 'SALESMAN'
description: Tonight, television gets a rare opportunity to play matchmaker between film and theater. The production of Arthur Miller's ''Death of a Salesman'' that CBS will broadcast this evening at 8 features the performances that graced last year's Broadway revival starring Dustin Hoffman as that quintessential American dreamer, Willy Loman. Usually, when plays are presented on television, they are videotaped before a live audience - as was the case with recent cable TV productions of ''Sweeney Todd'' and ''You Can't Take It With You'' - with only perfunctory gestures toward adapting the work for another medium.

title: MIDWIFE TO THE REVOLUTION
description: THE BIRTH PROJECT By Judy Chicago. Illustrated. 231 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. Cloth, $35. Paper, $17.95.

title: PENN STATE HALTS TEMPLE RALLY, 27-25
description: Penn State built a 24-10 halftime lead on the running of D. J. Dozier and passing of John Shaffer, then hung on to beat Temple, 27-25, today.

title: WHEN THE WORD MEETS THE PICTURE
description: ''IN ART,'' the critic Harold Rosenberg once wrote, ''ideas are materialized, and materials are manipulated as if they were meanings.'' Indeed, art has the advantage over thinking, writing and talking of being substantial. Art achieves a concreteness forever denied to words and ideas.

title: WHEN SPORTS IMITATES A TRAFFIC JAM
description: IWAS hard-core as a boy - a sports nut who took his calling seriously.

title: A PROFESSOR AT HARVARD LAW HEADS TO WEST AND TO RIGHT
description: AS a general proposition, tenured posts on the Harvard Law School faculty are relinquished about as willingly as seats on the United States Supreme Court. In fact, while Harvard professors occasionally leave to take deanships elsewhere, no one has left Harvard for a comparable post elsewhere for many years.

title: HOMOSEXUALS V. THE MILITARY
description: A Federal judge held last week that rules barring homosexuals from the armed forces take precedence over local antidiscrimination laws. His decision overturned an order by the Philadelphia Commission on Human Relations requiring Temple University to bar representatives of the Judge Advocate General's Corps from interviewing potential recruits on campus because the corps, like the rest of the military, refuses to accept homosexuals.

title: OHIO STATE SUBDUES PITTSBURG BY 10-7
description: Jim Karsatos passed to the wide receiver Cris Carter for a touchdown with 4 minutes 19 seconds to play tonight to give Ohio State a 10-7 victory over Pitt (1-1).

title: THE CASE FOR MICHAEL TIPPETT
description: American audiences have always been surprisingly neglectful of English music. Edward Elgar is represented in our concert halls almost exclusively by his ''Enigma'' Variations; Ralph Vaughan Williams by miniatures such as the ''Greensleeves'' and Tallis fantasias rather than his majestic nine symphonies; and Benjamin Britten by the ''Young Person's Guide to the Orchestra'' and an occasional staging of one of his operas.

title: HARD TIMES FOR POETS
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada Gains World Cup
description: Canada qualified for the World Cup finals for the first time when it defeated Honduras, 2-1, today.

title: CRATING A TAX BILL WITH 36 AUTHORS
description: TOWARD the end of a two-day retreat in the Virginia countryside to discuss tax legislation last weekend, Representative Dan Rostenkowski asked Treasury Department officials, Congressional staff members and tax experts from academia to leave the room so he could address the members of his Ways and Means Committee in private.

title: 'VICTIMS' ASSISTED IN TEST OF DISASTER PLAN
description: Military cargo planes carried about 600 ''victims'' of a simulated earthquake in Missouri to area hospitals today in a test of the new National Disaster Medical System, officials said.

title: WESTBURY GROUP FIGHTS NEW ZONING
description: A GROUP of Westbury businessmen is fighting new zoning laws recently passed by the Village Board of Trustees. The businessmen say the laws are so restrictive that they could turn the business district into a ghost town.

title: RENAISSANCE FOR REGAL WATER LILIES
description: ''Don't be afraid, sweetheart, the leaf will support you! Smile for the photographer,'' Pop said as he called encouragement to a little girl balanced precariously on a giant leaf of a tropical water lily (Victoria cruziana) floating in the pools at the Missouri Botanical Garden in St. Louis.

title: A TRAITOR TO HIS CLASS
description: HUGH DALTON By Ben Pimlott. Illustrated. 752 pp. Manchester, N.H.: Jonathan Cape/Merrimack Publishers' Circle. $29.95.

title: MEESE CALLS NICARAGUA A 'TERRORIST COUNTRY CLUB'
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that Nicaragua had become a ''country club'' for terrorists from around the world.

title: IMPORT CONTROLS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK MOVES TO PRESERVE GROUND WATER
description: New controls to protect upstate New York ground-water supplies from possible contamination by landfills were announced yesterday by Governor Cuomo.

title: INDIA IS HOPEFUL ON COMING U.S. VISIT
description: Indian officials say they want the United States to help ease tensions with Pakistan on a number of subjects, including Karachi's purported effort to build nuclear weapons.

title: WINNING HER FATHER'S WAR
description: IN COUNTRY By Bobbie Ann Mason. 245 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $15.95.

title: MEXICO'S RAINY SEASON DELICACY
description: Mexico's cuitlacoche - a rich, black, mushroom-like food that is actually a corn fungus, and a supremely ugly one at that - is nevertheless one of the country's most popular seasonal offerings. In the United States, cuitlacoche (pronounced kweet-la-COH-chay, and also spelled huitlacoche) is known as corn smut and is little known except, perhaps, to distraught farmers - and indeed, one's first instinct upon seeing it is that it is something that should be destroyed.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;

WHEN THE FARMERS COME TO TOWN
description: EXHAUST fumes, screeching traffic, big, tall buildings all around, and Wilma Bryant was pinching and poking yams for sweet potato pie. ''Every Thursday,'' she said, gently jabbing to test for freshness, ''every Thursday I come here so I can make my pies for the weekend.''

title: Politicians Should End Pollution, Too
description: I read, with great interest, your article about the Aug. 26 meeting of the Board of Legislators [''County Moves to Comply With Vote on Apartheid,'' Sept. 1] , which discussed the legislation to ban the sale of spray paint to minors. This legislation, as was accurately reported, is designed to make it more difficult for teen-agers to participate in graffiti.

title: CABLE TV
description: Though death and taxes are perennials, the period after Labor Day offers a couple of seasonal blooms: political campaigns and a return to school.

title: ARMY ROLLS OVER WESTERN MICHIGAN
description: Army continued a long tradition of success in season openers today as Coach Jim Young used four quarterbacks in a 48-6 thrashing of Western Michigan.

title: JOHNSON COOL IN COMMAND
description: ''LAST year, I was a wreck at the end of the season,'' Dave Johnson remembers. ''I used to suck down about 10 antacid pills every game. This year, I'm doing fine.''

title: BERGEN COMPANY ENLIVENS TV GRAPHICS
description: WITH the football season now under way, more people are likely to be seeing the artistry of Harvey Dubner on Monday nights than will see Michelangelo's work in the Sistine Chapel in a year.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: RETURN TO REGION. By Juan Benet. Translated by Gregory Rabassa. (Columbia University Press, $18.95.) ''Return to Region'' is a brilliant novel by one of Spain's major writers. The Region of the title is mythical and unforgettable. One imagines it in northern Spain, in the Pyrenees, a desolate, mysterious and sparsely populated place. Above it looms El Monje, a peak in the shape of a death mask; those who cross Region's river and climb into the mountains never return. There is a church called El Salvador (the Saviour) and a hotel-brothel run by an old woman named Muerte (Death). If Region is not hell, it is one of the circles on the road to hell. Old Dr. Sebastian lives in a wreck of a house, unattended but not alone. Upstairs, behind a padlocked door, sleeps his retarded godson, heavily sedated by the doctor who has an unwanted visitor, a woman who has just returned to Region, some 20 years after the end of the civil war, in the middle of Franco's long reign. The doctor and the woman exchange haunting stories of their lives in which characters appear who are common to both, and who merge, separate, become one again. The doctor has been blighted in love; the woman has had many lovers (the first a German volunteer to the Republic's cause during the Civil War), and has passed part of her time in Muerte's brothel. Underlying their respective tales is the Spanish Civil War, its fratricidal cruelties, its tragedies; their stories are haunted by fear, weighed down by guilt and impotence.

title: SAN DIEGO
description: San Diego is a city that until recently seemed incomplete. It had a beautiful harbor, a superior climate, one of the world's best zoos, one of America's finest urban parks and plenty of other visitor attractions. But its downtown seemed desolate, the result of postwar expansion on the outskirts of the city, which left downtown largely to derelicts and entrepreneurs catering to sailors on leave.

title: NEW CASSETTES: DISNEY, KAZAN AND SUTHERLAND
description: Cilea's ''Adriana Lecouvreur'' Starring: Joan Sutherland, John Shaw, Anson Austin and Heather Begg. The Australian Opera Chorus and the Elizabethan Sydney Orchestra conducted by Richard Bonynge.

title:
GARDENING;

TIPS ON GETTING THE TASTIEST OF APPLES
description: THERE is nothing better than biting into a crisp, juicy apple in the fall. Depending upon the cultivar, it may be sweet, tart or even spicy. Trouble is, many of the apples at supermarkets and produce stores are just like the average store-purchased tomato -they are tasteless.

title: IMPRESSION IS LIVELY IN NEW ARTISTIC CLOTHES
description: MODERN art has become a moving museum, thanks to the recent outbreak of clothes and accessories adorned with designs that reflect the work of such masters as Picasso, Matisse, Miro, Toulouse-Lautrec and Calder.

title: PROTECTIONIST DESPAIR
description: To the Editor:

title: DONALD BOUGHRUM WEDS ELISE ANNE MCLAUGHLIN
description: Elise Anne McLaughlin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. McLaughlin of Rumson, N.J., was married there yesterday to Donald James Boughrum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Boughrum of Middletown, N.J. The Rev. Thomas Rittenhouse performed the ceremony at Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;

THETAER COMPANY BORN OVER THE FENCE
description: WHEN Linda C. Mossey moved to East Rockaway from Albany over a year ago, she discovered that she had a great deal in common with her next-door neighbor, Kevin F. Harrington.

title: ELISSA LEONARD WED TO JEROME H. POWELL
description: Elissa Ann Leonard, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Hill Leonard of Rockville, Md., was married yesterday to Jerome Hayden Powell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Powell of Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. Arthur Jellis, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony in the Bethlehem Chapel of the Washington Cathedral.

title: STATE ATTRACTING PUBLISHERS
description: IN THE last 25 years, many New York publishers, short of storage space, have turned to New Jersey, a move that also has seen publishing contribute to the state's exploding commercial growth.

title: LISA KILDAHL MARRIED TO ALAN G. HIGHET
description: At the Lutheran Church of the Good Shepherd in Scarsdale, N.Y., yesterday Lisa Marie Kildahl, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John P. Kildahl of Scarsdale, was married to Alan Geoffrey Highet, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Joseph Malcolm Henry Highet of Geraldine, New Zealand. The Rev. Dr. Gerard R. Gaeta performed the ceremony.

title: THE MODERN FOCUSES ON CONTEMPORARY VISIONS
description: What's new? The question, endemic to our fashionable culture, can never be put to rest. We have seen, in photography in the last 20 years, ''New Documents,'' ''New Topographics,'' ''New Pictorialism,'' ''New Landscapes,'' ''New Color'' - all categories invented to designate the presence of something novel and therefore, it is assumed, interesting. Now there is ''New Photography,'' an exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art of 45 photographs by four relatively little-known image makers. Given the show's title, and the authority of its curator, John Szarkowski, who directs the museum's Department of Photography, ''New Photography'' could be expected to satisfy our yearning for the new for at least the immediate future.

title: KORNGOLD WAS MORE THAN A MOVIE COMPOSER
description: If only it had developed a thumb, the octopus (malacologists speculate) could have controlled the world. Now that I'm a one-handed pianist, I can appreciate - too late, alas! - that as a two-handed pianist I had all the power of an octopus with a thumb. Three centuries of keyboard repertory at my mercy: limitless choice; endless variety. More music has been written for my instrument than any performer can hope to handle in a lifetime.

title: MISS GUYER WED TO A. L. TRUMP
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., yesterday Marion Leslie Guyer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Leigh Guyer of New York, was married to Andrew Lewis Trump, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Paul A. Trump of Lancaster, Pa. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Stephen J. Chinlund, the rector, assisted by the bridegroom's father, who is pastor of Grace Lutheran Church in Lancaster.

title: 31 INJURED IN CAR ACCIDENTS
description: As many as 100 vehicles were involved in three separate chain-reaction collisions on a rain-slick highway in which at least 31 people were injured before the authorities closed parts of the freeway. The crashes, each involving dozens of cars, occurred shortly after 2 A.M. on the North Central Expressway here.

title: WYOMING YOUTH WINS HIGH SCHOOL TOURNEY
description: Alexander Fishbein, a 17-year-old national master from Casper, Wyo., scored 5 1/2- 1/2 to win the first Arnold Denker Tournament of State High School Champions, held at the Diplomat Hotel in Hollywood, Fla. He was given a $1,000 scholarship.

title: CHANGES PROPOSED IN MALPRACTICE SUITS
description: A PANEL of doctors, lawyers and insurance executives has recommended 14 wide-ranging changes that it says will cut the number of malpractice suits in New Jersey, lead to ''dramatic reductions'' in the rising cost of malpractice premiums and guarantee the continued availability of malpractice insurance.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: AUTUMN THEATER While the summer theaters at Ivoryton and Thomaston closed before the end of the season because of poor business and fire-safety problems respectively, Westport's Country Playhouse is extending its schedule for two weeks until Oct. 6.

title: STEVIE WONDER -- THE POP IS VINTAGE
description: All the qualities that have made Stevie Wonder the most important creator of pop-soul music in the last 15 years abound on ''In Square Circle'' (Tamla 6134), the singer-composer-producer's first solo studio album in five years.

title: FINGER LAKES VINTAGE TIME
description: At harvest time in New York State's Finger Lakes district, bees that drone around the small Esperanza winery, which occupies a corner of a 147-year-old Greek Revival mansion, get so mellow on sugar from crushed grapes that they can't fly. ''They lie on the ground and just spin on their backs helplessly,'' says Jeff Sully, the consulting wine maker. ''I had one sleeping on my shirt for five minutes.''

title: NEW CASSETTES: DISNEY, KAZAN AND SUTHERLAND
description: Pinocchio Walt Disney Home Video 87 minutes. $79.95 No animated film can rival Walt Disney's ''Pinocchio'' for sheer personality. Everything and everyone in it comes alive, from the flirty goldfish in Geppetto's workshop to the old man's extraordinary collection of cuckoo clocks (a mother spanking a baby, a turkey avoiding a farmer's ax, and many others).

title: WIRETAPS REVEAL DR. KING FEARED REBUFF ON NONVIOLENCE
description: Newly released transcripts of wiretapped telephone conversations of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. show that days before his assassination in 1968 he was deeply disturbed about his standing as a civil rights leader.

title:
INVESTING;

A HEADY TIME FOR COMMUTER AIR STOCKS
description: THE rapid growth in the number of pasengers flying on commuter airlines in recent years has sent the profits of many of these companies zooming. And investors have bid up the prices of many of their stocks: Over the past year some have quintupled.

title: ALARM AND DECORUM
description: THE NAYLORS By J. I. M. Stewart. 192 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $13.95.

title: BRITONS 'UTTERLY CONDEMN' OUSTERS BY SOVIET
description: The British Foreign Secretary responded angrily tonight to the ordered Soviet expulsion of 25 Britons.

title: MISS TREDWELL IS WED TO COOPER A. BOTWAY
description: Mary Hall Tredwell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Robert Tredwell of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesterday to Cooper Alan Botway, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford A. Botway of New York and Paris. The Rev. Richard E. Ryder Jr. performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church of Chappaqua.

title: Some Good Omens For New York And the Series
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MISTRAIL DECLARED IN ALABAMA VOTING FRAUD
description: A judge has declared a mistrial in a voting fraud case, the second mistrial in nine days in a Federal investigation of voting practices in Greene County, where the Government is dominated by blacks.

title: USING COMPUTERS TO TEACH THE BARD
description: SHAKESPEARE, who may have turned over in his grave a few times while his plays were turned into musical shows and movies, surely would be intrigued by a new approach to teaching his entire repertory through computer graphics.

title: A Pair of Blows To Westway
description: While the Westway saga has had more false finales than Beethoven's Ninth, a few chords struck last week suggested that a conclusion might finally be in sight. In separate developments, a Federal appeals court upheld the key portion of a lower court ruling that barred Westway's construction, and the House of Representatives voted to block Federal funds for the proposed $2 billion highway and development project. Neither action delt a fatal blow to Westway, but together they indicated that the obstacles facing its proponents have become immense.

title: COUNTY CONCERT SEASON BEGINS
description: WITH the New Orchestra of Westchester's gala opening last night, the concert season may be considered officially under way.

title: MEMORIES HELP TO REJUVENATE AN AGING THEATER
description: Alice Manning, like many other residents of this city, has vivid memories of the early days of the Academy of Music here when it was a theater on the pre-Broadway circuit and performers like Rudolph Valentino and Ethel Barrymore strolled down Main Street to their lodgings at the old Draper Hotel or the Plymouth Inn.

title: THE PENNIES CUP
description: One of Washintgon's more durable commerical institutions is the Tschiffely Pharmacy, founded here 110 years ago by a Swiss immigrant.

title: SEPTEMBER DREAM THAT MAY COME TRUE
description: EVERYBODY has dreams. Hell, for a buck I can buy a multi- million-dollar dream. But the best dreams are those in September, when my team's fighting for first place, and everything's coming together, and I can savor the run.

title: PURSUING PENTHOUSE
description: CHERYL RIXON'S legal problems began in 1979, only moments after she was chosen Penthouse's ''Pet of the Year'' in a televised pageant sponsored by the magazine and held at the Aladdin Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev..

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

ARTS BENEFIT
description: The Council for the Arts in Westchester is celebrating its 20th birthday Saturday night with a touch of mystery. The gala benefit entitled ''Stars!'' is being held at Stouffer Westchester Hotel (tickets $150 a person; call 428-4220), and it features not only a salute to community arts leaders past and present but also a galaxy of ''surprise guests.''

title: DERELICT SHIPS: TREASURE OR EYESORE?
description: SINCE 1931, when the late John A. Witte established his marine salvage yard in Rossville, S.I., just across the Arthur Kill from Carteret, hundreds of obsolete craft have arrived for stripping and ultimate demolition.

title: SEABROOK'S COSTS SPLIT NEW ENGLAND
description: Arguments over the Seabrook nuclear plant and the possibility of electricity shortages in coming years may threaten regional energy planning in New England, according to officials at the New England Governors' Conference.

title: DISPUTE OVER PRESS STRAINS ISRAEL-EGYPT TIES
description: A dispute has erupted between Egypt and Israel over Egyptian press coverage of Israel and assertions in opposition newspapers that Israeli diplomats, academics and researchers here are spies.

title: GAYLE E. LOVELY WEDS SIMON D. FITZPATRICK
description: Gayle Elizabeth Lovely, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald E. Lovely of Greenwich, Conn., was married at the nondenominational First Church of Round Hill there yesterday to Simon Denis FitzPatrick, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Denis FitzPatrick of Salisbury, England. The Rev. John Olofson, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: SECRECY IS SOUGHT IN ANALYSTS TRIAL
description: The Justice Department has asked a Federal judge to keep secret some of the evidence to be presented at the trial of a Navy analyst who is accused of illegally passing classified photographs to a British publication In a motion that was filed in secret, or under seal, prosecutors asked for permission to remove markings that showed the United States might have shared the photographs with other nations' intelligence services. The prosecution also asked for permission to introduce classified documents or photographs as evidence that would be shown to lawyers, the judge and jury but would not become part of the public record.

title: A CANDIDATE FOR 'BEST CARD PLAYER'
description: If one had to select the best card-player of all time, there would be no easy answer. One would have to consider such stars of the past as the late Oswald Jacoby and the late Howard Schenken. There are many strong American candidates of the modern era, but nobody, perhaps, who stands out above the rest. Europe has had many stars in this department, and the cognoscenti would probably choose between the Italian stars who shone brightly for two decades: Pietro Forquet, Giorgio Belladonna and Benito Garozzo.

title: COMING OF AGE IN CAROLINA
description: I AM ONE OF YOU FOREVER By Fred Chappell. 184 pp. Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press. $14.95. KITE By Ed Minus. 278 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95. FRED CHAPPELL has written novels, stories, poetry, essays and reviews. Though perhaps best known as a poet - he was co-winner of this year's Bollingen Prize - he began his career in the early 1960's by publishing three novels in rapid succession, then a fourth a few years later. But ''I Am One of You Forever'' is his first novel in 12 years.

title: ROOSEVELT AIMS AT COMEBACK
description: Markell Granderson is back for Roosevelt (8-1 last season) of Yonkers. Coach Tony DeMatteo expects to be able to say the same for the Indians, although only five starters return. ''We always play a lot of seniors,'' said DeMatteo, who hasn't had a losing season in 16 years of coaching at Roosevelt. ''I don't expect anything different from the other years.''

title: CLIMBERS DIE IN STORM ON GRAND TETON PEAK
description: A sudden snowstorm has killed three mountain climbers and injured two others on Grand Teton Mountain in Grand Teton National Park, a park spokesman said Friday.

title: BILL ON SEAT BELT USE GOES TO CALIFORNIA GOVERNOR
description: California motorists would be required to use seat belts next year or face a $20 fine under a measure the Senate sent to Gov. George Deukmejian today.

title: CONTROLS PROPOSED ON HOUSEHOLD TOXICS
description: A BILL designed to regulate the disposal of common but hazardous household chemicals and of hazardous wastes generated by small businesses was passed by the Assembly and sent to the Senate last week.

title: ATTORNEY GENERAL OPENS LOCAL OFFICE
description: THE State Attorney General opened a branch office in White Plains last week to serve Westchester, after announcing its first major housing-discrimination suit in the county and promising to help other victims of discrimination.

title: B.C. WHITE WEDS SUSAN D. OSBORNE
description: Susan Dayton Osborne, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Morris Osborne Jr. of Sandy Hook, Conn., was married yesterday to Brian Christopher White, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Francis White of Wilton, Conn. The Rev. Charles W. Stubbs performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: PUNISHING YOUNG MURDERERS
description: Last week, for the first time in more than two decades, a man was executed for a murder he committed when he was younger than 18. After 10 years on death row in Texas, the convict, 28-year-old Charles Rumbaugh, received a lethal injection for killing an Amarillo jeweler during a robbery in 1975, when Rumbaugh was 17.

title: ACTING, LIKE MKUSIC, IS A VITAL ALLY OF DANCE
description: Some choreographers, critics and estheticians insist - and quite rightly - that dance is an independent art and not simply an adjunct to music or drama. However, just as dance is almost always accompanied by music, so, too, dancers are often called upon to portray specific characters. And even in plotless works they may have to evoke moods or feelings. Thus dancing can be the ally of both music and acting.

title:
ANTIQUES;

CELEBRATION OF NEW ENGLAND COLLECTIBLES
description: THE Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford will sponsor a program on Oct. 5 to acquaint antique collectors, dealers and museum personnel with recent trends in the market for Connecticut Valley and New England antiques and paintings.

title: THE SECRET BEHIND THE 'STAR WARS'
description: Mr. Broad's article suggests fundamental problems in our research system. Our scientific subculture encourages researchers to sacrifice ethics, morality and personal integrity for professional prestige and companionship.

title: Taxes in the Wings
description: As for the President's principal priority, tax revision, the heavy going is also still to come.

title: CLARE MONAHAN IS WED TO JEFFERSON S. MYERS
description: Clare Tully Monahan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Paul Monahan Jr. of Washington and Rehoboth, Del., was married yesterday to Jefferson Slaydon Myers, the son of Dr. and Mrs. I. Slaydon Myers of Martinsville, Va. The Rev. Michael J. O'Sullivan performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Washington.

title: DEFICIT REDUCTION WILLBRING DOWN OUR DEBT FEVER
description: To the Editor:

title: BUT CAN HE WATCH TV?
description: A Federal judge sent David A. Wayte, a 24-year-old draft resister, home last week and told him to stay there for six months. Mr. Wayte, of Pasadena, Calif., who studied philosophy at Yale University and has been a community activist, admitted in court in June that he had failed to register for the draft. He faced a maximum sentence of 10 years in prison and a $10,000 fine.

title: ATLANTIC CITY CASINOS' REVENUES SET A RECORD
description: For the second consecutive month, Atlantic City casinos registered the largest gross revenues since casino gambling began in New Jersey in 1978.

title: INCOMES INCH UP
description: Personal income for August is expected to rise by four-tenths of 1 percent, the same increase seen in July, according to Martin Mauro, senior economist at Merrill Lynch Economics. A few weeks ago, said Mr. Mauro, he was predicting a smaller increase, but ''employment growth was stronger than we expected.''

title: IMAGE PROBLEM IN RHODE ISLAND
description: A $900,000 campaign to improve Rhode Island's appeal, including advertisements that feature Gov. Edward DiPrete, has opened just when Mr. DiPrete's own image is at its lowest point since he took office in January.

title: DR. LESLIE MARTIN WEDS W. F. MACHEN AND JANET MARTIN WEDS R. A. FISHER
description: Dr. Leslie Ann Martin was married yesterday to William Fletcher Machen and her sister, Janet Kennedy Martin, was married to Richard Alan Fisher. The Rev. Dr. John Shimer, a Methodist minister, performed the double ceremony at the home of Dr. Martin and Mr. Machen in Weston, Mass.

title: MT. LAUREL RULES CITED IN NEW YORK
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan has ruled that New York City must abide by the principles set down in two landmark New Jersey court decisions that require communities to spur development of low- and moderate-income housing.

title: SAUCY PAPER GAINS STATURE WITH FRENCH
description: The other day, while much of France seemed caught up in a late-summer traffic jam, an unusually light-hearted word fluttered like a butterfly onto the solemn and dignified headlines of Le Monde. It was ''fuse,'' used metaphorically to refer to the unsubstantiated speculation that Defense Minister Charles Hernu might be asked to resign.

title: THE USESOF ADVERSITY
description: President Reagan seems to be thinking a little less these days about ideology and a little more about history. He is not alone. Despite the noisy clash and clatter of politics within and between the nations, there is a glimmer of hope that many political prophets who promised to save the world when they came in are now adjusting to the brutal facts and trying to save themselves as they go out.

title: JOHN HOLT, AUTHOR AND EDUCATOR, DIES AT 62
description: John Holt, a teacher whose book ''How Children Fail'' sparked a national debate in the 1960's on the quality of the nation's schools, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Boston. He was 62 years old.

title: VIETNAMESE CURRENCY IS DEVALUED AGAIN
description: Vietnam today announced the devaluation of its currency for the second time in less than six months, according to a Hanoi radio broadcast monitored here.

title: THOMSON PACES SENIORS
description: Peter Thomson of Australia, the leading money winner on the Senio PGA Tour, shot a 3-under-par 69 for the second consecutive day today to maintain the lead in the $250,000 Richmond Classic.

title:
ART;

THREE SHOWS CELEBRATE THE PRINT
description: ARTISTS in this country have been interested in imaginative, innovative prints since the etching renaissance of the l880's. We, of course, are most familiar with the mid-20th-century surge of print creativity, which was fueled by a growing market for original art. Both eras spawned groups of printmakers dedicated to promoting appreciation of their efforts, largely through group shows.

title: SUBWAY CONCERTS MUSIC TO FIGHT/SWITCH BY
description: That there is good music to be heard in the New York City subway won't come as news to some riders -not, for instance, if they've ever boarded the R at Times Square. Arrive there around noon and one is likely to hear a young violinist, an old blues shouter or a trio playing recorders.

title: ''SHOPPER'S SHUTTLE''
description: Westchester now has a ''shopper's shuttle,'' a 30-passenger minibus that takes older people from the Crestwood Lake apartments in Yonkers to go shopping on Thursdays.

title: Insurance Trouble For Dentists
description: Although the article calling attention to the malpractice crisis that exists in dentistry and most particularly in oral surgery was excellent [''Insurance Rates Soar for Dentists,'' Aug. 11,] it is regrettable that an official representative of the New York State Society of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgeons was not consulted as an unfortunate misconception regarding an important peripheral area could have been avoided.

title: COLLAGES THAT WREST DIGNITY FROM THE HOLOCAUST
description: The Holocaust has not been a viable subject for art. A handful of artists have built monuments to it, but the subject has always seemed too large and too terrible, and the consensus was that whatever images it inspired would appear trivial and anecdotal alongside the evidence of photographs and films. How could art deepen our understanding of a subject about which it seemed that there was nothing more visually to be said?

title: TOWN IN DECLINE FINDS NEW HOPE
description: IT has been five years since most of Sterling's jobs, and about a third of the town's industrial base, went up in smoke with a fire at the Revere Textile Company. But on Friday, new hopes will rise from the ashes.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: No Losing Choosing When Gertrude Stein lectured in America in 1934 she drew large, enthusiastic audiences. These comments about 16th-century poetry, taken from ''Lectures In America'' (Beacon Press), may - or may not - explain her popularity.

title: THE ABORTION CONFLICT
description: It was disgusting to read of the threats to the lives of Dr. Bours and his family and the firebombing of his clinic.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HEAVEN'S BREATH: A Natural History of the Wind. By Lyall Watson. (Morrow, $19.95.) A single sneeze, the naturalist Lyall Watson informs us, expels as many bacteria as someone reading ''War and Peace'' aloud from end to end.

title: PHONY LEGACIES
description: To the Editor:

title: YOUTH THEATER AT PURCHASE OFFERS 'EXPLOSIVE' LEARNING
description: LOCATING inner magic, letting it out and molding it are samplers of the catch phrases that have summed up the credo of Gloria Landes's Youth Theater, a course in self-expression through the performing arts for youngsters. It begins its third year -and seventh semester - on Saturday at the State University of New York at Purchase, where it runs through Nov. 23.

title: LISA GALLUZZI MARRIES
description: Lisa Laura Galluzzi, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Galluzzi of Ballston Lake, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Cooley Baity Jr., a son of Jeanie Baity of Rye, N.Y., and Mr. Baity of San Marino, Calif. The Rev. Paul Bryan performed the ceremony at St. Clement's Roman Catholic Church in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. The bride's father is a senior designer in the turbine business group of the General Electric Company in Schenectady. Mr. Baity's father is a senior partner in the law firm of Baity & Joseph in Los Angeles, New York and Richmond.

title: HONDURAS SENDS TROOPS TO BORDER AREA
description: Part of a battalion of Honduran troops moved to that nation's border with Nicaragua today, but no further clashes were reported between the two countries after a major border incident Friday.

title: NATURALIZING CHEESECAKE
description: FOR SOME UNACCOUNTABLE reason, I had always believed that cheesecakes, one of America's favorite desserts, was of German origin. And in scanning German cookbooks over the years, I have discovered numerous recipes for Quarkkuchen, the Teutonic name for the dessert.

title: MIGRANT WORKERS: STATE WEIGHS BILL
description: A PROPOSED change in the eligibility requirements for unemployment compensation could determine whether New Jersey farmers have enough workers to help plant and harvest crops next year.

title: U.S. SPACE-ARMS TEST CONDEMNED BY SOVIET
description: The Soviet Government press agency Tass today condemned the American testing of an anti-satellite weapon as a stepping up of war preparations.

title: NEW ARTIFICIAL HEART DESIGN AIMS TO END STROKE PROBLEM
description: Researchers have begun to design improvements in the Jarvik-7 artificial heart to correct a design flaw that preliminary tests point to as a partial explanation of the strokes that have seriously complicated its use.

title: PLANNED SURRENDER
description: In September 1945, Georg Gaertner, a German soldier captured by Allied troops in Tunis, escaped from a prisoner-of-war camp in New Mexico to avoid being sent back to Schweidnitz, his hometown, which was then under Soviet occupation.

title: 'ACHIEVER' LOOKS TO NEW HORIZONS
description: VICKI SELTZER of Old Westbury is traveling these days in the company of Elizabeth Swados, Carol Bellamy and Sally Ride. That is not to suggest that the 36-year-old Dr. Seltzer is working on a new musical for Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival, running for mayor of New York or planning a new venture in outer space.

title: FLYING MACHINE REKINDLES CONTROVERSY
description: ANDREW KOSCH, a Stamford biology teacher, is planning to build a bat-like flying machine that probably will never carry him higher than a few feet or farther than half a mile. It most likely will be difficult to steer when it is in the air.

title: A NEIGHBOR, A FRIEND
description: MARTIN has been dead two years. I often gaze out my bay window at his empty brick home with its peeling picket fence.

title: THE MUSIC THEATER FESTIVAL, A MERE IDEA IN 1983, STARTS SECOND BIG SEASON
description: ''MUSIC theater, as we define it, is an art form in which music and theater are equal partners, with the human voice playing a major role,'' said Eric Salzman. ''We mean to include everything from the opera to the musical in our festival, but most of the material falls somewhere in between.''

title: HOW TO RECORD THE GLORIOUS COLORS OF AUTUMN
description: CAPTURING the autumn leaf can present a challenge for a photographer's vision, tenacity and ability to handle accessories. To harvest spectacular images this fall, a photographer must plan carefully, anticipate the possibilities of both the best and worst weather and have an early-warning system that tells him when autumn begins to blossom.

title: GIANT PUNTER CONFIDENT
description: Practice heated up as it usually does, with one especially hard tackle sending reverberations through the entire team. The pass-rush drill left three Giants propped on their knees, trying to put their helmets back in place. The wide receiver Lionel Manuel walked bent over to the sideline gasping for breath. This was the Giants working out the other day in preparation for this afternoon's game against the Packers in Green Bay.

title: THE STORYTELLING CAPITAL OF TENNESSEE
description: ''Once upon a time . . .'' A primitive cave dweller, crouched under the dank shelter of a rock ledge or around the leaping flames of a campfire, may have grunted the first invitation to companions to shift attention from cold or hunger or a prowling saber-toothed tiger to an invisible realm. The realm of imagination. Whenever, wherever storytelling began, centuries of shamans and grandparents around the world have practiced its magic to preserve sacred myths, promote family peace and for sheer enjoyment.

title: NEW CASSETTES: DISNEY, KAZAN AND SUTHERLAND
description: An Evening with the Royal Ballet Starring Margot Fonteyn, Rudolf Nureyev and David Blair. MCA Home Video. 87 minutes. $29.95 Long a favorite among ballet fans in art movie houses, this 1963 film of Britain's Royal Ballet catches the company at the beginning of the fabled Fonteyn-Nureyev partnership and the start of the brilliant decade that resulted in the Royal Ballet's greatest popularity.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 15, 1985 International Moscow ordered the expulsions of 25 British diplomats, embassy staff members, correspondents and businessmen in retaliation for Britain's expulsion of 25 Soviet officials last week after the defection of the K.G.B. chief in London. The expelled Britons were matched against Russians whom London told to leave. [Page 1, Column 6.] Repair of the Pacific alliance rupture over nuclear policy will be taken up in talks in Washington between the United States and New Zealand, Reagan Administration officials said. Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger will hold meetings with Geoffrey Palmer, New Zealand's Deputy Prime Minister on Thursday and Friday. [1:4.] Attacks on the meeting in Zambia Friday between South African businessmen and leaders of the outlawed African National Congress came from South African Government leaders and some black political groups. ''I do not know what the businessmen achieved, except to show signs of weakness toward the enemies of South Africa,'' President P.W. Botha was quoted as saying. [1:5.] World leaders will come to New York in record numbers to attend the General Assembly of the United Nations, an occasion that will also mark the organization's 40th birthday. Kings, presidents and prime ministers will be among the 95 leaders at the session's opening Tuesday. [1:3.] National The national debt, by the middle of next year, is expected to reach $2 trillion, a two plus 12 zeros. Like some other milestones in the country's history, it arouses scrutiny and wonder.

title: WHY WE BUILD 'FORTRESSES'
description: THEY sit squinting out at us from the roadside: Shoe boxes with slits for windows, or bright white things, like bathroom fixtures, with mirrored eyes. The last few years have seen a building boom along suburban highways.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE SHAKER CHAIR. By Charles R. Muller and Timothy D. Rieman. (The Canal Press, Box 28, Canal Winchester, Ohio 43110, $39.95.)

title: MORE CORPORATIONS BECOMING WORKING MUSEUMS
description: With more than 30 world-renowned sculptures rising here from the grounds of Pepsico Inc., with the Chase Manhattan Bank buying 1,200 painting and prints this year, and with dozens of other nearby companies assembling major collections, the corporate headquarters of New York and its suburbs are becoming some of the nation's largest repositories of art.

title: HOUSE PANEL BLOCKS MOVE TO CENSOR ARTS FUNDING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 - An attempt by three members of the House of Representatives from Texas to cut off Federal funds to poets they accused of having written pornographic poetry has failed in Congress and has led to a suggestion by the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts that the Government does not make a very good censor.

title: ADOPTION RED TAPE IS CUT AFTER STUDY BY BAR COMMITTEE
description: ADOPTIONS of children with special needs are taking less time as a result of new procedures developed by an American Bar Association committee.

title: INDUSTRIAL POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: AUSTRALIA'S ARTS ARE THRIVING
description: Australia is the country where there are such things on restaurant menus as Balmain bugs and yabbie tails; the country where towns and cities rejoice in such names as Wagga Wagga (all right; so we have Walla Walla), Nuriootpa, Dubbo and Humpty Doo. It is a free-and-easy country where everybody is on a first-name basis immediately after being introduced. It is a lusty country where a newspaperman can write a gleeful piece about the problems of using the toilet during the time he was the only male in an otherwise all-women company, using terms that would not be allowed in any American family newspaper.

title: MICHIGAN DOWNS NOTRE DAME
description: Steve Beuerlein did not have his throwing shoulder cut open for this. An inch of bone was removed from the clavicle of his right shoulder less than five months before today, the day the quarterback wanted to help point Notre Dame's football program in the right direction after four years of frustration.

title: HARD TIMES FOR POETS
description: To the Editor:

title: BALLET: 'JARDIN AUX LILAS'
description: AT long last, American Ballet Theater's lilacs bloomed again. On Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, the company offered this season's first performance of Antony Tudor's ''Jardin aux Lilas,'' a work also known in English translation as ''Lilac Garden.''

title: A CITY CONVULSED BY HISTORY
description: COMMON GROUND A Turbulent Decade in the Lives of Three American Families. By J. Anthony Lukas. 659 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: A SENATE PANEL TAKES ON JUSTICE
description: Critics have been saying for months that, when it comes to corporate crime, the Justice Department's bark is worse than its bite. Last week, the Senate Judiciary Committee agreed to investigate whether the department had been sufficiently aggressive in attacking white-collar criminals.

title: CHILD MARRIAGES
description: GOVERNOR CUOMO ended a minor form of sex discrimination in New York State last year by signing a law authorizing boys 14 and 15 years old to marry. The law stipulated that they first get the permission of their parents and a Family Court judge.

title: L.I. COMPANIES FIND PROFITS ABROAD
description: CYBEX, a manufacturer of physical-therapy and fitness equipment, began exporting its products 12 years ago almost by chance.

title: LAURA C. DAMSON BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Laura Claire Damson, a daughter of Iris Gerber Damson of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Barrie W. Damson of New York, was married at her mother's home yesterday to Arthur Lawrence Gruen, the son of Mrs. Bernard Berch of Larchmont, N.Y., and Dr. Peter H. Gruen of Scarsdale. Rabbi Daniel S. Wolk performed the ceremony.

title: MILAN BRIO
description: THE NEW FURNITURE designs, as usual, will hardly be off the drawing boards when the Salone del Mobile Italiano, the prestigious furniture fair, opens in Milan this Thursday. But even in their sketch or prototype stages, one trend seems to have emerged: the preponderance of non-Italian designers working for Italian firms.

title: BRUTALIZATION IN THE SERVICE OF THE STATE
description: TORTURE By Edward Peters. 202 pp. New York: Basil Blackwell. Cloth, $24.95. Paper, $9.95.

title: B.Y.U. TROUNCES WASHINGTON
description: Lakei Heimuli and Vai Sikahema ran for two touchdowns each as Brigham Young traded its passing game for the run today in routing Washington, 31-3.

title: BAIL HEARING IN HARTFORD THEFT
description: A detention hearing began today for the first of 12 Puerto Rican nationalists accused in the $7 million robbery at a Wells Fargo armored-car depot in 1983.

title: THE VELOCITY OF NEWS
description: In olden times, newspaper copy was edited from a large semicircular table with a wedge, or slot, in which sat the chief copy editor. This ''slot man'' received news copy from the ''backfield,'' and would deal the stories out to his ''rim men,'' much as a dealer would pass out cards in a poker game.

title: NEW YORK'S WATER NEEDS RESTUDIED
description: In July, an intergovernmental task force began reviewing proposals designed to avoid future water-supply emergencies in New York. Several of the measures are identical to those proposed in 1965 by city water planners.

title: HOW A NEWS FREAK TRIED -- AND FAILED -- TO TAKE THE CURE
description: I AM a news freak. At five minutes before each hour, my nose begins to run, my fingers twitch and a cold sweat breaks out in the small of my back.

title: WHY THE FAIRNESS DOCTRINE IS STILL IMPORTANT
description: Clearly, the Fairness Doctrine still rouses passion. It is either a threat to free speech or the last, best hope for the voiceless; it is a yoke on broadcasters' necks or a necessary restraint to keep them in line. Old arguments over broadcasting rules and regulations usually smell musty; this argument stays fresh and new. In part, this is because political postures change and opponents and proponents, loosely speaking, change positions. In the 1970's, liberal Democrats seemed ready to discard the Fairness Doctrine; political vagaries now make them its defenders. Over the years, meanwhile, the doctrine has been used, and abused, by all sides. At the moment, the Federal Comunications Commission, whose child the doctrine is, wants to disown it. Radio and television broadcasters may applaud, but it is not a good idea.

title: KOCH BIDS BANKS CUT PRETORIA TIE
description: Mayor Koch sent out a letter to the presidents of 12 banks Friday, urging them ''to immediately suspend all banking activities in South Africa, to call in all your loans and to refuse to roll over maturing debts until the state of emergency is rescinded and apartheid is ended.''

title: TO THE EDGE OR THE UNIVERSE: THE NEW AGE OF ASTRONOMY
description: ONCE IN A LIFETIME, AND THE time is now, the most celebrated vagabond of the solar system, Halley's comet, streaks out of the dark void, dashes by Earth, takes a turn around the Sun and emerges resplendent with an even brighter tail of gas and dust.

title: NEW COACH TRYING TO TEACH COLUMBIA TEAM HOW TO WIN
description: IN late August, on the first day of Columbia's preseason camp, Tony Tutrone could not help reflecting on his disheartening three-year affiliation with the Lions. And when his new coach, Jim Garrett, who brought tidings of hope to the feeble program, asked the senior defensive end to stand before his teammates and describe the past, and what winning this season would mean to him, Tutrone was overcome.

title: TOWN AND GOWN JOIN IN BUILDING HOUSING
description: MADISON, a four-square-mile borough that used to be home to the fabulously wealthy, is now struggling with a shortage of affordable housing.

title: Striking Out Isaac Newton
description: In ''The Fastest Pitcher in America,'' by Sheldon Sunness, Aug. 11, we read that softball pitching star Ty Stofflet has a ''riseball'' that will ''leap'' not merely the modest ''hop'' of baseball's fastball, but a ''foot or two'' on its way to the plate.

title: VICTIMS OF AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Mark McGann, Sales Aide, MARRIES ALISON LEE RUTTER
description: At St. James' Episcopal Church in New York yesterday Alison Lee Rutter, a daughter of Mrs. Donald Paul Rutter of Bernardsville, N.J., and the late Mr. Rutter, was married to Mark McGann, a son of Mrs. Thomas Francis McGann of Sarasota, Fla., and the late Dr. McGann. The Rev. Frederick Baldwin performed the ceremony.

title: REVIVING ALBANY
description: In downtown Albany, in an area near the State Capitol that is undergoing public and private revitalization, an $18 million office and retail complex will be built for Keycorp by the Omni Development Corporation.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

CONDOMINIUMS: THE FEVER BREAKS
description: THERE we were, drinking coffee from a thermos and peering through the window at 7:30 in the morning. We could have been a group of overage adolescents camped out at the box office hoping to get rock-concert tickets. Or we could have been early-bird shoppers at a clearance sale, hoping to get a glimpse of the merchandise. We were, in fact, a group of Long Islanders stricken with the latest suburban disease: condominium fever.

title: SOLVING DISPUTES IN CO-OPS
description: THE spiraling cost of garage space in New York City is creating a plethora of new issues for cooperative boards, for residents in buildings undergoing conversion and for anyone who plans to stay on as a regulated tenant in a nonevict co-op.

title: FAIRFIELD SCHOOL HALTS FOOTBALL FOR LACK OF INTEREST
description: ALL summer long, Jim Karageorge looked forward to his second season as a starter on the Andrew Ward High School Varsity Football team in Fairfield, even though he knew he would have to play both offense and defense because of a shortage of players.

title: HOME IS THE WANDERER
description: WE were doing what everyone else was doing around this time of year, flying into Kennedy International Airport returning from vacation. Well, not everyone was returning; after all, not everyone had been away, but many of us were.

title: LAURIE F. BAKER MARRIES
description: At the United Methodist Church in Huntington, L.I., yesterday Laurie Francesca Baker, an account supervisor with Burson-Marsteller, a public relations firm in New York, was married to Charles Seward Stine, a vice president of Laurel Printing Inc. in Elmsford, N.Y. The Rev. John Baker performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Harold Paul Baker of Laurel Hollow, L.I., and Mr. and Mrs. Charles Newhard Stine of Manlius, N.Y.

title: DISPUTE OVER FIRE ISLAND DEVELOPMENT
description: A FEDERAL proposal to simplify development on Fire Island has been welcomed by residents. But many residents say a new state law designed to do the same thing is inadequate.

title: GILDED GUNBOAT
description: ''Gold-plating'' is the Pentagon's term for designing expensive extras into new weapons. The practice is doubly pernicious. The added cost means fewer weapons can be bought; the added complexity means more breakdowns.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Don Popovic, who coached the now-defunct New York Arrows to four Major Indoor Soccer League championships, has been named coach of the Pittsburgh Spirit. Popovic, who also coached the now-defunct Las Vegas Americans, replaces John Kowalski, who was dismissed in May. . . . John E. Fetzer, the 84-year-old board chairman and former owner of the Detroit Tigers, was hospitalized with what was described as a mild heart attack.

title: CARUSO SERIES NEARS ITS END
description: With only a little hyperbole, RCA launched ''The Complete Caruso'' seven years ago -a project to bring to disks all the known recordings of Enrico Caruso in fresh new sound by means of the Stockham Soundstream Computer Process. That project is finally reaching completion, with the release this month of Vol. 16 - the last in the series. Three volumes remain to be issued - the earliest recordings, numbered Vols. 1, 2 and 3.

title: Q AND A
description: A History Lesson Question: What can you tell me about the two town houses on the northwest corner of Park Avenue and 64th Street? . . . S. A. H., Summit, N.J. Answer: The corner house, No. 600, was built in 1910 for Jonathan Bulkley, who headed his family paper firm, Bulkley, Dunton & Company, according to Christopher Gray, an architectural historian. No. 604 was built in 1920 and occupied by a succession of families. Both were acquired in 1946 by representatives of Sweden.

title: BAYPORT BOWING OUT OF LEAGUE V
description: At the end of a fine 1984 season, the Bayport football team suffered a 48-12 loss to Riverhead for the League V title in Suffolk County. The defeat closed out the team's season with a 5-2-1 record, one of the better records in the county.

title: WOMEN GET CHANCE TO RACE
description: Few women show up in the final tally of competitors at international sailing regattas around the world . But that situation is beginning to change as women gain the experience needed to compete with men at that level.

title: BILLS SET FOR JET RETURNEES
description: While accountants scrambled looking for tax openings, and agents ran interference for their clients, and players searched for shelters, and fans wondered whether the Jets would ever come to terms with their holdouts, the Buffalo Bills calmly figured it would be business as usual today when the clubs meet at Giants Stadium.

title: 'EVITA' IN MOUNTAIN LAKES
description: GIVEN the omnipresence of ''Evita,'' there is no point in tracking down every production in sight. What is edifying, though, is seeing the contrast between a lavish production, like the one put on by Millburn's Paper Mill Playhouse in June, and the necessarily scaled-down version now at Neil's New Yorker Dinner-Theater.

title: 2 Judges Take Places On U.S. District Court
description: Two new judges of the Federal District Court for the Southern District were sworn in last week.

title: MISS MACGREGOR BECOMES A BRIDE
