description: At the Fox Chapel Presbyterian Church in Pittsburgh yesterday Susan Morse MacGregor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm MacGregor of Pittsburgh, was married to Charles Stephen Shaw Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Shaw of Alexandria, Va. The Rev. James A. Churchill performed the ceremony.

title: CRASH OF BOEING 747 NEAR TOKYO LINKED TO FATIGUE IN METAL
description: Japanese officials investigating the crash of a Boeing 747 airliner near Tokyo last month said yesterday that signs of metal fatigue had been found along a rear-cabin repair that was improperly carried out by a Boeing team in 1978.

title: CHOOSING BETWEEN TWO KILLERS
description: Cases of AIDS are doubling each year. Well before any vaccine or treatment can be developed, the disease may kill tens of thousands and their care will cost billions. Yet AIDS is so hard to contract that further transmission could in theory be halted immediately by public health measures. Why aren't authorities rushing to take them?

title: GOLDIN'S FUTURE: STILL AHEAD
description: When Harrison J. Goldin first took over as City Comptroller, the talk was that ''the young dynamo,'' as he was called both affectionately and not so affectionately, was only biding his time. Surely, this was a future candidate for mayor of New York.

title: DOMESTIC FAIRIES FOR THE NURSERY GARDEN
description: Opening this selection of 19th-century illustrated children's books is like stepping through two looking glasses - into our own childhood storybooks, and back once more to the Victorian works that influenced them. VICTORIAN COLOR PICTURE BOOKS (Stonehill Publishing Company/Chelsea House, $50), edited by the children's literature authority Jonathan Cott, offers tales and verses both comforting and quirky, set in historical context by way of an introductory dialogue between Mr. Cott and the illustrator Maurice Sendak.

title: TURNTABLES AUGUR AN LP FEATURE
description: According to the more impatient prophets of the digital age, the LP record is a dying breed, singing its swan song. The bit and the byte will carry music from now on.

title: ARRESTED WRITER
description: THE plight of Lev Timofeyev, a Soviet writer said to be held in Lefortovo Prison in Moscow, is one of the 15 cases that the American section of the International Society for Human Rights is now actively publicizing.

title: Generous Golfer
description: When he was growing up in Horseheads, N.Y., there wasn't a junior golf program in the area to help Joey Sindelar hone his game. Sindelar, who managed to win the 1972 New York State junior championship, star at Ohio State and make the pro tour without benefit of such a program, has now moved to help give young golfers what he lacked.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:Someday, we've said, after stopping during driving trips at roadside historical markers, we will do a marker trip, stopping at every one. Do any states compile lists of them, so one could plan in advance? - S. I. J., Baltimore Answer:Calls to a dozen state tourist offices across the country found that in some states - including Virginia, South Carolina and Pennsylvania - a listing of markers is for sale. The sampling did not turn up any states that sent out free lists. Travelers are advised to check with state tourist offices and inquire which, if any, state or local organization maintains a directory of markers. Among the publications available is ''A Guide to Virginia's Historical Markers,'' which was published this year by the University Press of Virginia in cooperation with the Virginia Historic Landmarks Commission. The book gives details of the state's 1,500 markers, many of which stand on the sites of battles involving Indians and clashes during the Civil War. One marks the burial spot of the inventor of the five-string banjo, Joel Walker Sweeney, on State Route 24, 3.2 miles east of Appomattox. The book is available for $8.95, including postage, from University Press of Virginia, Box 3608, University Street, Charlottesville, Va. 22903.

title: CLINIC PROPOSAL FOR HAITI'S POOR
description: STUDENTS at the University of Connecticut Dental School may soon be making regular trips to Haiti, but it will not be for vacation.

title: AMY GURNEY AND FREDERICK S. NICHOLAS 3D MARRY
description: Amy Ramsdell Gurney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert R. Gurney Jr. of Roxbury, Conn., and New York, was married yesterday to Frederick Snow Nicholas 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Jr. of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. Bruce M. Shipman performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Roxbury.

title: DROP REPORTED IN ROBBERIES ALONG INTERSTATE 95 AT MIAMI
description: Criminals pushed off Interstate 95 by increased surveillance and arrests after complaints of highway robberies have moved back to city streets, the police say.

title: CAROL FEIN, AN EDITOR, WED TO JEFFREY MITCHELL HOFFELD
description: Carol Joan Fein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell Fein of Cresskill, N.J., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Mitchell Hoffeld, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Hoffeld of Fort Lee, N.J. Rabbi Irving Block officiated at the Regency Hotel.

title: A KALEIDOSCOPE OF AMERICAN DESIGN
description: The impact of history on objects produced in this country since 1900 is a compelling theme of ''High Styles:

title: MIDDLE-CLASS ELITIST
description: I AM TOO DISDAINFUL of shoddy goods. The word for this condition is ''elitist.'' It is a bad word which is meant to make the person to whom it is applied seem despicable. The air is filled with such words. Notice how rotten you feel when somebody calls you a ''sexist,'' a ''Yuppie''? You don't like feeling rotten, do you? So you stop saying ''lady,'' you sell your BMW. Anything to avoid further assault, right?

title: HISTORIAN COMPILES A COLONIAL GLOSSARY
description: ASK Richard M. Lederer Jr. if he knows any languages, and he'll answer, ''I speak Colonial.''

title: 'STAR WARS' AND MUPPET WIZARDS TEAM UP IN 'LABYRINTH'
description: There are two actors made of flesh and blood and one real baby in ''Labyrinth.'' It is necessary to keep such scores on Jim Henson movies, since that tall, bearded puppeteer with the long face and graying hair most often armors himself with the yak hair, metal bones, plastic eyeballs and rubber teeth of his own creations.

title: MISS WRIGHT HAS WEDDING
description: The Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Anson Elisabeth Wright, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Marshall Wright Jr. of New York, to Christian Nolen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Nolen of New York and West Yarmouth, Mass. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: BRIGHTON BEACH MEMOIR
description: IT is only a 30-minute bus ride from the Five Towns Senior Center in Hewlett to the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn. But for the 40 members of the senior center and their guests who took a bus and walking tour there recently, it seemed like a trip to another country.

title: THE SECRET BEHIND THE 'STAR WARS'
description: In the last paragraphs of William J. Broad's article on Peter Hagelstein (''The Secret Behind 'Star Wars,' '' Aug. 11), I found some of the most chilling statements on nuclear weapons that I have ever seen in print.

title: NEW COUNSEL FOR CUOMO
description: In his relatively brief legal career, Evan Davis of New York has held a variety of posts, in both the public and private sector.

title: WHERE IACOCCA AND COMMON SENSE ERR
description: THERE IS usually a simple common-sense solution to any economic problem. And usually it is wrong.

title: KENNEDY ROUTS TRUMAN, 36-0
description: The 1985 Public Schools Athletic League football season opened yesterday with a lot of zeros: six shutouts, including a 36-0 romp by defending champion Kennedy over its Bronx rival, Truman.

title: KATHERINE S. HALL WEDS PAUL RISKO
description: The marriage of Katherine S. Hall, a psychotherapist with the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, to Paul Kevin Risko, an associate in the New York law firm of Davis Polk & Wardell, took place yesterday in Upperco, Md. The Rev. William Rich, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Jackson Hole Farm.

title: TRADE GIVES DEMOCRATS A CAUSE AND REPUBLICANS A HEADACHE
description: WHILE President Reagan was meeting with Republican Congressional leaders last week, the talk turned to trade problems, and all eyes focused on Senator John C. Danforth, the 49-year-old lawmaker from Missouri who has emerged as his party's leading voice on trade matters. According to one listener, Mr. Danforth politely but firmly told Mr. Reagan that he had to ''bend a little bit'' or risk being swept aside in the storm of restrictive legislation now starting to rumble through Congress.

title: SOPRANO, CELLIST AND PIANIST
description: Allison Welles The soprano Allison Welles, who made her New York debut at Merkin Concert Hall last Sunday afternoon, studied at the Manhattan School of Music and has spent the last few years concertizing in Europe.

title: A $2 TRILLION NATIONAL DEBT: NOT JUST ANOTHER MILESTONE
description: A national debt of $2 trillion, which the United States is nearing, is one of those milestones - the population's reaching 200 million, or the nation's turning 200 years old.

title: SOUND ECONOMICS, SOUND TRADE POLICY
description: The tidal wave of restrictive trade legislation pending in Congress has concentrated President Reagan's mind wonderfully. In his second term, he is beginning to give to trade policy the attention so sadly lacking in his first.

title: CLOSE ENCOUNTER WITH A COMET
description: An American spacecraft had mankind's first brush with a comet last week. The International Cometary Explorer flew through the tail of the comet Giacobini-Zinner as it streaked through space about 44 million miles from Earth.

title: UNLICENSED COLLEGE OPENS
description: TINY Shelton College has resumed classes at its Cape May campus with 10 students enrolled, but it will offer only certificates, rather than degrees, says its chancellor, the Rev. Carl McIntire.

title: DISKS REVEAL THE CREATIVITY OF JOSEPH JOACHIM Barrymore L. Scherer writes frequently about the arts.
description: Like his friend Clara Schumann, in her widow's cap and weeds, revered by her contemporaries as the supreme classical pianist, Joseph Joachim (1831-1907) was venerated as the greatest classical violinist of the 19th century - the thinking man's musician in a world overrun by flashy virtuosos. Although Joachim is remembered today for his intimate association with Johannes Brahms, he was also a composer in his own right, with over 14 published works to his credit, including four violin concertos and five concert overtures. Until now, apparently the only Joachim work available on record has been the once-celebrated ''Hungarian'' concerto, Op. 11. However several new releases allow us to take a deeper look into his creative legacy.

title: K.G.B. SUFFERS A SETBACK IN BRITAIN
description: After scoring important points in the secret spy war in West Germany, the K.G.B. might well have engaged in philosophical stocktaking last week. The British Foreign Office announced that the head of Soviet intelligence in London had defected and given enough information to warrant the expulsion of 25 Soviet officials.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE CHALLENGE OF HIDDEN PROFITS: Reducing Corporate Bureaucracy and Waste. By Mark Green and John F. Berry. (Morrow, $19.95.) In 1983 the Grace Commission received a huge amount of attention for its report on how the Federal Government could save billions of dollars by eliminating waste.

title: FORMER LIBERIAN OFFICIAL IS SENTENCED TO PRISON
description: A former Liberian Finance Minister was sentenced to 10 years in prison Friday night after a military court found her guilty of sedition.

title: MOTHER RETURNS TO WORK, WITHOUT FRILLS
description: I THOUGHT I was ready, ripe, even overdue. My oldest, at 10 years old, could brush her own hair and make her own breakfast (she takes a cooking class on Wednesday). My youngest, at 5, loved kindergarten and boarded the school bus each day without a backward glance at good old Mom. My husband had been singing the Sha Na Na's hit song ''Get a Job'' every time I talked about the price of chicken, or rather, the cost of Capezios. It was time, high time, I imagined, to join the ranks of working mothers. So last February I went back to teaching high-school English after a decade of child-care leave. Nothing, as the song says, will ever be the same.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: MARINE environmentalists say this has been the worst summer for ocean and estuarine water quality since 1976, when there was a massive fish kill off the Atlantic coast.

title: CONVICTING A BATTERED WIFE
description: EVERYDAY DEATH The Case of Bernadette Powell. By Ann Jones. 202 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $15.95.

title: AUBURN TRIUMPHS WITH JACKSON'S 205
description: Bo Jackson scored twice and rushed for 205 yards today to lead Auburn (2-0) to a 29-18 victory over Southern Mississippi. Jackson has two-game totals of 495 rushing yards and 6 touchdowns.

title: ANTI-SANDINISTAS VOW TO END RIGHTS ABUSES
description: Nicaraguan rebel leaders say they have begun to emphasize human rights and respect for civilians in an effort to improve the public image of the guerrillas and their conduct in the field.

title: THE TEXAS LITERATI: WHOSE HOME IS THIS RANGE, ANYHOW?
description: THERE is a genteel, but not always gentle, literary war going in Texas, fought, discreetly of course, on several fronts under several banners. Some of the engagements are mere skirmishes; battles of place, or the resistance of the natives to invasion by foreign troops. But there is a longer-running, more fundamental struggle going on that questions the validity of such basic assumptions as ''Texas writing'' and ''Texas writers.'' It is no longer enough to say ''I am a Texas writer.'' The speaker must stipulate ''I am a Houston writer . . . I am an Austin writer . . . a Dallas writer,'' or, more significantly, ''I write in Texas but I'm not a Texas writer.''

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Sept. 15, 1985 Fiction

title:
DINING OUT;

FINDING MONO AMONG THE SUSHI
description: AFICIONADOS of the Japanese delicacy sushi have, no doubt, discovered by now that those lovely fish and rice morsels offered at Takesushi rank among the best in the county. Order sushi or sashimi here and you can't miss. But few diners know that this spot also offers a small number of appetizers and main dishes from the kitchen, savory ''things'' (mono) that are grilled, fried or steamed (yakimono, agemono or mushimono) and that give the menu variety not often found in pure sushi establishments.

title: LINKING PAINTING AND CERAMICS
description: A NATURALLY exuberant spirit flowing between painting and ceramics is the most pronounced characteristic in the work of Eva Bouzard-Hui, now on view at the State Museum here.

title: HUNT BOWS OUT IN NORTH CAROLINA
description: With ''go'' or ''no-go'' decisions by incumbents and probable challengers still pending in several crucial races, assessing the odds that the Republicans' can retain control of the Senate in next year's elections is not easy. But people who calculate such things agreed last week that the Democrats' hopes of regaining the dominance they lost in 1980 were dampened when former Gov. James Hunt of North Carolina decided not to run for Senator John East's seat.

title: NEW BACH CHORALE-PRELUDES VIE FOR FAVOR
description: This time last year, few people in the world guessed that more than 30 works lay in a library at Yale just waiting to be certified as authentic compositions by Bach - the famous Bach, that is, the one whose 300th birthday we are celebrating this year. Yet, here at hand already are two different recordings of 33 chorale-preludes, whose existence was revealed to the world only last December.

title: VERSAILLES: A LIVELY CITY ON ITS OWN
description: The standard Versailles visit goes something like this: From the center of Paris you find your way to the RER C-line train that stops at the Versailles-Rive Gauche station, walk to the chateau, wait in line, take a quick tour, then return straight to the action in the capital. It is not the best way to experience Versailles.

title: ON THE OUTSKIRTS OF CAP TOWN, A FALLEN YOUTH IS MOURNED, AND ANGER RISES
description: A single coffin, draped in the black, gold and green colors of the exiled and outlawed African National Congress, lay today outside a modest brick home in this ramshackle black township on the outskirts of Cape Town.

title: ANTI-APARTHEID PROTEST GAINS GROUND
description: When President Reagan imposed limited economic sanctions this week against South Africa, he was responding in part to a broad anti-apartheid protest movement in this country that barely existed 10 months ago.

title: WASHINGTON SHARPENS ITS SWORD
description: HEAVY LOSSES The Dangerous Decline of American Defense. By James Coates and Michael Kilian. 430 pp. New York: Viking. $22.95.

title: WEST SIDE DEMOCRATS TO NOMINATE A CANDIDATE FOR STATE SENATE SEAT
description: Democratic politicians are to meet on the West Side of Manhattan today to pick a candidate for the State Senate seat that was left vacant by the death of Leon Bogues.

title: A BOOM IN 'ECONOMIC' REAL ESTATE DEALS
description: FOR real estate investors, 1985 has been the year of the ''economic'' deal. Since the Treasury made its modified flat tax proposals in November, tax-oriented real estate investments have fallen from favor, as investors became concerned that tax changes would reduce the future value of interest and depreciation deductions.

title: CELEBRATING AMERICAN DESIGN
description: ON THE FOURTH FLOOR OF A CONVERTED factory building on Lafayette Street in lower Manhattan, hundreds of sheets of plywood are stacked along one side of an 8,000-square-foot loft. The scene changes dramatically from week to week as a crew of carpenters, following the detailed blueprints of Robert Venturi, the noted Philadelphia architect, deftly cut and mold the plywood into a series of portable walls and platforms that zigzag and undulate and fold like sheets of origami into 8-by-10-foot sections.

title: MISS CASSIDY WED TO AN EXECUTIVE
description: Mary Louise Cassidy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Cassidy of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to John G. Finnegan Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Finnegan of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Robert J. Randall performed the ceremony at St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Noroton, Conn He was assisted by Msgr. Cornelius O'Brien.

title: NEW CROP: JOBS FOR IMMIGRANTS
description: FARMING strawberries in the midst of Bridgeport may seem like a challenge to some people, but Mohammed Noory, who escaped on muleback over the hills of Afghanistan at night to get to this country, believes he and other Asian immigrants will have little trouble.

title: BOSTON IS GROWING AGAIN AFTER THREE DECADES OF SHARP POPULATION DECLINE
description: After dropping steadily for more than 30 years, Boston's population has made a turnaround and in the past three years has begun to grow again, according to city officials and the Census Bureau.

title: The Rubber-Pasta Circuit
description: George McGovern is not exactly a member of the working class, but he does have to make a living. Even Italy's Communist Party can appreciate that.

title: DEATH-CAMP MEMOIR
description: AUSCHWITZ True Tales From a Grotesque Land. By Sara Nomberg-Przytyk. Edited by Eli Pfefferkorn and David H. Hirsch. Translated by Roslyn Hirsch. 185 pp. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press. $16.95. IN this remarkable memoir, Sara Nomberg-Przytyk describes Dr. Josef Mengele as ''that monster in the body of an Adonis'' who was ''so handsome that he inspired trust.'' Mengele, the Nazi war criminal whose remains were recently discovered in Brazil, would sit back in his armchair in the infirmary at Auschwitz, engage the newly arrived female patients in conversation and make them feel so comfortable they would ''forget where they were and start describing their ailments.'' Such sick people could never survive the arduous conditions in the death camp, and Mengele would use the women's illnesses as justification - on ''humanitarian'' grounds - for sending them immediately to their deaths.

title: A HANDFUL OF LABELS PRESERVE THE TROUBLED BLUES
description: In Chicago there may be 30 or 40 blues clubs of varying size and quality, ranging from nothing more than the corner bar with free entertainment to clubs with regularly scheduled performances and a cover charge. But in any case, many of the musicians who work these bars have little if any exposure outside of Chicago. And despite the renewed interest in blues spawned by the guitarist Stevie Ray Vaughan, the late Z. Z. Hill and a revival of bands interested in the raw energy of rock's roots, most musicians will have to be content with reaching a small audience.

title: DEBORAH LAWLER MEAGHER IS MARRIED TO JONATHAN LEOVY STANLEY AT VASSAR
description: Deborah Lawler Meagher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Coupe Meagher of Hyde Park, N.Y., and Waitsfield, Vt., and Jonathan Leovy Stanley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Stanley of Canton, Conn., were married yesterday. The ceremony at the Vassar College Chapel in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., was performed by the Rev. Charles Beausoleil, the Roman Catholic chaplain there.

title: WHAT WILL BE THE FATE OF THIS GIGANTIC SCORE?
description: Contemporary observers and subsequent generations usually view the composition of any given time in radically different ways. In the 1820's, for instance, most everyone in the musical know counted Spohr and Spontini as great composers, and hardly anyone had heard of Schubert.

title: PEOPLE'S BANK IN ROCKLAND TO REOPEN WEDNESDAY
description: Throughout the day a small string of customers went to the People's National Bank of Rockland County on Route 59 to peer through the locked doors and read the notices declaring the bank insolvent.

title: LEARNING DISABLED TAUGHT 'LIFE' SKILLS
description: EACH weekday, buses from 53 New Jersey school districts pull up in front of a red-brick building on Morris Street here.

title: HOME, QUIRKY HOME
description: WITH the loan of a weekend retreat for our family recently came an instruction sheet from the owners, explaining and preparing us for its little idiosyncracies. Seems you had to flip a switch on the wall for the television to go on, as well as to spotlight the ceiling beams. The front screen door would close only part way, the toilet handle had to be jiggled in the downstairs bath or it would run incessantly, and the dishwasher started in the ''off'' position. Duly noted, we moved in and coped amazingly well. And why not? We all come from jerry-rigged domiciles, admit it or not.

title: Marilyn Alice O'Neill WED TO C. A. WAGNER
description: Marilyn Alice O'Neill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Francis O'Neill of Upper Saddle River, N.J., and Cooperstown, N.Y., was married in Cooperstown yesterday to Christopher Alastair Wagner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Reese Wagner of Clinton, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth O. Jones of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church performed the ceremony at the Farmers' Museum Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Marcel Turcot, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: A SUNDAY ATHLETE BRINGS OUT HIS RETIRED GLOVE
description: THEY were an odd assortment of men, ranging in age from mid-20's to mid-50's, from lean and fit to hopelessly out of shape, dressed in everything from grease-stained madras shorts and black dress shoes to regulation baseball knickers and cleats.

title: ONE OF THE GANG
description: FOR all but one of the last 15 years, Larry Bowa helped keep the Mets out of first place in the Eastern Division, with Philadelphia and then Chicago, but now he is a member of the Mets, with all the obligations and privileges that entails.

title: THRONG OF KINGS, PRESIDENTS AND PREMIERS COMING TO U.N.
description: The chief of protocol at the United Nations fears he ''will be submerged under the waves.'' The intelligence chief for the New York Police Department is studying where to park a mini-police headquarters on New York city streets. Four teams of workers on scaffolds are fighting the clock to scrape away years of soot and rust from the 39-floor aluminum and steel United Nations headquarters.

title: 14-HOUR CONCERT IN ILLINOIS SEPT. 22 WILL SEEK $50 MILLION TO HELP FARMERS
description: Seeking to imitate the success of the Live Aid concert that benefited famine victims abroad, 50 leading country and Western and rock musicians are planning to appear at a 14-hour concert Sept. 22 in Champaign, Ill., to help the nation's distressed farmers.

title: Delaware Studies A Canine Case
description: THE Delaware Attorney General, fresh from victory in a major murder trial this week, turned his attention to some possible ''flea bargaining'' in the case of Daisy, the celebrated mail dog of Harrington.

title: EPISCOPALIANS TAKE A BREAK IN DISNEYLAND
description: When they become fatigued with the labyrinthine worlds of theology and politics, many of the delegates to the Episcopal Church's General Convention have been breaking away to tour the more whimsical realms of Tomorrowland, Fantasyland, Adventureland and Frontierland.

title: RACE FOR AMERICA'S CUP IS ALREADY UNDER WAY
description: SEVERAL groups with ties to Westchester are preparing to challenge the Australians with the intent of regaining the America's Cup from the Royal Perth Yacht Club in 1987. Employing the most modern technology and aided by large budgets, they are prefacing their ocean encounters with competing claims about which group is best suited to make the run.

title: LENDL, AS GOLFER, FIGHTS ALZHEIMER'S
description: THE winner's check at the United States Open tennis championship went to a determined Ivan Lendl of Greenwich, Conn., last Sunday. But earlier this summer when a relaxed Mr. Lendl casually played golf with other athletes and player-donors at the Metropolis Country Club in White Plains, he received no check at all. In fact, Mr. Lendl contributed a check of his own, part of $45,600 in donations to the Westchester Chapter of the Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association. The player-donors contributed $500 each to golf along with the professional athletes.

title: LOUISIANA GOVERNOR'S TRIAL ON FRAUD CHARGES IS EXPECTED TO BE LONG AND COMPLEX
description: Tuesday morning, in a Federal District Court here, the suave, silver-haired Governor of Louisiana, Edwin Edwards, will stand before the bench to face trial on charges of racketeering, mail and wire fraud.

title: VETERAN REUNION DRAWING PROTESTS
description: Veterans of an American infantry division and the German Waffen SS soldiers they battled in World War II more than 40 years ago have been exchanging visits for a decade and plan to meet again in a few weeks, according to members of the American group.

title: POSSE SEEKS SLAYERS OF N. CAROLINA TROOPER
description: A North Carolina state trooper was shot to death on a highway today, and a posse of 100 people using 10 bloodhounds searched rough, mountainous terrain for two convicts who escaped from Arkansas.

title: R. E. KNOX WEDS HELENE HOLBROOK
description: The marriage of Helene Morrison Holbrook to Robert Eden Knox, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Donald Knox of Springfield, Va., took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. David D. Holbrook of Katonah, N.Y. The Rev. Louise Parsons Weld performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: THEY'RE CALLED KILLER BEES
description: ONE THING TO STRESS IN ANY ARTICLE,'' SAYS Binford Weaver, ''is that beekeepers are not the enemy. They are the country's first line of defense.'' Weaver - 57 years old, with thick gray hair and deep squint lines around his eyes - is sitting in the office of Weaver Apiaries, in Navasota, Tex., worrying about the news from California. Several colonies of ''killer bees,'' presumably descended from a colony that stowed away on a ship from South America, have been found in that state. Properly described as Africanized honeybees, the ''killer bees'' are one mean bunch of insects - aggressive, hard to handle, prolific breeders. They have killed animals and humans in mass stinging attacks, although a single ''killer bee'' sting is no worse than that of any other honeybee.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 13 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 13 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: LOOKING FOR SOMEONE ELSE
description: IT is Tuesday night and I have given in. With the Westport Unitarian Singles Group as my destination, I drive up Lyons Plains Road, planning my arrival at about 8:15. That way I do not have to stand around too long feeling awkward, waiting for the discussion to start. Problem is that 350 people have already arrived and there are no more parking places. That means I have to proceed on up the road to a place that will accept the overflow of cars. That also means a quarter-mile trek back to the Unitarian Church.

title: NEW & NOTWORTHY
description: VICTORY OVER JAPAN, by Ellen Gilchrist. (Little, Brown, $7.95.) This collection of 14 short stories about Southern women from World War II to the present won the 1984 American Book Award for Fiction. Last year Beverly Lowry wrote here that these stories are ''wonderful to tell aloud,'' though she found ''problems with a few. . . . But this is a writer who does not play it safe and so the risks and misses are bound to be there. The pay-off is definitely worth the ride.'' Little, Brown has also reissued the author's novel, THE ANNUNCIATION ($7.95). Its heroine is Amanda McCamey, who grows up on a Mississippi Delta plantation, marries money, rejects it and moves to a university town to work and make new friends. Reviewers praised the book as rich, evocative, intelligent and strikingly original. WHEN AND WHERE I ENTER: The Impact of Black Women on Race and Sex in America, by Paula Giddings. (Bantam, $8.95.) ''When and Where I Enter'' is a history of the dogged determination of black women to survive in America. Last year in The Book Review Gloria Naylor wrote of the author that ''by sorting through a vast amount of primary and secondary material, by reading innumerable novels and conducting exhaustive interviews, she compiled a narrative history of black women from the 17th century to the present, with particular emphasis on the black women's club movement of the 1890's to the 1940's. It was a labor of commitment and love - and it shows.''

title: MORALITY WITHOUT SERMONS
description: TIME AND TIME AGAIN Autobiographies. By Dan Jacobson. 213 pp. Boston: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $15.95.

title: HAIR-CURLING ADVENTURES
description: On a tour of French chateaus, I encountered one of those striking American grandmothers, perpetually fresh as a daisy in Ultrasuede and a coiffure reminiscent of Marie Antoinette. We discovered a mutual shortcoming. Neither of us could do a thing with her hair.

title: SCHOOLS ADD SERVICES BY SHARING
description: FOUR high school students in Pleasantville will take Latin by television with eight students in Ossining.

title: POLICE RECRUIT LESSON 1: DISCIPLINE
description: THE line between thinking like a police trainee and thinking like a police officer can be a difficult one to cross. At the Nassau County Police Academy, discipline marks that crossing point.

title:
GARDENING;

TIPS ON GETTING THE TASTIEST OF APPLES
description: THERE is nothing better than biting into a crisp, juicy apple in the fall. Depending upon the cultivar, it may be sweet, tart or even spicy. Trouble is, many of the apples at supermarkets and produce stores are just like the average store-purchased tomato -they are tasteless.

title: WRITERS IN NEW LONDON
description: Some prominent writers will gather at Connecticut College, in New London, this week to discuss the relationship between fiction and nonfiction.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: MICHELLE ROSEN ENGAGED
description: The engagement of Michelle Rosen, an associate with the New York law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, to Richard Silverman, a news editor for Dow Jones News Retrieval in South Brunswick, N.J., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Rosen of East Windsor, N.J., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Silverman of Nesconset, L.I.

title: ALL HAIL ROTHENBERG
description: Susan Rothenberg, the painter, will have her first Washington solo exhibit of paintings and drawings at the Phillips Collection from Sept. 21 to Nov. 17. The Phillips says Miss Rothenberg is ''widely accepted as one of the most original and influential of contemporary American artists,'' whose work, ''representing a third generation of the New York School, is seen by critics and scholars as a bridge between the formal structures of Minimalism and the New Expressionism.''

title: A RARE PEACE ON PESTICIDE REGULATION
description: The Hatfields and the McCoys of environmental regulation made peace last week, and not a grudging but possibly a pattern-setting one.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: TOO MUCH TOO SOON. By Jacqueline Briskin. (Putnam, $17.95.) At first glance, Jacqueline Briskin's latest novel appears to have all the ingredients of a delicious romance, the kind best read while lying in bed nibbling chocolate-covered caramels.

title: MODERN MUSIC
description: The late Roger Sessions was a pivotal force in 20th-century American music - as theorist, teacher and, above all, composer. Sessions, who died earlier this year at the age of 88, studied with the fabled Horatio Parker (who also taught Charles Ives) and later served as an assistant to Ernest Bloch.

title: IMMUNIZATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;

TIPS ON GETTING THE TASTIEST OF APPLES
description: THERE is nothing better than biting into a crisp, juicy apple in the fall. Depending upon the cultivar, it may be sweet, tart or even spicy. Trouble is, many of the apples at supermarkets and produce stores are just like the average store-purchased tomato -they are tasteless.

title: CLAIRE SUMMERLIN WEDS M. F. SLATTERY
description: Sandi Claire Summerlin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Summerlin of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Martin Francis Slattery of New York and Leucadia, Calif. The Rev. Eugene G. Connolly, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Alastair Daele-Guinan, performed the ceremony in the Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral in Manhattan.

title: WINNERS OF PRIMARIES READY DRIVES
description: BERNICE SPRECKMAN, in her fourth term on the Yonkers City Council, won the Democratic primary for Mayor last week and earned the right to challenge the Republican incumbent, Angelo R. Martinelli, in his drive for a sixth term.

title: THAILAND'S MILITARY SUFFERS SOME SELF-INFLICTED WOUNDS
description: It was a dismal attempt at a coup that stood for nothing and solved nothing. Last Monday, for the second time in just over four years, Manoon Rupekarchorn, a disaffected former colonel followed by 22 tanks and about 500 men, tried to overthrow the Government of Prime Minister Prem Tinsulandonda. Again, he failed. But what may seem like the end of the story may be just the beginning.

title: SONDHEIM'S 'FOLLIES' EVOKES OLD BROADWAY
description: What does a Broadway hit sound like? According to a Stephen Sondheim song titled ''It's a Hit!,'' it's ''the sound of an audience losing its mind.'' That's not a sound that has been largely associated with Mr. Sondheim's commercially problematic career - even ''It's a Hit!'' was written for a Broadway flop, ''Merrily We Roll Along'' - but the joyful noise could be heard last weekend at Lincoln Center, where the composer's ''Follies'' was revived for two nights in a concert performance. As played by the New York Philharmonic, conducted by Paul Gemignani and sung and acted by an illustrious cast of past and present Broadway hands, ''Follies'' filled Avery Fisher Hall with the sound of an audience losing its mind long before Barbara Cook got around to delivering the show's torch song, ''Losing My Mind.'' New York's theatrical community, which shared the hall with civilian ticketholders, found itself enjoying its first uninhibited hoot since the gala, record-breaking performance of ''A Chorus Line'' two Septembers ago.

title: THE ARMING OF LEBANON: GUN-RUNNING ON THE RISE
description: For more than a decade, weapons and ammunition have poured into the killing grounds of Lebanon from a vast variety of sources, turning the country into an arms supermarket.

title: IN NEW YORK, A WEB OF INTRIGUE
description: IN 1981, the year Pope John Paul II was shot in Rome, a new Italian organization surfaced on Park Avenue in New York. Known as ''Grand Italia,'' its goal was to unite 120 million Italians and people of Italian descent in a ''second Risorgimento'' of worldwide Italian rebirth.

title: IMMUNIZATIONS
description: To the Editor: In addition to smallpox vaccination no longer being reuired in any country, travelers should know that tetanus boosters are recommended only ever 10 years, although many physicians lower that interval for travelers who go to remote places.

title: HIROSHIMA MAIDENS IN AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: HALL OF SCIENCE IN QUEENS ASKS YOUTHS TO GRADE IT
description: Dr. Alan J. Friedman is striving to create what New York City officials hope will be one of the world's leading exhibition centers for science and technology.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about photojournalism in the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday misstated the time and place of a Carl Mydans exhibition.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE OVAL AMULET By Lucy Cullyford Babbitt. 243 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $13.50. (Ages 12 and up) FANTASY novels with young female protagonists have become quite popular in recent years, and deservedly so. Lucy Cullyford Babbitt's ''Oval Amulet'' is distinctive in that it looks beyond the basic question of sexual equality to show that the traditional differences between the acceptable behavior of men and that of women are not only artificial, but often limiting and harmful to both sexes.

title: TRYING HARDER
description: COMEBACK Case by Case: Building the Resurgence of American Business. By Ezra F. Vogel. 320 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95 WHAT the United States can learn from Japan has been a growth industry since the publication of Ezra Vogel's thought-provoking book, ''Japan as Number One.'' But many people forget that the subtitle was ''Lessons for the United States.''

title: TRISHA BROWN BRINGS HER DANCES TO CITY CENTER
description: Although Trisha Brown has been making and presenting dances in New York since the early 1960's, her company's forthcoming engagement at the City Center - six performances beginning Tuesday -looms as an important milestone for the choreographer - her first engagement in an ''establishment'' midtown house.

title: FALLOUT FROM SOUTH AFRICA SANCTIONS
description: Lesotho is in a bind. That is evident at the country's only railroad station, where all trains go to South Africa, and at its power stations, where all electricity comes from South Africa. The tiny nation also gets all of its oil and telephone calls through South Africa, and most of its labor force works there.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LADY'S TIME. By Alan V. Hewat. (Harper & Row, $16.95.) This ambitious first novel describes the life of a turn-of-the-century New Orleans ragtime pianist, Lady Winslow (nee Alice Beaudette), and through her tries to depict the birth of jazz and ragtime.

title: JAYS THRIVE ON YANKEES' TURF
description: Their mood was subdued, not jubilant. The Toronto Blue Jays were not quite prepared to bury the Yankees last night, but they did seem to relish the thought of an emotional lift in a critical four-game series.

title: SENTENCE SETTERS
description: A commission with the mandate to set uniform guidelines for Federal criminal sentences took shape last week, when President Reagan named its seven members. The panel was established under a 1984 law designed to reduce the disparities among punishments meted out by different judges for similar crimes.

title: THE PROPHETIC SHOE SALESMAN
description: THE BUREAUCRATIZATION OF THE WORLD The First English Edition of the Underground Marxist Classic That Analyzed Class Exploitation in the USSR. By Bruno Rizzi. Translated and with an introduction by Adam Westoby. 111 pp. New York: The Free Press. $16.95.

title: PLANNERS INFLUENCE RIVERSIDE HOUSING IN COLLEGE POINT
description: IF there are fishermen living in College Point, Queens, they have reason to rejoice. With a nudge from the City Planning Commission, Bernard Janowitz is going to build two public fishing piers, extending 60 feet into the East River and connected with the nearest public thoroughfare, 120th Street, by 200-foot-long walkways.

title: WINNERS AND LOSERS
description: THE primary election last week ended with such lopsided victories in the most visible races that the lists of winners and losers would seem clear and simple. But hidden in the columns of numbers were warnings that even the widest of margins did not remove all the thorns from the roses.

title: ADIRONDACK PANEL PICKS A SITE
description: The Town of Newcomb in Essex County, with a population of 681 scattered over 225 square miles, has been recommended as the site of a new $4.1 million center for visitors to the Adirondack Mountains.

title: WHEN TRUTH BECAME A DEFENSE AGAINST LIBEL
description: To the Editor:

title: FINALES OF SUMMER, PRELUDES OF AUTUMN
description: THERE was a time when September was a quiet month in Connecticut, a kind of cultural breathing spell between the rush of summer festivals and the launching of the fall season. No longer: Thanks to late finishes and early starts, fine music continues in bountiful supply all over the state.

title: TRIBAL POSITIONS HARDEN IN INDIAN LAND DISPUTE
description: The words of the elders of this Hopi village were freighted with the dark lessons of time: that only land is of lasting value and that the Hopi and the Navajo were arguing about the land long before white men arrived with their solutions.

title: FROM THE CAHIERS CRITICS, AN ENDURING LEGACY
description: George Bernard Shaw, in one of a number of letters he wrote to R. E. Golding Bright beginning in 1894, when Bright was 20, repeatedly advised the aspiring drama critic to describe what he saw and to avoid statements of sweeping, usually meaningless generalities. Golding Bright apparently followed Shaw's directions with care. He became a successful drama critic and later an even more successful drama agent, representing Shaw himself, among others.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN THE WEATHER BUSINESS
description: It was a matter of precision. Compu-weather Inc. meteorologists in Flushing, Queens, predicted that a ''monster snow storm'' would begin a little after noon, and that there would be 12 inches or more. Expect a blizzard, they said.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: PREVIN. By Helen Drees Ruttencutter. (Marek/St. Martin's, $14.95.) This lively book is an expanded version of a two-part profile of Andre Previn that appeared in The New Yorker, where Helen Drees Ruttencutter, the author of ''Quartet'' and ''Pianist's Progress,'' works on the editorial staff. Mr. Previn, now the music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra, had an unconventional passage to classical musicianship.

title: AIDS THE SUBJECT AS NEW YORK SCHOOLS OPEN
description: AIDS dominated the first week of classes in the New York City public school system, with administrators defending in schoolhouse and courthouse their decision to admit a second-grade pupil who suffers from the disease. School officials estimated that about 12,000 students in Queens stayed away from the first day of school to protest the unidentified youngster's admission to regular classes. They said that almost all the remaining 934,000 students in the system reported as scheduled.

title: HEMPSTEAD OFFENSE STRONG
description: Lawrence and Hempstead kick off their 1985 football seasons in a cable-televised game next Sunday, commencing the Nassau County Divison I race in grand style, with two of the top four ranked teams going head-to-head. But in the eyes of the Lawrence coach, Richard Mollo, top-ranked Hempstead (9-1-1) will be No. 1 until they're beaten.

title: NEW CASSETTES: DISNEY, KAZAN AND SUTHERLAND
description: Baby Doll Starring Karl Malden, Carroll Baker, Eli Wallach; directed by Elia Kazan, 1956 Warner Home Video 115 minutes. $59.95 Nearly 30 years after the furor it generated, ''Baby Doll'' seems an unlikely object of moral condemnation.

title: THE MALKOVICH MAGNETISM
description: HE SEEMS AN ODD CHOICE FOR A movie star. He is pigeon-toed and speaks with a whine. Prematurely bald, he has an odd-shaped head and, until some recent bridgework, his teeth were a mess.

title: AIDE TO HOMELESS PLANS $10,000 DASH
description: CYNTHIA WALLQUIST is not normally a runner. ''I take my dog for long walks,'' said Miss Wallquist, a White Plains resident. ''That's about the extent of it.''

title: ELEGANCE IN TARRYTOWN
description: If it is elegance you seek, look no farther than Lyndhurst, once the home of Jay Gould.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE ESSENTIAL ROYSTER: A Vermont Royster Reader. Edited by Edmund Fuller. (Algonquin Books, $18.95.) England has its essayists, whose perfect diction, public-school trained, flows periodic from their pens on almost any subject at all.

title: DINERS: NEW STYLE OR OLD, A PLACE CALLED HOME
description: In an age of fast-food franchises and trendy restaurant chains, the roadside diner remains a familiar -- and welcome -- sight in New Jersey ''No doubt about it,'' said Michael Kelker, vice president of a diner manufacturing concern in the town of Middlesex. ''New Jersey is the diner state. It's the center of the industry. There are more diners per square mile in New Jersey than in any other state in the union.''

title: LATEST CAUSE ON CAMPUS: SAYING NO TO 'STAR WARS'
description: Sanford Gottlieb is a self-described ''peace activist'' who achieved a certain note in 1965 when he helped organize one of the first big protest marches in Washington against the Vietnam war.

title: STONY BROOK STATE BEATS RAMAPO, 22-6
description: Joe Greco completed touchdown passes of 2 yards to Jim Hayes and 30 to Pete Impagliazzo as Stony Brook State, playing a complete varsity schedule for the first time since joining Division III of the National Collegiate Athletic Association three years ago, opened the season yesterday afternoon with a 22-6 victory over Ramapo.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE
description: Who was the greatest professional football player of the quarter century from 1960 through 1984 ? Jim Brown, perhaps? Johnny Unitas? O. J. Simpson? Ray Nitschke? Would you believe Ray Guy? By one measure, at least, the Raider punter is the most highly regarded player of the period. In balloting by the selectors of the Pro Football Hall of Fame to pick an all-star team for the 25-season span, Guy received more votes than any of the 51 other players named to the first and second teams.

title: 4 INDIAN CHEFS COPE WITH THE OCCIDENT
description: RICHARD GRAHAM did not believe that the Indian grocery stores in the United States could possibly have all the spices he and his fellow chefs would need for the three-and-a-half-month, six-city odyssey that has them moving in and out of different time zones every few weeks. So they brought everything with them. Needlessly, as it turned out.

title: SOME FACTS ON 'ORANGES'
description: Prokofiev himself conducted the first performance of ''L'Amour des Trois Oranges'' in Chicago's Auditorium on Dec. 30, 1921. A French translation of the libretto, which the composer adapted from Carlo Gozzi's fantastic 18th-century comedy, ''Fiaba dell' amore delle tre Melarancie,'' was used at the premiere.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''I think there is a sentiment that we have to act on trade. If we don't have an aggressive trade policy, I feel it would cost momentum and possibly even votes on the tax reform bill.''

title: THE MAGNIFICENT ORSONS
description: ORSON WELLES A Biography. By Barbara Leaming. Illustrated. 562 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95. ORSON WELLES The Rise and Fall of an American Genius. By Charles Higham. Illustrated. 373 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $19.95. THE MAKING OF ''CITIZEN KANE'' By Robert L. Carringer. Illustrated. 180 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $22.50.

title: A FATHER'S ANGER
description: IN ''BAD DAY AT BLACK ROCK,'' a film my father wrote, Robert Ryan tells Spencer Tracy: ''Nobody around here has been big enough to make you mad. I believe a man is as big as the things that make him mad.'' I've never forgotten those lines. They are linked to one of my earliest memories of my father: Dad is pacing the living room, holding the phone under an arm like a football and screaming into the receiver, ''Don't tell me how to write the goddamn thing!''

title: ARMS TALKS WITH SAUDIS
description: The Reagan Administration has long been trying to sell new F-15's and other advanced military equipment to Saudi Arabia but it has met resistance in Congress from supporters of Israel.

title: A PLACE FOR LOVERS -- OF GARLIC
description: TOLEDO, a Spanish restaurant in Great Neck, is underutilized except on Saturday evenings. Yet it offers a number of commendably prepared, assertively seasoned specialties.

title: Light to Shine On Nantucket
description: THANKS to a group of Nantucket preservationists, a new lighthouse on the island's Great Point will be a replica of the 1818 brick-and-stone model that succumbed to a storm last year, and not a steel tower with a mechanical light.

title: JUDICIAL PANEL NEARS DECISION ON U.S. COURT POWER DISPUTE
description: A panel of Federal appellate judges in Cincinnati is expected to make a decision Monday on a power struggle between Federal district judges here.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bloomingdale $90,000 *2* 17 Hamilton Street *2* 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 33-year-old expanded ranch; *2* new roof, laundry room, 1-car garage; *2* taxes $1,786. Iselin $98,000 *2* 262 East Iselin Parkway *2* 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 28-year-old ranch; *2* basement bathroom, recessed radiators; *2* taxes $1,801. Livingston $152,000 *2* 36 Spring Road *2* 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old bilevel; *2* new roof, patio, 3-zone heat; *2* taxes $2,402. Maplewood $99,000 *2* 143 Jacoby Street *2* 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; *2* 2 apartments, new roof and porch; *2* taxes $2,929. Metuchen $113,000 *2* 30 Dolores Drive *2* 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 25-year-old split level; *2* family room, screened porch, *2* central air-conditioning; taxes $2,428. Phillipsburg $82,900 *2* 320 Park Avenue *2* 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 27-year-old ranch; *2* copper plumbing, finished basement, 1-car garage; *2* taxes $1,234. OTHER AREAS Simsbury, Conn. $137,000 *2* 7 Meadow Crossing *2* 4-bedrooms, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old contemporary; *2* views of mountains, 2 acres; *2* taxes $2,595. Ardsley, N.Y. $194,000 *2* 35 Larchmont Street *2* 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old frame ranch; *2* screened porch, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; *2* taxes $3,680. Mineola, L.I. $135,000 *2* 469 Jefferson Avenue *2* 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 38-year-old Cape Cod; *2* eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; *2* taxes $1,700.

title: ITALIAN HIDEAWAY IN MIDLAND PARK By ANNE SEMMES
description: ARTURO'S, tucked into a mini shopping strip in Midland Park, near Ridgewood, is one of those little finds that its regulars, understandably, would like to keep under wraps.

title: BALTIMORE SALUTES ITSELF
description: Stop mourning the passing of summer and plunge into the festivities of fall. The 16th Annual Baltimore City Fair, which begins Friday, is a good place to start.

title: A CITY SENTENCING PLAN HAS PUT 1,700 TO WORK
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that about 1,700 people convicted of misdemeanors have been assigned to clean up city recreation areas in a two-year-old alternative sentencing program.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: PHAEDRA: A Novel of Ancient Athens. By June Rachuy Brindel. (St. Martin's, $14.95.) In ''Phaedra,'' a few sprigs snipped from Greek legend, a sprinkle of romance, sex and violence, and a generous dash of antipatriarchal and pacifist sentiment have been stirred into a heady broth of scholarship on archaic nature cults and pre-classical Greek society.

title: SOUTH AFRICA FLIRTS WITH REFORM
description: Informed that an eminent rival had died, Talleyrand remarked memorably to a colleague, ''Now what did he mean by that?'' And so have we learned to respond to hints from South Africa's white Government that apartheid is dying at last.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: ROCK GARDENS How does your garden grow? If you are a card-carrying member of the American Rock Garden Society, naturally with rocks. And today at 10 A.M. at Clark Garden in Albertson, members of the Long Island chapter of the society make the rest of the gardening world privy to their secrets at the annual Symposium and Plant Sale. There will be slide-lectures on such subjects as ''How to Build a Rock Garden'' and ''Rock Garden Plants for Sun or Shade,'' with such experts as Joann Knapp, past president of the Long Island Horticultural Society, giving the lowdown, and a sale of choice specimens. The symposium, through 3 P.M., costs $5 to attend, and includes admission to Clark Garden on I.U. Willets Road. The plant sale, from 12:30 to 3 P.M., comes with regular garden admission of $1.50 or 75 cents for senior citizens and children. For information call 621-7568. CAN YOU CANOE? As one of the more scenic spots on the South Fork, Acabonac Harbor in the Springs section of East Hampton is a veritable boating oasis, particularly for those who like to do their boating at a leisurely pace in a canoe. Today the pace picks up a bit when the local Historical Society stages its Fifth Annual Great Bonac Canoe Race. Open to those over 15 years of age, registration, at the end of Louse Point, is at 10 A.M. and costs $6 a person. The races get under way at 11 A.M. when the racing canoes take off.

title: ROBIN NEIMARK PLANS TO MARRY FREDERIC SEEGAL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ira Neimark of Harrison, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Robin Margery Neimark to Frederic Milton Seegal, the son of Miriam Emden of New York and the late Milton Seegal of Los Angeles.

title: CAR BOMB HURTS 2 IN ULSTER
description: Three masked gunmen packed a stolen car with explosives and set off a powerful blast late Friday that heavily damaged the commercial center of Omagh, 80 miles west of here, slightly wounding two people, the police said today. No one immediately took responsibility for the blast.

title: PREDICTING THE PATH OF FASHION TRENDS
description: FOR Pat Tunsky of Washington Town, forecasting trends in fashion represents a careful blend of politics, history and economics, topped off with a splash of popular culture.

title: PROVIDENCE'S REPERTORY
description: In Providence, R.I., the Trinity Square Repertory Company begins its 22d season Friday with Christopher Durang's play ''The Marriage of Bette and Boo.''

title: LINKS AND WINKS
description: QUINX Or The Ripper's Tale. By Lawrence Durrell. 201 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.

title: RUTGERS GAINS TIE WITH FLORIDA, 28-28
description: Joe Gagliardi threw a 16-yard touchdown pass to Bruce Campbell with 35 seconds left and then connected with Curtis Stephens for a 2-point conversion to give Rutgers a surprising and exciting 28-28 tie today with highly favored Florida.

title: YANKS SLIP AGAIN RIGHETTI FAILS IN 7-4 DEFEAT
description: This was the night the Yankees' bullpen collapsed - and right smack in the middle of a pennant race.

title: THE ABORTION CONFLICT
description: If the United States Department of Justice, obligated to protect our constitutional rights, enabled black students in the 1960's to pass through obstructing mobs to their classrooms by assigning a guard of Federal marshals, shouldn't the Justice Department protect the constitutional rights of women entering an abortion clinic today? Does the failure so far to assign marshals mean that the Justice Department picks and chooses our rights at whim? LAWRENCE $:ADER President Abortion Rights Mobilization New York City

title: ON AIRLINE SAFETY, THE RECORD IS REASSURING
description: When the deregulation of this country's airlines went into effect in late 1978, anxiety rippled through the ranks of safety specialists. They worried that, in an era of proliferating airlines and unfettered competition, economic pressures would dilute the attention paid to safety. So far, statistics show, those fears have not been realized. Still, last week, as investigators searched for the cause of a DC-9 accident in Milwaukee that was the third crash of a large domestic scheduled airliner this year, the old concerns came to the fore again.

title: PARENTS OF ABUSED CHLDREN FIND HELP IN SUPPORT GROUP
description: SOME of the adults are chatting in the living room, others linger over the pot-luck lunch of barbecued chicken and sweet potato pie. Young children wander in and out from the backyard. Then two cakes are brought in, candles blazing, and everyone gathers around to sing ''Happy Birthday'' to one of the mothers.

title: THE SECRET BEHIND THE 'STAR WARS'
description: William Broad's article on the Lawrence Livermore weapons lab reminded me of the Faust legend, with Peter Hagelstein as Dr. Faustus, and with Lowell Wood, director of Livermore's O Group, as Mephistopheles. MARK GOODMAN Princeton, N.J.

title: TO CALIFORNIA FOR GOLD, PENNSYLVANIA FOR HISTORY
description: Prospecting For All That Glitters In hopes of striking it rich, some people play lotteries. Others hopefully emulate those whose dreams came true at Sutter's Mill, Calif., in 1848: They pan for gold.

title: STARTING A SCHOOL
description: AFTER repeated discussions about the shortcomings of public education, Carol Wimer and her friend Cheryl McLauchlan, department chairmen at Hawthorne (N.J.) High School, did what many dissatisfied employees talk about but never do. They quit and started their own enterprise.

title: 'UNITED STATES' GETS A FRESH START Steve Schneider regularly reports about developments in cable.
description: It was supposed to be an innovation in television, an expansion of the possibilities of the situation comedy. It was supposed to inaugurate a tradition of realism for the genre, operating without the cartoonish trappings that reduce so many sitcoms to hollow farces. It was, in the words of its creator, supposed to ''put characters on a slide like laboratory specimens and use a television set like a microscope to examine their marriage.'' It was supposed to challenge viewers, rather than coddle them.

title: JOCELYN JONES WEDS FRANCIS GREALY JR.
description: Jocelyn Fenwick Jones, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Fenwick Jones of Baltimore, was married in Washington yesterday to Francis P. Grealy Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Grealy of Crestwood, N.Y., and Vero Beach, Fla. The Rev. John Breslin performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. William's Chapel on the Georgetown University campus.

title: MONIQUE MARI PARRISH WEDS MORGAN GILHULY
description: The marriage of Monique Mari Parrish, a daughter of Dr. David Parrish of Boulder, Colo., and Maria Russell Parrish of San Clemente, Calif., to Robert Morgan Gilhuly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Gilhuly of Cos Cob, Conn., took place yesterday at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Vincent J. O'Connor performed the ceremony.

title: CITY LAW ON WATER METERS ANGERS BUILDING OWNERS
description: A NEW law requiring the installation of water meters in all new or substantially renovated residential buildings in New York City is drawing complaints from developers and building owners, who call it unfair and ineffective. City officials, however, insist that it will be an effective conservation measure.

title: THE ABORTION CONFLICT
description: I was pleased to read a straightforward article on the abortion issue (''The Abortion Conflict,'' by Dudley Clendinen, Aug. 11). Doctors such as Peter Bours who are performing a legal and safe medical procedure need to speak out and refuse to be intimidated by a small percentage of the population who are threatened by freedom of choice.

title: RONI TANNENBAUM TO WED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harold Tannenbaum of East Windsor, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Roni Tannenbaum to Kyle Dean Chadwick, a son of Matilda L. Wuest of Avenel, N.J., and the late William Chadwick.

title: LEWIS AND SLANEY WIN
description: Victories by Carl Lewis and Mary Decker Slaney highlighted the Seoul International Track and Field Meet today at Olympic Stadium, as United States athletes dominated the competition.

title: POLICE SEEK GRAFFITI AUTHORS
description: The Police Chief here has asked a handwriting expert to examine remarks on a men's room wall at police headquarters in order to identify who wrote them.

title: DRUGGED DRIVERS
description: THE police in six communities in New Jersey began last December to check the brain waves of some motorists in hopes of catching those driving under the influence of drugs.

title: 40-STORY TOWER ON 2D
description: Since the late 1960's many of Second Avenue's low-rise residential and commercial buildings have given way to high-rise residences built primarily for the city's growing ranks of upwardly-mobile young professionals.

title: DOLLARS AND CENTS
description: ASSEMBLYMAN Farrell finished third in Tuesday's Democratic mayoral primary, but he took one title.

title: LAURIE CREEDON IS WED TO TODD JOSEPH MARTIN
description: Laurie Kathleen Creedon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Creedon of Stamford, Conn., and Chatham, Mass., was married yesterday to Todd Joseph Martin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Martin of De Pere, Wis. The Rev. Matthew Mees performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Chatham.

title: TAKING STOCK
description: GIVEN THE EX-pense of good clothing - a well-tailored suit can cost $400 and considerably more - ''investment dressing'' is an increasingly valid approach to maintaining a wardrobe.

title: CLINTON HILL
description: THE quiet, tree-shaded peace of the 200 block of Clinton Avenue is one of the central features of Clinton Hill, a Brooklyn neighborhood just a few blocks east of Fort Greene Park.

title: RISE AND FALL AT THE DENTURE WORKS
description: LETTER TO LORD LISZT By Martin Walser. Translated by Leila Vennewitz. 149 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $13.95.

title: SUZANNE ROTHSCHILD MARRIES
description: Suzanne Trott Rothschild and John Wilkinson Baynard were married yesterday at the Phippsburg (Me.) Congregational Church. The Rev. Ronald Speckmann performed the ceremony.

title: LET'S RESUME TALKS ON COEXISTENCE
description: The November summit meeting in Geneva provides an opportunity to begin a long overdue dialogue on the requirements for coexistence between the United States and Soviet Union. Almost all of the superpower negotiations since 1969 have dealt with arms control. But the arms race has continued unchecked because we have failed to negotiate an agreement on the limits of our political competition. The summit is the place to begin.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You are the victims of a vindictive act of retaliation. You should in no way feel any blame or stigma.''

title: FED SHOULD AIM AT GROWTH, NOT AT M-1
description: IMAGINE that your car's heat gauge is a little off, enough to push the indicator from the normal range into the danger zone, even though the car is running normally. Now imagine that you are a member of the Federal Reserve Board, looking at the recent explosive growth in M-1, the monetary aggregate that is supposed to affect economic growth and inflation most directly. The two situations have more in common than many economists - particularly monetarists - would like us to think.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

BEHOLD THE GREED MACHINE
description: WHEN I was growing up in the 1950's, children, asked what they wanted to be when they grew up, usually responded, ''I want to help people'' or ''I want to build bridges.''

title: Misspeaking Oneself
description: William Safire ridicules Soviet leader Gorbachev for confusing the Soviet Union and Russia (''Open Mike,'' On Language, Aug. 11). Mr. Safire then says: ''In America, if the President were caught in such a political-cultural gaffe, the White House spokesman would be out 10 minutes later to explain that the President 'misspoke himself.' '' As Safire's first two words demonstrate, United States confusion is much deeper and more casual.

title: NEW MODERATE-RATE HOUSING PLAN
description: WITH help from seven insurance companies, a new corporation is being established in New York City to provide long-term financing to build or rehabilitate thousands of apartments in low-income neighborhoods that would be priced for the moderate-income market.

title: WHEELCHAIR GAMES IN 11TH ANNUAL MEET
description: ''WHEELCHAIR athletes can do virtually everything but jump. And we're working on that,'' said Tyler Kaus of Irvington, a wheelchair athlete who is a national champion in table tennis.

title: THE 'BULGARIAN CONNECTION' IS STILL ON TRIAL
description: WHEN the Papal shooting trial resumes in Rome this week after a summer recess, the court will start at last to hear independent testimony on the ''Bulgarian connection.'' So far, it has heard mostly from the gunman, Mehmet Ali Agca, who has done his bewildering best to becloud the proceeding, in which four fellow Turks and three Bulgarians are charged with conspiracy to assassinate Pope John Paul II. Now 120 witnesses for the state and scores more for the defense will help determine the veracity of Mr. Agca's pre-trial confession, the basis of the charges.

title: PRETORIA ASSAILS PARLEY IN ZAMBIA
description: South African Government leaders and some nonwhite political groups issued sharp criticism today of a group of the country's white businessmen who met in Zambia on Friday with leaders of the outlawed African National Congress.

title: Jennings Switches And Strikes Memory
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
ART;

THE COLOR RED IS DOMINANT AT WESLEYAN SHOW
description: THE usually demure Davison Art Center at Wesleyan University in Middletown is currently a ''visual jostling,'' and the color red prevails. The exhibition is ''art for the masses,'' Russian Revolutionary art from the Merrill C. Berman collection. In the catalogue we are informed that in Russian the word ''red'' is very much like the word ''beauty.''

title: LAURA ANNE FUHRMAN WED
description: The marriage of Laura Anne Fuhrman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Leon Fuhrman of Rockville Centre, L.I., to Howard Benjamin Twersky, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Joshua Twersky of Easton, Conn., took place last evening at the Middle Bay Country Club in Oceanside, L.I. Rabbi Paul Joseph performed the ceremony. The bride graduated from Northwestern University. Mr. Twersky is a graduate of Williams College and a third-year student at the Tufts University School of Dental Medicine.

title: DIVESTMENT EFFORT GROWS
description: Since 1977, 54 American colleges and universities have divested a total of $251 million in holdings of South African-related assets, according to the American Committee on Africa. Of that total $10.8 million was divested between April and June of this year.

title: Defend the Right To Abortions
description: It is my understanding that women who have abortions do not take the matter lightly [''Long Island a Stage for Abortion Fight,'' Sept. 1] . It is an issue tht women give considerable thought and soul searching before undertaking such an action.

title: Renwed Appreciation Of Sacred Heart Cathedral
description: The Aug. 25 Opinion Page article ''The Jewel in Newark's Crown'' is the most thoroughly researched and well-written article I've ever read about the Cathedral of the Sacred Heart.

title: U.S. MILITARY SERVICES REPORT METTING RECRUITMENT GOALS
description: The Defense Department says it has met all its recruitment goals for the first nine months of this fiscal year, although the percentage of those entering the services with high school diplomas has dropped slightly.

title: ON LOVING THEM OLD FERRYBOATS IN DECEMBER AS IN MAY
description: To the Editor:

title: Waterfront Issues: Another View
description: This is in reference to a letter [''Waterfront Zoning: 2 Cases to Compare,'' Aug.4] by George Raymond.

title: '2000' REPORT OFFERS 29 PROPOSALS
description: FOLLOWING are summaries of the 29 recommendations made by Westchester 2000, which recently completed a two-year-long study of the county's future and will present its findings at 9 A.M. on Saturday at the County Center in White Plains. The session is free and open to the public.

title: GIANT JIGSAW IN KEENE
description: Puzzle fanatics, take note. Students at Keene State College, in southwest New Hampshire, will be going for the Guinness Book of World Records next weekend by assembling what they say will be the world's largest jigsaw puzzle.

title: INTIMACY MEN CAN NEVER KNOW
description: JUST FRIENDS The Role of Friendship in Our Lives. By Lillian B. Rubin. 235 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $15.95.

title: Testing ASAT And Moscow
description: An Air Force missile destroyed a defunct six-year-old military satellite 290 miles above the Pacific Ocean last week in the first United States test of an anti-satellite weapon or ASAT. Whether the ''absolutely flawless'' experiment, as the Air Force called it, compromised the possibility of an arms limitation agreement with the Soviet Union remained to be seen.

title: PREAMATURE BABIES ARE STUDIED AT YALE
description: FROM birth, premature babies, who can arrive up to three months early, are different. They are smaller and scrawnier, and their skin tends to be yellowish from jaundice.

title: IRAQ SAYS IRAN AIR RAIDS
description: Iraq accused Iran tonight of renewing air attacks on civilian areas and said 20 civilians were wounded today in the northern city of Sulaimaniya.

title:
THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER;

NUMBER CRUNCHING ON THE MACINTOSH
description: SOFTWARE is what sells hardware, except perhaps to the most dedicated of techies. The classic success story of the little software engine that could concerns Visicalc, the first computerized spreadsheet, or electronic worksheet, for number crunchers. Back in the early days of personal computing, Visicalc saved Apple from the fate of being just another pretty computer in the burgeoning hobby marketplace, and turned it into a machine that business executives across the country began scooping up.

title: HIGH TECH BLOSSOMS ALONG THE POTOMAC
description: IT was called a High Tech Career Faire, the Old English spelling lending a touch of Dixie whimsy. The place was the conference hall of the Westpark-Best Western Motel at Tyson's Corner, Va., about 10 miles from downtown Washington.

title: G. S. MILNOR WEDS MARCELA PENARANDA
description: The marriage of Marcela Penaranda, a daughter of Josefina Lleras of New York and Dr. Alfonso Penaranda of Bogota, Colombia, to G. Scott Milnor took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Kirkbride Milnor Jr., parents of the bridegroom, in East Chop, Mass. The Rev. David A. Garcia, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. PLANS TALKS ON ATOM ARMS IN PACIFIC AREA
description: The United States and New Zealand have agreed to hold high-level talks next week to deermine if the yearlong rupture in the Pacific alliance over nuclear policy can be repaired, Administration officials said today.

title: MEXICAN-AMERICANS IN TEXAS MOVE INTO POLITICAL MAINSTREAM
description: The harvest of 1967 was a bitter one for farm workers in the lower Rio Grande Valley of Texas. Gov. John Connally had dispatched the Texas Rangers to break a strike. Their efficiency left a bitter taste among Mexican-Americans, a reminder of their political impotence at the hands of the Anglo majority.

title: GREAT SQUARES
description: Around the world, public squares serve special functions in big cities, opening up large spaces where city dwellers can escape from cramped living quarters and breathe, physically and spiritually, more freely. In celebration of some of the most beautiful and exciting of these open spaces, the Municpal Art Society on Wednesday will open a photo exhibit entitled ''Great Squares of the World.''

title: ALFONSIN GROWS EVERMORE POPULAR
description: President Raul Alfonsin's anti-inflation plan, 11 weeks old last week, appears to have done more for his popularity than for price stability. The inflation rate has indeed dropped, to 3.1 percent in August from the monthly average of 25 percent before the wage-and-price freeze was instituted. But even more spectacular than the slowing of inflation, according to the latest polls, has been the rise in Mr. Alfonsin's standing with the public, which is at its highest point since he came to office 21 months ago.

title: ANNUAL STAMP FESTIVAL WILL OPEN THIS WEEK
description: The 1985-86 stamp collecting season will get off to a lively start with the annual Stamp Festival scheduled for Friday through next Sunday at Madison Square Garden in New York City. Show hours are Friday 11 A.M. to 7 P.M., Saturday 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. and Sunday 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is $3 each day. The show, which is sponsored by the American Stamp Dealers' Association, will feature over 60 dealers, selected postal agencies, exhibits, door prizes, an auction, lectures and an attractive souvenir card. The souvenir card will be distributed free of charge to each paying adult. In keeping with the show's railroad theme, the card features a full color reproduction of the 1901 2 cent Pan-American block that depicts the Empire State Express.

title: Bright Skies for Springs
description: Things seem to be looking up for Ron Springs. A week ago the 28-year-old running back lost his job with the Dallas Cowboys and faced charges that could have led to a long jail term.

title: ELIKA L. SOSNICK PLANNING TO WED M. F. ROSENBAUM
description: Prof. and Mrs. Stephen H. Sosnick of Davis, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elika Lisa Sosnick to Michael Francis Rosenbaum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis F. Rosenbaum Jr. of New York and Wilton, Conn.

title: WYOMING GOVERNOR SEEKS BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
description: Gov. Ed Herschler, a popular Democrat who is serving his third term, has filed for bankruptcy here, listing liabilities that exceed his assets by nearly $2 million.

title: SOUPS OFFER A GOOD WAY TO MAKE USE OF FALL'S BOUNTY
description: THE late summer harvest is superb for soup-making.

title: MARY GUARRACINI, PHYSICIAN, WEDS RONALD DIPRINZIO
description: At St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan yesterday Dr. Mary Elizabeth Guarracini, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Guarracini of Lawrenceville, N.J., was married to Ronald John DiPrinzio, the son of Yolanda DiPrinzio of New York and the late Enzo DiPrinzio. Msgr. Robert J. Kane performed the ceremony.

title: INDUSTRIAL POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: UPRISING IN EAST GERMANY. And Other Stories. By Jochen Ziem. Translated by Jorn K. Bramann and Jeanette Axelrod. (Adler Publishing Company, P.O. Box 9342, Rochester, N.Y. 14604, Paper, $8.95.)

title: A BISHIP'S MISSION
description: 'We are no longer a middle-class white church. We are a church that is multicultural, and the leadership of the church is beginning to make that clear.' rrBishop Edmond L. Browning rrwho was elected last week as the Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church.

title: REWARDING CONTEST WITH FEW PRIZES
description: EVEN as angling tournaments in which the prizes amount to tens of thousands of dollars continue to proliferate, a professor of Renaissance literature who caught his first fish in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, is completing the arangements for a fishing contest in which there are no financial rewards whatsovever.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

ARE ROLLS OF COINS MAKING A COMEBACK?
description: A stigma has been attached to the word ''rolls'' in the coin collecting hobby.

title: BELLE FRANCE
description: To the Editor: If there is, as I suspect, a lingering cliche view of French hauteur or brusqueness vis-a-vis the American traveler, my journey throughthree provimnces in the country this summer compel me to help put it to rest.

title: H. R.PENA IS MARRIED TO M. CHRISTINA CARTER
description: At Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington yesterday M. Christina Carter, director of development for the Institute for Research on the Economics of Taxation in Washington, was married to Humberto Ruben Pena, legislative counsel for the Bristol-Myers Company in Washington. The Rev. James L. Connor performed the ceremony.

title: WHAT TO DO WITH (GASP!) FREE TIME
description: AS sure as the leaves will soon fall from the trees, the ''leaf''-lets will come. Westchester's affluent children are to be inundated with a myriad of after-school, weekend self-improvement choices. Localities will sponsor teams and clinics in every possible sport, there will be school clubs in chess, cooking and karate, Boy/Girl Scouts will reassemble and the newspapers will be replete with announcements of ''The Lessons'' (ballet, music, art, gymnastics, theater, computer).

title: NICARAGUA TAKES J.S. TO COURT
description: Nicaragua resumed last week its international legal offensive against the United States for backing anti-Sandinista rebels, but Washington chose to respond only indirectly.

title: SECURITIES
description: To the Editor:

title: THE SOUTH IS WORRIED TOO
description: THE theme of the conference was the growing internationalization of the South's economy. But when the governors of 13 Southern states gathered at their annual meeting here last week, the subject that seemed most on their minds was what they could do to check the continuing loss of jobs in the region as a result of competition from foreign imports. ''We have got to do something to reverse the tremendous hemorrhage in our trade policy,'' said Gov. Bob Graham of Florida, a Democrat and the host of the two-day conference. ''What you are seeing here is a reflection of the tremendous frustration that governors feel over a situation they see as being out of control.''

title: STEPHEN TIMOTHY ROLL MARRIES JOAN MARIE LOURD
description: Joan Marie Lourd, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Lourd of New York and Sherman, Conn., was married yesterday to Stephen Timothy Roll, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Roll of Arlington, Va. The Rev. Dayton Dewey, the Episcopal chaplain at Roosevelt Hospital in New York, performed the ceremony at the College of Physicians, a medical library in Philadelphia.

title: APPEALS COURT TO HEAR FREEDOM PLEA BY BONANNO
description: An appeals court has been asked to free Joseph Bonanno, who went to jail for refusing to testify about a ''commmission'' of top Mafia leaders.

title: MARY QUANTZ MARRIES JEFFREY DAVIES FURBER
description: Mary Cameron Quantz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Theodore Quantz Jr. of Summit, N.J., was married there yesterday to Jeffrey Davies Furber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Edward Furber of Sherborn, Mass.
