The Rev. Dr. William R. Phillippe performed the ceremony at the Central Presbyterian Church.

title: ROBIN RYDER IS BRIDE OF KENNETH J. KENCEL
description: Robin Anne Ryder, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold J. Ryder of Hamden, Conn., was married there yesterday to Kenneth John Kencel, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Kencel of Orchard Park, N.Y. The Rev. Walter J. Burghardt and the Rev. Robert Brooks Lawton performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Charles McDonald assisted.

title: GENERAL FOODS WAITS FOR THE PAYOFF
description: JELL-O. Maxwell House coffee. Post Grape-Nuts.

title: 'MISHIMA': FILM EXAMINES AN AFFAIR WITH DEATH
description: When he died at the age of 45 in 1970, Yukio Mishima was recognized at home - and abroad - as the pre-eminent writer of his generation to emerge from postwar Japan. He had chronicled, with protean skill and Nabokovian complexity, the social and moral dilemmas of his nation as it was thrust, headlong, into the confusions of the 20th century. And he had succeeded, unlike any other writer before him, in creating a glittering alloy of Eastern and Western traditions, classical and contemporary forms.

title: SOLIDARITY SUPPORTERS ASK POLISH ELECTION BOYCOTT
description: In a letter being circulated clandestinely, 100 Solidarity supporters have called for a boycott of parliamentary elections next month.

title: YANKS SLIP AGAIN FOUR ERRORS IN 5-1 LOSS
description: The Mets took another tumble in the homestretch today when they made four errors, lost to the Montreal Expos again and fell into second place in the National League East.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: HARDBALL BY DEFENSE LAWYER
description: On most days, in most settings, they reign supreme, these big, strong men who make a very good living performing in front of screeching, adoring multitudes. But the baseball players who have been summoned to testify at a cocaine-trafficking trial in Pittsburgh are facing an unusual adversary in Adam Renfroe Jr., who has proven himself as wily and tenacious a foe as any found on the playing field.

title: 136th Victim in Dallas Crash
description: The crash of a Delta Air Lines jumbo jet last month has claimed its 136th victim, a 23-year-old Miami man who was burned over 80 percent of his body. The victim, Gregg LaPedus, died Friday after contracting pneumonia, according to a spokesman at Parkland Memorial Hospital. He had been in the intensive care burn unit at the hospital since the crash of Delta Flight 191, which went down at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport in a thunderstorm on Aug. 2.

title: A WALK THROUGH THE SMALL WORLD OF BONSAI
description: IF you have ever wondered how the Japanese do bonsai, the art of creating extraordinary little trees, you have an opportunity this week in Stamford. An exhibit opens Tuesday and will continue through the end of October at the Champion International Corporation's rooftop greenhouse, located at the corner of Tresser Boulevard and Atlantic Street. It will be open to the public from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. except Sunday and Monday.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A. G. SPALDING AND THE RISE OF BASEBALL: The Promise of American Sport. By Peter Levine. (Oxford University, $16.95.) Some famous people avoid exposure to biographers.

title: IN PURSUIT, ROSE DANCED TO HAPPY TUNE
description: ISADORA DUNCAN once said that her dream was to teach the world to dance. Miss Duncan, it seems, would have approved of Pete Rose who, without setting out to do so, stirred many to kick their heels, in one fashion or another.

title: CAUTHEN WINS ST. LEGER
description: Steve Cauthen, capturing his fourth major race of the year, guided Oh So Sharp to victory today in the $135,590 St. Leger.

title: ANTIQUE HUNTING IN BUCKS COUNTY
description: Bucks County, Pa., is one of the few places left to antique the old-fashioned way - by driving up and down country roads in search of a dealer or a restorer who lives on a hidden lane or where you can find a good strip of shops on the highway.

title: VEXATION OF TONGUES
description: PROPHETS OF EXTREMITY Nietzsche, Heidegger, Foucault, Derrida. By Allan Megill. 399 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $24.95.

title: CAPITALISM BY EXAMPLE
description: SHOOTING OURSELVES IN THE FOOT By Bernard J. O'Keefe. 294 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $15.95.

title: CITY OPERA: A CORSARO-SENDAK 'THREE ORANGES'
description: THE New York City Opera has a new star: a lady of formidable stature and irresistible charm who stole the show last night at the opening of Prokofiev's ''Love for Three Oranges.'' A 30-foot-high prima donna created by Maurice Sendak, the production's designer, this hugely appealing creature played the fat role of the Cook with relish, scoring one of the season's truly gargantuan hits.

title: CONGRESS PONDERING KEY ISSUES
description: IN the next few weeks Congress is expected to consider a number of issues vital to Long Island, including tax reform, hazardous-waste cleanup, and protection for aquifers. If Congress fails to take action on these matters before the scheduled adjournment in early November there could be major consequences for the programs on Long Island, Congressmen said.

title: ARCANE BROWN BAG
description: PEOPLE WHO CARRY bottles of wine into restaurants that do not have liquor licenses are known as brown-baggers. When the New York State Liquor Authority decided to crack down on this widespread and not-all-that-nefarious practice, the teetotaling legislation introduced in the State Legislature was promptly dubbed ''the anti-brown-bag law.''

title: BENNETT WARNS STATES ON CHURCH SCHOOL AID
description: Secretary of Education William J. Bennett has cautioned state school superintendents against scaling back all forms of aid to parochial schools because of the recent Supreme Court decision banning remedial classes in parochial schools that are taught by public school teachers.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE IMMIGRANT'S DAUGHTER. By Howard Fast. (Houghton Mifflin, $17.95.) When a novel opens with the widowed heroine's 60th birthday party one might expect the ensuing story to be a leisurely, meditative retrospective of loves won and lost, children borne and raised.

title: GIVING NEW LIFE TO OLD GARDEN TOOLS
description: SHOVELS, rakes, hoes and other outdoor yard and garden tools will normally last for years without any maintenance or repairs. But efficiency is greatly reduced when metal parts are allowed to become rusty and dirty, when blades get nicked, bent or dulled and when handles crack or work loose.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: SENATE

title: FOR NEW HOTELS, ROADBLOCKS ALONG ROUTE 110
description: ONE year ago, business people in the Melville area were elated by the announcement that four major new hotels were to be constructed.

title: RENEWED APPRECIATION OF SACRED HEART CATHEDRAL
description: To comment on Mr. Quirk's question about why St. Catherine of Siena and St. Francis of Assisi are missing in the Italian Chapel of the Cathedral of the Sacred Heart and why St. Lucy Filippini is central.

title: PATRICIA M. FREDERICK WEDS
description: The marriage of Patricia M. Frederick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie S. Frederick of Bohemia, L.I., to Dr. Girard E. Robinson, a fellow in child psychiatry at the Payne Whitney Clinic of the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, took place yesterday at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Dr. and Mrs. John Robinson of Buffalo.

title: Philadelphia Aims at Illiteracy
description: FOR many years, Philadelphia has liked to think of itself as the country's historical nexus, an international cutural center and the home of many institutions of higher education.

title:
ANTIQUE;

COURSES, LECTURES AND EXCURSIONS
description: FRIED Brie prepared in an iron spider on an 18th-century hearth, Sunday hikes to historic sites in the Ramapos and surveys and studies of furniture, clocks, jewelry and porcelain are among the course offerings, lectures, how-to's and excursions scheduled across the state this fall with a focus on antiques and places of historic interest.

title: NEW YORK'S FOREIGN-LANGUAGE PRESSMAY LACK A GIANT BUT NOT DIVERSITY
description: Once a major metropolitan newspaper with a circulation of nearly a quarter of a million, The Jewish Daily Forward is now more a weekly magazine than a newspaper, publishing 25,000 copies.

title: RICH TEXANS RUB ELBOWS WITH REBELS
description: The 30-year-old scion of a Mississippi family with some money to spare came to Dallas with his Puerto Rican-born wife for a $500-a-plate dinner and the chance to rub shoulders with anti-Communist rebels from around the world.

title: A $10 MILLION GIANT IN AN INFANT INDUSTRY
description: ON Aug. 17, 1978, Maxie Anderson, Ben Abruzzo and Larry Newman became the first people to cross the Atlantic Ocean by balloon. They got the glory -but in many ways, the Weather Services Corporation of Bedford, Mass., did much of the work.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Sept. 15, 1985 Fiction

title: A LETTER FROM FERRARO
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro has told potential supporters that she will decide before the end of the year whether to challenge Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican, for his seat in 1986 or to ''speak out independently as a private citizen'' instead.

title: THIRD WORLD SEEKS ITS PLACE IN SPACE
description: In the 22 years since the United States launched the first communications satellite, the so-called geostationary orbit 22,300 miles above the Equator has become the hottest property in space. There are an estimated 138 satellites in the orbit now, relaying telephone calls, television pictures and weather reports, and about 160 more are in various stages of planning.

title: GOOD DESIGN IS SOUGHT FOR NEW CONDOS
description: THERE was a time when location and price per square foot were the primary factors in buying a co-op or a condominium. But to an ever greater degree, a third factor - good design - is joining the others, even if it pushes up the price.

title: URBAN LEAGUE IS REBOUNDING AFTER CUTS IN GOVERNMENT AID
description: After Harriet R. Michel delivered a rousing speech recently to a crowd protesting South Africa's racial policies, a labor leader who apparently mistook her for a political candidate asked, ''What are you running for?''

title: THE ABORTION CONFLICT
description: I am against abortion, but this does not mean that I support those so-called Christians who find it necessary to firebomb abortion clinics.

title: BOARD REJECTS TEXTS THAT 'WATER DOWN' EVOLUTION
description: Five publishers have been given until Oct. 15 to tell the California Board of Education whether they will heed its request to revise science textbooks to include more information on evolution.

title: EXCERCISE MAKES 'WIMP' A WINNER
description: SIX years of correcting papers in front of the televison set, on my oversoft club chair, had turned my spinal column into a pretzel.

title: A CAREER BLOOMS IN CAMP COMEDY
description: AT the age of 12, Meghan Robinson played Colonel Pickering in a summer-camp production of ''My Fair Lady.'' She was living in Wilton, attending private schools in Darien and in Danbury where her father, Victor Robinson, a sculptor in Wilton, was then in charge of the school's art departments. She describes herself as a ''faculty brat.''

title: U.S. TO CONDUCT NATIONAL SURVEY TO DETERMINE RADON GAS HAZARD
description: An official of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency said yesterday that the agency would conduct a national survey to locate naturally occurring radon and to determine the potential hazard of the radioactive gas.

title: COMPUTERS THAT PLUG INTO THE WEATHER
description: FOR years, anyone could, for a fee, get a black-and-white readout of a radar scan that was taken at any one of the National Weather Service's 77 radar sites. The readout would indicate oncoming rain.

title: FINDING YOUR WAY IN FEZ
description: Few places are as well-suited for a walking tour as the Medina, the old quarter of Fez. In fact, there is really no other way to visit the old city, since most of the streets are too steep or narrow to permit even a scooter to maneuver in comfort. Houses seem to have sprung up wherever there was space, leaving only small gaps between the buildings for traffic to slip through. Often the upper stories have been cantilevered out over the street, turning the passage into a tunnel. It is said that in some neighborhoods the maze of alleyways was deliberately designed to confound an invading enemy; whatever the case, the result has been an urban landscape of unparalleled beauty and complexity.

title: MANAGING PENNANT RACE PRESSURES
description: BILLY MARTIN was not so tense, not so preoccupied with the pennant race that he had no time for Marie Selig. In fact, it was she who didn't wait for him, and that's why he wound up sending her a dozen roses.

title: FINDING STRENGTH IN A GENTLER TIME
description: THE room inside reflected a glimpse of the sunlight. It was morning, and she sat on a well-worn couch in front of a bay window. Her heart was pounding; her hands trembled with old age and insecurity. The face was bony-thin and fragile and looked as if a good hot meal might help.

title: HELENE SHAMASH IS MARRIED ON L.I.
description: Helene Beba Shamash, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack E. Shamash of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Tom Flood Schwinn, the son of Mrs. John Stallman of McQueeney, Tex., and Tom L. Schwinn of Wellington, Kan. The Rev. Francis B. Creamer Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton.

title: IN PRAISE OF THE SHOWY ORIENTAL POPPIES
description: I find it impossible to overlook oriental poppies. Even though their bloom period is brief, from the end of May into June and the plants ripen and dry before being cut back and disappearing. Some gardeners call them overrated. Others overplant the dead foliage with asters or annuals or anything for the sake of explosively vivid blooms.

title: SEASON OPENERS
description: Sports at Avery Fisher Sept. 18 - The 1984 Los Angeles Olympic Games may be sports history, but in the hands of a maker of sports documentaries, they will be relived at a triple benefit at Avery Fisher Hall in Lincoln Center. With 18 camera crews, a three-time Emmy Award winner, Bud Greenspan, has produced ''16 Days of Glory,'' which will be shown for five hours on television next year. A two-and-a-half-hour preview will be shown for the benefit of the New York Road Runners Club, the Central Park Conservancy and the Cappy Petrash Greenspan Foundation, which provides grants for sports-related endeavors. A 6 P.M. cocktail party and buffet attended by many athletes will precede the 7:30 P.M. screening. Tickets, $200, from 212-808-8100 or at the door. Help for City Opera Sept. 18 - A cocktail benefit for the New York City Opera, which lost about 9,000 costumes used in 74 productions in the Passaic, N.J., fire Sept. 3, will be held at the Alex Rosenberg Gallery at 20 West 57th Street. The 6 to 8 P.M. benefit will show recent works by Gerson Leiber. Tickets, $50, from 212-757-2700. Shakespeare's Back Sept. 18 - Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival is heading into its 31st season with a benefit for one of the Public Theater's newest projects. It is the two-year-old British-American Cultural Exchange, which provides for the exchange of productions with the Court Theater in London. The evening starts at 6 P.M. with cocktails and dinner at the Safari Grill, Third Avenue at 65th Street, followed by a preview of the movie ''Plenty,'' an adaptation of the Public's stage production, starring Meryl Streep and John Gielgud.

title: A RARE PITCH TO WOMEN FROM TWO EUROPEAN BANKS
description: MARIE Antoinette Huegenin, manager of Europe's newest women's bank, works out of a rather austere office: No carpet, no pictures on the blue and gray walls, and only a telephone on her spartan desk.

title: FACT AND FICTION IN WRITING
description: NORMAN MAILER and William Styron are among the writers who will bring their widely differing views to a conference titled, ''Fiction/Nonfiction: A Troubled Relationship,'' Thursday through Saturday at Connecticut College in New London.

title: SEARCHING FOR A METEROROLOGICAL NICHE
description: WEATHER companies do a lot more than prevent rained-out picnics. They get involved in plant-site studies. They help investors decide whether to go for grain futures. They enable utilities to plan for peak load times, create environmental impact statements, even help movie companies schedule outdoor shoots.

title: DESERT ENCROACHMENT IS PREDICTED IN CHINA
description: The English-language China Daily said today that misuse of land threatens to turn an area the size of South Carolina into desert in the next 15 years unless preventive steps are taken.

title: CHANGE PARTNERS AND DANCE
description: CARACOLE By Edmund White. 342 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $17.95.

title: HARD TIMES FOR POETS
description: To the Editor:

title: CRIME
description: Not many women write tough-guy private-eye mysteries. Sara Paretsky is one who does. She appeared on the scene three years ago with ''Indemnity Only'' and followed it up two years later with ''Deadlock.'' Now comes the third in the series, KILLING ORDERS (Morrow, $15.95).

title: Banning Smoking In Restaurants
description: Legislating for the health of the public is the mark of a progressive society. But according to the logic of Fred Sampson, president of the New York State Restaurant Association [Opinion Page, Aug. 18] , the demands of the marketplace should determine whether there is a smoking ban in restaurants.

title: DANCE
description: ''What did you do last summer?'' Several choreographers can reply, ''We made dances.'' Thus H. T. Chen, David Dorfman, Holly Fairbank and Linda Tarnay spent the summer at the Yard, an art center on Martha's Vineyard that annually plays host to choreographers.

title: Toll-Plaza Crash Kills Man
description: A 26-year-old man was killed today when his car was hit in the rear and burst into flames at the Stratford toll plaza on the Connecticut Turnpike.

title: REAGAN AND HEAT
description: The wave of severe heat and humidity that sapped Washingtonians for two weeks has passed, and people are getting back to normal autumn activities. But the heat was felt even in the White House, prompting this recollection by President Reagan: ''I remember as a boy a preacher in our church one Sunday, in the dog days of summer, told us that because of the heat he was going to preach the shortest sermon that we had ever heard. And he said just seven words, 'If you think it's hot now, wait.' ''

title: FARRELL THREATENS ST. JOHN'S TRADITION
description: Despite relinquishing the coveted city high school Division A crown in the Metro Bowl to John F. Kennedy last year, the Catholic High School Football League is approaching this season with some promising talent. St. John the Baptist, last year's Division AAA champion and eventual 30-26 loser to Kennedy, faces stiff competition from Monsignor Farrell and St. Anthony when play begins this week.

title:
GARDENING;

TIPS ON GETTING THE TASTIEST OF APPLES
description: THERE is nothing better than biting into a crisp, juicy apple in the fall. Depending upon the cultivar, it may be sweet, tart or even spicy. Trouble is, many of the apples at supermarkets and produce stores are just like the average store-purchased tomato -they are tasteless.

title: Article 004096 -- No Title
description: Convinced that frail and elderly Americans are often better off living at home, seven charitable foundations have agreed to work together to develop new alternatives to institutionalized care.

title: CHECKERED CAREER OF THE TITANIC'SSIBLINGS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ABORTION CONFLICT
description: To see the daily human pain suffered by those who bear the burden of being born unwanted and unloved and to see them live with the often concurrent problems of emotional or physical abuse, poverty, violence and never getting a break in life convinces me that Dr. Bours has a greater vision than the nameless cowards who firebomb his clinic. To think how many children are born into this life resented rather than revered. Abortion serves a moral need not only for the man and woman confronted by unwanted pregnancy but for society as well. JESSICA DEE ROHM New York City

title: WOMEN IN LOVE AND PRINT
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest: THE VISITORS WHO CAME TO STAY. By Annalena McAfee. Illustrated by Anthony Browne. Viking Kestrel. $11.95. (Ages 5 to 10) Katy lives with her father near the seashore, where they have shared a quiet, routine life since her parents' divorce.

title: THE KOCH LANDSLIDE WITH WORDS AND MUSIC BY THE MAYOR
description: IN ''Mayor,'' the musical based loosely on the book by the same name, former Mayors John V. Lindsay and Abraham D. Beame sing a lament. They turn to Mayor Koch and ask, ''How do you do what you do? How do you get away with it?''

title: COUTURE MAKES A COMEBACK
description: THE FASHION BUSINESS IS FULL OF CONTRADICTIONS. No angle of it ever seems to follow a predictable course. The case of the couture is certainly an example.

title: A DURTE IS KIDNAPPED
description: For President Jose Napoleon Duarte, the latest example of Salvadoran terrorism was an affair of both state and the heart. The target was his 35-year-old daughter, Ines Guadalupe Duarte Duran, who was pulled from her car by armed kidnappers as she left a university in San Salvador last week.

title: SELLING A SALE TO CONGRESS
description: Neither United States officials nor anybody else has a clear idea of when, if ever, Jordan's King Hussein will sit down with the Israelis to discuss peace. But against strong Congressional opposition, the Reagan Administration seemed determined last week to keep Jordan as happy and friendly as possible by selling it F-20 fighter planes, antiaircraft missiles and other advanced weapons.

title: 81% FOUND OPTIMISTIC ON ECONOMIC RECOVERY
description: Eighty-one percent of the public expects the economic recovery to continue at least until the end of this year, according to the latest Gallup Poll. Fifty-four percent expect the strong economy to extend into 1987 or beyond.

title: MOSCOW TO EXPEL 25 BRITONS IN ACT OF SWIFT REPRISAL
description: In a swift and stern retaliation for the expulsion order given to 25 Soviet officials and others by Britain, the Soviet Union today told 25 British diplomats, embassy staff, correspondents and businessmen to leave the country.

title: STATES TO POLICE FIELD SANITATION
description: In the first major regulatory action since he became Secretary of Labor five months ago, Bill Brock gave himself an 18-month extension last week on a matter hotly contested for 13 years - a Federal field sanitation standard for farm workers. But the delay advanced matters in a way that may please the migrant workers and their advocates, who have maintained that Federal regulation is a necessary protection against parasitic illnesses and side-effects from pesticides, more than the farm lobby, which has questioned the link between sanitation and disease.

title: PHOTOGRAPHS TRACE 50 YEARS OF FARMING
description: TO live off the land was the dream of Hazel and William Andrew Colson in 1921. In that year they married and bought a house and land in West Suffield, where they grew tobacco and raised dairy cows. They worked their land for nearly four decades.

title: MISS TREGURTHA BECOMES A BRIDE
description: At St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn., yesterday Dorothy Ann Tregurtha and Thomas Stothart Croskey Jr., who graduated with the class of '81 from Cornell University, were married by the Rev. Edward Howley.

title: On Keeping Scarsdale Intergenerational
description: Scarsdale Citizens for Senior Housing is grateful for the Westchester Weekly's coverage of our efforts [''New Housing for Elderly Urged,'' Sept. 1] , and for Betsy Brown's excellent reporting. We would like to clarify one point: our group was founded only last December; its accomplishments have, therefore, taken just eight months, rather than the two years mentioned in the article, to achieve.

title: A CLASSIC CHOREOGRAPHER TURNS TO 'SONG AND DANCE'
description: Peter Martins sits quietly in the orchestra of the Royale Theater, watching rehearsals of ''Song and Dance,'' the Andrew Lloyd Webber show that he is choreographing. It is not that things are going smoothly. They are not. Only half the cables for the set have been fitted, so he can choose to rehearse either with lights or with scenery, not both.

title: CHIEF'S CROWN STUNS FIELD IN MARLBORO
description: Donald MacBeth, dropped as the jockey for Chief's Crown after a narrow loss in the Preakness Stakes four months ago and rehired only because the two jockeys who had ridden him since then were on other mounts, made the reunion into the most dramatic upset of the year by steering the 3-year-old to narrow victory over Gate Dancer in the $500,000 Marlboro Cup yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: RESPIGHI'S 'LA FIAMMA': Italian Opera from HungaryGeorge Jellinek, author and critic, is host of the nationally syndicated radio program ''The Vocal Scene.''
description: There was a time when complete recordings of Italian opera emanated - logically enough - from Rome and Milan. Later on, with the onset of global projects and international superstars, London emerged as a plausible point of origin. More recently, however, the focal point for such enterprises seems to have shifted to Munich and Budapest. If this sounds farfetched, please read on.

title: 5 REPORTED KILLED IN SWISS TRAIN CRASH
description: Five people were killed and about 60 were injured today when a passenger train collided head-on with a pair of locomotives, railway officials said. The two drivers and three passengers were killed, the police said. The accident occurred between Lausanne and the small town of Morges on the shores of Lake Geneva when the train collided with a locomotive pulling another engine to a depot.

title: HOME IN THE CITY, JOB IN THE SUBURBS
description: THE typical commuter pulls out of a two-car garage each morning, fights the rush-hour traffic to a job in the city and returns to the quiet suburbs at night.

title: THE POLITICS OF THE PLAIN
description: MONSIEUR JOURDAIN, the Moliere bourgeois, was so misguided as to conclude he'd been talking prose all his life, his bogus instructor having defined prose as whatever is not verse. But as nobody talks in rhyme, so nobody talks in prose. Prose came late into every written language, and very late into English. Even Chaucer had few clues to its workings. A special variety, ''plain'' prose, came especially late. Plain prose, the plain style, is the most disorienting form of discourse yet invented by man. Swift in the 18th century, George Orwell in the 20th are two of its very few masters. And both were political writers -there's a connection.

title: PLAINFIELD: 80'S SURREALISM
description: TWEED'S new art gallery at 127 Watchung Avenue is smaller than its previous storefront, but the image this Plainfield group projects has lost none of its cockiness.

title: Another Scramble In Congress Over Spending
description: Between now and Thanksgiving Day, when House and Senate leaders hope to have brought the first session of the 99th Congress to an end, no date looms larger than Oct. 1, the start of the 1986 fiscal year. That is the day by which the legislators must approve 13 regular annual appropriations bills or scramble, as they have for the last nine years, to pass a continuing resolution that will provide money for Government operations. To no one's surprise, the first full week of Congressional business after the summer recess demonstrated that a timely close to the appropriations process is hardly likely.

title: DON'T PAY ME TOO MUCH, PLEASE!
description: I AM a teacher. But with all the talk about paying teachers more, I hope they do not raise our salaries too much. If they do, I may lose my superior style of life.

title: ORDER IN GEORGETOWN
description: Last spring the quiet gentility of Georgetown was being disrupted by disorderly crowds of thousands of teen-agers and other weekend tourists teeming in the business streets of the neighborhood. So the District of Columbia police inaugurated a program to reduce the congestion: a ban on weekend parking on the main thoroughfares, M Street and Wisconsin Avenue, and further, a close scrutiny and spot inspections of cruising cars and increased issuance of jaywalking summonses.

title: CARDS WIN TO TAKE FIRST
description: Ozzie Smith's run-scoring double highlighted a two-run sixth inning today that carried the St. Louis Cardinals into first place in the National League East with a 5-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

title: BALKY COMPUTER PUTS DRIVERS ON HOLD
description: THE Kean administration is having problems again with the issuing of drivers licenses.

title: JAMES TWEEDY WEDS MISS MCGOLDRICK
description: Margaret Newbold McGoldrick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. McGoldrick of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to James Dorrance Tweedy, a son of Richard B. Tweedy of Darien and the late Louise Dorrance Tweedy. The Rev. Britton W. Woodward, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Church Island on Squam Lake, N.H.

title: No Headline
description: It was in the exquisite opera house of balustrades and chandeliers built by King Louis XV for the wedding of his son and heir that, according to historians of the great palace at Versailles, a band of monarchist soldiers unleashed the anger that led to the palace's finish as a home for kings. That was 196 years ago. The soldiers of the King of France, the representative of God on earth, were in the opera house for an evening of revelry. Singing monarchist songs, they trampled the Tricolor, which had already become the symbol of the simmering revolutionary movement. News of the soldiers' sacrilege reached Paris and, two days later, on Oct. 6, 1789, a revolutionary crowd stormed Versailles demanding that the King leave the palace and return to the city. Louis XVI and his much-disliked wife, Marie Antoinette, who appeared on a balcony of the palace to try to appease the revolutionaries' fury, had no choice. They left for Paris that night. The balance of power shifted to the revolutionaries. Three years later, Louis XVI and his Marie Antoinette died on the guillotine.

title: CONFERENCE TO EXAMINE COUNTY'S FUTURE
description: MORE than 1,500 county residents, elected officials and representatives of organizations are expected to gather at the County Center next Saturday to see the results of a two-year-long study of Westchester's future and the proposals on what is needed to insure its beauty and viability.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

SLOOPS FESTIVAL
description: FERRY Sloops is having a big season. The nonprofit organization, which describes itself as ''dedicated to the preservation of the Hudson River,'' is acting as host to a festival at the Hudson Valley Tennis Club in Hastings-on-Hudson today, and to a concert by the folk singer Tom Paxton Saturday night at the Tarrytown Music Hall.

title: PIPE-BOMB DEATH PUZZLES AUTHORITIES
description: TSCHERIM SOOBZOKOV'S home on 14th Street, in a working-class neighborhood, is empty and boarded up. Splinters of wood and bits of broken glass remain on the front porch, signs of a pipe bomb explosion last month.

title: FOR THE RECORD
description: To the Editor: I am writing concerning the following statement printed in the Travel section of the Sunday New York Times, Aug. 4, 1985, page 14, next to last paragraph:

title: POP MUSIC
description: John Wallowitch, an heir to the arch, waspish tradition of Cole Porter and Noel Coward, has returned to solo performance for the first time in two-and-a-half years at the Ballroom Theater, 253 West 28th Street. The composer-singer-pianist, whose show 'Cracked Cups'' was one of the last and most successful coffeehouse shows of the 1960's, has written hundreds of songs over the years but has only performed his own material in clubs during the last decade.

title: WILTON WELCOMES A NEW MALL
description: The Town Green, an 18,000-square-foot retail complex with an open-air pedestrian mall in the heart of Wilton Center, is to be officially unveiled this weekend, 30 years after it was first envisioned by planners.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Brandeis Chapter Offers Study Groups The Central Westchester chapter of the Brandeis University National Women's Committee sponsors a Fall Sampler Brunch 9:15 A.M. Thursday with a speaker and an explanation of planned mini-courses, workshops and trips. The study group charges are $25 or less, with all proceeds donated to the Friends of the Library at the university in Waltham, Mass.

title: ARE HIGH SCHOOLS LIKE SHOPPING MALLS?
description: Starting with ''A Nation at Risk,'' the 1983 report of the National Commission on Excellence in Education, study after study has found a lot wrong with American public high schools. Last week three Boston-area researchers weighed in with one of the gloomiest appraisals to date. In ''The Shopping Mall High School,'' the three, Arthur G. Powell, Eleanor Farrar and David K. Cohen, contend that high schools have lost faith in the value of education. They are like shopping centers, the authors argue, offering ''something for everyone'' and measuring success by volume -the number of diplomas granted. The study, based on visits to 15 public and private high schools in 1981-82, describes teachers who neither require nor expect learning and students who know that they will pass if they simply attend classes. Many teachers, the researchers wrote, ''use student passivity as an excuse to cover up their own passivity.''

title: THE SHAMEFUL SCURRY DEAL
description: ONE year in spring training, Rod Scurry disappeared from the Pittsburgh Pirates for a few days without permission and without an explanation, the same Rod Scurry who early last season would submit to drug rehabilitation. When questioned then by law-enforcement officials about his supply of cocaine, his answers would inspire the investigation that has shamed baseball at the current Pittsburgh drug trial. But upon his return to the Pirates in spring training a year ago, the left-handed pitcher confronted Charley Feeney, who covers the Pirates for The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette.

title: ANDREI GAVRILOV DISPLAYS HIS PIANO VIRTUOSO
description: Piano watchers have watched Andrei Gavrilov as best they might for a decade, ever since he won the Tchaikovsky Competition, but the Soviet cultural authorities were erratic about putting him on view in the West after his triumph. He and his wife now live in London, beneficiaries (so far) of the increased tolerance that has allowed some Russian artists to take up residence abroad without defecting.

title: PERU FINDS ITSELF ALONE IN REGIONAL UNITY BID
description: Since its founding 61 years ago, Peru's governing party has always viewed greater Latin American cooperation as a needed counterweight to the United States' huge influence over the region.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: THE REAL AMADEUS To start its 1985-86 season, the Mozart Society of Philadelphia will ''set the record straight'' by debunking the play/movie ''Amadeus.''

title: REAGAN FAVORS REPEAL OF BAN ON THIRD TERM
description: President Reagan has told a group of state legislators that he believed the Constitution should be changed to allow Presidents to serve more than two terms, the White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, said today.

title: DECLINE IN BOMBINGS FOUND
description: The number of bombings in the United States in the first six months of this year decreased by 6 percent from the same period a year ago, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today. This year's bombings have included 299 explosive and 63 incendiary incidents, according to the bureau report, which said that they had resulted in 10 deaths, 44 injuries and property damage estimated at more than $3.6 million.

title: 10 ARE HURT AS CAR JUMPS CURB
description: Ten pedestrians were injured in Brooklyn yesterday as a car careering from a collision ran onto the sidewalk. The most severely hurt was a 35-year-old Brooklyn rabbi, whose left foot was partially severed.

title: P.B.A. FIGHTING USE OF HEARSAY TO CURB ABUSE
description: An attempt by the New York City Police Department to use unsubstantiated civilian complaints of brutality or misconduct to help evaluate police officers has ignited a court fight between the city and an officers' union.

title: GETTING AT THE CAUSES OF BRITAIN'S LATEST BALCK EYE
description: The photograph that shocked Britain most last week showed a young black man striding along a street in Handsworth, a blazing Molotov cocktail in his hand. It appeared under headlines that said ''Bloodlust,'' ''War In the Streets'' or ''England, 1985.''

title: A SAMURAI'S REMARKABLE WIFE
description: WOMAN IN THE CRESTED KIMONO The Life of Shibue Io and Her Family Drawn From Mori Ogai's ''Shibue Chusai.'' By Edwin McClellan. 192 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $15.95.

title: THE POLITICS OF RACE
description: WHAT New York's black and Hispanic politicians appeared to have harvested most often in the Democratic primary were unredeemed promises. Mr. Farrell, the black mayoral candidate, ran third, carrying only three Assembly Districts. The three Hispanic candidates for City Council president polled a total of just over 20 percent.

title: EROTIC, EXOTIC AND CRAZED
description: A TRANSPARENT TREE By Robert Kelly. 200 pp. New Paltz, N.Y.: McPherson & Company. Cloth, $20. Paper, $10.

title: A TALE OF TWO VIEWS ON EROTICA
description: Across the Potomac in two of the capital's bedroom communities, the vivid pictures and words, films and videotapes are one man's pornography and another man's erotica.

title: THE EXTRA COST OF GOING IT ALONE
description: Little evokes more consternation among solo travelers than the emotional and financial problems they often face because they are alone. Some of them feel conspicuously awkward in hotels or restaurants or on cruises or tours, when everyone else seems to be with someone. Also, many resent the stiff surcharges that are often imposed upon them for being alone.

title: FIRST-RATE ITALIAN IN BRANFORD
description: FIRST impressions can be wrong. They certainly were for us at Serino's at Short Beach in Branford.

title: LISTENING FOR LIFE AMONG THE STARS
description: THE SEARCH FOR EXTRA-terrestrial intelligence is a minuscule part of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's budget, but it is a project dear to the heart of James M. Beggs, the agency's administrator. Mr. Beggs, a man burdened by difficult questions of national space policy, smiles broadly when he talks about it. ''I believe there must be intelligence out there somewhere,'' he says, ''and we ought to be listening for it.''

title: MANAGING THE MONEY SUPPLY STILL COUNTS
description: OVER THE past 20 years, the United States has experienced three major episodes of accelerating inflation - 1966 to 1969, 1973 to 1974 and 1977 to 1979. Each episode began with the avoidable mistake of rising money growth and ended in recession. In each case, many argued that tight money would choke off economic expansion, that the monetary statistics were no longer trustworthy and that money creation would not cause inflation this time. Today, we hear the same arguments.

title: Compacted
description: Over at the State Department, experienced justifiers have worked up a new shorthand phrase to explain, more briefly and painlessly than the truth, why a policy that originally seemed right just did not work out. ''That policy was OBE'd,'' they say. The initials stand for ''overtaken by events.''

title: 2 Former Amin Officers Join Uganda Council
description: Two army officers who served under President Idi Amin in the 1970's were among four guerrilla leaders named to Uganda's ruling Military Council after agreeing to cooperate with the new Government, Radio Uganda announced.

title: DIVERSE CROWD HEARS FARRAKHAN IN LOS ANGELES
description: The cars parked at the Forum sports arena, Chevrolets and Toyotas, Mercedes-Benzes and BMW's, family sedans and clunkers, represented the whole spectrum of southern California incomes and lifestyles. They were driven by people who turned out Saturday night to hear a speech by Louis Farrakhan, the leader of a Black Muslim sect.

title: Ray Knight Hears It
description: HIS wife says, ''Don't let them affect you,'' but Ray Knight can't help feeling it when the Shea Stadium crowd begins to howl.

title: Waiting for Dignity in the Fields
description: For 13 years, American farm workers have been asking the Federal Government to insure them drinking water in their workplace, which is to say the fields, along with toilets and places to wash up.

title: WEIGHT IS PROBLEM FOR SPINKS
description: MICHAEL SPINKS stretched his long frame the length of the king-size bed in the darkened hotel room and gave his impressions of light-heavyweight champions moving up to fight heavyweight champions.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. The Mets, just back from Montreal, open a seven-day home stand against the Phillies, Cubs and Pirates.

title: Teacher Strikes Continue in 5 States
description: Court-ordered negotiations were conducted yesterday in Pawtucket, R.I., in an effort to end a strike by teachers that began Sept. 4.

title: KREIG AND WARNER SPARK SEAHAWKS
description: Dave Krieg fired five touchdown passes, four of them to the wide receiver Daryl Turner, and Curt Warner rushed for 169 yards and a pair of scores as Seattle rolled to a wild 49-35 victory today over San Diego.

title: TOWN TELLS SUMMER PEOPLE TO LEAVE FOR WINTER
description: Marion Craft, tending her African violets, and her husband, William, tinkering with his patio barbecue, seem happy in their retirement.

title: Ghana Bus Kills 26 in Crowd
description: A bus raced into a crowd celebrating a minor chief's assumption of office in central Ghana, killing 26 people, the Ghana news agency reported today. The accident occurred Saturday in Ekumfi-Ekotsi, 73 miles north of here.

title: Advertising;   Commerce Department Is Moving to SSC&B
description: SSC&B, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is going to be working for the New York State Commerce Department in its noble attempts at bringing new businesses into our fair state.

title: Shell Refinery Sale
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group has set a Friday deadline for signing an agreement to sell its 320,000-barrels-a-day oil refinery on Curacao to the Netherlands Antilles Government, a company statement said. Shell said earlier that it would close the plant by Sept. 30 but the latest statement said work on dismantling the installations would begin next Friday unless an agreement was signed by then.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Have any schools won Ivy League championships in both football and basketball during the same school year?

title: A. H. Robins Cites a Cash Problem
description: The A. H. Robins Company, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in the wake of Dalkon Shield litigation, said it could be almost $15.5 million in the red by the end of this month.

title: Shoe Industry Plan by U.S.
description: Labor Secretary Bill Brock has asked governors in major shoe-producing states to help assist dislocated shoe workers, and committed $5 million in Federal funds for the project.

title: LOG HOMES PRESERVE ADIRONDACK STYLE
description: Krissa Johnson can chainsaw a log to the precision of a sixteenth of an inch. She spends punishing hours suspended high above the ground in a crane cab, maneuvering bulky logs.

title: Susan Fraker Weds Maynard Parker
description: The marriage of Susan Fraker, a member of the editorial board of Fortune magazine, to Maynard Michael Parker, the editor of Newsweek magazine, took place yesterday in Millbrook, N.Y. Judge Pierre Leval of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York performed the ceremony at the home of John S. Dyson, former chairman of the New York State Power Authority, and Mrs. Dyson.

title: SMOKERS' ILLS COST BILLIONS, U.S. SAYS
description: A Federal agency has estimated that $12 billion to $35 billion will be spent in the United States this year to treat smoking-related diseases.

title: Terrorists in Philippines Kill 25 in Movie House
description: Terrorists threw grenades into a crowded movie house in the southern Philippines today, killing at least 25 people and wounding more than 100, the authorities said.

title: Score for Washingtonian
description: The Washingtonian magazine will be 20 years old next month, but Philip Merrill, who has owned it since 1979, is planning a deliberately muted celebration. On Sept. 26, invited guests will attend an informal after-work reception in the offices of the magazine, a monthly. Mr. Merrill has decided to take the money it would have cost to hold a celebrity-studded anniversary dinner at a first-class hotel, which he estimated at $100,000, and instead give 20 Washington charities $5,000 each in the name of the magazine.

title: Penn Expected to Lead Ivies
description: The Ivy League's 30th season begins next Saturday and the story line this year will follow Penn's attempt to win a part or all of the football championship for a fourth straight year. The best challenges will come from Yale and Harvard.

title: PRELIMINARIES FOR SUMMIT MAY FORECLOSE OPTIONS
description: It is still two months until President Reagan's summit meeting with the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, but the two protagonists are already bargaining in public.

title: WESTERN NOVELS RIDE HIGH AGAIN
description: Years after moseying off into the sunset, the western novel, once America's most enduring morality play, is again riding high in the literary saddle.

title: Cobb's Big Knock
description: When Pete Rose began his final countdown to Ty Cobb's career hit record this month, reporters hit the road with him, pounding out dispatches faster than Rose pounded out base hits. And by the time he arrived back in Cincinnati last week, geared up for his big moment, about 300 journalists were on hand.

title: SAUDIS SAY REAGAN CLEARED PURCHASE OF BRITISH PLANES
description: Saudi Arabia went ahead with a decision to buy more than $4 billion worth of British fighter planes after President Reagan assured King Fahd that the United States would not object to the sale, Saudi sources said today.

title: A Pair Of Good Ideas
description: Contrary to popular opinion, not all headlines bring us bad news or bad ideas or both. Two recent political stories, for example, concerned good ideas and one of them even constituted good news. Down with the two-term limitation: Meeting with an organization of conservative state legislators in Tampa, Fla., President Reagan advocated a constitutional amendment to repeal the 22d Amendment, passed in l951 as the Republican Party's posthumous revenge against Franklin D. Roosevelt. This would allow Mr. Reagan's successors to seek more than two terms.

title: Unsung Heroes And Outlaws
description: Everyone remembers Jesse James, Judge Roy Bean and Will Rogers. But history managed to forget Ben Hodges, Fredrick L. McGhee and Bill Pickett.

title: STEEL'S FIERCE DOMESTIC BATTLE
description: For the American steel industry, imports remain a worry, but they are not the dominant issue they were a year ago when the President's program to control foreign shipments was announced. Today, the main problem is closer to home: The mills are caught up in a fierce battle among themselves for market share and are cutting each other up on prices.

title: U.S. SAYS RUSSIANS HELD LIAISON CREW
description: A United States military crew was detained at gunpoint by Soviet troops in East Germany for about nine hours last weekend, the Pentagon said today.

title: Drug Trial Set to Resume
description: The second trial to result from the Federal drug investigation involving baseball players as witnesses is scheduled to begin Monday.

title: LAND PACT, SALES TAX, AND DEATH
description: The possibility that the Puyallup Indians will press their claim to a big piece of the Tacoma waterfront and much of downtown Tacoma appears to have been ended by a tentative agreement between the Indians and Federal, state and local offcials.

title: BANKS AND SOUTH AFRICA: THE TURNING POINTS
description: The usually unflappable senior vice president of a major New York bank sat in his Westchester home a few weeks ago watching television excerpts from a long-awaited speech by South Africa's President, P. W. Botha. Like many other people, the banker had expected Mr. Botha to be conciliatory and indicate that his Government would change its racial policies.

title: Richard A. Meyerson Marries Jane Gordon
description: Jane Lori Gordon, a daughter of Joyce Gordon of New York and Merrill Ian Gordon of West Bloomfield, Mich., and Bal Harbour, Fla., was married yesterday to Richard Allan Meyerson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Meyerson of Long Beach, L.I., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony at the Terrace Restaurant in Manhattan.

title: DANCE: IN PHILADELPHIA, CUNNINGHAM'S 'ARCADE'
description: Merce Cunningham has taken the rare step of creating a work for a ballet company rather than his own modern-dance troupe and the result is ''Arcade'' for the Pennsylvania Ballet -a moving and unusually beautiful esthetic experience.

title: WORKERS HEAR PRAISE FROM POLISH CLERICS FOR SOLIDARITY'S AIMS
description: With prayers for Solidarity's ideals and with accolades for its leaders, Roman Catholic clerics greeted more than 50,000 industrial workers who came here on a pilgrimage today.

title: DUARTE AIDES REPORTEDLY TO MEET WITH REBELS ON FREEING DAUGHTER
description: Two high-level Salvadoran Government officials flew to Mexico this afternoon to meet Salvadoran rebels who may be holding the daughter of President Jose Napoleon Duarte, according to a foreign diplomat here and a Salvadoran source aware of the negotiations.

title: REDSKINS STRUGGLE TO DEFEAT OILERS
description: ''It was nothing pretty,'' Joe Gibbs said, and to a great extent he was right.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MOONSHINE: A Life in Pursuit of White Liquor. By Alec Wilkinson. 153 pages.

title: IMPATIENCE IN THE RUINS
description: IN the distance beyond Yankee Stadium during the third inning yesterday, thick black smoke drifted into the sky. And inside Yankee Stadium, as the Toronto Blue Jays were scoring six runs in what would be a 8-5 triumph, the Yankees' chances in the American League East may have gone up in smoke, too. In the ruins of their third consecutive loss, the Yankees are suddenly four and a half games behind the first-place Blue Jays, with only three weeks remaining in the schedule.

title: British Officials Meet; More Expulsions Seen
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher met today with two senior Cabinet officials, and press reports said they discussed whether to order more Russians to leave the country in response to the Soviet expulsion of 25 Britons.

title: Democracy Can Take a Balanced-Budget Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE TRENCHES AT PEOPLE AIR
description: On Friday night of the recent Labor Day weekend, Laurie Gillespie and Rick Avjean, customer service managers for People Express Airlines, faced three planeloads of irate passengers who had been waiting in the North Terminal of Newark International Airport for hours.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 16, 1985
description: The Economy

title: U.S. SANCTIONS STIR AFRICAN WARINESS
description: After President Reagan's announcement of limited trade and financial sanctions against South Africa, the black-governed countries on that nation's borders continue to express wariness about the use of economic sanctions against apartheid.

title: Ivory Coast Cocoa Crop
description: Heavy rains have aroused concern about next season's Ivory Coast cocoa crop, and the world's largest producer could have problems reaching its output target, according to Agriculture Minister Denis Bra Kanon. He said the heavy rains last month could cause cocoa pods to rot and had already destroyed the fertility of some of the flowers that would have matured into pods. Concern over the effects of the rains on the Ivory Coast's 1985-86 crop, which has a target of 500,000 metric tons, has helped support world market prices for cocoa.

title: Search Continues In Trooper's Death
description: Searchers whose number increased to more than 200, continued to comb thickly forested mountains today for two fugitives from an Arkansas jail suspected in the shooting death of a state trooper.

title: The Worm and the Apple;   Stamps Move; Traffic Doesn't; Postal Outreach
description: Manhattan means standing in line - for movies, buses, tokens, cash, the morning coffee and postage stamps. The last line is perhaps the most onerous: many a lunch hour is lost in the pursuit of a sheet of twenty-two's.

title: GRAND PRIX TO BRAZILIAN
description: Ayrton Senna mastered alternating rain showers and sunshine today to win the Belgian Grand Prix with a faultless drive and score the second Formula One victory of his career.

title: Topping-Off Celebration
description: The Army and Navy Club, a landmark that has overlooked Farragut Square since 1912, will ''top off'' the $35 million reconstruction of its headquarters with a flag-raising and progress-hailing ceremony tomorrow.

title: MCNEIL, JETS RUSH PAST BILLS
description: It was a dazzling afternoon of records, near-records and realized dreams today for the Jets, who found in the Buffalo Bills the perfect solution for their malaise.

title: The Attack on Alaska's Parks
description: If you think that the astonishing wildlife and scenic resources of Alaska that were added to the national park system by Congress in 1980 are safely protected for all time as they are supposed to be, you are wrong.

title: PRETORIA'S LATEST HINTS
description: For nearly a week, there have been intimations of change in this racially divided land, hints wrapped in coded messages of intent designed to assure a hostile world and a black majority part skeptical and part bellicose that the indignities will soon be lessened.

title: Caller Says a Hostage Was Freed in Lebanon
description: A man claiming to speak for the Islamic Holy War organization told a Western news agency here today that the group had released the Rev. Benjamin Weir, one of seven Americans believed to be held hostage after have disappeared in West Beirut in the last year and a half.

title: METS KEEP PACE AS YANKEES SLIP
description: It had some soap-opera touches, but the Mets aren't quibbling about style these days: Danny Heep, the perennial understudy, replaced the hurting Darryl Strawberry at curtain time, hit a three-run home run in the first inning and played the starring role as the Mets beat the Montreal Expos, 6-2.

title: Two Boys Die in Fire; Bars Blocked Escape
description: Two young boys were killed and their three brothers injured yesterday when they were trapped in a burning Brooklyn apartment by bars placed illegally on the window of their bedroom, authorities said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 16, 1985
description: International

title: FOREIGN INVESTMENT IN U.S. UP SHARPLY
description: The level of foreign investment in manufacturing in the United States increased sharply in 1984 from 1983, largely because of foreign acquisitions of American companies. And experts predict that the figures for this year will show an even higher rate of growth.

title: SPEECHES INSPIRE THE JETS
description: Following the Jets' 42-3 victory over Buffalo today, Freeman McNeil recalled that the week had been filled with emotional calls to arms.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Cardinal Entertainment Corp., Los Angeles, has appointed its former president, Paul A. Joseph, to be chief executive and its former vice chairman, Robert Sterling, to be chairman upon the resignation of Ralph Kent Cooke from both posts.

title: 'A HISTORY OF CONSUMER PROTEST'
description: THE consumer movement isn't a likely subject for television; it is, as ''America at Risk: A History of Consumer Protest'' says, ''often ephemeral, sometimes disorganized and frequently strident.'' It's hard to film something like that, but ''America at Risk'' does its best, and its best is pretty good. The one-hour documentary, which uses old newsreel film, still photographs and interviews, will be seen on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight.

title: Taxi Driving Is Difficult, Dangerous, Punishing and Frustrating
description: To the Editor:

title: Defector's Danish Stay
description: When Mr. Gordiyevsky was an attache at the Soviet Consulate and later a high official at the Soviet Embassy here he was a popular member of the diplomatic corps who would dine out with journalists and politicians and joke that he was a member of the K.G.B., according to reporters here.

title: Muriel Smith, 62, Created Carmen Jones on Broadway
description: Muriel Smith, the singer and actress who created the role of Carmen Jones on Broadway, died Friday at a city hospital. She was 62 years old.

title: Skip Trial Wins by a Neck
description: Skip Trial took the lead in the middle of Philadelphia Park's homestretch and held off a late run by El Basco to win by a neck in the seventh running of the $300,000 Pennsylvania Derby today.

title: INDIA BANS CRITICAL PUNJAB REPORT
description: The Indian Government has banned a report on violence in Punjab state and arrested two people involved in putting out the report.

title: WHAT THE U.S. CAN DO
description: As the South African drama has unfolded over recent weeks, one striking fact has been the irrelevance of the United States Government. In a period of the most fundamental crisis and change in the modern history of South Africa, Washington is playing no significant role.

title: CENTER FOR TRANSPLANTS AIDS PITTSBURGH ASCENT
description: ''When you say medicine, I think transplant,'' says William R. Berry, executive director of the American Council of Transplant Physicians. ''When you say transplant, I think Pittsburgh.''

title: LATEST EPISODE IN GUCCI FAMILY FUED
description: The fierce family feud over control of the Gucci leather empire took a new turn last week as an Italian court sequestered the 50 percent share of the company controlled by Maurizio Gucci, its chairman.

title: MITTERRAND INVITES 14 NATIONS TO JUDGE A-TEST SITE'S SAFETY
description: A day after returning from a trip to French nuclear weapons testing sites in the South Pacific, President Francois Mitterrand today invited the leaders of the 14 countries in the region to visit the area and assure themselves of its safety.

title: EUROPEANS DEFEAT U.S. IN RYDER CUP
description: A team of Europe's best professional golfers today beat the United States in a Ryder Cup Match for the first time in 28 years. The score was 16 1/2-11 1/2.

title: Advertising;   Consumer Magazine Planned
description: THERE is a potential comedy routine in trying to describe what Jerry Jontry and Norman L. Aronson are up to.

title: Mary Genoese Weds Bruce Peter Duignan
description: Mary Elizabeth Genoese, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Genoese of Brooklyn, and Bruce Peter Duignan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher Duignan of Hilton Head, S.C., were married yesterday. The Rev. Eugene Prior performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Innocents in Brooklyn.

title: Mixed Fortunes for Steelmakers
description: Different companies are faring differently as the steel industry tries to cope with changing conditions. Here is a look at the major companies: United States Steel Corporation - Steel now accounts for only 35 percent of U.S. Steel's revenues. Most of its sales come from its Marathon Oil division, which it bought in 1982, and U.S. Steel is reported to be ready to make another big acquisition as a further counterweight to steel and oil. Analysts praise the company for the changes in its steel operations, which showed an operating profit of $85 million in the second quarter. The steel division has shrunk drastically, with 100,000 jobs eliminated and some 150 plants closed. The company lost $1.2 billion in 1983 and reported a profit last year of $493 million - helped by one-time gains from asset sales and accounting changes.

title: Democracy Can Take a Balanced-Budget Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: Must All of Our Shoes Be Made Abroad?
description: To the Editor:

title: JAPAN EXPANDS CAR SALES IN EUROPE
description: The Fiats and Renaults rotate on turntables, and the Mercedes-Benz limousines are spotlighted like movie stars. But out in hangar-like Hall 10 here at Europe's biggest automobile show, Japan's cars - Hondas, Nissans, Mazdas, Mitsubishis and others -are lined up as in a used-car lot.

title: Israel Expels 18 Palestinians Released From Jail Last May
description: Israel today expelled to Jordan 18 Palestinians who were freed from Israeli jails last May in a prisoner exchange between Israel and a Palestinian guerrilla organization, a military spokesman said.

title: Washington Watch;   Broadcast Vs. Cable
description: With the possibility of court relief rapidly diminishing, several broadcast lobby groups, led by the National Association of Broadcasters, are talking with members of Congress about legislating a ''must carry'' rule.

title: A Merger Quandary For Richardson Kin
description: He is only 38 years old, but Stuart S. Richardson, chairman of Richardson-Vicks Inc., already must know a bit about loyalty, both to his family and to his company.

title: FINAL SECONDS PROVE COSTLY
description: Three Southeastern Conference teams that led non-conference opponents going into the final minute of play at home Saturday gave up a touchdown with 37 seconds or less remaining and did not win. Florida was tied by Rutgers, 28-28; Tennessee was tied by U.C.L.A., 26-26, and, in the biggest upset of the day's major college football games, Kentucky was beaten by Bowling Green, 30-26.

title: ROBINSON: LONG CLIMB TO THE TOP
description: EDDIE ROBINSON leaned back in his old, familiar leather chair, and glanced around his office.

title: An Encounter With a Grandmaster
description: As a professional violinist, William Cruso has happy memories going back 65 years. He played at Hyde Park for Gov. Franklin D. Roosevelt and was a member of the orchestra on the opening night of ''Fiddler on the Roof.''

title: U.S. PRISON POPULATION GREW 5% IN FIRST HALF OF '85, BUREAU SAYS
description: The nation's Federal and state prison population grew by 5.6 percent in the first six months of 1985, the equivalent of 1,000 new inmates each week, the Bureau of Justice Statistics reported today.

title: Futures/Options;   'Securitization' Of Britain
description: ONE of the chief beneficiaries of the continuing invasion of the British financial community by American banks has been London's booming financial futures markets. The main reason is that the American banks have introduced what London bankers refer to as ''securitization,'' or the packaging of mortgage and other loans into exchange-traded shares and other securities.

title: Washington Watch;   Deregulation Forum
description: One of the Reagan Administration's most aggressive advocates of governmental deregulation is getting an additional forum. The Federal Communications Commission chairman, Mark S. Fowler, will head the Council of Independent Regulatory Agencies, comprising the chiefs of the 14 independent regulatory commissions.

title: MTV PRESENTS VIDEO MUSIC AWARDS
description: THE cable channel MTV broke its own rules Friday when it telecast the Second Annual MTV Video Music Awards live from Radio City Music Hall. There were far more black faces -presenters, performers, audience -than usual. There was profanity, starting with Eddie Murphy's opening monologue as host. There was even live music.

title: Proposed Cut in Funds Would Derail Amtrak
description: To the Editor:

title: LIONS DOWN COWBOYS, 26-21
description: Eric Hipple passed for one touchdown and ran for one and the Detroit defense forced five Dallas turnovers today as the Lions held off the Cowboys for a 26-21 victory, their second straight under Darryl Rogers, their new coach.

title: Gold Star Cleared
description: The Gold Star Tele-Electric Company, a Korea-based electronics company, said the International Trade Commission had ruled that it did not violate trade laws by importing double-sided floppy disk drives. The Tandon Corporation of Chatsworth, Calif., had charged the company and others with misappropriating trade secrets, and sought to exclude imports of floppy disk drives. Gold Star had denied the charges.

title: Democracy Can Take a Balanced-Budget Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: CONFUSION RULES RATE OUTLOOK
description: The bond market's uncertainty about the outlook for the economy and interest rates is reflected in recent trading, which has been erratic, but has left rates within the range that has prevailed since mid-May.

title: Yanks Get Joe Niekro
description: The Yankees reunited the Niekro brothers yesterday, but their move was more out of need than nostalgia. They picked up Joe Niekro from the Houston Astros, and Manager Billy Martin said he would start the righthanded knuckleball specialist Thursday night at Detroit.

title: CUOMO ASSERTS WESTWAY FACES A TIME BARRIER
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that the Westway project might soon ''run out of time'' and that he might be forced to decide whether to abandon the project and trade in Federal funds for mass transit.

title: Airship Passengers
description: Airship Industries, the British dirigible manufacturer, has been licensed to carry fare-paying passengers. The company's managing director, Jack Birchmore, said the permit meant that Airship Industries could operate its own airline. However, officials said that the company had no such plans at present and that all of its eight airships were committed to advertising or other nonpassenger-carrying work.

title: Spending a Life in the Law
description: As lawyers, you will be the objects of admiration and cynicism. The legal profession today offers ample justification for both. One thing is clear: It needs the best you can give it. Those to whom being a lawyer is just the means to personal wealth and power may gain both, but they will miss many of the satisfactions the profession offers.

title: STUDY FINDS MORE UNWED COUPLES LIVING TOGETHER
description: The number of unmarried men and women living together has more than tripled since 1970, climbing to nearly two million couples as young Americans continue to postpone marriage, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Ex-Prosecutor Is Nominated For a Manhattan Senate Seat
description: A 31-year-old former assistant district attorney, David A. Paterson, won the Democratic nomination yesterday to fill the State Senate seat on the West Side of Manhattan left vacant by the death Aug. 6 of Leon Bogues.

title: DEBT LIMIT MAY DELAY U.S. AUCTIONS
description: The Treasury's financing schedule is a source of uncertainty in the bond markets as traders and investors wonder when Congress will approve an increase in the Federal debt ceiling.

title: The Worm and the Apple;   Stamps Move; Traffic Doesn't; Gridlock Backslide
description: ''Don't block the box'' was the slogan of the anti-gridlock campaign launched a year ago by New York City's Bureau of Traffic.

title: MODEST ECONOMIC PACE SEEN
description: Corporate economists have become convinced that the economy is gathering steam, but their forecasts fall far short of the Reagan Administration's robust growth predictions for the second half of this year.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BLACKS AND THE WEST Among typical American stereotypes, the black cowboy, even the black as settler of the expanding West, rarely appears in the portrayals of past that are packaged for us. Yet blacks were figures on the scene, active figures who played important roles in the great national movement to the Pacific. This is what the new exhibition, ''The Black West,'' is all about, at the New York Public Library's Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, 515 Lenox Avenue, at 135th Street (862-4000).

title: Into the Elephant's Den
description: Representative Jim Chapman, the Texas Democrat who edged into the House last month by winning a close special election, is already moving to defend his seat next year. Even before he was sworn in, he wrote to the 200 political action committees that had contributed to his Republican opponent, Edd Hargett, soliciting their financial backing for his 1986 re-election bid.

title: CENSORSHIP AND CHILDREN
description: The decision Friday in California to reject more than 20 science textbooks because they ''water down'' instruction on evolution is seen by experts as a sign of a small but growing reaction against the pressures exerted on schools and publishers by religious fundamentalists.

title: Advertising;   Blakemore & Killough Gets G.O.P. Business
description: Blakemore & Killough, which Charles B. and James K., respectively, started in January, has announced that it has become ad agency for the National Republican Congressional Committee.

title: YAMANI CITES CONCERNS ON OIL PRICES
description: The Saudi Arabian oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, said over the weekend that crude oil prices could fall to between $15 and $18 a barrel next spring, but only if there is a price war because producers fail to cooperate to stabilize the market.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday misstated the amount that Trans World Airlines would pay the Texas Air Corporation as a result of the cancellation of a merger agreement. The correct amount for the cash payment is $43 million.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Particular attention must now be given to women, both lay and religious. Their role in the church and society must be clarified, their rights and dignity must be affirmed, and their advancement to positions of leadership and decision-making must continue.'' - Bishop James W. Malone, President, National Conference of Catholic Bishops [A1:6.]

title: Salmonella Outbreak Laid to Tainted Milk
description: A five-month study on the nation's largest salmonella outbreak has confirmed suspicions that tainted raw milk entered the Hillfarm Dairy's piping system and was mixed with pasteurized milk.

title: Maine Man Wins Lottery
description: A Maine man who played the dates of his birthday, wedding anniversary and stepson's birthday won a $935,919 jackpot today in the first regional lottery drawing in the country. The man, Richard Campbell, director of financial aid at the University of Southern Maine here, said he bought the Tri-State Megabucks ticket about two hours before the inaugural drawing Saturday night.

title: Democracy Can Take a Balanced-Budget Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: MENCHEN REMEMBERED ON 105TH ANNIVERSARY
description: The Saturday Night Club, the roistering music and drinking society founded in 1902 by and for the friends of the late H. L. Mencken, the acid-penned journalist and critic who left his mark on a generation of American readers and writers, was recreated here over this, his 105th birthday weekend. The reviews were mixed.

title: WHEN LANDMARKS LURE THE SUICIDAL
description: The two bridges that cross Rock Creek Park in Northwest Washington are among the most striking in the capital, overlooking a picturesque forest with narrow streams and miles of bending roadway. But in recent years the bridges, the Duke Ellington Memorial and the Howard Taft, have also had an irresistible lure for people who want to commit suicide.

title: ROCK: FOREIGNER PERFORMS
description: FOREIGNER arrived at Madison Square Garden on Thursday with a vintage-1985 hit -and a concert that evoked a vanished era of mid-1970's rock. From a halfhearted laser display to drawn-out guitar solos, from ponderous tempos to dowdy stage postures, Foreigner was a reminder of how lugubrious pre-punk rock could be.

title: SPY REPORTEDLY FLED AFTER SOVIET CALL
description: A summons to return to Moscow for consultation prompted the head of the K.G.B. in Britain to seek asylum in a ''safe house'' in the south of England in July, according to a senior British official.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET SIGN OLYMPIC PACT
description: The top Olympic officials of the United States and the Soviet Union today signed an agreement of sports cooperation that encouraged participation in the 1988 Olympic Games but did not commit teams from the two nations to appear in Seoul, South Korea.

title: City Officer Arrested on L.I.
description: A New York City probationary police officer accused of assaulting the manager of a Long Island bar has been arrested and suspended from the force, the police said. A police spokesman, Officer Fred Elwick, said the probationary officer, 23-year-old James Mulvaney of Coram, L.I., was accused of striking the manager of the Tara Inn in Port Jefferson, L.I., with a beer mug after the manager confronted him for taking the mug out of the bar. The officer was arrested by the Suffolk County police late Saturday night.

title: Diane Gutwillig and Scott Pearlman Are Wed
description: Diane Beth Gutwillig, a daughter of Mrs. Robert Schoenthaler of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Roger Gutwillig of White Plains, was married yesterday to Scott Anthony Pearlman, the son of Mrs. Michael Sember of New Orleans and Robert Pearlman of Darien, Conn. Dr. Sheldon Ackley performed the ceremony at the New York Society for Ethical Culture.

title: Change Urged On Latin Debt
description: The principal Latin American development bank said today that the West's strategy for dealing with the debt crisis was foundering and urged a new policy.

title: MUST ALL OF OUR SHOES BE MADE ABROAD?
description: To the Editor:

title: CHIEF'S CROWN OVERTAKING SPEND A BUCK
description: ''He's retiring as the champion 3-year-old,'' the owner Dennis Diaz was saying in the paddock at Belmont Park Saturday afternoon, following his announcement that he was retiring Spend a Buck to stud. ''They'd really have to come and take it away from him.''

title: Catching Up
description: * Ken Brett, the former major league pitcher whose mention of Utica, N.Y., in a televised beer commercial led to his being appointed manager of that city's Class A club, found mixed results in his first year on the job. Largely because of a .214 team batting average, the Blue Sox finished the season with a 35-41 record, 19 games behind first-place Oneonta in the Yawkey Division of the New York-Penn League.

title: QUESTION WITH NO REPLY
description: Sometimes members of Congress are hard pressed to find ways to answer questions posed in letters from their districts.

title: Advertising;   People
description: * Berta Ledecky name executive vice president at the Healthcare Division of Bozell & Jacobs.

title: A McDonald's 'Poison Pill'
description: The McDonald's Corporation said yesterday that its board of directors had adopted an anti-takeover plan designed to make it more expensive for a hostile bidder to acquire the giant fast-food chain.

title: OUTDOORS: QUARRY WAS BONITO, CATCH WAS BLUEFISH
description: TERNS and gulls were wheeling above breaking fish when we launched our canoe on the nearly-smooth waters of Vineyard Sound an hour after sunrise.

title: Market Place;   Corporations' Profit Outlook
description: NEXT month, when corporations begin to report third-quarter earnings, overall results are likely to be generally uninspiring. That's one reason, experts suggest, why the stock market has been in the doldrums lately, since profit expectations often drive equity prices.

title: Better Than Real, Part I
description: Exuding New York City atmosphere, a tree-lined block of charming, turn-of-the-century brownstones was what the script seemed to demand. And sure enough, after some scouting, the advertising agency finally found what it was looking for.

title: Valve at Carbide Plant Releases Chemical
description: A safety valve accidentally opened in a waste treatment facility at the Union Carbide Corporation's plant here Saturday night, allowing up to 100 pounds of mono methyl amine to leak out, a spokesman for the company said today.

title: SENATORS PONDER VALUE OF LETTING TV IN THE DOOR
description: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, recently boasted: ''I am on television more than any other politician in America.''

title: RALLY HEARS TUTU'S DAUGHTER
description: Several hundred people at a prayer vigil at Dag Hammarskjold Plaza yesterday heard the 21-year-old daughter of Bishop Desmond M. Tutu of South Africa say, ''I truly believe South Africa will be free in my lifetime.''

title: West German Export Report
description: West German exports should accelerate in the second half of 1985 to ennd the year at 8 percent above last year's levels, adjusted for inflation, Deutsche Bank A.G. said in an economic report.

title: Washington Watch;   Trade Feelers From Canada
description: ALTHOUGH Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada is still weighing the matter, many analysts here expect he will shortly ask the United States to open talks aimed at further liberalizing trade between the two countries.

title: Washington Watch;   Busy Day for F.T.C.
description: The Federal Trade Commission will have a full agenda when it meets this morning on regulatory matters. Actually ''deregulatory'' is probably a more apt description.

title: KARPOV WINS 5TH GAME
description: Anatoly Karpov pulled ahead in the defense of his world chess championship when Gary Kasparov telephoned his resignation of the fifth game of their match in Moscow to the referee yesterday. The 34-year-old champion leads his 22-year-old challenger by 3-2.

title: CATHOLIC BISHOPS SAY WOMEN'S ROLE SHOULD BE LARGER
description: The nation's Catholic leadership yesterday asserted that the Roman Catholic Church in the United States needed to affirm the ''rights and dignity'' of women in the church and to further ''their advancement to positions of leadership and decision-making.''

title: Resignation At Genrad
description: Genrad Inc., which has been experiencing financial difficulties of late, said that W. Douglas Hajjar has resigned as executive vice president, chief operating officer and chief financial officer.

title: NETWORK WOES AFFECT OLYMPIC TALKS
description: The inability of the International Olympic Committee last Friday to award the United States television rights for the 1988 Games in Seoul, South Korea, may signal a turning point in the relations between the networks and those who hold rights to major sporting events, participants in the Olympic negotiations said yesterday.

title: EXCERPTS FROM U.S. BISHOPS' REPORT
description: Following are excerpts from the text of a report on the Roman Catholic Church in the post-Vatican II era, prepared by Bishop James W.
