Malone, president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, and submitted to the secretariat of the Synod of Bishops in preparation for the meeting called by Pope John Paul II.

title: The U.N. Today: Sept. 16, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 3 P.M. to close 39th session.

title: CITY WATER USE CUT ONE-SIXTH IN FIVE MONTHS
description: New York City's campaign to save water amid its worst drought in 20 years has cut daily consumption one-sixth from last year's levels, and city officials, in an end-of-summer assessment yesterday, called the effort so far a qualified success.

title: Bridge: A New Book Urges Players To Expand Their Thinking
description: Those players, and they are legion, who defend by rule of thumb or from force of habit never advance very far in the game.

title: Advertising;   Armour Frozen Foods To Fallon, McElligott
description: The Fallon, McElligott, Rice formula of doing good advertising, entering lots of advertising shows, and letting the trade press promulgate news of the victories, appears to be a winning one. Last week, the agency capped a nine-month winning streak with a $15 million hit: the Armour Frozen Foods Company, a St. Louis-based division of Conagra Inc. of Omaha.

title: CARIBBEAN WAR GAMES: NOT EVERYONE IS DELIGHTED
description: For the last few days several hundred American soldiers with camouflage greasepaint on their faces, and policemen from four small Caribbean islands, dressed up like soldiers, have been struggling through the jungle-covered mountains north of here.

title: TWO BODIES FOUND, ONE WITH GUNSHOT, AT MARINA
description: The body of a 25-year-old man who had been shot was found aboard a boat at a marina on Long Island's South Shore early yesterday. About four hours later, the body of the boat's owner, a 50-year-old Brooklyn man, surfaced in the water about 25 feet away.

title: Paine Webber Lures Junk-Bond Specialist
description: The Paine Webber Group, which for the past year has been building up its investment-banking capabilities by plucking talent from other Wall Street firms, announced that Peter R. Brinckerhoff has joined the firm's corporate finance division as managing director and head of its high-yield and leveraged-buyout group.

title: G.M. CAR BUILT IN JAPAN WINS E.P.A. TEST ON FUEL MILEAGE
description: A model of the Chevrolet Sprint won the Government's top fuel mileage rating for 1986 cars and was the first car to score 60 miles a gallon on the highway, the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: A Story Chinese Guidebooks No Longer Tell
description: To the Editor:

title: COOTIE WILLIAMS, ELLINGTON TRUMPETER, DEAD
description: Cootie Williams, the Duke Ellington Orchestra trumpet player whose internationally recognized signature was the growling, muted horn, died of a kidney ailment yesterday in Long Island Jewish Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Queens.

title: CONCERT: FOLK CITY'S 25TH YEAR
description: FOLK CITY'S 25th Anniversary Concert at Pier 84 on Saturday evening was hardly the first time that folk-identified singers from the last three decades shared the same stage. But the four-hour marathon, which attracted a sold-out crowd of more than 8,000 to the pier at 12th Avenue and 45th Street, offered an unusually comprehensive overview of the evolution of folk music since the 1960's folk boom. The concert, which featured some 15 acts, demonstrated a marked contrast between the concerns of the 60's folk veterans and their contemporary descendants, since the artists who are spearheading a modest folk revival have carried the music out of the political and into the personal realm.

title: Joe Masiell, Singer and Actor Appeared in 'Jacques Brel'
description: Joe Masiell, the singer and actor who attained prominence in the musical ''Jacques Brel is Alive and Well and Living in Paris,'' died of bone cancer Friday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 45 years old and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: Better Than Real, Part II
description: Before leaving for his new job overseas, the West Sider figured that an outfitting trip to Banana Republic at Broadway and 87th Street, specializing in the safari look, was called for.

title: Running Hard
description: ''Dear friend,'' the letter began. Those words alone were enough to make Jack Donlan laugh. The letter went on to say that Ed Garvey was running for the United States Senate from Wisconsin and would be grateful for financial help.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Sept. 16, 1985: *2*MONDAY Bunker Hill Inc Secs Rochester Tel Corp Horizon Bancorp Thompson Medical *2*TUESDAY Bell Atlantic Corp Federal Paper Board CPC International Savannah Elec & Pwr Central Soya Shaklee Corp Citicorp Upjohn Company *2*WEDNESDAY American Intl Group National Fuel Gas American Tel & Tel Natl Serv Industries Anderson Greenwood NorthernStates Pwr MN Carolina Pwr & Lt St Joseph Lt & Pwr Flight Safety Intl Stone & Webster Inc Keystone Intl US Shoe Corp Mony Mtge Investors Vestaur Securities *2*THURSDAY Air Products & Chem Kaiser Cement Alexander & Alex Svc NYNEX Corp Ames Dept Stores Ponderosa Inc Arkansas Best Corp Russ Togs Central Maine Pwr Southern Cal Edison ConAgra Inc Stevens (JP) & Co Dow Chemical Transamerica Corp Insilco Corp *2*FRIDAY CTS Corp General Eletric Combined Intl Corp Media General Inc General Cinema *2*SATURDAY Tektronix Inc

title: CARDS DOWN CUBS; CEDENO GOES 5 FOR 5
description: Cesar Cedeno went 5 for 5 and drove in four runs, two with a homer, and Danny Cox won his 16th game today as the St. Louis Cardinals beat the Chicago Cubs, 5-1. The victory kept the Cardinals a half game ahead of New York in the National League East.

title: Coastal States Plan Study of Beach Litter
description: The states of Oregon, Washington, California, Rhode Island and Alabama plan to mobilize thousands of people for a beach cleanup Sept. 21 that is expected to help scientists learn how garbage affects marine life.

title: SCM GETS INJUNCTION ON HANSON
description: A Federal judge in New York, in a victory for the SCM Corporation, has issued a preliminary injunction preventing Hanson Trust P.L.C., the British conglomerate, from acquiring any additional SCM stock or voting any of the company's shares.

title: HISPANIC CENTER HOLDS BENEFIT ART AUCTION
description: At an auction of contemporary art yesterday, the fortunes of many young New York artists were entertwined with those of a neighborhood whose Hispanic population is struggling to stay vital and alive.

title: For the Teacher: More Than an Apple
description: New York City's schools have now opened, but still short 300 teachers. That's just one symptom of a national problem. In the next decade, new teachers will be needed everywhere.

title: DEBATE GROWS IN U.S ABOUT WHO SHOULD FINANCE AFTER-SCHOOL CHILD CARE
description: As more parents turn to day-care programs to supervise their children before and after school, education and government officials are debating who will shoulder the costs and responsibilities.

title: Lendl Triumphs
description: One week after he won the United States Open, Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia defeated Brad Gilbert of the United States, 6-4, 6-0, today to win the $21,000 first prize at a Grand Prix tennis tournament.

title: Man Is Facing Charges Over Medical Garbage
description: A Philadelphia man accused of illegally storing five tons of used hypodermic needles, intravenous bottles and other medical garbage at a warehouse in the town of Cortlandt was arrested Saturday, the authorities said.

title: PUBLISHERS BACK BOOKS REJECTED IN CALIFORNIA
description: Four publishing companies that have been asked to revise their science textbooks to include more material on evolution yesterday defended their treatment of the subject and dismissed claims that they had ''watered down'' their material under pressure from conservative, fundamentalist groups.

title: WHERE PATIENTS LEND A HAND
description: Nearly 2,500 years ago Hippocrates met with his students under a plane tree to discuss the science of medicine. Among the things he is said to have taught was that the doctor should conceal medical information from patients, never discuss their condition with them and give direct orders.

title: BRAZIL'S PROTECTED COMPUTERS
description: It only merited a couple of lines in President Reagan's trade speech 10 days ago, but his threat to retaliate against the protectionism of Brazil's computer and data-processing industry set off immediate nationalist protests here.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Bloemfontein, South Africa, on Thursday about an offer by President P. W. Botha to consider restoring blacks' citizenship, referred incorrectly to the number of whites in the country. There are four and a half million South African whites.

title: Some Insider Advice
description: As part of his trouble-shooting assignment for Secretary of State George P. Shultz, Edward J. Derwinski, the department counselor and former Illinois Congressman, made a recent unpublicized trip to Liberia. Reports had reached Washington that Gen. Samuel K. Doe, the Liberian chief of state, had arrested leaders of political factions opposing him in the elections this fall. Mr. Derwinski carried with him an aide-memoire extolling the virtues of democratic government and stressing the importance of free elections.

title: The Incredible Shrinking Mortgage
description: Just make one extra payment each year and be rid of your 30-year mortgage eleven years ahead of schedule . . . Choose a 15-year mortgage instead of a 30-year mortgage and save more than $100,000 in interest.

title: TAX BILL ON COAST FAILS AGAIN
description: Opponents of the unitary worldwide method of corporate taxation have again lost a major legislative battle in California.

title: Advertising;   General Foods Switches Tang Account to O.&M.
description: General Foods is switching the domestic account for its Tang breakfast drink to Ogilvy & Mather, which already handles the brand in some other countries.

title: No Way to Lower Health Care Costs
description: So-called prospective payment programs, which fix the number of hospital days or the cost allowed for a given illness, are now being touted as the latest panacea for the nation's soaring medical bills. Everyone agrees that something must be done to contain costs. But prospective payment programs are a seductive -and destructive - idea.

title: AFTER MUCH PREPARATION, JEWS USHER IN NEW YEAR
description: Up since 6 to prepare holiday dinner for 10, Chaja Polner stood in line yesterday at the A. Wilhelm bakery in Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, waiting to buy two loaves of challah and a cake of honey-covered balls called taigelach.

title: IN A CAPE TOWNSHIP, SPIRIT RISES ABOVE REALITY
description: In this wretched patchwork of hard times, which could pass for the last stop on the road to nowhere, Arion Mgweba can still be a man.

title: Janet S. Carter Is Wed To Malcolm C. Persen
description: Janet Shaw Carter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Sterling Carter of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Malcolm Campbell Persen, a son of William Persen of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mrs. Persen. The Rev. Gary Ritts, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the Carter home.

title: Imogene Oler Is Married To Wayne Donald Soper
description: The First Congregational Church of Old Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Imogene Elizabeth Oler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Oler of Old Greenwich, and Wayne Donald Soper, a son of Jeannine L. Soper and Donald Soper, both of Norwalk, Conn. The Rev. Dale Greene performed the ceremony.

title: FARMERS' PROBLEMS SHARED BY LENDERS
description: Wilford Lindbloom never had much use for banks. He felt he had a solid rock, his local Production Credit Association, to lean on for his financing needs.

title: Inflation at Nevada Casinos
description: Twenty-five-dollar slot machines have made their appearance in Las Vegas. To play the Las Vegas Hilton's four machines, installed last week, gamblers must purchase one-ounce pure silver tokens.

title: Hutton Lunch Intrigues Panel
description: The chairman of a House panel said today that he was trying to determine if there was a link between the extension of a Federal grand jury investigation of E. F. Hutton Group Inc. and a lunch between Hutton's chairman and former Attorney General William French Smith.

title: STEVEN WRIGHT, COMIC, 'ON LOCATION'
description: HOME BOX OFFICE doesn't always have much to smile about when it comes to original programming, but the pay-cable service has compiled a decidedly strong record in the area of comedy specials. Its ''On Location'' series has recorded, unedited and uncensored, the in-performance acts of comedians ranging from Robin Williams and George Carlin to John Candy and Eugene Levy as the polka-crazed Schmenge Brothers. The collection adds up to an invaluable library of contemporary humor.

title: LOOK OUT SAM SPADE, SUSAN'S ON THE CASE
description: Susan Rosen's right arm is in a sling. She pulled some muscles in her shoulder and elbow recently when, while trying to enforce a court order, she escorted a woman into the Long Island home that the woman had once shared with her estranged husband.

title: SOCIAL DEMOCRATS RE-ELECTED IN SWEDEN
description: Prime Minister Olof Palme and his Social Democratic Party retained a tenuous grip on power in Sweden in national elections today.

title: ROOTS OF AIDS BOYCOTT: RECORD OF INDEPENDENCE
description: The atmosphere was charged as 500 people packed the auditorium of Public School 63 in Ozone Park, Queens.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: MISSING GIRL, 14, FOUND SLAIN IN JERSEY
description: A 14-year-old girl who had been missing since Thursday night has been found stabbed to death in a ditch not far from her home in Morris County, N.J., authorities said yesterday.

title: Tailgating in Style
description: Since it got going at the Yale Bowl more than half a century ago, the pregame parking-lot picnic known as tailgating has become an almost universal tradition on football Saturdays. Its popularity has produced a fierce competition for choice parking places near college stadiums, and this, in turn, has produced a windfall of sorts for athletic departments. Taking advantage of the demand, many colleges reserve the best places for boosters who make big contributions.

title: PACKERS DEFEAT GIANTS
description: In the moments when their quarterback was forced to throw from his knees, and in the moments when their receivers dropped the simple passes, it was plain that in the space of a week, the Giants had lost their cool efficient manner.

title: SINGLE PARENTS AND DATING
description: FOR single parents, dating while raising a child or two has a way of taking on the characteristics of a mission impossible.

title: EXPERTS FORESEE ADVERSE EFFECTS FROM PRIVATE CONTROL OF PRISONS
description: Several experts on criminal justice expressed concern Friday that private companies that owned and operated prisons would press for longer sentences and less use of probation or halfway houses and other alternative programs in an effort to keep the prisons filled and protect their investment.

title: LOSS OF GENE DIVERSITY IS THREAT TO CHEETAHS
description: WHEN Marco Polo visited Kublai Khan at his summer residence in the Himalaya Mountains 700 years ago, he reported that the Mongol ruler kept 1,000 cheetahs as hunting companions.

title:
SCOUTING;

Count Them Out
description: Though Coach Kay Stephenson of the Buffalo Bills says he is willing to accept reponsibility for the 42-3 humiliation administered Sunday by the Jets, a number of his players won't let him. Nor, for that matter, will Ralph Wilson. ''We've got a few very good players,'' the outspoken owner says, ''and the rest can't play in the National Football League.''

title: PANEL STUDIES BILL TO EASE FINES AGAINST STATES OVER WELFARE
description: The Senate Finance Committee is considering a bill to ease Federal penalties imposed on states that make errors in administering the nation's primary welfare program.

title: Tracy-Locke
description: Continuing its hot streak, Tracy-Locke, the BBDO subsidiary in Dallas, has been named agency for the Phillips Chemical Company, a subsidiary of Phillips Petroleum, which is already a client. The new account, previously with Fletcher/Mayo Associates in Kansas City, bills in the $2 million range. Tracy-Locke estimates that it has gained some $35 million in the new billings in the last quarter.

title: Apple Review Of Chairman
description: Steven P. Jobs, chairman and co-founder of Apple Computer Inc., has recruited five Apple employees to join him in forming a new company, he told Apple last week. As a result, the Apple board is reviewing his status with the company, a spokesman said.

title: Long-Distance Pulses
description: Scientists at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico have used a laser beam to guide a series of intense particle-beam pulses. The test is viewed as important step for President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative.

title: New Doubleday President
description: James R. McLaughlin, a senior vice president of Doubleday & Co., has been named president and chief executive officer of the publishing company, effective Oct. 1. He will succeed Nelson Doubleday, who will become chairman, succeeding John T. Sargent. Mr. Sargent will become chairman of the executive committee. Mr. McLaughlin, 50, joined Doubleday in 1962 as a financial analyst and has been president of its Dell Publishing operation since 1981.

title: VW Price Rise
description: Volkswagen United States Inc. said it would raise prices of its 1986 models an average of $75, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, over comparably equipped cars. The price for options has increased about $32, or 2.2 percent.

title: REACTION MILD TO OIL PRICE CUTS
description: Oil prices and the stock prices of major oil companies fell moderately yesterday in response to news that Saudi Arabia, the premier oil power, had cut its prices and would raise production.

title: Texans Return Home After Spill of Acid
description: About 300 people were allowed to return home today while workers continued cleaning up thousands of gallons of deadly sulfuric acid that spilled into the Medina River after a train derailment Saturday.

title: Sales Up, Inventories Flat in July
description: Business sales in July posted the sharpest gain since April while inventories grew barely at all, the Commerce Department said today.

title: CANADIANS ARE VERY MIFFED
description: At Cap's Bar on Jarvis Street this noon, patrons sipped cold draught beer and discussed the Toronto Blue Jays' weekend success against the New York Yankees. The clear feeling was that by winning three of four games against the Bronx Bombers, Toronto now has the best chance of any American League team of being in the World Series.

title: CITY OPERA: NEW TENOR
description: A GOOD new tenor joined the New York City Opera in a testing role Saturday. Gran Wilson has been making the rounds of the regional companies in bel canto roles of Donizetti and Rossini, and as Tonio in ''Daughter of the Regiment'' he had the confidence of experience behind him.

title: Westwood to Buy Mutual Network
description: Westwood One Inc., the nation's largest producer and distributor of nationally sponsored radio music programs, said today that it had agreed to acquire the operating assets of Mutual Broadcasting Systems Inc., a worldwide radio network. Mutual, which specializes in news, public affairs and sports programming, has been owned by the Amway Corporation.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LYRICAL TRIBUTE What greater tribute to a lyricist than to have the words sung by a pair of acclaimed professionals to an audience that is virtually guaranteed to recognize everything it hears. This is the case at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street (758-2272), where Kaye Ballard and Arthur Siegel open a six-week stint tonight, drawing all their material from the musical legacy of E. Y. (Yip) Harburg.

title: HOMESTEADING DREAMS COME TRUE IN ALASKA
description: The word ''homesteading'' usually evokes images of pioneers toiling on the fringes of civilization to eke out a living from the land. It is a thing of the past in most places, but not in Alaska's dwindling frontier.

title: LOSS AND INJURIES PROVE SOBERING
description: A day after the Giants confronted the hard fact of losing, they assessed the fallout: one fallen kicker, a few other battered players, and over all, a new sense of vulnerability.

title: People
description: Anthony Bucci and Norbert Sieber have been elected senior vice presidents at Marc & Co., Pittsburgh.

title: U.S. Acts on Grocery Specials
description: The Federal Trade Commission took the first step today to legalize the popular practice of getting rain checks or substitute items from the grocery when it runs out of an advertised special.

title: Macmillan Stake In Zondervan
description: The Zondervan Corporation, a religious publisher based here, said Macmillan Inc. had bought 5.28 percent of Zondervan's common stock outstanding in unsolicited open-market trading.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Citrus Canker Is Found In 14th Florida Nursery
description: A citrus nursery owned by Coca-Cola Foods Division today became the 14th victim in a year of citrus canker, the tree-killing bacterial disease that threatens Florida's $2.5 billion industry, officials said.

title: INFLIGHT SERVICES INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,367,000 for the latest year and $1,004,000 in the previous year.

title: The Long Prologue to a Drama Played in a Cracow Synagogue
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 'NATURAL RESOURCE'
description: Not long ago Davey Johnson, the Mets' manager, and Frank Cashen, their general manager, were discussing the tender loving care required to minimize the risk to the 20-year-old right arm of Dwight Gooden.

title: EX-GAS STATION ATTENDANT CHARGED WITH SLAYING GIRL
description: A 19-year-old former gas station attendant was charged today with the murder of a high school girl who authorities said was abducted at random last week.

title: Secretary Bennett on the Court and the Judeo-Christian Tradition
description: To the Editor:

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE Festival of India is all around us, in art, music and fashion, and will be with us until well into 1986. In fashion, it takes several forms: paisleys, silks, lavish embroideries, high-collared Nehru jackets and pipestem pants. And rich-looking jewels, real and otherwise. For most of us, the jewels are mostly otherwise. How many of us have a maharajah's treasure?

title: U.S. PANEL STUDIES BUSINESS AND SOUTH AFRICA
description: A United Nations panel began four days of public hearings today on whether multinational corporations operating in South Africa help sustain the system of apartheid.

title: QUANEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1 million.

title: HNG/Internorth Sells Utility Unit
description: HNG/Internorth Inc., the Omaha-based gas pipeline company, said it had agreed to sell its subsidiary, the Peoples Natural Gas Company, to Utilicorp United Inc., a Kansas City, Mo., provider of electricity and natural gas.

title: RANGERS' CAMP TO STRESS VARIETY
description: Veterans for all three New York-area hockey teams are scheduled to report to training camp today, and when the Ranger players arrive, they will discover that 21 rookies and free agents have already been released.

title: Girl, 7, Is Crushed to Death By Bus on Trip to Disneyland
description: The parents of a 7-year-old girl were told Sunday that their daughter was crushed to death beneath the wheels of a bus while on a trip to Disneyland with her uncle, according to the authorities.

title: Michigan Issue Gets Top Ratings
description: A $350 million issue of Michigan notes due Sept. 29, 1986, was tentatively offered yesterday with a yield of 5.50 percent through underwriters led by Citibank.

title: KAPOK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,489,000 in the latest quarter on the sale of an asset; and a gain of $2,489,000 on the sale of an asset and a gain of $4,594,000 on the sale of property in the latest nine months. c-Net loss.

title: U.S. STANCE SET IN SOVIET TALKS, MCFARLANE SAYS
description: Robert C. McFarlane, President Reagan's national security adviser, said today that the Administration had established policy positions in ''every area'' of disagreement with the Soviet Union to use in talks at the November summit meeting.

title: Silas Joins Nets
description: The New Jersey Nets completed an overhaul of their coaching staff yesterday with the addition of Paul Silas, a former player and coach in the National Basketball Association, as assistant coach. The 42-year-old Silas, who was an agent for athletes and entertainers in in the New York metropolitan area the last two years, joins the new team of Dave Wohl, the head coach, and Bob MacKinnon, an assistant.

title: U.S. TURNS INTO DEBTOR NATION
description: The United States has become a debtor nation for the first time since World War I, owing foreigners more than they owe it, a Commerce Department report indicated today.

title: ALEKSEI YEPISHEV, EX-COMMISSAR OF SOVIET MILITARY'S POLITICAL ARM
description: Gen. Aleksei A. Yepishev, for 23 years the chief political commissar of the Soviet armed forces, died Sunday after a long illness, the Soviet press agency Tass announced. He was 77 years old.

title: FIRST CITY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: UNIVERSAL VOLTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $129,500 provision for unusual losses for inventory writedowns. c-Includes a $866,000 provision for unusual losses for fixed assets and inventory writedowns. d-Includes $350,600 for the latest year and $1,092,100 for the prior year in unusual losses for fixed assets and inventory writedowns. e-Net loss

title: Decision Seen On Fund Plan
description: Federal officials said today a decision is likely within a few weeks on whether to create a quasi-government corporation to manage about $2.3 billion in assets owned by the Federal fund that insures savings and loan deposits.

title: Wrong Forum for Tax Protest
description: The New York State Education Department wants 16 school districts to join in tomorrow's national protest of President Reagan's proposal to eliminate the deductibility of state and local taxes. The agency would have schools focus attention on the issue through classroom discussion and forums involving students, parents and local legislators.

title: ROOKIE LIFTS CARDS IN SWEEP OF PIRATES
description: Manager Whitey Herzog of the St. Louis Cardinals had no reservations about using the rookie pitcher Pat Perry in a pressure situation.

title: WASHINGTON HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $668,000.

title: 2 Hurt Critically In Football Game
description: Two Job Corps trainees who collided during a weekend football game were hospitalized in critical condition with severe head injuries, officials said today.

title: GULTON INDUSTRTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 24
description: b-Net loss.

title: SUN CITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: b-Net income

title: WINGS WEST AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
COLLEGE LOAN CRACKDOWN INTENSIFIES
description: New York and New Jersey, faced with such high levels of default that they could lose part of the Federal money that guarantees college student loans, have intensified their efforts to force repayment and head off an increase in new defaults.

title: NEWCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: Tanner Likely Witness
description: Manager Chuck Tanner of the Pittsburgh Pirates is expected to be a defense witness Tuesday in the trial of the Philadelphia caterer accused of dealing cocaine to major league baseball players.

title: BUCKLEY SAID TO REFUSE NEW YORK BAR INTERVIEW
description: James L. Buckley, the former Republican Senator from New York, has refused to submit to an interview with a New York Bar Association screening committee considering his qualifications for appointment to the Federal Court of Appeals in Manhattan, according to lawyers and Administration officials.

title: Article 010022 -- No Title
description: The A. H. Robins Company, which has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in the wake of litigation over its Dalkon Shield contraceptive device, said that three banks had offered to provide it with $35 million in revolving credit to help it meet operating expenses usually encountered each fall. The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company of New York would provide $23 million; the Bank of Virginia, $7 million, and the Central Fidelity Bank of Richmond, $5 million, company officials said.

title: Japan's Exhibit Seen in the Red
description: Japan's Expo 85, a mammoth exhibition designed to illustrate life in the dawn of the robot age, closed today after a six-month run and bitter complaints from business executives that they had lost money.

title: GALLSTONES REMOVED WITHOUT MAJOR SURGERY
description: GALLSTONES - a vexing health problem affecting millions of Americans and normally requiring major surgery or long-term treatment with pills - can often be quickly dissolved in the body with a new method devised by doctors in Minnesota.

title: Turk Stance on I.M.F.
description: Prime Minister Turgut Ozal said today that Turkey did not plan to sign a new standby agreement with the International Monetary Fund. His declaration, at a news conference, was at odds with recent official statements. In August, Deputy Prime Minister Kaya Erdem said a new agreement was planned. Mr. Ozal said Turkey ''has solved its problem and the I.M.F. is enormously glad about this.''

title: Chinese Get Credit Cards
description: China entered the plastic money age today when two leading bankers became the first Chinese citizens to own credit cards. The chairman of the Bank of China, Bu Ming, and its president, Wang Deyan, were presented with two Mastercards bearing a picture of the Great Wall.

title: Rates Show Slight Declines
description: Interest rates fell slightly yesterday in quiet trading. Besides the absence of many market participants because of the Jewish New Year, analysts said activity was subdued while investors and traders wait for more economic data.

title: New Head At Raymark
description: The Raymark Corporation said today that its board had dismissed its president, Frederick J. Ross, and replaced him with a vice president who was about to leave the company after a failed attempt to buy its industrial products division.

title: AMREP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The year-earlier share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated to give effect to a 25 percent stock dividend paid in November 1984.

title: SMALL LOUISIANA HOSPITAL FEELS EFFECT OF CASE AGAINST GOVERNOR
description: Here, in a hot green field beside Highway 30, in the outskirts of this working-class town of 12,000 people, the steel girders rise for a private hospital, a business as well as a place to treat the ill.

title: Lighter Schedule
description: Hana Mandlikova said yesterday the Virginia Slims of Chicago tennis tournament, being held now, will be her last event in the United States this year.

title: Wind-Shear Detection
description: To the Editor:

title: Split Loyalties . . .
description: Canadians who have settled in New York, and adopted the Yankees, were in some conflict over the weekend during the games against the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: GUIDE BOATS RETURN TO ADIRONDACKS
description: The Adirondack guide boat, a sleek model light enough to carry and elegant enough to be a collector's item, is staging a comeback.

title: PERU'S LEADER OUSTS GENERAL
description: President Alan Garcia has dismissed Peru's top general after criticizing his conduct of the war against Maoist rebels, a Government statement said today.

title: 'EXCESSIVE' STUDENT DEBT IS CITED
description: Many college students are financing their educations with ''excessive loans'' that leave them unwilling or unable to take financial risks when they graduate, according to a Carnegie Foundation report made public today.

title: DRILLING REVEALS OLD CLIMATES
description: USING a technique normally seen in Antarctica or the Arctic, scientists have drilled deep into a thick slab of ice in the tropics in search of information about the past climate and atmosphere. From a massive ice cap atop a 19,000-foot peak in the Andes mountains of Peru, scientists from Ohio State University and the University of Nebraska, using a solar-powered drill, have extracted two core samples.

title: DANCE: ALESSANDRA FERRI IN BALLET THEATHER ROLE
description: DEBUTS and cast changes kept American Ballet Theater's audiences and dancers busy over the company's final weekend at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: THE DANCE: RAPPAPORT
description: IN the works that Linda Rappaport and her company, House on Fire, presented Thursday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio, 55 Bethune Street, some element of the production always proved more interesting than Miss Rappaport's choreography.

title: Putting Time Back on Its Feet
description: After a hundred years on Third Avenue and a few weeks in Muttontown, a landmark sidewalk clock is headed for Queens. The city is out $1,000, but has gained two new clocks in the bargain.

title: Required Reading;   Why We Need Theater
description: Robert Linowes, the head of the new board of the Folger Shakespeare Library Theater, speaking at a Sept. 10 gala celebrating the recent fund drive that saved the theater from closing:

title: PLANT USE WAS UP A BIT IN AUGUST
description: The operating rate at the nation's factories, mines and utilities advanced slightly in August but remained well below the level of a year ago, the Government reported today.

title: CASCADE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
2 SENATORS EVALUATING PROSPECTS FOR WESTWAY
description: New York's two Senators said today that at Governor Cuomo's request they would conduct an immediate assessment of whether there is still hope of winning Congressional support for Westway.

title: IMPRESSIVE VICTORY BOLSTERS MORALE
description: Still basking in the glow of his team's 42-3 victory over Buffalo Sunday, Coach Joe Walton of the Jets had the look of a contented taskmaster this afternoon.

title: JUMPING-JACKS SHOES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
MERRILL'S SCM OFFER IS OFFICIAL
description: A group led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets and executives of the SCM Corporation yesterday officially offered to buy SCM's 12.25 million shares at $74 apiece, or a total of $906.5 million.

title: EAGLE-PICHER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Bridge: Regular Partnerships Have Inside Track in the Bidding
description: Those who complain that they are at a disadvantage against partnerships who use ''all those artificial conventions'' are kidding themselves. The artificialities play a very small role.

title: GETTY PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss. Per share net adjusted to reflect 5 percent stock dividend to be paid in October and a 4-for-3 stock split paid in April 1985.

title: NEW ENGLAND LEADS NATION WITH AVERAGE PAY OF $14,421
description: Residents of New England had the highest incomes in 1984, with the Northeast benefiting from success in new technology and service business and the Sun Belt still mired in oil problems, Government economists say.

title: AUDIO/VIDEO AFFILIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Gruccis Dedicate Yaphank Factory
description: The new Grucci fireworks plant was dedicated here today. It replaces a factory leveled by an explosion in Bellport on Nov. 26, 1983.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL SYSTEMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The results for the year-earlier 9 months were adversely affected by an extended shutdown of the company's principle waste management faciltiy near El Dorado, Ark.

title: GRAPHIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Hunter Media Adds
description: Maclean Hunter Media of Stamford, Conn., which owns Progressive Grocer magazine and is the subsidiary of a Canadian company, has acquired the National Mall Monitor, a four-year-old trade publication published six times a year. William Bisson, who has been its vice president for sales, has been promoted to vice president and publisher, replacing Robert Norins, who will serve the magazine as a consultant.

title: LOTUS PROGRAM HAS A DEFECT
description: The Lotus Development Corporation said yesterday that thousands of copies of a new version of its Symphony business software program had a serious flaw that could cause users to lose large amounts of data.

title: DELTA QUEEN STEAMBOAT CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Buyer of Steinway Sees a 'Challenge'
description: When Bruce A. Stevens was growing up in Shenandoah, Iowa, his family had a Steinway piano for his sister, a singer and musician. But Mr. Stevens, who has spent his career in business, ''barely'' plays and ''wouldn't want to have anybody hear me.''

title: 9.45% Top Yield On Illinois Bonds
description: The State of Illinois is offering $100 million of sales tax revenue bonds with yields ranging from 5.75 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 8.4 percent in 1995, 9.25 percent in 2005 and 9.45 percent in 2015, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Swiss Adopt Pollution Curbs
description: Switzerland announced today that it would impose Europe's strictest automobile emission standards beginning Oct. 1, 1987, to reduce air pollution that is killing forests. New cars will have to meet standards as stringent as those in effect in the United States since 1983, ruled the Federal Council.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Shea Stadium. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs.

title: MISKITO LEADER REPORTS HELP FROM EUROPE
description: Brooklyn Rivera, a leader of Miskito Indian rebels in Nicaragua, said today that organizations in Europe had pledged substantial amounts of aid to his cause.

title: GOODEN MASTERFUL AGAIN, FANNING 11 IN TWO-HITTER
description: Well, they finally got him some runs: nine, to be exact. They were the first runs scored in his behalf in three games. And Dwight Gooden showed his appreciation in Shea Stadium last night by pitching a masterpiece: a two-hitter that subdued the Philadelphia Phillies for his 21st victory of the season against only 4 defeats.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 17, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 3 P.M. to open 40th session.

title: INSTITUTE OF CLINICAL PHARACOLOGY PLC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The dollar amounts are converted from Irish pounds for convenience at the noon buying rate of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York at June 30 of $1.0330 equals 1 pound and at June 29, 1984 of $1.0985 equals 1 pound.

title: Bell Helicopter Furloughs Set
description: Bell Helicopter, a unit of Textron Inc., said yesterday that it would temporarily lay off about 1,800 of its 2,700 production employees to conduct a ''wall-to-wall'' inventory to meet Army accounting standards.

title: Robert Baker Is Dead at 48; A Talent Agent and Director
description: Robert Baker, a talent agent, died of lung cancer on Saturday in New York City, where he lived. He was 48 years old.

title: Stocks Close Mixed in Slow Trading
description: Wall Street stock prices closed mixed yesterday as blue-chip issues performed slightly better than the rest of the market. Trading volume, slowed by the Jewish New Year's holiday, was the lightest in more than two months.

title: 6 BLACK AFRICAN NATIONS BACK SANCTIONS
description: The leaders of the six black-governed nations near South Africa have issued a call for increased international pressure against the Pretoria Government, including economic sanctions.

title: Boy Returned to Mother After 6-Week Abduction
description: A 21-month-old Maryland boy missing for six weeks was back with his mother today, but officials said the reunion might have been earlier had the Texas authorities not returned the child to the abduction suspect a month ago.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 17, 1985
description: International

title: LATIN ARMS TRADE DETAILED IN COURT
description: A former analyst for the Central Intelligence Agency testified before the World Court today that there was ''no credible evidence'' that the Nicaraguan Government had provided significant quantities of arms to insurgents in El Salvador for at least the last four years.

title: SHOREHAM IS SHUT DOWN BECAUSE OF FAULTY GAUGES
description: The process of testing the Shoreham nuclear power plant has been halted by the Long Island Lighting Company while technicians search for the cause of malfunctioning water-level indicators in the plant's reactor core.

title: KEAN'S POPULARITY AT A PEAK AS HE PRESSES FOR 2D TERM
description: Four years ago, when he was running for governor of New Jersey, Thomas H. Kean promised to hold the line on income and sales taxes. After he was elected by the narrowest of margins, the recession deepened, the state's deficit grew to more than $500 million, and he signed legislation increasing both tax rates.

title: News Conference Set By Reagan at 8 P.M.
description: President Reagan will hold a nationally televised news conference tonight, his first full news conference since before his cancer surgery in July, the White House spokesman said.

title: Reagan Repeats His Tax View on New York
description: President Reagan repeated today his contention that New York taxpayers stand to gain if Congress enacts his sweeping plan to revise the Federal income tax.

title: CATHOLIC REPORT: DEBATE IN A NEW STAGE
description: The sweeping changes enacted by the Second Vatican Council are irreversibly entrenched in the life of the Roman Catholic Church, but have also become the source of considerable debate over what they mean to this country and others around the world in a new era.

title: HOSTILE BID FOR VICKS BY UNILEVER
description: The struggle for control of Richardson-Vicks Inc. intensified yesterday when Unilever N.V., the giant British-Dutch concern, began a hostile tender offer for all of the stock of the consumer products company at $56 a share in cash.

title: SHIP LEAKS OIL IN KILL VAN KULL
description: A Polish freighter leaked 80,000 gallons of her fuel oil into the Kill Van Kull -creating a spill classified yesterday by the Coast Guard as ''medium'' - after a rock ripped a 20-foot gash in her hull late Sunday night.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers signed Ron Springs, the former Dallas Cowboy running back. . . . Gary Doak, the former defenseman and assistant coach of the Boston Bruins, was named head coach of the hockey team at the University of Massachusetts. . . . The Hartford Whalers announced the signing of the defenseman Dana Murzyn, their No. 1 draft choice, to a multiyear contract. . . . Bobby Carpenter, the Washington Capitals' high-scoring center, ended his three-month holdout yesterday and signed a long-term contract. . . . Joseph Dunlevy, an assistant at James Madison, has been named assistant basketball coach at Hofstra. . . . Kazbek Tambi, a star defender at Columbia University and later a player for the Cosmos, was signed by the Minnesota Strikers of the Major Indoor Soccer League. . . . A Czechoslovak shot-putter, Remigius Machura, and the women's world discus record holder, Zdenka Silhava of Czechoslovakia, have been disqualified for life by the European Athletics Association for failing tests for drugs after competition at the European Cup Finals in Moscow.

title: 24 Lebanese Die In Shelling in Tripoli
description: Fighting between rival Moslem militiamen in the northern Lebanese port of Tripoli has left at least 24 dead and 75 wounded, the police said today.

title: Giant Overhaul
description: The San Francisco Giants, in last place in the National League West, are ready to dismiss tomorrow General Manager Tom Haller and Manager Jim Davenport, according to a newspaper report.

title: Offering Is Made For Texas Utility
description: The Matagorda Navigation District of Texas is offering $115 million of tax-exempt revenue bonds for the Central Power and Light Company, through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: Ohio Tank Workers Stay Out Despite Tentative Agreement
description: About 2,300 workers at a General Dynamics Corporation plant here stayed off their jobs today despite a tentative agreement on a new three-year contract.

title: The Cosmos, the Universe
description: The faction in favor of admitting women as members of the Cosmos Club appears to have won a modest victory.

title: ISRAEL AND THE BIRDS VIE FOR PRECIOUS AIR SPACE
description: It was a perfectly clear spring morning, Lieut. H., a young Israeli fighter pilot, recalled, and he was flying his A-4 Skyhawk bomber near the Dead Sea when suddenly an unidentified object came straight at him. ''I couldn't tell what it was,'' he said. ''As it got closer, instinctively I ducked. That's all I remember. I woke up on the ground with a parachute around me and my neck broken.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Pope John's basic purpose in convening Vatican II was to heal the centuries-old breach between the church and the world.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL NEW YORK (NL) - Recalled John Christensen, outfielder, from Tidewater of the International League.

title: Howe Has A Relapse
description: Steve Howe admitted to Minnesota Twins officials tonight that he had used cocaine last weekend, the club said.

title: CABLE TV INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: Farrakhan Charges Bradley Shows 'Contempt' for Blacks
description: Louis Farrakhan, a Black Muslim leader criticized by community leaders as an anti-Semitic demagogue, said today that Mayor Tom Bradley's condemnation of him showed contempt for black people.

title: In Face of Threats, Gandhi Goes to Punjab
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi defied death threats today to campaign from behind a bullet-proof shield in Punjab State. He urged people to ''tackle the plague of terrorism'' by voting in state elections next week.

title: Jersey Man Held In Double Slaying
description: An Edison man was accused today of murdering two women whose bodies were found Saturday in their apartment here, authorities said.

title: EXPERTS SPLIT ON ISSUE OF QUALITY OF SCHOOLS
description: PARENTS can easily come down with an acute case of schizophrenia from reading the contradictory reports about the state of the public schools. One set of experts asserts that the schools are better than they have been for years. Others say that the schools are in terrible shape and are responsible for every national problem from urban poverty to the trade deficit.

title: Oklahoma State Freshman Dies
description: James W. Clark, a freshman who was a member of the Oklahoma State University football squad, was found dead in his room today, a victim of an apparent suicide, school officials said.

title: 20 Guerrillas Reported Killed In Attack by Sri Lanka Troops
description: Security forces stormed a guerrilla stronghold and killed 20 Tamil separatists, the Government said today, just hours after announcing an extension of a cease-fire.

title: Modern Munching
description: Dustin Hoffman, Christopher Reeve and Teri Garr were there, lending a show-business air to the world premiere of Martin Scorsese's ''After Hours'' at the Museum of Modern Art the other night.

title: ...and High Rollers
description: Meanwhile, the chairmen of the utilities that share the New York-Ontario border have a bet on the outcome of the American League East race - a bushel of New York apples versus a gallon of Ontario maple syrup.

title: SMITHSONIAN VOTES AGAINST DIVESTING
description: A sharply divided board of regents of the Smithsonian Institution declined today to sell the institution's stock in companies that do business in South Africa.

title: DEFENSIVE CHANGES HAVE LIONS ROARING
description: One of the first things Darryl Rogers and his new coaching staff did when they took over the Detroit Lions for this season was scrap the old defensive schemes. Then they decided the Lions would blitz a lot. Then they crossed their fingers. So far, so good.

title: No Pedestals
description: Alan Page, a former star of the Minnesota Vikings, said it was unfair to expect athletes to adhere to higher standards than the rest of the society.

title: 1866 JAIL IN CINCINNATI IS SHUT AFTER DECADE OF COURT FIGHTS
description: The main cell block at the Community Correctional Institution, one of the oldest urban jails in the country, closed its doors today after more than a decade of courtroom battles.

title: DEATH LIST NAMES GIVEN TO U.S. JURY
description: A neo-Nazi group accused of assassinating a radio talk show host in Denver also considered killing Norman Lear, the television producer, and Morris Dees, an Alabama lawyer, because of Jewish ties and their work against of the white supremacy movement, a member of the group testified today.

title: Hughes Says Satellite Is Total Loss in Orbit
description: An $84 million satellite put into orbit by the crew of the space shuttle Discovery last month apparently is dead, Hughes Communications Inc. said late today.

title: BINGO KING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The latest year results include inventory writedowns of $743,000 and obsolete equipment writedowns of $184,000. In addition a $275,000 provision was made in the latest year to write down the value of its New York plant, reflecting the company's decision to close the plant in early 1986. The company also said that the results of the first three quarters of 1985 have been restated to reflect the writedowns and a restatement of the cost of sales. The fiscal 1985 loss resulted in an income tax refund for prior years of about $656,000 which will be used to reduce corporate debt of $5.5 million.

title: ASIAN CRIME GROUP HIT BY U.S. ARRESTS
description: Top leaders of ''an Asian organized-crime syndicate'' were arrested yesterday in an undercover operation that struck ''a significant blow'' at the group's far-flung criminal activities, according to an announcement yesterday by Federal and police authorities in Manhattan.

title: Giant TV Campaign Set For Beneficial Corp.
description: Yesterday, Dancer Fitzgerald Sample began to prove that you do not have to be jolly and green to be a good giant.

title: British Output Declines
description: Britain's industrial production slumped 1.1 percent in July, the Government said today. Officials called the decline erratic and said the basic trend remained upward.

title: BUYING YOUR FIRST HOME COMPUTER
description: RICHARD was in the middle of retyping the fifth draft of his fourth novel when he realized he was spending more time typing than writing. He began looking for a computer to deliver him from such drudgery, and he drew up two requirements: It had to be relatively easy to learn to use, and it had to be cheap.

title: PENTAGON TOLD TO IMPROVE MEDICAL READINESS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -

title: WORTHINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
FOR U.N. AT 40, MIXED MESSAGE FROM REAGAN
description: When President Reagan goes to the United Nations' 40th birthday party next month, he will be offering stately felicitations but also presenting clear evidence of harder times for the world body under the Reagan Administration.

title: STUDY FINDS DESEGREGATION IS AN EFFECTIVE SOCIAL TOOL
description: A 15-year study of black students educated in predominantly white suburban schools has found that these students were more likely than those educated in predominantly black city schools to attend largely white colleges, to live and work in racially mixed communities and to have white friends.

title: Marshals Seeking Ex-Official Of Liberia After His Escape
description: Federal marshals today joined a search for a man awaiting extradition to Liberia who escaped from jail with four other inmates by sawing off a bar on a window and sliding down sheets.

title: Duper Out
description: The Miami Dolphins wide receiver Mark Duper has been knocked out of the lineup for at least six weeks because of a leg fracture, Coach Don Shula said yesterday. The injury, at first thought to be minor, put a damper on the Dolphins' first victory of the season.

title: 'Death of a Salesman' Doubles 1966 Audience
description: The highly acclaimed production of ''Death of a Salesman'' starring Dustin Hoffman on CBS Sunday night drew about twice as many viewers as an earlier version of the play on CBS nearly two decades ago.

title: PETROLEUM HELICOPTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
In Defense of the Old-Fashioned Assembly Line
description: To the Editor:

title: RCM TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: BARNES ENGINEERING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results include tax credits of $26,000 in the latest quarter; $24,000 in the year-ago quarter; $100,000 in the latest year, and $44,000 in the previous year.

title: Atlantis Test Is a Success
description: The crew of the space shuttle Atlantis breezed through a dress-rehearsal countdown today to set the stage for the ship's maiden blastoff Oct. 3 on a classified military mission.

title: Painter Is Killed by Train
description: A 25-year-old member of a bridge-painting crew was killed by a Long Island Rail Road train yesterday as he was crossing tracks beneath the Kosciusko Bridge in Maspeth, Queens. The painter, whose name was withheld by the police pending notification of his family, suffered a fractured neck. He had been walking with other members of the crew when the accident occurred at 3:10 P.M., a few hundred yards east of the Penny Bridge station on the seldom-used rail line connecting Long Island City and Jamaica.

title: HONECKER IN PLEA ON CHEMICAL ARMS
description: East Germany has begun a campaign to persuade the West German Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl to back an accord banning chemical weapons from central Europe.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Protectionism Just Won't Work
description: There have always been economists for hire willing to tell Congress that America's widget industry can't possibly compete with Koreans working for a bowl of rice a day. Now, however, arguments for curbing trade are coming from respected academicians with little to gain from their apostasy. Though they spur the current drive for protectionism, their theoretical arguments bear little relevance to modern American conditions. Most of their recommendations can be lumped into three categories:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BankAmerica Corp., San Francisco, said its Bank of America unit had won a one-year contract to provide an electronic funds-transfer system for retailers who will be selling California state lottery tickets beginning Oct. 3. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Cruguet Wins 5
description: Jean Cruguet rode five winners in six mounts yesterday at Belmont Park, including Intensify in the $36,000 Bronze Jet Purse.

title: HARVEY GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $153,000 in the latest half and $105,000 in the latest quarter. c-Net loss.

title: 38 ARE HURT IN ROME IN A GRENADE ATTACK ON AN OUTDOOR CAFE
description: A grenade exploded tonight at an outdoor cafe crowded with tourists on the Via Veneto, wounding about 38 people, the police and hospital officials reported.

title: Outlook For Jobs in Retailing
description: MAJOR retailers have been reducing their middle management staffs to cut costs and make operations more efficient. Although that means fewer jobs and slower promotions for middle managers, store executives say retailing still offers good opportunties for new college graduates.

title: Special Copter to Aid Search for 2 Suspects
description: A heat-detecting helicopter that can find humans on the ground joined the three-day search by 300 people today for two men suspected of killing a state trooper.

title: AT&T Unit Details Layoffs
description: The states of California, New York and New Jersey will each be forced to shoulder more than 1,000 of the 24,000 layoffs announced last month by AT&T Information Systems as a consolidation and cost-cutting move, a company spokesman said today.is based here, employs 117,000 people nationwide and announced the layoffs on Aug. 21, the spokesman, Kathy Coulahan, noted. Most of those being eliminated are in staff support and administrative positions, she said.

title: DIGITECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
An Urgent Decision
description: It is a wasteful exercise to speculate whether the Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, is ready to make real concessions to get an arms agreement that would include a ban on development and testing of ''Star Wars'' but not on research, or whether he is just cleverly harvesting a propaganda windfall. The tea leaves won't tell.

title: STEELERS SMOTHERED BY BROWNS, 17-7
description: Gary Danielson hit Fred Banks, a rookie, with a 17-yard scoring pass and Earnest Byner burst 21 yards up the middle for a touchdown as the Cleveland Browns defeated the Pittsburgh Steelers, 17-7, Monday night.

title: CHINESE ADIEU: FIVE WHO ARE GIVING UP JOBS
description: Ye Jianying Born May 14, 1897, son of wealthy merchant in Guangdong Province . . . Joined Communists in 1927 . . . From 1928 to 1931, studied military science in Moscow . . . Helped plan Long March with Mao Zedong . . . Chief of staff of Eighth Route Army fighting the Japanese . . . In World war II, sent by Mao to Chongqing as liaison officer with United States forces . . . Deputy chief of staff of Communist forces during civil war . . . Briefly served as first Communist Mayor of Peking in 1949 . . . Later Guangdong Province governor . . . Promoted to marshal in 1955 . . . Appointed to Politburo in 1966 on eve of Cultural Revolution . . . Held on throughout that period of turmoil, allied to Zhou Enlai . . . Elected deputy chairman of party in 1973 . . . In 1976, played key role in arrest of Gang of Four . . . Subsequently threw his support to Deng Xiaoping . . . His son, Ye Jianmin, recently appointed governor of Guangdong Province.

title: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE: NEW SOFTWARE ARRIVES
description: THE latest catchword in computing is artificial intellegence, or AI. Most researchers in the field do not promise anything as radical as self-replicating computers in the near future. Some, however, do honestly seem to feel that the reproductive facility is the only human aspect computers will be lacking a couple of decades from now. AI, then, is entering the world of hype usually attendant upon any new technology. The reality is something quite different, of course. For the most part it is yet to be seen. Several new products employing AI techniques to make software easier to use are expected to be released this fall. Symantek has a word-processing and database package with a ''natural-language front end.'' That is, it is supposed to allow the user to tell the computer in plain English what to do. Javaline, a financial modeling package, and Paradox, another database manager, are both said to be ''artificially intelligent.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE GOOD TERRORIST. By Doris Lessing. 375 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95. AS Doris Lessing's listless new novel begins, its central figure, Alice Mellings, joins a small band of revolution-spouting squatters in a beat-up London house. For 15 years, Alice, now 36, has been keeping company with a fellow revolutionary named Jasper. We learn early that their relationship has not been consummated sexually, Jasper not inclining that way. Alice may have her problems, too. There is a casebook hint of sexual sublimation, as she faces arrest at a demonstration: ''She yearned for it, longed for the moment when she would feel the rough violence of the policemen's hands on her shoulders, would let herself go limp, would be dragged to the van . . . .''

title: CONTINENTAL HEALTHCARE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Books: Lens on Life
description: CAPA. By Richard Whelan. 342 pages.

title: BUSY NIGHT OUT, FOR 'NETWORKING'
description: ''NETWORKING'' is not new, but for generations it has been confined to the exclusive enclaves of private men's clubs and golf courses. Recently, however, groups that would never have fit into the old-boy network - young men and women who are on their way up, or hope to be - have begun setting up their own networks to swap cards and information. In New York, where - more than in any other city - you are what you do, it is possible to bring together hundreds of people and their business cards for a networking evening. And if sometimes the evening also leads to romance, that is a fringe benefit.

title: NATPAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Working Profile: Raymond J. O'Connor;   The Outside-Inside Tracks of Energy Regulation
description: Rarely has a top Federal official proved more resistant to the blandishments of Washington than Raymond J. O'Connor, the New Yorker who has emerged this year as the suddenly activist head of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission.

title:
SCOUTING;

Losing Battle Continues
description: There is no joy in Glenville: The Trojans struck out Friday night, again.

title: INSURERS OPPOSE BILL TO FORCE EMPLOYERS TO WIDEN BENEFITS
description: Insurance companies and health officials differed today over a bill that would require businesses to include children's preventive care services in employee health benefits.

title: Bloom Agency-Dallas Names New President
description: Robert H. Bloom, a Dallas-based kidnapper of Yankee talent, announced Friday from his chairman's chair at the Bloom Companies that he had once again reached out to Gotham and this time would be pulling in a new president and executive creative director for the Bloom Agency-Dallas.

title: U.S. JUDGES IN OHIO ORDERED TO SHARE POWER
description: A Federal judicial panel ruled today that the Chief Judge of the United States District Court here will have to share authority over court policy with his colleagues, who have said he wields too much power.

title: U.S. Postpones Talks On Soviet Air Accord
description: State Department officials said today that the United States had postponed negotiations that were scheduled to begin today on a civil aviation agreement with the Soviet Union.

title: Air Force, Navy Award Contracts
description: Five contracts totaling more than $200 million have been awarded to the United Technologies Corporation, the Defense Department said. The largest, worth $130.1 million, was awarded by the Air Force to the Pratt & Whitney Government Products Division for 49 F-100 engines for the F-15 and F-16 fighter aircraft.

title: PUBLISHERS SET TO REVISE SCIENCE TEXTS TO CALIFORNIA STANDARDS
description: Several publishers of textbooks that were rejected last week by the California Board of Education for use in seventh- and eighth-grade science classes said they expected to revise their textbooks in time for adoption next year.

title: New Broadcast Board Chief
description: Malcolm S. Forbes Jr. was designated today by President Reagan as chairman of the Board for International Broadcasting, the group that oversees operations of Radio Liberty and Radio Free Europe. Mr. Forbes, deputy editor in chief of Forbes magazine, will succeed Frank Shakespeare, who is retiring.

title: MODERN GALLERIES DRAWN TO SOHO
description: The moving vans and carpenters have returned to their shops, the art gallery season is beginning, and a trend is clear: many galleries handling contemporary art have moved or are contemplating a move from 57th Street to the SoHo district of Manhattan.

title: Edwin V. Huggins Dies at 77; Ex-Westinghouse Executive
description: Edwin V. Huggins, a retired executive vice president of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and a former assistant secretary of the Air Force, died Friday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 77 years old and lived in Summit.

title: HOUSTON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Phylicia Ayers-Allen In Town Hall Concert
description: Phylicia Ayers-Allen, who is currently seen on television as Bill Cosby's wife in ''The Cosby Show,'' will perform tonight at Town Hall.

title: ROBOT THAT SPOTTED TITANIC ALSO FOUND SUNKEN SUBMARINE
description: The nuclear-powered submarine Scorpion that sank in the Atlantic Ocean off the Azores in 1968 was photographed by the unmanned Navy submersible that found and photographed the Titanic on Sept. 1, Pentagon officials said today in Washington.

title: NUMEROUS POSSIBLE BUYERS SHOW INTEREST IN U.P.I.
description: Several prospective buyers have submitted nonbinding ''expressions of interest'' in acquiring United Press International, U.P.I. executives said yesterday.

title: When Funds Suspend Sales
description: IN mid-May, the Vanguard Group of Investment Companies suspended the sale of shares to new investors in the Windsor Fund, the nation's largest equity mutual fund, after net assets had swelled to $3.4 billion. ''There's simply a point at which a fund can grow too large,'' said John C. Bogle, Vanguard's chairman.

title: RADIO STATIONS REDUCE AIR TIME GIVEN TO NEWS
description: Radio stations across the country are reducing the amount of air time devoted to public affairs and news programming, as a result of Federal deregulation and the broadcast industry's changing economics, according to news executives gathered here from across the nation for their annual convention.

title: Judge Refuses to Halt Burial Of 16,500 Aborted Fetuses
description: A judge has refused to halt the burial of 16,500 aborted fetuses found more than three years ago in the backyard of a man who operated a medical laboratory, ending an appeal by a feminist group that wanted the fetuses incinerated.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Atico Financial Corp., a Miami-based holding company, has named to its board Erwin Allen, Patrick J. Cesarano and J. Frost Walker 3d.

title: REFUGEES COUNSELED IN URBAN COPING
description: At first, for some Indochinese refugees on Andrews Avenue in the Bronx, fear was a daily part of their lives.

title: U.S. TONES DOWN VERSION OF EAST GERMAN INCIDENT
description: The Defense and State Departments today toned down the Reagan Administration's original description of the Soviet detention of an Army vehicle in East Germany, an episode that was divulged Sunday by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger.

title: A HIGH-STANDARD EDUCATOR IN CALIFORNIA: BILL HONIG 3D
description: In California, with its reputation for leading the trendy, Bill Honig sounds like a man from another century when he talks about ''transmitting values'' and ''educating for democracy'' as State Superintendent of Public Instruction Mr. Honig's name became national news last Friday when the California Board of Education rejected every science textbook submitted for use in the seventh and eight grades because materials on evolution were ''watered down'' to avoid controversy.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: U.S. WILL ASK PRETORIA TO SET UP NEW SYSTEM FOR BLACK COMPLAINTS
description: A United States official here said today that the Reagan Administration would press South Africa to create ''institutions'' to enable blacks to register formal complaints about brutality and misbehavior by the country's security forces without fear of harassment.

title: DESIGNERS TO REDO BLAIR HOUSE
description: Two New York City designers, Mario Buatta and Mark Hampton, have been selected to redecorate Blair House, the Government's official guest residence, the State Department said today.

title:
SCOUTING;

On the Stand
description: The testimony being given at the drug trial in Pittsburgh has been enough to sadden anyone with even a modest interest in major league baseball, but, on occasion, things lighten up, if only a little bit.

title: RIO GRANDE DRILLING reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
JUDY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Purchaser of Tower Has Big Coast Holdings
description: The price, Walter H. Shorenstein acknowledged yesterday, was a full one: $660 million for 1.8 million square feet of office space. But Mr. Shorenstein, who on Friday agreed to pay that much for BankAmerica's 52-story world headquarters tower and two adjoining buildings in downtown San Francisco, said the buildings are worth the money.

title: WAR, PEACE AND ANGOLA
description: With its raid today into southern Angola, South Africa seems to have revived an issue that has lately been lost in the welter of its own domestic turmoil: the continued presence of Cuban troops in Angola.

title: RAPID-AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a gain from note and debenture purchases of $12,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $2,646,000 and a gain from note and debenture purchases of $77,000.

title: MEETING ON DUARTE DAUGHTER HELD
description: Senior political representatives of the Salvadoran rebel front said today that although a member of the front had met privately with Salvadoran Government representatives about the kidnapping of President Jose Napoleon Duarte's daughter, he did not do so as a representative of the group.

title: AT 40, U.N. NEEDS A FIRMER U.S.
description: In this year of 40th anniversaries, it remains to observe the founding of the United Nations, and the opening, today, of the 40th General Assembly.

title: NASHVILLE: SOUND: COUNTRY MUSIC IN DECLINE
description: Nashville's country music stars are really wailing the blues these days. Audiences are dwindling, sales of country records are plummeting and the fabled Nashville Sound, which defined country music for decades and made this comfortable, tree-shaded Tennessee city one of the world's leading recording centers, may soon sound as dated as the ukulele.

title: Largest Telescope
description: Preparations have begun atop Mauna Kea, Hawaii's highest volcano, for construction of what will be by far the world's largest and most powerful telescope. The site has been leveled and a formal ground-breaking ceremony was held there last week. When completed in 1991, the telescope will be a mosaic of 36 mirrors, independently controlled by computer and forming a combined surface 400 inches in diameter.

title: Don't Disallow 401(k) Retirement Plans
description: To the Editor:

title: WEALTH OF QUARTERBACKS UNUSUAL LUXURY AT YALE
description: A debate about 19th century French poets -Verlaine versus Rimbaud - seems more plausible on the Yale campus than a quarterback controversy. But in the days leading to the start of the university's 113th football season on Saturday, the curiosity mounts about the quarterback position.

title: AMID REQUIEM FOR A MATADOR, VOICES OF REPROACH
description: It was the sixth and last bull of the afternoon, and as the sun was dropping over the baked plains of Castille, Jose Cubero stood six feet in front of the half-ton beast, sighted his sword and lunged forward.

title: The Fallout In EPIC Case
description: The failure by the Equity Programs Investment Corporation, a nationwide seller of real estate limited partnerships, to make payments on nearly $1.4 billion in mortgages and mortgage-backed securities it issued, has raised concern in the financial community that companies that bought EPIC obligations could suffer serious losses.

title: PRETORIA MOUNTS A RAID IN ANGOLA ON NAMIBIA REBELS
description: South African forces raided southern Angola today in what was described as a pre-emptive strike against guerrillas fighting Pretoria's control of South-West Africa.

title: MCCORMICK & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1.4 million, or 11 cents a share, on the sale of property for the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes a gain of $22.2 million, or $1.78 a share, from the sale of property.

title: CONSTRUCTION OF BOWLING ALLEY WITH FEDERAL FUNDS ASSAILED
description: The small, isolated town of Duchesne, Utah, is about to get a $450,000, six-lane bowling alley to be financed by water users and Federal taxpayers through the United States Bureau of Reclamation.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Agreement On Satellites
description: Third world countries secured a partial guarantee of access to a crowded band of communications satellites during a conference that ended today.

title: DIPLOMAT ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary gain of $139,000.

title: Union Carbide To Shut 2 Plants
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said today that it would close its two carbon products plants in Niagara Falls, N.Y., in 1986 and lay off at least some of the 212 workers there.

title: GOVERNOR OFFERS PLAN FOR PRISONS
description: Gov. Lamar Alexander said today that he would seek new prison construction and changes in laws in a move designed to satisfy a Federal judge's order to improve overcrowded state prisons, where rioting left one man dead and $8 million in damage this summer.

title: MANHATTAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: MANY USES FORECAST FOR EXPLOSIVE WELDING
description: Larry Bement puts things together by using explosives to blow them up.

title: UTL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEWPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
VALUE LINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
The Drumbeat of Acid Rain
description: For five years President Reagan has refused to lift a finger against acid rain, the slow poison eating the life out of lakes and trees from the Rockies to the Eastern Seaboard. To each new report urging action, the Administration has always responded that too little is known about acid rain to justify any plan of action. The excuse was never valid, and has now been rendered embarrassing by the frank appraisal of Drew Lewis, Mr. Reagan's special representative on acid rain.

title: SOUTHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said all year-ago figures adjusted for an accounting change and per share figures adjusted for 10 percent stock dividend paid in August.

title: SUICIDE AND DROWNING RULED IN L.I. MARINA DEATHS
description: The unexplained deaths of two men over the weekend at a Long Island marina - one found shot on a boat, the other found floating nearby in the water - were listed by authorities yesterday as an apparent suicide and an accidental drowning.

title: OPTICAL RADIATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Churning Is Charged
description: Murlas Commodities Inc., a commodity trading company, was charged today by a Federal agency with running up excessive commission fees while buying and selling commodity futures for its customers.

title: Tulsa Player Stable
description: Marcus Anderson, the safety for the University of Tulsa, was in stable condition in a Tulsa hospital yesterday after being carried from the field in the final minute of the loss to Texas Tech last Saturday. The senior from Topeka, Kan., sustained two broken vertebrae in his neck in what officials said was a career-ending injury. He is expected to resume classwork next week, according to Don Morton, the Tulsa coach.

title: PROTECTIONIST MOOD: MOUNTING PRESSURE SMOOT AND HAWLEY
description: After pursuing a free-trade policy for the past 50 years, the United States Congress is seriously considering protectionist measures of the sort contained in the damaging Smoot-Hawley tariff act of 1930, which many economists believe helped to create the Great Depression.

title: THE SOCIAL SCRAMBLE IS ON
description: MANHATTAN'S fall social season roared off to an early start with too many parties and too few nights, and its usual overload of silks, satins and big jewels. But such all-stars as Brooke Astor, Drue Heinz and Jayne Wrightsman were still in Europe. Marietta Tree was zipping from Cape Cod to Washington. And John and Susan Gutfreund were at home celebrating the recent birth of John Peter Gutfreund.

title: Layoffs at Storage Technology
description: The Storage Technology Corporation, the computer software company that lost $505.5 million and filed for Chapter 11 reorganization last year, said it would eliminate 500 more jobs.

title: Constitution Day
description: Today, Constitution Day, is the only day of the year when all four pages of that historic document are on public view. The rest of the year, only the first and last pages are on view because of limited space in the display case, in the Exhibition Room at the National Archives. Today, while the full document is temporarily on view in a larger display case, between 1 and 8 P.M. a military honor guard will be on hand, performing a changing of the guard every 30 minutes.

title: MEESE DEFENDS HANDLING OF WHITE-COLLAR CRIME
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d today firmly defended the Reagan Administration's handling of white-collar crimes and said he welcomed Senate hearings on how decisions were made on whether to prosecute large corporations.

title: Federal Farm Bank Loss Seen
description: The Federal Farm Credit System, a network of federally organized banks and cooperatives, will lose between $350 million and $400 million this year, with additional losses expected in 1986, the president of the agency that raises funds for the system said yesterday.

title: FOUNDED LIVING THEATER
description: Julian Beck, whose Living Theater expanded the frontiers of theatrical innovation for nearly 40 years, died of cancer Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan, to which he had recently returned after 20 years of self-exile in Europe.

title: YANKEES BLOW 5-3 LEAD IN 9TH
description: This was Cleveland, not Toronto. But the Yankees, a team in turmoil and in trouble, kept sliding. Yesterday at the Stadium, they lost more ground in a pennant race that is slowly falling from their grasp. Their performance in a 9-5 loss to the Indians was both untimely and unlikely.

title: MONEY-MANAGING FIRM ACQUIRED BY PRUDENTIAL
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America, the nation's largest institutional money manager, announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Jennison Associates Capital Corporation, a closely held money management firm based in New York, for $80 million.

title: 'HONOR,' NEW SERIES ON ABC
description: ACCORDING to ''Our Family Honor,'' New York City is controlled by two families -the law-and-order McKays, heavily stocked with policemen, and the crooked Danzigs, surrounded by villainous heavies. The new ABC series, which gets under way tonight at 9:30 o'clock with a special two-hour premiere, has a knack for being simple-minded. The show exploits complicated questions and invariably comes up with stupefying answers.
