title: Conservatives Get Fine Over Letter From Block
description: Young Americans for Freedom, a conservative group, has agreed to pay a $9,400 civil penalty for a 1984 fund-raising letter signed by Agriculture Secretary John R. Block, the Federal Election Commission disclosed Sunday. The letter urged President Reagan's re-election.

title: New Regional Airline Planned
description: Presidential Airways, a new regional low-cost carrier, said today that it would begin service with 20 flights a day Oct. 10 to five cities from its hub at Dulles International Airport outside Washington.

title: FINDINGS ON REMIANS OF MISSING IN ACTION DISPUTED
description: Leaders of a Vietnam War veterans' group took issue yesterday with a Pentagon statement that the remains of some American servicemen missing in Southeast Asia had been positively identified.

title:
SCOUTING;

Mind Control
description: Do coaches in big-time college football exercise total domination of their players? Not really. Asked yesterday about the psychological state of his legions as they prepared for next Saturday's game against Missouri, Fred Akers of Texas said: ''Sometimes you can't control what players think. You can tell them what to say, but what they think is something else.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 17, 1985
description: International

title: Sallie Mae in Offering Of Floating-Rate Notes
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $100 million of 10-year, floating-rate notes at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc. Interest on the notes will be adjusted weekly and paid quarterly at 7/8 percentage point above the average bond equivalent yield set at auctions of 91-day Treasury bills.

title: Miller Shoots 68 And Leads by 1
description: Bob Miller of Knollwood shot a 2-under-par 68 today to take the opening-round lead in the 54-hole Izod Met P.G.A. Championship at the Country Club of Fairfield.

title: RESORT COLLECTIONS: PICK OF SEASON
description: By the end of next month, clear-colored silk dresses, linen suits and pale cotton sweaters will be nudging aside the big winter coats and other heavy wool winter fashions that have dominated in stores all over the country for the last few months.

title: PPG Repurchases 10.8 Million Shares
description: PPG Industries said today that it had purchased about 10.8 million shares of its stock for $529.8 million, or $49.25 a share. The stock buyback amounts to about 15.4 percent of PPG's outstanding common shares.

title: Ex-Thai Chief Reported Sought in Failed Coup
description: The police were reported to have issued an arrest warrant today for a former Prime Minister implicated in an attempt a week ago to overthrow the Thai Government.

title: ZYMOS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BRAIN DEFECTS SEEN IN THOSE WHO REPEAT VIOLENT ACTS
description: MEDICAL specialists who study human violence are becoming more confident that by sophisticated studies of brain function they can predict repeated violent crimes by people who have committed one or more aggressive acts.

title: CHINESE RETIRING 10 AGING LEADERS IN A WIDE SHUFFLE
description: China's Communist Party announced the retirement of 10 of the 24 members of the ruling Politburo today, beginning one of the most extensive high-level shuffles since the Communists came to power in 1949.

title: T.W.A.'S NEW AD CAMPAIGN
description: STEWART G. LONG, senior vice president, marketing and sales, of Trans World Airlines, told his ad agency he wanted a different kind of TV ad campaign and lots of frequency. And if you are watching the tube in New York or any of the seven other T.W.A. major markets tomorrow night you will see that Ogilvy & Mather gave him what he asked for.

title: Aquino Murder Trial Prompts U.S. Question
description: The United States today publicly questioned a decision to ignore evidence from six American servicemen at the trial of 26 men accused in the killing of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. The comment came in a State Department statement issued by the United States Embassy three days after the prosecution rejected the use of the evidence.

title: GURU'S AIDES QUIT COMMUNE
description: The personal secretary of Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, the Indian guru, has resigned along with several other top leaders in a power struggle within the religious group that lives on a commune here, a spokesman for the group said today.

title: Soviet Said to Have Allowed 29 Jews to Leave in August
description: The Soviet Union allowed 29 Jews to leave for the West in August, equal to the record low of last October, the Intergovernmental Committee for Migration said today in its monthly statement on refugees processed worldwide.

title: BRITAIN, IN RETALIATION FOR OUSTERS, ORDERS 6 MORE RUSSIANS TO LEAVE
description: Britain announced today that it had ordered the expulsion of six more Russians for spying.

title: G.M. Selling Plant To California City
description: The General Motors Corporation, which closed its auto-assembly plant here three and a half years ago and furloughed about 4,200 workers, will sell the facility to the city for $15 million, far below its appraised value of $40 million. Mayor William Dewitt announced the details of the sale, saying the 90-acre plant was sold below value so South Gate could attract new businesses and jobs.

title: Whither Douglas?
description: The future of H. Eugene Douglas, the State Department's Coordinator for Refugee Affairs, is provoking speculation and some confusion among department officials. Several weeks ago Secretary of State George P. Shultz was said to have asked Mr. Douglas, who holds the rank of ambassador, to resign because he had become a controversial public figure, having criticized some private refugee organizations for supporting the idea of assisting Salvadorans who enter this country illegally.

title: Ex-Carter Aide Is Released
description: Hamilton Jordan, who served as White House chief of staff under President Carter, was released today from Emory University Hospital, where he was treated for cancer of the lymph system, a hospital spokesman said. She said Mr. Jordan, 40 years old, would probably begin other treatment this week and added that doctors have told him his chances for recovery were good.

title: CORRECTION
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday misidentified the scene of a children's observance of Rosh ha-Shanah. It was the Riverdale Temple.

title: Claridge Casino Ad Set for New York
description: Another quite different advertising campaign will also be breaking tomorrow in New York for Del Webb's Claridge Casino Hotel in Atlantic City. And the interesting part about the effort by Avrett, Free & Ginsberg is that it recognizes the kind of folks who are crowding the Boardwalk and the casinos these days.

title: Sperry Computer
description: The Sperry Corporation has introduced a personal computer that is compatible with the International Business Machines Corporation's PC-AT computer. Sperry said its computer works 45 percent faster than the top I.B.M. Personal Computer and includes twice the expandable memory capacity and double the mass storage capacity. Sperry said its machine, the PC/IT, priced at $4,340, also supports three times as many users.

title: How to Make Schoolbooks Smarter
description: By flatly rejecting two dozen science textbooks submitted for use by seventh- and eighth-graders, California's board of education has sent a powerful message to schoolbook publishers that the movement for educational excellence is serious. The action is particularly welcome in the wake of years of acquiescence by school boards and publishers to pressures from the right and left that have produced a ''dumbing down,'' in Education Secretary William Bennett's term, of textbooks in science and other fields.

title: OPPENHEIMER & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Chief at a Subsidiary To Head Mannesmann
description: Mannesmann A.G., the diversified West German steel products company, has named Werner Dieter, the head of a major subsidiary, to be chief executive.

title: Tug of War for Tuna Ends With Decision
description: An 800-pound tuna worth $3,350 has prompted a fierce battle between two competing groups of anglers, who spent more time fighting each other for possession of the prize catch than in reeling it in.

title: BRITISH INFLATION FALLS
description: Britain's annual inflation rate fell to 6.2 percent last month, from 6.9 percent in July, its sharpest fall in more than two years, the Employment Department said Friday.

title: Judge in Wisconsin Is Guilty In Stabbing Death of Lawyer
description: A former judge accused of beating and stabbing to death the law partner of the man who ousted him from office in an election has been convicted of first-degree murder.

title: ARNOLD W. CARLSON
description: Arnold W. Carlson, a former vice president and controller of Time Inc., died Saturday at New York Hospital.

title: 'YO SOY,' NEW LOOK AT THE CHICANOS
description: THERE has been a change of tempo in the drive to improve the lot of Mexican-Americans since the clamorous surge for radical improvement in the 1960's. ''Yo Soy'' (''I Am'') is a program that charts the course of this large, Southwestern-American ethnic community, which makes up 60 percent of the 20 million Hispanic-Americans.

title: SPIDERS SEDUCED INTO YIELDING SECRETS OF WEB
description: To many spiders, the web is everything.

title: An Illinois Effort To Get Mitsubishi
description: The State of Illinois has paid about $100,000 to option 1,800 acres of land in the center of the state to lure a $500 million Mitsubishi Motors Corporation automobile plant, a state official said.

title: Water Lessons for New York
description: Scanning the headlines of New York City's newspapers these days is like a flashback to the front pages of The Los Angeles Times when California suffered its worst drought -the two-year dry spell of 1976-77.

title: 2 FORMER STUDENTS AT CHOATE TO PLEAD GUILTY IN DRUG CASE
description: Two former students at the Choate Rosemary Hall preparatory school will plead guilty next week to Federal charges of importing cocaine from South America, a Federal prosecutor said today.

title: Buyers Sought For Arco Plaza
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company and the BankAmerica Corporation said their partnership that owns the Arco Plaza office complex here had chosen two real estate companies to try to sell the property.

title: BONN PACT IS SEEN OVER 'STAR WARS'
description: A West German parliamentary delegation told Congressional committees today that Bonn would sign an agreement setting terms for West German companies to take part in research on President Reagan's spaced-based missile defense program, American and West German officials said.

title: INQUIRY BEGINS INTO CHARGES OF BEATINGS BY RAIL OFFICERS
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's office is investigating charges that three off-duty Long Island Rail Road police officers assaulted three commuters after an argument on a train in Pennsylvania Station.

title: CRAFT HOUSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Twins Release Howe
description: Steve Howe, the Minnesota relief pitcher who missed five games over the weekend in what he later described as a ''temporary recurrence'' of his problems with cocaine, asked for and was given his unconditional release yesterday. The Twins said he would ''devote his immediate, full attention to complete recovery from his personal problems.''

title: NORTH CAROLINA SENATOR SAYS HE WON'T SEEK RE-ELECTION
description: Senator John P. East, Republican of North Carolina, announced today that he would not seek re-election to a second term next year and endorsed the candidacy of David B. Funderburk, former United States Ambassador to Rumania, for his Senate seat.

title: W. A. Waltemade, 74, A Retired State Justice
description: Wilfred A. Waltemade, a retired justice of State Supreme Court, died Friday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 74 years old and lived in Westchester County.

title: LEWIS AIDE SAYS WHITE HOUSE GOT NO PLAN ON CURBING ACID RAIN
description: No recommendations have yet been presented to the White House by the President Reagan's special representative on acid rain, Drew Lewis, his spokesman said today.

title: LAURA ASHLEY, BRITISH DESIGNER, IS DEAD AT 60
description: Laura Ashley, the British designer who founded the international fabric and clothing empire that bears her name, died yesterday at a hospital in Coventry, England. She was 60 years old.

title: CONSUL RESTAURANT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Jury Selection Begins In Trial of Gov. Edwards
description: Jury selection began today in the racketeering trial of Gov. Edwin W. Edwards of Louisiana.

title: FOOD LABELS: HOW MUCH THEY DO, AND DON'T, SAY
description: In 1956, the story goes, Estes Kefauver, then a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, stopped at the supermarket and bought a packaged cherry pie. The picture on the package showed a slice stuffed with cherries. The pie inside the box, however, was mostly crust. Furious, the Senator from Tennessee introduced the first comprehensive legislation against deceptive food labeling.

title: PRESIDENT URGES U.S. LAWMAKERS TO BLOCK PROTECTIONIST 'STAMPEDE'
description: Calling on Congress ''to work with me,'' President Reagan warned tonight that ''a mindless stampede toward protectionism will be a one-way trip to economic distaster.''

title: Hazardous-Waste Cleanup: E.P.A. Superfund Is Doing the Job
description: To the Editor:

title: Digging Around Underground
description: Washington does not have the artifacts or crypts of long-forgotten kings and noblemen that are sometimes found when much older capitals like Rome or Paris or Vienna are periodically dug up. Still, despite its shallower history, the capital of the United States is fast becoming what one local architect and amateur historian, Don A. Hawkins, calls ''a city of layers.''

title: TRIAL TO PROCEED, NEW ZEALAND SAYS
description: New Zealand's Prime Minister said yesterday that new informaton in French newspapers on the sinking of the anti-nuclear protest ship Rainbow Warrior in Auckland would not affect the scheduled trial of two French agents arrested in the case.

title: Metaphors of Doom
description: To the Editor:

title: DIODES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE STORIES OF MURIEL SPARK. 314 pages. E. P. Dutton. $18.95.

title: SMALL-THEATER DISPUTE WITH EQUITY IS SETTLED
description: A settlement was announced yesterday in the dispute that for nine months has disrupted the production of new American plays by small theaters or by independent producers in low-cost showcases. Normally, about 150 plays a year in New York are produced by those means.

title: PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC ISSUES
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference last night in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: INTERPHASE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SENATE, IN REVERSAL, VOTES FOR ALIEN FARM WORKERS
description: The Senate voted today to establish a new Government program under which farmers could bring up to 350,000 aliens into the United States to harvest perishable fruit and vegetables.

title: SATELLITE DISHES CAN SKIRT TV SANCTIONS
description: Just because a major college football team is on probation with sanctions against live telecasts of its games does not mean the games can't be seen live from start to finish. In this age of satellites, dishes and television pirates, such a probation penalty by the National Collegiate Athletic Association is virtually unenforceable.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch on Aug. 7 about United States legal efforts to restrict Japanese killing of sperm whales incorrectly described Japan's response to an International Whaling Commission moratorium on sperm whaling.

title: KING INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $47,700 in the latest quarter, and income from discontinued operations of $173,718 and a tax credit of $106,000 in the year- ago quarter.

title: Bishops Order Investigation Into Catholic Relief Services
description: The operations of Catholic Relief Services in Ethiopia and elsewhere, recently the target of charges by former and present staff members, will be examined by a special church panel under John Cardinal Kroll of Philadelphia, the National Conference of Catholic Bishops said Monday.

title: NORTH HILLS ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income. The company said results include pre-tax charges of $6.8 million in the latest quarter and $16.8 million in the latest six months relating to re-alignments of its business.

title: Debris From Plane Is Found in Ocean
description: A wheel, its housing and a brake lining found in the ocean off Montauk today are believed to be from an airplane that disappeared last weekend with two Long Island residents aboard, authorities said.

title: JAPANESE CITY WHERE GANGSTERS SHOW CIVIC PRIDE
description: The residents like this old port city so much that even the criminals worry about hurting its reputation.

title: ANDROS ANALYZERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
Palestinian Is Charged In Rome Cafe Attack
description: The Italian police today charged a Lebanese-born Palestinian with having thrown two grenades into a Rome cafe on Monday, wounding 38 people.

title: Missing Rebel's Body Is Found in Costa Rica
description: The mutilated body of Dr. Hugo Spadafora, a colorful guerrilla fighter, was found this week in southern Costa Rica, according to reports from San Jose, the capital.

title: U.S. SEEKS PLANE COMPETITION
description: Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr., feeling the pinch of tightening budgets, has ordered engineering and procurement officials to study ways of injecting competition into the Navy's biggest aircraft contract, the F/A-18 Hornet fighter made by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, according to Pentagon officials and industry sources.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: COMMERCIAL INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $356,000. c-Net income. The company said results for the latest fiscal year include the results of Xenia Food Communications Inc. and Sachs Nut Co., following their acquisitions on July 25, 1984, and Sept. 7, 1984, respectively.

title: CONTACT IS MADE IN SALVADOR CASE
description: A little-known group has taken responsibility for kidnapping a daughter of President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador, according to two Government officials involved in the case.

title: Allied-Signal Celebrates Tie
description: The managements of the Allied Corporation and the Signal Companies, obviously pleased by the merger that will become final today, are planning a $3 million advertising effort to announce the existence of Allied-Signal and explain what it does.

title: SECRETARY IN KOHL'S OFFICE IN BONN IS SAID TO DEFECT TO EAST GERMANY
description: A secretary in Chancellor Helmut Kohl's office was reported today to have defected to East Germany with her husband, a senior official in a foundation close to one of West Germany's governing parties. Both are suspected of spying. The defection by the couple, Herbert Adolf Willner and Herta-Astrid Willner, was the latest in a chain of disappearances that has disclosed widespread penetration of Bonn's power centers by Communist agents.

title: RHODES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
SAGE ENERGY CO reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes writedowns of $16.5 million on the value of the company's drilling rigs and a writedown of $24 million from charges caused by reserve revisions and well abandonments. c-Net income.

title: Want a Job in Beirut?
description: The United States Ambassador to Lebanon, Reginald Bartholomew, will complete two years in that hazardous assignment next month, and the word in State Department circles is that he will soon be given another more pacific post. The day after Mr. Bartholomew arrived in Beirut in 1983, terrorists bombed the Marine garrison, killing 241 American servicemen; 11 months later, he was among those wounded in the car-bombing of the United States Embassy that ultimately claimed a dozen lives.

title: Bridge: Same Deal in Two Rooms Sometimes Varies Widely
description: Those who study the records of major matches expect to find some resemblance between the proceedings in the two rooms. But there are times when the researcher, scratching his head, is inclined to think that the deal has suffered a complete transformation between the open room and the closed room.

title: HARRIS CHASANOFF
description: Harris Chasanoff, a real-estate lawyer and a partner in Chasanoff Properties of Jericho, L.I., died at the Long Island Jewish-Hillside Medical Center Sunday. He was 78 years old and lived in Old Westbury, L.I.

title: CALNY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 13
PRAB ROBOTS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
U.N. GENERAL ASSEMBLY OPENS WITH HIGH HOPES AND HOST OF ISSUES
description: Facing a host of divisive issues ranging from the militarization of space to sanctions against South Africa, the United Nations General Assembly opened its 40th year of deliberations today. A United Nations spokesman said it was a welcome challenge.

title: PRIVATE SCREENINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
REAGAN DEFENDS FINANCING FOR AIDS
description: President Reagan, who has been accused of public indifference to the AIDS crisis by groups representing victims of the deadly disease, said last night that his Administration was already making a ''vital contribution'' to research on the disease within the limits imposed by ''budgetary restraints.''

title: Portec Deal Is Off
description: Portec Inc., a rail car and construction equipment company, said it had ended a $23.50-a-share leveraged buyout agreement with an investor group headed by an affiliate of Weiss, Peck & Greer, the New York investment firm. Portec also said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 1 million shares of its common stock; the company currently has 3.8 million shares outstanding. Portec also said the board had decided that management should continue to concentrate for the near-term on operations and consider selling portions of the company.

title: 7TH TRIDENT SUBMARINE STARTS SEA TRIALS TODAY
description: Pentagon officials said today that the Navy's seventh Trident-class nuclear missile submarine, the Alaska, will begin its sea trials on Wednesday in the Atlantic Ocean off Groton, Conn.

title: OPPENHEIMER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: Apartheid Assailed in Italy
description: About 3,000 members of religious, social and political groups marched through Rome today to protest the South African Government's policy of apartheid. The demonstrators ended the march in a square in the city's center, where leaders of the protest, including representatives of the Rome city council and labor unions, made speeches condemning Pretoria's policy of racial segregation.

title: Father Kills Son And Then Himself
description: A Jamestown man apparently stabbed his wife and killed his 10-month-old son today and then killed himself, the police said.

title: REAGAN AND THE COURTS
description: Like all members of the human race, members of the Supreme Court of the United States have birthdays. This is usually noted around here at the opening of the Court's autumn term, especially this week, on the 198th birthday of the Constitution, when Chief Justice Warren Burger of Minnesota and Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell of Virginia both turn 78.

title: $1 Million Bail Set In Hartford Theft
description: A Federal magistrate set bail at $1 million today for a Wells Fargo robbery defendant, Jorge Farinacci Garcia, ruling that the Government had failed to prove he was dangerous and would flee before trial.

title: Ex-F.B.I. Agent Backed At His Espionage Trial
description: The trial of Richard W. Miller, the first agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to be accused of espionage, heard testimony today tending to support his position that he was seeking to infiltrate the Soviet intelligence agency, the K.G.B.

title: AUBREY NIEL MORGAN
description: Aubrey Niel Morgan, a former British diplomat and patron of the arts who was a brother-in-law of the aviator Charles A. Lindbergh, died Saturday at his farm here.

title: MONARCH AVALON INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: PESTO MAY NO LONGER BE FASHIONABLE, BUT IT'S STILL VERSATILE
description: PESTO, which was all the rage just a few seasons ago, seems to have slipped quietly into the oblivion decreed for foods no longer faddish. This year's trend-following hosts and hostesses are scarcely able to mention its name, let alone pass it with a bowl of pasta. All is not lost, though. A mixture as flavorsome as this blend of basil, nuts, cheese and olive oil does not have to be the belle of the dining room. It can be just as captivating as a kitchen wallflower.

title: Cuomo Says He Doubts Ferraro Will Run
description: Governor Cuomo said he would be ''very surprised'' if former Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro decided to run for United States Senator next year.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: ROOKIES GET LESS IN N.F.L. COST CUTS
description: The idea was to reduce spending, and it worked. The 28 National Football League clubs paid out approximately 10.5 percent less to draft choices in 1985 than they did in 1984, according to league figures, and league officials believe the decrease could help keep more teams solvent in the years to come.

title: Contaminated Fish
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Advertising;   New Type Of Phone Campaign
description: BELL ATLANTIC, the Philadelphia-based communications company whose territory contains 14 percent of the nation's population and 3.5 percent of its land mass, is one of the seven operating companies that were created after divestiture by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. And when its first corporate ad campaign begins to run Sunday on television, it will be the last of the companies to go public with such advertising.

title: Georgia Bank's Interstate Deal
description: The Citizens and Southern Georgia Corporation said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the Citizens and Southern Corporation of South Carolina for about $400 million, or $55 a share.

title: ALFIN FRAGRANCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Thayer Loses Sentence Plea
description: A Federal District judge here has denied a motion by Paul Thayer, a former Deputy Secretary of Defense, and Billy Bob Harris, a Dallas stockbroker, to reduce their four-year prison sentences. The two had pleaded guilty to obstruction of justice charges.

title:
A WESTWAY TRADE-IN, OR NOT?;

No - Build The Road
description: The Westway plan for an interstate highway, a park and real estate development on the West Side has prevailed over the option to trade-in funds for other mass transit purposes through the administrations of four governors, three mayors and four Presidents. My organization, New York Citizens for Balanced Transportation, sees no reason why it should not continue to prevail - despite Governor Cuomo's indication yesterday that he will seek a trade-in if the Sept. 30 trade-in deadline is not extended. Westway remains no less essential to the city and state than it has been in the past.

title: Shoreham Resumes Tests at Low Power
description: Low-power testing at the Shoreham nuclear power plant resumed today after a five-day shutdown, according to a spokesman for the plant's owner, the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: 4 DECADES OF HISTORY IN '45/85'
description: ABC News sweeps up 40 years of history tonight. Where have we been, and where are we going? We were optimistic after World War II. Then we felt beleaguered. Old verities crumbled, and somehow we lost our way. For the most part, ''45/85'' suggests, this was because of our preoccupation with the Soviet Union, a nation we understood imperfectly. Apparently, the last four decades have been a learning process. ''45/85,'' three hours long, can be seen on Channel 7 starting at 8 P.M.

title: O'NEILL-MOFFETT RACE IS NEAR
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill and former United States Representative Toby Moffett set the stage today for a fight for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination in 1986.

title: GRIFFIN TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income The latest results are after research and development expenses of $319,200 for the quarter and $602,200 for the 6 months. The year-earlier results are after research and development expenses of $150,700 for the quarter and $300,700 for the 6 months.

title: Hotelier May Sell Big Stake
description: Severyn Ashkenazy, the real estate developer of luxury hotels such as L'Ermitage in Beverly Hills, said he might sell up to half of his growing hotel network to investors to shore up more than $100 million in delinquent loans on various properties.

title: Inco Incentives For Retirement
description: Inco Ltd. said 1,274 hourly employees eligible for the previously announced voluntary retirement program would be offered incentives of one week's pay for each completed year of paid employment, up to 26 years.

title: REAGAN RULES OUT DEAL WITH SOVIET ON SPACE WEAPONS
description: President Reagan tonight ruled out negotiations with the Soviet Union on the development and testing of his proposed missile defense in space in exchange for deep cuts in the Soviet nuclear arsenal.

title: Timeout in Title Chess Called by Kasparov
description: Gary Kasparov, the challenger for the world chess championship, took a timeout today, postponing for two days his sixth game with the titlist, Anatoly Karpov.

title: PRISM ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Chrysler Plan To Cut Costs
description: The Chrysler Corporation will try to reduce its operating costs by 30 percent by 1990 because of increased foreign competition, the company's president, Harold Sperlich, said today.

title: RAID BY PRETORIA DENOUNCED BY U.S.
description: A senior Reagan Administration official today denounced South Africa's military raid into Angola and suggested that it might violate international law.

title: PERFECT EGGS: HARD, SOFT OR IN-BETWEEN
description: PEOPLE who eat eggs for breakfast generally have unyielding preferences for how they should be cooked - soft, medium or hard. Thirty seconds one way or the other can make a vast difference in the results.

title: Ginsberg Takes 2-Shot Golf Lead
description: Roger Ginsberg of Muttontown, L.I., shot a three-under-par 67 and moved into first place with a 36-hole total of 136 in the $40,000 Izod Metropolitan P.G.A. championship today at the Country Club of Fairfield.

title: TANNER CONTRADICTS BERRA'S TESTIMONY
description: Chuck Tanner, the manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates, testified in United States District Court today that he never specifically warned Dale Berra to stay away from Curtis Strong, who is accused of selling cocaine to major league baseball players in Pittsburgh from 1980 to 1984.

title: Real Estate;   Replacing Seamen's Institute
description: JUST 18 years after it was built, one of New York's most distinctive structures is disappearing and will be replaced by a gleaming office tower twice as large and many times more expensive.

title: ANIMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income. c-After extraordinary gains of $31,000 for the quarter and $69,000 for the 9 months.

title: ALPINE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Travels With Deaver
description: Michael K. Deaver, who resigned as White House deputy chief of staff in May to open a public relations business, has proved to be more fortunate than most in building on his past associations and creating a thriving practice in short order in the highly competitive Washington arena.

title: 2 Captured in Killing Of Carolina Trooper
description: Two fugitives suspected of killing a rookie North Carolina trooper surrendered today when they were surrounded by bloodhounds and a posse of 300 people on a rugged mountain.

title: I.B.M. 'Very Discouraged' on South Africa
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, one of the leaders of the American business community in South Africa, said that unrest there ''is having a significant impact on I.B.M.'s South African business'' and added that it was ''very discouraged'' by the business and economic environment there.

title: Tonelli Misses First Practice
description: John Tonelli was the only player who played in every game for the Islanders last season, but he was the only player missing today when the team opened training camp at Cantiague Park.

title: PRESIDENT OF MOZAMBIQUE ASSERTS SOUTH AFRICANS STILL ASSIST REBELS
description: President Samora M. Machel of Mozambique, in a meeting with South Africa's Foreign Minister, has accused South Africa of ''seriously and repeatedly'' violating a nonaggression pact, the South African Press Association said today.

title: EMF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said revenue in 1985 included a partial recovery of a bad debt from AM International of $334,000.

title: Pilots' Union Tells Members To Seek Jobs at Continental
description: The Air Line Pilots Association is authorizing its members who are striking Continental Airlines to apply for an estimated 450 new jobs expected to open at the airline, the union's president said today.

title: FOR YOUNGSTERS, A TOUCHABLE TOY EXHIBIT
description: FOR as long as they please, young visitors to Philadelphia's Please Touch Museum can play with re-creations of toys from as far back as a century-and-a-half ago and with toys meant to represent playthings of the future. There are long calico dresses, aprons and sun bonnets hanging on convenient hooks in a Pennsylvania farmhouse setting, replete with a rag doll and a rocking horse chair.

title: ACAPULCO Y LOS ARCOS RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
Mississippi Refinancing $205 Million Road Issue
description: Mississippi is offering $205 million of highway revenue refunding bonds through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: PHYLLOXERA FOUND IN CALIFORNIA GRAPEVINES
description: The phylloxera aphid is attacking some vines in California areas thought previously to be largely immune to the insect, which devastated the vineyards of Europe in the 1870's. The regions affected include a small area in the Napa and Sonoma Valleys, north of San Francisco, and larger areas in Monterey County to the south.

title: DEBATE SPURS HEARINGS ON RATING ROCK LYRICS
description: A Senate committee begins hearings tomorrow on whether references to sex and violence in rock-and-roll lyrics should be regulated, in what is shaping up as the latest and most far-reaching battle between the makers of popular music and its detractors.

title: An Apology to Canada
description: Tom Niles, the United States Ambassador to Canada, has issued an apology to the Canadian people for the Yankee fans who booed the Canadian national anthem when it was sung before a game against the Toronto Blue Jays in Yankee Stadium last week. ''Most Americans, indeed most New Yorkers, were as deeply offended as were Canadians,'' the Ambassador said in a statement issued through the American Embassy in Ottawa. ''I hope,'' he continued, ''that Canadians realize that the booing reflected excessive partisan spirit in support of the home team and not any hostility to Canada.''

title: GREENPEACE ATTACK: MEMO IN MARCH, DEATH IN JULY
description: In late May, six weeks before an environmentalist group's ship was sunk by an explosion in New Zealand, Gerard Andries, an agent of the French intelligence agency, was noticed in London by the British secret service.

title: 200 Hospitalized in India
description: Nearly 200 high school girls were hospitalized for possible food poisoning after complaining of dizziness at Nedumangad, 18 miles from Trivandrum in southern India, the United News of India reported today. The cause of the apparent poisoning was unknown.

title: Mookie Wilson Hacks Away
description: It was little more than a week ago that Dave Johnson faced the decision about his center fielder for the rest of the season. It was either going to be Mookie Wilson, the incumbent recovering from shoulder surgery, or Len Dykstra, the scrappy rookie, who had kept the Mets in the pennant race for two months by getting on base and flopping on his belly like a baby otter in the outfield.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Greenmarket Problems A small but potentially significant controversy seems to be brewing over the Greenmarket held on Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays at the north end of Union Square. Now known as Union Place, the former parking lot area north of the park has been the site of one of the most popular farmers' markets in the city since 1976.

title: SYSTEMATICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Marathon Mixup
description: When Fred Lebow arrived in Rome a couple of weeks back for the I.A.A.F./Mobil Grand Prix track final, he received mixed news about one of the star attractions in next month's New York City Marathon, which he directs.

title: U.S. GRAND JURY TO OPEN PRESSER CASE INQUIRY
description: A new Federal grand jury will examine whether Government officials violated the law in their three-year investigation of Jackie Presser, the teamsters' union president, a Justice Department official said today.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Chicago Cubs at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Opener of two-game series. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs.

title: A QUIET FORCE IN CONTEMPORARY ART
description: A quiet man in a pin stripe suit has been making the rounds of art gallery openings, museum lectures and other season-opening art events, his unflamboyant manner belying that he is one of the key figures in the contemporary art world.

title: SOVIET ASTRONAUTS ROCKET INTO ORBIT
description: Three Soviet astronauts were launched into space today to join two others who had brought the Salyut 7 space station back to life over the summer after its batteries had failed.

title: For Young Classicists, a Silver Lining
description: To the Editor:

title: Avian Exotica
description: Parrots have been sighted in Central Park.

title: COMPUTERCRAFT INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
description: b-Net income.

title: Elbow Surgery for Sisk
description: Doug Sisk suffered another setback in his career, and perhaps a ruinous one, when bone chips were discovered yesterday in his right elbow. The Mets said the 27-year-old relief pitcher would undergo surgery within the week and would not pitch for six to nine months, and perhaps not at all next season.

title: Bills Sign Pair
description: Two players cut by the Cleveland Browns this summer have been picked up by the Buffalo Bills, one making a return appearance. The returnee is Joe DeLamiellure, 34 years old, who played guard for the Bills from 1973 to 1979, then was traded to Cleveland, where he spent the next five seasons.

title: STUDY FINDS KEY BEAM IN 63D ST. TUNNEL IS STRONG
description: A key girder in the 63d Street subway tunnel whose effectiveness has been in question is strong enough to support existing and future loads, a consultant studying the tunnel has concluded.

title: CURTIS M. HUTCHINS
description: Curtis M. Hutchins, a Maine industrialist who was chairman of the Dead River Company, which owns thousands of acres of forest in the state, died Sunday at the Eastern Maine Medical Center here of cardiac arrest caused by complications of a blood clot in an ankle. Mr. Hutchins was 78 years old.

title: AMERICA SPORTS ADVISORS reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
BRIEFS
description: * CIP Inc., a unit of Canadian Pacific Enterprises Ltd., said it plans to spend $44 million to upgrade its newsprint mill in Trois Rivieres, Quebec.

title: MOHAWK DATA SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE scene is the courtroom, Appellate Division, State Supreme Court, Second Department, Brooklyn Heights. A couple of hundred candidates for admission to the bar are assembling in a room already crowded with family and friends who have come for the swearing-in ceremony. As the last of the lawyers-to-be enter, one candidate looks up to notice a flake of gold leaf lazily wafting downward from the ornately decorated ceiling.

title: PUBLISHERS PLAN PANEL SESSION
description: Walter F. Mondale, the 1984 Democratic Presidential nominee, and Robert C. McFarlane, President Reagan's national security adviser, will discuss Mr. Reagan's second term Wednesday before the convention of the Southern Newspaper Publishers Association.

title: FOR NIEKROS, DREAM REALIZED
description: Joe Niekro remembered watching the game on television, following every pitch his brother threw in a failed attempt to win his 300th game in the big leagues last Friday night. And he remembered how disappointed he had been when a prior commitment kept him from attending the game in person.

title: COMING RIGHT UP
description: Immediately after waking, I turn on the TV set to see what is coming right up. There is always something or somebody fascinating coming right up.

title: METS DEFEATED, FALL TWO BACK
description: It always seems to happen on the night after Dwight Gooden does his thing. The Mets took another stumble in the stretch last night when they lost to Shane Rawley and the Philadelphia Phillies, 5-1, and fell two games behind the St. Louis Cardinals with only 18 to play.

title: Consumer Division Of Searle for Sale
description: The Monsanto Company and G. D. Searle & Company said today that the sale of Searle's domestic consumer products division was ''currently being explored.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Clyde Drexler, the former University of Houston star who has played two seasons with the Portland Trail Blazers, will get a two-year contract extension that will keep him with the team through the 1988-89 season. . . . The Philadelphia 76ers' No. 1 draft pick, Terry Catledge, a 6-8 forward from South Alabama, has signed a contract that his agent said was guaranteed for three years. . . . Pete Incaviglia, the Arizona State slugger who was chosen eighth by the Montreal Expos in the June draft, said he would pass up his last year of collegiate eligibility to prepare for a professional career. . . . Curtis Celestine, a 6-7 forward from Montreal, has enrolled at Iona, making him the third Canadian player to join the Gaels in the past two years. . . . Bob Weinhauer, the former Arizona State basketball coach, was named coach of the Detroit Spirits of the Continental Basketball Association, an appointment that had been expected. . . . The Tacoma Stars of the Major Indoor Soccer League have signed the former Cosmos forward Andrew Parkinson to a multiyear contract. He was the Cosmos' second-leading scorer last winter with 15 goals and 13 assists. . . . Joan Benoit will enter the marathon race in Chicago on Oct. 20, her first appearance in the event since she won the gold medal at the Los Angeles Olympics last summer.

title: ELK ASSOCIATES FUNDING CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
MEGADATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Q&A
description: Q.

title: The U.N. Today: Sept. 18, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY General Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: NUGGET OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
GENERATION GAP ADDS TENSION AMONG SOUTH AFRICAN BLACKS
description: It's a Saturday in Soweto and conflict seems inevitable.

title: An Emblem Is an Emblem Is an Emblem
description: There could be a few thorns along the way, but prospects are now, well, rosy that the nation will soon have an official flower: The rose.

title: MINERAL WATER FROM GEORGIA BEING BOTTLED
description: Mineral-rich water from a spring that was once known for its supposed curative powers is being bottled for sale again for the first time in almost 50 years.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE food most widely praised by French chefs who have visited the United States within the past 20 years is, without question, lamb. Although the texture of American lamb is first-rate, it is the flavor that gives it an exceptional appeal.

title: STUDY WEIGHS PROBLEMS IN STAMFORD EXPANSION
description: After 15 years of business expansion that has made Stamford one of the nation's most highly concentrated centers of corporate offices, the growth of the city and its surrounding towns shows few signs of slowing down, according to a detailed analysis released today.

title: AKRON DOCTOR GOES ON TRIAL IN 'RIGHT TO DIE' CASE
description: Opening arguments were heard here today in the trial of a doctor who refused to disconnect a terminally ill woman from a respirator at her family's request.

title: TRADE BOOK EXECUTIVE IS NAMED
description: Joni Evans, who started her publishing career as a reader in the fiction department of McCall's and Ladies Home Journal, has been named president of the trade book division of Simon & Schuster.

title: DWG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a gain from discontinued operatons of $44,000 and an extraordinary credit of $202,000. c-Net income. Latest quarter includes the results of Royal Crown Cos. on a consolidated basis.

title: CARDINALS WIN SIXTH STRAIGHT
description: Ozzie Smith hit a three-run homer, and Cesar Cedeno and Willie McGee added two-run drives as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Pirates, 10-4, tonight.

title: PARIS PAPER SAYS THE FRENCH SANK GREENPEACE BOAT
description: A leading French newspaper reported today that the sinking of the anti-nuclear protest vessel Rainbow Warrior was the work of French military divers, and that the Defense Minister apparently had approved the operation.

title: Regulatory Bill Advances
description: The House voted today to expand the regulation of government securities dealers by creating a new agency under the Federal Reserve Board.

title: ROCHES' ALBUM STRIKES A NEW NOTE
description: ''ANOTHER WORLD,'' the fourth Warner Brothers album in six years by the Roches, represents a striking stylistic departure for the New York-based folk singing and songwriting trio. The record is their first serious attempt to accommodate the tastes of top-40 radio, a medium that, despite widespread critical acclaim for the Roches, has so far resisted their charm. Instead of emphasizing individual quirks, the vocal arrangements on the new album favor a sweetly homogenized blend, and the instrumentation makes liberal use of drum machines and synthesizers.

title: Yes - for Transit
description: Now is the time for Mayor Koch, Governor Cuomo and New York's senators to remember their obligations to ordinary New Yorkers and to forget their obligations to the real estate promoters, bankers and con-tractors, Big Labor bosses and power brokers. Now is the time to reverse themselves on Westway - as Mr. Cuomo indicated yesterday he might have to do - and accept trade-in.

title: The Mideast's Young Antagonists
description: To the Editor:

title: SHAPIRO CAMPAIGNING ON RECORD OF INNOVATIONS AS ESSEX COUNTY EXECUTIVE
description: Peter Shapiro, the Democratic candidate for governor, stood on the steps of the State House in Trenton the other day and promised, if elected, to give New Jersey homeowners a 15 percent reduction in their property taxes with ''no ifs, ands or buts, no fine print and no gimmicks.''

title: A 'Do As We Do' Move
description: When the Reagan Administration and the A.F.L.-C.I.O. are found on the same side of an issue, it is usually worth noting. The labor federation has maintained for years that the United States should ratify conventions adopted by the International Labor Organization, particularly when they involve stands like those against slavery and for equal opportunity, but the Administration has opposed such action on the ground that it could result in international interference with Federal and state laws.

title: Restocking Sought In Loss of Scallops
description: A Suffolk County Legislator today proposed transplanting young scallops from New England into Peconic Bay, where the scallop population has been devastated by an algal bloom.

title: Thai Ex-Prime Minister Held in Coup Attempt
description: A former Prime Minister, the deputy supreme military commander and three former army officers were arrested today and charged in connection with an attempted coup on Sept. 9.

title: EX-NAVY DOCTOR TELLS OF FATALITY
description: A retired Navy doctor charged today that Comdr. Donal M. Billig, a Navy heart surgeon accused of involuntary manslaughter in the deaths of four patients, used a ''rough technique'' and ''sacrificed accuracy for speed'' in operations he performed at the Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md.

title: WISCONSIN INSURER MAY EXCLUDE AIDS COVERAGE
description: To combat a rising number of health claims by victims of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, Wisconsin's largest insurance companies may begin excluding coverage of the disorder, company executives said today.

title: GUIDRY YIELDS 5 TIGER HOMERS
description: The voice belonged to Billy Martin, but it was subdued and unusually restrained. Not feisty. Not stubborn. Not at all like Billy Martin.

title: OPERA: 'CENERENTOLA' CAST CHANGES
description: THE City Opera's ''Cenerentola'' cast Sunday afternoon had two newcomers - William Parker, singing Dandini for the first time with the company, and Susanne Marsee, whose familiar Cinderella has not yet been noted in these pages this season.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL CLEVELAND (NBA) - Placed Kevin Williams, guard, on waivers.

title: Rates Mixed; Auctions Put Off
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday as the credit markets were beset by uncertainty over the schedule of Treasury financings.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''With the state of emergency in effect, and violence and repression affecting the lives of so many South Africans, we believe the South African Government must be held publicly accountable for its actions.'' - Sondra McCarty, a State Department spokesman. [A11:1.]

title: OPTO MECHANIK INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
New York Job-Training Programs' Best Friend
description: To the Editor:

title: Contain the Futures Future
description: Thousands of unsophisticated investors have been conned in recent years by smooth-talking salesmen bearing promises of easy money in precious metals and currencies: profits in gold and silver, guaranteed . . . Make millions with pennies in yen and marks. Ordinary brokers face regulatory discipline for such tricks. But through some fancy political footwork, a small group of securities sellers known as leveraged contract merchants have evaded effective oversight.

title: Mexican Demonstrators Set Fire to a Town Hall
description: Demonstrators protesting what they said were fraudulent elections set fire Monday to the town hall in Agua Prieta, opposite Douglas, Ariz., and overturned and burned several cars, officials said.

title: DR. WILLIAM WILLCOX, A HISTORIAN
description: Dr. William B. Willcox, a historian and editor of the papers of Benjamin Franklin at Yale University, died of cancer Sunday at his home in North Haven, Conn.

title: Consumer Debt Up In July
description: Americans took on $6.25 billion more in installment debt than they paid off in July, up by more than $1 billion from June, the Government said today.

title: Pope Might Visit U.S. In 1987, Bishops Say
description: The Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States said today that Pope John Paul II might visit America in the fall of 1987.

title: Hanson's Appeal To Be Expedited
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Manhattan agreed yesterday to expedite an appeal by Hanson Trust P.L.C., the British conglomerate, in its battle with the SCM Corporation. Hanson has been barred by a lower court from buying stock in SCM or voting the 3.1 million SCM shares that it bought hours after pulling out of a takeover battle for the company.

title: SPECIALIZED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 18, 1985
description: International

title: ENERGY OPTICS INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: A COVETED RECIPE FOR PICKLED LOX IS OUT OF THE BARREL
description: OVER the four days ending yesterday, which included the Rosh ha-Shanah holiday, about 7,200 portions of pickled lox were served at the Concord Resort Hotel in Kiamesha Lake, N.Y. Listed on the menu as ''Fillet of marinated lox with Concord cream sauce and onion platter, sliced tomato,'' pickled lox is the most popular of the 120 or so dishes regularly served at the hotel. It is more popular than the matzoh ball soup or the chopped liver. Long ago it passed the pickled herring for these honors.

title: Letter: On Dairy Price Supports;   Don't Pull the Rug From Under Farmers
description: To the Editor:

title: Problems Continue
description: Although not signed, John (Hot Rod) Williams, the former Tulane basketball star, has been working out informally with the Cleveland Cavaliers, but his legal problems in New Orleans may not be over. The office of Harry Connick, the New Orleans District Attorney, said that an appeal would be filed today in an effort to bring Williams back to trial on charges of sports bribery in connection with the Tulane point-shaving scandal.

title: JAPANESE PANCAKES: FAST-FOOD FAVORITE
description: AMERICAN pancake aficionados, accustomed to flapjacks slathered with butter and saturated with maple syrup, might consider a cuttlefish and cabbage griddlecake an unlikely culinary combination. In Japan, however, okonomiyaki - thick, Frisbee-size pancakes full of vegetables and seafood or meat - are a savory fast-food favorite. They are sold by street vendors, cooked in home kitchens and eaten at convivial restaurants, where customers can gather around a griddle and create their own custom-made mixtures.

title: REALTY INCOME TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Dr. Borrow-and-Spend
description: When President Reagan took office denouncing the national debt, it hadn't quite reached $1 trillion. In the next 12 months it will pass $2 trillion -$2,000,000,000,000 and still counting. The man who regularly decries ''tax-and-spend'' Democrats has, in less than five years, earned his Ph.D. in the art of borrow-and-spend. Under current conditions, borrow-and-spend is worse.

title: UPSTATE TEEN-AGER CHARGED WITH MURDERING HIS FAMILY
description: A 17-year-old honor student stabbed his parents and younger brother to death Monday night, fled the murder scene in a family car and then crashed into another auto, killing the driver, the police said today.

title: CITY CONTINUES TO GAIN JOBS, MAYOR REPORTS
description: Employment in New York City is continuing to grow and residents of the city are reaping the benefits, Mayor Koch reported yesterday.

title: Peculiar Hesitation On Krugerrand Ban
description: To the Editor:

title: Hand Disorder
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: NATIONAL DATA COMMUNICAIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The losses in both latest periods include a $851,524 loss from the writeoff of obsolete computer equipment.

title: TOSCA & CO. INSPIRE TOPS AND TOWELS
HEAD OF WESTWOOD ONE ELATED BY MUTUAL DEAL
description: Norman Pattiz, chairman and chief executive of Westwood One Inc., says he feels ''absolutely terrific'' about his company's agreement this week to buy the operations of the Mutual Broadcasting System from the Amway Corporation.

title: COGENIC ENERGY SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
No Time to Gloat For Ken Moffett
description: One day early last year, during the winter after the St. Louis Cardinals had shipped Keith Hernandez to the Mets, Ken Moffett gave a talk to a sports-journalism seminar in Washington. Only three months before, Moffett had been dismissed as executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, in part because of an internal split over how to address the sport's drug epidemic. Now he took up the drug issue again, saying that some of the union's player representatives believed there were ''four or five'' regular users per club. And, in a lengthy anecdote, he left a clear impression that, at least in his own mind, both Hernandez and Doug Bair had been traded by St. Louis the previous June because of cocaine use.

title: INTERDYNE CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-The company said it had no sales in both year-ago periods.

title: EARL R. FORD
description: Earl R. Ford, an architect, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 62 years old.

title: AIDS Drug Approved For Experimental Use
description: The Government has approved the experimental use in the United States of an anti-AIDS drug that has been available only in France, a spokesman confirmed today.

title: DANCE: TRISHA BROWN OPENS AT CITY CENTER
description: THOSE who did not frequent the downtown precincts of experimental dance activity in the 1960's and 70's might not have caught the dancer and choreographer Trisha Brown at her most rebellious.

title: A New Regimen For Rangers' Camp
description: First, they underwent ''fitness assessment,'' then ''equipment issue'' and then the hockey players ran around the parking lot. The regimen had begun.

title: United Faces U.S. Curb On Pacific Route Deal
description: United Airlines' ambitious plan to become a major trans-Pacific carrier suffered a setback yesterday from the Justice Department, which said the proposed acquisition of routes from Pan American World Airways would reduce competition substantially.

title: MUBARAK HOPEFUL ON TABA ISSUE
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said today that progress had been made toward resolving Egypt's dispute with Israel over the territory known as Taba.

title: GENESEE COMPUTER CENTER reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Political Memo;   Slouching Toward the Center (Post-Reagan)
description: Nothing is forever in politics, not even the political alignments wrought by the alchemy of President Reagan.

title: A Casino Agrees To Close for a Day
description: The Caesars Hotel Casino has agreed to a one-day closing as a penalty for careless dealings with a Canadian banker who lost millions of dollars of embezzled money at the gaming hall, state regulators said today.

title: PALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
New Captains for the Port
description: At a weighty public dinner some years ago, S. Sloan Colt, a banker and chairman of the Port Authority board, rose to address his black-tie audience. ''Good evening, boss,'' he said to the Governor of New York, seated on his right.

title: CORRECTION
description: An editorial yesterday attributed the phrase ''dumbing down'' of textbooks to Education Secretary William Bennett. The term comes from his predecessor, T.H. Bell.

title: U.S. 'Ready' to Reopen Cuba Immigration Pact
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the Reagan Administration was ''ready'' on ''short notice'' to reactivate an immigration agreement with Cuba that was terminated by Fidel Castro.

title: Phibro Is Offering First Oil Warrants
description: The first public offering of crude oil warrants was announced yesterday by Phibro-Salomon Brothers.

title: Over the River
description: What its developers describe as the first enclosed shopping mall in the country with nothing but discount, off-price and factory outlet stores is to open tomorrow in Woodbridge, Va., a suburb of the capital. Called Potomac Mills, it will initially occupy 87 acres of enclosed space, with 50 stores now and 32 more in March; later, 46 more acres of space will add 88 more stores. To help compenstate for the fact that it is about 20 miles from the capital (''30 minutes from the White House'' is the advertised claim), the mall will include an Elvis Presley Museum licensed by the singer's estate, exhibiting a wide range of his property including two white Lincoln Continentals.

title: ATTEMPT TO REOPEN A SCHOOL IS BARRED
description: The police arrested scores of high school teachers, students and their parents today after they sought to reopen one of over 400 schools closed down by the South African authorities earlier this month.

title: REAGAN OBJECTS TO A PROVISION IN HOUSE FARM BILL
description: President Reagan is likely to veto the farm bill sent to the House floor, Republican Congressional leaders said today, because he objects to a provision that would establish new means of protecting incomes of farmers and subsidizing exports of crops.

title: WINE TALK
description: It's harvest time in the Beaujolais region and, in contrast with rather depressing news from neighboring Burgundy recently, Beaujolais appears to be in good shape in terms both of quantity and quality. Georges Duboeuf, the best known of the Beaujolais shippers, said last week that while quantity would be average or a little less than average, quality should range from very good to excellent. The average production in Beaujolais is about 1.5 million hectoliters or about 40 million gallons of wine a year.

title: ARO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a credit of $2.7 million, or $1.12 a share, for deferred taxes for the company's domestic international sales corp.

title: CREWS CLEANING UP OIL SPILLED BY SHIP OFF S.I.
description: Cleanup crews worked throughout the day to soak up an estimated 80,000 gallons of fuel oil that had spilled from a Polish freighter into the Kill Van Kull off Staten Island.

title: COMPUTER DEPOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
NEW-PARENT LEAVE: U.S. LAG ASSAILED
description: More than 100 countries provide paid, job-protected time off to new mothers, but the United States is not among them. A diverse group of lobbyists is joining forces to try to change that.

title: Venetian Rosh ha-Shanah
description: On the first night of Rosh ha-Shanah in Venice, two dozen New Yorkers found that the same impulse had brought them together in a tiny square quite a bit off the tourist path.

title: AS GOODEN KEEPS ROLLING, 'THERE'S NO STOPPING HIM'
description: ''I've caught a lot of good pitchers,'' Gary Carter was saying last night at Shea Stadium, searching for comparisons, ''but Doc's in a class by himself. It's remarkable. He's only 20 years old. If he stays healthy, nothing is beyond his reach.''

title: Vote Fraud Retrials Planned
description: A United States Attorney, Frank Donaldson, says he will seek retrials in two voter fraud cases that ended with divided juries. Mr. Donaldson said Monday that his office intended to prosecute Mayor James Colvin of Union and Bobbie Nell Simpson of Forkland, a deputy registrar. He declined to discuss the cases further. A mistrial in Mayor Colvin's case came Sept. 4 after one juror held out for a not guilty verdict. Mrs. Simpson was acquitted of one count Friday but a Federal jury could not reach agreement on 10 other vote fraud charges against her.

title: ENERGY CAPITAL DEVELOPENT reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
MAKING CITY MORE COURTEOUS, A NASTY TASK
description: ''I have always considered courtesy a sign of weakness.'' - Buford Davis, a former cabdriver selling hot dogs yesterday on a midtown street corner.

title: MEXICAN DEMONSTRATORS SET FIRE TO A TOWN HALL
description: Demonstrators protesting what they said were fraudulent elections set fire Monday to the town hall in Agua Prieta opposite Douglas, Ariz., and overturned and burned several cars, officials said.

title: Goldman Recruits Another Professor
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company, a busy recruiter of college professors in recent months, announced yesterday that it had hired Richard W. Roll, a faculty member at the Graduate School of Management of the University of California at Los Angeles. Mr. Roll will serve as a vice president in the mortgage securities department.

title: EX-JUNTA LEADERS ACCUSED IN DEATHS
description: Government prosecutors charged nine former military leaders today with having been ''desk authors'' of the disappearance of more than 9,000 Argentines in the late 1970's and early 80's.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: A dispatch from Jerusalem on Aug. 30 reported Israel's announcement that it had captured a yacht carrying an American, an Australian and six Palestinian guerrillas. The article said the army did not produce evidence to support its assertion that the guerrillas were members of Al Fatah, the organization headed by Yasir Arafat.

title: NEW CAR-BOMBING IN SOUTH LEBANON
description: A car bomb exploded today at an outpost of the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army, killing or wounding 30 militiamen, Government television said.

title: Really Upset
description: Peter Fleming assesses his dismal play after losing to 19-year-old Brad Pearce at a Los Angeles tennis tournament: ''It was like mixed singles out there.''

title: Argentine Tower Bombed
description: A bomb today seriously damaged a replica of London's Big Ben clock tower, a frequent target of Argentine nationalist groups who oppose British occupation of the Falkland Islands. The police said the blast occurred inside the six-story brick tower and hurled a heavy metal door more than 25 yards, badly damaged balconies and masonry coats of arms, cracked one wall and broke all the windows.

title: VOTERS IN OREGON DEFEATING PROPOSAL FOR STATES SALES TAX
description: Oregon voters today continued their long-standing opposition to a state sales tax, defeating a proposed 5 percent tax by a 4-to-1 margin in a special election that drew a heavy turnout, early returns showed.

title: MACY, R H & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: The company said the latest year had 53 weeks, compared with 52 weeks in 1984.

title: SUPPORTERS OF WESTWAY PLAN A POSSIBLE TRADE-IN
description: Governor Cuomo, Mayor Koch and New York's two Senators agreed today to trade in Federal funds for Westway if they failed in an effort to win more time in Congress to try to save the highway, a spokesman for the Governor said.

title: NEW CBS WEDNESDAY NIGHT LINEUP
description: CBS isn't fooling around with Wednesday evenings. The network's prime-time schedule, from 8 to 11 P.M., has been completely redecorated with new series. The new ornaments range from silly farce, based on a hit movie, to vigilante justice, television action-adventure-style.

title: CHINA SHAKE-UP: TRIUMPH FOR DENG
description: When dozens of high-ranking Chinese officials raised their open palms on Monday and voted for their own retirement, they were acting out a scenario devised years before by an aging man tramping around his vegetable patch in a muddy army barracks.

title: FOODARAMA SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: b-Includes a charge of $307,000 to settle a lawsuit and a writedown of vacant land. c-Includes a gain of $574,000 on the sale of a store and the $307,000 charge. d-Net loss In the year-ago 9 months, 16 of 18 New Jersey stores were struck by meat cutters from Jan. 15 to Feb. 13.

title: Lufthansa Buys 10 Boeing Planes
description: Lufthansa, the airline owned by the West German Government, said that it had signed a contract to buy 10 Boeing 737-300 jetliners to be delivered in the second half of 1986.

title: SOFTGUARD SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The company was incorporated Aug. 4, 1983 so the results for the year- earlier period are from that date to June 30, 1984.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HARLEM LAUGHS Small's Paradise has been renowned for decades for its live presentations of jazz. Recently, in addition to its music programs, Small's has introduced ''Comedy Wednesdays,'' a weekly feature. From 7 to 10 P.M., a host of comedians - most of them minorities, some well-known, some aspiring - offer what the management describes as ''family oriented'' performances, meaning that the gutter humor with which some popular comics are identified is prohibited.

title: HELDOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: DANNERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $916,000 on the disposition of specialty divisions.

title: MEESE SEES RACISM IN HIRING GOALS
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d today compared supporters of racial employment quotas to Americans who once argued ''that slavery was good not only for the slaves but for society.''

title: CONAGRA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 25
Lure to Private Firms To Help the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: DIVI HOTELS N V reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
LODGISTIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Jordan Leaves Hospital
description: Hamilton Jordan, diagnosed last week as having cancer of the lymph system, has volunteered for experimental treatment at the National Cancer Institute in Bethesda, Md. Mr. Jordan, White House chief of staff under President Carter, checked out of Emory Hospital on Monday night and left today for Maryland.

title: KILLEARN PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SCREEN: FROM RUSSIA, 'RUTHLESS ROMANCE'
description: WEALTH figures prominently in the workings of ''Ruthless Romance,'' a Soviet film whose various characters are led astray by the prospects of marrying well. This theme may be traditional - the film is based on ''The Dowerless Bride,'' Alexander Ostrovsky's 19th-century play - but the writer and director, Eldar Ryazanov, still manages to approach it with a degree of ingenuousness. The result is an elaborate costume drama, extremely lavish by Soviet standards, that means to evince astonishment at the ways in which money corrupts.

title: STUDYING NEW YORK CHILDREN AT PLAY
description: KHADIJAH SHAHEED, 27 years old, stood outside the Marcy housing project in Brooklyn, shaking her head in puzzlement at the children playing a sidewalk game with bottle caps. Although she had known the game as a child, some of the rules were different now. And the bottle caps were weighted with candle wax, not the melted crayons that kids had used in her day.

title: Ticor Rebuffed
description: A proposal by the Ticor Mortgage Insurance Company to bail out the troubled Equity Programs Investment Corporation was rejected yesterday by the largest investors in Equity Programs obligations. The investors include the Federal National Mortgage Association and seven institutional investors. The Ticor proposal, made last week, calls for a restructuring of Equity Programs mortgages and mortgage securities under which investors in those obligations would receive lower interest.

title: THE ESSENCE OF A LANDMARK: BEAUTY, HISTORY OR CHARACTER?
description: Never mind that the Algonquin Hotel's marquee and awnings are not the originals. This was where Edna Ferber and Dorothy Parker and Alexander Woollcott gathered to be seen and to be catty. And what, the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission was asked yesterday, could make for a more appropriate New York landmark?

title: Reprieve Ends
description: The former Madison Square Church Mission House at 432 Third Avenue is falling again. This time, it is doing so with the city's permission.

title: COOPERBIOMEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $4,157,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes a net gain of $613,000 from the sale of its HLA product line to a subsidiary of the SmithKline Beckman Corp. d-Net income

title: HEALTH
description: THE special pain of being a fat child in a world that worships thinness is hard for many adults to appreciate. Although a significant percentage of overweight children are not unhappy and participate unimpeded in normal childhood activities, many others suffer the censure of their peers, their parents and even themselves.

title: Market Place;   Middle South Gains Support
description: MIDDLE SOUTH UTILITIES INC. offers the latest example of what some Wall Street analysts call ''nuclear shock.'' Pressed by severe liquidity problems, the holding company whose four subsidiaries supply electricity in Arkansas, Louisiana, Mississippi and Missouri omitted its third-quarter dividend in late August. And the price of its stock has plunged by more than 35 percent since July.

title: APPLE COMPUTER ENTREPRENEUR'S RISE AND FALL
description: In his years of guiding Apple Computer Inc., Steven P. Jobs had become the epitome of the American entrepreneur, a symbol of the wealth and power that can arise almost overnight in California's Silicon Valley.

title: STATE CONTROL SOUGHT FOR INDIANA LICENSE OFFICES
description: Gov. Robert D. Orr has asked Indiana lawmakers to pass legislation that would have the state take over operation of the politically controlled motor vehicle license branch offices by July 1988.

title: Noel, Noel
description: The frost is not even on the pumpkin hereabouts, but one of the earliest harbingers of Christmas, the Smithsonian Institution's fall gift catalogue, has made its appearance. One new offering is a Smithsonian exclusive: video cassettes of ''To Fly,'' the 27-minute film that has delighted audiences at the National Air and Space Museum for years, for $29.95. Only 100 days left.

title: Welcome Program For Homosexuals
description: Newcomers usually have to learn about New York life the hard way, through experiences that may be confusing and frustrating. If the newcomer is homosexual, those experiences can be frightening and dangerous as well.

title: Stocks Mixed as Dow Gains 2.24
description: Stock prices closed mixed yesterday on Wall Street in somewhat heavy trading. The Dow Jones industrial average gained just enough to crawl over the 1,300 technical support level.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption yesterday in Metropolitan Report misidentified a croquet player. He was Maurice Marsac.

title: UTILITIES AGREE TO ABSORB PORTION OF OVERRUNS FOR UPSTATE A-PLANT
description: The five utilities building the Nine Mile 2 nuclear plant in upstate New York have agreed to absorb at least $900 million in construction overruns, state officials said yesterday evening.

title: COLAVITA NAMED HEAD OF STATE G.O.P.
description: New York Republicans unanimously chose the party's Westchester County chairman, Anthony J. Colavita, as their state chairman today and applauded when he promised to lead a strong campaign to beat Governor Cuomo.

title: VICORP RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 4
Prince Needs Privacy, Palace Tells the Press
description: The Prince and Princess of Wales have asked the press and television to allow their first-born son the chance to begin his schooldays in the most normal circumstances possible.

title: Sandinista Atrocities Charged by a Defector
description: A Nicaraguan defector who said he worked for Interior Minister Tomas Borge asserted today that large numbers of peasants and Miskito Indians had been killed by the Government because of suspicion that they might join United States-backed rebel forces.

title: Colorado Will Track AIDS Virus Carriers
description: The Colorado Board of Health today decided to begin keeping a list of people who test positive for the AIDS virus. It was apparently the first time a state agency had taken such a step on acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

title: INITIO INC reports earnings for 13wks to Aug 31
SUPERMAGNET DESIGN CHOSEN FOR A 60-MILE ATOM SMASHER
description: Federal scientists yesterday took the first major step toward the construction of what they say will be the biggest and costliest pure science project in history: an atom smasher so big it would encircle an area the size of New York City.

title: SENATE VOTES EMERGENCY TOXIC CHEMICAL PROGRAM
description: The Senate voted today to create a new program to cope with chemical emergencies of the kind that killed more than 2,000 people last December in Bhophal, India. The measure is part of a bill to renew and enlarge the toxic waste cleanup program that is expected to come to a vote Thursday.

title: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, 1985
description: International

title: Vietnam to Display in China
description: In November, Vietnam will display goods in a Chinese exhibition for the first time since the late 1970's, a Vietnamese diplomat said today.

title: NIEKRO FAILS AGAIN IN BID FOR 300TH, 5-2
description: Phil Niekro had left 70 passes for the game. His mother had come from Lansing, Ohio, and his wife from Atlanta. His sister was in the stands. His brother was on the Yankee bench. Relatives had come from all over Michigan to watch him pitch.

title: 202 DATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
C. W. Post Partly Open
description: Some part-time teachers began teaching their classes today, as the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University held its strike-delayed opening. A total of 360 full-time faculty members walked off the job 10 days ago and remain on strike. Frank Bianco, a spokesman for the striking Collegial Federation, said the union did not object, because the courses taught by the part-timers were not those taught by the strikers.

title: SUPER VALU STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 7
description: b-After a $433,000 loss from discontinued operations. c-After a gain of $23,877,000 from discontinued operations.

title: More Important Than Money
description: It was not a benefit. Raising funds never came up. Nobody even made a speech.

title: SEMTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: GODDESS: The Secret Lives of Marilyn Monroe. By Anthony Summers. 415 pages. Illustrated. Macmillan. $18.95. ANTHONY SUMMERS, a veteran journalist formerly with the BBC and now living in Ireland, has a habit of taking worn-out subjects and making them seem fresh and alive again. He did it in his first book, ''The File on the Tsar,'' about the disappearance of the last Russian imperial family. He did it again in ''Conspiracy,'' an account of the assassination of President John F. Kennedy and its investigation that appeared nearly 17 years after the event. And now he has done it again, most effectively of all, in ''Goddess: The Secret Lives of Marilyn Monroe,'' a biography of the film star that focuses its harshest light on the circumstances surrounding her death by apparent suicide on Aug. 4, 1962.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN POLICE KILL 2 PEOPL IN CAPE TOWN MIXED-RACE AREAS
description: Two people, including a 10-year-old boy, were shot dead by the police in mixed-race areas here today, while near Pretoria policemen fought with demonstrators after the funeral of a 3-year-old victim of earlier police attacks.

title: Rail System in Need of Conrail-Style Repair
description: To the Editor:

title: Peru Ousts 2 Generals After Peasant Massacre
description: The Joint Armed Forces Command said today that soldiers massacred about 40 Andean peasants last month.

title: WALL STREET AWAITS VIDEO WUNDERKIND
