description: In recent years, successful start-up companies in hot new industries have been raising bigger and bigger bundles of cash for themselves and their founders by selling shares to the public. It happened in personal computers with Apple Computer, in computer software with Lotus Development and in biotechnology with Genentech.

title: PERSONAL TRIUMPHS IN AN 86-0 DEFEAT
description: In those final moments before the first game of their football season, the Mounties of Eastern Oregon State College talked about hope and surprises. They were about to take the short walk from their dressing room at Montana State to Reno H. Sales Stadium, to play the defending Division I-AA champion of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: MARK IV INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The figures for the latest second quarter include the results of LFE Corp., acquired June 1, and the figures for the latest six months include LFE results for the latest second quarter only.

title: NEW YORK WOMAN IS ELECTED TO KEY POST IN ELECTRICAL UNION
description: The United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America elected a woman as secretary-treasurer yesterday, marking one of the few times a woman has advanced to such a high position in a United States labor union.

title: Plan to Control Growth In San Francisco Signed
description: Mayor Dianne Feinstein signed San Francisco's new downtown plan Tuesday, imposing the toughest planning restrictions of any city in the nation.

title: Democrats Lose Their Way
description: The Democratic Party's success over the past 50 years has been due in large part to its advocacy of a positive, large-minded agenda. Yet on several fronts -particularly international trade policy - Democrats are now in danger of reversing their role.

title: British Put Onus on Soviet
description: Prime Minister Thatcher, who is visiting Egypt, was quoted today as having said that the expulsions ''show the Soviet Union in a pretty poor light.''

title: Airbus Favored In Indian Purchase
description: Europe's Airbus Industrie appears to be winning a battle with the Boeing Company for a billion-dollar contract with Indian Airlines, a senior aviation official said.

title: NEW TEACHERS GET A PAY RISE OF 38% IN NEW YORK CITY
description: Starting salaries for New York City teachers will rise immediately by nearly $4,000, to $18,500, as part of a new contract announced yesterday by an arbitration panel. The most experienced teachers will also receive large increases.

title: Pryor Emerges
description: Aaron Pryor, the International Boxing Federation junior welterweight champion who had been the object of a search by boxing officials concerned that he may have succumbed to cocaine addiction, surfaced in Cincinnati, asserting that he was drug-free and ready to defend his crown.

title: BEHIND REED'S CITICORP SHUFFLE
description: In his announcement yesterday of a reorganization of top management, John S. Reed, Citicorp's chairman of one year, indicated that he was trying to make the world's largest, and possibly most powerful, banking organization a considerably more harmonious and conciliatory institution.

title: A New Adler Symphony
description: ''The Lady Remembers,'' a new symphony composed by Richard Adler in honor of the Statue of Liberty, will have its world premiere on Oct. 28 at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington.The concert, by the Detroit Symphony, will mark the start of a yearlong celebration of the statue's centennial in 1986. Mr. Adler has composed other symphonic pieces and Broadway musicals, including the music and lyrics for ''Pajama Game'' with Jerry Ross.

title: BRITISH-SOVIET OUSTERS
description: As the dust settled on the six-day diplomatic shootout between Britain and the Soviet Union over charges of espionage, the most striking aspect was Moscow's resolute and unexpectedly sharp reaction.

title: 8 Cases of AIDS Among U.N. Employees
description: Eight cases of AIDS have been identified among United Nations staff members in the last four years and four deaths from it occurred, the organization said today.

title: UNILEVER CONTESTS NEW STOCK
description: Unilever N.V., the big Dutch-British company, accused Richardson-Vicks Inc., the maker of Vicks cold remedies, in court yesterday of discriminating against shareholders and helping the Richardson family, founders of the company, to further entrench themselves.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE BRISTOL-MYERS COMPANY-William Robert Miller, vice chairman of the board, bought and exercised options of 17,591 shares giving him directly a balance of 46,753 shares.

title: CREDIBILITY OF WITNESS FOR DEFENSE AT ISSUE IN CALIFORNIA SPYING TRIAL
description: The first defense witness at Richard W. Miller's espionage trial acknowledged today that he paid $1,000 to the defendant, a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, to obtain information, a transaction the prosecution portrayed as a bribe.

title: RARE PAINTINGS RESTORED IN NANTUCKET
description: PERCHED on top of a scaffold on the altar of Nantucket's Old South Church, the decorative painting restorer Darla Olson carefully chisels away loose plaster to expose the faint image of a column painted on the back wall.

title: Roots of the Malpractice Insurance Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Details of Equity Pact With Regional Theaters
description: Details of the new contract between Actors Equity and the League of Resident Theaters have been released. A tentative accord was reached two weeks ago, but by mutual agreement no details were released until the pact was approved by memberships of the union and the theater association.

title: Roots of the Malpractice Insurance Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: AEROSONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
I.R.S. STEPPING UP PRESSURE ON CHEATS
description: The growing failure of American people to pay their income taxes has prompted a drive by the Internal Revenue Service to improve its ability to identify and prosecute tax cheats, according to Roscoe L. Egger Jr, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue.

title: HERS
description: MIRROR, mirror on the wall suggested that it was time to revive the looks, and since I am apprehensive of the knife, I took myself to a rejuvenation clinic in Bucharest. I had read an interview wtih Prof. Ana Aslan in which she promised not the return of bonny youth but a permanent tenure on middle age, a guarantee that pleased me by not being too halcyon or too boastful.

title: A Question of Confidence
description: In his first months as Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev has come across as above all a self-confident man. That quality marked, for example, his recent Time magazine interview, with its brisk extemporaneous replies to hard questions and its knowing references to the West.

title: LTV Pension Plan
description: The LTV Steel Company has missed a deadline for making $175 million in annual pension contributions and was awaiting word from Federal officials on whether the payment could be waived, a spokesman for LTV's parent company in Dallas said.

title: A.T.&T. ALLOWED TO LINK UNITS
description: The Federal Communications Commission, trying to stimulate competition in the telephone equipment industry, dropped its requirement that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company maintain a corporate wall of separation between its marketing of long-distance services and telephone and computer equipment.

title: ANIMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income c-After extraordinary gains of $31,000 for the quarter and $69,000 for the 9 months. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: MINISTER'S DENIAL OVER GREENPEACE
description: Defense Minister Charles Hernu maintained his innocence today in the face of press reports here suggesting that he had ordered the sabotage July 10 of a ship owned by the anti-nuclear and environmentalist group Greenpeace.

title: YANKEE MOOD SAGS WITH THEIR SLUMP
description: All around him, there was typical pregame activity: a card game, a few players reading the sports section of the local newspaper, a teammate undergoing treatment in the trainer's room. But Don Mattingly sensed something unusual. And when someone suggested that perhaps the Yankees were flat, that they seemed worn down and sluggish from a season approaching its final weeks, he nodded.

title: Middle South
description: Middle South Utilities Inc. said two of its units, the Mississippi Power and Light Company and the Arkansas Power and Light Company, should have sufficient revenues to make monthly payments for nearly 70 percent of the Grand Gulf 1 nuclear power plant, based on an allocation by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. It said recent rate increases to help pay for Grand Gulf have made the payments possible.

title: Kodak Shows Still Video Unit
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, in a further broadening of its product line, introduced new electronic imaging products yesterday, including a still video system that allows people to display photographs on their televisions.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Bayly, Martin & Fay, an insurance brokerage firm with headquarters in Fort Worth, has named Andrew H. Marks chief executive officer of its New York and northern New Jersey offices.

title: MOSCOW MATCHES BRITISH EXPULSION
description: The Soviet Union today ordered five more British Embassy staff members and another British correspondent out of the country. The figure matched the number of Russians ordered expelled by Britain two days ago.

title: Abraham Meltzer, 68, Triangle Pacific Chief
description: Abraham Meltzer, founder and chairman of the Dallas-based Triangle Pacific Corporation, died Sunday after a long illness at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 68 years old and had residences in Great Neck, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla.

title: EDWARD B. SCHULKIND
description: Edward B. Schulkind, a retired trust and estate lawyer, died Sept. 14 at his home in Manhattan.

title: 3COM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
TEAM DEFENSE KEY TO RANGER COACH
description: They perched all around. An assistant coach stood on one balcony, another on another balcony. Scouts watched, so did the general manager, and cameras looked on from overhead. The Rangers, on their first day of skating, were peered upon by at least a hundred eyes.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I am very unhappy with the level of corruption that existed and may continue to exist, and I am resolved not to allow it to exist any more.'' -Mayor W. Wilson Goode of Philadelphia, referring to the police department. [A1:1.]

title: MOZART'S 'FIGARO' ON ARTS CHANNEL
description: OPERA lovers need no excuse for attending to still another production of Mozart's ''The Marriage of Figaro.'' But there are several things special about the version scheduled for tonight at 8 o'clock on cable's Arts & Entertainment channel.

title: JUDGE CLEARS DOCTOR WHO REFUSED DEATH PLEA
description: A judge here has directed a verdict in favor of a doctor who was being sued on the ground that he had improperly refused to disconnect life-support systems on a 70-year-old terminally ill woman.

title: UNITED SOFTWARE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Scali, McCabe, Sloves Buys Into Paris Shop
description: Scali, McCabe, Sloves - whose nine offices include outposts in Toronto, Montreal, London, Dusseldorf, Mexico City and Melbourne - is about to take its first small step into Paris.

title: Topics;   On Shaky Ground Root Problem
description: In his hit song ''Luckenbach, Texas,'' Waylon Jennings suggested that country music stardom had become more painful than pleasing. ''We've been so busy keeping up with the Joneses, four-car garage and we're still building on,'' he sang.

title: Texas Utilities' 12% Trust Bonds
description: The Texas Utilities Electric Company is offering $75 million of 12 percent first mortgage and collateral trust bonds due 2015 at a price of 99.35, to yield 12.08 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The bonds are rated A-2 by Moody's and A+ by S.& P. Following the bond sale, the company said it is offering to repurchase $150 million of outstanding first mortgage bonds of its Texas Power and Light Company and Texas Electric Service Company divisions. The securities include Texas Power 17 1/2 percent bonds due 2011, which Texas Utilities is offering to buy for $1,200 per $1,000 face amount, and Texas Electric's 16 percent bonds due 2012, which it is offering to buy at $1,192.50.

title: I.B.M. Offers A PCjr Deal
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, apparently having difficulty selling its remaining PCjr home computers, is aiming at a new market: its own employees.

title: Giants Make Changes
description: The San Francisco Giants, languishing in last place in the National League West, yesterday got a new general manager, a new field manager and the promise of more personnel changes to come. ''We're not afraid to make changes and we will make changes,'' said the new general manager, Al Rosen, who took over for Tom Haller just a week after Rosen had been dismissed by the Houston Astros.

title: Life Terms Demanded For 5 in Argentina
description: The Government prosecutor asked a court today to sentence five former Argentine military rulers to life in prison on charges of murder, torture and kidnapping during an anti-insurgency campaign in the late 1970's and early 80's.

title: TAB PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
COMPUTER HORIZONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
CITY CONSIDERS EXPANDING SERVICE
description: Experimental ferry service between Brooklyn and Manhattan is deemed successful, and the city is now considering seven proposals that would make the service permanent and provide a range of other features, a city official said yesterday.

title: ITALO CALVINO, THE NOVELIST, DEAD AT 61
description: Italo Calvino, the master of allegorical fantasy who became Italy's leading contemporary novelist, died early today in a hospital in Siena, Italy, from the effects of a stroke he suffered on Sept. 6. He was 61 years old.

title: DESIGN STUDENTS' MENTORS
description: Having a mentor in the business world is useful, and New York students of interior design can find such an adviser through a program of the American Society of Interior Designers.

title: Chinese Party Meets
description: The Communist Party today convened a special national conference, of a kind it has not held since 1955, to select replacements for the dozens of veteran officials who resigned from the party's Central Committee earlier in the week.

title: Pneumo's Orders
description: IC Industries said its Pneumo Corporation subsidiary had received orders valued at more than $200 million from the Boeing Commercial Airplane Company for landing gear. Deliveries of the gear for the 767, 747 and 737 aircraft will begin early next year and continue through 1991, the company said. The gear will be built by the Cleveland Pneumatic Company, a Pneumo subsidiary.

title: Mormon Team Goes To O.&M.
description: IN this town, the capital of world advertising, an agency changing its creative director is a fairly routine happening. But what has happened at Ogilvy & Mather Partners under the recently established leadership of Jeffrey W. Woll, managing director, has all the earmarks of a truly unusual event.

title: MONDALE CRITICAL OF SPACE WEAPONS
description: President Reagan should use the proposed space-based defense system against incoming missiles as ''a bargaining chip, not a monkey wrench'' in his Geneva summit meeting with the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale said today.

title: PREMIER INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
U.S. OFFICIAL SAYS JORDAN ARMS SALE WILL PROCEED
description: A high-ranking State Department official told a sharply critical House subcommittee today that President Reagan would soon announce plans to sell advanced American fighter planes and antiaircraft missiles to Jordan.

title: WAGS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: Merck Stock In Sharp Drop
description: Concern that an anti-hypertension drug produced by Merck & Company might have harmful side-effects sent the company's stock sharply lower yesterday in heavy trading.

title: 'Y' OFFERS ROOMS TO CANCER PATIENTS
description: FOR out-of-town cancer patients who must travel to New York City for chemotherapy there is now an alternative to the loneliness of a hotel room. An experimental program sponsored by the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and the West Side YMCA provides inexpensive lodging in a supportive environment.

title: EWING SIGNS PACT WORTH UP TO $30 MILLION
description: Patrick Ewing signed a complex contract with the Knicks yesterday that guarantees him appoximately $17 million for six years and could possibly bring him more than $30 million should he remain with the team for 10 years. The final four years of the contract are not guaranteed.

title: REAGAN MAY SEEK TRUST LAW EASING
description: The Reagan Administration is considering asking Congress to relax the nation's antimonopoly laws because they might inhibit American industry's ability to compete abroad, Secretary of Commerce Malcolm Baldrige said today.

title: The Enviable Mrs. Astor
description: When John Jacob Astor arrived in New York City in 1783 he had two suits, enough money for a few meals and seven flutes to sell. When he died 65 years later he was the richest man in America.

title: 'MAMA' MAY HAVE TO MOVE
description: One of Off Broadway's longest-running musicals, ''Mama, I Want to Sing,'' is likely to lose its home in a city-owned theater.

title: Stadium Fright
description: Except for forgetting the words, missing the tune and singing off key, Mary O'Dowd's rendition of the Canadian national anthem, ''O Canada,'' before the Yankee-Toronto game at Yankee Stadium last Saturday night was close to perfect.

title: Bid by Taubman Seen; Refinancing Move Cited
description: A. Alfred Taubman, who yesterday announced a major refinancing of $2 billion worth of his real estate properties, may be preparing to make a large acquisition or other diversification move to add to his growing business, cultural and professional sports holdings, investment bankers said yesterday.

title: A Comment on South Africa
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is likely to force American banks to make public the amount of loans they have outstanding to South Africa, John S. Reed, chairman of Citicorp, said yesterday.

title: Plastic License Plates?
description: New York State's Motor Vehicles Department is looking into the possibility of switching from metal to plastic license plates when it issues new plates next year. To coincide with the 1986 Statue of Liberty centennial, the new plates will be stamped with a logo depicting the statue. Department officials said they must make a recommendation to Governor Cuomo by Jan. 1 on the exact design and material for the plates.

title: MEASUREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
Transactions
description: BASEBALL CLEVELAND (AL) - Acquired Rich Yett, pitcher, from the Toledo Mud Hens.

title: Mississippi Bonds Yield Up to 8.70%
description: Strong investor demand enabled underwriters to raise prices and reduce interest rates on a $205 million issue of Mississippi highway revenue refunding bonds.

title: Gorbachev's Risky Domestic Reforms
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev has seized the high ground on domestic reforms. In the Soviet Union, where the strongest campaign rhetoric follows rather than precedes elections, he has been stumping hard against the status quo. His speeches have made him an instant hero in a country notably lacking in heroes.

title: COMPLICATIONS OVER TRADE-IN FOR WESTWAY
description: New York officials, reluctantly drafting plans to transfer $1.7 billion in Federal funds earmarked for Westway to a more modest road project and mass-transit improvements, are confronting serious political and financial complications.

title: AMERICAN HOSTAGE IN LEBANON FREED AFTER 16 MONTHS
description: President Reagan announced today that the Rev. Benjamin Weir, who had been held hostage in Lebanon for 16 months, had been released and was back in the United States with his family.

title: HUNT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
U.S. Delegates to U.N. Are Named by Reagan
description: President Reagan has nominated nine people to represent the United States at the 40th session of the General Assembly, a American spokesman said yesterday. Lieut. Gen. Vernon A. Walters is again the chief delegate.

title: SOUTHERN HOSPITALITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Court Curbs Thrift Figure
description: A judge today ordered the ousted president of Old Court Savings and Loan and his wife to limit personal spending to $1,000 a week, saying the couple had thwarted his earlier attempt to control their finances.

title: C.D.'s, Money Funds Show a Slight Increase
description: Rates on certificates of deposit and money market mutual funds rose slightly for the week ended yesterday, while bank money market accounts continued to hold steady.

title: PHILADELPHIA MAYOR PRESENTS PLAN TO COMBAT GRAFT IN POLICE FORCE
description: Responding to growing evidence of widespread police corruption, Mayor W. Wilson Goode announced a sweeping package of measures today to combat graft, including the appointment of a special prosecutor.

title: REAGAN SAYS TAX CODE NOW AIDS 'RICH STATES'
description: President Reagan today assailed as ''unfair'' and ''unjust'' the Federal income tax provision that allows deductions for payments of state and local taxes.

title: WILSON FOODS CORP reports earnings for 14wks to Aug 3
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,963,000 and charges of $4.7 million related to the repayment of Chapter 11 creditors' claims, sale of two company plants, expenses related to plant closings and other one-time items. c-After an extraordinary gain of $564,000 from retirement of debt. d-Net income after an extraordinary gain of $32,689,000 from the termination of a retirement plan and tax credits.

title: General Dynamics Strike Cripples Tank Building
description: Five thousand hourly workers for the General Dynamics Corporation walked off their jobs today at plants in three states, virtually halting construction of the M1 and M1A1 tanks for the Army, officials said.

title: TOP PENTAGON DOCTOR IS UNHAPPY WITH READINESS
description: The Pentagon's top doctor said today that ''only small gains'' had been made in eliminating jurisdictional problems that caused the Navy to turn away Army medical helicopters in the Grenada invasion and led an Air Force officer to bypass an outstanding Army hospital in the evacuation of wounded marines from Beirut in 1983.

title: CITY PORTS CHIEF RESIGNS POSITION AFTER TWO YEARS
description: The city's Commissioner of Ports and Terminals, Susan Frank, resigned yesterday after two years on the job.

title: Trying to View Market Future
description: WHENEVER the Dow Jones industrial average passes through a round number like 1,300, investors take notice even though market professionals tend to regard such moves as more psychological than meaningful.

title: Yeutter Urges Japan to Act
description: President Reagan's top trade negotiator, Clayton K. Yeutter, urged Japan today to open its markets to imports ''pretty darn fast'' or face retaliation from other industrialized nations and a ''nervous'' Congress.

title: THE ELUSIVE GARBO TURNS 80
description: There was no trace of her at the bookstore around the corner where she often stops. The movie moguls have long since given up. Not even the Swedish Consul General had a clue what she was up to.

title: DEEPER SPENDING CUTS ARE PROPOSED
description: In a fresh signal of determination to cut the deficit, the House Rules Committee has told the House Ways and Means Committee to increase its proposed spending cuts by more than $2 billion.

title: THE SCREEN: MERYL STREEP AND STING IN 'PLENTY'
description: PITY poor, beautiful, elegantly dressed Susan Traherne, an English woman with a terminal case of ineffable feelings, something she apparently caught while working with the Resistance during the Nazi occupation of France during World War II.

title: NO TAX LAW THIS YEAR, LEADERS SAY
description: Congressional leaders agreed today that there would not be time to enact tax revision legislation this year.

title: FIRECOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, 1985
description: The Economy

title: PHOENIX AMERICAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SPECIAL ARMY FOOD HELPS HEFTY TROOPS
description: An army may march on its stomach, but it won't get very far if overeating turns the stomach into a potbelly.

title: TOON TO BE DEVELOPED PATIENTLY BY JETS
description: Although Al Toon had a debut receivers dream about, producing a 50-yard gain on the first pass thrown to him in the National Football League, the Jets still plan to keep him under wraps Sunday when they face the Packers at Green Bay.

title: Wesray Appoints Head For Ailing Wilson Unit
description: As president and chief executive of the Prince Manufacturing Company in the late 1970's, John P. Murray helped build the then struggling maker of extra large tennis racquets into a smash success before selling it to Cheseborough-Pond's Inc. in 1982.

title: Direct Gets Assignment
description: TRW Information Systems Group, made up of three companies in the computer and data processing field, has given an unnamed multimedia direct marketing assignment to Direct Inc., a subsidiary of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, which said that billings could be in the $6 million to $8 million neighborhood. The group, whose regular agency is Wyse Advertising, has one unit that provides consumer credit information, another that provides lending data for the real estate industry and one that is the largest third-party computer maintenance company.

title: STAGE: 'SONG & DANCE,' WITH BERNADETTE PETERS
description: IN ''Song & Dance,'' the new Andrew Lloyd Webber show at the Royale, the star Bernadette Peters and the choreographer Peter Martins all but break their necks trying to entertain us. In the first act, Miss Peters belts and sobs and shimmies her way through a solo song cycle that runs for a full hour. After intermission, Mr. Martins takes over, sending nine admirable dancers, led by Christopher d'Amboise, into a non-stop, 40-minute exhibition of pyrotechnics. So why is ''Song & Dance'' grating (Act I) and monotonous (Act II)? The mystery isn't hard to solve. No one has given Miss Peters anything to sing about or Mr. Martins's dancers any reason to leap. Empty material remains empty, no matter how talented those who perform it.

title: Prices Off for Treasury Issues
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds declined yesterday amid weak investor demand for a new issue of 9 percent notes due in two years.

title: OIL-DRI CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes the sale of the company's German plant and related European market operations, which resulted in a gain of $588,000.

title: CBS News Said to Plan Elimination of 100 Jobs
description: As part of company-wide budget cutting at CBS, the network's news division is expected to announce today the elimination of some 100 jobs, CBS News staff members said yesterday.

title: BIOTECH CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: LARSEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
'GIGI ON LONDON STAGE
description: A stage version of the musical film ''Gigi,'' boasting many new lyrics by Alan Jay Lerner, opened here last night - and was received with rapture by its audience but much more skeptically by several critics.

title: I.M.F. Sees Slow Growth
description: Economic growth in the industrial world will expand by only 3.1 percent next year, according to an International Monetary Fund forecast to be published next month, Western monetary officials said today.

title: FIRST CONTINENTAL REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Tough Going For the Beemer
description: The old Beemer, if truth be known, is probably as tough as it was in 1938, when it was turned out in Germany by the Bavarian Motor Works as a prototype of the dream BMW of the future.

title: SERVAMATIC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: The Year of Dee-fense
description: ''DEE-fense!'' cry the fans, and from Grid Wars to Star Wars to Trade Wars, 1985 is shaping up as the Year of Dee-fense.

title: NO PLAYERS CALLED AS TESTIMONY ENDS
description: Testimony ended today in the Federal trial of a Philadelphia man charged with selling cocaine to major league baseball players.

title: POPULARITY ON THE RISE
description: LOG homes now comprise nearly 1.5 percent of all new homes built in the United States, according to Jim Birdsong, executive director of the Home Manufacturers Councils.

title: Topics;   On Shaky Ground Case Closed in India
description: Press freedom and India's good name are the beneficiaries of the New Delhi Government's decison not to prosecute Brahma Chellaney. The young Associated Press reporter, an Indian national, was accused of filing false and inflammatory dispatches from the Punjab when Government troops stormed the Golden Temple in June 1984.

title: Most French Air Traffic Is Stopped by Strike
description: French air traffic controllers began a two-day strike today to press demands for increased pension benefits, halting most air traffic.

title: MOYNIHAN SEES NO WAY TO WIN A WESTWAY VOTE
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said tonight that there was no practical way to win a Congressional vote that New York needs to proceed with the Westway project.

title: SCHMIDT, GUERRERO TURNED IT AROUND
description: Mike Schmidt was standing by the batting cage in Shea Stadium the other night when a former teammate, Tim McCarver, walked up and said, ''Schmitty, what adjustments did you make?''

title: Charity Without Guilt
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CHAMPION TENDS TO BUSINESS
description: He likes to think of himself as a businessman. He makes his office in the gyms and converted hotel showrooms where the heavy bags hang like sausages in a butcher shop and the air is thick with the smell of sweat. In one such room on the second floor at the Riviera Hotel, Larry Holmes completed the familiar prefight routine this week, the monotony alleviated by the presence of his family.

title: Saudis Said to Cut Oil Prices
description: Saudi Arabia has executed at least three crude oil sales contracts that lowered its oil price to spot-market levels on a net-back basis, United States Energy Secretary John Herrington said today.

title: Affirmative Action Is Backed
description: A bipartisan group of 125 House and Senate members urged President Reagan today to retain affirmative action guidelines for Federal contractors.

title: 2 Sides Warned At Stewart Trial
description: A State Supreme Court judge yesterday criticized both the defense and the prosecution in the trial of six transit police officers charged in the death of Michael Stewart.

title: KOHL REPORTEDLY PASSED UP A CHANCE TO CHECK ON DEFECTORS
description: The Interior Ministry said today that Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Interior Minister Friedrich Zimmermann recently declined to order surveillance of a secretary and her husband who have now reportedly defected to East Germany.

title: Conservationists and Others Battle a Reagan Nominee
description: The National Wildlife Federation, the country's biggest conservation group and one whose members tend to be politically conservative, has never in its 49-year history opposed a Presidential nominee to an executive agency. But it has just ended that tradition. In testimony prepared for the Senate Armed Services Committee, the group vigorously and at length opposes the nomination of Robert K. Dawson to be Assistant Secretary of the Army for Civil Works, the Army's top civilian construction job.

title: O'Brasky Is Named To H.P.G. Senior Post
description: David O'Brasky, who is 50 years old but not for long, is joining Joseph Hanson at the Hanson Publishing Group as a senior vice president.

title: KIDNAPPERS OF DUARTE'S DAUGHTER SET NEW TERMS
description: The kidnappers of the daughter of President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador have established new conditions for opening negotiations on her release, according to a senior Salvadoran official who is closely involved in the case.

title: Top Amfac Officer Quits Dual Posts
description: Amfac Inc., the San Francisco-based conglomerate whose interests range from wholesale distribution to hotels, said yesterday that Myron Du Bain, president and chief executive since 1983, had resigned.

title: City Obligation Bonds Priced to Yield Over 9%
description: New York City is offering $350 million of general obligation bonds tentatively priced with yields of 9 percent and higher for bonds due in 1996 and beyond, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Rushing Slowly
description: The Walk Before You Can Run Award has to go to the Kansas City Chiefs, who have not had a 100-yard rusher in any game since Billy Jackson rolled up 102 against Minnesota in the 1981 season finale. That was more than three years ago, and the length of the drought is best understood in light of this other statistic: Twenty-seven of the National Football League's 28 teams - all but the Chiefs - had at least one runner with a 100-yard output as recently as last season.

title: REESE SHOOTS 209 TO WIN MET FINAL
description: Don Reese wound up the winner in the $40,000 Izod Met PGA Championship today at the Country Club of Fairfield. He never expected it.

title: FRENCHMAN UNDER FIRE:EUGENE CHARLES HERNU
description: Each spring, on Pentecost Sunday, a small group of friends make a pilgrimage to Solutre, in the forest of Morvan, to remember old times and talk about the years to come.

title: Bridge: Cavendish Calls on Its Stars For Monthly Lecture Series
description: One reason that the Cavendish is the world's most famous bridge club is that it has far more than its fair share of internationally famous stars.

title: EDWARD WOODWARD, NEW TV HERO
description: ''This scene calls for being slightly drunk,'' said Edward Woodward to his director, Russ Mayberry, ''but I'm afraid he'll have to be rather drunk with this deep brown voice of mine.''

title: SENATE ALIEN BILL DRAWS CRITICISM
description: The chief House sponsor of a comprehensive immigration bill joined Hispanic groups today in criticizing a move by the Senate to admit up to 350,000 aliens to the United States to harvest perishable fruit and vegetables.

title: METS RALLY TO OVERCOME CUBS
description: ''Somewhere along the line,'' George Foster was saying, ''we feel the Cardinals are going to lose.''

title: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
'Routine' Tests Due For Reagan on Friday
description: President Reagan will visit the Bethesda Naval Medical Center on Friday for the first in a series of follow-up examinations in connection with his cancer surgery of July 13, the White House said today.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: CRITICS SAY REAGAN FORECLOSES ARMS ACCORD
description: Critics of the Reagan Administration said today that President Reagan's refusal to use his space-based defense program as a ''bargaining chip'' for cutbacks in Soviet offensive weapons had seriously hurt prospects for progress on arms control at his meeting in November with Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: 'Dial-a-Porn' Service Wins Ruling in Utah
description: A Federal judge today dismissed criminal charges against a New York ''dial-a-porn'' service, saying that Congress had failed to include telephone transmissions in anti-pornography legislation.

title: FEDERATED GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Longer Virginia Slims From Philip Morris
description: Philip Morris U.S.A., which made such a big deal out of cigarette length back in the 1960's with its 100 millimeter Benson & Hedges, will outdo itself on Oct. 8 with the introduction of a line extension of its Virginia Slims, female-oriented brand, that is 120 millimeters long.

title: Devil Coach Seeks Backup for Resch
description: In contrast to his rookie season with the team last year, Coach Doug Carpenter of the Devils this time knows most of the people in camp.

title: POP: HARBURG TRIBUTE
description: IN the lyrics of the late E. Y. (Yip) Harburg, there is a sense, often mischievously expressed, of ''seeing through'' the surfaces of life into an implacable void. Songs like ''It's Only a Paper Moon'' and ''Old Devil Moon'' puncture the dream of the true romance they purport to exalt.

title: NEW YORK IS 'BOUNCING BACK,' CITY REPORT ASSERTS
description: Crime decreased overall, though park vandalism rose sharply. Ambulances responded quicker to emergencies, but it generally took cars and taxis more time to get across midtown Manhattan. Drunken-driving arrests were up and streets were cleaner, but the city's response in child-abuse cases was unacceptably slow.

title: POETRY AND DANCE
description: POSSIBLY because they both, in their own ways, concern themselves with rhythm and vivid imagery, the verbal art of poetry and the nonverbal art of dance seem curiously akin. Quite a few dance critics have been poets, from Theophile Gautier in the 19th century to Edwin Denby in our time.

title: Two-Way Trading Seen
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to approve a pilot program Thursday to create a two-way link between the American Stock Exchange and the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: DISCOUNT AIR SERVICE PLAN TO ATLANTA REJECTED
description: Amid angry protests from nearby homeowners, local officials here refused today to back a plan to use a small, county-run airport as the hub to operate daily low-cost air service between Atlanta and seven cities.

title: HIGH COURT BARS U.S. ROLE IN 2 CASES
description: The Supreme Court refused today to allow the Justice Department to make oral arguments as a friend of the court in two of the major cases of the coming term. One case involves abortion, the other affirmative action on jobs.

title: Hard Choice for Farrell
description: Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr. may be caught in the middle Saturday, when the Manhatttan Democratic Committee nominates a successor to Councilman Frederick E. Samuel, who died two days after winning renomination in last week's primary.

title: PORT CHESTER TRIES FOR A COMEBACK AMID HARD TIMES
description: ''Port Chester used to be a thriving, bustling community,'' recalled Jay Feinsod, who was born here 42 years ago, went to school here, married his high school sweetheart and took over his father's business, Feinsod Hardware. The store has been operating since 1947.

title: Required Reading;   Illionitis, Anyone?
description: Remarks by Representative Thomas E. Petri, Republican of Wisconsin, to the House of Representatives, Sept. 17:

title: SHERMAN DRUTMAN
description: Sherman Drutman, a State Superior Court judge, died Sunday at Lawrence and Memorial Hospitals in New London. He was 60 years old and lived in Hamden.

title: Japan's Military Outlay
description: The Japanese Government approved a five-year military spending program today calling for the outlay of $76.3 billion over the next five years. The figure is likely to exceed the Government-set ceiling of 1 percent of gross national product, a move urged on Tokyo by Washington. The decision, which was reached after an all-night session involving Finance Minister Noboru Takeshita and the Defense Agency chief, Koichi Kato, at the Prime Minister's official residence, was approved by the National Defense Council and a special Cabinet session.

title: Carlsberg Bought
description: The Carlsberg Corporation, a real estate financial management service, said it had agreed to merge with the Southmark Corporation for about $55 million in cash and preferred stock. Southmark, a real estate investment concern in Dallas, said each Carlsberg share would be exchanged for $5.50 in cash and $5.50 in market value of adjustable-rate preferred stock. Carlsberg said the Dallas concern would issue about 575,000 shares of the preferred stock and pay about $28 million in cash.

title: Digital Plant For Mexico
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation plans to open a factory in Chihuahua, Mexico, to manufacture its Microvax II computer series. The company did not disclose the size of its investment but said the leased plant, 250 miles south of El Paso, Tex., would begin shipping products early next year.

title: STUDIES FAIL TO LINK AIDS WITH SWINE FEVER
description: Studies by the New York State Health Department have found no correlation between acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, and another viral disease, African swine fever, state officials say.

title: CONGRESS TRADE REVOLT: REAGAN LAG AND JOB CUTS
description: At his news conference Tuesday night, President Reagan warned Congress against pursuing a ''mindless stampede'' toward protectionist trade legislation. But today, House Republican leaders met to craft a package of trade bills that go well beyond what the Administration seems willing to accept.

title: 1,000 PEKING STUDENTS MARCH IN RESENTMENT AGAINST JAPAN
description: Chinese students staged one of the biggest protest demonstrations here in years when they marched through Tiananmen Square today waving banners and shouting slogans against Japan.

title: LAWYERS SAY SCHOOLGIRL IN MIDDLE OF DISPUTE MAY NOT HAVE AIDS
description: The child at the center of a controversy over whether students with AIDS should be admitted to classes in New York City public schools may not have the disorder, the city's chief lawyer said yesterday.

title: Brustein Group Wins 1985 Jujamcyn Award
description: The American Repertory Theater of Cambridge, Mass., directed by Robert Brustein, will receive this year's Jujamcyn Theater Award for its ''outstanding contribution to the development of creative talent for the theater,'' according to an announcement by Richard G. Wolff, president of Jujamcyn Theaters. The award, established last year to honor a regional theater or regional theatrical organization, carries a $50,000 cash prize; last year's recipient was the O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn.

title: Work Stations For 3-D Design
description: WHEN engineers sketch designs for a new chemical plant, petroleum refinery or other complex plants, a major challenge is figuring how to keep the miles of piping, electrical wiring and ventilating ducts from colliding when the actual construction begins.

title: Hybritech Agrees To Bid by Eli Lilly
description: Eli Lilly & Company said yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to buy Hybritech Inc., a San Diego-based medical research company, for about $300 million.

title: ACQUITTALS SEEM LIKELY AS AQUINO TRIAL NEARS END
description: Two years after the assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino, the truth remains as elusive as ever, and the way seems clear for the acquittal of some or all of the 26 men charged with involvement in the killing.

title: PUBLISHER DECIDES U.S. NEEDS ENGLISH PRAVDA
description: Sensing the opportunity to profit from Americans who are curious about life in the Soviet Union, a retired publisher here plans to begin printing a daily edition of Pravda in English.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: WHAT'S IT AWL ABOUT Gerald Ford, Jimmy Carter, the Beatles, Willie Mays and Earl Weaver, among others, have worn handmade shoes. Raymond Robinson, from Woodbury, Tenn., made them. He is a shoemaker - not a cobbler, who mends shoes, but a shoemaker who has been at it for 24 years. For 15 years he made shoes by machine; for the past nine, trained by older and more experienced workers, he has sewn them himself.

title: EX-HOSTAGE SAID TO CARRY MESSAGE FROM CAPTORS
description: The Rev. Benjamin Weir, whose release from captivity in Lebanon was announced today, carried a message from his captors that set out demands for the release of the remaining Americans being held in Lebanon, Reagan Administration officials said.

title: A.M.C. Recalls 2,850 Cars
description: The American Motors Corporation recalled about 2,850 French-made 1985 Renault Fuego and Sportwagon cars today for repair of a steering wheel nut.

title: Shell Pulls Out
description: A unit of Shell Oil Company said it had plugged and abandoned a second exploration well and has no plans for further drilling in a nine-square-mile area of the Gulf of Mexico off the Florida panhandle.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in some editions of Business Day yesterday about the Control Data Corporation misidentified Michael Geran. He is an analyst for E.F. Hutton & Company.

title: World Bank
description: The World Bank yesterday announced two separate financings in the Eurobond market. A 600 million Deutsche mark issue of 6 1/2 percent, 10-year Eurobonds was offered at a price of par through underwriters led by Deutsche Bank A.G. Another issue of 10 5/8 percent Eurobonds totaling $200 million was offered at par through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley International.

title: Suntory Wine Accord
description: Suntory Ltd., the large Japanese liquor company, signed an agreement today with Chateau Lafite-Rothschild to distribute the French vintner's wines in Japan and exchange wine-making technology.

title: Family Ties
description: The people who pick the all-America football teams prefer to delay the task until the season has been played, which seems reasonable enough. On the other hand, why should a fan who enjoys devouring such selections be required to wait three more months? How about an all-America listing based on performance of a candidate's kinfolk who have preceded him on the playing fields of America?

title: Now There Are Six
description: The release of the Rev. Benjamin Weir, one of the seven kidnapped Americans still held hostage in Lebanon, is splendid news in itself and in what it suggests: that determined diplomacy can bring deliverance to the six others as well. Perhaps even in this labyrinth, there are channels of contact with the kidnappers who have so far been demanding what the United States cannot deliver - the release of 17 of their comrades convicted of terrorist crimes in Kuwait.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: American Telephone and Telegraph Co. declared a quarterly dividend of 30 cents a share, unchanged from the previous period. It is payable Nov. 1 to shareholders of record Sept. 30.

title: Rubber Bullets: Riot Weapon
description: Rubber bullets are used by South African authorities extensively in confrontations with crowds. The bullet is an inch and a half in diameter and three inches long and weighs about three ounces.

title: FAILED BANK REOPENS UNDER NEW OWNERSHIP
description: The People's National Bank of Rockland County, which was ordered closed last Friday because of insolvency, reopened today under new ownership. While some customers said they were worried, for most it was business as usual.

title: A MOTHER AND DAUGHTER VS. THE COLLEGE ADMISSIONS PROCESS
description: MY 16-year-old daughter slumped against the doorway of the college admissions office. ''It happened,'' she groaned. ''A stress interview.''

title: Gender Tenders
description: The term ''gender gap'' died in last year's Presidential election, and the White House and its helpers at the Republican National Committee are working to make sure there is no renaissance.

title: S. F. Pryor Jr., Airline Pioneer
description: Samuel F. Pryor Jr., an early aviation industrialist and a longtime associate of Charles A. Lindbergh, died today at his country home in Kipahulu Valley on the island of Maui. He was 87 years old.

title: INTERMAGNETICS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 25
description: b-Net loss.

title: WEAVES, CERAMICS IN AN ARTFUL DISPLAY
description: THE current show of six ceramists and two weavers at the Hadler-Rodriguez Gallery emphasizes function as well as aesthetics. Mark Pharis of Minnesota makes soy sauce bottles and teapots with inset tops resembling mushrooms.

title: Banker's Wife Slain in Texas
description: The wife of a bank president was found shot to death in her home here today after her husband told the authorities he had received a telephone call from a man who threatened to harm her unless a ransom was paid. The police found the victim, Rebecca Patton, 42 years old, dead of multiple gunshot wounds about 3 P.M. at the couple's home. The Federal Bureau of Investigation said her husband Frank, president of the Castle Hills National Bank, received the telephone call at the bank about 40 minutes earlier.

title: NEW LAW TO PROTECT COMPUTER DATA SOUGHT
description: Computerized information would gain legal protection from unauthorized access or interception under legislation that Representative Robert W. Kastenmeier and Senator Patrick J. Leahy plan to introduce Thursday.

title: HIGH-BUSH BLUEBERRIES ON A PENTHOUSE TERRACE
description: Experienced city gardeners know that with space at a premium, it's vital to get the most mileage from each plant. Some, like Joseph Sirola, an actor who also likes to cook, seek out species that are not only ornamental but yield edible crops as well. With autumn approaching, few plants rival the versatility of the high-bush blueberries, said Mr. Sirola, which includes among its assets ''incredible crimson fall color.''

title: RAID BY 500 SOUTH AFRICANS INTO SOUTHERN ANGOLA CONTINUES
description: South African military officials said today that a raid into southern Angola that began two days ago was continuing, and that nearly 500 soldiers had been deployed to track down a battalion of Namibian insurgents.

title: HUBIE BROWN'S NEW CENTER
description: After all the weeks of negotiations, Patrick Ewing was Hubie Brown's now. When the Knicks' coach walked into the Hall of Fame lounge at the Garden where Patrick Ewing's complex multimillion-dollar contract was about to be announced yesterday, he looked up at the 7-foot, 253-pound rookie in the gray double-breasted suit.

title: MAJOR LANDLORD INDICTED IN BOSTON
description: Harold Brown, a landlord who owns more residential and commercial space than any other in the city, was indicted today on Federal charges of bribing a city building inspector and lying to a Federal grand jury about it. Mr. Brown later pleaded not guilty to both charges in Federal District Court.

title: AUDITORS FAULT TRANSIT AUTHORITY
description: The Transit Authority's failure to conduct adequate engineering studies before buying two huge buildings will add $36 million to renovation costs, according to an audit released yesterday by the City Comptroller.

title: PATHOLOGIST CITES HEROIN IN DEATH OF BELUSHI
description: Dr. Michael Baden, New York City's former chief medical examiner, testified today that if John Belushi had not consumed heroin on March 5, 1982, he would not have died.

title: TODAY'S ENGINEER IS OFTEN A WOMAN
description: WHEN Eleanor Baum was growing up in Brooklyn, family and friends advised her against pursuing a career in engineering. ''I remember the message,'' she said. '' 'No one will want you, you'll be overeducated, you won't find a job or a husband either.' '' Even high-school teachers were discouraging, suggesting that engineering was a poor choice for a woman, including one with an aptitude for science and mathematics.

title: Firestone Plans Major Cutbacks
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company announced a major cutback yesterday of its North American tire operations that will result in a $100 million charge against earnings in its 1985 fiscal year.

title: WEBCOR ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: STUDENT READING HELD ITS LEVEL FOR 14 YEARS, FEDERAL SURVEY FINDS
description: Students were reading at least as well in 1984 as they did in in 1971, but two of the three age groups tested have not improved since 1980, according to a study made public today.

title: TRANSIT GOALS BEING MET, GUNN SAYS
description: The president of the Transit Authority said yesterday that most of the 340 goals he set for the agency last year would be achieved by the end of this year.

title: McMahon Sits Out
description: Jim McMahon, the Chicago Bear quarterback who has been nursing a stiff neck and muscle spasms, did not practice yesterday and will not start tonight's game against the Minnesota Vikings, according to club officials, who said McMahon's backup, Steve Fuller, would start. . . . John Jefferson, the wide receiver who was a free agent and had sat out training camp because he wanted to be traded, has signed a one-year contract with Green Bay after no other team showed interest in meeting the Packers' terms for a trade. . . . Jimmy Raye, the offensive coordinator for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, suffered a broken leg Tuesday when he was struck by a car while jogging.

title: RED SOX ROUT BLUE JAYS, 13-1
description: Rich Gedman hit for the cycle and drove in seven runs to lead an 18-hit attack, and Al Nipper (9-11) scattered six hits tonight as the Boston Red Sox routed the Toronto Blue Jays 13-1.

title: CLASS AT L.I. SCHOOL GETS A TAX LESSON
description: While President Reagan was pushing his tax reform program in Concord, N.H., today, John Sparks was trying to explain to his social-science class here how that plan might hurt their school, Longwood High.

title: On the Seventh Day
description: Melina Mercouri, the actress whose credits include the film ''Never on Sunday,'' will appear at the Smithsonian Institution's Natural History Building, to deliver a lecture, next Sunday.

title: STEWART SANDWICHES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Net income.

title: Star Wars: Vanity and Reality
description: You can hear two voices whenever Ronald Reagan talks about ''Star Wars,'' as he did again Tuesday evening. One speaks for a Presidential vanity, insisting he has pointed the way to a perfect defense that will one day make nuclear weapons obsolete. The other speaks for Presidential reality, longing in the three short years that remain to develop a saner relationship with the Soviet Union.

title: DISPUTE OVER INTENT IN DRUG CASE DIVIDED F.D.A. AND JUSTICE DEPT.
description: The Food and Drug Administration recommended last year that felony charges be filed against a large drug company and some of its managers for failing to report lethal side effects of a blood pressure drug, but the Justice Department decided to proceed with misdemeanor charges, department officials said today.

title: HOWARD B WOLF INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CARDS' STREAK AT 7 ON FORSCH 3-HITTER
description: Bob Forsch pitched a three-hitter, and Willie McGee, the league-leading hitter, hit a double and two singles tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 7-0, for their seventh consecutive victory.

title: Jackson Assails Press On Portrayal of Blacks
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson says the news media portray blacks as ''less intelligent than we are.''

title: BUILDING OF HOUSES UP BY 6.2%
description: Housing construction in August posted its best gain in five months, the Commerce Department reported today. Analysts said that the 6.2 percent increase provided further evidence that the economy was showing signs of a revival.

title: U.S. SAYS SOVIET COPIES SOME ARMS
description: A report made public by the Defense Department today says that the Soviet Union, working from a checklist of Western technology, has been systematically stealing or obtaining thousands of documents and components each year to build up its own military industries.

title: TRACING THE PATHS OF 20TH-CENTURY AMERICAN DESIGN
description: TODAY the Whitney Museum of American Art, at Madison Avenue and 75th Street, opens one of the most ambitious design shows held to date in this country. Unusual in conception and execution, ''High Styles: 20th-Century American Design'' is a bold and often surprising look at the stylistic innovations in the design of American products and furnishings made between 1899 and 1985.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WASHING machines, refrigerators and large pieces of furniture without casters can be a chore to move. Even if the object does have casters, they often do not swivel and are facing the wrong direction. Pushing, shoving or dragging the object can damage the floor and furniture and cause a strained back or pulled muscle in arms or shoulders.

title: Baldwin-United Plan Opposed
description: Eight banks that lent $584 million to the Baldwin-United Corporation for its ill-fated purchase of the MGIC Investment Corporation oppose Baldwin's proposed bankruptcy reorganization plan. The banks filed their objection Tuesday in Federal Bankruptcy Court.

title: General Tire Account To Hesselbart & Mitten
description: Hesselbart & Mitten, an agency whose name may not have been on every tongue in the business yesterday, may be there today thanks to winning the General Tire and Rubber account that bills between $5 million and $7 million.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Accounts
description: Wendy's International to Impact, the Promotion and Design Company, Chicago, for sales promotion.

title: The U.N. Today: Sept. 19, 1985
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Public hearings on transnational corporation activities in southern Africa - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: GIANTS' HAJI-SHEIKH PUT ON INJURED LIST
description: The Giants, attempting to correct a weakness in their kicking game, placed Ali Haji-Sheikh on injured reserve today and replaced him with Jess Atkinson, a 23-year-old rookie from Maryland.

title: THOR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
PATTERN PROCESSING TECHOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Drunken Driver Guilty Again
description: Clarence Busch, whose hit-and-run killing of a 13-year-old girl five years ago led to the formation of Mothers Against Drunk Driving, has been convicted of his sixth drunken driving offense. A Superior Court jury deliberated for about four hours Tuesday before finding the 52-year-old defendant guilty of driving under the influence of alcohol last April. He served 16 months in prison for vehicular manslaughter in a 1980 accident that killed Cari Lightner, the daughter of Candi Lightner, who later founded MADD.

title: Cost-Cutting Plan At Boise Cascade
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation announced a cost-cutting plan that includes layoffs and a freeze on hiring and salary increases, citing the intense competition for business in the depressed market for forest products. A spokesman, Doug Bartels, said wage concessions also might be sought from some workers as the company strives to cut its payroll costs by at least 3 percent.

title: Irish Eyes Are on Congress, and Not Smiling
description: The word that packed the Senate hearing had been most sudden and roundabout, arriving first by way of watchful people in Ireland, according to Agnes Mallon, a native of County Mayo, Eire. She drove down at 3 A.M. from her home in County Rockland, New York, she explained, to fight the proposed new extradition treaty worked out between the Governments of Britain and the United States.

title: One Group's Role in the Struggle for Central American Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: NEW YORK PHOTOS
description: Wurts Brothers Photograph New York: Architectural Photographs 1895-1960, Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street, 212-534-1672.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Chicago Cubs, at Shea Stadium, finale of two-game series. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Tigers, at Detroit, last game of a three-game series. (Television - SportsChannel 7:30 P.M.) Braves vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Atlanta. (Television -WTBS, 5:35 P.M.) Boxing Rosendo Alonso, champion, vs. Tyrone Jackson, 12 rounds, for the Continental Americas super featherweight championship, at the Felt Forum. First preliminary, 7:30 P.M. The World Boxing Council is the sponsor of this title, which is intended to help stimulate boxing. Alfonso, a Mexican now living in San Diego, is 27-12-1 with 14 knockouts. Jackson, undefeated in 21 professional fights, 16 by knockout, is from Harlem. (Television - MSG Network, 7:30 P.M.) Calvin Grove vs. Paul DeVorce, 10 rounds, featherweights, at the Atlantis Casino Hotel, Atlantic City. First preliminary, 8 P.M. Croquet U.S.C.A. National Singles and Doubles Championships, at the Sheep Meadow, Central Park, 8 A.M. to 6 P.M. Third day of competition. Football Minnesota Vikings vs. Chicago Bears, at Minneapolis. Both are undefeated in two games this season and tied with Detroit for the National Conference Central Division lead. The Bears won both games from the Vikings last season in an intense rivalry that dates to 1961. The Vikings, however, lead the series, 25-20-2, and have Bud Grant back as coach. Mike Ditka, the Bears' coach, has Walter Payton and a defense that led the N.F.L. in sacks with a record 72 last season.

title: Conrail Talks Unsuccessful
description: The Chicago and North Western Transportation Company said today that it had ended discussions with the Norfolk Southern Corporation about certain ''protective conditions'' in Norfolk Southern's proposed acquisition of Conrail.

title: BASIC HAND TOOLS DESIGNED FOR EASIER USE
description: FISKARS is a company based in Helsinki, Finland, and Wausau, Wis. Perhaps best known for its lightweight, orange-handled plastic and stainless-steel scissors, it has recently come out with a new line of hand tools.

title: BUILDING FROM AFAR: A LOG HOUSE RISES IN DISTANT MONTANA
description: FOR years the idea of building a second home in a wilderness woods had fermented in our family conversations. There was never much doubt about where: on 10 acres overlooking a river in the endless fir forests of northwestern Montana. Nor about what: a log home suitable for eventual year-round living.

title: Comings and Goings
description: According to her associates at the Wilhelmina modeling agency, Toni O'Reilly, an Irish-born model has received a 2.5 carat diamond engagement ring from Ron Darling, the Met pitcher, but no wedding date has been set. . . . Bob McCammon, the 44-year-old former coach and general manager of the Philadelphia Flyers, has joined the Edmonton Oilers as an assistant coach. McCammon said he had sought the Oiler post after growing tired of retirement.

title: METROMAIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
Rutgers Board of Governors Approves a Divestiture Plan
description: Rutgers University will sell $1.9 million of the $7.5 million in stock that it holds in companies doing business in South Africa, the university announced today.

title: DANCE CAUCUS URGES MAYORAL COMMISSION
description: The Modern Dance Caucus, a group of choreographers and modern-dance company managers, called on Mayor Koch yesterday to establish a commission to investigate the problems of modern dance in New York.

title: Rival Lebanon Militias Battle for the 4th Day
description: Lebanon's northern port of Tripoli was engulfed in fierce fighting for a fourth day today, and the police said casualties had been mounting.

title: Topics;   On Shaky Ground Transparent Defense
description: It would never occur to President Reagan to boast that he stands ''pretty near the middle'' between democracy and Communism. Yet he relies on just such misplaced evenhandedness to defend his limited sanctions against South Africa's white minority regime:

title: Honduras Debt Talks
description: The Government has decided, it said today, to suspend talks with 40 private American banks until a new administration takes office next year. The topic of the talks is renegotiation of payments on Honduras's $2.3 billion foreign debt. After elections on Nov. 24, a new president and congress will be sworn in Jan. 27.

title: REPUBLIC RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: TRIAL IN ROME HEARS ERRATIC TESTIMONY
description: The trial of eight men accused of conspiring to murder Pope John Paul II resumed today with erratic testimony from a witness who the prosecution had hoped would bolster its case and new, sweeping declarations by the leading witness, Mehmet Ali Agca.

title: Minister Suspended In Harassment Cases
description: A minister accused of sexually harassing five women was suspended from preaching when a panel of 13 other ministers on Tuesday convicted him of disobeying church laws.

title: Anti-Sandinista Chiefs Meet U.S. Aid Official
description: Three leaders of the Nicaraguan guerrillas fighting the leftist Sandinista Government met today with the United States official in charge of overseeing the distribution of $27 million in nonmilitary aid for the rebels.

title: FERRARO AND HOLTZMAN DISCUSS PLANS
description: In their first acknowledgement of their potential candidacies, Geraldine A. Ferraro and District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn yesterday discussed their possible opposition next year in a Democratic primary for the United States Senate.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Washington Talk page last Saturday about the case of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg misstated the amount of information the Government has released on the investigation and execution of the couple. According to the attorney for the Rosenbergs' sons, ''about 210,000'' pages of documents have been released.

title: ROCK: BANDS PERFORM IN FOLK CITY BENEFIT
description: ROCK bands played to benefit Folk City on Tuesday, in a marathon seven-act show.

title: BISHOPS BEGIN PLANNING FOR VISIT BY POPE, EXPECTED IN 1987
description: Planning has begun for an expected week-long visit by Pope John Paul II to the United States in the fall of 1987, officials of the National Conference of Catholics Bishops disclosed yesterday.

title: Days Inns Hotel
description: Days Inns of America Inc., the Atlanta-based chain of hotels, said that it had purchased a 600-room hotel in Manhattan from Holiday Inns Inc., a unit of the Holiday Corporation, as part of an expansion aimed at gaining a greater presence in metropolitan downtown locations. It would not disclose the price. Days Inns, whose hotels are primarily in the Sun Belt, said it had also acquired a property in Detroit and was seeking others in Boston, Chicago, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh, St. Louis and Washington.

title: TEXAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income.

title: FURNITURE WITH BARK
description: THE company was started a year ago to produce a range of well-crafted rustic furniture.

title: Weekend in Washington
description: The idea is deceptively simple, yet only Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the Missouri Democrat, does it on such a grand scale: invite a group of constituents to Washington for a long weekend and make sure they pay their own way for the right to see the Representative and the Government in motion. So, the ''1985 Gephardt Weekend in Washington, D.C.,'' as it is called in the official program, begins tonight with the arrival of a group from St. Louis on an Ozark Airlines charter.

title: Missouri Keeps Rape Law
description: The Missouri Supreme Court has preserved the state's rape law from a clerical error that would have automatically repealed the law. In a ruling Monday, the court threw out a sweeping anticrime package, approved this year by the Legislature, that would have resulted in repealing the rape law. Because of a change made in the anticrime law by the clerk, the bill signed by Gov. John Ashcroft ''never took effect as law,'' the court said.

title: Berent Friele, an Associate Of Rockefellers in Business
description: Berent Friele, a business associate for many years of the Rockefeller family and special assistant for diplomatic relations to Nelson A. Rockefeller when he became Governor of New York, died Sunday while hiking near Bronxville, N.Y. He was 90 years old and lived in Bronxville.

title: Brooklyn Connection
description: When Olympia Trails started bus service from the World Trade Center and Grand Central Terminal to Newark Airport in 1984, some people were skeptical, said the company's president, Nick Agathis.

title: Alzheimer's Is Bankrupting U.S. Families
description: To the Editor:

title: MATERIAL SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
THE U.S. QUANDRY
description: The Reagan Administration found itself in a quandary today as it sought to open the door for negotiations with Lebanese kidnappers on the release of the remaining American hostages, even though it was reasserting that the captors' demands were unacceptable.

title: COURT APPROVES RESTARTING PENNSYLVANIA REACTOR
description: A Federal appeals court today cleared the way for restarting the undamaged reactor at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant, which was shut down six years ago after the nation's worst commercial nuclear accident.

title: SENDING A MESSAGE
description: A Detroit businessman asked how it was possible that the multibillion-dollar American communications and advertising industries seemed to fail in delivering America's message to the Russians. They are so obviously effective here, he said, why can't they get the word through?

title: Dining Out Guide: Sunday Night
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: Minnesota Seeks Cause Of Penicillin in Milk
description: State officials were trying today to determine how milk adulterated with penicillin was allowed into retail supplies.

title: The Importance of Choice in Family Planning
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Bridge: Confusion May Be a Result When West Is in North Seat
description: In expert bridge circles, compass designations can be quite confusing: North can be West, and West can be North.

title: A Bibulous Thief
description: A thief with a discriminating palate has struck in Brooklyn.

title: ECOLOGY WARNING FROM WORLD BANK
description: The World Bank warned today that the destruction of environmental systems is ''assuming massive proportions'' in many developing countries, particularly in Africa, where it said ''widespread denudation of the vegetable cover'' had caused a shortage of firewood for 100 million people.

title: Patriots Sale Reported
description: He spent four hours this week inspecting the New England Patriots' training facilities, watching the team practice and meeting with members of the Sullivan family, which owns the club. Now there are reports that Robert K. Kraft, a Boston businessman who once tried to buy the Red Sox, has reached a tentative agreement to buy the Patriots, Sullivan Stadium and the adjacent Foxboro Raceway from the Sullivans for $91 million. Neither Kraft nor the Sullivans were commenting yesterday, but both The Boston Globe and The Boston Herald said unidentified sources had told them a tentative sale agreement had been reached.

title: A BOOTH-BY-BOOTH GUIDE TO THE FIFTH AVE. BOOK FAIR
description: Following is a booth-by-booth browser's guide to ''New York Is Book Country'' Fair:

title: Diner's Journal
description: FROM the avenue, it looks like just another slick East Side neon-and-fern bar specializing in frozen drinks sporting little umbrellas. Inside, though, the unmistakable aroma of garlic indicates something more substantial. Pizzico, a six-week-old Italian trattoria-like restaurant at First Avenue and 75th Street, turns out a host of beguiling little pizzas as well as some bright and tasty salads in a friendly, informal setting.

title: PHILHARMONIC: KORNGOLD CONCERTO
description: THE desire to prove our ancestors wrong is one of the great forces that keep the world turning. So it is in music that we are always happy to dredge up discarded works and give them a hearing with our keen modern ears, ever in hope that a reappraisal will discover merits that past generations overlooked. It was reappraisal time last night at Avery Fisher Hall for Erich Wolfgang Korngold's Concerto for Piano, Left Hand, and Orchestra in C sharp, a one-movement piece that came into being along with many others of its strange type as a result of the commissioning fervor of Paul Wittgenstein, who lost his right arm in World War I. Korngold was hailed as one of the most prodigious young talents in musical history, right up there with Mozart and Mendelssohn, early in this century. He wrote an opera at age 21 that still survives, if only barely, in the repertory, ''Die Tote Stadt.'' However, he had been generally dismissed in serious circles by the time he wrote this concerto. He went to Hollywood in 1934 and wrote many excellent movie scores, becoming possibly the richest composer in the world before his death in 1957. He remains one of music's most fascinating cases of unfulfilled genius.

title: First Boston Offers Four Separate Issues
description: The First Boston Corporation yesterday startled the debt markets with a simultaneous offering of four separate issues of collateralized mortgage obligations totaling $801 million.

title: PHILADELPHIA EVICTS FAMILY IN JERSEY FOR TAXES
description: Fifteen police officers and sheriff's deputies evicted a New Jersey family of four from its home today for nonpayment of $20,000 in Philadelphia wage taxes.

title: RIGHT-WING EXTREMISTS SEEK TO RECRUIT FARMERS
description: Right-wing extremist groups, some militantly anti-Semitic and counseling violence, are conducting a recruiting and propaganda effort aimed at financially troubled farmers throughout the Middle West.

title: DRAW IN CHESS MATCH
description: The sixth game of the world chess championship between the titlist, Anatoly Karpov, and his challenger, Gary Kasparov, ended in a draw today after Kasparov's 27th move.

title: F.A.A. TO INCREASE AIR CONTROLLERS
description: Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole announced plans today to add nearly 1,000 air traffic controllers over the next two years and 500 aircraft safety inspectors over the next three years.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds decreased $154.5 million, to $208.52 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: A Change of Heart?
description: Since 1982, Donald E. Moreland, a Cape Cod policeman, has been trying to promote the idea of a World Peace Day on which nations would suspend all fighting for 24 hours. He has tried, largely in vain, to enlist the support of the White House, ambassadors and officials at the United Nations, the Vatican and a wide range of other authorities.

title: TRIO-TECH INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Includes tax credits of $93,000 for the quarter and $303,000 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $225,000 for the quarter and $840,000 for the year.

title: VILLANOVA GIVES POLISH CARDINAL WARM WELCOME
description: When Jozef Cardinal Glemp, the Primate of Poland, visited Villanova University today, he was greeted by sights and sounds he might encounter at any college in the land: rock-and-roll blaring from a car radio, students munching burgers at the Connelly Center snack bar and young women wearing slightly punkish haircuts.

title: U.S. Uranium Pacts Voided
description: A Federal judge, acting at the request of three mining and milling companies, has voided the Energy Department's contracts for enriched uranium ore.

title: Stokely Offering
description: Stokely USA Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial offering of two million shares of common stock at an estimated $10 to $13 a share.

title: Nihilator Captures Pace
description: Nihilator outlasted his stablemate, Pershing Square, today to capture the Little Brown Jug, the third leg of pacing's Triple Crown.

title: CORRECTION
description: An editorial Wednesday misnamed the new chairman of the Port Authority. He is Philip Kaltenbacher.

title: STEP TAKEN TO END GENERAL STRIKE
description: The Government declared a state of siege today and arrested labor leaders who had refused to end a 16-day-old general strike. The strike was organized as a protest against a wage freeze intended to fight inflation of 14,000 percent.

title: KOTCHEFF'S 'JOSHUA'
description: ''THE Apprenticeship of Duddy Kravitz,'' the first collaboration between the director Ted Kotcheff and the novelist Mordecai Richler, is best remembered for its astute portrait of the title wheeler-dealer and for the comic avidity Richard Dreyfuss brought to the role. ''Joshua Then and Now'' reunites Mr. Kotcheff and Mr. Richler, who have worked together several times, for what amounts to a less sharply-drawn character study masquerading as a drama.

title: SLENDER FURS BY MAXIMILIAN
description: An emphasis on wild mink, which has taken a back seat to the tamer ranched varieties for about 40 years in the United States, and a return to the fitted coat are two of the fashion points Maximilian is making for fall and winter. The lush wild mink skins, which come from Canada, are used for a graceful jacket with rounded corners that can be worn with pants or any-length skirts. The most luxurious version of the fitted coat is in brown Russian broadtail with a generous collar of Russian sable.

title: A Fastidious Thief
description: A thief with a fastidious streak has struck in Greenwich Village.

title: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD UP SLIGHTLY IN MONTH
AMERICAN AT THE HAGUE SITS IN JUDGEMENT ON U.S.
description: The prepared testimony was finished at this afternoon's session of the World Court.

title: COURT ORDER DELAYS VICKS STOCK PLAN
description: Unilever N.V. won a temporary restraining order yesterday prohibiting Richardson-Vicks Inc. from issuing preferred stock carrying super voting rights intended to block a Unilever takeover.

title: Advertising;   People
description: * C. Patrick Mandarano and Ruth L. McCarthy have been named senior vice presidents at Carrafiello, Diehle & Associates, Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Philharmonic Ratifies New 3-Year Contract
description: Members of the New York Philharmonic ratified a new three-year contract yesterday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall. The vote was 56 to 34.

title: ITALO CALVINO, THE NOVELIST, DEAD AT 61
description: Italo Calvino, the master of allegorical fantasy who became Italy's leading contemporary novelist, died yesterday in a hospital in Siena, Italy, from the effects of a stroke he suffered on Sept. 6. He was 61 years old. Mr. Calvino was among the handful of major novelists of international standing and was to have delivered the prestigious Norton lectures at Harvard this fall.

title: AT 67, BERNSTEIN COMES HOME TO CARNEGIE HALL
