description: Once he was a ubiquitous figure in the music world - on television, explaining the intricacies of a Beethoven symphony to an enraptured young audience; on Broadway, with a string of hit musicals, culminating in ''West Side Story,'' and in New York Concert halls, leading the New York Philharmonic through one of its most productive and rewarding decades.

title: TCBY ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Retail Service Shift At Bank of America
description: The Bank of America, the nation's second-largest banking organization after Citibank, yesterday named Donald A. Mullane, an executive vice president, to head its consumer financial services operations - a job that includes responsibility for all the bank's retail services worldwide.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Armstrong Rubber Co., New Haven, has named Ivor J. Evans president of Blackstone North America Co., a subsidiary based in Jamestown, N.Y., that makes automotive and industrial products. Mr. Evans succeeds Reginald A. Lenna, who will retire Oct. 1.

title: VILLAGE MOURNS DOCTOR SHOME SAW AS A SAINT
description: More than once, Dr. John Kraai told grieving families not to expect a bill. ''You've already paid too much,'' he would say.

title: PASSER'S 'CREATOR'
description: ''CREATOR,'' Ivan Passer's new comedy, is about a terribly lovable, possibly insane biologist (Peter O'Toole), a Nobel Prize winner, who spends his time attempting to clone the wife he lost in childbirth 30 years before.

title: New Heck's President Was Part of Acquisition
description: Heck's Inc., a discount department store chain with more than 160 outlets in nine Southeastern and Middle Atlantic states, said yesterday that Theodore W. Kazleman had been named president and chief operating officer.

title: Advertising;   Addenda
description: * The Star will increase its circulation rate base 9.4 percent, to 3.5 million, and advertising rates the same percentage, as of the Jan. 7 issue.

title: Hockey;   DEVILS ACQUIRE JOHNSON FROM ST. LOUIS
description: The Devils acquired Mark Johnson, a center on the gold-medal-winning 1980 Olympic hockey team, from the St. Louis Blues yesterday for Shawn Evans and a future Devils' draft choice.

title: Old War, New Query on Missing Troops
description: ''Dear Mr. Secretary,'' began the letter from veterans seeking an accounting of comrades listed as missing in action or taken as prisoners of war.

title: How to Promote an Alternative to Protectionism
description: To the Editor:

title: AM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $3,547,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and $9,544,000, or 23 cents a share, for the year, and a gain of $5 million, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and year related to the company's reorganization. c-Includes a tax credit of $4,487,000, or 12 cents a share. d-Includes a tax credit of $9,919,000, or 25 cents a share, and a gain of $49,206,000, or $1.24 a share, resulting from the company's termination of its retirement plan.

title: New Zealand Air Sells Eight Planes
description: New Zealand Air Ltd., a state-owned airline, said it had sold eight older aircraft - six Boeing 737's and two McDonnell Douglas DC10-30's - to the International Lease Finance Corporation, a United States concern that owns and leases jets, for $106 million.

title: HEARING ON ROCK LYRICS
description: The lyrics to rock songs replaced the normal preoccupations of the Senate Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee today as the panel listened to a debate on what some groups insist is record-album pornography.

title: Eureka Talks Planned
description: Britain has invited leading industrialists and financiers from 18 countries to a conference next month to discuss financing for Europe's Eureka high-technology project, the Foreign Office said today. The conference on Oct. 14 will examine how Europe's financial markets can best back development projects. Eureka is intended to help Western Europe keep pace with technological advances in the United States and Japan.

title: Frank B. Hall
description: Frank B. Hall & Company said it had sold to the Reliance Insurance Company $50 million face amount of Hall's newly issued 12 percent exchangeable preferred stock as well as warrants to buy 2.7 million shares of the insurance broker's common stock.

title: UNINTENDED VICTIMS
description: The ''mindless stampede to protectionism'' against which President Reagan warned at his news conference probably would be aimed mostly at Japan - but the Latin American debtor nations could well be among its major victims, with grim consequences for Latin democracy, hemispheric security and the U.S. banking system.

title: KIN IN U.S. WORRYING ABOUT FATE OF RELATIVES
description: The devastating earthquake that struck Mexico City yesterday morning left Mexican-Americans across the country wondering about the fate of friends and relatives south of the border, with no way to obtain any reliable information.

title: NEW HIGH-RISES ARE BARRED IN MUCH OF UPPER EAST SIDE
description: The Board of Estimate yesterday barred new high-rise buildings on the residential side streets of the Upper East Side to protect the architectural character of the neighborhood.

title: HUNDREDS ARE FEARED DEAD AS BUILDINGS FALL AND BURN
description: A powerful earthquake struck central and southwestern Mexico early today, devastating parts of this city and three coastal states. The quake disrupted travel, commerce and communications and took a heavy toll of life and property.

title: State Seizes Iowa Insurer
description: Iowa's Insurance Commissioner, Bruce Foudree, today seized control of the Iowa National Mutual Insurance Company, saying its management had embarked on a ''course of destruction'' that caused losses of as much as $60 million.

title: Stocks Stage Broad Technical Rally
description: The stock market yesterday staged a broad-based technical rally in which secondary stocks greatly outpaced the blue chips.

title: BIOMET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
SCHYGULLA IN 'SHEER MADNESS'
description: WERE it not for the presence of two extraordinarily compelling actresses, Hanna Schygulla and Angela Winkler, Margarethe von Trotta's ''Sheer Madness'' might seem exactly that. The film, which opens today at Cinema Studio 2, presents a feminist view of friendship that is as peculiar as it is incomplete. The plot concerns the bond that develops between Olga (Miss Schygulla), a professor of women's literature, and Ruth (Miss Winkler), a gifted and extremely reticent artist who is desperately fearful of the outside world. From their first meeting, they share a warmth and understanding that can be only dimly understood by the film's other principals, who have the ill fortune to be men.

title: Good Losses
description: He wouldn't have believed it at the time, but something good did indeed emerge from those two 20-loss seasons that Roger Craig, the new San Francisco manager, suffered with the Mets two decades ago. ''Losing was a tremendous influence in shaping my pitching philosophy,'' says Craig. ''I learned the value of being competitive regardless of the circumstances.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page on Sept. 6, about the U.S.-Arab Chamber of Commerce, incorrectly characterized its Washington telephone number. The number - (202) 293-3162 - is in fact listed in the local directory.

title: CONDOMINIUM PLAN GIVES HARLEM A LIFT
description: To walk down Central Park West to Central Park South and then up Fifth Avenue is to stroll past some of the most expensive residential real estate anywhere. But turn the corner at the north end of the park, and there is, as if by some alchemy, a stark change. The buildings are suddenly and obviously not as well maintained, the street is dirtier, and there, just off Lenox Avenue, sit two beautiful old stone apartment buildings, bricked up and vacant since they were seized by the city for nonpayment of taxes in the 1970's.

title: New Gonorrhea Strain Resisting Tetracycline
description: Government medical researchers today reported the first cases of gonorrhea that cannot be treated with tetracycline, a drug often prescribed for patients allergic to penicillin.

title: Witness in Rome Trial Contradicts Agca
description: A Turkish witness for the prosecution in the papal plot trial today contradicted Mehmet Ali Agca's assertion that Bulgarians had organized and paid for the assassination attempt on Pope John Paul II in 1981.

title: MARINO HOPES TO STAY AWAY FROM BROTHER-IN-LAW
description: For some reason, the Kansas City Chiefs and the Miami Dolphins have managed to make their occasional meetings memorable, and most of their 12 encounters, at least those since 1969, have been close games.

title: ART: BASQUIAT, WARHOL
description: LAST year, I wrote of Jean-Michel Basquiat that he had a chance of becoming a very good painter providing he didn't succumb to the forces that would make him an art world mascot. This year, it appears that those forces have prevailed, for Basquiat is now onstage at the Tony Shafrazi Gallery at 163 Mercer Street, doing a pas de deux with Andy Warhol, a mentor who assisted in his rise to fame.

title: EDWARDS, A G & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
STRUCTURE OF POLIO VIRUS DECIPHERED BY SCIENTISTS
description: The complete three-dimensional structure of the polio virus has been determined, and researchers said today that the feat should help them develop a safer, more effective vaccine against the disease.

title: Stars of the Year Gone Next Year
description: By now, the fuzzy-cheeked legions of the Yankees' minor league system should be getting the idea: If you have dreams of a long career in the Bronx, then by all means do well on the farm. But not too well.

title: FROM MANN AND WEIL, SONGS FOR ALL SEASONS
description: POP history often has a way of coming into focus only years after it was made. Take, for example, the young songwriting teams who toiled in the cubicles of Broadway music publishers during the early 1960's: Carole King and Gerry Goffin, Barry Mann and Cynthia Weil, Ellie Greenwich and Jeff Barry. Only in retrospect, and years after the advent of rock journalism, did the creators of many of the biggest 60's hits become recognized as pop music ''auteurs.''

title: Bid by MidAmerican
description: ''he MidAmerican Commodity Exchange, a 105-year-old futures market that trades small agricultural contracts, has asked its big brother, the Chicago Board of Trade, to consider reorganizing the exchange as an affiliate. The request comes at a time of extensive consolidation within the commodities industry.

title: BRONX MAN, 27, COMMITS SUICIDE AFTER KILLING WIFE AND DAUGHTERS
description: A 27-year-old Bronx man killed his estranged wife and their two daughters yesterday and then fatally shot himself, the police said.

title: HISTORY NOT IN MICHAEL SPINK'S CORNER
description: Actually, Larry Holmes won't be the first bigger guy Michael Spinks has encountered in a fight. As a youngster growing up in St. Louis, Spinks often incurred the wrath of the neighborhood toughs who had run afoul of his older brother Leon. Spinks likes to recount how the big kids made him pay for Leon's various transgressions.

title: EX-CELL-O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
PERSONAL SPENDING SOARS 1.2%
description: Americans went on a buying spree in August, increasing their personal spending by the largest amount since April. But they financed the purchases by pushing their savings level to a record low, the Government reported today.

title: Dollars, Children and an American Priority
description: To the Editor:

title: Glass Cuts Kissinger's Nose
description: Former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger suffered a slight cut on his nose today from glass shattered by a news photographer who inadvertently crashed through a glass partition at the Citadel, a military school where Mr. Kissinger spoke on nuclear arms issues.

title: EX-JERSEY SENATOR, REPORTED MISSING IN BAHAMAS, CHARGED IN FRAUD CASE
description: A former New Jersey State Senator, reported to have vanished while scuba diving this month in the Bahamas, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges that he and two other former state officials defrauded a teamsters pension fund.

title: WEIR SAYS CAPTORS WANT 17 RELEASED
description: An American clergyman, freed by kidnappers in Lebanon after 16 months, said today that he had told President Reagan that Shiite militants continue to insist that they will not release the remaining American captives until the United States obtains the release of 17 terrorists held in Kuwait.

title: Communication
description: Undercover city investigators were on surveillance in Brooklyn. Signals from their second-hand radios were too weak and had to be relayed through a ''repeater'' device concealed in an empty car.

title: CARDS' ATTACK WORRIES GIANTS
description: After playing two games against teams with limited offensive weapons, the Giants face a severe test Sunday against the undefeated St. Louis Cardinals.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET RESUME TALKS ON ARMS
description: The United States and the Soviet Union resumed negotiations on nuclear and space weapons here today with no sign of a break in the six-month-old deadlock.

title: WESTWAY ALTERNATIVES RAISING NEW QUESTIONS
description: Already it has been dubbed Lessway - the decidedly unofficial designation for any of a half-dozen or so stripped-down transportation alternatives to Westway.

title: PENTAGON TESTS NEWS SYSTEM
description: The Pentagon said today that it secretly flew 12 reporters to a routine training exercise in Kentucky early this morning in a successful test of a system for allowing news coverage of the early stages of American military operations.

title: Art Dealer to Called In Ex-Employee's Trial
description: Defense lawyers said today that they would subpoena the art dealer Andrew Crispo in the trial of Bernard LeGeros, a former employee accused of slaying a Norwegian fashion student.

title: New York City
description: Interest rates for some of the New York City bonds due in 1986 through 1991 were reduced slightly, while yields for longer maturities were unchanged. The rates were set through negotiation between the city and underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. Yields for the bonds range from 5.60 percent in 1986 to 7.70 percent in 1990, 8 7/8 percent in 1995, 9 3/8 percent in 2000, 9.55 percent in 2005, 9 5/8 pecent in 2006 through 2009, and 9.53 percent for 9 percent bonds due in 2010 at a price of 95.

title: SWEEPING STAFF CUTS AT CBS NEWS
description: In the most severe single cutback to hit network television news, CBS News announced yesterday the elimination of 125 jobs, representing a 10 percent reduction in the news staff of 1,250.

title: 8 Are Taken Hostage For 3 Hours at Prison
description: A convicted murderer angry at being dismissed from a prison job took eight hostages today at the maximum-security Trenton State Prison, but released them unharmed three hours later, correction officials said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Everybody and their brother wants to build on the Upper East Side, and unless you stop them, they will.'' - Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis, Democrat of Manhattan, during a Board of Estimate zoning hearing. [A1:1.]

title: MODEST REVIVAL TO BEGIN FOR VILLANOVA FOOTBALL
description: For Kevin McNicholas, it is an opportunity to start at quarterback for four years, to have an offensive system built around his right arm.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tony McKegney, a 27-year-old left wing who had been entering the option year of his contract with the Minnesota North Stars, has signed a three-year contract with the club. . . . Barry McGuigan, the World Boxing Association featherweight champion who is to defend his title against Bernard Taylor in Belfast next week, disputed rumors that he had reinjured his right hand and insisted that he would be ready for the bout. . . . Ken Macha, a 35-year-old former Toronto infielder who has played for the Chunichi Dragons in Japan since 1982, has left the team after being told his contract would not be renewed because the club policy wants to use more young Japanese players. . . . Maricica Puica, the Rumanian who won the Olympic 3,000 meters last year, has withdrawn from the Fifth Avenue Mile Sept. 28 after being suddenly summoned home by Rumanian sports authorities, according to Fred Lebow, the president of the New York Road Runners Club, which sponsors the race. . . . Bjorn Borg, the 29-year-old Swedish tennis star, became a father Wednesday night when his 18-year-old fiancee, Jannike Bjorling, gave birth to a son in Stockholm, according to the Borg family.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ORWELL: The Lost Writings. By George Orwell. Edited and with an introduction by W. J. West. Illustrated. 304 pages. Arbor House. $20.

title: House Votes Amtrak Subsidy Of $603.5 Million, a 10% Cut
description: The House today approved to a bill calling for a $603.5 million Federal subsidy for Amtrak in the 1986 fiscal year. It also ordered a study of whether the passenger railroad could make more money.

title: ART: 'NEW HORIZONS,' AT THE GUGGENHEIM
description: TO be able to appreciate the strengths of ''New Horizons in American Art: 1985 Exxon National Exhibition,'' at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum through Nov. 3, it is necessary first of all to disgregard the title. The show has very little to do with ''new horizons in American art.''

title: PLOT THICKENS AT ARBOR HOUSE
description: IT has the ingredients of a potboiler: A young woman from the Middle West, with no formal training, moves to New York and joins a publishing house founded by a brilliant but temperamental editor. He sells the house to a larger company, and is dismissed when his contract expires. The young woman takes his place, and the house seems to thrive. But employees start abandoning the company, and even the woman has sought a job elsewhere. Industry gossips wonder: Was she jumping or being pushed?

title: 'Kiri Te Kanawa,' Profile of the Soprano
description: What is it like to be an opera star -a prima donna whose attractiveness and charm are almost as radiant as her singing? A hint of an answer is given in ''Kiri Te Kanawa,'' a profile of the New Zealand-born soprano to be shown tomorrow from 10 to 11 P.M. in Channel 13's ''Creative Edge'' series.

title: MARSHALL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
'STAR WARS' TO BE SUMMIT FOCUS
description: A senior White House official said today that President Reagan planned to make his space-based defense program a central theme of his meeting in November with Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: DYNEER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
A.M.C. Proposal
description: The American Motors Corporation may seek as much as $500 million to $600 million in state grants to build a new auto plant or refurbish its current facilities in Kenosha, a company vice president, Jerry L. Sloan, said. Without the state aid, the auto maker ''would be forced to locate elsewhere,'' Mr. Sloan said, adding that if the state made such concessions, ''we would be building a new small car in Kenosha.''

title: Berra Testifies in Court Again
description: Dale Berra of the Yankees testified in a second trial in United States District Court today that he had purchased cocaine from a man accused of selling the drug to major league baseball players.

title: ANITEC IMAGE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes nonrecurring after-tax income of $656,000, or 11 cents a share, from a real estate tax settlement with the City of Binghamton, N.Y., covering the fiscal years between 1982 through 1984.

title: STRUGGLE
description: IN ''A Matter of Struggle,'' Joan Harvey's feature-length documentary, Richie Havens, the folk singer and song writer, travels around America with two little girls, Meagan, 10 years old, and Toni, 8, who are as concerned as he is about the foreign and domestic policies of the Reagan Administration.

title: Thomson Plan With Olivetti
description: Thomson S.A. of France and Ing. C. Olivetti & Company of Italy, two of Europe's major electronics concerns, have joined Acorn Computer Group P.L.C., Olivetti's British home computer subsidiary, in an effort to create standards that could be used to develop small computers for sale throughout Europe.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium. Ron Darling is scheduled to go for his 17th victory against Rick Reuschel (13-7) in the opener of a three-game series. (Television - Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 8 P.M.) Yankees vs. Orioles, at Baltimore, opener of three-game series. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 8 P.M.) Padres vs. Atlanta Braves, at San Diego (Television - WTBS 10:05 P.M.) Golf World Seniors Invitational, second round, at Charlotte, N.C. (Television -ESPN 3 P.M. live.) Ladies PGA Konica San Jose Classic, opening round, at San Jose, Calif. Final event on the domestic tour, and both Nancy Lopez and Pat Bradley are in striking distance of $400,000 in earnings. Amy Alcott won here last year with a 15-under-par 211. LaJet Classic, at Abilene, Tex., second round. Harness Racing Sportsman's Park, Cicero, Ill., $354,553 Breeders Crown Trot for 4-year-olds and up. The Team Nordin Stable entry of Sandy Bowl, driven by John Campbell, and Keystone Edmund, driven by Jan Nordin, is the 2-to-1 early favorite for this race, which will be contested at a mile over the five-eighths-mile Sportsman's Park oval. (Television - ESPN 10:30 P.M.) Garden State, 8 P.M. The $300,000 Garden State Park Mile for 2-year-old pacing colts is the feature, and Follow My Star is the early favorite. (Television -Channels 23, 50, 52 and 58, 10:30 P.M.) Yonkers, 8 P.M. Monticello, 7:30 P.M. Other Events AUSTRALIAN RULES FOOTBALL: Preliminary final.

title: Deliver Us From Our Electoral College
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATE ROLL-CALL ON BILL ON ALIENS
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate voted today to approve a bill intended to reduce illegal immigration:

title: Cuba Agrees To Debt Shifts
description: Cuba, which has been urging third world nations to repudiate their foreign debt, has agreed on a rescheduling plan for some of the debt it owes to foreign banks, Credit Lyonnais said today.

title: MANOR CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Per share amounts reflect 3-for-2 stock split declared in August and to be distributed Sept. 30.

title: CITY DEFENDS DIAGNOSIS OF GIRL IN AIDS DISPUTE
description: The New York City Health Department said yesterday that it was standing by a physician's diagnosis that a public school pupil has AIDS despite statements from the child's lawyer that she might not have the disorder.

title: A New Manpower Man
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger is preparing to name Chapman B. Cox, the Pentagon's general counsel, as Assistant Secretary for Manpower, Installations and Logistics, according to department sources. He would succeed Lawrence J. Korb, a one-time scholar at the American Enterprise Institute who had served in the post since 1981 and resigned earlier this year to join the Raytheon Company.

title: SOUTH AFRICA ADMITS BREAKING MOZAMBIQUE PACT
description: Amid conflicting reports about its latest invasion of Angola, South Africa acknowledged today that its forces had also violated an nonaggression pact with neighboring Mozambique.

title: STAGE: 'SOLO VOYAGES,' PLAY EXCERPTS
description: ADRIENNE KENNEDY'S brief but imaginative plays, written over a period of 20 years, are densely populated by characters from a spiritual and mythic past as well as a tangible present. In ''The Owl Answers,'' Shakespeare, Chaucer and Anne Boleyn commingle with a questing American black woman; all worlds converge on a subway train in Manhattan.

title: BANTAM, AT 40, SPREADING ITS WINGS
description: When the first books rolled off the presses of Bantam Books in 1945, the 20 titles included ''The Great Gatsby'' by F. Scott Fitzgerald, ''The Grapes of Wrath'' by John Steinbeck and ''Life on the Mississippi'' by Mark Twain. The 25-cent reprints proved so popular that ''within a very short time our profit equaled our entire invested capital,'' Ian Ballantine, Bantam's founder, recalled yesterday.

title: JANE CLYMER
description: Jane Clymer, a Brooklyn resident and junior at the University of Vermont in Burlington, died Sunday at the university medical center after being struck by a car Saturday.

title: SONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The share earnings represent American Depository Receipt (ADR) with one ADR equal to one common share. All results were converted at the exchange rate of 237 yen equals 1 U.S. dollar as of July 31, 1985.

title: 'STREETWALKIN''
description: TIMES SQUARE tawdriness is ordinarily the province of male directors, but Joan Freeman has made a fast-paced, creditable B-movie out of ''Streetwalkin','' the tale of a naive young prostitute and her sadistic pimp. Why would Miss Freeman, a Harvard graduate from Shaker Heights, Ohio, turn from PBS documentaries and independent film making to this sort of thing? The answer to that is potentially more interesting than the film itself, but Miss Freeman does demonstrate a mastery over this distinctly limited form.

title: BROADWAY
description: A NEW Frank Loesser musical more than 15 years after the composer's death?

title: BOOK COUNTRY IS FOR BROWSERS
description: LISTEN, dear reader, and you shall hear Of books and authors from far and near.

title: Angels Catch Royals
description: The California Angels moved into a tie for first place with Kansas City in the American League West by defeating the White Sox, 8-0, tonight.

title: Chasing Bullets
description: People in and out of Washington have complained for years that the Congressional Record is not an entirely accurate account of what happens in Congress. One problem is that members are permitted to insert in the printed Record speeches that were never delivered on the floor, along with supporting documents that were never read there.

title: Beware, Bo
description: With Auburn leading both polls this week and Bo Jackson leading the nation in rushing, the Tigers are off and growling like a heavy favorite to sweep college football's two most sacred honors: the national championship and the Heisman Trophy. On the other hand, the smart isn't betting on it, especially the smart money that knows something about history.

title: 3 MORE FUMIGANTS FOR GRAIN BANNED
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it was taking off the market three more fumigants widely used by farmers to prevent insect infestations. The agency said it was taking the action because of the substances' potential to cause cancer.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   In Defense of Banks
description: In a recent article on the Op-Ed page, Ira Glasser, a lawyer, recounted his frustrations with New York City banks - and touched a nerve. All too often a visit to the bank is a nightmare of interminable lines, rude tellers and ignorant clerks.

title: EAST GROUP PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After gains on the sale of investments of $9,000 for the quarter and $4,299,000 for the 9 months. c-After gains on the sale of investments of $3,871,000 for the quarter and $17,448,000 for the 9 months.

title: PHARMAKINETICS LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: James Moody Quartet
description: The saxophonist and flutist James Moody will lead a quartet tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil , 88 Seventh Avenue South above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M. tonight and tomorrow; 10, 11:30 and 1 A.M. Sunday. There is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN POLICE START BRUTALITY INQUIRY
description: The police in Cape Town said today that they were investigating allegations of police brutality after complaints by mixed-race citizens of unprovoked attacks.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: THE venerable Coach House relishes its reputation as the Model T of American cuisine. While all the zealous young whippersnappers chase their free-ranging chickens and slather goat cheese on everything but the candlesticks, this Greenwich Village landmark putt-putts along with its rack of lamb, chicken pot pie and other reliquiae from the original James Beard Cookbook.

title: Jefferson Joins Browns
description: John Jefferson, the wide receiver, was traded yesterday to the Cleveland Browns, a day after ending a long holdout and signing a one-year contract with the Green Bay Packers.

title: Engine Maker Releases Data
description: A small company's effort to expand its jet engine parts business has forced the Pratt & Whitney Group of the United Technologies Corporation to release information it had considered proprietary.

title: METS GAIN ON CARDINALS WITH PITCHING AND POWER
description: To get from the home-team dugout to the locker room at Shea Stadium, you walk about 50 yards along a wooden passageway beneath the first-base grandstand. Last night, the Mets may have set a club record for mileage as they traveled the route, from one ball game to another.

title: No Ducking at the Tranportation Department
description: This time a year ago things were going well for Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole.

title: Iowa Govenor Seeking $91 Million Budget Cut
description: Citing a farm economy that ''went to hell in a handbasket'' this summer, Gov. Terry E. Branstad has proposed a 3.85 percent across-the-board cut in the state's $2.2 billion budget.

title: TALKS ON PACIFIC ALLIANCE FAIL
description: The United States and New Zealand failed agree today on a formula for ending their dispute over nuclear policy, State Department officials said.

title: Rumors On Hutton Spur Stock
description: The stock price of E. F. Hutton Group Inc. jumped in active trading yesterday, as the latest of a series of takeover rumors swirled through the market. Hutton's stock rose $2.375 a share, to $36.25, on a consolidated volume of nearly 660,000 shares.

title: JACK I. STRAUS, 85, MACY'S LEADER THROUGH 4 DECADES OF EXPANSION
description: Jack Isidor Straus, former chief executive officer of R. H. Macy & Company and a civic leader and philanthropist, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 85 years old and had homes in Manhattan, Oyster Bay, L.I., and Boca Grande, Fla.

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
The Next-Best Way
description: The inevitable is near: Governor Cuomo, Mayor Koch and Senators D'Amato and Moynihan agree that New York will file to trade in Westway by Sept. 30, the deadline for converting Federal highway funds into transit money.

title: Gracie Square Art
description: Art will be in bloom this weekend at Carl Schurz Park, East End Avenue, between 84th and 87th Streets.

title: WHEN AMERICAN DESIGN GROWS UP
description: THERE are roughly 300 objects in the Whitney Museum of American Art's vast exhibition ''High Styles:

title: Pinckney, Suns Agree
description: Ed Pinckney, the 6-foot-9-inch forward who helped Villanova win the national championship last season, has agreed to terms on a multiyear contract with the Phoenix Suns. A club spokesman said Pinckney, the club's first-round draft choice, is expected to sign the pact this week.

title: Advertising;   An Agency Gets Back Into Ice Cream Field
description: For Roy Sloan of Brooklyn Heights, the switch of the Haagen-Dazs account to the international McCann-Erickson from Advertising Management, after the premium ice cream company was acquired by Pillsbury, was a bittersweet experience. His agency lost its top piece of business, but it took a giant to replace what in effect is a one-man shop, a cottage industry.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 20, 1985
description: The Economy

title: Tax Reform's Penalty For an Elderly Couple
description: To the Editor:

title: ART: EXHIBIT INTRODUCES ABAKANOWICZ OF POLAND
description: THE room is packed with rows of bodies seated on the floor, but all we see is their brown, wrinkled backs as they sit hunched over in submissive silence. They could be gulag inmates, assembled for the order of the day, or primitive tribesmen in thrall to a charismatic leader. At once individuals and a crowd, they hypnotize the viewer by virtue of their rhythmic massing.

title: American Plan
description: The American Plan Corporation, a Dallas-based insurance holding company, has reached an agreement with the United States Assurance Corporation that will result in a $40 million cash infusion into American Plan. The deal provides for a loan of $7 million in cash before Oct. 1 and for the purchase of $33 million of a new series of convertible preferred stock before Dec. 31. In addition, United States Assurance has agreed to buy about 52 percent of American Plan's common shares from the company's chairman and chief executive, Abe Jay Lieber, and his family. Mr. Lieber has been ill, the company said.

title: GELDINGS FAVORED IN TWO MAJOR RACES
description: John Henry may be retired, but other geldings running beyond their pedigrees are taking his place as stars. Geldings will be favored in both of this weekend's major races, with Win heading a field of 12 in the Turf Classic at Belmont Park and Creme Fraiche the leading prospect in the $500,000 Super Derby at Louisiana Downs.

title: NEW LIFE AT LOBRO
description: Stepping out of a taxi in front of Bar Lui, Donna Clarke, a visitor from Palm Beach, Fla., met friends who told her reservations at the new restaurant were backed up 45 minutes. ''Quel bummer,'' she sighed. ''I guess I'll just drink.'' She'd heard of Bar Lui and wasn't going to miss it.

title: SOLID STATE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Year to April 30
REAGAN TELLS MOZAMBICAN OF DISTRESS THAT PRETORIA VIOLATED PACT
description: President Reagan met today with the President of the Marxist-ruled nation of Mozambique and told him he was ''distressed'' to learn that South Africa had violated a nonaggression pact with his country.

title: COUSINS HOME FURNISHINGS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $1.1 million from a combination of nonrecurring losses and gains for the quarter and year.

title: The U.N. Today: Sept. 20, 1985
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets on complaints by Angola at 10:30 A.M. >GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: A FEAR OF CRIME IS SAID TO HARM OUTER BOROUGHS
description: The downtown areas of Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx will not achieve economic vitality unless steps are taken to remove the public's fear of crime in those areas, according to a study by two civic groups.

title: Coffee Plan Rejected
description: Coffee-producing countries rejected an export incentives proposal today that was presented by coffee-consuming nations at International Coffee Organization negotiations. ''We cannot accept any mechanism that leads to penalties on undershipment,'' said a spokesman for the producers, Jorio Dauster. The meeting was called to draw up market-stabilization arrangements for the new crop year beginning Oct. 1.

title: Puerto Rican Folk Art
description: An exhibition of artwork from Manhattan's Museo del Barrio will open a celebration of the folk arts of Puerto Rico, beginning today at the Henry Street Settlement Arts Center, 466 Grand Street.

title: UPBEAT IMAGE IS SOUGHT FOR HEARST'S EXAMINER
description: This autumn, if all goes as planned, the publisher of The San Francisco Examiner will be the somewhat reluctant star in a series of television commercials promoting a new look for the paper, where William Randolph Hearst began building his newspaper empire in 1887.

title: CARDINALS' STREAK ENDS AT 7 GAMES
description: The Cardinals had a seven-game winning streak snapped tonight as they lost to the Phillies, 6-3, and saw their lead over the Mets in the National League East cut to one game.

title: Combustion Selling 3 Oil and Gas Units
description: Combustion Engineering Inc., a major supplier of electric power equipment, said yesterday that it would sell most of its oil and gas business and take a $200 million charge against third-quarter earnings, resulting in a loss for the year.

title: STUCK THIRD AVENUE BRIDGE CAUSES CHAOS AT RUSH HOUR
description: The Third Avenue Bridge, connecting the Bronx to upper Manhattan, stuck open during a routine test yesterday, causing ''near gridlock'' during the afternoon rush hour in the streets near its entrance.

title: COSMOPOLITAN CARE reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
14 CHARGED IN KICKBACKS IN CITY HOUSING PROJECTS
description: Fourteen people were charged yesterday with paying or receiving bribes and kickbacks at New York City's Housing Authority, bringing to 56 the number of people accused this year in a widening inquiry into the agency's repair and maintenance program.

title: Economic Scene;   Tax Proposal Found Skewed
description: THERE are several ways to analyze the effect of changes in tax law on people in different income classes - a process that tax planners call ''burden analysis.'' One common way is to figure the average percentage increase or decrease in taxes in each income category. Another is to calculate the increase or decrease in dollars.

title: JOINT STATEMENT ON WESTWAY
description: Following is the text of the joint statement on a trade-in of Westway funds issued yesterday by Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch:

title: CURB ON IMPORTS OF TEXTILE GAINS
description: The Congressional rebellion against President Reagan's trade policies accelerated today as a House subcommittee approved legislation that would reduce imports of textiles and apparel by up to 40 percent.

title: U.S. STEEL RAISES PRICE FOR SHEET BY ABOUT 10%
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steelmaker, yesterday raised the selling price of its major product by about 10 percent. Analysts said they expect the move to start a much-needed industry trend toward higher prices.

title: AMERICAN RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Faculty at Post Votes To End 11-Day Strike
description: Striking faculty members at the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University ended an 11-day strike by voting in favor of a new three-year pact today, school and union officials said.

title: HELD BY KUWAIT: 17 SHIITES
description: On Dec. 12, 1983, bombings took place in several places in Kuwait, including the American and French Embassies, the international airport, a petrochemical plant and an American residential area.

title: Auto Workers' Strike Slows Tank Production
description: A strike by 5,000 workers at five General Dynamics military plants in three states has crippled production of M-1 Army tanks, but a company official said today that the September schedule would be met.

title: 17 More Teachers Jailed In Rhode Island Strike
description: Seventeen more striking Rhode Island teachers were sent to jail yesterday for defying a back-to-work order, bringing to 53 the number of union members imprisoned in a 12-day strike.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''If Flavio Bucci was walking down a street in Rome, he would be followed by a crowd,'' said Ken Wlaschin, programming director for the American Film Institute.

title: Chief of Wheeling Expected to Resign
description: Dennis J. Carney, the embattled chairman and chief executive of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, is expected to submit his resignation to a special session of the board Friday, according to sources close to the company.

title: TIGERS SWEEP FADING YANKS
description: The race slipped a little farther away from the Yankees tonight, but Billy Martin continued to insist that his team ''keep pushing.'' Instead, they keep sliding.

title: 'MISHIMA,' A LIFE OF THE JAPANESE WRITER
description: IN his lifetime, Yukio Mishima wrote approximately 40 novels, 18 plays and 20 volumes of short stories, becoming the first modern Japanese writer to be almost as famous and respected internationally as he was at home. Though Mishima's fiction exhibits a continuing preoccupation with death, blood and suicide, Mishima himself carefully nurtured a flamboyant public personality that seemed designed to contradict the morbid obsessions of his writings.

title: MEXICO SEEN OUT OF COMPLIANCE WITH I.M.F. PLAN
description: Mexico has fallen out of compliance with an austerity program established by the International Monetary Fund, probably costing it more than $900 million in I.M.F. assistance and substantially complicating its relations with creditor banks around the world, financial sources said last night.

title: A 24-Foot Cookie
description: A giant cookie is on the menu in Peekskill Sunday. Chefs and culinary students from the metropolitan area will gather at the Peekskill Riverfront Green, off Route 9. to bake a chocolate chip record-breaker capable of serving 6,000.

title: Second Septuplet Is Home
description: The second of the three surviving septuplets went home from the hospital with his parents today, hooked up to an oxygen tank that will help him to breathe. Richard Charles Frustaci, one of seven babies who were born prematurely on May 21 to Samuel and Patricia Frustaci, was described by doctors at Children's Hospital of Orange County as ''in excellent shape'' despite his weak lungs. His sister Patricia went home two weeks ago, but his brother Stephen will be kept in the hospital for at least one more week to allow him to gain more weight.

title: PRICES UP FOR NOTES AND BONDS
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose modestly yesterday, fueled by a widely circulated rumor that the Commerce Department will announce this morning a 2.8 percent estimated rise in gross national product for the third quarter, after inflation.

title: 'SPENSER: FOR HIRE,' IN SERIES DEBUT ON ABC
description: SPENSER, the good-looking hero of the new private-eye series making its debut on Channel 7 this evening at 9, looks at his attractive woman friend and, eyes twinkling, confesses, ''I never said I was smart - just tough and sexy.'' But having already listened to him quoting Wordsworth and Melville, we know the big lug is just being modest. ''Spenser: For Hire'' was plucked by the executive producer John Wilder from a series of detective novels written by Robert B. Parker.

title: Market Place;   Caution Grows On Ad Stocks
description: AFTER climbing to record prices this year, stocks of advertising agencies have pulled back recently in line with general weakness in the equity market. Analysts following this group now are taking a somewhat cautious view of its prospects.

title: 'Birth of an Orchestra' At Prospect Park
description: Musicians of Brooklyn Initiative, a collective of Brooklyn performers, will give their inaugural concert Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Prospect Park Bandshell, near Prospect Park West and Ninth Street. The free concert, dubbed ''Birth of an Orchestra,'' will conclude with music by the 50-piece MOBI Jazz and Repertory Orchestra led by the trumpeter Lester Bowie; the group includes David Murray, Joseph Jarman, Julius Hemphill and Roscoe Mitchell on saxophones, Joe Bowie and Craig Harris on trombones, Vernon Reid on guitar, Eliot Zigmund and Steve Reid on drums.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Eldar Ryazanov, a writer-director who is known as ''the Russian Billy Wilder'' on the one hand and ''the Russian Johnny Carson'' on the other, was deep into a three-egg omelet at a Sunset Boulevard motel this week. Mr. Ryazanov, whose ''Ruthless Romance'' opened Wednesday at the Embassy-49th Street Theater in New York after its screening at the Toronto Film Festival, has a television audience estimated at 100 million people for his weekly ''View of the Movies'' and was voted the most popular director in the Soviet Union last year.

title: GENCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $8,822,000 for the quarter and $2,221,000 for the 9 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $3,685,000. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2,615,000. The latest third quarter and 9 months results include after tax special charges of $3.4 million, or 16 cents a share. The year-earlier quarter and 9 months results include after tax special charges of $10.3 million, or 47 cents a share.

title: Advertising;   New Ratliff + Shanley To Specialize in Art
description: Paul Shanley, former publisher of Art in America magazine, has joined Morris Ratliff in the creation of Ratliff + Shanley, a new ad agency specializing in the advertising of art galleries and other art world institutions.

title: FRASER REALTY GROUP INC reports earnings for Year to May 31
PATRICIA MILLER AYRES
description: Patricia Miller Ayres, an editor of Guideposts magazine and former general manager of Parents Magazine Press, died Tuesday at Roosevelt Hospital of a cerebral hemorrhage. She was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 20, 1985
description: International

title: AUCTIONS
description: TWICE in five years, Sotheby's has offered the same 17th-century Dutch drawing at auction - the first time identified as a Rembrandt, the second as ''attributed to Rembrandt.'' The presale estimates differed substantially, and so did the results.

title: Speaking of Transportation . . .
description: Peering over his glasses, puffing on his cigar, Representative Jack Brooks, chairman of the House Committee on Government Operations, wore a grin as wide as a smoked-glass windshield today as the visiting Senator waxed indignant about the problem of privileged Government locomotion in the capital.

title: Uganda Guerrillas Said to Besiege Town
description: Guerrillas are besieging Government troops in the western town of Mbarara, leaving hundreds of civilians dead and forcing hundreds of others to flee, witnesses were quoted as saying today.

title: Thai Officer Arrested In Slaying During Coup
description: The police arrested one of two junior officers accused of fatally shooting two television journalists during the unsuccessful coup last week, the newspaper Thai Rath reported today.

title: U.S. COUNTERS PUBLIC FEARS OF AIDS
description: The top three Federal science administrators responsible for research on AIDS said today that the disease was causing an ''epidemic of fear'' and feeling of helplessness that was ''absolutely unnecessary.''

title: Unabated Problems in New York City Voting
description: To the Editor:

title: TEXAS AIR MAKES OFFER FOR FRONTIER AIRLINES
description: The Texas Air Corporation, fresh from a takeover attempt for Trans World Airlines, yesterday offered to buy Frontier Holdings Inc., which runs the nation's 15th-largest carrier, Frontier Airlines.

title: BEARS DEFEAT VIKINGS
description: Jim McMahon, who was placed in traction earlier this week because of neck injuries, threw three third-quarter touchdown passes tonight to power the Chicago Bears to a 33-24 victory over the Minnesota Vikings.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL MONTREAL (NL) - Appointed Gary Hughes as Director of Scouting.

title: DEMOCRATS ASK PANEL TO BROADEN INQUIRY INTO WHITE-COLLAR CRIME
description: Democratic members of the Senate Judiciary Committee asked today that the panel broaden its investigation of the Justice Department's prosecution of corporate crime.

title: Economic Sanctions Work
description: The debate over economic sanctions against South Africa again raises the question of whether sanctions work. Each time the United States considers them, pundits flood the public with reminders about the League of Nations and Ethiopia, the oil embargo against Japan in 1941, 25 years of trade restrictions against Cuba and the United Nations sanctions against Rhodesia. President Jimmy Carter's grain embargo, triggered by the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, is another favorite example of the foolishness of sanctions.

title: Coastal Coal Deal
description: The Coastal Corporation said that it had agreed to buy Texaco Inc.'s 50 percent stake in the Skyline Coal Project in Scofield, Utah, for $34 million. The transaction, which is subject to government approvals, will give Coastal 100 percent ownership of the project, formed in the late 1970's as a joint venture with the Getty Oil Company. Texaco said the sale would complete the disposition of the United States coal properties that it acquired in its merger with Getty in 1984.

title: MAJOR EVENTS FOR WESTWAY
description: Following is a short history of the Westway project: 1971 - Members of the State Urban Development Corporation propose the Wateredge development, Westway's predecessor. It envisions the creation of 700 acres of new land along the West Side of Manhattan. 1973 - An asphalt-laden dump truck, dispatched to repair the old West Side Highway, built in the 1930's, crashes through an elevated section of the road. Much of it is closed, never to be reopened. 1974 - The Westway project is proposed to create a new West Side Highway and redevelop the West Side corridor. Opponents sue to block it. Hugh L. Carey, after winning the election for Governor, reverses his opposition to the project. 1977 - The State Transportation Department applies to the Army Corps of Engineers for a Hudson River landfill permit. 1978 - Edward I. Koch, after winning election as Mayor, reverses himself and backs the Westway project. 1981 - The Corps of Engineers issues a dredging and landfill permit. President Reagan presents the city with a symbolic $85 million check to buy right of way, declaring that ''the Westway project begins today.'' 1982 - Judge Thomas P. Griesa of Federal District Court blocks the permit, saying the corps did not adequately consider the effects of the landfill on striped-bass hatcheries in the Hudson River. 1983 - A report commissioned by Governor Cuomo favors abandoning the Westway project and trading in the money for mass-transit funds. The Governor rejects the recommendation. 1984 - The Corps of Engineers holds public hearings on the project and its environmental impact, especially the effects on striped bass. 1985 - The corps issues a new permit, and the matter returns to Judge Griesa.

title: ON THE EAST SIDE, EATING, SHOPPING AND NONSTOP FUN
description: THERE are street fairs and there are street fairs, but Sunday's Third Avenue Festival, its promoters say, is the largest one-day street festival in the United States. Hundreds of thousands of people are expected to jam every foot of upper Third Avenue to eat, shop and be entertained from 11 A.M. to 5:30 P.M.

title: South Africa Loan Listings
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission does not plan to require American banks to disclose their lending to South Africa, officials said today.

title: Tax-Free Bonds
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation announced this week plans to sell $125 million of tax-exempt bonds in the week of Oct. 7, through competitive bidding. Proceeds of the sale will be used to retire about half of the corporation's commercial paper notes.

title: INDONESIAN TELLS OF A SLAVE TRAP AT TRIAL OF TWO CHARGED BY U.S.
description: An Indonesian woman testified Wednesday that the people she thought were going to help her rise from the poverty of Jakarta to prosperity in California took away her passport and made her a virtual slave.

title: MITTERRAND ORDERING INTELLIGENCE SHUFFLE IN GREENPEACE CASE
description: President Francois Mitterrand today ordered an overhaul of the French intelligence agency, which has been at the center of a scandal over the sinking of an antinuclear protest ship in New Zealand.

title: The Arts' Key Role in Our Society
description: This is a year curiously dotted by anniversaries; and one must hope that, as we salute the bitter memories of war, a less dramatic anniversary will not slip by unnoticed.

title: Panel Drops Plan for $1 Fee For Some Who Enter Country
description: Bowing to pressure from border state Senators, the Senate Finance Committee on Wednesday dropped a proposal to charge $1 a head for people entering the United States on foot, by bicycle or by private automobile.

title: HOLLYWOOD TURNS OUT FOR AIDS BENEFIT
description: More than 2,500 people, including Elizabeth Taylor, Shirley MacLaine and Mayor Tom Bradley, crowded into the Westin Bonaventure ballroom here tonight to raise money for AIDS victims, a cause that was far from popular a few months ago.

title: NEW YORK LEADERS GIVE UP WESTWAY AND SEEK TRADE-IN
description: New York's top elected officials today abandoned their decade-long effort to build Westway and said they would seek to use the Federal money set aside for the project to build a less-elaborate road and help mass transit.

title: Why We Are Now a Debtor Nation
description: When a reporter asked the President, at his news conference this week, whether he was disturbed that America had become a debtor nation, Mr. Reagan was well primed.

title: EPIC Accused By Creditors
description: The bank trustees for mortgages and mortgage-backed securities sold by EPIC Mortgage yesterday filed a contempt of court motion against EPIC. They asserted that it might be diverting funds.

title: A FRAGILE PART OF MEXICO'S SHORE GIVES WAY
description: It was an earthquake that had to happen.

title: Halcyon Holds 7.9% SCM Stake
description: Halcyon Investments, a New York-based limited partnership, said it had purchased 784,300 shares of the SCM Corporation, or 7.9 percent of the New York-based chemical concern.

title: Water Customers Aided by Tax Cut
description: Customers of a water utility in Queens will receive credits of $25 to $34 on average bills of $230 to $309 because of a change in a city tax law and a State Public Service Commission ruling, the state said today.

title: SENATE VOTES BILL DESIGNED TO CURB ILLEGAL MIGRANTS
description: The Senate today passed a comprehensive bill intended to curtail illegal immigration after breaking a procedural deadlock that had delayed a vote for two days.

title: EXCERPTS FROM EX-HOSTAGE'S NEWS CONFERENCE
description: Following are excerpts from the Rev. Benjamin Weir's news conference, held at the National Presbyterian Church and Center in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Filipinos Plan Protests; Army Goes on Full Alert
description: The Philippine Army was placed on full alert today as anti-Government activists called for strikes and a mock trial of President Ferdinand E. Marcos to mark the 13th anniversary Saturday of the declaration of martial law.

title: BAR MORE RUSSIANS, WEINBERGER SAYS
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the United States should reduce the number of Soviet citizens it allows to work and travel here in order to curtail their collection of American military technology.

title: KOCH, INVITED TO U.N., ASSAILS RUSSIA AND BULGARIA
description: Mayor Koch came to this center of diplomacy today and within minutes denounced two countries, held what diplomats might term a ''spirited'' news conference, and then, striding through the building's corridors, asked, ''How'd I do? Did I do all right?''

title: 2 Hurt in L.I. Copter Crash
description: A helicopter crashed and burned at Long Island-MacArthur Airport here today, injuring the pilot-instructor and a student, according to Warren Greene, an airport official. The pilot was identifed as John Kjekstad, 23 years old, of Smithtown, and the student, Otto Rieder, 20, of Holbrook. Mr. Rieder was in critical condition and Mr. Kjekstad in satisfactory condition at Brookhaven Memorial Hospital in East Patchogue.

title: Advertising;   Ad Executive Who Is His Own Spokesman
description: Although he is an advertising man, Harold Levine, chairman of Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, knows a thing or two about public relations as well.

title: A Planner's Planner
description: It was in the Board of Estimate chamber that Norman Marcus last saw Millard Humstone - once his mentor at the City Planning Department and long a master of the Zoning Resolution's intricacies.

title: Beaver Harris Sextet
description: The drummer Beaver Harris will lead his jazz sextet, the 360 Degree Experience, on Sunday at 7 P.M. at St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street (935-2200). Errol Parker will open the concert with piano solos. Tickets are $5.

title: BERNADETTE PETERS TRAINS VOICE LIKE A MUSCLE
description: It seemed the last thing Bernadette Peters should be doing in the afternoon yesterday after opening in ''Song & Dance,'' in which she must not only sing nonstop for a solid hour but also carry the entire first act of the show.

title: Peak Grain Output Seen
description: World grain production this season should break records, despite a downward revision in forecasts for wheat harvests, the International Wheat Council said today. It estimated that grain output would rise 2.4 percent, to 1.35 billion metric tons, from last year's record of 1.32 billion.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Friday PLENTY MORE HARE David Hare, the British playwright who won acclaim with ''Plenty'' a while back, has a new play starting performances at the Public Theater this weekend. ''A Map of the World,'' which stars Elizabeth McGovern, Zeljko Ivanek, Roshan Seth and Alfre Woodard, is directed by Mr. Hare. Set in Bombay at a Unesco conference on world poverty, the story revolves around the ideological showdown between an Indian novelist and an English journalist, with a young American actress caught in the middle. Weekend performances are at 8 P.M. on Friday, Saturday and Sunday. Tickets are $20 and $25. Also at the Public this weekend is an unusual film event, a reconstructed version of Erich von Stroheim's ''Queen Kelly.'' The film, a 1929 epic starring Gloria Swanson, was shut down with nearly two-thirds of its script still to be shot when Miss Swanson declared the director a ''madman'' and demanded that Joseph Kennedy, the producer, remove him. This reconstruction used the original shooting script to realize, as closely as possible, the director's intended vision. Showings are today, Saturday and Sunday at 4:30, 6:15, 8, and 9:45 P.M. Tickets are $5. Information: 598-7105. VIDEO TECHNOLOGY AND ART Anyone interested in the new video technology and its impact on art and design can head uptown to Harlem for ''The Artist and the Computer,'' an exhibition of avant-garde art, video, dance, music, graphics and technology. Systems on display include the Fairlight Computer Video Instrument, the Hearn Video Lab Processor, the Easel Paint and Graphics System with Lumena software, the Alpha Syntauri Music Synthesizer, the Jones Frame Buffer, Colorizer and Computer Interface, all demonstrated by artists who have used and designed them.

title: AMERICA II SKIPPER RESIGNS HIS POST
description: John Kolius, who has been leading the New York Yacht Club's campaign to win back the America's Cup in 1987, has resigned as skipper and sailing manager of the America II syndicate.

title: Meridian Rejected
description: Meridian Bancorp Inc. said its offer to acquire the Commonwealth National Financial Corporation for $38 a share, or about $113 million, had been rejected by Commonwealth.

title: POTAMKIN CHRYSLER FRANCHISE
description: The Chrysler Corporation said yesterday that the sole dealership it owns and operates in Manhattan had been acquired by Victor Potamkin, the New York entrepreneur who runs the nation's leading Cadillac dealership, under a franchise agreement.

title: Exxon Pipeline Bond Repurchase
description: The Exxon Pipeline Company yesterday announced plans to repurchase up to $100 million of marine terminal revenue bonds issued by Valdez, Alaska, on behalf of the company.

title: PRATT & WHITNEY'S WORKHORSE
description: In the 21 years since the debut of Pratt & Whitney's JT8D jet engine, it has made its mark in aviation history. This engine powers nearly half of all commercial planes flying today, and it has compiled a record of having flown more hours than all other commercial jet engines combined.

title: NATIONAL SERVICE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Percussion-Saxophone
description: The percussionist Jerome Cooper will play duets with the saxophonist Kalparusha tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Images and Sound, 177 Franklin Street, near Hudson Street, fourth floor (219-3651). Tickets are $7.

title: Victory for Farrell
description: Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., who ran a poor third in the Democratic mayoral primary, fared considerably better in his latest election. He was unanimously re-elected Manhattan Democratic chairman by the Manhattan party's executive committee Wednesday evening.

title: Advertising;   Thoughts From a Reasearcher
description: ALTHOUGH only a teen-ager when he left his native Hungary, George S. Fabian already had a burning desire to know what makes some products successful and what makes consumers tick.

title: WIDOW SAYS ASIAN GANG ARRESTS MAY SHOW WIDER PLOT IN MURDER
description: Helen Liu, the widow of Henry Liu, a slain Chinese-American journalist, said Tuesday that the racketeering complaints brought in Manhattan Monday against alleged members of the United Bamboo gang might show a broader conspiracy surrounding the murder of her husband.

title: NEW DELAY SEEN IN REDEVELOPING TIMES SQ. AREA
description: The Times Square redevelopment project may not be finished until more than a year after its original 1991 completion date, according to a construction timetable released yesterday.

title: SENATE PANEL VOTES FARM BILL, DEFYING CHAIRMAN AND WHITE HOUSE
description: The Republican-controlled Senate Agriculture Committee, defying both its chairman and the White House, tonight approved a four-year farm bill whose costs would exceed the level set in the 1986 budget Congress adopted in July.

title: KASPAROV BLOCKS KARPOV'S EDGE WITH WHITE
description: Gary Kasparov, challenger for the world chess championship, played crisply and precisely to force the champion, Anatoly Karpov, to a draw in the sixth game of their match in Moscow's Tchaikovsky Concert Hall on Thursday.

title: RIGHTS AIDE CALLS QUERIES RACIST
description: The head of the Federal Commission on Civil Rights Thursday accused the chairman of a House subcommittee of racism for questioning why more women and members of minority groups were not appointed to the commission's new state advisory panels.

title: St. Peter's Loses
description: Ed Christensen rushed for two touchdowns to lead Marist to a 21-0 victory over St. Peter's tonight. The Peacocks (0-1) suspended the sport last season after an opening loss, 72-0, to Catholic University, after which school officials found that 4 of the 29 available players were ineligible.

title: HEARING ON PRESSER TIE HELD
description: A laywer for the Justice Department told a Federal judge today that the Reagan Administration had ''no hidden agenda'' behind its motion to dismiss an indictment of Allen Friedman, the uncle of Jackie Presser, the teamsters' union leader.

title: A PROMISING MILITARY TAKEOVER IN UGANDA
description: To the Editor:

title: GROUP CANCELS MEETING WITH SS
description: About 50 American veterans of World War II, in the face of criticism, canceled a reunion with German Waffen SS troops they fought, a member of the United States group said Thursday.

title: Ford Prices 2.9% Higher On '86 Cars
description: The Ford Motor Company today announced price increases for its 1986 model cars that it said average 2.9 percent.

title: ORBIT INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a charge of about $900,000 with respect to research and development services performed by Zytrex Corp., which has filed a petition for reorganization under the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: ECKERD, JACK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $6,858,000 for the quarter and $6,053,000 for the year and a loss from disposal of discontinued operations of $60,645,000 for quarter and year. c-Net income. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $211,000. e-After net from discontinued operations of $1,649,000.

title: PRINCETON STARTS A NEW ERA
description: Princeton football players have had to be on the ball long before they handle the ball in their opening game against Dartmouth at Hanover, N.H., today.

title: PAPER PRODUCTS TO COOK WITH
description: In the well-ordered kitchen of a decade or two ago there were four disposable products made of paper: muffin cups, napkins, wax paper and paper towels. Among the more advanced cooks or those who gave elegant dinner parties, there might have been a roll of parchment paper for an ''en papillote'' dish and ''panties,'' the ruffled bits of paper used to cover the bare bones on such dishes as a crown roast of lamb. Those of us who could not find parchment paper or paper panties substituted aluminum foil. It didn't look as elegant, but it worked.

title: U.S. STARTS INQUIRY ON G.N.P. LEAK
description: The Commerce Department, faced with what appeared to be the second premature disclosure of the ''flash'' estimate of the gross national product's growth in as many quarters, said today that it had called in the Federal Bureau of Investigation to help find out how it occurred.

title: ONLY CHEERS FOLLOW U.S. STEEL'S PRICING
description: Although there was cheering yesterday in the steel industry for the United States Steel Corporation's move to lift the price of sheet steel, no other mills immediately followed suit. Some analysts doubted whether the increase would stick, others said it was too early to tell.

title: PERCHANCE TO SEE
description: The struggle to get the attention of members of Congress, and their key aides, never ends here in the city of eternal lobbying.

title: STATE DEPT. ASSISTANCE QUAKE IN MEXICO: FEARS AND WORRY NORTH OF THE BORDER
description: The State Department has established a task force on the Mexican earthquake to answer the questions of Americans concerned about United States citizens in that country, officials said today. The telephone number, which will operate around the clock, is (202) 653-7959.

title: BAY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income including gains on disposition of investments of $3,332,525.

title: FERRARO UNCERTAIN ABOUT SENATE BID
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro said today that she would not seek the Democratic nomination to oppose Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York if she thought that another expected Democratic candidate, District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn, could defeat him.

title: SENATE PANEL BACKS TOBACCO BILL AND EXTENDS TAX
description: After complex political maneuvers, the Senate Finance Committee today approved measures that would change the tobacco price support program and permanently extend the 16-cent-a-pack cigarette tax.

title: THE MAKING OF A $500 MILLION U.S. POSTAL SERVICE DEFICIT
description: To the Editor:

title: FALCON PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: b-Net loss.

title: MAX & ERMA'S RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 4
ART INSTITUTE OF CHICAGO BUYS PORTRAIT OF KILLER
description: The Art Institute of Chicago has purchased a portrait of John Wayne Gacy, who was convicted in 1980 of the sex killings of 33 young men in Chicago, according to James N. Wood, the director of the museum.

title: BEWARE THE WATCHBIRDS
description: The contemplation of revenge is as sweet in Washinton as anywhere, and the victim is rarely warned.

title: GUILLERMO SARABIA, 49, BARITONE AT MET OPERA
description: Guillermo Sarabia, a Mexican-born American baritone who sang with both the Metropolitan Opera and the New York City Opera, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Thursday night in Amsterdam, where he lived. He was 49 years old.

title: WORTH TUTTLE HEDDEN
description: Worth Tuttle Hedden, an award-winning novelist and a champion of minority rights, died last Saturday at the Williams Health Care Facility in Augusta, Me. She was 89 years old.

title: An Acquisition By First Union
description: The First Union Corporation said its board and the board of Southern Bancorp Inc. of Greenville, S.C., had approved a definitive agreement for First Union to acquire Southern Bancorp for $216 million.

title: U.S. EXPERTS POISED TO HELP IN RESTORING PHONE SERVICES
description: American telecommunications experts were preparing to leave for Mexico yesterday to try to restore telephone and telex services, both in shambles after Thursday's earthquake.

title: HARRY A. MURRAY DIES: HEADED LORD & TAYLOR
description: Harry A. Murray, former president of Lord & Taylor and an executive of the department-store chain based on Fifth Avenue for 27 years, died Thursday at Point Pleasant (N.J.) Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Spring Lake, N.J., and on Longboat Key in Sarasota, Fla.

title: BUSH AND FAMILIES OF HOSTAGES MEET
description: Vice President Bush met today with the families of the six remaining American hostages in Lebanon and told them that the United States would be willing to talk to the captors to try to gain their release.

title: RISK-BASED PREMIUMS ARE ASKED BY F.D.I.C.
description: An estimated 13 percent of the nation's banks, those judged to be engaged in risky practices, would pay higher premiums for Federal deposit insurance under a proposal outlined today.

title: CABARET: BASSEY SINGS
description: Although 20 years has passed since Shirley Bassey became an international star belting out the title song from the movie ''Goldfinger,'' the Welsh-born pop diva has kept in perfect control of a fire-and-thumbtacks voice that still sounds all but indestructible. Miss Bassey, who appeared at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday and Wednesday with a medium-sized orchestra, projects a musical personality that is like a giant cartoon poster both in its size and in its one-dimensional dramatic expressiveness.

title: HERPES ISMUCHMORE THAN AN ANNOYANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN ANDLIBERAL ARTS
description: Without fuss or fanfare or a formal position paper, President Reagan has come out solidly in favor of the liberal arts degree. He gave his view when a college student at a White House meeting said, ''I'd like to know what you see as the value of a liberal arts education in today's fast-moving, high-tech society.''

title: IN TRADE, FAIR IS AS FAIR DOES
description: About 10 days ago President Reagan announced that the United States for the first time was pressing specific charges of unfair trade practices against Japan, South Korea, Brazil and the European Economic Community.

title: THEODORE YNTEMA, EX-OFFICIAL AT FORD, DIES
description: Theodore O. Yntema, a former vice president and director of the Ford Motor Company, died Wednesday at Henry Ford Hospital here. He was 85 years old and lived in West Bloomfield, Mich.

title: 'MORONS,' SPACE-TOURIST COMEDY
description: Since ''Morons From Outer Space'' is not the most promising title imaginable, the good-natured British farce that accompanies it is a nice surprise. This comedy, directed by Mike Hodges (''Pulp,'' ''Get Carter'') and written by two co-stars of ''Not the Nine O'Clock News,'' challenges the usual notion that the extraterrestrials who visit us are the cream of the universe. What if a group of ordinary tourists, the interplanetary equivalent of middle-class, middlebrow vacationers in a mobile home, were to wind up here by accident? The movie asks this question, answers it and provides some enjoyably offbeat humor along the way.

title: PERCHANCE TO PRAY
description: In Washington, the word ''litany'' is routinely misused by bureaucrats and others to mean any kind of a list. But at the Washington Cathedral, appropriately, someone knows that the first meaning of litany is a prayer in which the clergy and the congregation alternately recite lines of supplication and responses.

title: OLD-MUSIC GALA
description: Music Before 1800 will hold its 10th anniversary gala tomorrow at 6:30 P.M. A champagne buffet will be followed by a concert featuring performers and music from the 10 years of Music Before 1800 concerts.

title: White Joins Eagles
description: Reggie White, a standout defensive end in the United States Football League, signed a series of four one-year contracts with the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: A WAY TO FIGHT PAC'S
description: A year from now, candidates for Congress will begin their campaigns. But the money - lots of it - has already been pouring in.

title: QUAKING MEXICO
description: Scientists say it was only a matter of time before a coastal quake would rip through Mexico, causing havoc that no Richter scale alone can measure. But what a time. Thursday's earthquake devastated the hemisphere's most populous city, spreading despair and destruction among a people already numbed by misfortunes. Mexico now faces a huge bill for reconstruction at a moment when oil prices are falling and its hard-pressed Government faces yet another crisis over a towering $96 billion foreign debt.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 21, 1985
description: International

title: ACA JOE reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 4
description: b-Net loss including a loss of $347,243 from discontinued operations.

title:
PATENTS;

Wheelchair Put in Door Of Auto by Elevator
description: A wheelchair elevator and means for docking the wheelchair inside a car door were patented this week for the Ford Motor Company.

title: INITIO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: b-After income taxes attributable to loss from discontinued operations amounting to $126,500. c-After income tax benefit attributable to loss on discontinued operations amounting to $79,000.

title: PROFITS UP A SLIGHT 0.3% IN QUARTER
description: After-tax corporate profits rose a slight three-tenths of 1 percent in the April-June quarter, the first increase since early 1984, the Government said today.

title: FOUNDER OF TEXTILE COMPANY
description: Paul A. Johnston, the chairman, president and chief executive officer of the New York-based Johnston Group Inc., died Wednesday at North Carolina Memorial Hospital in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan and Chapel Hill.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch by The Associated Press from Delaware, Ohio, in Sports Pages yesterday, on the outcome of the Little Brown Jug harness race, reversed the names of winners of the two other parts of pacing's Triple Crown. Chairmanoftheboard won the Cane Pace and Pershing Square the Messenger Stake.

title: SPINKS AT 200 FOR TITLE FIGHT
description: Michael Spinks wanted this to be a surprise. So he swore his camp to secrecy and told a little lie, saying he really did not know how much he weighed. He said he had not even stepped on a scale for several weeks. Let the reporters speculate, Spinks decided. That would add to the drama. And let Larry Holmes talk all he wanted about how he would kick sand in the scrawny light heavyweight champion's face.

title: FALSE FLASHES OF GROWTH
description: According to the Commerce Department's ''flash'' report, the economy grew at an annual rate of 2.8 percent in the third quarter. Don't bet your savings on it. For the last three years, this quarterly report has been at least one-half point off the mark every time; once it was three points off. A statistic so dependably wrong is one to do without.

title: RECONSTRUCTING VIDEO VERSIONS OF SILENT CLASSICS
description: Sitting in the dark on Wednesday, the afternoon of Greta Garbo's 80th birthday, Kevin Brownlow and David Gill - the film restorers who brought back Abel Gance's 1927 ''Napoleon'' - were watching a bright screen at the Museum of Broadcasting. With them was Leatrice Gilbert Fountain, the daughter of the actor John Gilbert.

title:
PATENTS;

X-ray Scan For Space Shuttles
description: X-RAY equipment to check the alignment of metal parts in space shuttles was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Tax-Shelter Partnerships
description: THE recent highly publicized problems of the EPIC group of real estate and mortgage companies has called attention to the limited partnership form of tax shelter used as an investment vehicle by these companies.

title: DSHIPS REPORTED MISSING OFF THE MEXICAN COAST QUAKE IN MEXICO: FEARS AND WORRY NORTH OF THE BORDER
description: Two merchant ships, five Mexican trawlers and two dozen small fishing boats disappeared in the Pacific Ocean off the coast of Acapulco after the earthquake that rocked Mexico Thursday, the director of Spain's special fishing radio link said today.

title: 15-YEAR-OLD SENTENCED TO DIE FOR KILLING THREE IN ARKANSAS
description: A 15-year-old was sentenced to death today in the stabbing deaths of a classmate and the classmate's two elderly great-aunts, one of whom was raped.

title: 2 Pleas of Guilty In Prison Beatings
description: Two guards at Trenton State Prison have pleaded guilty in connection with the purported beatings of 15 inmates last year.

title: BRITISH TELECOM PLC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The results in pounds sterling have been expressed in U.S. dollars at an exchange rate of $1.31 to the pound, the rate prevailing on June 30, 1985. The share earnings are per American Depository Receipt (ADR) and each ADR represents 10 shares of British Telecom ordinary stock.

title: EQUALITY & DIVERSITY: KEYS TO UNITY & COMMUNITY
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATE REFUSES TO CUT TOXIC WASTE CLEANUP
description: The Senate today refused to cut the $7.5 billion proposed for a five-year extension of the toxic waste cleanup fund, rejecting arguments that a leaner, more effective program could be had for $1.8 billion less.

title: FDP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Dog Frees Brake; Car Rolls
description: Affie, a dog left in a parked car, apparently released the emergency brake, sending the automobile crashing through a guard rail and leaving it dangling 30 feet above the ground. It took construction workers nearly two hours to lower the car safely. Affie's owner, Curtis Pearson, 23 years old, said the year-old dog became excited when alone.

title: FROM SCASSI FOR FALL: SLEEK PARTY DRESSING
description: ''There is nothing spare about this collection,'' Arnold Scaasi said before his fall couture show. ''It's pure luxury. That's what women want from me.''

title: Satellite Postponed
description: A California company has canceled plans to launch an $85 million satellite in December because of the failures of two similar satellites, which have strained relations with its insurers.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10. 1. Prokofiev's ''Love for Three Oranges.'' Maurice Sendak. 2. They are 10 of the 24 members of the ruling Politburo of the Communist Party of China. 3. Daily consumption of water declined as a result of New York's campaign to save water amid its worst drought in 20 years. 4. The United States has become a debtor nation, owing foreigners more than they owe it. 5. Mr. Hernu denied press reports suggesting he had ordered the July 10 sabotage of a ship owned by Greenpeace, an antinuclear and environmentalist group, but acknowledged that he had authorized a team of agents to monitor plans for protests against French nuclear testing in the Pacific. 6. A 60-mile atom smasher, designated the Superconducting Super Collider. 7.
