As part of a new contract, teachers' salaries over all will increase by 19 percent over three years and starting salaries will increase by 38 percent. 8. W. Wilson Goode of Philadelphia. 9. 40. Six. 10. A seismic sea wave, popularly called a tidal wave. 11. A St. Paul publisher intends to begin printing a daily edition in English of Pravda, the official Soviet newspaper. 12. Evolution. 13. To continue seeking a permit for Westway, they felt, would be to gamble what could be more than a billion dollars of trade-in money on the chances of overcoming legal impediments to the project. 14. Steven P. Jobs. Apple Computer Inc. 15. The number of Soviet officials expelled from Britain and the number of Britons expelled from the Soviet Union in retaliation. 16.

title: CONGRESSMAN FACES INQUIRY
description: The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct has begun a preliminary inquiry into a Democratic Congressman's acceptance of free rides on an airplane owned by a corporation, the panel's chairman said Thursday.

title: MEXICO HOLDING OFF ON ACCEPTING U.S. AID OFFERS
description: American officials said today that the Mexican Government had declined, for the time being, to accept offers of financial help from the United States to aid in earthquake relief.

title: AMID RUINS, A GRIM WAIT
description: The Hotel del Carlo stood like a cracked accordion on the Plaza de la Republica. Smoke rose from the debris of the Hotel Romano, five blocks away, while on the Avenida Juarez anxious family members gathered to await word about relatives buried in the debris of a Government technical school.

title: MAJOR EARTHQUAKES: THE LAST TWO DECADES
description: The earthquake in Mexico on Thursday was classified as major, a designation used when the magnitude is over 7 on the Richter scale. Here are other major quakes in which at least 1,000 people have been killed in the last two decades. Khurasan, Iran August 1968. An estimated 12,000 people were killed in this northeastern province. Gediz, Turkey March 1970. More than 1,100 people died; this city in western Turkey was virtually destroyed. Yungay, Peru May 1970. Between 66,000 and 70,000 people are believed to have died and 600,000 were left homeless by an earthquake and subsequent avalanche that buried this northern resort city. Guatemala City February 1976. Nearly 23,000 people died in an earthquake and subsequent avalanches northwest of the capital that left a 200-mile-long fissure 8 feet wide and 10 feet deep. Tangshan, China July 1970. An earthquake originating under this northern China city killed more than 750,000 people, according to Western estimates, and destroyed more than half of the city's buildings. Mindanao, the Philippines August 1976. An earthquake and 18-foot tidal wave killed an estimated 8,000 people and left 150,000 homeless on this island. Van, Turkey November 1976. More than 4,000 people died in eastern Turkey. Bucharest, Rumania March 1977. Part of the capital was destroyed and more than 1,500 people died. Tabas, Iran September 1978. Up to 25,000 are believed to have died in earthquakes and numerous aftershocks that hit this Salt Desert city in northeastern Iran.

title: DEMOCRATIC DELUSIONS ON PROTECTION
description: A mindless stampede toward protectionism will be a one-way trip to economic disaster. - PRESIDENT REAGAN The President's courageous stand against additional import restraints makes good economic sense. Protectionism would raise consumer prices and destroy as many jobs in export industries as it saves in businesses beset by imports. What has yet to be understood in Congress, notably by timid Democrats, is that resisting protectionism probably makes political sense as well.

title: Bail Is Denied Suspect Linked to Asian Gang
description: A purported member of a Taiwan-based organized-crime group who had been arrested on drug charges was ordered held without bail yesterday in Federal District Court.

title: APPLE HOPEFUL ON PROFITS
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that its sales of personal computers to schools were increasing and that it expected to post higher earnings for the quarter than many analysts had projected.

title: DATAMETRICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: LUFTHANSA
description: Lufthansa A.G., the state-owned airline, said an agreement it had signed to buy airliners from Airbus Industrie was worth $1.3 billion.

title: 2D G.O.P. CANDIDATE TO MAKE SENATE BID IN NORTH CAROLINA
description: Representative Jim Broyhill announced today that he would run for the United States Senate seat being vacated next year by Senator John P. East, setting the stage for a potentially divisive Republican primary.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN CLERIC IS FREED ON BAIL
description: The Rev. Allan Boesak, a prominent anti-apartheid leader, was formally charged and freed on bail today after nearly a month in detention.

title: Capitalists at Columbia
description: The blockade of Hamilton Hall last spring may have rekindled the hopes of Columbia University radicals. But the tenor of the times was better reflected at a meeting of Columbia Equity Partners, a new student group with 50 members and $10,000 in its coffers, that will operate as a mutual fund for student investors.

title: Reagan to Visit Her Mother
description: Nancy Reagan, beginning a five-day trip without her husband, will fly to Phoenix on Monday to visit briefly with her ailing 89-year-old mother, Edith Davis. Later that day, the First Lady will continue on to Los Angeles, where she will attend a fund-raising dinner on Tuesday for the Joffrey Ballet.

title: ACAPULCO FELT MILD TREMOR
description: The earthquake that wrecked much of Mexico City rippled through this coastal resort with a mild tremor that the authorities said had caused no casualties and no damage.

title: TIGHTENING UP ON THE SPREAD OF NUCLEAR ARMS
description: Representatives of more than 75 countries are meeting in Geneva to conduct the third five-year review of the 1970 Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. If this review is to be worthwhile, the United States must take the lead in proposing more stringent controls on the transfer of sensitive nuclear technology to countries that do not possess nuclear weapons. Otherwise, the conference may increase rather than reduce the danger that atomic weapons will spread beyond the current nuclear fraternity.

title: UGANDA LIFTS CURFEW
description: The Ugandan Government announced today that it had lifted an eight-week-old nationwide curfew and ordered a freeze on the bank accounts of the deposed President, Milton Obote, and 15 of his top aides. The Kenyan press agency also reported that the Ugandan Government and the rebel National Resistance Army had agreed to resume peace talks next week in Nairobi, Kenya.

title: THE END OF A COMPUTER DAILY
description: When it started last spring, Computer Industry Daily seemed like a sure thing: a morning newspaper for the gossipy, information-hungry computer business, where smart executives keep as close an eye on the competitor's development laboratory as on their own.

title: NO CLEAR LINK TO FRANCE ON GREENPEACE
description: The police here say that they have collected more than 200 witnesses and 1,000 pieces of evidence in the sinking of the Greenpeace vessel Rainbow Warrior in July, but that they have no proof of French Government involvement.

title: RECOVERY TERMED 'COMPLETE'
description: President Reagan today underwent the first of a series of what the White House called ''normal and routine'' medical examinations, and doctors said later that he had made a ''complete recovery'' from the surgery he underwent in July.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report last Saturday in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page, about a letter soliciting subscriptions for The Washington Times, misidentified the committee headed by Representative Dante B. Fascell, Democrat of Florida. It is the Foreign Affairs Committee; its Senate counterpart is the Foreign Relations Committee.

title: MANFRED GOTTFRIED, 85, DIES: A FORMER CO-EDITOR OF TIME
description: Manfred Gottfried, the first writer hired at Time magazine when it was founded in 1923 and a former co-editor in chief, died of a heart attack Thursday in Falmouth, Mass. He was 85 years old and lived in Falmouth and Jamaica.

title: ARLEY MERCHANDISE reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
STAKE SOLD BY POSNER
description: Victor Posner, the Miami financier, yesterday sold his 38 percent stake in Peabody International Inc. at a price that was below what other shareholders are expected to receive when the concern merges with the Pullman Company.

title: PHILIPPINE SOLDIERS FIRE ON PORTEST,KILLING 14
description: Fourteen people were shot and killed by soldiers today in a town 300 miles south of here during protests marking the anniversary of martial law. Officials said the troops had opened fire in self-defense.

title:
PATENTS;

Foam Barrier Designed For Control of Crowds
description: Patent 4,541,947 was granted this week for a foam barrier that can be used to control crowds and rioting. The patent was granted to Charles J. Clark and Edward M. Bennett and assigned to their employer, the Rockwood Systems Corporation of Lancaster, Tex.

title: Lockheed Must Change Nuts On 5 New Transport Aircraft
description: As many as 25,000 nuts on each of five new C-5B aircraft will have to be replaced before the Air Force will accept the planes, a spokesman for the Lockheed Georgia Company said today.

title: Panel to Study Growth
description: The Joint Economic Committee of Congress will try to get some indications of how long the current economic expansion will last, it announced today.

title: Pengo Seeking A Restructuring
description: Pengo Industries said it had executed a letter of intent with its secured creditor to restructure about $148 million of secured debt.

title: European TV Deal
description: Compagnie Luxembourgeoise de Telediffusion S.A. and News International P.L.C. plan to form a venture involved in television broadcasting, the principal stockholder in Compagnie Luxembourgeoise, Bruxelles Lambert S.A., said. The projects would include direct broadcasting from satellites and program production, the company said.

title: Justified Complaints
description: When an Oiler touchdown was called back on a penalty in the third quarter of Sunday's 16-13 loss to the Washington Redskins, and the Houston coach, Hugh Campbell, started pulling his hair, it was not the first time that a National Football League coach had questioned an official's call. And when an Oiler touchdown was called back on another penalty in the fourth quarter and Campbell again went into orbit, it was not the second time, either.

title: DRUMS OF ROCK MUSIC BEAT FOR DIFFERENT CAUSES
description: When 40 leading rock and country bands perform a benefit concert for American farmers tomorrow, they will underscore the new impact of popular musicians on political and charitable causes - efforts that have raised more than $100 million this year alone.

title: YOUTH SAYS HE KILLED FAMILY FOR MOCKING COLLEGE DREAMS
description: A high school honor student charged with killing his mother, father and brother told the police that his parents had ''constantly put him down'' for wanting a college education and that he had been thinking of killing them for two years, according to a detective on the case.

title: WITH A LITTLE HELP, 2 FROM KOREA FIND LEGAL SYSTEM WORKS
description: In Kyoon Ahn, a Korean greengrocer, is not likely to join Ernesto Miranda or Clarence Gideon on the title page of a landmark legal decision.

title: EAGLE TELEPHONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CIRCUIT CITY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Bastian Industries said its board had received a proposal from Benson A. Selzer, chairman, to buy all the Bastian shares held by others for optional packages of cash and securities valued from $4.50 to $5 a share.

title: UGANDAN LEADER FREES 195
description: Uganda's new military ruler, Lieut. Gen. Tito Okello, today freed 195 detainees who had been held without trial for as long as four years. The Uganda radio also announced that a dusk-to-dawn curfew imposed when the army overthrew President Milton Obote in July had been lifted. Interior Minister Paul Ssemogerere said 202 detainees were left in the jail, 128 of them former agents of Mr. Obote's disbanded National Security Agency.

title: SECOND MAJOR QUAKE ROCKS MEXICO: DESTRUCTION WORSENS AS DEATH TOLL REACHES 1,300 WITH 1,000 STILL MISSING
description: A second major earthquake struck Mexico tonight, causing more buildings to fall and knocking out power in the northern part of the capital.

title: CHURCH STUDY URGES RATINGS SYSTEM FOR TV
description: A study issued yesterday on ''Violence and Sexual Violence in Film, Television, Cable and Home Video,'' which had been commissioned by the National Council of Churches of Christ, recommends that broadcast networks and stations be required by the Federal Communications Commission to adopt the ratings system used for movies. It also suggested that the F.C.C. ''should be required by Act of Congress, if necessary, to conduct annual hearings'' in which ''producers of television programming will be required to explain how and by whom decisions are made to determine the content of entertainment programs.''

title: THE LOUIS-CONN LESSON
description: Whenever a light heavyweight champion challenges a heavyweight champion, boxing people remember when Billy Conn almost took the title from Joe Louis - almost. And when Larry Holmes's prodigal trainer, Richie Giachetti, was preparing for the heavyweight champion's title defense tonight against Michael Spinks, he learned a lesson from the film of how Joe Louis won that 1941 bout with a 13th-round knockout after Billy Conn had been ahead on two of the three official scorecards through 12 rounds.

title: LILLY INDUSTRIAL COATINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
AIDS DIAGNOSIS DEBATE CLOUDS QUEENS LAWSUIT
description: Lawyers in the Queens case in which the city's policy on students with AIDS is being challenged differed yesterday on whether the case would continue if a child who figures prominently in the case was determined not to have AIDS.

title: WEINBERGER'S NEW ROLE: A SUMMIT SENTINEL
description: In the political stagecraft preceding the November summit meeting in Geneva, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger appears to have assigned himself the job of dashing what he regards as exaggerated expectations.

title: WITNESS IN RACIST TRIAL IDENTIFIES GUNMAN IN SLAYING OF RADIO HOST
description: A former member of a white supremacy group, the Order, has identified one of 10 members of the group on trial here as the gunman in the machine-gun slaying of a Denver radio talk show host.

title: Stocks Are Lower; Blue Chips Falter
description: Fear that the expiration of major futures and options contracts would play havoc on stock prices kept investors out of the stock market yesterday. In the end, however, the market was down only slightly, although blue chips suffered a big selloff.

title: Wrong Attorney
description: To the Editor:

title: RANSBURG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss including a $2.5 million provision for restructuring debt.

title: 36 ARE DEAD IN AREA NORTHWEST OF CAPITAL
description: Thirty-six people were killed and 354 injured Thursday when the earthquake struck a series of towns in Jalisco State, northwest of Mexico City, according to reports reaching here today.

title: COLLEGE GAMES AT A GLANCE
description: Home teams are listed first. Season records are in parentheses.

title: DEFENSE MINISTER RESIGNS IN FRANCE OVER BOAT ATTACK
description: The French Defense Minister resigned today and the head of France's intelligence agency was dismissed as the Government moved to end the political crisis surrounding the sabotage of an antinuclear protest ship in New Zealand.

title: JAZZ: HERBIE HANCOCK
description: ''We don't play together too often,'' the pianist Herbie Hancock said Wednesday, introducing the members of the trio that has sold out the Village Vanguard (178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street) through tomorrow. The trio, with Ron Carter on bass and Tony Williams on drums, was Miles Davis's rhythm section in the 1960's, and its occasional reunions generate thoughtful, subtly startling music.

title: MARWICK,HURDMAN SAID TO HOLD TALKS
description: Peat Marwick, the nation's second-largest accounting firm, and KMG Main Hurdman, the ninth-largest, are holding preliminary merger discussions, sources at both firms said yesterday.

title: Freighter Is to Be Auctioned
description: A Japanese freighter is to go on the auction block Sept. 30 to help clear a $6.1 million debt to Citibank, Federal officials said today. The freighter, the Palm Star Sumida, was seized by Federal marshals when it arrived here Aug. 14, one day after her parent company, Sanko Steamship, filed for bankruptcy in Japan. Brokers estimated her value at $3 million.

title: Sorry State
description: Manager Sparky Anderson of the Detroit Tigers comes down hard on Lance Parrish, whose season may have come to an early end because of a back injury resulting from some pregame roughhousing: ''There are only two things that can happen when you fool around in the clubhouse. Nothing can happen, or something negative can happen. And saying 'I'm sorry' can't bring it back.''

title: ACCOUNTANT GUILTY OF SEX BIAS
description: The Price Waterhouse accounting firm illegally discriminated against a woman when it refused to promote her to partner in 1983, a Federal District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell ruled today.

title: THE JOSTLING TO SELL WATS
description: Competition in the long-distance phone market has found a new dimension, with the major companies making special efforts to promote their profitable WATS services. These are some of the lures being offered:

title: State to Replenish L.I. Scallop Stocks
description: The state will contribute $100,000 in emergency funds to introduce new scallops in Long Island waters where algae covered prime shellfish beds this summer, destroying much of the fall scallop crop.

title: Rhode Island Teachers Reach Contract Accord
description: Teachers here reached a tentative agreement in their strike today, allowing 53 violators of a back-to-work order to be freed from jail.

title: U.S. QUERIES SCHOOL STANDARDS FOR MINORITIES
description: The Justice Department said today that it was investigating whether public schools had engaged in an ''offensive'' form of discrimination by lowering academic standards to make it easier for minority students to graduate.

title: TRW SETS BUYBACK OF STOCK
description: TRW Inc., the big Cleveland aerospace and automotive company, said yesterday that it would buy back at least five million of its own shares, and possibly as many as eight million, at prices between $80 and $88 a share.

title: BLUES FOR OLD MR. RUST
description: There were some heavy emotional moments at our house this week after I said it looked as if we'd finally have to junk the Rustmobile. I didn't use the word ''junk,'' of course. What I said was, ''We might have to put the Rustmobile to sleep.''

title: CLOTHING STEAMER RECALLED
description: AN electric clothing steamer called Wrinkles Away has been voluntarily recalled by the manufacturer, the Consumer Product Safety Commission says. The Franzus Company of New York, which makes the product, has received about 50 reports of burn injuries when boiling water spilled from the base.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Bishops in California Oppose Death Penalty
description: California's 26 Roman Catholic bishops, who are unanimously opposed to the death penalty, want lawmakers to make their own decision on the issue based on conscience rather than public opinion.

title: VIOLATING TEXTBOOK RULES CAN BE THE WAY TO A SLAM
description: The textbooks advise a partnership to bid a suit slam if there is a good fit, at least three aces and the equivalent of 33 high-card points. Slight exceptions are common, and there are some weird situations in which the guidelines disappear altogether.

title: 3RD-QUARTER G.N.P. RISE PUT AT 2.8%
description: The Government estimated today that the economy is growing at an annual rate of 2.8 percent in the current quarter, a little faster than in the first half of the year but a far less vigorous rebound than forecast by the Administration.

title: University Establishes Animal Welfare Chair
description: The nation's first professorship in humane ethics and animal welfare has been established at the University of Pennsylvania, school officials announced today.

title: INTERNATIONAL ROBOMATION- INTELLIGENCE reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: b-Net loss.

title: U.S. BATTLE SHIP GOES TO BALTIC TOJOIN INNATO MANEUVERS
description: The battleship Iowa is headed to the Baltic on the first voyage there by a ship of its class since World War II, a United States Embassy official said today.

title: DELAY FORESEEN FOR A TRADE-IN FROM WESTWAY
description: The Federal Highway Administrator said today that it could take New York City years to get all its money for trading in funds from Westway unless Congress appropriated more money for such trade-ins.

title: U.S. TO PROPOSE NEW EFFORT TO EASE DEBT CRISIS
description: The United States, in a major change of strategy, will propose that the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund undertake an unusual joint effort to ease the debt crisis and improve economic performance of poor countries in Africa and elsewhere.

title: PERCHANCE TO THINK
description: One antidote to the glossolalia of government and politics in the capital is offered by the Folger Shakespeare Library. The library, just out of earshot of the Capitol, is giving a series of poetry readings and seminars Oct. 16-April 23. The poets are Lucille Clifton, Jorie Graham, Gregory Orfalea, Jerry Ward, Anthony Hecht, Nicholas Christopher, Robert Hass, William Pritchard, Thomas Transtromer, Rita Dove and Michael S. Harper.

title: FORSCHNER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and including losses from discontinued operations of $69,000 for the quarter and $178,000 for the year. c-Includes a loss of $358,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $2,522,000 representing costs associated with discontinuing the company's retail store business.

title: METS LOSE IN 11 TO PIRATES, 7-5
description: It took four hours, 12 pitchers and 11 innings to complete, and it may haunt the Mets' memories of their 1985 pennant race for a long time: the night they lost a 7-5 thriller to the Pittsburgh Pirates, the team with the worst record in baseball, in a game decided on a bad-hop single.

title: A SOUL DOUBLE BILL
description: James Brown and two former members of the Temptations, Eddie Kendricks and David Ruffin, will sing a soul double bill tonight at 8 and midnight at the Beacon Theater, Broadway at 74th Street (787-1477). Tickets are $18.50 and $20.

title: Mullen Signs Pact
description: Joe Mullen, the high-scoring, hard-bargaining right wing for the St. Louis Blues, brought 15 months of contract negotiations to a lucrative conclusion by signing a one-year contract that will bring him an estimated $200,000 plus a chance at $70,000 in ''achievement bonuses.''

title: Trash Basket for the 80's?
description: Optimism prevails at the Sanitation Department. In its tireless efforts to control trash, the department has developed yet another trash basket.

title: SAN JUAN RACING ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary net gain from the sale of a parcel of land of $273,934, or 6 cents a share, and includes a loss from the discontinued segment of the company's communications division of $107,278.

title: HOPING TO SETTLE DOWN AT 27
description: Mark Johnson gathered some belongings and planned his trip to the last stop in his professional hockey career. Johnson had been traded to the Devils from the St. Louis Blues, and as he gathered his things at home in Madison, Wis., yesterday afternoon he thought of all the things that had to be done.

title: Article 019105 -- No Title
description: The National Endowment for the Arts awarded nearly $22 million today to 50 arts organizations, including a first-time, $1 million grant to the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts here. The grants are meant to help the organizations achieve long-term financial stability and attract greater private support.

title: NEWS OF QUAKE VICTIMS AWAITED IN LOS ANGELES
description: The nation's largest Hispanic community reacted with fear and frustration as worried people scrambled for information on friends and relatives in Mexico but remained virtually cut off from any communication with the earthquake-ravaged country.

title: A TOUGH FRENCH DECISION MAKER: PAUL QUILES
description: For a long time, Paul Quiles, who was named France's Defense Minister today, was known in the Socialist Party as Robespaul. The name was meant to recall Robespierre, the ruthless French revolutionary responsible for the Terror in 1793 and 1794, in which thousands of ''enemies of the people'' were executed.

title: ABETTING DRUG ABUSE
description: To the Editor:

title: A Turk in Rome Trial Denies Bulgarian Payoff
description: A Turkish witness for the prosecution in the papal plot trial denied today that accomplices of Mehmet Ali Agca received $1.2 million from the Bulgarian secret service to kill Pope John Paul II, as Mr. Agca had charged.

title: TACOMA BOAT PAYMENTS ASKED
description: The Tacoma Boatbuilding Company said it had received notice that its lender banks had terminated credit agreements and demanded immediate payment of loans.

title: DISASTER MAY COMPLICATE DEBT WOES
description: The earthquake that devastated parts of Mexico on Thursday will aggravate its grave economic problems, including the task of repaying its $96 billion foreign debt, bankers and economists said yesterday.

title: JURY STUDYING REPORT OF CONFLICTS IN S.I. BOROUGH CHIEF'S ACTIVITIES
description: A special grand jury began hearing testimony this week in an investigation into reported conflicts of interest in actions by Borough President Ralph J. Lamberti of Staten Island.

title: Third Avenue Bridge Reopens Early in Day
description: The Third Avenue Bridge, after being closed to traffic between the Bronx and upper Manhattan Thursday because of a mechanical malfunction, was reopened early yesterday in time to avoid traffic delays that had been expected during the morning rush hour.

title: Expert on the Scene
description: Splattered with paint, Moira Moynihan looked like just the person the Smithsonian Institution was searching for.

title: PANEL BACKS DENIAL OF ACCESS TO TRIAL DOCUMENTS
description: A Federal appellate court panel ruled today that the public and the press had no constitutional right to see documents and depositions during civil trials in which such materials were used as evidence.

title: Cavaliers Sign Williams
description: Another trial is over for John (Hot Rod) Williams, a month after the one in New Orleans ended.

title: COUNTRY ROADS
description: WHERE SHE WAS. By Anderson Ferrell. 141 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95. This remarkable first novel by Anderson Ferrell has the shimmering, light-refracted quality of an Impressionist painting - but an Impressionist painting done by someone with the sensibilty of an Edward Hopper and the narrative terrain of an Andrew Wyeth. If one strains, in describing this novel, to summon comparisons with paintings, it is because ''Where She Was'' has such a sensuous, visual impact on the reader; it makes you see and feel through the power of its images, its finely tuned renderings of mood and color and light.

title: FRISELL ON GUITAR
description: Today at Roulette, 228 West Broadway, at White Street (431-1022), the guitarist Bill Frisell will play solos at 9 P.M. and trios - with Tim Berne on alto saxophone and Joe Baron on drums - at 10 P.M. Tickets are $6.

title: ATTACK BY IRAQIS ON IRAN RAISES WORLD OIL PRICES
description: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products rose sharply on the world market yesterday on reports that an air attack by Iraqi jets inflicted heavy damage on Iran's main oil-export facility in the Persian Gulf.

title: CARDINALS RALLY TO 5-3 VICTORY
description: Cesar Cedeno and Terry Pendleton hit consecutive triples in the ninth inning tonight to break a 3-3 tie and send the St. Louis Cardinals to a 5-3 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title:
PATENTS;

Dispenser of Liquids For Pets and Plants
description: John A. Paoluccio of Modesto, Calif., got a patent this week for a liquid-dispensing device that provides water for birds, small animals, plants and the like.

title: Nicaraguan Claim Seeks $375 Million From U.S.
description: Nicaragua filed a $375 million compensation claim against the United States at the World Court today.

title: DURO-TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Rumors Hurt MGM's Stock
description: Rumors that the sale of the MGM/ UA Entertainment Company to Turner Broadcasting System Inc. had run into problems sent MGM/UA's stock tumbling $1.75, to $24.625, yesterday, with 974,200 shares traded.

title: CONVICTION ENDS DRUG TRIAL
description: A Federal jury found Curtis Strong guilty today of 11 counts of selling cocaine to major league baseball players between 1980 and 1983. The verdict ended an often-sensational 14-day trial that drew enormous attention as some of the top stars in the sport testified about their drug use.

title: U.N. ASSEMBLY SETS AGENDA
description: The General Assembly today approved a 146-point agenda, including a new Soviet item on the peaceful exploitation of outer space aimed at the United States Strategic Defense Initiative, or ''Star Wars,'' as it is often called. The 159-member Assembly, which opened its session Tuesday, endorsed recommendations made earlier this week by its steering committee.

title: STATE TO CITE M.T.A. PLANS IN WESTWAY TRADE-IN EFFORT
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's 20-year capital improvement plan will form the basis of the state's request for the trade-in of Westway funds for mass transit, according to Federal and state officials.

title: DATA ARCHITECTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $80,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes a tax credit of $191,000.

title: EXTREMISTS IN FARM BELT ARE ASSAILED
description: Representatives of farm, civil rights and religious groups yesterday denounced the efforts of right-wing extremists who they said were promoting anti-Semitism and violence among financially and emotionally troubled farmers in the Middle West.

title: RED CROSS IS HOPING TO USE SATELLITE TIE TO ASSESS AID NEEDS
description: Officials of the League of Red Cross Societies and of the American Red Cross transported a portable satellite dish to Mexico today to open a communications link, Red Cross officials here said.

title: Indonesian Oil Report
description: A consortium headed by a joint venture between the British Petroleum Company and London and Scottish Marine P.L.C. has made an important oil find in the Strait of Malacca off Indonesia, oil industry sources said today.

title: CLUES SOUGHT FOR SAFER CONSTRUCTION
description: To specialists in earthquake-resistant construction, the heavy damage inflicted upon Mexico City in the disaster Thursday will provide the most valuable demonstration they have ever had of what design features in a modern city are most resistant to such an onslaught, particularly when structures are built on a deep accumulation of sediment.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 21, 1985
description: The Economy

title: FLORIDA WEIGHS NURSERY BAN TO FIGHT CITUS
description: TAgriculture officials in Florida today called for a one-year ban on sales by the state's citrus nursery industry to fight the spread of the tree-killing bacterial disease, citrus canker, in orange and grapefruit groves.

title: TEACHERS' CONTRACT, BY LOBA
description: The new contract between New York City and the United Federation of Teachers is an important achievement for the school system. As important, it demonstrates the practicality of LOBA, Last Offer Binding Arbitration.

title: SOUTH AFRICA ACKNOWLEDGES FOR FIRST TIME IT SUPPORTS ANTI MARXIST REBELS IN ANGOLA
description: South Africa acknowledged today for the first time that it was supporting the rebels fighting the Angolan Government.

title:
SCOUTING;

'The Professor Of Shooting'
description: He may not have sparkled with the glitter of a Jerry West or an Oscar Robertson, but, like the .220 hitter who becomes an acclaimed major league manager, Stu Lantz is gaining more renown in his postcareer occupation as a tutor than he ever did as a player. Indeed, Lantz, a guard who left behind eight-season averages of 12.4 points a game and .435 success from the floor when he retired from the National Basketball Association almost a decade ago, has come to be known as ''the professor of shooting'' - a kind of poor man's Pete Newell, or at least the short man's Pete Newell.

title: BLUEPRINT FOR VAST CLEANUP OF CHESAPEAKE BAY OFFERED
description: Three states, the District of Columbia and the Federal Government today made public a comprehensive blueprint for cleaning up the polluted waters of the Chesapeake Bay.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Oh, I was scared. It swayed and swayed and then people shouted, 'Run, run, the building will fall.'

title: Californians in House Seek To Restore Oil Leasing Pact
description: A bipartisan group of California House members introduced legislation Thursday to carry out an offshore oil agreement reached with Interior Secretary Donald Hodel in July but later scrapped.

title: United Energy And Midcon Link
description: The Federal Trade Commission's challenge to the Midcon Corporation's proposed acquisition of United Energy Resources Inc. will not inhibit the merger of the two companies, Joseph Wells, vice chairman of Midcon, said today.

title: OFFICIALS ON COAST TERMED PREPARED
description: Mexico City's earthquake was a stunning reminder to Californians of what might well happen to a major city in their state, according to state disaster preparedness planners.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bobby Jones, the Philadelphia 76er forward, underwent surgery to remove a bone spur from his left ankle and will probably miss about a week of the regular-season. . . . The Kansas City Royals extended Manager Dick Howser's present contract for two years, through the 1988 season. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Currier Hospitalized
description: The Giants' already thin secondary corps may be depleted further for tomorrow's game with St. Louis. Bill Currier, a nine-year veteran safety, was hospitalized yesterday in an effort to help speed his recovery from a lower back injury, and he is a doubtful starter for the game at Giants Stadium.

title: CITIZENS GROWTH PROPERTIES (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After tax credits of $28,000 for the quarter and $222,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $500,000 for the quarter and $605,000 for the 6 months.

title: T.C.U. SUSPENDS SIX PLAYERS
description: In an unusual situation in which the players turned themselves in, six members of the Texas Christian University football team, including the Heisman Trophy candidate Kenneth Davis, were suspended indefinitely today by Coach Jim Wacker after they revealed they had been taking illegal cash payments from a booster as part of their original recruitment.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE SQUARE DEAL The Municipal Art Society worries about the city, issuing warnings about what it sees as clear and present dangers to the look of things that represent the essence of New York in the best sense.

title: INFOTECH MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss including a tax credit of $200,000.

title: DELOREAN CHARGED WITH FRAUD
description: John Z. DeLorean was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges that he defrauded investors in the failed DeLorean Motor Company of $12.5 million and used $8.9 million of that amount for his own enrichment.

title: PACER TECHNOLOGY & RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AGAIN SEEING HALLEY'S COMET: A TWICE TOLD TAIL
description: As far as most people are concerned, Halley's is the comet, a once-in-a-lifetime celestial spectacular that recurs on average every 76 years or so with slight irregularity. Most other comets are less accommodating -they either come every few years, or at intervals of thousands of years, or when you least expect them.

title: ON-LINE SOFTWARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: SINKING YANKEES 6-1/2 BACK
description: Their eighth consecutive loss, a 4-2 decision to the Baltimore Orioles, rubbed the Yankees the wrong way tonight, but then, Manager Billy Martin rubbed his nose at the wrong instant, and it was that ill-timed act that helped the Yankees tumble six and a half games behind Toronto.

title: K.G.B. Holds Russian as Spy
description: The Soviet intelligence agency, the K.G.B., today announced the arrest of a Soviet citizen it said had spied for the United States Central Intelligence Agency and given military information to an American diplomat.

title: KOREAN FAMILIES VISIT AFTER BORDER IS OPENED
description: For the first time since the end of the Korean war 32 years ago, North and South Koreans met and embraced long-separated relatives living on the other side of the fortified Korean border.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium. Dwight Gooden has a string of 31 scoreless innings going. (Television -SportsChannel and WHT 1:15 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:15 P.M.) Yankees vs. Orioles, at Baltimore. (Radio - WABC 770, 1:15 P.M.) Cardinals vs. Montreal Expos, at St. Louis. (Television - Channel 4, 1:15 P.M.) Padres vs. Atlanta Braves, at San Diego (Television - WTBS, 11:15 P.M.) Boxing Larry Holmes, champion, vs. Michael Spinks, 15 rounds for I.B.F. heavyweight title, at Las Vegas, Nev. The other featured bout is Julio Cesar Chavez, champion, vs. Dwight Pratchett, 12-round W.B.C. superfeatherweight championship. (Television - HBO, 9 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 9 P.M., English and WJIT 1480 AM, 9 P.M. in Spanish.) Croquet U.S.C.A. National Singles and Doubles Championships, Central Park, 69th Street and West Drive, 8:30 A.M., quarterfinals and semifinals. Football Boston College at Pittsburgh, (Television - Channel 11 and USA Network, noon); Memphis State at Florida State, (Television - WTBS, noon); North Carolina State at Wake Forest, (Television - MSG, noon); Cornell at Penn, (Television - Channel 13, 1 P.M.); C. W. Post vs. Merchant Marine, at Greenvale, L.I., 1 P.M. (Television -Cablevision, Channel 26, 4 P.M. tape in New York and Long Island and Channel 12 in Connecticut. Radio - WCWP 88.1 FM 1 P.M., live); Fordham vs. Catholic U., at Jack Coffey Field, Rose Hill, the Bronx (Radio - WFUV-FM 90.7, 1 P.M.); Wagner at St. John's, 1 P.M.; Harvard at Columbia, (Radio - WKCR-FM 89.9, 1:30 P.M.); Iona at Villanova, 1:30 P.M.; Fitchburg at New York Maritime, 1:30 P.M.; Rutgers at Army, 2 P.M.; Michigan at South Carolina.

title: No Headline
description: Secretary of Agriculture John R. Block said today that omnibus agriculture bills pending in both the Senate and House would need ''major surgery'' to avert a veto by President Reagan.

title: COURT HEARS OF EX-F.B.I. AGENT'S PROBLEMS
description: Richard W. Miller repeatedly shaped up and hung onto his job as an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation through a 20-year roller-coaster career of warnings for incompetence and commendations for his work, according to records introduced at the trial of the former agent for espionage.

title: RALSTON PLANS SALE OF FOODMAKER UNIT
description: The Ralston Purina Company said yesterday that it would sell its Foodmaker Inc. restaurant subsidiary to Gibbons, Green, Van Amerongen, a New York investment concern that specializes in leveraged buyouts, and members of the unit's senior management for about $450 million.

title: Indian Pt. 2 Shut By Short Circuit
description: Consolidated Edison's Indian Point 2 nuclear plant shut down automatically today when an electrical transformer short-circuited, according to a company spokesman.

title: Bolivian Mine Workers Continue General Strike
description: Thousands of Bolivian mine workers defied back-to-work orders today after President Victor Paz Estenssoro decreed a state of siege and banished 144 strike leaders into internal exile.

title: SHORT AND LONG RATES DECLINE
description: Short- and long-term interest rates declined yesterday, as Commerce Department data for the third-quarter gross national product helped defuse fears that rates might rise in the future.

title: HIGH BRITISH MINISTER TO MEET P.L.O. AIDES
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain said today that her Government would meet soon with a delegation that includes two senior officials of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: PAULSON TAKES CONTROL AT WHEELING
description: The embattled Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation today named Allen E. Paulson, its largest shareholder and a leading businessman, as chairman.

title: Distant Memories
description: With a long-distance event scheduled for Central Park in this weekend's projected muggy weather, a woman famous for competing under adverse conditions has some advice for the other runners. ''Just be a little bit more careful,'' says Gabriele Andersen-Schiess, who gained worldwide attention with her near-collapse at the finish of the Olympic marathon last summer.

title: BRANDT IN EAST GERMANY: CRIES OF 'WILLY!' ARE FEW
description: One day in 1970, Chancellor Willy Brandt arrived by train in the East German city of Erfurt. He was on a mission that he hoped would end in the normalization of ties between the two German states that had emerged from war and the ideological division of Europe.

title: IN BROOKLYN AND WUEENS, HIGH FIASHION
description: High-fashion boutiques abound in Manhattan and in the city's prosperous outer suburbs. But two of New York's best high-fashion boutiques are in Brooklyn and Queens: Jimmy's, at 1226 Kings Highway in Flatbush, and Hirshleifer's, at 116-15 Queens Boulevard in Forest Hills.

title: A SHAGGY-DOG STORY ON THE FUND-RAISING CIRCUIT
description: ''Excuse me,'' said a young socialite at the rooftop garden party, ''but there is dog hair on my pasta salad.''

title: WESTINGHOUSE 'CASTLE' GETS A NEW LIFE
description: For decades, residents of this industrial valley town gauged time by the clock in the tower of the imposing Westinghouse office building, often called the Castle.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: COURT RULES LIBYA'S JERSEY MANSION IS EXEMPT FROM TAXES
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that Libya is exempt from property taxes on a $1 million, 25-room mansion here that was purchased for the head of its United Nations mission.

title: TOUR OF 'WEST SIDE STORY' FACING DIFFICULTY
description: A national tour of ''West Side Story'' - which this weekend finishes a three-week engagement at its first stop, the Kennedy Center in Washington - is in disarray and, apparently, financial distress.

title: Wild Alaska Cattle Shot After a Roundup Fails
description: An effort to round up cattle that grew wild after nearly a century of roaming on a remote Alaskan island has failed and most of the animals have been shot, Federal officials say.

title: Guerrillas Black Out Lima for 45 Minutes
description: Guerrillas blacked out Lima Friday night and attacked two offices of President Alan Garcia Perez's party and a police station, the authorities said.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: A POPULAR, long-held belief is that rivers and streams that support freshwater trout are almost pristine because these fish can live only in clean water.

title: CATS JUST AREN'T UP TO SNUFF ANY MORE
description: THEY do not make cats the way they used to. When I was growing up, we had a series of cats who lived in a little outbuilding, which housed my father's ham radio outfit. Into one wall my father had sawed and then hinged a small cat door. The cat, or cats, came and went at will. There was no yowling the way this present one yells at any door or window it feels like yelling at. I think they made cats of a more independent sort in the old days.

title: STRENGTH COMES FROM ONE LANGUAGE
description: I HAD been living out of the country for several years and was caught by surprise in 1976 when I received my absentee ballot from the Town of Greenwich to vote in the Presidential election. It was printed on one side in Spanish. Something very different was happening under the surface of life in Connecticut. And it still is.

title: A Dying Breed
description: THE MOVIE SCENE IS pure bliss these days if you're a gangster fan. Not since Warner Brothers packed Barton MacLane away in mothballs have there been so many tough cookies looking daggers at each other, so much mayhem and snarling, so many guys named Vito and Red pumping so many Tommy-gun bullets into sound-stage reproductions of the old Warner Brothers Edward G. Robinson set.

title: SUPPORT PLEDGED
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THE SEARCH FOR NEW IDEAS
description: WHILE THEO-ries in architecture and design change faster than the speed of a paint roller, major design movements occur rarely. And often they take well over a decade to become established. It has been nearly 20 years since the architect Robert Venturi wrote ''Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture,'' the book that shattered the boxy International Style glass and steel buildings that had been the signature of modern ar-chitecture, leading the way to the so-called post-modern movement and to the use of historical references in design. Yet it is only in the last few years that postmodern buildings have begun to change our cities' skylines and that postmodern home furnishings have become widely available.

title: ALICE, THE RADICAL HOMEMAKER
description: THE GOOD TERRORIST By Doris Lessing. 375 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: READERS SPEAK OUT ON CLASSES FOR GIFTED
description: The article ''Classes for Gifted Provoke Debate'' is very critical of the Three Village School District that labels nearly 15 percent of its students as gifted and talented. There is no question that the ways in which we identify students for gifted programs today are unsophisticated. Test scores measure only a small portion of one's abilities. They do not measure task orientation, motivation, creativity or leadership, which are important elements of achievement or accomplishment in one's field. As educators, our aim should be to identify students with potential in all areas and meet their varied needs.

title: ITS STEEL-ONLY STRATEGY HAS YET TO YIELD A PROFIT
description: STEEL. Once the country seemed to provide unlimited markets for the industry to build cities, create industrial empires, win wars. The steelmakers grew comfortable and complacent, and so, after a time, did their union workers.

title: THE LATEST HEIRLOOMS
description: TWENTIETH-century Art Nouveau and Art Deco furniture and objets d'art can often still be had at relatively low prices. But the value of the most innovative pieces is rising by leaps and bounds, and the auctions at which they are featured are often exciting events.

title: ERNEST NAGEL, 83, PHILOSOPHER AND COLUMBIA TEACHER, DIES
description: Prof. Ernest Nagel, a philosopher known for his work on the implications of science, died of pneumonia Friday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 83 years old.

title: Former E.P.A. Administrator Arrested on Drinking Charge
description: Anne M. Burford, the former head of the Environmental Protection Administration, was arrested early today for being drunk in public shortly after her husband was arrested for driving while intoxicated, according to the police in Arlington County, Va.

title: GURU'S COMMUNE ROILED AS KEY LEADER DEPARTS
description: The desert commune here that recruited homeless people from around the country last year, in what some local residents said was an effort to stack the voting in local elections, is once again in turmoil. A key leader has departed, and a string of allegations against her is being investigated by six law-enforcement agencies.

title: 14 Charged in Housing Bribes
description: Many superintendents at New York City housing projects have been maintaining a prosperous, if illegal, relationship with suppliers, city and Federal officials said last week. Fourteen people were charged Thursday with paying or receiving bribes and kickbacks.

title: ANI STERN TO WED GRAPHIC DESIGNER
description: The engagement of Ani Stern and Joseph A. Guglietti has been announced by Caryl Stern of New York and Dr. Harold Stern of Woodbridge, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony C. Guglietti of North Providence, R.I.

title: Manchild Coming of Age
description: We seek in vain from James Conniff insights into a retarded person's struggle to survive urban life in this society.

title: FLICKERING THEATER OF MYTHS
description: It was almost 9 o'clock in a small village on the east coast of Bali. Farmers, priests, government officials, shopkeepers, men and women, grandparents and children sat in a large yard, chatting in the dark. In front of them, a white cotton screen glowed from the light of a coconut-oil lamp; at the back of the yard, men gathered around tiny tables to play games of chance. Suddenly, the bright sounds of xylophones (gender) jolted through the night, joined quickly by the rest of the gamelan orchestra: gong, kendang (a double-ended drum), kajar (a bronze pot struck with a mallet) and ceng ceng (cymbals). The audience drew closer, some sitting in front of the screen, others disappearing behind it. A leaflike shadow swirled onto the white cloth, as if caught up in some mystic wind. A solitary voice rose, reedlike, above the tune. The shadow play -the wayang kulit - had begun.

title: 7TH GAME DRAWN IN TITLE CHESS MATCH
description: The seventh game of the world chess championship match between Gary Kasparov and the titleholder, Anatoly Karpov, was drawn today on the 31st move.

title: CAPE COD FACES NUDITY QUESTION
description: DOES a ban on nudity at the Cape Cod National Seashore discriminate against women?

title: CONNECTICUT, THE TOLL STATE
description: PLANNING our vacation this year was not easy. Television commercials offered us so many appealing choices.

title: Topics;   Innovators Uncorking the East
description: For 300 years, repeated failure created the conviction that European vinifera, the vine that produces the world's classic wines, had no future east of the Rockies. Now, as winegrowers in upstate New York and in Virginia, Maryland, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts and Indiana start bringing in their grapes, they are harvesting the fruit of Dr. Konstantin Frank's tenacity. Dr. Frank, a resident of Hammondsport, N.Y., who died recently at the age of 86, helped prove that when grafted onto hardy rootstock, vinifera could survive punishing winters in the Finger Lakes country and elsewhere in the East.

title: Rebels in Uganda Said to Cut Off Town
description: Forces of Uganda's largest rebel group today cut off the town of Masaka, 80 miles west of here, and Government troops moved into position to defend it and the capital, witnesses said.

title: A GROUP THAT INVESTS 'SWEAT EQUITY' IN ARTS
description: In a city that does not offer the artist the mix of muse and marketplace that can be found in New York City, the Washington Project for the Arts provides a firm sense of focus and energy for the Washington art community.

title: LABOR'S IMAGE CONCERNS NEW CHIEF
description: IN one sense, Betty L. Tianti broke with tradition this month when she became the first woman in the country to head a state A.F.L.-C.I.O. chapter.

title: Judicial Restraint
description: The case of nine Federal District judges in Cleveland v. the court's Chief Judge was decided last week. A Federal judicial panel found that Judge Frank J. Battisti exercises too much power and ordered him to share it with his colleagues.

title: WHO LOST MOUNT ALTO?
description: In the new Soviet Embassy compound atop the District of Columbia's Mount Alto, 350 feet above sea level, laser-beam listening devices are now being installed by Soviet technicians. They have a clear line of sight to the White House and the Capitol. Aimed at windowpanes, the superbugs will be able to pick up conversations in all the rooms with north-facing windows.

title: MARY WOOD IS BRIDE OF SEWELL CORKRAN 3D
description: The marriage of Mary Margaret Wood, the daughter of Mrs. Robert A. Wood of Alexandria, Va., and the late Mr. Wood, to Sewell Hopkins Corkran 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Corkran Jr. of Naples, Fla., took place yesterday. The Rev. Jack McClendon performed the ceremony at St. Andrew Presbyterian Church in Purcellville, Va.

title: CULTIVATING THE GARDEN
description: The farm is always looking for the unusual, because this very often is a good selling point. We are attracted by the general overall look of the plant.

title: Back to Tool
description: THE KREMLIN MAY be expert at encrypting missile telemetry, but it is helpless to decipher the latest American college slang. Our own Defense Intelligence Agency, monitoring all calls home for money, is wondering if some pernicious wax has clogged up its all-hearing ''Big Ear.'' Post-teen lingo is changing too fast for this generation of computers, and the harried snoopspooks cannot hack it.

title: Art
description: Since John Dobkin became its director, not so long ago, the National Academy of Design on Fifth Avenue and 89th Street has taken on an international character. Though still the bastion of a certain kind of American painting and the repository of a remarkable collection of works by former Academy members, it has gone foraging in France and Italy and Spain, returning on each occasion with exhibitions that no other institution in Manhattan had thought of mounting.

title: RETIREMENT UP 50% FOR STATE U. FACULTY
description: THE retirement rate for faculty members at State University campuses on Long Island is at least 50 percent higher this year than it was last year, university officials say.

title: MISS SIMONE WED TO M. A. MUNIER
description: At St. James' Episcopal Church in Manhattan yesterday Laura Methe Simone, a daughter of Susan Simone of Belvedere, Calif., and Raymond Simone of New York and Weekapaug, R.I., was married to Michael Anthony Munier, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis Munier of San Francisco. The Rev. Susan Harris, assisted by the Rev. John Appleyard, performed the ceremony.

title: More Jobs in the City
description: Already congested and short of housing, New York City is at least also enjoying a job resurgence. Mayor Koch said last week that the number of people on payrolls in the city grew 1.5 percent in the first six months of this year, compared with the same period in 1984.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: AFTER THE REUNION. By Rona Jaffe. (Delacorte, $17.95.) When last heard from in ''Class Reunion,'' at least three-quarters of Rona Jaffe's select group of 1950's Radcliffe grads were still happily immersed in their college-romance marriages and, as expected, living comfortably as upper-class housewives and successful career women.

title: ST. PAUL MEETS NERO
description: THE KINGDOM OF THE WICKED By Anthony Burgess. 379 pp. New York: Arbor House. $17.95.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: GOING TO THE DOGS While the dog days may be over in terms of climate, in terms of our canine friends the fall fun is just beginning. Today for instance, the Mid-Island Kennel Club holds its annual show at Nassau Beach Park in Lido. All breeds will be on display in such endeavors as obedience-trial match show sessions from 7:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. at the park's West Terrace parking lot. There is no admission charge.

title: U.N. TERM TO TIE UP CITY TRAFFIC
description: When the deputy police chief for Manhattan South met recently with residents of the community around the United Nations, he told them he had good and bad news for them.

title: MAMARONECK TOPS PORT CHESTER, 21-14
description: The quarterback Bill Garrity threw for 111 yards and rolled up 103 more on the ground to lead Mamaroneck to a 21-14 victory over Port Chester.

title: EARTHQUAKE FALLOUT
description: Harry Cavan of Ireland, a senior vice president of soccer's international governing body, said that the earthquakes that rocked Mexico last week might force a year's postponement of the World Cup soccer matches scheduled to begin in Mexico next May. ''It's difficult to see how Mexico City could cope with 24 World Cup teams plus all the officials,'' he said.

title: IN KOREA, REUNIONS IN TEARS
description: Kim Kun Nyo was nervous this morning, squeezing a crumpled handkerchief and avoiding people's eyes. In a few minutes she was to meet her younger brother.

title: PRESIDENT BIDS CONGRESS PASS TAX PLAN THIS YEAR
description: President Reagan, still convinced that his sweeping tax bill can be enacted by the end of the year, has privately told Congressional leaders that he wants the House and Senate to remain in session until work is completed, a senior White House official says.

title: DEVELOPERS ZERO IN ON COLUMBUS CIRCLE
description: FOR almost a century, Columbus Circle has played the tortoise to the hare of Manhattan real-estate development, moving in brief bursts of energy only when expansion of other sections of the borough faltered. Now it is undergoing a period of rapid growth that may carry it nearer the long-ago expectations of some city planners who predicted that it would be the eventual hub of the city.

title: MARC STEVEN ROSENBERG MARRIES TINA A. PEKARNE
description: Tina Anne Pekarne, an associate in the New York law firm of Golenbock & Barell, and Marc Steven Rosenberg, an associate in the New York law firm of Cravath, Swain & Moore, were married yesterday in Manhattan aboard the Empress of New York. Rabbis Eugene Lipsey and Elliot Spar officiated.

title: PLAYWRIGHTS REDISCOVER THE USES OF POLITICS
description: In the lineup of possible productions for the new theater season there are at least eight plays that address political questions; five of them are written by Americans and half are scheduled for Broadway houses. How much comfort this development will give people who complain that the theater needs more political themes is uncertain. The political spectrum of these plays is not very wide and a couple of them - Howard Fast's ''Citizen Tom Paine'' and William Luce's ''Lillian,'' based on Lillian Hellman's three autobiographical books - could not possibly avoid being political, given their subjects.

title: TAKE A RIDE ON THE READING, COLLECT $25 MILLION -
description: IN 1973, four Chicago-area businessmen got a chance to do in real life what most people can only do in a Monopoly game: Buy the Reading Railroad.

title: TREE HOUSE CAUSES ZONING DISPUTE
description: CAN a children's tree house violate a town's building codes? That question will be answered by the South Salem Zoning Board of Appeals next month when it rules on a plea by the owners of the tree house for a variance on height and setback regulations.

title: TAX CODE REVISIONS ON GAMING PROPOSED
description: WHEN Federal lawmakers begin dealing with the tax-reform issue in coming weeks, casino-gambling legislation may be included.

title: JOBLESS FUND PAYS OFF DEBT
description: CONNECTICUT businesses heaved a sigh of relief last week when the State Labor Department announced it had retired a debt that has resulted in special assessments against employers for the three years.

title: SHARING 'STAR WARS'
description: Both superpowers are approaching the Geneva summit conference, only two months away, in the worst possible mood of distrust and hostility. The air is thick with posturings, propaganda ploys and premonitions of failure. A major and decisive act by President Reagan is required to clear the air that threatens to choke the summit proceedings.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Three New Yorks Interpreting New York City is one of the inhabitants' favorite pastimes, a way, perhaps, of defending themselves against it. In ''New York'' (Little, Brown), an anthology compiled by Mike Marqusee and Bill Harris, E. B. White describes New York as seen by the native, the commuter, and the settler.

title: TRIAL OF 9 IN ARGENTINA TROUBLES MANY
description: Argentines are now in their fifth month of watching nine men who once ruled their country tried as criminals. These former leaders, the prosecutor argued this week, oversaw a nightmarish campaign, exterminating more than 9,000 people, and deserve sentences ranging from 10 years to life in prison.

title: ASYLUM GRANTED
description: Petr Klima, the high-scoring left wing who sneaked away from the Czechoslavak national hockey team during a training visit to West Germany last month, has been granted asylum and had signed a multiyear contract with the Detroit Red Wings, the club announced.

title: FRESH AMERICAN ESTHETICS
description: ONLY THE skylights suggest that this apartment was once an artist's garret. Yet the original combination of modern art and design objects that fills the top-floor apartment of this 1820's Greenwich Village building reflects a genuine commitment to American design. Little wonder: the occupants, David Sanders, the owner of the high-tech D. F. Sanders stores, and Craig Logan Jackson, an interior designer, spend a good deal of time seeking out the best in current art and craftsmanship. The result is a style of decorating that has flair and freshness.

title: OUT WITH THE OLD AND IN WITH THE IDEOLOGICALLY CORRECT
description: A former foreign leader and frequent visitor here once asked Deng Xiaoping about the best strategy for regaining office. ''Be patient,'' Mr. Deng said, laughing. It was advice born of experience. Few leaders have been as far down as Mr. Deng was between 1966 and 1973 and again between 1976 and 1977, when Mao Zedong and his cronies reduced the disputatious little man from Szechuan to the status of an ordinary worker. The Red Guards called him a ''Napoleon'' for his imperious ways, but the nickname proved more apt than they imagined.

title: Protesters Delay Ore Vessel
description: Protesters from the environmental and anti-nuclear organization Greenpeace delayed for five hours today the docking of a British ship scheduled to carry uranium ore to Hamburg, West Germany, protest organizers said. Two people were arrested in the protest, in which six small boats circled the ship, the Clydebank, as it approached its berth.

title: HEAVY EQUIPMENT NEEDED BY MEXICO
description: Mexico's most pressing need in the wake of disastrous earthquakes that struck this week is for heavy equipment to demolish damaged and dangerous buildings and to sort through the rubble for those trapped alive and for the dead, a Mexican Cabinet member said today.

title: ONE-MAN SHOW ON P. T. BARNUM COMES TO CANDLEWOOD
description: THE life of the ''Prince of Humbug,'' who was born in Bethel and has been memorialized in Bridgeport, where he was once the mayor, will be celebrated at the Candlewood Playhouse in New Fairfield for the second time this year.

title: POTATO SALADS WITH PIZAZZ
description: BECAUSE POTATOES ARE WHAT IS known as a root vegetable, they are often categorized as a winter food. The truth, of course, is that they are very much a part of warm weather in the form of potato salads.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We will bury our dead with sadness, but at the same time we will renew our will to live and to cure our wounds.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: AMERICAN MUSICAL REVUE: From ''The Passing Show'' to ''Sugar Babies.'' By Gerald Bordman (Oxford University, $17.95.) Gerald Bordman, whose encyclopedic ''American Musical Theatre'' traced the history of popular musical productions primarily through a year-by-year report of activities in New York, has drawn from this same basic material a pair of more narrowly focused books, ''American Musical Comedy'' and ''American Operetta.''

title: NEW DORP OVERPOWERS MCKEE, 41-14
description: The opening of the game between McKee and New Dorp left New Dorp in an unusual position - afraid to score again for fear of the McKee kick returner, John Labora.

title: WARNINGS ON 'SOLAR' ROOMS
description: ATTRACTED by Federal and state tax credits and the possibility of saving on energy costs, thousands of Long Islanders have built or are thinking of building ''solar'' rooms. But in many cases, consumer affairs officials warn, the buyer may be getting a lot less than he bargained for.

title: SOUTH AFRICA
description: To the Editor:

title: JAMES LEVINE: NEW ERA AT THE MET
description: NOTHING SO EMBODIES THE DURA-bility of America's great cultural institutions as the 102-year-old Metropolitan Opera - tradition-rich, prestigious, conservative and grand, somehow defying the complexities of scheduling, the fragility of throats and egos, the dizzying economics of production and the probability of improbable crises to raise the curtain seven times a week from September to May. For most of its first century, the house that opens tomorrow evening with its grandiose ''Tosca'' has stood at the apex of the operatic world. And today, as the Met enters a new era of management, the conductor James Levine stands at the helm, with unprecedented power in his hands and startlingly grave doubts in his heart. ''I often think,'' he says, ''my God, I'm going to be in the generation that sees this whole thing die.''

title: MARRIOTT STAKES OUT NEW TERRITORY
description: FOR the last decade, things were good for the Marriott Corporation. Few sizable companies in any business can grow at 20 percent year after year, but the aggressive company from the suburbs of the nation's capital made fast growth its credo. Marriott's business hotels sprouted in choice suburban, airport and downtown locations and the company - and its industry - seemed to be on a never-ending growth spiral. But times have changed. The hotel market has become overbuilt and business has slackened. And feisty Marriott, which anticipated many of these changes, is now switching gears within the industry and taking its name where it has never been before.

title: Major Afghan Battle Is Reported Over
description: A monthlong Soviet and Afghan offensive against Moslem rebels near the border with Pakistan appears to have ended, and both sides are retreating from the main battle areas, guerrilla sources said today.

title: O'NEILL AND MOFFETT PREPARING TO WAGE NOMINATION BATTLE
description: GOVERNOR O'Neill's schedule these days, especially on weekends, looks as if he is running for something. A Democratic headquarters opening here, a town committee picnic there.

title: A GRIM ERA FOR HEAVY EQUIPMENT
description: AFTER World War II ended, the United States Army left behind hundreds of mighty Caterpillar tractors to help a decimated Europe and Asia rebuild. What began as a generous gesture ultimately established the American machine as the world's unofficial tractor. It also helped make America's construction equipment industry predominant the world over.

title: TRADE TALK
description: The White House has invited a group of business leaders to a private talk by President Reagan tomorrow.

title: SHE FINDS NET GAIN IN TENNIS
description: AS THE old saying goes, it's an ill wind that blows no good.

title: STEEPLECHASE RACES MAKE L. I. COMEBACK
description: ONE hundred and two years ago the most famous steeplechase race in America, the Meadowbrook Cup, was inaugurated on Long Island. Over the years some of the biggest names in horse racing and in high society turned out for the event - including the Duke of Windsor, August Belmont, Alfred Vanderbilt and Winston Guest.

title: A VISIT WITH UNCLE SAM
description: In late September, the quietest hideaways around Washington lie along the banks of the Potomac. And always when he gets the itch, Uncle Sam drops down from his heavenly abode to ask how things are going.

title: MUSEUM SHOWS ITS TREASURES
description: AN ART museum is more than a place where exhibitions are assembled, even though many of us think of them as nothing more than that.

title: LIST OF MERIT SEMIFINALISTS
description: THE National Merit Scholarship Corporation has announced the semifinalists from New Jersey for awards in 1986.

title: MISSING ART BAFFLES BOSTON
description: ACCOUNTS of this year's Boston Arts Festival, an outdoor extravaganza on the banks of the Charles River, read more like a police blotter than a critic's review.

title: FOR U.N. AT 40 MID-LIFE IS JUST ANOTHER CRISIS
description: As the United Nations General Assembly opened for business last week in its 40th year, many delegates suggested that the organization was still not ready to emerge from the wilderness.

title: PARADERS HONOR HEROINE IN HIJACK
description: Thousands of German-Americans and Germans marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday in the annual Steuben Day Parade, reviewed by the first woman to serve as grand marshal in the parade's 28 years.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Inflation Deflated There's more good news for consumers ahead. August's consumer price index, due out this Tuesday, should show at most two-tenths of 1 percent growth, says Sam Nakagama, chief economist for Nakagama & Wallace Inc. That would mean four consecutive flat months for the index, which measures the movement of retail prices that consumers pay.

title: THIS LAND WAS THEIR LAND
description: RESTITUTION The Land Claims of the Mashpee, Passamaquoddy, and Penobscot Indians of New England. By Paul Brodeur. Afterword by Thomas N. Tureen. Illustrated. 148 pp. Boston: Northeastern University Press. $18.95.

title: IN EUROPE, THE EMPHASIS IS ON SIMPLE DESIGN
description: A recent vacation in central Europe turned into a busman's holiday when I took a detour to Berlin to attend the ''Funkausstellung.'' This vast biennial exhibit of the latest sound and video equipment provided opportunities to compare the event with similar shows in this country.

title: PACKER QUATERBACK TEMPTS PASS RUSH
description: When the Jets' Mark Gastineau thinks of Lynn Dickey, the productive but plodding quarterback of the Green Bay Packers, it is with hand-rubbing glee. Gastineau, pro football's most renowned sack-maker, describes Dickey as a compliant sort once he is cornered.

title: SOUTH AFRICA: DREAM AND REALITY
description: SOUTH AFRICA REGULARLY surprised and astonished me in my second stint there as a correspondent for The New York Times from 1980 to 1983. It was a sensation available only to outsiders who could maintain access of a kind on all sides of the nation's racial and political boundaries as few South Africans can. Only such a voyeur could experience the huge evasions of the whites and the seemingly helpless knowledge of the blacks, the willful denial of reality as well as its crushing weight.

title: WHY THE DATA MAY BE OFF
description: Is the United States truly a debtor nation, as the Commerce Department reported last week? I think not. While there is no disputing that America's international investment position has fallen dramatically, the official figures give a highly misleading impression. The reason lies in a failure to properly allow for inflation.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: POLLUTION CONTROL WILL COST PLENTY, BUT WHO WILL PAY?
description: Senate renewal of the toxic waste cleanup law and a hint of a modest program to reduce acid rain caused rumblings of displeasure at the White House last week. But in both cases the underlying issue was not environmental. The question was money, and how to raise it.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Sept. 22, 1985 Fiction

title: Manchild Coming of Age
description: I would like to thank James Conniff for sharing himself as the father of a mentally retarded child in ''Manchild Coming of Age'' (About Men, Aug. 18). It was a beautiful, honest and very real account.

title: BANNISTER LEAVES RUNNING BEHIND FOR ACADEMIC AND MEDICAL PRUSUITS
description: He is wearing a tailored blue suit and crown-speckled tie and is talking, of all things, about the intricacies of the brain.

title: SHARED EXPERIENCES
description: New ideas come from experiences, New York experiences or experiences when traveling. And I certainly think that new ideas come through communication with other people, conversations.

title: RESERVISTS CLL UPON MUSICAL MATERIEL
description: WHEN Staff Sgt. Daniel E. Hillsman of Mount Vernon took to the streets here last weekend, he was armed and ready. So were the other uniformed members of his military unit, which earlier had spent the morning at Cortlandt's Camp Smith preparing to prove themselves in the field - or, in this case, along the main thoroughfare of this small Hudson River village.

title: B.Y.U. SUBDUES TEMPLE
description: Robbie Bosco passed for four touchdown, including three to the wide receiver Mark Bellini, to rally Brigham Young (3-1) to a 26-24 victory over Temple tonight. The Owls are 0-3 by the margin of 7 points.

title: UP FROM GENTILITY
description: THE LIVELY AUDIENCE A Social History of the Visual and Performing Arts in America, 1890-1950. By Russell Lynes. Illustrated. 489 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $27.95.

title: STATE FINES POLLUTER $1.6 MILLION
description: THE Witco Chemical Corporation here has agreed to pay the state's Department of Environmental Protection at least $1.6 million in fines and costs involving the contamination of its manufacturing plant, the city's sewer system and local waterways.

title: A MOST IMPORTANT MAN ON CAPITOL HILL
description: DAN ROSTENKOWSKI, the 57-year-old Democratic committeeman from the 32d Ward, stands on the corner of Noble and Evergreen in northwest Chicago. He is a big man, 6 feet, 2 inches tall, with the thick, powerful build of a linebacker for the Chicago Bears. Behind him squats his home, a three-story brick fortress built by his grandfa-ther. The front room once held a savings and loan, and the Polish immigrants who swarmed into the neighborhood would come by every week, drop a quarter into a slot and take a receipt. But today, the neighborhood has changed, and many of the children of those immigrants drive their station wagons up to bank windows at suburban shopping malls.

title: ZENAS CROCKER IS WED TO SUSAN HOLLEB STOLL
description: At the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York yesterday Susan Holleb Stoll, project manager and northeast territory manager in New York for G. H. Bass & Company, the shoe manufacturer, was married to Zenas Crocker, director of marketing for United Pay Telephones Inc. in Garden City, L.I. The Rev. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony, assisted by Canon John W. Davis, an Episcopal priest.

title: HEILBRONER TO OPEN LECTURE SERIES
description: THE economist and author Robert Heilbroner will be the first of four speakers in this year's President's Leadership Forum series at the State University of New York at Purchase. Dr. Heilbroner's lecture, ''Peering Through the Mist of History,'' will be given on Tuesday, Oct. 1, at 8:30 A.M. in the college's Performing Arts Center.

title: PRETORIA WORRIES ABOUT ITS FLANK
description: THE South African Government opened a second front last week in its battle for regional control. As internal unrest continued, it sent 500 soldiers into southern Angola in what it called a pre-emptive strike against rebels fighting its fiefdom, South-West Africa.

title: ENDURANCE: A BALANCING ACT
description: Endurance -- the ability to go, and keep going, longer, harder, faster -- takes more than strength.

title: WHEN IT COMES TO MOVIES, THE WORLD LOOKS TO AMERICA
description: A recent issue of Le Point, a leading French news magazine, carried on its cover a full-page illustration for a story on ''Culture: How to Resist America.'' The bottom half of the illustration shows a besieged European continent with tiny figures of d'Artagnan and Don Quixote girded for battle, supported, more or less, by a Rhine Maiden, Arlequino, Michaelangelo's David, the Parthenon, and Shakespeare's Globe Theater. Above, high in the sky, all-conquering, invincible, flies a United States astronaut, festooned with electronic equipment and bearing on his winglike arms Mickey Mouse, E.T., a cowboy and Marilyn Monroe.

title: ANNOUNCERS SET A BAD EXAMPLE
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: BEAN AND REID LEAD SOUTHWEST GOLF CLASSIC
description: Andy Bean and Mike Reid each birdied the 18th hole today and shared the third-round lead of the $400,000 Southwest Golf Classic with 15-under-par 201.

title: IN APPLE ORCHARDS, HARD-WON VICTORY
description: THOUGH the state's apple growers faced some difficulties this year, including a late frost last spring and high heat and humidity in recent weeks, most expect to harvest a hearty crop of big and juicy apples.

title: HELPING WORKERS WITH PARENT CARE
description: ONE worker, a secretary at a corporation in southern Connecticut, took early retirement recently to care for her ailing father. Another gets up daily at 3:30 A.M. to bathe and dress her elderly mother before leaving for work. She must return home by 3 P.M., she said, to resume her care of the frail woman.

title: FROM PLAN TO PERMANENCE
description: THE FIRST time I ever hired a workman, I was 8. The project was a guinea pig house, and I did not put the job out to bid. There was no competition for Mr. Esper, who was our handyman and dug the rose bed, changed the storm windows and could fix almost anything. Client and contractor did not negotiate the fee: We agreed immediately that one dollar was the right price.

title: AIDING ATHLETES: A GOOD BEGINNING
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: EDUCATION OFFICIALS SAY INQUIRY IS A SURPRISE
description: The Secretary of Education and his predecessor in the Reagan Administration said yesterday that they had not been aware the Justice Department had been investigating for several years whether public schools were discriminating against minority students by lowering academic standards to make it easier for them to graduate.

title: MISS CLIFFORD WED TO N. B. KOECHLIN
description: Mary Catherine Clifford, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul C. Clifford of Montclair, N.J., was married there yesterday to Nicolas Baker Koechlin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard A. Koechlin, also of Montclair. Msgr. Edward J. Larkin performed the ceremony at St. Cassian's Roman Catholic Church.

title: MUSIC: WORKS BY ROGER SESSIONS
description: ROGER SESSIONS, who died last March at the age of 88, was such a beloved figure within the modernist New York contemporary-music community that all manner of memorial concerts and programming have been scheduled for this fall. On Thursday in St. Paul's Chapel on the Columbia University campus, a particularly appealing Sessions concert was offered featuring his music for voice and organ.

title: INDIANS SEEK NEW MARKER AT MASSACRE SITE
