description: Descendants of the 400 to 500 Indians who were killed by the Colorado militia on the banks of Sand Creek more than a century ago want to replace the plaque on a monument that calls the area a ''battleground.''

title: AIR FORCE BOUGHT UNNECESSARY TOOLS, REPORT SAYS
description: A Congressional investigation made public today asserted that two major military contractors had sold the Air Force maintenance tools it did not need and had billed the service for the cost of developing other tools that had been in use for years.

title: GRANT TO EXPAND AIDS EFFORT
description: THE County Department of Health, which is already caring for a half-dozen AIDS patients in their homes, has received $100,000 to establish a pilot program aimed at helping 10 times that number.

title: BOOSTER TELLS OF PAYMENTS
description: Dick Lowe, a Fort Worth oilman, said he was one of the boosters involved in making improper payments to Texas Christian University football players that led to the suspension of six of them Friday. Lowe said he was prepared to undergo public scrutiny and would cooperate with a National Collegiate Athletic Association investigator, who is expected on the T.C.U. campus early next week, The Dallas Morning News reported today.

title: Fashion Photos That Shun Good Customers
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Killed in Yosemite When Limb Hits Truck
description: An oak tree limb crashed onto a truck carrying tourists in the Yosemite Valley today, killing two tourists and injuring 12 others.

title: U.S. AS DEBTOR: A THREAT TO WORLD TRADE
description: THE United States is now experiencing the most dramatic transformation in its international financial position since World War I. The Commerce Department announced last week that sometime within the last few months, America became a debtor nation on recorded transactions for the first time since 1914.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE RED CITY: Limoges and the French Nineteenth Century. By John M. Merriman. (Oxford University, $29.95.) John M. Merriman, a professor of history at Yale University, has written a thorough account of the industrialization of the French city of Limoges. His microscopic lens is a mixed blessing: it illuminates at times, but it also obscures - particularly during the discussions of municipal elections. This flaw is compounded when he assumes an excessive amount of prior knowledge on the part of his readers. All the details, however, bring a wonderful intimacy to this story, beginning with the revolt, in 1830, of the bourgeois businessmen - who rightly saw themselves as the force behind the city's economic growth - against the landholders and clerics who had long dominated Limoges. As a result of their increased power and prosperity, the city's porcelain and shoe manufacturers soon found themselves scrambling, in a volte-face partnership with their erstwhile conservative foes, to stem the radical socialism of an increasing - and increasingly vocal -working class. Mr. Merriman is deft and entertaining in his use of two groups - porcelain makers and butchers - to emphasize the tension between what was and what was to come. Throughout Limoges's transformation from Restoration city to ville rouge, the porcelain manufacturers, and later their workers, formed the vanguard for virtually all social and political progress. The butchers remained defiant and even comical atavists, clinging to their religious rituals in an increasingly secularized climate and resisting every municipal effort to clean up their neighborhood, where among the ''hacked and hanging pieces of meat, the glistening livers and . . . large pools of blood'' could be found ''niches sheltering pretty statues of saints or rich madonnas with azure coats starred with gold, before which burned religious lamps.'' Mr. Merriman is at his best when he brings to life the social and political motivations of the citizens of Limoges.

title: MASSACHUSETTS COLLEGES MOVE TO CUFB DRINKING
description: Boston University's Backstage Pub no longer serves beer. There's a two-drink limit at Williams College. And Smith College students charged with underage drinking will no longer get legal help from the school.

title: IMPORTED BARGAINS ARE READY TO DRINK
description: WITH increased use of computerized inventory systems by retail wine outlets and full cases of many of the best vintages presold a year or two in advance of release by the producer, there is little possibiity of fulfilling the connoisseur's fantasy of walking into a shop and finding a dusty, long-forgotten great bottle at its original price. However, because of the continued strength of the dollar against most foreign currencies and the glut of wine from recent bountiful European harvests, the bargains at area stores are in imported wines that are ready to drink now.

title: County, Out of Money, Starts to Cuty Work Force
description: The Jackson County government ran out of money Friday, and about 40 county workers were facing layoffs.

title: No Big Deal
description: I AM SITTING AROUND THE KITCHEN table of a house in Ithaca, N.Y. - kind of a spectator to this gathering, being an out-of-towner - when it dawns on me, in a way no longer at all abstract or metaphorical, how much the situation of men and women has changed in the 15 or so years of my maturity.

title: Democrats Assert President Is 'Bankrupting' the Farms
description: President Reagan has turned his back on the family farmer and is ''bankrupting rural America'' with a policy of aiding big corporate farms and allowing farm income to drop, Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, asserted today in the Democrats' weekly radio address.

title: Quakes Sow Devastation In Mexico
description: A gigantic shift on the Pacific Ocean floor jarred Mexico's west coast last week, causing devastation in Mexico City, 230 miles away. Preliminary reports said the earthquake had killed several thousand people, leaving thousands more injured and homeless. Yesterday, a White House official predicted the final total of dead and injured would be in the tens of thousands.

title: MISS DAVENPORT A BRIDE IN JERSEY
description: The marriage of Caroline Hayes Davenport to David C. Johnson Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Johnson of Orange Park, Fla., took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. John Davenport, parents of the bride, in Middletown, N.J. The Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York performed the ceremony.

title: IN THE RUBBLE OF A BATTERED CITY, GRIM SEARCH FOR LIVING AND DEAD
description: Mariel Dolores Robles walked into the small, brick room hesitantly, her hand held to her face. It was a room she had hoped she would never enter.

title: MOSCOW'S MOSLEMS
description: LABOUR AND NATIONALITY IN SOVIET CENTRAL ASIA An Uneasy Compromise. By Nancy Lubin. 305 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $32.50.

title: Giving Immigration the Business
description: Once, walking through his apricot orchard, a California grower was asked what would happen if Congress reformed immigration law, sharply curtailing illegal farm workers. ''I'd go out of business the next day,'' he said. In that case, how much could he sell his land for? ''Who said anything about selling the land? I'd cut down the apricot trees and plant walnuts. You don't need to pick walnuts; you can shake them down.''

title: RESIGNATION DEMAND AT SAVING UNIT REPORTED
description: Maryland officials were reported today to have called for the resignation of top executives at the Community Savings and Loan Association and its real estate syndication unit in an effort to gain tighter control of the companies.

title: IN THE FOREST, THE TRUE PATH DISCOVERED
description: IF only for a while, on this soft summer night, enter the forest and begin the journey that takes you through deep, dark wood, and to the water's edge, where still farther out, the light of the moon is reflected in the gentle, hypnotic lull of the sea.

title: WHEN EAST MEETS WEST IN CLASSICAL COMPOSITION
description: Cross-breeding, as scientists who splash about in the gene pool know, is not without problems but sometimes can work out remarkably well. The mule, offspring of a male donkey and a female horse, is famously ill-tempered and a dead end reproductively; nonetheless, it has pulled its load for humanity for centuries. Hybrid corn, sturdier and more vigorous than the pure strains, is one of this century's agricultural triumphs.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

ON AUTUMN
description: I LOOK forward to the days when the house will be filled with autumn's breath, when I'll awake from summer's hibernation. I relish the autumn for its civility and its decency toward the human spirit.

title:
GARDENING;

THE RASPBERRY, A ROSE AMONG FRUITS
description: RASPBERRIES elicit visions of mouthwatering goodness. Whether eaten direct from the bush, chilled and dusted with sugar, or with ice cream or as jam on toast, their distinctive flavor has made them a favorite with people of all ages.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BROTHERHOOD OF ARMS: General Dynamics and the Business of Defending America. By Jacob Goodwin. (Times Books, $18.95.) Scarcely a month seems to pass without a scandal involving the Pentagon: tanks or antiaircraft guns that do not work, $650 ashtrays, country club dues and kennel fees passed on to taxpayers as weapons development costs.

title: RUNNING OUT OF WATER, SHENOROCK LOOKS TO COUNTY
description: WHILE water-use restrictions - no watering lawns, filling pools or washing cars - is a novelty of this summer's drought for county residents, water rationing has become a way of life in Shenorock, a lake community in the town of Somers. Residents here have had to cope with water-use restrictions since 1976 when the community was forced to tap a nearby lake as a water source. Shenorock has lived under a declared water emergency since July 11, 1983, when a moratorium was imposed on new building and the use of water outdoors was prohibited.

title: A FUTURE FOR HOME COMPUTERS
description: his year represents the 10th anniversary of the personal computer, originally heralded as the most fabulous of all home appliances. Yet, in the machine's decade of existence, nothing has turned out the way its pioneers expected. True, for a number of years, home-computer sales boomed, and by now personal computers have in fact invaded almost every nook and cranny of the business world. But 10 years ago, the home, not the office, was perceived as the real market for microcomputers.

title: Senator's Daughter Doing What Comes Naturally
description: To the Editor:

title: QUEENS CLERICS' PANEL GIVES OFFENDERS 2D CHANCE
description: The 17-year-old youth faced the two Protestant ministers and the Roman Catholic priest and nun and recalled how he had helped steal a car telephone from a parked automobile.

title: TEXAS STOPS MISSOURI, 21-17
description: Bret Stafford, a surprise starter at quarterback, scored on a weaving 36-yard run to help Texas (1-0) to a 21-17 victory over Missouri (0-2) tonight.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: VALLEY TRADITION The Connecticut River Valley is the subject of a wide-ranging exhibition opening today at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford. Because the valley, running from the Canadian border to Long Island Sound, was isolated from the European-dominated coastal communities, yet thrived within its own agricultural economy, its inhabitants were able to develop a strong, independent style that manifested itself in crafts, fashion and the fine arts.

title: SUBWAY SMOKE BOMB INJURES 30
description: At least 30 people were injured last night after a gang of youths tossed a smoke bomb into a car of an IRT No. 4 train as it traveled between the 138th and 149th Street stations in the Bronx, according to transit and police officials.

title: MIDDLE EAST JOURNEY, BOSTON'S SEA CREATURES
description: Explore Israel On Tour With Archeologists Spanning 4,000 years of history and sites that resonate with historical and religious grandeur - Jerusalem, Tel Dan, Gamla, Belvoir, Megiddo, Masada, Caesarea, Herodion and Jericho - a two-week tour of Israel with a focus on archeology has been scheduled for next month.

title: Airlift Command Gets Chief
description: Gen. Duane Cassidy assumed command of the Military Airlift Command on Friday, replacing Gen. Thomas Ryan Jr., who has retired. The command is responsible for all air transportation duties for the Defense Department and has about 100,000 civilian and military members and 1,000 aircraft.

title: CLARIDGE'S HOTEL
description: To the Editor: Reading Barbaralee Diamonstein's article on Claridge's (Travel, Aug. 4) reminded me of my stay there a few years ago.

title: WORLDWIDE, U.N. TACKLES PROBLEMS LARGE AND SMALL
description: In villages throughout El Salvador, a one-day truce halts the fighting as medical teams inoculate children against five fatal diseases. Halfway across the world, near the Aswan Dam in Egypt, a restoration team puts the finishing touches on a 20-year project to save the historic temple of Abu Simbel.

title: KAREN CLARK IS WED
description: Karen Leigh Clark and David Michael Brush, both 1982 graduates of the University of Pennsylvania, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J. The Rev. Patrick Brown performed the ceremony. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Don Campbell Clark of Convent Station, N.J., and Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Neil Brush of Huntington, L.I.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: ARTIST MEETS HOLLYWOOD THE film ''Compromising Positions'' has made Carole Jeane Feuerman, a Roslyn sculptor, a movie star - kind of.

title: Wind-Shear Warning Computer Ready to Protect Airliners
description: To the Editor:

title: SATELLITES ARE EYES IN SKY FOR WILDLIFE STUDIES
description: When caribou No. 5871 beds down for a nap on the tundra, Larry Pank knows it, 400 miles away in his Fairbanks office.

title: Broadcast TV
description: How far does the four-square, straight-arrow Clark W. Griswold family travel in ''National Lampoon's Vacation''? Far enough for some fast, funny satire, and not so far out that the humor turns sloppy. [The film] , which is more controlled than other Lampoon movies have been, is careful not to stray too far from its target. The result is a confident humor and throwaway style that helps sustain the laughs - of which there are quite a few.

title: WEST 95TH REHAB
description: When a 30-story condominium called the Columbia went up on Broadway and West 96th Street in 1982, the seeds of further development for the Upper West Side were sown. The success of that effort led to other commercial and residential projects along Broadway and prompted revitalization on sde streets as well.

title: ELECTRONIC U
description: AS Ronald F. Gordon envisioned it, Electronic University would be open 24 hours a day, and its student body would be spread all over the country. It would offer courses over an electronic network to anyone with a personal computer and a modem to let the computer ''talk'' to other computers over the telephone.

title: PENN USES DEFENSE TO DEFEAT CORNELL
description: Jim Crocicchia threw a 1-yard touchdown pass to Brent Novoselsky late in the first half today as Penn, the defending Ivy League champion relied on a sturdy defense to hold off Cornell, 10-6, in the season openers for both teams.

title: STUDENTS OBJECT TO FACULTY ROLE IN HARVARD GUIDE
description: Allegations of faculty censorship of a student-edited guide evaluating courses at Harvard University have disturbed the autumn calm as students complete their first week of classes here.

title: DECISION IS UNANIMOUS
description: He was fighting against time and diminishing skills, and on this occasion, Larry Holmes also took on the memory of a popular heavyweight champion whose record he was trying to equal. Michael Spinks, a bold young light heavyweight, used these factors to his advantage tonight, accomplishing what no one in his weight class had done before. In the process, Holmes left the ring a loser for the first time in his professional career.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE DISAPPEARANCE OF GREGORY PLUCKROSE. By Elizabeth Gundy. (Dial/Doubleday, $15.95.) You will probably find yourself picking out and stowing away your favorite lines from this curious, comic and thoroughly satisfying novel.

title: PARLEY CRITICIZES NUCLEAR POWERS
description: A 90-nation conference reviewing the treaty to ban the spread of nuclear weapons called today on the United States and the Soviet Union to step up their disarmament efforts, saying the two nations have failed to fulfill a treaty obligation to end the nuclear arms race.

title: ARMS AND THE MIND
description: CLAUSEWITZ Philosopher of War. By Raymond Aron. Translated by Christine Booker and Norman Stone. 418 pp. Englewood Cliffs, N.J.: Prentice-Hall. $17.95.

title:
ART;

EXAMINING THE WORLD OF TODAY'S ILLUSTRATION
description: THE labels accompanying the artwork in the ''Overview of Contemporary Illustration'' at the College of New Rochelle (through Nov. 3) don't reveal whether the art was actually made to accompany an article or is a product of an artist's own fancy. This is intentional, for the premise of the show is that illustration and the so-called fine arts share the same principles.

title: CROSSROADS THEATRE IS AT A TURNAROUND
description: SPLENDID things have been happening to the Crossroads Theatre Company, which is now in its eighth season. Nevertheless, Lee Richardson, the artistic director, does not intend to let local success get in the way of reaching out for national recognition.

title: SUSAN AND CYNTHIA JACOBSEN TO MARRY JOHN C. KEAN 3D AND J. R. LEAMAN 3D
description: Susan Stoddard Jacobsen and John Colby Kean 3d plan to be married Dec. 21. Miss Jacobsen's younger sister, Cynthia Scott Jacobsen, and J. Richard Leaman 3d are planning a May wedding.

title: A Step Down In Zoning for the East Side
description: For 25 years new buildings on the Upper East Side of Manhattan have been encouraged to stand tall, but last week the Board of Estimate adopted zoning restrictions that will encourage the coming generation to sit down next to the town houses and tenements on the area's side streets.

title: CUOMO, A VIRTUOSO OF THE AIRWAVES, THAKES HIS VIEWS RIGHT TO THE PEOPLE
description: Twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week, New York radio stations can dial a toll-free number and get Governor Cuomo's recorded voice for their news broadcasts.

title: RECITAL: HARPSICHORDIST
description: THE harpsichordist Martha Hagen, who made her New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall Thursday night with a program of works by Bach, Rameau, Couperin and Scarlatti, studied at Concordia College in Minnesota and later at Montana State University and in Oslo, Norway. Miss Hagen, who currently lives in Montreal, has participated in master classes with Kenneth Gilbert, Gustav Leonhardt, and Colin Tilney, among others, and has recorded for both the French and the English networks of the CBC.

title: PAKISTAN BUS CRASH KILLS 30
description: AT least 30 children were killed and more than 30 injured today when their school bus overturned in Punjab Province, the Pakistan Press International news agency reported. Most of those who were killed were riding on top of the packed bus, which rolled over when part of its suspension broke north of the town of Leiah, 205 miles west of Lahore.

title: Draft Resister Is Paroled
description: Benjamin H. Sasway, the first person jailed since the Vietnam War for refusing to register for the draft, was paroled from Federal prison Friday after serving six months of a 30-month sentence. His lawyer, Charles T. Bumer, said Mr. Sasway, 24 years old, would resume his interrupted college studies.

title: INVENTIONS IN SPACE
description: Some Congress-watchers believe that the House and Senate already have their hands full trying to cope with earthly commerce, but at least one lawmaker has extended his area of concern to include patent rights for inventions perfected in outer space.

title: GOALS BEYOND THE GOAL LINES, BUTMUCH TALENT IN BETWEEN
description: TIM GREEN tossed the first blocker aside and then moved to his left, reaching to make the tackle on the Mississippi State quarterback, Don Smith. But two blockers hit him and all three went down, Green down and out.

title: FARMERS AWAIT CUES OF NATURE AND THE CONGRESS
description: For weeks to come, Tom Ostrander and Loren Colle will be nervously watching the course of the Congressional debate on farm law.

title: Manchild Coming of Age
description: We at the National Down Syndrome Society read with great interest Mr. Conniff's article. It captures so well today's philosophy about the potential of people born with Down's syndrome, and speaks to the dignity of a person like Mark who has grown up in a loving and caring home environment.

title: THREE VIEWS OF A BEREFT SUITOR
description: Hector Berlioz's Symphonie Fantastique is a thermometer of a conductor's romantic affinities. Berlioz wrote it at the age of 26 while in the grip of a one-sided passion - a ''convulsion,'' he called it in his ''Memoirs'' - for the Shakespearean actress Harriet Smithson. His program notes for the autobiographical score describe ''a young musician of extraordinary sensibility'' who ''in a paroxysms of despair caused by unhappy love has poisoned himself with opium.'' His ''diseased brain'' transforms his passion into music.

title: 21 HELD AND 25,000 WATCHES SEIZED IN A COUNTERFEITING CASE
description: Agents of the Secret Service and the Customs Service have arrested 21 people and confiscated 25,000 watches in what law-enforcement officials called the largest seizure of counterfeit watches in the nation.

title: SUSAN DARNOW IS MARRIED
description: Susan Tanya Darnow, a senior media planner with Young & Rubicam in New York, was married yesterday to Paul David Aspesi, an account executive with Whitney & Whitney Advertising in Irvington, N.Y. The Rev. Shannon Bernard, a Unitarian minister, and the Rev. Leslie Ivers, a Roman Catholic priest, performed an interfaith service at the Community Unitarian Church at White Plains. Mrs. Aspesi is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Darnow of Ardsley, N.Y. Her husband's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Harold Aspesi of Rye, N.Y.

title: NEED FOR A GLOBAL EFFORT SEEN
description: President Reagan, advised that the Mexican earthquake disaster is much worse than originally feared, offered substantial American aid today and moved to help organize a worldwide relief effort if Mexico asks for one.

title: PLANTING PLASTIC
description: THE LAND-scape architect Martha Schwartz defines a garden as a place that is ''conducive to contemplation and understandable on a human scale.'' It need not necessarily contain plants - ''Certainly many fine Japanese gardens do not,'' she explained.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LOADED DICE: The True Story of a Casino Cheat. By John Soares. (Taylor Publishing, Dallas, $15.95.) Remarkable for its audacious schemes, this story reveals how John Soares and a half-dozen others made hundreds of thousands of dollars cheating Nevada's casinos during the 1960's.

title: MISS WALWORTH PLANS TO MARRY R. W. SCHRIJVER
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Theodore H. Walworth Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Joan Walworth, to Robert William Schrijver, the son of Mrs. Adolf L. Schrijver of New York and Bethel, Conn., and the late Mr. Schrijver. A November wedding is planned.

title: DEVELOPING THE PRIVATE SELF IN A WORLD THAT IS NO LONGER INSULAR
description: One of the noblest objectives in higher education is to enable students to develop an understanding of themselves, a sense of responsibility toward their fellow man and a respect for the world in which they live.

title: PEKING
description: Westerners have been marveling at Peking for more than seven centuries, since the day in 1275 when Marco Polo's caravan arrived at the city then known as Khanbaliq, capital of Kublai Khan. These days the traveler must share the wonders with thousands of other visitors, but the capital is large and varied enough for the more intrepid to plunge themselves readily into a milieu where Chinese ways survive untouched by alien intrusion.

title: Taking Toys Seriously
description: My professional training (child development) and latest business undertaking (retail toys) made me quite interested in Marguerite Kelly's article ''Taking Toys Seriously'' (Aug. 18). After two readings I was left feeling that although many good points were made, the important issues of sexism and aggression didn't get much serious treatment.

title: CLEARING THE MISTS FROM OLYMPUS
description: GREEK RELIGION By Walter Burkert. Translated by John Raffan. 493 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $30.

title: PIONEER COLLECTORS OF 'NATIVE' PAINTING
description: When Edgar William and Bernice Chrysler Garbisch began collecting American folk paintings in 1944, very few of the works they purchased to decorate the walls of their sprawling, Georgian-style 20th-century manor in Maryland were by identifiable artists. The Garbisches' role in what then happened in this unexplored field, represents a classic case of collectors' involvement in areas of art and antiques, some of the results of which are documented in ''American Naive Paintings from the National Gallery of Art,'' on view through Dec. 1 at the Museum of American Folk Art, 125 West 55th Street.

title: JAPAN'S TRADITIONS
description: Japan's emergence as a leading industrial power has stimulated great interest in the nation, its people and customs. As with other cultures, a considerable understanding of Japanese life can be obtained from its postage stamps.

title: PORTENTS - OR MAYBE JUST SILLINESS
description: Without getting into the always ticklish issue of whether television directly influences or merely reflects what is happening in the world at large, viewers of the new season now unfolding can already detect some of the more pronounced attitudes being cheerfully exploited by the entertainment merchants. For one thing, scripts are returning to badmouthing New York with an almost gleeful abandon. For another, teen-agers are receiving, and accepting, more lectures on the virtues of chastity. And, perhaps not surprisingly, vigilantism is riding the law-and-order trails with an accelerating vengeance.

title: JEAN ALEXANDER WED IN BOSTON
description: Jean Elise Alexander, the daughter of Mrs. Paul C. Cavanagh of New York and Edward Alexander, was married yesterday to Lance Hardie Duncan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Russell Duncan of Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. George F. Emerson performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Church in Boston.

title: NATIONAL CONFERENCE ON THE ARTS
description: THE American Council for the Arts is sponsoring a three-day national conference on the arts, starting today in Washington. The conference, called ''Connections: The Arts in a Changing Society,'' has as its co-chairmen John Brademas and Barbaralee Diamonstein.

title: PHILADELPHIA TAKES ON ITS COPS ON THE TAKE
description: Police corruption has been a staple of life here for years.

title: 54 YEARS OF GIVING CREATURES COMFORT
description: THE world was altogether different 54 years ago, when a brand-new veterinarian drove across the Suffolk County farmlands in a snowstorm to talk to an East End colleague about working there.

title: FIRE SPURS TOWNS TO PROTECT FILES
description: A FIRE last month that destroyed the Salisbury Town Hall has prompted officials in other towns to take steps to insure that their records are protected from disaster, according to Dominic A. Persempere, the state's public records administrator.

title: TAMARA EDDY IS MARRIED TO MARK S. BROWN, BANKER
description: Tamara Eddy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roderick Eggert Eddy of Lake Forest, Ill., was married there yesterday to Mark S. Brown, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Brown of Verona, N.J. The Rev. Claibourne Bell performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: HE BROUGHT HIS EYE AND HIS DARING TO SPAIN'S CIVIL WAR
description: How lucky to be Robert Capa, or so it must have seemed during the heyday of photojournalism, when Life magazine was flourishing, when photography was still the principal form of visual communication, when photographers could achieve a celebrity undreamed of by today's television news cameramen, when journalistic celebrity was not incompatible with a kind of free-wheeling maverick life that is scarcely imaginable in today's gigantic communications corporations, and when the principal subject for photojournalists was a vast international conflict in which, it was generally agreed, America was on the right side.

title: LOSING CONFIDENCE AND OPPORTUNITIES: Daniel Patrick Moynihan
description: WHAT killed Westway? After more than a decade of debate, the proposed $2.3 billion highway and development project was officially declared dead last week. Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch said they would seek to trade in $1.7 billion in Federal highway money for mass-transit improvements and a scaled-down road connecting 42d Street and the Battery. Many officials agreed that a combination of adverse court rulings on environmental issues and growing opposition to Westway in the House of Representatives was the immediate cause of its death. But there was disagreement on why Congressional discontent had mounted and on what the end of Westway signified. Alan Finder, an editor of The Week in Review, asked two Congressional experts last week for their thoughts on the project's demise. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a Democrat, is New York's senior senator. Representative James J. Howard, Democrat of New Jersey, is chairman of the House Public Works and Transportation Committee. Excerpts follow.

title: EVOLUTION AND THE .400 HITTER
description: THE FLAMINGO'S SMILE Reflections in Natural History. By Stephen Jay Gould. Illustrated. 476 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $17.95.

title: A LABORATORY FOR NEW DANCE MARKS A MILESTONE
description: Choreographers, performers and those who work behind the scenes will gather on Thursday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music for an event that is becoming one of the city's dance rituals. On that night, an invited audience will witness Dance Theater Workshop's second annual presentation of the New York Dance and Performance Awards, familiarly known as the Bessies, after Bessie Schonberg, the noted dance composition teacher. The event will also celebrate, in a way, the 20th anniversary of the Dance Theater Workshop, which has served most single-mindedly to promote, legitimize - and affirm - new dance.

title: Spartan's Odyssey
description: The first New York Times Magazine article I read after returning from a 5,000-mile 12-day train trip from Albuquerque to New York City was Russell Baker's ''Spartan's Odyssey'' (Sunday Observer, Aug. 18). I am very happy to reassure Mr. Baker that every place is not the same place yet.

title: GRATIA L. ROBERTSON WED TO JOHN F. CASSIDY ON L.I.
description: Gratia Lee Robertson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Robertson of Riverside, Conn., and John F. Cassidy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Cassidy of New York and Torrington, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. Donald Huston performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church in Bridgehampton, L.I.

title: HOLLY HAMMONDS IS MARRIED IN MAINE
description: The marriage of Dorothy Holly Hammonds, an associate in the Washington law firm of Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld, to Peter Woodard Galbraith, an adviser to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, took place yesterday at the Wilson Memorial Chapel in Ocean Point, Me. The Rev. Mary Hillas, aunt of the bride, performed the Protestant ceremony.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE PATHFINDERS: The Saga of Exploration in Southern Africa. By Peter Becker. (Viking, $17.95.) These are not the best of times for a sympathetic appraisal of the hardships endured by the white colonizers of southern Africa.

title: CONGRESS VOTES TO RELEASE $4.8 BILLION IN HIGHWAY FUNDS
description: Congress has passed a bill to release $4.8 billion in Federal money for Interstate highways and mass transit.

title: BRAZIL'S LEADER URGES NEGOTIATIONS ON DEBT
description: Brazil's new civilian President, Jose Sarney, has said he prefers negotiations to confrontation on the regional debt crisis, but he has warned that the country will reject any solution that prolongs its four-year-old recession.

title: NEW YORK CITY OUTLETS CITED ON HEALTH CODE
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 7 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: MCENROE CASNCELS BECAUSE OF FLU
description: Top-seeded John McEnroe withdrew from the $315,000 Volvo Tennis-Los Angeles men's tournament today, suffering from stomach flu.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;

Modernism in Focus
description: The Bauhaus - the school of architecture and design opened in Weimar, Germany, by Walter Gropius and continued in Dessau and, briefly, in Berlin until Hitler forced its closing - was famous for exploring the creative possibilities of materials, art forms and techniques. Its chairs and buildings are perhaps more widely known than the photographs made there, but though it came late as a formal part of the school's curriculum, photography clearly played a significant part in Bauhaus life.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: THE KING OF SWING Nostalgia will reign at Waterloo Village Friday night, when Benny Goodman, the King of Swing, plays with a big band for the first time in more than 10 years.

title: CABARET: TERESA BURRELL
description: TERESA BURRELL, who has appeared on Broadway in ''Eubie!'' and in ''Dreamgirls,'' is a still-ripening talent who is more comfortable belting Motown-styled songs than interpreting the sophisticated supper club ballads that pepper her act.

title: EFFECTS OF RETIREMENT PLAN DEBATED AS DECISION NEARS
description: WESTCHESTER lawmakers must soon decide whether to join in the state's Retirement Incentive Plan that could allow as many as 17 percent of the county's 8,000 employees to choose early retirement next year.

title:
WEEK IN BUSINESS;

LAURA ASHLEY
description: The business of designing Victorian-style prints began 32 years ago on the London kitchen table of Laura Ashley and her husband, Bernard. At the time of Mrs. Ashley's death at the age of 60, nine days after a fall at her daughter's home, Laura Ashley had expanded into a multinational company with more than 220 shops worldwide and annual sales of $130 million. Mrs. Ashley caught the public's fancy with the nostalgic prints and frilly clothing styles, but she said her creations were inspired more by her country way of life. She once told an interviewer: ''Living quite remotely as I have done, I have not been caught up with city influences and we just developed in our own way.''

title: KINGS OF THE ROAD
description: ''I'm the type of guy that likes to roam around. I'm never in one place, I roam from town to town. I'm the wanderer, they call me the wanderer. . .''

title: LABOR CONFERENCE FOCUSES ON NEED FOR CHANGES TO REINVIGORATE UNIONS
description: The union of the future must offer membership to people outside unionized work places, confront employers with weapons other than strikes, emphasize organizing and serving workers in smaller businesses and demand strengthened roles in how businesses are run.

title: SUSAN CHARNLEY IS THE BRIDE OF GREGORY DE NEVERS
description: The marriage of Susan Charnley, a daughter of Mrs. Bailey Warren Brown of Bronxville, N.Y., and Gregory Clark de Nevers, the son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Vincent de Nevers of Greenbrae, Calif., was performed yesterday by the Rev. Kenneth Norris of the Church of the Gospel Ministry at Pepperwood Ranch in Santa Rosa, Calif., a nature preserve of the California Academy of Sciences in San Francisco.

title: P. A. HARVEY, SARAH LARKIN ARE MARRIED
description: Sarah Meigs Larkin, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles L. Larkin Jr. of Middlebury, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter Ashforth Harvey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eldon Harvey Jr. of Stonington, Conn. The Rev. Dr. A. Edward Couch performed the ceremony at the Middlebury Congregational Church.

title: AGING 'BABY BOOMERS' BUOY CO-OP AND CONDO OUTLOOK
description: THE market for home ownership in New York City is being reinforced by the new demographics of the 1980's and 90's. A maturing baby-boom generation will continue to define the future of the region's housing market - as well as that of the nation as a whole - but in a fashion quite different from the 70's.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Lots of Things to Do, To Learn, To Teach As the school year reopens from kindergarten through college, low-cost learning options for everyone from infant to adult also resume through community organizations such as the Y.W.C.A. of White Plains and Central Westchester. The brochure slogan is ''Women on the Move'' in this 55th year of the Y.W.C.A., with family memberships at $75, individual adult memberships for $35 and children under 17 for $17; men and boys may become associate members. Most courses and events cost less for members.

title: BENEFITS BY AND FOR ARTISTS
description: Confluent Writers Sept. 22 - For the first time in 20 years the International PEN Congress of poets, playwrights, essayists, novelists, translators and editors will be held in the United States, from Jan. 12 through 18 in New York. Thousands of the world's top writers are expected, and to raise funds for the 48th PEN Congress the American hosts are holding eight Sunday-night champagne receptions starting at 7 P.M. at the Booth Theater, with each hosted by two writers. The hosts this evening are Saul Bellow and Eudora Welty; on Oct. 6, Isaac Bashevis Singer and Alice Walker; on Oct. 20, William F. Buckley Jr. and John Irving; on Oct. 27, Susan Sontag and Kurt Vonnegut; on Nov. 10, Joan Didion and Tom Wolfe; on Nov. 17, Norman Mailer and Gore Vidal; on Dec. 1, Arthur Miller and William Styron, and on Dec. 15, Woody Allen and John Updike. Tickets, $1,000 for entire series, from 212-334-1660. Playhouse Renovation Sept. 26 - Until 1974, the Hunter College Playhouse was a special cultural hub for the East Side, presenting student productions and the debuts of promising artists. But the 690-seat theater fell into disrepair, sharply curtailing the productions, as a result of the city's fiscal problems (Hunter is part of the City University of New York). Renovation is now planned, and the state has agreed to match the funds collected at a special benefit at the college auditorium on 69th Street near Park Avenue. The pianist Emanuel Ax will play Beethoven, Stravinsky and Rachmaninoff with the Hunter College Symphony.

title: Q AND A
description: Liability in a Slaying Question: I lease space in an office building where a woman was murdered a year ago after going to a health club. All the tenants and the landlord have just received summonses to answer a complaint that we were negligent for not keeping an eye on the hallway and we are being sued for $125 million. Am I, as a tenant, responsible for the safety of visitors to the space leased by other tenants? What should I do? . . . J. D., Manhattan Answer: There have been cases where a landlord has been held responsible for the safety of visitors to a building. Lawyers say it is possible that a tenant could be held responsible for visitors' safety depending on the circumstances. While they say the brief facts you have outlined indicate that the claim may be novel and your liability unlikely, you must answer a summons with which you have been served.

title: MICHIGAN TROUNCES S. CAROLINA BY 34-3
description: Michigan continued to rebound from its first non-winning season since 1967 today with its second consecutive victory over a higher-ranked opponent, routing South Carolina, 34-3, behind the passing and running of Jim Harbaugh.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest: DO NOT OPEN. Written and illustrated by Brinton Turkle. Unicorn/Dutton. $3.95. (Ages 5 to 8) A paperback edition of a splendid variation on the genie-in-the bottle story featuring a doughty and almost completely fearless lady named Miss Moody and her cat, Captain Kid.

title: SOARING PRICE OF BOSTON HOMES LAID TO STRONG LOCAL ECONOMY
description: When Lawrence Dwyer set out to find a house in South Boston late last year, he never imagined it would take him nine months.

title:
ART;

ARTISTS EXPLORE GOD AND MAN
description: RELIGIOUS faith and the rituals of worship have inspired artists since the dawn of civilization, and continue to do so, even in our relentlessly pragmatic, materialistic society.

title: The Clubhouse Dealer
description: The conviction of Curtis Strong in Pittsburgh last week for selling cocaine to major league baseball players was something of an anti-climax. The drama had come in preceding weeks when an all-star lineup of ballplayers, including Keith Hernandez of the Mets and Dave Parker of the Reds, took their turns to testify against the 39-year-old caterer. Mr. Strong, who faces a long prison sentence, and his lawyer, Adam Renfroe Jr., who was held in contempt for ''reprehensible behavior'' during the trial, will appeal, arguing that the case sets a bad precedent. By granting immunity to the ballplayers, Mr. Renfroe said, the court was in effect ''legalizing the sale of cocaine'' among them.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: FIDDLE AND BOW. By Robert Taylor Jr. (Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill, $15.95.) The mind grows dizzy as it skips along a genealogical path that winds from the 19th into the 20th century, through several generations of a prolific Tennessee family with a limited supply of names.

title: BOSTON WASTE SITE OFF JERSEY SOUGHT
description: The Massachusetts agency that operates Boston's sewage-treatment plants is seeking temporary permission to dispose of its sludge at a newly designated Atlantic Ocean dumping site off New Jersey.

title: BRIDGE PLAN CAUSES SAG HARBOR UPROAR
description: LAST year, Sag Harbor officials came up with a plan to replace the Otter Pond Bridge, a span about 30 feet long that is the southern entrance to the village from the Sag Harbor-Bridgehampton Turnpike.

title: Clashes Are Reported In Capital of Sudan
description: More than 10,000 Sudanese took to the streets today to call for more aggressive Government action against rebels in the south of the country.

title: WILDERNESS COMMUNITY BECOMES FAMILY
description: I AM traveling along the Saw Mill River Parkway from Yonkers to White Plains. It is a short trip. My car responds easily; the highway, bordered by lawns and guardrails, is well engineered. Trees and woods exist because they present no obstacle to sight and enhance the scenery. The sky intimates rain, but it doesn't matter. My windshield wiper works with the flick of a switch. Also, I carry an umbrella.

title: STATE WEIGHS VOTE ON RENT
description: MORE than half of the landlords covered by rent-stabilization guidelines will be ineligible to receive rent increases, some for two years, if the state finds that the Rent Guidelines Board in fact intended to vote the way it appears to have voted on Sept. 11.

title: CARDS' GREEN POSES PROBLEM FOR GIANTS
description: Roy Green chuckled. He said that if he were to write a book about his life as a wide receiver in the National Football League, he might begin it by saying: ''It wasn't always like this for Roy Green. . . .''

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, 2:05 P.M. Terry Leach will start for the Mets in place of Ed Lynch, who has been bothered by back spasms. (Television - Channel 9, 2 P.M.) Cardinals vs. Montreal Expos, at St. Louis. (Television - Channel 7, 2 P.M.) Yankees vs Orioles, at Baltimore. (Television - Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 2 P.M.) Croquet U.S.C.A. National Singles and Doubles Championships, at the greens just north of the Sheep Meadow, 69th Street and West Drive, Central Park, semifinals and finals, 10:30 A.M. Football Giants vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Giants Stadium, 1 P.M. Neil Lomax leads the undefeated Cardinals, who were picked by many to win the division title. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M. Radio -WNEW, 1130; 1 P.M.) Jets vs. Green Bay Packers, at Milwaukee. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; 4 P.M.) Hockey Rangers vs. Islanders, at Madison Square Garden, National Hockey League exhibition game, 7:35 P.M. (Television - MSG Network, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660; 7:20 P.M.) Running Harvey Electronics Women's Half Marathon, at 69th Street and East Drive, 9 A.M. More than $50,000 in prizes will be awarded in this 13.1-mile road race, the final women's tune-up for the New York City Marathon. Gabriele Andersen-Schiess, the Olympic marathoner, will be among the competitors. Hudson Toyota Five-Mile Race, at Liberty State Park, Jersey City, 11 A.M. Geoff Smith of England, two-time Boston Marathon winner, and Ed Eyestone of Brigham Young, winner of the National Collegiate Athletic Association 5-kilometer and 10-kilometer races this year, are entered.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;

A VICENTE IN SEARCH OF HIMSELF
description: FOR an artist who insists he ''does not have much to say about art,'' Esteban Vicente is uncommonly eloquent on the subject.

title: Camera;   NIKON SHOWS THE WAY WITH A VIDEOTAPE
description: SOMETHING different comes with the new motor-driven Nikon N-2000 35-millimeter single lens reflex camera - a videotape instruction book.

title: BEFORE THE BIG BANG
description: PERFECT SYMMETRY The Search for the Beginning of Time. By Heinz R. Pagels. Illustrated. 390 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title:
DANCE VIEW;

BALLET THEATER SURVIVES ANOTHER SET OF CRISES
description: American Ballet Theater advertised its recent two-week run at the Metropolitan Opera House as an ''Encore!'' season. Perhaps ''Here we go again'' might have been more apt a label.

title: JEANNE ELLEN ARRIGONI MARRIED TO BIFF J. O'REILLY
description: Jeanne Ellen Arrigoni, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Arrigoni of Harrison, N.Y., and Biff J. O'Reilly, the son of Dr. Hugh O'Reilly and Maureen O'Reilly, both of Kensington, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. Daniel Lanahan, the bridegroom's great-uncle, performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

title: REASONS TO BE NERVOUS
description: MIDAIR By Frank Conroy. 149 pp. New York: Seymour Lawrence/E. P. Dutton. $15.95.

title: 100 HAITIANS ARE FEARED DROWNED BY SMUGGLERS
description: As many as 100 Haitian refugees are presumed drowned after they were tossed from a crowded, rickety fishing boat by crews paid to smuggle them into the United States, Federal immigration officials said Friday.

title: OUT FROM UNDER MAO
description: CHINESE DEMOCRACY By Andrew J. Nathan. Illustrated. 313 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95. IN 1975, with a quarter of the century still to go, Prime Minister Zhou Enlai set a goal for China that has never changed through the succeeding political turmoil: accomplishment by the year 2000 of the ''four modernizations'' - in industry, agriculture, science and technology, and defense.

title: CRACKDOWN ON CRIME GROUP
description: The syndicate is active in Taiwan, the Philippines, Saudi Arabia, Hong Kong, Japan and the United States, and it boasts as many as 15,000 members, according to court documents. Its sales and revenues might be the envy of many multinational corporations, but its methods and goals would not: according to the documents, the syndicate's operations are decidedly illegal.

title: THROWING THE FISH OVERBOARD
description: IN FORM Digressions on the Act of Fiction. By Ronald Sukenick. 247 pp. Carbondale: Southern Illinois University Press. $16.95.

title: SMALL-TOWN WEEKLY MARKS 100th YEAR
description: AMY D. FOSTER, who will be 90 years old in December and who for half a century has been writing ''Local Happenings'' for The Elmer Times, recently completed a special assignment: A column for the paper's 100th-anniversary issue.

title: PRESERVING SYMBOLS
description: 'The ''21'' Club is not the most beautiful building in the world.

title: WILANDER GAINS FINAL
description: Mats Wilander of Sweden defeated Henri Leconte of France 3-6, 6-3, 6-1, today to advance to the final of the $100,000 Martini Open.

title: ART OF EATING A CLUB SANDWICH
description: THERE is no way to eat a club sandwich that does not offend, embarrass or necessitate dry cleaning.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

DANGER: LEAD IN OUR WATER
description: THERE is lead in our drinking water. It is there because up to a third of the homes in Nassau County have lead pipes bringing in water. These pipes were put into the homes at the time they were built, but over the years the lead has become corroded and is leaching into the water.

title: T. PATRICK DUGGAN WEDS MISS HAILEY IN CONNECTICUT
description: V. Ann Hailey, vice president for finance and control at Pepsi-Cola U.S.A. in Purchase, N.Y., and T. Patrick Duggan, president of Duggan Consulting Associates, a business strategy consulting firm in Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday at their home in Weston, Conn.

title: ROYALS AND ANGELS REMAIN IN A TIE
description: Doug DeCinces homered and drove in four runs and Kirk McCaskill allowed three hits over eight shutout innings to lead the California Angels to a 12-3 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 22, 1985
description: International

title: CHAIN TO AID CANCER SOCIETY
description: THE store opened with a wine-and-cheese party. Designer clothes hang in the display window alongside Visa and MasterCard stickers. The uncluttered, spacious main room features new carpeting - and perfectly presentable dresses selling for $8.

title: SEX AND SCHOOL CLINIC: A CITY AT ODDS
description: In Room 165 at DuSable High School, teen-agers can receive not only general medical care but also birth control pills and condoms.

title: SNAKE SACKING CONTESTS SPLIT PENNSYLVANIANS
description: In Pennsyslvania people may kill rattlesnakes, but since Jan. 1 they have not been allowed to toss live ones in sacks, and this has made a lot of firemen angry.

title: AMY L. ZACHARY WEDS JOURNALIST
description: The Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Amy Lioba Zachary, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Zachary of New York, to James Sheldon Jr., a son of Mr. Sheldon of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Eleanor Bernert Sheldon of New York. The Rev. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony.

title: A MODERN SETTING FOR ANTIQUES
description: DESIGN'S NEXT direction is toward symmetry, simplicity and restraint, says 33-year-old Gary Hager, who works in the venerable Manhattan firm of Parish-Hadley Associates. ''The style Rothschild may be considered terribly fashionable these days, but who has the staff needed just to brush the curtains or dust the trimmings?'' His own apartment is convincing evidence of his convictions.

title: SCOFFLAW CREDIT
description: MANHATTAN parking scofflaws were offered a convenient way to pay their fines in July 1984. The New York City Transportation Department said they could begin using credit cards to get their cars out of the pound.

title: DR. KUHNS IS WED TO DR. C. A. LANG
description: Dr. Janet Susan Kuhns, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Kuhns of Tenafly, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Christopher Anthony Lang, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard R. Lang of Parma, Ohio. The Rev. Harry Chase performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church in Tenafly.

title: STATE GETS FIRST BANK OF VALVES FOR HEARTS
description: STORED in ordinary glass flasks in a refrigerator at the Deborah Heart and Lung Center here are six human heart valves from ''living'' donors - small round pieces of tissue that may one day mean life for six patients.

title: THE PREGNANT DETECTIVE
description: IN A LARGE, stately home in a quiet, old-money Los Angeles neighborhood, the television producer Barney Rosenzweig got ready for work. A particularly adept practitioner of West Coast sartorial style, he picked an outfit that could best be described as authoritatively casual: handsome crew-neck sweater, pale shirt underneath, khaki slacks, and pastel argyle socks slipped into soft leather loafers.

title:
INVESTING;

THE BEARS SPEAK UP ABOUT I.B.M.
description: TWO weeks ago, when the Dow Jones industrial average started to hit the skids, I.B.M. was a pocket of relative strength. While the Dow fell 28 points for the week ending Sept. 13, Big Blue held its own. Last Monday, when the broad averages meandered, I.B.M. actually advanced 3/4. It did slip 1 5/8 on Tuesday - a day the Dow slid 10.98 points -but was soon trading at about 127, smack in the middle of its 52-week high/low range of 116 to 138 1/4.

title: Will Success Spoil Stamford?
description: Few mayors would feel sorry for Stamford, Conn. The city's rapid growth of the last 15 years shows no sign of abating.

title: FACADE REVIVAL
description: In a city that see as many major construction projects as does New York, modest efforts often escape notice. But a small, carefully done restoration can have as much impact on a street or a neighborhood as a rehabilitation done on a grand scale.

title: DANCE: TRISHA BROWN AT THE CITY CENTER
description: THE Trisha Brown Company offered three of Miss Brown's finest dances Wednesday night at the City Center. The program triumphantly demonstrated that Miss Brown has made a fine art out of squirming.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: The Russians Are Coming, The Russians Are Coming Starring Carl Reiner, Alan Arkin, Eva Marie Saint; directed by Norman Jewison, 1966 Playhouse Video 135 minutes, $59.98 Nearly 20 years after it first opened, this remains not only a relevant movie but an exemplar of the rare feat of packaging a serious message inside a comic story.

title: SPECIALISTS EXPRESS SURPRISE AT INTENSITY OF AFTERSHOCK
description: While specialists at the National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo., had expected one or more severe aftershocks after the devastating quake that struck Mexico on Thursday, they said yesterday that they were surprised at the intensity of the one that struck on Friday.

title: VILLANOVA DEFEATS IONA
description: Football returned to Villanova University this afternoon for the first time since the 1980 season and the Wildcats celebrated with a 27-7 victory over Iona before a sellout crowd of 13,405.

title: Manchild Coming of Age
description: When my daughter was born ''normal'' last year, I praised whatever gods there may be for having smiled upon us.

title: NBC'S 'GOLDEN GIRLS' GAMBLES ON GROWN-UPS
description: When it comes to women, television has always had an obsessive love affair with youth.

title: JAPAN'S ANCIENT ART OF LACQUERWARE
description: Joao Rodriguez, a Portuguese missionary, wrote of finding a varnish of unsurpassed quality, like ''smooth shiny ivory,'' applied to everything from jewelry to armor in an island kingdom east of China during the 16th century. Early traders, dazzled by this rare lustrous coating that was produced from the sap of an indigenous tree of the sumac family, christened it with the name of the land of its origin -Japan.

title: SARAH FRENCH MARRIED TO KEVIN A. J. WEAFER
description: Sarah Ann Cochrane Spies French, a daughter of Sarah Simpson French of Tucson, Ariz., and John Herndon French 2d of New York, was married yesterday to Kevin Anthony John Weafer, a son of John J. Weafer and the late Mrs. Weafer of North Scituate, Mass. The Rev. Gary Fertig performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Manhattan.

title: MARY P. LARKIN AND A TV EDITOR MARRIED IN JERSEY
description: Mary Patricia Larkin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. Larkin of Montclair and Point Pleasant, N.J., and Eugene G. Caputo Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Caputo of Atlanta and Elizabeth City, N.C., were married yesterday. Msgr. Vincent P. Coburn performed the ceremony at St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Bloomfield, N.J.

title: DeLorean's Troubles, Cont.
description: When he reflects on his failed automobile company, the ordeal of his drug trial and a bitter divorce, John Z. DeLorean says he deserved what happened to him. ''I was an arrogant egomaniac,'' says Mr. DeLorean, who describes himself as a born-again Christian.

title: GRAMBLING COACH ONE VICTORY AWAY
description: Eddie Robinson, Grambling's head football coach since 1941, moved a victory closer to the record books last night.

title: BRUNSWICK WINS 18TH STRAIGHT GAME
description: The Brunswick School was undefeated in nine games last year, and in seven of those victories it blanked the opposition. Yesterday, the Connecticut school scored its second shutout of this season in defeating Rye Country Day, 22-0, and now has won 18 games in a row over three years.

title: AN ISLE FOR DIVERS - AND NONDIVERS
description: When the beach resort on Panglao Island in the Philippines was founded last year, the idea was that it would be mainly a dive camp - an outpost for seasoned and aspiring scuba divers and snorkeling enthusiasts.

title: LATEST DEBATE AT THE U.N.: WHO WILL OR WILL NOT COME
description: The Western delegate to the United Nations touched the tip of his forefinger to his nose, closed his eyes and sniffed. ''I have a sense, a sense that Mr. Gorbachev may be coming,'' he said. ''Wouldn't it be a dramatic surprise?'' Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, is not among the nearly 100 heads of state or government expected at the 40th anniversary of the United Nations General Assembly in the next few weeks.

title: MASS PRODUCTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan Seeks to Avoid 'False Hopes' for Talks
description: President Reagan today reiterated his willingness to negotiate nuclear arms reductions at his coming meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev but said he did not want to ''raise false hopes.''

title: NEW VOICES, HARSH WORDS IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: TO kill a snake, goes an old African proverb, you must first crush the head. That seems at least partly the thinking that has inspired South Africa's white authorities to conduct a widespread campaign of detentions and arrests against those seen as leaders of the spreading protest movement.

title: 55-1 SHOT CAPTURES THE TURF CLASSIC
description: Noble Fighter, a 55-1 shot who backed into the lineup only four days ago, posted a dramatic upset victory over favored Win yesterday in the $718,500 Turf Classic at Belmont Park, the richest thoroughbred race ever run in New York.

title: JEAN-FRANCOIS BIZALION MARRIES KATE MOODIE
description: At St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church in Amagansett, L.I., yesterday Kate Moodie, the daughter of Betty Blue Moodie of Sarasota, Fla., and John Alexander Moodie of New York, was married to Jean-Francois Bizalion, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Bizalion of Arles and La Ciotat, France. The Rev. Peter Allen performed the ceremony.

title: SURROGATE ATTICS
description: The proliferation of condominium communities in the suburbs has spawned a new type of warehouse development known as ministorage.

title: STATE GRANTS SUBSIDY FOR UPSTATE BUS RUNS
description: New York will give Greyhound Lines Inc. $416,000 to continue service on 12 routes linking 100 upstate communities under an agreement intended to avert threatened cancellations, the state said.

title: MINORITIES STILL LAG IN READING
description: Since 1971, minority students have made greater gains than white children in reading achievement. But even with the improvement, they lag so far behind white students that the average black or Hispanic 17-year-old reads at about the same level as the average white 13-year-old.

title: BULK OF TOWERS MUST BE LIMITED
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;

THE RASPBERRY, A ROSE AMONG FRUITS
description: RASPBERRIES elicit visions of mouthwatering goodness. Whether eaten direct from the bush, chilled and dusted with sugar, or with ice cream or as jam on toast, their distinctive flavor has made them a favorite with people of all ages.

title: The Young Hemingway
description: Peter Griffin's piece on Ernest Hemingway and the three short stories made interesting reading, but the words ''gaudy dancers'' used in ''The Ash Heel's Tendon'' set off alarms in my head.

title: BEYOND THE GLOSS OF THE NEW ASIA
description: Asia - how Western it may look, but how Eastern it will always be. For first-time travelers and for old friends who have stayed away a few years, a journey into the Pacific is a startling voyage of discovery. Glittering hotels, brassy boutiques, credit-card life styles, fast food, fast cars and fashionable people who regard the rest of us as a little seedy - the kaleidoscope of images dazzles modern Marco Polos. Glimpse the skyline of Hong Kong by night - and see if you can remember Manhattan.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: WALK THROUGH COLD FIRE By Cin Forshay-Lunsford. 205 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $14.95. (Ages 12 and up) THREE years ago Delacorte Press announced a literary competition to encourage young adult fiction by previously unpublished novelists. ''Walk Through Cold Fire,'' the most recent prizewinner, is a tale in a time-honored tradition - a story of misunderstood adolescents. Written by an 18-year-old woman, the novel is described by its publisher as ''rich in autobiographical detail.'' Thus it is not surprising that, while also rich in melodrama, it has the ring of authentic adolescent angst.

title: MONTAUK'S LIGHTHOUSE: ON THE EDGE OF DISASTER?
description: IT STANDS like a sentry on watch, a solitary figure on the easternmost bluffs of Long Island. Commissioned 190 years ago by President George Washington, the Montauk Lighthouse has become one of the most photographed structures in America because of its dramatic location.

title: AL FRESCO LUNCH HAS ITS APPEAL
description: PASSING by hordes of executives clamoring around ''21'' or La Grenouille for lunch on the way to a deli for a tuna salad on rye can be a very demeaning experience. Hospitality would bubble within me as I eyed these gray-suited groups, laughing heartily and slapping each other on the back, each of them about to casually consume, costwise, what to most people would amount to a few weeks' worth of groceries.

title: ARMY OVERCOMES SOLID RUTGERS, 20-16
description: When Army prepared this week for its game with Rutgers, the one thing stressed the most was blocking by running backs on sweep plays out of the wishbone.

title: JOAN TEETOR SAXE WEDS
description: Joan Teetor Saxe of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Steven S. Marder of New York, were married yesterday in the chapel at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Andrew J. W. Mullins performed the ceremony. The previous marriage of Mr. Marder, the vice president of merchandising for the Majestic Mills Company in New York, ended in divorce, as did that of the bride.

title: A Green Party in Britain
description: Britain's environmentalist movement decided today to change its name to the Green Party in an effort to emulate the success of its better-known sister groups on the Continent. The 5,000-member movement, known as the Ecology Party for nine years, approved the change after a heated one-hour debate at its annual conference in this southeastern English town.

title: CONTROLLING CONTOURS
description: SOME WOMEN DO IT BY STARTING THE DAY TOSSING, tumbling and gyrating to the commands dictated by a tape-recorded or televised exercise program. Others visit a gymnasium and sweat their way through aerobics classes or weight-lifting regimens.

title: NEW QUESTIONS ON CORPORATE CRIME
description: Congressional critics who argue that the Reagan Administration is soft on corporate crime got more grist for their mill last week. It was disclosed that the Justice Department, ignoring a recommendation from the Food and Drug Administration, had classified as misdemeanors rather than felonies the failure of a large drug company and some of its managers to report lethal side effects of a blood pressure medication.

title: HOMOSEXUALS STEPPING UP AIDS EDUCATION
description: A young man circled a table in the East Village one recent afternoon, approaching and then retreating from the stacks of AIDS literature offered by the Gays Men's Health Crisis.

title: SUSN E. TIFFT WEDS ALEXANDER JONES
description: The marriage of Susan Elizabeth Tifft, a writer for the international editions of Time magazine, to Alexander Susong Jones, who reports on the news media for The New York Times, took place yesterday at the First Congregational Church of Thetford Hill, Vt. The Revs.

title: CHAMBER ESTABLISHES SUPPORT GROUP FOR SMALL BUSINESSES
description: HOPING to decrease small-business failures by raising entrepreneurial spirits, the Westchester Chamber of Commerce has started a peer-group support program for the county's small-business owners.

title: THE TOUGHEST CALL: STARTING A ROOKIE
description: THE VETERAN had charge of the offense for 12 series on opening day and moved the team for 96 yards and no points. It was not all his fault. Often, receivers missed passes and linemen missed blocks. Six times, an offensive player was penalized. Eight times, the quarterback was sacked. So with a little more than eight minutes left in the game and his team losing by three touchdowns, the coach pulled the veteran out of the game and sent in the rookie.

title: 'Right to Die' Suit Fails in Ohio
description: An Ohio physician won a quick victory last week in what is believed to be the first trial in which survivors charged that a doctor had violated a patient's ''right to die.''

title: THOUSANDS RALLY AGAINST MARCOS RULE
description: Tens of thousands of protesters took to the streets here and in other Philippine cities today to mark the 13th anniversary of the declaration of martial law.

title: A Captive Is Released
description: Islamic radicals in Beirut released one of seven American hostages last weekend and threatened new anti-American violence. According to the Rev. Benjamin M. Weir, a Presbyterian missionary who was freed after being held for 16 months, the radicals vowed to kill the six remaining hostages and stage new kidnappings unless Kuwait released 17 prisoners, three of whom are under sentence of death for terrorist bombings.

title: GOLDWATER, SOFTER BUT STILL SPICY, REFLECTS ON A FADING ODYSSEY
description: The celebrated chin that critics thought conveyed arrogance but admirers thought symbolized conviction no longer juts upward and outward to make a point.

title: BALKANS AT THE BORDER
description: The illegal influx of aliens to this country is being Balkanized, according to the current newsletter of the Federation for American Immigration Reform, a Washington-based lobby.

title: DEFINING PERU
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;

A NEWCOMER IS DRAWING CROWDS
description: WHEN we counted seven Cadillacs and a Jaguar in the crowded lot of this unassuming block of innocuous shops dominated by graffiti-covered walls, we knew that something interesting was going on. The magnet drawing all this attention is Valentino's, a newcomer to the county, although the chef and co-owner, Valentino Roina, was for many years associated with a well-known restaurant on Arthur Avenue in the Bronx.

title: GIANTS MOVE LIKELY
description: Al Rosen, appointed general manager of the San Francisco Giants last Wednesday, said yesterday that the Giants probably would not play in Candlestick Park next season. In an interview to be televised on ABC's SportsBeat today, Rosen said there were three options for the Giants next year: building a stadium in downtown San Francisco, sharing the Oakland Coliseum with the A's or moving to nearby San Jose.

title: CHOOSING A SPREADSHEET FOR THE MAC
description: THE spreadsheet war is heating up as more and more publishers release electronic worksheets. None of them, however, has succeeded in overcoming the dominance of the Lotus Development Corporation's 1-2-3. Even Lotus could not top itself by publishing Symphony. Offering more features than the original 1-2-3 does, Symphony nevertheless has not managed to garner a market share as large as its predecessor's.

title: Union Official Assails Shapiro Proposals
description: Peter Shapiro's campaign emphasis on trimming the state's work force is denigrating individuals who work in public service.

title: Fire Destroys Laboratory
description: Fire destroyed a multimillion-dollar commercial fisheries laboratory and injured 10 firefighters here this morning, officials said.

title: A TIME FOR CONTINUITY
description: THE CONCEPT of newness, the idea of things being different from what has come before, has an odd role in our culture at this moment, and so in our architecture. It seems at once to attract and to repel us. We want our buildings, our houses, to be new and different, to stake a claim for our own time on the landscape of history. Yet at the same time we are striving earnestly to hold on to the architecture of the past and to evoke some of its qualities in the new things that we build. We want to be new, but we do not want to be that new, in other words, and that casts the whole meaning of the quest for new ideas in a somewhat unusual light.

title:
THE CREATIVE PROCESS;

THEME DREAMS
description: When I design my home collection, I'm inspired by dreams of what I'd like to see in my home.

title: VERMONT INTENSIFIES RAIDS ON MARIJUANAN GROWERS
description: The police in Vermont have conducted an aggressive campaign this summer to crack down on large marijuana-growing operations and have already seized nearly triple the number of marijuana plants that were found last year.

title: RISE IN NASAL INHALER ABUSE WORRIES OFFICIALS
description: A growing number of teen-agers and young adults appear to be using the drugs in nasal inhalants by intravenous injection as a substitute for amphetamine, medical authorities say. Health officials are particularly concerned about the physical damage and occasional deaths linked to a practice that many abusers consider harmless.

title: Laura Ashley Is Buried In Wales Countryside
description: Laura Ashley, the fashion designer, was buried today in the quiet Welsh countryside that had inspired her style.

title: ITALIAN FARE, GOOD AND PLENTY
description: BRING a healthy appetite to Il Cortile, a new Italian restaurant in Syosset. The portions are massive.

title: ELIZABETH CARAVELLA WED
description: Elizabeth Ellen Caravella, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Augustine Joseph Caravella of Riverside, Conn., was married there yesterday to Robert Clinton Reynolds, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Clinton Reynolds Jr. of New Vernon, N.J. The Rev. Vincent J. O'Connor performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church.

title: ITHACA WINS AND EXTENDS STREAK TO 12
description: Mike Middaugh, a junior quarterback, rushed for 50 yards and passed for another 44 as Ithaca today won its 12th straight game, blanking St. Lawrence, 13-0.

title: SCHOOL POPULATION ON A ROLLER COASTER
description: THE number of school-age children has been falling across the country since 1980, and Connecticut has led the decline with a drop of 13.5 percent in its population of children age 5 to 17.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: DEBUNKING IN PHILADELPHIA Before conducting works by Mozart in Philadelphia tonight, Davis Jerome aims to ''set the record straight'' about the composer.

title: READERS SPEAK OUT ON CLASSES FOR GIFTED
description: In response to your article on separate and enriched classes for ''gifted'' children, I should like to state that I do not believe in ''segregation'' in any situation.

title: REBUFF TO GUARD
description: WHEN the Air National Guard asked Concord, Mass., to lend it the mold of its famous bronze statue ''The Minuteman,'' so the Guard could make a copy for display at its support center, citizen groups objected and the town's five selectmen rejected the request.

title: REJECTING THE CITY AND ITS HIGHWAY: James J. Howard
description: WHAT killed Westway? After more than a decade of debate, the proposed $2.3 billion highway and development project was officially declared dead last week. Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch said they would seek to trade in $1.7 billion in Federal highway money for mass-transit improvements and a scaled-down road connecting 42d Street and the Battery. Many officials agreed that a combination of adverse court rulings on environmental issues and growing opposition to Westway in the House of Representatives was the immediate cause ofWHAT killed Westway? After more than a decade of debate, the proposed $2.3 billion highway and development project was officially declared dead last week. Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch said they would seek to trade in $1.7 billion in Federal highway money for mass-transit improvements and a scaled-down road connecting 42d Street and the Battery. Many officials agreed that a combination of adverse court rulings on environmental issues and growing opposition to Westway in the House of Representatives was the immediate cause of Question. Why did the House of Representatives coalesce as it did in recent weeks against Westway?

title: UPDATING THE GREENHOUSE
description: LIKE MANY AR-chitects and designers who attempt urban space-stretching feats, Harry Stein, a Los Angeles-based designer, enlarged a one-bedroom penthouse by building a glass-enclosed addition on the adjacent roof.

title: PLAYING TO THE CROWD
description: WITH only two months remaining until President Reagan meets Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Geneva, the United States and the Soviet Union have arrived at the fateful period when they must decide whether the first summit conference in six years is to transcend the deep divisions and suspicions between them. Preparing the ground this week, the new Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, will meet Secretary of State George P. Shultz in New York and Mr. Reagan in Washington. Meanwhile, in Geneva, Soviet and American arms-control negotiators have resumed their deadlocked talks on nuclear and space-defense weapons. The discussions in the United States and Switzerland will lay the groundwork for the meeting of the two leaders on Nov. 19 and 20. They may offer early indicators of what can be accomplished, providing a basis for Moscow and Washington to decide whether to pursue compromises in a further preparatory session.

title: CLARK SPARKS CARDS' TRIUMPH
description: Jack Clark hit his first home run since Aug. 16, a two-run shot in the seventh inning, to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 7-6 victory over the Montreal Expos today that kept St. Louis two games ahead of the Mets in the National League East.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:What and when is Southern California's Doo Dah Parade? -A. B., Nutley, N.J. Answer:The Doo Dah Parade in Pasadena, Calif., has been held each year since 1978. It began when a group of residents who had gathered in a bar near the Rose Bowl decided to stage a humorous version of the city's annual Tournament of Roses Parade. Unlike that New Year's event, the Doo Dah Parade always takes place on Sunday - this year on Dec. 1. The parade has no theme or judging, and any floats entered must be hand-powered, but according to Peter Apanel, founder and coordinator, there is no shortage of entries. This year the Synchronized Briefcase Drill Team - a group of executives and office employees - will be marching again in business attire, along with the Marching Leeches (in appropriate costume) and a group called the Texas Chain-Saw Massacre Drool Team, which carries chain saws with the teeth removed. Some 2,000 participants, making up 125 groups, including bands, are expected to parade along the one-and-a-quarter-mile downtown route, starting at noon. Mr. Apanel says the parade and the number of spectators have been growing each year.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CHARLEYHORSE. By Cecil Dawkins. (Viking, $15.95.) This second novel by Cecil Dawkins appears to be an ordinary contemporary western, portraying an unmarried, capable, tomboy ranch woman named Charley, who loves the prairie better than the kitchen, and a cultured Eastern schoolmarm named Juna.

title: FULLBACK LEADS SAYTVILLE TO 20-13 VICTORY
description: Jim Carbonari arrived late, but in time to save the day - ''almost like here comes the cavalry,'' according to Coach Lee Van Voorhees of Sayville. The senior fullback did not come to his squad's season opener against Half Hollow Hills West on a horse, but he did score the winning touchdown in the 20-13 victory.

title: THE CONSTITUTION CHRONICLES
description: THE CHIEF JUSTICE OF THE United States shares a birthday with the United States Constitution. On Sept. 17, 1987, Warren E. Burger will reach 80 years of age, and the American system will be 200 years old.

title: DEBORAH HANSON BECOMES A BRIDE
description: The marriage of Deborah Paige Hanson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jon F. Hanson of Bedminister, N.J., to Harold John Imperatore, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George E. Imperatore of Franklin Lakes, N.J., took place yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Harvey B. Hoffman, pastor emeritus of the Middle Collegiate Church in New York and grandfather of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Second Reformed Church in Hackensack, N.J. He was assisted by the Revs.

title: SCEOND CHANCE
description: Mary O'Dowd, the Manhattan singer who forgot the words of the Canadian national anthem and mangled the tune last Saturday night before the Yankees-Blue Jays game, may get another chance. She has received an invitation from the Mayor of Toronto and The Toronto Star to sing the anthem before one of the three Yankee games Oct. 4-6. If the Blue Jays agree, Miss O'Dowd said yesterday, she will be there ''to atone for the horrible thing I did last weekend.''

title: MARY KUSER LANE IS WED TO A BANKER
description: Mary Kuser Lane, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur S. Lane of Harbourton, N.J., was married yesterday to Thomas Frederick McNamara, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. McNamara of McLean, Va., and Cataumet, Mass. Msgr. Leonard R. Toomey performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart in Bay Head, N.J.

title: Second Mexico Quake Described by Tourists
description: Air passengers arriving here from Mexico City today said the second earthquake that hit the capital caused already weakened buildings to collapse and sent people running into the streets for safety.

title: WHEN IT PAYS TO REFINANCE A MORTGAGE
description: WHEN Robert J. Grosso and his wife, Carolyn, bought their five-bedroom colonial in New Jersey two years ago, they financed the property with a 13 7/8 percent, variable-rate mortgage. They recently discovered that they owed almost $4,000 more than they had originally borrowed. The mortgage had a negative amortization feature, so when rates increased, the monthly payment remained the same and the difference was added to the principal. Dismayed, the couple decided to shop for a better deal.

title: Workers in Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSICAL EXPRESSION THROUGH ELECTRONICS
