description: Recent advances in computer technology are making many musicians' most extravagant fantasies come true - the ability to control dozens of sophisticated instruments single-handedly, to print accurate, detailed scores of their improvisations quickly, to recreate every nuance of a brilliant performance perfectly and to play ''live'' with other musicians in locations separated by thousands of miles.

title: COLUMBIA'S COACH FURIOUS AFTER ROUT
description: He wore a Columbia blue T-shirt and Columbia blue shorts. If anyone doubted what Jim Garrett was doing at 218th Street and Broadway yesterday afternoon, there were the large white letters on his T-shirt. ''COACH,'' it read. Jim Garrett had come dressed for success.

title: A CLASSIC SOUP TO HONOR A GUEST
description: There are certain foods in Asia that when served to one's guests convey honor and respect. Shark's fin, cooked slowly for several days and served braised and intact, as a softened comb on a bed of delicate mustard greens, or as vermicelli-like strands in a thick soup, is one. Duck, either in the style of Peking or smoked over special green tea leaves from Hangzhou is another.

title: Plane Crashes on I-95; 2 Die
description: A small private plane crash-landed into the center barrier of Interstate 95 at midmorning today, killing both people on board, officials said. The pilot managed to miss vehicles on the highway.

title: BRUDZINKSI ACTIVATED AFTER ENDING HOLDOUT
description: Bob Brudzinski, the Miami Dolphins' most valuable linebacker the past two seasons, ended his two-month holdout today, signed a three-year contract and was immediately activated for Sunday's game against Kansas City.

title: NOW, SCULLEY GOES IT ALONE AT APPLE
description: IN the new era at Apple Computer, the day begins at 7:30 A.M. with a meeting of the executive staff.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bergenfield $136,500 *2* 21 Fahrner Street *2* 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 28-year-old split-level; *2* new wall-to-wall carpeting, 220 wiring; *2* taxes $2,567. Clinton $125,000 *2* 9 Messig Road *2* 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 19-year-old bilevel; *2* fenced yard, new kitchen, pool; *2* taxes $2,413. Hopatcong $87,500 *2* 24 Inns Avenue *2* 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old colonial; *2* sun porch, fireplace, new septic system; *2* taxes $1,542. Mendham $190,000 *2* 4 Carroll Drive *2* 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 14-year-old colonial; *2* raised living room, screened porch, entrance foyer; *2* taxes $3,319. Stanhope $84,000 *2* 10-185 Dell Place *2* 1-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 5-year-old town-house condominium; *2* great room, $111 monthly charges; *2* taxes $1,587. Vernon $73,000 *2* 2 Iris Court *2* 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 10-year-old bilevel; *2* 2-zone heat, fireplace, deck; *2* taxes $1,558. OTHER AREAS Scarsdale, N.Y. $247,500 *2* 12 Bradley Road *2* 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 31-year-old colonial; *2* eat-in kitchen, wine cellar, family room, patio; *2* taxes $5,208. Farmington, Conn. $205,000 *2* 343 Main Street *2* 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 6-year-old contemporary; *2* on hillside with views, pool, 2 acres; *2* taxes $1,659. Selden, L.I. $106,000 *2* 14 Anne Drive *2* 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 20-year-old split-level ranch; *2* dining room, eat-in kitchen; *2* taxes $2,100.

title: PLAYING TWO ROLES
description: Many of New York's younger experts, mostly in their thirties, have shown a mysterious and unexpected tendency to skip attendance at a national championship during the past three years. The cause turns out to be the baby boomers' baby boom: The missing experts reappear at the next National, proudly displaying Andrea, Dana, Daniel, Robin or Andrew and look for someone who will help out by looking after baby while they try to win national titles.

title: HAYDEN O'CONOR WEDS LUCY SHURTLEFF
description: The marriage of Lucy Hurd Shurtleff, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Lothrop Shurtleff of Mendham, N.J., and Hayden Tomkins O'Connor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hayden O'Connor of Cazenovia, N.Y., took place yesterday. The Rev. David Hoag performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Mendham.

title: REBEL CHIEF SAYS ANGOLA IS PRESSING LARGEST ATTACK IN 10-YUEAR WAR
description: Jonas Savimbi, leader of a rebel army in southeastern Angola, says his forces are under attack in the biggest Government troop offensive against them in a decade of civil war.

title: PERMANENT GLOBAL WATER SHORTAGE FORESEEN
description: Conservation and efficient use of existing supplies will be the only realistic answers to what is expected to be a permanent global water shortage, according to a new study issued today by the Worldwatch Institute.

title: USING SOVIET GAS TO KEEP OPEC REELING
description: TWELVE years ago, OPEC jolted the world economy by curtailing production, raising prices and ushering in the era of limits and high energy prices. Inevitably, consumers curtailed demand. Today, OPEC is producing at less than half of capacity, and Saudi Arabia, OPEC's stoic hero, has reduced its production to a bare quarter of capacity.

title: Alfred Kirchhofer, 93, Editor At The Buffalo Evening News
description: Alfred H. Kirchhofer, who for nearly 40 years was managing editor and then executive editor of The Buffalo Evening News, died Thursday at Buffalo General Hospital. He was 93 years old.

title: FROM FAITH TO FATALISM
description: THE PARADOX OF HISTORY Stendhal, Tolstoy, Pasternak, and Others. By Nicola Chiaromonte. Foreword by Joseph Frank. Postface by Mary McCarthy. 156 pp. Philadelphia: The University of Pennsylvania Press. Paper, $13.95.

title: BRENDA DAVIS WEDS HAROLD V. MCCOY JR.
description: Brenda Lynn Davis, a daughter of Barbara L. Davis of New York and Madison, Conn., and Ralph G. Davis of League City, Tex., was married yesterday to Harold V. McCoy Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. McCoy of Garden City, L.I. The Rev. William Roberts performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: THEATER: 'SHORT CHANGE'
description: THE ultimate revelation in Geoffrey Gordon's ''Short Change'' at the Samuel Beckett Theater is that the big man on campus, despite his habit of manipulating everyone, is all tender teen-ager inside, with a big, generous heart. The underlying theme is education off campus as three male undergraduates and a young woman begin to share an apartment.

title: FOR MYSTERY LOVERS, THE THRILL IS BACK
description: THE Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale has always been successful with productions of mystery plays - they schedule at least one into every season.

title: Attorney General Meese Likens Quotas to Slavery
description: There have always been two strands to the Reagan Administration's argument against race-conscious employment standards. One is the contention that mandated goals discriminate against qualified whites or men by forcing employers to bypass them. The other is that they hurt the intended beneficiaries - blacks or women - by making such people dependent, in this instance upon the Government.

title: CHRONICLE OF A SCANDAL
description: NIGHTMARE Women and the Dalkon Shield. By Susan Perry and Jim Dawson. Illustrated. 261 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $16.95.

title: BRIDGEPORT FOUNDRY OPENS GALLERY
description: THE Renaissance Art Foundry of Bridgeport will open its own sculpture gallery tomorrow, in the Landmark Building at Broad and Atlantic Streets in Stamford. It is believed to be the first time that a foundry has offered editions of its castings in a separate gallery that it owns and manages.

title: U.S. COMPANIES BID TO END APARTHEID
description: The heads of 10 of the biggest American companies operating in South Africa have formed a group that they say will work with businesses there in lobbying for an end to apartheid.

title: LILY TOMLIN: COMEDY WITH A BITE
description: Lily Tomlin is a storyteller. When she talks about putting her show together, when she reminisces about growing up in Detroit, when she recalls the seedling days of her career, she tells, each time, a little story, a tale of Lily, with an introduction, a middle, a subplot and, usually, a punchline.

title: A LIFE UNLIKE HIS ART
description: GIACOMETTI By James Lord. Illustrated. 575 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $30.

title:
WEEK IN BUSINESS;

THE 'FLASH' DIMS HOPE FO A REBOUND
description: Third-quarter growth was pegged at 2.8 percent in the ''flash'' G.N.P. estimate, not much better that the revised 1.9 percent rate of growth in the second quarter. That means that while the economy is gaining, it is not anywhere near the Administration's 3 percent growth target for the year. Because the ''flash'' estimate rarely is the final growth figure, some analysts were reluctant to write off the third quarter. But others note that in times of sluggishness the figure often is revised downward, as, indeed, was the second-quarter figure. Still, most say future improvement is likely.

title: UNRAVELING PACIFIC AIR FARES
description: Trying to find the lowest air fare from the United States across the Pacific to Asia is like groping through a maze.

title: TRACKING CANCER ON L. I.
description: EXPERTS studying the high incidence of breast cancer among Nassau County women are trying to determine whether the cause is an environmental agent, life style, demographics or a combination of these factors.

title: IN CHINA, YOU'LL NEVER WALK ALONE
description: If you are planning to go to China to get away from it all, replan, because you will never see nobody there.

title: GREAT VOICES OF THE PAST SING ON IN REISSUES
description: In the perennial debate over the state of things operatic, the one point on which all parties agree, sadly, is the current shortage of great singers. And the one segment of the opera world exempt from that condition, happily, is the record industry, where the stars of yesteryear never retire (or if they do, are always available for a comeback). It would not be healthy to let devotion to the singers of the past substitute entirely for rejoicing in the art of such great artists as are among us here and now - but their records can both satisfy the voice-starved ear and serve as a beacon for a younger generation of successors.

title: MIRIAM E. FISHER WED TO AN ARTIST
description: Miriam Edith Fisher, a daughter of Drs. George and Mary Stuart Fisher of Haddonfield, N.J., was married yesterday to George Vincent Schaefer Jr., a son of Madeleine DuzoDuzo and Mr. Schaefer, both of Astoria, Queens, in a ceremony at the Religious Society of Friends Meeting House at 221 East 15th Street.

title: Who or What Is Magda V.?
description: To the Editor:

title: Israelis Report Copter Damaged in Lebanon
description: The Israeli military reported tonight that an Air Force helicopter had been shot at and damaged while it was on the ground in the area of southern Lebanon that Israel regards as its security zone, and that three soldiers had been injured in another incident in the zone, when their vehicle hit a mine.

title: A 1985 Model Immigration Bill
description: After years of arguing about the nation's immigration law, the House and Senate almost agreed on a broad package of revisions near the end of the 1984 Congressional session. But agreement eluded them and the bill died.

title: THROWING SOME MONEY AT NEW YORK'S TEACHER SHORTAGE
description: THE Koch administration won its arbitration battle with the United Federation of Teachers last week, but the city's 59,500 instructors had something to cheer about, too. The new contract raised their starting pay by 38 percent over three years and provided a premium to the most experienced among them. Salaries for new teachers will rise from $14,527 to $18,500 this year - the same minimum set by the state of New Jersey - and $20,000 next September.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure Section on Aug. 25 about the artist Red Grooms, and one in the same Section on Sept. 8 about coming art exhibitions, misstated the schedule of the traveling Grooms retrospective now at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts in Philadelphia. It will appear at Denver, Los Angeles and Nashville. In May, the Whitney Museum in New York will open a separate installation by Grooms.

title: Cable TV
description: Six exceptional men - three of them directors, three of them the leading characters in the directors' films - lend special luster to the cable movie schedule this week.

title: ONLY TWO SEXES, BOTH CRAZY
description: STANLEY AND THE WOMEN By Kingsley Amis. 256 pp. New York: Summit Books. $14.95.

title: DIFFERENT 'STUFF'
description: We look around and sort of see what's interesting, what isn't popular yet. In other words, from a commercial point of view, what is available, what is not now currently being sold and popular.

title: AS FALL BEGINS, OUTLOOK FOR FOLIAGE IS MIXED
description: Foliage from southern to northern New England will run the spectrum from brilliant to less than spectacular this fall, a weather expert believes.

title: Chancellor to Head Colleges
description: Kenneth Shaw, chancellor of the Southern Illinois University System, has been named president of the University of Wisconsin System. Dr. Ben Lawton, president of the Wisconsin System Board of Regents, said Friday that Mr. Shaw, 46 years old, would assume the post on Feb. 1, 1986.

title: SUSAN MONAHAN WED TO STEVEN KRONHEIM
description: The Unitarian Church of All Souls in Manhattan was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Susan M. Monahan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Monahan of Wyckoff, N.J., to Steven R. Kronheim, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Kronheim of West Long Branch, N.J. The Rev. Richard Leonard performed the ceremony.

title:
THE CREATIVE PROCESS;

IMAGINATIVE SELF-PORTRAITS
description: I don't start looking for new ideas in an empty room or a design studio. I don't think that people who design constantly reserve special moments just to look for ideas.

title: READERS SPEAK OUT ON CLASES FOR GIFTED
description: The attack that gifted/talented programs represent elitism is an unfortunate and distorted view. We never seem to have trouble supporting a highly ''elite'' and talented group that wear special jackets and uniforms to identify them, the school band to play for them, and even youngsters to cheer for them.

title: Baseball;   Stardom Beckoned Mattingly, McGee Since Days in Minors
description: DON MATTINGLY recalls that Willie McGee ''could do it all.''

title: CYNTHIA A. WILLOUGHBY IS WED TO ERIC HAUETER
description: Cynthia Anne Willoughby, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rodney E. Willoughby of Hillsborough, Calif., was married yesterday to Eric Scott Haueter, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eric D. Haueter of Stamford, Conn., and Adelboden, Switzerland. Msgr. John J. Murphy performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Burlingame, Calif.

title: A Boost for the Atom Smasher
description: Physicists as a rule are not given to wild-eyed exaggeration. So when some of the most distinguished pure scientists, including Nobel laureates, compare the plans for the world's largest atom smasher to the building of the Pyramids and the Panama Canal, people take notice.

title: TO A RUSSIAN, K.G.B. OFFERS A TASTE OF THE GOOD LIFE
description: This has been a heady season for spy fiction devotees of 007 and Moscow Centre. The real world, it seemed, had decided to give the fictional types a run for their money: in the United States there were John Walker and his kin; in West Germany, Hans Joachim Tiedge and his ilk, including a secretary in Chancellor Kohl's office who defected last week with her husband; in East Germany an American officer shot dead outside a Soviet base, and in Moscow allegations from the United States Embassy that Russians had been tracing Americans with spy dust.

title:
EDUCATION WATCH;

STUDENTS MAKE TOUGH GRADERS
description: Frustrated by their lack of involvement in education reforms, high school students in Chicago set out last summer to write their own report card of the schools. Last week they issued the final grades.

title: J.A.L. Official Dies, Apparently a Suicide
description: A Japan Air Lines maintenance official who had been negotiating compensation payments with families of the 520 victims of the crash Aug. 12 of a J.A.L. jet died today of knife wounds in an apparent suicide.

title: RESORT OWNER NEAR DEAL ON STATE LAND
description: AN AFFLUENT resort owner here and his company, who were indicted last year on charges of fraud, stand to gain ownership of a local state-owned ski mountain.

title: OFFICE DEVELOPMENT MOVING UP ROUTE 17
description: DESPITE a sustained surplus of speculative office space throughout Bergen County, developers continue to build there in hopes that the excess will have vanished by the time their projects are finished and demand will once again be strong.

title: PENNSYLVANIA VILLAGE FOR SALE
description: Once again this town is for sale. For $300,000, with 20 percent down, a buyer can get 23 houses, 13 garages, a chapel, ballfield, water system and even a 1984 pickup truck.

title: Route 206 Proposal Called Disastrous
description: The nostalgic article by Philip B. Taft Jr. on Route 206 [Sept. 8] was timely. The state's Department of Transportation, aided by the Federal Highway Administration, has a plan to eliminate the random human activity and rolling, pastoral beauty Mr. Taft remembers so fondly.

title: THE FILM FESTIVAL AT 23 - MORE HITS THAN MISSES
description: Whenever someone - most often, someone from Hollywood - asks me whether the annual New York Film Festival is really necessary, I usually answer as quick as a flash, with wit unflagging, ''Well, it depends . . . .'' That is, it depends on the movies that are shown. The 23d New York Film Festival opens Friday night at Lincoln Center with two showings of Akira Kurosawa's newest film, ''Ran,'' described in the special syntax of the festival's program as ''a samurization of 'King Lear,' '' with, ''for melodramatic spice . . . a Lady Macbeth figure.''

title: 2-DAY TOLL IS RAISED TO 3,000
description: More buildings crumbled today in the heart of Mexico City after a second earthquake struck the city Friday night.

title: A RACE FOR IMPORT CURBS
description: Perhaps sensing the political gains that trade winds might blow their way, Congressional Democrats and Republicans scrambled last week to attach ''Made on Capitol Hill'' labels to proposals for preserving the jobs and profits of domestic factory workers and owners.

title: ALICE E. KENNEDY WED TO DONALD W. LANGE
description: Alice Elizabeth Kennedy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Martin Kennedy of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Donald William Lange, a son of Gloria Ann Lange of Morristown, N.J., and Donald E. Lange of Key West, Fla. Deacon George Saulnier performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Assumption Roman Catholic Church in Fairfield. Msgr.

title: A Few Koreans Meet Relatives
description: Direct contacts between North Korea and South Korea have been occurring this year at a pace unprecedented since the Korean war ended in 1953. Last week, in an emotional and largely symbolic encounter, a handful of representatives of the estimated 10 million families divided by the two countries' enmity met in Seoul and Pyongyang.

title: CLEANUP OF CHEMICAL SITES CONTINUES IN NIAGARA FALLS
description: Love Canal has worked its way into the annals of environmental history, but it is only one of several chemical dumps in the Niagara Falls area that will require years of cleanup and monitoring, officials say.

title: POLITICAL UPSET MAKES WAVES
description: A 34-YEAR-OLD political buff who decided to wage his own campaign for office after working for other candidates for at least 17 years has upset the Long Island political establishment with his victory over Supervisor Hannah Komanoff of Long Beach in the Democratic primary.

title: SEASON BEGINS AT THE THEATERS
description: WE have been looking ahead to the new seasons of most of the orchestras and chamber societies in the county, but there are other sources of fine concerts in Westchester - the presenting theaters, among them the State University of New York's Purchase Arts Center, the Emelin Theater in Mamaroneck and Peekskill's Paramount Center for the Arts. Much like Carnegie and Avery Fisher Halls in New York, these centers not only rent their facilities to performing-arts organizations, but devise major subscription series of their own.

title:
ANTIQUES;

A WORK LABELED NEW HAVEN
description: ALTHOUGH from the time of its founding in the 17th century, New Haven has always enjoyed a special sense of its own identity, for years no early furniture was known to exist that was signed or labeled as having been made there.

title: C. K. HENNIGAN AND MISS BARNES ARE WED AT YALE
description: At the St. Thomas More Chapel on the Yale University campus in New Haven, Caroline Porter Barnes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel S. Barnes of Radnor, Pa., and Stony Creek, Conn., was married yesterday to Christopher King Henningsen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor W. Henningsen Jr. of Pelham Manor, N.Y. The Rev. Richard Russell, a Roman Catholic chaplain at Yale, performed the ceremony.

title: READERS SPEAK OUT ON CLASSES FOR GIFTED
description: Those educators and parents in the Three Village School District who question the wisdom of ''tracking'' and the validity of the standardized tests that determine student selections [''Classes for Gifted Provoke Debate,'' Aug. 25] are to be commended for their reservations. For, in fact, research data have shown that while such so-called homogeneous groupings may be of limited benefit for the ''gifted'' (only intellectually gifted, however), its effect on average children is clearly negative and for the slow learners, disastrous.

title: GOODEN'S HOMER HELPS METS WIN
description: He sat behind a table and picked up a microphone, and then Dwight Gooden began to talk about his favorite subject: hitting. He had waited for the moment, it must have seemed, forever.

title: A NEW 'AID' CONCERT TESTS THE APPEAL OF CHARITY
description: Are viewers growing tired of charity-oriented events?

title: 5 LEADING NATIONS GATHERING TODAY FOR FISCAL TALKS
description: The Treasury Department announced today that the finance ministers and the heads of the central banks of the five leading non-Communist industrial countries would confer Sunday in New York.

title: ON THE PAYROLL
description: When the White House wants to get a fallen partisan back on the Federal payroll, there is almost always a way.

title: OH, SAY CAN YOU SING THIS?
description: Perhaps, after big league baseball added two Canadian teams, it was only a matter of time until Americans found the foreigners threatening. Not that either the Toronto Blue Jays or the Montreal Expos have any Canadian players, mind you.

title: EXPLORING THE POLYNESIAN PARADOX
description: The land and the people of the four inhabited islands of Western Samoa, independent since 1962, still contain the physical and spiritual essence of Polynesia. Although Christianity arrived with the missionary John Williams in 1830 and soon conquered the people with gifts and God, the structure of Polynesian life there has - bearing in mind that beliefs and behavior vary widely from island to island across the Pacific - remained intact. First the Germans and then the New Zealanders became colonial rulers of Western Samoa in the early 20th century, and the Americans and the British were constantly making administrative proposals, but the inhabitants never became a colonized people. Their pride and their humor are still intact. They remain, as John Williams found them, a ''very lively, jocose, kind people.''

title: Red Cross Dispatches Aid Team and Supplies
description: The American Red Cross said today that it had sent 10 relief workers and 10,000 pounds of medical supplies to Mexico City for earthquake relief.

title: OVERLOOKING THE ILLS IN COLLEGE SPORTS
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: RECYCLING PROSTHESES
description: AFTER Benita Feuery had a mastectomy last February, she, like many women, had numerous adjustments to make. But there was one area, she said, that people seemed to ignore: the cost of looking normal for women who have had mastectomies.

title: A NATION LIVING ON BORROWED MONEY AND, PERHAPS, TIME
description: When he was asked about the United States becoming a ''debtor nation'' in his news conference Tuesday, President Reagan noted the sunny side of the trade deficit, which has nearly doubled in each of the last two years.

title: Heart Recipient Has Fever
description: Michael Drummond, who was kept alive nine days with an artificial heart before receiving a human organ, has been returned to an intensive care unit because he may have an infection, hospital officials said today.

title: WYNDHAM LEWIS: PAINTER, POLEMICIST, ICONOCLAST
description: Few British artists, in this or any century, have made such a noise about their calling as Wyndham Lewis (1882-1957). A painter and the moving spirit of Vorticism, the short-lived art movement born out of Cubism and Futurism, Lewis was agog with insights and outputs, also functioning as a novelist, poet, essayist, critic and pamphleteer. He used all these mediums to push his iconoclastic views of the world and jab at the smugness of British social and cultural life. ''To make the rich of the community shed their education skin, to destroy politeness, standardization and academic; that is, civilized, vision, is the task we have set ourselves,'' he wrote in the first issue of Blast, the scrappy magazine he edited as a vehicle for Vorticist views. ''We will convert the king, if possible. A Vorticist king! Why not?''

title: A Case for Port
description: WITH ALL THE CUR-rent concern over alcohol excess and the rush to adopt what appear to be lighter, less potent drinks, one of the best alternatives to hard liquor has been virtually overlooked. It is Port. Yes, Port. Because of its color, usually dark red, Port is often thought to be heavy, which it isn't. Because of its rich, full flavor, it is often thought to be high in alcohol. It is usually around 17 percent, less than half of most distilled spirits.

title: The Young Hemingway
description: Publication of three previously unpublished stories of Ernest Hemingway (''The Young Hemingway, Three Unpublished Stories,'' Aug. 18) is a disservice to a great writer and to American scholarship. In his introduction, Peter Griffin writes innocently that it is ''impossible'' to be certain why Hemingway failed to publish these apprentice pieces.

title: HILARY S. BEDFORD BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Hilary Sue Bedford, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clay Patrick Bedford Jr. of South Laguna, Calif., was married yesterday to Charles Hough Parkhurst, a son of Ann Hough Parkhurst of Dallas, Pa., and Frank Ellsworth Parkhurst 3d of Kingston, Pa., and Prout's Neck, Me. The Rev. Wilfred A. Files performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Rye Beach, N.H.

title: NEW FARMING VENTURE: RAISING DEER FOR FOOD
description: Sitting on the back porch of their farmhouse the other evening, Eliot and Susanne Clarke counted 146 deer gamboling in a nearby pasture.

title: HISPANIC CITIZENS HONOR HERITAGE AND REVIEW STATE'S HIRING POLICY
description: Empire State Plaza took on the air of a fiesta this week as Hispanic Americans from around the state and Puerto Rico gathered here to celebrate their heritage, discuss two reports on the extent of Hispanic poverty and press for more jobs in the state government.

title:
GARDENING;

THE RASPBERRY, A ROSE AMONG FRUITS
description: RASPBERRIES elicit visions of mouthwatering goodness. Whether eaten direct from the bush, chilled and dusted with sugar, or with ice cream or as jam on toast, their distinctive flavor has made them a favorite with people of all ages.

title: ANEW MAGAZINE FROM SMITHSONIAN
description: The Smithsonian Institution has decided to begin publication of a new magazine, Air & Space, which is to be modeled after its successful Smithsonian magazine.

title: Hard Times for Poets
description: To the Editor:

title: VICKI LYNNE WELLS BECOMES THE BRIDE OF DOUGLAS RANLET LAMONT IN BOSTON
description: The marriage of Vicki Lynne Wells, a daughter of Caroline Wells of Wareham, Mass., and Leo W. Wells of Brockton, Mass., to Douglas Ranlet Lamont took place yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston. The Rev. Francis Greer performed the ceremony.

title: THE LITERATI TAKE TO THE BOARDS FOR SAKE OF PEN
description: SAUL BELLOW and Eudora Welty were each greeted with sellout crowds at their public appearances in New York earlier this year, so it is not surprising that their joint appearance tonight at the Booth Theater has been sold out for weeks. Also sold out are the seven other literary Sunday nights on Broadway this fall, nights in which the 774 subscribers who paid $1,000 each will be treated to what Norman Mailer described as ''16 of the best writers in America.''

title: MINNESOTA EFFORT TO LIMIT WELFARE ROLLS IS BLOCKED
description: Legal challenges have balked state and county officials in their effort to discourage unemployed people from moving to Minnesota from other states.

title: PARENT'S FEAR AND CHILD SAFETY
description: WHEN I was a child my parents never gave it a second thought if I hugged a relative. Or kissed a friend. Or snuggled in the babysitter's lap for a bedtime story. Or took a walk around the block, by myself.

title: HELEN OFFNER HAS WEDDING
description: Helen Leila Offner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elliot M. Offner of Northampton, Mass., was married at the Amherst College Chapel yesterday to Peter Gurdon Clifford, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Clifford of Darien, Conn., and Wainscott, L.I. Bishop George L. Cadigan, the former Episcopal chaplain of Amherst College, performed the ceremony.

title: TUNING FINE SYSTEMS
description: The latest generation of electronic gadgetry for the home has been endowed with capabilities far beyond those of its immediate predecessors. The monitor-receiver -the successor to what was once simply the television set - today has separate connecting terminals for all the equipment contained in an up-to-date video system: a video cassette recorder, a videodisk player and perhaps even a satellite receiver. The result is a far better picture than was obtainable with older sets that required connecting the VCR or videodisk player to the antenna.

title: DANCE: DANIEL MALONEY
description: DANIEL MALONEY, a former member of the companies of Martha Graham and Mary Anthony, has organized a group of his own called Dance Probe, which performed Friday night in Mr. Maloney's studio at 736 Broadway.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

FOR CHINA FOLLOWERS
description: Past and future travelers to China, armchair travelers, China buffs and the Chinese population of Westchester have an unusual opportunity to learn more about Chinese language, culture and society, as well as to meet other community members with similar interests, at the Chinese-American Cultural Center at Pace University in White Plains.

title: DISPLACED WORKERS: MORE HELP IS SOUGHT
description: ALTHOUGH Governor Kean has conditionally vetoed a bill to help workers who lose their jobs when plants close or move out of the state, and the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has urged the Legislature to accept a diluted measure, Democrats are holding out for stronger legislation.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: THE new president of Centenary College in Hackettstown - and the first woman to hold the post - walks four miles a day with her Afghan, and sometimes people going into Dr. Stephanie M. Bennett's office have to nudge the dog aside.

title: Off to Britain? A New Source
description: The British Tourist Authority, at 40 West 57th Street in New York, has installed a computer system that visitors can use to help find hotel rooms, rental cars and tourist attractions in Britain.

title: TEACHING TEACHERS IN BALTIMORE
description: AS part of a basic writing test, an applicant for a Baltimore teaching job wrote the following hypothetical note to parents about their child's problems:

title: COLUMBIA HONORS DONOR
description: The largest contributor to athletics at Columbia University appeared quite moved at the dedication of the school's soccer field yesterday, especially when he was told he had been made honorary captain of the soccer team.

title: INDIA AND PAKISTAN DIFFER OVER U.S. MISSION
description: A United States mission to India and Pakistan this week was praised in Pakistan but criticized in India for suggesting the two nations undertake ''regional initiatives'' to avert a nuclear arms race on the subcontinent.

title: POTRAIT OF THE ARTIST AS ALMOST PERFECT
description: STRAVINSKY Selected Correspondence Volume Three. Edited and with commentaries by Robert Craft. Illustrated. 543 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $35.

title: DWIGHT STRIKES EARLY
description: FIVE days ahead of his own timetable, Dwight Gooden achieved the ultimate fringe-benefit thrill a pitcher can have yesterday: a towering home run to salt away a victory in the height of a pennant race.

title: IF IT AIN'T BROKE...
description: THE RAVISHED IMAGE Or How to Ruin Masterpieces by Restoration. By Sarah Walden. Illustrated. 174 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $13.95.

title: WAGNER IN 52-28 ROMP
description: Terry Underwood, a freshman tailback who did not play the final quarter, scored touchdowns on runs of 4, 2 and 7 yards as undefeated Wagner College routed St. John's University, 52-28, yesterday at Redman Stadium, Jamaica, Queens.

title: IN VITRO FERTILIZATION CLINIC IN COUNTY
description: AFTER wanting to become a mother for nine years, Martha Qualben decided her only option was to try to have a ''test tube baby.''

title: DOUBLE BEDS AND OTHER TORTURES
description: THE MARITAL ARTS By Arthur Hoppe. 206 pp. New York: Arbor House. $12.95.

title: JERSEY PLANS TO ADD 9,000 PARKING SPOTS FOR TRANSIT PATRONS
description: N.J. Transit officials have authorized a statewide expansion of railroad and bus park-and-ride lots that would add 9,000 parking spaces at a cost of more than $24 million.

title: HOLLIE MORRISON MARRIES IN JERSEY
description: At the First Presbyterian Church of Red Bank, N.J., yesterday Hollie Morrison and Paul Jackson Nielsen, members of the class of '86 at the University of Pennsylvania Law School, where they are members of The Law Review, were married by the Rev. Dr. Gerald Spencer Mills. The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Frederick Morrison of Rumson, N.J., was attended by her sister, Cynthia Leslie Morrison.

title: THE POLISHED APPROACH
description: WOMEN WHO WISH TO project this fall's stylish look will devote time to more than mere attire.

title: AIR FARES DROP ON NEW YORK-NEW ORLEANS ROUTE
description: A price competition initiated by People Express Airlines has brought lower air fares for flyers between New York and New Orleans.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Northeast Journal column last Sunday misidentified the Rhode Island director of economic development. He is Louis A. Fazzano.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

REMEMBRANCES
description: WHEN Rabbi Chaim Stern of Temple Beth El of Northern Westchester in Chappaqua was preparing to usher in Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, last Sunday evening, he recalled another name for the holiday: Yom Hazikaron - the Day of Remembrances.

title: FOR BRITISH ALLIANCE PARTIES, A SCENT OF VICTORY
description: The two British parties that formed an alliance four years ago now lead in public opinion polls and have begun to talk about how they would form a government after the next general election.

title: PLANTS THAT SHOW OFF IN AUTUMN
description: This is a good time of year to plant. In fall vegetative and floral growth are beginning to cease and entering a resting period. There is less of a drain on the plants' energy. The weather is cool, yet soil temperatures are still warm. The situation is ideal for growth. In fact, research has shown that root growth continues provided soil temperatures are above 40 degrees. This can occur in the metropolitan New York area as late as mid-December.

title: European Synagogues
description: To the Editor:

title: A COZY NICHE FOR BOOK LOVERS
description: THE once sleepy village of New Preston is all astir these days, as Anglophiles, bibliophiles and garden lovers converge there in growing numbers.

title: SOME DISHES WITH A CHINESE INFLUENCE
description: MORE and more, international boundaries are being crossed when it comes to food. Cooking techniques, spices, flavoring agents, exotic fruits and vegetables are being borrowed from other cultures and amalgamated to create a new hybrid cuisine. A pie may be made with a crust of poblano chilis or sliced eggplant instead of pastry; pine nuts, sun-dried tomatoes and raddichio tossed into a green salad; or fresh guava served with cheese instead of the usual pear or apple.

title: MEREDITH DAVIS IS MARRIED
description: Meredith Chandler Davis, a freelance editor and writer, and Stratford Pressley Sherman, an associate editor of Fortune magazine, were married yesterday. The Rev. Kenneth B. Swanson performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in New York.

title: RULES AUTONOMY AN ISSUE IN CUP TRIALS
description: Challengers for the America's Cup are scheduled to gather in Newport, R.I., tomorrow to work out details for next year's trial races in Perth, Australia. And if the mood at the last challengers' meeting prevails, there may be an effort to unite against Australian involvement in how those races are organized.

title: ''LIVING LIBRETTOS''
description: OPERA at Florham, under the artistic direction of Dr. Charles F. Del Rosso, is a professional company presenting one-act operas and the original plays from which the librettos were written.

title: ETHICS
description: To the Editor:

title: CLARIDGE'S HOTEL
description: To the Editor: ''Aplomb . . . at Claridge's'' sent me back to 1944. We were two American Red Cross girls on our first leave from the boondocks, luxuriating in a fling at Claridge's.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;

TORONTO SEES 'YANK AS A 4-LETTER WORD
description: LAST Sunday, while the Toronto Blue Jays were capping the most significant series in their history with an 8-5 triumph over the New York Yankees, Howard Cosell suddenly became a popular figure in this country.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

BANKS ARE NOW SELLING PRECIOUS METAL
description: More and more Americans are going to banks these days not to borrow money or deposit it, but to buy collector and bullion-type coins. Banks do not pose a threat to coin dealers yet, and perhaps they never will. Still, they are becoming an important retail outlet for certain types of bullion and rare coins.

title: ALASKA FIGHTS U.S. PLANS ON OFFSHORE OIL DRILLING
description: State officials are trying to stop Federal plans to drill for oil in the Bering Sea, which contains the state's richest fishing waters and the largest supply of red salmon in the world.

title:
ANTIQUES;

MORVEN SHOW: PREMIERE EVENT
description: WITH prestigious sponsorship, an impeccable location and 32 highly selective dealers expected to show some of their choicest acquisitions, the New Jersey Antiques Show at Morven may well achieve the recognition it seeks as the state's premiere antiques event.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''We have to improve our ability to identify national trends as they begin to occur, to become more effective, to increase our presence and to avoid being just a 'gotcha' kind of law enforcement agency.'' Roscoe L. Egger Jr. Commissioner of Internal Revenue

title: The U.N., Still an Infant at 40
description: In fairness, it should be said of the United Nations on its 40th anniversary that the world has got the global parliament it wants. Like the League of Nations before it, the U.N. is a feeble keeper of the peace because its sovereign members won't trust it even with a nightstick.

title:
DINING OUT;

IF COSTLY WINES ARE YOUR THING
description: LAST January, William Perretti, a car dealer, opened a restaurant in Carlstadt. A considerable amount of money was spent refurbishing the space previously occupied by a now-defunct restaurant (A Touch of Class), putting together an elaborate wine cellar and staffing what is now called Perretti's.

title: A BOOK STORE MORE THAN BOOKS
description: Paula F. Ludlow of Brookhaven should know that those of us who loved the Book Case in Sayville [Letters to the Editor, Sept. 8] were/are aware of the Sou'wester Bookshop in Bellport.

title: COMPUTER MUSIC IS VERY MUCH ALIVE
description: A new music season is upon us, with the big, familiar institutions rumbling into action. In New York especially, the home of the music business and hence the home of music-business conservatism, all might seem pretty much as usual. Yes, a couple of decades ago there were signs of revolution in the air, but that seems now like mere nostalgia. Pierre Boulez talked about blowing up opera houses, Leonard Bernstein speculated with glee and gloom about the demise of the symphony orchestra, and all manner of hairy avant-gardists looked ready to storm the barricades.

title: SOUTHERN CALL UPSET BY BAYLOR
description: Tom Muecke ran for one touchdown and threw for another, and Baylor made a goal-line stand to upset Southern Cal, 20-13, tonight.

title: Silicon Valley Saga
description: Steven P. Jobs was the hero of the New Age, the college dropout who launched Apple Computer Inc. in his garage.

title: GIVING TO CHARITIES: GET FACTS
description: WHEN a Waterbury-based charity was recenlty charged with using donations to rent a video cassette recorder and an X-rated movie instead of fulfilling the dreams of dying children, many Connecticut residents became concerned about where their charitable contributions were going.

title: Youth Finds There's a Cloud Along With the Silver Lining
description: An 18-year-old orphan who was awarded $346,800 from the sale of a bag of unclaimed jewels he found beside a railroad track is keeping out of the public eye after receiving repeated threats, his lawyer says.

title: 10 Suspects in Terrorist Trial Escape From Lisbon Prison
description: Ten terrorism suspects and a Spaniard used sprays to neutralize prison guards and escaped through the main door of a jail in central Lisbon today, the Noticias de Portugal news agency said.

title: GEORGE CLINTON: POP MUSIC'S PRECIOUS NATURAL RESOURCE
description: George Clinton has been in pop's vanguard for almost 20 years with ''P-funk,'' his own mixture of James Brown's dance rhythms, the shriek and whine of heavily amplified guitars, and a controlled chaos of sound effects, voices and other deliberately loony effects. He has influenced today's younger rap and funk stylists as profoundly as his own generation was influenced by James Brown. But during the past few years, the fresh street rhythms of New York's rappers and break dancers and the increasing sophistication of synthesizer and drum machine technology have taken dance music in new directions. Mr. Clinton's response to these trends has made his most recent albums a fascinating study in pop symbiosis.

title: EILEEN A. BOISI IS ENGAGED TO MARRY W. H. DOBBS 3D
description: Mr. and Mrs. James O. Boisi of Old Brookville, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Eileen Ann Boisi to William H. Dobbs 2d, a son of William D. Dobbs of Darien, Conn., and the late Marie Shea Dobbs.

title: SHOTS SEEN ROUND THE WORLD
description: ROBERT CAPA A Biography. By Richard Whelan. Illustrated. 342 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95. ROBERT CAPA PHOTOGRAPHS Edited by Cornell Capa and Richard Whelan. Illustrated. 242 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $35. WHEN Endre Erno Friedmann was born in 1913 on the Pest side of Budapest, all the signs indicated he would be a famous man - he emerged from the womb still wrapped in his caul and he had a full head of dark hair and an extra little finger. He became his mother's favorite child - not bad for a middle son -and from that day until his untimely death, he could do no wrong in her eyes or, it seems, anyone else's. We remember him today as Robert Capa. As portrayed in Richard Whelan's fact-packed, fast-paced biography, Friedmann-Capa was a lovable libertine who became the world's greatest war photographer.

title: WHAT'S IN A HOT CLUBS? ANYONE
description: MAX CASEY and Miranda Brouillet had passed the first test at the door of the Palladium - getting into the roped-off zone in front of the discotheque - but they still looked unhappy. Cornering one of the doormen, Haoui Montaug, Miss Casey pressed close to his side and whispered in his ear, begging for a free admission. Reaching into his pocket, Mr. Montaug pulled out a single pass.

title: NEW ZEALAND SENSES A VICTORY OVER FRANCE
description: A protest flotilla neared the site of a planned French nuclear test in the South Pacific today. And New Zealand, its pride hurt by a sabotage mission reportedly carried out by French agents, savored a moment of vindication.

title: ST. LOUIS SEES METS AS GLITTERY FAVORITES
description: ORDINARILY, the rivalry between St. Louis and New York, as embodied by the Cardinals and Mets, would not be a heated one. For much of the Mets' existence, St. Louisans have looked upon the Mets as more lovable than loathsome, a kind of low-budget operation in comparison to the elitist Yankees. The Yankees were the New York Board of Trade and power brokers. The Mets were Queens, Suffolk and Uniondale.

title: A Federal System Could Rescue South Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: UNITED NATIONS: 40 YEARS OF GROWTH AND CONFLICT
description: xhrrJune 26, 1945 United Nations Charter signed in San Francisco. Oct. 24, 1945 United Nations is created as Charter comes into force. Jan. 10, 1946 First General Assembly, with 51 nationsrepresented, opens in Central Hall, Westminster, London. Feb. 1, 1946 Trygve Lie, a Norwegian, appointed first Secretary General. Dec. 11, 1946 Assembly meets in New York. Nov. 29, 1947 General Assembly adopts plan to end British mandate in Palestine, and partition it into Arab and Jewish states with Jerusalem under U.N. administration. Dec. 10, 1948 General Assembly adopts Universal Declaration on Human Rights. Jan. 7, 1949 Dr. Ralph Bunche secures cease-fire between new state of Israel and Arabs. Dec. 3, 1949 General Assembly establishes office of High Commissioner for Refugees. Jan. 10, 1950 Soviet Union, after Security Council fails to act on its proposal to oust representative of Nationalist China, boycotts Council. June 27, 1950 When North Korea invades South Korea, Security Council - acting in the absence of the Soviet Union -votes military sanctions and calls on members to help repel invasion. In July, establishes unified force under United States command. Jan. 5, 1952 Overriding South African objections, General Assembly takes up question of apartheid. April 7, 1953 Dag Hammarskjold, Swedish diplomat and economist, elected Secretary General after Trygve Lie's resignation. July 27, 1953 U.N. and North Korea sign truce agreement. Nov. 3, 1956 Prime Minister Nagy of Hungary appeals to Security Council to counter Soviet invasion. A day later, Assembly approves resolution, 50 to 8, but it remains unenforced. Nov. 6, 1956 First Emergency Special Session of General Assembly meets over Suez Canal crisis.

title: ASSUMING THE MANTLE AT SCHLUMBERGER
description: IN a quiet moment last Tuesday, six days after he became chairman and chief executive of Schlumberger Ltd., Michel Vaillaud was asked what qualified him to lead the giant oilfield services and electronics company. ''I don't feel qualified,'' the 53-year-old Frenchman replied softly. ''But I'll enjoy trying, and I may eventually do it.''

title: YALE GETS A SCARE, BUT EDGES BROWN
description: Yale beat Brown today, 10-9, in a game that the Elis' captain, Carmen Ilacqua, said, ''We should have won, 35-0.''

title: ISRAEL'S MUSICAL CHAIR POLITICS, ONE YEAR LATER
description: Reading all the political indicators in Israel today, the right-wing Likud party should be worried. After a year of the national unity government, the popularity polls show the Likud leader, Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir, trailing Prime Minister Shimon Peres by 40 percentage points. If elections were held tomorrow, the pollsters say, Likud would lose nearly one-third of its Knesset seats to more extremist right-wing parties such as Rabbi Meir Kahane's Kach. To complicate matters further, Likud leaders have lately been preoccupied with an internal struggle among contenders for Mr. Shamir's crown, notably Deputy Prime Minister David Levy and two other Cabinet members, Moshe Arens and Ariel Sharon.

title: Where to Send Aid for Mexico
description: Following are some of the agencies accepting donations for disaster relief in Mexico: American Friends Service Committee, 1501 Cherry Street, Philadelphia, Pa. 19102. Contact: Paul Brink, (215) 241-7000.

title: Corrections
description: Because of out-of-date information from Amtrak that was published in the August-September issue of The Official Railway Guide, the Practical Traveler column of Sept. 1 gave an incorrect 30-day round-trip excursion fare for transporting cars on the Auto Train. The fare is $239.

title: LYME DISEASE REPORTS IN WESTCHESTER DOUBLING PACE OF 1984
description: Confirmed cases of Lyme disease, a bacterial infection caused by the bite of the deer tick, are being reported to Westchester County's Health Department at double the pace of last year, according to officials.

title: HOLLIS
description: In sharp contrast to many of the city's poorer neighborhoods, with their dilapidated housing, weak schools and high crime rates, the stable, single-family-house neighborhood of Hollis in southwestern Queens has for nearly a generation provided an attractive middle-class alternative for minority families seeking a better life.

title: REBUILDING BLOCK IN PHILADELPHIA
description: WITH a nudge of his toe, Mayor W. Wilson Goode of Philadelphia last week unfurled a roll of roofing material across the top of a nearly completed house on land belonging to Henry Gamble.

title: The Beauty in Owning One's Home, Finally
description: To the Editor:

title: SHAPING THE NEW SCULPURE OF THE STREET
description: BUILDERS once had little trouble accommodating art in public spaces.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Sept. 22, 1985 Fiction

title: NINA V. LAWRENCE IS A BRIDE
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday Nina Valerie Lawrence, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Clitherall Lawrence Jr. of Greenwich, was married to Charles Lockwood Halsey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rittenhouse Halsey, also of Greenwich. The Rev. Dr. John W. Bishop performed the ceremony.

title: Words Of the Right
description: William Safire tells us that the term ''anti-hardliners'' includes ''neutralists, doves, leftists, and . . . unilateral disarmers'' (''Words of the Right,'' On Language, Aug. 18). Who else could believe the present American arms binge has nothing to do with national security and will not further peace, liberty or democracy around the world? Unless doves and leftists have a monopoly on intelligence, there are many others who feel that MX, nerve gas and ''Star Wars'' are not the only alternatives to unilateral disarmament and surrender. We would appreciate a label on one of Mr. Safire's mental watertight compartments that says ''Others.'' LEE PAUL Linwood, N.J.

title: 93-YARD RETURN HELPS NOTRE DAME WIN
description: Tim Brown returned the second-half kickoff 93 yards for a touchdown and grabbed a 49-yard pass to set up Allen Pinkett's 2-yard touchdown tonight, leading Notre Dame (1-1) to a 27-10 victory over Michigan State (1-1). Pinkett rushed 25 times for 116 yards for his 16th 100-yard game.

title: SPY SUSPECT'S RECORD AS F.B.I. AGENT IS CRITICIZED
description: A decade before he was arrested on spy charges, two of Richard W. Miller's supervisors at the Federal Bureau of Investigation tried to get him discharged and one ''chewed him out'' regularly for shoddy work, the supervisors testified Friday.

title: Film/Music
description: Glenn Gould's unexpected death at the age of 50 on Oct. 4, 1982, brought to an end one of the most curious musical careers of the century. A pianist of international reputation by the time he was 25, he retired from the concert stage before he was 32. He had apparently always disliked playing in public, and he stopped as soon as his accountant told him it was feasible to do so. Thereafter, he devoted himself to recordings, broadcasting and writing.

title: LOSS TO AGE NOT CANDLES
description: IN several of his recent fights, Larry Holmes appeared ready to be dethroned. And last night, weary and worn, he was dethroned - by Michael Spinks, now the first heavyweight champion to hold the world light heavyweight title as well.

title: BUTTONING UP A HOUSE FOR WINTER
description: CLOSING a summer house or leaving a house for an extended vacation involves more than just locking the door. There are a number of precautions that should be taken while the house is still occupied, to prepare it for winter.

title: A BREAST CANCER SUPPORT SYSTEM
description: A PROGRAM at Adelphi University is helping women cope with breast cancer. Volunteers, especially women who have undergone treatment for breast cancer, are being sought to work three consecutive hours each week in a telephone service program.

title: CAPITAL WEDDING FOR MISS WINSTON
description: Elizabeth Newell Winston, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Winston of Washington, was married there yesterday to Robert William Taylor Anthony, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Anthony of Brooklyn. The Rev. William Smith performed the ceremony at the Chevy Chase Baptist Church.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

POLO FOR CREDIT
description: The game of polo is believed to have started in Persia more than 2,500 years ago. It is being taught for the first time in a Westchester university this fall.

title: KISCOVERING TRADITION
description: TRADITIONALISM IS not dying out. In fact, there exists a new group of practitioners, most of whom have been carefully groomed by some of this country's leading masters.

title: IN ONE PARISH, THE SURVIVORS OFFER THANKS
description: The sun had yet to peek over the mountains that ring this valley and the fog still lay heavy upon the marshes and along the ridges when the parishioners of San Sebastian Marti climbed the rough dirt street named Calle Corona to attend mass today in their makeshift church.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LUISA DOMIC. By George Dennison. (Harper & Row, $14.95.) One of the happiest literary occurrences of the past several years has been the emergence of a surprising number of new novelists and short-story writers whose books celebrate rural life in contemporary America, yet at the same time transcend the limitations traditionally associated with regional fiction.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: GIDEON'S SPRING: A Man and His Kibbutz. By Zerubavel Gilead and Dorothea Krook. (Ticknor & Fields, $19.95.) Zerubavel Gilead is a well-known Israeli poet and top editor of a kibbutz publishing house that not only issues worthy (he stresses the word worthy) works by members of the kibbutz but also publishes fiction and nonfiction of general interest.

title: SCANDINAVIA'S MINISTERS LACK MANDATES
description: Scandinavian voters - like the Americans who sent Ronald Reagan to the White House, the Britons who moved Margaret Thatcher into 10 Downing Street and the Germans who elected Helmut Kohl Chancellor - have been edging to the right during the last decade. But if elections over the last two weeks in Sweden and Norway are any indication, they are having second thoughts about where their conservative parties would lead them.

title:
THE CREATIVE PROCESS;

OFF A BEATEN TRACK
description: I travel in some fairly remote areas and find inspiration in some of the most unlikely places. One of our most popular ottomans was taken from a small piece of fabric that we saw in Ecuador.

title: THE MAID DRINKS KEROSENE
description: BABYLON By Rene Crevel. Illustrated by Max Ernst. Translated and with an Afterword by Kay Boyle. 169 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. $15.50.

title: HARRY HALL GERE
description: Harry Hall Gere, the former director of real estate for Trinity Church in lower Manhattan, died Thursday at his home in Little Silver, N.J. He was 78 years old.

title: STYLISH NEW AMERICAN IN HARTFORD
description: A restaurant named Panache has to be pretty sure of itself to prevent backfire.

title: ANN BARNARD IS A BRIDE
description: Ann Barnard, a daughter of Mrs. Arthur Earl Barnard and the late Mr. Barnard of Port Washington, L.I., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Alan Rohrbach, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Rohrbach of Douglassville, Pa. The Rev. W. Kurt Von Roeschlaub performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Port Washington.

title: LIMITING GROWTH
description: Within the last decade, the open space along Interstate 684 near the Westchester County Airport has become a mecca for major companies, which have established corporate headquarters or leased space in campus-like office parks there.

title: POISONED PAWN
description: Some opening variations give rise to what amounts to long-running duels in which White invests enormous ingenuity in the effort to wipe out the black defenses and Black puts in just as much work to prove that the attack is merely a pipe dream.

title: ACHAMBER: CHELSEA ENSEMBLE
description: THE Chelsea Chamber Ensemble's Friday evening concert at Carnegie Recital Hall was notable mainly for the world premiere of Joseph Fennimore's Sextet for Piano and Winds. This slight, pleasing confection began with searching solos for the woodwinds, alternating with jangling, clockwork piano passages; the second movement, subtitled ''Rite of Passage,'' had a witty, jerky bounce that can only be described as Chaplinesque. Mr. Fennimore is seemingly a Francophile; his Sextet called to mind, by turn, Faure, Debussy, Poulenc and a softer, gentler Messiaen.

title: PERFORMANCES DAILY
description: BETWEEN THEATER & ANTHROPOLOGY By Richard Schechner. Foreword by Victor Turner. Illustrated. 342 pp. Philadelphia: The University of Pennsylvania Press. $35.

title: YANKS WIN, 5-2 AND END SLIDE
description: Minutes after Don Mattingly fielded Cal Ripken's bouncer and stepped on first base, Billy Martin sat in his office and said: ''We've been waiting for that last out for eight days.''

title: SOUTH AFRICA
description: To the Editor:

title: SEMIFINALISTS FOR MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS
description: THE semifinalists in the National Merit Scholarship Corporation's annual competition represent a half of 1 percent of all high school seniors in the country. Nationwide, they total some 15,000 students.

title: SHAPING THE NEW SCULPTURE OF THE STREET
description: BUILDERS once had little trouble accommodating art in public spaces.

title:
GARDENING;

THE RASPBERRY, A ROSE AMONG FRUITS
description: RASPBERRIES elicit visions of mouthwatering goodness. Whether eaten direct from the bush, chilled and dusted with sugar, or with ice cream or as jam on toast, their distinctive flavor has made them a favorite with people of all ages.

title: H. Pierson Mapes Dies at 78; Advertising Executive for TV
description: H. Pierson Mapes, a retired advertising executive who commissioned the theme song ''There She Is'' for the first televised Miss America Pageant in 1955, died of cancer Wednesday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. He was 78 years old and lived in Sloatsburg, N.Y.

title: EXPERIMENTS IN HOUSEHOLD DESIGN
description: DESIGN objects by architects, decorators and craftsmen are flooding the marketplace. And each new wave of designs seems more daring than the last.

title: FOR NEW YORK LOBBYISTS, IT WAS WESTWAY WEEK
description: For Brad C. Johnson and Judy L. Chesser, this has not been the best of weeks.

title: 'QUEEN KELLY' OPENS - MORE THAN 50 YEARS LATE
description: One of the most indelible moments from Billy Wilder's classic film ''Sunset Boulevard'' finds the eclipsed silent star Norma Desmond (played, of course, by Gloria Swanson) indulging in her favorite pastime - watching her own old movies. Norma gazes enchanted as her younger self mimes piety and longing for an audience of two in the diva's Beverly Hills palazzo. ''Still wonderful, isn't it?'' she croons to her glazed-eyed gigolo, for whom those flickering images are snapshots from the Stone Age. ''We didn't need dialogue! We had faces!'' Norma exclaims, and then proves it by tilting her matchless profile into the beam of light cast by the movie projector.

title: COLUMBIA HOLDS ON, 20-18, AFTER LEADING BY 20-0
description: Columbia scored the first three touchdowns and held on for a 20-18 victory over Newark Barringer yesterday at Schools Stadium in Newark.

title: WHEN BIRDERS FLOCK SOUTH, GUESS WHO WATCHES THEM
description: SITTING quietly on our perch, a dozen of my passerine friends and I were enjoying the Indian Summer of Cape May County as we paused for a few days of rest and relaxation before getting on with our fall migration to our winter home in South America.

title: MUSIC SEASON WILL OFFER WIDE VARIETY
description: THE 1985-86 music season in New Jersey offers a broad variety of imaginatively planned programs and concert series in virtually all styles. For several classical music institutions, the season represents a milestone.

title: Topics;   Innovators Who Said That?
description: South Africa's Ambassador-designate to the United States, Herbert Beukes, spoke startling words on last Sunday's ''Meet the Press.'' He insisted that a decision has been made in Pretoria to ''dismantle'' apartheid, to restore ''common citizenship'' to all South Africans and extend real political rights to a huge black majority.

title: SOUTH KOREAN OPPOSITION LEADER FAULTS U.S.
description: A South Korean opposition leader said last week that United States support for the Government of President Chun Doo Hwan had inflamed anti-American sentiment in South Korea.

title: DESPITE TOXIC WASTE, 350 SEEK LOVE CANAL HOMES
description: Rosanna Vance, who wants to move her family out of its inner-city neighborhood here, has her eye on a two-bedroom split-level house on a quiet street in a nearby suburban area.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: TIGERS ON THE TENTH DAY AND OTHER STORIES. By Zakaria Tamer. Translated by Denys Johnson-Davies. (Quartet Books, $12.95.) On the face of things these 24 short parables convey world-weary, somber wisdom about power.

title: 70 YEARS OF NAKIAN IN STAMFORD SHOW
description: HAVING acquired a new architectural wing, the Stamford Museum can now spread its curatorial wings. For the new extension adds 2,000 square feet of exhibition space in the form of a gallery and a sculpture terrace and, on its lower story, another 2,200 square feet for storage and the preparation of exhibitions. As a result, the museum, at 39 Scofieldtown Road, can now display its permanent collection - and plans to celebrate its 50th anniversary next year by so doing.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE PEARL Written and illustrated by Helme Heine. Unpaged. New York: Margaret K. McElderry/ Atheneum. $11.95. (Ages 3 to 5) HELME HEINE'S ''The Pearl'' is an enchanting parable about greed -the story of a pinkish beaver, who becomes totally entranced with a freshwater pearl mussel, and of his friends, the other animals of the forest, who avidly look for pearl mussels of their own.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: THE GLORY OF THEIR TIMES: The Story of the Early Days of Baseball Told by the Men Who Played It, by Lawrence S. Ritter. (Vintage, $7.95.) Firsthand accounts of what it was like to be a major league baseball player between 1898 and 1947. The range is from Pittsburgh's Tommy Leach, who played in the first World Series, to Detroit's Hank Greenberg, who led the American League in home runs in three different years. Lawrence S. Ritter's 1966 collection of 26 tape-recorded interviews seemed to our reviewer, Wilfrid Sheed, ''quite simply the best sports book in recent memory. . . . This one tells it right.'' Another highly praised baseball book is SADAHARU OH: A Zen Way of Baseball, by Sadaharu Oh and David Falkner. (Vintage, $4.95.) Mr. Oh retired in 1980 after playing for 22 years with the Tokyo Giants and hitting 868 home runs. The New York Times sports columnist George Vecsey said this autobiography reads like ''The Natural'' by Bernard Malamud as ''edited by Ernest Hemingway, with research by James Michener.'' THE ODYSSEY: A Modern Sequel, by Nikos Kazantza-kis. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $12.95.) Nikos Kazantzakis, the author of ''Zorba the Greek,'' takes up in his epic poem where Homer's ''Odyssey'' left off. Odysseus has come home, and the question is whether, after all his wars and adventures, he can settle for tranquil domesticity. Writing in these pages in 1958, Dudley Fitts saluted a ''superb poem. . . . Superb and enormous: The twenty-four Books, Homer's number, are made up of 33,333 lines.''

title: AT FIRST, A JOKE AMONG PALS
description: The purchase of the Reading Railroad in 1973 - a bankrupt, crumbling institution - at first seemed like a ''ha-ha, why not?'' idea, recalled John Sullivan, now chief executive of the Reading Company.

title: A NEW POUPLARITY FOR LATIN IN SCHOOLS
description: DURING the first 18 years Donna Lyons taught Latin at Enfield High School, she had to teach English as well to maintain her full-time job. This year, for the first time, too many students have enrolled in Latin for Miss Lyons to be able teach them all.

title: CAPS MAKE LOANS LESS PERILOUS
description: WHEN adjustable-rate mortgages were first introduced in the early 1980's, the potential for rising payments was so great that wary borrowers soon dubbed them ''the neutron mortgage.'' Like the neutron bomb, which would kill people but preserve property, the mortgage would quickly eliminate those who are unable to keep up with the payments while leaving the house intact.

title: STATE IS HONORING THE ARTS WITH A WEEK OF CELEBRATIONS
description: AS PART of a national celebration of the 20th anniversary of the National Endowment for the Arts, a series of music and dance performances, readings, art exhibitions and craft festivals will be held throughout the state this week.

title: TEACHERS' STRIKES OFF AND ON
description: While New York City's teachers were enjoying last week the prospect of higher pay, many of their counterparts around the country were hitting the bricks.

title: STUDY SEES ATOM WAR AS CAUSING AIDS EPIDEMIC
description: A large-scale nuclear war would cause many more deaths from devastating fires, climatic changes and radiation than previously estimated, as well as a variety of long-term medical problems like AIDS, cancer and rampant infection, scientists asserted today.

title: DAMCE' SHELLEY LEE PERFORMS
description: FIRST, it seemed to be about eggs.

title: Good Beaches? Try Florida
description: I must say I found much to disagree with in ''Beaches You'll Never Forget'' [Opinion Page, Sept. 1] . Sure Jones Beach and the Rockaways are lovely, but unless one arrives very early the $3.50 per car at Jones doesn't guarantee a short walk from the car to the beach to the water.

title: THE UNEXPECTED MIX
description: UNTIL RECENT-ly, minimalism and luxury seemed to be totally antithetical decorating styles. One espoused stark, hard-edged and functional spaces; the other favored soft, often cluttered rooms that tended to a touch of fantasy. But a number of young designers have been trying to bridge the gap between these two disparate sensibilities.

title: THE RIGHT CHOICES: GOOD HEALTH
description: IT HAS BEEN MORE THAN 15 years since the White House Conference on Food, Nutrition and Health focused on the American food supply and found it wanting. As former President Richard M. Nixon said in opening the conference: ''We see, then, that the problem of hunger and malnutrition is, really, two separate problems. One is to insure that everyone is able to obtain an adequate diet. The second is to insure that people actually are properly fed, where they have the ability to obtain the adequate diet.'' Enough time has elapsed for food manufacturers seriously concerned about the nation's health to make changes. And slowly, as some segments of the industry have switched from selling good times to selling good health, changes have taken place. The results are mixed.

title: STAGE: AT SOUTH STREET, 'FIRST NIGHT OF PYGMALION'
description: TOWARD the end of ''The First Night of Pygmalion,'' which had its first night Wednesday at the South Street Theater, there occurs a dramatic moment. The fabled, now faded star, Mrs. Patrick Campbell, pleads with George Bernard Shaw for a role in one of his new plays and he refuses. The scene works pretty well, but it has the unintended effect of calling attention to how few dramatic moments have occurred in the preceding hour or more.

title: South Africa: Dream and Reality
description: SOUTH AFRICA REGULARLY surprised and astonished me in my second stint there as a correspondent for The New York Times from 1980 to 1983. It was a sensation available only to outsiders who could maintain access of a kind on all sides of the nation's racial and political boundaries as few South Africans can. Only such a voyeur could experience the huge evasions of the whites and the seemingly helpless knowledge of the blacks, the willful denial of reality as well as its crushing weight.

title: MISS MAYER TO BE BRIDE
description: Melissa Ann Mayer and John Ely Pflieger plan to be married in January, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Charles Mayer of Bethesda, Md., have announced. Mr. Pflieger's parents are Mr. and Mrs. John Ely Pflieger of New York.

title: MERIT SEMIFINALISTS NAMED
description: THE National Merit Scholarship Corporation has announced the semi-finalists from Nassau and Suffolk Counties for awards in 1986.

title: LIMITING THE NORTH SHORE'S GROWTH
description: SINCE the overhaul of the city zoning ordinance in 1961, rezoning has normally come in two forms: the creation of new special zoning districts, and refinements to allowable uses or densities within existing zones, with carefully tailored changes to zoning maps.

title: REAGAN TO PUSH FREE TRADE IN TALK MONDAY
description: President Reagan, in a speech Monday on trade policy, plans to propose a ''multipronged effort'' to expand United States exports and broaden the nation's power against unfair trading practices, White House officials said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption Sept. 15 with an article on antiques hunting in Bucks County misidentified one of the shops. The caption under the top photograph should have identified the shop as that of Dorothy and Abby Brooks in Lahaska Antique Courte on U.S. 202.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Sade Diamond Life CBS/Fox Video Music 30 minutes, $14.98. The Nigerian-born British pop singer Sade has a cool vibratoless wail reminiscent of the young Astrud Gilberto and photogenic good looks to complement a voice that projects an imperturbable sophistication.

title: Catholic Bishops Seek a Wider Role for Women
description: For years Roman Catholic women have tried without much success to rise to positions of authority in the church. Last weekend they got a pledge of support from a powerful source: the leadership of the American church.

title: Pitfalls in Mandating A Balanced Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: STADIUM OPPOSED
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson told a predominantly black rally of 500 people in Miami yesterday that they should be prepared to boycott the Miami Dolphins in order to stop the team's owner from building a 73,000-seat stadium in their neighborhood. Residents of northern Dade County neighborhood fear they will be subjected to huge increases in traffic and decreased property values if the stadium and adjacent commercial development is allowed to be built.

title: WHO CARES ABOUT TRADE?
description: Is protectionism really the paramount political cause of the late 1980's? A lot of politicians in Washington, Democrats and Republicans alike, think so, and they are clamoring for trade barriers. One California Congressman even attacked President Reagan for serving French wine at the White House.

title: RUNNERS LED ASTRAY BY MARATHON ESCORT
description: Mark Coleman, a social worker from Newburgh, N.Y., won the Buffalo-Niagara Falls International Marathon today in a race where more than 50 of the top finishers were led over the wrong course.

title: NATIONAL GROUP DISTRIBUTES FOOD IN NEW YORK
description: The fare in the cafeteria of St. Augustine's School on Franklin Avenue, near 163d Street in the South Bronx, was varied but substantial yesterday, as a national food-assistance program, Share, began operating in the New York area by distributing food packages to almost 3,000 families.

title: Echoes From Auckland Harbor
description: One of the top members of Francois Mitterrand's Government has gone down with the Rainbow Warrior, and so has a leading Admiral. Defense Minister Charles Hernu resigned last week after the French newspaper Le Monde published an account of the antinuclear protest ship's sinking.

title: KHAN WINS TITLE
description: Jahangir Khan of Pakistan, the world champion, won the Malaysian open squash-racquets championship tonight, defeating Kelvin Smith of Australia, 9-0, 9-0, 9-5, in the final. Khan earned $3,635, Smith $2,427.

title: MERIT SCHOLAR SEMIFINALISTS NAMED IN COUNTY
description: THE semifinalists in the National Merit Scholarship Corporation's yearly competition represent one-half of 1 percent of all high-school seniors in the country. Nationwide, they total some 15,000 students.

title: EMPHASIZING NAILS AND EYES
description: NAILS EMPHASIZE THE HANDS, AND ARE ESPECIALLY pleasing when polished and well tended. In much the same way, eyebrows emphasize the eyes, lending expression, depth and drama.

title: SUMMIT: 18 FELLOWSHIP WINNERS
description: THE Summit Art Center is the setting for an exhibition featuring works by 18 recipients of craft fellowships for the year 1984-85.

title: YORK COLLEGE
description: To the Editor:

title: MISS SIMON TO MARRY COLIN PAGE ON DEC. 29
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lee K. Simon of Wilmington, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter Barbara Jane Simon to Colin John Page, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Page of Newbury, England. The wedding is planned for Dec. 29.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: ''Teeny-Tiny and the Witch Woman, and Other Scary Stories'' Children's Circle 42 minutes. $29.95 How can you go wrong with a hero named Teeny-Tiny? This diminutive lad extricates his brothers (named ''Big One'' and ''In-the-Middle,'' of course) from the clutches of the truly horrid Witch Woman in the forest.

title: MEDICAID EXTENDER LIKELY
description: WHEN it reconvenes this week, the State Senate is expected to approve a pared-down version of the so-called ''medically needy bill.''

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error on page 38 of The Times Magazine today, the article headlined ''New Era at the Met'' misidentifies the baritone cast by the Metropolitan in ''La Traviata'' with Beverly Sills. The scheduled singer was Ingvar Wixell. William Walker appeared in the first two performances as a substitute when Mr. Wixell was ill.

title: OPERAS ARE FOR YOUNGSTERS TOO
description: Are you searching for an opera that the local kindergarten can perform? How about a chamber drama in three acts that lasts only six minutes? Or perhaps a music theater work that chronicles the adjustment problems of adolescence?

title: MARTIN, WHITSON SCUFFLE IN HOTEL BAR
description: Billy Martin, once more the Yankees' embattled manager, and Ed Whitson, one of his pitchers, became involved in a fight with each other early today, marking the second time in 26 hours that Martin had an incident in the bar at the team's hotel. Early Saturday morning, Martin had a mostly verbal encounter with a man he had been drinking with.

title: W. JAMES COUSINS JR. MARRIES MIMI CORBETTA
description: Maryann Corbetta, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis J. Corbetta of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to W. James Cousins Jr., a son of Mrs. Cousins of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Cousins. The Rev. Charles Crawford Smith performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church in New Canaan, of which the bridegroom's mother, Margaret Cousins, is the administrator.

title: Votes in Congress;   Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: KATHERINE GALLUP WED TO ERIC PENN HYMAN
description: Katherine Elizabeth Gallup and Eric Penn Hyman were married yesterday at the South United Methodist Church in Manchester, Conn., by the Rev. Dr. Shepard Johnson.

title: COUNTING THE STATE AND LOCAL LOBBYISTS
description: Nobody is quite sure how many cities, counties, public authorities, school districts, transit systems and other public bodies have lobbyists here in the capital.

title: HAWAIIANS FEAR LOSS OF THE NATIVE LANGUAGE
description: For most of the world, the word aloha sums up the spirit of the Hawaiian islands. In the Hawaiian language aloha means love, but it is used here mostly as a greeting or to say farewell. And it is spoken with such warmth that it seems doubtful the word will fade from use.

title: HOSTS' LIABILITY CURB IS URGED
description: Homeowners who serve alcohol at parties should be liable for automobile accidents caused by a guest only if the driver was well above the legal limit of intoxication, a legislative commission has proposed.

title: PATH OF THE FIRE-EYED GODDESS
description: We rose before dawn and met inside the crater, hoping to reach the top of Diamond Head by sunrise. It was an easy hike, flavored by a softly pungent odor from the keawe brush that fills the wide and ancient bowl. It takes half an hour to cross the crater floor and climb past abandoned concrete bunkers and gun emplacements to the topmost point on the rim of this world-famous landmark.

title: THOSE LILLIPUTIAN TELEVISION SETS CAN DO A KING-SIZE JOB
description: In the old-time comics, Dick Tracy had a TV set small enough to be strapped on his wrist like a watch. That, of course, was sheer fantasy. Now the video industry has caught up with the indomitable detective. Though most TV sets are not sufficiently petite to be worn on the wrist, some of the latest models fit comfortably in a coat pocket or a purse.

title: BACKPACK: NEW TRAILS
description: THE backpack has got around a good deal in the last several years. It started, of course, as a mountain-trail carryall; it moved on to become the big bookbag on campus, and then began showing up on city streets, where many young professionals use it as a less stuffy version of the attache case.

title: SCHOLAR AS SCHEHERAZADE
description: ORIENTAL TALES By Marguerite Yourcenar. Translated by Alberto Manguel in collaboration with the author. 147 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $12.95.

title: HOPE FOR THE HOOKS AND BULLET PRESS
description: A VETERAN outdoor writer once explained to me the formula for a successful hunting or fishing story: ''First you tell 'em what you're going to say, then you say it, then you tell 'em what you said.'' At the time I didn't know this was common advice in many kinds of writing, but I immediately recognized it as the form of most outdoor stories and appreciated what it said about the general state of outdoor writing.

title: U.S. Farms That Treat People Like Animals
description: To the Editor:
