title: Burger Says Delays Reduce Deterrent of Death Sentence
description: Warren E. Burger, Chief Justice of the United States, says there has been no conclusive evidence that the death penalty is a deterrent to murder because of the length of time it takes to execute a prisoner.

title: Senate Delay on Debt Disrupts Sales
description: While the Treasury waits for the Senate to approve legislation raising the Federal debt ceiling, the Government's schedule of securities auctions has been disrupted.

title: Asian Trading: Dollar Declines
description: The United States dollar fell sharply in erratic Asian trading today.

title: M. Susan Roy Marries Randall Mark Rothenberg
description: The marriage of M. Susan Roy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Grover Dean Roy of Huntsville, Ohio, and Randall Mark Rothenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin J. Rothenberg of Fair Lawn, N.J., took place yesterday at the William Pitt Colonial Inn in Chatham, N.J. Judge Sherwin D. Lester of New Jersey Superior Court performed the ceremony.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;

Traveling Trend
description: When it comes to inspiring regional interest, Permian and Lee have absolutely nothing, of course, on their big brothers at Austin. In fact, the Longhorns of the University of Texas have been made to feel so at home on the range that they almost never graze on out-of-state pastures.

title: BANKERS PLAN TO MOVE WITH CAUTION ON DOLLAR
description: Key participants in the foreign-exchange markets said that they would proceed cautiously today following the statement released yesterday by the finance ministers of the non-Communist world's five leading economic powers - the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain and France.

title: 5 YEARS OF IRAN-IRAQ WAR: TOLL MAY BE NEAR A MILLION
description: Five years of fighting between Iran and Iraq have resulted in a toll of war dead that may be approaching a million, according to intelligence estimates here.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: FEW ANSWERS IN AIDS SUIT
description: ''I've gotten a few more facts and a little more confusion,'' Carol Bouchard of Queens said the other day as she left State Supreme Court in Jamaica.

title: U.N. GUESTS' WISHES ARE HOTELS' COMMANDS
description: ''This is New York. You can do anything. You can get anything.''

title: MGM FILM DISPUTE: TALKS SEEN
description: Executives at the MGM/UA Entertainment Company and Turner Broadcasting System Inc. have requested a meeting with top executives at Rainbow Services Inc. to discuss their battle over the rights to films in the MGM film library, according to a source close to Rainbow.

title: 3 HURT IN CHINATOWN SHOOTING
description: Three teen-agers were wounded last night, one critically, by a young man with a pistol who fired four times into their car as they sat parked at 27 Henry Street in Chinatown, the police said.

title: Eagles Upset Redskins, 19-6
description: Randall Cunningham passed to Earnest Jackson for a fourth-quarter touchdown today and Paul McFadden connected on four field goals to lead the Philadelphia Eagles to a 19-6 upset of the Washington Redskins.

title: Tracy Ann Strousse Weds Andrew Hardenbergh
description: The marriage of Tracy Ann Strousse, a daughter of Marcia Dembow Strousse of Stamford, Conn., and David Strousse of Rye, N.Y., to Andrew Collis Hardenbergh took place yesterday at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center. The bridegroom is a son of Nancy Chalmers Hardenbergh and the late Collis Morgan Hardenbergh of Wayzata, Minn.

title: REPORT WARNS ON PERSONNEL AT NUCLEAR SITES
description: Thousands of people who have drug, alcohol or psychological problems are involved in handling the nation's nuclear weapons, a Stanford University professor said today.

title: Save Our Historic Houses
description: To the Editor:

title: CHINA'S ECONOMIC PLAN KEEPS TRADE DOOR OPEN
description: After a period of reassessment, China has unveiled an economic blueprint for the next five years that sticks firmly to the ''open door'' policies charted at the beginning of the decade by the country's pragmatic leader, Deng Xiaoping.

title: Sutton Tops Reid In Abilene Playoff
description: Hal Sutton rolled in a 15-foot birdie putt on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff today to beat Mike Reid for the $72,000 first-place check in the $400,000 Southwest Golf Classic.

title: ETHNIC DIVERSITY SHARED ON 3D AVE.
description: Peter Walker ate quiche, proving, he said, ''that real men do eat quiche, eventually.''

title: Road to Accident-Free Driving in America
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: BERNSTEIN LEADS MAHLER 9TH AT CARNEGIE
description: TO the extent that Leonard Bernstein is not wholly sui generis, he seems the last of a breed, an unashamed emoter in an age of music-making dominated by the cautious, sober or superficial. He is surely, as an imminent exhibition at the Museum of Broadcasting reminds us, the most-watched conductor of all time, and it was fascinating to watch him Saturday as he opened the Carnegie Hall season with the Israel Philharmonic in Mahler's Ninth Symphony.

title: OUTDOORS: STABILIZING A CANOE
description: ACTING on a remark made to me this spring by a canoe manufacturer, I have discovered a way to make canoes more suitable for fly fishing.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: When Rickey Henderson set the major league record of 130 stolen bases with Oakland, how many times was he thrown out stealing?

title: WATERLOO IV: NOW OR LATER
description: It was inevitable, from the moment George Steinbrenner dismissed Yogi Berra last spring, that this time would come. It always comes, this moment, as long as the cast is George Steinbrenner, boss, and Billy Martin, manager.

title: Turkish Export Loan
description: Yapi ve Kredi Bankasi, a Turkish bank, has signed an agreement for a $50 million pre-export financing facility.

title: SPECULATION INTENSE ON FEDERAL RESERVE VACANCIES
description: Trade, taxes and the deficit may be the headline economic issues, but there's nothing quite like an important job vacancy to ignite the capital's high-octane rumor mills.

title: S.&S. Compton Adds Renault
description: The American Motors Corporation, with two agencies -Grey Advertising and Saatchi & Saatchi Compton - for two vehicle lines - Renault and Jeep - decided to put all of its eggs in one basket. On Friday A.M.C. announced it would be S.&S. Compton, which has been working on Jeep since 1964.

title: BOTH ENGINES OF DC-9 LOST POWER BEFORE FATAL PLUNGE, OFFICIALS SAY
description: Both engines of the Midwest Express Airlines DC-9 jet that crashed in Milwaukee Sept. 6 experienced power losses, according to Government officials and a spokesman for the engine manufacturer.

title: Statement Excerpts On Economic Problems
description: Following are excerpts from the statement issued yesterday by the finance ministers and central bank governors of Britain, France, Japan. the United States and West Germany:

title: Chief of Hybritech Calls Lilly Tie Aid to Growth
description: Howard E. Greene Jr., chairman and chief executive officer of Hybritech Inc., says his medical research company's agreement last week to be acquired by Eli Lilly & Company for about $300 million is ''an opportunity to have our cake and eat it too.''

title: Debate Postponed On America's Cup
description: An international field of yachting competitors, fearful the Australians are placing the America's Cup race in jeopardy, planned today to postpone a debate about the challenger series until differences with the Australians are settled.

title: OLD HAND IN U.N. JOB: JAIME DE PINIES
description: Twenty-five years ago, during a General Assembly session dominated by the antics of Nikita S. Khrushchev, a young Spanish diplomat jumped from his seat to challenge the Russian leader.

title: Insuring for AIDS
description: The insurance industry has begun to take notice of AIDS. Some companies would like to have applicants for health or life insurance tested for AIDS antibodies, a sign of having been exposed to the virus. They threaten to exclude AIDS from coverage altogether if denied the data.

title: EX-CHAMP'S BITTER EGO
description: THE demon of his bitter ego has always been Larry Holmes's toughest opponent. Until he lost his heavyweight title to Michael Spinks in a unanimous 15-round decision Saturday night, other boxers had been relatively easy for him. He had been unbeaten in 48 bouts with 34 knockouts. But he had never quite conquered himself. He resented those who confined him to Muhammad Ali's shadow. As he approached his opportunity to equal Rocky Marciano's 49-0 record, he resented tributes to the popular champion of three decades ago. His bitter ego wouldn't permit him to win graciously. And when he finally lost, his bitter ego wouldn't permit him to accept it graciously.

title: Seats for Lions Fans
description: The setting was even more noteworthy than the score Saturday, as the Columbia Lions defeated the Harvard Crimson, 3 to 0, in their new stadium at the Baker Field complex.

title: Judge Bowman Is Wed To Revish Windham
description: Judge Janice Bowman of the New York City Civil Court in Brooklyn was married yesterday to Revish Windham, a vocational specialist with the State Division for Youth in Manhattan. The Rev. M. Moran Weston performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Terrace on the Park in Flushing, Queens.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Phoenix yesterday on Senator Barry Goldwater incorrectly described former Senator Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania. He is alive.

title: From Iranian Delegate, A Bouquet and a Message
description: The corps of journalists covering the United Nations expands dramatically as various heads of state arrive to address the Assembly. More than 200 reporters from Latin America are expected here this week to cover the appearances of the leaders of Brazil, Panama, Peru, Uruguay and Venezuela.

title: MILITARY CUTTING SPENDING PLANS FOR NEXT 5 YEARS
description: The Defense Department, in an effort to cut its long-range spending plan without reducing its nuclear weapons program, has approved sweeping cutbacks in projected spending on conventional military forces, according to Reagan Administration officials.

title: JAIL FRACAS REPORTED AFTER BURFORD ARREST ON DRINKING CHARGE
description: Anne M. Burford, former Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, scratched and insulted a guard while she and her husband, Robert, the director of the Bureau of Land Management, were in jail on drinking charges this weekend, the authorities said today.

title: U.N. AGENCY ANNOUNCES STEPS TO COORDINATE FIGHT AGAINST AIDS
description: The World Health Organization has announced a series of measures to combat acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Hillary Cole Is Married
description: Hillary Brooke Cole, a daughter of Mrs. Herbert J. Stiefel and Gordon E. Cole, both of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Richard Fitzgerald McAllister, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John McAllister of New York.

title: The Gift
description: She was selling soft drinks and hot dogs from a pushcart at Greeley Square outside Gimbel's at 33d Street, an old woman in a sweater with holes in the sleeves and a stained apron and dark, wary eyes.

title: ISRAEL OBJECTS TO BRITISH MOVE
description: Moshe Arens, the acting Israeli Foreign Minister, summoned the British Ambassador to a meeting in Jerusalem today to convey Israel's displeasure over an invitation of Palestinians to London.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TALKIES When they say there is a lot of big talk up at the 92d Street Y, they are not talking loosely or disparagingly. This is a Y that doubles as an important city cultural center, and cultural activity extends to hearing from the great, or at least prominent, minds of our times. Starting today, more than 50 speakers will give a series of lectures that will carry on into next spring.

title: REPORT ON U.S. DIET ADVISES LOWER NUTRIENT LEVELS
description: In a move with broad implications for American eating habits and food assistance programs, a committee of the National Academy of Sciences has drafted a report calling for lower recommended levels of some vitamins and minerals needed to maintain health.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;

Pre-empted Series
description: Just about the only thing bigger than the skies of western Texas is the rivalry between Midland Lee and Odessa Permian. That is what they say down in western Texas, anyway, and they sure do have a point.

title: JETS TROUNCE PACKERS WITH PRESSURING DEFENSE, 24-3
description: With barely any offense and with Freeman McNeil sputtering in the face of a gamble by the Packers, the Jets displayed resourcefulness today in halting the Green Bay Packers, 24-3.

title: BID FOR ASIA WEEK
description: Time Inc. said Friday that it had agreed to acquire The Reader's Digest Association's 80 percent interest in Asiaweek Ltd., the publisher of Asiaweek, an English news magazine based in Hong Kong.About 16 percent of the company's equity is held by Asiaweek's editor-in-chief, Michael O'Neill. Time also expects to buy the outstanding 4 percent that is held by Hong Kong interests, the company said.

title: In Dropping a Name, Better Get It Right
description: One of the biggest challenges here is keeping track of the hundreds of names and faces at the world organization. Given the variety of languages and organizations, this can lead to some confusion, as occurred one day last week at hearings on transnational corporations operating in South Africa.

title: Striking Workers Ratify Agreement at Ford Plant
description: United Auto Workers members at Ford Motor Company's Lorain Assembly Plant voted today to ratify an agreement to end their two-week strike over health, safety and production grievances.

title: RAID INTO ANGOLA REPORTED TO END
description: South African troops were said today to have withdrawn from southern Angola after a weeklong invasion depicted here as a campaign against forces of the insurgent South-West Africa People's Organization.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: F.D.R.: A Biography. By Ted Morgan. 830 pages. Illustrated. Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title: MARTIN JOKES AFTER BRAWL
description: Joking that ''I hurt my arm bowling,'' Billy Martin, the embattled manager of the Yankees, showed up at Memorial Stadium today with a broken arm following an early-morning punching, kicking, grappling brawl with Ed Whitson, one of his pitchers.

title: 'Pass the Hat' Is No Just Wage for an Artist
description: To the Editor:

title: Teachers End 13-Day Strike
description: The 600 teachers who stayed away from their classrooms for 13 days in a strike were expected to be in school Monday after ratifying a three-year agreement with their School Committee. The strike ended early Friday when negotiators for the Pawtucket Teachers Alliance and the School Committee reached the agreement, which includes a 19.5 percent pay increase over three years.

title: DeLorean Responds To U.S. Fraud Charges
description: John Z. DeLorean, who was indicted in Detroit last week on charges of defrauding investors in the failed DeLorean Motor Company, said yesterday that he was innocent.

title: WITH HOUSES IN RUBBLE, THOUSANDS ARE REFUGEES IN THEIR HOMETOWN
description: For the last four days Rosa Contreras, a 25-year-old secretary, her 60-year-old mother and about 40 neighbors have been living on a patch of grass under a jacaranda tree within sight of their destroyed apartment building.

title: Democrats See Administration Shift
description: In joining four other major trading nations in an effort to push down the value of the American dollar, the Reagan Administration was seen as openly trying to head off a rising tide of protectionist legislation in Congress.

title: U.N.'S INTERNAL CONFLICT: REALITY EDGING OUT VISION
description: In the postwar chill of the cold war, the United Nations was a place of high drama, where live debates televised from its chambers often drew better ratings than Westerns and where children were taken to see important men make peace.

title: FOTIU MAINTAINS HIS FURIOUS PACE
description: When you open the door to the ice and let Nick Fotiu out, it's like letting the wind loose. The coach, it is assumed, must have abandoned the game plan, because there can be no sense in allowing someone to skate around spinning and falling and crashing over the puck and over himself with his stick in the air.

title: 1988 CAMPAIGN SPURS WORRY FOR REPUBLICANS IN MICHIGAN
description: Presidential politics and dismal weather converged on this old resort island this weekend, and there were complaints about both at a gathering of Michigan Republicans.

title: HELPING ELDERLY AT HOME
description: ''I DON'T want a stranger in my kitchen.''

title: Zia Promises to End Pakistan Martial Law
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq has promised that eight years of martial law in Pakistan will be ended by Dec. 31 and outlawed political parties will be able to resume activity.

title: The Law on the Side of Young AIDS Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: POPE APPEALS FOR UNIVERSAL EFFORT TO EASE SUFFERING IN MEXICO
description: Pope John Paul II appealed ''to every human heart'' today to join in an international effort to aid the victims of the Mexican earthquakes. He asked that ''the God of every consolation'' grant comfort to the suffering.

title: GUIDRY EARNS 20TH FOR A THIRD TIME AS YANKS WIN, 5-4
description: With fight news apparently supplanting thoughts of a pennant in the players' minds, the Yankees went out today and won one anyway - the 20th one -for The Gator.

title: CITY OPERA: 'TRAVIATA'
description: ''LA TRAVIATA'' is a necessary foundation post for any repertory company, and the New York City Opera is lucky to have a production of Verdi's familiar favorite as handsome as the one that returned to Lincoln Center on Saturday afternoon. Lloyd Evans has remounted the sets, which mix the suggestive and the specific with good effect, and Patton Campbell's costumes give the revelers of Acts I and III a dark elegance that also conveys a sense of the ominous. Frank Corsaro is the director.

title: STAGE: AN ADAPTATION, 'CUSTOM OF THE COUNTRY'
description: WHEN a playwright adapts a perfectly fine novel like ''The Custom of the Country'' to the stage, there should be some compelling reason for doing so. Otherwise, why not just let the original work stand on its own? Jane Stanton Hitchcock, the author of a new theatrical version of Edith Wharton's 1913 book, has failed to provide that reason. In her play at the McGinn/Cazale Theater, Mrs. Hitchcock cleverly demonstrates that it is possible to compress the important plot points, principal themes and major characters of a lengthy novel into less than two hours of stage time. But, given that most of the flesh and drama of the Wharton original are missing, the achievement seems somewhat more pointless (and less fun) than building a replica of the Eiffel Tower out of toothpicks.

title: Sudan Bans Protests After Street Clashes
description: The Sudanese Government banned street demonstrations today after 2 people were killed and 45 were wounded in fighting Saturday.

title: TV Spots Start Tonight For Commodore Amiga
description: A spare, gray-haired man in a gray jumpsuit is seen walking purposefully up and down a series of shadowy staircases and then emerging in what can best be described as a temple-like hall, at once ancient and modern. At the end of it is a platform that can best be described as an altar. Something tabernacle-like glows from its center. As he nears, we see the object is a personal computer. A simple press of the button and he is bathed in its glow. He smiles, eyes closed as he soaks up the artificial light. Then, as our TV screen is filled with the computer screen on which appears a wide-eyed fetus, the voiceover delivers practically its only line in the 60-second commercial: ''Re-experience the mind unbounded.''

title: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 23, 1985
description: The Economy

title: AXEL SPRINGER, GERMAN PUBLISHER, IS DEAD AT 73
description: Axel Springer, the builder of West Germany's largest publishing empire and a prominent conservative voice for three decades, died last night in West Berlin. He was 73 years old.

title: PANEL CHIEF CITES AIDS COSTS
description: The chairman of Governor Cuomo's AIDS Research Council said yesterday that the spread of the disease has placed new strains on health-care facilities around the state.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Sept. 23, 1985: *2*MONDAY American Express SCM Corporation Esterline Corp Sterchi Bros Stores Primark Corp *2*TUESDAY Borg-Warner Penney (JC) Co Cleveland Elec Illum Public Service Co Delmarva Pwr & Lt Saul (BF) RI Est Inv Tr Montana Power Co Toledo Edison Northern Ind Pub Serv USAir Group *2*WEDNESDAY EG & G Inc Ocean Drill & Explor Hunt Mfg Co Raytheon Co Iowa Resources Washington DC Gas Lt Medtronic Inc *2*THURSDAY Acme-Cleveland Corp Research-Cottrell Boston Edison Roper Corporation Campbell Soup (US) Webb (Del E) Corp C'monwealth Energy Wyle Labs *2*FRIDAY CP National Pacific Telesis Group Central Hudson G&E Piedmont Aviation Curtice-Burns Inc Potlatch Corp Federated Dept Stores Ralston Purina Harper & Row Rexham Corp Homestake Mining Southwestern Bell Corp Lowe's Companies Viacom International

title: NEW ZEALAND ASKS FOR AGENTS' NAME
description: Prime Minister David Lange condemned France today for having ordered its agents to sabotage the Greenpeace protest ship Rainbow Warrior in Auckland Harbor.

title: UGANDAN GUERRILLAS CAPTURE NILE BRIDGE, AND THEN GIVE IT UP
description: Ugandan Government troops today retook a strategic Nile River bridge that rebel forces had seized earlier in the day, according to travelers arriving in the capital.

title: SWISS GRANT WOMEN EQUAL MARRIAGE RIGHTS
description: Swiss voters today narrowly approved a Government-sponsored law that gives women equal rights in marriage, eliminating the last national legal bastion of male supremacy.

title: THRIFT UNIT INSURANCE PLAN SEEN
description: To the relief of many leaders of the savings and loan industry, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board is expected to decide within the next 10 days to form a new institution that would relieve its beleaguered deposit insurance unit of some $3 billion in troubled assets.

title: CONCERT: A DAYLONG MIX OF COUNTRY WITH ROCK
description: A cause can do wonders for a concert -particularly a cause that's close to home. Farm Aid, the all-day benefit concert at the University of Illinois Memorial Stadium, began shortly before 10 A.M. today with a song dedicated to farmers by Willie Nelson and Neil Young, about ''families trying hard to stay together and make a stand.'' It was the first of many. In a show scheduled to run long past midnight, virtually every performer -more than 50 were on the bill, plus unannounced guests - made an effort to hand-pick songs for the occasion. The crowd's response, despite a rainy opening half, made passable songs good, and good songs magnificent.

title: Midland Bank Shift Is Set
description: The Bank of England's deputy governor, Christopher McMahon, is expected to take over as chairman of Midland Bank P.L.C., Midland's current chairman, Donald Barron, said today.

title: London Awaits Hedging Surge
description: AS the clouds of uncertainty thicken over much of the world's financial and currency markets, London's futures and options markets, which are situated in one of the biggest money centers, are still waiting for a flood of hedging business to engulf them.

title: Stockman Snaps Shut
description: When he was President Reagan's budget director, David A. Stockman was famous for his volubility, confessing the uncertainty of his fiscal estimates to an interviewer and suggesting the idea of Federal tax increases, which were repugnant to the President, in a speech that was certain to get into print.

title: U.S. AND 4 ALLIES PLAN MOVE TO CUT VALUE OF DOLLAR
description: Finding the high value of the dollar unwarranted, the top economic officials of the United States and four other major industrial countries said yesterday that they were prepared to work in concert to drive the dollar down.

title: William Frucht, an Editor, Is Wed to Candace Ovesey
description: Candace Beth Ovesey, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lionel Ovesey of New York, and William Frucht, the son of Dr. and Mrs. David Frucht of Huntington, L.I., were married yesterday.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Lock 'Em Up! (All 1 Percent)
description: As of June 30, America's prisons held 490,041 inmates, a criminal nation whose population exceeds that of St. Louis and equals Seattle's or Denver's. It was 26,183 higher than on Dec. 30, and the increase nearly matched the 26,610 added in all of last year.

title: FASSBINDER PLAY DRAWS ANTI-SEMITISM CHARGES
description: For almost a decade, a play by Rainer Werner Fassbinder, ''Garbage, the City and Death'' has haunted - but not appeared on - the Frankfurt stage. Written in the mid-70's after street protests about the high-rise development of the city's residential West End district, the play was denounced as anti-Semitic, and was shelved.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Phillies, at Philadelphia, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 7:35 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Football Seahawks vs. Los Angeles Rams, at Seattle. Last week the Heisman Trophy winner Charles White -filling in for a still unprepared Eric Dickerson, who reported late for camp following a contract holdout -had his first 100-yard rushing game in five years. He led the Rams to a 17-6 triumph over the Eagles that kept Los Angeles in first place in the N.F.C. West. Countering 440 yards passing and four touchdown passes by Dan Fouts of San Diego, Dave Krieg rallied Seattle from a 23-14 halftime deficit to a 49-35 victory over the Chargers, throwing for 307 yards and equaling his club record of five touchdown passes, four of them to Daryl Turner. Curt Warner also contributed 169 yards rushing to keep Seattle atop the A.F.C. West standing. The Seahawks are 5-1 on Monday nights, while the Rams are 12-11 on Mondays and 4-5 on other ABC prime-time games. (Television - Channel 7, 9 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660; 9 P.M.) Hockey Devils' rookies vs. Rangers' rookies, National Hockey League exhibition game, at Ice World, Union Avenue and Route 46, Totowa, N.J., 7:30 P.M. The Devils' first-year players have a tradition to maintain: They are unbeaten in 13 straight rookie games, including their first this year, an 8-4 victory over the Flyers' rookies last Thursday in Totowa. Other Events GOLF AND TENNIS: First Publishers Invitational benefit for Reading Is Fundamental Incorporated, at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club, Scarborough-on-Hudson, N.Y., 10 A.M. There are 144 golfers and 64 tennis players.

title: SPINKS IS GIDDY WITH SUCCESS
description: FACING reality could have been as numbing as the sting of a crisp left jab, the kind Larry Holmes boasted would land like a hammer on Michael Spinks's jaw. Instead, Spinks awoke on the first day of his reign as the International Boxing Federation heavyweight champion in a more euphoric daze, still unable to appreciate the impact of what he had accomplished.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Bank Note Co., the 190-year-old security printing company, has appointed Calvin W. Aurand Jr. president, replacing Salvatore F. D'Amato, who becomes deputy chairman.

title: The Mask Slips
description: It was bound to happen. Last week the White House held a background briefing on Africa for reporters, under the proviso that the authority answering questions was to be identified only as ''a senior Administration official.''

title: THE DANCE: MONTREAL FESTIVAL
description: Muteki Sha, the Butoh dance company from Japan that performed in Montreal Saturday night and that will appear in New York on Saturday and Sunday at the Asia Society, is one of the highly diverse entries in the first ''Festival International de Nouvelle Danse'' currently in progress here.

title: BRITAIN AND NORWAY OUT OF OIL SPOTLIGHT
description: Once a major focus of attention when the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries price levels and production quotas were under pressure, Britain and Norway now find themselves happily on the sidelines as OPEC members prepare to deal with Saudi Arabia's threat to raise production and undermine world oil prices.

title: Gemayel Urges End To Lebanon Strife
description: President Amin Gemayel urged all Lebanese today to set aside their differences and join hands in ending the country's 10-year-old national strife.

title: Time Capsule Allows Boston To Peek 100 Years Into Past
description: Mayor Raymond Flynn on Sunday pried open a corroded copper box placed in a cornerstone in 1884, and found a vial of ancient Egyptian oil, a black change purse and yellowed newspapers.

title: Democratic Committee Picks Clark for Council
description: Hilton B. Clark has been designated the Democratic nominee in the Nov. 5 election for the Harlem seat on the City Council left vacant by the death of Councilman Frederick E. Samuel.

title: Montana Leads 49ers Past Raiders, 34-10
description: Joe Montana threw two touchdown passes and the linebacker Milt McColl ran 28 yards with a fumble recovery for another today as the San Francisco 49ers stopped the Los Angeles Raiders, 34-10, before a crowd of 87,006 at the Los Angeles Coliseum.

title: A VOICE FOR CONTROL OF THE POPULATION EXPLOSION
description: At first glance, Avabai B. Wadia does not strike those around her as a person in the vortex of one of the world's most divisive issues - population control. Refined, small in stature and ever so slightly stooped as she begins her 73d year, she does not look like an advocate of any sort. Indeed, when she attended an awards ceremony at the United Nations, she sat on the dais, a lone woman dwarfed by the gray-suited men on either side.

title: New Twists for Conrail Offer
description: Executives of the Norfolk Southern Corporation are busy assessing the damage to their bid for the Government-controlled Consolidated Rail Corporation from last week's surprise announcement by the Chicago and North Western Railroad. The Chicago line said that it was breaking off talks with Norfolk Southern on concessions the big carrier could make to end the Chicago line's opposition to a Norfolk Southern-Conrail merger.

title: Accord at Maine Shipbuilder
description: The smaller of two striking union locals voted overwhelmingly today to end its 22-week walkout at Bath Iron Works, but the shipbuilder threatened to consider ''other options'' if no settlement is reached soon with the larger bargaining unit.

title: INDIA'S FLOURISHING COURIERS
description: Along the streets of one of this city's crowded business districts, where people, handcarts, cars and trucks scramble for space, India's most efficient courier services are flourishing in a trade they have practiced for more than a century.

title: IN CATSKILLS, AN INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT AIRLINES DON'T USE
description: With great pomp and ceremony, an international airport opened 16 years ago in this tiny rural community in the Catskills 100 miles north of New York City.

title: DOUGLAS IN TV FILM
description: In the new CBS-TV movie ''Amos,'' which will be shown at 9 P.M. on Sept. 29, Kirk Douglas plays a feisty former baseball coach consigned to a nursing home after an automobile accident. While there he makes friends with several of the other patients, played by Dorothy McGuire, Noriyuki (Pat) Morita and Ray Walston, but he battles with the tyrannical head nurse, played by Elizabeth Montgomery. As the CBS press release describes the plot, she is ''in constant conflict with her rebellious and strong-willed patient. Amos's resentment at being placed in a nursing home is futile as his life becomes rigidly regulated by Nurse Daws.''

title: ANGELS WIN AND LEAD BY 1
description: Julio Franco's error on a grounder by Rod Carew enabled Rufino Linares to score from second base with one out in the 12th inning today, giving the California Angels a 10-9 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

title: THE MET TUNES UP FOR NEW SEASON
description: A few minutes after 7:30 tonight, Carlo Felice Cillario will summon three rasping, portentous chords from the Metropolitan Opera orchestra, and the fabled golden curtain will begin its first public ascent of the year. It's opening night at the Met and, to inaugurate this 102d season, Luciano Pavarotti, Montserrat Caballe and Cornell MacNeil will join forces for what promises to be a memorable performance of Puccini's ''Tosca.''

title: FOR TUNISIANS IN LIBYA, AN ABRUPT HOMECOMING
description: The billboard on the far side of the Tunisian-Libyan border here said ''Welcome to You'' in Arabic and showed Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in white robes with his arms outstretched.

title: KOCH ASSAILS HIM AS ANTI-SEMITE
description: The Rev. Louis Farrakhan, the Black Muslim whose attacks on Judaism have been rebuked by Jewish leaders and others, plans to discuss black economic and political power at a rally at Madison Square Garden on Oct. 7, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: TRANSIT AGENCY CITED FOR NEGLECT OF USED AUTOS
description: Used automobiles, some worth $3,000 or more, were left by the Transit Authority to rust in train yards for up to nine years - and then sold as scrap for $10 apiece, according to a city audit.

title: 64 NEWCOMERS JOIN CHINA'S LEADERSHIP
description: The Communist Party took a second major step toward rejuvenating its leadership today when it named 64 newcomers, mainly middle-aged, to its Central Committee, replacing the same number of officials who retired last week.

title: WOHL HOPING TO BRING STABILITY TO NETS
description: Dave Wohl's small office in the Byrne Meadowlands Arena reflected his hectic preparations for the opening of the Nets' training camp Friday at Princeton University. Sheets of play diagrams, defensive alignments and scouting reports were everywhere. Atop a file cabinet sat a television set, a videotape recorder and piles of tapes of last season's games.

title: Firing the Hiring Scorekeeper
description: For 20 years, the Federal Government has used its own business to promote the nation's business. Companies that want contracts must agree to affirmative-action requirements that open job opportunities to women and minorities. This progressive program works, yet for some reason it displeases the Reagan Administration.

title: Sheila Franklin Wed to Thomas Lieber
description: Sheila Williams Franklin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Franklin of New York and Oyster Bay, L.I., was married yesterday to Thomas Kent Lieber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Lieber of Pittsburgh. Algernon D. Black, leader emeritus of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, performed the ceremony at the Franklin home in Oyster Bay.

title: 150 Turks Arrested At Folk Singer's Funeral
description: About 150 people were arrested today when the funeral of a popular leftist folk singer turned into a demonstration, witnesses said.

title: A NOVICE POET TAKES IN 'THE POMP -- THE COURT -- THE ETIQUETTE' OF 1855
description: Emily Dickinson, the nation's reclusive master poet who chose to live outside history and shun distractions of the loud and the self-important, made one of her rare journeys beyond Amherst, Mass., to Washington, of all places.

title: SATISFACTIONS OF THE DIPLOMATIC DEAN
description: When the welcoming committee gathers to greet visiting foreign leaders on the South Lawn of the White House, the dean of diplomats is the one standing next to the President. When the more than 140 chiefs of foreign missions who are stationed in Washington file onto the House floor to hear the President's State of the Union address, he's at the front of the line.

title: Indian Airlines Selects Airbus
description: Indian Airlines has issued a letter of intent to purchase 19 Airbus A320 aircraft worth $1.2 billion, senior civil aviation ministry sources said Saturday.

title: SPORTS NEWs BRIEFS;   World Cup On Despite Quakes
description: The Organizing Committee of the 1986 World Cup said today that the 1986 World Soccer Cup will go on as planned in spite of the devastating earthquakes here. ''The committee categorically denies any reports that the World Cup will be postponed,'' the committee said. On Saturday, committee officials visited the two main stadiums in Mexico City and, with the aid of architects and engineers, determined that the structures were intact.

title: RELIEF AGENCIES AWAIT ADVICE ON USE OF DONATIONS
description: Major relief organizations in the United States began raising money this weekend for the victims of Mexico's earthquakes, while awaiting reports from teams of experts in Mexico on how best to spend the donations.

title: Wait-and-See Time for Rates
description: The credit markets appear to be waiting for some new developments to push interest rates above or below the range that has prevailed since mid-May.

title: HEATING OIL OUTLOOK CALLED STABLE
description: Despite the fact that inventories of heating oil are currently at their lowest level in years, most oil experts expect supplies to be more than adequate during the winter season. This means, they said, that consumers should face at most only slight increases in retail prices from last winter's moderate levels.

title: Tests Start On New Magazine
description: TIME INC. goes into supermarkets in 13 markets today to begin the 17-week test of its latest magazine entry, Picture Week.

title: People
description: David Cantor, James Lawson and Raymond Groff were appointed senior vice presidents of Needham Harper Worldwide.

title: Takeover Talk In Natural Gas
description: TAKEOVERS - real and rumored - in natural gas pipeline companies have tantalized the investment community since early spring. But now, it seems, more than a rumor is needed to move a stock in this group.

title: TROOPS GUARD GANDHI IN PUNJAB DRIVE
description: Despite continuing threats to his safety, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi has been traveling through Punjab State exhorting Sikhs and Hindus to vote for the governing Congress Party and end three years of turmoil.

title: TIGHT SECURITY TO MARK 40TH U.N. ANNIVERSARY
description: The 40th meeting of the United Nations General Assembly will require more than half the Secret Service agents in the nation, about 10 percent of New York City's police force, Coast Guard patrols on the East River and a new computer system to coordinate an unparalleled mobilization of city, Federal and international security agencies.

title: Catholics Hold a Faith Rally
description: Nearly 13,000 Roman Catholics, some from as far away as Ohio, shouted praise and raised their voices in song in a faith renewal rally Saturday at the Boston Garden. The rally was organized to rekindle the faith of ''Sunday morning Catholics,'' an organizer said. The Rev. John Bertolucci was one of several Catholic evangelists who gave rousing speeches about the Bible, prayer, penance and the need to share Christian lessons with others.

title: Protocol for All And at All Hours
description: The man with one of the most delicate tasks for the next month is Aly I. Teymour, the United Nations chief of protocol. Part of his job is to greet all of the heads of state and government when they arrive at the airport, no matter the hour.

title: Wheat Proposal Draws Fire
description: With the farm bill due to expire this month, the agribusiness lobby is working overtime on the terms of a new measure. Among the flood of ideas to aid farmers is a proposed amendment by Representative Berkeley Bedell, Democrat of Iowa, that is being protested by bakers, poultry and livestock interests and the Agriculture Department.

title: Dialogue#2
description: Art imitates life, but not usually with such a short lead time.

title: Catching Up
description: Dwayne McClain, whose game-high 17 points led Villanova to its national championship victory over Georgetown last spring, did not do anything nearly so impressive over the summer. That, at least, is the view of Coach George Irvine, whose Indiana Pacers made the 6-foot-6-inch guard a second-round draft choice three months ago.

title: ANOTHER LONG DAY FOR GREEN
description: When Roy Green catches one pass in 60 minutes of football, as he did today in the Giants' 27-17 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals, it's hard to imagine him having a worse afternoon. In fact, he has. The last time the Giants and Cardinals played here, in the 12th game of last season, Green had no catches.

title: Linda de Groot Weds John Calotta on Coast
description: At the Queen of the Snows Roman Catholic Church in Squaw Valley, Calif., yesterday Linda Ann de Groot, an interior designer with Peter F. Carlson Inc. in New York, was married to John Gregory Calotta, an associate in the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling. The Rev. James J. Mulligan performed the ceremony.

title: Keeping Cool About AIDS
description: I do research on the virus that causes AIDS, acquired immune deficiency syndrome. I check levels of antibodies in blood samples. I study cultures of the virus and test new drugs that might kill it. I began working with AIDS blood samples long before the disease was recognized as common enough to deserve a name and before its cause was identified as viral. I've studied blood, semen and tissue samples for four years. Like other scientists in this field, I've also suffered many small indignities.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REPORT COMPILED BY 2 PROFESSORS ON SETTING CITY PRIORITIES
description: Following are excerpts from the introduction to ''Setting Municipal Priorities, 1986,'' edited by Charles Brecher and Raymond D. Horton. The introduction summarizes the findings of a number of contributors, including Mr. Brecher and Mr. Horton.

title: THE RAINBOW WARRIOR TRIAL: FROM AUCKLAND TO PARIS
description: July 10 - Two explosions sink a 160-foot ship, the Rainbow Warrior, belonging to the environmentalist group Greenpeace, in Auckland, New Zealand. A Portuguese-born photographer, a naturalized Dutch citizen, is killed. July 11 - New Zealand policemen determine that the sinking was caused by two bombs placed on the ship's hull. July 12 - New Zealand policemen begin looking for a Frenchman who was seen by the crew near the Rainbow Warrior before the explosions, and arrest a French-speaking man and woman with false passports who say they are Swiss citizens. July 24 - The man and woman, identified as 33-year-old Alain Turenge and 36-year-old Sophie Turenge, are charged with murder, arson and conspiracy to commit arson. A statement from the French Embassy in Wellington condemns the bombing and says Paris was ''in no way involved.'' July 26 - The New Zealand police issue warrants for three crew members of French-registered yacht, the Ouvea, believed to be somewhere in the Pacific. It was chartered in the French Pacific island territory of New Caledonia and was seen leaving Auckland the day before the Rainbow Warrior was sunk. Aug. 8 - Prime Minister Laurent Fabius announces that France has begun an official inquiry into the sinking of the Rainbow Warrior.

title: Losers in a 'No-Losers' Tax Reform Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: John B. Wallace, Investigator In the Lindbergh Kidnapping
description: John B. Wallace, the New Jersey state police captain who helped arrest the man convicted of kidnapping and murdering Charles A. Lindbergh's son, died Wednesday at the Kimball Medical Center in Lakewood, N.J., after suffering a stroke July 30. He was 84 years old and lived in Lakewood.

title: Drought Cookery
description: Take one drought, ask your colleagues how they cope with it and publish the results. Yield: an eight-page collection titled ''The Waterless Cookbook.''

title: Sharon Sadow, a Lawyer, Married to Andrew Alper
description: Sharon Sadow, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph George Sadow of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Andrew Michael Alper, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Milton Alper of Chevy Chase, Md. Rabbi Balfour Brickner performed the ceremony at the Mamaroneck (N.Y.) Beach and Yacht Club.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It was agents of the D.G.S.E. that sank the boat. They acted under orders.''

title: CRITICISM FOR COLUMBIA COACH
description: The day after his first loss as the football coach at Columbia University, Jim Garrett yesterday defended and expanded upon his postgame comments in which he compared the attitude formed by Columbia's recent losing tradition with an addict's submission to a drug habit.

title: RUBBLE SIFTED IN MEXICO, BUT HOPES ARRE WANING
description: Feverish rescue efforts continued in stricken neighborhoods of Mexico City today, but hope for survivors of two devastating earthquakes last week appeared to be waning. Many mourning families turned to the task of burying their dead.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Earnhardt Wins, Holds Off Waltrip
description: Dale Earnhardt held off a charging Darrell Waltrip during a five-lap dash to the checkered flag today and won the Goody's 500 Nascar Grand National stock car race.

title: Bridge: Some Major Tournaments To Start New Season Soon
description: For most purposes the tournament bridge year does not correspond to the calendar. All the events that from first card to last card extend over seven months or more begin in the second half of the year.

title: United Nations Calendar
description: 40th GENERAL ASSEMBLY -The 15-day general debate of the 40th annual General Assembly opens today and will feature 12 speakers. President Jose Sarney of Brazil and President Alan Garcia Perez of Peru will lead off the morning and afternoon sessions, respectively, with speeches expected to focus on the Latin American debt crisis and regional stability.

title: MARKETING HARVARD'S REVIEW
description: After decades of telling business people how they should handle their marketing problems, Theodore Levitt, the new editor of the Harvard Business Review, has one of his own to worry about: the Lee Toblers of the world.

title: Dallas Paper Reports Graft at Salvation Army
description: Merchandise earmarked for the needy has been systematically siphoned from a Salvation Army thrift store operation and sold for profit or transferred to associates of a key executive of the charity, The Dallas Morning News reported today.

title: Hurricane Threatens Islands in Caribbean Sea
description: A tropical storm named Gloria grew into a hurricane today and aimed its 75-mile-an-hour winds toward the Leeward Islands, with forecasters predicting it would draw even more strength from the warm Caribbean Sea.

title: ONCE AGAIN, 5tH AVE. IS BOOK COUNTRY
description: In the grand ballroom of the Plaza Hotel yesterday, Jean Auel, author of ''The Clan of the Cave Bear,'' reminded a sold-out audience at a literary brunch that, ''Today is the fall equinox, the day the sun crosses the equator. Today, everywhere in the world, day and night will be of equal length.''

title: Ulster Rebels Kill Soldier
description: Two Irish nationalist guerrillas shot and killed an 18-year-old British soldier who was walking two young women home from a dance early today. In a telephone call to local radio stations, the outlawed Irish Republican Army took responsibility for the killing of Pvt. Martin Patten in the city of Londonderry. Another soldier with Private Patten was not attacked.

title: BEARISH VIEW OF TRADE BILL
description: ONE of the coalitions opposing the textile quota bill on the ground that it would result in higher prices for clothing and other goods made with imported textiles plans to blanket Capitol Hill today with a sample of what it contends will be ''Christmas agony.''

title: For Whom Does Jaruzelski Speak?
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski will arrive in New York tomorrow, primarily to attend the United Nations General Assembly. The Reagan Administration has refused to see him, asking in effect just whom he represents. In this, the Administration is quite right, for the General can hardly claim to speak for the Polish people.

title: FRANCE CONCEDES ITS AGENTS SANK GREENPEACE BOAT
description: The French Government admitted tonight that agents of its intelligence service sank an antinuclear protest ship in New Zealand.

title: CELEBRITY FAMILIES: PROBLEMS OF SUCCESS
description: Although Jack Brown loved to wear his father's Pro Bowl jacket with its bright piping and big white letters, he had achieved only minor success in sports himself. Certainly he had nothing like the attainments of his father, a former National Football League star who had enhanced his fame by promoting light beer.

title: MUSICIANS GIVE CONCERT TO AID NATION'S FARMERS
description: Despite occasional downpours, Willie Nelson, Bob Dylan, Neil Young and 50 other leading rock and country musicians came together today to help the nation's farmers in a concert that was both a musical and political event.

title: STUDY BY SCHOLARS CALLS FOR IMPROVED CITY SERVICES AND MORE AID FOR POOR
description: With economic recovery now a reality in New York, the city should concentrate on further improving services and finding ways to help the poor share in the wealth and comfort that smiles on others, according to a report compiled by two professors.

title: Finance Minister Quits
description: Colombian Finance Minister Roberto Junguito has resigned and has been replaced by central bank governor Hugo Palacios, President Belisario Betancur said tonight. Mr. Junguito, who during his term helped negotiate a $1 billion loan from foreign banks, will become ambassador in Paris.

title: METS FALL THREE BACK
description: The Mets lost another game yesterday, and now they are losing time. They approach the final two weeks of the regular season knowing their last scheduled road trip will likely determine whether they win a division title or drift hopelessly out of a race.

title: NEW ANSA PROGRAM STIRS HIGH HOPES
description: In the midst of a year in which most personal computer software companies have pursued merger partners more intensely than new products, a new company called Ansa Software will introduce an unsual program this week that has already attracted much attention from analysts.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: An article in the sports section yesterday on Columbia University's 49-17 loss to Harvard in football reported that the Columbia coach, Jim Garrett, referred to his players as ''drug-addicted losers.''

title: THE EMMYS
description: ''Cagney and Lacey'' was named the best television drama series of the 1984-85 season tonight at the 37th annual Emmys presentation. Tyne Daly, the series co-star with Sharon Gless, was named best dramatic actress in a series.

title: LONGER DAYS AT THE BIG BOARD
description: Chester Pado can sleep late this week. But it will be the last week that the Los Angeles stockbroker can stay in bed until the ripe hour of 5 A.M. Starting next Monday, he and thousands of others nationwide will be rising even earlier to accommodate the New York Stock Exchange's decision to squeeze an extra 30 minutes of trading into the front part of the day.

title: Competition Post Cuts Navy's Costs
description: Rear Adm. Stuart F. Platt, competition advocate for the Navy, says he leaves work every day with a clear conscience.

title: MICHIGAN PROVES PROPHETS WRONG
description: Michigan was the forgotten power of the past during this year's preseason predictions, which were made in the heat of August and already are being regretted as fall begins. After all, Illinois, Iowa and Ohio State were the highly regarded Big Ten teams, and there was a feeling that the Wolverines, coming off their worst season under Coach Bo Schembechler (6-6), had lost too much on defense to be taken seriously. The result is that Schembechler may laugh at the experts' expense when this season is over.

title: Slow Pace of Summer Yields to Quicker Steps
description: The normally languid pace at the United Nations quickens appreciably this time of year.

title: Ruling on Rudeness
description: John McEnroe's conduct on the tennis court may be rude, ill-tempered and ungentlemanly, but it does not give a spectator who witnessed - and apparently provoked - some of those shenanigans the right to sue him, a Nassau County judge ruled recently.

title: Weekly on Military to Debut
description: Military policy and purchasing issues are expected to get even closer scrutiny with the debut this week of Defense News, a weekly newspaper being published by the Times Journal Company of Springfield, Va.

title: GROUPS TAKING AID DONATIONS
description: Following are some of the agencies accepting donations for disaster relief in Mexico: American Friends Service Committee, 1501 Cherry Street, Philadelphia, Pa. 19102. Contact: Paul Brink, (215) 241-7000.

title: EAST ASIA'S VAUNTED GROWTH SLOWING
description: For the vaunted ''miracle'' economies of East Asia -Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, Singapore and Hong Kong - the days of extraordinary growth appear to be coming to an end. The main reason for the slowdown and widespread anxiety in the region is its intimate link with the United States, which first fueled its rise and now threatens its future.

title: Next Stop, Hornell, N.Y.
description: This train was so far uptown, it was upstate.

title: REPUBLICAN NOMINEE CHARGES HARASSMENT BY A KOCH AIDE
description: Diane McGrath, the Republican candidate for Mayor of New York City, charged yesterday that a member of Mayor Koch's staff had ''threatened, harassed and intimidated'' her during a parade Saturday.

title: Muskie Papers at Home
description: The papers accumulated by Edmund S. Muskie in a lifetime of public service are being presented to his alma mater, Bates College in Lewiston, Me. Ceremonies dedicating a facility to house them will be held there on Saturday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 23, 1985
description: International

title: GIANTS OUTMUSCLE CARDINALS, 27-17
description: For days, the game had been touted as an intricate chess match: the Giants' muscle against the St. Louis Cardinals' awesome offensive arsenal.

title: LADY'S SECRET, $2.60, CAPTURES RUFFIAN
description: Two weeks ago, it looked as if two of the biggest cinches in racing were that Spend a Buck would be the champion 3-year-old colt and Mom's Command the champion 3-year-old filly. Now, both are shaky propositions. Chief's Crown beat older horses in the Marlboro Cup Sept. 14 to rise to the leadership of the 3-year-old colts. Yesterday, Lady's Secret beat older fillies for the second straight time, winning the $169,800 Ruffian Handicap at Belmont Park by four lengths in an outstanding performance that has made her a serious contender for her division's title.

title: NEW HOUSING IS HAVEN IN RIVERDALE
description: Many sat in folding chairs on the well-trimmed lawn. Some were in wheelchairs. And they spoke gratefully of their new homes in the Frances Schervier Apartments - homes they said had given them new hope, new friends and an escape from the leaky pipes, rickety floors and unsafe halls they left behind.

title: GLEASON AND CARNEY IN 'IZZY AND MOE'
description: ON a recent flight from Milan to New York, the movie-cum-headsets offered a curtain-raiser: a black-and-white episode of ''The Honeymooners'' from the 1950's. It seems Jackie Gleason and Art Carney, doing their Ralph Kramden and Ed Norton routines, have become comedy classics, and in less time than it took Charlie Chaplin and Buster Keaton for their romps in the silents.

title: South Africa Says No
description: After a period of seeming indecision, the South African Government has given its answer to demands for political change. The answer is to intensify repression at home and military aggression abroad.

title: PARIS SPIES: SHADY PAST OF AGENCY
description: The Greenpeace scandal is only the latest of many that have shaken the French secret service since the end of World War II, embarrassing governments and leading to mass ousters of personnel and other attempts to tighten political control over the agency.

title: KASPAROV'S ATTACKS REBUFFED IN TITLE CHESS DRAW
description: Gary Kasparov made strenuous efforts to attack in the seventh game of his world title chess match, but the champion, Anatoly Karpov, turned them back to reach a draw Saturday in Moscow's Tchaikovsky Concert Hall.

title: AFGHAN DRIVE CALLED A FAILURE
description: Afghan rebels said today that one of the fiercest Soviet offensives in the six-year Afghan conflict had failed to cut guerrilla supply routes from Pakistan.

title: BELLOW AND WELTY READ TO AUDIENCE AT OPENING OF PEN CELEBRATIONS
description: The Broadway opening of the PEN Celebrations, eight Sunday nights this fall featuring 16 noted writers reading from their work, got off on a high note with appearances at the Booth Theater by Saul Bellow and Eudora Welty, two of the most esteemed figures in the nation's literature.

title: 2 DIE IN ALABAMA PLANE COLLISION
description: A corporate jet and an ultralight one-person plane collided today, killing two people and injuring five.

title: Karin Rose Kahn Weds J. A. Lebed
description: Karin Rose Kahn, a daughter of Dr. Gloria Batkin Kahn and Robert Kahn of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Jay Aaron Lebed, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hartzel Z. Lebed of Bloomfield, Conn., and Philadelphia, were married yesterday. Cantor Robert Toren performed the ceremony at the Tappan Hill Restaurant in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Joseph E. Hobel Wed To Marjorie H. Cohen
description: Marjorie H. Cohen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Cohen of Haworth, N.J., and Joseph E. Hobel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip S. Hobel of New York and East Hampton, L.I., were married yesterday. Rabbi Frederick Pomerantz performed the ceremony at the Hobel home in New York.

title: Politics and Smoke
description: A shift of only four seats in next year's elections would give Democrats control of the Senate again, making President Reagan a considerably lamer duck in the last two years of his term. It's not surprising, therefore, that knives already are being sharpened, curve balls are being thrown, and the public interest is taking a licking.

title: TRIAL BEGINS IN CONSPIRACY ON CASINOP PROFITS
description: Nine people accused of diverting nearly $2 million from Las Vegas casino profits are to go on trial Monday, two years after they were indicted, in a case that the Government says reflects ties between organized crime and teamsters' union officials in the late 1970's.

title: U.S. ASSAILED FOR CONTROLS ON HIGH-TECH EXPORTS
description: The export controls that the United States has imposed on high-technology items are seen as less burdensome now than they were a few years ago, but many of the regulations are still viewed as pointless by executives and economic experts in East-West trade.

title: MERCENARY MAGAZINE WIDENS APPEAL
description: Ten years ago, a men's adventure magazine rejected Robert K. Brown's proposal to write a piece about a mercenary in the Rhodesian Army.

title: Cat's Gratitude
description: The earliest known collection of English colloquial sayings, John Heywood's Proverbes of 1546, announced that ''a cat may looke on a king.'' So there seems to be ample precedent for the Capitol Hill ceremony tomorrow in which Rimfire, a 3-year-old cat from Cheverly, Md., will look gratefully at Representative Mario Biaggi of the Bronx while the New Yorker receives a cross-stitched wall hanging from Evelyn Jones to recognize his sponsorship of a law to permit pets in Federally financed housing for the aged. Mrs. Jones is president of Potomac Area Cat Enthusiasts, stitcher of the sampler and owner of Rimfire.

title: A STUDY OF COCAINE ON THE JOB
description: THE afflictions of mankind are the issues on which nonfiction television - and all news organizations, for that matter - often do their best work. Sometimes the spreading of the word about a problem temporarily displaces others in the rush for public attention that will bring funds and governmental energies to bear on a solution.

title: Massachusetts Rejects Homosexual Rights Bill
description: The Massachusetts House of Representatives rejected a homosexual rights bill today after three and a half hours of debate over civil rights, concern about AIDS and the endorsement of a homosexual style of life.

title: IVY SET TO FACE NONLEAGUE RIVALS
description: The eight Ivy League teams this Saturday take on what are euphemistically called nonleague opponents. That means these rivals, for the most part, will be stronger, larger, faster, more learned about football and therefore more likely to win.

title: FISHING FOR GEMS OF EDUCATIONAL SOFTWARE IN A SEA OF JUNK
description: HUNDREDS of new programs are introduced into the educational software market each year. A random sampling has revealed many, perhaps most, of these programs to be mind-numbing duds that ought to be flunked. Few parents or teachers have the time or money to evaluate each new product for educational and price value. How, then, does one select reliable programs that instruct as well as entertain?

title: STERCHI BROTHERS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
TOURISTS ARE ENCOURAGED NOT TO CANCEL TRIPS
description: A Mexican official said in New York yesterday that, despite cancellations by tourists in the aftermath of the earthquakes in Mexico, he would still encourage those concerned for their relatives and friends to travel there and ''find out for themselves.''

title: Chinese Farmer Allowed To Stay in United States
description: A Chinese farmer who was befriended by marines in war-torn China nearly 40 years ago, can stay in the United States indefinitely and can be joined by his family, officials said today.

title: GOODMAN ASSAILS POLICE ON RECRUIT SCREENINGS
description: The city's Police Department is hiring new officers without making thorough background investigations, the chairman of a State Senate investigations committee asserted yesterday.

title: Michigan Hospital Refunding Bonds
description: Michigan State Hospital Finance Authority is issuing $117.1 million of hospital revenue refunding bonds for the Harper Grace Huron Valley hospital, with a maximum yield tentatively set at 9.926 percent for bonds due 2016, through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: MET LIFE: 'OLD LADY' IS ACTIVE
description: Chalk up another entrant in the financial services derby. It is the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, once the epitome of a narrowly focused lumbering giant in one of the most conservative sectors of the financial world. Now it is shucking off its reputation as the ''Old Lady of One Madison Avenue'' as it revs up to take on the likes of the American Express Company, Sears, Roebuck & Company and the Prudential Insurance Company of America in the red hot competition for consumer money decisions.

title: An Asian USA Today
description: The Gannett Company announced today that it had contracted with a Singapore publishing company to print the international edition of USA Today for distribution in Asia beginning in October. Gannett's chairman, Allen H. Neuharth, said a contract for printing had been signed with Singapore Newspaper Services, a subsidiary of Singapore Press Holdings, which publishes Straits Times of Singapore. It will be the first foreign printing of the nationwide daily newspaper.

title: General Mills Net Off 9.6%
description: General Mills Inc. today reported a 9.6 percent drop in fiscal first quarter earnings to $48.9 million, or $1.10 a share, from $54.1 million, or $1.20 a share, in the comparable period a yare ago.

title: WORLD MAIL CENTER reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Detroit Tigers, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. The Yankees open their final home stand of the season, 10 games against the Tigers, Orioles and Brewers, before going to Toronto for the final three games of the season against the Blue Jays.

title: CONCERT: ZIZI MUELLER
description: ZIZI MUELLER'S flute recital at Merkin Hall on Sunday night was a debut of sorts, but happily, music of interest was on display and not just the credentials of a particular performer. Miss Mueller, who has had considerable experience in South America and in New York's music and theater world, left the familiar repertory at home, in other words, and gave us five pieces by 20th-century composers.

title: Sutter Scrutinized
description: Bruce Sutter, the reliever signed by the Atlanta Braves as a free agent for $10 million at the start of the season, is scheduled to undergo a test this week to determine the source of the pain in his right shoulder that has hampered his pitching since June.

title: Dataquest Chief Officer Is Moving to Pyramid
description: Dataquest Inc., a leading provider of industrial and high-technology market analysis, said yesterday that E. David Crockett had resigned as president and chief executive to become president of the Pyramid Technology Corporation, a super-minicomputer manufacturer based in Mountain View, Calif.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE Italian link to New York is getting stronger and stronger. And it isn't only because of Bloomingdale's current merchandise promotion. True, Diego Dalla Palma, who designs the makeup for most of the top Italian fashion houses, did introduce his line of beauty products in the store over the weekend, but that isn't the only place where Italian accents are being heard these days.

title: East Meets Koch
description: ''I understand that your Government is now involved in a governmental shake-up. Does this mean you are all safe?''

title: MISSING EX-OFFICIAL IN JERSEY IS DENIED A PLEA FOR LENIENCY
description: A Federal judge today dismissed a sentence-reduction motion filed by a former New Jersey State Senator and convicted extortionist who has been missing since Labor Day.

title: Shareholders Back Uniroyal Buyout
description: Uniroyal Inc. stockholders approved a $746 million leveraged buyout by a group of the company's managers and the New York investment firm Clayton & Dubilier Inc. Each current owner of Uniroyal's common stock will receive $22 a share in cash in the transaction, which makes Uniroyal a private company. A two-thirds majority of Uniroyal's 35.3 million shares of common and preferred stock was required to approve the deal.

title: SUN'S ROTATION DEFIES EXPECTATION
description: ALTHOUGH astronomers have long sought an explanation for the intricate and strikingly symmetrical cycles of sunspots, only now have they found a way to look into the solar interior and observe deep-seated motions that may be the controlling factors.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL DETROIT (NBA) - Signed John Long, a free-agent guard, to a 3-year contract.

title: QUEBEC PARTY HAS NEW BLOOD BUT THE OLD FIRE SEEMS GONE
description: For all the waving of campaign placards and shouting of partisan supporters, the old spark seemed missing from a political rally that the Parti Quebecois held the other night at a high school auditorium in the Montreal suburb of Longueuil.

title: A Call for Teaching Morals and Ethics in Schools
description: SHOULD the schools teach morals and ethics and, if so, how? President Reagan and William J. Bennett, his Secretary of Education, have recently accused the schools of being ''value neutral,'' but their plea for the teaching of moral values has aroused controversy because it was linked to their quest for prayers in the schools. This makes many parents and others nervous because they believe in the wall that separates church and state.

title: 60 GREETERS READY FOR U.N. BIRTHDAY
description: Sure, the job sounds as if it's all glamour - greeting diplomats at the city's airports, then opening up the world of New York to them, from a Mets game one night to ''Tosca'' the next. And, oh, the parties, parties, parties!

title: Williams on Waivers
description: Sylvester (Sly) Williams, the former Knick forward, was placed on waivers by the Atlanta Hawks. Williams, who averaged 13.9 points for the Knicks in 1981-82, was traded to the Hawks for Rudy Macklin before the 1983-84 season. The 27-year-old Williams was the Knicks' first-round draft pick in 1979. . . . Nate (Tiny) Archibald, the six-time N.B.A. all-star, was named assistant basketball coach at the University of Georgia. . . . The forward Kurt Rambis has signed a new multi-year contract, the Los Angeles Lakers announced. . . . John Long, the Pistons' guard, signed a three-year pact with Detroit.

title: Heart Patient Is Reported Ailing
description: Michael Drummond, the Arizona man who had an artificial heart before it was replaced with a donor human heart two weeks ago, may be suffering from a mysterious infection that is giving him a fever and breathing problems, hospital officials said today.

title: BARCO OF CALIFORNIA (CO)(A) reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-Net income.

title: NATIONAL HMO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-The company went public in December 1983 and therefore year- ago results were not available.

title: PARK ELECTROCHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
USENCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
2 Win Awards
description: Libby Riddle, the first women to win the 1,135-mile Iditarod dogsled race across Alaska, and Michele Mitchell, the 1985 world champion 10-meter platform diver, have been named Sportswomen of the Year by the Women's Sports Foundation. The 29-year-old Miss Riddles, from Tellers, Alaska, won in the professional category and the 23-year-old Miss Mitchell, from Phoenix, Ariz., was selected in the amateur category.

title: PLAN FOR CUTTING HOSPITAL COSTS BY REWARDING DOCTORS DRAWS A.M.A. FIRE
description: Under a new plan to trim costs, doctors at seven Paracelsus Corporation hospitals in California who keep the number of services for Medicare patients to a minimum receive a cash reward from the company.

title: LINKING MAC TO THE I.B.M. PC
description: IF the field of personal computing seems somewhat confused and disoriented, then the dichotomy between the I.B.M. and Apple Macintosh operating systems seems downright schizophrenic. Had the automobile industry developed both left-hand and right-hand drive cars, with separate roads for each, the situation would be roughly analogous to that now existing in the realm of personal computer operating systems.

title: 'OTHER LOVER' ON CBS
description: THERE'S a moment of truth in ''The Other Lover,'' the television movie on CBS at 9 this evening. It comes at the very beginning when Jack Hollander, a novelist, is infuriated by the soft-porn cover put on his latest book. Confronting Claire Fielding, his publisher's new marketing director, he demands to know what the cover has to do with what he has written. She confesses that she didn't even have time to read the book but then adds, assertively, ''Jack, you and I want the same thing for this book - we want it to sell.'' That is the contemporary ethic in a nutshell. That, folks, is realism.

title: MILLER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Club Med Inc., a subsidiary of Club Mediterranee S.A., has appointed Jacques Giraud president and chief executive officer, effective Nov. 1. He succeeds Serge Trigano, who will assume new duties at the parent company's headquarters in Paris.

title: Arms and the Art of Long-Distance Flexibility
description: The White House has often asserted since the arms control talks resumed last March that United States negotiators in Geneva have ''unprecedented flexibility.'' But is that really the case? ''Let's put it this way,'' a senior Reagan Administration official answered with a chuckle. ''Their instructions specify the objectives, but they are permitted to talk about different ways the Russians can meet those objectives.''

title: Gibson's Proper Refusal To Allow a Klan Rally
description: To the Editor:

title: Milner Testifies Again
description: John Milner, a former outfielder and first baseman who played with the Pirates and the Mets, testified in Federal District court here today that he used cocaine during the final four seasons of his major league baseball career, sometimes purchasing as much as seven grams per week, which he said he shared with his Pirate teammates.

title: SCORES INCREASE ON COLLEGE ENTRANCE EXAMS
description: The average scores of last June's high school graduates on the standardized tests used by college admissions offices showed modest gains over the previous year, the two major testing agencies reported yesterday.

title: FIGHTING IS RESUMED IN LEBANESE TOWN AFTER 12-HOUR LULL
description: Rival Moslem militias resumed fighting here today after nine days of bloodshed that has left at least 95 dead and 330 wounded.

title: People
description: * John E. Eckelberry has been elected executive vice president and to the board of Doremus & Co.

title: Victim Identified As Jersey Woman
description: The victim of a strangling in Manhattan has been identified as a 21-year-old woman from Pompton Lakes, N.J., the New York City police reported last night.

title: PROGRESS REPORTED IN STRUGGLE TO SAVE IMPERILED RUINS
description: FOR thousands of years, the Indus River has brought the blessing of water for crops and the curse of destructive floods. But today the Indus River poses a new danger to the site of an ancient civilization that flourished at the same time as those in the river valleys of the Tigris and Euphrates and the Nile.

title: Penney Is Buying Cableshare Stake
description: The J. C. Penney Company said it had agreed to acquire the 36 percent of Cableshare Inc. held by Rogers Cablesystems Inc. The purchase would give Penney, the New York-based retailing company, access to in-home shopping technology being developed by Cableshare, which is based in London, Ontario.

title: PROPOSAL WOULD ALLOW EXPORT OF NEW DRUGS
description: The trade initiative announced by President Reagan today includes a proposal that would permit American drug manufacturers to export drugs not yet approved by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Wang Proposal
description: Wang Laboratories Inc. has asked shareholders to approve a measure at its Oct. 22 annual meeting making it more difficult for a takeover to succeed. The provision would require that any takeover be approved by two-thirds of all shareholders and a majority of both the holders of class B stock, which is widely held, and of class C stock, about 73 percent of which is owned by the company's founder, An Wang, his family and trusts they control. Wang's bylaws now require only a two-thirds vote of the shares outstanding.

title: GRIM REALITIES FOR FAMILIES OF ALZHEIMER'S VICTIMS
description: To the Editor:

title: CHIEF'S POST GIVEN UP BY GRAY
description: The United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that Harry J. Gray, its forceful, flamboyant chairman who has been one of the nation's most aggressive acquirers of other companies, would relinquish his additional post as chief executive officer on Jan. 1.

title: SEISDATA SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: GIANTS DEFENSES WERE WELL 'DISGUISED'
description: With the euphoria of Sunday's victory over St. Louis behind them, the Giants emerged from their meetings this morning, shaking their heads like doctors who had lost a patient.

title: Grim Realities for Families of Alzheimer's Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: HAMMERMILL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 8
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in February 1985.

title: SHEVARDNADZE EXPECTED TO OFFER SOVIET ARMS IDEAS TO REAGAN
description: Reagan Administration officials and members of Congress said today that they had been told that Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union was bringing serious proposals on arms control to his meeting with President Reagan this week.

title: Cost for Air Force Fighter Tool Is Backed
description: Two major military contractors denied today that they had conspired to bilk the Air Force on a high-priced tool contract, and two Air Force generals agreed that the companies had followed proper procedures.

title: Speak Up for Soviet Jews
description: Some 400,000 Jews, among them my husband Anatoly, are being held hostage in the Soviet Union. Will any of these thousands ever taste the bright air of freedom in their ancient homeland, Israel? The American public and its officials might usefully put this excruciating question to the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, during his visit this month to the United States - for its answer lies entirely in the hands of his barbaric Government.

title: Advertising;   Campbell Likened to Ripe Plum
description: ''WE are a plum waiting to be plucked,'' said James V. McConnell Jr., describing the ripe condition of Campbell-Ewald's New York office in relation to the high rollers of the package-goods community.

title: Judge Edward Tamm, Ex-F.B.I. Official, 79
description: Judge Edward A. Tamm of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, a former F.B.I. official, died of cancer Sunday. He was 79 years old.

title: COMPREHENSIVE CARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
ZIYAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income.

title: 2 Reported Killed in Lebanon
description: Israeli troops in the border ''security belt'' in southern Lebanon killed two Arab guerrillas during the night, the military command said here today.

title: A DEVALUED DOLLAR: THE LIKELY EFFECTS
description: For the American consumer, the attempt to devalue the dollar could bring to an end an era in which foreign goods, from coffee to fine French wines, have been bountiful and inexpensive, economists said yesterday.

title: U.S. EXAMINES IF COMPUTER USED IN '84 ELECTION IS OPEN TO FRAUD
description: A branch of the National Security Agency is investigating whether a computer program that counted more than one-third of all the votes cast in the United States in 1984 is vulnerable to fraudulent manipulation.

title: Dancer Announces Changes at the Top
description: Gary M. Susnjara, 46 years old and president of Dancer Fitzgerald Sample/ New York, has been elevated to chairman to make room for the new president, Joseph P. Mack, 51. In order to accomplish that feat, Peter F. McSpadden, former chairman, gave up the title while remaining president and chief operating officer of DFS Holdings, the parent on high.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: NANCY REAGAN ARRIVES IN MEXICO WITH AN INITIAL $1 MILLION IN AID
description: Nancy Reagan visited survivors of the earthquake disaster today, delivering a letter of sympathy from her husband and a $1 million ''down payment'' on United States Government disaster aid to Mexico.

title: Trouble at T.C.U.
description: Morris (Snake) Bailey, a member of the Texas Christian University Hall of Fame and a contributor to its football program, has accused F. A. Dry, the former Horned Frogs' football coach, with asking him to set up a illegal fund for his players, according to a published report in The Fort Worth Star-Telegram.
