Six players, including Kenneth Davis, the star running back, who finished fifth in Heisman Trophy voting last season, were suspended by Jim Wacker, the current T.C.U. coach, last Thursday after he learned they had received cash payments from T.C.U. boosters, a violation of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules.

title: Rights Group Faults U.S. On Guatemala Situation
description: A human-rights monitoring group has asserted that the Reagan Administration has refused to acknowledge major human-rights abuses in Guatemala under three successive Governments there.

title: JUDGE BARS MOST OF INTERVIEW IN BELUSHI CASE
description: Municipal Judge James Nelson today ruled inadmissible most of a taped interview in which Cathy Evelyn Smith said she administered a dose of drugs to the comedian John Belushi before his death.

title: Ex-Pittston President Picked by Air Express
description: The Air Express International Corporation, a financially troubled air freight company based in Darien, Conn., yesterday named Hendrik J. Hartong Jr., a former president of the Pittston Company, to be chairman and chief executive officer.

title: INTERNATIONAL DYNERGY reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net loss. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 1-for-8 stock distribution and a 100 percent stock dividend to the public shareholders in August 1985.

title: Inmate Fatally Stabbed By Cellmate in Texas
description: An inmate was stabbed 22 times by his cellmate today and became the 27th prisoner killed this year and the seventh this month in the Texas prison system, a prison spokesman said.

title: RAIDERS' PLUNKETT IS OUT FOR 4 WEEKS WITH INJURY
description: As if the season has not progressed sourly enough for the Los Angeles Raiders, who are now 1-2, they learned yesterday that Jim Plunkett has a dislocated left shoulder and will be unable to play for at least four weeks.

title: Maryland Home Bonds
description: The Maryland Community Development Administration is issuing about $150 million of single-family mortgage revenue bonds, including fixed-rate interest-bearing bonds, zero coupon bonds and ''put'' bonds.

title: Canada's Fisheries Minister Resigns Over Tuna Scandal
description: Canada's Fisheries Minister resigned today, five days after admitting he approved the sale of more than a million cans of tuna determined to be unfit for human consumption.

title: WESTERN DIGITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax loss of $669,000. c-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $295,000 for the quarter and year and extraordinary tax credits of $729,000 for the quarter and $1,852,000 for the year.

title: NOBILITY HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: b-Net income including a pretax gain of $679,605 for the quarter and 9 months on the sale of a plant.

title: Bombs in India Kill 3 As Punjab Vote Nears
description: Sikh terrorists set off seven bombs today, killing three girls on the last day of the Punjab state election campaign.

title: Market Place;   Cautious View On Oil Stocks
description: INTERNATIONAL oil stocks have outperformed the equity market so far this year, thanks partly to the surprising resilience of crude oil prices. But Wall Street analysts are taking a more selective view of this group because of their belief that the price of crude will drop by 1986 and affect some companies more adversely than others.

title: SAUDIS' KING ASSERTS FREEDOM TO CUT PRICES
description: Saudi Arabia's King Fahd said today that if other OPEC members believe it is in their own interest to cut oil prices, Saudi Arabia should have the same freedom as long as production stays within the organization's quotas.

title: SHULTZ TELLS U.N. HE SEES A CHANCE TO AVERT WAR RISK
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States and the Soviet Union now had a ''historic opportunity'' to reduce the risk of war. But he accused Moscow of making ''blatantly one-sided'' statements that were holding up progress in the arms talks in Geneva.

title: 24 CITY GROUPS TO SUPPLY HOMELESS WITH HOUSING
description: The city has selected 24 nonprofit groups to create permanent and temporary housing for about 2,000 of New York's more than 21,000 homeless people, officials announced yesterday.

title: INSURERS WARY ON SATELLITES
description: In the last 20 months, seven communications satellites have failed to reach orbit successfully. The dismal record has shaken the confidence of insurers and raised the prospect that some may drop out of the business, analysts say.

title: MET OPERA: SEASON PREMIERE
description: BEYOND opera there is grand opera, and beyond that a separate category that may be called grandiose opera, a perfect example of which the Metropolitan Opera presented last night with a heavy-handed performance of Franco Zeffirelli's ''Tosca'' to open its 1985-86 season. This is the visually spectacular version of the Puccini work that astonished and gratified Met audiences last season with its opulent decor, ingenious stage machinery and larger-than-life dimensions, and an unusually dressy first-night audience seemed to find the sets no less to its liking on this occasion.

title: Coast Guard Site Destroyed
description: A fire destroyed a major Coast Guard communications center on Kodiak Island early today, severely damaging the Coast Guard's ability to monitor distress signals in the North Pacific. The cause of the blaze, which destroyed four communications systems, was unknown.

title: Skipper Explains
description: John Kolius fought back tears at news conference in Newport, R.I., as he explained why he resigned last week as sailing manager for the New York Yacht Club's America II syndicate. The 33-year-old Kolius blamed disagreement with management and ''syndicate politics'' for his leaving. John Bertrand of San Francisco, and Tom McLaughlin of San Diego, have been named to replace him in the club's effort to become the challenger and win the America's Cup back from Australia.

title: Congress;   The Rich Get Richer and Elected
description: The House of Representatives, which prides itself on being ''the people's House,'' has been turning into a rich man's club.

title: McDonnell Inquiry
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said it and some of its middle-level managers had been subpoenaed to testify before a Federal grand jury here concerning the pricing of F-15 jet fighter contracts.

title: Don Tennant Company Names a New Chief
description: Elizabeth D. Harrington, 42, who joined the Don Tennant Company in Chicago last year as president, last week was given the big title, chief executive. Mr. Tennant remains chairman and chief creative officer.

title: WARNER EXECUTIVE RESIGNS
description: Mark Rosenberg, the president of worldwide theatrical production at Warner Bros. since 1983, abruptly announced his resignation today. The announcement came in the middle of an excellent box-office year for the studio.

title: ART: CHRISTO'S NEW WRAPPING IN PARIS
description: It was the best of times to be by the Seine. Over the weekend, sailboats were out in force, rainbowed with spinnakers. The excursion boats had never done such a trade. People were standing five and six deep on the Pont des Arts, the beloved footbridge downstream from the Pont Royal, and staring upstream. Motor cruisers went putt-putt, the all-but-naked sunbathers toasted themselves on centenarian stones, and even vagrants got onto their feet to see what was going on. They all got their money's worth, and not least the Mayor of Paris, Jacques Chirac, who came down on Sunday from the Hotel de Ville to thank Christo, the Bulgarian-born artist long resident in New York, for what he had done to enliven the city.

title: Ft. Worth Airlines' Chapter 11 Filing
description: Fort Worth Airlines, which operated commuter flights in seven cities in Texas and Oklahoma, has canceled flights and filed for protection from creditors under Federal bankruptcy laws. John Y. Bonds, a lawyer for the nine-and-a-half-month-old airline, said the Chapter 11 petition for reorganization was filed Sunday morning.

title: MURDOCH WILL BUY OUT DAVIS'S HOLDINGS IN FOX
description: Marvin Davis, the wealthy Denver oilman, officially bid farewell to the entertainment industry today by agreeing to sell his 50 percent stake in the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation to Rupert Murdoch for $325 million in cash.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Honda Motor Co., Gardena, Calif., said it had increased prices for its 1986 model cars by an average of 4.3 percent, or $387 per car, over comparable 1985 prices.

title: PRESIDIO OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GROUPS OF KOREANS CROSS BORDER, ENDING KIN VISIT
description: Groups of North and South Korean visitors recrossed the border today and returned home after historic reunions with separated families they had not seen since before the Korean War.

title: ACTION PACKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Dickerson Returns to Rams With a Rush
description: Eric Dickerson returned to National Football League play with a splash tonight, rushing for three touchdowns as the Los Angeles Rams defeated the Seattle Seahawks, 35-24.

title: F.D.I.C. ASKS CURB ON MERGERS
description: In a setback to large banks that want to cross state boundaries, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation proposed revised guidelines today that would restrict big-city banks in takeovers of banks in smaller communities and that would facilitate mergers of one small bank with another.

title: NETWORK ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $1,021,714 from the sale of land. c-Net loss.

title: SCHOLASTIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: Year-ago results include a nonrecurring pretax gain of $7,631,000 from the disposition of property in Englewood Cliffs.

title: Losers
description: What a coach says to his players in the locker room is both his business and his business. It reflects his knowledge of the team and his skill at teaching character. But what a coach says in public is also public business because that, for good or ill, also teaches character. George Steinbrenner, the New York Yankee owner, teaches it negatively every time he ridicules his players. And now Jim Garrett, Columbia's new football coach, seems determined to make even George Steinbrenner look good.

title: Topics;   Family Secrets; The Oyster Mystery
description: ''Follow me,'' a father once said to his son as they left a train at New York's Grand Central. Promising to share a secret, he led the boy toward the Oyster Bar, where three corridors join beneath a vaulted ceiling.

title: Mexico's Deeper Distress
description: There has been a vast, spontaneous outpouring of sympathy for the suffering caused by Mexico's earthquake, particularly in this area of the United States that was once a part of Mexico.

title: LTX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1,226,000.

title: U.S. SETS GUIDELINES ON USING GENE TRANSPLANTS IN HUMANS
description: National guidelines were approved today for a revolutionary type of medical treatment known as gene therapy, to be used on humans against a range of fatal hereditary diseases.

title: Short-Term Rates Tumble
description: The credit markets reacted ambivalently to Sunday's agreement on a plan to bring down the value of the dollar, as short-term interest rates fell sharply while long-term bond yields rose.

title: Chinatown Bank Suit
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is suing the chairman of a failed bank in New York's Chinatown and dozens of his relatives and business partners to recover $14 million lost by investors in bogus deposit certificates, an attorney said yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ELECTROSOUND GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $109,000. c-Net loss and includes a tax credit of $21,000.

title: HAROLD BENNETT
description: Harold Bennett, who was principal flutist for the Metropolitan Opera orchestra from 1944 until his retirement in 1965, died of cardiac arrest Sept. 17 at his home on Long Island.

title: Faith Shaken
description: The post mortem of the day was issued by Joe Theismann, who learned this lesson from the Redskins' 19-6 loss to Philadelphia: ''Maybe we're not as good as everybody says we think we are.''

title: 2 Stadium Plans Still in Running
description: State officials said yesterday that they had narrowed to two the list of developers seeking to build a domed football stadium in Flushing, Queens. Both finalists have agreed to build an 82,000-seat, oval-shaped stadium with a structurally supported roof, they said.

title: THE STAGE: 'LUNIN: THEATER OF DEATH'
description: ONE is not quite sure whether John Patrick Shanley is holding the characters in ''Savage in Limbo'' up to ridicule or seeking a compassionate understanding of them. The gifted actors in this first play in the premiere season of the Double Image Repertory Company at the 47th Street Theater makes Mr. Shanley's lonely people interesting and sometimes attractive, but they cannot resolve the emotional confusion of the play.

title: Still Life
description: Every autumn James H. Boren announces a conference of the International Association of Professional Bureaucrats, a Washington-based whimsy of which he is president and which has as its motto ''When in doubt, mumble.'' Mr. Boren makes a living as a humorous public speaker, and, working in paperclips and loopholes, he uses funny metal sculpture to illustrate his satire of the body politic. Next Monday he will show some of his works in the Hyatt Regency on Capitol Hill.

title: FOR SCHOOL, SOME SMART CLOTHES
description: School has started, so for lots of children it's a fond farewell to T-shirts, blue jeans and shorts and hello to blazers, regimental stripe ties, lace-collar dresses, ankle socks and patent-leather shoes. It is the time of year when many of New York's youngsters are as well-dressed as their parents - at least at the beginning of the day.

title: YANKEES PLANNING NO PUNISHMENT
description: The Yankees will take no action in the last two weeks of the season against Ed Whitson or Billy Martin for their wild brawl in Baltimore early Sunday morning, George Steinbrenner said yesterday.

title: CBS SALE OF TRI-STAR WEIGHED
description: CBS Inc. is considering selling its interest in Tri-Star Pictures, the Hollywood studio that it formed with Columbia Pictures Industries and Home Box Office in 1982, a Tri-Star official said today.

title: DRUG TRIAL LEAVES TARNISHED IMAGES
description: From its beginning three weeks ago, the baseball-and-cocaine trial in Pittsburgh produced a continual stream of scenes and images that had the aura of a watershed event for the sport. Player after player - seven in all - took the witness stand and, looking more like ordinary mortals in suits and ties than superstars, told of their own and their teammates' drug use. Not since the infamous Black Sox scandal about 65 years ago had baseball been so publicly humiliated, and even then the stain did not touch as many big names as it did in Pittsburgh.

title: CML GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Dole Foresees Debt Struggle
description: Senate Majority Leader Bob Dole said last night that he expects a major struggle over raising the Federal debt ceiling and warned that the Senate will probably again take the issue past the deadline before passing legislation.

title: Sports of The Times;   Jim Garrett: 4th-and-Long
description: Jim Garrett has coached the Columbia University football team for only one game, but his back is already against the goal line, and the wind is already in his face.

title: State Dept. Formally Accepts Credentials of South African
description: The State Department announced today that it was prepared, after a five-month delay, to formally accept South Africa's designation of Herbert Beukus as its Ambassador to the United States.

title: THREAT TO INTERVENE CAN BE EFFECTIVE
description: Nowhere in the statement that the United States and four other nations published Sunday did they explicitly invoke the use of intervention to drive the dollar down. Nevertheless, there was only one message in the single-spaced, nine-page statement: a threat to intervene.

title: Grace Note for Summer
description: Summer did not slip away unnoticed.

title: PERU CAVE ARTIFACTS ARE 10,000 YEARS OLD
description: AS long as 10,000 years ago, early inhabitants of the high Andes had domesticated plants and were weaving cloth, according to age determinations reported recently in the journal Science.

title: The Chinese Take An Economic Step
description: The extraordinary turnover that began last week in the Chinese Politburo and military establishment marks a tactical victory for the reform coalition led by Deng Xiaoping. A Communist Party conference ousted nearly one-third of the political and military establishment and replaced it with younger, more technically competent officials. It is, however, far from clear that this effort will in fact lead to the kinds of technological or political changes required to bring China into the modern world economy.

title: MET OPENING REVIVES GLITTER
description: The Metropolitan Opera opened its new season last night in high style, reviving the sort of glitter and glamour that used to be a first-night tradition years ago. On stage, there was a sold-out performance of ''Tosca'' with Luciano Pavarotti and Montserrat Caballe. In the audience were black tie, jewels and evening dresses.

title: STAGE: 'THE BLOOD KNOT' BY FUGARD
description: In 1961, ''The Blood Knot'' was introduced at a single, Sunday night performance in a private theater club in Johannesburg, a production that co-starred the playwright, Athol Fugard, and a former saxophonist, Zakes Mokae. The play went on to become an international triumph and the foundation of Mr. Fugard's career as a dramatist.

title: 2-YEAR HOUSE ARREST INSTEAD OF JAIL TERM IS ORDERED FOR FRAUD
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn, in an unusual ruling, yesterday sentenced a woman convicted of insurance fraud to ''house arrest,'' saying she must be confined to her home for two years.

title: U.S. ACTIVISTS UNIT FOR SPACE DEFENSE
description: The Department of Defense today activated its first unified space command to oversee all military programs in space and perhaps, in the future, to operate the strategic missile defense system that the United States is seeking to develop.

title: BUDGET AX FAILS TO MAKE DENT IN AID PROGRAMS FOR STUDENTS
description: CONGRESS has blocked virtually all the cuts in aid to college students that the Reagan Administration proposed last winter and, with no visible Administration opposition, Congressional subcommittees are drafting legislation to keep grants, loans and work opportunities essentially intact for five years.

title: REAGAN PROPOSES EXPORT SUBSIDIES TO GAIN MARKETS
description: President Reagan today announced a plan to subsidize some exports in an effort to open foreign markets to American goods.

title: Uniroyal Process Blamed for Death
description: A new procedure for treating chemical wastes is believed to have caused an explosion July 26 that killed an engineer at a chemical plant here owned by Uniroyal Inc., company officials said today.

title: Luring Trade With Loans
description: The $300 million war chest that would combat what the White House has called predatory export financing by foreign governments is expected to be administered by the Treasury.

title: GIVING MONEY-QUIETLY
description: JOAN K. DAVIDSON, president of the J. M. Kaplan Fund, has no quarrel with New York's celebrated big benefit galas. She concedes their necessity and the fun it is to dance to a good band in a beautiful room. But she rarely goes.

title: LEADERS AIR DIFFERENCES AT CHINESE PARTY MEETING
description: The Communist Party ended a national conference here today with an unusual airing of policy differences that have created tension between Deng Xiaoping, the reform-minded veteran who is China's pre-eminent leader, and more doctrinaire figures in the party hierarchy.

title: JUDGE APPROVES TRUMP'S NAME ON A 2D CASINO
description: A Federal judge today refused to bar Donald J. Trump from using his name on his new casino hotel in Atlantic City.

title: RESCUE EFFORTS, AND BURIALS, CONTINUE IN MEXICO
description: Mexico's earthquake-battered capital began returning to normal today, but that effort created new problems.

title: TEXAS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
WILLIAM K. SAUNDERS
description: William K. Saunders, an executive vice president of J. P. Stevens & Company, died of a heart attack Sunday in Rhode Island. He was 61 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.

title: 14 FEARED KILLED AS AIRLINER HITS PEAK IN VIRGINIA
description: A commuter airplane carrying 14 people crashed into the side of a cloud-shrouded mountain in the Shenandoah National Park this morning, and rescuers reported no signs of survivors, the state police said tonight.

title: FROM QUAKE RELIEF TO DEBT, U.N. SPEAKERS OPEN DEBATE
description: The General Assembly opened its general debate today in a 40th anniversary session that will bring together the largest gathering of world leaders in history.

title: PERIL OF SURGERY THAT PROVED FATAL CITED IN HAERING ON NAVY DOCTOR
description: A Navy anesthesiologist testified today that the death of one patient, after surgery by the former top heart surgeon at Bethesda Naval Medical Center, was probably linked more to the dangers of the operation than to any clumsiness on the part of the surgeon.

title: Weakening the Dollar Is Not Enough
description: President Reagan has belatedly recognized that protectionist sentiment in Congress may be stronger than his veto power. Shoring up the veto is the purpose of his new attacks against the high-priced dollar and unfair foreign competition. Both efforts mark a change of policy. Both can be helpful. Both continue to address symptoms rather than causes of America's painful trade imbalance and loss of manufacturing jobs.

title: SYSTEMS TECHNOLOGY ASSOC reports earnings for Year to May 25
description: b-Includes tax credits of $43,560 for the latest year and $156,339 for previous year.

title: MARY KENNEDY WILSON
description: Mary Kennedy Wilson, the president of Kennedy Insurance Brokers of New York City and a former New York City teacher, died of cancer Sunday at her home in Bronxville, N.Y. She was 52 years old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 24, 1985
description: International

title: Air Disasters: Deregulation Is Not the Culprit
description: To the Editor:

title: Nature, Not Man, Was First to Make Plutonium
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW POLICIES TO SHORE UP AM RADIO ARE STUDIED
description: AM radio, once the only broadcast system in America and still the backbone of the nation's emergency broadcast system, has lost 71 percent of the listening audience to FM radio, according to industry studies.

title: Measles Vaccine
description: Last year fewer than 3,000 cases of measles were reported in the United States, a reduction of 99.9 percent since the introduction of a vaccine in 1963. Yet last year more than 1.5 million children died of the disease and its complications in the less developed world.

title: 40TH ASSEMBLY GETS OFF TO A TIMELY BEGINNING
description: Recent General Assembly sessions have started so much later than the appointed hour of 10 A.M. that when 11 former General Assembly presidents met last June, one of their recommendations on ways to improve the debate was to start the meetings on time.

title: 'MAIN STREET,' NBC DOCUMENTARY FOR TEEN-AGERS
description: A NEW nonfiction television series, ''Main Street,'' directed specifically to the junior high set, but not necessarily exclusively so, makes its debut today from 4 to 5 P.M. on NBC.

title: SUPERIOR CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-After a tax credit of $106,000. c-Net loss after a loss of $931,248 from discontinued operations.

title: FARM AID BENEFIT CONCERT HAILED AS AROUSING PUBLIC
description: The organizers of Farm Aid, the benefit concert initiated by Willie Nelson, said today that the 14-hour concert succeeded in arousing the public's interest in farm issues even though it fell short of reaching the fund-raising goals.

title: Financial Aid Stressed
description: While the United States and other countries continue sending small teams of technical specialists to Mexico on earthquake rescue and recovery missions, public health officials said today that Mexico's most pressing and costly need lies weeks or months ahead in the reconstruction of as many as 10 devastated hospitals in Mexico City.

title: A Central Banker To Head Midland
description: Christopher McMahon, the 58-year-old deputy governor of the Bank of England, has been named chairman of Midland Bank P.L.C. He will join Midland's board early next year and succeed Sir Donald Barron when he retires in mid-1987.

title: Worthy Cause
description: If the most zealous fan in America is the one who is willing to back his fervor with the most cash, then Jim Fuller may be the most zealous fan in America.

title: Clues to the Selection Of Federal Judges
description: To the Editor:

title: There May Yet Be a Richard IV in England
description: To the Editor:

title: Careers;   Improving Courses for M.B.A.'s
description: IN recent years deans and faculties of graduate schools of business administration have been re-evaluating ways to meet the needs of the future. One result has been the requirement of communications courses by Dartmouth, Columbia and others because so many M.B.A. students did not write or speak well. Courses in strategic planning have also been high on the agenda at some business schools, along with courses in small-business management.

title: TRAPPED 4 DAYS IN MOUND OF RUBBLE,A DAZED MEDICAL STUDENT IS RESCUED
description: Last Saturday night, three days after the earthquake struck, someone heard a muffled cry in the mound of rubble that had been the Juarez Hospital.

title: PAVAROTTI REFLECTS UPON THE CELEBRATED VOICE
description: Opera has known careers as remarkable as Luciano Pavarotti's, but not many, and rarely more than one in any generation. The beloved Italian singer approached last night's Metropolitan Opera opening as a star not only at the top of his profession, but one who has reached beyond it to a public not normally concerned with opera. He has taken his knocks, as well as garnering his laurels, along the way.

title: Times Mirror Sells 3 TV Stations
description: The Times Mirror Company, publisher of The Los Angeles Times, Newsday and six other daily newspapers, is selling three of its seven television stations for $84 million in cash.

title: FULLER, H B CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $1,574,000 from a patent licensing agreement. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $100,000 for the quarter and $132,000 for the 9 months, a loss of $435,000 for the 9 months on the disposal of discontinued operations and a loss of $729,000 for the 9 months on the disposal of assets in Lebanon.

title: EMONS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After a writedown of $7 million on railcars. The company filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act in March 1984 and is negotiating a reorganization plan with creditors.

title: U.S. TO GIVE STATE $70 MILLION TO FOSTER NONPROFIT HOUSING
description: The Federal Government said yesterday that it would provide $70.3 million for subsidized housing developments for the elderly and disabled in New York State.

title: End to I-95 Tolls Might Be Sooner
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill today said he hoped to eliminate tolls on the Connecticut Turnpike by November, a month earlier than originally planned.

title: Richardson-Vicks
description: Richardson-Vicks Inc., continuing its efforts to fend off an unwanted takeover by Unilever N.V., said its board of directors had authorized the company to increase its stock-buyback program to up to seven million common shares. The company, which earlier said it would repurchase up to five million shares, said it had bought about that amount as of Friday. The company also said the board increased the funds for such purchases to $350 million, from $300 million.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: RELOCATION PLAN IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: A Government commission proposed a plan today for the resettlement of 42,000 people, the overwhelming majority of them blacks, in order to consolidate the so-called homeland of KwaZulu.

title: Israel Absolves Troops In West Bank Inquiry
description: An inquiry ordered by Israel's military chief of staff failed to turn up evidence of soldiers in the occupied West Bank forcing Arabs to kiss a donkey's backside and clean a mule's teeth, a military spokesman said today.

title: Freddie Mac Begins $100.1 Million Offering
description: The first issue of mortgage pass-through securities in the Euromarket was announced yesterday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, which is offering $100.1 million of 10 3/4 percent mortgage participation certificates backed by a pool of multifamily home mortgages.

title: Getty Said to Aid Dissident British Miners
description: John Paul Getty Jr., the American millionaire, is reported to have given about $210,000 to help finance a group that is trying to break away from the National Union of Mineworkers. There was no immediate response to the reports by Mr. Getty.

title: SEAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $90,000. c-Net income. d-Includes an extraordinary credit of $145,000. e-Includes tax credits of $348,000 for the latest 9 months and $367,000 for the year-earlier period. The latest third quarter and 9 months nets include a charge of $2,060,000 for the writeoff of Seal's investment in New England Tube and Machine Co. and a provision for possible costs arising from related litigation.

title: Tacoma Boat Files Chapter 11 Petition
description: The Tacoma Boatbuilding Company said it had filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws. In its filing in New York, the company said it needed concessions from its employees in order to reorganize successfully.

title: Suffolk Executive Seeks 40% Tax
description: A 40 percent cut in the Suffolk County general-fund tax rate was proposed today by County Executive Peter F. Cohalan, who announced his county budget plan for 1986.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch by United Press International from Philadelphia on Saturday, about a professorship in animal welfare at the School of Veterinary Medicine at the University of Pennsylvania, misidentified the branch of the university that was criticized previously for animal experiments. It was the medical school, not the veterinary school.

title: Carnegie Fund Honors 13 Heroes in 2 Nations
description: Thirteen people who risked their lives rescuing or trying to save others were honored today by the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission.

title: LEFT VS. RIGHT: BRAIN FUNCTION TIED TO HORMONE IN THE WOMB
description: SCIENTISTS are tuning into the internal dialogue carried on between the right and left hemispheres of the brain, and their findings are offering clues about the underlying causes of mental deficits such as dyslexia and mental gifts such as mathematical genius.

title: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
description: SOVIET TURN TO SPEAK - The Soviet Union takes its turn at the podium today when Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze addresses the delegates. While Mr. Shevardnadze speaks, Avital Shcharansky, wife of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, a Soviet labor camp inmate, said she would hold what she calls a ''General Assembly of Truth'' from a symbolic prison cage outside the United Nations headquarters.

title: JARUZELSKI'S APPEARANCE AT U.N. HIGHLIGHTS THE ECONOMIC PROBLEMS FACED BY POLAND
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, who arrives in New York on Tuesday to address the United Nations, is making his first trip to the West at a time when Poland is facing serious problems.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE WORKSHOP OF DEMOCRACY. By James MacGregor Burns. 671 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95. AMONG the many virtues of James MacGregor Burns's masterful ''Workshop of Democracy'' is that he is unafraid to take the measure of some of America's revered icons. In relating the development of the country in his new book - from the Emancipation Proclamation to the start of the New Deal - he quotes Walter Lippmann, the columnist who sometimes made Presidents tremble, on literary and political matters. While Mr. Lippmann's ideas are given due respect, Mr. Burns also reveals cracks in his image under the searchlight of time.

title: Reagan and Taxes
description: President Reagan is to visit Athens, Tenn., today to make a speech on his tax revision plans. Regardless of how his plans are doing among the politicians and bureaucrats on Capitol Hill, Mr. Reagan almost always gets a lot of applause and laughs as he travels around the country bashing existing tax laws.

title: Leak at Salem Nuclear Plant
description: A valve in the Unit 1 reactor at the Salem nuclear power plant began leaking water at 8:48 A.M. today. The Public Service Gas and Electric Company said the plant operated on a minor emergency alert for eight hours until repairs were made.

title: Wagons and Taxes
description: Meanwhile, as the House Ways and Means Committee begins drafting tax legislation this week, hundreds of lobbyists are competing for attention, many of them turning to public relations gimmicks.

title: G.E. Leads Patents List
description: The General Electric Company and the International Business Machines Corporation had the most patents granted last year in the United States, followed by two Japanese companies, according to statistics compiled by a private trade association.

title: Injuries at Camp
description: The first hockey camp for Ted Sator, the new Ranger coach, is anything but easy.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF SPEECH TO BUSINESS AND GOVERNMENT LEADERS
description: Following is a transcript of a speech yesterday by President Reagan on trade policy to business and Congressional leaders and Cabinet officials in the East Room of the White House as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network. Thank you. Thank you all. Thank you very much and welcome to the White House.

title: Ship Carrying Aliens Seized
description: The Coast Guard seized a small freighter in a shipping channel here today and a spokesman said it was carrying 111 aliens and 75 to 100 pounds of marijuana.

title: F.T.C. Cites Loophole
description: The Federal Trade Commission said today that on Tuesday it will propose the closing of a loophole in a law that requires corporations to obtain advance clearance from antitrust regulators before buying up a large block of another company's voting stock. The proposed change would require owners of an entity formed or used principally to make acquisitions, regardless of its size, to notify the F.T.C. and the Justice Department of a proposed acquisition as if the owners themselves intended to make the acquisition.

title: A JUDGE FAULTS INSURANCE RATES FOR MALPRACTICE
description: The state's decision to raise medical malpractice insurance rates was granted ''in a manner contrary to the laws of logic and statute,'' a judge in the Bronx has ruled.

title: Promotions At Wheeling
description: As part of its management shakeup, the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation announced new positions today for two senior executives.

title: CONCERT: BROOKLYN MUSICIANS' GROUPS
description: MUSICIANS OF BROOKLYN INITIATIVE, a new musician-run cooperative in Brooklyn, promised ''The Birth of an Orchestra'' at the Prospect Park Band Shell on Sunday, and it was quite an orchestra. A line of saxophonists stretched across the commodious stage, with brass behind them, four percussionists in back and sections of bassists and guitarists filling in the flanks. The music, all of it composed, conducted and performed by members of the cooperative, went on for some five hours.

title: 7 UNIONS SCRAMBLE TO WIN OHIO PUBLIC EMPLOYEES
description: A bitter fight involving seven unions is being waged to organize public workers in Ohio, despite an A.F.L.-C.I.O. principle that unions should avoid such fights, which deplete resources.

title: KLEINERTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $475,000 for the quarter and $830,000 for the 9 months. c-Including extraordinary gains of $341,000 for the quarter and $829,000 for the 9 months.

title: Topics;   Family Secrets; The Panda Solution
description: Taxonomists have argued for years on how to classify the giant and lesser pandas. Some say pandas are cousins to bears, others aver their kinship to raccoons.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 24, 1985
description: International

title: GREENWICH: 'AN INTERNATIONAL SUBURB'
description: When she moved here from England three years ago, Jennifer Brown was mildly surprised to see the stone fences, winding roads and verdant countryside. ''Looks like home,'' she said.

title: LESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
INITIATIVE MAY WIDEN TRADE GAP
description: President Reagan's multifacted new initiative on trade is not expected to cause any overnight improvement in the trade deficit, and could even cause it to widen beyond the $150 billion projected this year, analysts said today.

title: AGENCIES SPLIT IN BABY-FORMULA CASE
description: The Food and Drug Administration strongly recommended criminal prosecution of a company that manufactured defective infant formula, but the Justice Department decided not to file charges last year on the ground that evidence was lacking, according to internal Government documents.

title: VESTAUR SECURITIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: Net income represents net investment income.

title: SANMARK-STARDUST INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated to reflect 10 percent stock dividend issued December 1984.

title: In Quotes
description: Maybe he meant it or it might have been just a morale booster, but Dexter Manley, the Washington Redskins' defensive end, looking ahead to Sunday's game against the unbeaten Chicago Bears, told The Chicago Sun Times: ''We're going to have to knock Walter Payton out of the game.''

title: RUPTURED PIPE SPEWS GASOLINE INTO S.I. STREETS
description: A pipeline ruptured on Staten Island yesterday, sending a geyser of gasoline 100 feet in the air, spilling 35,000 gallons into the streets and forcing the evacuation of 30 homes and a nursery school.

title: CHILEANS HAIL JUDGE, THEIR DIFFIDENT DRAGON-SLAYER
description: In many ways, Judge Jose Canovas Robles is the Judge John J. Sirica of Chile.

title: STAODYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss including a charge of $30,000 from the reversal of a tax credit. c-Net income.

title: ROBOT DEFENSE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
PERUVIAN PRESIDENT, AT THE U.N., WARNS I.M.F. THAT DEBT REPAYMENT MUST BE EASED
description: President Alan Garcia Perez of Peru threatened today to pull his country out of the International Monetary Fund if policy changes are not made to ease the repayment of his nation's foreign debt.

title: IN PARIS, A FASHIOPN PARADE
description: A fashion show put on by 500 models from all over the world paraded before an audience of 50,000 on a runway near the Arch of Triumph in the First International Fashion Festival. A heat wave wilted the clothes if not the spirits of the audience.

title: EUROPEANS SEE MUTED REACTION
description: Sunday's joint declaration by the United States, Japan, West Germany, France and Britain that they would cooperate in bringing down the value of the dollar made a clear impression on the financial markets in Europe today. The dollar plunged in relation to all European currencies, and the shares of European companies with heavy exports to the United States fell, in some cases sharply.

title: LAWMAKERS DOUBT BILLS WILL BE HALTED
description: Congressional leaders said today that President Reagan's speech outlining a new trade policy would probably not be sufficient to head off legislation aimed at protecting American industries from imports.

title: WILDERNESS EXPERIENCE reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income including tax credits of $1,800 for the quarter and $16,800 for the 9 months.

title: Boeing Seeks India Air Talks
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that it wanted to continue negotiations with Indian Airlines on a major aircraft sale, after the airline's decision to award the contract to Airbus Industrie, the European consortium.

title: EGYPT FACES CRISIS AS CURRENCY FALLS
description: A plunge in Egypt's currency has sparked a financial crisis here that is shaping up as the first major political test of Prime Minister Ali Lutfi's new Government.

title: DOLLAR PACT HELPS DOW SOAR 18.37
description: Stock prices surged yesterday in response to the weekend agreement by the United States and four other industrial nations to try to lower the value of the dollar.

title: RABBIS' YOM KIPPUR MESSAGES STRESS PERSONAL ACCOUNTABILITY
description: Yom Kippur, the holiest day on the Jewish calendar, begins at sundown today with many rabbis throughout the New York metropolitan area planning sermons on the themes that dominate the sacred day of fasting, introspection, prayer and repentance.

title: Tiniest Transistor
description: The smallest transistors ever made of silicon have been produced by researchers through X-ray techniques at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the university said today.

title: A CITY'S SIMPLE WISH: 'TO RETURN TO NORMAL'
description: Mexico's capital shook itself awake today, dented and shaken. But within an hour, crowds of office workers, long lines of traffic and the buzz of sidewalk life all indicated that the city and its people were recovering with unusual speed and grace.

title: McEnroe, Borg To Play Match
description: John McEnroe and Bjorn Borg will play one of the six tennis exhibition matches in their world tour on Nov. 14 at the Met Center in Bloomington, sponsors of the match said today.

title: DEFECTOR MAKES QUICK JUMP TO N.H.L.
description: They were sitting in a room on the 40th floor of a West German hotel - the American hockey team official and the man on the verge of a new career, a new country and a new life.

title: SOFTWARE AG SYSTEMS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Bridge: Close Attention to Bidding Helps Determine Lead Suit
description: Careful attention to the bidding will often serve to solve opening lead problems. When two suits are equally attractive on the surface, clues to the distribution of the opposing hands may be available.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE LATIN LOOK A brisk midtown stroll can lead to the handsome landmark mansions at Park Avenue and 68th Street, and a stroller who enters No. 680, the Center for Inter-American Relations, at the corner, will be brought into the 19th century as it appeared to photographers south of the border. ''Latin America Last Century: Photographs From the Hoffenberg Collection'' is the new show in the main-floor gallery. It is a fascinating retrospective look at a world little known to most of us.

title: The Villain Isn't Always Our Society
description: POISON, poison everywhere -in the air we breathe, in the water and food we consume, in the ground beneath our feet. Each day there's some new horror on television or in print: leaks from chemical plants, spills from wrecked trucks and trains, toxic fumes from industrial fires, electrical transformers that dump PCB's, school ceilings that shed asbestos, nuclear reactors oozing radioactive isotopes, mutagenic ''spy dust'' sprinkled by Soviet agents. The list seems endless.

title: NEW ZEALAND ASKING 'MILLIONS' FROM FRANCE
description: Prime Minister David Lange said today that he would demand reparations from France for material damage and for ''the affront to the sovereignty of New Zealand'' in the sinking of an antinuclear protest ship.

title: Eyes on Oklahoma
description: One of the Senate seats that the Democrats increasingly think they have a chance to take away from the Republicans next year is in Oklahoma. The seat is currently held by Don Nickles of Ponca City, a conservative.

title: COLUMBIA REPRIMANDS COACH
description: Jim Garrett, the Columbia football coach, was reprimanded by university officials yesterday for harsh remarks he made about his team after the season-opening loss to Harvard on Saturday.

title: PHYSICIAN, HEAL THYSELF
description: The injury report for next weekend's pro football games will not be issued until tomorrow, but what is already certain is that few players came out of Sunday's schedule more badly racked up than one man whose duty is to tend to those players. Physician, heal thyself.

title: ON DINING, TRAVELING AND EGGS
description: It has been 20 years since a sheriff's posse used clubs and whips and tear gas to drive back a line of civil rights marchers trying to cross the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma, Ala.

title: SCHOOL STANDARDS: U.S. INQUIRY ON MINORITIES DRAWS SUSPICION
description: By announcing an investigation of whether high schools have lowered graduation standards for minority students, the Justice Department focused new attention on one of the most sensitive and complex issues in education.

title: REAGAN AND MUBARAK DIFFER ON P.L.O.
description: President Reagan reiterated today that the United States was willing to meet with the Palestine Liberation Organization if it accepted two United Nations resolutions and the right of Israel to exist.

title: Required Reading;   Cigarettes and the Deficit
description: Gov. James J. Blanchard of Michigan, in a letter sent Sept. 11 to all governors, with a copy to President Reagan, regarding the nation's economic health:

title: TRADE-IN PLAN: HALF MAY GO FOR TRANSIT
description: New York City officials said yesterday that under a tentative formula, at least half of the $1.7 billion in Westway trade-in funds would eventually go to mass-transit projects.

title: CARDS RALLY AGAIN
description: Terry Pendleton of St. Louis tripled home two runs with two outs in the eighth inning, giving the Cardinals a 5-4 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.

title: DECISION DATA COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CHEMICALS CALLED HAZARDOUS BY U.S.
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that two chemicals, ethylene oxide and chloroform, would be listed as hazardous air pollutants under the Clean Air Act.

title: GENERAL MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 25
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $11 million.

title: MITTERRAND' WORST CRISIS
description: Almost throughout what has come to be called the Greenpeace affair, one figure in France has remained conspicuously detached, reserved, even aloof. He has rarely made public statements, has submitted to no press conferences, and has generally appeared to stay above the fray.

title: Literary Games in Moscow
description: After two rounds of boycott, Americans are again represented at Moscow's international book fair, exhibiting normally forbidden fruit to hungry patrons in exchange for adding luster to the event. That's the tacit bargain, and it is probably worth making, but not if the Soviet Government persists in censoring not only the books to be shown but also the American delegates who accompany them.

title: CARTER HOMER POWERS METS
description: The Mets began 10 fateful days on the road tonight with a team meeting called by George Foster, who stood in the locker room and delivered the word: Don't give up, don't think the St. Louis Cardinals ''can walk on water.''

title: THE UNITED NATIONS AND NEW YORK CITY: A 40-YEAR LOVE-HATE RELATIONSHIP
description: To some New Yorkers, the United Nations is an important institution that makes the city the capital of the world; to others, it is one that should be transported somewhere across the sea.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I do not belong to the ranks of pessimists who claim that the days of the United Nations are numbered.

title: Foote, Cone Makes Another Paris Move
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, which already owns two ad agencies in Paris, has reached an agreement to purchase a majority interest in a third, Effivente, with 1985 billings of about $18 million. The operation will be renamed EFFI/ FCB and will continue under the leadership of Michel L. Hopitault, its founder and president.

title: Small Change
description: Ann Meyers, a four-time all-America basketball star at U.C.L.A., was one of four inductees at the Women's Sports Foundation's Hall of Fame ceremonies yesterday at the Plaza, where she echoed what has become a frequent complaint among female athletes.

title: Uganda Soldiers Said to Loot Town
description: Uganda's second-largest city, Jinja, was paralyzed today after Government troops looted shops and homes, according to reports reaching here.

title: New Plant Closings At Hewlett-Packard
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, extending a series of plant closings because of a sharp downturn in the computer industry, said yesterday that it would close all of its non-sales facilities during the Thanksgiving and Christmas holiday weeks, affecting 45,000 employees.

title: BALANCE COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,192 for the latest first quarter and $4,610 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: Prices Stable in Europe
description: Consumer prices in the European Economic Community were unchanged in August from the month before, putting prices 5.5 percent higher than the level of a year earlier, the trade bloc said today. It was the first time in the 27-year history of the Common Market that the monthly consumer price index did not rise, the organization's statistics office said. The office said prices fell last month in Luxembourg, West Germany and Denmark, while there was no change or slight increases in the seven other member countries and in Spain and Portugal, which are to become Common Market members in January.

title: ARC INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $28,500. c-Net loss

title: MOTORCADES AND CELEBRITY-GAZING SLOW EAST-SIDE TRAFFIC TO A CRAWL
description: Traffic was extremely heavy and moved at a crawl on many East Side streets around the United Nations headquarters yesterday as the 40th meeting of the General Assembly got under way. The congestion was expected to be even worse today, traffic officials said.

title: East Meets the F.D.A.
description: Another attempt to bring tiger fugu to New York is under way. And the arrival of this delicate and potentially dangerous Japanese blowfish has sent a frisson through the gastronomic world.

title: Nature, Not Man, Was First to Make Plutonium
description: To the Editor:

title: Baboon Tests Are Halted
description: University of Pennsylvania officials said today that they have reprimanded researchers responsible for head-injury research on baboons and have indefinitely suspended all such research using primates at the medical school.

title: Steel Company Resignations
description: The Continental Steel Corporation said its chairman and seven outside directors had resigned from its 12-member board after the company decided it could not afford to renew its directors' and officers' liability insurance.

title: AT U.N. ASSEMBLY HALL, PLEAS FOR PEACE
description: Representatives of some member countries told the General Assemby today that while the United Nations might have lost some its prestige and support, it was time for all to make a renewed commitment to the organization's mandate to promote peace.

title: FIGURING OUT THE JETS IS A DIFFICULT TASK
description: Attempting to figure the performance of the Jets from week to week has been a fruitless obsession - perhaps something like trying to grab the new, slippery jerseys the defensive line unveiled in Sunday's 24-3 victory over the Green Bay Packers.

title: Pigs and Puberty
description: Pigs must be raised in groups of three or more in order to reach puberty on time, according to a study by the Agricultural Research Service in Clay Center, Neb.

title: Business and the Law;   Class Actions: A Key Ruling
description: DEFENSE lawyers often attack the plaintiffs' bar for ''forum shopping.'' Much of that criticism is reserved for class action attorneys, who are often accused of scouring the nation for the best states to bring their huge suits in.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Sacramento, Calif., in some copies on Sept. 14 about the California Board of Education's rejection of science textbooks, over what was called inadequate treatment of evolution, gave an incorrect date for a ruling by Federal District Judge William Overton overturning Arkansas' requirement that the Biblical theory of creation be taught along with evolution. The ruling was made in January 1982.

title: Clouding the Issue Of Blacks' Needs
description: The vitriolic exchange between Reagan Administration officials and black leaders, who charged each other with racism, has clouded the question of how blacks feel about a range of social and political issues.

title: Jays Lead Yanks by 6
description: Jesse Barfield hit his 25th home run of the season, and Jim Clancy and Tom Henke combined on a five-hitter tonight to help lead the Toronto Blue Jays to a 5-1 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: DOLLAR PLUNGES TO 16-MONTH LOW IN REACTION TO 5 NATIONS' ACCORD
description: The dollar yesterday recorded its largest one-day drop in the 12-year history of floating currency rates as traders predicted that governments would take sterner action to depress the dollar.

title: STANDARD MICROSYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a disc tax credit of $460,000.

title: NEW OFFER FOR SCM IS REJECTED
description: Hanson Trust P.L.C., the British conglomerate, said yesterday that it had told the SCM Corporation that it was willing to buy the big American food and pigments company for more than $900 million - if SCM broke a contract to sell two key operations to Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Apple Sues Ex-Chief Over Computer Venture
description: Apple Computer Inc. today filed suit against its former chairman, Steven P. Jobs, in connection with his attempts to set up a new computer company staffed by five former Apple employees. The suit, which had been threatened by Apple for more than a week, also names Richard A. Page, one of the five Apple employees who resigned from the company to join Mr. Jobs in his new venture.

title: WINE
description: According to a recent survey, 30 percent of all French people over the age of 10 never drink wine. At the same time some 28 percent of the French population over age 10 think of wine purely as a drink to be served on special occasions.

title: UNDERCOVER REPORTERS ON ABC'S 'INSIDERS'
description: IF you tuned into ''Hollywood Beat'' on ABC last Saturday, you found a new weekly series about two young men conducting their undercover investigations in a series of disguises. If you tune into ''The Insiders'' tonight at 8 o'clock on ABC, you will find a new weekly series about two young men doing more or less the same thing. The difference? On ''Hollywood Beat,'' the heroes are policemen; on ''The Insiders,'' they are newspaper reporters, ''undercover'' newspaper reporters. So much for variety and imagination over at ABC these days.

title: Revlon Rejects Reduced Offer
description: Revlon Inc. yesterday rejected a reduced offer previously announced by Pantry Pride Inc. to acquire the cosmetic and health care company for $1.36 billion, or $42 a share. Revlon said the offer was ''grossly inadequate and not in the interest of Revlon shareholders.''

title: Oil Project Loan Set
description: The Synthetic Fuels Corporation today awarded $60 million in subsidies for an oil project in Texas despite a supposed understanding with the White House that no grants would be approved until President Reagan decides whether he wants the agency abolished.

title: Winning War on Weeds
description: To the Editor:

title: ECONOMIC GROWTH SEEN BY SPRINKEL IN TAX PLAN
description: President Reagan's tax revision proposals would lead to substantial long-term growth in the American economy and allow millions of new jobs to be created over the next decade, the President's Council of Economic Advisers said today.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Seve Ballesteros, the Spanish golfer who has appeared in only nine P.G.A. tournaments this year, said he would not attain the 15-tournament minimum needed to retain his membership in the tour next year but expressed hope that tour officials would find a way to allow him to play in about 10 tournaments in 1986. . . . Duriel Harris, a receiver who played for the Miami Dolphins from 1976 to 1983, has rejoined the team after being cut by the Dallas Cowboys. . . . The Green Bay Packers announced the signing of the free agent Jim Zorn. Zorn, 32 years old, played 10 years with Seattle before being released Sept. 2. . . . The Dallas Mavericks signed first-round draft pick, Detlef Schrempf, to a four-year contract.

title: Sovran in Accord With Suburban
description: The Sovran Financial Corporation said its board and the board of Suburban Bancorp had approved an agreement to merge Suburban into Sovran in a transfer of shares valued at $405 million.

title: Iran vs. Iraq - A Personal Feud
description: The fifth year of the Iran-Iraq war has come to an end and the prospect for peace appears dimmer than ever before. The war has settled into a desperate stalemate, but the antagonists remain unwilling to compromise, largely because the confrontation is ultimately a personal feud between two totalitarian rulers, the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and President Saddam Hussein, who exercise overwhelming power with impunity.

title: PAYOFFS AT T.C.U. LISTED BY BOOSTER
description: Dick Lowe, the Fort Worth oil man who has revealed that he and other alumni had helped subsidize seven football players who have been suspended at Texas Christian University, says he cannot remember the precise amounts all the college athletes at the school received to play football over the last five years. But, ''a good blue chip running back,'' he explained, would bring $10,000 to $25,000 in cash, plus a car and $1,000 a month spending money.

title: So Thin the Skin
description: After I reported sighting a lot of derelicts passed out in Manhattan gutters, five New Yorkers wrote angry letters. Five doesn't seem like many letters for a city of 7,071,639 people, unless you are in the writing business, but in the writing business, five letters is heavy mail and very encouraging. It means only 7,071,634 people would rather watch television than read.

title: ART: PARIS CELEBRATES PICASSO
description: Of the inauguration of the Picasso Museum in Paris Monday afternoon and evening, it can be said that not since the end of World War II has the Parisian art world lived through so happy a day.

title: Rose Chasing Cobb Again
description: The Rose-vs.-Cobb rivalry, considered dead once Pete got his 4,192d career hit two weeks ago today, is in fact not quite.

title: VALLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
FILM: 'THE TOKYO TRIAL'
description: ''THE TOKYO TRIAL'' is a 4 1/2-hour account of the International Military Tribunal for the Far East that is visually satisfying but historically empty. Masaki Kobayashi, the director, himself a prisoner of war, has interspersed the trial scenes with bits from World War II archives that, granted the importance of the trial itself, seem largely irrelevant.

title: Debt Ratings Cut for Five
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered the debt ratings yesterday of five forest products companies, affecting some $4.4 billion of outstanding debt.

title: What Farm Aid Can't Deliver
description: Last July's Live Aid concert for African famine relief demonstrated the power of show business talent to tap America's generosity. No surprise, then, that it should be followed by last Sunday's Farm Aid concert, a similar affair to raise money for struggling farmers.

title: Heart Recipient Worsens
description: Michael Drummond, the former artificial heart patient, was put back on a respirator today as his condition worsened to serious, officials said. Mr. Drummond, 25 years old, who received a human heart Sept. 7 after being kept alive for nine days on a mechanical Jarvik-7 heart, had been listed in fair condition. He experienced difficulty breathing today and his blood pressure was unstable.

title: SELLING THE GREEN BOOK AND MUCH MORE
description: EVER wonder what happened to the giant cast-iron seals that once graced the West Side Highway? The tokens the city minted for a prospective fare increase that never took place? Or the steel mesh wastebaskets on New York street corners that were recently replaced by containers painted bright orange?

title: A COUNCILMAN FROM QUEENS
description: Walter H. Crowley, a member of the City Council from Queens, died yesterday at his home in Elmhurst. He was 53 years old.

title: GENERAL INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
description: b-Net income.

title: Church Gives Millions In Antipoverty Grants
description: The United States Catholic Conference, deploring what it said was ''a laissez-faire approach to capitalism'' that perpetuated poverty, today announced more than $6.5 million in grants and loans to self-help projects.

title: TO NEW YORKERS, BORDER WAR WITH JERSEY HAS CLAIMED A VICTIM: WESTWAY
description: In the annals of Manhattan, they may write someday that a project called Westway was the biggest casualty in the border wars between New York and New Jersey.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: GALAPAGOS. By Kurt Vonnegut. 295 pages. Delacorte Press/Seymour Lawrence. $16.95. WITH ''Galapagos,'' the author's 11th novel, we're back in familiar Vonnegut territory: the subject is the end of the world (or at least the end of the world as we know it); the objects of lamentation are man's cruelty to man, contemporary society, modern technology and, of course, the horrors of war - World War II and Vietnam, as well as the more generic variety. Although there are no singsong refrains like ''hippity hop,'' ''hi ho'' or ''so it goes,'' the narrative voice still has the quality of a verbal shrug - flip, careless and willfully casual (''the people would eat up all the food, gobble, gobble, yum, yum, and it would become nothing but excrement and memories''), and the characters still bear more of a resemblance to cartoon figures than regular human beings. The narrator is a Vietnam veteran named Leon who happens to be the son of the erstwhile Kilgore Trout, the hero of ''God Bless You, Mr. Rosewater'' and ''Breakfast of Champions.''

title: POSTAL INCREASE HELD UNLIKELY
description: The United States Postal Service said today that cost-cutting measures had reduced its operating deficit by more than half and predicted that no increases in the rates for mailing cards, letters and packages would be necessary for at least two years.

title: Children of Mexico
description: The Capital Children's Museum, which has featured an exhibit of arts and crafts from Mexico for the past five years, is organizing its own special relief effort for young survivors of the Mexican earthquakes.

title: Northern Israel Is Hit By Katyusha Rockets
description: Missiles fired from Lebanon struck northern Israel Monday night, causing slight property damage but no casualties, military sources said today.

title: AMERON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
10-Day Car Sales Rise By 32.3% From '84 Level
description: Sales of new American made cars began to slow in mid-September from the frenzied levels of previous weeks but still managed a strong gain, the nation's major auto makers reported today.

title: Paul Mann, 71, Dead; An Actor and Teacher
description: Paul Mann, actor, teacher and director, died of a stroke yesterday in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 71 years old and lived in New York City. Best known as an acting coach, he was the founder and director of the Paul Mann Actors Workshop in New York.

title: DECOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
COURT BACKS F.D.A. APPROVAL OF SWEETNER
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that the Government had followed proper procedures in approving the use of aspartame, a low-calorie sugar substitute.

title: QUAKE WAS LESS CRIPLLING THAN FEARED
description: Six days after the first of two major earthquakes rocked Mexico City the extent of damage to the capital is beginning to be seen in less catastrophic terms than many had feared in the immediate aftermath of the disaster.

title: Economic Scene;   Rating Banks For Insurance
description: A SHARP rise in bank failures during the past few years has put the spotlight on the multibillion-dollar funds that insure depositors against loss: the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

title: Top-Level Promotions At American Brands
description: American Brands Inc. said yesterday that it will restructure responsibilities among a number of its top executives, effective Jan. 1.

title: 'Funny Kind Of Coalition' On Textiles
description: Labor and management have fought a number of brushfire wars across the South in recent years over the unionization of textile mills. But on Capitol Hill these days, the old antagonists are working closely together on a common problem: protecting the textile industry from a flood of foreign imports.

title: BALDRIGE SAYS A VETO OF A TEXTILE BILL WILL PREVAIL
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige predicted today that the Senate would sustain a Presidential veto of a bill to curb textile imports that Congress is expected to pass in a few weeks.

title: PAYCHEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
32d Victim of Coast Killer
description: The name of Mary Exzetta West, a 16-year-old girl whose skeletal remains were found this month in a Seattle park, was added today to the list of victims of a now believed responsible for 32 deaths.

title: AZTEC MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income.

title: ERIC DICKERSON KEEPS HIS PROMISES
description: On his opening night, two weeks later than most National Football League employees had theirs, Eric Dickerson kept his word. The Los Angeles Rams' tailback predicted that he would be ready (''I'll be no slouch,'' he had said) despite only four days of practice and two days of study halls.

title: CARDS KEEP STREAK GOING
description: Terry Pendleton singled home two runs in the first inning, and the St. Louis Cardinals scored twice more on a third-inning Pittsburgh error tonight to gain their fifth straight triumph, a 5-4 decision over the Pirates.

title: Off-Duty Guard Kills 2 And Commits Suicide
description: An off-duty state corrections officer shot and killed the woman he lived with and her brother early yesterday and then shot himself to death after tossing the key to his Brooklyn apartment to police officers, according to a police spokesman.

title: Barbie Asks Release; Refers to Greenpeace
description: Klaus Barbie, the Gestapo chief of Lyons, asked the French Government today to release him on the ground that he had been following orders just like the French agents who sank a ship of the antinuclear group Greenpeace in New Zealand.

title: LA QUINTA MOTOR INNS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Groups Taking Aid Donations
description: American Friends Service Committee, Mexico Earthquake Relief, 1501 Cherry Street, Philadelphia, Pa. 19102. (215) 241-7141. American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, Mexico Relief, Room 1914, 60 East 42d Street, New York, N.Y. 10165. American Jewish World Service, 1290 Avenue of the Americas, Suite 1276, New York, N.Y. 10104.

title: HOWARD JOHNSON ACQUIRED
description: The Marriott Corporation and Prime Motor Inns Inc., two of the nation's leading hotel companies, said yesterday that they would buy the Howard Johnson Company from its British parent for $314 million.

title: ARMOR TO BE AUCTIONED
description: A custom-made Colt revolver, two complete safari suits and the elbow joint from a medieval suit of armor are three of 147 items scheduled to be sold Oct. 8 at Christie's in a benefit auction to raise money for the arms and armor department of the Metropolitan Museum.

title: Ruffles and the Deficit
description: Political orchestration is one of Washington's more occult sciences, visible in its outward manifestations but prearranged behind the scenes with considerable skill and industry. Take the release of a new 275-page book, ''The U.S. Trade Deficit: Impact and Implications,'' that Touche Ross, the accouting concern, is presenting in the capital this week with ruffles and flourishes.

title: I.M.F. Posts Net Deficit
description: The International Monetary Fund today reported its first net deficit from operations in nearly a decade, reflecting the delinquency in repayments by four countries.

title: SCOTT & FETZER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a $2,265,000 gain on the disposition of discontinued operations.

title: Letter: On Police;   Holding On to the Finest
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Scarcity of Bay Scallops The problems that have beset bay scallops in New York State, where the season opened on Sept. 16, have been widely reported. Brown algae have destroyed the beds in Little and Great Peconic Bays, normally one of the state's major sources, starving and suffocating the shellfish there. The algae present no human health problem but are devastating to scallops.

title: Real Estate;   An Arcade Replacing Dubrow's
description: INSTEAD of boiled chicken and blintzes there may be croissants, pasta and frozen yogurt, but come spring, workers in the garment district will be eating in Dubrow's again. A food-oriented arcade will open in the space on Seventh Avenue near 38th Street where the cafeteria had served stick-to-the-ribs Jewish-style meals for more than 30 years.

title: MET OPERA: SEASON PREMIERE
description: BEYOND opera there is grand opera, and beyond that a separate category that may be called grandiose opera, a perfect example of which the Metropolitan Opera presented Monday night with a heavy-handed performance of Franco Zeffirelli's ''Tosca'' to open its 1985-86 season. This is the visually spectacular version of the Puccini work that astonished and gratified Met audiences last season with its opulent decor, ingenious stage machinery and larger-than-life dimensions, and an unusually dressy first-night audience seemed to find the sets no less to its liking on this occasion.

title: COMMODORE INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $15.1 million for the quarter and $10.7 million for the year. c-Net income. The latest quarter loss included an inventory writedown of about $63 million, and certain one-time charges against income of $14 million.

title: CRITICIZED PUNTER PASSES UP PRACTICE
description: A business-as-usual approach at the Columbia football practice yesterday failed to answer two questions the Lions must eventually face.

title: MEXICANS LINK DAMAGE IN QUAKE TO BREACHES OF CITY BUILDING CODE
description: A group of intellectuals and many architects here say they believe that a number of buildings destroyed or heavily damaged in the two earthquakes last week had been built in violation of the city's building codes.

title: How to Get Tough With Nerve Gas
description: Nerve gas is a hideous weapon, but as long as Soviet troops are equipped with chemical munitions, American troops cannot be denied an effective response. That's why the Defense Department's plan to build a new generation of chemical arms - so-called ''binary'' weapons - is so dismaying. Never mind their vast extra cost, their destabilizing effect on NATO or the initiation of a new race in chemical arms; the new binary weapons will be less effective.

title: Pricing Is Set In Louisiana Issue
description: A $181.6 million issue of Louisiana general obligation bonds was priced yesterday, through underwriters led by the Bankers Trust Company, which submitted the winning bid in competition for the financing.

title: Hurricane in Atlantic Threatens East Coast
description: Hurricane Gloria, a major storm with winds nearing 150 miles an hour, gathered strength tonight and forecasters warned that it could strike anywhere from the Carolinas to New England.

title: SOVIET MINISTER, AT THE U.N., PUSHES A 'STAR WARS' BAN
description: The Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, said today that his Government was determined to reach an agreement with the United States that would ban space defense weapons as well as achieve ''truly radical reductions'' in existing nuclear arsenals.

title: The Last Rule
description: Manager Whitey Herzog of the St. Louis Cardinals discloses his prescription for insomnia: ''I read the rule book. After five minutes of obstruction and interference, I'm fast asleep.''

title: NAVY SECRETARY FINDS CRITICS AT FAULT FOR SECURITY LAPSES
description: Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. acknowledged today that Navy internal security had grown lax, but he said Congress and journalists were to blame because they diverted Navy investigators' attention to minor fraud cases and demanded that the Navy focus on improving combat readiness.

title: MODERN FARM AID TO EASE THE CRISIS
description: The Farm Aid concert held here Sunday is expected to raise tens of millions of dollars to help ease the plight of financially strapped farmers. That may sound like a considerable sum, but it will hardly solve the problems that beset American agriculture.

title: NEW SOVIET FOREIGN MINISTER IS MAKING GOOD IMPRESSION AT U.N. ASSEMBLY
description: When the Soviet Foreign Minister realized that he was going to be 12 minutes late for a noon meeting with the President of Uruguay, he was concerned that he might offend his host, who has a reputation for punctuality.

title: PLAYERS WANT ROLE FOR UNION IN TESTS
description: Within hours after Peter Ueberroth, the commissioner of baseball, bypassed the Major League Players Association yesterday and issued a direct appeal for players to volunteer for drug tests, many players indicated that they would submit to such tests - but only if they were approved by the union.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: FOR more than three million American children, the sounds of birds singing, music playing and people talking are seriously muted or distorted by a defect in hearing, and each year 4,000 more children are born into a world of near silence.

title: Walter Reade
description: The Walter Reade Organization Inc., an operator of 11 motion picture theaters in Manhattan, said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to sell to Columbia Pictures Industries the balance of its shares not already owned by Columbia. The transaction was valued at about $19.9 million. Columbia, a subsidiary of the Coca-Cola Company, already owns 41.7 percent of Walter Reade's 5.5 million shares.

title: CHEATING ON BUS FARES PUT AT $23 MILLION A YEAR
description: The Transit Authority loses more than $23 million a year because of shortchanging by passengers when they board city buses, according to a report released yesterday by the inspector general of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: FERNANDEZ ALLOWS 2 HITS AND FANS 9 AS METS TRIUMPH
description: The Mets kept racing down the homestretch in pursuit of the St. Louis Cardinals tonight, and they did it in style: Sid Fernandez pitched a sizzling two-hitter with nine strikeouts that stopped the Philadelphia Phillies, 7-1.

title: Agca Changes Account Of How He Got Pistols
description: Mehmet Ali Agca changed his testimony today on how he got the pistol he used to wound Pope John Paul II, saying he now did not remember.

title: Turkish and Soviet Ships Collide in the Bosporus
description: The Turkish naval assault ship Meltem broke up after colliding with a Soviet naval support vessel in the Bosporus today, but there were no casualties, the state television said.

title: Tucker Signs Contract
description: Trent Tucker, the sharp-shooting Knick guard, has signed a new multiyear contract, the club announced yesterday.

title: 'STAR WARS': HOW THE TERM AROSE
description: President Reagan first outlined his program for a space-based defense against incoming missiles during a televised speech on March 23, 1983.

title: Stumbling to Geneva
description: President Reagan's casual public remarks and even some of his carefully edited speeches are causing him trouble again as he tries to deal with the control of world trade and nuclear weapons.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Slayer of 10 Prostitutes Sought by Los Angeles
description: One killer apparently slew at least 10 prostitutes in two years, torturing them first and mutilating them afterward, the authorities said today.

title: Devils Deny Fund Woes
description: The Devils are not behind in their payments to the National Hockey League, John J. McMullen, the owner and chairman of the team, said yesterday in response to a claim by Alan Eagleson, the executive director of the players' union.

title: INTEGRATING SCHOOLS ON L.I.: STATE ACTS IN AN UNUSUAL SITUATION
description: The integration order issued by the state recently against the Sewanhaka Central High School District on Long Island is the first attempt in nearly a decade by New York education officials to mandate racially balanced schools.

title: BUDGET NOMINEE GIVES VIEW ON CUTS
description: President Reagan's nominee to head the Office of Management and Budget, James C. Miller 3d, indicated today that he would pursue Federal spending cuts with as much intensity as David A. Stockman, his predecessor, and would not rule out trying to curb retirement and health insurance programs.

title: COOKWARE MADE OF CAST IRON
description: CAST iron, one of the oldest materials for pots and pans, still has a place in this modern era of stainless steel and sophisticated alloys. Its major benefit is its ability to retain heat for a long time and distribute it evenly.

title: CHINA APPOINTS 5 NEWCOMERS TO RULING POLITBURO
description: The Communist Party appointed five newcomers to its ruling Politburo today, among them two men in their mid-50's who are widely regarded here as possible leaders of China after the current hierarchy under Deng Xiaoping steps down.

title: Steel Union Agrees to Talks
description: Union officials agreed today to resume contract negotiations Monday with the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation. The strike by the United Steelworkers of America has idled 8,200 workers in Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia since July 21, when a bankruptcy judge gave the company permission to void its contract with the union.
