The company filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act last April.

title: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
description: A SUMMIT WARM-UP - The most discussed and most influential event at this year's General Assembly session is a meeting that will take place in Geneva, not New York. Thatis the meeting in November between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader. The official warm-up begins today when Secretary of State George P. Shultz sits down with Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the Soviet Foreign Minister, for a four-hour chat.

title: BIG WEEK FOR TV'S BIG 2
description: History, went the title of an old movie, is made at night, and on television it's even more specific: it's made on Wednesdays and Fridays when ''Dynasty'' and ''Dallas'' are broadcast.

title: FEDERAL PAPER BOARD CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 7
Marwick Ends Hurdman Talks
description: Preliminary merger talks between Peat Marwick, the nation's second-largest accounting firm, and KMG Main Hurdman, the ninth largest, were terminated yesterday after three days of negotations in Amsterdam between officials of the firms' international organizations.

title: FROM ENVOYS TO GUIDES, NEW ENERGY AT THE U.N.
description: The hot dog man in front of the United Nations declined - ''categorically'' - yesterday to cooperate further with ''the worldwide media,'' charging that reporters have ''continually misrepresented'' his positions on foreign affairs.

title: San Diego Mayor Calls No Witnesses in Trial
description: The defense in the case of Mayor Roger Hedgecock rested today without calling a witness, stunning the court in the retrial of the Mayor on charges that he accepted illegal contributions for his 1983 campaign and then lied about it.

title: U.S. SAYS NATIONS ARE NOT DESTROYING DRUG CROPS
description: A new State Department report on worldwide drug production says that most major drug-producing nations continue promising to eradicate their marijuana, coca or opium-poppy crops while actually doing little or nothing toward that end.

title: Plowed Under
description: The Garden of Eden, a cause celebre on the Lower East Side that came to symbolize residents versus bureaucrats, was demolished yesterday, after months of protest and court action.

title: Jobs Calls Apple Suit 'a Shock'
description: Steven P. Jobs, the former chairman of Apple Inc. said today that a lawsuit Apple filed against him over his attempt to set up a new computer company was ''absurd and a shock.'' He said he had offered to agree in writing that his new company would not hire masses of Apple employees or use Apple's proprietary technology.

title: A GADFLY FOR ENVIRONMENTAL CAUSES
description: Since its inception 14 years ago in Vancouver, British Columbia, the Greenpeace environmental organization has served as a gadfly on issues ranging from whaling to nuclear testing, from acid rain to the disposal of toxic wastes.

title: BLASIUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including tax credit of $88,000. c-Including tax credit of $180,000 and loss from discontinued operations of $42,000.

title: SPEAKERS AT U.N. ASK ARM CONTROL
description: Seeking to promote disarmament, leaders from northern Europe, the Balkans and the South Pacific today advocated banning nuclear weapons from their regions.

title: Long, Long Way
description: George Steinbrenner, taking his time and gathering his facts before deciding what to do about the Martin-Whitson off-the-field confrontation, has rarely been so careful in assessing on-the-field performance. The latest shot from the hip came little more than a week ago, when the boss belittled Dave Winfield as a ''Mr. May,'' suggesting that what the Yankees needed again was a ''Mr. October, or Mr. September'' - i.e., Reggie Jackson.

title: Give Drugs to Addicts
description: To the Editor:

title: DELAWARE BASIN UNIT REPORTS A WORSENING OF DROUGHT'S EFFECTS
description: The Delaware River Basin Commission said today that drought conditions were worsening throughout the four-state basin area.

title: $115 Million Bonds From New Mexico
description: A $115 million New Mexico offering of severance-tax bonds was priced yesterday, through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Jays' Lead At Seven
description: Dennis Lamp (11-0) pitched 4 Z innings of shutout relief and the Toronto Blue Jays scored two runs on wild throws to beat the Red Sox tonight, 6-2. They lead the Yankees by seven games.

title: Japan Pledges Trade Effort
description: Japanese officials, hoping to avoid harsh protectionist measures, said today that they would cooperate with the trade policy outlined by President Reagan Monday.

title: Sharp Words
description: When last we left City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin and Mayor Koch, their on-again, off-again political relationship was on-again.

title: EASTERN SHUTTLE ABORTS TAKEOFF FROM WASHINGTON
description: An Eastern Airlines shuttle plane bound for New York's La Guardia Airport from the Washington National Airport was forced to abort its takeoff this afternoon when a helicopter crossed the path of the plane, Federal aviation officials said.

title: INTERSTATE BAKERIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 24
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $779,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $439,000.

title: TRYING FOR 300TH, NIEKRO LOSES 250TH
description: This can not be Phil Niekro's idea of history. Instead of becoming the 18th pitcher in major league history to win 300 games, Niekro last night became the seventh to lose 250. He is finding each defeat more difficult to accept.

title: Borrowed Pandas
description: A day after Mayor Koch made a pitch to Chinese officials for two pandas for the Bronx Zoo, New York Zoological Society officials said pandas would be coming - but only for a visit.

title: POREX TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $3,683,000. c-After a loss of $3,462,000 on disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Back on the Air
description: If followers of Met telecasts who have no access to cable are wondering what ever happened to Dwight Gooden, they have sufficient cause. The last time Dr. K. appeared on over-the-air TV was Aug. 25, when he posted his 20th victory.

title: POMP AND PAGEANTRY AT MET OPENING PARTY
description: THE pageantry didn't stop on stage at the opening of the Metropolitan Opera's new season. A festive scene on the Met's grand tier and dress circle included a lavish supper party and Chanel fashion show that did not end until well after midnight.

title: QED EXPLORATION reports earnings for Year to July 31
NBC Journalists' Deaths Are Ruled Accidental
description: A police coroner said today that two NBC News journalists who died covering an attempted coup were killed accidentally by rebel soldiers.

title: No Headline
description: Mark Canton has been appointed president of worldwide theatrical production at Warner Brothers, it was announced today by Robert A. Daley, the chairman of Warner Brothers Inc., and Terry Semel, the company's president.

title: PEKING, IN A SURPRISE, AGREES TO NUCLEAR-PLANT INSPECTIONS
description: China today agreed to join the other four major nuclear powers in opening some of its civilian nuclear plants to international inspection and safeguards.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, the Charlotte Curtis column yesterday gave an incorrect telephone number for the J. M. Kaplan Fund. The number is (212) 661-8485.

title: ITT Strategy
description: Directors of the ITT Corporation have adopted restrictions on use of its salaried employees' retirement plan that are intended as a defense against an unwelcome takeover. Documents filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission said the company's board adopted amendments providing that for five years after a hostile acquisition the assets of the retirement plan could be used solely to pay for medical benefits. A company spokesman said the retirement plan has ''something less than $100 million in excess funds.''

title: SENATORS VISIT SHIPYARD AT GROTON TO CALM FEARS
description: In an effort to allay fears of layoffs and reduced military spending at the mammoth Electric Boat shipyard here, three members of the Senate Armed Services Committee toured the plant and spoke with dozens of its workers today.

title: EXCERPTS FROM U.N. SPEECHES BY SHULTZ AND SHEVARDNADZE
description: Following are excerpts from speeches at the General Assembly by Secretary of State George P. Shultz on Monday and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union today. Mr. Shevardnadze's speech was translated by the Soviet Mission. Shultz Speech Much of the conflict in the world today stems from the refusal of some governments to accept the reality that the aspirations of people for democracy and freedom simply cannot be suppressed forever by force.

title: 19 Flogged in Sudan
description: Nineteen southern Sudanese received 25 lashes each in a public courtyard next to a Khartoum court today for their part in street disturbances in the capital last Saturday, witnesses said.

title: ANTIMISSILE SHIELD HELD TO RAISE RISK OF A NUCLEAR WAR
description: The development of a defense against intercontinental missiles might make nuclear war between the United States and the Soviet Union more likely, analysts for Congress's Office of Technology Assessment concluded in a report made public today.

title: DOTRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SYDNEY H. EIGES
description: Sydney H. Eiges, a former vice president for public information of NBC, died of cancer last Friday at St. Mary's Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: EDWARD E. B. WEISS
description: Edward E. B. Weiss, former senior vice president of Doyle Dane Bernbach and a writer on advertising and marketing, died of cardiac arrest Monday at the Mary Manning Walsh Home in Manhattan. He was 86 years old.

title: Ranting and Raving Over Redskins
description: This city's basic art form, identifying with a winner, dissolved in a hail of boo's and recriminations last Sunday as the young men once hailed heroically as Smerfs, Hogs, and Joe the earnest victor all lost a football game.

title: DANCE: PINA BAUSCH'S 'KONTAKTHOF' IN MONTREAL
description: You need not have suffered through the wobbly high heels and tight strapless dresses of the 1950's to recognize what the women in Pina Bausch's dance-theater piece ''Kontakthof'' are communicating as they parade onstage in this attire for nearly three hours.

title: TAKING A SHORTCUT TO HOMEMADE BREAD
description: SPEED is certainly the keynote of most American kitchens today, as evidenced by all the labor-saving appliances now available: food processors, pasta machines, ice-cream makers, microwave ovens - anything that cuts preparatory and cooking time. The demand for dishes that are quick to fix is clear, too, in the increasing number of publications that tell readers how to turn out meals, soup to nuts, in minutes.

title: ROSTOPOVICH CONDUCTS AT WOLF TRAP ON PBS
description: MSTISLAV ROSTROPOVICH, probably the most highly regarded cellist after Pablo Casals, has yet to develop into a reliable orchestra leader. However, like many limited conductors, he has in his repertory certain works that he understands completely, and of which he is capable of leading extraordinary performances.

title: Gannett Plans Station Sales
description: The Gannett Company plans to sell three television stations and two radio stations to comply with Federal Communications Commission rules governing the company's acquisition of the Detroit-based Evening News Association.

title: 'QUIBBLING' CADET MAY BE SUSPENDED FROM AIR ACADEMY
description: The highest-ranking junior-class cadet at the Air Force Academy reportedly faces a year's suspension for ''quibbling,'' an offense that the academy authorities consider to be the same as lying.

title: Guerrillas in Uganda Attack Army Garrison Near Capital
description: Rebel guerrillas attacked a Government army garrison less than 10 miles west of Kampala today and exchanged mortar and rocket fire with troops north of the capital, Western diplomats said.

title: Restarting of Reactor Halted
description: Justice William J. Brennan Jr. of the United States Supreme Court today halted the scheduled restarting of an undamaged reactor at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant until at least noon Friday.

title: Le Watergate
description: As Yogi Berra said, it's ''deja vu all over again.'' In July, French agents in New Zealand sank the ship of a group protesting France's nuclear testing, killing a member of the crew. France ordered an inquiry that quickly acquitted the Government. The French press discovered that the truth lay elsewhere and the Defense Minister resigned. Now a flustered Government has confessed that it did in fact authorize the sabotage but won't say at what level. So people ask: What did President Mitterrand know, and when did he know it?

title: Ally to the End in Dr. King's Philosophy of Nonviolence
description: To the Editor:

title: ONE BROOKLYN STREET, MANY ETHNIC FLAVORS
description: BROOKLYN is a borough of well-defined neighborhoods, and Court Street is a chain that ties several of them together. From Brooklyn Heights to Red Hook, the languages heard on Court Street, whether Arabic, Italian or the cadences of Wall Street, reflect the traditions of these neighborhoods. In much the same way, the food along the street, in both shops and restaurants, is a rich amalgam from the generations of immigrants who have passed through.

title: WINE SCHOOL IN NEW YORK READY FOR A SEASON OF DIVERSITY
description: ALTHOUGH there remain a number of first-rate introductory courses that teach the basics of wine and wine tasting, the emphasis of many advanced wine courses in New York City nowadays is geared to pairing wines and foods, as Americans discover that, indeed, the two are meant for each other.

title: Cookie Shop Robber Hunted in High-Rise
description: One hundred police officers searched through a 35-story apartment building on East 72d Street for six hours last night for a man believed to have been one of a group that held up a cookie shop a block away.

title: Schools Getting the Books They Ask For
description: To the Editor:

title: SHUBERT ARCHIVE SORTS TREASURES OF THE STAGE
description: A word to anyone looking for the original script of ''The Whistling Oyster'': It's been found. The sheet music to ''The Girl and the Kaiser'' turned up, too. And, yes, the photograph of Maestro Buddy Swan, the child conductor of the ''Hellzapoppin'' pit band, has been unearthed.

title: More Trouble Than Usual
description: Looking for trouble spots in Brooklyn yesterday morning, Samuel I. Schwartz found more than he had bargained for.

title: Cetus Partnership
description: The Cetus Corporation announced the formation of a partnership with Ben Venue Laboratories Inc. to formulate, manufacture and market generic anti-cancer drugs worldwide. Cetus will market the products while Ben Venue, a private company based in Bedford, Ohio, will be responsible for formulation and manufacturing. Robert A. Fildes, Cetus's president and chief operating officer, said the partnership would offer a full line of chemotherapy drugs within the next 12 months, all of them off-patent.

title: Bid Made to Bar Press
description: The lawyer representing Joe Pepitone on drug charges asked a judge yesterday to bar the press from a hearing on his motion to dismiss charges against the former Yankee first baseman.

title: POLICE RAIDS NEAR CAPE TOWN
description: Heavily armed South African security officers sealed off three black townships around Cape Town today in what they said was an investigation into incidents of rioting.

title: U.S.-Japanese Trade Locked in a Prison of the Past
description: To the Editor:

title: LOCAL COSTS CLIMB 0.7%
description: Driven by higher costs for housing and clothing, consumer prices in New York and northeastern New Jersey increased by seven-tenths of 1 percent in August, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. Nationally, consumer prices rose by two-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A cloud hangs over baseball. It's a cloud called drugs and it's permeated our game.''

title: Drummed
description: Where else but in Washington would otherwise rational people pay $250 each to don formal evening dress, sit in a teepee-decorated hotel ballroom and watch Representative Morris K. Udall, the veteran Arizona Democrat, be drummed into the Comanche nation? This ancient initiation ritual takes place Oct. 3 at the Sheraton Washington Hotel as the highlight of a benefit for Americans for Indian Opportunity. The event enjoys bipartisan blessing, with the duties of host shared by the two Congressional majority leaders: Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, and Representative Jim Wright, Democrat of Texas.

title: DOLLAR THREATENS IMPORT BARGAINS
description: Customers of Zabar's on Manhattan's Upper West Side learned firsthand on Monday how a weakened dollar in the currency markets will pinch their wallets. Within hours of the plunge in value of the dollar in foreign exchange trading, the gourmet delicatessen and housewares emporium raised by 6 percent the price of fine Swiss cookware that had been set out for sale just three days earlier.

title: ELECTRIC GUITARS
description: ELECTRIC guitars. They weep, they wail, they blat, they skronk. Resourceful musicians have been wringing fresh sounds out of them since Eddie Durham, Bob Dunn, Charlie Christian and other pioneers began wiring their own pickups in the 1930's. After all this time, one might suppose their capabilities had been exhausted. But certain musicians are still getting undreamed-of sounds with nothing but an electric guitar and an amplifier.

title: OFFICIAL SAID TO HAVE ORDERED SHIP 'NEUTRALIZED'
description: A leading French newspaper said today that the order for French agents to take action against an antinuclear protest ship in New Zealand was given by Charles Hernu, who was then Defense Minister.

title: 5 CHINESE ON THE RISE
description: Hu Qili Tennis-playing intellectual who speaks English and often wears Western suits . . . Born in 1929 in Shaanxi Province . . . (Name pronounced hoo tshee lee) . . . Mechanical engineering graduate of Peking University, who joined the Communist Party while still a student in 1948 . . . Worked his way through ranks of the party's youth league, becoming a member of league secretariat in 1960's under Hu Yaobang, now party's General Secretary . . . Purged in 1966 as ''capitalist roader'' . . . Surfaced in 1972 as a party official in Ningxia-Hui . . . Brought back to Peking in 1978 as Young Communist League's general secretary and vice president of Peking's Qinghua University . . . Promoted to Central Committee and Secretariat in 1982.

title: Reining In a Display
description: Whenever he catches a touchdown pass, Billy (White Shoes) Johnson, the Atlanta Falcon receiver, gets so excited that he cannot keep his white shoes still.

title: Niceties From the Kremlin
description: If smooth protocol arrangements are any guide, the omens for the summit meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev in November are improving. An American interagency team has just returned from a preparatory session in Geneva impressed with how easily the Russians were working with the Americans on logistics and protocol.

title: A MEMOIR: WHEN THE U.N. WAS YOUNG
description: They were strange, those first years of the United Nations, so far back in the mid-40's and 50's, and sometimes quite wonderful.

title: MEDICAL CARE IN THE ARMED FORCES IS DEFENDED BY SURGEONS GENERAL
description: The top administrators of the American armed forces medical system, which treats 23,500 patients a day in 168 hospitals around the world, defended military medicine today, saying it was equal to civilian health care, if not better.

title: MICROPRO INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a $736,000 gain from a 1983 sale of stock. c-Net loss.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Centex Corp., a Dallas-based company with operations in home building, general construction and construction products, has named James E. Herndon chairman and chief executive officer of Center General Construction Cos. Also, Joe R. Walker has been appointed president of J. W. Bateson Co., another subsidiary.

title: Void Will Sometimes Fail To Deliver on Its Promise
description: In France it is a chicane, which smacks of chicanery. In English-speaking countries it is a void, which might seem an empty asset. But all over the world it rates to make several tricks if there are plenty of trumps available.

title: BURNS, PHILP CO LTD reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Results are in Australian dollars.

title: Advertising;   Magazine Tries New Campaigns
description: AN ''Under New Management'' sign is hardly necessary at The New Yorker magazine. Not when there are so many little happenings that say it quite clearly without a sign.

title: Ultra Poetry
description: Nathan Whiting, the 38-year-old Brooklyn poet who finished fifth in the Sri Chinmoy 1,000-mile road race in Flushing Meadow last May, has completed a lengthy work about the experience entitled ''Steps.'' He hopes that it ''gives an idea of what a long race is all about,'' but in any case it does give an idea of what Nathan Whiting is all about - someone who is clearly as given to ultramarathon poems as he is to ultramarathon runs: ''Steps'' goes on for 35 typewritten single-space pages.

title: I.B.M. TO REVAMP SALES FORCE
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, in its second major corporate reorganization in four years, said yesterday that it would revamp its two largest marketing organizations to make its sales force more efficient.

title: $100 Million Issue Offered by Seattle
description: Seattle is offering $100 million of electric-revenue bonds, through an underwriting group led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Peruvian Gets Rebuke From Shultz on I.M.F.
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz personally rebuked President Alan Garcia Perez of Peru today for his criticism of the International Monetary Fund in a General Assembly address, State Department officials said.

title: Internment Panel Is Told U.S. Hid Security Data
description: The United States Government concealed evidence showing that 120,000 Japanese-Americans interned in World War II detention camps posed no threat to national security, a Federal court was told today.

title: ARTS HIGH SCHOOL STILL INCOMPLETE
description: A year after it opened, the most expensive public high school ever built in New York City remains unfinished and troubled by design problems that have forced the Board of Education to curtail some classes for safety reasons and to order costly repairs.

title: Larry Shue, 39, Dies; Playwright and Actor
description: Larry Shue, a playwright and actor, was killed in the crash of a commuter airplane in Virginia's Shenandoah National Park on Monday morning. Mr. Shue was 39 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Detroit Tigers, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs.

title: MARTIN, WHITSON PUT BRAWL IN PAST
description: Billy Martin and Ed Whitson, the Yankee manager and pitcher who argued and fought late Saturday night in a Baltimore hotel, both tried to push the incident into the background yesterday at Yankee Stadium. But Martin, his broken right arm in a new cast, revealed that he had also sustained two cracked ribs in the altercation.

title: BREAKFAST BY FRENCH FOR VISITOR
description: Chantal de Kemoularia, whose husband, Claude, is the French representative at the United Nations, is known as the ''gastromacy'' expert of the diplomatic corps for a recent speech linking truffles and truces.

title: SENSORMATIC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
PANEL OF DOCTORS PICKED TO SCREEN AIDS STUDENTS
description: Seven doctors were named yesterday to a new panel that will recommend on a case-by-case basis whether children with AIDS may attend New York City public schools.

title: FLORA M. RHIND
description: Flora Macdonald Rhind, a former secretary of the Rockefeller Foundation who was active in its efforts to improve education for blacks, died of cancer last Thursday at her home in Kennett Square, Pa.

title: MEDCO CONTAINMENT SERVCES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Year-earlier results are not available because the company was formed in June 1983 for the purpose of acquiring a mail service prescription drug business. The acquisition was completed effective October 1983.

title: Mutual Dismissal
description: In his 13 high-scoring seasons with the Montreal Canadiens, Guy Lafleur often spoke out against Canadien management and did not get any more for it than a little extra notoriety. When he retired to a front-office job during the last season, however, somebody apparently forgot to tell him that a public-relations man is not supposed to criticize his employer in public.

title: INTERNATIONAL MULTIFOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
OPERA: JANACEK'S 'JENUFA' IS REVIVED AT THE MET
description: MORALISTS may not commit most of the world's crimes, but stern righteousness can force them to commit some of the worst. Leos Janacek's ''Jenufa,'' which returned to the Metropolitan Opera Tuesday night after a decade's absence, examines that truth as it plays itself out in a Moravian village late in the 19th century. The opera, whose central character is a proud matriarch named Kostelnicka Buryja, unravels a dark domestic drama in which an illegitimate baby is killed by a proud old woman so that the family name can be protected. Daytime television has doubtless mined this plot thoroughly, but its tragic potential is undiluted.

title: TOP HEART SURGEON ASSAILS NAVY DOCTOR ACCUSED IN DEATHS
description: The top heart surgeon at the nation's military medical school testified today that a Navy surgeon accused of negligence in the deaths of five heart patients was ''blind in one eye,'' incompetent to perform cardiac surgery and dishonest in evading proper supervision.

title: No Judicial Activism In Brown v. Board
description: To the Editor:

title: Public Relations Branch Is Latest DYR Venture
description: DYR, the joint venture between the world's two largest ad agencies, Young & Rubicam of the United States and Dentsu of Japan, has now been joined by another venture, this time in the field of public relations and public affairs. DYR Public Affairs is being headed, as managing director, by Hironobu Shibuya, 39, a former executive director of the United States-Japan Foundation, a New York-based group that works to build better relations between the two nations.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25, 1985
description: Markets

title: HEALTH CARE DEVELOPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
U.S. TEAM SEEKS CAUSE OF CRASH THAT KILLED 14
description: The bodies of 14 people killed when a commuter plane crashed into a mountain were carried down rugged trails today as investigators looked for clues to the cause of the crash.

title: Drug-Trial Summations
description: The prosecution told the jury hearing baseball's second cocaine trial today that it did not have to condone the activities of its two ballplayer-witnesses in order to believe their testimony against Robert (Rav) McCue, who is accused of cocaine-trafficking.

title: DOLLAR UP SLIGHTLY IN WARY DAY
description: The dollar rose modestly yesterday, following Monday's record plunge, as traders warily tested the currency markets to see if central banks would intervene.

title: Stocks Fall Sharply, but General Foods Is Up 16 5/8
description: Stock prices dropped sharply yesterday as Wall Street had second thoughts about the significance of a five-nation effort to force down the value of the dollar.

title: General Foods Gets An Offer
description: The General Foods Corporation, rumored to be a takeover target for at least three months, said yesterday that it had received what it called ''an unsolicited telephone proposal'' to buy the company. Its stock leaped $16.625 on the news, to $101.50.

title: M.T.A. Bond Offering Has Top Yield of 10 1/8%
description: The Metropolitan Transit Authority in New York is issuing $125 million of transit facilities revenue bonds with a maximum yield tentatively set at 10 1/8 percent for bonds due in 2015, through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company.

title: Commodore Posts Big Loss in Quarter
description: Commodore International Ltd. said yesterday that it lost $124 million in its fourth fiscal quarter, 50 percent more than the computer maker had projected. It also said that its auditors had issued a qualified opinion about the company's financial health.

title: Two Leaders of P.L.O. Warned by Dissidents
description: A Palestinian radical group said today that it would kill two leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization if they attended Middle East peace talks in London next month.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN DIVESTMENT VOTED BY STATE U. TRUSTEES
description: The trustees of the State University of New York, changing a policy adopted five months ago, voted today to sell the university's $11.5 million in holdings in companies doing business in South Africa.

title: Market Place;   New Horizons Looks Ahead
description: WHEN Edward J. Mathias describes the period since mid-1983 as ''a very difficult one for investors in emerging growth companies,'' he speaks from experience. He is president and portfolio manager of the $1.3 billion T. Rowe Price New Horizons Fund, now observing its 25th anniversary as the nation's largest mutual fund investing in small growth companies.

title: UEBERROTH'S DOUBLE-PLOY
description: ''If cocaine is so bad,'' a 6-year-old boy asked his father recently, ''how come Keith Hernandez and Joaquin Andujar are doing so good?'' In those few words, that youngster explained baseball's drug problem better than anyone else has. And in those few words, that youngster also explained Commissioner Peter Ueberroth's request that each major-league baseball player voluntarily agree to a urinalysis for illegal drugs three times a year without warning. For all the millions of dollars involved for adults in player contracts and TV income, baseball is still a kids' game. As such, it owes the kids, as well as everybody else, an apology for what has occurred on the witness stand in the Pittsburgh drug trials.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in New York Day by Day on Saturday misidentified the assistant to the Smithsonian Institution who helped prepare its two Festival of India exhibitions. She is Maura Moynihan.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: DURING my childhood in France, a goodly number of dishes that arrived on the table had been cooked in the fireplace of the front room of the house. I was accustomed, then, to the sweet smoky flavor imparted to foods by the burning of apple and cherry twigs or vine cuttings from the vineyards of Chablis nearby.

title: Apollo Computer Expects a Loss
description: Apollo Computer Inc., citing reduced spending by its industrial customers, said that it would report an operating loss of about $4 million in its third quarter, which ends Saturday. The company, based in Chelmsford, Mass., said it would take a one-time charge of about $14 million reflecting the costs of severance payments, inventory writedowns and excess capacity.

title: COASTAL INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: U.S. ISSUES DIETARY GUIDELINES
description: The Reagan Administration today released an updated edition of dietary guidelines for Americans, essentially unchanged from recommendations issued more than five years ago by the Carter Administration.

title: WALTERS HAD ROLE IN HOSTAGE TALKS
description: State Department officials said today that the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, Lieut. Gen. Vernon A. Walters, had been sent to Syria recently as part of an effort aimed at freeing the remaining American hostages in Lebanon.

title: Coe Glade, 85, Dead; Sang in Many Operas
description: Coe Glade, a mezzo-soprano who sang with many American opera companies, died Monday at her home in Manhattan after a long illness. She was 85 years old.

title: 'SMALLER' PLAYERS PROVE VALUE
description: Nothing is more exciting to watch on a football field than a running back going past average defenders who might outweigh him by 100 pounds and never having a hand laid on him. There are a lot of these excellent smaller-than-average running backs in the nation. Divisions II and III teams are loaded with them because the major or Division 1-A schools generally reject them when recruiting.

title: BOWL AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Eastern Air Official Is Named President
description: Eastern Air Lines Inc. yesterday named Joseph B. Leonard, a 42-year-old engineer who has run the carrier's daily operations as executive vice president since May, to be president and chief operating officer.

title: Q & A
description: Q.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP BY 0.2%
description: Consumer prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent in August, the Labor Department said today, meaning that inflation for the first three quarters of 1985 is running at an annual rate of 3.3 percent, the lowest in almost two decades.

title: LOUIS SGARRO
description: Louis Sgarro, a bass-baritone who sang with the Metropolitan Opera from 1954 to 1975, died of a heart attack Monday in Old Bridge, N.J. He was 65 years old, and lived in Old Bridge.

title: FEDERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Players Unit Sues Breakers for Pay
description: The United States Football League Players Association filed a $1.2 million lawsuit today against the financially ailing Portland Breakers.

title: AAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $630,000.

title: REAGAN HOPEFUL SOVIET WILL OFFER DEEP ARMS CUT
description: President Reagan expressed hope today that the Soviet Union would offer a bigger cutback in nuclear weapons than the 40 percent reduction proposals that the Soviet Foreign Minister is said to be bringing to Washington this week.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about Yom Kippur sermons misidentified the rabbi of the Sutton Place Synagogue. He is David B. Kahane, not Marc H. Tanenbaum.

title: Note and Bond Prices Higher
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds advanced and yields declined yesterday, while bill rates were largely unchanged in lackluster trading. Much of the buying came after the Federal Reserve indirectly added liquidity to the money market.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25, 1985
description: International

title: Governor Presses Sides In Seattle Teacher Strike
description: Gov. Booth Gardner of Washington slammed his fist on the table for emphasis yesterday in urging negotiators to end the 22-day Seattle teachers' strike, the largest of the school walkouts in five states.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Computer Task Group Inc., Buffalo, said it had acquired Data Force Inc., a computer service company with headquarters in Seattle.

title: Betsy Magness, 61, Is Dead; A Cable Television Executive
description: Betsy Magness, co-founder with her husband, Bob, of Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable television operator, died Sunday of a heart attack in Frankfurt, West Germany. She was 61 years old.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ANOTHER ROUND In 1981, Lanford Wilson's ''Tale Told,'' the third play in his Talley family trilogy, opened at the Circle Repertory Theater. It received mixed reviews and Mr. Wilson apparently agreed with some of the critical reservations because he has reworked it and retitled it ''Talley & Son.'' This new version is also being presented by Circle Rep, 99 Seventh Avenue South, at West Fourth Street, where it is now in previews for its New York premiere, after a run at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center.

title: Holmes's Interpretation
description: He may have failed in his effort to match the 49-0 record turned in by the late Rocky Marciano and he may have been bitterly disappointed by the loss to Michael Spinks Saturday night, but Larry Holmes, the deposed International Boxing Federation heavyweight champion, denied yesterday that he had denigrated Marciano after the fight in comments addressed to the fighter's brother, Peter Marciano. ''I didn't put Marciano down, I never said that,'' declared Holmes, who complained that a remark that ''Rocky couldn't carry my jockstrap,'' had been quoted out of context.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: DURABLES GOODS ORDERS INCREASED BY A STRONG 3.4% IN AUGUST
description: Orders to United States factories for so-called big-ticket durable goods rose a strong 3.4 percent last month, the latest in a string of business barometers showing a moderate rebound in August.

title: HAYES-ALBION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After tax credits of $1,092,000 for the quarter and $3,660,000 for the year. c-After a tax credit of $2,162,000.

title: People
description: * Thomas J. Mullins has been appointed senior vice president at Eisaman, Johns & Laws, New York.

title: Bernard B. Brandt, 75; Started Theater Chain
description: Bernard B. Brandt, a co-founder and president of the Brandt Theaters chain, died of a heart attack Monday in New York City. He was 75 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: PAY 'N PAK STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: The Day Bisbee, Ariz., Deported 1,000 Miners
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR A FEW PUZZLED AFRIKANERS, A TASTE OF HUNGER
description: Paul van den Bergh, a 31-year-old unemployed handyman, took his wife Jeanette and his four-year-old daughter Janette out to lunch Monday. They went to their usual place - a soup kitchen.

title: CONTRACTOR GAVE TO JERSEY G.O.P.
description: The company that designed the State Motor Vehicle Division's problem-plagued computer system contributed $15,000 to the Republican State Committee a month after receiving the $6.5 million contract without competitive bidding, a company official told a legislative committee today.

title: Expos 17 Cubs 15: 8 Homers
description: Andre Dawson hit three home runs, including two in a 12-run fifth inning, and drove in a club-record-tying eight runs today as the Montreal Expos held on to beat the Cubs, 17-15, in a game in which the teams hit eight home runs and got 37 hits.

title: GREENPEACE ATTACK LINKED TO KEY ATOMIC TESTS
description: The sabotage of an antinuclear protest ship by French agents was intended to stop the environmentalist group Greenpeace from disrupting the testing of two types of nuclear weapons that are part of a new generation of French armaments, according to French sources and others.

title: New Talks For Wheeling
description: The stalled talks between the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation and its striking employees will soon be reopened, according to representatives of the United Steelworkers of America.

title: DOWN-HOME DOVE HUNT AND PIG PICKIN
description: THE highways were teeming one recent Saturday with evidence of two of the greatest revels of the Alabama fall. Football fans zoomed along Interstate 85 to the gridiron of the No. 1-ranked Auburn University, to give bone-chilling voice to the ''War Damn Eagle'' decals on their cars. Others, ignoring the green and white interstate signs, veered south toward towns with such plaintive names as Hurtsboro and Hardaway, to worship in the cult of a different bird.

title: WALL TO WALL SOUND & VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
WRITER ORDERED TO PRODUCE TAPE IN BELUSHI CASE
description: A judge ordered a freelance writer today to produce a tape recording of Cathy Evelyn Smith discussing the death of the comedian John Belushi from a drug overdose in 1982.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: A Small, Senatorial Town
description: Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona is a conservative Republican. Senator Paul Simon of Illinois is a liberal Democrat. An unlikely pair, one might think, to be sharing the same parade route.

title: COTTON FARMS TROUBLED BY FOREIGN COMPETITION
description: To all outward appearances, Robert Mashburn was doing very well. He was smiling as he watched his giant green mechanical monsters moving across a snow-white field, picking cotton at the start of another harvest.

title: GUN SMUGGLING ON THE INCREASE, U.S. AIDES SAY
description: In early 1981 two American agrarian advisers and a Salvadoran official were shot to death in what has become one of the most notorious unresolved crimes in El Salvador. Now American law-enforcement officials say they have evidence that an American-made semiautomatic pistol, which had been smuggled out of Florida, was used in the killings.

title: 3 UNSIGNED GIANTS MAY FACE DEADLINE
description: With the season in its fourth week, Mark Haynes, the Giants' All-Pro cornerback; Casey Merrill, a defensive end, and Earnest Gray, a wide receiver, remain unsigned and the Giants hinted yesterday that they may be approaching a cutoff point.

title: UEBERROTH ASKS ALL PLAYERS TO UNDERGO TESTS FOR DRUGS
description: Peter Ueberroth, saying ''a cloud hangs over baseball,'' urged all major league players yesterday to submit voluntarily to drug tests.

title: 4 Arrested in Soviet Protest
description: Four people, including two Christian clergymen, were arrested today in a Yom Kippur rally outside the Soviet Embassy to protest the treatment of Jews in the Soviet Union. The police charged the four with demonstrating within 500 feet of an embassy.

title: G.M. to Expand Michigan Plant
description: The General Motors Corporation said that it would spend more than $500 million to modernize and expand its metal stamping plant in Grand Rapids, Mich. The move is a part of G.M.'s continuing program to update its existing facilities.

title: OPERA: 'JENUFA' AT THE MET
description: Moralists may not commit most of the world's crimes, but stern righteousness can force them to commit some of the worst. Leos Janacek's ''Jenufa,'' which returned to the Metropolitan Opera Tuesday night after a decade's absence, examines that truth as it plays itself out in a Moravian village late in the 19th century. The opera, whose central character is a proud matriarch named Kostelnicka Buryja, unravels a dark domestic drama in which an illegitimate baby is killed by a proud old woman so that the family name can be protected. Daytime television has doubtless mined this plot thoroughly, but its tragic potential is undiluted.

title: RATINGS: A PHOTO FINISH
description: When is a whisker not a whisker? When it comes to audience ratings in television, that's when.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Detroit Tigers, at Yankee Stadium (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.). Mets vs. Cubs, at Chicago.

title: Virginia Reopening Case Of Vanished Teen-ager
description: Paul A. Sciortino, the state prosecutor, said Tuesday that he was reopening an investigation into the disappearance of a Connecticut teen-ager seven years ago in Virginia Beach.

title: WAYS TO STOP SPREAD OF AIDS IN MILITARY STUDIED
description: The military health authorities are studying how to prevent the spread of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, among the more than 2.1 million men and women in the armed forces, Pentagon sources said today.

title: BIG SHIFT IN SELLING SOFTWARE
description: Large companies, which buy everything from yellow pads to computers by the truckload, are tired of buying programs for their personal computers in twos and threes at near retail prices.

title: BONES FOUND ON MEXICANS' DESERT PATH TO U.S. JOBS
description: By the time the sheriff arrives there is usually nothing left under the scorching sun but bones, perhaps just a skull, and some tattered clothing. Sometimes the sheriff beats the coyotes to the scene and there are identifiable bodies lying bloated on the desert floor.

title: Standing Up for Schools
description: Corporate America has a special stake in public schools, but companies displeased with the products of the educational system often do little more than complain. Now the Committee for Economic Development, a prominent corporate research and policy organization, offers a far more constructive response.

title: NIPPON TELEGRAPH IN PACT WITH I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and Nippon Telegraph and Telephone said yesterday that they would enter a joint venture to build a complex computer network in Japan, marking the Japanese telecommunications giant's first major cooperative agreement with an American multinational corporation.

title: GIANT KICKER TAKES POSITIVE APPROACH
description: Jess Atkinson sat cross-legged in front of his locker stall, seemingly oblivious to the swirl of activity round him: hoots and hollers at one end, loud joking 10 feet from him, and, in the middle of the room, the thumping sounds blasting from an oversized radio.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS
description: American Rustic: Architecture and Furniture for the Landscape, Dairy at Central Park, east of the Carousel and north of Wollman Rink, near 64th Street; 212-397-3183.

title: Repertory Theater Gets $843,332 Federal Grant
description: The American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., received a grant of $843,332 this week from the National Endowment for the Arts -the only grant given this year under the endowment's program for ensemble theater companies.

title: Bomb Kills Yugoslav Child
description: A 4-year-old child was killed and nine people, including four other children, were wounded when a bomb the children were playing with exploded today inside their home in the southern province of Kosovo, the Yugoslav press agency reported. It was unclear from the report whether the explosive was one left over from World War II or a modern bomb. Kosovo has been a center of unrest among ethnic Albanians, who are demanding more autonomy from Yugoslavia.

title: CARNEGIE HALL BENEFIT
description: One of the appeals of an evening at Carnegie Hall is the awareness of all that has gone before. Whether one's point of reference is Tchaikovsky, Caruso, Heifetz, Sinatra or the Beatles, virtually every musical luminary of the past century has paid a visit to Carnegie. There's always been a symbiosis between music and fantasy.

title: PRETORIA ORDERED TO STOP BEATINGS
description: A South African judge today ordered the police in Port Elizabeth to refrain from assaulting detainees held under the country's state-of-emergency decree.

title: Military Manpower Rises
description: A recent spurt in active-duty strength of the nation's military services slowed in August but still increased by more than 1,500 individuals, the Pentagon said Tuesday. As of Aug. 31, the Army, Air Force, Navy and Marines had a combined strength of 2,157,456, up 1,546 compared with the total on July 31 and an increase of more than 13,600 over the same period last year.

title: Officials Ending Inquiry Into Fire
description: The state Fire Marshal's Office is listing the cause of the Arlington Park race track fire as unknown and is closing its investigation.

title: IN SEARCH OF VINTAGE FISHING TACKLE
description: WHILE fishing in a secluded Pennsylvania inlet 20 years ago, Albert J. Munger got the best hit of his life. He set his drag tightly and inch by inch reeled against 100 pounds of sheer resistance.

title: UNION SAYS PLAYERS RESIST DRUG PLAN
description: Officials from the Major League Baseball Players Association said yesterday that players have been virtually unanimous in refusing to respond directly to a request from the commissioner that they submit to drug tests.

title: SOME IN JAZZ HOPE STREETS ARE AVENUE TO SUCCESS
description: Lunch hour was over, and so was Vincent Herring's first performance of the day. Beside the Xerox Building at Third Avenue and 43d Street, he packed up his alto saxophone and divided, five ways, the bills and change that passers-by had tossed into the bass-drum case.

title: Jerome B. Trichter, 80, Ex-City Health Official
description: Jerome Bernard Trichter, for many years an assistant New York City health commissioner, died of congestive heart disease Tuesday at Doctors' Hospital in Hollywood, Fla. He was 80 years old and lived in Hollywood.

title: Alaska Radio Link Restored
description: The high-frequency, two-way radio communications system knocked out by a fire that destroyed a Coast Guard installation on Kodiak Island Monday has been restored, the Coast Guard said today. The system is the primary method of communication used by the Coast Guard and mariners.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

title: Baker Names President
description: The Baker International Corporation, a major manufacturer of equipment and services for oil and gas production with headquarters in Orange, Calif., today named James D. Woods president and chief operating officer.

title: WHICH MAGAZINE DO YOU READ?
description: Some call it ''the battle of the slicks,'' the competition in the capital for advertising, readers, visibility and influence among three glossy monthly magazines, The Washingtonian, Regardie's and Dossier.

title: Soviet-Chinese Talks Due
description: The Chinese Foreign Ministry said today that China and the Soviet Union will begin a seventh round of normalization talks here on Oct. 4 at the level of deputy foreign ministers. The Chinese delegation is to be led by Qian Qichen, the Soviet group by Leonid F. Ilyichev. The sixth round was held in Moscow in April.

title: CARDINALS WIN, 6-3, INCREASING LEAD TO 4
description: Tommy Herr hit a three-run homer, and Vince Coleman stole three bases and scored three runs, leading the St. Louis Cardinals to their sixth straight triumph, a 6-3 decision over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight.

title: Football's Biggest Winner
description: Paul Bryant was a Bear of a man, of course, and so was George Halas. But have you heard about Gordon Wood?

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about the United Nations misidentified one speaker. He was Jacques Poos, Foreign Minister of Luxembourg, not Geoffrey Palmer, Deputy Prime Minister of New Zealand.

title: ROADWAY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 7
U.S. WARY OF SEIZING T.W.A. KILLERS
description: United States officials have now identified the three men suspected of having killed a young Navy diver aboard a hijacked Trans World Airlines plane in Beirut last June, but they say they are reluctant to take steps to bring them to trial.

title: OXFORD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
U.S. DENIES FAMILY PLANNING AID TO A U.N. GROUP
description: The United States today redirected $10 million originally allocated for United Nations-sponsored population control programs, saying they include one in China that uses coercive abortion or involuntary sterilization.

title: POLISH CHIEF IS CAUGHT UP IN THE WHIRL
description: On his first full day in New York today, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski surveyed the city from the roof of Rockefeller Center. Turning to his host, David Rockefeller, at a private lunch, the Polish leader remarked that for such a big city, it was wonderfully clear, with little pollution.

title: Hepatitis at Hotel Is Said to Be Over
description: Connecticut's first hepatitis outbreak in several years has run its course, with 69 cases confirmed at the Danbury Hilton Hotel, a state health official said today.

title: 'Sharp and Short and Dramatic'
description: The South African Government over many years has used force to crush demands for change. That is its answer now: repression at home, aggression abroad. But this time the victims of apartheid have not been crushed. After a year, after thousands of detentions, the protest continues.

title: MAJOR HURRICANE THREATENS MIDDLE OF EAST COAST
description: A powerful hurricane described as ''one of the strongest on record in the Atlantic'' churned toward the Eastern seaboard tonight with sustained winds of 135 miles an hour and a hurricane watch was posted from the Carolinas to Virginia.

title: WAUSAU PAPER MILLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
All Hail Bear
description: After James S. Brady, the Presidential press secretary, was wounded in the 1981 assassination attempt on President Reagan, he received many toy bears as ''get well'' gifts from people who knew his nickname was Bear. So when Worlds of Wonder, a toy company, decided to give the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children a toy bear as a kind of mascot, it seemed natural to turn to Mr. Brady to help with the publicity. Mr. Brady, who is still recovering from his wounds, and his 6-year-old son, Scott, will be given a toy bear today as the center announces that the bear, indeed, has been named its national spokesman.

title: F.B.I. CHIEF SUBPOENAED TO TESTIFY AT AGENT'S TRIAL ON SPYING CHARGE
description: The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation has been subpoenaed by the defense to testify in the trial of Richard W. Miller, the only agent of the bureau ever charged with espionage, it was disclosed in court today.

title: THE ROCK CONCERT FINDS AN INTENSE NEW FORM
description: IN ''Dog Eat Dog,'' a song she introduced at the Farm Aid concert in Champaign, Ill., last Sunday, Joni Mitchell sang about the ''land of the short attention span/Nothing to savor long enough to really understand.'' Paradoxically, she might have been singing about the concert itself, which presented more than 50 acts by limiting them to segments of 5, 10 or 20 minutes.

title: BEATRICE COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
JOHN BASS
description: John Bass, a member of the New York City Ballet's corps de ballet, died Tuesday at his home in Manhattan of complications from treatment for lymphatic cancer.

title: Key Officer at Syntex Plans Early Retirement
description: Richard G. Rogers, president and chief operating officer of the Syntex Corporation, a drug company based in Palo Alto, Calif., has announced that he will take early retirement Dec. 31, to devote more time to personal and family interests.

title: FROM RUBBLE OF HOSPITAL, BABY'S CRY BRINGS JOY
description: The towering cranes and grinding bulldozers turned off their motors to let rescue workers listen in silence for sounds of life. As the engines died in the first hour of this morning, a small, quavering baby's wail rose from the ruins of Mexico City's General Hospital.

title: What National Emergency? Whose?
description: South Africa has thrown the United States into a state of national emergency. No, this is not a new alarm; no invasion is threatened and no hostages have been seized. President Reagan has declared the ''emergency'' simply to forestall Congressional sanctions against Pretoria and impose his own instead. The merits of that policy aside, the law allows him to act unilaterally only by perceiving a sudden danger:

title: GREENPEACE AND THE PARIS PRESS: A TRICKLE OF WORDS TURNS INTO A TORRENT
description: The newspaper Le Monde, which has published a number of exclusive reports on the Greenpeace affair in recent days, ran a brief article on Tuesday to disclose who its principal source was not: Pierre Joxe, the Minister of the Interior.

title: PUNJAB VOTE PEACEFUL DESPITE MILITANTS' THREATS
description: Despite threats by Sikh militants, voters in the Punjab turned out in vast numbers today in an election aimed at bringing an end to three years of violence and turmoil in the northern state.

title: City Employees of Liverpool Strike Over Spending Curbs
description: A one-day strike today by employees of this near-bankrupt city to protest spending curbs imposed by the Government shut down City Hall, kept thousands of children out of school and curtailed other services.

title: YANKEE BATS ERUPT, TIGERS ROUTED, 10-2
description: The suggestion that he is perhaps the leading candidate for the most valuable player award in the American League causes a certain uneasiness in Don Mattingly. But the numbers make it almost indisputable.

title: MINORITY LEGISLATORS SPLIT ON LEADER
description: The Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus has been thrown into confusion by a move by some black members to deny the caucus chairmanship to the acting chairman, who is Puerto Rican.

title: HEART ATTACK KILLS BOY DURING SOCCER PRACTICE
description: A 14-year-old New Jersey boy died of a heart attack Tuesday while practicing with the Burlington Township High School soccer team, a county medical official said yesterday.

title: Domingo, in Mexico, Cancels Chicago 'Otello'
description: Placido Domingo, who rushed to Mexico City after the earthquakes there to help search for missing members of his family, has canceled Lyric Opera performances set for tonight and Saturday, the company said today.

title: Oil Supplies Are Surveyed
description: The world appears to have enough oil to last until the mid-21st century, the United States Geological Survey said today. But, it said, because most of the known and undiscovered reserves are in the Middle East, the United States can expect to face several repetitions of the energy crises of the 1970's.

title: AUCTION OF GENERAL FOODS SEEN
description: The General Foods Corporation, moving swiftly after getting a long-expected takeover bid said to be from the Philip Morris Companies, has invited some of the wealthiest concerns in the world to join in a secret bidding contest, insiders said yesterday.

title: Armed Patient Frees Doctor
description: An armed mental patient gave up today without incident and freed a doctor he had held hostage for 14 hours.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: COPPER pipe and tubing are the most common type of home plumbing, so do-it-yourselfers often find themselves working with it. Whether replacing a faucet, repairing a pipe or adding water lines for a new appliance, a knowledge of how to cut and join copper pipe may be necessary.

title: Panhandled Fans
description: Manhattan drivers know to stay especially alert at intersections, keeping an eye out for entrepreneurial window-washers.

title: U.S. Unit on Missing Travels to Hanoi
description: A four-member United States military delegation traveled to Hanoi today to discuss the recovery of remains of American servicemen still listed as missing in action in Vietnam.

title: Consumers Power Elects
description: William T. McCormick, who recently resigned as chairman of the American Natural Resources Company following a takeover by the Coastal Corporation, was named chairman, president and chief executive today of the Consumers Power Company, based in Jackson, Mich.

title: AVONDALE MILLS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 25
description: b-Net income. c-Including a gain of $2,209,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Dickey Will Not Start
description: The evaluation of the quarterback was that he had been ''inconsistent'' during his team's 1-2 start, so for the fourth game this Sunday, Lynn Dickey, the Green Bay starter for the past several seasons, will be sitting on the bench, and Randy Wright, a second-year reserve, will be calling the Packer signals. The switch may seem routine given the Packers' poor offensive play this season, but what makes the evaluation of Dickey's performance and his demotion unusual is that they did not come from the Packers' coach, Forrest Gregg, but from Dickey, himself.

title: G.O.P. Luncheon To Hear Reagan
description: President Reagan will come to New Jersey next week to speak at a $250-a-plate fund-raising luncheon sponsored by the State Republican Committee, a spokesman said today.

title: Frontier Unions Sue To Bar Texas Air Bid
description: Frontier Airlines' labor coalition filed a lawsuit today seeking to block the Texas Air Corporation from making a tender offer for controlling interest in Frontier Holdings Inc., the airline's corporate parent.

title: ABORTED AIR SHUTTLE TAKEOFF LINKED TO CONTROLLER'S ERROR
description: A procedural error by an air traffic controller at Washington's National Airport probably resulted in a helicopter's crossing the departure path of an Eastern Airlines shuttle plane as both were taking off Tuesday, Federal air safety investigators said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: U.N. SPEAKERS ALL DENOUNCE APARTHEID
description: Foreign leaders of countries as diverse as Cuba, Britain, and Mozambique condemned South Africa's system of apartheid in speeches before the General Assembly today.

title: Weak Arguments For Amtrak Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. EXPORT FINANCING AIMED AT FRANCE, JAPAN
description: France and Japan are the main targets of a new policy the United States is preparing to fight what it is calling predatory export practices of foreign governments, Administration officials said today.

title: Piedmont Air
description: Piedmont Airlines announced that it had ordered 19 additional Boeing 737-300 airplanes.

title: EMPIRE AIRLINES GETS TWO OFFERS
description: Empire Airlines, a fast-growing regional carrier that has its hub in Syracuse, said yesterday that it had received two proposals to be acquired at a premium of the current market price.

title: Advertising;   Account
description: * Bechtel Information Services to Spring, O'Brien & Co.

title: PROVIGO INC reports earnings for 16 wks to Aug 10
STATE'S AIR GUARDSMEN REMAIN SET FOR ACTION
description: The jet fighter tears through the clouds, dips a wing earthward and unleashes a blaze of cannon fire at a column of target tanks below.

title: Imperial May Join Allied Bid
description: Imperial Group, the tobacco and food giant that sold its Howard Johnson hotel and restaurant subsidiary on Tuesday to the Marriott Corporation and Prime Motor Inns Inc., said that it had been asked by Elders IXL to join the Australian brewer's bid for Allied-Lyons P.L.C., one of Britain's largest food and drinks companies.

title: Two American Presidents' Different Cancers
description: To the Editor:

title: L.I. Man, 19, Held In Theft of Torah
description: A maintenance worker for an East Meadow synagogue was arrested on Yom Kippur, Judaism's most solemn day, on a charge of attempting to pawn the temple's Torah, the Nassau County police said.

title: Advertising;   SSC&B Wins Account For 2 Tenneco Units
description: The advertising assignments for Speedy Muffler King of Toronto and Car-X Service Systems of Chicago, both parts of Tenneco, are being consolidated effective Jan. 1 at SSC&B, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York.

title: Plenty of Plans For Battery Place
description: Land rush to a landfill.

title: URUGUAYANS PLAY HOST, FRANTICALLY
description: Ten days ago Julio Cesar Lupinacci took over as Uruguay's representative at the United Nations and immediately faced a crisis: the visit of his country's President, Julio Maria Sanguinetti, who came to New York a few days later.

title: JAYARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Wheat Sale Complaints
description: Australian wheat growers condemned the United States today for the subsidized sale of 500,000 tons of wheat to Egypt, Australia's main customer. The sale was ''economic lunacy,'' the chairman of the Australian Wheat Board, Sir Leslie Price, said in a statement. The deal, Washington's first under its export enhancement program, was $20 a metric ton below current commercial prices.

title: U.S. Backs Death Penalty Bill
description: The chief of the Justice Department's criminal division urged Congress Tuesday to pass a comprehensive bill that would permit the Federal Government to execute spies and Presidential assassins.

title: TWISTER OUTBREAK MAY 31 FOUND HIGHLY UNUSUAL
description: On May 31, when tornadoes left 65 people dead in Pennsylvania, the state experienced as many twisters capable of leveling a house as usually hit the nation in a year, according to a meteorologist studying the outbreak.

title: Dickerson Injured
description: Eric Dickerson, the Los Angeles Rams' running back, suffered a cracked bone in his left hand during the team's victory over the Seattle Seahawks Monday night, team physicans have discovered, but the injury is not expected to limit his action against the Atlanta Falcons Sunday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ON THE OTHER FOOT Those things that are seldom what they seem - in fact, those things that are the opposite of what we think they should be - constitute the exhibition ''The Topsy-Turvy World - Moral Satire and Nonsense in the Popular Print.'' The 86 prints, representing 500 years of offbeat views, go on view today through Nov. 2 at Goethe House, a German cultural center at 1014 Fifth Avenue, at 83d Street (744-8310).

title: AMPAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
description: STAR COUNCIL SESSION - All eyes will be on the Security Council this afternoon, when the foreign ministers of the 15-member panel meet to discuss was to strengthen the Council. It is the first meeting at that level since 1970. Council aides say no dramatic results are expected, but that just the gathering of the personalities should generate some interest.

title: Morris Shapiro Dead; A Civil Rights Lawyer
description: Morris Shapiro, a civil rights lawyer, former vice president of the Liberal Party of New York State and former president of the City Club of New York, died yesterday, two days after suffering a heart attack while swimming near his retirement home in Coconut Creek, Fla. He was 82 years old and had lived in New York and Westport, Conn.

title: NEW HOOD ART MUSEUM OPENING AT DARTMOUTH
description: The first-day crowds this Saturday will notice something unusual about the Hood Museum of Art on the Dartmouth campus.

title: KASPAROV GETS DRAW IN CHESS
description: Gary Kasparov displayed lucid defensive technique to draw the eighth game of his world championship chess match with Anatoly Karpov yesterday in Moscow's Tchaikovsky Concert Hall.

title: TEST GIVING ADULTS HIGH SCHOOL DEGREES IS TO INCLUDE ESSAY
description: Adults seeking high school equivalency diplomas will have to write an essay as part of the equivalency test starting in 1988, the sponsor announced today.

title: CALLERS REACT TO RELEASE OF SKETCH OF SUSPECT IN PROSTITUTE'S DEATHS
description: After releasing a composite drawing of the man they believe tortured and killed 10 prostitutes in less than two years, the police have received more than 100 calls from the public, an official said today.

title: 'DEMPSEY AND MAKEPEACE'
description: THE British are clearly more experienced and adept than we are at making quality serial dramatizations, but American producers have a decided edge in turning out slick entertainments in the form of popular action-adventures. From ''Charlie's Angels'' to ''The A-Team,'' the studios in Los Angeles have developed a distinctive knack, while the typical British product, with a few exceptions, has remained puzzlingly sluggish. If evidence is needed, there is tonight's ''Dempsey and Makepeace'' on WPIX, Channel 11, at 8 o'clock.

title: Encore Co-founder Quits Finance Post
description: The Encore Computer Corporation, a start-up company that has had trouble bringing its new super-minicomputer to market, said yesterday that Henry Burkhardt 3d, a co-founder, had resigned as senior vice president, finance and operations, citing ''differences in operating style.''

title: THE SLENDER MINMALIST LOOK STARS AT MILAN FAIR
description: Striking minimal shapes, a more serious emphasis on function and flexibility and a strong dose of fantasy were the main directions at the 25th Salone del Mobile Italiano. The furniture fair, which opened Sept. 18 for a seven-day run, was combined with the lighting show Euroluce.

title: Currency Reporting Fine
description: The Greater Providence Deposit Corporation has been fined $50,000 in a United States District court for failing to report 21 large cash transactions made by a Woonsocket coin dealer in 1980 and 1981. The bank pleaded guilty two months ago to violating the Federal law that requires financial institutions to report to the Internal Revenue Service all cash transactions exceeding $10,000. Greater Providence did not report cashing 21 third-party checks, each for more than $10,000, for Harold and Elaine Chorney and their company, Cumberland Coin.

title: CALIFORNIA BIOTECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Nestle to Close Libby Units
description: Nestle Holdings Inc., the United States subsidiary of Nestle S.A., the giant Swiss-based food company, said today that it would be closing the headquarters and food production facilities of its Libby, McNeill & Libby division within the next six to nine months. The closings will idle 655 employees.

title: Taxes Are an Issue in Payoffs to Players
description: If a college running back is paid $25,000 in cash and a $1,000 a month to carry a football every Saturday, does he have to file a tax return and report the cash as income?

title: Le Pistolet Fumant
description: As someone certain in 1973 that Watergate would blow over, I now offer France's President, Francois Mitterrand, this list of Ten Ways to Ride Out the Storm. 1. Disabuse yourself of the assumption that ''Watergate cannot happen here.'' For years, we heard Frenchmen say that Richard Nixon's transgressions would rate no more than a shrug in national-security-conscious France. But when venality combined with stupidity hits home, it hits hard, and its impact could dislodge a President in Paris as well as Washington. 2. Remember that, for the chief of state, the cover-up is always worse than the crime. No prior knowledge of the original crime did not help President Nixon, and it will not help you; concern yourself with bringing high-level culprits to justice, lest criminality in protecting them touches you. 3. Stop minimizing the original crime. That only focuses more attention on the cover-up; instead, get furious at the original attack on the Rainbow Warrior. Cut out this ''absurd crime'' nonsense, which smacks of the Nixonian ''third-rate burglary'' misconception. Let others talk cynically of the humiliation of being caught - demonstrate that you understand what is really shameful, and become incensed at the moral blindness of the bomb plotters. 4. Get ready to accurately answer the question ''Who ordered the mission? What did Francois Mitterrand know and when did he know it?'' If you and your closest Government advisers were not involved, be prepared to struggle with the French military, part of which was involved in an act that cannot be sanctioned by the state.

title: BELIEFS ON JEWS DESCRIBED AT NEO-NAZIS' TRIAL
description: Defense attorneys today attacked the credibility of a Government witness in a trial of 10 members of a neo-Nazi group, questioning his beliefs that Jews are conspiring to take over the United States Government.

title: EDUCATION DEPT. SEEKING TO ALTER BILINGUAL EFFORTS
description: The Reagan Administration will seek changes in Federal bilingual education programs to give local school districts more flexibility in choosing teaching methods and to emphasize fluency in English rather than knowledge of students' native languages and culture, according to Education Secretary William J. Bennett.

title: Accord on Bruins' Sale
description: A Boston group of financiers has reached agreement to buy the Boston Bruins and Boston Garden for $50 million from a Buffalo firm, promising fans that hometown owners would not only improve the National Hockey League team but also air condition the 64-year-old arena.

title: Malfunctioning Valve Delays Shoreham Tests for 2 Hours
description: The Long Island Lighting Company reported that low-power testing at the Shoreham nuclear power plant was stopped for more than two hours today because a valve malfunctioned.

title: 3 ISRAELIS SLAIN BY PALESTINIANS IN CYPRUS
description: Palestinian gunmen stormed a small private yacht moored in the marina of this bustling tourist port shortly before dawn this morning and killed three Israelis aboard it in the course of a siege that lasted nearly 10 hours.

title: School Clinic in Chicago Retained Despite Protest
description: A school clinic criticized for giving contraceptives to teen-agers survived a stormy school board hearing today.

title: GODARD'S 'HAIL MARY' TO OPEN OCT. 9
description: ''Hail, Mary,'' a new film by Jean-Luc Godard that was dropped by its anticipated American distributor following protests that the movie was blasphemous, will be distributed in this country by New Yorker Films.

title: Help for Indians
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Advertising;   Old Song Is Revived For Toyota
description: GEORGE E. BORST, the corporate marketing manager of Toyota Motor Sales, U.S.A., considers the six-year-old ''Oh! What a feeling'' campaign warm and humorous - and a nice way to keep his company's name in front of consumers when it is already selling all the vehicles it can import.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in some copies yesterday on Chantal de Kemoularia, the wife of the chief French delegate to the United Nations, alluded incorrectly to the nationality of Karl Marx. He was German.

title: Advertising;   Us Magazine Adopts New Campaign Theme
description: Fallon McElligot Rice of Minneapolis has a penchant for spreads, or two-page ads, that seem to be made up of two independent ads. And that's what it has given one of its newest clients, Us magazine.

title: 'SPIES WHO NEVER WERE'
description: A SINGULARLY bittersweet footnote to history is the stuff that tonight's ''Memories of War'' program, at 10 P.M. on WNET/Channel 13, is made of. ''The Spies Who Never Were'' is a two-hour documentary about refugees from Nazism who found themselves in Britain when World War II erupted and, instead of being welcomed as friends, were hustled off -politely and understandably, in light of bureaucratic confusion and national fear - as possible spies to Canada, where they were interned virtually as prisoners of war.

title: Fish Stories on Tax Reform
description: WE'VE come to the eve of tax reform, with a bill about to emerge from the deep. Next week the House Ways and Means Committee begins the real work of framing a tax reform package.

title: Iraq Says Its Planes Again Raided Oil Depot
description: Iraq said its warplanes attacked the Iranian oil terminal at Kharg island again today, while Iran said its forces killed more than 65 Iraqi soldiers in hand-to-hand fighting on the western front of the Persian Gulf war.

title: 3 Bombs Damage a Building After Rally On New Caledonia
description: Three bombs exploded early today after a rally in this French Pacific territory, which is torn by a dispute over independence between European residents and the indigenous Melanesian population.

title: HERS
description: ON the Spanish Steps in the blazing sun. The heat and the haze and the seemingly limitless supply of beautiful, mainly blond, young girls. City of domes, city of gold leaf and beggars and gadflies and chic little shops, replete with sewing ladies so that any purchase can be altered within the hour. In the siesta time the women lie sprawled in their tiny shops, often entwined with one another, like paintings depicting scenes of ancient, lascivious Rome.

title: POLAND PUSHES CRACKDOWN, BUT ON LESSER KNOWN ACTIVISTS, NOT ON LEADERS
description: Although the number of political prisoners and detainees in Poland has risen over the last few months, the dissidents being imprisoned these days tend to be relatively unknown men and women whose fates are less likely to command attention and stir protest here or abroad.

title: LAND OF LINCOLN SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $454,760 from a nonrecurring dividend distribution of preferred stock of the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. The company said results for the latest quarter and year reflect a provision for loss on securities of $2.1 million relating to dealings with Parr Securities Corp., a New York-based securities broker-dealer.

title: The Poems (Pornographic or Not) No One Reads
description: To the Editor:

title: HOPE FADES IN SEARCH FOR SURVIVORS IN MEXICO
description: As exhausted international rescue workers dug desperately into several collapsed buildings today, Mexican and United States officials said the chances of finding any more survivors of the two earthquakes that shook the city late last week were quickly diminishing.

title: BRITAIN JOINS EUROPEAN PARTNERS IN MEASURES TO COUNTER APARTHEID
description: Britain announced today that it had decided to join the rest of the Common Market in imposing anti-apartheid measures against South Africa. But the Government said it continued to oppose mandatory economic sanctions against Pretoria.

title: CORRECIONS
description: A report in New York Day by Day yesterday about a privately maintained garden on the Lower East Side called the Garden of Eden incorrectly described the extent of its demolition. Most of the wall surrounding the garden was razed, but not the plantings. They are to be removed before the city builds housing there.

title: Utah Bond Offer Is $111.1 Million
description: Utah is offering about $111.1 million of triple-A rated general obligation bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Tonka Settles S.E.C. Case
description: The Tonka Corporation has settled charges brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission that it failed to maintain adequate controls of its corporate investments, the S.E.C. said Tuesday. The agency said it had also filed a civil injunctive action against L. Martin LeBus, Tonka's former chief financial officer and treasurer, and three of his associates.

title: ANGELS AND ROYALS TRIUMPH
description: Juan Beniquez hit a three-run homer tonight and Gary Pettis had a two-run double, helping the California Angels beat the Chicago White Sox, 7-4.

title: BEIRUT MOSELMS IN TRUCE ACCORD
description: Lebanese Moslem militia leaders agreed tonight on new security measures to go into effect tomorrow to halt fighting in West Beirut and end shortages of gasoline and bread there.

title: Arco and Santa Fe Get China Pact
description: China will sign a $500 million deal with the Atlantic Richfield Company and the Santa Fe International Corporation to develop an offshore natural gas field in what would be the biggest single foreign investment in the country under Peking's seven-year-old open policy, industry sources said. The contract will be signed Saturday with the Government-run China National Offshore Oil Corporation.

title: HOPE FOR THE SUMMIT
description: WHEN Ronald Reagan and Mikhail S.
