Gorbachev meet for the first time in November, the result could easily be disappointing - either outright failure and recrimination or cosmetic agreements on minor issues that mask the absence of any real progress. Yet the President could also do better than just a ''get acquainted'' session. Whether by inadvertence or design, there is now an opportunity for a major breakthrough.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL NEW YORK-PENNSYLVANIA LEAGUE - Announced agreement to move Newark (N.Y.) Orioles to Harrisburg, Pa., for 1986 season.

title: Pistons Sign Haywood
description: Spencer Haywood, who retired in 1983 after 13 seasons and five teams in the National Basketball Association has signed a contract with the Detroit Pistons, and General Manager Jack McCloskey said the 35-year-old power forward has looked very impressive during informal workouts. Haywood agreed, saying: ''I've been gone two years but I haven't lost anything.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * British Aerospace P.L.C. said it had sold 10 more BAE 125 Series 800 business jets for about $60 million.

title: Existing Home Sales Up 9.2%
description: Sales of existing homes surged 9.2 percent last month to hit their highest level in almost six years, a real estate trade group reported today.

title: Water Main Bursts
description: A water-main break at 5 o'clock this morning caused a section of Tonnele Avenue to collapse and led to major traffic jams, but no residents reported losing water service, the police said.

title: INSURER STUDY SCREENING FOR AIDS
description: Fearing large claims by victims of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, the life insurance industry is considering new ways of finding out if applicants have the disorder.

title: RB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $251,000 from the extinguishment of debt and a cumulative loss of $2,262,000 from an accounting change.

title: HYBRID TEAS WIN PRIZE AS BEST ROSES
description: RARELY does the hybrid tea sweep the All-America Rose Selection trials. But it did this year. For the first time in many years, only this category of roses was honored with three prizewinners. In the past, all classes of roses had been represented.

title: Horse Racing;   MEADOWLAKE OUT WITH SORE SHINS
description: Meadowlake, the 2-year-old Hold Your Peace colt who won his debut by 22 lengths and then took the Arlington-Washington Futurity by 8 1/2 lengths Saturday, is out for the year with sore shins. He was being ballyhooed as a wonder horse, and though he is clearly a talented colt, he would have had a tough time defeating the East's top juveniles had he fulfilled his initial schedule of coming to New York for the Nov. 2 Breeders' Cup Juvenile.

title: SAN-BAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $645,000 for the quarter and $2,741,000 for the year and extraordinary gains of $313,000 and $8,903,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income The company said 1984 results include a pre-tax gain of $402,000 from the sale of real estate in the fourth quarter and a pre-tax reversal of a $350,000 deferred compensation accrual in the first quarter.

title: Prosecutors Rest Cases In Aquino Trial
description: Three prosecutors unexpectedly rested their cases today against the military Chief of Staff, Gen. Fabian C. Ver, and 25 others charged in the killing of the Philippine opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr.

title: FPA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Moderate Quake Hits Alaska
description: A moderate earthquake shook the Anchorage area this afternoon, but there were no reports of damage or injuries. The quake was also felt at Homer, Kenai and Palmer. The United States Geological Survey in Golden, Colo., said the temblor was measured at 4.6 on the Richter scale, an index of earthquake severity, with each unit increase representing a thirtyfold increase in the energy released.

title: VERTIPILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $58,004 for the quarter and $63,004 for the 6 months.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SEPTEMBER 26, 1985
description: International A 4 1/2-hour American-Soviet talk apparently failed to narrow the gap between the two countries on arms control issues. After the meeting with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said that despite speculation that a new Soviet plan might be unveiled yesterday ''there were no particular new proposals put on the table.''[Page A1, Column 6] The Pentagon disputed a warning by a new Congressional study that the program to develop an antimissile defense system might increase the risk of nuclear war.[A1:6] Latin America's leading debtor nations, worried by the political perils of their continuing financial crisis, are beginning to balk at carrying out austerity programs urged by the International Monetary Fund.[A1:4-5] A South African judge ordered the police in Port Elizabeth to refrain from assaulting detainees held under the country's state-of-emergency decree. The decision represented the first judicial acknowledgement of police brutality and a victory for a 25-year-old surgeon, Wendy Orr, who had campaigned against what she called systematic assaults on prisoners by the police.[A1:3] Rescue workers are still finding a trickle of survivors in the mountains of snapped steel girders, concrete slabs, crushed brick and rubble that dot Mexico City nearly one week after two major earthquakes. As many as 800 people are believed buried in the collapsed section of Mexico's largest hospital. Early yesterday one infant was found alive.[A10:1-4] Palestinian gunmen in Larnaca, Cyprus, stormed a small private yacht moored in the marina of the bustling tourist port and killed three Israelis aboard it in the course of a seige that lasted nearly 10 hours.

title: 'STAR WARS' BATTLE: MOSCOW AND CONGRESS INCREASE THE PRESSURE ON REAGAN
description: The confluence of Soviet diplomacy and developments in Congress has increased the pressure on President Reagan to bend in his refusal to make his space-based missile defense a ''bargaining chip'' in arms talks with the Soviet Union.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: JUSTICE DEPT. INDICTS 9 KLAN MEMBERS IN CAROLINA
description: Nine members of the Ku Klux Klan in North Carolina have been indicted on conspiracy charges in a series of cross-burnings and shootings designed to discourage blacks and whites from living or socializing together, the Justice Department announced today.

title: The Interloper
description: Some city Republicans are muttering over an invitation by State Senator Roy M. Goodman, a Republican, to the city's leading Democrat, Mayor Koch, to a Goodman fund-raising dinner that falls in the middle of the mayoral campaign.

title: RPS PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $5,000 for the quarter and year. c-After an extraordinary gain of $2,000 for the quarter and year and a gain of $42,000, or 3 cents a share, on settlement of liabilities under Chapter 11 proceedings for the year.

title: A Limited Phone Link From Mexico Opened
description: For the first time since last Thursday's earthquake, Mexican telephone authorities have made outgoing international phone available to the public, United States telephone officials said today.

title: Comings and Goingss
description: Dana Kirk, the Memphis State basketball coach, testified before a grand jury that has been investigating sports gambling in western Tennessee, but afterward he said his appearance had been in connection with a review of his personal ''financial affairs and tax liabilities.'' Kirk, expressing confidence that no illegality would be found, declined to say whether he had been asked anything about Memphis State. . . . Eight of nine charges that had been lodged against Vanderbilt's former strength coach, E. J. (Doc) Kreiss, were dismissed yesterday when a judge ruled that the statute of limitations had expired before the charges accusing Kreiss of illegally distributing steroids to athletes at Vanderbilt and two other colleges, Clemson and Colgate, were filed. . . . Mary O'Dowd, the Manhattan club singer who bungled the Canadian national anthem before a recent Blue Jays' game at Yankee Stadium, may have to wait a while before making her musical amends. Miss O'Dowd, who had been invited by the mayor of Toronto and The Toronto Star newspaper to sing the anthem during the season-ending Yankee series against the Blue Jays next week, said the engagement had been canceled because the Blue Jays had not been consulted and had already engaged other singers for the Yankee dates.

title: Coast Savings In Conversion
description: Coast Savings and Loan Association, California's thirteenth-largest thrift institution, said today that its directors approved a conversion from a mutual savings and loan into a publicly held association. Coast has assets of $6.8 billion.

title: Janacek's 1st Major Opera
description: Leos Janacek derived the libretto for his first major opera, ''Jenufa,'' from a Czech play, ''Her Foster Daughter,'' by Gabriela Preissova, and in early performances the work went under that name. The first performance on Jan. 21, 1904, created a stir in Brno, but its progress stalled there for years.

title: Whitson Start Delayed
description: Billy Martin said last night that he would not use Ed Whitson until the team goes on the road for its final series at Toronto.

title: Make Trade Fairer - Everywhere
description: Only 14 American movies played in South Korea last year, because Korean regulations prevented more. That's unfair trade. American restrictions on sugar imports force consumers here to pay four times the world price, and impoverish tropical countries that produce it more efficiently. That's unfair too. Now that President Reagan has declared war on other nations' ''unfair'' practices, it is worth noting how others perceive ours.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: ANDERSEN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
KAISER ALUMINUM CHALLENGED
description: A group led by Joseph A. Frates, the Tulsa, Okla., investor, said yesterday that it would seek a restructuring of the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, and that it might try to gain control of the struggling company.

title: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS BLOCK AFLUTTER AS THE CAMERAS ROLL ONCE MORE
description: Meryl Streep, Jack Nicholson, Stockard Channing and Richard Masur were in the kitchen of 15 Garden Place in Brooklyn Heights, attending a cinematic dinner party. A caravan of vans and trucks was parked outside, with thick wires snaked along the sidewalk. Orange traffic cones banned residents' parking.

title: Spatial Skills in School
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 26, 1985
description: Companies

title: BOMB EXPLOSION IN CENTRAL ROME WOUNDS 14 AT BRITISH AIR OFFICE
description: A powerful bomb ripped through a British Airways terminal here today, wounding at least 14 people. The police said a Palestinian teen-ager had confessed to hurling the explosive.

title: Stocks Slide Again; Dow Is Off 9.07
description: Wall Street stock prices fell sharply yesterday for the second consecutive day as investors decided to cash in more of the exceptional profits made during Monday's explosive rally.

title: Topics;   Up in Smoke Self-Punishment
description: The footnotes to boxing history will duly note that Larry Holmes has apologized. The main text, however, will still record his graceless and boorish remarks after Michael Spinks dethroned him last Saturday as the heavyweight champion of the world.

title: METS COLLAPSE IN NINTH INNING
description: On a bleak and chilly afternoon today in old Wrigley Field, the Mets may have made their last stand.

title: Deficit Record Hit in August
description: The Federal Government's budget deficit hit a record $203.43 billion in August with one month still to go in the current fiscal year, the Treasury Department said today. But officials said the final deficit should be slightly lower because of an expected surplus in September.

title: Alabama City Faulted on Bias
description: The Justice Department said today that Mobile, Ala., had failed to establish a school system designed to remedy desegration and should be compelled to submit a plan for getting the job done.

title: British Notes Are Repackaged
description: Merrill Lynch Capital Markets has repackaged $100 million of floating-rate notes recently issued by Britain and is offering the new securities as 9 3/8 percent notes due in 1988 at a price of 100 1/4.

title: Dropped
description: The $73,600-a-year post of Archivist of the United States, vacant since mid-April, is apparently not going to Peter J. Duignan, a Californian who was saying four months ago that President Reagan would appoint him as soon as a security clearance had been completed. Congressional sources say the White House has quietly passed word that the nomination, which was never formally announced, has been dropped.

title: DANCE: NEWMAN TROUPE
description: ROSALIND NEWMAN AND DANCERS opened a new dance series Wednesday night that is being sponsored this season by the Joyce Theater, 19th Street and Eighth Avenue.

title: OHIO HOSPITAL WORKERS WIN A KEY LABOR ELECTION
description: A large group of Ohio public workers have voted on which unions they want to represent them, with the National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employees winning a major victory.

title: Arizona Transplant Patient Improving Despite Infection
description: The condition of Michael Drummond, the heart transplant patient here, improved slightly today as his body continued to fight a lung infection, officials at University Medical Center said.

title: Rising Tax, Rising Sales
description: Block-long lines are not yet obscuring the ''Buy Now or Else'' signs that have gone up in liquor store windows around town. But it isn't the absolute last minute, either.

title: Bridge: Attack on a Political Enemy Can Be a Two-Edged Sword
description: Attempts to attack political enemies in the sphere of sport and recreation can have double-edged results. In bridge, a threatened boycott has successfully removed South Africa from the world stage, but third-world pressure against Israel has been largely counterproductive.

title: FRANCE BLAMES 2 AIDES IN SHIP RAID
description: Prime Minister Laurent Fabius, trying for the first time to fix ultimate responsibility for the sinking of the antinuclear protest ship Rainbow Warrior, blamed two former senior French Government officials tonight for having given the go-ahead for the operation.

title: VOTE FRAUD JURY IS PROTESTED
description: An all-white jury was selected today for the trial of Spiver Gordon and Frederick Daniels, two black political leaders accused of mail and vote fraud in connection with the use of absentee ballots in a 1984 Greene County Democratic primary.

title: A Mideast Peace Initiative in Urgent Need of U.S. Involvement
description: To the Editor:

title: Social Insurance Pioneer
description: To the Editor:

title: LUTOSLAWSKI RECEIVES MUSIC PRIZE IN LOUISVILLE
description: The hotel had chrome-and-glass elevators and an atrium with well-tended plants, but the man in the plaid suit noticed only the trio of musicians.

title: Citrus Canker Is Found At 2 More Florida Sites
description: Citrus canker has been discovered in a second commercial grove and another tree nursery, bringing to 16 the number of infected sites, state agriculture officials said today.

title: A VOTE TO BLOCK S.I. ATOM ARMS IS SET FOR BALLOT
description: The City Clerk's office yesterday cleared the way for a referendum on the citywide ballot in November designed to block the Navy from establishing a base on Staten Island for ships that might carry nuclear weapons.

title: 3 Gain World Cup Finals
description: West Germany, Spain and Bulgaria clinched places in next year's World Cup soccer finals in Mexico, while the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia and Finland improved their chances today. There are now 11 teams set for the 24-nation tournament.

title: PARACHUTIST'S DEATH LEADS TO TRAIL ON COCAINE
description: The investigation of the parachutist who died when he hit the ground with a duffel bag of cocaine strapped to him has uncovered some unusual leads, and beyond that has drawn the public's attention to the the latest battlefield in the war on drugs, Federal agents say.

title: MCFADDIN VENTURES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
G.O.P. HOPEFUL FACING PROBLEMS IN BID FOR MICHIGAN GOVERNORSHIP
description: After moving quickly to establish himself as the leading candidate for the 1986 Republican nomination for Governor of Michigan, William Lucas is encountering some problems that could slow his momentum and tarnish his political image.

title: Politics;   Possible Perils Await the G.O.P. Up in Michigan
description: Michigan, which has frequently played only bit parts in Presidential primary campaigns, suddenly finds itself in a starring role in the political drama that could be called ''Front-Runners and Dark Horses.''

title: MARTIN'S FOGGY FUTURE
description: Haggard and hollow-eyed, Billy Martin was sitting behind his desk in the Yankee manager's office before Tuesday night's game. The cast on his broken right arm was in a white sling, the result of his three-round brawl with Ed Whitson in the bar, the lobby and on the third floor of a Baltimore motel last weekend. And every so often, Billy Martin winced in pain. ''I found out I got two cracked ribs, too,'' he said.

title: 2 in San Antonio Held In Banker's Wife's Death
description: Two men arrested on a tip face charges of murder in the slaying of the wife of a bank president who was told to pay ransom, officials said today.

title: LIFESTYLE RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 10
description: Lifestyle Restaurants was formerly known as Beefsteak Charlie's Inc.

title: NEW DEMAND MADE IN SALVADOR CASE
description: The kidnappers of the daughter of President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador have added a new demand, telling the Government it must release 34 rebels in exchange for her release, according to people involved in the case.

title: He Wants to Play
description: Carlton Fisk of the Chicago White Sox, whose homer Tuesday night at California was his 32d as a catcher this season (tying Lance Parrish's American League record), has hit four others during the 24 games in which he has filled the designated hitter's slot. Fisk will turn 38 in December, but, unlike many other players of advanced years, he finds nothing at all attractive about being a d.h.

title: Harry Payne Whitney Is Dead; Yachtsman From Manhattan
description: Harry Payne Whitney, a yachtsman and former businessman, died Sept. 18 after heart surgery at the Maine Medical Center in Portland, Me. He was 60 years old.

title: Technology;   A Windshield Clears Ice Fast
description: SCRAPING ice from automobile windshields on winter mornings is one of the less pleasant chores that drivers face. Few, however, have the time or patience to wait the 15 minutes or so for the engine's cooling system to warm up enough for the defroster-blower to do the job.

title: Roderick W. Cameron Dies; Wrote on History and Travel
description: Roderick William Cameron, author of books on history and travel, died on Sept. 18 at his home in Menerbes, France, after a long illness. He was 71 years old.

title: BANK IN RHODE ISLAND UNDER INQUIRY
description: Former Attorney General Griffin B. Bell has been hired to investigate allegations of wrongdoing at the Fleet National Bank made in connection with a spreading scandal involving a Rhode Island agency established to make low-interest mortgage loans.

title: A Russian Expert Who Has the President's Ear
description: Suzanne Massie, an American author and lecturer on Russian history, has long been vocal in her appreciation of the culture and people of ''a country I think of as almost my own,'' as she puts it.

title: Uganda Troops Clash With Rebels
description: Uganda troops clashed with rebel forces 80 miles southwest of Kampala today and diplomats expressed concern for 200,000 people fleeing a Government offensive north of the capital.

title: Glemp Returns to Poland
description: Jozef Cardinal Glemp, head of the Roman Catholic Church in Poland, returned home today from what he called a ''very successful'' one-week trip to the United States.

title: A POIGNANT TIME FOR RUMANIA'S DWINDLING JEWS
description: ''No conversions to Judaism are accepted,'' announces a handwritten sign at the door to the office of Rumania's Chief Rabbi. ''It is useless to insist.'' A sign that might have been the height of sarcasm some years ago in a country that has known as much anti-Semitism as the rest of Eastern Europe reflects today's reality. Jews enjoy the privilege of being allowed to emigrate more or less freely, and many Rumanians are ready to pay the price of adopting an unpopular faith for that opportunity.

title: MANY CHALLENGES FACE WHEELING STEEL'S CHIEF
description: George A. Ferris, in his first week as chief executive officer of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, has quickly won agreement with the United Steelworkers of America to reopen labor talks after a two-month stalemate.

title: Georgia Power's Preferred Stock
description: The Georgia Power Company is offering 2 million shares of $25 adjustable-rate preferred stock with an initial dividend yield of 9.53 percent through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Koch Criticizes Plans For Appearances by 2
description: Mayor Koch has written to 116 fellow members of the Black-Jewish Coalition urging them to speak out against the Rev. Louis Farrakhan and Rabbi Meir Kahane, both of whom are planning appearances in New York next month.

title: U.S. AIDES SEE GUN SMUGGLERS AS LOW PRIORITY
description: United States law-enforcement officials say they are having little success stopping illegal exports of American-made arms.

title: BUTLER NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $33,696.

title: SPORTO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Include a charge of $90,000 from litigation settlement.

title: CANVAS FLOOR COVERINGS THAT TRICK THE EYE
description: ALTHOUGH trained as a fine arts painter and printmaker, James O'Shea, below, is now making his living creating painted canvas floorcloths.

title: PENTAGON DISPUTES AGENCY'S WARNING ON MISSILE DEFENSE
description: The Pentagon today disputed the warning of a new Congressional study that President Reagan's program to develop an antimissile defense system might increase the risk of nuclear war.

title: STAGE: 'GOODBYE FREDDY'
description: IN a play or a movie, whenever old friends get together at the funeral of one of their number for an evening of regrets and revelations, it is inevitable that the situation will be shrouded by ''The Big Chill.'' Such is the case with Elizabeth Diggs's ''Goodbye Freddy.'' Among the author's several minor contributions to the overworked wake genre is that the characters have known one another since grammar school. One could regard the play as ''The Big Children.''

title: PACE OF THE CITY SLOWS ON YOM KIPPUR
description: Stores closed. Officials took the day off. And children, on a holiday from school, attended synagogue yesterday to celebrate Yom Kippur, the holiest day on the Jewish calendar.

title: Rutgers Fund-Raiser Quits
description: The chairman of Johnson & Johnson Inc. has resigned as head of a Rutgers University fund-raising campaign because of the school's decision to sell its stock in companies operating in South Africa, the university said today.

title: Martha Graham Is Given Medal of Honor by Paris
description: The choreographer Martha Graham accepted the city of Paris's Medal of Honor on Tuesday after a performance by her modern-dance troupe that received cheers, a standing ovation and repeated curtain calls.

title: SENATE APPROVES MEASURE ON BUDGET
description: The Senate today approved a temporary budget that will keep the Government running through Nov. 14 and avoid the usual threat of having to shut down Sept. 30 at the end of the fiscal year.

title: Joblessness in E.E.C.
description: Unemployment in the European Economic Community rose to 11 percent of the work force in August, from 10.9 percent in July, reflecting higher joblessness among women, the Common Market's statistics office said today. It was the highest unemployment rate since the rate was 11.1 percent in April. The total number of jobless people in the Common Market stood at nearly 12.5 million in August, an increase of 87,000 from the month before.

title: Guatemala Candidates Expecting Fair Election
description: Six candidates for vice president in Guatemala's first civilian Government in 31 years said today that they believed the November election would proceed as planned and be fair and free from electoral fraud.

title: Salmon Migration Is Awaited
description: The inshore migration of big chinook salmon in late summer and early fall is eagerly awaited by Lake Ontario anglers.

title: PRUDENTIAL FINANCIAL SERVCES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a reserve of $5,770,000 established for the company's exposure from agreements with Bevill Bresler & Schulman Inc., which has been placed in receivership. c-Net income

title: FOR RUTGERS, 'BIG TIME' PROVES ELUSIVE
description: The Governor said he was ''proud of Dick Anderson,'' as though the Rutgers football coach were a new link in the Garden State Parkway. Joe Paterno was ready with more praise.

title: Staff Warmth
description: The arm's-length relationship that has long existed between the staffs of President Reagan and Vice President Bush has eased.

title: 2 MOZAMBICAN CHILDREN DIE IN EXPLOSIONS AT ARMS DEPOT
description: A series of explosions rocked a Mozambican Army ammunition depot in the suburbs of Maputo today, killing two children and injuring 40 people, according to reports from Mozambique.

title: FACING A NEW, SOLITARY LIFE IN A TINY WEST SIDE ROOM
description: THE retreat-from-divorce room in which I was skinny and distraught - both a factory and a monk's cell, it seemed to me at the time - was the maid's room in one of those wilting grand apartments on West End Avenue in Manhattan. The widow who rented it to me discussed the potential irksomenesses on both sides - her piano, my typewriter; we came to a statesmanlike agreement - no com-plaints about either. She failed to warn me about the compassionate pots of boiled potatoes that she would be slipping through my door. This meant that, despite my grand, depressed, sanctified isolation, I would occasionally have to break my silence: ''Thank you, Mrs. Weinstein.''

title: NIEKRO MIRRORS YANKS' BROKEN SEASON
description: Phil Niekro may have relieved his frustration when he took a bat and destroyed part of a public-telephone enclosure in a corridor outside the Yankee clubhouse Tuesday night, but the act really symbolized the helplessness of an entire Yankee season.

title: How Not to Milk American Farmers
description: To the Editor:

title: VASILY KRIVOSHEIN
description: Archbishop Vasily Krivoshein of Brussels, a prelate of the Russian Orthodox Church, has died during a pilgrimage to Leningrad, the Tass press agency said Tuesday.

title: Fire Damages Warehouse
description: Fire swept through a huge Federal Government warehouse today, forcing the evacuation of an elementary school and causing $3.5 million in damage, although no records were destroyed, the authorities said. There were no injuries.The warehouse is part of the General Services Administration's 291-acre Fort Worth Records Center, and one building that burned was full of plywood and paper products.

title: Advertising;   Xerox Taps Marschalk For Direct-Mail Job
description: The Marschalk Company, another Interpublic agency, has received a ''multimillion-dollar'' direct-marketing assignment from Xerox. And, while it has done direct marketing for some general clients in the past, this is the first time it has worked exclusively on such an assignment.

title: Subway Series Fading
description: The Toronto Blue Jays and the St. Louis Cardinals are getting close to canceling a Subway World Series.

title: COMMENTS BY EAGLESON ANNOY DEVILS
description: The hierarchy of the Devils is becoming miffed and frustrated by comments that it says undermine efforts to build a viable franchise for the National Hockey League in the Meadowlands.

title: LATIN DEBTORS RESISTING AUSTERITY, CITING POLITICAL PRESSURE AT HOME
description: Latin America's leading debtor nations, worried by the political perils of their continuing financial crisis, are beginning to balk at carrying out austerity programs urged by the International Monetary Fund.

title: Farm Credit System Sets Rates for Bond Sale
description: The Farm Credit System announced details yesterday of its first bond sale since its senior officials warned that it might need Federal assistance to cope with mounting losses on loans to farmers.

title: A CHOICE OF AUCTIONS, CRAFTS AND FLEA MARKETS
description: Several flea markets, craft fairs and auctions will take place this weekend in the New York area.

title: HOLDING THINGS IN PLACE
description: FOR holding down garbage-can tops or securing luggage on the top of a car, straps and cords found in many hardware stores can be very handy.

title: QUICK & REILLY GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Topics;   Up in Smoke Pack It In
description: High-class saloons have long understood that consumers of alcohol, feeling guilty, would rather pay extra for one giant drink than conspicuously order a second or third. Now tobacco companies are catching on.

title: FUND SELECTS HEAD FOR STUDY OF PUBLIC POLICY
description: The Lynde and Harry Bradley Foundation of Milwaukee, which recently became one of the wealthiest philanthropies in the country, has selected a new executive director to develop a public policy program in support of conservative causes.

title: CONFERENCE NEXT MONTH ON POPULAR MUSIC
description: A conference entitled ''A Century of Popular Music in New York'' will be presented Oct. 10-13 at the Library and Museum of the Performing Arts, 111 Amsterdam Avenue, at Lincoln Center.

title: Flames at Three Mile Island Cause Minor Damage at Plant
description: An electrical fire struck the Unit 1 reactor at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant just two days before the unit's planned restart, the plant's operator confirmed today.

title: SENATE STUDY CALLS FOR NEW LAWS TO PROTECT AGED HOSPITAL PATIENTS
description: The Senate Special Committee on Aging said today that new laws were needed to prevent hospitals from prematurely discharging elderly Medicare patients.

title: Murderer in Peeping Case
description: William Archie Fain, released from prison after serving nearly 16 years for murder and rape, was back behind bars today after two men told police they had caught him peeping into a bedroom window of a house in which one of them lived. Mr. Fain, a roofer who lives in nearby Campbell, escaped execution on the murder charge because of an error in jury selection. He was granted parole three times but each time it was withdrawn because of public outcry.

title: IN EAST RIVER, A GOLD FRIGATE AND HIGH HOPES
description: A salvage expert said yesterday that he had found and intended to raise H.M.S. Hussar, a 26-gun Revolutionary War frigate that was carrying a British Army payroll in gold coins and 80 American prisoners when she sank in the East River in 1780.

title: KEVEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company noted that in the year- earlier fourth quarter, it recognized the benefit of income taxes previously deferred on export sales through its domestic international sales corp. of $1,141,000, or 22 cents a share. The figures for the fourth quarter, fiscal year and prior periods, include the results of Surface Science Laboratories Inc., acquired in January 1985, and accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MR. PALOMAR. By Italo Calvino. Translated from the Italian by William Weaver. 130 pages. A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $12.95. AT first, I thought I'd made a serious error while reading Italo Calvino's ''Mr. Palomar,'' a new novel by the distinguished Italian writer who died at the age of 61 only a week ago.

title: JUNO LIGHTING reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Chairman of Sovran A Leader in Mergers
description: C.A. Cutchins 3d, the 62-year-old chairman and chief executive of the Sovran Financial Corporation, Virginia's largest bank holding company, knows a thing or two about mergers. He started small, but as time has passed his horizons have expanded.

title: Nixon, the Dinner Guest
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon has agreed to appear at a dinner to be given in his honor by the National Black Republican Council Oct. 17 at the New York Hilton. It will be the only dinner honoring him that Mr. Nixon has agreed to attend this year, in this country, according to his administrative assistant, John Taylor, who added that Mr. Nixon was honored at a number of dinners on his recent trip to the Far East and South Asia.

title: SECOND CANADIAN CABINET OFFICIAL QUITS IN A WEEK
description: A Canadian Cabinet minister announced his resignation today in the second such departure from the year-old Mulroney Government this week.

title: Blast in Muffler Shop Kills 4 in Florida City
description: An explosion ripped through an automobile muffler shop Tuesday, killing four people, injuring eight and rocking homes and businesses throughout the neighborhood, the authorities said.

title: Cardinal Poma Dies; Church Leader in Italy
description: Antonio Cardinal Poma, a leader of the Roman Catholic Church in Italy during 10 years of social upheaval over abortion, divorce and left-wing terrorism, died of heart problems today. He was 75 years old.

title: Atari Officer to Leave Post
description: James L. Copland, vice president in charge of marketing for the Atari Corporation, announced today that he is resigning to start a software distribution company.

title: Advertising;   Addendum
description: * The New Yorker magazine will raise its rates 5.6 percent in January.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''There were no particular new proposals put on the table, but there was a thorough exchange of views and I think it was most worthwhile.''

title: A CO-OP'S LEAFY RETREAT FOR OWNERS AND PLANTS
description: GIVING city houseplants a summer outdoors is not always easy to arrange. But a lucky group of Upper West Side co-op residents have what may be a unique solution. Their plants spend the summer in the building's garden, tended by Thomas Parisi, a shareholder who has created a green, flowery space in what was once a neglected back area.

title: As Tax Increase Nears, Sales of Liquor Climb
description: Faced with a hefty increase in the Federal excise tax on liquor next week, some consumers may be tempted to reach for the W. C. Fields lament, ''The cost of living has gone up another dollar a quart.''

title: Notes and Bonds Up Modestly
description: Treasury note and bond prices rose modestly yesterday, spurred by speculation that the Federal Reserve will encourage lower interest rates in order to foster a decline in the value of the dollar.

title: PRICE RISE ON STEEL SPREADING
description: Major mills yesterday joined in price increases on sheet steel and tin plate in the industry's first major effort in two years to reverse tumbling prices.

title: Market Place;   Spur to Stocks Overseas Seen
description: A FIVE-NATION plan to drive down the value of the dollar should in the long run enhance prospects for stocks overseas, according to investment experts. The United States - along with Britain, West Germany, France and Japan -signaled its intent on Sunday to weaken the dollar as part of an effort to correct imbalances in world trade.

title: D'AMATO PROPOSES DEARIE FOR BENCH
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said yesterday that he had recommended the United States Attorney in Brooklyn for a Federal judgeship.

title: A WEEK DEVOTED TO ART DECO DESIGN
description: THE style known as Art Deco has an enduring appeal. ''It's elegant and it's kitsch,'' said William T. Weber of the Rambusch Decorating Company in Manhattan. ''It's appealing to the young and the old alike. It's exuberant but also refined.''

title: TEXT OF THE CHARTER PROPOSAL
description: Following are the text of a question that would be put before city voters in November on whether to amend the City Charter, and the text of a summary of the amendment that would also appear on the ballot:

title: Yields Firm on C.D.'s As Money Funds Gain
description: Rates on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were firm for the week ended yesterday, while money market mutual funds showed a slight gain.

title: SPEAKES ASSAILS LACK OF COVERAGE OF TAX PLAN BY NATIONAL REPORTERS
description: The White House today asserted that President Reagan's plan to modify the Federal income tax system had gathered public support despite a ''steady drumbeat of skepticism'' from reporters from national news organizations.

title: THE WRAPS COME OFF A 1901 BEAUX-ARTS MANSION
description: THE five stories of scaffolding around the Benjamin Duke mansion at 1009 Fifth Avenue stayed up so long that when the poles and planks were dismantled several weeks ago, it amounted to an unveiling. Neighbors who had nearly forgotten the details of the house during the three years the facade was being restored were confronted with a regal copper roof and a pristine brick-and-limestone Beaux-Arts facade. The carefully restored six-story house looks as though it were a period building belonging to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, just across the street.

title: EASTERN TROUT THREATEN SPECIES IN YELLOWSTONE
description: Park officials are watching closely this week to see if they were successful in efforts last month to kill off a foreign species of fish that threatened another species here.

title: OPERA: TADDEI IN 'FALSTAFF,' AT THE MET
description: IT is one of opera's oldest and most durable plots: the young singer steps out on the stage for the first time and brings down the house. That scenario played itself out at the Metropolitan Opera Wednesday night with only one slight variation. The debutant was Giuseppe Taddei, making his first Met appearance at age 69 in the title role of Verdi's ''Falstaff.'' Mr. Taddei, who has been one of the leading baritones on the international scene for nearly half a century (he made his opera debut in Rome in 1936), arrived with a glittering splash. His Falstaff, not only wittily acted and fully formed, was astonishingly well sung. The voice is not exactly plummy these days, but it retains a wonderfully liquid quality in lyric passages as well as the ability to bark out in the buffo style that for most Falstaffs is the beginning and end of the vocal gamut.

title: Minnesota Bonds
description: A $150 million issue of Minnesota general obligation bonds was offered yesterday through underwriters led by Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: THAI LEADER STRESSES STABILITY
description: Prime Minister Prem Tinsulandonda, who recently survived the second attempted coup against his administration in less than five years, is going to the United States to convince investors that Thailand is economically and politically stable.

title: VICTOR POTAMKIN, THE SALESMAN
description: VICTOR POTAMKIN wants to sell you a car. He would prefer to sell you a Cadillac - he wouldn't buy any other kind of car himself, he says - but he would also be happy to sell you a Subaru, a Dodge, a Volkswagen, a Renault, an Isuzu, a Lincoln or a Toyota from one of the 28 dealerships he owns with his two sons, Robert and Alan. ''We'll sell you a car for a $100 profit,'' he said. ''We won't let you go.''

title: DEWEY ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income after extraordinary charges of $3,000 for the quarter and $206,000 for the year.

title: MCI Names President
description: The MCI Communications Corporation announced that Bert C. Roberts Jr. had been named president and chief operating officer. The appointment, which is effective Oct. 1, had been expected by securities analysts. Mr. Roberts succeeds V. Orville Wright, who earlier this summer was named vice chairman.

title: Coke to Sell Unit
description: The Coca-Cola Company has agreed to sell Embassy Pictures to Dino De Laurentiis Productions Inc. for an undisclosed amount, the companies have announced. Coke, which acquired Embassy Communications and Tandem Productions last month for $485 million in cash and common stock, will retain ownership of Embassy Television, Embassy Home Entertainment and Embassy Telecommunications. Coca-Cola said the sale was in accordance with previously announced plans to divest itself of Embassy's film operations.

title: MANHATTAN DAY SCHOOL BLENDS DIVERSITY, JEWISH TRADITION
description: JONATHAN BERNSTEIN, 7 years old, came home the other day and said to his parents, Irwin and Suzanne Bernstein, ''I love school so much that I hope it will have a junior high school, a high school and a medical school.''

title: A.M.C.-China
description: The American Motors Corporation and a Chinese company will begin production today of Jeep Cherokees in Peking, A.M.C. officials said. The joint venture company, the Beijing Jeep Corporation, plans to produce 750 Jeep Cherokees by the end of 1985 and about 4,500 in 1986, A.M.C. said. The Chinese version of the Cherokee, a four-wheel-drive station wagon, will be virtually the same as those produced in Toledo, Ohio.

title: Victory Song
description: Manager Buck Rodgers of the Montreal Expos, borrowing from Cole Porter, reflects on Tuesday's 17-15 victory over Chicago: ''It was just one of those things, just one of those crazy things.''

title: Refinery Deal In Curacao
description: The Netherlands Antilles Government and the Royal Dutch/Shell Group have signed a letter of intent that will allow the Government to take over Shell's Curacao oil refinery, a Government spokesman said.

title: DOLLAR FALLS A BIT AMID INTERVENTION
description: The dollar fell moderately yesterday as a consensus formed that central banks are serious about intervening in the currency markets to force down the dollar.

title: COMPUSCAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
GOOD NAME OF VIDALIA ONION IS AT ISSUE IN A GEORGIA COURT
description: Attorneys for a man accused of illegally selling out-of-state onions as the sweet, more expensive Vidalia onions argue that there is no legal definition of a Vidalia onion.

title: Trade Study Is Blocked
description: The White House Office of Management and Budget has scuttled a proposed study by the United States International Trade Commission into practices of semiconductor manufacturers, officials of both agencies said today. The move marks the first time the O.M.B. has blocked a proposed study by the trade commission, an independent agency.

title: SOVIET AIDE OFFERS NO NEW ARMS PLAN IN MEETING SHULTZ
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and the Soviet Foreign Minister met for four and a half hours today but apparently failed to narrow the gap between the two countries on arms control issues.

title: Falwell Ordered to Pay The $5,000 He Offered
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell was ordered by a judge Tuesday to honor a $5,000 offer to a homosexual who proved that Mr. Falwell had attacked his church.

title: AFP IMAGING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $116,155.

title: Reuben Hill, 73, Dies; Professor of Sociology
description: Reuben L. Hill, a retired professor of sociology at the University of Minnesota who specialized in research on family sociology, died of heart attack Saturday in Oslo, Norway. He was 73 years old.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Bank Ltd., the international banking arm of the American Express Co., has elected to its board Sheldon Gordon, most recently vice chairman and head of the investment committee of Shearson Lehman Brothers. Mr. Gordon was also elected chairman of the American Express Bank (Switzerland) A.G., Zurich.

title: Hawaii Volcano Spouts Lava
description: Kilauea volcano hurled molten rock 1,000 feet high today in the 37th major phase of an eruption that began Jan. 3, 1983, on the Island of Hawaii, 200 miles from Honolulu on the Island of Oahu. A stream of lava from the outburst, which began Tuesday, stopped a mile short of a residential area, Royal Gardens. Kiluaea is perched on the eastern flank of the 13,600-foot Mauna Loa, the other active volcano on Hawaii Island.

title: Rebuff for Lewis
description: After winning four gold medals at the 1984 Olympics and setting several records since then, Carl Lewis may have thought he didn't need to practice before joining the United States track and field team at the International Amateur Federation's World Cup in Canberra, Australia, next weekend. The Athletics Congress, which runs the American team, thought otherwise.

title: MENTAL DISTRESS STALKS MEXICANS
description: Countless people are aimlessly walking the streets. Others have collapsed in hysteria. At least one young woman committed suicide.

title: Columbia Punter Officially Resigns
description: Pete Murphy, the Columbia punter who was singled out for extremely harsh criticism by Coach Jim Garrett after the 49-17 loss to Harvard last Saturday, yesterday announced his resignation from the team.

title: 4th General Foods Suitor Seen
description: The Ralston Purina Company has been invited to make a takeover bid for the General Foods Company, insiders said yesterday.

title: Reagan's 'Facts' - Artistic License
description: For a country with a major theatrical tradition - films, stage, television - we are singularly deficient in our understanding of Ronald Reagan.

title: William C. Rose, Biochemist; Cited for Amino Acids Work
description: William C. Rose, a University of Illinois biochemist whose work on proteins and amino acids was honored with the National Medal of Science in 1967, died Wednesday, the university reported.

title: UNIVAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes $6,835,000, or $1.23 a share, from sale of the Van Waters & Rogers plant in Dallas.

title: SENATE BACKS BILL FOR CLEANING UP HAZARDOUS DUMPS
description: The Senate today voted to provide $7.5 billion over the next five years to clean up hazardous waste dumps.

title: PLAYERS PLAN TO CERTIFY AGENTS
description: In a move to curb unscrupulous agents, the National Basketball Players Association has unanimously approved a plan to certify all agents, effective Nov. 1. The 23 player representatives took the action Monday at a meeting in Chicago.

title: Olin Restructuring To Cut 3,500 Jobs
description: The Olin Corporation yesterday announced a major restructuring that will cut employment by 3,500 and result in a $330 million pretax charge against earnings in the third quarter.

title: Inland Steel Sees Deficit
description: The Inland Steel Company said today that it expects to report a net loss of about $50 million, or $2 a share, in the third quarter and that the company will eliminate its 12.5-cents-a-share quarterly common stock dividend that would have been paid on Dec. 1.

title: Market Place;   Food Stock Speculation
description: TAKEOVER fever swirling around the General Foods Corporation has ignited interest in other packaged food companies, sending some stocks, along with the purveyor of Jell-O and Maxwell House coffee, to record prices this week.

title: DINNER CELEBRATES BERNSTEIN PROGRAM
description: When Leonard Bernstein found television, music found Americans where it had never found them before. Mr. Bernstein has been a composer, a conductor, a pianist and a teacher, but television made him a communicator - one who helped persuade a generation of viewers that classical music was neither as elitist nor incomprehensible as prejudice had made them believe.

title: Optimism on Sutter
description: The 1985 season has come to an early end for Bruce Sutter, the high-paid relief pitcher, but neither he nor the Atlanta Braves are complaining. Sutter, who has been bothered by a sore shoulder off and on over the last three months, was removed from the staff after a day of medical tests determined that there wasn't anything wrong that couldn't be cured by rest and exercise.

title: STRIDE RITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
MUSIC: THE PKILHARMONIC IN A SCHNITTKE PREMIERE
description: ALFRED SCHNITTKE, often mentioned as the most talented Soviet composer of the postwar generation, has been known in this country mostly by reputation. But to judge from his ''In Memoriam...'', which the New York Philharmonic and Zubin Mehta gave its New York premiere last evening, the esteem in which he is held in avant-garde circles is not misplaced. The 1978 work, an arrangement for orchestra of his Quintet for Piano and Strings of two years earlier, made a strong impression for its instrumental skill, its haunting sonorities and power to seize and sustain a mood.

title: SCREEN: 'DEATH OF RICCI'
description: GIAN-MARIA VOLONTE won a 1983 best-actor award at the Cannes Film Festival for his performance in ''The Death of Mario Ricci,'' a quietly meticulous film by the Swiss director Claude Goretta. Opening today at the Thalia, ''The Death of Mario Ricci'' follows a week in the lives of two journalists visiting a small Swiss village. Bernard Fontana (Mr. Volonte) is a quiet, somber, reflective television journalist, recently crippled in an accident, who is on location to do an interview with the help of his young assistant, Didier Meylan (Jean-Michel Dupuis). Their subject is Prof. Henri Kremer (Heinz Bennent), an expert on world hunger, whose studies of that problem have brought him to the brink of utter despair.

title: Iraqis Again Attack Iranian Oil Terminal
description: Iraqi warplanes struck again today at Iran's main Kharg Island oil terminal, and shipping sources said exports from the terminal had been halted.

title: EUROPEANS AT U.N. UNITE IN CALLS FOR AN END TO THE ARMS RACE
description: European envoys called today for an end to the arms race, noting that the 40th anniversary of the United Nations coincides with the 40th anniversary of the Hiroshima bombing.

title: COMMUNICATIONS & CABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: F.D.I.C. Wins Court Case
description: Seven partners who bought the First National Bank building downtown in late 1982 for $75 million - 10 months before the bank was declared insolvent - have been ordered to begin paying $31.8 million plus interest to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation by United States District Judge Lucius Bunton. The ruling was issued Wednesday in a lawsuit that contended payments on the property were overdue.

title: Boxer Reinstated
description: Stanley Ross, one of the 40 boxers suspended by New Jersey authorities earlier this year after chemical tests found traces of drugs in their systems, has been reinstated because the state failed to keep proper track of the test results, according to the acting athletic commissioner, Nick Ballistreri. In ordering the reinstatement, Ballistreri said that several other boxers who have appealed their suspensions may have to be reinistated for the same reason.

title: Say It Ain't So, Peter
description: Commissioner Peter Ueberroth has proposed a remedy worse than the problem in his appeal to major-league baseball players to submit to unscheduled testing for possible drug abuse. The players have every reason to insist that this program be negotiated with their union, and their rights respected.

title: RECITAL: FREDERICK MOYER
description: FREDERICK MOYER, who played a recital Monday night at Merkin Hall (129 West 67th Street), is a first-class young pianist. His playing is clean, unmannered and full of ideas and intelligence.

title: THE SCREEN: 'RAN,' DIRECTED BY AKIRA KUROSAWA
description: IT would be difficult to imagine a more appropriate way to open the 23d New York Film Festival than with the two showings, which are scheduled for tonight at Lincoln Center, of Akira Kurosawa's ''Ran'' (''Chaos''), a film of the sort of grandeur that brings to mind Griffith's ''Birth of a Nation,'' ''Napoleon Vu par Abel Gance'' and Eisenstein's ''Ivan the Terrible.''

title: Caution On 'Star Wars'
description: The Lawrence Livermore Laboratory here is a nerve center for President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative - the still largely imaginary ''Star Wars'' in terms of scientific assurance. Staff members are eager to point out that the lab does a lot more, designing nuclear weapons but also non-military work, such as research into fusion energy and environmental radiation problems.

title: STORM FORECAST SEEN AS PRIMITIVE ART
description: Predicting the path of a hurricane is still a primitive art in which skill and luck play complementary roles, according to meteorologists.

title: EAGLES SHOWING STEADY PROGRESS
description: The Philadelphia Eagles ended practice this afternoon with the enthusiasm of a team whose wounds had been licked and healed.

title: Accounts
description: * Logicsoft Inc., Farmingdale, L.I., which markets personal computer software, hardware and systems, to Greenstone & Rabasca Advertising, Melville, L.I.

title: KOCH AND CUOMO SLICE WESTWAY PIE IN PLAN FOR A FEDERAL FUNDS TRADE-IN
description: Mayor Koch and Governor Cuomo carved up the remains of Westway yesterday, agreeing to give at least 60 percent of the nearly $2 billion in Federal funds and local grants to mass-transit projects and about $800 million to a new highway between the Battery and West 59th Street.

title: Anxiety in Pennsylvania
description: Gov. Dick Thornburgh of Pennsylvania is seriously contemplating challenging Senator Arlen Specter, a fellow Republican, in the 1986 state primary. But the other principal Pennsylvania Republican, Senator John Heinz, is strongly opposed to such a move, saying, ''There is no reason for any Republican primary to take place.''

title: OPERA: 'FALSTAFF' AT THE MET
description: It is one of opera's oldest and most durable plots: the young singer steps out on the stage for the first time and brings down the house. That scenario played itself out at the Metropolitan Opera Wednesday night with only one slight variation. The debutant was Giuseppe Taddei, making his first Met appearance at age 69 in the title role of Verdi's ''Falstaff.'' Mr. Taddei, who has been one of the leading baritones on the international scene for nearly half a century (he made his opera debut in Rome in 1936), arrived with a glittering splash. His Falstaff, not only wittily acted and fully formed, was astonishingly well sung. The voice is not exactly plummy these days, but it retains a wonderfully liquid quality in lyric passages as well as the ability to bark out in the buffo style that for most Falstaffs is the beginning and end of the vocal gamut.

title: Turner Assets
description: The Turner Broadcasting System said yesterday that it might sell some assets, including a minority stake in its Cable News Network, as part of its planned acquisition of the MGM/UA Entertainment Company. According to Wall Street sources, Ted Turner has approached various concerns, including CBS and NBC, about selling 20 to 30 percent of the news service. Any asset sale, Mr. Turner said, would be part of a restructuring and not intended to help finance the $1.5 billion MGM purchase.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alco Health Services Corp., a full-service wholesale distributor of pharmaceutical products with headquarters in Valley Forge, Pa., said it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire Meyers & Co. of Tiffin, Ohio, from Hillman Securities Inc. for 1,110,000 shares of Alco Health Services common stock.

title: Black & Decker
description: The Black & Decker Corporation said that it would consolidate its United States power tools and related units into a single operating group, eliminating about 100 management and staff jobs in the process. The company said that it would bring together its professional power tools, consumer power tools, outdoor products, accessories and product service units, which currently employ 600 people, at one location near Black & Decker's Towson, Md., corporate headquarters. About 125 employees will be relocated in the consolidation.

title: SIKH MODERATE PARTY SWEEPS PUNJAB VOTING
description: Voters in the troubled state of Punjab rejected the Congress Party of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi on Wednesday and chose a moderate Sikh party to form a new state Government, according to returns announced tonight.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Atlantic Financial, Bala Cynwyd, Pa., has appointed Phillips F. Lewis president of First United Federal Savings Bank, its California division.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: On Promoting Fear in the Minds of Our Nation's Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: SAFECARD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
FRIGITRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NEW ANTITRUST CHIEF VOICES CONCERNS ON CONRAIL
description: The Reagan Administration's proposal to sell the Consolidated Rail Corporation to the Norfolk Southern Corporation may have inadequate provisions for protecting rail competition, the new chief of the Justice Department's antitrust division said today.

title: Stanford Investigating 23 Suspected of Cheating
description: In what Stanford University officials say is the largest investigation in the history of the university's honor code, 23 of 744 students in a psychology class are under investigation.

title: Virginia Publisher To Start Defense News
description: For years, the Times Journal Company down in Springfield, Va., has covered the military complex with The Army Times, The Navy Times and The Air Force Times.

title: MEDICAL ELECTRONICS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $80,711 for the quarter and $258,370 for the 9 months. c-Net losses.

title: Hutton Agrees to Georgia Probation
description: E. F. Hutton & Company signed a consent decree yesterday with the State of Georgia that puts Hutton on probation for a year for its illegal check overdrafting practices, but allows its business there to continue unabated.

title: SERRANO ASSERTS HISPANIC VOTERS LOST FRANCHISE
description: Assemblyman Jose E. Serrano, who was defeated in the Democratic primary for Bronx borough president, charged yesterday that many Hispanic voters in the Bronx had been disenfranchised by irregularities at the polls.

title: Yankees Are Rained Out
description: The Yankees' game last night with the Detroit Tigers was called because of rain and will be made up after the regular season only if necessary to determine a division winner in the American League East.

title: REAGAN HOPING FOR ARMS PROPOSAL BY SOVIET
description: President Reagan is hoping that a ''concrete proposal'' to limit nuclear arms will be offered by the Soviet Foreign Minister in their meeting Friday, the White House national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane, said today.

title: BEACHFRONT DWELLERS BRAVE THE RISKS
description: Despite many risks and difficulties, beachfront development in the New York region has continued briskly in recent years as the lure of ocean vistas and the luxury of beachfront living have, for those able to afford it, outweighed the drawbacks.

title: YEN'S RISE NOW SEEMS KEY GOAL
description: It is becoming increasingly clear that last Sunday's five-nation accord to work together to lower the dollar was largely aimed at putting pressure on Japan to follow through on past pledges to strengthen the value of the yen. A stronger yen would help cut the United States trade deficit, by making Japanese imports more expensive for Americans to purchase and by making United States goods less expensive in Japan.

title: Advertising;   'Doughnut' TV Spots For Caldor
description: FOR its first real foray into television advertising, the Caldor discount store chain will embrace the old doughnut concept.

title: Ewing's Numbers
description: He may have gained renown and been drafted No. 1 because of his ability to play defense, to rebound and to intimidate, but the numbers show that, when the Knick camp opens tomorrow at Hofstra University, Patrick Ewing will have no reason to apologize if the issue of offensive production comes up. Indeed, his four-year college figure of 15.3 points a game is right in line with those of the other first-round picks this year -13th out of 24, to be precise. It is also pretty close to the norm for the college averages of No. 1 overall picks during the last decade, starting in 1976 with John Lucas, 18.3, and continuing with Kent Benson, 15.3; Mychal Thompson, 20.8; Magic Johnson, 17.1; Joe Barry Carroll, 17.7; Mark Aguirre, 24.5; James Worthy, 14.5; Ralph Sampson, 16.9, and Akeem Olajuwon, 13.3.

title: ART: A DEFOREST SHOW
description: INTRODUCING his new work at the Frumkin Gallery, 50 West 57th Street, Roy DeForest says in the catalogue that art is ''simply a matter of appearances.'' These, he insists, are ''real, whole and dense - never deceiving unless given critical interpretation.''

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE Restructuring at Top Of Metropolitan Life
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, the nation's second-largest life insurer, yesterday announced a restructuring of its top management that it said was partly a response to the company's diversification.

title: AVERY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Unforgotten Concubine
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: THE VIENNA PHILHARMONIC
description: BARELY more than six months ago, the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra came to Carnegie Hall for three concerts of standard repertory under the direction of Leonard Bernstein. Last night, the same orchestra was back in the same hall, this time under Lorin Maazel, for the first of three straight nights of more unrelievedly mainstream warhorses. It's a great group, and all, but doesn't it ever play anything but the basics?

title: Wheeling Plans Management Cuts
description: The strikebound Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation said that to further conserve cash, it would reduce the salaries of all management personnel 10 percent and increase managerial layoffs. Both actions are effective Oct. 1.

title: ABOUT BOSTON
description: Kenneth N. Carstens has been very busy. A white South African who has lived half his 50 years in the United States, he spent all last week linking up with other Boston area activists against racial separation in his country.

title: COMPUTERIZED BUYING NETORK reports earnings for Year to June 30
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: United Technologies
description: William F. Paul, the 49-year-old president of United Technologies' Sikorsky Aircraft division, has been named senior vice president, defense and space systems, of the parent company, United Technologies said today. Two other promotions were also announced. Robert Zincone, Sikorsky's executive vice president, will become president of the division, and Eugene Buckley becomes executive vice president for operations.

title: CHURCH'S FRIED CHICKEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 8
Jays Wait and Then Lose
description: The Blue Jays lost to the Boston Red Sox, 4-1, tonight in a game that started 3 hours 18 minutes late because of rains preceding Hurricane Gloria.

title: SENIOR K.G.B. MAN SAID TO DEFECT AND GIVE SPYING DATA TO THE WEST
description: A senior member of the K.G.B. has defected and is providing information to the West about Soviet espionage operations in Europe and the United States, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: A Fair Choice for the P.L.O.
description: In an effort to save the deadlocked Arab-Israeli peace process, King Hussein of Jordan has come to Washington to ask for unilateral concessions to the Palestine Liberation Organization. We should refuse him for his own good.

title: New Zealand Is Shaken By Large Earthquake
description: An earthquake centered in the Pacific Ocean 350 miles off New Zealand shook many parts of the two main islands today, but there were no immediate reports of damage, a Government scientist said.

title: CANADA SEEKING PACT WITH U.S. ON FREER TRADE
description: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said today that he had told President Reagan that Canada was interested in negotiating a liberalized trade agreement between the two countries.

title: QUINONES COUNTERS ATTACK ON BILINGUAL INSTRUCTION
description: City Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones yesterday defended instructing students who do not speak English in their native languages and criticized the Federal Education Secretary for challenging the approach.

title: Oil Prices Surge on Producer Moves
description: Prices of crude oil and oil products, as well as oil-company stocks, rose significantly yesterday on the world markets as Iran, beleaguered by Iraqi bombing attacks, and the Soviet Union, apparently beset by production problems, separately announced a temporary halt to crude-oil exports. In addition, Saudi Arabia said that its state-owned oil company would accept no new customers for two weeks.

title: AIDS TESTS FOR TROOPS ASSIGNED ABROAD ASKED
description: Defense Department health officials, acting on the advice of civilian medical advisers, have proposed that the military screen all troops assigned overseas for exposure to the AIDS virus, Pentagon officials said today.

title: When All the Restaurant's a Stage
description: To the Editor:

title: Not-So-Vital Statistics on William Bennett
description: Education Secretary William J. Bennett, known as outspoken, has created a stir most recently with proposals for changes in Federal bilingual education programs. Here are some personal insights, as provided by him:

title: Senate Approves Funds For Intelligence Units
description: The Senate voted tonight to authorize large-scale but unspecified spending for the nation's intelligence agencies in fiscal year 1986, which starts Oct. 1.

title: BLOUNT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income.

title: AIDS-LIKE AILMENT GIVEN TO MONKEYS
description: Scientists at Harvard University have succeeded for the first time in infecting monkeys with a disease almost identical with acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS. They said they expected the animals to provide a vitally needed model for experiments with vaccines and drug treatments against the fatal disorder.

title: Rangers Win
description: Dave Gagner and Steve Patrick each scored a goal and had an assist to spark the Rangers to a 7-5 National Hockey League exhibition victory over the Buffalo Sabres tonight.

title: TOP HEALTH OFFICIAL AND EXPERT SEEK GREATER RISE IN AIDS MONEY
description: The debate over the adequacy of Government financing for AIDS research intensified in Congress today as a top public health official said he had recommended an additional $70 million increase next year and a Harvard scientist said even that would not be enough to cope with a ''mounting disaster.''

title: Dramaturgy Is Subject Of Hunter Symposium
description: The dramaturg, a person considered to be the literary adviser to a theater company or playwright, will be the subject of a one-day symposium on Nov. 2 at Hunter College, Park Avenue and 68th Street.

title: THOSE RESCUED BABIES: WHY THEY SURVIVED
description: Babies are normally born with an extra reserve of fluids and a capacity to handle stress, and this, along with pure luck, may have accounted for the incredible survival of a few infants found buried in the rubble of the Mexico earthquake, specialists in pediatric medicine said yesterday.

title: BROOKLYN ARTS CENTER OPENS FIRST 'FRINGE SERIES'
description: In ''Showmanship,'' Oliver Phillip Walker's comedy about professional wrestling set in the Deep South, our latest national craze is presented as the grown-up equivalent of heavy metal rock.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: LE SCANDALE GREENPEACE
description: At Le Maryland, a brass-counter cafe in a working-class neighborhood not far from the Bastille, Bernard Barral serves espresso and beer and ham sandwiches made of elongated slices of crusty bread. The Greenpeace affair, he says, does not bother him very much.

title: 2 BRITONS KIDNAPPED IN BEIRUT
description: Gunmen kidnapped two British women today in West Beirut, witnesses said.

title: JERSEY TO GET SLAYING SUSPECT
description: An accused terrorist who has been indicted in the 1981 slaying of State Trooper Philip Lamonaco will be arraigned Friday before a Somerset County judge, the state police announced today.

title: ROBERTA Z. SULZBERGER
description: Roberta Z. Sulzberger, for many years the executive secretary of the Institute for Dermatologic Communication and Education, in San Francisco, died of cancer Tuesday.

title: HURRICANE'S THREAT BRINGS EVACUATION OF FIRE ISLAND
description: Fire Island residents frantically nailed boards to window sills, took their most valuble possessions and rode ferryboats to the Long Island mainland yesterday in an evacuation of Fire Island intended to prevent loss of life in case Hurricane Gloria came to the metropolitan area.

title: BELLEVUE DOCTOR SAYS STEWART LACKED HEARTBEAT AND PULSE
description: A Bellevue Hospital physician testified yesterday at the trial of six transit police officers accused in the death of Michael Stewart that Mr. Stewart had no heartbeat, pulse or blood pressure when emergency-room personnel began their resuscitation efforts in the early morning hours of Sept. 15, 1983.

title: Loan Seen For Manila
description: The Government of the Philippines, after an unannounced visit here two weeks ago by Prime Minister Cesar Virata, may borrow an additional $100 million from the International Monetary Fund within the next couple of weeks, monetary officials here said today.

title: HURRICANE STRIKES ISLANDS ON COAST OF NORTH CAROLINA
description: Hurricane Gloria crashed into the spindly barrier islands of the Outer Banks near Cape Hatteras early today, as the storm pushed northward along the Atlantic Coast, forcing the evacuation of hundreds of thousands of residents as far north as New England.

title: ELECTRO RENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
A Question of Letters At OTB
description: More letter symbols may be on their way out, if offtrack bettors agree.

title: ARMS TALKS: 'YOUR MOVE'
description: When President Reagan and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze meet on Friday, they will do so without benefit of the usual prior diplomatic stage-setting. Officials on both sides said the result might be little or no progress in nuclear arms control unless the unusual happens.

title: ART: GREEK VASE PAINTING ON DISPLAY AT THE MET
description: GREEK vase painting is a subject of undisputed artistic importance that has rarely inspired passion outside the academic world. ''The Amasis Painter and His World: Vase-Painting in Sixth-Century B.C. Athens,'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is an example of the problem. The idea is original and the subject is rich, but the treatment is so scholarly and unimaginative that it would be difficult for someone not already familiar with vase painting to realize what the show has to offer.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Finance/New Issues column of Business Day on Wednesday misstated the new, lower debt rating of the Union Camp Corporation. It is AA-.

title: Bridge: New York Is the Latest Stop For a Much-Traveled Expert
description: The world's most traveled expert during the past year was no doubt Phillip Alder, who edited one of the world's leading bridge magazines, International Bridge, for four years.

title: SAFETY-KLEEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 7
description: b-After a gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $3,706,000.

title: F.A.A. ORDERS MORE INSPECTIONS OF SUSPECT PARTS IN JET ENGINES
description: The Federal Aviation Administration yesterday ordered airlines to inspect key parts of hundreds of Pratt & Whitney engines. The failure of such a part caused a fatal blaze on a British Boeing 737 last month.

title: McCoy Tyner Trio
description: The pianist McCoy Tyner and his trio will perform tonight and tomorrow at Mikell's, 760 Columbus Avenue at 97th Street. Sets begin at 10 P.M., midnight and 1:30 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum. Information: (212) 864-8832.

title: JOUSTING AT THE CLOISTERS
description: On Sunday at the Cloisters, courtesy of the Medieval Festival Guild of New York, one can see how men squared off to establish a pecking order back in the Dark Ages, before modern times settled on the methods of Larry Holmes and Michael Spinks. For the third year, the guild is presenting a festival that will transform the park surrounding the Cloisters into an evocation of a 15th-century town, under the direction of Madeleine Pelner Cosman. Between noon and 5 P.M., there will be two parades, dozens and dozens of performers and, for the grand finale, a joust.

title: A Hunting Weekend
description: If you would like to see how a black bear can be trapped or listen to a duck caller, you can visit the Belleayre Ski Center tomorrow or Sunday in the Catskill Mountains, where the State Department of Environmental Conservation is holding a hunting and fishing weekend, open to the public without charge.

title: SENATE CUTS FUNDS FOR TREASURY AND POSTAL SERVICE
description: The Senate, in a first test of its willingness to make the spending cuts called for in the budget plan Congress approved in August, voted today to cut $139 million from the appropriation for the Treasury Department, the Postal Service and some other agencies.

title: KUWAIT AGAIN RULES OUT PRISONER-HOSTAGE TRADE
description: Kuwaiti officials reiterated today that they had no intention of releasing 17 convicted terrorists in exchange for the freedom of 6 remaining Americans believed to be held hostage in Lebanon.

title: Nippon Phone, A.T.&T. in Pact
description: The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Company, which earlier this week entered into a business agreement with I.B.M., said yesterday that it had agreed to a ''information exchange'' with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Market Closes Mixed, But Dow Rises by 8.74
description: Stock prices were mixed on Wall Street yesterday. Blue-chip issues were propped up by a strong performance in oil stocks and General Foods, while the broader market sagged.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about a letter written to the Black-Jewish Coalition by Mayor Koch, asking members to speak out against the Rev. Louis Farrakhan and Rabbi Meir Kahane, misstated the Mayor's relationship to the organization. He is not a member.

title: Salem 1 Valve Leaks Again
description: Engineers at the Salem 1 nuclear power plant here today repaired a leaking valve and called off their second low-level emergency alert in four days. The coolant valve, which malfunctioned Monday, was repaired at 2 P.M., six hours after the leak was discovered.

title: CURTIS D. GIDDINGS
description: Curtis D. Giddings, a teacher and former vice president of the Yonkers Board of Education, died of a heart attack after surgery Saturday at White Plains Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: Rory Stuart Trio
description: The guitarist Rory Stuart will lead a trio tonight at the Jazz Center of New York, 380 Lafayette Street near East Third Street (212-505-5660). Tomorrow, the saxophonist Archie Shepp will bring a trio, which will be joined by the singer Abbey Lincoln. Shows start at 9 and 10:30 P.M.; tickets are $8.

title: Help for the Boys
description: After Hoover High School in Fresno, Calif., went through the entire 1984 season without winning a game, Coach Pat Plummer was ready to try anything to get the team on the road to victory in 1985. So when Bridgette Farris, a 16-year-old star of girls' soccer, said she wanted to play football, Plummer didn't quibble.

title: CBS OPTIMISTIC ABOUT NETWORK TV
description: Despite an unanticipated erosion of advertising revenue over the past year, CBS yesterday issued a rosy projection for the future of network television in 1990.

title: Futility in Cleaning The Coal We Burn
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM: 'MAXIE,' COMEDY
description: GLENN CLOSE should never have played either of the roles she has in ''Maxie,'' let alone both of them. As a demure young wife named Jan, she is hopelessly coy, and as the 1920's siren of the title she's just plain hopeless. It seems that one day Jan and her nice young husband, Nick, are steaming off wallpaper in their new apartment when they find that Maxie, the deceased former tenant, has left an inscription; pretty soon she has come back and gotten a great deal noisier. ''Maxie'' was adapted by Patricia Resnick from a Jack Finney novel, and was undoubtedly less insufferable on the page than it is here.

title: topics;   Balanced Accounts Blind
description: Representative Don Edwards of California wonders why the United States Commission on Civil Rights has sharply reduced the number of women and minority members heading the commission's state advisory panels. The state advisers are supposed to alert the commission to race relations problems across the country.

title: Israel Asks Cyprus To Extradite Palestinians
description: Israel asked tonight for the extradition of three Palestinians held in the murder of three Israelis in a marina in Larnaca, Cyprus, on Wednesday.

title: Massachusetts Bonds at 5 1/4-9 1/4%
description: Massachusetts is offering $150 million of general obligation bonds, through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: AUCTIONS
description: WHAT are the wire whisks, copper mixing bowls and funnels from James Beard's kitchen worth? Or the marble-topped, iron-based dining table around which Danny Kaye, Julia Child, Burgess Meredith and Andre Surmain gathered? Bidders will find out when property from the estate of Mr. Beard, the chef and cookbook author who died at the age of 81 in January, is auctioned next Thursday at William Doyle Galleries, 175 East 87th Street.

title: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
description: DAY NO. 5 - A King, a Prime Minister and a President are among those who are to address the General Assembly today. The assembly has already heard from 43 foreign delegations as it enters its fifth day of debate. King Hussein of Jordan is to begin the morning session and will be followed by the Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, and the Foreign Ministers of East Germany, Madagascar and Afghanistan. President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania is to lead off in the afternoon. He will be followed by the Foreign Ministers of Ireland, Rumania, Saudi Arabia, Burma, Zaire and Sierra Leone.

title: WHAT'S IN A NAME? NOT MONEY, BRITONS DISCOVER
description: If your last name is Bowman, Birkett, Edmondson, Grigg or Tyson, then you may find a letter from a Lord Gibson waiting for you in the mail.

title: JACQUELINE DE RIBES: A DESIGN FOR SUCCESS
