description: Tall, slender and serene, Jacqueline de Ribes is accustomed to being in the spotlight. With her regal bearing, immaculate grooming and elegant couturier clothes, she has always attracted attention, whether at restaurants, small dinners or huge charity balls.

title: 6 Are Reported Killed In New Sudan Fighting
description: Gunfire broke out in parts of Khartoum early this morning and riot policemen were deployed as tension mounted between northern and southern Sudanese. At least six people were reported killed and many were reported arrested.

title: Settlement Is Reported In Chicago Official's Suit
description: The former Chicago school superintendent, Ruth Love, and the Board of Education have reached a tentative settlement in her $12 million lawsuit against the board that does not include ''payment of any kind.''

title: Balanced Accounts; Injudicious Label
description: When Edward Tamm, then a protege of J. Edgar Hoover, was nominated for a Federal judgeship in 1948, liberals bridled. They said Mr. Hoover's personal assistant could not be relied on to protect individual rights against the Government.

title: ADDISON-WESLEY PUBLISHING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said year-earlier 9 months' share earnings have been restated to reflect a change in accounting principles, net of taxes.

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE season for fund-raising banquets is under way. One of the first open to the public will be held Oct. 12 at Le Ferrandi, the student-run restaurant at the French Culinary Institute (462 Broadway, at Grand, 219-3300).

title: Victory for Rutherford
description: Johnny Rutherford achieved a belated Indy car victory, his first in four years, when an appeals panel overruled a decision by track officials that had cost him a victory in 200-mile race in Canada on Sept. 8. Rutherford, who had been leading when a caution flag was displayed toward the end of the race, was passed by Pancho Carter on the final lap after track officials said the caution flag had been lifted. The appeals panel ruled that the pass had been illegal since the green, all-clear flag, had not been displayed at the time.

title: Senate Panel Backs Nominee For Director of Budget Office
description: The Senate Governmental Affairs Committee today approved the nomination of James C. Miller 3d for budget director and sent his name to the full Senate for confirmation.

title: FOR THE METS, IT AIN'T OVER
description: In a distant city, Dr. Gooden once again behaved like a Cy Young Award pitcher with touches of a latter-day Babe Ruth yesterday, insuring that baseball in New York will continue to have some excitement and validity into the final week of the season.

title: Continental's Pilots Suspend Picketing but Continue Strike
description: The Air Line Pilots Association said today that it was temporarily suspending picketing in its strike against Continental Airlines, which began Oct. 1, 1983, but the union insisted that the strike was continuing.

title: CARDS DEFEAT PHILLIES ON TUDOR'S SHUTOUT
description: John Tudor won his 20th game with a four-hitter and his 10th shutout of the year as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 5-0, tonight.

title: Storm Information Hot Line
description: A special telephone hot line has been activated for information about Hurricane Gloria. The 1-900-410-6622 hotline was set up for the 1985 Atlantic hurricane season, which runs June 1 to Nov. 30.

title: Governor of California Signs New Walfare Law
description: Gov. George Deukmejian signed a bill today that requires most able-bodied welfare recipients in California to seek jobs or training as a condition of receiving their welfare checks.

title: Chris Connor at J's
description: Chris Connor will sing with the Richard Rodney Bennett trio tonight and tomorrow at J's, 2581 Broadway above 97th Street (212-666-3600). Sets begin at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M.; there is a $10 cover and a $7 food or drink minimum.

title: HIPOTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Save the Children From the Executioner
description: To the Editor:

title: New President At Wyle Labs
description: Wyle Laboratories Inc., an electronics components distributor that has suffered badly in the continuing semiconductor slump, yesterday named the head of its electronics marketing group, Charles M. Clough, to be president and chief operating officer.

title: The Financial World Marches On
description: The last vestige of the First National City Corporation disappeared yesterday with the end of ticker symbol FNC.

title: EUROPEANS SEE KEY YEN ROLE
description: Although the five nations participating in last Sunday's accord to seek a lower dollar reiterated earlier agreements to modify features of their domestic economies, monetary officials from the European contingent - Britain, France and West Germany - said yesterday that the most decisive action is expected to come from Japan and the United States.

title: Lugar: In Low Key, But Lunging for Power
description: Senator Richard G. Lugar, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, has been spending much of his free time lately writing a book on foreign policy.

title: Vintage Interiors
description: A 30-room Colonial mansion in Staatsburg in the Hudson Valley, refurnished by 25 interior designers as a showcase of their talents, will be open for inspection starting tomorrow as a benefit for the Hudson Valley Philharmonic Orchestra.

title: IN KEAN-SHAPIRO RACE, CONTRASTS IN MARKETING
description: To hear Peter Shapiro's campaign manager explain it, the strategy for Mr. Shapiro in his race against Governor Kean in the Nov. 5 election must avoid the recent marketing problems encountered by Coca-Cola.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: THE one question I am asked most frequently is where to dine in the Lincoln Center area. For all the brouhaha about a restaurant explosion along Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, there are precious few places where a concertgoer can eat nearby without risking exposure to dreary bar fare or ersatz ethnic in a clamor that puts construction sites in a favorable light.

title: For Children
description: The Duckling's Party THE DUCKLING'S PARTY, the last program of the season at the Hans Christian Andersen Statue, will include Andersen's ''Ugly Duckling'' and ''Elsie Piddock Skips in Her Sleep'' by Eleanor Farjeon, told by Diane Wolkstein, Saturday at 11 A.M. Shirley Keller will play guitar music, and children and their parents are invited to bring skip ropes for the annual contest in Central Park, 72d Street and Fifth Avenue. Free. Plays, Stories, Shows GOLDILOCKS AND THE THREE BEARS, Saturday and Sunday at 1:30 P.M., and HUMPTY DUMPTY FALLS IN LOVE, Saturday and Sunday at 3, by the Little People's Theater Company, at the Courtyard Playhouse, 39 Grove Street. Admission: $4. Reservations required: 765-9540.

title: AS HOPES RISE FOR KNICKS, PRESSURE INCREASES FOR BROWN
description: More than four months have passed since that Sunday afternoon in May when Dave DeBusschere fidgeted before a national-television audience, then pounded his fist on the table in front of him to celebrate the results of professional basketball's first draft lottery. In that time, the Knicks and their prospects for the coming season have been popular subjects among local fans. How is Bernard's knee? Will they trade Cartwright? Or sign any free agents?

title: UEBERROTH INVITES UNION DRUG INPUT
description: Having failed to induce baseball players to agree individually to drug testing, Commissioner Peter Ueberroth yesterday dropped his effort to skirt the Players Association and said he would welcome the union's ''participation in eliminating the drug cloud over baseball.''

title: CLASH OVER FUTURE OF BROADWAY STAGES CONTINUES
description: Imagine strolling to the theater in Times Square through a canyon of office towers, 50 to 70 stories tall, that crowd out the sky and the neon lights of Broadway.

title: UNION OFFICIAL LED SEAFARERS IN CANADA
description: Hal C. Banks, a union official who led the Canadian seafarers' union in the 1950's and early 1960's, died of heart disease Tuesday at St. Mary's Hospital in San Francisco. He was 76 years old.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: IT was a week of festivities that found guests working as hard as their hosts. Paul Davis, the poster artist, was feted in the lobby of the Public Theater at a party for his book, ''Paul Davis: Faces'' (Friendly Press). But for the first 20 minutes, Mr. Davis was absent. It seemed the party's co-host, Joseph Papp, had called an advertising meeting.

title: Jazz at Roulette
description: The flutist Robert Dick will play new compositions and improvisations, with John Zorn on reed instruments and Jim Staley on trombone, tonight at Roulette, 228 West Broadway at White Street (212-431-1022). Tomorrow there will be music by Bill Horvitz on guitar, Butch Morris on cornet and J. A. Deane on electric trombone, and Sunday the pianist David Lopato and the poet Ruth Danon will perform. Concerts begin at 9 P.M.; tickets are $5.

title: Teachers Strikes End In Seattle and Ohio
description: Negotiators last night settled the 3-week-old strike by 3,700 teachers in Seattle, ending the nation's largest teachers' strike, while in Toronto, Ohio, officials announced a tentative agreement, enabling its 1,220 students to return to class next week.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: TABLE OF CONTENTS. By John McPhee. 293 pages. Farrar Straus & Giroux. $15.95.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, a Washington dispatch yesterday on the suspects in the Trans World Airlines hijacking incorrectly referred to the possibility of United States indictments in the case. No indictments are expected to be handed up soon.

title: Dedication
description: Ignoring the pelting rain, children of the United Nations International School loosed 500 multicolored balloons to inaugurate their new playground on the East River yesterday.

title: COUNCIL BACK MORE PUBLICITY FOR CITY PACTS
description: Despite objections from the Koch administration, the City Council yesterday approved a bill requiring the city to give public notification of all proposed consultant contracts over $50,000.

title: A Tough Line
description: Joseph E. diGenova, the United States Attorney for the District of Columbia, in a speech to a group of lawyers in Arlington, Va., tells how he would deal with players implicated in the big drug case if he were Commissioner Peter Ueberroth: ''Nothing that I say here should be misconstrued as criticizing my good friend Jerry Johnson, the U.S. Attorney in Pittsburgh. He had to give these players immunity to get at the pusher.

title: Knowing Real Antiques
description: For those who would like to learn how to tell a genuine antique from a fake, the place to go tomorrow at 3 P.M. is the New York State Museum in Albany for a session on ''The Real Thing: Recognizing Prime Examples of the Arts and Crafts Movement.''

title: U.N. COUNCIL AGREES ON NEED TO IMPROVE
description: A special commemorative session of the Security Council, its first at the ministerial level in 15 years, approved a unanimous declaration today that recognizing the ''urgent need to enhance the effectiveness of the Security Council.''

title: PARIS INDICTS 4 FOR REVEALING SECRETS OF GREENPEACE AFFAIR
description: Four members of the French intelligence agency and a suspended army officer were indicted today on charges of providing secret information to the press about the operation against the antinuclear protest ship, the Rainbow Warrior.

title: Stepped-Up Fighting Reported in Uganda
description: Fighting was stepped up today between the army and guerrillas seeking control of Masaka, the country's third-largest city.

title: SAFETY KEY: KEEP IN TOUCH
description: The National Weather Service advises people threatened by a hurricane to keep radios or televisions turned on, and to start planning evacuation and safety procedures well ahead.

title: GREENPEACE VESSEL FLOATS AGAIN, BUT SEEMS DOOMED TO SCRAPHEAP
description: The antinuclear protest vessel Rainbow Warrior was refloated today, more than two months after being sunk by French agents.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 27, 1985
description: International

title: TULTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
THE STAGE: 'PARADISE'
description: ''PARADISE!'', a new musical that opened the season, so to speak, last night at Playwrights Horizon, begins on a promissory note. The first song is entitled, ''This Could Be the End.'' Would that it were.

title: Semiconductor Upturn Seen
description: The long-depressed semiconductor industry will recover in 1986, with worldwide sales increasing 18 percent, to $25.5 billion, an industry committee predicted today.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds declined $516.0 million, to $208 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: PENTAGON ACTS ON DYNAMICS DIRECTOR
description: The Defense Department said today that it had begun proceedings to revoke the top-secret security clearance of Lester Crown, the biggest shareholder and an influential board member of the General Dynamics Corporation, because of his involvement in a 1972 bribery case.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''All our weather planes and radars create a false impression that we can do a great job forecasting.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 27, 1985
description: International

title: Mixed Reaction From Ex-Lions
description: Coach Jim Garrett's none-too-restrained behavior after Columbia's severely disappointing loss to Harvard last Saturday may not have played particularly well with his superiors, but it gets an O. K. review from the biggest football star whom Morningside Heights has produced in a number of years.

title: TRANSITRON ELECTRONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-Net income The company said its results for fiscal 1985 include a gain of $11.8 million from the sale of its computer cable division in November 1984, a $6.2 million provision for estimated losses from the disposition of property and equipment and the shutdown of certain facilities, of which $2.2 million was recorded in the fourth quarter.

title: Unit Signs Pact in Strike At Philadelphia Papers
description: Mailers at The Philadelphia Inquirer and Daily News signed an agreement today on job security, paving the way for nine striking unions to bargain together with the newspapers' publisher on the remaining issues in the 20-day-old walkout.

title: Carrington Band
description: The drummer Terri Lyne Carrington will lead 11 musicians tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street (212-864-5400). The performers include the singer Dianne Reeves, the pianist Geri Allen, the bassist Rufus Reid and the saxophonists Steve Coleman, John Purcell and Greg Osby. Tickets are $12.

title: Say What?
description: When President Reagan meets with the new Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, in the White House today, their conversation will be translated simultaneously, and the principals and other participants in the session will hear the language being spoken directly through one ear and a translation into either English or Russian through a single headset earphone in the other ear.

title: POSSIBLE BOMB IS FOUND HERE ON HAITIAN JET
description: A device suspected of being a bomb was discovered yesterday in the suitcase of a man who boarded a Haiti Air flight at Kennedy International Airport but then left five minutes before the plane was scheduled to depart, authorities said.

title: THE BEST IN CLASSICAL INDIAN MUSIC
description: THE Festival of India is a huge, mixed media umbrella sheltering Indian arts events across the country over an 18-month period. For New Yorkers who love classical Indian music, however, there hasn't been much to hear thus far. Yes, earlier this month there was a potpourri program at Alice Tully Hall that offered music along with dance and theater, and Zubin Mehta did his bit for the old country at the New York Philharmonic's opening concerts.

title: FILM FESTIVAL: THE GLOBAL FLAVOR IS BACK
description: CHAOS will indeed reign at the opening and closing nights of the 23d New York Film Festival.

title: Builders Didn't Call Titanic Unsinkable
description: To the Editor:

title: Man in Landmark Court Case Arrested in Tavern Shooting
description: Danny Escobedo, whose murder conviction was overturned in a landmark 1964 Supreme Court decision that guaranteed the right to legal counsel, was arrested today and charged with shooting a barroom companion in the cheek, the police said.

title: Hungarian, at the U.N., Meets With Israeli Foreign Minister
description: The Foreign Ministers of Israel and Hungary met today for the first time since 1967, when Hungary broke diplomatic relations after the Middle East war, an Israeli diplomat said today.

title: Nina Simone
description: Nina Simone will sing tonight and tomorrow at 10 and midnight at the Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets (212-475-5120). Tickets are $15, and there is a two-drink minimum.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL WASHINGTON (NBA) - Signed draft choices Kenny Green, forward, and Manute Bol, center.

title: SKIP TRIAL CAPTURES PEGASUS
description: Skip Trial, who scored a surprising victory over Spend a Buck in the Haskell Handicap eight weeks ago, posted a milder upset tonight by holding off the favored Stephan's Odyssey by a neck to win the $333,400 Pegasus Handicap for 3-year-olds at Meadowlands Race Track.

title: FILM: 'INVASION U.S.A.'
description: CHUCK NORRIS'S ''Invasion U.S.A.,'' which opens today at the RKO Warner Twin and other theaters, is a ''Wake Up, America!'' movie of a goofiness to make one long for the sanity and conviction of John Milius's ''Red Dawn.''

title: Battening the Hatches, New York-Style
description: They are orange. They are rounded.

title: 'THE STUFF,' A HORROR SPOOF
description: IT takes a little while to see how ''The Stuff'' is going to tackle the business of selling the public junk food that may be lethal. This horror film spoof, written and directed by Larry Cohen and opening today at Loews Astor Plaza and other theaters, plays it as comedy, such straight comedy that at moments it is in danger of becoming tendentiously unfunny.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Ray Williams, who played with the Celtics last season, has been signed to an offer sheet by the Los Angeles Clippers. . . Terry Donahue, the U.C.L.A. football coach, who had two years remaining on his contract, signed a three-year extension. . . . Chris Kotsopoulos, the defenseman who was turned away from the Hartford training camp after his suspension was lifted, is in limbo while the Whalers try to work out a trade for him. Kotsopoulos, who is involved in a contract dispute, was suspended after failing to attend a practice and scrimmage on Monday. . . . Mario Tremblay, a 31-goal scorer last season with Montreal, will miss 8 to 10 weeks after having surgery for a separated left shoulder. . . . Ferris Fain, the American League batting champion in 1951 and 1952, has been charged with growing marijuana and possession of marijuana for sale, both felonies, at his home in Placerville, Calif.

title: Herbert Greene Dead; A Director of Musicals
description: Herbert Greene, the musical director of many Broadway shows, including ''The Music Man,'' for which he won a Tony Award in 1958, died of a heart attack Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 64 years old.

title: G.M.A.C. Issue
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation is offering $500 million of 10 percent notes due 1990 at a price to investors of 99 3/4, to yield 10.07 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Australian Rules Football Hawthorn Hawks vs. Essendon Bombers, at Melbourne. Grand Final of the Victorian Football League, which is roughly equivalent the Super Bowl. This is what Australians call the premiership in the sport that resembles rugby, both American and Gaelic football and soccer, but was codified in 1859, before any of those sports were. Hawthorn won the Grand Final from Essendon in 1983, and last year Essendon won the Grand Final from Hawthorn. This year, Essendon won the double round-robin regular-season title with a 19-3 record. (Television - ESPN, 12:15 A.M., live.) Baseball Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M., opener of the four-game series. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Pirates, at Pittsburgh. (Television - Channel 9, 7:35 P.M. Radio -WHN,1050; 7:30 P.M.) Braves vs. San Diego Padres, at Atlanta. (Television - WTBS, 7:35 P.M.) Boxing Jose Quinones, champion, vs. Curtis Parker, 12 rounds, for the Continental Americas Middleweight Championship at Atlantis Casino Hotel, Atlantic City. First preliminary, 8 P.M. Quinones, from San Juan, Puerto Rico, is 19-5-2 with 15 knockouts. Parker, of Philadelphia, is 28-6 with 21 knockouts. (Television - MSG, 10 P.M.) Harness Racing Freestate Raceway, Laurel, Md. The $309,554 Breeders Crown for 4-year-olds and up is the richest race ever for aged pacers. The field of seven is led by On the Road Again, the richest racehorse in harness history, with career earnings of $2,455,706 and 16 victories in 22 starts this year alone.

title: PROTEIN THAT SETS OFF GROWTH OF A HUMAN ORGAN IS FOUND
description: Scientists at the Harvard Medical School have discovered and produced in pure form a human substance that stimulates the production of blood vessels.

title: Pentagon;   Rocking the Boat, the Tank, the Jet
description: Just before he retired as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff three years ago, Gen. David C. Jones rocked the military establishment by advocating more authority for the Chairman to make him the chief operating officer of the armed forces.

title: N.H.L. Seeks Image And Hires Ohlmeyer
description: The National Hockey League has just hired its first ad agency in its 69-year history - Ohlmeyer Advertising.

title: People
description: * R. John Cooper, general counsel and secretary, and Roger Craton, chief financial officer, have been named executive vice presidents of Young & Rubicam.

title: THE GREAT A.F.C. SHOOTOUT: MARINO AND ELWAY TO CLASH
description: Rarely do two of the best quarterbacks grace one field on the same afternoon. In the case of Denver's John Elway and Miami's Dan Marino, it has never happened before. They came into the National Football League in the same year, 1983, and in the same round in the college draft, the first; but their teams have not played since 1975, when the Dolphins won, 14-13.

title: Baldwin Deal With S.E.C.
description: The Baldwin United Corporation has settled with the Securities and Exchange Commission on charges it violated antifraud, proxy-solicitation, reporting and accounting provisions of the Federal securities laws in its sales of annuities in the early 1980s. The information was contained in a suit filed in United States District Court in Cincinnati yesterday.

title: Topics;   Balanced Accounts; Moscow's Unused Gold
description: Here's an inviting, practical proposal that President Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev could sensibly approve at their meeting in November: Use the Soviet Union's lend-lease debt of $674 million to fund a two-way educational exchange program.

title: The Stage: Lily Tomlin In 'Search for Signs'
description: IN ''Nashville,'' the Robert Altman film that marked her graduation from television-sketch comedienne to actress, Lily Tomlin was just one of many vivid characters in a throbbing panorama of contemporary American life. To say that this artist has continued to grow in the decade since then is to abridge the story drastically. In Act II of ''The Search for Signs of Intelligent Life in the Universe,'' her new show at the Plymouth, we find that Miss Tomlin and her longtime collaborator, the writer and director Jane Wagner, are attempting what might well be considered their own theatrical update to Mr. Altman's epic. They treat the audience to an idiosyncratic, rude, blood-stained comedy about American democracy and its discontents - and, this time around, Miss Tomlin plays all the parts herself.

title: Death of a Highway
description: Westway, which died officially yesterday, held out some benefit for almost everyone. For the New York region, it promised an efficient traffic route between mainland America and Long Island. For Manhattan, it promised relief from traffic that clots city streets. For Greenwich Village and Chelsea, it promised a graceful green gateway to the Hudson. And for everyone, by containing pollutants, it promised cleaner air.

title: ROLL-CALL IN SENATE ON WASTE CAMP
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate passed the $7.5 billion toxic waste cleanup bill today:

title: PRESIDENT OF UNITED GETS ADDED TITLE
description: The board of directors of UAL Inc. has approved changes in management including a transfer of the chief executive's title in its United Airlines subsidiary, the company announced yesterday.

title: GOODEN PITCHES HIS 8TH SHUTOUT
description: It was cold, it was windy, it was damp, it was growing impossibly late in the pennant race and it was becoming a very long shot, indeed. But the Mets had Dwight Gooden on the mound again this afternoon, and they were safe for one more day.

title: Couple Killed by 'Warriors'
description: Two gunmen dressed in Japanese warrior clothes killed a British couple as they drove into the garage of their apartment building here Wednesday night, the police said today. Detective Jack Holder quoted witnesses as saying they heard shots and saw two men wearing the black costumes of Ninja warriors, who in ancient Japan were trained in the art of assassination, running away. The police said they knew of no motives for the slayings.

title: Citicorp to Add Arizona Bank
description: Citicorp, the nation's largest bank holding company, said it had agreed to buy Great Western Bank and Trust, Arizona's fifth-largest bank, effective Oct. 1, 1986.

title: SHADOW OF CHANGE ON COOPERSTOWN'S TRADITION
description: The crystalline lake immortalized in the novels of James Fenimore Cooper shimmers in clear sunlight these days, a cheerful salute to the fall season here.

title: SPY TRIAL JUDGE SEEKS IDENTITIES
description: A Federal judge who will preside at the trial Jerry A. Whitworth, a retired Navy radioman accused of espionage, today ordered prosecutors to disclose the names of two informers.

title: Kaiser Aluminum
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said that there was no merit to a proposed restructuring of the company filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission by an investor group led by a Tulsa, Okla., investor, Joseph A. Frates.

title: Rates Mixed in Slow Trading
description: Both the short and long ends of the government bond markets posted moderate gains yesterday, while prices of intermediate debt issues registered modest losses.

title: A HOUSE VERSION OF TAX PLAN
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, today presented a plan for revising the Federal income tax system that follows the structure of President Reagan's plan but differs from it in many important aspects.

title: PREMIERES OF 'TWILIGHT ZONE' ANB 'MACGYVER'
description: TWO of the more interesting efforts in new series are having their premieres this weekend: ''The Twilight Zone,'' on CBS tonight at 8 o'clock, and ''MacGyver,'' on ABC Sunday at 8 o'clock.

title: Control Data To Sell Ticketron
description: The Control Data Corporation, which has been battered by the weak market for computers and peripherals, said that itwas offering its Ticketron unit for sale. Ticketron operates a nationwide computerized ticketing service for athletic and entertainment events.

title: DOLLAR INTERVENTION: HOW EFFECTIVE IS IT?
description: The dollar has remained strong for several years, despite widespread sentiment that it is overvalued and repeated predictions that it would soon tumble. Efforts by some governments, particularly West Germany's, to bring it down in recent years by selling huge amounts of the currency, have had only limited effect.

title: Real Estate;   Renewals Without Tax Aid
description: EXPERIENCE has given Solomon T. Scharf some firm views about real estate development. Among these are to stay clear of government agencies and programs and to seek no tax abatements.

title: NO DROUGHT RELIEF EXPECTED
description: Gloria is billed as the Atlantic hurricane of the century, but even its drenching rains would do little to alleviate the drought in eastern New York, two experts said today.

title: Economic Scene;   The Open Door Policy in China
description: DENG XIAOPING, the 81-year-old Chinese leader who this week moved 64 younger and better-educated people into key positions in the Central Committee of the Communist Party, keeps trying to rejuvenate this ancient, backward, centrally controlled society in every way he can.

title: NICHOLS INSTITUTE reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
2 EMPLOYEES ARE KILLED DURING JEWELRY HOLDUP
description: Two employees of a jewelry wholesaler in the midtown diamond district were shot to death yesterday and another was seriously wounded by two robbers who left the concern's 12th-floor office with a sack containing jewels and cash.

title: TII INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-After equity in net losses of affiliate of $402,000 for the quarter and $668,000 for the year. c-After equity in net losses of affiliate of $232,000 for the quarter and $869,000 for the year, and an extraordinary tax credit of $30,000 for the year.

title: POLL FINDS LOSS OF CONFIDENCE IN U.S. COURSE
description: The American public is losing some of its confidence in the direction the country is going and is now evenly split about whether it is headed the right way or off on the wrong track, a New York Times Poll shows.

title: FILM: SPACEK IN 'MARIE'
description: FILMS about lone crusaders battling corruption are helped immeasurably when the hero is presented as a person of some complexity - when a Karen Silkwood is introduced as a flawed, ordinary figure, then transformed and even ennobled by a determination to seek justice. The best of the post-Watergate movies in this mode have made a point of underscoring their characters' imperfections, so that their heightened social consciousness stands out in sharper contrast. ''Marie,'' which like ''Silkwood'' and ''Serpico'' and ''Norma Rae'' depicts one person's fight against corporate or institutional injustice, is a fast-paced, well-acted drama that takes a simpler approach. Its heroine's unqualified nobility is the greatest limitation to an otherwise tight, suspenseful and highly involving story.

title: U.S. APPEALS COURT TO REVIEW SELECTION OF VOTE FRAUD JURY
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit agreed today to review an emergency request by defense attorneys to stop the voter fraud trial of two black political activists, but took no immediate action.

title: A LIST OF THE FILMS THAT WILL BE SHOWN AT THE FESTIVAL
description: The New York Film Festival opens tonight at Lincoln Center -with two screenings of ''Ran'' and a gala afterward at Tavern on the Green - and closes Oct. 13. All films, unless otherwise indicated, are at Alice Tully Hall. Opening and closing nights are sold out. Available tickets for other performances, at $6 and $8, can be obtained at the Tully Hall box office (362-1911). The following is a schedule of the films:

title: HENRY ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: HOUSE UNIT BACKS CURB ON TEXTILES
description: Congress moved closer to a confrontation with the White House over trade policy today as the House Ways and Means Committee approved a bill that would cut back textile imports from a dozen countries by as much as 40 percent.

title: SHULTZ MEETS HUSSEIN ON ARMS SALE AND PEACE TALKS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz held an unpublicized dinner with King Hussein in New York this week to discuss the Reagan Administration's problems with the imminent announcement of the sale of advanced American aircraft and other military equipment to Jordan, Government officials said today.

title: British Sign Deal to Sell 132 Aircraft to Saudis
description: Britain today concluded a multibillion-dollar agreement for the sale of 132 British advanced technology aircraft to Saudi Arabia. Defense Minister Michael Heseltine, who signed the agreement for Britain, said it was ''the largest export negotiation this country has ever concluded.''

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: THEY are still asking Marie Ragghianti in Nashville:

title: Wagner's 'Lime Street' To Begin Its Run on ABC
description: ''Lime Street,'' another new series on Channel 7, had its special premiere last week and begins its regular weekly run tomorrow at 9 P.M. The show clearly means to stand or fall on the appeal of Robert Wagner, who is also one of the producers. Mr. Wagner has had a reasonably solid career in films and such television series as ''To Catch a Thief,'' ''Switch,'' and ''Hart to Hart.'' He is handsome and personable, the equivalent of easy listening in pop music.

title: Dining Out Guide: Pre-Theater
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CAFE 43 RESTAURANT AND WINE BAR, #147 West 43d Street (869-4200) -

title: POLICE SHIFT 4 INSTRUCTORS FOR REMARKS
description: Three instructors at the Police Department firearms range in the Bronx have been transferred after an inquiry into complaints that they had made sexually suggestive and disparaging remarks to female trainees, officials said yesterday.

title: UNITED AIRCRAFT PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a credit of $666,500 due to forgiveness of previously deferred and current taxes.

title: TUNISIA BREAKS OFF TIES WITH LIBYA AND OUSTS 4
description: Tunisia broke diplomatic relations with neighboring Libya today in a bitter dispute touched off by Tripoli's expulsion of migrant workers.

title: The Hart Household
description: Like many another set of parents, Senator Gary Hart and his wife, Lee, have found that the departure of their children for college has enabled them to move to more professionally convenient housing. With their daughter, Andrea, and son, John, both away for the academic year, they have shifted from a house in suburban Bethesda, Md., to a place on Capitol Hill only six blocks from the Senator's work space.

title: VALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss c-After losses from discontinued operations of $14,464,000 for the quarter and $16,516,000 for the 9 months.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL CHICAGO (NBA) - Signed Charles Oakley, first-round draft choice, to three-year contract.

title: The Biaggi Gratitude
description: It wasn't easy for Detective Lieutenant Mario Biaggi to get into New York Law School in the early 1960's, but the Dean, Daniel Gutman, got him a dispensation from the requirement for a college degree and a full-tuition scholarship, and the decorated police officer graduated from night school in 1965 and was admitted to the bar a year later at the age of 49.

title: ISRAEL WON'T ACT AGAINST PRETORIA
description: The Israeli Foreign Minister said in New York yesterday that despite anti-apartheid steps by other governments, his country had no intention of taking measures against South Africa.

title: SENATE VOTES TO RETAIN 16/ FEDERAL CIGARETTE TAX
description: The Senate tonight approved a 45-day extension of the 16-cent Federal cigarette tax that is now scheduled to drop to 8 cents a pack Oct. 1.

title: WESTWOOD ONE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Racing Canceled
description: Officials at Suffolk Downs, anticipating heavy rains and high winds from Hurricane Gloria, today canceled the thoroughbred racing program scheduled for Friday. The move was made to allow track employees to prepare for the storm and minimize damage. Racing was expected to resume Saturday afternoon.

title: Afghan Refugees Who Shouldn't Be Behind U.S. Bars
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet and Oman Set Up Ties
description: The Soviet Union and the Persian Gulf sultanate of Oman have agreed to establish diplomatic relations, the official press agency Tass announced today.

title: BROADWAY
description: JUDITH IVEY, who has already garnered two Tony Awards (''Steaming'' and ''Hurlyburly'') in her comparatively short stage career, will return to Broadway March 13 in ''Precious Sons,'' by George Furth. Her co-star, Ed Harris, introduced to New York audiences in Sam Shepard's ''Fool for Love,'' will be making his first appearance on Broadway in the story of a couple who have divergent dreams for their teen-age sons. Also making their Broadway debuts will be Norman Rene, artistic director of the Production Company, who will direct the play, and Marty Bell, who is co-producing with Roger Berlind.

title: JETS ARE PROMISING IMPROVED OFFENSE
description: The offense of Freeman McNeil and the Jets has ranged from little to spectacular this season. But McNeil, the leading rusher in the American Conference, said today that he and his teammates would not be fooled again Sunday if the Indianapolis Colts tried old methods to stop him.

title: A RARE OPPORTUNITY TO SEE GIACOMETTI BY THE DOZEN
description: IN Paris not long after World War II, Alberto Giacometti was the paradigmatic human being. In his life, as much as in his art, he set the rules and the style of the time. Neither rich (initially), nor pompous (ever), nor decorated (the very idea is absurd), he carried about as much baggage, in outward terms, as St. Jerome in the desert. But he defined the possibilities of life - what was still worth doing, what could just conceivably be done, and what could not be done but was very much worth trying. He abjured the very notion of success, whether in esthetic or in worldly terms. Yet he produced the irreplaceable images by which not only he himself, but the period as a whole, will be judged.

title: INVENTION DESIGN ENGINEERING ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Year to July 31
The Language Is the Melting Pot
description: In one provocative speech, Education Secretary William Bennett has reopened the national debate on bilingual education and done so constructively. He calls the present Federal policy, with its emphasis on instruction in the student's native language, ''confused'' and ''overbearing.'' He wants to give local school districts more flexibility to help students become proficient in English as quickly as possible. That desirable goal should, by now, be beyond dispute.

title: CALIFORNIA AMPLIFIER reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Soviet Trade Deficit
description: The Soviet Union recorded a $3.07 billion trade deficit with the West in the first half of 1985, with Western economic experts attributing the shortfall to a sharp decline in oil and gas sales and a weaker dollar. The deficit, disclosed in figures released today by the Foreign Ministry, compared with a $772 million surplus in the comparable period in 1984.

title: Sharon Was Defamed, An Israeli Court Rules
description: A district court today awarded Ariel Sharon, the former Defense Minister, $2,000 for trial costs in his Israeli suit against Time magazine and ruled that the magazine had defamed him.

title: GOLDEN WEST HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 24
description: b-Including a tax credit of $70,000. c-Net loss after a loss of $26,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Harvard Investment
description: Harvard University is considering selling its $5 million investment in the Philip Morris Companies because of concerns that product-liability suits against cigarette companies could lower the stock's value, a school official said. The university has sold stock in other tobacco companies, including American Brands, Brown & Williamson and R. J. Reynolds. The review is ''not being conducted from the standpoint that tobacco stocks are immoral or wrong,'' said Walter Cabot, president of the Harvard Management Company, which oversees the university's $3 billion endowment.

title: 45 L.I. BUSINESSES ACCUSED OF CHEATING UTILITY METERS
description: Forty-five people, including several restaurant operators, have been charged here with stealing electricity and natural gas worth $1.2 million from the Long Island Lighting Company by hiring a lock picker who rolled back their utility meters, officials said today.

title: DOLLAR, MOSTLY UP, FALLS AGAINST YEN
description: The dollar continued to sag against the Japanese yen yesterday following the sale of as much as $1 billion in Tokyo by the Bank of Japan.

title: Ad Revenues Off
description: The member magazines of the Publishers Information Bureau in August collectively carried 10,072 advertising pages, a drop of 7.4 percent from August last year. Revenues for the same month were off eight-tenths of 1 percent, to $304.6 million.

title: U.S. SAYS 2 WORKERS IN HEALTH CARE GOT AIDS VIRUS ON JOBS
description: Federal health officials confirmed today that two health care workers had been exposed to the AIDS virus, apparently after they accidentally stuck themselves with needles used to take blood samples from AIDS patients.

title: Nihilator's Bid For Mark Put Off
description: Plans to let Nihilator, the 3-year-old pacer, try today for harness racing's mile speed record were postponed, according to a spokesman at The Red Mile race track.

title: UNILEVER INCREASES OFFER FOR VICKS TO $60 A SHARE
description: In an 11th-hour attempt to rescue its offer for Richardson-Vicks Inc., Unilever N.V. raised by $4 a share the price it would pay for the Wilton, Conn., consumer products company.

title: AS STORM NEARS, METROPOLITAN AREA BATTENS DOWN
description: As a hurricane warning was issued yesterday for New York City, New Jersey, Long Island and Connecticut, officials hurried to activate emergency plans and then braced for what they feared could be the most destructive hurricane to approach the metropolitan area in this century.

title: IN TUNISIA, NO. 2 IS CHAMPING AT THE BIT TO BE NO. 1
description: He has been at the epicenter of Tunisia's continuing tensions with Libya, standing up to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, meeting with Arab leaders abroad, moving against unions at home.

title: CHESS GAME ADJOURNED
description: The ninth game of the world chess championship between the titlist, Anatoly Karpov, and Gary Kasparov was adjourned on the 42d move today.

title: WRITER WHO WITHHELD TAPES IN BELUSHI CASE IS SENTENCED
description: A freelance writer was held in contempt today and sentenced to 10 days in jail and a $1,000 fine after he refused to turn over a tape in the John Belushi murder case.

title: WEEKEND GUIDE
description: Friday THE TELEVISED BERNSTEIN Leonard Bernstein's television career is the subject of an exhibition starting today at the Museum of Broadcasting, which will launch a selection of screenings of the maestro's television appearances with a seminar starring the conductor himself. The discussion, which begins at 4 P.M. at the Ford Foundation, 320 East 43d Street, features Mr. Bernstein; Humphrey Burton, producer-director of ''Great Performances''; Roger Englander, producer-director of ''Young People's Concerts,'' and Brendan Gill, drama critic for The New Yorker. Tickets, at $15, can be purchased at the Museum of Broadcasting, 1 East 53d Street. Over at the museum, exhibition screenings offer 60 hours of programming dating back to Bernstein's 1954 television debut on ''Omnibus.'' Today's screenings, which are at noon and 2:30 P.M., feature the maestro's first television lecture, a 1954 ''Omnibus'' program analyzing Beethoven's Fifth Symphony, and a 1960 recording of the New York Philharmonic in West Berlin, with Bernstein discussing Beethoven's music and performing the Piano Concerto No. 1. Tomorrow's screenings, which are also at noon and 2:30 P.M., are a 1968 ''Young People's Concerts'' program called ''Forever Beethoven'' and a 1981 performance of Bernstein conducting the Vienna Philharmonic and the Vienna State Opera Chorus in Beethoven's Symphony No. 9. Suggested contribution to the museum is $3. Information: 752-4690.

title: HOUSE REJECTS MOVES TO CUT MILK AND SUGAR PRICE SUPPORTS
description: In the first test this year of whether Congress will be willing to curtail Federal support of the nation's debt-burdened farmers, the House today solidly rejected proposals to reduce Government aid to sugar growers and dairy farmers.

title: Conviction in Drug Trial
description: A jury today convicted a Pennsylvania accountant on 7 of 13 charges that he sold cocaine to major-league baseball players. The conviction of Robert McCue was the second in the Federal prosecution here of seven men in connection with drug use within the sport.

title: ON OSHA OPENING
description: Much to his apparent chagrin, Labor Secretary Bill Brock is having a hard time filling one of the most important positions in the department: head of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. Officials say at least three people have turned down the job.

title: 68 CRIMES, INCLUDING 14 MURDERS ARE CHARGED TO MAN IN CALIFORNIA
description: Richard Ramirez was arraigned today on charges involving 68 crimes, including 14 killings and 22 sexual assaults, that were part of a yearlong series of seemingly random attacks.

title: GLORIA COVERAGE, IN EYE OF THE STORM
description: ''People oughtn't to think of this as an unreal television drama,'' Governor Cuomo told Jack Cafferty, a WNBC anchorman, yesterday afternoon. ''It is real.''

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13. 1. Paris's oldest bridge, the Pont Neuf, was wrapped in more than 40,000 square yards of material by Christo, the Bulgarian-born American artist. 2. The new Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, made the remark in his first address to the United Nations General Assembly. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, used the term ''Star Wars.'' 3. In an unusual ruling, a judge sentenced Miss Murphy, who was convicted of insurance fraud, to ''house arrest,'' saying she must be confined to her home for two years. 4. Mr. Bennett proposed changes in Federal bilingual education programs, to emphasize fluency in English rather than knowledge of students' native languages and cultures. 5. Britain, West Germany, France, Japan and the United States agreed to work to drive down the value of the dollar. 6. With a home run, the first in his career, and two singles against Pittsburgh and a single against Chicago, Gooden had 21 hits for the year, the most by any Met pitcher. The previous record was 18 by Tom Seaver. 7. For the first time since the early 1950's, North Korea and South Korea allowed their citizens to cross the heavily armed border for family reunions. 8. Lower. 9. The East River. 10. Vins de table, or so-called table wines. 11. The order, that police in Port Elizabeth refrain from assaulting detainees held under the country's state-of-emergency decree, was the first judicial acknowledgement of police brutality. 12.

title: 2 Thrift Units Taken Over
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has approved the acquisition of Family Savings and Loan Association, Springfield, Va., by Columbia First Federal Savings and Loan Association, Bethesda, Md., the Government agency said yesterday.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN ARMY BEGINS A 'HUMAN AID' DRIVE
description: The South African Army today started what it called a campaign to win the hearts and minds of black township residents, building a soccer field in Tembisa, a segregated area north of here.

title: LOAN TO VON BULOW FROM GETTY REPORTED
description: Claus von Bulow paid the legal expenses of his two trials on attempted murder charges with a $1 million loan from John Paul Getty Jr., the oil magnate, a magazine has reported.

title: 8 SLAIN IN HOLDUPS IN 2 BRUSSELS STORES
description: Eight people were shot dead tonight when gunmen opened fire without warning during two holdups that were carried out about 15 minutes apart in suburban Brussels supermarkets, the police said.

title: MARATHON OFFICE SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Business Day on Thursday with an article about the Latin American debt problem misstated Argentina's inflation rate for 1984. It was 688 percent.

title: WHY WORK SHOULDN'T BE A FAMILY AFFAIR
description: To the Editor:

title: SYNCOM CORP reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Net income The company attributed a significant portion of its latest year loss to non-recurring acquisition and financing costs incurred in the acquisition of four food wholesale companies.

title: POSTPONEMENTS
description: Following are the sporting events of interest to the metropolitan area that were postponed or canceled because of yesterday's storm:

title: PRAGUE CLOSES BORDER: TERRORIST ATTACK CITED
description: Czechoslovakia closed a major crossing at the Austrian border today, saying a terrorist attack had taken place at the post near Bratislava, the Interior Ministry said.

title: Stadium Approved
description: Overriding objections by neighborhood organizations and a plea by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, the Dade County Commission voted, 7-1, early yesterday to give final approval for construction of a 73,000-seat stadium for the Miami Dolphins in a quiet residential neighborhood, many of whose residents want no part of the project. Three separate homeowners associations have been fighting the stadium, which they say will disrupt their middle-class neighborhood, a predominantly black area in northern Dade County.

title: DRUG DISCUSSION SET
description: Commissioner Peter Ueberroth said today that he would talk to each baseball player who admitted drug use in testimony at the Pittsburgh cocaine trials before deciding whether to apply punishment.

title: KNICKS SIGN BURTT TO ONE-YEAR PACT
description: All summer long, Steve Burtt, a free agent, worried about his future. As the days passed, the former Iona star wondered if the Golden State Warriors would re-sign him or if some other team would present an offer sheet.

title: REAGAN NOTIFIES CONGRESS OF ARMS SALE TO JORDON
description: President Reagan notified Congress today that he intends to sell Jordan $1.5 billion to $1.9 billion in arms, including 40 advanced fighter aircraft.

title: CROWD HAIL KUROWASA AT TWO 'RAN' SHOWINGS
description: The Japanese director Akira Kurosawa loves big storms, and nature in all its majesty is an intrinsic force in his latest film. Yesterday, New York briefly handed him a whopper for background - Hurricane Gloria - to usher in his epic movie ''Ran,'' the opening work at the 1985 New York Film Festival.

title: ARMS TALKS: SOVIET OFFER MAY BREAK THE LOGJAM
description: The Soviet proposal reportedly made to President Reagan today seems likely to break the six-month logjam in the Soviet-American arms negotiations in Geneva and to open the way to more intensive preparations leading up to the President's meeting in November with Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: MARYLAND REPUBLICAN TO LEAVE SENATE NEXT YEAR
description: Senator Charles McC. Mathias Jr., Republican of Maryland, announced today that he would not seek re-election in 1986, further clouding his party's hope of maintaining its Senate majority.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL ATLANTA (NBA) - Signed Scott Hastings, forward, to a multi-year contract.

title: Abitibi Stock Bid
description: Gulf Canada Ltd. said it is making a $21-a-share (Canadian) tender offer to minority holders of Abitibi-Price Inc. until Oct. 11.

title: POLISH LEADER ASSERTS TRADE SANCTIONS SOW CHAOS
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, apparently in an allusion to the United States, told the General Assembly today that ''chaos and anarchy'' were being deliberately sown in Poland.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CHINESE FOLK DANCES At the Young People's Chinese Cultural Center, 90 West Broadway, Chinese dance has been taught for more than 10 years. The center teaches folk dances from about 30 of the 55 minority groups in China and 10 dances from the Han Chinese.

title: Dumping Seen On Pistachios
description: The California Pistachio Commission has filed petitions charging that subsidized Iranian imports were dumped on the American market at prices below production costs.

title: MITEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 23
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $5.1 million, resulting from costs related to recently announced plant consolidations.

title: Lendl May Miss Court Showdown
description: An eagerly awaited encounter next week between Ivan Lendl and Boris Becker, the United States Open and Wimbledon tennis champions, will probably not be realized.

title: Pennsylvania Opposes Restart of 3 Mile Island
description: The state today joined an antinuclear group in urging the United States Supreme Court to continue an order blocking restart of the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant.

title: No Headline
description: Hurricane Gloria delivered a quick but devastating blow to parts of Long Island yesterday, slamming first into Fire Island at noon with 90 mile-per-hour gusts.

title: John J. Montuori Dies at 56; Owned the Jefferson Market
description: John J. Montuori, owner of the Jefferson Market in Greenwich Village, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Park Ridge, N.J. He was 56 years old.

title: JETS' MIANO TAKES LONG PATH TO PROS
description: The game against the Colts tomorrow is the one that Rich Miano has worried about since the Jets plucked him from the sands of Waikiki and put him back into a uniform.

title: Sims Out for Season
description: Billy Sims, the Detroit running back who missed half the 1984 season with a knee injury, said he had given up on the idea of rejoining the Lions this season and would concentrate on preparing for 1986. ''I know it won't be this year,'' he said, citing recent consultations with the Detroit team physician and with Dr. Robert Teitage, the surgeon who operated on the knee after it was injured in a game against the Minnesota Vikings last October.

title: Yen, Continuing Strong, Is at 4-Year High in U.S.
description: The dollar continued to weaken against the Japanese yen today, ending a week that saw a broad retreat by the dollar after five industrial nations pledged to bring down its value.

title: Harrison Traded
description: Dennis Harrison, a Philadelphia Eagles defensive end who had stayed away from the team in an effort to force a renegotiation of his contract, was traded to the Los Angeles Rams yesterday after telling the Eagles he wanted to end his holdout. In exchange for Harrison, a fourth-round draft pick in 1978, the Eagles will get a fourth-round draft choice next year and a seventh-round pick in 1987.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 28, 1985
description: The Hurricane

title: COLLEGE GAMES AT A GLANCE
description: Home teams are listed first. Season records are in parentheses. Hurricane Gloria may force some games to be canceled this morning.

title: Using a Trust To Ease Taxes
description: ONE of the most advantageous ways of leaving a substantial estate to a child while reducing or eliminating a huge tax bill is by establishng a kind of trust called a grantor retained income trust.

title: No Hard Feelings
description: When Rickey Henderson set a Yankee club record by stealing his 75th base of the season on Wednesday, nobody was more interested than Bob Maisel, a Baltimore Sun sports columnist whose father, Fritz Maisel, established the previous Yankee record back in 1914.

title: GELMAN SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $175,000.

title: DRAMA IN AMERICA: THE FORGOTTEN ART
description: To the Editor:

title: A LESSON IN TRUST FROM PRETORIA
description: As a classic French treatise warned in 1716, ''Even the most dazzling diplomatic triumphs which have been gained by deception are based upon insecure foundations. They leave the defeated party with a sense of indignation, a desire to be revenged and a resentment that will always be a danger.'' In South Africa they have yet to learn that lesson.

title: UNITED FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: PEOPLE IDENTIFIED AS SOVIET AGENTS ARE REPORTED TO HAVE QUIT C.I.A.
description: Administration officials said today that people identified by a K.G.B. defector as Soviet agents had quit the Central Intelligence Agency and that one of those implicated had fled the United States.

title: CLEAN OUT YOUR DESK - AND DON'T EXPECT THANKS
description: I haven't been able to sleep lately. Not long ago, the top executives of a Fortune 500 company told more than 100 employees they were being laid off because of budgetary constraints.

title: BEHIND THE PHILIP MORRIS BID
description: The Marlboro man, that mythic marketing dynamo, will do a lot for the Jell-O company, many food analysts predict.

title: Accused Terrorist Arraigned In Slaying of Jersey Trooper
description: An accused terrorist, Thomas Manning, was arraigned before a Superior Court judge here today for the murder of a New Jersey state trooper, Philip Lamonaco, in 1981. Bail was set at $5 million, the state police said.

title: CONTRAS' HELPERS ON THE WRONG SIDE OF U.S. AND WORLD LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: TEACHING SHOPPERS TO PROTEST
description: ''S HOPPERS are sheep,'' says John Tschohl. ''Insult them, ignore them, avoid their questions, and all they'll do is leave the store in a huff and complain to their friends.''

title: RETRENCHMENTS SET AT STEEL COMPANIES
description: Three steel companies reported further retrenchments yesterday as the difficult times in the industry continue.

title: MILE IS A GIANT STEP FOR OVETT
description: Steve Ovett, who will run in the Fifth Avenue Mile today, had a lot on his mind this week: potholes, the threat of a hurricane, the sheer pressure of competing against some of the world's elite runners.

title: TURN OFF THE INTERNAL RADAR
description: Many people have nerves of steel, many have minds like a computer - and a sensitive few are walking barometers. Their mood goes up or down like the weather loach in a fish tank at every twitch of cyclone or depression. Hurricane Gloria was much on the minds of these sensitive souls.

title: HARTMARX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
DOCTOR'S LAWYERS WANT A DISMISSAL
description: Defense lawyers at a hearing today called for the dismissal of charges that a Navy surgeon killed five patients through negligence, contending that their client's decisions were based on reasonable judgment.

title: PHILIP MORRIS TO BUY GENERAL FOODS FOR $5.8 BILLION
description: The Philip Morris Companies, the nation's biggest cigarette maker, has agreed to buy the General Foods Corporation, one of the country's biggest food producers, the two companies announced yesterday.

title: Ford-Mazda Talks
description: The Ford Motor Company is negotiating to sell engines and other parts to Mazda of Japan, Donald E. Petersen, Ford's chairman, said. The parts would be used in the small cars the Japanese company will build at its plant in Flat Rock, Mich. Ford owns about 25 percent of Mazda and has an agreement to buy roughly half of the cars made at the plant, which is due to begin production in late 1987.

title: U.S. Conducts Nuclear Test
description: The United States conducted an underground nuclear test today at the Nevada Test Site at 7:15 A.M., Pacific time, the Department of Energy said. It was the second announced test since the United States refused to join the Soviet Union in a nuclear test freeze that Moscow declared on Aug. 6.

title: 280,000 FLEE HOMES
description: Hurricane Gloria charged up the Atlantic seaboard yesterday and slammed into the New York metropolitan region with pounding winds and heavy rains. Long Island and Connecticut bore the brunt, but most of the region appeared to take the awesome storm in stride.

title: 20-20 Vision
description: Joaquin Andujar had already reached the plateau, and so John Tudor's victory Thursday night over Philadelphia gave the St. Louis Cardinals two 20-game winners this season. The Chicago White Sox had such a pair only two years ago in LaMarr Hoyt (24-10) and Rich Dotson (22-7), but no team in the National League had been so blessed since 1969, when Ferguson Jenkins (21-15) and Bill Hands (20-14) starred for the Cubs and Bill Singer (20-12) and Claude Osteen (20-15) did likewise for Los Angeles. And to find the last such Cardinal duo, you have to go all the way back to the war year of 1942, when Mort Cooper was 22-7 and John Beazley 21-6.

title: HOME TV KEEPS AN EYE ON BABIES WOMEN IN PRISON SAY ABUSE LED THEM TO CRIME
description: Home video surveillance systems, originally used chiefly as security devices to see who is at the front door, are increasingly being used to keep an eye on the baby while parents or sitters are elsewhere in the house. With a special camera, such a closed-circuit television system transmits a black-and-white image of the infant in a crib or playpen to a screen at another location.

title: THE STORM THAT STILLED OTB
description: New Yorkers yesterday learned their city's one true sign of a real public emergency. Not the closing of schools, which shut down for mere snowstorms. Not the suspension of alternate-side- parking regulations, which can be prompted by parades or holidays. Certainly not the disruption of commuter and mass-transit schedules, which is more the rule than the exception. Not even constant news bulletins interrupting television shows, which intrude for any old international crisis or Presidential press conference.

title: BANKS SAID TO SET TALKS ON SOUTH AFRICAN DEBT
description: In a first step toward resolving the South African debt problem, representatives of 29 banks in at least five major industrial countries have agreed to meet in London Oct. 23 to begin negotiations on rescheduling Pretoria's estimated $24 billion of foreign debt, Swiss banking sources said today.

title: ANGELS, ROYALS DEFEATED
description: Andre Thornton's two-run double highlighted a five-run fourth inning and Neal Heaton and Vern Ruhle combined on a five-hitter tonight to lead the Cleveland Indians over the California Angels, 7-3.

title: SEANTE PLEA TO REAGAN
description: All 100 members of the Senate have signed a letter to President Reagan urging him to make human rights an issue at his meeting in November with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, Senate leaders said today. ''We are writing to reaffirm our strong support for you in presenting our country's forceful position in regard to human rights, free emigration and the release of prisoners of conscience,'' the senators told Mr. Reagan.

title: 9TH CHESS TITLE GAME A DRAW DESPITE LAST-MINUTE FLURRY
description: Anatoly Karpov and his challenger, Gary Kasparov, slogged through most of the ninth game of their world championship chess match and, after an 11-move flurry of thrust and parry in the adjournment session, agreed to a draw yesterday in Moscow's Tchaikovsky Concert Hall.

title: HURRICANE SHORTENS TREASURY TRADING
description: The government securities market opened for about an hour yesterday, but then closed at 10 A.M. after major securities dealers decided that absenteeism was too high as the result of Hurricane Gloria.

title: A LANDLORD'S SUGGESTION FOR MOM-AND-POP STORES
description: As rents rise steeply, the plight of the small owner-operated neighborhood store in New York City must be addressed by city officials and the business community alike. Some city officials advocate commercial rent control as a solution. Leaders in the real estate industry have proposed only midblock zoning changes that would allow residential space to be converted to retail use. Both positions could threaten the city's economy, are inequitable and unworkable, and might lead to chaos in the commercial real estate market. The solution lies in landlords offering cash payments to tenants.

title: PARIS INTELLIGENCE CHIEF ALLEGES PLOT ON AGENCY
description: The new head of France's intelligence agency said tonight that he had discovered a ''malicious operation'' to destroy the agency.

title: NEW ENGLAND DAMAGE WORST IN RHODE ISLAND
description: Hurricane Gloria visited New England last today on its passage from the Carolinas toward Canada, leaving one person dead, hundreds of thousands without electrical power and many battered boats and toppled trees.

title: Landsat Contract To RCA, Hughes
description: The Commerce Department said it had awarded a contract of up to $250 million to the RCA Corporation and the Hughes Aircraft Company to operate the Landsat satellite system and to build and operate new satellites.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 28, 1985
description: Companies

title: EARTH'S SPIN FUELS POWERFUL 'ENGINE' THAT DRIVES HURRICANES
description: As surely as the earth turns, and for that very reason, nature likes to assert itself in spirals. Currents of air and sea, whirlpools, dust devils skipping across the desert floor and water gurgling down the drain - all are, in a fundamental sense, spiral responses to the earth's rotation. So, too, are the awesome power and harsh beauty of a hurricane.

title: SPANIARD SEES NATO SUPPORT
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez said today that he was confident his fellow Spaniards would vote to remain in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in a nationwide referendum scheduled for early next year.

title: APARTHEID IN OTHER WORDS
description: The white-minority Government in South Africa seems poised to coin another new phrase to mask an old practice. Resistant to reform of its apartheid policies, Pretoria seems eager to reshape its official language instead.

title: U.S. RELAXES SCIENTIFIC DATA POLICY
description: The White House announced today that the Government would not try to restrain the publication of unclassified scientific research.

title: DAIRY FARMERS INTENT ON MILKING ONLY COWS
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: n.a. Not available* Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BY BAKER'S DOZENS, NEW FOOD TERMS FOR POSTERITY
description: ''What,'' asked a reader recently, ''is 'post nouvelle cuisine'?''

title: SIC GLORIA TRANSIT
description: When we heard that Hurricane Gloria might be coming our way we recalled the old American maxim that says, ''When terrified, go shopping.'' As a result, we now have: 1. Ten gallons of bottled drinking water. 2. A carton of canned cold consomme soup. (Doesn't have to be heated before eating; our electric stove is useless whenever wind takes down the power lines.) 3. Two spare can openers. (Our regular can opener is always lost when it's needed and, the manufacturing industry being what it is these days, by buying two can openers you might get one that works.) 4. A battery-operated radio. 5. A backup set of radio batteries guaranteed to last up to six months. (In case of an unusually long hurricane.) 6. A regular-size flashlight and a giant-size flashlight. (The regular size for hunting for lost can openers; the giant size in case we have to go outside - we don't want neighbors to think we can't afford the biggest.) 7. A molded tarpaulin car cover to fit over the automobile. (Guaranteed to keep hurricane-force rains from getting through the crack in the windshield.) 8. Forty feet of tarpaulin-car-cover tie-down rope. (When tied to the car cover and lashed around the car axles, this is guaranteed to keep the tarpaulin car cover from blowing away in winds up to 110 miles per hour.) 9. Brightly colored tarpaulin-car-cover kite tail. (If winds exceed 110 m.p.h. this will not only give the tarpaulin-car-cover excellent aerodynamic stability in the upper atmosphere but will also, thanks to its bright coloring, make identification and recovery easier after the hurricane.) 10.

title: 'HUEY LONG,' A DOCUMENTARY ON THE LOUISIANA POPULIST, BY KEN BURNS
description: The depressed late-1920's and early 1930's produced some remarkable American characters, including the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, the radio priest from Detroit whose sermons were less religious than political, and Dr. Francis E. Townsend, the elderly Long Beach, Calif., physician whose ''Townsend Plan'' was a kind of crackpot preview of what eventually came into being as Social Security. The times were tough then and a desperate citizenry was ready to listen to almost anybody with a plan - or even a promise.

title: IN MOSCOW, A HUNGER TO KNOW AMERICA
description: I thought I knew, from the three years I spent in Moscow in the mid-1970's, how curious most Russians are about the United States. But my previous experience hardly prepared me for what I saw this month at the Moscow Book Fair, where an exhibit of American books was overrun with people 10 hours a day. I was stunned by the Russians' voracious hunger for information about America, and I began to rethink my ideas about when and where it makes sense to boycott contacts with the Soviet Union.

title: Rangers Tie, 1-1
description: Mike Rogers's goal at 16 minutes 59 seconds of the third period gave the Rangers a 1-1 tie with the Buffalo Sabres in a National Hockey League exhibition game tonight.

title: DEBATE ON U.S. BILINGUAL EDUCATION: BLENDING METHODOLOGY AND SOCIOLOGY
description: The other day, in a statement defending bilingual education, Nathan Quinones, the New York City Schools Chancellor, said, ''It is not a subversive activity in this country to learn a language other than English.''

title: SCHOOL PICTURES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income including a gain of $729,799 from the sale of land and buildings.

title: SNARED IN APARTHEID'S WEB: THE JAILED CHILDREN
description: Fanie Goduka, 11 years old, dreamed the other night that he was still locked in a prison cell that echoed with his screams of fear.

title: SHULTZ TO RECEIVE AN AWARD FROM A FOREIGN POLICY PANEL
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz will receive the National Committee on American Foreign Policy's Hans J. Morgenthau award at a ceremony in New York next week, the State Department said today.

title: UGANDA REBELS REPORTED TO OVERRUN ARMY CAMP
description: Ugandan rebels have overrun the army barracks in a key southwestern town, residents there said today.

title: STORM THREAT SHUTS FINANCIAL MARKETS AND MANY BUSINESSES
description: Commerce in the world's largest business center all but ceased yesterday as the threat of Hurricane Gloria led businesses in the metropolitan area to close almost en masse.

title: JAPAN SEEN TARGET OF CHIP PLEA
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27 -Three of the nation's largest computer chip manufacturers will file an anti-dumping petition against at least eight Japanese semiconductor companies on Monday, sources in the industry said today.

title: FROM TEA TO TRADE
description: Speaking of import legislation, free-trade lobbyists are stepping up their efforts, and gimmickry, to defeat protectionist bills.

title: POPE AND LUTHERAN LEADER ENCOURAGE UNITY BID
description: Pope John Paul II and Bishop James R. Crumley Jr., leader of the Lutheran Church in America, have sent each other letters expressing their pleasure at the ripening relationship between their two churches and encouraging further ecumenical talks.

title: PANTRY PRIDE RAISES REVLON BID TO $50
description: Pantry Pride Inc. raised its acquisition offer for Revlon Inc. by $8 a share yesterday, to $50, and repeated that it was interested in negotiating a friendly merger.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Paris dispatch Thursday on the role of the press in the Greenpeace affair incorrectly described the newspaper Le Matin.

title: A DRAMATIC BUILDUP, THEN A BRIEF VISIT
description: ''Scary,'' Cheryl Gagliano said yesterday in Hampton Bays, L.I., where the wind was howling, the trees were whipping back and forth and all the shades in the house had been pulled down - except the one for peeping out. ''My husband was just wondering if the roof might go.''

title: Control Data Credit Moves
description: The Control Data Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest computer manufacturer, said today that it had pledged the stock of its Commercial Credit Company unit as security for existing borrowings and was holding discussions with its lenders to restructure certain revolving credit arrangements.

title:
PATENTS;

Directional Controls For a Boeing Airplane
description: The Boeing Company, in Seattle, has patented an aircraft with directional controlling canards.

title: TIKHONOV RETIRES AS SOVIET PREMIER
description: Prime Minister Nikolai A. Tikhonov, at 80 the oldest member of the Soviet leadership, retired today and was replaced by Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, one of the new younger generation of Soviet leaders.

title: Mariners Extend Cottier's Pact
description: Chuck Cottier will return to manage the Seattle Mariners next season, the club announced today.

title: Xerox Sale
description: The Xerox Corporation said that it had sold 1,000 of its new artificial-intelligence work stations to Applied Expert Systems Inc., a Massachusetts-based software house that will resell the machines with programming for financial planning. The sale, valued at $20 million, marks the start of Xerox's efforts to obtain a major share of the market for the machines.

title: ISOLATED WINNERS IN DUMMY ARE NOT ALWAYS DISASTROUS
description: When Viscount Goschen introduced the phrase ''splendid isolation'' 90 years ago, he was talking about Britain, not bridge. Isolation of established winners in the dummy is never splendid but not invariably disastrous.

title: Fund at Tulsa Reported
description: The former Texas Christian University head football coach F. A. Dry and a former assistant, both of whom have been implicated by T.C.U. alumni in the operation of a fund for cash payments to athletes, were linked to a similar fund at the University of Tulsa, The Dallas Times Herald reported today. The newspaper said the involvement of Dry and the assistant, Bob Junko, in the Tulsa payments surfaced during a criminal and civil tax fraud case against Woodrow Cole, a former president of a Tulsa booster organization.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Atlantic Richfield Co., Los Angeles, said it expects to complete the previously announced sale of its American Brass division to Buffalo Brass Co. on Oct. 15. The division consists of six mills that are part of Arco Metals Co. Terms were not disclosed.

title: HOUSE UNIT BACKS 16 CENT CIGARETTE TAX
description: The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to approve a 45-day extension of the Federal cigarette tax of 16 cents a pack. The tax is scheduled to drop to 8 cents a pack on Tuesday.

title: RATE RISE ON SOME MAIL DEFERRED
description: Postmasters around the country have been told to defer a rate increase for charities, certain newspapers and nonprofit organizations, Dave McLean, a spokesman for the Federal Postal Service, said in a telephone interview today.

title: ECOLOGISTS SET TO ASSESS STORM'S TOLL
description: As Hurricane Gloria swept along the Northeastern coast yesterday, ecologists prepared to assess how its violent winds, waves and rains had affected the balance of nature.

title: FAST-RISING ECONOMIST FOR A TOP KREMLIN POST
description: Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, who was appointed Soviet Prime Minister today, is an engineer and industrial manager by training, not a Communist Party official.

title: PENTAGON WEIGHS NEW PLAN TO ARMOR AND CONCEAL MISSILES
description: The Defense Department is studying a new plan that some senior officials believe may provide a politically acceptable and militarily desirable base for the MX missile, according to Congressional and Reagan Administration officials.

title: MAN ACCUSED OF CONSPIRACY TO SELL AIRCRAFT PARTS TO IRAN
description: The Justice Department today announced the arrest of a Virginia man on charges of trying to smuggle military aircraft guidance systems to Iran.

title: Grumman Order
description: The Grumman Corporation won a $675 million contract to develop a radar system to help NATO forces attack tanks and other moving targets behind enemy lines. Grumman's aerospace unit was chosen over the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the Hughes Aircraft Company for the Air Force contract and will have until 1990 to perfect a system. The system will initially use modified Boeing 707 aircraft that can spot targets for destruction by multi-warhead conventional missiles.

title: 'PROTECTION' IS A SCAPEGOAT LABEL
description: To the Editor:

title: 'STEAMING,' DIRECTED BY JOSEPH LOSEY
description: ''Steaming'' is a very small, unexceptional movie to end the exceptional career of Joseph Losey, the American director who died last year at age 75 in England, where he'd spent much of his life after being blacklisted by Hollywood in the early 1950's.

title: PROGRAMS LINKING WELFARE TO WORK
description: Programs that require or encourage people on welfare to work for their benefits have spread around the nation and have resulted in full-time jobs for some recipients and reductions in caseloads and costs in some areas, according to studies of the programs and interviews with administrators and participants.

title: ALPHA MICROSYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 25
description: b-Net income.

title: Dow Raises Resin Price
description: The Dow Chemical Company said today that it had increased the price of its primacor adhesive resins by 3 cents a pound, effective Nov. 1. Dow said the new prices would range from 93 cents to $1.04 a pound, depending on film grades.

title: COURT RULINGS IN NAVY SPY CASE ON COAST BUOY DEFENSE LAWYERS
description: Defense lawyers for Jerry A. Whitworth, the retired Navy radioman accused of espionage, said today that they were encouraged by a Federal district judge's order that prosecutors disclose the names of two secret informers and selected wiretap transcripts.

title: 2 Editors at Time Scheduled To Exchange Their Positions
description: The managing editor of Time magazine and a senior executive of Time Inc. will exchange jobs, the company said yesterday.

title: PLAY BALL, PLAY BILL
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt is a chief sponsor of a bill to clamp down on Japanese imports and of another bill to overhaul the Federal income tax system. He is also an inveterate St. Louis Cardinals fan, the kind who fiddles with his radio dial late at night trying to find a station that is broadcasting his beloved baseball team.

title: ALLIED SIGNAL BUYBACK PLAN
description: Allied-Signal Inc. said its board had authorized an increase in the company's stock repurchase plan to 25 million shares of common stock and had also authorized the redemption or repurchase of all of its outstanding preferred stock.

title: JERSEY IS STRUCK A GLANCING BLOW
