description: Hurricane Gloria roared, rained and blustered up the New Jersey coast yesterday and then moved on, leaving in its wake modest property damage and a general sense of relief among officials and the more than 90,000 people evacuated from seaside areas.

title: THE CONCERTGEBOUW AND HAITINK AT CARNEGIE
description: Bernard Haitink will make his last three New York concert appearances as the music director of Amsterdam's Concertgebouw orchestra, next week at Carnegie Hall.

title: PANAMANIAN PRESIDENT SAID TO OFFER RESIGNATION
description: President Nicolas Ardito Barletta, bowing to pressure from Panama's military, labor and business leaders, offered his resignation today, legislators said. The National Assembly convened to swear in a successor.

title: Opportunity Beckons for Traders
description: The financial markets have never lacked for opportunity-seekers. So when the wind and the rain from Hurricane Gloria shut down the stock exchanges, foreign exchange trading and many of the commodity markets yesterday, there were more than a few eager traders ready to fill the void.

title: STORM RAISING LEVELS OF RESERVOIRS FOR CITY
description: Yesterday's storm greatly raised the water level in reservoirs that supply New York City, according to city officials, but the level still remains far below what it should be for this time of year.

title: The Top Line
description: A salute to the Miami Dolphins' offensive line, but also to Dan Marino's quick release:

title: CATALOGUES WITH A DIFFERENCE
description: If Macy's doesn't tell Gimbels, does Bloomies tell Neiman's?

title: ANGLICAN CHURCH'S ROOTS
description: To the Editor:

title: JURY IS SEATED FOR TRIAL OF LOUISIANA GOVERNOR
description: A jury was seated today in the trial of Gov. Edwin W. Edwards of Louisiana and seven other men charged under Federal antiracketeering laws with illegally making $10 million through a hospital construction venture.

title: ROBERTA Z. SULZBERGER
description: Roberta Z. Sulzberger, for many years the executive secretary of the Institute for Dermatologic Communication and Education, in San Francisco, died of cancer Tuesday.

title: REVCO DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 24
9 ON TRIAL ACCUSED OF INFLUENCING TEAMSTERS
description: The trial of nine reputed organized crime figures who are accused of conspiring to take control of two Las Vegas casinos will disclose links between the underworld and the teamsters' union, a Federal prosecutor has charged.

title: FIRE TRUCK BELLS TOLL IN CAPITAL FOR OLDEST RETIRED FIREFIGHTER
description: Fire truck bells tolled this week in a funeral tribute for the District of Columbia's oldest retired firefighter, who in his 35-year career saw equipment change from horse-drawn wagons to modern fire trucks.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week.

title: HUSSEIN, AT U.N., URGES TALKS ON MIDEAST BY SUPERPOWERS
description: King Hussein of Jordan said today that any consultation on the Middle East between the United States and the Soviet Union was ''both necessary and positive.''

title: HURRICANE MERELY SIDESWIPES PENNSYLVANIA AND DELAWARE
description: Hurricane Gloria brought much of the Middle Atlantic region to a standstill today as residents braced for the worst. But the worst never came as the storm merely sideswiped eastern Pennsylvania, Delaware and southern New Jersey.

title: Pierce Says He';; Quit Cabinet Before 1989
description: Samuel R. Pierce Jr., a member of President Reagan's original Cabinet, said today that he planned to leave as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development before the President's term ends in January 1989.

title: SWEET LAND OF MULTIPLE VISIONS
description: Whenever Congress debates immigration, the oratory almost always evokes different visions of America, its past and its future.

title: Melbourne Futures
description: The beginning of trading in stock futures on the Melbourne Stock Exchange was quiet and cautious with only limited interest from institutions, traders said today. Trading in futures of the Broken Hill Proprietary Company's stock accounted for all 27 contracts that moved.

title: Margaret Fishback, 85: Writer of Light Verse
description: Margaret Fishback Antolini, an advertising copywriter noted for her humorous poems, died Wednesday at the Camden (Me.) Community Health Care Center.

title: AWARDS GIVEN IN DANCE
description: Dance Theater Workshop presented its second annual New York Dance and Performance Awards Thursday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The awards, known as the Bessies, honor achievements in dance and performance art, particularly those of artists working in smaller, alternative spaces.

title: SOVIET REPORTED TO OFFER 50% CUT IN NUCLEAR ARMS
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister met with President Reagan today and was reported to have proposed a 50 percent reduction in the offensive nuclear arsenals of the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: TRADE GAP NARROWED IN AUGUST
description: The nation's trade deficit narrowed to $9.9 billion in August, the smallest since December 1984, chiefly reflecting both a lower volume of imported oil and a lower price for it, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: AIR TRAVELERS ARE MAROONED
description: Air traffic was substantially grounded in the New York metropolitan area and much of the Northeast yesterday, but by late afternoon airlines were scrambling to restore service to passengers marooned by the hurricane. Operations were expected to be largely back to normal by today.

title: DON'T FENCE OUR SCHOOLCHILDREN IN
description: To the Editor:

title: Founders Life
description: Anderson, Clayton & Company said it had signed a definitive agreement to sell the American Founders Life Insurance Company of Austin, Tex., to a wholly owned subsidiary of the American Continental Corporation for $58 million.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Advertising Column in some editions of Business Day on Thursday misidentified the song from which Toyota Motor Sales, U.S.A., has taken its new campaign theme. The title is ''I Got Rhythm,'' and it is from the 1930 show ''Girl Crazy.''

title:
PATENTS;

A Utility Shutoff In Quakes
description: A device will, in case of an earthquake, automatically shut off the electricity, gas or water in a utility system, avoiding damage from building collapses or fires.

title: MILLION UTILITY CUSTOMERS ON L.I. AND IN CONNECTICUT LOSE POWER
description: Long after Hurricane Gloria passed through the Metropolitan area more than a million homes and businesses on Long Island and in Connecticut were left without electrical power and utility officials said it might be a week before service is restored to all customers.

title: FINANCIAL CLOSINGS SPREAD RAPIDLY
description: Bowing to nature, not only did Wall Street shut down yesterday but its silence stilled nearly all activity in most of the nation's other financial markets as well.

title: COMMUTER RAILROADS AND SUBWAYS DISRUPTED BY DEBRIS AND FLOODING
description: Gusts and flooding from Hurricane Gloria forced a suspension of all Long Island Rail Road service for about four hours yesterday and curtailed operations of the New York subway and the Metro-North Commuter Railroad.

title: Midland Acquiring Crocker Loans
description: The Crocker National Corporation, parent of the Crocker National Bank, and Midland Bank P.L.C. said that their boards had approved an agreement for Midland to acquire $3.1 billion of Crocker's foreign loans and to establish a new United States subsidiary to acquire up to $500 million of Crocker's domestic assets. Since May, Crocker has been a wholly owned subsidiary of Midland, which is based in Britain and previously had owned 57 percent of Crocker.

title: METS DEFEATED AFTER 5-2 LEAD
description: The Mets took another step backward in the National League East race tonight when they lost to the Pittsburgh Pirates, 8-7.

title: AVANTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 7
TECHNOLOGY A LIFESAVER
description: Hurricane Gloria's path along the Northeast coast was destructive to property, but lives were spared in part because technological advances provided a picture of the storm's every movement in plenty of time for residents to take adequate precautions.

title: IN SOUTH, RAIN AND WIND LEAVE MODERATE DAMAGE
description: Some low-lying areas remained flooded today and more than 15,000 residents of coastal North Carolina were without electricity, but relieved state officials said that damage as a result of Hurricane Gloria was far less than feared.

title: FEDERAL PANEL RECOMMENDS ENDING 8,000 RAILROAD JOBS
description: A Presidential emergency board, set up to help avert a national rail strike, recommended Thursday that the jobs of 8,000 railroad workers, including firemen, be eliminated on most of the nation's freight-carrying railroads.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We scared the hell out of the hurricane and it went elsewhere.'' -Mayor Koch. [1:6.]

title:
PATENTS;

Body Tissues Identified By Ultrasound Echoes
description: A method of identifying body tissues at a distance by testing ultrasound signals was patented this week for the North American Philips Corporation, in New York.

title: Import-Fee Report Denial
description: The Reagan Administration today denied a report that it is considering a major policy shift to support an import user fee to finance an expanded training program for workers who lose their jobs because of foreign competition.

title: CHIEF HURRICANE ORACLE TO THE NATION: NEIL LA VERNE FRANK
description: A scientist with a flat crewcut who grew up in tornado country and wanted to be a basketball coach has suddenly become a familiar face on millions of television sets as Mr. Hurricane.

title: OUTER BANKS: BRAVE TALES AFTER STORM
description: The S&R Supermarket, on the Route 158 bypass in Kitty Hawk, was the place to go along the Outer Banks today, not only for groceries but also for news of how the neighbors had withstood Hurricane Gloria.

title: Congdon & Weed To Be Acquired
description: Contemporary Books, a Middle West publisher, has announced it will acquire Congdon & Weed, the independent New York publishing house that filed for bankruptcy this year.

title: SEATTLE TEACHERS TO VOTE ON NEW CONTRACT TODAY
description: Seattle teachers are to vote today on a proposed $8.4 million one-year contract aimed at ending the nation's largest teacher strike.

title: PROPHET OF DOOM
description: THE NUCLEAR AGE. By Tim O'Brien. 312 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95. Tim O'Brien's most recent novel, ''Going After Cacciato,'' published in 1978, was one of the finest books to emerge from the Vietnam War. Picaresque, mythic in dimension, ''Cacciato'' found, in the hallucinatory dreams of a renegade soldier, the perfect metaphor - and narrative strategy - for dealing with that most surreal and anomalous of wars. It made the reader both apprehend the ugliness of death and combat, and also viscerally experience the hero's panic and soft, eager longings for safety and escape.

title: POWER IS LOST IN MUCH OF CONNECTICUT
description: About half of Connecticut's homes and businesses were without power today after Hurricane Gloria's race across the state.

title: COMPTROLLER'S WARNING TO BANKS ON TRUSTS
description: The Acting Comptroller of the Currency, H. Joe Selby, has warned almost 100 big banks, including the Chase Manhattan Bank of New York and the First National Bank of Boston, that they have been mishandling some of the funds of their trust and estate clients, industry and regulatory sources said today.

title:
PATENTS;

Way to Make Materials For Duplicating Teeth
description: Dr. Howard Cohen, a Long Island orthodontist, was granted a patent this week on materials for duplicating teeth. He believes this represents a major advancement in dentistry and thinks patent 4,543,063 will increase the effectiveness and quality in the construction of fixed bridges and crowns.

title: Job Offer at Fordham
description: Frank McLaughlin, the former Fordham basketball star who has been head coach at Harvard for the last eight seasons, said he had been offered the job as Fordham's athletic director and planned to accept it.

title: SIKHS CHOOSE PUNJAB LEADER
description: Sikh leaders who won the Punjab state election on Wednesday selected a moderate today to become Chief Minister of the state, avoiding a battle that had threatened to hamper their ability to govern.

title: AT COLLEGIATE LEVEL, SOCCER IS THRIVING
description: Despite the disappearance of the North American Soccer League, soccer at the collegiate level continues to grow vigorously in quantity, in popularity and in quality as well.

title: MONTANAN IS SENTENCED IN ABDUCTION OF ATHLETE
description: A man who shunned society and said he hoped to establish a tribe of mountain people was sentenced to 85 years in prison today for his part in the kidnapping of a young woman and the killing of a would-be rescuer.

title: Herzog Speaks Out
description: Whitey Herzog, manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, did not mention names but he mentioned a lot of disappointments because of the use of cocaine by his players over the past few years. He said in an interview with today's Washington Post that 11 members of the Cardinals were ''heavy users'' of cocaine during the early 1980's and that Montreal was the city where the drug was readily available.

title: 'WHEN FATHER WAS AWAY'
description: The title euphemism of ''When Father Was Away on Business'' refers to a trip taken by the young hero's parent - not a business trip, but a journey to a labor camp. It also indicates the boyish perspective from which the story is seen. This warmly appealing Yugoslav film, winner of the Golden Palm at this year's Cannes Film Festival, makes charming use of 6-year-old Malik Malkoc (played by Moreno D'E Bartolli) and his outlook without sacrificing a larger and more knowing directorial overview.

title: Reagan Names Rourke As Air Force Secretary
description: President Reagan announced today that he would nominate Russell A. Rourke, Assistant Secretary of Defense for Legislative Affairs, to succeed Verne Orr as Secretary of the Air Force.

title: TODAY
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Yankee Stadium, 2:05 P.M. (Television -SportsChannel and WHT, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Pirates, at Pittsburgh. (Television - Channel 9, 7 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7 P.M.) Expos vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Montreal, doubleheader. (Television - Channel 4, 3:15 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880, 3:07 P.M., both only the first game) Braves vs. San Diego Padres, at Atlanta. (Television - WTBS, 11:15 P.M.) Boxing Barry McGuigan, champion, vs. Bernard Taylor, 15 rounds for the World Boxing Association featherweight championship, at Belfast, Northern Ireland. This is the first defense for McGuigan since he took the title from Eusebio Pedroza on June 8. McGuigan, a Catholic married to a Protestant, has eschewed politics and united the country behind him. He is 27-1 with 23 knockouts. Taylor, from Charlotte, N.C., is 33-0-1, the only blemish on his record coming against the former champion Pedroza. (Television - Channel 7, 1:30 P.M.) Football Syracuse at Virginia Tech, (Radio -WNYE-FM 91.5, 11:55 A.M.); Alabama at Vanderbilt, (Television - WTBS, noon); Pittsburgh at West Virginia, (Television - MSG, noon); Miami at Boston College, (Television - Channel 11, and USA Cable network noon); Massachusetts at Harvard, (Television -Channel 13, 1 P.M.); Army at Pennsylvania, 1 P.M.; Marist at St. John's, 1 P.M.; Penn State vs. Rutgers, at Giants Stadium, 1 P.M.; Columbia at Lafayette, (Radio - WKCR-FM 89.9 1:30 P.M.); Lehigh at Princeton, 1:30 P.M.; Fordham at U.S. Merchant Marine Academy, 1:30 P.M. (Radio - WFUV-FM 90.7, 1:30 P.M.); Ramapo at Pace, 1:30 P.M.; Stony Brook at Wagner, 1:30 P.M.; Hofstra at C. W. Post, 1:30 P.M.; Texas at Stanford, (Television - Channel 2, 3:30 P.M.); Auburn at Tennessee, (Television - Channel 7, 3:30 P.M.); U.C.L.A. at Washington; Southern Methodist at Texas Christian; (Television - ESPN, 7:30 P.M.); Oklahoma at Minnesota, (Television - WTBS, 8 P.M.); Grambling vs.

title: Office Manager Out at Hutton
description: The manager of the E. F. Hutton & Company office here has resigned.

title: REAGAN AND OVERKILL
description: As Public Speaker No. 1, President Reagan knows there is always the danger of overkill. And the other day, in Athens, Tenn., he told a story about brevity involving a country preacher who found himself almost alone in church.

title:
PATENTS;

High-Temperature, Gas-Cooled Reactor
description: A gas-cooled, high-temperature nuclear reactor has been patented for a West German company. Patent 4,543,232 was granted this week to Claus Elter and four co-inventors, who assigned it to Hochtemperatur-Reaktorbau of Cologne.

title: TURN OFF THE WATER
description: After a hurricane hit eastern Long Island in 1938, it was reported that a Bridgehampton man returned home to find two feet of ocean in his living room and a second notice from the local water company in his mailbox.

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES FINED $1.5 MILLION
description: The Federal Aviation Administration announced today that American Airlines had been fined $1.5 million for violating Federal regulations on aircraft safety maintenance and inspection.

title: THE ERROR IN CALLING AMERICA A DEBTOR NATION
description: To the Editor:

title: TRUMAN EDGES LEHMAN
description: Truman scored with just under two minutes remaining to edge visiting Lehman, 14-13. Coach Carmine Colasanto of Lehman said later that he would protest the game because of an official's call in the fourth quarter.

title: ARMS COMPANY SEEKS NEW MARKETS
description: FOR 120 years workers have poured past the gate early each morning into New Haven's Winchester firearms factory to assemble ''the gun that won the West'' - the famous Winchester rifle. Their numbers have dwindled in the past 10 years, and many of the fourth-generation machine operators feared that the struggling manufacturer would soon close its doors.

title: Gallup Finds Public Divided On Aid to Parochial Schools
description: The American public is about evenly split on whether the Constitution should be amended to permit government financial aid to parochial schools, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: DEER TROUBLE
description: THERE appeared to be agreement that there were ample deer on the 2,100-acre Crane Reservation and Wildlife Refuge in Ipswich, Mass. What was in sharp dispute was what to do about them, if anything.

title: U.S. STUDY FINDS ONE IN FIVE BIRTHS OUT OF WEDLOCK
description: Births to unwed mothers are continuing a steady climb and now account for one baby in every five in the United States, Government statisticians report.

title: NEW ORLEANS STREETCARS TURN 150
description: A block party 6.6 miles long began here early today, a 150th rolling birthday party for the streetcar.

title: A FRESH LOOK AT THE MERITS OF GOLDENROD
description: A plant which hangs around with bad company will lose its reputation. An excellent example is the genus Solidago, the goldenrods. These showy perennials are unfairly maligned as a cause of hayfever. They have nothing to do with allergic reactions which are triggered by the wind-borne pollen of ragweed, an inconspicious plant which grows in the same areas.

title: THEATER: 'MOWGLI,' A KIPLING MUSICAL
description: ''We've had to brave everything from a hurricane to a Philadelphia newspaper strike,'' Eric Salzman, one of the two artistic directors of the American Music Theater Festival, said tonight at the Annenberg Center here. ''Still, we've done awfully well. We have two shows here tonight -'The Gospel at Colonus' and 'Mowgli,' with a third, 'The Golden Land,' only a few blocks away. And they've all drawn a pretty good house.''

title: AN ARTISTIC ABODE
description: THE SCRAPBOOK that Alexander and Tatiana Liberman have kept of their country home in northwestern Connecticut is a vivid chronicle of the property's evolution over the last 17 years. The earliest photographs show the cottage, which was built in 1937, as something of an ugly duckling, with a warren of dark, wood-paneled rooms heavily shaded by dense cherry trees. ''It was quite a sinister place,'' recalls Mr. Liberman, who is the editorial director of the Conde Nast publishing company and a noted sculptor and painter. ''The trees were so thick they cast a shadow around the house, so that the interiors were dark by 3 o'clock, even on summer afternoons.''

title:
INVESTING;

A 'VALUE' MANAGER COURTS THE LITTLE GUY
description: PRIVATELY OWNED investment counseling firms have traditionally been off-limits to individual investors. These independent organizations have courted as clients the multibillion- dollar corporate and public pension funds, which generated higher fees.

title: No Headline
description: Christopher Wallace To Marry Emily Croll

title: THIRD WORLD DEBT
description: To the Editor:

title: Isabelle Beekman Marries a Lawyer
description: At St. James' Episcopal Church in New York yesterday Isabelle Sabina Beekman, a daughter of Dr. Robert S. Beekman of New York and the late Mary Marckwald Beekman, was married to Gary Scott Fergus, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Malcolm Fergus of Wexford, Pa. The Rev. Carleton J. Sweetser performed the ceremony.

title: GRAMMARIAN PASSES THE WORD
description: WHEN the talk gets around to best-selling authors, you don't hear the name John Warriner mentioned in the same breath with Harold Robbins, Judith Krantz, Sidney Sheldon and Ken Follett.

title: Miss McConnico Marries in Texas
description: Mayme Jessica McConnico, the daughter of Ann Brassell Ryan of Fort Worth and the late Milledge Vance McConnico Jr., was married there yesterday to Timothy Perot Greer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Pearson Greer of Spokane, Wash. The Rev. Dr. Cecil Sherman performed the ceremony at the Broadway Baptist Church.

title: ROCKET REDUX
description: AS A WRITER, I LIVE IN THE world of literature and ideas, but I entered that world as an emigre from a medieval fiefdom, the sports world of Michigan. The king and queen of that principality were the Detroit Tigers and the Detroit Lions. The princes were the University of Michigan and the Michigan State teams. On a festival day, such as the Fourth of July, my father and I would drive four hours to Detroit for an audience with the king; it rounded out the year and it was as obligatory as bringing the first fruits to the temple.

title: Hoping for Early Retirement
description: RALPH and Janice Hood admit it: They are conservative investors. But four years ago they embarked on a program they realize is somewhat chancy, hoping it will pay off with early retirement.

title: RACE FOR GOVERNOR SET BY WESTPORT LEGISLATOR
description: State Representative Julie D. Belaga of Westport has created a campaign committee to seek the 1986 Republican nomination for governor.

title: AN OFFER BY SHEVARDNADZE PUTS REAGAN ON THE SPOT
description: WALKING with President Reagan along the White House Colonnade from the Oval Office to the State Dining Room, the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, scanned the brightening Friday morning sky. ''Look, Mr. President,'' the Soviet official exclaimed. ''We have brought you the sun.'' Mr. Reagan, who chatted with Mr. Shevardnadze about the hurricane that skirted Washington hours before, grinned.

title: COPTER DISPUTE
description: THE New York City Police Department wanted to buy a $1.3 million helicopter. The manufacturer refused to sell, because the city insisted that the contract include a ban on job bias against homosexuals.

title: AGEE AND OTHERS
description: ANGELS UNAWARES Twentieth-Century Portraits. By T. S. Matthews. 294 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $17.95.

title: SOCIAL EVENTS
description: Jeweled Benefit Oct. 1 - The publisher Malcolm Forbes has a collection of jeweled works by the Russian craftsman Carl Faberge that is matched only by Queen Elizabeth's collection. The glittering objects, including some of the Easter eggs created for the Czarina Alexandra, will be on display at the Forbes Magazine Galleries, 60 Fifth Avenue, at 12th Street, at a benefit reception for the New York branch of the English-Speaking Union. Tickets for the 6 to 8 P.M. benefit, $60, from 212-879-6800. Party at the Armory Oct. 2 - For 28 years, the Young Adult Institute and Workshop has provided training and treatment in New York City and Westchester for the physically and mentally disabled of all age groups, operating 25 group homes and 4 day-treatment centers as well as providing home visits. A benefit for the nonprofit group will provide an evening of dining and dancing at the Park Avenue Armory at 67th Street, where regional American foods and music will be provided. Dress is regional, formal or informal. Tickets, $200, from 212-563-7474. Hispanic Settlement Oct. 2 - Founded in 1934, Casita Maria was the first settlement in the city to serve the Hispanic community. It is situated in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx and also operates the Carver Community Center in Spanish Harlem. The settlement provides programs in education, arts and athletics as well as maintaining a summer day camp and a family support system. One source of funds is its annual dinner-dance benefit, to be held this year at the Plaza Hotel starting with cocktails at 7:30 P.M. Tickets for the black-tie event, $275, from 212-581-7370.

title: SEA'S MYSTERY AND TITANTIC: A SALUTE
description: AT 6 o'clock on a hot July evening in the North Atlantic 40 years ago, I was leaning against the port rail of the troop transport taking our battalion home after the last hard fighting in the Ruhr. No winds stirred; the Atlantic was a millpond. In our wake lay a defeated Germany; in our nostrils still lay the smell of burned buildings, wet plaster and decay in the Rhine-Herne Canal. Ahead was homeland: in three days we would be welcomed into Port Chester by a small tender, and a good looking young American matron on that tender with long, marvelous legs who served us glasses of ice-cold milk - the first we had tasted in months. I have never forgotten the milk or the legs, and I hope I never will.

title: TAX PROPOSALS SPAWN UNCERTAINTY
description: ON Capitol Hill, lawmakers are seriously considering the sweeping overhaul of the income tax system proposed by President Reagan, a restructuring that would touch virtually all Americans and virtually every aspect of their financial affairs.

title: A FORUM TO RIGHT FINANCIAL WRONGS
description: YOU'RE in a snit. You've left your apartment in good condition after the end of a two-year lease, but the landlord won't return your security deposit. Or the television repairman charged $150 to fix your faulty color-tuning device, but the darn thing still doesn't work right, and the repair service won't return your telephone calls.

title: UNCLE JAKE AND THE MOSQUITO-CRAZED PROSPECTOR
description: ADVENTURES IN THE ALASKAN SKIN TRADE By John Hawkes. 396 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95. INNOCENCE IN EXTREMIS By John Hawkes. 92 pp. Providence, R.I.: Burning Deck. Cloth, $17.50. Paper, $8. THE new book by that veteran producer John Hawkes is the most accomplished meaningless novel I have ever read. I say ''meaningless'' partly in disparagement, but also partly as neutral description. ''Adventures in the Alaskan Skin Trade'' refers to nothing outside itself; it sets off, as you read it, none of those anticipations of significance you expect of serious fiction; it lacks the tug of profundity that pulls you through a book and amounts to a promise from the author that behind his story is his real subject and your task as a reader is to crack the narrative code disguising it. Imagine ''Moby-Dick'' as just - as only -what Hemingway called it, ''a fish story,'' and you have a model for understanding this often gorgeous prose poem to Alaska and to male camaraderie.

title: CUTTING THE TIES THAT BIND
description: WE ARE always leaving each other in order to arrive somewhere else, be it geographical or emotional distance that we travel. Not long ago my mother was going on vacation. She needed me to take her to the airport. I said no. I had a doctor's appointment that night and I didn't want to miss it. Did she understand, I added, that I'd be tired from work and that there would be nothing wrong with her taking a cab?

title: TURNAROUND ON SUFFOLK BUDGET
description: ONE year ago, Suffolk County faced such major financial problems that the County Executive, Peter F. Cohalan, proposed a bare-bones austerity budget for 1985. But things have changed drastically.

title: WHY WE SHOULD CHANGE THE LIBEL LAW
description: LYING ON A DESK IN A GOVernment laboratory near Washington is an article about serious misconduct in the scientific community. The article was written more than two years ago, but you cannot read it. You cannot learn whether some distinguished scientists listed themselves as co-authors of published articles they neither wrote nor researched or whether they should have known that research published under their names contained false or misleading statements. You can neither see the evidence summarized in the article nor decide for yourself whether any of the scientists acted irresponsibly or unethically. You cannot do any of this, ironically, because of the law of libel.

title: STILLMOVING TOWARD MARKET SOCIALISM
description: RECENT moves in China against inflation and corruption have chilled optimism among the Chinese and the foreign business community about China's economic reforms. Some people have suggested that the Government may have reached the limits of its drive toward market socialism.

title: KARPOV AND KASPAROV DRAW TENTH GAME IN CHESS MATCH
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov agreed to draw the 10th game of their world championship match on the 37th move today after Kasparov brought his opponent into a position known as perpetual check.

title: THE CHANGES SEEMED STAGGERING
description: THE WORKSHOP OF DEMOCRACY The American Experiment. Volume Two. By James MacGregor Burns. 671 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: YANKEES WIN ON 2-RUN 9TH
description: The pennant race may be all but done, but Dave Winfield still is one of the game's most aggressive hitters, Don Mattingly's swing is still line-drive sweet, Rickey Henderson is still menacingly fast, and Ron Guidry, even less than perfect, can still throw the right pitch in the crucial situation.

title: VIENNA A TO Z
description: To the Editor: I was delighted to read ''The Capital from A to Z.'' The entry for Yiddish, however, it seems to me, has the tail wagging the dog.

title: Police Assaults In South Africa
description: Some had welts and blisters, apparently the result of whippings. Others had perforated eardrums from heavy blows to the head. One man had bruises on his genitals, another had been forced to drink gasoline and still another had been ordered to stand barefoot while bricks were dropped on his feet.

title: 4 MORE U.S. VICTIMS ARE FOUND
description: The United States Embassy today identified four more American victims of Mexico's two earthquakes, and officials reported no damage or injuries from a third temblor that sent thousands of people fleeing into the streets Friday night.

title: PERFORMANCE ART
description: Max Roach is one of the architects of be-bop drumming - but he has never limited his repertory to be-bop. Over the past decade, he has performed or recorded with -for starters - the free-jazz pianist Cecil Taylor, a string quartet, an all-percussion group, a rapper and a breakdancer.

title: DROUGHT POINTS UP WATER PLAN'S VALUE
description: THIS summer, the words from ''The Rime of the Ancient Mariner,'' ''Water, water, everywhere nor any drop to drink,'' often crossed the mind of Beth Weinstein in the State Department of Health Services.

title:
ABOUT MEN;

COMPETING WITH BRUCE
description: JUST OVER A YEAR AGO, MY WIFE BEGAN AN obsession with Bruce Springsteen.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: From Sacred to Secular Plot Plot in fiction, says Peter Brooks, helps us overcome the anxiety caused by the loss of the ''sacred masterplot that organizes and explains the world.'' In ''Reading For the Plot'' (Vintage), he describes the narrative impulse as our instinctive answer to the crowding of experience.

title: COMPUTERS REMAKE THE L.I. OFFICE
description: THE computer revolution is changing the look of the Long Island corporate world.

title: Dr. Diane Young Wed To Dr. Robert J. Mich
description: The Memorial Church at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Dr. Diane Caroline Young and Dr. Robert John Mich. The Rev. John MacInnis, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: RULING MAY END SOME CABLE SHOWS
description: LONG ISLAND cable companies could eliminate duplicate channel offerings if a Federal court decision declaring ''must carry'' stations unconstitutional is upheld. The Island's public broadcasting station and new commercial station would probably not be hurt by the ruling, operators of cable systems said.

title: David J. Biggar Is Wed To Elisabeth C. Brady
description: The marriage of Elisabeth Charlotte Brady, the daughter of Jeanne Aspinwall Brady of Ossining, N.Y., and John L. Brady Jr. of New York, to David J. Biggar, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. Biggar of Chappaqua, N.Y., took place yesterday. The Rev. William C. Heffner performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: THE CHANGING WORLD OF NEW YORK INTELLECTUALS
description: As a college English major with an appetite for literary criticism, I find the neo-conservatives of The New Criterion a very appealing group. By recapturing the distinctions between what the old-school intellectuals of the Partisan Review termed high and low art, culture, particularly literature, might be revitalized. PAMELA J. COLLARD Rochester

title: Ueberroth Bows To Players on Drug Testing
description: Peter Ueberroth, the baseball commissioner, held a news conference in Manhattan last week to announce that the national pastime has to rid itself once and for all of what may be the favorite pastime of some baseball players: using drugs.

title: UEBERROTH'S DRUG-TESTING PLAN SOFTENS PLAYERS' TRUST IN HIM
description: SO much for Peter Ueberroth's idea of being commissioner of the players as well as commissioner of the owners. Bowie Kuhn, early in his 15 1/2-year reign as commissioner, tried to adopt that role for himself, but he never inspired the trust and confidence of the players. Ueberroth, in his first year in office, won over some players, perhaps a sizable number, by his actions before and during the strike earlier this season.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN ECONOMIC HISTORY
description: TO an economist, defining ''money'' these days is a challenge, given the near-daily creation of new financial instruments. But imagine the situation back in colonial America: Until 1738 Massachusetts accepted corn, beef and hemp in payment of income taxes. Figuring out the size of the money supply - when was food just food, and when was it money? - and estimating its impact on inflation during that period make interpreting M-1 or M-2 look like child's play.

title: Philadelphia Papers Quit Talks in Strike
description: Representatives of Philadelphia Newspapers Inc. walked out of contract talks today and said that they would return when nine striking unions ''are ready to bargain realistically.'' A Federal mediator said he would meet separately with both sides.

title: IN MEXICO, DIGGING OUT HAD A POLITICAL EDGE
description: The United States response to Mexico's disastrous earthquakes over the last 10 days has provided a microcosm of daily relations between the two countries, which have been cordial but often with a hint of pique just below the surface. The United States was both quick and generous in its response to Mexico's plight. According to the United States Ambassador here, John Gavin, $2.5 million in materials and equipment has arrived and another $2.5 million is committed. In addition, communications gear was on the way to help rebuild Mexico's crippled international telephone system.

title: REAGAN'S TURNABLOUT ON THE DOLLAR
description: THE first sign that the Reagan Administration was making a major change in its international economic policy came last April in a speech that Secretary of State George Shultz made at Princeton. Mr. Shultz defended the Administration's economic policies - but for the first time, he conceded failures, particularly the swelling budget deficit.

title: THE MET SINGS THE PRAISE OF CORPORATE SPONSORSHIP
description: After Montserrat Caballe and Luciano Pavarotti had finished singing ''Tosca'' at the Metropolitan Opera's opening Monday night, patrons who had purchased $1,000 seats repaired to the Grand Tier for a post-performance supper. There they were regaled with a half-hour fashion show of Chanel's fall ''haute couture'' line.

title: Thais Settle Cambodians In Camp Near the Border
description: The Thai Government announced this week that it had finished moving about 55,000 displaced Cambodians to a new site on the Cambodian border.

title: TREASURY REPLIES
description: To the Editor:

title: THE RETURN OF THE SOLDIER, AND A PENNANT IS WON
description: CELEBRANTS of the 40th anniversary of V-J Day should reserve a niche for the exciting climax of World War II's final pennant race. The date was Sept. 30, 1945, and the heroes were baseball's leading symbols of patriotism and valor, the slugger Hank Greenberg and the one-armed Pete Gray.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM VERDI TO HITCHOCK
description: British Rock: The First Wave Written and directed by Patrick Montgomery and Pamela Page. MusicVision 60 minutes, $29.95 Screaming young girls are heard almost continuously in ''British Rock: The First Wave,'' a history of pop's British Invasion and aftermath.

title: 27 Die in Indian Bus Crash
description: A bus carrying pilgrims to a Hindu temple in northern India swerved off a sharp bend and plunged into a gorge, killing at least 27 people and injuring 22, the United News of India said.

title: TAX PLAN CAUSING STIR ON 2D HOMES
description: TAX proposals from the Reagan Administration would significantly curtail the ability of vacation-home owners to deduct the interest they pay on their mortgages. But Charles Roover, a Boston lawyer who owns one vacation home near Sarasota, Fla., and is building another on Martha's Vineyard, says the changes are not likely to affect him.

title: BEST SELLERS: Sept. 29, 1985
description: Fiction

title: FARRAKHAN'S STEP BACK INTO SLAVERY
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL HIGHLIGHTS VIA SATELLITE AID TV STATIONS
description: FOR the employees at Baseball Newsatellite, going to work can seem a lot like passing a Saturday afternoon at home. They prop their feet up, maybe catch a bite, and settle down in front of the television set for nine innings.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:I would like to spend the Christmas holidays at an old inn on Cape Cod, preferably one that has festivities - and a fireplace. To whom should I write for information? -L. W. K., Oak Ridge, Tenn. Answer:Inns that are open at Christmas are included in the Cape Cod Resort Directory, which is sent out by the Cape Cod Chamber of Commerce (Hyannis, Mass. 02601; 617-362-3225). The 66-page directory, which lists hundreds of accommodations, is free but inquirers are asked to send $1 to cover postage. It gives details, with rates in some cases, of everything from housekeeping units to historic inns. Most of the Cape's accommodations close in the fall; a key shows which places are open the year round.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM VERDI TO HITCHOCK
description: Foreign Correspondent Starring Joel McCrea, Laraine Day, Herbert Marshall and George Sanders; directed by Alfred Hitchcock, 1940 Lightning Video 120 minutes, $59.95 Despite its title, this one has a lot less to do with journalism that it does with its British-born director's eagerness to alert prewar America to the menace of Nazism and his penchant for stories about people who witness events practically nobody believes.

title:
GARDENING;

DON'T THROW AWAY THOSE LEAVES
description: WHILE watching leaves flutter gracefully on autumn breezes may be a pleasant pastime, once on the ground they must be dealt with or they will lead to such problems as a smothered lawn.

title: THE RACE IS LOW-KEY FOR KOCH AND 3 RIVALS
description: With Election Day only five weeks off, Mayor Koch is running a low-key campaign by choice while his three major opponents are operating low-visibility campaigns by necessity, an acute shortage of campaign funds.

title: WHEN AVANT-GARDE MEETS MAINSTREAM
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music's 1985 Next Wave Festival is literally opening with a splash. For Pina Bausch's dance-theater extravanganza, ''Arien,'' which begins performances on Tuesday, the stage of BAM's opera house will be flooded with ankle-deep water.

title: Chatter Aloft
description: To the Editor: One way to lessen flight fatigue is to be free in silence of the chatter of one's neighbor. After having spent hundreds of hours in the air over 3 oceans, 4 continents and 40 countries, I have at last perfected effective ploys to silence the most persistent natterer.

title: BLACK YOUTHS RIOT IN LONDON DISTRICT
description: Rioting broke out tonight in a predominantly black area of London after a police inspector shot and wounded a black woman in a raid at her home.

title:
GARDENING;

DON'T THROW AWAY THOSE LEAVES
description: WHILE watching leaves flutter gracefully on autumn breezes may be a pleasant pastime, once on the ground they must be dealt with or they will lead to such problems as a smothered lawn.

title: PAPERBACKS IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WOMEN OF THE FOUR WINDS. By Elizabeth Fagg Olds. (Houghton Mifflin, Paper, $8.95. Cloth, $17.95.) Elizabeth Fagg Olds, a former foreign correspondent for The Christian Science Monitor and a Time-Life bureau chief in Mexico, has assembled brief biographies of four female adventurers.

title: PAPERBACKS IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A STRANGE VIRUS OF UNKNOWN ORIGIN. By Jacques Leibowitch. Translated by Richard Howard. (Available Press/Ballantine, $4.95.) Since AIDS (acquired immune deficiency syndrome) was discovered in 1981, reported cases of the disease have doubled each year, creating one of the most feared epidemics of modern times.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;

JUST LIKE HOME
description: RYE is a place people come back to. So says Jayson Alberts, president of Jayson Alberts Realty on Elm Place: ''A lot of our customers grew up in Rye. They go away to college, get married, then they move back, to live and to raise their own children here.''

title: RUNNING FOR THE DOLLARS
description: HARD-CORE NEW YORK HORSEPLAYERS know Aqueduct as the dreary setting for the seemingly endless offseason that runs from late October through April. But on Saturday, Nov. 2, as much of racing's human and equine elite as will ever be found at Royal Ascot, Saratoga or Longchamps will be congregated in that functional plant beside Jamaica Bay. What happens that day could shape the future of thoroughbred racing.

title: THE UNDOING OF ROBERT FOMON
description: FOR nearly a year now, Robert Fomon's efforts have backfired as he sought to remove E. F. Hutton from the uncomfortable glare of public scrutiny and scandal.

title: FORECLOSURE ON STATUE OF LIBERTY THREATENED IN WATER BILL DISPUTE
description: Officials of Jersey City and the National Park Service are in dispute over a billing of nearly $1 million for water the city provides to Liberty Island.

title: RENTING IS RIGHT FOR SOME
description: TWO years ago Dana and Elease Wright realized that most enduring of American dreams: They bought their own home. But despite the mystique of home ownership in America, they made the commitment cautiously, buying the house only after they had rented it three years.

title: ON THE USES OF POWER BY MARRIAGE
description: For a while, the Senator expressed puzzlement as to why the committee was meeting, why there were so many well-known witnesses and why so many onlookers were crowded into the hearing room.

title: A CARIBBEAN COURSE, A PACIFIC CRUISE
description: French Cooking On St. Barts As the nights grow longer and the cold days of winter near, no one can be blamed for fantasies built around some sun-drenched Caribbean island. If the prospect is the 9.5-square-mile French Antillean speck that is St.-Barthelemy, 12 miles southeast of St. Martin, then it might accurately include a series of cooking courses to be taught this winter by the man known as Chef Hubert.

title: REAGAN WELCOMES SOVIET PROPOSALS ON ARMS CUTBACKS
description: President Reagan today welcomed new Soviet arms proposals that reportedly call for 50 percent cuts in the offensive nuclear arsenals of the two superpowers. He said the United States was ''ready for tough but fair'' negotiations.

title: CHOOSING A SEAT ALOFT
description: Selecting an economy-class seat in a jetliner can be a challenge. Typically, you are asked by an airline employee whether you prefer ''smoking or nonsmoking'' and ''window or aisle.'' These choices may be sufficient because on most aircraft in service today, most seats are at least marginally acceptable to most passengers. But if you want to be sure that your seat reclines fully, that a window seat is really next to a window, that you are not directly above a wing that obscures your view, that you will be able to see the movie and that you are not near a lavatory, where passengers tend to congregate, you will probably have to make your wishes clear before your seat assignment is made.

title: NEW PRESIDENT TAKES OFFICE IN PANAMA
description: Vice President Eric Arturo Delvalle was sworn in as the new Panamanian leader today after the resignation of President Nicolas Ardito Barletta.

title: THE INSTITUTIONALIZATION OF THE ILLEGAL ALIEN
description: When the Senate took up a comprehensive bill to curtail illegal immigration earlier this month, the growers of fruits and vegetables once again demonstrated their considerable political power.

title: Workers Near Mine Victims
description: Recovery crews have tunneled to within 600 feet of the bodies of 27 miners who died in a fire last December at the Wilberg Mine, but recovery is not expected until late October, a mine spokesman said Friday. The bodies were sealed nearly a mile inside the mine by the fire.

title: OF GAWKERS, A COCKATEEL AND TOURISTS
description: As of Monday night, 388,678 visitors had toured the United Nations this year, up slightly from the 372,853 who took the tour in the same period last year.

title: HOLDOUTS BATTLE DEVELOPERS IN SITE WARS
description: HIGH construction costs, restrictive zoning, the long approval process and exorbitant land costs are among the many factors that deter development in New York City, real-estate professionals say. But the wild card in this pack of risks, they add, is the presence of rent-regulated tenants on a development site.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: HELEN HAYES BALL Helen Hayes, one of America's most-beloved actresses, will celebrate her 85th birthday Oct. 10 with a charity ball on Friday and an exhibition of career memorabilia that opens Oct. 12.

title: A DARK MEMORY OF TY COBB
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Amy Wilmerding Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Amy Wilmerding, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David R. Wilmerding Jr. of Rosemont, Pa., to Walter Roy Manny, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Manny of New Canaan, Conn., took place yesterday. The ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church on Fishers Island, N.Y., was performed by the Rev. John F. Smith, chaplain of the Groton School, of which the bride is a graduate.

title: Nancy Schultz Marries
description: Nancy J. Schultz, a daughter of Evelyn Schultz of Elmont, L.I., and the late Theodore Schultz, was married yesterday to Charles F. Crofts 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Crofts Jr. of Riverhead, L.I. The Rev. Robert Batule performed the ceremony at St. Boniface Roman Catholic Church in Elmont. The bride is a computer manager with the National League of Professional Baseball Clubs in New York. Mr. Crofts is a software engineer for the Grumman Aerospace Corporation in Melville, L.I., for which his father is a senior engineer.

title: Tax Simplification And Tax Deductibility
description: The trouble with Assemblyman Halpin's plea to preserve state and local tax deductions [Opinion Page, Sept. 8] is that it further erodes the central idea of tax simplification.

title:
TV VIEW;

GOOD INTENTIONS DON'T REDEEM 'AMOS'
description: There are people, especially network employees, who go about pretending that there is something momentously significant in September's ''new season'' of series premieres. This amiable charade continues despite the probability, based on the record of past seasons, that between 75 and 90 percent of the new shows will fail, and despite the fact that the overall programming picture has changed dramatically for television in the last several years. The commercial networks have lost their stranglehold on prime-time viewers. Their combined share of the total audience has declined by more than one-fifth in recent years, and is likely to go on slipping for a while as the public further explores the worlds of cable and videocassettes.

title: Seattle Teachers Vote To End 25-Day Strike
description: Seattle teachers voted yesterday to accept a $8.4 million contract offer and end the nation's largest teacher strike.

title: RE-EXAMING YOUR BENEFITS
description: SOME of the most cherished benefits at the work place, including health insurance and retirement plans, face significant changes under President Reagan's tax proposals. As a result, compensation specialists say this is the time for taxpayers to study their benefits carefully.

title: MIDWIVES FACE THREAT OF HIGH INSURANCE COST
description: Aleida Llanes-Oberstein, a midwife at the Queens Midwifery Association, has been telling expectant mothers due after Oct. 1 to find someone else to deliver their babies.

title: KIDNAPPING RENEWS FEARS OF SALVADOR'S ELITE
description: The abduction of the daughter of President Jose Napoleon Duarte has reawakened fears among El Salvador's prominent families, who say it may force them to make drastic changes in their lives.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 19 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week cited 19 food establishments for violating the health code.

title: KOURIS WINS 24-HOUR RACE
description: Yiannis Kouris, the Greek-born distance runner who says he runs to feel at one with nature, achieved a rare union with the elements yesterday when he improved his world record by completing 178 miles during a 24-hour road race that took him and 37 other competitors through the rain and wind of Hurricane Gloria.

title: TREASURY WITHOUT GUM
description: IF they were gold coins, deep-sea divers would be searching for them now. Instead, they were baseball bubble-gum cards, which kids trade and adults collect unless their mothers tossed them into the garbage while cleaning a closet. Dumped into the Atlantic Ocean not far from New York bay more than three decades ago, that batch of cards eventually disintegrated. But if those cards could be recovered now, they might be worth millions. One card alone in that 1952 series, the first Mickey Mantle card, has been sold for as much as $3,000.

title: ROYALS AND ANGELS LOSE TO STAY EVEN
description: Dennis Burtt, making only his second major league start, combined with Pete Filson and Ron Davis on a four-hitter as the Minnesota Twins beat the Kansas City Royals today, 5-3.

title: JACKSON KNEE HURT
description: Tony Robinson passed for four touchdowns and set up another with a 39-yard run as Tennessee (1-0-1) routed No. 1-ranked Auburn, 38-20, in a Southeastern Conference game today.

title: 'ORIANE,' A GOTHIC ROMANCE
description: FINA TORRES'S ''Oriane'' is a handsomely set and photographed Venezuelan gothic romance with a club-sandwich narrative form. Its first layer is about Marie and her French husband, Georges, who return to Venezuela to sell the family hacienda Marie has inherited from her aunt, Oriane.

title: PARKS IN THE AREA A POTPOURRI OF JURISDICTIONS
description: ALONG New Jersey's westernmost boundary is a scenic crazy quilt of Federal and state preserves and historic sites that few people outside of Salem County - and even some there - have ever heard about.

title: PAPERBACKS IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CHRISTIE MALRY'S OWN DOUBLE-ENTRY. By B. S. Johnson. (New Directions, Paper, $6.95. Cloth, $14.95.) The British writer B. S. Johnson published an abundance of fiction, poetry and essays in the 10 years before his suicide in 1973, at age 40.

title: DEDICATED FOE RESUMES A LIFE WITHOUT WESTWAY
description: Friends of Marcy Benstock remember an evening, well into her 11-year battle against Westway, when she was invited to a dinner party and asked to contribute a dish. Cranberry relish, it was.

title: MCMAHON OF BEARS DOE THING HIS WAY, AND DOES IT ALL
description: SO what do you suppose the quarterback was doing while the team was practicing kickoff returns the other day. Watching? Chatting with the coach? Granting an interview?

title: On Language;   Playing in Pretoria
description: SPEAKER THOMAS P. O'Neill Jr. did not like the way President Reagan took away the House's thunder at the Government of South Africa. Congress was readying a bill to apply sanctions; the President, to head off Congressional seizure of the setting of foreign policy, announced his intention to put forth a series of sanctions by executive order.

title: Votes in Congress;   Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: WIND IS A MAJOR CHALLENGE IN DESIGNING TALL BUILDINGS
description: Winds like those that accompanied Hurricane Gloria on Friday do not threaten to topple multistory buildings, engineers and building officials say. But designing those buildings so that they will not sway or lose parts of the facade is a major challenge.

title: Mary McDonald, James M. Carolan Exchange Vows
description: Mary Ann McDonald, a candidate for a doctorate in Italian language and literature at Yale University, and James Martin Carolan, a candidate for a doctorate in comparative literature at Stanford University, were married yesterday. The Rev. John Fanning performed the ceremony at St. John of the Cross Roman Catholic Church in Middlebury, Conn.

title: ROBINSON TIES BRYANT RECORD
description: Coach Eddie Robinson of Grambling tied the record of Paul (Bear) Bryant as the winningest coach in college football history with 323 victories tonight when his Grambling team defeated Oregon State, 23-6.

title: THAI CUISINE ARRIVES IN COUNTY
description: THOSE who think that the cuisine of Thailand is little more than foods seasoned with tongue-scorching spices served with a lot of rice will be pleased to stand corrected. This Far Eastern cuisine incorporates into its own culinary tradition the curries of India and the Chinese knack of contrasting and balancing texture and flavor and of cooking foods quickly. The flavors that give Thai food its distinctive edge come from such ingredients as fragrant coriander, lime, lemon grass, a range of chilies and nam pla (a fermented fish sauce), used alone or teamed with neuturalizing peanut sauce, coconut milk or cucumber. Whatever combination, the result adds up to a cuisine deliciously complex and engaging.

title: COMPIEGNE: RESTRAINED EXTRAVAGANT
description: Discovering the enigmatic chateau at Compiegne is like finding a somber textbook to be a dashing novel at heart. Its exterior, a ponderous stone triangle, scorns all royal embellishments, having neither a moat, nor a turret, nor even a golden dome to call its own. The chateau might, in fact, be mistaken for a state treasury or library presiding by chance over a vast and glorious 36,000-acre forest and hunting preserve. Compiegne's history, however, is another tale.

title: WAR RIVALS DROUGHT IN AFRICA'S HUNGER CRISIS
description: War, rather than drought, is increasingly becoming the main cause of hunger and homelessness on the Horn of Africa.

title: Officer Is Machine-Gunned
description: A motorist, speeding away from a police officer who had pulled him over Friday evening, fired a machine gun, wounding the officer, but the officer was not seriously hurt, a police spokesman said. The police believe the man may have committed an armed robbery and fired a shot at an armored car guard earlier at a Las Vegas, Nev., shopping mall, said Officer Alonzo Passmore of Las Vegas.

title: CONGRESS REPLIES
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CHANGING WORLD OF NEW YORK INTELLECTUALS
description: In his lively article ''The Changing World of New York Intellectuals'' (Aug. 25), James Atlas doesn't quite do justice to the ideas of the founding generation of the 1930's. Despite the Depression, Fascism, Stalinism and war, the group thought Western society capable of progress.

title: A Contribution called Deserving of Mention
description: Your coverage of the County Board of Legislators's recent South Africa disinvestment resolution omitted an important piece of history.

title: AN ALL-INCLUSIVE SYSTEM
description: SELECTED WORKS OF RAMON LLULL (1232-1316.) Edited and translated by Anthony Bonner. Illustrated. Two volumes. 1,329 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $125; $150 after Sept. 30.

title: EX-FLORIDA LEGISLATOR SHAKEN BUY U.S. CHARGE
description: A former state legislator, once considered one of Florida's most powerful politicians, is on trial here, accused of helping drug smugglers hide their illicit profits.

title: TEXTILE WORKERS TAKE $1 AN HOUR LESS, BUT MILL PROMISES TO PAY IT BACK
description: Just two months ago the huge red-brick mill that dominates the economy of this small community seemed destined to shut down, like scores of other textile plants in the low hills of the Shenandoah Valley.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: AUTHENTIC ANTIQUES The Antiquarian and Landmarks Society will hold its 19th annual Connecticut Antiques Show at the State Armory in Hartford, from 4 to 10 P.M. Friday, 1 to 10 P.M. Saturday and 1 to 6 P.M. Sunday.

title: C. G. Carey Wed To Miss Gordon
description: Wendy Gordon, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Stanton Gordon of Woodbridge, Conn., and South Wellfleet, Mass., was married yesterday to Charles Gordon Carey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Carey of Bethesda, Md., and Sunapee, N.H. The Rev. George McLean Milne, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the First Church of Christ in Woodbridge.

title: LOUISVILLE STARTS SLOWLY DESPITE SCHNELLENBERGER
description: THE Howard Schnellenberger express that is rolling through Louisville this fall has been absent in one very important place - on the football field - and the incongruity is striking.

title: GETTING THE ESTATE IN ORDER
description: SIGNIFICANT events, such as marriage or the birth of a child, should give rise to estate planning. But many people put it off. ''It has nothing to do with finances,'' said Colleen H. Nemdanick, a tax lawyer and estate planning adviser in St. Louis. ''It has to do with mortality.''

title: Tax Reform Time Is Now
description: To the Editor:

title: COUNTY ROLE OF COLAVITA, NEW STATE G.O.P. HEAD IS ASSESSED
description: AFTER party leaders in the County Center re-elected him chairman of the Westchester County Republican Committee earlier this month, Anthony J. Colavita got into a car and drove to Albany arriving after midnight.

title: NONE FOR THE ROAD
description: IT is 9 P.M. on a Thursday night, and in New Rochelle they do know where they children are. At least a few hundred, 16 and older, are dancing the night away at Sneakers, the county's first nonalcoholic disco.

title: A Key to Human Growth
description: Scientists know that a malignant tumor feeds on blood vessels in the human body and must generate new ones to survive and grow.

title: CAPE COD PROSPERITY'S PRICE: SQUEEZING OUT THE WORKERS
description: The workers who earn their living from Cape Cod's tourists are having a tougher time finding their own lodgings because of high real estate prices, and that is threatening the area's economy, analysts say.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: BERKSHIRES WAGON TRAIN Instead of tangling with highway traffic to enjoy colorful fall foliage in the Berkshires next weekend, some New Englanders are choosing an older mode of travel - wagon train.

title: Nobody Loves a Joker
description: I SOMETIMES FAIL THE test of the airport security machines. It is embarrassing. A red light flashes, ominous electrical sounds occur. An official woman says, ''Just a minute!''

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM VERDI TO HITCHOCK
description: Gaslight Starring Ingrid Bergman, Charles Boyer, Joseph Cotten and Angela Lansbury; directed by George Cukor, 1944. MGM/UA Home Video 113 minutes, $39.95 In this psychological thriller set in Victorian London, a greedy man subtly tries to drive his new wife insane.

title: TIME OFF FOR MCENROE
description: Weary in body and spirit after losing, John McEnroe talked about giving up the chase to be No. 1 in the tennis rankings for the fifth year in a row after losing to Johann Kriek, 7-6, 3-6, 6-1, Friday night in the quarterfinals of the $267,000 Transamerica Open tennis tournament.

title: Allison Abouchar Marries
description: The marriage of Allison Beth Abouchar and Jeffrey Reid Cross, graduates of Bucknell University, took place yesterday at Faith Lutheran Church in Murray Hill, N.J. The Rev. Thomas K. Tewell performed the ceremony. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Abouchar of Summit, N.J. The bridegroom, senior editor for Bayard Publications in Stamford, Conn., is a son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Reid Cross Jr. of New Canaan, Conn.

title: BABY BOOM SPURS LAMAZE CLASSES
description: THE mini-baby boom on Long Island has led to an increase in the number of women, and men, taking courses in natural childbirth.

title: SEEING DOUBLE
description: STARTING this week, Nassau County residents who happen to be spinning their UHF television dials might get a little confused.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: THIS WEEK:

title: Hidden Facts
description: In ''Hidden Facts'' (Sunday Observer, Sept. 1), Russell Baker's basic premise is that both hats and mustaches are ''adornments of concealment.''

title: 1983 ARREST AN ELUSIVE CLUE TO NEO-NAZI GROUP'S PLANS
description: The crime wave that included arson, robberies and murder for which members of the neo-Nazi group the Order are now standing trial in Seattle occurred after one of its leaders was released on bond on a counterfeiting charge in December 1983.

title: PHILADELPHIA PROPS BILLY PENN'S TOWER
description: PHILADELPHIA'S statue of William Penn is holding up pretty well, but the same cannot be said for the thing that holds it up. The statue's perch, the tower atop City Hall, has been weakened by old age, acid rain and the effects of incompatible metals reacting to one other.

title:
HOME VIDEO;

NEW CASSETTES: FROM VERDI TO HITCHOCK
description: Otello Starring Kiri Te Kanawa, Vladimir Atlantov and Piero Cappuccilli; conducted by Zoltan Pesko and directed by Gianfranco deBosio Thorn EMI/HBO Video 135 minutes, $39.95. Kiri Te Kanawa looks like an angel, and sings like one; Desdemona in ''Otello,'' the angel of the Verdi canon, is surely her best role outside of Mozart.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

ANNIVERSARY SALE IS SCHEDULED
description: Stack's of New York, now observing its 50th anniversary in the coin auction business, will mark the occasion by staging one of the year's most important sales next month. A number of major rarities will be featured and the sale seems likely to rank among the highest-grossing auctions ever conducted by the company. The 1,666 lots are expected to realize a total of more than $4 million.

title: LUCIANO PAVAROTTI IN THE ROLE OF JUDGE
description: LUCIANO PAVAROTTI sat in the middle of the Philadelphia Academy of Music on Friday, bespectacled, wrapped in a brightly-colored shawl and beating time with his pencil. It was 5:30 in the afternoon of a long day - Mr. Pavarotti had left his New York apartment at roughly the same time that Hurricane Gloria arrived. Yet he showed no weariness, no impatience, as yet another young singer - one of 148 he will listen to in the next week - stepped before him.

title: RECONSTRUCTING A 20'S BALLET
description: A packed house awaited the world premiere ''like the opening of Tutankhamen's tomb,'' according to a London Times correspondent who found the performance ''funny, sinister and exotic.'' But, he added, ''to call it dancing is to beg questions only a ballet critic could answer.''

title: STATE TURNING A SPORTLIGHT ON CRAFTS
description: IN AN intensive statewide celebration, crafts in New Jersey will be spotlighted throughout the month of October. Organized by the State Council on the Arts and given the imprimatur of a proclamation by Governor Kean, the celebration, with more than 70 separate events, is designed to engage almost everyone in the state who makes, displays, sells, collects, teaches or simply loves crafts.

title: ALONG THE CONNECTICUT SHORE
description: Connecticut may officially be a part of New England, but there are vast stretches from the New York border eastward that to the rest of us New Englanders look suspiciously like the suburbs of New York City. Not until you get beyond New Haven does New England really begin. There the population starts to thin out, the urban sprawl swings north toward Hartford, and the shoreline towns and villages begin to take on that air of huddled concentration around a harbor, a river, a white-painted steeple that spells New England in earnest.

title: Wisconsin Names Educator
description: Kenneth Shaw, chancellor of the Southern Illinois University system, has been named president of the University of Wisconsin system. Ben Lawton, president of the university system's board of regents, said Friday that the 46-year-old chancellor accepted the appointment effective next Feb. 1.

title: PAPERBACKS IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE FIRST ROCK & ROLL CONFIDENTIAL REPORT: Inside the Real World of Rock & Roll. By Dave Marsh and the Editors of Rock & Roll Confidential.

title: POWER STILL OUT TO MILLION HOMES IN NEW YORK AREA
description: More than one million homes and businesses across the metropolitan area remained without power yesterday in the wake of Hurricane Gloria, and utilities said it might take up to a week to restore full service.

title: LOOKING INWARD, M.I.T. SEEMS READY TO STRENGTHEN ARTS AND HUMANITIES
description: The signs of change are scattered and preliminary. Yet the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has been buzzing with questions about its educational mission, and seems to be giving a new lift to the arts and humanities.

title: HERE'S BALTIMORE, FOR $1 MILLION
description: A PART of Baltimore where hardly anyone wanted to live has turned around so smartly that it now offers the kind of living hardly anyone can afford: the city's first million-dollar condominium.

title: IN THE SOUTH, CHARGES OF A NEW KIND OF VOTE FRAUD
description: For the last year, Federal agents have been working the hardscrabble counties of western Alabama, questioning hundreds of people, many of them elderly shut-ins, as part of an investigation of voting fraud.

title: FRESH LIGHT ON MINIMALISM'S FOUDING TRIO
description: The founding trio of minimalist composers - Terry Riley, Steve Reich and Philip Glass - have long resented being grouped together; Mr. Reich has been particularly bitter about what he feels to be a diminishment of his individuality. And yet the grouping, and especially the pairing of Mr. Reich and Mr. Glass, continues, and not just by critics. It is perpetuated by the release schedules of record companies, which have poured new releases by all three men onto the market recently. One company, Nonesuch, has almost simultaneously come forth with recordings by Mr. Glass and Mr. Reich.

title: MCGUIGAN STOPS TAYLOR
description: Barry McGuigan, making the first defense of his title, stopped previously unbeaten Bernard Taylor of Knoxville, Tenn., after eight rounds today to retain his World Boxing Association featherweight crown.

title: MOVIE ADS
description: To the Editor:

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Yankee Stadium, 1 P.M. This doubleheader was scheduled after Hurricane Gloria caused postponement of the game Friday night. Phil Niekro, still seeking his 300th victory, will start one of the games, his next-to-last start of the season. (Television - Channel 11, 1 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 1 P.M.) Mets vs. Pirates, at Pittsburgh, 1:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 1:30 P.M.) Minnesota Twins vs. Kansas City Royals, at Minneapolis. (Television - Channel 7, 2 P.M.) Football Jets vs. Indianapolis Colts, at Giants Stadium. The Jet defense has not allowed a touchdown in 10 straight quarters. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M. Radio -WMCA, 570; 4 P.M.) Giants vs. Eagles, at Philadelphia. This is their second meeting this season, and the Eagles did not score in the first one. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 1 P.M.) COLLEGES: University of Connecticut vs. Yale, at New Haven, 1:30 P.M., Rutgers-Newark vs. St. Peter's, at Breslin Field, Lyndhurst, N.J., 1:30 P.M. Both games were postponed by the hurricane. Soccer Victory vs. FICA, Michelob Cup Championship, at Old Boys High School Field, Troy Avenue and Rutland Road, East Flatbush, 5 P.M. The consolation game between Les Piquets and Nascimenpous will be held at 3 P.M. Thorougbred Racing Belmont Park. The $75,000-added Matron for 2-year-old fillies at seven furlongs is the feature. The program starts at 1 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 6:30 and 11 P.M.).

title: Novelists and Their Passions
description: To the Editor:

title: DOBBS FERRY STREAK REACHES 31
description: Dobbs Ferry extended its winning streak to 31 games - the longest in New York State - by shutting out its archrival Ardsley, 21-0, at Gould Park. The Eagles gained their second victory of the season behind the strong running of the fullback Kevin Costello, who rolled up 185 yards on the ground and scored two touchdowns.

title: Jolyne K. Caruso Wed To Shawn FitzGerald
description: St. William the Abbott Roman Catholic Church in Seaford, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Jolyne Kristen Caruso, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Caruso of Massapequa, L.I., to Shawn P. FitzGerald, a son of Bernard L. FitzGerald of Boston and the late Eileen FitzGerald. The Rev. Donald Bair performed the ceremony.

title: LAND OF THE ALSO RISING SUN
description: RANSOM By Jay McInerney. 279 pp. New York: Vintage Contemporaries/Random House. Paper, $5.95. Cloth, $15.95. JAY MCINERNEY is a serious, gifted artist. His first novel, ''Bright Lights, Big City,'' is a brilliant and moving work - unique, refreshing, imaginatively powerful and authentically conceived. ''Ransom,'' on the other hand, while dealing competently with some of the same themes - alienation, self-alienation and the need for context and continuity - rarely rises above the level of mere competence. It feels thoroughly conventional, thoroughly uninspired.

title: TERRY AND THE PIRATES
description: KHRUSHCHEV WAS AT THE UNITED Nations, pounding his shoe. Castro was at the Hotel Teresa with his chickens. Kennedy and Nixon were debating United States policy toward Quemoy and Matsu. Hammarskjold was trying to stop a civil war in the Congo. Clemente was in right field for the Pittsburgh Pirates, Mantle was in center field for the New York Yankees and Stengel, at 70, was insisting he was too young to retire as Yankee manager. There were giants in those days. Revisionists will have centuries to analyze the words and the deeds of 1960. But a quarter of a century is a totally appropriate time to look back at a manic World Series, the last World Series before expansion changed the balance of baseball.

title: AMHERST OVERCOMES BOWDOIN
description: Paul Foye directed a solid Amherst offense and Scott Lebo, a running back, scored two touchdowns today in a 24-15 victory over Bowdoin at Whittier Field.

title: ARMY WILL GET TANKS DESPITE STRIKE, BUILDER SAYS
description: Despite a 10-day strike by 5,000 assembly-line workers, the General Dynamics Corporation says it will meet its current delivery schedules on tanks for the Army.

title: BOARD ASKED TO SET 'CORE OF LEARNING'
description: THE State Board of Education meets this week to vote on a recommendation that the state spell out what a high school student should know before graduating.

title: CONSTRUCTION STARTS ON DAM FOR UTILITIES
description: CONSTRUCTION of the $217 million Merrill Creek Reservoir in this Warren County community was begun last week with a ceremonial ground-breaking at the site here.

title: A 'GUYS AND DOLLS' DONE NICELY-NICELY
description: THEATER THREE in Port Jefferson has come up with a winner with its production of ''Guys and Dolls,'' the Frank Loesser, Abe Burrows, Jo Swerling musical about the saints and sinners of Broadway in the late 1940's.

title: ON INTERNATIONAL THEMES
description: The Principality of Monaco has announced details on 23 stamps and two souvenir sheets that are being issued during the second half of 1985. Since the marriage of the late American actress Grace Kelly to Prince Rainier III, the stamps of Monaco have become popular in this country.

title: MELTED FOOD, LANTERNS AND CAMARADERIE IN GLORIA'S WAKE
description: Gertrude Copnall, of Southampton, L.I., looked inside her rapidly defrosting refrigerator yesterday and started cooking.

title: ANTIQUES L'FUN, FOLKSY' SHOW IN SHORT HILLS
description: FROM what was largely a tabletop presentation just a few years ago, the Short Hills Antiques Show has been skillfully nurtured by astute volunteer management into a popular event that now attracts quality dealers, as well as serious browsers and buyers.

title: No Headline
description: From James Atlas's article, one can only surmise that membership in the sanctum of New York intellectuals is gained by becoming a leading literary critic with a penchant for reveling in polemics on social matters in conformance to the dominant ideology of the inner circle of literati.

title: HECKLER FIGHTS EFFORT TO OUST HER FROM POST
description: Margaret M. Heckler, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, is being pressed by White House officials to leave her post and has asked to meet Monday with President Reagan to discuss her future, according to Administration officials.

title: MEDICARE
description: To the Editor:

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;

BUYING BULBS ON A FLORAL DUTCH TOUR
description: Surely one of the most glorious sights on earth is the spring bulb display in the Netherlands. Each year, at the end of April and early May, hundreds of thousands of garden lovers from all over the world make a pilgrimage to feast their eyes on millions of blooming tulips, daffodils and hyacinths. They travel to the bulb fields, which are mostly in the western section, and to Keukenhof Gardens, the showcase of the Dutch bulb industry, to view the plantings.

title: PRISONERS GET LESSON IN DRAMA
description: It is not the money that motivates the young actors of the Geese Theater Company. They make $63.50 a month. Nor is it the year-round travel, crisscrossing the country in a rickety bus. It is, they say, their audiences, people behind bars for a few years or a lifetime, and the message that the troupe hopes to get across.

title: Dr. Despina Terris Marries
description: At the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York yesterday Dr. Despina K. Terris, a third-year resident in radiation oncology at the New York University Medical Center, was married to Dr. Richard A. Gervasio, a third-year resident in anesthesiology at the Beth Israel Medical Center in New York. The Rev. Robert Stephanopoulos performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Dr. and Mrs. Costas Terris of Wilmington, Del., and Mr. and Mrs. Ralph A. Gervasio of Hamilton, N.J. The bride will retain her name.

title: DEMOCRATIC LEADER SOLIDIFIES POSITION
description: RICHARD L. Weingarten, a 56-year-old lawyer from Yonkers, became the new chairman of the Westchester County Democratic Party last week and lost little time in establishing his authority.

title: Michael Paul Lazarus Wed to Laura F. Kline
description: At the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York yesterday Laura Fennelly Kline, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Patton Kline of New York and Watch Hill, R.I., was married to Michael Paul Lazarus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Hilliard Lazarus of Lancaster, Pa. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: GYM teachers should be given their due, says Edward W. Bradley, chief of the Governor's Council on Physical Fitness. And Mr. Bradley, a former gym teacher, was just given his.

title: PARK SLOPE TENANTS RENOVATING THEIR 23 BUILDINGS
description: Work has begun on 23 Brooklyn brownstones purchased last year by their residents from the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development after more than five years of complex negotiations with Federal and local housing officials.

title: MAKING THE MOST OF SPECIAL EVENTS
description: NONPROFIT organizations today are facing two problems: a reduction in monetary gifts due to waning federal subsidies, lessening tax incentives, and reduced corporate giving; and a loss of volunteers because rising inflation means that many families need two incomes.

title: LIONS TOP RUTGERS
description: Penn State was a little too strong and a little too tough for Rutgers today as the Nittany Lions beat the Scarlet Knights for the seventh straight time since the series between the two state universities resumed in 1977.

title: 10TH STRAIGHT VICTORY FOR MANCHESTER UNITED
description: Manchester United beat Southampton, 1-0, today to record its 10th straight English League soccer victory.

title: DEBTORS ON DEBT
description: At the United Nations General Assembly last week, Latin American leaders warned of the perils of austerity and called for more time to settle the region's $370 billion foreign debt. xh'Brazil will not pay its foreign debt with recession, not with unemployment, nor with hunger.' xhJose Sarney President of Brazil xh'We are faced with a dramatic choice: It is either debt or democracy.' Alan Garcia Perez President of Peru xh'The foreign debt problem of Latin America and other developing countries cannot be definitively solved through rescheduling that grants only temporary relief to the debtor countries and to the international community.' Bernardo Sepulveda Amor Foreign Minister of Mexico 'Our nations need urgent solutions.' Dante Caputo Foreign Minister of Argentina

title: GERMANY'S RICH CHEMICAL GIANTS
description: LAST May, BASF, the West German chemical giant, capped a major acquisition drive by laying out $1 billion for the American ink and paint maker, Inmont. Earlier this year, Hoechst, another industry leader, snapped up Rosenthal Technik, the technology arm of the Rosenthal porcelain group.
