At about the same time, Bayer, the third of Germany's chemical giants, announced ambitious plans to boost its drive into the United States pharmaceuticals market, including the construction of a multimillion-dollar research center near New Haven.

title: PAPERBACKS In short: Fition
description: WOMEN AND APPLETREES. By Moa Martinson. Translated by Margaret S. Lacy. (Feminist Press, $8.95.) Social activism and a folkloric style make for an interesting, if at times uneasy, blend in this novel of working-class women by a prominent Swedish writer.

title: DISABLED TO BENEFIT FROM AUCTION
description: MORE than 300 pieces of antique furniture and other collectibles have been catalogued. The chairs have been counted, refreshments have been arranged and volunteers have been lined up to carry the items to cars and trucks.

title: OPERA: '''ROSENKAVALIER' AT THE MET
description: IT would probably be rash to say that Kathleen Battle is the finest Sophie in the entire 74-year history of ''Der Rosenkavalier,'' but the performance she gave Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera certainly raised the possibility.

title: READY THE U.N. TO TAKE ON GLOBAL DISASTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: PAPERBACKS IN SHORT: FICTION
description: PARENTS' DAY. By Paul Goodman. (Black Sparrow, Paper, $12.50. Cloth, $20.) Paul Goodman (1911-1972) is best known as a 60's social critic, author of such books as ''Growing Up Absurd,'' but for most of his career he was a remarkably productive, if little-known, literary artist.

title: VIENNA A TO Z
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from Vienna and read the excellent article, I would like to recommend a wonderful guidebook, ''Vienna Inside Out: Sixteen Walking Tours'' by J. Sydney Jones. If readers cannot find a copy of this guidebook (it is not listed in Books in Print) they can look for the author's latest guidebook to Vienna, a paperback called ''Viennawalks,'' which was published in April by Holt, Rinehart & Winston. ''Vienna Inside Out'' helped us see not only the beauty that is Vienna but also to feel the rich history that is Vienna.

title: A SOPRANO FASCINATED WITH THE PAST
description: One of the most exciting new prima donnas in opera is Julianne Baird.

title: 700 CRIME SITES SHUT DOWN BY POLICE UNDER NEW YORK CITY PADLOCK LAW
description: After a year in use, New York City's padlock law has halted illegal narcotics, gambling and prostitution operations at more than 700 sites, according to officials.

title: 2 More Suspected Spies Held in West Germany
description: Two more suspected Communist spies have been arrested in West Germany, raising to 11 the number of West Germans the Government fears have passed secrets to East Germany, the chief prosecutor's office said today.

title: SYSTEMS TO WARN OF WIND SHIFTS ARE TO BE PUT ON NEW BOEING JETS
description: New Boeing jets will include cockpit systems to warn pilots about catastrophic wind shifts, company officials say.

title: 11TONS, NO TAKERS
description: THE newspaper recycling project at the Pulaski Street Elementary School in Riverhead was so successful that a few years ago school officials decided to construct a building solely to house the collected papers.

title:
BENDS IN DELAWARE BORDER SOW CONFUSION;

FISHING-LICENSE CASE STIRS CALL FOR RESOLUTION
description: ''THE truth,'' wrote Justice Benjamin Cardoza in a 1934 United States Supreme Court decision, ''is that almost from the beginning of statehood, Delaware and New Jersey have been engaged in a dispute as to the boundary between them.''

title: Diana Hoadley Weds Conrad B. Bailey
description: The First Church Congregational in Fairfield, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Diana Lynn Hoadley, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh A. Hoadley of Greenfield Hill, Conn., and Conrad Beuttel Bailey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce M. Bailey of Milton, Mass. The Rev. Richard L. Rush performed the ceremony.

title: Recent Sales
description: Belvidere $66,000 *2* 420 Greenwich Street *2* 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 73-year-old town house; *2* slate roof, enclosed porch, 200-foot-deep lot; *2* taxes $1,127. Englishtown $126,000 *2* 43c Millstone Road *2* 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 6-year-old colonial; *2* family room with fireplace, patio, 3 acres; *2* taxes $2,557. Frankford Township $84,000 *2* Dalrymee Road *2* 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 12-year-old ranch; *2* almost 1 acre, 3-car garage, modern kitchen; *2* taxes $2,325. Hardyston $94,500 *2* 2 Deer Trail *2* 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 11-year-old chalet; *2* cedar siding, fireplace, $100 Lake Tamerack association dues; *2* taxes $2,624. Kearny $85,000 *2* 193 Magnolia Avenue *2* 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; *2* sun room, natural woodwork, porch; *2* taxes $1,113. Springfield $227,000 *2* 19 Green Hill Road *2* 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old split-level; *2* marble floor in foyer, patio; *2* taxes $3,061. OTHER AREAS Cedarhurst, L.I. $150,000 *2* 509 Oxford Road *2* 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 45-year-old Cape Cod; *2* dining room, eat-in kitchen, *2* den, 1-car garage; taxes $1,500. Armonk, N.Y. $200,000 *2* 14 Byram Brook Place *2* 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old frame ranch; *2* deck, eat-in kitchen, paneled basement, *2* 0.934 acre; taxes $3,238. Orange, Conn. $210,000 *2* 606 Grassy Hill Road *2* 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old ranch; *2* lakefront, cathedral ceilings; *2* taxes $2,796.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Unemployment: Up Again The September jobless rate, due out Friday, will return to the 7.2 percent level it has been so fond of this year, says Cary Leahey, vice president and senior economist at Shearson Lehman Brothers. That will be somber news for economists who last month heralded a sharp drop in unemployment as a clear indication that the long-awaited economic rebound was at hand.

title: TYLENOL SLAYINGS REMAIN A MYSTERY
description: The three-year search for the person who killed seven people by poisoning Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules with cyanide has slowed considerably in recent months.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: AMONG the infrequently heard-of links in New Jersey's ecological chain are amphibians, that group of animals that includes frogs, toads and salamanders. These water-dependent species, of which there are about 2,500 worldwide, occupy a niche somewhere between reptiles and fish.

title: RABBI RECALLS HER TRIP AND ROLE IN BAR MITZVAH IN CRACOW
description: The following article, written by Rabbi Emily Korzenick of Scarsdale, was excerpted from a presentation she gave this month to her congregation, The Fellowship for Jewish Learning, and at Bet Am Shalom in White Plains. It concerns her recent trip to Poland to participate in the bar mitzvah of Eric Strom of Stamford, Conn. CAN I distill this experience? Can I bring forth the ways in which it deepened our understanding of our Jewish past? Do I perceive the ways in which these experiences can open doors to new possibilities, strengthening the meaning and value of Jewish community? Can I reach out to respond appropriately to the suffering of the Polish people despite my own feelings about their anti-Semitism over the centuries?

title: MITTERRAND CAN'T PUT IT BEHIND HIM
description: WAS it a sabotage plot against a pesky envionmentalist group planning to protest French nuclear testing in the Pacific? Or was it merely an information-gathering mission transformed without authorization into a nasty piece of freelance terrorism that has savaged France's reputation abroad and caused political crisis at home?

title: WORKING WITH WALLBOARD
description: GYPSUM board, often referred to as drywall, wallboard or Sheetrock (the latter is the brand name of one of the original manufacturers), is probably the most widely used material for interior house walls and ceilings. The panels are easy to cut, fit and install, and they can be painted or papered easily.

title: CALENDARS
description: Dog Shows Today - Westbury Kennel Club 63d all-breed and Nassau Dog Training Club's 37th obedience trial, C. W. Post, Northern Blvd., Brookville, L.I.; 1,922 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES SPORTS MAGAZINE: Part II, Sept. 29, 1985
description: Why We Keep Score Triumph may be elusive in life, but sports gives us winners everyday.

title: JUDGES TO RULE ON COSTA RICA PRESS LICENSING
description: A panel of human-rights advocates is considering whether Costa Rica's law requiring licensing of journalists violates the public's right to information.

title: DO SCHOOLS NEED AN OFFICIAL LANGUAGE?
description: In only eight months on the job, Education Secretary William J. Bennett has managed to stir up enough controversy for a full four-year term.

title: Anne Dempsey Becomes Bride
description: Anne Marie Dempsey, an account executive at Young & Rubicam Inc., and William Carter Sullivan 3d, an administrative officer at Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, were married yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Lakeville, Conn. Msgr. James C. Wilders performed the ceremony.

title: BELLFLOWERS CAN MAKE BORDERS BRILLIANT
description: Fall is time to take a critical look at what has worked or not worked in the flower border. It is a time to evaluate how the perennials, the supporting structures, have performed. Perhaps a plant of a different shape, height or color could improve next year's display.

title: GENEROUS GOVERNMENT, STINGY PUBLIC
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN maintains that if Government did less for the needy, private charity would step in and make up the shortfall. Liberals have dismissed his view as romanticized and naive. But two scholars have come up with some evidence that Mr. Reagan has a point.

title: Congress Looks At Outgo And Income
description: With the end the 1985 fiscal year only days away, Congress concentrated last week on Federal spending, both its amount and its purposes.

title: 'We Both Feel Secure'
description: FOR most of their working lives, John and Lucille Smaidris gave little thought to planning for retirement. He spent 37 years with the International Harvester Company; she worked 28 years as a secretary for Atlantic Richfield, and both participated in em-ployee stock and thrift plans at work.

title: SCHMELING TURNS 80
description: He may not pack the punch he once did, but for a man who was celebrating his 80th birthday yesterday, Max Schmeling seemed remarkably fit and eager for the next challenge. ''I often think about my past,'' he said in an interview, ''but I'm much more interested in the present and future.''

title: FOLLOW THE LEADER ON PRODUCTIVITY
description: WEIGHTY Congressional studies and screeching headlines in recent years have proclaimed that the United States is losing its competitive edge. Its productivity has been far outstripped by that of Japan, West Germany and other foreign nations. President Reagan's 1981 decision to slash corporate tax rates and increase incentives for companies to modernize plants and equipment was designed to wipe out the discrepancy.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: SEAFOOD FESTIVAL Fresh seafood - all you can eat for $15 - will be the centerpiece of Commercial Township's annual Seafood Festival in Mauricetown next Saturday and Sunday.

title: THE PRESIDENT'S HARD SELL ON FREE TRADE
description: On successive days last week, President Reagan tried to turn the tide of restrictive trade legislation rolling across Capitol Hill. On Sunday, the Administration convened a meeting of the world's five leading industrial nations and exacted a promise that they would act together to drive down the high value of the dollar - a principal cause of expensive American exports and cheap foreign imports. On Monday, the President advanced a program for combatting the soaring trade deficit that included a $300 million fund to help subsidize American sales abroad.

title: WORKSHOPS
description: The New York City Loft Board is expected next month to approve regulations for major renovations of the estimated 6,000 registered residential lofts throughout Manhattan and Brooklyn.

title: Albert Otten, 99, Industrialist Who Fled Germany in 1930's
description: Albert Otten, a leading industrialist in Germany who immigrated to the United States in the early 1940's, died Thursday at his home in Teaneck, N.J. He was 99 years old. Mr. Otten, who was born in Bonfeld, Germany, owned and controlled steel and manufacturing companies employing more than 10,000 people throughout Germany in the years before World War II.

title: CREDIT CARDS BEST USED JUDICIOUSLY
description: CREDIT cards are not only a way of life among consumers, but an increasingly important part of the nation's financial system. At the end of 1984, 99 million Americans held more than 700 million credits cards, according to H. Spencer Nilson, author of the Nilson Report, a newsletter that follows developments in the credit-card industry.

title: WINNING: WHY WE KEEP SCORE
description: For when the One Great Scorer comes To mark against your name, He writes - not that you won or lost - But how you played the Game.> - GRANTLAND RICE Winning is fun; losing is hell.> - BILLY MARTIN I HOPED THAT MY RESEARCHES into the matter of winning would verify something I had long suspected: that the word ''triumph'' derives from the Roman custom of requiring the vanquished to say ''umph'' three times. No such luck.

title: ADULTERY WITH THE EXTERMINATOR
description: LOVE LIFE By James D. Houston. 260 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: FILM, THEATER AND TV ACTOR
description: Lloyd Nolan, a journeyman character actor in Grade B movies for two decades before he won critical acclaim for his role as Captain Queeg in ''The Caine Mutiny Court Martial'' on Broadway and television in the mid-1950's, died Friday of lung cancer at his home in Los Angeles. He was 83 years old.

title: STATE OF PLAY
description: The decision of Republican Senator Charles Mathias of Maryland not to run for re-election next year has sent a shiver up the spines of Republican pols everywhere.

title: IN EUROPE, 'STAR WARS' IS MORE THAN A POCKETBOOK ISSUE
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev makes his first visit to Western Europe as leader of the Soviet Communist Party this week. It seems hardly accidental that he is starting with France, which has rebuffed President Reagan's program for putting antimissile weapons in space.

title: UPWARD FROM PEBBLES
description: FROM ONE TO ZERO A Universal History of Numbers. By Georges Ifrah. Translated by Lowell Bair. Illustrated. 503 pp. New York: Viking. $35. A GERMAN merchant of the 15th century asked an eminent professor where to send his son for a good business education. The professor responded that German universities would be sufficient to teach the boy addition and subtraction but that he would have to go to Italy to learn multiplication and division. Before you smile indulgently, try adding the Roman numerals CCLXVI, MDCCCVII, DCL and MLXXX without first translating them.

title: VIENNA A TO Z
description: To the Editor: From our recollections of a visit to Vienna 10 years ago, we could add other favorites to the alphabet in the article ''The Capital from A to Z'' (Travel, Aug. 25) by Paul Hofmann. For instance:

title: CARDS SPLIT WITH EXPOS
description: Darrell Porter's single snapped a 2-2 tie in the 11th inning and led the St. Louis Cardinals to a 4-2 victory today over the Montreal Expos and a split of a doubleheader.

title: FORCES THAT PLAY UPON FARMERS
description: Norma O'Leary's ''Waht Do Farmers Want?'' [Opinion page, Sept. 8] misses the fact that the awful situation of today's farmers derives from a time back in the 1970's when various measures were employed to boost farm production and facilitate the gobbling up of small farms by large ones.

title: A Rising Star Turns Defector
description: The espionage business may never have seen a year like it. First Hans Joachim Tiedge, West Germany's top spy-catcher, defected to East Germany, fearful that his cover as a double agent had been blown.

title: POST HANDS HOFSTRA FIRST DEFEAT, 20-10
description: The C. W. Post-Hofstra rivalry, halted in 1979, resumed in upset fashion yesterday as the Pioneers scored all their points in the final quarter to overtake previously undefeated Hofstra, 20-10, at Hofstra Stadium in Hempstead, L.I.

title: A SCANDINAVIAN SALUTE
description: FOR the next nine months, performers, artists and lecturers from Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway and Sweden will be saluting the 75th anniversary of the American-Scandinavian Foundation with a series of cultural events.

title: Bryn Luxner Has Wedding
description: The marriage of Bryn Macy Luxner, a daughter of David Luxner of New York and Mrs. Peter H. Kaskell of New York and Wilton, Conn., to Thomas McNeal Wood, a son of Dr. Francis A. and Dr. Mary Wood of Montclair, N.J., took place yesterday at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Wilton. The Rev. Stephen D. Parker performed the ceremony.

title: CASINOS EYE POLITICAL ARENA
description: THE casino industry is showing signs of entering the political arena, and the possibility is worrying several legislators and the vice chairman of the state's Casino Control Commission.

title: GIANTS NEED A STEADY OFFENSE
description: The last few days have been good ones for the Giants.

title: New Panel Named For AIDS Testing
description: The Health Department last week appointed seven doctors to a panel that will recommend, case by case, whether children with AIDS should attend New York City public schools. The formation of the panel, which Mayor Koch said includes some of the nation's leading experts on the disease, creates a two-step screening process for children with AIDS who seek to enter the schools. Mr. Koch had previously established a four-member panel, made up of a doctor, a school official, a social worker and a parent, to determine whether a child with AIDS would pose a danger to himself or others in school.

title: Madeleine F. Shipley Weds Selden R. Dickinson
description: The marriage of Madeleine F. Shipley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert F. Shipley of New York, to Selden R. Dickinson, a son of Dr. and Mrs. S. Jerome Dickinson of New York and Siasconset, Mass., took place yesterday. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: POETRY SERIES STARTS
description: AN award-winning poet, Alicia Ostriker, opens the ninth season of the Fairfield County Poet's Voice series today with a reading from her work at the Greenwich Library.

title: SALES TAX
description: To the Editor:

title: HALLMARKS OF MODERN FINNISH GLASS
description: A comprehensive retrospective of 20th-century Finnish glass - the first ever held in this country - opens Tuesday and remains through Jan. 5 at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, Two East 91st Street. On view in ''The Modern Spirit: Glass From Finland,'' are 500 works by all the masters of the medium from Alvar Aalto to Tapio Wirkkala, and by many of their lesser known colleagues.

title: HECTIC DAYS FOR U.N.'S FIRST LADY
description: When Javier Perez de Cuellar was named Secretary General of the United Nations in 1982, his wife, Marcela, was given almost as much advice as he was.

title: Brenda L. Payne Wed to Engineer
description: At the St. Albans Congregational Church in Queens yesterday, Brenda Lynn Payne and Leopold Anthony Whiteman Jr. were married by the Rev. Cecil Prescod.

title: ZUBIN MEHTA IN FILM
description: The world premiere of the film ''On Wings of Fire,'' starring the New York Philharmonic's music director, Zubin Mehta, will take place Wednesday at 6:30 P.M. at the Ziegfeld Theater, 141 West 54th Street.

title: 421A LEASE RENEWALS
description: Question: The building in which I live got a property-tax exemption under the 421a program. My lease, which expires Dec. 31, 1986, was accompanied by a notice that says: ''The tax abatement expires on June 30, 1988. Upon the expiration of the last lease in existence prior to June 30, 1988, the landlord will not be required to renew your lease at stabilization rates.'' What options will I have on Dec. 31, 1986, and in 1988? What significance does the notice have? . . . L. K., Manhattan Answer: When your lease expires Dec. 31, 1986, before the exemption has expired, you are entitled to a renewal. When that lease expires after the exemption has expired, you can continue under rent-stabilization protection. Only when you move would the unit no longer be covered by rent stabilization, according to representatives of the city, state and landlords.

title: TRUTH AND CANCER
description: BELIEVE me, I know that the last subject you want to read about, while you're enjoying your bagels or croissants on a Sunday morning, is cancer. I would feel the same way, except that I'm stuck with the disease.

title: Taiwan Seizes Magazines
description: The authorities have seized 81,000 copies of seven opposition magazines, officials said today. The officials said the magazines were seized in two raids Friday because they included articles that confused public opinion.

title: FESTIVALS TO CELEBRATE THE HARVEST
description: KAY POLLARD of Milford wore a hat fashioned in the likeness of a Leghorn chicken. Morris Hogan, in denim overalls and cap, sold sweet cider from his Burlington mill. Michelle Hettwer of Plymouth won first prize for the giant kohlrabi she had grown in her garden. And Rose Tricarico of Wolcott rendered ''Turkey in the Straw'' on her fiddle - all at the 37th annual Terryville Country Fair, which drew some 15,000 people on a recent weekend.

title: A WARNING FOR FALL ON LYME DISEASE
description: SUMMER has ended, but health officials in the county say residents should continue to be cautious about Lyme disease.

title: IS ACTION OR POLITICS THE REAL ATTRACTION?
description: It's about a week before Christmas. Mikal and Nikko, two Soviet agents, are drinking beer, relaxing and trading Commie-type small talk in an open-air, seaside bar near Miami. ''Look at them,'' sneers Mikal, indicating the carefree, bikini-clad capitalists around them. ''Soft, decadent - they don't even understand the nature of their own freedom.''

title: China and Russia Move Up Some Fresher Faces
description: Younger men were promoted to top positions in the Soviet Union and China last week as Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Deng Xiaoping tightened their grasp on the levers of power.

title: FROM THE RUNWAYS TO REAL LIFE
description: IT makes for fine sport, following the season's fashions from their debut on the runway to their debut on the sidewalk. Besides, identifying the work of a well-known designer can provide a most satisfying sense of accomplishment, the sort that Roger Tory Peterson might feel when he spots the season's first scarlet tanager. Anyone can play, but it does require a fast eye and instant recall, because six months have gone by since the European and American designers first presented their fall collections.

title: Fiona F.Lally and David Baker Shorr Are Married
description: Fiona Francesca Lally, a reinsurance broker at Guy Carpenter & Company in New York, and David Baker Shorr, a political consultant, were married yesterday. The ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church was performed by the Rev. Charles A. Baldwin, the chaplain at Brown University, from which the couple graduated in 1983.

title: MANAGING ASSETS TO EXPAND RESOURCES
description: LAST fall Larry J. Dixon, an I.B.M. executive who lives in Connecticut, sold a couple of summer homes and was trying to decide how to invest the proceeds.

title: Bethany M. Panzirer Weds Bruce Gilboard
description: Bethany M. Panzirer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Panzirer of New York, was married yesterday to Bruce Howard Gilboard, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Gilboard of North Andover, Mass. Rabbi Harvey Tattelbaum and Cantor Bruce Rubin officiated at the Pierre Hotel.

title: L.I. WOMEN STUDY MANAGING MONEY
description: AS THE number of single women living on Long Island has increased dramatically in recent years, so has their interest in controlling money more effectively.

title: Marjorie Beth Glazer Weds S. H. Edelstein
description: The marriage of Marjorie Beth Glazer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Glazer of New York, to Steven Howard Edelstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Edelstein of Brooklyn, took place last night at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York. Rabbi Judah Nadich, assisted by Rabbi Marc Tannenbaum, performed the ceremony.

title: THE KESH IN SONG AND STORY
description: ALWAYS COMING HOME By Ursula K. Le Guin. Illustrated by Margaret Chodos, With Music by Todd Barton. 523 pp. New York: Harper & Row. Paper, boxed with cassette. $25. WITH high invention and deep intelligence, ''Always Coming Home'' presents, in alternating narratives, poems and expositions, Ursula K. Le Guin's most consistently lyric and luminous book in a career adorned with some of the most precise and passionate prose in the service of a major imaginative vision.

title: WRONG AGENCY
description: To the Editor:

title: Raise the H.M.S. Hussar
description: A salvage expert said last week that, using a sonar device similar to the one that earlier this month helped locate the Titanic, he had found a potential underwater treasure closer to home: a British Revolutionary War frigate that was carrying enough gold coins to cover a Redcoat payroll when it sank in the East River in 1780.

title: PRO-TEXAS, ANTICHILI
description: HONKYTONK GELATO Travels Through Texas. By Stephen Brook. 283 pp. New York: Atheneum. $12.95.

title: D.T. D'Antonio Wed to Miss Pell
description: Pamela Condon Pell, a daughter of Mrs. Ralph F. Colin Jr. of New York and Peter Stuyvesant Pell of Las Cruces, N.M., was married yesterday to Dennis Thomas D'Antonio, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. D'Antonio of Fort Salonga, L.I. at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Thomas D. Bowers performed the ceremony.

title: QUICKENING CHANGE IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: A visitor returning to South Africa after an absence of five years is reminded of the story of the old fellow who heard the clock strike 13 and said, ''It's never been this late before.''

title: Shining Path Guerrillas Said to Kill 14 in Peru
description: Maoist guerrillas attacked an Andean village with guns and explosives, killing 14 people and wounding 8, the police said today.

title: OFFICE HAZARDS
description: To the Editor:

title: IN WHOSE FOOTSTEPS TO THE BRITISH THRONE?
description: To the Editor:

title: MARYLAND BLANKED
description: ''Michigan means defense.''

title: Miss Pitaro Weds Ken A. McMillen
description: Regina Pitaro, a daughter of Justice Nicholas L. Pitaro of State Supreme Court and Mrs. Pitaro of Ozone Park, Queens, was married yesterday to Ken A. McMillen, a son of Maxine Korte of Blue Springs, Mo., and the late Austin McMillen. The Rev. H. Scott Matheney, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University, from which the bride and bridegroom received M.B.A. degrees.

title: EXCERPTS FROM JARUZELSKI INTERVIEW
description: Following are excerpts from an interview in New York yesterday with Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, as translated by his aide:

title: MEN BUILDING RESORT IN ALASKA GET LONESOME
description: Here in the back country where the dirt road shrinks to a rock-strewn path, Tom Williams and some of his crew say they are willing to do without telephones, electricity or running water, but they say they are tired of doing without women.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The markets are broiling. Just everything is going right if you want to see prices rise -or wrong if you want to see them fall.''

title: THE UNRELENTING UNSOLICITED
description: TO test a theory of mine - that junk mail is taking over the world - I have for the past week been collecting my mail in a large paper sack from the grocery store. It is now filled three-quarters of the way to the top with the contents of my mailbox for six days - 53 pieces of mail.

title: OF ARMOR AND THE MAN
description: THE 25-year-old running back, has a Hollywood agent, a literary agent, a commercial agent and an agent to negotiate his contracts with the Los Angeles Rams.

title: CORRECTION
description: The location of the Five Towns Senior Center was incorrectly reported in the Long Island Journal of Sept. 15. The center is in Woodmere.

title: More Data on Corporate Crime
description: Senate Democrats critical of the Justice Department's handling of corporate crime attempted to shore up that criticism last week with documents that showed the department ignoring a strong recommendation for prosecution from the Food and Drug Administration.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 29, 1985
description: International

title: TRADITIONAL TOUCHES
description: DEVELOPMENTS in so-called high technology may offer men both information and amusement, but when it comes to the jewelry they wear, it is memories of things past that attracts them. A man may have a cellular telephone in his automobile and a compact-disk player in his home, but his jewelry box is likely to contain gold and silver antique timepieces, tie bars, crest or intaglio rings, cuff links, key rings, collar pins and belt buckles.

title: BRODCAST TV
description: Not only a popular success but also the recipient of critical accolades, the 1982 comedy ''Tootsie'' comes to commercial television for the first time on Sunday at 9 P.M. on ABC.

title: Weather May Hamper Air-India Investigation
description: Investigators trying to find out why an Air-India jumbo jet plunged into the Atlantic are hurrying to gather wreckage from the ocean floor before wintry weather makes recovery operations impossible.

title: KNICKS' BAILEY FAINTS IN DRILL
description: As Patrick Ewing dressed for his first Knick workout today, the heralded 7-foot center from Georgetown said: ''I can't wait. I'm anxious to see what it's about.''

title: O'MARA WINS MILE IN UPSET
description: Running the first mile road race of his career and regarded essentially as a ''rabbit'' who would set the early pace, Frank O'Mara of Ireland stunned a strong field of world-class runners yesterday when he captured the Fifth Avenue Mile.

title: SOUTHOLD ACTS TO HONOR U.N.
description: IT WAS Jack Kamaiko of Greenport who had the idea first, back in May. The 40th anniversary of the United Nations was coming up in October. Wouldn't it be nice to have some recognition of it locally?

title: MASS PRODUCTION
description: To the Editor:

title: GOALS ARE OUTLINED FOR KING'S COLLEGE
description: WHEN Dr. Friedhelm K. Radandt is installed as the third president of The King's College in Briarcliff Manor on Saturday, he will already have taken a step toward one of his goals for the college: to make the privately supported, Christian liberal-arts school better known in the Westchester community.

title: THE UNUSUAL SEASON TO COME
description: NO one is going to say there is nothing new on the state's regional theater stages this coming season. Anyone looking for familiar fare will have to look hard.

title: REHAB ON 67TH
description: Demolition of most of a firehouse and a police station built in the 1880s is expected to begin next month as the first phase in a $13 million replacement project that will preserve the facades of both buildings.

title: KEEPING AN EYE ON KEMP
description: There is fairly compelling circumstantial evidence that Representative Jack F. Kemp, the former professional football quarterback, is already campaigning for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination.

title: BLACK MARKET SALES RISE IN ARMS STOLEN FROM U.S. MILITARY BASES
description: Tens of millions of dollars worth of advanced, American-made weapons intended for military use are showing up on the black market, according to officials from the Defense Department, other Federal agencies and members of Congress.

title: A SWITCH IN STAMFORD
description: In sharp contrast to the sleek modern styling that typifies the new generation of commercial structures in downtown Stamford, a new office building now under construction there will have a decidedly classical look.

title:
THE CAREFUL SHOPPER;

Food Processors At Lowered Prices
description: The Robot Coupe International Factory Outlet in East Norwalk opened three months ago to provide reconditioned home food-processing machines at 50 percent off the suggested retail price, new machines at a 25 percent discount and accessories at a 20 percent markdown. The manufacturing is done in France along with the production of Robot Coupe professional food-processing machines for restaurants and institutions. The price of the gift or bridal kit RC2000 white model with accessories, ordinarily $245 retail and initially $183.75 here, has been lowered to $149.95 at Norwalk. The only color choices are in the RC2100 model - chrome, white or red.

title: ALBANY SESSION TO TAKE UP HOUSING
description: A stalled plan to build or repair thousands of New York City apartments with money borrowed from the Battery Park City Authority will be pressed at the special legislative session this fall, according to Governor Cuomo's top aide.

title: KING, GULOTTA: EYES ON ALBANY
description: EVEN before Election Day, two Nassau Republicans running for re-election to local offices in November are being mentioned for the Republican state ticket next year.

title: A HISTORICAL COMMENTARY ON WAR
description: When Gwynne Dyer first approached the Pentagon several years ago and sought cooperation for an ambitious documentary called ''War,'' he was told, in effect: We'll let you film the soldiers and sailors, the fliers and marines, the training and even some of the weapons - but we won't allow you to interview any of the top-level policy-makers.

title: NOR ANY DROP TO DRINK
description: TROUBLED WATER The Poisoning of America's Drinking Water - How Government and Industry Allowed It to Happen, and What You Can Do to Insure a Safe Supply in the Home. By Jonathan King. 256 pp. Emmaus, Pa.: Rodale Press. Paper, $8.95.

title: Angela Bandeira de Mello Is Married
description: Angela Oliveira Bandeira de Mello, a daughter of Jose Bandeira de Mello of Rio de Janeiro and the late Maria Eugenia Bandeira de Mello, was married yesterday to Thomas Woodfin Keesee 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Keesee Jr. of Mount Kisco, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. William E. Foley performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: Robert G. Babson And Miss White Exchange Vows
description: Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Helen Christine White, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Shoemaker White Jr. of Greens Farms, Conn., to Robert Grey Babson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Clifford Babson of Sherborn, Mass. The Rev. Stephen Chinlund performed the ceremony.

title: JOB EXPERIMENT LETS THE RETARDED WORK
description: Five days a week, long before dawn, 23-year-old Derrick leaves his Bronx home and takes the hourlong subway ride into midtown.

title: QUAKES MAY SPUR MEXICAN DISPERSAL
description: For years, Mexican officials have talked about decentralizing the Government, moving entire agencies out of the capital as a way of stemming its virtually uncontrolled growth.

title: GROWING PAINS FOR BRAZIL'S DEMOCRACY
description: When the armed forces stepped down in Argentina in December 1983, and in Uruguay 15 months later, the political parties of pre-coup days immediately reappeared, Congress came alive and something that could be recognized as the democracy of yore returned. But when 21 years of Brazilian dictatorship ended in March, neither the tradition nor the structure of party politics was ready to fill the vacuum. There was hardly a memory of democracy.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: MEMBERS of the New Jersey Business and Industry Association, the Meadowlands Chamber of Commerce, the Clifton-Passaic Regional Chamber of Commerce and the New Jersey Interagency Council on Smoking and Health will hold three seminars this week to discuss compliance with the state's new smoking laws.

title: A Referendum Set On Navy Base In the City
description: While the United States Navy wants to make a home in New York City, some New Yorkers are determined to make it feel unwelcome. Concerned that the plan to build a base for seven ships on Staten Island would bring nuclear weapons into the city, an antinuclear group succeeded last week in placing on the citywide ballot in November a referendum on the proposal. The City Clerk's office cleared the way by ruling that 23,000 signatures in the latest round of petitions, 8,000 more than the number needed, were valid.

title: 5 BLACKS KILLED IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: The authorities today reported the deaths of five blacks in the continuing racial violence that has shaken this nation for more than a year and has claimed more than 700 lives.

title: BACK TOOK MONEY
description: J. C. Morris, a former Texas Christian running back who says he had denied receiving illegal payments as a college football player, has now acknowledged receiving $600 a month from Dick Lowe, the former T.C.U. regent who recently resigned after admitting making payoffs to student-athletes. ''Lowe was my sugar daddy,'' Morris told The Dallas Morning News.

title: 10 WRITERS WIN $25,000
description: LATE next month, 10 writers will each receive $25,000 tax-free from the Whiting Foundation, a private, New York-based philanthropic organization with an emphasis on the humanities. Foundation officials say this is the largest private program exclusively for writers.

title: SUDAN SAYS IT FOILED A COUP BID
description: The Sudanese Government said today that it had foiled an attempted coup by southern Sudanese who had foreign support.

title: OYSTERS GALORE
description: IF THE DISH HAS AN OYSTER IN IT, BILL TAYLOR HAS made it. He may even have invented it.

title: MEXICO O MEXICO!
description: It took the recent earthquakes in Mexico - the cries of children in the rubble - to make this capital think a little more seriously about the accidents of life and death and the common problems of the Western Hemisphere.

title:
ART;

MASTER OF ILLUSION IS PRESENTED IN WHITNEY RETROSPECTIVE
description: IN his own day, which was the late 19th century, John Haberle's illusionistic paintings were more likely to be seen in bars and billiard halls than in art galleries. The first retrospective of this Connecticut native is at the Whitney Museum of American Art in Stamford through Nov. 6.

title: CLEANUP IS SEEN AS TAKING WEEKS
description: The cleanup of damage done by Hurricane Gloria's rampage through New England may take weeks, officials said today as more than 1.3 million New Englanders remained without power.

title:
PAPERBACKS;

CHILDREN'S BOOKS: LOUISA MAY ALCOTT WITHOUT FEAR
description: WHEN I was growing up, any mention of The Classics struck terror in my heart. A slow reader, I was interested mainly in comic books and the Nancy Drew series, which my best friend supplied - as long as I paid her a penny a day. Since that seemed a high price, I resolved to improve my speed. When I finished ''The Mystery in the Old Clock'' in one day, I pronounced myself an accomplished reader, and my mother went out and bought me ''Little Women.'' ''It's a classic,'' she said. ''I loved it, so will you.'' Little did she know that the handsomely illustrated volume was so overwhelming I never finished it. This article may be the first she knows of my failure.

title: Unquenchable Fires
description: To the Editor:

title: Gandhi Hails A Loss in Punjab
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party lost the election in troubled Punjab state last week, but he didn't seem to mind. Mr. Gandhi hailed the victory of the relatively moderate Akali Dal Party as a triumph for democracy, nonviolence and ''Bharat Mata'' - Mother India.

title: THE BIG BUSINESS IN ARMS AND ADD-ONS
description: Early this month, on a day unremarkable for any degree of military alarm, a Pentagon spokesman announced the sale of 88 American-made cannons to Pakistan. Britain, he continued, had agreed to buy 4 rapid-fire guns of the type ships use to shoot down incoming missiles and South Korea had ordered 21 attack helicopters. Altogether, these and other arms transactions were worth $623 million on the international market, where the United States rang up about $14.5 billion in sales last year.

title: EMBATTLED PROJECT NOT DEAD
description: THE PROPOSAL to build a pumped-storage hydroelectric facility involving Schoharie Reservoir and Esopus Creek has not been laid to rest.

title: AT THE MERCY OF 'ANY MAN'S WORD'
description: NEVER GUILTY, NEVER FREE By Ginny Foat with Laura Foreman. 307 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: Amy Stursberg Weds Philip Gellert Barber
description: The marriage of Amy Jessica Stursberg, a senior budget planner for the New York City Office of Management and Budget, and Philip Gellert Barber, an associate in the New York law firm of Schulte, Roth & Zabel, took place yesterday at Waveny House in New Canaan, Conn. Justice of the Peace Henry Coleman performed the ceremony.

title: A CAUTIONARY LIFE
description: AGAINST RACISM: UNPUBLISHED ESSAYS, PAPERS, ADDRESSES, 1887-1961 By W. E. B. Du Bois. Edited by Herbert Aptheker. Illustrated. 325 pp. Amherst: University of Massachusetts Press. $25.

title: JUNIOR VARSITY TEAMS CREATE 'MONOR LEAGUE' FOR PLAYERS
description: LAST year, Coach John Burke led the New Utrecht High School varsity football team to one of its finest seasons, compiling a winning record before losing, 8-0, to John Jay High School in the B-Division city championship game.

title: Anne Roberts Is Wed To William Paul Inch
description: Anne Drew Roberts, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce L. Roberts of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to William Paul Inch, a son of Kenneth W. Inch of Scarborough, N.Y., and Mrs. Donald D. DeJohn of Bedford Village, N.Y. The Rev. Walter L. Pitman performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church of Darien.

title: AUDIT OUTLINES ERRORS IN WELFARE PAYMENTS
description: A RECENT audit of Aid to Families with Dependent Children cases processed by the county's Department of Social Services found that 35 percent of the families studied were either ineligible or overpaid, amounting to a loss of about $8.4 million when projected to the entire caseload.

title: 5 Accused of Attempt To Sell Radios to Iran
description: Three West German and two Iranian nationals have been indicted on charges that they tried to ship 6,000 military radios to Iran in defiance of a ban on arms shipments to the Islamic republic.

title: A DAY IN THE UNEASY LIFE OF SOWETO'S BLACK MAYOR
description: The day started well for Edward Kunene but then, it somehow became unraveled.

title: DESPITE PROTESTS, DEER HUNTS ARE SET
description: Rejecting a proposal to put deer on birth control, state wildlife officials have decided to proceed with a deer hunt to reduce the size of the herd in a suburban state park near here.

title: THE CHANGING WORLD OF NEW YORK INTELLECTUALS
description: Whatever the truth of Hilton Kramer's view of the effect of the radical movement of the 1960's, the large body of Vietnam protesters were not extremists. Does Mr. Kramer really mean to suggest that the legitimate protest against the more invidious aspects of that war represented a ''subversion of civilized values''? At age 59, my view is that the generation of the 1960's, apart from its radical counterpart, was the first to see war for what it is - a total breakdown of civilized values, and the ultimate threat to art in all forms. BARBARA S. ROBBINS Nantucket, Mass.

title: U.S. STUDIES POLLUTION IN SOUND
description: THE Federal Government, New York State and Connecticut will conduct a two-year study of Long Island Sound to find ways to combat growing pollution that is threatening marine life.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN BAY HEAD
description: RESIDENTS of Bay Head like their tiny borough's reputation as a quiet Jersey Shore community. They hold in disdain the boisterous discos of nearby Belmar and the sprawling show-houses that line the beaches farther north.

title: SHOESTRING OPERA TROUPE THRIVES
description: AS the Long Island Opera Company begins its 25th season, Bernard Hart, the artistic and musical director, has no illusions about where the troupe has been and where it is going.

title: JARUZELSKI SAYS THAT REAL FORCE OF SOLIDARITY HAS BEEN DISSIPATED
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, said yesterday that the Solidarity union, which was crushed by his Government after martial law was imposed nearly four years ago, no longer existed as ''a real and organized force.''

title: 'NEW AGE' MUSIC JUST KEEPS OOZING ALONG
description: It's soft and sweet, smooth and unassuming. It turns up at better restaurants all around town. It's not the latest recipe for creme caramel - it's ''new age'' music, a creditable idea gone awry. Or so it would seem with the latest of new age record releases.

title: SYNAGOGUES MAKING UNUSUAL EFFORT TO RECRUIT YOUNG, DISSAFFECTED JEWS
description: Before Rosh ha-Shanah, members of the Hebrew Institute of Riverdale fanned out through the Bronx neighborhood attaching fliers to trees and lampposts, inviting Jews who did not belong to the synagogue to come to a free service.

title: AN ARCHITECT BUILDS WITHOUT CLIENTS
description: FOR any architect, there are many difficult aspects to building a house. But for Anthony Woolner, one of the hardest is waiting for the house to sell. For unlike other architects, he builds on speculation.

title: AFFIRMATIVE ACTIONS FREED IN LIBERIA
description: Liberia's vainglorious President, Gen. Samuel K. Doe, may not care a whit about American protests over his five-year record of repression. But he plainly cares about the Reagan Administration's suspension of $25 million in economic aid, which those protests triggered.

title: Katheryn Jeffery Becomes a Bride
description: Katheryn McConnell Jeffery, a daughter of Sarah Penhallow Jeffery of Fort Worth and David Elwood Jeffery of Birmingham, Mich., was married yesterday to Eugene Hamilton Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton of Huntington, L.I. The Rev. Robert Titus Hollett performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: THE GREAT RETREAT TO VICTORY
description: THE LONG MARCH The Untold Story. By Harrison E. Salisbury. Illustrated. 419 pp. New York: A Cornelia & Michael Bessie Book/ Harper & Row. $22.95.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Livingstone Bramble, the World Boxing Association lightweight champion, will defend his title against Tyrone Crawley in Reno Nov. 23. The match had been set for Oct. 12. . . . Bowie Kuhn, the former commissioner of baseball, has been elected to the board of directors of Northern Telecom Ltd., the Canadian communications company he has served as a consultant since April. . . . Bill Sudakis, a former utility player for the Yankees, Mets, Los Angeles Dodgers and three other major league teams, was arrested by undercover agents at his home in Huntington Beach, Calif., and charged with selling an ounce of cocaine and possessing a kilogram of the substance.

title: IMAGINATIVE ITALIAN AT A FAIR PRICE
description: UNTIL recently, high-quality Italian restaurants in Connecticut were in no way proportionate to the number of people of Italian descent in the state.

title: DEVELOPER BUYS MILLS
description: STATE and local officials were elated after the announcement last week that when the American Thread Company closes its Willimantic mills later this year, the buildings will not be vacant long.

title: Brendan Thomas Byrne Jr. Marries Barbara Moakler at Mount Holyoke
description: The marriage of Barbara Ann Moakler, a senior vice president in the investment banking division of Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York, to Brendan Thomas Byrne Jr., an associate in the New York law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, took place yesterday in South Hadley, Mass. The Rev. Cronan R. Tyms performed the Roman Catholic cermony at the Abbey Chapel on the campus of Mount Holyoke College, from which the bride graduated magna cum laude.

title: Making a Fantasy Concrete
description: When he got out of college 13 years ago, Bruce Merrifield recalls, he fantasized about owning a business some day. But, like many other people, he was not sure just how to go about it.

title: DELAWARE ENDS SHAGGY DOG STORY
description: THIS is absolutely the last report on Daisy, who got into trouble with the dog warden in Harrington, Del., while following a letter carrier around and became a cause that commanded the sympathy of a nation and the attention of the state Attorney General. Unless something else happens.

title: FEARING RADON THREAT, HUNDREDS PHONE AGENCIES IN 2 STATES
description: Hundreds of residents of northern New Jersey and southern New York, concerned about nearby findings of dangerous levels of radon, a radioactive gas, have been calling state agencies in recent weeks, trying to learn if their homes are contaminated.

title: THE OLD BALL GAME
description: Not everyone in Washington forgets Joe Grzenda's place in the city's history. Nor that of Dick Billings. Together, they were the last pitcher-catcher battery ever to play for the Washington Senators.

title: CHANNELING ENERGY - AND CASH - INTO THE COMMUNITY
description: ON a recent summery afternoon, William S. Woodside, chairman and chief executive of the American Can Company, sat in his West 57th Street office overlooking Central Park, and spoke with some emotion about matters he considers important.

title: HOSPITALS CAUTIONED ON EARLY DISCHARGES
description: THE agency that monitors the care of Medicare beneficiaries in New Jersey is concerned about ''the possibility'' that patients are being sent home from hospitals too soon.

title: Satellite Rides Atlas Rocket Into Preliminary Earth Orbit
description: An unmanned Atlas Centaur rocket streaked into space tonight, lighting up a cloudy sky on its way to deliver a $30 million communications satellite into preliminary orbit.

title: LAKELAND RESIDENTS PROTEST 'DOUBLE TAXATION'
description: TAXPAYERS in the Lakeland Central School District last week became the first citizens group in the county to hold a public meeting opposing the proposed elimination of state and local tax deductability, An estimated 150 area residents, expressing concern about ''double taxation'' in one of the county's least wealthy school districts, gathered at Lakeland Senior High School in Shrub Oak to listen to a panel of economists, educators and politicians.

title: PAPERBACKS IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: INDIA: The Siege Within. By M. J. Akbar. (Penguin, $5.95.) Given its deep divisions, the Indian subcontinent is remarkable not for the separation of Pakistan and Bangladesh but for the fact that the fragmented states of India still hang together.

title: Indictments For 9 Klansmen
description: The Ku Klux Klan has fallen on hard times in recent years, but now and then there are flashes of the particularly virulent violence that has long been its specialty. The Department of Justice announced last week that nine members of the Klan had been indicted in North Carolina on conspiracy charges for their roles in a series of cross burnings and shootings.

title: PISANI REFLECTS ON HIS CHANGED LIFE
description: LOOKING back, Joseph R. Pisani, window salesman, said he harbored ''certain disappointments'' about the legal difficulties that changed his status from Joseph R. Pisani, State Senator, ''but I have no regrets.''

title: CRYSTAL BALLS AND STRIKES
description: Without question, the Los Angeles Dodgers would win the National League championship series in 1983 and move on to the World Series for the fourth time in seven years. The Dodgers, after all, were playing Philadelphia, and hadn't they destroyed the Phillies during the regular season by winning 11 of the 12 games the teams played?

title: KING OF THE NEW CANADA
description: ONE DAY LAST MARCH, AT BARRY T's ROAD-house out there on sleazy 104th Street - wedged between welding shops and cinder-block strip joints and used-car lots - Edmonton's amiable sportswriting fraternity was gathered for its annual awards luncheon. The writers were going to present Wayne Gretzky with their Sports Professional of the Year award again.

title: Ex-C.I.A. Clerk Admits Guilt in a Spy Case
description: A former employee of the Central Intelligence Agency in Ghana has pleaded guilty to a charge of disclosing classified information in a plea-bargaining arrangement in which the Government dropped 15 other espionage-related charges against her.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: THE VALUE OF M-1
description: To the Editor:

title: LANGE SEEMS DELIGHTED TO BE IN THE CENTER OF THINGS
description: THEIR friends and neighbors the Australians like to say that New Zealanders are very balanced people - they have a chip on both shoulders.

title: PAPERBACKS IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE BEST AMERICAN SHORT STORIES 1985. Edited by Gail Godwin with Shannon Ravenel. (Houghton Mifflin, Paper, $8.95. Cloth, $14.95.) Novels have ample time and means to seduce the reader; short stories, however, must bewitch at first glance, thus accounting for their varied effect on readers.

title: 3 BOOKS THAT CAN HELP YOU CONTROL YOUR FINANCES
description: NOT the athletic type? Your tennis game consists mainly of running back to retrieve the balls you couldn't return, and golf is but a succession of sand traps? Not to worry. No reason to play these games if they cause more frustration than pleasure.

title: JAPAN RESEARCH
description: To the Editor:

title: 'SMITHTOWN IS DYING'
description: IN 1958, Main Street, Smithtown, had meat markets, an A. & P. where many senior citizens shopped, a Bohack's supermarket near a Howard Johnson's restaurant, and a 5-and-10-cent store -Woolworth's - where browsing for bargains was authentic bargain hunting.

title: The Pont Neuf Wrapup
description: For Christo, the artist who has ''wrapped'' the coast of Australia and 11 islands in Florida's Biscayne Bay, draping one bridge might not seem like much of a challenge.

title: MIAMI WINS, 45-10, AT BOSTON COLLEGE
description: Miami erupted for first-half touchdowns today on a 100-yard interception return by Selwyn Brown and an 82-yard pass play from Vinny Testaverde to Brian Blades and routed Boston College, 45-10, Saturday.

title: POP MUSIC HAITIAN STYLES
description: WEDNESDAY and Thursday, Sounds of Brazil (204 Varick Street) offered a lesson in the evolution of Haitian pop. Coupe-Cloue, who has led a band since 1957, played guitar-centered Haitian pop on Wednesday, while the Magnum Band, a younger group, played a more modern Haitian style on Thursday.

title: MAJOR U.S. NARCOTICS TRIAL INVOLVING THE MAFIA GO OPEN AT FOLEY SQ.
description: A major narcotics trial involving the Mafia is set to start tomorrow, beginning a hectic period of important organized-crime cases at the Federal courthouse in lower Manhattan.

title: Building Homes For the Homeless
description: New York City took significant strides last week toward one long-term solution to homelessness: city officials selected 24 nonprofit groups to create permanent and temporary housing for about 2,000 homeless New Yorkers. The community groups will buy vacant city-owned buildings for $1 each and rehabilitate them, using city grants or low-interest loans.

title: ARTIST WINS IN FINGER RULING
description: An artist who contended that part of his finger was bitten off by his landlord in a dispute over a late rent payment was awarded $6,600 in damages. The landlord, Frank Gallo, testified in County Court that the artist, David Merrill, 32 years old, had deliberately stuck his fingers in Mr. Gallo's mouth to hurt him. Mr. Gallo said he bit down on the finger to restrain Mr. Merrill. Mr. Merrill testified that the injury hampered his ability to do detailed artwork.

title: THE SPIRIT OF '85
description: As I write this, a distinguished professor of Victorian literature is conducting his classes with a black eye. The dashing scar that runs above the upper lip of his colleague, an equally distinguished professor (of Renaissance literature), is healing nicely. These hypercivilized men, both in their 50's, received their wounds not in a barroom or during a demonstration against apartheid but on another field of honor, the squash court.

title: MOSLEMS IN REVOLT
description: WOMEN AND THE FAMILY IN THE MIDDLE EAST New Voices of Change. Edited by Elizabeth Warnock Fernea. 356 pp. Austin: The University of Texas Press. Cloth, $24.50. Paper, $11.95. ON the door of an inn in chalk was drawn a woman's face.

title: LOWER RATES WIOLL KICK OFF A BOOM
description: ALTHOUGH the precise timing is uncertain, a very powerful economic boom is likely to begin during the second half of 1985. Real gross national product should increase at an annual rate of between 6 percent and 8 percent over the next four to five quarters - nearly triple the consensus forecast.

title: Susan L. Ziebarth Wed to Executive
description: Susan Leslie Ziebarth, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack A. Ziebarth of Basking Ridge, N.J., and Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday to Lee Augustus Delaporte 3d, a son of Mrs. Delaporte Jr. and the late Mr. Delaporte of Madison, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Calvin Jackson performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church of Basking Ridge. He was assisted by Msgr.

title: Diane Healey Marries James Linen 4th
description: Diane B. Healey, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mike Blumenthal of Sharon, Mass., and Imperial Point, Fla., was married yesterday to James A. Linen 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Linen 3d of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. John Bishop performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich.

title: Joanne Mikulich Weds R. A. de Guardiola Jr.
description: The marriage of Joanne Mikulich, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Mikulich of Sherman, Conn., to Robert Alexander de Guardiola Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. de Guardiola of Palm Beach, Fla., took place yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Thomas Bowers pereformed the ceremony.

title: LASERS AND LISTENING CREATE SPEAKERS FOR SMALL HOMES
description: I never had a chance to kibitz in Escoffier's kitchen, but I don't believe he ever just followed a recipe - not even his own. I have a hunch he'd fine-tune each dish, trusting his tongue and nose.

title: KOCH AND GOTBAUM DEBATE RULING ON WAGES
description: Mayor Koch and the labor leader Victor Gotbaum, who usually battle at the bargaining table in New York City, came to Washington last week to argue opposite sides in a debate over whether public employees should be covered by Federal wage and hour laws.

title: EVENTS AND PHOBIAS
description: SOVIETICUS American Perceptions and Soviet Realities. By Stephen F. Cohen. 160 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $12.95.

title: AFFIRMATIVE ACTIONS MIXED MEDIA
description: Though there turned out to be little in the way of serious storm news Friday, viewers following the course of Hurricane Gloria on television did manage to learn something about seniority.

title: AGING OF AMERICA: NOT QUITE SO FAST
description: To the Editor:

title: TURMOIL IN THE RACKS: THE SECOND PAPERBACK REVOLUTION
description: WHEN, almost 50 years ago, an innovative publishing house reissued 10 popular American novels in soft covers, the experiment revolutionized the audience for books in the United States. Today, when a majority of all books sold in the United States are in soft covers, a second paperback revolution is under way. This time, however, it is being led by demanding readers and price-conscious booksellers, while publishers scramble to keep up with all the changes.

title: THE SENSUAL PHILOSOPHER
description: MR. PALOMAR By Italo Calvino. Translated by William Weaver. 130 pp. New York: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $12.95.

title: IT WASN'T EXACTLY THE FORECAST OF THE CENTURY
description: WITH their satellites, radar and computers, meteorologists have become adept at tracking hurricanes. Predicting their course and intensity, however, is another matter.

title: FINANCIAL PLANNING IS REALLY MANAGEMENT BY OBJECTIVE
description: ANY time you have more money on hand than bills to pay, experts say, you have participated in financial planning. Today, however, financial planning is so widely used, it has engendered a profession of specialists known as financial planners.

title: FINDING WISCONSIN'S OLD-STYLE CHEESES
description: ''To Make an Excellent Winter Cheese,'' advises ''Martha Washington's Booke of Cookery'' of 1749, for ''2 gallons of new milke, take 10 quarts of stroakings & 2 quarts of cream, put to it 4 spoonfuls of rennit, set it together as hot as you came from ye Cow.''

title: FOSTER HITS 20TH HOMER
description: After the Mets lost to Pittsburgh Friday night, Wally Backman remarked that ''they haven't buried us yet, but we are in the coffin.'' The Mets, their pitching arms pushing mightily against the lid, defeated the Pirates, 3-1, today and prompted Backman to say, ''We just opened the coffin right up. They can't put us in yet. This gave us life. A loss today would have put us in the ground.''

title: A Clearance Challenge
description: Lester Crown, the biggest shareholder and an influential board member of the General Dynamics Corporation, may lose his membership in an increasingly exclusive club: the holders of top-secret security clearances. The Pentagon, which has been tightening security lately, said last week that it would try to revoke Mr. Crown's access to classified information because of his involvement in a 1972 bribery case.

title: SCIENCE IN THE STYLE OF ENGELS
description: THE DIALECTICAL BIOLOGIST By Richard Levins and Richard Lewontin. 303 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $20.

title: CREWS WORK OVERTIME TO RESTORE POWER
description: The aftermath of Hurricane Gloria was wearing heavily yesterday on the face of Frank Tomlins, a lineman for Northeast Utilities in Connecticut. His cheeks were covered with stubble, and his eyes had the weariness of a man who had worked 22 of the last 24 hours.

title: PAPERBACKS IN SHORT: NONDICTION
description: NO EVIL STAR: Selected Essays, Interviews, and Prose. By Anne Sexton. Edited by Steven E. Colburn. (University of Michigan, $8.95.) ''I tell so much truth in my poetry that I'm a fool if I say more,'' Anne Sexton warns Patricia Marx in an interview included in ''No Evil Star.''

title: Article 041353 -- No Title
description: The State Department has proposed a five-year, $5.5 billion program to overhaul security at its embassies and to counter Soviet-bloc espionage overseas, department officials said today.

title: SHRINKING REAL OF SOLITUDE AT SEA
description: Last summer I sailed my humble family boat into Portofino, on the Tuscan coast of Italy, and met a kind and charming American called Bob. He lived there in a small catamaran and had appointed himself unofficial harbormaster.

title: O'NEILL BACKS $18,500 BASE FOR TEACHERS
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill has promised to ask the 1986 General Assembly to approve a minimum starting salary of slightly over $19,000 for teachers and to have the state pay half of all local education costs.

title: HEAVY BREATHING IN ARCADIA
description: WHAT about Aristotle's wife? What sort of literature gave her the most pleasing catharsis? More than likely, it was a genre not even mentioned in her husband's ''Poetics'' - the romantic novel.

title: IS THE ARTIFICIAL HEART BAD FOR THE BRAIN?
description: Medical researchers often encounter surprises when they experiment on humans, even though hundreds of animals have been subjeced to the same tests. In the case of the artificial heart, the surprise has been the frequency of strokes, either from blood clots that have developed in the device or from bleeding caused by anticoagulation therapy designed to prevent the clots. In any event, four of the six humans who have received Jarvik-7 artificial heart implants have suffered strokes, an injury to the brain caused by the impaired flow of blood.

title: YALE GAME IS CANCELED
description: The football game between Yale and the University of Connecticut, which had been postponed from yesterday to today in the wake of Hurricane Gloria, was called off altogether last night because of continuing hazardous conditions in and around the Yale Bowl in New Haven. Yale officials said they had made the move after the Mayor of New Haven, Biagio DiLeto, citing safety considerations, asked for the cancellation.

title: SHOPPING FOR A MORTGAGE
description: GREGORY P. HICKEY, a 35-year-old tax partner with Price Waterhouse, in Los Angeles, went mortgage shopping a few months ago to finance the $350,000 home he wanted to buy in the Hancock Park section of Los Angeles.

title: GURU'S FORMER AIDE DENIES SHE TRIED TO KILL HIME
description: Ma Anand Sheela, former top aide to the leader of an Oregon commune, has denied his accusations that she tried to kill him and his doctor, according to Stern magazine.

title: PATRICK EWING AND THE ART OF DEFENSE
description: IT'S HOT, REALLY HOT, ON THE CONCRETE STEPS OUT-side archaic McDonough Arena at Georgetown University on this bright July day. The weatherman said the temperature would reach 88 and the humidity a sticky 77 percent. He was right. You don't have to see the sweat cascading down the face, shoulders and legs of Patrick Ewing to know that it's even worse inside. The soon-to-be Knick center, the No. 1 pick in this year's National Basketball Association college draft, is in a hotly contested game of two-on-two with three other former members of the Hoya basketball team.

title: BAY STATE STARTING FIGHT ON DRUGS IN THE SCHOOLS
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis is planning an aggressive public education campaign against what surveys show is a substantial presence of drugs in Massachusetts classrooms.

title: MAKING WAVES IN THE GENE POOL
description: RECOMBINATIONS By Perri Klass. 283 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95.

title: Arab Boy in West Bank Town Is Killed by a Hand Grenade
description: A 13-year-old Arab boy was killed by a hand grenade in the West Bank town of Hebron this afternoon.

title: L.I. CONCERNS FACE FINES ON POLLUTION
description: LONG ISLAND companies will face increasing pressure in coming months to comply with Federal air pollution standards adopted nearly a decade ago.

title: A BRIDGE INTO NORTH SALEM'S PAST
description: IT is only a small one-lane, keystone bridge off Route 116 here, one that probably goes unnoticed by the majority of motorists. To many of the town's 4,654 residents, however, the Keeler Lane Bridge does more than cross the Titicus River: it spans generations of a family that has long been a keystone of this close-knit community.

title: MAKING INVESTMENT CHOICES IN THE FACE OF THE DEFICIT
description: INFLATION has fallen two-thirds from its level of five years ago, and financial assets are back in style. It's happy days again for stocks and bonds and bye-bye to gold bars and other physical assets.

title: NORTHERN TOWNS WEIGH PROPOSALS TO BUILD THREE HOTELS
description: THE bucolic towns of North Salem and Lewisboro, which have no police departments, no town water supply or sewer systems, no apparent enthusiasm for growth, and more acres than residents, are faced with the prospect of three large new hotels within a five-mile strip along Route I-684.

title: ARMY ROUTS PENN TO STAY UNBEATEN
description: A fleet-footed Army infantry today ran over, around and through Pennsylvania for 449 yards on the way to routing the Quakers, 41-3, before 23,765 at Franklin Field.

title: EMELIN EXPLORES A RESIDENT TROUPE
description: THE Emelin Theater in Mamaroneck, which begins its 14th season on Friday, has become known as a showplace for music and dance of all styles, for children's shows, for lecture series - and for an occasional play. But such theatrical luminaries as Claire Bloom and Uta Hagen have graced its stage, starring in single-night stopovers of touring shows, and there is new hope that the theatrical offerings may be strengthened.

title: PAPERBACKS IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ELSEWHERE. By Jonathan Strong. (Available Press, $4.95.) This harsh, uncompromising novel is set in the outskirts of a nameless city where children are marked early for disaster.

title: RUNNING FOR PUBLIC OFFICE AND PRIVATE PROFIT
description: New York has long been known for its political big spenders - Mayor Koch's re-election campaign this year will cost more than $6 million - but there are plenty of big savers, too. Many public officials in the city, like those elsewhere, raise money almost continuously, even in nonelection years, and thus sit on campaign treasuries that might make Chase Manhattan proud.

title: THE CHALLENGE OF THE 'IRREGULARS'
description: To the Editor:

title: OUSTER OF ARTISTIC DIRECTOR DIVIDES THE CURTIS INSTITUTE OF MUSIC
description: The bright red banner with the Curtis Institute of Music logo still furls proudly over the door of the imposing old mansion, and students carrying instrument cases still trudge across the gracious quiet of Rittenhouse Square on their way to one of the nation's leading conservatories of music. As a clock tolls 3 P.M. in the square, the students are gathering in the grand central hall of the institute, where A. Margaret Bok, chairman of the Curtis board, is pouring tea from a lace-covered table.

title: ONE-WAY DOGMATISM
description: The Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, which frames the entrance to New York Harbor, is a wonder - the world's longest suspended span. To some neighbors, it's also a nuisance, a polluter.

title: GUNMAN IN CYPRUS SAID TO BE BRITON
description: One of three gunmen who killed three Israelis aboard a yacht off Cyprus Wednesday was identified today as a Briton.

title: Melissa Hoefer to Wed William Lester Branch
description: Melissa Hoefer and William Lester Branch plan to be married Oct. 26. The future bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Burns Hoefer of Bronxville, N.Y., and Charlestown, R.I., who have announced her engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel F. Branch of Nashville.

title: LEBANESE MILITIA ATTACKS MOSLEM RIVALS IN TRIPOLI
description: Thousands of Syrian-backed militiamen using Soviet-built tanks, field artillery and Katyusha rockets attacked the northern port city of Tripoli today in an effort to capture it from Moslem fundamentalists.

title: FOES OF REGIME FREED
description: The Liberian leader, Gen. Samuel K. Doe, has dismissed his Labor Minister and ordered the release of several Government opponents, the authorities and press reports said Friday.

title: Acid Leak in Massachusetts Forces Closing of Highway
description: Acid leaked from a tank at a plastics plant today, releasing fumes that forced the closing of 10 miles of an interstate highway near Springfield.

title: THE CHANGING WORLD OF NEW YORK INTELLECTUALS
description: For all of James Atlas's concern with the Jewishness of the New York intellectuals of the period in question, he doesn't trouble to examine any of the multitude of reasons - including increasingly evident Soviet anti-Semitism, the success of Zionism and American-Jewish support of Israel's territorial intransigence and military expansionism - that drove American Jews away from the intellectual left in such large numbers. All he does is lump together rightward-turning Jews, along with other intellectuals, as middle-class opportunists, uneager to forsake creature comforts for ''a cold-water flat.'' WILLIAM A. FAHEY Northport, L.I.

title: ORCHESTRAS SCHEDULE A BUSY SEASON
description: TODAY marks the 20th anniversary of the National Endowment for the Arts and the last day of New Jersey Arts Appreciation Week, an appropriate time to note the variety and scope of arts groups in the state.

title: Liza Gennaro, a Dancer, Weds Scott Alan Evans
description: Liza Gennaro, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Gennaro of New York and Oxford, Conn., was married in New York yesterday to Scott Alan Evans, a son of William R. Evans Jr. of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Mrs. Eliot Yehle Marshall of Philadelphia.

title:
DANCE VIEW;

CUNNINGHAM EXPLAINS HOW HE CREATES HIS WORKS
description: The music-television channel MTV may have promoted the idea of spliced-in, cut-up, dissociated imagery to rock music fans, but such ideas are nothing new to anyone who has followed Merce Cunningham's prophetic view of discontinuity-as-continuity in his choreography.

title: SON OF MAD COMICS
description: NUTS!

title: Oil Spreads in Pennsylvania
description: An oily substance apparently originating from a toxic waste dump spread a 60-mile slick over the Susquehanna River today, threatening the water supply for thousands of people, officials said. Heavy rain that accompanied Hurricane Gloria on Friday probably caused the spill from a drainage site of the Butler Mine, said Larry Pawlush, a water quality officer with the Department of Environmental Resources. Wastes, some toxic, were illegally dumped at the site in the 1970's, he said.

title:
ART;

TWO GROUP SHOWS THAT STAND OUT ON THE EAST END
description: EVEN though the ''season'' in the Hamptons ended on the Labor Day weekend, cultural activities continue after the departure of the tourists and summer tenants. More and more in recent years, the East End galleries have been able to maintain a lively schedule of exhibitions throughout the fall and into the holiday season.

title: GULDA REASSERTS HIS CLAIMS TO FAME
description: Friedrich Gulda has refused to succumb to the increasing specialization of our age, refused to limit his horizons to one small portion of the musical spectrum. A prodigious talent, whom Harold Schonberg once hailed in The New York Times as ''a continuation of the great German traditions of piano playing exemplified by Schnabel and Backhaus,'' he chose to reject the cloistered life of a virtuoso in favor of a career that paid equal attention to jazz and classical music, to performance, composition and improvisation.

title: HOBOKEN OFFERS A PLAN TO CURB DEVELOPMENT
description: Hoboken's new administration has drafted a proposal aimed at slowing rapid development that is driving up rents and driving out longtime residents, officials said.

title: Lorraine Pratte and Jacob Lewis Wed
description: Lorraine Barbara Pratte, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Pratte of Worthington, Ohio, and Jacob Matthew Lewis, a son of Rachel Benet Lewis of Watertown, Mass., and Peter A. Lewis of New York, were married yesterday. Judge Rufus King 3d of the District of Columbia Superior Court performed the ceremony at the Sheraton Grand Hotel in Washington.

title: HARVARD SETS BACK MASSACHUSETTS, 10-3
description: Brian White hit Terry Denson on a 60-yard scoring pass, and Rob Steinberg kicked a 43-yard field goal after a fumble recovery late in the first half today, rallying Harvard to a 10-3 victory over Massachusetts.

title: BLACKS AND JEWS CONFRONT DISAGREEMENTS
description: AS Jews celebrated the High Holy Days, the 10-day period of self-evaluation and introspection that ended last Wednesday with Yom Kippur, members of Westchester's black and Jewish communities joined last Sunday to explore and examine their faults and prejudices, resolving to do more to improve their relationship.

title: A Step Closer to Gene Transplants
description: Only a few years ago, even some pioneers in gene transplantation warned that it was too early to use the controversial treatment on human patients. All of the very few attempts to do so, performed without Federal approval, had failed.

title: THE OTHER TAX PLAN IS UNVEILED AT LAST
description: Dan Rostenkowski countered President Reagan's tax proposal with one that would be more favorable to low- and middle-income taxpayers. The long-awaited proposal from Mr. Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means panel, followed the outline of the President's proposal, but included a higher corporate tax rate and permits partial deduction of state and local taxes where the President would allow none. Mr. Rostenkowski's plan was called more realistic than the President's by several legislators, but many say it will face some of the same hurdles.

title: PLAYING AIR GUITAR
description: Adam Liptak's article struck a familiar note. For many years, I sang air soprano for the Metropolitan Opera Saturday broadcasts.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: THE FAIR COUNTRY If you've got it, why not flaunt it? And since Suffolk is still one of the major agricultural counties in the state, the local Cooperative Extension Association is only too anxious to show what area farmers have produced. So today from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M., when the Riverhed campus of Suffolk County Community College hosts the Third Annual Long Island Fall Harvest Festival, the emphasis will naturally be on that harvest. True, there will be entertainment provided by such groups as the St. Maximillian Kolbe Dancers and the Pep Boys country and western music ensemble, and children's games and activities. But the food displays and demonstrations, an ''Old Time Produce Auction'' and animal displays will dominate the scene. The campus is on Route 51 and admission is $1.

title: FROM YOUNG ARTISTS, DEFIANCE BEHIND A SMILING FACADE
description: Anyone making the rounds of New York galleries in the last two years is likely to have noticed the emergence of something that can be loosely described as a mid-1980's style. It is identified with the East Village. The subject matter it serves is drawn from middle-class life and popular culture. It is characterized by lush, thickly encrusted surfaces and smiling, youthful faces, many of them as sweet and mindless as the faces in soap operas and comic strips. The style is accessible, seductive and hedonistic. Its appearance has generated considerable confusion. Pleasure and fun have never before been an integral part of American art. While American modernists made art that barely even paid lip service to the great American need to be liked, a young East Village artist like Rodney Alan Greenblat not only wants his work to be liked but is brazenly undefensive about it. While modernism remained generally uneasy about relations with commerce and power, for many younger artists in the East Village and SoHo the taboo against careerism has all but disappeared.

title: FOLLOWING HITLER
description: THE DEATH OF MY BROTHER ABEL By Gregor von Rezzori. Translated by Joachim Neugroschel. 632 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/ Viking. $19.95.

title: ESSENDON RETIANS TITLE
description: Essendon won its second consecutive Victorian Football League Australian Rules Football Grand Final, defeating Hawthorn, 170 to 92, today at the Melbourne Cricket Ground.

title: Duke University Inaugurates H. Keith Brodie as President
description: Dr. H. Keith Brodie was inaugurated today as the seventh president of Duke University.

title: CABLE TV
description: The cable movie week has variety -comedy, thrillers, opera, family fare, some antique pearls and two premieres of last-year's hits. These are ''All of Me,'' a bright caper with Lily Tomlin and Steve Martin (voted best actor by the N.Y. Film Critics) and ''Country,'' a fervent drama of struggling Iowa farmers with Jessica Lange and Sam Shepard.

title: THE PARKING LOT: LIFE IN THE SLOW LANE
description: I'M parked alone in my car, waiting for my wife to return with her shopping cart, overburdened with our weekly cargo of groceries. It is a windy, rain-slicked day in the parking field at the shopping plaza just off Route 109.
