Empty four-wheeled shopping carts go sailing by, tacking smartly downwind as though guided by ghostly hands.

title: FINDING THE RIGHT CAR DEAL
description: BUYING an automobile can be enormously complicated. Not only is it the second largest purchase most people make (after a house), but there is usually financing to arrange, a used car to dispose of and insurance and options to consider.

title: AFOOT ON THE YORKSHIRE MOORS
description: Across the length and breadth of Britain, driving's out and walking's in.

title: COACH SHOULD SHOW FAITH
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
ANTIQUES;

FOCUS ON QUALITY IN HARTFORD SHOW
description: FOR probably all but the most knowledgeable browsers at antique shows, there is often uncertainty over whether a coveted item, costing hundreds or thousands of dollars, is authentic. And when a show displays American, European and Asian objects from a long period of time, a buyer may well feel overwhelmed by a lack of knowledge needed to make an intelligent purchase.

title: MISPLACED CREDIT
description: To the Editor:

title: ENTREPRENEURS GET ADVICE
description: SOME came to seek advice -and, possibly, cash. Some came to scout for clients.

title: CHARTING A DIFFERENT KIND OF OUPUT
description: PLOTTERS are peripherals unknown to most personal computer users. While tens of millions of printers have been sold since microcomputers started invading the business world, only several hundred thousand plotters - essentially printers for presenting pictorial data - have made their way off the manufacturers' shipping docks. Yet, as overlooked as they might be, plotters have a very definite place in the world of personal computing.

title: FINANCING FOR MAJOR OUTLAYS
description: THERE are seers who argue that it is not so smart to buy a house anymore. It will not appreciate at the rate it once did. It may be hard to sell when the time comes. It is not the investment it once was. But people go on buying houses. In Sheboygan, Wis., Daniel Schmidt bought his first house last June. Mr. Schmidt, a 21-year-old maintenance mechanic for a chair company, who can ''handle anything,'' had no idea of buying until a broker persuaded him to start looking. He looked at 40 houses, and finally paid $30,000 for a two-family house near a park. He offsets the $419 monthly cost of mortgage debt, taxes and insurance with rental income from a tenant and payments from roommates, who live with him.

title: DAVID HARE: PLAYWRIGHT AS PROVOCATEUR
description: FOR A PLAYWRIGHT, that moment of artistic self-identification can come with his first produced play, or, perhaps, with an early neophyte effort. In the case of David Hare, the turning point occurred with his third full-length play, ''Knuckle,'' an oddly convoluted mystery that deals with various forms of corruption. The circumstances of the play are characteristic of the author's unorthodox career. After finishing the play, he showed it to his agent, who rejected it. The author then gave it to another agent, who loved it. ''Knuckle'' was optioned by a major commercial producer and presented on London's West End in a 1974 production starring Edward Fox and a new Canadian actress named Kate Nelligan.

title: Concert Money to Aid Farmers in 17 States
description: The first $100,000 raised by the recent Farm Aid concert will be distributed to 12 organizations to feed hungry farm families in 17 states from Florida to Wyoming, officials have announced.

title: NUTLEY WINS, 32-0
description: Joe Verga ran for two touchdowns and passed for two more to lead Nutley to a 32-0 victory over Teaneck in the first game of the season for each team yesterday in Nutley.

title: 'ONE MO' TIME' DONE TO A TURN
description: ''HOLD on to your chairs,''

title: Medicare-Fee Situation: A Doctor's Evaluation
description: The article, ''More Doctors Join Limited-Fee Plan'' [Sept. 1] , is misleading and contains both error-in-fact and opinions masquerading as facts.

title: AN INSECTICIDE STIRS ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERN ON THE EAST END
description: SEVERAL towns on the East End are considering efforts to prevent the use of the powerful insecticide Abate within their borders.

title: SEPTEMBER BEGINS THE YEAR FOR SOME
description: THE new year begins, for me, in September, never in January. It always has, and it always will. For years it was the beginning of the school year; it still is for me and my younger children. When you are in it, school is, after all, Life. I loved the fuss and bother of getting my children ready to start.

title: WHICH WAY TO HELP POOR KIDS? NEITHER.
description: Are schools lowering academic standards to ease the way for minority students? William Bradford Reynolds, the Reagan Administration's civil rights chief, thinks so and regards that as an ''offensive'' form of discrimination. He's certainly right, if that's what schools are doing. But what's even more offensive is the Administration's perverse policy. Even as it professes concern for the academic performance of minority students, it has continually sought to cut Federal aid for programs to help them.

title: EARNING POWER: A RANDOM SAMPLING OF PAY FOR PLAY
description: FRANK GANDY: No. 1, Professional Archery Association, $13,000

title:
ART;

JERSEY CITY: WATERCOLOR AND PHOTOGRAPHS
description: The early 20th-century American master John Marin (1870-1953) is usually remembered for his dynamic studies of Manhattan and Maine.

title: THE CHANGING WORLD OF NEW YORK INTELLECTUALS
description: In his article on New York's intellectuals, James Atlas quotes me as saying that it was a tradition among New York intellectuals to marry money.

title: HAZARDS OF INDOOR POLLUTANTS BEING EXAMINED
description: AFTER new carpeting was installed last summer in the offices of Dr. Jan A. J. Stolwijk, chairman of the Department of Epidemiology and Public Health at Yale Medical School, members of his staff complained for several weeks of tearing eyes, headaches and irritated throats.

title: Route 110 And New Hotels
description: The article ''For New Hotels, Roadblocks on Route 110'' [Sept. 15] seemed to omit the basis for community resistance to the Marriott hotel project on 15 acres of the 130-acre McGovern sod farm at the intersection of Pinelawn Road and the Long Island Expressway service road.

title: THE MYTH OF THE TAMED BUSINESS CYCLE
description: MOST economic theory since World War II has been profoundly influenced by the work of John Maynard Keynes, and is based on the idea that government fiscal and monetary policies can alter the course of the economy, assuring longer expansions and shorter recessions. To prove the point, economists point to historical charts of the gross national product, showing that the economy has been much less volatile since 1945.

title: A.N. Williams 3d And Miss Randall Exchange Vows
description: Mari-Alice Randall, the daughter of Bettie Randall Reilly of Washington and George S. Randall of Detroit, was married in Washington yesterday to Avon Nyanza Williams 3d, the son of State Senator and Mrs. Williams Jr. of Nashville. The Rev. James Holmes performed the ceremomy at St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square.

title: BREAD PUDDING IN COMEBACK
description: TAKE some stale bread and what do you have? A dressing for a chicken or turkey, some crumbs with which to coat veal cutlets, French toast for breakfast, homemade Melba toast for canapes or, best of all, a handsome dessert. Bread puddings, essentially homely creations that make use of leftovers are enjoying a new surge of popularity.

title: GROUPS WIDEN USE OF PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: Leaders of community groups say they are greatly increasing their afternoon programs held in New York City public schools in response to a new custodial contract that all but ends fees for the after-school use of classrooms, gymnasiums and other buildings.

title: PAIN RELIEF
description: To the Editor:

title: ANTICIPATING THE NEEDS OF OLD AGE
description: IN generations gone by, aging parents commonly lived with children or, when poor health made that option impractical, in nursing homes whose expense was largely borne through a combination of the patient's savings and retirement income and whatever contributions the children could muster.

title:
MUSIC VIEW;

HOW FAR CAN YOU STRETCH AN OPERA LIBRETTO?
description: In the age-old argument over the comparative importance of words and music in opera, the word has been losing out badly of late. After decades, perhaps centuries, when the composer's actual notes were treated rather cavalierly, musicians now regard them with respect, if not reverence. However, librettos and the stage directions that are the ligaments and sinews of any drama have come to be treated as mere jumping-off places, as springboards to whatever dramatic notions strike a director's fancy. Can such a schizophrenic attitude ever make sense? Perhaps, but only rarely and only if the integrity of the work can be maintained.

title: RUMANIAN REBUTS CRITICISM IN U.S. CONGRESS
description: Rumania is ready to forsake favored tariff treatment from the United States if Congressional critics continue to press for greater rights for the nation's Hungarian minority, an official said in a recent interview.

title: CRIME
description: Ruth Dudley Edwards seems to have staked out an area for herself - the British Civil Service. Three years ago in her only previous mystery story, ''Corridors of Death,'' she dealt with the unlovely ins and outs of the bureaucracy - the backbiting, the pettiness, the jealousies, the misplaced ambitions. In THE SAINT VALENTINE'S DAY MURDERS (St. Martin's, $12.95), she takes another look at the system.

title: IN ATLANTIC CITY, STORM'S TOLL WAS CASINO PROFITS
description: Hurricane Gloria caused no loss of life and little property damage here Friday, but it will go into the record books as causing the first citywide closing of the casinos since the first gambling hall opened in 1978.

title: AND NOW FOR AN OLD ITALIAN 'DYNASTY'
description: It is almost enough to make a story editor for ''Dynasty'' blush - or at least take notes. But the venality, the greed, the cruelty, the intrigue, the betrayal, the vindictiveness and the brute ambition that weave through ''The Borgias,'' a 10-part series that gets underway Wednesday evening at 9 on Arts and Entertainment, are largely based on historical record.

title: CONCERN VOICED ON SHRINKING CALIFORNIA LAKE
description: The license plate on a little pickup truck spells out the issue:''H204MNO.''

title: JAPAN
description: To the Editor:

title: TOO MUCH OFFENSE CREATES WEAKNESSES
description: Currently, an overall tendency to strike back rather than to be contented with defense prevails to the point where it is overdone. Games are being lost because of the reluctance to defend.

title: 13 Charged With Looting
description: Thirteen people were arrested in New Haven late Friday and early Saturday for breaking into businesses in areas where burglar alarms were not functioning as a result of storm-related power failures, the police said. Special police patrols, some with dogs, were assigned to those areas yesterday. Those arrested were charged with burglary, larceny and attempted larceny.

title: POLITICS
description: GOVERNOR KEAN said recently that he and the Democratic-controlled Legislature could share the blame or the credit if they failed or succeeded in enacting a plan to finance an environmental-improvement program, Last week, after the Governor signed the required financing bills, the administration and the Legislature wasted no time in taking the credit.

title: NOVELISTS AND THEIR PASSIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: A SAINT IN HIS OWN DAYS
description: GOD'S FOOL The Life and Times of Francis of Assisi. By Julien Green. Translated by Peter Heinegg. 273 pp. San Francisco: Harper & Row. $16.95.

title: GETTING THE LAY OF THE LAND -- FROM THE AIR
description: ''You can't see anything from 30,00 feet. Get an aisle seat, order a drink, lean back and go to sleep.'' So goes the refrain that denies to countless air travelers what, on a transcontinental flight, can be an exciting visual experience.

title: DANCE
description: This season, an unusual number of groups from other countries will dance here. Among the most important is Tanztheater Wuppertal, Pina Bausch's company from Germany, which begins a two-week season Tuesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Max L. Koeppel, 86, Investor And Brooklyn Orchestra Aide
description: Max L. Koeppel, former president of the Brooklyn Philharmonic Orchestra and founder of a real-estate investment concern, died Tuesday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Kings Point, L.I.

title: F.A.A. Levies A Record Fine
description: After a three-month audit of maintenance procedures, the Federal Aviation Administration fined American Airlines $1.5 million last week for violating aircraft safety and inspection regulations.

title: Kean Wins Challenge Of Campaign Ad Law
description: The State Supreme Court has unanimously struck down a campaign-spending law that was challenged by Governor Kean as a violation of free speech.

title: DETOH IS SLUGGISH IN TAKING COWDIN
description: Ketoh scored a 2 1/2-length victory as the 3-to-5 favorite in the $174,800 Cowdin Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday, but the undefeated 2-year-old was not as impressive as he had looked winning his debut two weeks ago.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

BUS SAFETY
description: Because of a transmission error, an item in last Sunday's Westchester Journal gave incorrectly the name of the director of a bus-safety program conducted by the Putnam/Northern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services. He is Noel Kaiser.

title: BEING AUSTRALIA
description: AUSTRALIA ALWAYS SEEMED SO FAR away and perhaps not so important. Suddenly, there was Secretary of State George P. Shultz flying off to Canberra, the Australian capital, to listen more carefully to what the folks down under had to say about global defense strategy. At parties in Manhattan, the learned were talking about great Australian films and applauding the Aussies' delightful bravado in snatching the America's Cup from the stuffy New York Yacht Club. Business executives were going off eagerly to vibrant Sydney following the Labor Government's unexpected decision to open the Australian economy to foreign banks. At home, my kids were rattling around to Men at Work and other Australian rock groups.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: A COUPLE of years ago, Malcolm Muggeridge, the British writer and television personality, told William F. Buckley Jr. that he was almost always disillusioned when he met the people he admired most. But, he said, he would like to meet Pope John Paul II.

title: AMENDING THE CONSTITUTION BY DEFAULT
description: Few things are taken more seriously in America than changing the Constitution: Witness the years of debate over the Equal Rights Amendment, a right to life amendment and a balanced budget amendment. Yet we may be on the threshold of amending our basic charter without rewriting a single word - and with barely a word of debate on the pros and cons of the changes that await us.

title: MODEST GROWTH IS ALL WE CAN EXPECT
description: THE economy has been almost stagnant since the early summer of 1984, reflecting the adverse effects of both high real interest rates and the overvalued dollar. Although the sharp increase in the basic money supply (M-1) during the last 10 months is fueling hopes of renewed, vigorous economic growth, such a conclusion is almost certainly unwarranted. More likely, sustained strong growth will elude us this year and in 1986, with only a modest acceleration the best we can expect.

title: Audrey Shuman Is Bride
description: Audrey Shuman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Shuman of Purchase, N.Y., was married there last night to Bruce S. Nathanson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Nathanson of Cranbury, N.J. Rabbi Daniel Wolk and Cantor Ellen Math officiated at the Century Country Club. The bride is an account supervisor at Ogilvy & Mather, the New York advertising agency of which Mr. Nathanson is a vice president and account supervisor.

title: Wedding Planned For Miss Laccetti
description: Col. Joseph N. Laccetti, U.S.A.F. retired, and Mrs. Laccetti of Falls Church, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter Caroline Jeannette Laccetti to Thomas G. Reitz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William K. Reitz of Wantagh, L.I. A November wedding is planned.

title: OYSTER FESTIVAL IN PERIL IN NORWALK
description: IN recent years, Norwalk has often been overshadowed by nearby Stamford as that city became a corporate boom town while in Norwalk time seemed to stand still.

title: CONNOISSEURMANSHIP
description: To the Editor:

title: AFLOAT ON THE BOLOTOMY
description: THE PERSONAL HISTORY, ADVENTURES, EXPERIENCES & OBSERVATIONS OF PETER LEROY By Eric Kraft. Cambridge, Mass.: Apple-wood Books. Seven volumes. Paper, $4.95 each. This ''serial novel'' of seven short volumes (more are expected) is a real delight. Peter Leroy, the hero, is an intelligent, eager-to-please but otherwise unremarkable little boy growing up in Babbington, N.Y., a fictional town famous for its clams, during the 1950's. As an adult Peter recounts the little moral lessons that shaped his character. He freely admits to changing details and rearranging events, and this reinventing of the past is full of sly insights into the way writers create fiction.

title: PATERNITY LEAVE FOR MUNICIPAL WORKERS FOCUS OF COURT CASE
description: WHEN Timothy M. Hogan and his wife, Joan, were expecting their third child, he requested time off from the Hartford Police Department, where he serves as a lieutenant, to witness the birth and to help out at home.

title: STYLISH SUSHI IN EAST HAMPTON
description: THE latest information on Fresno Place in East Hampton is that the restaurant will remain open through the fall. The schedule has been somewhat curtailed already. It was closed on Tuesdays throughout the summer and now it is also closed on Wednesdays. It is a situation the owner is playing by ear, depending on business. It might even stay open during the winter.

title: A ROUSING START BUT A SHAKY FUTRURE
description: LAST Monday, Alfred G. Roth pulled out of the driveway of his suburban home at 2:30 A.M. and was behind his desk at Chemical Bank long before dawn. That day, as the bank's chief foreign exchange trader, he was in the thick of the action that drove down the dollar by a hefty 5 percent against other foreign currencies.

title: Playing Air Guitar
description: I thoroughly enjoyed Adam Liptak's article ''Playing Air Guitar'' (About Men, Sept. 1).

title: GREENPEACE AFFAIR: WATERGATE ON THE SEINE?
description: At the Institute of Political Science, one of the main avenues to a French career in diplomacy and government, students of comparative politics often study this question: Could Watergate happen in France?

title: 4 TOWNS RECYCLE LEAVES
description: FOUR Middlesex County towns have joined together to collect fallen leaves and return them to the earth.

title: CHARTING A COURSE: FOUR STORIES
description: FOR the past three years, James and Christine Robinson have been trying to make all the right investment moves. But the couple, who live and work in New York City and recently had their second child, have seen their plans thrown into the air by the Reagan Administration's tax proposals.

title: TAILORED FREEDOM
description: To the Editor:

title: INVESTORS TO SHARE TEASURE OF SPANISH SHIP
description: Jim Lindsey's garage needed a new roof and his kitchen stove should have been replaced, but the coal miner from Taylorville, Ill., put $1,000 of his savings into a treasure hunting expedition.

title:
GARDENING;

DON'T THROW AWAY THOSE LEAVES
description: WHILE watching leaves flutter gracefully on autumn breezes may be a pleasant pastime, once on the ground they must be dealt with or they will lead to such problems as a smothered lawn.

title: TO WHAT ARE ATHLETES ENTITLED? NOT TO COCAINE
description: PROFESSIONAL American athletes are today's highly paid folk heroes who live in a media-created fishbowl, the most recent one located in the Federal court building in Pittsburgh, where two trials focused attention on the extent of cocaine use in major league baseball. Our folk heroes have substituted clay feet for the customary spiked shoes. Enjoying an immunity from prosecution, they are freely disclosing their own past use of the drug, and in addition, pushing their buddies out of the cocaine closets around the country's ball parks. Even the venerable Willie Mays has been ''fingered'' by a former teammate.

title: The Merits Of Condo Conversion
description: THE two-family house, long a fixture in many older residential neighborhoods, is a practical way of cutting housing costs because rent from the second unit helps offset the owner's mortgage and maintenance costs.

title: SOONERS PREVAIL BY 13-7
description: Second-ranked Oklahoma, led by the defensive ends Derrell Reed and Kevin Murphy, held off a late threat by Minnesota for a 13-7 season-opening victrory tonight, Oklahoma's scoring came on Earl Johnson's short touchdown dive and two 21-yard Tim Lashar field goals.

title: RESILEINT COLUMBIA LOSES 13TH STRAIGHT
description: After his first game as the football coach at Columbia, Jim Garrett offered blunt opinions that pushed his punter off the team, jolted the Columbia community and helped earn him a reprimand from the school's administration. Today he offered compliments.

title: TRACING GERMANY'S FOLKLORE TRAIL
description: Germany at its most nostalgic is a land of legends, myths and folklore - Sleeping Beauty, Cinderella, Snow White, Hansel and Gretel, Rumpelstiltskin, Little Red Riding Hood, the Pied Piper of Hamelin.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: INMATE coordinators of Rahway State Prison's 10-year-old Scared Straight project - designed to rehabilitate juvenile offenders before they reach a maximum-security facility - fear it might collapse if private donations do not increase.

title: It Must Be Fall: The Students Are Back
description: Residents of the Sixth Ward in New Brunswick know that summer has ended because, like the fog coming in on a cat's paws, the caravans of vehicles slowly crawl through the streets with passengers carefully scrutinizing house numbers.

title: PAPERBACKS IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HAPPY ARE THE MEEK. By Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner, $3.95.) Praise the Lord and pass the black leather garter belts. Andrew M. Greeley, the priest known for his novels about the carnal clergy and lascivious laity of Chicago, has adapted his racy style to the mystery genre.

title: ARIZONA IS UPSET BY COLORADO, 14-13
description: The quarterback Mark Hatcher plunged for a touchdown from 2 yards out, capping a 40-yard drive set up by an interception, to give Colorado a 14-13 upset of Arizona tonight. Hatcher's touchdown late in the third quarter came after the safety John Nairn picked off a pass at midfield. Both teams are now 3-1.

title: KENT, AVON TRIUMPH
description: It is early in the season but already Erickson League followers are saying there is a crucial game coming up next week when Kent travels to Avon Old Farms.

title: PAPERBACKS IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: AMWAY: The Cult of Free Enterprise. By Stephen Butterfield. (South End Press, 302 Columbus Ave., Boston, Mass. 02116, $8.50.) The Amway Corporation has risen from a basement adventure in Michigan to an international empire.

title: A FORTNIGHT FULL OF FALL PREMIERES
description: THE music season in Connecticut is picking up steam, so let us preview a number of series that will be under way in the next two weeks.

title: LIFE UNDER THE MILI-TECHS
description: AND STILL THE EARTH An Archival Narration. By Ignacio de Loyola Brandao. Translated by Ellen Watson. 374 pp. New York: A Bard Book/Avon Books. Paper, $4.95.

title: Iraq Attacks Iranian Port For 5th Time in 5 Days
description: Iraqi warplanes attacked Iran's Kharg Island oil terminal today for the fifth time in as many days.

title: HEALTH OFFICIALS PLAN GLOBAL DRIVE TO FIGHT AIDS
description: Officials at the World Health Organization say they have won the medical and financial support needed to draft a worldwide strategy for combating acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS.

title: Security for Balloting High in New Caledonia
description: More than 3,000 paramilitary gendarmes and policemen took up positions across this French Pacific territory today ahead of crucial elections Sunday pitting French loyalists against Melanesian separatists.

title: NURSING HOMES
description: To the Editor:

title: UNIFORMITY IS GOAL OF BOXING GROUPS
description: In a Catskill Mountain retreat where boxers often sequester themselves to begin serious training for a bout, the New York State Athletic Commission opened its second international boxing symposium today, focusing on the standardization of rules among the estimated 40 commissions in the United States.

title: KONCAK SIGNS WITH HAWKS
description: The former Southern Methodist center Jon Koncak said he had approved financial terms of a four-year contract with the Atlanta Hawks, who made him their first-round draft pick. Koncak said he hoped to report to training camp in Charleston, S.C., Sunday.

title: WHEN GIVING TO A CHARITY, CONSIDER THE TAX LAWS
description: ''I OWE much; I have nothing; I leave the rest to the poor.'' - Rabelais Unlike the 16th-century French wit's less-than-charitable deathbed will, most people today have the means and the inclination to help those less fortunate than themselves or to support worthy causes. Nor is the act of giving only spiritually rewarding; it is also encouraged by the tax laws.

title: Fire Grounds Jet at Kennedy
description: A fire in the tail engine of a three-engine Eastern Airlines L-1011 forced boarding passengers off the jumbo jet yesterday at Kennedy International Airport, the Port Authority police said. The flight, No. 977, had been scheduled to go to Miami. The fire, caused by a faulty fuel line, was extinguished quickly and no one was injured, the police said.

title:
DINING OUT;

PRINCETON: NEW FACE ON THE BLOCK
description: NEWS last spring of big changes at the venerable Peacock Inn in Princeton led us to dine there just days after it had reopened under new ownership. This was too early for a review, of course, since a few months' wait before visiting a new restaurant is customary. However, such impulsiveness reflected the enthusiasm we share with many Princetonians about the arrival of a sophisticated new French restaurant, something the area has been sorely lacking.

title: Susan Bird Weds Gary W. Massey
description: At St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan, Conn., yesterday Susan Hasler Bird, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Bird Jr. of New Canaan and Stuart, Fla., was married to Gary W. Massey, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wayne H. Massey of Forestville, Md. The Rev. Roland M. Jones performed the ceremony.

title: PRISON PROPOSAL PUSHED
description: THIS rural Cumberland County township, which has the county's highest unemployment rate, may become the site of a $40 million-plus Federal medium-security prison next year.

title: VIENNA A TO Z
description: To the Editor: Would Paul Hofmann consider an alternative for his entry D?

title: THE P.L.O. IN EXILE
description: Judith Miller describes the Feb. 11 Arafat-Hussein accord as a ''milestone'' in which the P.L.O. appeared to relinquish its claim to an independent Palestinian state in favor of a state federated with Jordan and ''endorsed . . . Resolution 242.'' The P.L.O. did neither of these things.

title: SECURING THE FUTURE BY PLANNING EARLY
description: PRESIDENT Reagan's tax simplification package, if approved, is not likely to simplify retirement planning. Under the proposals, taxpayers may have to assume an increasing amount of the responsibility now held by their employers for organizing retirement planning. ''I see the burden shifting from the employer, which was the premier provider of retirement benefits, to the employee,'' said Walter Rudecki, tax manager in the Washington office of Ernst & Whinney, the accounting and consulting firm.

title: TRIAL NEARS END FOR COAST MAYOR
description: When Mayor Roger Hedgecock first stood trial in Superior Court last February on charges that he had conspired to funnel $350,000 into his 1983 campaign illegally, he insisted on telling the jury his side of the story.

title: TOPPING THE TANK OF NO-LEAD DEBATE
description: WHAT we have here is a hornet's nest, or at least a fairly buzzy mailbag.

title: Gwendolyn Gray Plans To Wed David Bowlby
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard Keating Gray of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gwendolyn Hampson Gray, to David Bradford Tupper Bowlby, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bradford Hugh Blaikie Bowlby of Toronto.

title: ANOTHER MAJOR NOVEL ELUDES ITS ADAPTER
description: The art of Edith Wharton has often been compared - and sometimes confused - with that of Henry James, but, as Edmund Wilson pointed out, there was a distinct difference in their attitude toward a world that they shared. Wharton was a social satirist, said Wilson, ''perhaps the first American to write with indignant passion against American values as they had come to present themselves by the end of the last century.'' The indignant passion of Edith Wharton defines ''The Custom of the Country,'' a remorseless, and often exceedingly comic novel about a willful woman, Undine Spragg, who climbs her way up the social and economic ladder, discarding men in her wake. Her single, and not exactly saving, grace is her extraordinary beauty.

title: REAL ESTATE
description: To the Editor:

title: CONFUSION CALLING
description: JAMES GALLAGHER of Centereach had just had his first contact with the leased phone. The encounter was not pleasant. ''I've had 14 years of schooling, but that phone is ridiculous,'' he said.

title: Lower Daily Requirements
description: For the 10th time since 1943, a committee of the National Academy of Sciences is preparing a report recommending new dietary allowances for vitamins, minerals and other nutrients.

title: Kathi Paton Has Wedding
description: Kathi Jean Paton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Brewster Paton of New Vernon, N.J., and Orleans, Mass., was married yesterday to Bro Uttal, a son of Mrs. Edmund L. Anderson of New York and Quoque, L.I., and the late Fred Uttal. The Rev. George E. Chorba 3d performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in New Vernon.

title: CUBAN REFUGEES ADAPT TO LIFE IN U.S.
description: Every day, five days a week, about 225 Cuban refugees are interviewed here by special Immigration and Naturalization Service examiners, and practically all of them become permanent residents of the United States.

title: CENTURIES OF TRIBUTE TO THE PLEASURES OF WINE
description: ''Wine: Celebration and Ceremony'' at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum (through Oct. 13) is a large, roomy and convivial affair. How could it be otherwise, when the iconography of wine-making is a rich and ancient subject, hallowed since Greek and Roman times and in existence even earlier? Sculpture and printmaking have made much of it. So have tapestries, glass, silver, porcelain, photography, the Persian miniature, the poster, the postcard, the bookbinder, the wallpaper designer and the movie still.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Cheyenne, Wyo., in some copies on Sept. 15 about Gov. Ed Herschler's filing in Federal Bankruptcy Court for protection from creditors misstated the total assets he claimed. His petition listed $7,518,233 in assets, including a pending claim for $7.5 million against a former business partner.

title: PROGRESS IS MADE IN UGANDAN TALKS
description: Ugandan troops and rebels fought for control of the town of Masaka today while progress was reported at cease-fire talks in Nairobi.

title: RESEARCH AND CAVIAR
description: THE WOODS HOLE CANTATA Essays on Science and Society. By Gerald Weissmann. Foreword by Lewis Thomas. 230 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Company. $14.95.

title: SCHOOL COSTS MAY REQUIRE NEW TACTICS
description: THE Reagan tax proposals, if they become law, could make a big difference in how parents finance their children's education. Those who have used trusts, for example, must beware, said Warren S. Shine, a tax principal with the accounting firm of Ernst & Whinney, because the President ''proposes to slice these out of existence.'' Amid all the possible changes there appears to be but one certainty: Educational costs will continue to rise. So, planners say, parents would do well this fall to re-examine their full range of options.

title: FERRARO CRITICIZES O'CONNOR AS TOO STRIDENT IN '84 CAMPAIGN
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro, the Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate in 1984, has asserted that Archbishop John J. O'Connor of New York appeared to be ''a single-issue Bishop'' in the campaign.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: POWER AND PRINCIPLE: Memoirs of the National Security Adviser 1977-1981, by Zbigniew Brzezinski. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $11.95.) The author's recollections of the years he served under President Carter make clear his belief that America's foreign relations must be based on a willingness to use power and a dedication to principle. Flora Lewis noted in The Book Review in 1983 that this memoir ''is fascinating as an insight into how a crucial part of government works.'' AMERICAN INDIAN MYTHS AND LEGENDS, edited by Richard Erdoes and Alfonso Ortiz. (Pantheon, $11.95.) The 166 legends from 80 North American Indian tribal groups were collected over 25 years and include stories not previously in print, classic accounts in their original form and tales gleaned from 19th-century sources and re-created to restore their authenticity. The 1984 book has tales of human creation, world creation, monsters and monster slayers, wars and warriors, love and lust, tricksters and animals. THE KEEPERS OF THE HOUSE, by Shirley Ann Grau. (Avon, $3.95.) A Southern family's violent history from the early 19th century to the middle of the 20th is the basis of what our reviewer, Frederick C. Crews, termed an ''excellent novel.'' He remarked in 1964 that Shirley Ann Grau's ''lucidity, her narrative directness, her reliance on the bare details of her plot instead of on ponderous philosophizing . . . are agreeable virtues.'' The book won the 1965 Pulitzer Prize for fiction. A second book in Avon's Southern Writers Series, of which there are six titles so far, is THE BLOOD OF PARADISE, by Stephen Goodwin ($3.95).

title: EDUCATION TOPS O'NEILL'S AGENDA
description: IF 1984 was the year to begin rebuilding the state's roads and bridges, and 1985 was the year of the tax cuts, Governor O'Neill served notice last week that 1986 will be what he called Connecticut's ''Year of Education.''

title: THE WORLD'S MOST POPULAR BOOK SHOW: FIVE MILLION VIEWERS IN PRIME TIME
description: WHEN William Styron was invited to discuss his novel ''Sophie's Choice'' on a Paris television talk show called ''Apostrophes,'' he was curious to know who else would appear. After all, it was a live, 90-minute, prime-time, Friday-night program. He was astonished to discover there would be no starlets, no comedians, no animal acts, no music - just writers talking about books.

title: The P.L.O. In Exile
description: In ''The P.L.O. in Exile'' (Aug. 18), Judith Miller states, ''Arafat has been brought to his current situation not by his own choosing, but by circumstance.'' Does Miss Miller believe that the destruction of Lebanon was a mere accident that happened to coincide with the consolidation of the Palestine Liberation Organization forces in that country in 1975? She should know better than to omit Arafat's understated purpose of destroying Israel by any means possible, while chasing his own feudal ambitions.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Essentially, we're going to have to rebuild the entire system. There's no estimate yet on what this may cost.''

title: WESTCHESTER 2000: WHAT PRICE SOVEREIGNTY?
description: WHEN the recommendations of Westchester 2000, a report on the county's future, were finally presented to the public last weekend, the emphasis seemed to be on helping the cities with housing and jobs. Mayor Ronald R. Blackwood of Mount Vernon said, in effect, that it was about time.

title:
GARDENING;

DON'T THROW AWAY THOSE LEAVES
description: WHILE watching leaves flutter gracefully on autumn breezes may be a pleasant pastime, once on the ground they must be dealt with or they will lead to such problems as a smothered lawn.

title: FINGERS IS UNHAPPY
description: His club is out of contention and his star relief pitcher is 39 years old, so George Bamberger, the manager of the Milwaukee Brewers, has been looking to next year by giving his younger relievers more exposure at the tail end of the season. That may seem logical, but it doesn't sit well with Rollie Fingers, the major league career saves leader, who has been sitting on the bench lately.

title: W.J. McDonough Weds Suzanne Falk
description: The marriage of Suzanne Clarke Falk of New York, Lake Forest, Ill., and Cuernavaca, Mexico, to William Joseph McDonough, executive vice president and chief financial officer of the First National Bank of Chicago, took place last evening at the couple's new home in Chicago. The Rev. David A. Donovan, associate pastor of the Fourth Presbyterian Church in Chicago, performed the ceremony.

title: SUPERFUND MUST BE TOUGH AND STRICTLY ENFORCED
description: AMERICA stands today at the threshold of a virtual public-health crisis.

title: ARMS ISSUE IMPERILS U.S.-NEW ZEALAND PACT
description: Though neither side wants it to, a 33-year-old defense treaty that links the United States and New Zealand appears to be unraveling over this country's insistence on barring nuclear-armed or nuclear-powered ships from its ports.

title: Another Senator Calls It a Day
description: The popularity of Senator Charles McC. Mathias Jr. with Maryland's voters has long frustrated ambitious Democrats there, and his liberal-to-moderate views have rarely failed to rile conservative Republicans everywhere.

title: U.N. REFUGEE AGENCY REPORTS LACK OF MONEY
description: The office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has announced a $92 million shortfall in programs paid for by Government contributions. It is the most severe financial crisis in the agency's 34-year history.

title: CITY OPERA WELCOMES 'KISMET' AND GEORGE HEARN
description: On Broadway, he was a living, twisting embodiment of the maniacal barber in Stephen Sondheim's ''Sweeney Todd,'' dispatching customers with a quick horizontal slice across the neck. This week George Hearn makes his debut at the City Opera in an earlier - and rather gentler - musical favorite, ''Kismet.''

title: CHESSYE FOSS HILL BECOMES THE BRIDE OF FREDERICK MOSELEY 4TH IN PRINCETON
description: Chessye Foss Hill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Scott Hill of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Frederick Strong Moseley 4th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Moseley 3d of Hamilton, Mass. Canon E. Rugby Auer, assisted by the Rev. Robert A. Bryan, performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: WHEN I learned recently that you could go from New Jersey to Delaware without crossing a river or bay, I . . . Delaware? Yes, Delaware.

title: A DEVELOPER OPENS ITS OWN HOUSE FACTORY
description: THE Kaplan Organization of Highland Park, one of New Jersey's largest builders, expects to build 750 to 1,000 houses, town houses and condominium apartments this year. Because of that volume, it particulary affected by a continuing skilled-labor shortage.

title: HEMPSTEAD TRIUMPHS
description: The Hempstead Tigers, reigning champions of Nassau County's Division I, and New York state's top-ranked team, continued to win. Hempstead (2-0) defeated the East Meadow Jets, 28-10.

title: Peace Treaty On Westway
description: The details of Westway's legacy took shape last week as Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch decided how to divide almost $2 billion in Federal and local money that had been committed to the highway and development project they reluctantly canceled two weeks ago. At least 60 percent, or $1.2 billion, will go to mass-transit improvements, from the overhaul of older subway cars to the renovation of tracks, signals and stations, with the rest financing a scaled-down highway between the Battery and West 59th Street.

title: SALES TAX
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT ABSTRACT ART ACHIEVED
description: IT IS NOW APPROXIMATELY THREE-QUARTERS OF A CENTURY since the first examples of abstract art - paintings and sculptures that make no direct, immediately discernible reference to recognizable objects - made their unexpected and bewildering debut in the cultural life of the Western world. Since that time, the manifold achievements of abstract art have been clearly seen to constitute one of the principal artistic traditions of the modern era.

title: THE HEALING POWER OF HISTORY
description: LAST February, for the first time in four years, I came down with the flu. I was engulfed in self-pity.

title: SHUFFLED LINE BOLSTERS THE JETS
description: An unlikely combination of players, some who never expected to be with the Jets this season, anchor the defense as it takes a surprisingly proud record against the Indianapolis Colts today at Giants Stadium.

title: CORNERED!
description: YOU WOULDN'T KNOW it by how much money they make or the number of products they endorse. On the average they earn less than any other players on the football field except the punters and place-kickers, and they are almost nonexistent as television pitchmen. But ask a National Football League personnel director who the best athletes in the league are and he will likely answer: the cornerbacks. Perhaps more than anyone else on defense, cornerbacks are now regarded as the guys who can win or lose the game, because they cover the game-breakers -the wide receivers.

title: UNDERSTANDING THE CHOICES WHEN INSURANCE SHOPPING
description: WHETHER you are shopping for life insurance to protect your first born, auto insurance for a new car or homeowners insurance, the same basic rules apply. The first is: Assess your needs. A couple with a new mortgage and three college-bound children have far greater insurance needs than a couple in their 60's who have adult children and substantial savings. The collision insurance you need for a new Cadillac will be more than for a 15-year-old Volkswagen.

title: WILL TAPE BE THE FILM OF THE FUTURE?
description: SOMETIMES, the future of photography turns up in the strangest places.

title: RETHINKING NUCLEAR WAR
description: Only 10 years ago, many scientists concluded that the planet could survive a major nuclear war, recovering within a decade. That judgment is now sharply questioned by new interest in the effects of nuclear explosions on the world's climate, cities and agriculture. The Reagan Administration contends that the debate is irrelevant to policy, which is based on the premise that nuclear weapons must never be used. Still, governments that threaten -and are threatened by - nuclear retaliation cannot be indifferent to knowledge of the consequences if deterrence fails.

title: RESCUING HISTORY
description: FOR years it stood in oblivion, a two-and-a-half-story frame house on a half-acre along a back road near Adams, Mass. But a year ago this month, Dr. Alice Grellner, a professor of English at Rhode Island College, bought the house for $48,000 and planned to give it the recognition she felt it should have as the birthplace of Susan B. Anthony, the suffragist.

title: BALLESTEROS ADVANCES TO FINAL
description: Severiano Ballesteros of Spain, the defending champion, sent Andy North of the United States out of the $260,000 World Match Play Championship today with a 4 and 2 victory in the semifinals.

title: Page-Staying and Stopping
description: To the Editor:

title: VANITIES OF THE HUNTING CLASS
description: DEVOTED LADIES By M. J. Farrell. With an Introduction by Polly Devlin. 303 pp. New York: Penguin Books/Virago Press. Paper, $6.95.

title: YONKERS STUDENT TO SUE IN EFFORT TO JOIN MALE FOOTBALL TEAM
description: THE Lincoln High School junior-varsity football team was scheduled to play its first game of the season yesterday and 16-year-old Jacqueline Lantz planned to be in the stands rooting. She would have preferred to be on the field playing.

title: ON THE CINCINNATI STREETS, IT'S ROSE 1, SABIN 0
description: While it appears that virtually everyone here loves Pete Rose, some have become annoyed at the speed with which the city named a downtown street for the baseball player who set a major league records for total hits.

title: Betsy H. Martens Becomes a Bride
description: Betsy Helene Martens, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Martens of Woodbury, Conn., was married yesterday to Edward Wilkinson Blodgett 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Winthrop Blodgett Jr. of Wilton, Conn. The Rev. James B. Christ, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church of Ridgefield, Conn.

title: Baker Says U.S. Wants Gradual Drop in Dollar
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said in an interview published today that the United States has not set a target for how much the dollar should fall in value, but ''a moderate, gradual decline would not displease'' the Reagan Administration.

title:
PAPERBACKS;

FOLKS WITH REFRIGERATOR MAGNETS
description: THE HISTORY OF WHITE PEOPLE IN AMERICA By Martin Mull and Allen Rucker. Illustrated. 143 pp. New York: A Perigee Book. Paper, $5.95.

title: STATE AUDIT FAULTS SOCIAL SERVICES UNIT ON TRAVEL EXPENSES
description: The State Social Services Department, which spends billions of dollars a year, lacks management controls over in-house expenses and outside contracts, according to two new state audits.

title: ROOSEVELT FREEDOMS AWARDS GO TO 5 IN UPSTATE CEREMONY
description: Several hundred people gathered here today to honor five distinguished men for their commitment to the ''Four Freedoms'' set forth by Franklin D. Roosevelt.

title: Elinor Streator Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward James Streator of Paris and Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter Elinor Craig Streator to Jorge Garcia Garcia, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ramon Garcia San Miguel of Gijon, Spain, and San Juan, P.R. A January wedding is planned.

title: MARTIN SCORSESE: THE FILM DIRECTOR AS A LOCAL ALIEN
description: Walking around the TriBeCa neighborhood where he lives, Martin Scorsese looks a little out of place.

title: THE ULTIMATE IN SAFETY PLAYS
description: Countries behind the Iron Curtain, notably Poland, have made a considerable impact on the tournament world in recent years. This would certainly have been greater but for official restrictions and lack of currency for travel purposes. The Poles have won two world team titles in the past seven years, and their poor showing in the 1985 European Championship is unlikely to be repeated. Their players dominate the European tournament circuit, winning cash prizes that are very substantial in Polish terms.

title: REVIVING A TROUBLE BUILDING
description: ''THIS building is not in the city's historic-preservation district,'' said Marc Crawford Leavitt, a developer who is rehabilitating the 48-unit, six-story building at 430 Clinton Avenue in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn.

title: INVESTING TO RETIRE: 3 CASE STUDIES
description: JOSEPH E. BIBEN, the owner and founder of the Joseph E. Biben Sales Corporation, of Philadelphia, hasn't fixed a date for retirement. Nevertheless, he is prepared.

title: PENNIES AND THE PASSING OF TIME
description: WHAT was this obssession with pennies, I wondered, sorting through the belongings in my father-in-law's house. Every room had its little cache on the bureau or windowsill, every drawer its overflowing cup or tray. In the bedroom a penny-filled glass pig served as a doorstop; in the den a blue velvet pouch acted as paper weight; in the kitchen a pewter goblet, filled to the brim, stood dutifully beside the back door, pennies spilling onto the counter like so much rusty wine. Indeed, as we worked our way from basement to attic we seemed to have recovered nearly half the nation's missing change.

title: ANDRE KERTESZ, 91, PHOTOGRAPHER
description: Andre Kertesz, a pioneer of photojournalism and an internationally acclaimed master of small-camera lyricism, died Friday at his home in New York City. He was 91.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: Sept. 29, 1985
description: Fiction

title: OF GOD AND GREAT-AUNTS
description: GOD has begun to appear in novels and Heaven knows what it means. In Joseph Heller's ''God Knows,'' He resembles ''the original comic Jewish novelist,'' according to Mordecai Richler, who reviewed the book in these pages. Stanley Elkin's God in ''The Living End'' is a cosmic wisecracker, who says He put mankind through all its trials and tribulations for no other reason than that ''it makes a better story.'' In Bernard Malamud's ''God's Grace,'' He is vengeful and narrow-minded. Timothy Findley, in his current novel ''Not Wanted on the Voyage,'' depicts God as depressed, self-dramatizing and unkempt.

title: SCHOOL CONVERSION
description: A residential rehabilitation now in progress near the central business district of Montclair, N.J., in which a developer is turning an old grade school into condominium apartments, is expected to further enhance the community's efforts to reinvigorate its downtown area.

title: JET CHASES LIGHTNING IN BID TO INCREASE SAFETY
description: Every day in summer when thunderstorms approach, two pilots climb into a specially equipped jet of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and fly into the clouds hoping to be struck by lightning.

title: PORNOGRAPHY AS PARADOX
description: WOMEN AGAINST CENSORSHIP Edited by Varda Burstyn. 210 pp. Manchester, N.H.: Salem House. Paper, $8.95.

title: DELHI
description: Indians refer to their capital as Dilli, which in Hindi means heart. Delhi has been at the crossroads of Indian history for a thousand years, and never more so than today. Its pace of politics, culture and finance has come more and more to set the tone for the rest of the country.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

SPEAKERS FORUM
description: County residents have the opportunity to hear speakers on a wide range of topics this fall and among the more unusual offerings are two that are free.

title: Killer Whale Born in Park
description: A killer whale has been born at Sea World, a marine a marine amusement park, and the mother and her calf were reported doing well, officials say.

title: COUNSELING BEFORE PREGNANCY
description: STUMBLING into life's momentous occasions may be thrilling, but when the occasion is pregnancy that could be risky, especially since the early weeks are known to be critical.

title: SHULA LEADS ALABAMA TO 40-20 ROUT OF VANDERBILT
description: Mike Shula ran for one touchdown and passed for another to lead Alabama to a 40-20 Southeastern Conference victory over Vanderbilt today.

title: SHOULD MAJORITIES RULE RESERVATION?
description: Fifty years ago, the Federal Government, alarmed at the effects of modern business on Indian tribes, moved to bring Anglo-American majority rule to tribal leadership. Through the Indian Reform Act, it encouraged the tribes to elect councils to rule in the place of chiefs.

title: THE MYSTERY OVER A KILLING IN HONDURAS
description: The violent death of an influential former Honduran Army officer has raised concern and suspicion in Honduran political circles and among key military officers.

title: THE ART OF SUCCESSFUL GOAL-SETTING
description: WHEN Dr. Euan Robertson, a 48-year-old professor of obstetrics at the University of Miami Medical School in Florida, recently decided to consult a financial planner, he assumed the goals he had set were all but impossible to meet.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM VERDI TO HITCHOCK
description: Faerie Tale Theater The Little Mermaid Starring Pam Dawber, Helen Mirren, Treat Williams; directed by Robert Iscove. CBS/Fox Video 60 minutes, $39.98 Take one of Hans Christian Andersen's greatest stories - the tale of the little mermaid who loved a sailor prince - a plausible script, an all-star cast, lavish sets and costumes, even a pleasant score, but use awkward, old-fashioned special effects and the result is a mixed success.

title: CHALLENGES
description: Washington is best known nationally for collecting considerable amounts of money from involuntary donors and spending it in ways that are often largely unseen by its former owners. But there are exceptions.

title: LE BON YACHT IN WHITBREAD
description: In yacht racing, there are few challenges more arduous than the Whitbread Around the World Race. Yet 15 sailboats with international crews appeared ready for the task yesterday as the 1985-86 Whitbread fleet sailed from Portsmouth, England, for the beginning of a 27,000-mile global voyage.

title: KING IS OFF BOARD
description: AT 10:55 A.M., a fearsome sound was heard across Long Island, as bad as anything Hurricane Gloria had done the day before. It went something like this: ''Whoosh-unhhh-thunk!'' Straight from the island of Jamaica, Hurricane Patrick had landed upon the National Basketball Association.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: LIKE all men, I have needs and desires.

title: Sara Helen Strauss Weds Andrew Ernest Tomback
description: Sara Helen Strauss, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Strauss of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Andrew Ernest Tomback, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. Tomback, also of Scarsdale, were married yesterday.

title:
PAPERBACKS;

GOODNESS WITHIN REACH
description: BRINGING UP A MORAL CHILD A New Approach for Teaching Your Child to Be Kind, Just and Responsible. By Michael Schulman and Eva Mekler. 362 pp. Reading, Mass: Addison-Wesley Publishing. Paper, $12.95. Cloth, $19.95. HAD this book been written in 1885 it would have been well received, because it extols the moral virtues of kindliness, justice and responsibility so dear to Victorian hearts. Its prescriptions for instilling morality in children are pre-Freudian: they are based on the belief that parents can set good examples and that children are emotionally uncomplicated and responsive to loving correction.

title: WE MIGHT AS WELL HAVE NO FAIRNESS DOCTRINE
description: To the Editor:

title: O'NEILL'S 'ICEMAN' SPRANG FROM THE ASHES OF HIS YOUTH
description: When Eugene O'Neill, at 50, began work on ''The Iceman Cometh,'' he was hurtling toward premature old age, tasting the imminent and bitter end of a writing career born 26 years earlier. His visionary outlook had long since revolutionized the American theater, and the cumulative force of such innovative and daring plays as ''The Emperor Jones,'' ''Desire Under the Elms,'' ''Anna Christie,'' ''Strange Interlude'' and ''Mourning Becomes electra'' had won him the Nobel Prize, an honor never before or since bestowed on an American playwright.

title: PAPERBACKS IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE LEGEND OF MAYA DEREN: A Documentary Biography and Collected Works. Edited by VeVe A. Clark, Millicent Hodson and Catrina Neiman.

title: SOLID-WASTE DISPOSAL: NO PAT ANSWERS AT HAND
description: IT WILL become increasingly evident in the years ahead, especially in New Jersey, that there are two distinct approaches to solid-waste management that involve resource recovery: (1) - The mass approach, which treats the entire waste stream as an undifferentiated material. (2) - The diversified approach, which treats the components (paper, glass, metal, plastic, food waste, yard waste, etc.) according to their particular nature.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Anaheim, Calif., on Sept. 15 about the Episcopal Church's General Convention incorrectly detailed the church's stockholdings in companies doing business in South Africa. The church holds $80 million in stock, and its pension fund holds $468 million in stock, but officials do not know how much involves companies active in South Africa.

title: HOMEOWNERS' INSURANCE COVERAGE OMITS SOME DAMAGE FROM STORM
description: Over the next few days, as insurance claims adjusters make the rounds of areas damaged by Hurricane Gloria, many homeowners will no doubt unhappily discover that not all types of damage are covered, even under the most comprehensive of homeowners' policies.

title: ANNE P. DONALDSON
description: Anne Peabody Donaldson, who was active in community affairs, died of cancer Wednesday at her home in New Canaan, Conn. She was 73 years old.

title: LET A FEW FLOWERS BLOOM
description: HALLS OF JADE, WALLS OF STONE Women in China Today. By Stacey Peck. Illustrated. 315 pp. New York: Franklin Watts. $15.95.

title: Cindi Rosenberg Engaged
description: The engagement of Cindi Robin Rosenberg to Lawrence Howard Michaels, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Isidore Michaels of Brooklyn, has been announced by her parents, Ronald Rosenberg of Brooklyn and Gina Rosenberg of New Springville, S.I. The future bride is a member of the class of '87 at Bernard M. Baruch College of the City University of New York. Mr. Michaels, who graduated cum laude from Long Island University, is an associate director for WNEW-Television in New York.

title: The Case of Commander Billig
description: A Navy heart surgeon who is trying to overturn charges that he was negligent in the deaths of five patients faced one of his chief accusers last week. In a pretrial military hearing, Col. Russ Zajtchuk, the top heart surgeon at the nation's military medical school, testified that Comdr.

title: RECORDING THE BRUTAL, FASCINATING FACES OF WARFARE
description: When photographers go off to war - as they have done with unfortunate regularly since the beginnings of the medium - they have to decide what to make pictures of. In a sense, they have to decide what war is. Should they show the pomp and glory of regiments preparing to enter the fray? The nobility of the men in the trenches? The chaos and confusion of combat itself? Or should they show the destruction war leaves in its wake, the casualties and corpses, the suffering of both civilians and combatants?

title: Free Trade Talks Set To Begin
description: President Reagan's demand that United States banks, insurance companies and other service industries get better access to foreign markets will be the major point of controversy at talks opening here Monday to discuss beginning a new round of international trade-freeing negotiations, according to trade officials.

title: 2 UTILITIES LACK STORM INSURANCE TO COVER GLORIA
description: Two electric power companies serving Connecticut and Long Island - the areas of the New York region hit hardest by Hurricane Gloria - said yesterday that they had no insurance to cover the damage inflicted by the storm.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Sept. 30, 1985: *2*MONDAY Ameron Inc Unocal Corp Cascade Natural Gas Xerox Corp Federal-Mogul Corp *2*TUESDAY Carolina Freight Corp Ohio Mattress Co Central Ill Pub Serv Pacific Lighting Harsco Corp Southwest Gas Corp Nevada Power *2*WEDNESDAY Carter Hawley Hale Murphy Oil Corp MGM Grand Hotels Southwestern Energy *2*THURSDAY Clevepak Mercantile Stores Gencorp Inc Sun Co Inc General Dynamics United Water Resources MGM/UA *2*FRIDAY Lomas & Nettleton U S West Milton Roy West Point Pepperel Travelers Corp

title: METS TRIUMPH ON CARTER'S HOMER
description: The emotions of the Mets during their game with Pittsburgh today went up and down more often than an elevator. They had the game won, then they weren't certain, then they thought they had lost it, then they had it won again but couldn't be too sure of that either until they were lodged safely in their clubhouse.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 30, 1985
description: Companies

title: RECITAL: OXANA YABLONSKAYA
description: OXANA YABLONSKAYA'S piano recital at the 92d Street Y on Saturday night was a curious mix of asceticism and Romantic extroversion. Miss Yablonskaya, trained in the Soviet Union and now living in this country, rumbled through six of Scriabin's early Etudes with a massive bravura.

title: Elizabeth Wald Becomes a Bride
description: Elizabeth Tolie Wald, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Wald of Larchmont, N.Y., was married yesterday to Wayne Frederick Forman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Forman of Levittown, L.I. Rabbi Irving Koslowe officiated at Estherwood, a National Landmark in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Bridge: Vulnerability May Be Key In Dramatic Leap to Slam
description: If an inexperienced player leaps majestically to the six-level he surely expects to make 12 tricks and is quite likely to emerge with an overtrick. But if the leaper is an expert this assumption is not necessarily valid.

title: Andrea Feld Wed To Seth L. Marvin
description: Andrea Susan Feld, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin F. Feld of New Brunswick, N.J., and Beach Haven, N.J., was married yesterday to Seth Lee Marvin, a son of John R. Marvin of Bayside, Queens, and the late Ruth Sulzer Marvin. Rabbi Z. David Levy performed the ceremony at the Fiddler's Elbow Country Club in Bedminster, N.J.

title: LAB FIRE RUINS STUDIES OF SANDY HOOK WATERS
description: For the last week, scientists have been examining the charred remains of the Sandy Hook Marine Laboratory here, dismayed by the loss of their laboratory, but devastated by the loss of their research.

title: Bishop Bars Homosexuals From Gathering in a Church
description: A homosexual rights conference cannot be held at a St. Paul Catholic church because policies endorsed by the organizers are inconsistent with church teachings, the head of the St. Paul-Minneapolis Archdiocese has said.

title: Iran Denies Funds Report
description: Central Bank Governor Mohsen Nourbakhsh denied today that Iran had a shortage of foreign currency and said oil revenue was coming in as scheduled.

title: 'KID VID' A GROWING MARKET
description: Bugs Bunny and She-Ra the Princess of Power, Heathcliff the Cat, Kermit the Frog, Spiderman, Pinocchio and such esoteric creatures as Thundercats, Mirthworms, Rainbow Brite, Scrabble People, Thundarr the Barbarian and Bunnicula the Vampire Rabbit are the newest things in video cassettes. They call it Kid Vid. Feature films are still the bread and butter of the video cassette industry, bringing in the lion's share of the revenues. At the recent video software dealers convention, 4,000 store owners went wild with excitement when RCA/Columbia announced that it would release ''Ghostbusters'' on Halloween. ''Ghostbusters'' and ''Beverly Hills Cop'' will bring customers into video stores this fall. Once inside, however, they are likely to buy a cassette for their children.

title: ANGELS LEAD AS ROYALS LOSE
description: Kirk McCaskill pitched a seven-hitter and Bob Boone and Dick Schofield drove in two runs each today as the California Angels beat the Cleveland Indians, 9-3, to take sole possession of first place in the American League West.

title: Catching Up
description: * John Drew, waived by the Utah Jazz last December because of repeated drug dependency, was released three weeks ago from Highland Ridge Hospital in Salt Lake City, having undergone a 90-day drug-rehabilitation program. Drew's treatment at Highland Ridge - part of a judge's sentence for passing bad checks last spring - allowed him time to compete in the Utah Pro-Amateur Summer League (he was the leading scorer, averaging 33.8 points a game), but his future as a pro is cloudy, to say the least.

title: BRIEFS b
description: Debt Issues

title: YANKS SWEEP PAIR AS MATTINGLY STARS
description: The performance was straight from the Earl Weaver school of dramatic arts: ranting and raving incessantly, shoveling dirt on an umpire's slacks, spinning his cap backward in an ultimate display of histrionics.

title: RACIAL TENSIONS JUST ONE FACTOR IN LONDON RIOTS
description: As police officers with heavy plastic shields and other riot gear dealt with a second night of violence in the mostly black district of Brixton this evening, clusters of young whites milled among crowds of young blacks in a spirit of common hostility to the authorities.

title: A Potpourri
description: As if everything needed for survival in the city might once have been found there, an old sign in a second-floor store window on Seventh Avenue, between 32d and 33d Streets, still promises these things:

title: THE BOBBY: FRESH LOOK AT HIS ROLE
description: Twice in five weeks the traditionally unarmed British police have shot an innocent member of a family during a raid on a house in search of someone else. Both shootings were described by the police as tragic accidents. Both touched off mob violence.

title: 17 KILLED IN GEORGIA WHEN PLANE FILLED WITH PARACHUTISTS CRASHES
description: A single-engine plane packed with skydivers preparing for a formation jump stalled shortly after takeoff today and nosedived onto a rural road, killing all 17 people aboard.

title: Olin Elects New President
description: John W. Johnstone Jr. has been elected president of the Olin Corporation, assuming the title and position held for the last two years by John M. Henske, chairman and chief executive officer.

title: DANCE: IN MONTREAL, EXPERIMENTAL TROUPES
description: As Montreal's ''Festival International de Nouvelle Danse'' drew to an end today it was obvious that the 14 experimental dance companies on view in the 11-day series had churned up debate and a small degree of controversy.

title: Retired Admiral Trying To Rescue Boat Builder
description: When he retired from the Navy as a Rear Admiral in 1977, all E. Thompson Westfall wanted to do was rebuild an old house on Sullivan Island, near Charleston, S.C.

title: HIGHER RATES FOR INSURANCE SEEN AFTER HURRICANE
description: While property damage claims from Hurricane Gloria's sweep through the New York metropolitan area have so far been generally less than insurers feared before the storm, spokesmen for several major property and casualty companies said yesterday that it was still too early to gauge the storm's net effect on their already beleaguered industry.

title: BRAWLING AND CAROUSING GONE IN BOOM OUT WEST
description: From the building of the first railroads in the last century to the giant dams and water and energy projects of this century, the West has long depended on armies of outside workers to come in, build a project, and then depart.

title: CHILI WAR, BOMBSHELL, OIL CLAIMS
description: Houston's great chili war goes on. It started when some Yankee carnival operator asked the Houston Health Department for a permit for a chili cookoff. That alerted the health inspectors, because it never would have occurred to a Texan to ask for a permit.

title: The Ultimate Chip
description: The new Soviet proposal for a 50 percent reduction in superpower offensive weaponry has made it clear that no serious arms control agreement can be reached unless President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative is ''on the table'' at Geneva.

title: Breathtaking Beauty Without a Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: But Who Decides What's Fair in Trade?
description: To the Editor:

title: French Loyalists Lead In New Caledonia Vote
description: French loyalists led in elections for a new regional parliament today, but a pro-independence party scored an upset by capturing three of four electoral regions, initial returns showed.

title: ON FIRE I., SOME STORM DAMAGE BUT MUCH RELIEF
description: Tony Lizzul was a little shocked by what he found in the backyard of his beach house when he returned here today.

title: Ugandans Express Hope As Peace Talks Adjourn
description: Peace talks between the Ugandan Government and rebels adjourned tonight with officials expressing optimism that a formula to end years of bloodshed was close.

title: Kurdish Rebels Kill 5 Turks
description: Five Turkish Army privates were killed by Kurdish guerrillas in an ambush in eastern Turkey last Wednesday, according to a military statement issued today. It said an officer was wounded in the attack, which took place near the town of Lice. The guerrillas escaped.

title: GIANTS GO TO 3-1
description: The Giants struck a blow today for the argument that defense wins football games. But their 16-10 overtime victory made an even stronger case for the notion that good fortune wins games.

title: WASHINGTON WHITES FOUND MORE LIKELY TO BE CRIME VICTIMS
description: White residents of the nation's capital are almost twice as likely as black residents to be victims of violent crimes, which contradicts the national trend in urban crime, according to a Government study released today.

title: Staying Afloat
description: The world's fastest swimmer, Matt Biondi, is back in the pool this month, trying to become the world's fastest water polo player. With hardly a break in action from a nine-month swimming season that he concluded in August with four world records, Biondi, as he says, ''dropped my goggles for polo,'' the sport that gave him his first international recognition.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Airlines has promoted Michael W. Gunn to senior vice president, passenger marketing. The company also appointed Dennis B. Crosby president of a newly created subsidiary, Direct Sales Enterprises Inc.

title: Sukemasa Irie Is Dead at 80; Hirohito's Grand Chamberlain
description: Emperor Hirohito's closest aide, Grand Chamberlain Sukemasa Irie, died of a heart attack at a Tokyo hospital today, two days before his retirement, the Imperial Household Agency reported. He was 80 years old.

title: Market Place;   Super-Regional Banks Emerge
description: THE banking landscape has been divided into the ''money center'' giants, typically in New York and Chicago, and the ''regionals,'' a designation applied to smaller banks in other parts of the country. But industry experts say that a new category - the ''super-regionals'' - soon will begin to flex its banking muscles.

title: THE SAGANS: FICTION AND FACT BACK TO BACK
description: There is no telescope in Carl Sagan's house, although there certainly are a few objects that invite attention. There is an exact Styrofoam copy of the Rosetta stone, which the 50-year-old astronomer has propped against the living room wall. From a Mobil gas station, there is a great red steel Pegasus. And just about everywhere there is a toddler named Alexandra - everyone calls her Sashie. But there is no telescope.

title: U.S. COMPANIES WEED OUT MANY OPERATIONS
description: America's huge industrial corporations, which have always tried to do as much as possible themselves, are backing away from the mines-to-markets orthodoxy that has prevailed since Andrew Carnegie's day.

title: Swiss Expert Faces Tough Bank Talks
description: Fritz Leutwiler, the 61-year-old former head of the Swiss central bank, has no illusions about South Africa's racial policies. ''There is no need to discuss apartheid,'' he once told an interviewer. ''We can agree on that within 10 seconds.''

title: Advertising;   Agency Stake Grows
description: Dai-ichi Kikaku, which was identified as the owner of 5.1 percent of the stock of Ally & Gargano, which went public in 1983, announced last week that it and its United States subsidiary had increased that investment to 7.5 percent of all the outstanding stock, or 166,600 shares.

title: Migrant Workers Chose a Union
description: Fourteen migrant workers unanimously chose a union today to represent them at a fruit and vegetable farm here in what is believed to be the first time that New Jersey farm workers have adopted a bargaining agent.

title: On High
description: Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, yesterday reported 100 percent employment for the construction industry in one Brooklyn household - his own.

title: Required Reading;   Technology and Shifting Relationships
description: Excerpt from a monograph published this month by the American Enterprise Institute entitled High Technology and American Foreign Policy, written by Lawrence S. Eagleburger, a former Under Secretary of State who is now president of Kissinger Associates:

title: Tentative Pact Set In Teachers' Strike
description: A tentative agreement was reached last night ending a nine-day strike by 230 teachers in the Manalapan-Englishtown Regional School District, according to both sides.

title: Mormon Leader Affirms Priesthood for Men Only
description: Mormon women cannot be ordained to the priesthood unless God orders a change in the practice of ordaining only men, a leader of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints says.

title: Advertising;   Generating Publicity For Fight
description: ''NOBODY here is sophisticated in the advertising business.

title: DOLLAR'S CAT-AND-MOUSE GAME
description: In pre-dawn darkness last Monday, Eugene W. Boehringer, a First Boston Corporation currency trader, groped for his home telephone to check on London. There, his firm's traders were frantically buying foreign-currency bonds and monitoring their position in United States dollars.

title: METROPOLITAN MUSEUM FILES PLANS FOR A NEW $35 MILLION STRUCTURE
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, which is still completing its huge southwest wing, has filed plans with the Landmarks Preservation Commission for a new $35 million structure.

title: Gant Takes Race But Waltrip Gains
description: Harry Gant got the victory in the Holly Farms 400 Grand National stock car race today, but Darrell Waltrip captured the lead in the chase for the Nascar points crown.

title: Mr. Meese's Freedom
description: The State of Oregon, a few years from now, makes the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church its official religion. Only members of that church may hold public office or teach in any Oregon school or college.

title: HELPING THE 'CO-DEPENDENTS' OF NARCOTICS ABUSERS
description: An increasing number of drug-rehabilitation programs are beginning to recognize that narcotics abuse seriously affects the parents, spouses, children and close friends of abusers.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Washington Talk page on Wednesday, about Bowen, Ill., hometown of Senator Barry Goldwater's mother, misidentified its mayor. He is Ronald Moormann.

title: JUDGE 'TRYING TO LEARN' IN SCHOOL AIDS DISPUTE
description: Justice Harold Hyman leaned forward in State Supreme Court in Queens and pressed the witness for details on examining children for the AIDS virus.

title: SUPERTANKER LEAKS 9,000 BARRELS OF CRUDE OIL INTO DELAWARE RIVER
description: A supertanker ran aground in the Delaware River late Saturday night, gashing a hole in its side and spilling 435,000 gallons of crude oil that threatened the water supplies of two cities and a wildlife refuge.

title: Therese Sarah Rosenblatt Is Married
description: Therese Sarah Rosenblatt and Marshall Sonenshine were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Peter R. Rosenblatt of Washington, by Rabbi Stanley Rabinowitz. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Sonenshine of Pompano Beach, Fla.

title: A 'GAME BALL' WITH DEJA VU
description: WHEN last seen, the Giants' one-time quarterback, Joe Pisarcik, cut recently by the Miami Dolphins, was sunning himself on a Fort Lauderdale beach. And when last heard from, Mark Haynes, their all-pro cornerback the previous four seasons, was in his Upper Saddle River, N.J., home, still a holdout. But yesterday, it was as if one were on the sideline and the other in the owners' box during the Giants' 16-10 victory over the Eagles on the cornerback Elvis Patterson's 29-yard interception return after only 55 seconds of overtime.

title: BEARS ROUT REDSKINS BY 45-10
description: Willie Gault's 99-yard kickoff return triggered a 31-point second quarter today as the undefeated Chicago Bears went on to rout the Washington Redskins, 45-10, for their fourth straight triumph.

title: INGENIOUS TACTICS GAIN A DRAW FOR KASPAROV
description: Beautiful tactical ingenuity by Gary Kasparov enabled him to bring his 10th world chess championship game with Anatoly Karpov to a draw on Friday in the Tchaikovsky Concert Hall in Moscow.

title: Advertising;   People
description: * William F. Rosenthal has joined Einson Freeman, a sales promotion agency, as senior vice president.

title: Dan River Aide to Shift To Britain as Consultant
description: William M. Fine has always had a soft spot for Britain and Ireland. He bought an Irish home near Galway years ago, and quite recently a farm outside London. So on Dec. 1, Mr. Fine, the 59-year old president of the consumer products division of Dan River Inc., will make the big leap, moving with his family to London to resume a career as a corporate consultant for multinational companies expanding in the United States, as well as for American companies.

title: Abbey D. Alkon Is the Bride of Jonathan Leonard
description: At Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, L.I., yesterday Abbey D. Alkon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris I. Alkon of Manhasset, L.I., was married to Jonathan S. Leonard, a son of Dr. and Mrs. A. Orin Leonard of Leominster, Mass. Rabbi Simon Resnikoff officiated.

title: SYMPTOM OF A BOOM: 75,000 AT BOOK FAIR IN RIO
description: A surge of interest has been apparent for the past two years, but the crowds that flocked to the display area of an elegant shopping mall here this month seemed to dramatize the point: In a country with little reading tradition, books have become Brazil's latest fashion.

title: NEW DROP IN MACHINE TOOL ORDERS
description: Machine tool orders continued to decline in August, falling 8.3 percent from the level of August 1984, according to the industry's trade group.

title: 'ANGRY HARVEST' AND A POLISH FARMER
description: AGNIESZKA HOLLAND'S ''Angry Harvest'' brings a good deal of directorial delicacy to bear upon a story that is essentially rather crude. It follows the growing wartime relationship between a Polish farmer and a beautiful Viennese woman, a Jewish refugee whom he helps to hide from the Gestapo. Their series of encounters holds considerable dramatic potential and, indeed, Miss Holland (whose screenplay, written with Paul Hengge, is based on the novel by Hermann Field and Stanislaw Mierzenski) attempts to give it some elements of suspense as well as a moral dimension. However, much of the staging and acting (particularly in the supporting roles) merely consigns the material to the realm of melodrama.

title: AQUEDUCT READIED FOR CUP
description: When the announcement was made last year that the Breeders' Cup would be held at Aqueduct his November, purists blanched at the thought of racing's gala being set at a track best known for its dinginess. While the track by Jamaica Bay still looks like the Aqueduct that horseplayers know and rarely love, some sweeping renovations that were unveiled yesterday will make it a more appropriate setting for the cup races Nov. 2.

title: No Headline
description: QUESTION: Forget the Subway Series - when was the last time two teams from New York finished second in the same season?

title: LIABILITY INSURANCE COST IS SOARING FOR LOCALITIES
