description: Municipalities across the New York metropolitan region are facing serious problems in obtaining liability insurance to protect themselves against a dramatic increase in damage awards and litigation, according to state and local officials.

title: V.I.P Call at N.Y.U.
description: The chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, Frank Hodsoll, is going to spend the day tomorrow at New York University as the guest of its president, John Brademas. On his schedule are a visit to the Tisch School of Art, lunch with faculty members, a speech at an afternoon seminar and dinner in the president's penthouse. The aim of the visit is to strengthen relations between the arts and higher education while demonstrating that the arts are bipartisan; Mr. Hodsoll is a Republican appointeee of President Reagan, and Mr. Brademas was the Democratic whip of the House of Representatives before he strayed into the groves of academe.

title: Play It Smart With Mexico
description: The devastating earthquakes that rocked Mexico earlier this month were a severe blow to that country's efforts to ''put its house in order'' economically and financially. But the natural disaster also served as a sobering reminder of the depth and breadth of United States ties to its troubled neighbor. Both factors argue for a new United States approach to Mexico.

title: Fruits of the 1785 Chesapeake Bay Action Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: ON ONE RESERVATION, A SUICIDE CRISIS
description: In less than two months, eight young Indians have hanged themselves on the Wind River Reservation, a two-million-acre tract of barren plains and rolling hills in central Wyoming.

title: PARTI QUEBECOIS ELECTS A MODERATE TO SUCCEED LEVESQUE AS PREMIER
description: Pierre Marc Johnson, a political moderate who favors independence for Quebec only as a last resort, was elected today as the leader of the Parti Quebecois. He succeeded Premier Rene Levesque, who has stepped down.

title: Advertising;   Scali, McCabe to Open Los Angeles Office
description: Richard Kelly, 38 years old, and Charles Silverman, 42, a pair of agency executives with impressive West Coast experience, have been rounded up by Scali, McCabe, Sloves to run a Los Angeles office. It opens tomorrow.

title: BUSINESS LEADERS IN PRETORIA URGE END TO APARTHEID
description: Leading businessmen in South Africa, including Afrikaners and representatives of foreign corporations, called in full-page newspaper advertisements today for the abolition of apartheid and negotiations with ''acknowledged black leaders'' on sharing power.

title: IN JERSEY, GOVERNOR'S RACE A CAPTIVE OF SEPTEMBER'SD LANGUOR
description: For a candidate on the stump, September can be the cruelest month.

title: Roxanne Parks Marries
description: The marriage of Roxanne Parks, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Parks of Norwalk, Conn., to Jeffrey Mark O'Brasky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David O'Brasky of Stamford, Conn., took place yesterday at the Ridgefield (Conn.)

title: ROLLINS WON'T MISS MIDNIGHT CALLS
description: Ed Rollins says he's tired and wants to earn some money and then, with a crack in his voice, he confesses that he'll miss the White House.

title: Met Mystery
description: Did the Mets booby-trap their infield in Shea Stadium two weeks ago to foil the sprinting St. Louis Cardinals? If so, did the booby trap turn on them and inflict a painful loss little more than a week later? And if that is so, will they look back and bemoan it when the regular season comes to a close next weekend?

title: Melanie Rosen Bride Of Mitchell J. Brooks
description: Melanie Jane Rosen and Mitchell J. Brooks were married yesterday at the Terrace Restaurant in Manhattan by Cantor Ellen S. Math. The bride is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney W. Rosen of Fall River, Mass.

title: Washington Watch;   F.C.C.'s Phone Plans Awaited
description: THE telephone industry staff of the Federal Communications Commission has been working overtime this weekend trying to crank out several major telephone policies for this week that will affect rates paid by businesses of all sizes, and residential customers as well.

title: Doris Reich, an Illustrator, Is Married to a Law Clerk
description: The marriage of Doris Emily Reich, a daughter of Stanley and Tamara Reich of Cape Coral, Fla., to Jeffrey Samuel Trachtman, a son of Drs. Gilbert M. and Joan P. Trachtman of New York, took place yesterday in the rose garden at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: CONGRESS'S TAX-REVISION DILEMMA
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski gave the members of his House Ways and Means Committee their first glimpse of his suggested alternative to President Reagan's tax-revision proposals Thursday afternoon. By Friday morning, the members were fielding calls from dozens of lobbyists complaining about one point or another in the chairman's presentation.

title: Heavy Supply of Tax-Exempt Issues
description: While the Treasury does not plan to auction any notes and bonds until Congress increases the debt ceiling, and is reducing the amount of outstanding Treasury bills, securities dealers said the unusually light supply of securities was helping to support prices.

title: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 30, 1985
description: International

title: Niekros Visit Ailing Father
description: Phil Niekro spent yesterday at the bedside of his ailing 72-year-old father in a Wheeling, W. Va., hospital. It remains uncertain whether the Yankee knuckleballer will return tonight to make his fourth attempt at capturing his 300th career victory.

title: Washington Watch;   Truckers Seek Insurance Study
description: Despite what would appear to be a cold shoulder from the Reagan Administration, the intercity bus and interstate trucking industry is still demanding that the Government step into what it is calling an insurance rates crisis.

title: Abraham Lass, Educator, And Sylvia Cole Are Wed
description: The marriage of Sylvia Cole of Fresh Meadows, Queens, to Abraham H. Lass, retired principal of the Abraham Lincoln High School in Brooklyn, took place yesterday in Manhattan. Rabbi Ronald Millstein performed the ceremony at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Jonathan R. Cole, son and daughter-in-law of the bride.

title: WILLIE MCGEE: A STAR WHO TYPIFIES HIS TEAM
description: BEFORE baseball pursued its own manifest destiny, St. Louis represented the last stop on a National League team's western trip. So it is the Cardinals who have really been America's team over the years, Whitey Herzog said. They were the favorites of the fans on both sides of the Mississippi River long before satellite dishes and cable television gave us the concept of a home team half a continent away.

title: CHILDREN AND VIDEO GAMES
description: MORE than a few anxious parents, uncertain about the effects of video games on their children, sighed with relief when the video-game craze of a few years ago subsided. Now researchers offer additional reasons for reassurance.

title: U.S. HOPES HUSSEIN CAN END DEADLOCK ON MIDEAST TALKS
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they were looking to King Hussein of Jordan, in his meeting with President Reagan on Monday, to provide an impetus for ending the deadlock in Middle East diplomacy and advancing the prospect of direct talks between Israel and a joint Jordanian-Palestinian group.

title: SHULTZ SAYS SOVIET OFFER WON'T HALT 'STAR WARS'
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the Reagan Administration would not stop work on its space defense program even in return for the 50 percent cut in nuclear arms that the Soviet Union is expected to propose formally this week.

title: Oui, Oui
description: As news of the French Government scandal continued to unfold in New York, the Consul General, Andre Gadaud, gave a luncheon for Claude Pompidou, widow of a former president, last week.

title: 2 Killed by French Train
description: A freight train crashed into a car at a crossing near the central city of Tours today, killing two people and injuring three others, all members of the same family, officials said. The accident occurred at a crossing 140 miles southwest of Paris, after the car was trapped by the automatic crossing gate, the police said.

title: Construction Contracts Almost Level in August
description: The total value of construction contracts awarded, a key barometer of economic activity, remained virtually even in August compared with the previous month, a sign that the industry was continuing what has been considered to be a building spree.

title: Narragansett Capital
description: The Narragansett Capital Corporation of Providence, R.I., said Friday that one of its portfolio companies, the Carolina Pump and Supply Corporation, had merged with Hughes Supply Inc. through an exchange of stock, making Narragansett the holder of about 69,000 shares of Hughes Supply.

title: VIOLENCE IN THE PUNJAB IS BEATEN AT THE BALLOT BOX
description: A successful and peaceful election in the troubled state of Punjab last week has raised new hopes that India can end three years of violence and turmoil over demands by Sikhs. But the voting also shows that the task remains extremely difficult.

title: BOSTON BUSING STILL A HEATED ISSUE
description: Rachel Twymon had listened intently to three impassioned hours of debate in the John F. Kenndy Library over a new book about Boston's busing crisis in the mid-1970's.

title: BUDGET MANAGING TWO MONTHS AFTER STOCKMAN
description: Although the staff still calls it ''Dave's office,'' the high-ceilinged cream-and-white room with yellow curtains, parquet floors and balcony overlooking Blair House has been vacant now for nearly two months.

title: Iraq Reports New Raid On Iranian Oil Terminal
description: Iraq said its planes attacked Iran's oil terminal at Kharg Island in the northern Persian Gulf today in the 16th raid since last month.

title: Spotlight Remains on Deficit
description: In the week preceding tomorrow's meeting of the Federal Reserve officials who set the course for monetary policy, the credit markets have been awash with speculation about whether the Fed would try to reduce the value of the dollar by lowering short-term interest rates or continue to hold policy unchanged as it has for more than four months.

title: GIANTS' DEFENSE AT ITS BEST
description: Even before Elvis Patterson's game-winning interception in overtime, the Giants stayed alive against the Eagles today the way they have against most teams - on their defense.

title: 2 Islanders Injured
description: Ken Morrow and Bob Bourne, two Islanders who are making comebacks from serious injuries last season, will be sidelined indefinitely. Both were injured Saturday night during an exhibition game against the Buffalo Sabres. Morrow, a defenseman, hurt his left shoulder in a fight, and Bourne, a left wing, injured his ribs crashing into the boards.

title: THE BOOSTER WHO SANG
description: IT is a lucky thing for the presidents of the nation's colleges that the latest sports recruiting scandal erupted when it did last week in Texas. The revelation of payments to young ''scholar-athletes,'' as colleges like to call their performers-in-residence, came just before the next meeting of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Presidents' Commission tomorrow in Denver.

title: 'WAR: A COMMENTARY BY GWYNEE DYER,' ON PBS
description: ''WAR: A Commentary by Gwynne Dyer,'' the opening program of an eight-hour PBS series that begins tonight at 9 on Channel 13, could more precisely be called ''Antiwar.'' For that is really the theme hovering behind the commentary -and commentary, not objectivity, is the operative word - that accompanies the strong language and pictures in this documentary produced by the National Film Board of Canada.

title: Advertising;   General Foods Agency Future
description: Mergers, especially those involving consumer packaged-goods conglomerates, are often unnerving to ad agencies. Three of General Foods' major agencies may feel uncertain as a result of its planned takeover by Philip Morris.

title: NEW THREAT MADE ON BEIRUT CAPTIVES
description: An anonymous caller who said he represented the Islamic Holy War organization said today that the group would hold a news conference at which it would produce some of the six Americans whom it is believed to be holding hostage.

title: D'AUBUISSON, SALVADOR RIGHTIST, QUITS PARTY POST
description: Roberto d'Aubuisson, the standard-bearer of El Salvador's militant and often violent right, stepped down today as the head of his party, the National Republican Alliance.

title: U.N. ACTIVITY RESUMES TODAY, BUT AT A SLOWER PACE
description: After a frenetic week of speeches by government leaders and a special session of the Security Council, the General Assembly resumes Monday at a more leisurely pace. The pace will pick up again late next month when world leaders arrive to mark the 40th anniversary of the United Nations.

title: Article 042364 -- No Title
description: Freed of the restraints of working for President Reagan, David A. Stockman, the former White House budget director, called today for an increase in taxes of ''at least'' $100 billion a year to reduce the Federal deficit and the ''traumatic economic dislocations'' it has created.

title: SCREENING OF BLOOD FOR AIDS RAISES CIVIL LIBERTIES ISSUES
description: A test developed to protect the nation's blood supply from acquired immune deficiency syndrome has emerged, in a few short months, as a potential new tool for tracking and perhaps slowing the spread of the disease. But determining how this tool should be wielded is provoking debate over questions of personal liberty and the public interest.

title: ANDRE KERTESZ, 91, PIONEER IN PHOTOGRAPHY, DIES
description: Andre Kertesz, one of the most influential photographers of this century, died Friday night at his home in New York City. He helped change the way photographers and picture magazines look at the world and defined the use of the hand-held camera. He was 91 years old.

title: Futures/Options;   Linked Boards Pass Big Test
description: THE year-old foreign currency futures linkage between the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Singapore International Monetary Exchange got its first test by fire last week.

title: 'CAGNEY & LACEY' BACK
description: NBC'S ''Miami Vice'' may have been last season's hot new series, but CBS's ''Cagney & Lacey'' continues to walk off with the top awards. In the recent Emmy competitions, ''Cagney & Lacey'' took six awards, including one for Tyne Daly - for the third year in a row - as outstanding lead actress in a drama series, and one for the show itself as outstanding drama series. That's not bad for a police series that was once canceled by CBS and was brought back by ''spontaneous'' viewer protests gleefully orchestrated by Barney Rosenzweig, the executive producer.

title: SCANT JOY FOR IVY OUTSIDE CONFERENCE
description: A milestone for Harvard's coach, Joe Restic, and the Brown defense provided the only positives for the Ivy League in its nonconference games on Saturday.

title: MIDWEST CITIES FIND NEW ECONOMIC LIFE ON OLD WATERFRONTS
description: For a hundred years the people who ran this city seemed bent on increasing the distance between themselves and Lake Erie. Tons of slag from steel mills, as well as other fill, were dumped into the lake, creating a dreary plain stretching out in front of the heights on which the main downtown area is built.

title: PHILIP MORRIS CHAIRMAN STUDIED SEVERAL OPTIONS
description: Hamish Maxwell, the chairman and chief executive of the Philip Morris Companies, did not arrive at the decision to acquire the General Foods Corporation lightly.

title: FLAT 3D QUARTER FOR STOCKS
description: The stellar stock price gains posted on many of the world's major exchanges in the first half of 1985 jerked to a stop in the third quarter, as the sluggish American economy forced companies and investors around the globe to reassess their strategies.

title: Markets Set To Resume
description: Activity on the nation's major financial markets is expected to return to normal today, following the widespread disruptions caused by Hurricane Gloria on Friday. There will, however, be one major change, unrelated to the storm: The Big Board today will introduce new hours of operation, beginning its trading day at 9:30 A.M.

title: AFTER 20 YEARS, EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS ARE A SOLID LEGACY OF GREAT SOCIETY
description: Twenty years ago President Johnson put forth his vision of a Great Society, forever altering the relationship between the Federal Government and education.

title: Home as Prison
description: ''Go to your room'' is a common punishment parents use to enforce family rules. Judge Jack Weinstein recently imposed the community's equivalent in a Brooklyn Federal court. He ordered ''house arrest'' for a woman convicted of insurance fraud, thereby recognizing the need for alternatives to prison.

title: Ballesteros Wins Match-Play Golf
description: Severiano Ballesteros of Spain posted a 6-and-5 victory over Bernhard Langer of West Germany today in the final of the $240,000 World Match Play Golf Championship.

title: NEW YORKERS REPLAY GAMES OF CHILDHOOD IN A FAR CRIME
description: You can take the kid out of New York City, but you can't take New York City out of the kid, according to an enthusiastic group of expatriates living here.

title: MEDIEVAL FESTIVAL: FORT AND CLOISTERS BEDECKED
description: SUNDAY was one of those exquisitely sunny afternoons positioned late enough in the season to be cherished rather than merely enjoyed. The Cloisters, usually one of Manhattan's quietest enclaves, was alive with the sound of flutes, trumpets and drums. Proud horses pranced down the long road from the museum, their riders bearing fanciful banners. A bevy of Maid Marians, hair bedecked with garlands, passed the time chatting with a group of medieval monks. The atmosphere was festive and exuberant.

title: Amy Tenney, Lawyer, Is Wed in Connecticut
description: Amy Susan Tenney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren S. Tenney of Rye, N.Y., and Hailey, Idaho, was married yesterday to David Gordon Levere, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Levere of Teaneck, N.J. Rabbi Daniel Wolk performed the ceremony at the Fairview Country Club in Greenwich, Conn.

title: An Insolent Little +3
description: Washington has a new monthly wine publication, a fat 24-page newsletter called Winefest that devotes a good deal of its attention to reviewing, using a new rating system. It's called Consumer Value Rating, and is intended to reflect quality with reference to price.

title: Dollar Slides In Toyko
description: The dollar slid to its lowest level against the Japanese yen since December 1981 in trading today and dealers expected a further fall.

title: Outdoors: Preserving History
description: MANY fly fishermen are intensely aware of the history and tradition of the sport and nowhere is this more evident than in the Catskills.

title: Why AIDS Children Should Not Go to School
description: To the Editor:

title: FED SEEN AS HOLDING ITS COURSE
description: The Federal Reserve Board is likely to decide on Tuesday to maintain its present course of fairly rapid money growth, a policy that points toward steady interest rates in coming weeks, most analysts believe.

title: SOONERS START LATE, BUT SUCCESSFULLY
description: Once Oklahoma started its long-delayed season Saturday night, the Sooners were in charge as expected even though the score was only 13-7 over a mismatched Minnesota team inside the Metrodome in Minneapolis.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THANKS TO TAKI The phrase ''Taki 183'' was the first of the modern graffiti scrawled moderately (some 20 years ago) on subway walls and rolling stock. It led to more names, larger names, artistically designed names and, eventually, an avante-garde art genre. Some people condemned the graffiti, which took attention away from the subway's dirt, and others hailed it. Now, despite the still-present dirt, higher forms of culture are coming into the subway.

title: Five Hurt at Outdoor Market As 2 Bombs Explode in Haifa
description: Two bombs exploded in the Israeli port city of Haifa today, one of them wounding five people, a police spokesman said.

title: Secret Virtues
description: Advocacy Institute operates on the theory that some corporate lobbyists might like to salve their consciences by devoting a little spare time to public interest efforts, the way high-priced lawyers occasionally take on poor criminal clients or pro bono causes. With such a faculty, the two-year-old institute teaches nonprofit conservation groups, consumer and health organizations and the like how to deal effectively with Congress.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: FINALE OF WESTWAY DEBATE
description: To New Yorkers, the debate over Westway had come to resemble the background noise in space that scientists hear from the beginnings of the universe. It was always there and no doubt very important, but it took quite an effort to listen to.

title: SATOR EYES A SYSTEM TO REVIVE RANGERS
description: SHAVINGS of ice kicked into the air as the hockey players swirled by the coach like so many shiny helmets in a row, following orders. And it was beautiful the way they moved, in delicate patterns.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Farrakhan's Following
description: Instead of fading away, as many people hoped he would after the 1984 campaign, the Rev. Louis Farrakhan, the leader of the Nation of Islam, has grown in influence. Once lucky to draw hundreds for a speech, he now attracts thousands - 10,000 in Washington last summer, 15,000 in Los Angeles this month. Next week, he comes to New York's Madison Square Garden.

title: Bangladesh Soccer Riot Leaves 150 Injured
description: At least 150 people were injured, 50 critically, in a soccer riot Saturday night in Dhaka, the police said today.

title: Song Thrown for Loss
description: Shouting cocaine may not be as dangerous as sniffing it, but at the University of Iowa they aren't taking any chances. They have moved to curb an outbreak of cocaine shouting that has broken out at Hawkeye football games.

title: HOPE AND DESPAIR OVERLAP AT INDIANS' CONFERENCE
description: ''Nih'i chih hoyha na'haasdlii,'' chanted Steve Darden, the young Navajo on the podium.

title: Samuel Rabinowitz Weds Mona Yaguda at Harvard
description: Mona S. Yaguda and Samuel Rabinowitz were married yesterday at the Cronkhite Graduate Center at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass., by Rabbi Cathy Felix.

title: EXPOS DEFEAT CARDS
description: Hubie Brooks lined a two-run triple to right field today, breaking up a seventh-inning tie and lifting the Montreal Expos to a 7-5 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: 2 KNICK HOPEFULS COMPETE FOR JOB
description: Between the two-a-day workouts at the Knicks' training camp at Hofstra University, Clinton Wheeler and Fred Cofield are the best of friends. They eat together, travel together, talk and socialize. But once they reach the basketball court, the friendship that began seven weeks ago in the Princeton Summer League is put aside.

title: Advertising;   Isidor & Paulson Feat
description: Despite Hurricane Gloria, which closed most of the major ad agencies Friday or at least cut drastically into their work force, Isidor & Paulson was able to pick up a $4 million account: Princess Hotels International, a subsidiary of the Lonrho organization of London. It has two properties in Acapulco, two in Bermuda and one in the Bahamas. The former agency was Spiro & Associates in Philadelphia.

title: DOLPHINS TRIUMPH ON MARINO'S PASSES
description: Miami's Dan Marino won his duel with Denver's John Elway, passing for 390 yards and three touchdowns today to lead the Dolphins over the Broncos, 30-26.

title: 3 Rock Band Members Are Slain in California
description: Three members of the local rock bands Rage and Shooter were slain in a suburban home by a man who apparently then watched television for several hours before committing suicide, the police said today.

title: CHICAGO COUPLE REGAIN CUSTODY OF THEIR CHILD
description: A judge has ordered the State Department of Human Services to return a 1-year-old girl to her parents, saying that it wrongly took the infant while the mother was stranded in Memphis.

title: THEATER: JASON ROBARDS IN 'THE ICEMAN COMETH'
description: NOTHING glows when the lights rise on Harry Hope's waterfront gin-mill and flophouse in Jose Quintero's new production of ''The Iceman Cometh.'' What comes dimly into view is a moldering, black-and-brown cave, barely discernible in a smudged gray-green haze. The derelicts who populate Eugene O'Neill's play describe this squalid setting as ''a morgue'' and ''a tomb,'' as ''The End of the Line Cafe'' and ''The Bottom of the Sea Rathskeller.'' As designed by Ben Edwards and lighted by Thomas R. Skelton at the Lunt-Fontanne, Hope's saloon of 1912 looks as ghostly as those bottom-of-the-sea glimpses of the Titanic. But in ''The Iceman Cometh'' the bodies of the inhabitants are still visible - still terrifyingly alive, twitching in the silt. To see O'Neill's bums sprawled comatose across their sooty dive is to know one of the most harrowing images ever produced by the American theater.

title: conomic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Preserving Deco
description: As cosmic as its appeal may be, the American Museum-Hayden Planetarium is easy to overlook in one respect: its Art Deco architecture.

title: Unwise Move to Admit Foreign Farm Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. (Television -SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Football Steelers vs.

title: Guarding Fierce Name
description: Pentagon sources report that Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger is fearful he may be losing his reputation for belligerence. In recent weeks, a number of articles have appeared about economizing in the military, which may be pacifying Congressional critics of spending and waste, but the Secretary is eager to correct any misapprehension that he is softening on the need for a mighty military. He stressed to a group of visiting editors that he had ''not acquiesced'' in efforts to wind down the buildup, and last week he reassured Republican Senate staffers: ''I'm the same stubborn and intransigent person.''

title: Washington Watch;   Citicorp Bid in Washington
description: Citicorp has set its sights on another interstate expansion: the District of Columbia. And the nation's largest bank is getting a lot of support from Mayor Marion Barry.

title: JETS HALT COLTS AT 5 AND WIN
description: The Jets, bruised and disparaged only a few games ago, are suddenly believing their own pep talks.

title: M. L. Hirschfeld Wed To Gabrielle V. Albans
description: Gabrielle Victoria Albans, the corporate attorney for the International Paper Company in New York, and Michael Lane Hirschfeld, a partner in the New York law firm of Seyfarth, Shaw, Fairweather & Geraldson, were married yesterday. The interfaith ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls was performed by the Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church, the minister of the church, and Rabbi Charles Lippman.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SEA DANGERS: The Affair of the Somers. By Philip McFarland. 308 pages. Illustrated. Schocken. $19.95. TRUTH being stranger than fiction, it shouldn't surprise anyone that the 19th-century naval incident recounted in ''Sea Dangers'' is the archetypal mutiny story, a ''Bounty'' in which the fathers win instead of the sons, a ''Caine Mutiny'' that doesn't cheat in its narrative viewpoint, a drama that Herman Melville would have borrowed if he hadn't been after bigger game, and even so he was gracious enough to acknowledge it in ''Billy Budd.''

title: Space Unit For Europe
description: Two aerospace companies in West Germany and Italy plan a joint venture to market the commercial uses of space.

title: Canadian Wins Music Competition
description: Marc-Andre Hamelin of Montreal was named winner of the 1985 Carnegie Hall International American Music Competition last night. Mr. Hamelin was one of three pianists competing in the final rounds held this weekend at Carnegie Hall.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We believe that the reform process should be accelerated by abolishing statutory race discrimination wherever it exists, negotiating with acknowledged black leaders about power sharing, granting full South African citizenship to all our peoples, restoring and entrenching the rule of law.'' - An advertisement by 91 business leaders in South Africa. [A1:6.]

title: Washington Watch;   Heated Textile Import Battle
description: The lobbying battle over the pending imported textile bill is not likely to cool any time soon, with the Senate expected to take up the textile bill sometime this week and the House waiting in the wings.

title: Two Cheers for New Financial Moves
description: In the span of 24 hours last week, the world had a new monetary system, and the United States a new trade policy. Both are welcome and necessary. But if they are to succeed, the United States and its major economic partners must address, with equal energy, the fundamental causes of recent imbalances. Here, last week's events give us less to cheer about.

title: Sudan Reports Arrests After Attempted Coup
description: A Sudanese Government newspaper said today that 163 military men and civilians were arrested after an unsuccessful coup was reported last week.

title: Cassandra's Kinfolk
description: In an effort to dispel the reputation of economics as the dismal science, its practitioners have taken to inventing bright phrases to liven up their abstract theories and gloomy forecasts. The latest is the product of International Moneyline, a newsletter that concluded the other day that ''the Federal Reserve is pushing the U.S. economy full speed ahead through a field of financial icebergs of which we have all been amply warned.''

title: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
description: WEEK No. 2 - The second week of General Assembly debate gets under way this morning when President Jaime Lusinchi of Venezuela opens the session at 10 A.M. Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda of Thailand is to speak in the afternoon. Also scheduled are the Foreign Ministers of China, Lebanon, Sudan, Bulgaria, the Bahamas, Albania, Tunisia and St. Christopher and Nevis.

title: JUNIOR CHESS CHAMPION TAKES HIS TITLE IN STRIDE
description: There was no fanfare to greet the new world junior chess champion when he returned Saturday night from the United Arab Emirates, just a band of beaming relatives ready to help carry his chalice-like trophy and the carved wooden chess set he had bought at the bazaar in Sharjah.

title: RESIDENTS FLEE TRIPOLI AS FIGHTING RAGES
description: A fierce battle for control of the northern port of Tripoli continued today with mounting casualties and fires burning out of control.

title: UNILEVER WINS BAR ON VICKS
description: A Federal judge has granted a preliminary injunction barring Richardson-Vicks Inc. from issuing a new series of preferred stock designed to thwart Unilever N.V.'s hostile takeover bid for the drug and consumer products company.

title: The Aid Some Farmers Need
description: Country-music fans now understand that a lot of farmers are having trouble making ends meet. So do the managers of the Farm Credit Banks, the privately owned farm lenders that are in danger of going broke. So, too, do the agriculture committees of Congress, which have drafted budget-busting farm-aid bills. There seems little understanding, however, of who is in trouble or why.
